title: For Bay, Aiming to Left Will Be All Right
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jason Bay was out on Field 7 for the first time Sunday, where the outfield dimensions replicate Citi Field. The Mets said they wanted to sign the right-handed-hitting Bay because his pull swing was well suited to the dimensions of Citi Fields left-field wall.

title: Lottery Numbers
Prudential P.L.C. Closes In on A.I.G. Unit
description: 5:14 a.m. | Updated Prudential P.L.C. confirmed early Monday morning that it had agreed to acquire American International Group for its Asia unit. The company said it would obtain the cash for the deal through a $20 billion rights issue and $5 billion in senior debt.

title: Lieutenant Governor Makes His Rounds
description: Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch of New York is the first ever appointed to the position in the state.

title: Nightmare No Shovel Can Beat
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

title: Germanys Merck to Buy Millipore for $7.2 Billion
description: Merck of Germany said on Sunday that it had agreed to buy Millipore, an American provider of purifiers and filters for biotechnology laboratories, for about $7.2 billion, including debt.

title: David Bankier, Scholar of Holocaust, Dies at 63
description: JERUSALEM  David Bankier, who helped expand the contours of Holocaust research by examining the participation of ordinary Europeans in the extermination of their Jewish neighbors, died over the weekend after a long illness, Yad Vashem, the Jerusalem Holocaust center, announced. He was 63.

title: A.I.G. Unit Said to Be Near Sale to a British Company
description: Prudential P.L.C., the British financial services company, was nearing a deal on Sunday to acquire the American International Groups big life insurance business in Asia for about $35.5 billion in a move that would help repay taxpayer bailout money, people briefed on the matter said.

title: Reyes Not Worried After Meeting With Investigators
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jose Reyes seemed completely relaxed and unconcerned Sunday about his interview with federal investigators at the Mets complex last Thursday.

title: Blogging the Closing Ceremony
description: The New York Times reporters Juliet Macur, Katie Thomas and Ian Austen provided live updates throughout the closing ceremony for the 2010 Winter Olympics from the downtown Vancouver arena, B.C. Place. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comments box below.

title: Unknotting Fathers Reins in Hope of Reinventing Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Prying open a closed economy is no easy job, especially if the country in question is Libya  a nation that has spent more than two decades with its back turned to the world. It becomes all the more challenging when doing so means taking on the legacy of your father and fighting an entrenched bureaucracy with little interest in serious change.

title: Lowes Puts Its Focus on Knowing the Customers Wants
description: THE bar in Cheers was supposedly where everybody knew your name. A leading home-improvement retailer plans to present itself as the place where everybody knows which type of washer you need, which type of insect is infesting your garden or which shade of purple a teenage girl can paint her room without driving her mother crazy.

title: A Manager Who Exceeded His Own Expectations
description: Lake Buena Vista, Fla.

title: Israeli Police Clash With Stone Throwers
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli police officers in Jerusalem entered the plaza containing Al Aksa Mosque on Sunday after Palestinian youths barricaded inside threw stones at visitors they believed to be radical Jewish settlers.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include personal income and spending for January, the Institute for Supply Managements manufacturing index for February and construction spending for January (Monday); the A.D.P. employment report for February and the I.S.M.s service index for February (Wednesday); revised fourth-quarter productivity, factory orders for January and pending home sales for January (Thursday); and unemployment for February and consumer credit for January (Friday).

title: Give the Olympics a Home
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Slain Hamas Operative Was Drugged, Dubai Police Say
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  A Hamas official who was killed in his hotel room here in January was first injected with a fast-acting muscle relaxant and then suffocated, Dubai police officials said Sunday.

title: In Senate, a Renewed Effort to Reach a Consensus on Financial Regulation
description: WASHINGTON  When Christopher J. Dodd announced in January that he would not seek a sixth term in the Senate, he called reform of financial regulation, along with health care, the two most important issues of our time, and pledged to spend his last year in Congress fully focused on his legislative duties.

title: A Big, Silly Dude Becomes a 7-Foot Force at Tulsa
description: TULSA, Okla.  The video was raw, but then so was the prospect.

title: Using Diplomatic Touch, an Outsider Challenges the Grip of Egypts Ruling Party
description: CAIRO  Since arriving to a heros welcome just days ago, the former chief international nuclear watchdog and Nobel Peace Prize laureate Mohamed ElBaradei has taken on the countrys leadership in the way you might expect of a career diplomat: using delicate language and a nonconfrontational approach.

title: At the End, No Bitterness, Just a Weary Smile
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Side by side they skied, their arms pumping in rhythm, their eyes riveted on the finish line. For more than two hours, Francesc Soulie of Andorra and Jonas Thor Olsen of Denmark had waged the loneliest of battles in the 50-kilometer classic cross-country race at Whistler Olympic Park.

title: Time for Goldman to Come Clean
description: Even mighty Goldman Sachs makes mistakes. The Wall Street banks decision to help Greece keep some of its debts hidden from public view in 2001 was one of them.

title: Crosbys Goal Ends Thriller as Canada Beats U.S.
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The roar first erupted inside Canada Hockey Place and stretched across the prairies of Manitoba, to the shores of Parry Sound, Ontario, to Cole Harbour, Nova Scotia.

title: Financial Reform Endgame
description: So heres the situation. Weve been through the second-worst financial crisis in the history of the world, and weve barely begun to recover: 29 million Americans either cant find jobs or cant find full-time work. Yet all momentum for serious banking reform has been lost. The question now seems to be whether well get a watered-down bill or no bill at all. And I hate to say this, but the second option is starting to look preferable.

title: Vote Seen as Pivotal Test for Both Iraq and Maliki
description: BAGHDAD  A few months ago, building on genuine if not universal popularity, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki appeared poised to win a second term as Iraqs prime minister. Now, as Iraqis prepare to vote in parliamentary elections on March 7, his path to another four years in office has become increasingly uncertain, his campaign erratic and, to some, deeply troubling.

title: Network News at a Crossroads
description: ABC News is making no secret about what is behind the sweeping staff cuts it now faces: raw survival instinct.

title: The Joy of X
description: At this stage in the series its time to shift gears, moving on from grade school arithmetic to high school math.

title: Quake Overshadows Clinton Tour of Region
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clintons five-nation Latin American tour, which begins Monday and is meant in part to address regional tensions, is instead likely to be overshadowed by the response to Chiles earthquake and efforts to line up support for the American campaign to isolate Iran.

title: For Canadas Faithful, a Gold That Means Most
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  There was no chance that the Very Rev. Glenn Dion would change the time of his 12:30 Sunday Mass at Holy Rosary Cathedral, a couple of blocks from the site of Sundays Olympic gold medal hockey game between Canada and the United States.

title: After Push in Marja, Marines Try to Win Trust
description: SEMITAY BAZAAR, Afghanistan  After the declaration this weekend that the battle for the Taliban enclave of Marja had been won, for the Marines standing behind sandbags and walking patrols, the more complicated work has begun. With it will be a test of the strategy selected by President Obama and the generals now running the Afghan war.

title: Rulings Restrict Clean Water Act, Foiling E.P.A.
description: Thousands of the nations largest water polluters are outside the Clean Water Acts reach because the Supreme Court has left uncertain which waterways are protected by that law, according to interviews with regulators.

title: Math of Publishing Meets the E-Book
description: In the emerging world of e-books, many consumers assume it is only logical that publishers are saving vast amounts by not having to print or distribute paper books, leaving room to pass along those savings to their customers.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Merck to Pay $7.2 Billion for Millipore
description: Merck of Germany said on Sunday that it had agreed to buy Millipore, an American provider of purifiers and filters for biotechnology laboratories, for about $7.2 billion, including debt.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Thursday with an article about the risks posed by poor construction in Istanbul and other growing cities in the developing world threatened by earthquakes mislabeled one city. It was Almaty, Kazakhstan  not Tashkent, Uzbekistan.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Olympic Flame Burns Brighter on Last Day
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Olympics that started under the cloud of an athletes death ended Sunday, much more joyously than they had begun.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Thursday about the band Acrassicauda, at Europa in Brooklyn, misstated the date of the release of its first CD. It is March 9, not next week. The review also misstated the connection of the CDs producer, Alex Skolnick, to the band Testament. He is still a member, not a former member.

title: Governors Troopers Pressured by Duty and Politics
description: Under New Yorks last Republican governor, George E. Pataki, the commander of his  personal State Police detail was found to have improperly intervened in an independent investigation of the governors campaign staff.

title: A Column That Lost Its Social Graces
description: The Party is over in Washington.

title: Home Fires: Retelling the War
description: After the multiple Academy Award nominations for two war movies, The Hurt Locker and The Messenger, the editors of Home Fires asked contributors, all veterans of the wars in either Afghanistan or Iraq, for their thoughts on these movies and the wider subject of war and narrative. What roles have such books and movies played in their own lives? How do they see the retelling and packaging of war stories and their effect on the public consciousness? Do they shed light on or simplify our understanding of actual conflict?

title: Canada Wins Hockey Gold
description: The Canadians controlled the final of the 2010 Olympics, but it took an overtime goal to secure the win after Zach Parise scored with 24 seconds remaining in regulation.

title: Nearly a Goat, Luongo Prefers to Dwell on His Gold
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Roberto Luongo stood 30 seconds from certain glory Sunday, when his place in Canadian hockey lore would be secure. Finish that half-minute without error, and his shaky gold medal hockey game would have been forgotten and forgiven, a hiccup compared with the disaster that occurred instead.

title: Haitis Futile Race Against the Rain
description: There were floods on Saturday in Les Cayes, in southwestern Haiti. It rained in Port-au-Prince on Thursday, and again on Saturday and Sunday night, long enough to slick the streets and make a slurry of the dirt and concrete dust. Long enough, too, to give a sense of what will happen across the country in a few weeks, when the real storms start.

title: Taking Balco Approach, Authorities Interview Athletes Linked to Galea
description: Following a strategy used by prosecutors in the Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative case, federal authorities are traveling the country to interview athletes who have been linked to the Canadian doctor Anthony Galea, who is under investigation for distributing performance-enhancing drugs.

title: After Fumble, Microsoft Redoes Phone Software
description: Mobile phone software from Microsoft has long resembled an underpowered version of its Windows desktop software. Users never embraced its bland interface, sluggish response time and businesslike menus that required lots of clicking to perform tasks.

title: Diego della Valle Adds Spice to Classics
description: An exploration of materials creates new versions of classics at Tod's.

title: Hochfelders Fast Rise and Fall in Real Estate
description: Even in a city saturated with success stories, Adam C. Hochfelder achieved more by his early 30s than most people do in a lifetime.

title: Pelosi Says Shell Get Votes Needed for Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker Nancy Pelosi says she is confident she will be able to get the votes needed to pass sweeping health care legislation in the House, even if it threatens the political careers of some members of her party.

title: Deal Will Put Times Content on 850 Screens
description: Starting Monday, video screens in coffee shops, casual eateries and airport newsstands in five major cities will display the work of The New York Times, under a deal with RMG Networks, a major owner of such screens.

title: In the Yankees, Park Sees His Chance to Win a Title
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Outfielder Greg Golson was originally given No. 61. Then, his number changed. It was all part of the Yankees plan to accommodate their newest player, the right-hander Chan Ho Park, who finally appeared in camp Sunday morning.

title: Mets Call Far Ahead for a Different Pitch
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It has been more than 10 years since Ryota Igarashi added a pitch. Back in 1999, when he was a rookie with the Yakult Swallows in Japan, he said, he learned how to throw a forkball in spring training, and it took most of the season until he could throw it with confidence.

title: U.S. Hockey Still Has Reason to Cheer
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  For Canadians, Sunday was the most important day in hockey history since Ontario army officers or Nova Scotia farmers, or whoever it was, first started whacking a disc around a frozen slough in the 19th century.

title: In Middle School, Charting Their Course to College and Beyond
description: Public schools have long offered their students the same basic academic program, with little real choice aside from foreign languages or an occasional elective in what was a one-size-fits-all approach that drove many families to seek private and charter schools.

title: Hockey Pilgrims Trek to Lake Placid, Where Its Always 1980 for Some
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  The Olympics and geopolitics have changed vastly more than this quaint village of 2,600 people in the Adirondacks since it was host to the 1980 Winter Games. The worlds top professionals now compete in the Games, and the Cold War that gave broader meaning to the Miracle on Ice hockey triumph is long over.

title: Cond Nast Is Preparing iPad Versions of Some of Its Top Magazines
description: Cond Nasts plans for the iPad tablet computer from Apple are getting firmer.

title: In Hawaii, Calm Prevailed Despite Tsunami Warning
description: KAUAI, Hawaii  Jim and Patty Kane, tourists from Rockford, Ill., awoke at their Waikiki hotel around 6 oclock Saturday morning to find a note slipped under their door telling them that their idyllic vacation would be interrupted by an approaching tsunami and asking them to fill up their bathtub.

title: In 50-Kilometer Race, Medalists Think Alike
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Petter Northug said he had one grand concept for the mens 50-kilometer cross country ski race Sunday.

title: Survey Finds Slack Editing on Magazine Web Sites
description: The only thing standard about magazines Web sites is that there are no standards.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,371 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans Friday:

title: Former Rutgers Star Succeeds at High School Alma Mater
description: LINCROFT, N.J.  Geoff Billet, all of 30 and in his first days as the basketball coach at his alma mater, Christian Brothers Academy, sat at a table at an open house in 2007 and pitched the programs merits to the mother of a prospective student. Seemingly satisfied, she asked, And which year are you, junior or senior?

title: Utah Bill Would Criminalize Illegal Abortions
description: DENVER  The origins of Utah State House Bill 12 lie in an act of dark and desperate violence.

title: A Republican Surprise
description: Set a group of plugged-in conservatives to talking presidential politics, and youll get the same complaints about the 2012 field.

title: White House Is Rethinking Nuclear Policy
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama begins making final decisions on a broad new nuclear strategy for the United States, senior aides say he will permanently reduce Americas arsenal by thousands of weapons. But the administration has rejected proposals that the United States declare it would never be the first to use nuclear weapons, aides said.

title: As Foreclosures Continue ...
description: President Obama went to Henderson, Nev., the other day to show Americans that he was responding to the cries for help from struggling homeowners (and maybe give a boost to Senator Harry Reids re-election). He announced a $1.5 billion effort to prevent foreclosures in five states hard-hit by the housing bust  Nevada, Arizona, California, Florida and Michigan  by feeding money into programs that would be developed and carried out by the housing agencies in the targeted states.

title: If the Lawyer Fails
description: Our legal system is complex and a lot more powerful than any individual. That is why the Constitution guarantees people accused of serious crimes the right to counsel. If a lawyer turns out to be negligent, the system must do all it can to protect the individuals rights.

title: Render Unto C Street
description: It is not unusual for members of Congress to arrange group rentals in Washington to share housing costs and, for some, underline their continuing outsider status. What is highly unusual, and unjustifiable, is the tax-exempt status as a religious institution enjoyed by a boarding house called the C Street Center that caters to conservative Christian lawmakers.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Without Morals
description: AFTER five years of investigation, the Justice Department has released its findings regarding the government lawyers who authorized waterboarding and other forms of torture during the interrogation of suspected terrorists at Guantnamo Bay and elsewhere. The reports conclusion, that the lawyers exercised poor judgment but were not guilty of professional misconduct, is questionable at best. Still, the review reflects a commitment to a transparent investigation of professional behavior.

title: Marketers on Facebook Find Photo Tagging
description: You know whats been annoying me lately? Facebook photo spam.

title: Judge Grants Asylum to German Home Schoolers
description: MORRISTOWN, Tenn.  On a quiet street in this little town in the foothills of the Smoky Mountains lives a family of refugees who were granted asylum in the United States because they feared persecution in their home country.

title: Union College Finally Admits Where It Is
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y.  For many years, Union College tried to conceal this crippled manufacturing city  for better or worse, its college town  from high school seniors.

title: Partisanships Influence on Health Bills Future
description: In one crucial respect, Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders understand each other better than their acrimonious debates would suggest.

title: Arthur Hayes Jr., Who Led F.D.A. in Tylenol Case, Is Dead at 76
description: Arthur Hayes Jr., who while leading the Food and Drug Administration during the Reagan administration helped calm consumer fears after a Tylenol poisoning case and, amid some controversy, approved the use of the artificial sweetener found in Equal and Nutrasweet, died Feb. 11 in Danbury, Conn. He was 76 and lived in Oxford, Conn.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Bomber Called C.I.A. Target Gift From God
description: In a posthumously released video message, the suicide bomber who killed seven C.I.A. employees on Dec. 30 said that his original target had been his handler from Jordanian intelligence, and that an invitation to meet C.I.A. officers at a remote base in Afghanistan had been an unexpected boon.

title: Helping to Do Good by Looking Good
description: Shirley and Edgardo Miranda-Rodriguez started their graphic design business guerrilla style, taking a few thousand dollars left over from a student loan and opening shop in their Brooklyn living room.

title: Bar Serves as Classroom for Immigrants Learning Job-Hunting Skills
description: Rosemary Agbonlahor had never gone to a bar, an outing reserved for men in her native Nigeria. Neither had Bigyan Khanal, a schoolteacher from Nepal, who said that drinking alcohol was rare in his homeland.

title: Food Shoppers Who Dont Spend It All
description: Researchers have noticed that more than half of purchases are unplanned, but shoppers are still able to predict near-perfectly beforehand the amount they will spend. A new study, soon to be published in the Journal of Consumer Research, examines this phenomenon.

title: Water-Cooler Reactions to The Marriage Ref
description: Update: 12:15 p.m.: Early overnight Nielsen ratings show that The Marriage Ref averaged 14.5 million viewers. Nine out of ten Olympics viewers kept watching the reality show, the ratings indicate.

description: heterodox : \he-t-r-dks, he-tr-\ adjective

title: Doesnt Anybody Want to Throw?
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Quarterbacks worked out at the scouting combine Sunday. But most of the big-name ones did not throw here, preferring to wait for their colleges pro days, when they can throw to familiar receivers.

title: Lawsuit by Moroccan-American Muslim Accuses Police of Bias in Hiring
description: As the New York Police Department has initiated and expanded counterterrorism efforts in foreign countries over the last several years, it has also aggressively tried to recruit speakers of Arabic and other languages of countries where Islam holds sway.

title: Queens Man Strangled Car Thief, Police Say
description: A Queens man trying to steal his neighbors car was strangled by the neighbor on Saturday night after being caught in the act, the police said on Sunday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sheldon Gilgore, Physician Who Led Drug Giants Pfizer and Searle, Dies at 77
description: Dr. Sheldon G. Gilgore, a leader of two major pharmaceutical companies during decades of rapid change in the drug business, died Feb. 12 in his home in Naples, Fla. He was 77.

title: Vancouver Brings Down Curtain on Winter Games
description: The Vancouver Games came to an end with a closing ceremony that included everything from giant cutout Mounties to a handoff of the Winter Games to Sochi, Russia.

title: Anderson Cooper Said to Meet With CBS News Executives
description: Do CBS News executives have their sights set on Anderson Cooper?

title: Peaceful Celebration in Vancouver, but Police Take No Chances
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The police shut down a major bridge into Vancouvers downtown, and bus service was temporarily suspended as thousands of hockey fans and Olympic celebrants continued to crowd the citys downtown on Sunday night.

title: News Quiz | March 1, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Time for Goldman to Come Clean?
description: Even mighty Goldman Sachs makes mistakes, Reuters Breakingviews says. The Wall Street banks decision to help Greece keep some of its debts hidden from public view in 2001 was one of them, Breakingviews says.

description: HOW  many people were killed and HOW  many displaced in the magnitude 8.8 earthquake that struck Chile this weekend?

title: European Union Moves Toward a Bailout of Greece
description: Greece, in the midst of a financial crisis, is planning a bond deal this week that depends on a lot of things going right, Landon Thomas Jr. and Stephen Castle write in The New York Times.

title: In Senate, a Renewed Effort on Financial Regulation
description: When Christopher J. Dodd announced in January that he would not seek a sixth term in the Senate, he called reform of financial regulation, along with health care, the two most important issues of our time, and pledged to spend his last year in Congress fully focused on his legislative duties, Sewell Chan reported in The New York Times.

title: What Are Your Favorite and Least Favorite Words?
description: There are two places in The New York Times where you can regularly read about words and languagethe On Language column in the Sunday Magazine and Schotts Vocab Blog. Tell us about the words you love and loathe, and tell us why, below.

title: Deal Will Put Times Content on 850 Screens
description: Starting Monday, video screens in coffee shops, casual eateries and airport newsstands in five major cities will display the work of The New York Times, under a deal with RMG Networks, a venture-capital backed owner of such screens, The New York Timess Richard Prez-Pea reported.

title: Shake-Up Is Citis Latest Rebranding Attempt
description: Bracing for more criticism over its enormous bailouts, Citigroup shook up its board on Friday and is preparing a marketing campaign to revamp its image with Washington and Wall Street, The New York Timess Eric Dash writes.

title: Solutia Agrees to Buy Solar Firm
description: Solutia, the chemical maker, announced Monday that it has signed a deal to buy Etimex Solar, a maker of chemicals used in solar panels, for $326 million.

title: Michael Burry: Subprime Short-Seller No. 1
description: Sure, very few people were prepared for the rolling disaster of the subprime mortgage crisis and its huge financial repercussions, but some investors saw it coming, and in an excerpt from Michael Lewiss new book, The Big Short: Inside the Doomsday Machine, one hedge fund manager shows he was way ahead of his time.

title: As Trial Resumes, Karadzic Calls Bosnian-Serb Cause Just and Holy
description: PARIS  Radovan Karadzic took the stand on Monday, mixing bombast with claims of innocence as his war crimes trial resumed in The Hague after a four-month delay.

title: Citi Denies Its Egg Is for Sale
description: Citigroup said on Sunday its online banking business Egg was not for sale, after a British newspaper reported the firm had held talks with trade buyers and a private equity firm.

title: Chile Officials Call for Aid as Devastation Sinks In
description: ANGOL, Chile  Chiles government, after initially waving off outside aid, changed course Monday as the devastation from the powerful earthquake sank in and the nations pressing needs became clear.

title: For Buyout Kingpins, the TXU Deal Gets Tricky
description: In the fall of 2007, nerves were fraying on Wall Street. Billions of dollars promised to private equity firms to finance an epic acquisition spree were threatened, and banks wanted dealmakers to share the pain. Renegotiate the loans, the banks said. The private equity firms disagreed: a deal, they argued, is a deal.

title: Essay: How Not to Depict a War
description: BAGHDAD  I long ago learned not to discuss war movies with soldiers. They tend to be detail-oriented and obsessed with authenticity. They frequently dismiss well-made, thought-provoking films because of some minor detail  the scope on a rifle is wrong, or the markings on a vehicle incorrect.

title: And the Band Played On
description: Incoming | Matt Haughey, founder of MetaFilter.com, via Twitter:

title: Shell Plans $3 Billion Asset Sale, Report Says
description: Royal Dutch Shell, the oil and gas company, is selling a number of assets, including its European liquid petroleum gas businesses, to fund a 28 billion ($42 billion) capital spending program, The Financial Times reported, citing people involved in the proposed deals.

title: 6 Months, $90,000 and a Great Idea
description: The print hanging behind the receptionists desk at Foundation Capital screams, Our greatest thrill is to loan you money  in chunky, red capital letters. Thats encouraging news for Michael Bauer, because he wants money and has put himself in a prime position to get it, The New York Times Ashlee Vance and Claire Cain Miller  write.

title: Silver Spring Said to Pick Banks for I.P.O.
description: Silver Spring Networks, a high-profile smart grid start-up, has tapped bankers to manage an initial public offering expected to launch in the middle of 2010, Dow Joness Clean Technology Insight reported, citing a person familiar with the situation.

title: Finding Untainted Jurors in the Age of the Internet
description: When Enron collapsed in 2001, thousands of employees at its Houston headquarters lost their jobs and savings, and the citys economy reeled. Much of the publics anger was directed at Jeffrey K. Skilling, the companys former chief executive, Adam Liptak reports in The New York Times.

title: Evidence in Africa: How Do You Do What You Do?
description: GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa  At a question-and-answer session after the workshop that the Evidence Dance Company conducted with children and teenagers from the Sakhuluntu community group, in the Joza township of Grahamstown, the children shyly asked questions  some in English, some in Xhosa, translated by Vuyo Booi, the groups founder.

title: Barclays Taps Ex-Goldman Banker for Asia Post
description: Barclays has hired former Goldman Sachs banker Johan Leven as co-head of corporate finance in Asia-Pacific, as the bank continues its push as a full-fledged investment bank, Reuters reported.

title: Three Years Later, Revisiting a Berlin Art District
description: About three years ago, Berlins Brunnenstrasse  a raw and rough street leading from Berlin-Mitte to Prenzlauer Berg and Wedding  was an emerging destination for the arty set. Back then, several pioneering galleries had settled in to long-empty storefronts and derelict courtyard spaces; the first upscale retail space and hipster bar had just opened. And that was all on one block.

title: Sensata Seeks $632 Million in I.P.O.
description: Sensata Technologies, a maker of electronic sensors, said Friday that it was seeking to raise as much as $632 million in an initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Apollo to Win Fight for Lyondell?
description: Lyondell Chemical creditors led by Apollo Management are set to reject a $14.5 billion bid from Indias Reliance Industries, setting the stage for a merger between the bankrupt chemical maker and Apollos Hexion Specialty Chemicals, The New York Post reported.

title: HSBC Disappoints, and Warns on Bad Loans
description: HSBC, Britains biggest bank, reported earnings for last year Monday that fell short of expectations and said it had said aside more money for bad loans, sending its shares falling.

title: Tibet House Benefit
description: Photos from the 20th annual concert for Tibet House US.

title: Hedge Fund Probed on Kickbacks, Report Says
description: United States authorities are probing individuals close to NIR Group on whether the U.S. hedge fund firm paid kickbacks to outsiders to inflate the value of its holdings, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: In DNA We Trust  Too Much?
description: Todays idea: DNA not only exonerates the innocent, but can also wrongly convict them, an article says  especially in cold cases short on other evidence. Problem: faulty DNA fed into larger databases raising the chances of a false positive.

title: Hedge Funds Said to Profit from Greek Debt
description: Several hedge funds have seen a windfall from Greek debt and providing insurance to overexposed European banks, The Financial Times reported, citing industry insiders.

description: Offense

title: Prudential to Buy A.I.G. Unit for $35.5 Billion
description: Prudential P.L.C. of Britain said Monday that it had agreed to buy American International Groups big life insurance business in Asia in a deal valued at $35.5 billion.

title: Lampooning Candidates in Iraq
description: In the rough-and-tumble world of Iraqi politics, where assassinations are an ever-present threat, it is the old-fashioned art of the satirical political cartoon that still has the ability to cut deeply.

title: Police Shoot Man Wielding Machete
description: Police officers responding to a call about an emotionally disturbed person in Brooklyn Sunday night were confronted by a man holding a machete and shot him in both legs, wounding him, the police said.

title: 3-D TVs Are Arriving, but Cant Play 3-D Yet
description: Dying to be the first on your block (or the first in America) to get a new 3-D TV? Sears and Amazon.com are taking orders for two Samsung 3-D-ready LCD TVs: the $2,600 46-inch UN46C7000, and the $3,300 55-inch UN55C7000 models.

title: Palo Alto Newspaper War and Other Highlights of Sundays Bay Area Pages
description: Read All About It | As many cities struggle to support one newspaper, Palo Alto has three: The Daily Post; The Daily News, which began publishing in 1995; and The Palo Alto Weekly, which has a daily online edition and has been around since 1979. And in a city where laptops, iPhones and Kindles are standard issue, many residents still walk a block or two to pick up one of the citys newspapers  all of which are free.

title: MSCI Buys RiskMetrics for $1.55 Billion
description: MSCI, the investment analysis firm known for its MSCI international stock indexes, has agreed to buy RiskMetrics Group for $1.55 billion in a cash-and-stock deal, Reuters reported.

title: The $6,000 Dog and a Cash-Free Toll
description: Youve heard of the Six Million Dollar Man. How about the Six Thousand Dollar Dog?

title: Astellas Makes $3.5 Billion Unsolicited Bid for OSI
description: Astellas Pharma, a Japanese drug maker, unveiled on Monday a $3.5 billion offer for OSI Pharmaceuticals, in what is its second unsolicited bid for a biotech company in as many years.

title: Sampler: Manners on the Bus, Seal Pups at Point Reyes and a New Oakland Park
description: Emily Post Will Be Commuting With You | The Golden Gate Transit agency has begun a campaign to improve the behavior of bus and ferry riders. They are being asked to refrain from talking for too long on their cellphones, occupying a nearby seat with a laptop and personal grooming like clipping fingernails and toe nails. Bus drivers and ferry workers will be able to refer to the code of conduct, which will be posted on every vehicle, to enforce the rules. It used to be smoking was a big issue, and now it is how people use the cellphone, said Mary Currie, spokeswoman for the transit agency. The problems change. But cellphone use is the No. 1 issue right now. We ask people to put phones on vibrate and not talk for long periods. In some cases, someone will get on in Santa Rosa and yack on their cellphone on business all the way into the city while the passenger next to them wants to get some sleep. [The Marin Independent Journal]

title: Milan: No Time to Spare
description: Halfway into the Jil Sander show, as ponytailed models zipped around the companys white showroom, nearly all of them in the same flat black boot with Velcro tabs, I thought: why cant young designers do clothes like this? At 42, Sanders designer, Raf Simons, is hardly old. But the clothes he designed for fall 2010 seemed to embody a sense of speed and energy that is certainly felt today, in the hyperactivity of texting and tweeting, in the connectedness of social media, in the economy and self-control you get from being able to shop or bank  or read a book or have sex  online.

title: Congress Takes Up Jobs Measures
description: The fate of stalled jobs-related measures in both the House and the Senate will occupy the attention of Congress this week.

title: Submit Your Funny Caption
description: Exhibitionism | Tell us whats going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned images were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. The latest funniest captions are at right.

title: Speed Read For March 1, 2010
description: Highlights from Mondays media coverage in The New York Times:

title: Senator Lincoln Gets a Democratic Challenger
description: Updated: Senator Blanche Lincoln, the Arkansas Democrat who was already facing a difficult bid for re-election, has a new problem. The states lieutenant governor, Bill Halter, declared that he is mounting a primary challenge against her.

title: Questions for Harry Markopolos
description: Before the Bernard L. Madoff scandal erupted, Harry Markopolos was toiling away as a little-known investigator who repeatedly pestered the Securities and Exchange Commission to take a look at the funny numbers of Mr. Madoff.

title: Casting an Oscar-Nominated Role
description: Melena Ryzik auditions for the casting directors of "Precious" and realizes that casting an Oscar-nominated film is much harder than she thought.

title: Its Not You
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have shared the face-saving phrases they reach for at awkward social moments.

title: Your Reaction: Declining Network News
description: In todays Times, Brian Stelter and Bill Carter write:

title: Video: Casting an Oscar-Nominated Role
Skilling to Make Case at Supreme Court
description: Jeffrey Skilling, the former Enron chief executive who was found guilty of fraud for his role at the collapsed energy giant, has one last shot at overturning that conviction on Monday by appearing before the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: Now Plating | The Omnivore Food Festival
description: Last week in Deauville, France, two generations of great and rising chefs converged at the Omnivore Food Festival to share their techniques. It was the fifth such event dedicated to celebrating the new wave of cuisine  as opposed to nouvelle cuisine  that the young food and wine organization has hosted.

title: Nasdaq and S.&P. Positive for the Year
description: Wall Street reached a milestone on Monday that had eluded it for some time: two major stock indexes crossed into positive territory for the year.

title: In Skyscraper-Land, a Spectacular Rise and Fall
description: Even in a city saturated with success stories, Adam C. Hochfelder achieved more by his early 30s than most people do in a lifetime. Through partnerships with prominent real estate families, he rose to manage or have ownership interest in $2.7 billion in Manhattan skyscrapers. He moved into Harry B. Helmsleys former Park Avenue office and was lauded for his heady deals and charitable work.

title: Personal Spending Tops Forecast; Income Lags
description: Paychecks are scarcer, consumer confidence is weak and the amount of household debt continues to grow. But even in the face of those pressures, spending by consumers rose modestly in January, the government said on Monday, as Americans reduced their savings rate.

title: Rare Display at National Gallery Depicts Wounds of Jesus Christ
description: Depictions of Jesus Christs wounds and suffering on the cross are on rare display at the National Gallery of Art, as the museum presents its first comparison of painting and sculpture from the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Media Equation: Crashing D.C.s Party
description: In todays Media Equation, David Carr writes:

title: Jimmie Johnson Wins Second Straight
description: A week ago, Jimmie Johnson took advantage of a yellow flag with 26 laps to go (and a little bit of luck) to win. Last Sunday at Las Vegas Motor Speedway, there was another late-race yellow. But this time, strategy more than luck contributed to Johnson winning his second straight.

title: SeaWorlds Orca Show Resumes With Tribute to Killed Trainer
description: Employees wept and audience members grew silent at SeaWorld as the theme parks popular killer whale show resumed over the weekend with a photo montage memorial for a trainer who had been killed days earlier by an orca in front of horrified spectators.

title: Bits Scan: Verizon Fees, E-Book Profits and Chilean Telescopes
description: Happy Monday morning, Bits readers. Heres your daily news round-up:

title: Neil Young Continues His Run
description: The Winter Olympics ended in Vancouver on Sunday night with an all-star Canadian tribute to Canada, which, amid the playful French-Canadian clowns, William Shatners jokes about writing ones name in the snow, Michael Bubls stripping off a Mountie uniform and the giant inflatable beavers, featured a performance from Torontos own Neil Young.

title: The Khaki Brigade
description: Snap to attention with utilitarian essentials. More

title: Details from the Precious Cutting-Room Floor
description: Last week the Bagger spent some time auditioning for Billy Hopkins and Jessica Kelly, the casting directors for Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire and other films, including Boys Dont Cry. While we wait for their people to call our people, we thought wed share some cutting-room floor details, like the fact that Mr. Hopkins is the ex-boyfriend of Lee Daniels, the director of Precious.

title: Ask a Graffiti Artist
description: This week, Lee Quiones, an artist who emerged from the subway art movement of the 1970s, responded to readers questions about his life, work and the evolution of graffiti as art in New York City.

title: Hamas Says It Is Extending Britons Stay in Detention
description: GAZA  A Hamas military court in Gaza decided Monday to extend the detention of a British journalist for another 15 days of interrogation on suspicion of unspecified security offenses.

title: Goldman Rejects Shareholder Pay Demands
description: 10:10 a.m. | Updated Just because Goldman Sachs said that it planned to listen to ideas from shareholders on executive compensation doesnt mean it intends to use them.

title: Vice Chairman of Fed to Retire, Letting Obama Reshape Board
description: WASHINGTON  The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve announced on Monday that he would retire in June, giving President Obama an expanded opportunity to put his stamp on the central bank as it faces a difficult balance between heading off inflation and addressing high levels of unemployment.

title: Pentax Toughens Its Rugged Camera
description: Once again, Pentax demonstrates a new focus on design with an update to its line of rugged cameras. The new $330 Optio W90 looks like it belongs on a mountainside (thanks to its included carabiner) and feels more solidly built than its predecessor, the Optio W80.

title: Old Age, From Youths Narrow Prism
description: The old woman had drawn down the shade in her room  hoping, I imagined, to stop the midday Miami sun from penetrating her grief. But the sun still hit the window full force and illuminated the shade like a Chinese lantern.

title: Latest Updates on Chiles Earthquake
description: As my colleague Marc Lacey reports, aftershocks struck Chile Monday morning, complicating efforts to rescue survivors of the 8.8 magnitude earthquake that devastated much of the country on Saturday. The death toll now stands at 711, but is expected to rise. The Lede is tracking the response to the earthquake online. Readers who are in Chile are encouraged to submit first-hand accounts in the form of text, video or photographs by posting comments or links in the thread below.

title: Kohn, Feds No. 2, Plans to Retire
description: Donald L. Kohn, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, who helped coordinate the central banks response to the fiscal crisis in 2008, told the White House on Monday that he would retire when his four-year term expires on June 23, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports.

title: Paterson Says He Will Not Resign
description: Gov. David A. Paterson said on Monday that he would not bow to pressure to resign and insisted that his authority had not been compromised by a domestic violence scandal involving a top aide that forced him to abandon the governors race.

title: My New Goals: Moving, Marketing and Sales
description: In a recent post, I mentioned the many things I learned about my company and even about myself during my extended time away on my honeymoon. I have now been back a few weeks, and it is time to address our short-term and long-term goals  and the action plan we will create to achieve them.

title: China Names Its Own Lama to Top Body of Advisers
description: BEIJING  Chinas handpicked Panchen Lama, the teenage religious figure whose legitimacy is a matter of dispute among many Tibetan Buddhists, has been appointed to the countrys top advisory body, the state media have announced.

title: Model-morphosis | Just Cavalli
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Patricia van der Vliet of Elite Model Management before (left, right) and after makeup by Charlotte Tilbury and hair by Paul Handon. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Sort of Grandish: The Animated Finians Rainbow That Almost Was
description: Its not easy to get a new production of Finians Rainbow off the ground, as its recent well-liked but short-lived Broadway revival reminds us. But another tantalizing take on the show can be seen on the blog of the animator Michael Sporn, which recounts how a feature-length cartoon version was quashed in 1955 before a single frame was shot.

title: Nine Almost .300 Averages to Know
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: Neighborhood Game Changers
description: In Brooklyn today, the discussion turned to food, not art, as the best barometer of gentrification. Brownstoner.com is collecting a list of restaurants that signified change in certain neighborhoods, like the Farm on Adderly in Ditmas Park and Robertas in Bushwick.

title: Monday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: With Olympic Flame Out, Russia Fumes Over Its Athletes Showing
description: MOSCOW  The Olympic flame in Vancouver had barely been doused before President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia, angered over his countrys disappointing performance at the Winter Games, began calling for athletic officials heads.

title: The Guilds Last Hurrah
description: Hallelujah! What appear to be the last remaining guild awards before the Oscars have been handed out, but  drat!  in terms of keeping you ahead of your colleagues/friends/family members in the pool, theres only so much to celebrate. The Costume Guild recognized Sandy Powell for The Young Victoria and Monique Prudhomme for The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus. Both are nominated for the best costume Oscar. The academy tends to favor period films (Ms. Powell) over fantasy (Ms. Prudhomme), though, so perhaps Lil Vicki has the edge.

title: Accounts, People & Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Get Ready to Board the Glee Express. Destination: Your Town?
description: For most musical acts, it is traditional to first go out on tour and then get bogged down in personal squabbles and inconvenient pregnancies. The cast of Foxs Glee, however, is doing things slightly backward: after the characters have endured their first season of trials, tribulations and trimesters, the actors who portray them will hit the road for a series of live performances, the Fox television studio and the shows co-creator Ryan Murphy said on Monday.

title: Rose Gray, Chef at River Cafe in London, Is Dead at 71
description: Rose Gray, who founded the River Cafe in London with Ruth Rogers, bringing many in England their first taste of the simple pleasures of straightforward Italian cooking, has died. She was 71. Among the chefs who worked at her restaurant were Jamie Oliver and Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall. Adam Gopnik, the New Yorker writer, once called the River Cafe the best Italian restaurant in Europe.

title: Connection Failure for PlayStation 3 Users
description: 3/2/10 | Update  Sony announced that it had fixed the problem and restored service. More details are here.

title: The Financial Times Chrystia Freeland Heads to Reuters
description: Chrystia Freeland, the United States managing editor of The Financial Times, has jumped to Reuters with the new title global editor at large, Reuters announced Monday. The Financial Times named Gillian Tett, an assistant editor, as Ms. Freelands replacement.

title: Photos of the Moment | Model Behavior
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Safety Agency Backs Off Honda Recall Demand
description: 8:39 a.m. | Updated

title: Closing Thoughts
description: We welcome you back from the two-week sporting event/time warp that NBC uses largely as an excuse to a) remind you that it is a major television network, b) show events competed in broad daylight at 10 p.m. and pretend nothing nefarious is going on, and c) imprint promos for its new shows on your brain until you laugh just to keep from screaming.

title: MSCI Is Still on the Hunt for an Index Deal
description: MSCI joined in on Mondays merger flurry with its $1.55 billion acquisition of the analysis and proxy advisory firm RiskMetrics, but it isnt done looking at deals yet.

title: Judge Orders New York to Move Mentally Ill Out of Large, Institutional Housing
description: New York State must begin moving thousands of people with mental illness into their own apartments or small homes and out of large, institutional adult homes that keep them segregated from society, a federal judge ordered on Monday.

title: Csar Awards Favor A Prophet
description: The widely praised Jacques Audiard film A Prophet (Un Prophte), already a grand prize winner at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival, added to its trophy collection on Saturday night when it was named best picture at the Csar awards, Frances equivalent of the Oscars, Reuters reported. The film, about a young man of Arabic descent and his journey through the French prison system, took home nine Csars in all, including those for best director, original screenplay and cinematography, as well as acting awards for Tahar Rahim, who plays the central character, and Niels Arestrup, who plays an aging mob boss whose influence he falls under.

title: Checking In: Bobby Vans
description: Excellent wine at half price? Good steaks? No problem getting a reservation? Well get to that soon enough.

title: YUCKIES
description: Young Unwitting Costly Kids  a dubious acronym for adult children who rely on financial support from their parents.

title: Greece Told That More Cuts Must Be Made
description: ATHENS  The commissioner for monetary affairs at the European Union, Olli Rehn, said on Monday that austerity measures announced by the Greek government to stave off a mounting fiscal crisis were in the right direction but not adequate to reduce a bloated budget deficit by 4 percent this year and tackle a debt crisis threatening the euro zone.

title: Public Health Departments Shrinking, Survey Finds
description: Public health workers are another casualty of recent budget cuts in cities and counties across the country.

title: The Morning Skate: Canadas Golden Moment
description: And after all that, the N.H.L. season resumes tonight with the Red Wings in Colorado, the only game on the schedule. For Mike Babcock, the first coach to lead teams to both the Stanley Cup and the Olympic gold medal, its back to his day job with the Red Wings.

title: The Claim: Fruit Juice Can Prevent Kidney Stones
description: THE FACTS

title: Obama Takes Aim at School Dropout Rates
description: President Obama pledged today to tackle the dropout rate of American high school students, calling it an economic imperative if the United States intends to remain competitive in the global society.

title: Media Source Buys Library Journal and School Library Journal
description: Media Source, the owner of The Horn Book, a review publication for childrens titles, has bought Library Journal and School Library Journal from Reed Business Information.

title: More Trouble Looms for Embattled Political Party
description: It has been a tough year for the Working Families Party, the labor-backed political powerhouse that played a pivotal role in the 2009 New York City elections but now faces a barrage of accusations that it violated campaign finance laws to aid its favored candidates.

title: What if High School Ended After 11th (or Even 10th) Grade?
description: Efforts to eliminate at least one year of high school for some students have been gaining momentum in recent weeks.

title: Connecting Your Car, Socks and Body to the Internet
description: Several years ago, I watched Vint Cerf, who helped draft the architecture of the Internet and is now chief Internet evangelist at Google, give a talk about the future of the Internet.

title: Taking Tax Questions on Education Credits and Deductions
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Spider-Mans New Nemesis: Unemployment
description: Spider-Man may be able to spin a web of any size, but how far can his secret identity, Peter Parker, stretch a dollar? The wall-crawling Marvel Comics hero will have to depend on his thrifty sense as much as his Spidey-sense in the months to come as a new story sees him become the latest addition to the nations ranks of unemployed. On Monday, Marvel said that in a plot line that begins in issue No. 623 of Amazing Spider-Man, Peter Parker  who has lately given up his gig at The Daily Bugle to become the official photographer of the mayor of New York  will lose that job and, potentially, his career as he becomes blacklisted throughout the city.

title: Baseball Historians Get Their Own Hall
description: For almost 40 years, the Society for American Baseball Research has painstakingly unearthed and saluted the accomplishments of long-forgotten contributors to the game. Now it will honor the stars of its own: by creating, in effect, the Baseball Historian Hall of Fame.

title: Now Showing | The Park, Episode 5
description: The fifth and final episode of our new original series stars Edoardo Ballerini, who played Christophers heroin-addicted lackey on The Sopranos. Click here to watch previous episodes of The Park, directed by Poppy de Villenueve and featuring performances by Macaulay Culkin, Qorianka Kilcher, Tammy Blanchard and Mary-Beth Peil.

title: Madoff Judge Endorses Trustees Rule on Losses
description: A federal bankruptcy judge in Manhattan has approved the fiercely disputed method used by the court-appointed trustee to calculate victim losses in Bernard L. Madoffs enormous Ponzi scheme.

title: Csar Awards Favor A Prophet
description: The widely praised Jacques Audiard film A Prophet (Un Prophte), already a grand prize winner at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival, added to its trophy collection on Saturday night when it was named best picture at the Csar awards, Frances equivalent of the Oscars, Reuters reported. The film, about a young man of Arabic descent and his journey through the French prison system, took home nine Csar awards in all, including those for best director, original screenplay and cinematography, as well as acting awards for Tahar Rahim, who plays the central character, and Niels Arestrup, who plays an aging mob boss whose influence he comes under. Read more on ArtsBeat

title: Judge Backs Trustees Plan to Repay Madoff Victims
description: 1:21 p.m. | Updated In an opinion released on Monday, a federal bankruptcy judge in Manhattan approved the controversial method that a court-appointed trustee was using to calculate the victims losses in Bernard L. Madoffs enormous Ponzi scheme, The New York Timess Diana B. Henriques reports.

title: Vacationing Chileans Struggle to Get Home
description: LIMA, Peru  There is the bus option, a two-day, hair-raising journey through mountainous terrain. There are charter planes, whose cost  tens of thousands of dollars  is prohibitive to most. Then there is the mad scramble at airports, where stranded Chileans try to shout or cry their way home. Or they do what Mara Jess Medina did Monday: simply throw down any luggage, sprawl on the floor with resignation and wait.

title: Featured Recipe: Roast Chicken With Fennel
description: Roasting a batch of fennel a couple of weeks ago, it occurred to me that its relatively long cooking time begged for it to serve as the base for a slightly more complicated dish. The idea here was that the fennel would lend its flavor to the chicken, the chicken would lend its juices to the fennel and the creation would need little else.

title: Chile Travel Alert
description: The State Department is urging people to avoid non-essential travel to Chile, in the aftermath of a powerful earthquake that struck 73 miles north of Concepcin.

title: G.O.P. Aims for California, but Rifts Arise
description: BURBANK, Calif.  If Republicans are to have a serious chance of capturing control of the Senate in November, they are going to have to win in traditionally Democratic states like California, where Senator Barbara Boxer, a three-term Democrat, is showing signs of vulnerability.

title: Aftermath in Chile
description: Looting is taking place in severely struck Concepcion and other cities, including Santiago, France 24 correspondent Cyril Vanier reports.

title: Freescale Places New Bet on the E-Reader Market
description: Freescale Semiconductor, the chip maker, is introducing a new microprocessor on Monday that it says will improve the performance and lower the cost of black-and-white e-reading devices.

title: Glitterati
description: Writing about makeup can be frustrating. You can never quite show the texture, the pigment and the sparkle that makes one eye shadow or foundation superior to the next. We here at T may have found a solution. In an interactive feature produced by the photographer Eric Maillet and the beauty editor of Numro magazine, Laurence Hovart, you can now click on a moonscape of color and texture. And voil! A hue with at view.

title: New Home for Rock Halls Archives
description: Some of the most interesting items at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland, like Buddy Hollys high school diploma and Jim Morrisons death certificate, are usually hidden in storage as part of the library and archive. But by the end of the year those items will have a new home in a high-tech $35 million building the museum will share with Cuyahoga Community College, about two miles from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fames lakefront headquarters, The Plain Dealer reported. We want this to be the worlds pre-eminent research center for rock n roll, Andy Leach, director of the halls archives, told the paper.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Bacardi USA, Miami, expanded its relationship with KSL Media, New York, by consolidating its media planning and buying account at the agency. KSL, which handles media services for brands like Bombay Sapphire and Grey Goose, adds those duties for brands like Bacardi and Dewars, which had been handled by Universal McCann, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Total billings for all the brands now handled by KSL were estimated at $20 million.

title: The BLT Partners Split
description: Laurent Tourondel, the chef who gave his name to the BLT empire, and his partner, Jimmy Haber, have parted company just two days short of the sixth anniversary of their association. They have divvied up their holdings in what both describe as an amicable divorce.

title: How the Same-Sex Marriage Case Could Play Out
description: Late Friday night, both sides in Perry v. Schwarzenegger filed briefs with Judge Vaughn Walker outlining their arguments over whether or not the 2008 state ban on same-sex marriage, Proposition 8, is constitutional. At the nonjury trial in January in San Francisco Federal District Court, lawyers presented their cases with testimony from two gay couples, who are the plaintiffs, political leaders and academic experts.

title: Campaign Commemorates Oscars Big Apple Connection (French and Otherwise)
description: Campaign Spotlight

title: Q & A With Stuart Elliott
description: Q & A With Stuart Elliott

title: Why Avatar Is Not the Top-Grossing Film
description: 9 p.m. | Updated

title: Your Experience in Stocks Is Probably Meaningless
description: So often we base our sense of risk on our own experience. The mistake, of course, is failing to realize that our experience is often so limited as to be of almost no value.

title: Underemployment, State by State
description: Many people watch the unemployment rate to get a sense of how much pain there is in the job market. But as we and others have pointed out, it includes only people out of work who are actively looking for work. It doesnt take into account people who have given up looking for jobs, and it doesnt include people who are stuck in part-time positions but really want to be working full time.

title: Closing School in an Anxious Age
description: My school district is closed today. Not because of the 30 inches of snow we received on Friday. And not because of the power, which came back to the high school by last night. No, it is closed, the predawn message from the superintendent said, because of what could be perceived as a vague threat against student and staff safety.

title: Georgia Republican to Resign House Seat
description: Representative Nathan Deal, a Georgia Republican, will resign from the House next week, a move that likely gives the Democrats a little extra breathing room as they try to pass legislation overhauling the health care system.

title: Healthier Frittatas, Straight From the Oven
description: Ive extolled the virtues of the egg before in this column as a wonderful food thats high in protein and low in calories, and a good source of vitamins B12 and E, riboflavin, folacin and iron. Eggs are relatively inexpensive, too, and that is why you find frittatas of one kind or another in many of the worlds cuisines.

title: Man Sleds, Dog Bites
description: There is something Zen about the snow. The city slows and quiets down as it falls, and the white blanket requires you to adapt your movements  smaller steps, more sliding  so as to work with the slippery surfaces and not against them.

title: The Art of the String Quartet: Remembering David Soyer
description: David Soyer, the founding cellist of the Guarneri String Quartet, died on Thursday at 87 (his obituary can be read here). The Guarneri was long-lived and world-renowned, and Mr. Soyer was known as a teacher and mentor as well as an accomplished musician.

title: For Rodriguez and Yankees, Another Bout of Disclosure
description: Last December, concerned Yankee officials reached out to representatives of their star slugger Alex Rodriguez. Along with everyone else in baseball, they had just learned that a Canadian-based doctor named Anthony Galea was under investigation as a possible distributor of performance-enhancing drugs. What the Yankees wanted to know was whether Rodriguez had ever had any dealings with Galea.

title: A Mothers Decision to Die
description: I was talking to a woman in Rhode Island the other day whose father is in a nursing home with advanced dementia. Her weary mother had voiced a fairly common sentiment: When I reach that point, just leave a bottle of pills by the bed.

title: Now Listening | Shearwaters The Golden Archipelago
description: Three months into working on The Golden Archipelago, the new album by Shearwater, the groups vocalist, guitarist and songwriter, Jonathan Meiburg, listened to a recording of the Bikini Atoll national anthem on the Internet. The natives were singing on the islet of Kili, where theyd been displaced since 1948 to make way for U.S. atomic tests.

title: Happy Birthday, Feb. 29 Edition
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: A Warning on Europes Forests
description: Europes forests have been expanding for the last 60 years. But the rate at which forests are growing in Europe is slowing, and forested areas face even more acute challenges in the future because of climate change, Janez Potocnik, the E.U. commissioner for the environment, warned today.

title: HSBC Bankers: Were Underpaid
description: From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague:

title: New Twists in Hurt Locker Brouhaha
description: Another day closer to the final Oscar ballot, another series of divisive  and divided  articles about the authenticity of The Hurt Locker.

title: Setting High Expectations
description: Setting High Expectations

title: Reading Aloud
description: Reading Aloud

title: Womens History Month Across the Curriculum
description: March is Womens History Month, and this years theme, according to the National Womens History Project and the Library of Congress, is Writing Women Back Into History. (Note, too, that International Womens Day is March 8.)

title: Calling on Students
description: Calling on Students

title: Are We Prepared for an 8.8 Quake?
description: The magnitude-8.8 earthquake in Chile, one of the strongest in recorded history, has left more than 700 dead and displaced 1.5 million people. But because of stricter building codes and the quakes greater distance from population centers, the damage was far less than that caused by the 7.0 quake in Haiti.

title: Readers Split the Difference on Tipping
description: In the opening scene of Reservoir Dogs, Mr. Brown, et al., are having breakfast at a diner. After Joe Cabot pays for the meal, he asks everyone to leave a tip for the waitresses and everyone does, except for Mr. Pink. After Joe calls him out, he reluctantly hands over $1. As a rule, Mr. Pink does not tip.

title: The Who Never Kept It So Kosher
description: O.K., whos still sober? asked Ed Greer, poking his head into the room.

title: Food Network Magazine Increases Rate Base, Again
description: Food Network Magazine is getting bigger.

title: Informal Mets Stroll Toward the Season
description: Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: Spanish Judge Accuses Venezuela of Aiding Basque and Colombian Militants
description: MADRID  A Spanish judge on Monday accused the government and armed forces of Venezuela of facilitating high-level contacts between Colombian rebels and Basque separatists, helping the groups learn bomb-making techniques and share intelligence for possible plots to assassinate Colombian politicians, including the president.

title: Bringing New Understanding to the Directors Cut
description: And now, just in time for Oscar junkies, comes a new statistical mincing of the movies that may someday yield an award category of its own: best fit between a movies tempo and the natural rhythms of the brain.

title: Somali Pirates Taking Trade to Terra Firma
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  It seems that there is a new breed of pirate out there, inland pirates, and their new quarry is trucks, not ships, carrying food.

title: Monday Puzzle: Some Light Number Music
description: After the heavy metal physics arguments about the papaya battery which are still ongoing, I thought we should relax with some lighter number music. Todays problem requires nothing more than simple arithmetic and in one case, finding the square root. Todays puzzle blog is based on problems devised by Dr. Aziz Inan, whom we met previously in Backdating.

title: Travel Deals: One-Day Celebrity Cruise Sale
description: Celebrity Cruises will have a one-day sale tomorrow, with discounted fares to the Caribbean starting at about $77 a night.

title: Mariners Say Goodbye to Their Weight Room
description: Because of some major moves, the Seattle Mariners have been pegged by some as the biggest winner of this past off-season.

title: Scent Notes | Chandler Burr
description: Spring has almost sprung. How will it smell?

title: Geneva Auto Show: Before the Rush
description: So much is going to be happening at the Geneva auto show, which opens to the news media on Tuesday, that automakers are having a hard time keeping it all under wraps. Displays are going up all over town, in train stations, the airport, in malls and hotel lobbies. Billboards are everywhere. Last year, you may remember, workers placing advertising banners for a new Volkswagen messed up and unfurled them a day early. This year the auto show opened the doors to the exhibition halls to early media arrivals, while some new concept cars were yet to be wrapped, automakers were rehearsing their elaborate press conferences and setting up.

title: 4 Charged in Concert Ticket Resale Scheme
description: Federal prosecutors in New Jersey said on Monday that four men operating under the name Wiseguy Tickets had broken into online sites, buying more than one million tickets to some of the countrys most popular musical and sporting events and then reselling them for more than $25 million in profit.

title: Donna Murphy Joins Anyone Can Whistle
description: The Tony Award winner Donna Murphy has been cast in the coming New York City Center Encores! revival of Anyone Can Whistle, the Stephen SondheimArthur Laurents musical that closed on Broadway after only nine performances in 1964.

title: Olympic Hockey Finale Drew Huge Ratings
description: What more could NBC ask for? The most medals an American team had ever won in a Winter Olympics and then a finale straight out of Hollywood (well, almost).

title: Goldman Discloses a New Risk: Bad Publicity
description: Its no secret that its been a tough year for Goldman Sachs, perhaps not in terms of their financials  the company reported very strong earnings for 2009 back in January  but clearly in the court of public opinion. Goldman has been pummeled over excessive compensation and its role in the global economic crisis, including the current crisis in Greece, and the firm has had to issue clarifications on statements made by its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, and to even hire a public relations firm headed by former President George W. Bushs director of communications.

title: Justices Wont Hear Uighur Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday said it would not decide a case involving Chinese Muslims detained for eight years at Guantnamo Bay that had been set for argument this month.

title: Electric Car Strategy: Follow the Fleet
description: Like other automakers, Ford Motor Company is betting heavily on electric vehicles as the economy recovers. That decision has been powering the prospects of Azure Dynamics, a company in Oak Park, Mich., that makes electric drive trains and other components for hybrid commercial fleet vehicles like courier vans.

title: Mixing Joy and Structure
description: Mixing Joy and Structure

title: Judge Clears Hurdle for Atlantic Yards
description: A justice in State Supreme Court paved the way Monday for the transfer of private land to the developer Bruce C. Ratner for his long-delayed $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, after rejecting a challenge by local property owners to the states use of eminent domain.

title: CNN Hires New Senior V.P. for Hispanic Strategy
description: The new boss for CNN en Espaol, Cynthia Hudson, has a notable title.

title: Correcting Behavior with Hand Signals
description: Correcting Behavior with Hand Signals

title: U.S. Births Rise in All Age Groups
description: The journal Pediatrics has published its annual report on birth and pregnancy in the United States, and it found that the number of babies born in 2007  4,317,119  was the highest ever recorded.

title: Schumanns Poetic Side, Poured Richly Into Songs
description: It took conviction, and some degree of courage, for the British baritone Simon Keenlyside to perform Schumanns Dichterliebe (A Poets Love) in his recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday. Not because this work is so difficult, although it is, but because it is so familiar, probably Schumanns most performed song cycle. Moreover, the lush expressivity and aching lyricism of the music almost defines Romanticism. So making this cycle sound fresh is not easy.

title: The Human Rights of Home
description: Human rights violations often seem the preserve of distant lands with despotic leaders and destitute peoples. But on Friday, federal officials preparing a report for the United Nations heard directly from New York residents and advocates about the abuse of rights in the city.

title: Grounding the Bank of Americas Ex-Chairman
description: Michelle Leder, who runs the Web site footnoted.org, is keeping an eye on corporate perks disclosed in regulatory filings this proxy season for DealBooks Perks Watch.

title: A Photo Collage From the CeBit Tech Trade Fair
description: The annual CeBIT technology trade show begins on Tuesday at the Congress Centre in Hanover, Germany. This years event, titled Connected Worlds, has more than 4,150 exhibitors from 68 countries and is expected to draw more than 300,000 attendees from the fields of information technology, green energy and education.

title: Alec Baldwin to Star in Equus on Long Island
description: Alec Baldwins character Jack Donaghy on 30 Rock may have complicated animal issues  the neutering of his childhood dog Pop, on his mothers orders, created all sorts of trauma  but he has nothing on the next alpha male Mr. Baldwin is to play. He will star as the psychiatrist Martin Dysart in a production of Peter Shaffers play Equus this summer at Guild Hall in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Finding Something to Like About April 15
description: Were smack dab in the middle of tax season, and I am done. I spent a couple of Saturdays gathering all of my bank statements and other documents, making post-closing general journal entries, and printing out financial statements to deliver to my C.P.A. for both our corporate and personal income tax returns. As my Canadian father would say, my books are now tickety-boo (translation: in perfect working order).

title: Oprah Winfrey Snags Precious For Her New Network
description: Oprah Winfrey, an executive producer of Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire, has lined up a television home for the Oscar-nominated film: OWN, her forthcoming cable channel.

title: Biden to Labor Leaders: Things Could Be Worse
description: ORLANDO  When Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke to the nations labor leaders on Monday, he seemed to be speaking not so much to them but to millions of disaffected Americans. And he pushed a straightforward message: We get it. We hear your pain, and were trying to do something about it.

title: A Great Failure
description: Via Mark Thoma, the trillion-dollar gap:

title: Watch Is Worlds Priciest Car Key
description: Heritage, precision and cachet are among the characteristics that fine watches and fine cars share. Generally, though, one can find a pretty good watch for less than the price of a pretty good car.

title: I Havent Read This
description: Neither have you. Stereotyping people by their favorite New York Times writer.

title: The Future of the Obama Era
description: My column today includes a quote from its subject, Mitch Daniels, warning Republicans about the perils of overconfidence. To drive the point home, heres a passage from a decades-old David Broder column, which Ezra Klein just exhumed from The Washington Posts archives, assessing Ronald Reagans presidency in the wake of the 1982 midterms:

title: Michael Douglas to Be Honored By Film Society of Lincoln Center
description: Michael Douglas says that when hes offered a lifetime achievement prize these days, he does an act of due diligence first. I normally check how many cardiologists are on the review panel for the award, just to see if they know something that I dont, he said Monday in a telephone interview.

title: Block Party | I Lego N.Y.
description: In February 2009, Christoph Niemann, the illustrator and childrens book author, published an installment of Abstract City, his monthly blog on The New York Times Web site. I Lego N.Y. depicted various Big Apple institutions, from the Statue of Liberty to the Metrocard, using that ubiquitous modular building system with hilarious, haiku-like economy of means. Those images, plus 13 new ones, are now available in book form. I Lego N.Y. (Abrams Image) radiates the affection that this onetime New Yorker (who now lives in Berlin) feels for his former home. My two painfully funny favorites are shown here.

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, March 1
description: The work of Toms Munita Philippi, a freelance photographer based in Santiago, Chile, has become instantly familiar to a worldwide audience in the last few days. But for those who watch credit lines, Mr. Munitas name is already widely known and well respected. And this is not the first earthquake he has covered.

title: Jets to Cut Jones, Latest Unemployed Running Back
description: The Jets announced Monday that they would release running back Thomas Jones when free agency begins Friday. The move seemed inevitable once it became clear that Jones, who will turn 32 before the start of the 2010 season, would not restructure his contract to save the Jets a $3 million roster bonus due next week.

title: Awareness: Report Calls for Spotlight on Hypertension
description: High blood pressure is the underlying cause of one in six deaths in the United States, but many Americans do not know they have it and doctors are lax about treating it, according to a new Institute of Medicine report that calls hypertension a neglected disease.

title: The Fairest of Them All | Ineke Hans Does Frankfurt
description: The big international design fairs are a smorgasbord of ideas for editors and store buyers  and occasionally even for designers themselves.
