description: Bain Capital said on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Styron, a Dow Chemical unit that makes plastics and rubber, for $1.63 billion in cash.

title: Now Bagging | Whitney Biennial Tote
description: For a cultural institution interested in promotional items, the tote bag is king. They are to museums and public radio stations what T-shirts are to rock bands, what bumper stickers are to middle school honor rolls. This limited-edition tote ($98) by Tommy Hilfiger celebrates the just-opened 2010 Whitney Biennial and highlights the work of one of its artists, Ari Marcopoulos. A New York photographer of Dutch extraction and a former assistant to Andy Warhol, Marcopoulos is known for the great lengths hell go to to get a picture, whether its shadowing the Beastie Boys or chasing snowboarders down the Alps. The image on this tote bag comes from Detroit, Marcopouloss video piece in the Biennial, about two boys who make electronic music in a small Detroit bedroom using little more than foot effect pedals. Marcopoulos was given an advance copy of the bag, which went on sale Thursday, and he approved of it. I thought it was going to be a really cheap tote bag, he said. But its functional. And when I wore it, people on the subway were checking me out.

title: Surprise! Taylor Swift Nominated For Five Academy of Country Music Awards
description: She may not be, in the words of the head of her record label, the best technical singer, but Taylor Swift will have another opportunity next month to appear astounded by her awards-show largess: shes been nominated for five Academy of Country Music Awards, including entertainer of the year. The nominations, which were announced on Tuesday morning, were most generous to the Nashville group Lady Antebellum, which picked up seven nominations including album of the year (for its self-titled 2008 release) and top vocal group, as well as single record of the year, song of the year and video of the year for Need You Now. Miranda Lambert is nominated for six awards, as is Carrie Underwood, the academys reigning entertainer of the year, who is once again nominated in that category. Kenny Chesney picked up four nominations, as did Brad Paisley and the Zac Brown Band. The winners will be announced at a ceremony in Las Vegas on April 18.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Porsche 918 Spyder Plug-In Hybrid
description: Introduced on Tuesday: Porsche 918 Spyder concept

title: Samurai Shopper | Age of Enlightenment
description: The Samurai Shopper, though possessed of boundless wisdom, is afflicted with a waggish skepticism  chalk it up to experience. I had to abandon the passionate energies and utter stupidity of youth. There wasnt a choice; birthdays happened. I do miss my younger self, especially the part where I awoke each morning looking radiantly fresh, like a shiny penny in a mud puddle. Now it takes many, many shiny pennies to find illumination, which mainly comes from skin-care counters. Like the Doges Palace in Venice, my exterior has borne the insults of time and seeks restoration to the alabaster glory that once was me. Besides, bright people dont deserve dull skin.

title: $15 Billion but Not a Lot of Sense
description: The Senate has passed a $15 billion package that is aimed at helping small businesses. There are two key parts. One is the extension of section 179 of the tax code, which allows up to $250,000 of capital expenditures to be expensed immediately instead of being depreciated over time. This will motivate some companies to make capital expenditures that will reduce their tax bills, which is good for the economy. The other part is the suspension of FICA payments for the rest of the year for new hires.

title: The Palm Pre Plus Creates a Hot Spot
description: Fortunately, when my Internet went dead I had just set up the new Palm Pre Plus from Verizon. Fortunately, I say, because the Plus can act as a wireless hot spot. I used it to temporarily replace my Wi-Fi network and was able to connect my desktop and laptop to the Internet through the phone.

title: Bits Scan: Pirate Bay, the Internet River and a Google Patent
description: Good morning, Bits readers. Its Tuesday, and although the weather in New York is mostly cloudy, our technology news is not:

title: Freakout-nomics
description: If you think conservatives are freaking out over the growing prospects that health care reform will, in fact, happen, wait until you see the freakout over climate change.

title: Launching a Rocket That Becomes a Boomerang
description: Those of us who have written something freakishly mean  we are legion in an age of snark  and then come to gnaw the bone of regret can identify with Will Leitch. Writing at Deadspin, Mr. Leitch walks back the cat on a missile he launched long ago at Roger Ebertthat was entitled, more or less, I Am Sick of Roger Eberts Fat (something even more nasty and less descriptive) Face. Mr. Ebert, perhaps the most famous film critic of our age, has lost his voice and part of his face to thyroid cancer and was recently profiled in Esquire to very remarkable effect. Now that Mr. Eberts face is no longer fat, Mr. Letich has had time to contemplate his choice of targets  Mr. Ebert had shown him significant professional courtesies over the years  and writes about what it was like to use his keyboard to do something really dumb.

title: G.M. Triples Opel Investment
description: Under pressure from European governments, General Motors said Tuesday that it would more than triple the amount of money it was committing to turn around its Opel and Vauxhall units while scaling back its request for public loan guarantees, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

title: Crime and (Fitting) Punishment
description: Not that Hollywood isnt adept at coming up with its own punishments  what was that latest Michael Bay movie?  but over at Movieline, the Baggers pal Mark Lisanti serves up some potential penalties for Nicolas Chartier, the overeager Hurt Locker producer who offended the Academy with an e-mail message dissing the (unnamed) competition, so that we can all get back to the important business of celebrating the underappreciated millionaires toiling in the obscurity of historys most glamorous industry. (Hear hear!)

title: Things You Could Have Watched Instead of Jay Leno
description: Yes, yes, were aware that Jay Lenos return on Monday night to The Tonight Show desk he vacated in May was the most important event in broadcasting since Edward R. Murrow covered the Blitz of London. Assuming you were so caught up in Mr. Lenos re-debut that you forgot to watch any other late-night television, what did you miss?

title: Disinflation in Recessions
description: Tim Duy is right  the Fed, and equally importantly the ECB, is seriously underestimating the deflationary danger.

title: Gowanus Canal Gets Superfund Status
description: The Environmental Protection Agency designated the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn a Superfund site on Tuesday and announced plans to clean up more than a centurys worth of noxious pollutants there.

title: U.S. Considers Brake Override System
description: The Obama administration may recommend that carmakers install a brake override system that is intended to prevent the sudden acceleration episodes that have led to recalls of millions of Toyotas, the transportation secretary, Ray LaHood, said on Tuesday.

title: Everything is Perfect
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Werent the Winter Olympics fantastic? The U.S. won a gold medal in downhill economy.

title: He Often Turned to Prayer
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Well, as you may have heard, former Vice President Dick Cheney is doing fine after suffering his fifth heart attack. He is like the Apolo Ohno of heart attacks.

title: Gowanus Canal Named Superfund Site
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency announced Tuesday that it was designating the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn a contaminated Superfund site, paving the way for a cleanup of decades-old pollution there. The decision comes as a blow to the Bloomberg administration, which had proposed a cleanup that would avoid such a designation. (See full article.)

title: Apple Sues Phone Maker HTC Over Patents
description: 11:16 a.m. | Updated  Added response from HTC and a link to the legal documents.

title: Being Ready, in Quake Zones or Snow Zones
description: Nearly every person on the planet lives in a hazard zone of some sort, with the possibility of a severe storm or shaking ground or bomb or some other disturbance disrupting daily life for many days, if not weeks. Having the capacity, as a household and community, to respond and get by without help for a while is vital. A lot of resilience is afforded through a little planning and investment.

title: NOW Calls for Paterson to Resign
description: A leading womens rights group that had once praised Gov. David A. Paterson for his work on violence against women is now seeking his resignation, saying his intervention in a domestic violence case involving a top adviser was inappropriate and disappointing.

title: After Recalls, Toyota Offers Incentives to Win Back Wary Customers
description: Toyota Motor, estimating that it lost 18,000 sales in the United States last month while its chief competitors enjoyed big gains, introduced incentives Tuesday as it tried to restore consumers confidence in its vehicles after three big recalls.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: TV Watch: A Triumphant Return, Filled With Insecurity
description: Richard M. Nixon may have staged a more elaborate comeback when he resurfaced in 1968 as the new Nixon, but its hard to recall a more labored victory lap than Jay Lenos return to The Tonight Show on Monday night.

title: Greece Set to Release Austerity Plan
description: ATHENS  The Greek government will announce new austerity measures on Wednesday aimed at raising additional money to help curb its bloated budget deficit and avert a debt crisis in the euro zone, a government spokesman said Tuesday.

title: Wrestling With Whisper Campaigns
description: There are mere hours to go until the Oscar polls close, which means all that dirty pool better have done its job by now. Like most sane people, the Bagger doubted that anybody would stoop to whisper campaigns or scare tactics in pursuit of a little gold man, but apparently both are perennial awards-race fixtures. Though he said he was too busy finishing his movie Black Swan to pay attention to the Oscar machinations this season (he did vote, however), the director Darren Aronofsky recently clued the Bagger into what he went through when he was promoting The Wrestler last year. There was some Web sites spreading this thing about how a hundred people had walked out of a screening because of the violence, Mr. Aronofsky said. Maybe that happened, I have no idea. What people told me is it didnt happen, or like three people walked out and they were all over 70 or something, which is understandable because the film was very violent. But it got picked up and spread around.

title: U.S. Children: Generation Snack
description: Parents are raising a generation of snackers  kids who eat almost constantly throughout the day as they graze on cookies, salty snacks and fruit drinks.

title: Tailgating Outside the Supreme Court, Without the Cars
description: WASHINGTON  Mike Sacks likes to be the first person in line for big Supreme Court arguments, and he was feeling pretty confident when he arrived at the court Monday morning around 8, 26 hours before the court would hear a big gun control case.

title: 8 Hurt in Fire in Criminal Court Building
description: Updated, 3:05 p.m. | A two-alarm fire broke out in the basement of the Manhattan Criminal Courthouse around 10:30 Tuesday morning. At least eight people sustained minor injuries, the Fire Department said: five firefighters, two civilians and one prisoner.

title: Mickey Mouse Fashion
description: You flew all the way down here from New York just to come to this place? says the guy behind the counter at the Marni outlet in Orlando, Fla., incredulous that two women of seemingly reasonable intelligence  this would be me and my friend Laura  would travel a thousand miles to chase a bargain on a saggy sack dress or a cashmere sweater with elbow patches.

title: Geneva Auto Show: 2011 Alfa Romeo Giulietta
description: Introduced on Tuesday: 2011 Alfa Romeo Giulietta

title: Testing the Republican Waters
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, publisher of The Daily News, put his toe in the water for the Senate seat in New York and apparently found the temperature to his liking. A story in The Albany Times Union (thanks to Politico for the point) reports that Edward F.Cox, chairman of the Republican Party in New York, has heard from a number of people interested in the seat, including Mr. Zuckerman.

title: Are Tax Refund Splurges Starting to Come Back?
description: Many Americans used last years tax refunds to pay down debt or save for the future. Now, it appears that more plan to spend their tax refunds on big splurges once again.

title: Microsoft R.&D. Celebrates the Human Body
description: When it comes to R.&D. eye candy, Microsoft is king.

title: Study Finds Cohabiting Doesnt Make a Union Last
description: Couples who live together before they get married are less likely to stay married, a new study has found. But their chances improve if they were already engaged when they began living together.

title: Horror Rappers Angered by Law & Order Episode
description: We thought we were discouraged because we had missed Mondays episode of Law & Order, which promised to center on the subculture of Juggalos, the fans of the hip-hop duo Insane Clown Posse who paint their faces like nightmare versions of childrens entertainers. But the episode, called Steel-Eyed Death, was an even greater disappointment to the members of the horrorcore music world, who say the show misrepresented them and their musical scene.

title: Fast Forward to Old Age, Please
description: THE other night at 3 a.m., I was in bed and my husband was frying a couple of eggs on my belly, and I shrieked, Flip, flip! and he turned onto his stomach, and I said, No, not you, the eggs.

title: Crudup to Star in The Metal Children
description: The actor Billy Crudup, whose last major New York performance won him a Tony Award, for Tom Stoppards The Coast of Utopia during the 2006-07 season, will star in the world premiere production of Adam Rapps play The Metal Children at the Vineyard Theater in May.

title: Job Blizzard Watch
description: Last week, I wrote about the potential for blizzard-related February job losses to derail the Democrats economic agenda, including their proposed health care overhaul. Goldman Sachs economists now estimate that, when the February jobs report is released this Friday, it will show a decline of 100,000 payroll jobs. Macroeconomic Advisers is predicting that the blizzard claimed between 150,000 and 220,000 jobs.

title: Beltran Says He Referred Reyes to Galea for Treatment
description: The federal investigation of the Canadian-based doctor Anthony Galea continued to take on a distinct New York tone on Tuesday as the third Met or Yankee in three days acknowledged that he had been contacted or interviewed by the authorities in connection with Galeas activities.

title: Junk Food Taxes?
description: Heres a terrific piece by Tom Laskawy on junk food taxes vs. good food subsidies.

title: A Novelist-Mother Writes to Calm Her Fears
description: Jodi Picoult writes to protect herself from her fears. Her stories of imperfect mothers  always mothers  struggling to protect their children in a dangerous world are her way of warding off the demons.

title: Beyond the Grill | Gold Teeth
description: Avant-garde fashion finds inspiration in many quarters, but few designers have been willing to tackle, um, dentistry. Enter the retainer necklace by Jules Kim of Bijules NYC, with its single protruding gold tooth  it would never be accidentally thrown away with a lunch tray in the junior high cafeteria. Kim created it especially for her roommate, the fashion photographer Brooke Nipar, who had lost a tooth in a bar fight; she cast it in gold and hung it from a detachable chain so that Nipar could pop it in her mouth or wear it around her neck with pride. Meanwhile, the London artist William Hunt has created a limited-edition set of silver cuff links made from casts of the wisdom teeth he had removed as a performance in art school.The three Six Six Six girls, whose macabre design line is named Triskaidekaphobia after the fear of the number 13, offer spiky silver bangles and slinky pendants sculptured from metal baby teeth; the San Francisco gothic brand Loved to Death offers actual human baby teeth set in gold, Victorian-inspired settings. And Dominic Joness yellow gold shark fangs interspersed with gold rose thorns are just begging for someone to take a nibble.

title: Venus in Fur May Transfer to Broadway
description: The theater producer Robert Fox, who is known for a sure touch with mounting intimate, small-cast plays on Broadway, is exploring the possibility of transferring the Classic Stage Companys production of Venus in Fur to a Broadway house, Mr. Fox said on Tuesday.

title: There She Goes (Again), Miss America
description: Once one of the nations most desirable singles, Miss America is unattached again and its not immediately clear who will pick her up off her feet. On Monday, the cable channel TLC became the latest television broadcaster to drop the long-running Miss America Pageant, Reuters reported. In a statement, TLC said that it was happy to have been part of the modernization and revitalization of the Miss America Pageant but was declining to renew its contract to show the event.

title: A Day at the Arcade for the Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Repeating as World Series champions is one thing. But far be it from Joe Girardi to select the same activity as last year for the Yankees team-building outing Tuesday. Eschewing a return trip to a pool hall, Girardi sent his players and coaches to a local video arcade, where they are competing in three popular games: IndyCar racing, Skee-Ball and Pop-a-Shot basketball. Winners of each competition will receive gift certificates.

title: Our Contest Winner Claims Her Prize
description: In December, we published newly digitized images of the manuscript for Charles Dickenss classic tale, A Christmas Carol. Readers were invited to spot additions or deletions made to the text by the author just before the story was published in 1843. As a reward for submitting the best response, Hilary Johnson of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was invited for tea at the Morgan Library and Museum with Alison Leigh Cowan, a reporter for The New York Times. Here, Ms. Johnson recalls some observations of her visit.

title: Senator Relents, and Jobless Bill Passes
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate ended a politically charged impasse over unemployment pay on Tuesday night, voting to allow jobless Americans in danger of exhausting their benefits another month of aid.

title: Obama to Make Statement, Not Speech, on Health Care
description: President Obama is likely to make a statement at the White House on Wednesday about moving forward with health care legislation, rather than give a speech elsewhere in Washington, D.C., as had been announced on Monday, his spokesman, Robert Gibbs, said.

title: Life With a Pouch on the Side
description: Ive got a little plastic secret.

title: Texas Mother Ecstatic About Posthumous Pardon for Wrongfully Convicted Son
description: As The Lubbock Avalanche-Journal reported, on Monday Gov. Rick Perry signed the first posthumous pardon ever issued by the state of Texas, officially clearing a man who had been wrongfully convicted of rape in 1986. The pardon came more than a decade after the man, Tim Cole, died in prison at the age of 39 from complications after an asthma attack, and two years after DNA evidence proved that another man had committed the crime.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Cadillac Returns to Europe With New Strategy
description: GENEVA  General Motors announced in February that it would create Cadillac Europe to manage import, distribution and marketing of the brand in Europe. At the Geneva auto show this week, the company elaborated on its plans, saying it was hoping to eventually sell only 3,000 cars a year through about 50 dealers.

title: More on the Bunning Benefits Blockade
description: Carl Hulse files the latest news from Capitol Hill on the impasse over jobless benefits engineered by Senator Jim Bunning, Republican of Kentucky.

title: Mashing Up the Navi
description: As the Carpetbagger notes, we are deep into the silly season, with Oscar campaigning now veering into a debate over the military efficacy of Hurt Locker. The scurrilous tactics rarely change the outcome, so we prefer to walk on the sunny side of the awards season. To wit, when we first saw Avatar, it put us in the mind of Dances with Wolves, but the Internet has spoken and the designated analogue is actually Pocahontas, with a series of the inevitable mash-ups quickly following. But none, as Awards Daily points out, match this one for sheer brilliance of juxtaposition:

title: Geneva Auto Show: Aston Martin Cygnet
description: Introduced on Tuesday: Aston Martin Cygnet

title: Justices Reinstate Settlement With Writers
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday resurrected a possible settlement in a class-action lawsuit brought by freelance writers who said that newspapers and magazines had committed copyright infringement by making their contributions available on electronic databases.

title: Robertas Goes Commercial
description: This low-resolution video promo posted online by Robertas Pizzeria in Bushwick is a masterpiece, 2 minutes 18 seconds of the kind of acting, lighting and captioning that would do public-access TV proud. Nothing like those slick restaurant commercials you get on broadcast TV.

title: Geneva Auto Show: 2011 Audi A1
description: Introduced on Tuesday: 2011 Audi A1

title: Calories Fill-In
ABT to Present Ratmanskys Bright Stream in Washington
description: The curious specialty of the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky is to envision a 20th-century Soviet Union that might have been, the land that composers once dreamed of optimistically, Alastair Macaulay wrote last year about the work of Mr. Ratmansky, the Russian artist. Mr. Ratmansky will have the chanceto present that vision again, in 2011. American Ballet Theater has announced that it will present the company premiere of Mr. Ratmanskys production of The Bright Stream on Jan. 21, 2011, at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The comic two-act narrative ballet about members of a Russian farm collective in the 1930s, set to music by Shostakovich, was first staged by Mr. Ratmansky for the Bolshoi in 2003. The original production was choreographed by Fyodor Lopukhov and first performed in 1935 in Leningrad. The ballet will also be performed during the companys spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which will run from May 16 through July 9, 2011. Mr. Ratmansky joined American Ballet Theater as Artist in Residence in January 2009.

title: Time Out for Good Behavior
description: We interrupt the usual stream of disturbing news  which includes Tiger Woodss emergence from family therapy, the New Mexico basketball coach Steve Alfords being reprimanded for yelling at an opposing player, and Alex Rodriguezs latest dabbling with the truth in baseball doping issues  to announce that it is National Sportsmanship Day.

title: Scramble in Chile to Save Quake Victims
description: Three days after an 8.8-magnitude earthquake devastated the city of Concepcion, Chile, the race is on to rescue survivors trapped under rubble.

title: Getting Old Is Expensive
description: The skyrocketing costs of health care arent just bad for Medicares solvency. They also spell trouble for the elderly themselves.

title: A New Kindergarten Doesnt Silence Old Complaints
description: As in many neighborhoods in the city, property values on the Upper West Side are frequently tied to the success of the neighborhoods schools. So the mere mention of changing the zones of which blocks are assigned to which schools is enough to send shock waves through the area.

title: Protecting Your Childs Hearing
description: For those of you who were charmed by the photo of Drew Brees and his son after this years Super Bowl, theres a story in todays Science section about those toddler-size ear protectors that 1-year-old Baylen was wearing. Yes, he needed them, as Joyce Cohen explains:

title: Q&A: Paying With Credit Cards in France
description: Q.

title: Model-Morphosis | Versace
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Karmen Pedaru from Next Model Management before (top, bottom) and after makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Mancakes
description: Cupcakes designed especially for men.

title: Obama to Consider 4 Republican Ideas on Health Care
description: President Obama has released a letter to Congressional leaders detailing four Republican ideas put forward at last weeks health care meeting that he will consider.

title: Geneva Auto Show: BMW 5 Series ActiveHybrid
description: Introduced on Tuesday: BMW 5 Series ActiveHybrid

title: Is It Better to Buy or Rent?
description: The answer to the question depends on many factors. Compare the costs of buying and renting equivalent homes.

title: Lil Wayne Sentencing Is Postponed Again
description: Eventually, the Rolling Stone cover line Lil Wayne Goes to Jail will be correct, but not today. On Tuesday a court spokesman in Manhattan told The Associated Press that sentencing for the rapper Lil Wayne had been postponed because of a basement fire at a courthouse.

title: Greek Troubles Trip Euro, to E.U. Exporters Relief
description: The European Commission has told Greece it will have to undertake additional austerity measures it it was to cut its deficit by 4 percentage points, to just under 9 percent of its gross domestic product.

title: Rose Gray, a Master of Italian Fare, Is Dead at 71
description: Rose Gray, a founder and chef of the River Caf in London, a restaurant that transformed the image of Italian cooking in Britain by emphasizing fresh ingredients and authentic country dishes, died Sunday at her home in London. She was 71.

title: Now Carrying | Steven Alans Got a Brand New Bag
description: Steven Alan has a thing for basics. Or, as the New York-based designer puts it, the perfect blank.  The perfect flannel shirt. The perfect five-pocket jeans. And now the perfect bag. Alans latest design is a waxed cotton and leather carry-on valise he created for V Australia, an offshoot of Virgin Airlines. You can hear all about the trip the airline sent Alan on for inspiration  Sydney, the Great Barrier Reef, the Daintree River  but for a designer obsessed with essentials, the real force behind the bag was simple: Where do you put your laptop and your laundry? And how can you wear it like a backpack without it looking like a backpack?

title: Investigators Are Told of Paterson Bid to Quiet Accuser
description: A key figure in the domestic abuse scandal bedeviling Gov. David A. Paterson told investigators that the governor phoned her to enlist her help in quieting the accuser, according to a person with knowledge of her account.

title: How to Contribute to Disaster Relief in Chile
description: The following organizations, listed by GuideStar, are accepting donations to help with relief efforts in Chile:

title: Building a Better Teacher
description: ON A WINTER DAY five years ago, Doug Lemov realized he had a problem. After a successful career as a teacher, a principal and a charter-school founder, he was working as a consultant, hired by troubled schools eager  desperate, in some cases  for Lemov to tell them what to do to get better. There was no shortage of prescriptions at the time for how to cure the poor performance that plagued so many American schools. Proponents of No Child Left Behind saw standardized testing as a solution. President Bush also championed a billion-dollar program to encourage schools to adopt reading curriculums with an emphasis on phonics. Others argued for smaller classes or more parental involvement or more state financing.

title: Delaware Broadens Standards for Poison Pills
description: The long-awaited opinion in the Selectica case came out this week from Delaware Chancery Court. Vice Chancellor John W. Noble, in the 71-page opinion, validated the Selectica boards decision to adopt a net operating loss poison pill and permit this pill to be set off after Versata intentionally crossed the pills threshold.

title: Microsoft Gaming Tech Has Broader Uses
description: Deeper into the R.&D. pipeline, Microsoft has more gaming-oriented technology.

title: Drinking to Glory
description: Im wondering if you could fit Mot and Chandon as the official Champagne of the Oscars somewhere in your Carpetbagger coverage? a publicist called to ask. Excellent timing: we were just working on a post about reckless drunks. Apparently acting like one is a quick route to Oscar glory, as Tom ONeil notes on The Los Angeles Times Gold Derby blog.

title: Obama Takes Economic Detour From Health Care
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  President Obama took a brief detour from promoting his health care plan in Washington and traveled here today in the latest stop on his economic and job-creation tour.

title: An Exit From City Hall for a Top Bloomberg Aide
description: Yet another top aide to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is making the transition from Bloomberg the mayor to Bloomberg the businessman.

title: Very Scary Things
description: So Im working on a climate-related project, and reading Marty Weitzman on extreme uncertainty (pdf). Weitzman directs us to the example of the PaleoceneEocene Thermal Maximum, when temperatures rose about 6 degrees C over 20,000 years, and there were mass extinctions.

title: Nine to Know: 2009 Home Run Leaders by Position
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: House Hunting in ... Tokyo
description: A TWO-BEDROOM ONE-BATH APARTMENT IN CENTRAL TOKYO

title: McConnell Warns Against Passage of Health Care Bill
description: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, warned Democrats on Tuesday that Republicans would use the issue of health care to bludgeon them in the November midterm elections if Democrats succeeded in passing a comprehensive overhaul.

title: In Return Engagement, Leno Soundly Defeats Letterman
description: Let the Leno-Letterman jousting resume. Jay Lenos return to The Tonight Show Monday was watched by about 6.6 million viewers, according to early Nielsen ratings, up about 25 percent from his average viewership in the first quarter last year.

title: Candidate Is Stabbed to Death in Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  An opposition candidate for Ethiopias Parliament was stabbed to death early Tuesday in what opposition leaders said was part of a widening campaign of repression ahead of May elections.

title: The Latest Health Care Developments
description: Over at the Prescriptions blog, our colleague David M. Herszenhorn has been keeping tabs on the back-and-forth over the ever-shifting state of health care legislation on Capitol Hill.

title: Geneva Auto Show: 2011 Toyota Auris HSD Hybrid
description: Introduced on Tuesday: 2011 Toyota Auris HSD Hybrid

title: Vain Glorious | London Calling
description: Who: The photographer Robyn Beeche.

title: CFs New Bid Puts the Pressure Back on Terra
description: The surprise bid by CF Industries Holdings for Terra Industries has reignited the four-way war in the fertilizer industry, pushing valuations even higher and extending what could become one of the longest takeover battles ever.

title: Labor Jumps Into Arkansas Senate Race
description: Organized labor rarely supports challengers to sitting Democrats, but the A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced on Tuesday that it was so dissatisfied with Senator Blanche Lincoln, a Democrat from Arkansas, that it had endorsed Lt. Gov. Bill Halter of Arkansas. He is challenging her from the left in the May 18 Democratic primary.

title: White House Response to Stimulus Criticisms
description: In a post this morning titled Wasted Stimulus, the economist Edward L. Glaeser argued that a big chunk of stimulus spending wasnt going to the areas that needed it most. Rather, he said, the money is being disproportionately spent on low-density areas that also happen to have low unemployment rates. Jared Bernstein, the chief economic adviser to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., has responded to Mr. Glaesers arguments.

title: Access Hollywood Gets a Spin-Off, and Its Live
description: NBC is creating a new daytime talk show based on its Access Hollywood entertainment brand.

title: Sallie Mae Gets Into Retail Banking
description: Sallie Mae is getting into the retail banking business.

title: BYD Links Up With Daimler to Build Electric Cars in China
description: GENEVA  As other Chinese automakers bypass the auto show here, BYD Auto and the Chinese companys Swiss importer, Martin Parsons, promised they will be in Geneva every year.

title: A Hiroo Apartment
description: A two-bedroom one-bath apartment in central Tokyo is on the market for 66 million yen (about $740,000).

title: Its Official but No Surprise: Jerry Brown Announces Another Run
description: Former California Gov. Jerry Brown officially announced  with a YouTube video and all  that he would yet again run for the states top post. The Democrat, who will be 72 in April, jumped in officially when his Web site went live with the announcement a little while ago.

title: Lets Put On a Gowanus Art Show
description: For decades, the Gowanus Canal has attracted  in addition to trash, sewage, body-dumpers and now, the loving attention of the federal Superfund program  a certain class of urban romantic.

title: Two Earthquakes in Two Months: Comparing the Quakes in Haiti and Chile
description: Overview | How do the earthquakes in Chile and Haiti compare? In this lesson, students perform a gallery walk to learn more about the earthquakes from a specific standpoint, and then do a specific research and presentation project or response activity. Finally, they seek answers to their lingering unanswered questions.

title: Toyota Executive Apologizes to European Customers
description: GENEVA  Kazuo Okamoto, vice chairman of the Toyota Motor Corporation, apologized to European customers Tuesday for problems with sticky accelerators that prompted a recall of 8 million cars.

title: A Meta Mash-Up
description: Oh man, this is getting so meta: over at the Media Decoder blog, David Carr, of the ex-Carpetbagger David Carrs, points his readers to Awards Daily, where Sasha Stone points her readers to this clip, which she calls the Final and best Avatar and Pocohantas Mash-Up.

title: California Ex-Governor Announces Encore Run
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If Attorney General Jerry Brown, who formally announced his candidacy for governor of California on Tuesday, is to succeed in his efforts to return to the job he held for eight years, he will have to convince an angry electorate that a career politician is the right choice at a time when voters here  and nationwide  seem to have little patience for that particular breed.

title: Real Estate Separation for Jann Wenner and Wife
description: Jann S. Wenner, the founder of Rolling Stone, has been separated from his wife, Jane Wenner, for many years, but recent real estate transactions suggest that the couple may finally be headed toward a more formal parting of the ways.

title: Mothers Next Act: Broadway
description: Any mother struggling to create a second act after the children have grown will be inspired by Susan DominussBig City column today. It is about Maddie Corman, a Westchester mom of three, who watched her dreams of stardom recede during the decade she spent at home with her children. (Full disclosure: like Dominus, I know Corman from the neighborhood.)

title: Geneva Auto Show: Bertone Pandion
description: Introduced on Tuesday: Bertone Pandion

title: Grass Fed | Wear Your Beets
description: Last summer, I picked up an album called Spit in the Face of People Who Dont Want to Be Cool by a band called the Beets, mainly because they were from Queens and because I liked the cover art. And because I have a record-buying problem. And possibly because of the food connection. But, honestly, I dont buy records because theyve got food on them, or else Id own some Joy of Cooking albums and wouldve let myself get that Northern Rocks Bear Weird Vegetable LP that came out on Sacred Bones Records last year.

title: HBO Will Play Game of Thrones
description: If youve been jonesing for an epic fantasy to help fill the gap between Peter Jacksons Lord of the Rings movies and the maybe-someday remake of Dune, HBO may have just rolled the saving throw you needed.

title: Gun-Toting Cleanup Crew Takes to Baker Beach
description: They came from as far as San Jose to a beach known for its clothing-optional policy, but the 21 participants at the Bay Area Open Carry meeting were fully clothed and then some.

title: U.S. Plans New Measure for Poverty
description: The federal government announced on Tuesday that it would begin producing an experimental measurement of poverty next year, a step toward the first overhaul of the formula since it was developed nearly a half-century ago by an obscure civil servant in the Social Security Administration.

title: A Widening Scandal for Governor Paterson
description: Carolyn Ryan, deputy metro editor of The Times, discusses the governor's role in an abuse case involving an aide.

title: U.N. Official Condemns Gaza Blockade
description: GAZA  The senior United Nations official for humanitarian relief took a tour of Gaza on Tuesday, a year after Israels war here, and declared keen concern for what he called the collective punishment of 1.5 million Palestinians due to the blockade enforced by Israel and Egypt.

title: WTA Sees New Frontier Online and in China
description: Eight months after taking over as chief executive of the WTA Tour, Stacey Allaster came to New York for an exhibition between two of her marquee players  the Billie Jean King Cup at Madison Square Garden  and was happy to be bearing a heartening lack of bad news.

title: A Blogger in the Senate?
description: It seems that Mickey Kaus, one of the deans of the blogosphere, is going to challenge Barbara Boxer in Californias Democratic primary. I fearlessly predict that he will lose, but I hope he acquits himself well enough (or at least entertainingly enough) to encourage more pundits and policy wonks to throw their hats into the political ring. Weve reached a point in American life where the line between celebrities, television personalities and politicians is tissue-thin. But when non-politicians who actually know something about policy  be they political journalists, think-tankers or public intellectuals  get involved in government, its almost always as spokespeople, speechwriters and policy advisers, rather than as actual candidates for office. National Reviews Rich Lowry flirted with a bid for New York mayor in 2001, and there was a brief Lawrence Lessig for Congress boomlet in 2008, but both Lowry and Lessig ultimately decided against running. And theres certainly no current American equivalent of Britains Boris Johnson, the magazine-editor-turned-Tory M.P.-turned-Mayor-of-London  or Michael Ignatieff, the historian, essayist and academic whos now the leader of Canadas Liberal Party.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, March 2
description: It is an incongruously wry image from a ravaged land: two world leaders presenting a nearly symmetrical picture as they prepared to embrace in Santiago. (That sense of seing two sides of a coin simultaneously is heightened subtly by the bilateral evergreen in the background.) But a real measure of Chileans anguish can be seen in Slide 3, by Pilar Olivares of Reuters, as Salome Tomita identified her son among the earthquake victims laid out at a gymnasium in Constitucin.

title: G.M. Goes Back to the Organizational Drawing Board
description: While the leaner General Motors that emerged from bankruptcy has made progress, G.M.s president, Mark Reuss, sees room for improvement. Consequently, he has made sweeping changes to G.M. North Americas organizational chart. He said his goals are to eliminate layers and allow managers to focus on their specialty, while positioning himself closer to the customer.

title: 400,000 Will Lose Jobless Benefits Next Week
description: An estimated 400,000 Americans will lose their unemployment benefits in the next week if Congress does not reauthorize unemployment insurance extensions, the Labor Department said in a statement.

title: A Troubled Shop Reopens, With Stipulations
description: Joseph Malewich will readily admit that he is not a bike guy. His passion lately has been for inventions, he said, such as a small face shield that mounts on a machine gun, made from military-grade titanium.

title: Supreme Court Still Divided on Guns
description: WASHINGTON  At least five justices appeared poised to expand the scope of the Second Amendments protection of the right to bear arms on Tuesday, judging from comments at an unusually intense Supreme Court argument.

title: Men and Women Suffer Different Travel Illnesses
description: Women and men are prone to different illnesses when traveling abroad, according to a new study published in the March 15 issue of Clinical Infectious Diseases.

title: For One Week, Idol Flips Male and Female Performances
description: American Idol viewers who have been looking forward to the return performances of its 10 remaining female contestants (perhaps to help them forget about the 10 remaining male contestants) will have to wait one more night: on Tuesday, Fox said that the shows male semifinalists will instead perform tonight and the female semifinalists will take the stage on Wednesdays show.

title: The Blackout as Revelation
description: In 1965, the lights went out from Ontario to the Eastern Seaboard. Prisoners rioted. Riders trapped in elevators and subway cars took to singing in the blackness. At La Guardia, one runway remained illuminated by a water-powered generator, its solitary glow calling to the sky like the last candle in the last window of all of New York. Streetlamps flickered out, trains slowed to a stop, and a quiet filled the air as the people of Gotham gathered at their windows to reflect upon their still and moonlit city. The birth rate, nine months later, spiked.

title: You Cant Weatherproof a Flight
description: AS thousands of passengers who were caught up in last months bout of snowstorms along the East Coast can attest, finding a new flight after a major weather cancellation is getting not only harder, but more complex.

title: Hiking Deep Into Dogon Country in Mali
description: A DRY, biting wind swept in from the Sahara as my young guide, David Dolo; my driver, Mahmadou; and I followed a local animist priest up a rocky trail in Dogon country in central Mali. Below us, the village of Hombori stretched across the yellow plain; above, I could make out hollows in the sandstone cliff face  natural grottoes used as burial chambers for more than a thousand years. After trudging for a half-hour up the punishing cliffside path, we stopped before a cave from which emanated a musty smell. I peered inside at a dozen grinning skulls and, behind them, piles of bones, shreds of clothing, and amulets and totems placed there centuries ago.

title: 36 Hours in Palm Beach, Fla.
description: PALM BEACHERS may have tightened their Gucci belts in the wake of the Bernard Madoff scandal. The Ponzi scheme cleaned out some local bank accounts, and the recession curtailed the lust for Limoges and other such items. Still, judging by the perfectly clipped hedges that envelop the manicured mansions, residents may be doing with less, but not much less. The tiny island, north of Fort Lauderdale on Floridas east coast, still boasts some of the countrys dreamiest estates, where the staff lives better than many Americans, cashmere sweaters in trademark pastel greens and pinks go for $800, and Rolls-Royces show up at Publix with regularity in a town where more is never quite enough.

title: Restaurant Review: Whiskey Soda Lounge in Portland, Ore.
description: At Whiskey Soda Lounge, in Portlands southeast corner, Asian surf rock blares and psychedelic orange lampshades cast a surreal glow, but its the food thats most striking. Small plates of aahaan kap klaem  Thai pub snacks  arrive one after the next, covering tiny tables, along with potent beverages to wash them down. Here, that means house-brewed fruit vinegars mixed with bracing spirits in concoctions like the Hunny, a cocktail of tequila, grapefruit juice, lime and honey-flavored drinking vinegar ($8). Pair that with Ikes Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings ($12), and its salty-sweet, almost caramelized coating, and you have the worlds perfect bar food.

title: Hotel Review: Aria Resort and Casino in Las Vegas
description: THE BASICS

title: Tuscany Without the Crowds
description: IT was a cold, foggy morning in Tuscany, and La Foce, a 15th-century villa that sits on 2,000 acres of rolling fields overlooking the storied Montepulciano vineyards, was eerily quiet.

title: Where Centro Parties at Night
description: UNTIL recently, there was one sound you could count on hearing every night at sundown in Centro, Mexico Citys historic district: the grind of metal gates descending, as stores and restaurants closed. Anyone brave enough to stroll the area at night would have a hard time distinguishing a taquera from a cantina, let alone finding one open for business.

title: Regulators Reviewing Owner of Derby Favorite Over Loans
description: Kentucky and New York racing regulators are reviewing whether Ahmed Zayat, owner of the early Kentucky Derby favorite Eskendereya, has jeopardized his license to race in those states because of loans he made to two convicted bookmakers.

title: Buenos Aires for Those Who Shun Steaks
description: IT was over a bowl of delicious, spicy-sweet peanut soup with pesto made from huacatay, or Andean black mint, that I realized the vegetarian diner was now perfectly welcome in Buenos Aires. As a vegetarian traveling in a country where beef takes center stage, I expected my meals to be relegated to an assortment of side dishes  sauted greens, some variation of potatoes  supplemented by the occasional granola bar. For many, myself included, the diet is not just a daily choice, but a way of life. I am a practicing Jain  a member of an ancient Indian religion that espouses ahimsa, or nonviolence toward all living beings  and my diet forbids all meat, poultry, fish and even eggs, though it does allow milk and cheese.

title: GMACs Chief Gets Payout Comparable to Blankfeins
description: GMAC, the money-losing auto and real estate lender that was bailed out by the government, awarded its chief executive, Michael A. Carpenter, a pay package comparable in size to the one given to Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive at the highly profitable Goldman Sachs, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Hyundai i-Flow
description: Introduced on Tuesday: Hyundai i-Flow concept

title: Angels Are Different, but Are They Better?
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Before Tuesday, I had not been to Tempe Diablo Stadium in 11 years. Since then, the Angels have added a lot of championship flags above the windows of the suites behind home plate.

title: Comebacker Shortens Dessenss Outing
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It took the Mets only seven outs into their Grapefruit League season to record their first injury.

title: Making Broadway Accessible for the Disabled
description: The next time you complain about not being able to see the stage from the nosebleed sections of a Broadway theater, think about not being able to see the stage at all.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Pininfarina 2uettottanta
description: Introduced on Tuesday: Pininfarina 2uettottanta

title: In the Belly of the Information Beast
description: Access and information are tightly related, to each other and to feelings of power and status.

title: Iraqs Hot New TV Show: Candidate Debates
description: For the first time in Iraq, voters are getting acquainted with their politicians through an old bit of political theater that is something rather new in Iraq: televised debates.

title: Swimming in Murky Waters Infested With Death and Life
description: A mermaid, who has wandered in from the water and cant find her way back, lies on a rock, half-dead. This image, described in a conversation, opens Ibsens Lady From the Sea and could handily serve as a portrait of its heroine.

title: A Conductor and a Violinist Turn Fresh Eyes on a Beloved Beethoven and a Brahms
description: Vladimir Jurowski appears not to have strained his imagination building programs for his visit to New York with the London Philharmonic. The first of his two concerts, on Monday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, offered two scores that could hardly be more standard: the Beethoven Violin Concerto and the Brahms Symphony No. 2. The second, on Sunday, is a slightly more inventive coupling of Shostakovich and Ravel.

title: Properties for $280,000
description: A home in Calvert, Tex., a row house in Philadelphia, and a house in Livingston, Mont.

title: Premiere of a Belber Play Set for Atlantic Theater Company
description: The world premiere of Stephen Belbers play Dusk Rings a Bell, directed by Sam Gold (Circle Mirror Transformation) will be the final show of Atlantic Theater Companys Stage 2 season, the theater announced on Tuesday.

title: Symphonic Drama: Rage-Filled Reunion for Slave and His Sister
description: Its hard to imagine a more riveting performance of Sibeliuss seldom-heard Kullervo than the thrilling interpretation given by the Minnesota Orchestra and Osmo Vanska, its music director, on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: What You Get for ... $280,000
description: CALVERT, TEX.

title: 3 Players Make Odd Pairing Singular
description: Schuberts Piano Trio in E flat (D. 929), written in 1827, was featured in the only public concert known to have been organized by the composer, in March 1828. The following year it was played during an event meant to raise funds for a memorial to Schubert, who died in November 1828. Shostakovichs Piano Trio No. 2 in E minor had its premiere in November 1944, with the composer as the pianist, and part of the piece was played at his funeral in 1975.

title: Union Makes Plea for Deal With N.F.L. as Uncapped Season Looms
description: With an uncapped season two days away, the N.F.L. Players Association made a public plea Tuesday for last-ditch negotiations with team owners and renewed a proposal for a one-year extension of the current salary cap, which owners have already rejected. In a statement on its Web site that it also announced on Twitter, the union also offered to negotiate a longer extension if the N.F.L. guarantees that the cap will not go down.

title: Officials in China at Odds Over Food Scandal
description: SANYA, China  A widening national toxic food scandal that has its roots in this tropical island resort area in the South China Sea has set off a rare case of public sniping between officials.

title: Disney, Cablevision Go Public in Fight Over WABC Fees
description: The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision each told viewers to take a side  their side  on Tuesday in a brewing battle over distribution payments that are increasingly seen as a vital for television broadcasters.

title: Obama Offers to Use  Some G.O.P. Health Proposals
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama offered Tuesday to address some of the concerns expressed by Republicans in the health care debate as the two parties maneuvered for advantage heading into the legislative end game.

title: Ex-Hospital Official Fined in Conflict of Interest Case
description: A former board member of New York Citys public hospital system has been fined $13,500 for his role in soliciting coveted training spots in city hospitals for students from a Caribbean medical school, the citys Conflicts of Interest Board said Tuesday.

title: A Casita in Madrid
description: Felipe Rein Acebo-Gomez spent 55 million pesetas ($375,000) renovating his home after buying it.

title: Grassley Pushes Back
description: The pushback against President Obamas overtures to Republicans is under way.

title: In Madrid, the Apartment That Came With a House
description: MADRID  Location may be the most important real estate consideration, but history is also a part of the equation, especially in a place like Madrid. There was no such thing as horizontal subdivision of real estate in Spain until 1939, said Felipe Rein Acebo-Gomez, explaining how his second-floor apartment, which he bought in Madrid in 1997, happened to include a 1,300-square-foot three-story house connected to the back of the building with a private garden.

title: What Were Reading: Steampunk, Roger Ebert and a City Called Google
description: Tuesdays roundup of interesting tidbits from around the Web, selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times:

title: Bill to Create U.S. Tourism Board
description: The number of foreign visitors to the United States in 2009 was 9 percent below 2000. A new bill that passed the Senate last week, and is expected to be signed into law, aims to reverse that trend.

title: A Non-Action Approach to Wine Making
description: American popular culture loves the man of action, but wine lovers might prefer the man of non-action. That is how Paul Draper, the chief executive and winemaker at Ridge Vineyards, characterizes his approach to wine. Ridge, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary this week, and Draper, who is marking 40 years with Ridge, are the subject of my column this week.

title: Now Nominating | Costume Designer Janet Patterson
description: Youve probably never heard of Janet Patterson, the costume designer who received her fourth Oscar nomination for Bright Star, a quiet meditation on the unconsummated love affair between Fanny Brawne and the poet John Keats. With a rsum that includes The Piano (1993), Patterson is revered by industry peers, few of whom have met her. Far from prolific, she retreats between movies for years at a time. So it was a surprise when, 13 years after my first approach to interview her, she responded to yet another e-mail entreaty by calling from her home in Sydney, Australia.

title: Iran Arrests Filmmaker Who Backed Opposition
description: Iranian authorities raided the home of a prominent filmmaker, Jaffar Panahi, early Tuesday morning and arrested him, his wife and daughter, along with 15 guests, the opposition Web site Jaras reported.

title: Beethoven That Is Robust, if a Little Strange
A Look at the Snarled Past of Armenians and Turks
description: Christopher de Bellaigues new book begins with the story of a journalistic blunder, the authors own. In 2001 Mr. de Bellaigue wrote a long essay for The New York Review of Books about Turkeys tangled history. It was a topic he thought he knew something about. At the time he was living in Istanbul and working as a foreign correspondent for The Economist.

title: Hurtling Through Beethoven, With Grace
description: Orchestral musicians often perform while sitting back comfortably in their chairs. But the members of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra were perched on the edge of their seats, bows flying and heads tossing, during their feisty performance at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening.

title: McConnell Brushes Off White House Overture
description: In a reply to President Obama, the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, on Tuesday said that last weeks heath care summit gave us an opportunity to show our constituents that there is a better way to proceed with the kind of reforms they truly want.

title: Surprise! Taylor Swift Nabs Five Nominations
description: Taylor Swift will have another opportunity to appear astounded by her awards-show largess: she has been nominated for five Academy of Country Music Awards, including entertainer of the year. The nominations, announced on Tuesday, were most generous to the Nashville group Lady Antebellum, which picked up seven nominations, including ones for album (for its self-titled 2008 release) and top vocal group, as well as single record of the year, song of the year and video for Need You Now. Miranda Lambert was nominated for six awards, as was Carrie Underwood, the academys reigning entertainer of the year, who was once again nominated in that category. Kenny Chesney picked up four nominations, as did Brad Paisley and the Zac Brown Band. The winners will be announced in Las Vegas on April 18.

title: Cables TLC Drops Miss America Pageant
description: Once one of the nations most desirable singles, Miss America is unattached again and its not immediately clear who will sweep her off her feet. On Monday the cable channel TLC became the latest broadcaster to drop the long-running Miss America Pageant, Reuters reported. In a statement, TLC said that it was happy to have been part of the modernization and revitalization of the Miss America Pageant, but was declining to renew its contract to show the event. The competition, which dates to 1921, was among the highest-rated television broadcasts in its 1960s-era heyday, but has been bounced from suitor to suitor since NBC stopped showing it after 1996. ABC ran the pageant from 1997 to 2005, then the country-music channel CMT in 2006 and 2007, before TLC picked it up in 2008. The 2010 pageant, won by Miss Virginia, Caressa Cameron, was watched by 4.5 million people in January, a record for the competition since it moved to cable.

title: Comic Book Writer Accused of Plagiarism
description: Nick Simmons, the son of the rock star Gene Simmons, sought to make a name for himself in the comic book industry as the writer and artist of Incarnate, a manga-style series from Radical Publishing. The attempt may have backfired. Last week the publisher announced plans to halt production of a collected edition of Incarnate after Internet message boards filled up with accusations that Mr. Simmons had copied layouts, dialogue and character designs from other manga series, including Bleach and Hellsing. On Monday Mr. Simmons said in a statement that the similarities were meant as an homage to artists I respect, and I definitely want to apologize to any manga fans or fellow manga artists who feel I went too far. He continued, My inspirations reflect the fact that certain fundamental imagery is common to all manga. Many readers werent buying it. Note that he doesnt acknowledge he went beyond homage to flat-out copies, wrote Johanna Draper Carlson, who reviews manga at comicsworthreading.com. (Above left, a drawing from Bleach. Right, one from Incarnate.)

title: In Return Engagement, Leno Routs Letterman
description: Let the Leno-Letterman jousting resume. Jay Lenos return to The Tonight Show on Monday was watched by about 6.6 million viewers, according to overnight Nielsen ratings, up about 25 percent from his average viewership in the first quarter of last year. David Lettermans Late Show on CBS was watched by 3.8 million, about average for his program. The Tonight Show was the No. 1 late-night offering when Mr. Leno, right, handed it over to Conan OBrien last spring. In the months that followed, the Late Show routinely beat Mr. OBriens Tonight in total viewers. In January, after NBC canceled Mr. Lenos 10 p.m. talk show and announced a plan to move him back to 11:35 p.m., Mr. OBrien left the network. Mr. Lenos Tonight Show return was heavily promoted during the Winter Olympics on NBC last month, but once the initial interest fades the real competition will begin, as NBC and CBS find out whether The Tonight Show can return to the No. 1 spot among total viewers  as if a certain redheaded comedian had never been there.

title: Crudup to Star in The Metal Children
description: The actor Billy Crudup, whose last major New York performance won him a Tony Award, for Tom Stoppards Coast of Utopia during the 2006-07 season, will star in the world premiere of Adam Rapps play The Metal Children at the Vineyard Theater in May. The play, to be directed by Mr. Rapp for the Off Broadway theater, is about a New York writer who travels to a small American town to defend one of his young-adult novels that has been banned by the school board, a confrontation that turns into a heated debate about religious beliefs and censorship. Mr. Crudup won the Tony for best featured actor in a play in 2007 for his performance as the literary critic Vissarion Belinsky in the first two parts of The Coast of Utopia. He had been nominated twice before for best actor in a play, for The Pillowman in 2005 and the revival of The Elephant Man in 2002.

title: Venus In Fur Eyes Broadway
description: The producer Robert Fox is exploring transferring the Classic Stage Companys production of Venus in Fur to a Broadway theater, Mr. Fox said on Tuesday. The new play, by David Ives, received wide critical acclaim when it opened in January, especially for one of its stars, the newcomer Nina Arianda, who plays a somewhat mysterious actress who becomes caught up in a sexual psychodrama during an audition for a director (played by Wes Bentley, of the film American Beauty). Mr. Fox, the lead producer of God of Carnage and a lead producer of the new Broadway production A Behanding in Spokane, said he had begun talking to New York theater owners about a transfer. Chief among the factors for such a move, he said, would be the availability of a very intimate house for the two-character work. He did not specify which theaters he preferred and cautioned that no deal was in place, and that the timing would largely depend on a theater becoming available. The Off Broadway run of Venus in Fur, directed by Walter Bobbie (Chicago), has been extended twice and is now scheduled to end on March 28.

title: Shopping With Colin Cowie
description: Gold tableware and home accessories that would bring glamour to any Oscar-night fte.

title: Elliott Associates Offers to Buy Novell
description: 10:08 p.m. | Updated The hedge fund Elliott Associates said Tuesday afternoon that it had made an offer to buy Novell in a deal that valued the business software company at about $2 billion.

title: From Hutch to Table
description: A seminar held in Brooklyn taught participants how to raise, slaughter and butcher rabbits; chefs demonstrated what to do with them.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Lexus CT 200h
description: Introduced on Tuesday: 2011 Lexus CT 200h

title: Having a Child to Save Another
description: Back when I was a medical reporter for The Times, Laurie Strongin and her husband, Allen Goldberg  and most of all their son Henry  became the faces I saw whenever I wrote about medical milestones. I met them when they were one of the first two families to try a new technology called preimplantation genetic diagnosis, or P.G.D., to have a baby who could donate the bone marrow that Henry, who was born with the genetic disease Fanconi anemia, needed to live.

title: That Tabletop Glamour
description: ON March 7, movie buffs everywhere will tune in to the 82nd Academy Awards ceremony, and many will hold parties that aim to bring a little of the evenings glamour into the home.

title: Singing the Romance in the Russian Soul
description: In opera the Russian mezzo-soprano Olga Borodina is a towering figure: a smoldering Carmen, a seductive Dalila and a commanding Amneris, with a magnetic presence that fills both stage and house. It was fascinating, then, to encounter another side of Ms. Borodina in the recital she presented with the pianist Dmitri Yefimov at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. Limiting herself to a patch of stage inside the pianos curve, she projected intense focus and concentration even when her material grew sentimental or impassioned.

title: A Greek Composers Japanese Inspirations
description: Whenever a composer looms large on the contemporary music scene, there is usually a choreographer lurking somewhere in the distance. In the case of Iannis Xenakis (1922-2001), the avant-garde Greek composer who was born in Romania and died in Paris, it is Luca Veggetti, an Italian who in 2008 choreographed a production of Xenakiss opera Oresteia at the Miller Theater.

title: In Iraq Election, Familiar Faces but New Coalitions
description: As leaders jockey for positions in the new government, current political alliances are not drawn as clearly along sectarian lines as they were in 2005.

title: Hedge Fund Makes $2 Billion Offer for Novell
description: Elliott Associates offered Tuesday to buy Novell, a business software maker, for $5.75 a share, according to our colleagues on the DealBook blog. But Wall Street expects the $2 billion offer to be raised  Novells shares rose as high as $6.07 in trading after the news was announced.

title: New Musicals That Strike a Somber Chord
description: The dream number from The Scottsboro Boys, the musical opening next Wednesday at the Vineyard Theater, is a nightmare: an imprisoned boy is forced to tap dance around an electric chair.

title: Tribeca Film Group Tries to Build a Distribution Brand of Its Own
description: LOS ANGELES  Entering its ninth year, the Tribeca Film Festival is set to become associated with a new venture to distribute films digitally and in theaters under the Tribeca name. It is also embarking on another initiative to make some offerings available online to the paying public at the same time that they are screening at the festival.

title: Remembering Barry Hannah
description: Twelve years ago, I talked an editor into assigning me a profile of the great novelist and short-story writer Barry Hannah, who died Monday at 67 at his home in Oxford, Miss. The pretext for the article was a flimsy one; he wasnt on the verge of publishing anything new. But like many people who have discovered Hannahs work and fallen in love with it, Id become a little obsessed with knowing more about him. If the short story, to borrow a phrase from Zola, sits at the exquisite point where poetry ends and reality begins, the best of Hannahs stories were somehow able to operate well over on the poetry side of that equation, laying bare a vision of reality that was hilarious, beautiful, heartbreaking and sometimes terrifying.

title: Police Spokesman Offers Account of Workshop
description: Last Friday, we ran a post about a workshop given for the benefit of the New York Police Department, among others, on how to deal with emotionally disturbed people, whose encounters with the police often turn injurious or worse. No one from the Police Department showed up; the events organizers said that two deputy inspectors from New York City precincts had confirmed they would attend.

title: Supreme Court Takes Up Gun Control Case
description: An unusually intense Supreme Court argument showed that the justices remain bitterly divided about the meaning and scope of the Second Amendment.

title: The Navi Capture the Online Buzz
description: Online data metrics are notoriously unreliable  do you count clicks or visits? Google searches or blog mentions?  but that doesnt stop people from using it. Nielsen Media reports that Avatar far outstrips the other best picture contenders in online buzz, which is presumably counted in the traditional way, via abacus. Its main competition, The Hurt Locker, comes in second and  apologies to Harvey Weinstein  Inglourious Basterds ranks dead last.

title: Into the Risk Pool
description: In a critique of high-risk pooling, the preferred conservative approach to insuring the uninsurable, Jonathan Cohn argues that the existing network of state-based pools feature brutal waiting times to enroll, and tend to be outrageously expensive once youre in them. Then he anticipates objections to his argument:

title: Leaving Money on the Table With the I.R.S.
description: Weve written before about all the tax deadbeats out there who owe taxes and dont pay them. But what about the people who are owed tax money from the government and never claim it?

title: Why (in Part) People Love Buenos Aires
description: I was there for two days, only  my first trip. While it was sort of obvious which parillas  essentially restaurants specializing in grilled meats  not to go to, it was more difficult to determine which ones were going to be worth a trip.

title: Facing the Exhaustion of Unemployment Benefits
description: While senators in Washington continued to debate on Tuesday whether to provide more financial help to the unemployed, thousands of New Yorkers were finding ways to cope with the loss of their weekly jobless benefits.

title: Dubai Police Chief Says He Knows an Israeli When He Sees One
description: Dubais police chief, Gen. Dahi Khalfan al-Tamim, said on Monday that the famously open city may soon block people who look or sound like Israelis from entering, no matter what passport they produce.

title: Brown Scores Three Committee Seats
description: Scott P. Brown, the newest member of the Senate, has received his committee assignments, and there seems to be a theme: The Massachusetts Republican has been given a slot on the Armed Services, the Homeland Security and the Veterans Affairs panels.

title: What Were Reading
Scorecard | Dolce & Gabbana Wins!
description: Remember that heritage buzzword Scorecard reported on from the Milan mens-wear shows? Its baaack! Dolce & Gabbana closed out the womens fashion week with a sentimental paean to sensuality and Sicilian seamstresses that left certain members of the fash pack quite literally in tears. Meanwhile, over at Emilio Pucci, Peter Dundass super-sexy showing included the founders signature prints numbering in the single digits. Bet you can guess how that one went down.

title: Conjuring Up Elders, With Their Secrets and Surprises Intact
description: Never underestimate the substance, the complexity, of a long life. Forgotten, Pat Kinevanes one-man show at the Irish Arts Center, gracefully illustrates that point with the mimickry, invention and formidable stamina of this actor-playwright, a native of County Cork. A portrait of four elderly people, all in their 80s or older and living in different nursing homes, the play offers recollections and re-enactments, and eventually reveals a latticework of shared destinies.

title: The Road Ahead (Its Bumpy)
description: Wondering exactly when the health care debate might reach some sort of resolution? Keep in mind that there are some very basic steps that need to be taken in the days ahead if Democrats, as expected, decide to push forward on their own.

title: Viacom Will Take Daily Show, Colbert Off Hulu
description: Unable to make the digital media dollars add up to their liking, Viacom willremove The Daily Show with Jon Stewart, The Colbert Report and other Comedy Central television shows from Hulu next week.

title: Kanye West Gets a Few (Thousand) Things Off His Chest
description: At his official Web site, kanyewest.com, Kanye West has posted a statement of purpose titled Creativity, in which he mourns the death of the designer Alexander McQueen and seems to address some of his own recent history (though your interpretation may vary), writing, in part:

title: Wall St. Bailout Eases New Yorks Downturn
description: In fall 2008, after Lehman Brothers collapsed and other Wall Street firms seemed ready to topple, New York appeared to be headed for a brutal recession, one that would rival the worst downturns in the citys history.

title: Iraqs Top Cleric Refuses to Influence Elections
description: NAJAF, Iraq  No one man in Iraq has more power to change the outcome of the countrys elections on Sunday than a frail cleric who lives in an ascetic house in this holy city. And yet he has refused to wield it, shaping the relationship between Islam and the state at a crucial juncture in Iraqs history.

title: An Indie Takes On Animations Big Boys
description: Even in a year with a lot of unlikely Oscar nominees, Tomm Moore is a reach. Mr. Moore, the director of the animated film The Secret of Kells, grew up and still lives in Kilkenny, Ireland, a one-cathedral town of a few thousand people about an hour and a half south of Dublin and 5,160 miles from Hollywood.

title: Postal Service Revives Cutback Plans
description: Faced with growing deficits and rapid erosion of its business, the United States Postal Service on Tuesday reintroduced proposals to cut costs, close post offices, raise rates and eliminate some services, most notably Saturday mail delivery.

title: A Park for Mr. Green
description: While the name Robert Moses rings synonymous, for better or worse, with the shaping of modern-day New York City, Moses was hardly the metropoliss first master planner.

title: If He Can, Above All, to His Own Self Be True
description: What if Shakespeare had never written Macbeth?

title: Apple Sues Nexus One Maker HTC
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple has relied on slick applications, and even slicker advertisements, to promote the iPhone and maintain its advantage over rivals like Google in the battle to rule the next generation of smartphones.

title: Gov. Patersons Oath
description: Gov. David Paterson gave New Yorkers his personal oath on Friday that he had never abused his office. It now seems clear that, at the very least, he tried to arrange a ham-handed cover-up to avert a scandal involving a top aide. There are also disturbing signs that he or other state officials may have unlawfully intervened to protect the aide from accusations of domestic violence.

title: Fuel Taxes Must Rise, Harvard Researchers Say
description: To meet the Obama administrations targets for cutting greenhouse gas emissions, some researchers say, Americans may have to experience a sobering reality: gas at $7 a gallon.

title: WWS 543, March 3
description: Readings. (doc)

title: When the Line for Dinner Is a Mile Long
description: NewarkOnce upon a time, any self-respecting aerialist or big-top roustabout ordered pie in the Pie Car. Of course. And heaps of fried chicken. Or beef stew with glorious gobbets of fat, swimming with hefty carrots and an armada of bobbing potatoes. Not to mention buckets of strong, steaming java.

title: Haunted by What Dad Did in the War
description: The sins of the father weigh heavily and sometimes scarcely at all in the documentary Harlan  In the Shadow of Jew Sss. The Harlan of the title is Veit Harlan, a filmmaker who thrived under National Socialism and directed Jew Sss (Jud Sss, 1940), one of the Nazis most notorious anti-Semitic works. He was the only director of the Nazi era to be tried after the war for crimes against humanity. Twice found not guilty, he directed nine more movies in the 1950s before dying in 1964 in a Capri villa with his wife and children by his side. Hes buried in a lovely cemetery with a smashing view of the Mediterranean.

title: Spoonfuls of Southern Cooking for Obama
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  Two days after discovering that his cholesterol had climbed 42 points in less than three years, President Obama sat down for a late lunch here today.

title: Mudslides Bury Villages in Eastern Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Torrential rain in eastern Uganda touched off a series of mudslides late Monday night, killing at least 83 people and causing devastation in villages, state emergency officials said.

title: Hurt Locker Producer is Barred From Oscar Ceremony
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hurt Locker, a presumed front-runner in the Oscar race since picking up a string of honors from critics and the Hollywood guilds, suffered a last-minute embarrassment on Tuesday as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences disciplined one of the films producers for violating the groups campaign rules.

title: Pfizer Said to Set Sights on German Drug Maker
description: Pfizer is reportedly gearing up this week to bid 3 billion euro ($4.08 billion) for Ratiopharm, a generic drug maker based in Germany, according to Bloomberg News, which cited two unidentified people with knowledge of the talks. The move would pit Pfizer, the worlds largest drug maker, against Teva Pharmaceuticals Industries of Israel, the worlds largest generic drug maker, and Actvis of Iceland, another big generic drug maker, both of which are said to be interested in Ratiopharm, according to Bloomberg.

title: What Apple vs. HTC Could Mean
description: The lawsuit that Apple filed on Tuesday against HTC, the mobile handset maker, opens up a lot of questions about the future of Android phones like the Nexus One and the cellphone market in general.

title: Is He Mellower? Ask the Guy Missing a Hand
description: FOUR years ago Martin McDonagh, the celebrated playwright whose flamboyantly gruesome dark comedies have brought smashed skulls, child murder and other carefully calibrated outrages to Broadway, shocked the theater world in an entirely new way.

title: TiVo to Offer Boxes That Go Beyond the Recorder
description: SAN FRANCISCO  TiVo, the Silicon Valley pioneer of digital video recorders, is once again trying to get consumers to pay for another set-top box that combines traditional television programming with a vast array of content from the Web.

title: For Supermodel With a Temper, No Charges
description: The supermodel Naomi Campbell, who has twice pleaded guilty to assault charges in the last three years, has been accused of letting her temper get the best of her once again.

title: With Turturro, Italy Knows No Bounds
description: Milan

title: A Yahoo Birthday Party With Carol Bartz
description: As part of its 15th birthday celebrations, Yahoo on Tuesday invited a group of reporters for a lunch with Carol Bartz, the companys chief executive. There were plenty of delicious cupcakes but no party hats. And as Ms. Bartzs public relations handlers warned ahead of the event, there was no news.

title: The Band Helped Writers Find Their Beat
description: MART CROWLEYs play The Boys in the Band opened off Broadway on April 14, 1968, and instantly made theater history: It was, as Clive Barnes wrote in his review in The New York Times, by far the frankest treatment of homosexuality I have ever seen on the stage.

title: States Rights vs. Gun Rights
description: The Supreme Court heard oral arguments on a major gun control case on Tuesday. The issue in the case, McDonald v. City of Chicago, is whether the Second Amendment protects the individual right to keep and bear arms against state and city gun laws.
