The case is considered a sequel to a Supreme Court decision in 2008, District of Columbia v. Heller, which limited what the federal government can do in restricting gun rights.

title: The Screens Now Setting Many a Stage
description: AT The Orphans Home Cycle titles and dates move across the screen like Star Wars credits taking a detour. At Fela! newspaper headlines like Fela Declares Self Black Power Man pop up on a screen. Even at Safe Home, a low-budget, bare-bones production that opened Off Broadway this year, scene changes were announced with 1950s newsreel footage.

title: USF1 Dream Over?
description: There have been rumors for weeks that the USF1 team would not make it to the grid in Bahrain. In more recent days there have been several more rumors that the operation is closing down. Now, Autosport.com is reporting that the team has indeed ceased to work on the 2010 car, and the employees are on unpaid leave. Keep posted.

title: Telling 'The Secret'
description: A look inside the Oscar-nominated film "The Secret of Kells."

title: Disney and Cablevision Take ABC Fight Public
description: The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision each told viewers to take a side  their side  on Tuesday in a brewing battle over distribution payments that are increasingly seen as vital for television broadcasters.

title: The Netherlands 2,  United States 1
description: Wednesday, 5:17 p.m. ET |Netherlands 2, United States 1

title: Before the Glow Fades: Figure Skating as Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Strive to Guard Dubais Image After Killing
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  The people who killed a Hamas operative in an airport hotel here in January seem to have thought they could pass it off as a natural death, or perhaps just another of this regions macabre mysteries. They injected him with a muscle relaxant, suffocated him and then smoothed away any signs of struggle, reattaching the hotel door chain as they left the room, investigators say.

title: Marion Barry Disciplined by Washington Council
description: WASHINGTON  In another twist in a long and troubled career, Councilman Marion S. Barry Jr., the former mayor of Washington, was unanimously censured and stripped of his committee chairmanship by his Council colleagues on Tuesday in response to corruption accusations.

title: Yes, Luis Castillo Is Still With the Mets
description: Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: Selling Breast-Feeding Bras and Emotional Support
description: BRAVADO DESIGNS specializes in breast-feeding bras, which feature cups that unfasten singly and stretchable fabrics that accommodate size fluctuations during pregnancy and nursing. But when it comes to marketing, the bra company emphasizes another type of support: emotional.

title: Mets Obstructed Views in Plain Sight
description: Mets fans had a tough time feeling comfortable in Citi Field last season, mainly because the team performed so poorly. But some fans were also irked that they could not see parts of the field from their seats, especially in left field.

title: Milk in a Can Goes Glam
description: SWEETENED condensed milk is everywhere. Theres probably a can or two lurking in your cabinets. It is the key to Key lime pie; it brings the sweet to Vietnamese coffee; it went to Rio for Carnaval last month in the shape of brigadeiros, bite-size balls of milk fudge that are a Brazilian national treat.

title: A Plan to Talk About Jobs, Elbowed Aside by Health Care
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  By the time March arrived, President Obama was supposed to be entering his third month of the year talking about three things: jobs, jobs, jobs.

title: Abuse Case Rouses Indias Middle Class
description: PANCHKULA, India  She was a gifted 14-year-old tennis player who idolized Steffi Graf and hoped to turn pro. He was a senior police official and president of the state lawn tennis club. He lured her to his office with a promise of special coaching that could make her tennis dreams come true, then groped her.

title: Blue Bottle Coffee in Brooklyn Raises Brewing to a Science
description: IT might come as a surprise to most espresso drinkers, but some of the most obsessive figures in coffee take their cues not just from Italy, but from Japan.

title: The Next Battles for Marja
description: Charlottesville, Va.

title: Israel: Jerusalem Mayor Delays Demolition Plan
description: The mayor of Jerusalem agreed Tuesday to delay a plan to demolish some Palestinian homes to build a complex that would provide new apartments for the residents. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had asked the mayor, Nir Barkat, to allow more time to reach an understanding with the residents of the neighborhood, in East Jerusalem just outside the Old City walls. Mr. Barkat has been negotiating with the Palestinians there, who are living in housing that is illegal under Israeli law. The residents have rejected the plan, fearing that once homes are destroyed, Jewish settlers will be moved in. There are Jewish settler projects on either side of the area.

title: France: Widow of a Rwandan Leader Is Arrested
description: The French police on Tuesday arrested the widow of Juvenal Habyarimana, the Rwandan president whose plane was shot down in 1994, setting off the massacre of 800,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu. Agathe Habyarimana, left, has lived in France since then. She was refused political asylum in 2004 and lost her appeal in October because French judges had found she was a central figure in the Hutu government that orchestrated the genocide. Her arrest came a week after President Nicolas Sarkozy visited Rwanda on a fence-mending trip where he admitted that France had made errors of judgment before the genocide. It was unclear if Mrs. Habyarimana would be extradited because France has refused to hand over other suspects for fear they would not receive fair trial.

title: U.S. Court Rejects Sexual Discrimination Lawsuit
description: A federal appeals court in Manhattan rejected a sexual discrimination lawsuit brought by two United Nations staff members against the organization and three top former officials. The court upheld a lower court ruling that American courts had no jurisdiction in the case because the defendants had diplomatic immunity. Cynthia Brzak, an American, and Nasr Ishak, who has dual French and Egyptian citizenship, worked for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva. They sued on the grounds that their careers suffered after Ms. Brzak accused Ruud Lubbers, the former head of the refugee organization, of sexual harassment, with Mr. Ishak encouraging her to speak out. Mr. Lubbers resigned in 2005 over the allegations, which he denied. The suit named Mr. Lubbers and his former deputy, Wendy Chamberlin, as well as former Secretary General Kofi Annan.

title: 2010 Iraqi Elections: Expats in Jordan
description: Iraqi refugees in Jordan are preparing to take part in the parliamentary elections, hoping this vote will bring a change to their country and allow them to go back home.

title: Young Talent Promises to Rekindle Mets-Braves Rivalry
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Chipper Jones is on the back end of his career, but the Atlanta Braves are getting close to introducing the next edition, a ferocious left-handed hitter who could torment the Mets for the next decade. His name is Jason Heyward, a 20-year-old slugging right fielder who has drawn comparisons to Darryl Strawberry and Fred McGriff.

title: Hideki Matsui Quietly Went to Angels His Way
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Hideki Matsui wrapped his fingers around his lips, making a megaphone with his left hand. In a deep voice that needed no translation, he bellowed a sound he did not hear often in seven seasons with the Yankees: Booooooo!

title: Yankees Mix Some Fun With the Fundamentals
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Repeating as World Series champion is one thing. But far be it for Joe Girardi to repeat the same activity in the Yankees team-building outing Tuesday.

title: Afghanistan Aims to Ban Live Coverage of Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Minute-by-minute news coverage by Afghan television stations of two recent suicide attacks proved an embarrassment for the government, showing that it could not stop militants from penetrating even heavily guarded areas of the capital.

title: The Waiting Is the Hardest Part
description: In the digital age, despair travels many avenues  through airwaves, tweets and blogs. Every electronic artery was clogged Tuesday morning with Knick fans wailing over their teams humiliating 124-93 loss to the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Hank Rosenstein, Player in First N.B.A. Game, Dies at 89
description: Hank Rosenstein, who played in what is considered the National Basketball Associations first game, in 1946, as an original member of the New York Knicks, died on Saturday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he lived. He was 89.

title: Players Bid to Keep Salary Cap Is Rejected
description: The N.F.L. Players Association made a public plea Tuesday for last-ditch negotiations with team owners and renewed a proposal for a one-year extension of the current salary cap, which the owners had rejected already. The union also offered to negotiate a longer extension if the N.F.L. guarantees that the cap will not go down. The N.F.L. immediately rejected the offer.

title: Woods Is Spotted Practicing in Florida
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Tiger Woods, who was reported to have left a Scottsdale, Ariz., rehabilitation facility over the weekend, practiced Monday on the range at Isleworth Country Club, the golf course in the gated community outside Orlando where he lives.

title: Seeing the Investor Value in Being Green
description: Constructing or renovating a building to make it environmentally sustainable can be a daunting task for any owner, but Jamestown Properties, a German commercial real estate investment company, has decided it will go green in nearly its entire $4 billion portfolio of buildings, all located in the United States.

title: Testaccio Ristorante
description: 47-30 Vernon Boulevard (near Jackson Avenue), Long Island City, Queens; (718) 937-2900, testacciony.com.

title: Bread and Butter
description: 46 Henry Street (Cranberry Street), Brooklyn Heights; (718) 858-9605.

title:
Under Fire, Rangel
Appears to Be Losing Grip of Committee
description: WASHINGTON  Caught in a swirl of ethics inquiries, Representative Charles B. Rangel, the dean of the New York Congressional delegation, appeared to be losing his grip on his powerful post as chairman of the tax-policy-writing Ways and Means Committee on Tuesday as Republicans planned to force a vote to remove him from his position.

title: Home Fires: The War Movie You Dont Want to See
description: This is the second in a five-part series, Retelling the War, in which veterans discuss how books, movies and other tales of combat shaped their perceptions of themselves and of war.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: Devils Parise Puts Medal Away and Nose Back to Grindstone
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  When Zach Parise took his leap into the corner boards to celebrate his goal with 24.4 seconds left that would send the gold medal game between the United States and Canada into overtime, it might have been the moment he took one of the greatest leaps an American hockey player can make  into the countrys sporting consciousness.

title: Quake Finds Tsunami Forecasts Still Limited
description: A wider network of buoys and better computer models gave forecasters in Hawaii on Saturday a much better picture of the approaching tsunami than they would have had in the past, but they admit that their models were not refined enough to declare whether a full-scale evacuation was really needed.

title: Dining Calendar
description: To Chase the Chill

title: A Word From the Wise
description: I was traveling via Los Angeles International Airport  LAX  last week. Walking through its faded, cramped domestic terminal, I got the feeling of a place that once thought of itself as modern but has had one too many face-lifts and simply cant hide the wrinkles anymore. In some ways, LAX is us. We are the United States of Deferred Maintenance. China is the Peoples Republic of Deferred Gratification. They save, invest and build. We spend, borrow and patch.

title: In Tracking Recovery, Jagged Lines
description: Could the economy be at risk of a double dip?

title: Scientists Taking Steps to Defend Work on Climate
description: WASHINGTON  For months, climate scientists have taken a vicious beating in the media and on the Internet, accused of hiding data, covering up errors and suppressing alternate views. Their response until now has been largely to assert the legitimacy of the vast body of climate science and to mock their critics as cranks and know-nothings.

title: Viacom and Hulu Part Ways
description: In the first major fracture between television show owners and the wildly popular Hulu.com, Viacom will remove The Daily Show With Jon Stewart, The Colbert Report and other Comedy Central programs from the video site next week.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament Goes Online, Clip by Clip
description: Even before Warner Wolf took us to the videotape, highlights have served fans as currency of their passion. Did you see that home run? That dunk? That overtime goal? That buzzer beater?

title: A Victory for a Fan Used to Defeat
description: I sure hope hockey fans in Pittsburgh feel lucky. I really do. Yeah, the Olympics were great, and like all Canadians, I was pumped that we won the gold medal. But now its back to reality, a reality where I find myself envying hockey fans in places like Pittsburgh and Tampa Bay.

title: Evolution by the Grassroots
description: Imagine the Earth without grasses.

title: Still With Obama, but Worried
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The nations union leaders said on Tuesday that they were appalled at remarks made by President Obama condoning the mass firing of teachers at a Rhode Island high school.

title: Loosey Goosey Saudi
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia

title: Whats a Goal Between Friends?
description: PITTSBURGH  For Pittsburgh Penguins fans, all is forgiven.

title: Possibility of Senate Run, Nurtured and Abandoned
description: A few weeks ago, Harold E. Ford Jr. had a telephone conversation with his friend Doug Band, the powerful counselor to former President Bill Clinton.

title: Choptank
description: THE Choptank River runs like a paper cut down the thumb of Marylands Eastern Shore, across the Chesapeake Bay from Baltimore, out of Kent County, Delaware, toward points south and west. There is marshland along parts of it, where ducks land in the fall and winter, where crabs once burrowed and oyster spat took hold. Rockfish still cruise its brackish waters, down to the salt. There is a lot of farmland along its shores.

title: Considering Choptank
description: My restaurant review this week is of Choptank, a restaurant in Greenwich Village that takes its cues from the Chesapeake Bay, Baltimore and the Eastern Shore of Maryland. It is vaguely southern, vaguely devoted to seafood, and casual in a college-educated sort of way. Its on Bleecker Street, off Seventh Avenue South.

title: Rustic Kale Soup
description: AT The Modern restaurant at the Museum of Modern Art, Gabriel Kreuther, the executive chef, makes a cranberry bean and kale soup, dotted with crushed cherry tomatoes, that was inspired by a rustic soup he had as a child, growing up on a farm in Niederschaeffolsheim, in the Alsace region of France.

title: Van Leeuwen Artisan Ice Cream Opens in Brooklyn
description: After dispensing ice cream churned from Hudson Valley milk and cream from their five butter-yellow trucks since 2008, Ben Van Leeuwen, his wife, Laura ONeill, and his brother, Peter Van Leeuwen, have settled down in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

title: Pain dAvignon Opens Retail Store
description: After 10 years of selling bread to restaurants and shops, Pain dAvignon has opened a retail outlet in the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side. You wont need a waiter at this tiny shop, where you are surrounded by nearly 36 different kinds of breads, rolls and pastries like croissants.

title: Onetime Rising Star Is in Retreat
description: Early one rainy morning in January 1988, a convoy of cars pulled onto the West Side Highway, slowed down and then stopped in all three lanes. Seven people got out. Rush-hour traffic halted. At the same time, just off the highway about 100 men and women blocked Riverside Drive. They wore gas masks and carried placards protesting the stench from a new sewage treatment plant that routinely drifted across West Harlem. In due course, the police arrived, and the seven people on the highway were arrested. Among them was a state senator, David A. Paterson, then 33 and serving his first full term in elected office.

title: Surreal Day in Court as Fire Delays a Rappers Sentencing
description: This may not be quite the way Lil Wayne would describe it, but all heck broke loose at the Manhattan Criminal Court building Tuesday morning.

title: Gridlock May Be Ending on Consumer Protection
description: WASHINGTON  A proposal to give the Federal Reserve the primary responsibility for protecting consumers from abusive and deceptive financial products emerged on Tuesday as a potential breakthrough after months of partisan gridlock in the Senate over the terms of a broad overhaul of financial regulations.

title: 3 U.S. Judges Testify in a Death Threat Case
description: His words barely filling the room, the witness timidly held his hand aloft to be sworn in.

title: Dont Tell the Kids
description: RABBITS are supposed to be easy to kill. The French dispatch them with a sharp knife to the throat. A farmer in upstate New York swears that a swift smack with the side of the hand works. Others prefer a quick twist of the neck.

title: Tuscan Rabbit Rag
description: Adapted from Samin Nosrat

title: Q & A on Rabbits and Backyard Farming
description: This week Novella Carpenter, who is featured in Kim Seversons article about eating rabbit, will be taking readers questions about rabbits and backyard farming. Please post your questions below.

title: The State of the Job Market  and of Inventories
description: For a Congressional hearing last month, Lawrence Katz prepared a nice overview of the labor market. But the hearing was never held, because of the blizzard. In my column this week, I mentioned a couple of numbers from Mr. Katzs analysis. You can read the testimony in its entirety here:

title: The Outtakes From the Rabbit Cover
description: Tiina Loite is the photo editor for the Dining section of The New York Times. Here she discusses the photography for this weeks cover story about killing and eating rabbits.

title: The Sea, Lifeblood of Chilean Towns, Turns Deadly
description: TUBUL, Chile  The sea gave this small fishing village life. But last weekend, stirred by the powerful earthquake that rocked Chile, it savagely turned on Tubul, swallowing houses and boats and sending most of its 3,000 residents scurrying for the hills.

title: Mimis Hummus Opens a Market Next Door
description: Mimis Hummus is one of the restaurants that have given Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, some allure for diners. Now its owner, Avi Shuker, has added something for shoppers, a beautifully curated little food shop next door. The store, all done in pale wood, is crammed floor to ceiling with products and ingredients, many destined for the Middle Eastern table.

title: 2 Top Guatemalan Police Officials Are Arrested on Drug Charges
description: MEXICO CITY  Guatemalan authorities arrested the countrys national police chief and the head of its antinarcotics unit on Tuesday on drug charges.

title: U.N. Is Faulted as Lacking Coordination of Aid and Security in Haiti
description: UNITED NATIONS  Humanitarian efforts by the United Nations in Haiti have lacked sufficient coordination with local organizations in delivering aid and establishing security, according to an independent assessment released on Tuesday.

title: Indicted Ex-Leader of Bosnian Serbs Calls Atrocities Myths
description: PARIS  Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb wartime leader, on Tuesday denied charges that his troops had committed large-scale atrocities during the Bosnian war, brushing aside the accusations as myths fabricated by his enemies.

title: Roman Flavor in Queens
description: "Midpriced Italian restaurants can be as predictable as cupcake places," writes Julia Moskin, "the same five flavors show up all over town. When one breaks the mold, like Testaccio, which opened in December with a Roman menu, we go." Testaccio, in Long Island City, is run by chef Ivan Beacco. The Roman inspiration is evident in the "braised oxtail, flower-like fried artichokes, and soft gnocchi with roasted exteriors, just glazed with tomato and gilded with cheese." Skip the "over-topped pizza" and instead go for the dishes that "get everything right  the smokiness of guanciale in bucatini all'amatriciana, a dressing's vinegary contrast to creamy-firm white beans and chunks of roast pork, an overlay of bottarga on spaghetti with garlic and clams." The location in Queens may seem like a far cry from Italy, but, Ms. Moskin adds, this stretch of Vernon Boulevard is "dark at night, but dotted with bright restaurants  like the original Testaccio, an unfancy neighborhood on the edge of Rome."

title: Happy Birthday, Chopin
description: How do you pay tribute to one of the greatest composers of all time on the occasion of his 200th birthday? A weeklong series of performances featuring 200 hours of the composer's work performed on five pianos sounds just about right. This week the Winter Garden at the World Financial Center is presenting just such a tribute to Frederic Chopin, who would have celebrated the big 2-0-0 on March 1. The festival, which runs daily beginning at 9 a.m., through Friday, includes an eclectic mix of performers, with Eduardus Halim, Kimball Gallagher, Vassily Primakov, Jeffrey Swann and tonight's featured artist, Christopher O'Riley. The performance by Mr. O'Riley, the host of "From the Top" on NPR, will begin at 7 p.m.

title: Alls Fair
description: The 2010 Armory Show, which opens on Thursday, promises to be one of the biggest art events of the year, literally. Last year's fine art fair at Piers 92 and 94 drew 56,000 visitors and over 200 dealers. Tonight MoMA is hosting a kick-off event at the museum to celebrate this year's exhibition. The party, which begins at 8:30 p.m., features a live performance by The Walkmen. The New York indie band, which, Ben Sisario writes, plays "exquisitely articulated songs of exhaustion and disaffection," will perform music off its most recent album in the Agnes Gund Garden Lobby. Adding to the mix will be the D.J. Justin Miller and the experimental band Human Rights, featuring members of Beirut, Psychic Ills, No Regular Play, and Volcano the Bear. Tickets for the party, which is also a benefit, start at $100. A shuttle bus will be available to transport guests from the Armory show at Piers 92 and 94 to MoMA.

title: GMAC Chief Gets $1.2 Million in Pay for 45 Days Work
description: GMAC, the auto and home lender, has not reported a profit since 2008. But it gave its chief executive, Michael A. Carpenter, a pay package rivaling that of Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief of Goldman Sachs, the nations most profitable securities company.

title: Calculating Poverty in New York: More by City Standard, and Less by Federal One
description: The number of poor people in New York rose by about 300,000, according to a new measure of poverty by the city that takes into account expenses like housing, medical costs and child care that the federal government does not include in its formulation.

title: Eight the Hard Way
description: As some commenters have noted, there are a couple of bugs in the Java applet (Play Against the Clock) version of this puzzle. The Across Lite file is correct. Sorry for the inconvenience.

title: Milan Fashion Week
description: Cathy Horyn's critique of the fall 2010 collections from Milan.

title: Top Political Adviser Leaving Bloomberg the Mayor for Bloomberg the Firm
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs top political adviser is leaving City Hall after guiding the mayor to his first two electoral victories, leading Mr. Bloombergs aborted bid for the presidency in 2008 and promoting, with varying success, the mayors education, transportation, budget and environmental agenda.

title: Ex-Official of Public Hospitals Is Fined in Bid to Aid School
description: A former board member of New York Citys public hospital system has been fined $13,500 for his role in soliciting coveted training spots in city hospitals for students from a Caribbean medical school, the citys Conflicts of Interest Board said Tuesday.

title: Producer of The Hurt Locker Barred From Oscars for Message to Voters
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hurt Locker, a presumed front-runner in the Oscar race since picking up a string of honors from critics and the Hollywood guilds, suffered a last-minute embarrassment on Tuesday as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences disciplined one of the films producers for violating the groups campaign rules.

title: Keeping Hope That a Voice Can Reverse Transit Cuts
description: The proposed cuts to New York Citys bus and subway service, considered the most severe in a generation, are entering the court of public opinion this week with a set of hearings being held by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is staring at a budget shortfall of nearly $800 million.

title: In Danbury, Hospital Patient Shoots Nurse
description: An 85-year-old man being treated at a hospital in Danbury, Conn., pulled out a gun in the cardiac care unit on Tuesday and opened fire, wounding a nurse before being tackled by hospital workers, the police said.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 2, 2010

title: Slumbering Pittsburgh Neighborhood Reawakens
description: PITTSBURGH  In the 1950s, the East Liberty neighborhood five miles east of downtown was Pennsylvanias third-largest shopping district, behind Center City Philadelphia and downtown Pittsburgh, with more than 500 local businesses and a population of 14,000.

title: Scholars School Reform U-Turn Shakes Up Debate
description: Diane Ravitch, the education historian who built her intellectual reputation battling progressive educators and served in the first Bush administrations Education Department, is in the final stages of an astonishing, slow-motion about-face on almost every stand she once took on American schooling.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about the challenges faced by Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, as she seeks re-election, misstated the number of terms Ms. Boxer has served in the Senate. She is in her third term, not her second.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Feb. 20 with the continuation of an article about the F.B.I.s closing of its investigation into the mailing of anthrax in 2001 misidentified one of the four nucleotides present in DNA sequences that are part of what the F.B.I. contends is a code in notes mailed with the anthrax. The letter "A" represents adenine, according to the F.B.I., not guanine. A corrected version of the chart can be found at nytimes.com/national.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about concerns that digital billboards may be a distraction to drivers described incorrectly the billboards shown. While the billboard at the far right was digital, the others were conventional billboards; the photograph did not show a succession of digital billboards.

title: Interference Seen in Blackwater Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  An official at the United States Embassy in Iraq has told federal prosecutors that he believes that State Department officials sought to block any serious investigation of the 2007 shooting episode in which Blackwater Worldwide security guards were accused of murdering 17 Iraqi civilians, according to court testimony made public on Tuesday.

title: A Vote for Peace
description: Northern Ireland has another major hurdle to cross on the long road to lasting peace. On Tuesday, the Belfast Assembly, the provinces governing body, is to vote on whether to approve the formal transfer of police and justice powers from London.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Canadas gold medal victory over the United States on Sunday in mens hockey at the Vancouver Games described the Miracle on Ice incorrectly. The United States stunning victory over the Soviet Union at the Lake Placid Games in 1980 came in a medal-round game, not in the semifinals.

title: Bad Science and Bad Policy
description: The federal law that mandates harsher prison terms for people arrested with crack cocaine than for those caught with cocaine powder is scientifically and morally indefensible. Bills to end the disparity are pending in both the House and Senate. Democrats who worry about being pegged as soft on crime will have to find their backbones and push the legislation through.

title: Fighting Chance
description: Hemmed in by residential development and the nations demand for energy, the number of sage grouse has dropped from 16 million to a few hundred thousand scattered across 11 Western states. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service is expected to decide soon whether to place the bird on the endangered species list.

title: Real Competition in Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Soap Opera
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fall of an Empire
description: To the Editor:

title: A Child in America
description: To the Editor:

title: The Water Polluters
description: To the Editor:

title: H.I.V., AIDS and Gay Mens Stories
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Tuesday with an article anticipating Sidney Crosbys first N.H.L. game for the Pittsburgh Penguins since he scored the decisive goal for Canada in its Olympic gold medal victory on Sunday misstated, in some copies, when the photograph was taken. The photograph, which showed Crosby playing against Brooks Orpik of the United States, who is also Crosbys Penguins teammate, was taken when the teams played on Feb. 21, not in the gold medal game.

title: Corrections
description: A dance column on Monday about New York City Ballets winter season referred incorrectly to the commission of the John Adams work Nave and Sentimental Music, which provides the score for the Peter Martins ballet of the same title. It was commissioned in the late 1990s by the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the Ensemble Modern Orchestra, the Vancouver Symphony and the Sydney Symphony. It was not commissioned by City Ballet.

title: Graduates Fault Advice of Guidance Counselors
description: Most people who graduated from high school in the last dozen years believe that their guidance counselors provided little meaningful advice about college or careers, a new study has found. And many said the best advice on their futures came from teachers.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Tuesday with an article about the Nazi propaganda film Jew Sss, whose director, Veit Harlan, is the subject of the documentary Harlan  In the Shadow of Jew Sss, was published in error. It showed the documentarys director of photography, Ludolph Weyer, not the director, Felix Moeller. The article also misspelled the name of the college in Minnesota where Linda Schulte-Sasse, who commented on Harlan, is a professor. It is Macalester College, not Macalaster.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Feb. 12 with a report in the Arts, Briefly column about the Vail International Dance Festival, where Larry Keigwin will be the artist in residence, carried an erroneous credit. The picture, of Mr. Keigwin, was by Tom Caravaglia.

title: Britain Grapples With Debt of Greek Proportions
description: LONDON  As Greeces debt troubles batter the euro, Britain has done its utmost to stay above the fray.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Ernst Beyeler, a leading dealer of modern art, misstated the name of the steel magnate and art collector from whom he acquired artworks by Klee, Giacometti and others. It was G. David Thompson, not David G. Thompson.

title: Survey Finds Few Have Fond Memories of Their High School Guidance Counselors
description: A survey being released Wednesday by Public Agenda, a nonprofit research organization, seems sure to provoke strong emotions among high school guidance counselors and students, to say nothing of high school graduates and their parents.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about David Soyer, the founding cellist of the Guarneri String Quartet, misstated the given name of the pianist who helped found the chamber music festival at Marlboro College in Vermont, at which Mr. Soyer performed regularly. He was Rudolf Serkin, not Rudolph.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Sunday about President Obamas pending decisions on nuclear weapons policy incorrectly said that nuclear posture reviews are issued every four years. Since the end of the cold war, they have been done in 1994 and 2002.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Does Haitis Earthquake Hurt Cambodia?
description: The silver lining to a tragedy like the Haiti earthquake is that it gets Americans focused on that countrys problems and reaching into their pockets to try to help. We may ignore Haitis day-to-day needs, but after the earthquake the outpouring truly was magnificent.

title: Snow Boots to Sockless, Briefly
description: IN the depths of a New York City winter, its easy to forget what tropical warmth really feels like  that close, comforting pressure on your bare skin, the humid aroma of vegetal growth and decay, the way vistas both urban and pastoral seem to shimmer, sigh and relax in the heat. You can remember these things, sure, but they seem abstract  faded dreams from another life.

title: Yes for Texas Governor Is No to Washington
description: HOUSTON  Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison had all the advantages a year ago when she laid her plans to run for governor: a high popularity rating, a party shaken by President Obamas victory, a big bankroll and, most important, the backing of influential Republicans, who felt the incumbent governor, Rick Perry, was too divisive and too conservative.

title: Catching Up With Matsui
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Johnny Damon asked last week at Tigers camp if it were true that Derek Jeter was getting married. I said I had no idea. Maybe, Damon joked, Jeter would show up with a drawing of his wife on a sketch pad.

title: Zuckerman Decides Not to Run Against Gillibrand for Senate
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the real estate and media tycoon, has decided not to run for Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrands seat this year, he said in an interview Tuesday night.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 995 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

title: California: White Hood Prompts Inquiry on San Diego Campus
description: The police at the University of California, San Diego, are investigating the discovery Monday night of what appeared to be a Ku Klux Klan-style hood on a statue outside the main campus library. The hood, crudely fashioned from a pillowcase, a university statement said, was found along with a rose placed in the statues fingers. The campus has been shaken by racial incidents in the past two weeks that have led to student protests and promises by administrators to improve the racial climate at the campus and the nine others in the system.

title: CF Returns to Terra Fray
description: The battles among fertilizer companies have been rejoined. CF Industries told shareholders in January that it was done chasing its big rival, Terra Industries. The nearly yearlong pursuit included some ungainly moments, as when CFs nominees to Terras board rejected one of CFs many offers.

title: In New York, Wall Street Bailout Softens the Blow of a Recession
description: In fall 2008, after Lehman Brothers collapsed and other Wall Street firms seemed ready to topple, New York appeared to be headed for a brutal recession, one that would rival the worst downturns in the citys history.

title: Jon Hamm of Mad Men Is Becoming the Voice of Mercedes-Benz
description: For three seasons, the actor Jon Hamm has played the 1960s adman Don Draper on the hit AMC TV series Mad Men. Beginning on Sunday, he gets to do some advertising work in the real world as the new commercial voice of Mercedes-Benz USA. Mr. Hamms voice will be heard in a commercial that Mercedes-Benz USA will run on local ABC stations in the carmakers 16 largest markets during the ABC networks broadcast of the Academy Awards.

title: Word of the Day | imponderable
description: imponderable \()im-pn-d(-)r-bl\ noun and adjective

title: Barry Hannah, Darkly Comic Writer, Dies at 67
description: Barry Hannah, a writer who found wide acclaim with wild, darkly comic short stories and novels set in a phantasmagoric South moving at warp speed, died on Monday at his home in Oxford, Miss. He was 67.

title: With Leno, Palin Pushes Back Against Family Guy
description: In an interview Tuesday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno, Sarah Palin once again criticized Family Guy, the Fox animated series, for a joke she believed was directed at her family, and rebuked the news media for not giving her the opportunity to fully explain her opinions on that show.

title: News Quiz | March 3, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: CFs New Bid Raises Thorny Questions
description: The battles among fertilizer companies have been rejoined. CF Industries told shareholders in January that it was done chasing its big rival, Terra Industries. The nearly yearlong pursuit included some ungainly moments, as when CFs nominees to Terras board rejected one of CFs many offers.

title: Greece Set to Release Austerity Plan

There is an assertiveness to the local pedestrian, borne of having too much to do, too little time to do it and too many tourists in the way. Of course, the manner can be observed among commuters headed toward the Port Authority Bus Terminal at rush hour. But its even memorialized in Central Park, where the walking-figure icons look as much like kick boxers as pedestrians.

title: Sampler: Layoff Notices in San Francisco, and Teaching How to Kill Rabbits
description: Sonoma County to Check Immigration Status | Starting Friday, the fingerprints of those arrested in Sonoma County will be sent electronically to the Department of Homeland Security and checked for immigration violations. Sonoma will be the first county in the Bay Area to participate in the departments Secure Communities program. Critics say the program gives local law enforcement officials a bigger role in immigration enforcement, which is conducted by the federal government. The program, which began in late 2008, is now used in 10 California counties, including Sacramento, Los Angeles and San Diego. This is a common-sense approach: Everyone who gets arrested gets checked for immigration status, said Matt McCaffrey, a sheriffs captain. In this case, theyre already in the system for entering into the country illegally or for having a record. Separately, a United States district court judge will hold a hearing on Wednesday in Oakland on a lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union, accusing the Sonoma County Sheriffs Office of routinely holding Latinos longer than the maximum 72 hours for immigration detention. [The Santa Rosa Press Democrat]

title: Fantasies of the Chicago Boys
description: Ah, Chile. Remember how, during the Social Security debate, Chiles retirement system was held up as an ideal  except it turned out that it actually yielded very poor results for many people, and the Chileans themselves hated it? Now we have the usual suspects claiming that Chiles relatively low death toll in the quake proves that  you guessed it  Milton Friedman was right. You see, the Chicago Boys made Chile rich, and thats what did it.

description: CAIRO  Arab League foreign ministers on Wednesday approved an American proposal that Palestinians hold indirect talks with Israelis, a move that could help restart direct discussions between the two sides that broke down more than a year ago.

title: Home Is Where the Art Is
description: As The Times reported back in December, galleries all over the city are moving from the storefront to the home front. The latest addition to this mini-movement? Paul Johnson of Johnson Trading, a design gallery on Greenwich Street, just opened a show called Home in the Chrystie Street loft he calls, well, his home. The subject of the show is the self-taught 60-something outsider artist Robert Loughlin. Loughlin spent most of his life being a picker (or chineur), one of those people scouring flea markets looking for rare resalable gems among the rummage  always in the hopes of selling Andy Warhol a cookie jar, as the writer Irwin Warren put it in his foreword for the shows program. Johnson started out as a picker himself, and about 10 years ago he began buying pieces from the back of Loughlins pickup truck at the old Chelsea flea market. His collection now comprises more than 500 pieces, from chairs, canvases, record covers, advertising posters and other bizarre objects  ivory teeth and baby seats  all scribbled on with Loughlins Tom of Finland-esque signature smoking head, obsessively filling every single one of the lofts 4,500 square feet. To this day, Loughlin still peddles his pieces (for $300 and up) at the Chelsea flea market, but it is unlikely anybody will ever be able to accumulate a collection of similar size or quality as Johnsons (not to mention as elegantly hung by the decorator to the stars Ricky Clifton). I definitely have enough now, and I dont have any more space in my house, says Johnson when asked whether hell continue collecting Loughlin. He pauses, before adding Unless its really good.

title: Q & A: When There Are Few Insurers to Choose From

In 24 of the 43 states studied, the two biggest insurers together covered at least 70 percent of the market. Last year, that was true in 18 of 42 states studied.

title: Lets Cast the Gilligans Island Movie
description: Televisions best-known three-hour tour is about to get its own two-hour big-screen adaptation (well, maybe two-and-a-half hours when you factor in commercials and previews).A film version of Gilligans Island, the classic 1960s CBS sitcom about seven stranded castaways living it up on an uncharted desert isle, is being prepared at Warner Brothers by producers who include the series creator Sherwood Schwartz, Variety reported (registration required).

title: Geneva Auto Show: 2011 Nissan Micra

title: The Envelope, Please.. . .
description: A clutch is one of those things that will be around for a while. Theyre just so classic, really  Ive got clutches from the 30s, in that envelope style thats really simple and not too overdone. This one is part of the collection that I just designed for Longchamp, and you can actually stuff a load of things in it and bash it around. The leather is textured to look like shagreen, which I love. Most bags are too heavy to carry things in, and so many of them are stiff, and you know its going to take years to mess them up. I like things that are already worn in, something tactile thats going to be comfortable on your skin. When I was working on the collection, I showed it to my daughter, but shes a bit  you know. She just said, Yeah, its all right. She prefers bling and Hello Kitty. She says she doesnt like Hello Kitty anymore, but I know she really does. I mean, I love it, too. I just nabbed her Hello Kitty makeup bag, in fact. What can I say? I like a mismatch.  As told to Alexandra Marshall

With 21 Republicans behind the bill, the vote tally was 78 to 19, and the legislation was signed into law by President Obama late Tuesday.

title: The Dartmouth Debate: Health Costs
description: The last year has introduced me to a lot of thoughtful students of health care policy. Three who have been particularly incisive are Elliott Fisher and Jonathan Skinner of Dartmouth and Peter Bach of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. And a debate has recently erupted among them, with Dr. Bach on one side and Dr. Fisher and Mr. Skinner on the other.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Fed Survey Finds Recovery Plods On
description: A report by the Federal Reserve on Wednesday portrayed an economy that was making hesitant progress but still wrestling with familiar troubles: high unemployment, tepid spending by businesses and consumers, and deterioration in the commercial real estate market.

title: Help for the Blind, Confusion for Everyone Else
description: Press any of the roughly 2,400 street-corner buttons that claim to control traffic signals for pedestrians in New York, and the chances are only one in four that they will actually work.

description: It seemed somewhat unlikely, but in recent years an old Russian hay fever pill had become one of the worlds best hopes for treating the growing epidemic of Alzheimers disease.

title: Battle Over Modern Warfare Game as Two Executives Depart
description: The runaway success of the military themed video game Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 has given way to corporate hostilities. On Tuesday, the heads of the game studio Infinity Ward, which produces the Call of Duty games for the publisher Activision Blizzard, abruptly left that company under unclear circumstances, Reuters reported. Activision said that Jason West, the Infinity Ward president, and Vince Zampella, the studios chief executive, had both departed.

While its still a few weeks and a few towns away, our colleague Glenn Collins had a cool article on Diners Journal last night about the circuss Pie Car, a venerable circus-train tradition where nowadays aerialist and roustabout alike graze on everything from dainty salads to 3 a.m. PBJ sandwiches. See full article.

He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. Targets have sought to bind acquirers as tightly as possible, seeking to avoid a deal collapse that destroys shares prices, similar to what happened to many targets amid the crisis.

title: Seeking Your Questions on Historically Black Colleges

That formal designation originated in 1980, when President Jimmy Carter signed an executive order to establish a federal program to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education. Last month, President Obama signed an executive order of his own that would add nearly $100 million to the program.

Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) holds at No. 2 with 118,000 sales, and Johnny Cashs American VI: Aint No Grave (American/Lost Highway), said to be the last of Cashs prolific late sessions with Rick Rubin, opens at No. 3 with 54,000. title: The Story of Eau

Fittingly, his first fragrance for Balenciaga also demonstrates his particular knack for keeping a respectful eye on the pastwhile forging a path to the future. With inspirations that range from the traditional (violet chypre, patchouli, cedar and carnations) to the more unusual (floor wax and gasoline), the resulting scent is ultimately modern enough for the likes of Charlotte Gainsbourg, his muse and the face of the ad campaign. It has a sexy presence thats not at all about romanticism, he says. Its more urban  a little sharp, even a little tough. More

title: Cab-Share Rollout Lacks Cabs and Sharers
description: Rain, rain, rain, on this day,It seemed to keep all the riders away!

title: For Heavy Metal, a Light Touch
description: From an outsiders perspective, the aesthetics of heavy metal music can seem fairly predictable. There are usually copious amounts of black, images of things rotting and references to corpses, funerals and obscure diseases  not to mention inadvertently comical names like Hypothalamus. Religious symbols will almost certainly be defaced. And when a book comes out on a legendary logo designer like Christophe Szpajdel, it will have the appearance of a hymnal, with its flexible, pebbled cover embossed with gold type in some vaguely Gothic font. Well, naturally. The funny thing is what happens once you crack it open  turns out Szpajdel, a 38-year-old Belgian whose day job is in forestry engineering, isnt all that inspired by death after all.

title: Travel Deals: Flight Sale on Iberia Airlines
description: Travelzoo has the scoop on a particularly thrifty find: round-trip flights from New York to Casablanca, Morocco for $587 . The deal is good for travel between April 13 and May 20.

title: Road to Broadway Is Paved With Matzah
description: Aspiring musical composers and lyricists, take note: Using YouTube to show your performance chops and creativity could lead to gigs on Broadway!

title: For the Best Yakisoba, Make it Yourself
description: I wish I could give you the name of a restaurant that serves good yakisoba, but despite the fact that this Japanese stir-fried noodle dish is essentially fast food, in this country its best made at home. There are literally thousands of versions; this weeks Minimalist column features mine.

title: Continental to Charge for Exit Row Seats in Coach
description: Continental Airlines announced today that it will charge for exit row seats in coach, starting March 17.

title: Graphic Content | Flipping My Lid
description: Steven Heller, a former art director at The New York Times, is a co-chair of the MFA Design Department at the School of Visual Arts and a blogger and author.

title: Earthquake Exposes Fault Lines in Chilean Politics
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  With a torrent of criticism over her governments response to the earthquake and little more than a week to dispel it before leaving office, President Michelle Bachelet on Wednesday intensified her efforts to provide help to the hundreds of thousands of people affected by the disaster and publicly began the fight to preserve her legacy.

title: Israeli Raid Canceled After Facebook Leak
description: Updated | 4:12 p.m. Israels Army Radio reported on Wednesday that a raid on suspected militants in the West Bank planned for Wednesday was called off by the countrys military because a soldier posted details of the operation on Facebook.

title: U.S. Circulates New Draft Proposal for Iran Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United States is circulating a draft of new, tougher sanctions against Iran that concentrate on the banking, shipping and insurance sectors of Irans economy and is now waiting for China and Russia to signal that they are willing to start negotiating over the measures, United Nations Security Council diplomats said Wednesday.

title: Starting Over at 55
description: AFTER 24 years as a marketing manager for Coors, Cinde Dolphin knew what was coming  Miller and Coors had just merged their United States beer operations, and hundreds of jobs were sure to be eliminated.

title: Shots and Tots in Brooklyn Bars, Revisited
description: A CNN report Tuesday has rekindled a smoldering debate of national, nay, potentially international significance, one that may affect a generation of future Americans.

title: Washington Report
description: As Representative Charles B. Rangel temporarily stepped aside as chairman of the powerful House Ways and Means Committee, Democrats were refocusing their strategy on passing legislation to overhaul health care.

title: Extra Points for Good Catwalking
description: AT some point during the fourth hour of playing a new video-game version of Project Runway, a sensation of nausea rolled in, like what happens when you finally pick your face up off the couch after a marathon viewing of the show.

title: Bad Investment Advice Can Turn a Free Meal Costly
description: TWO financial advisers regaled Marilyn and Paul Johnson a few years ago with free lunches and dinners at local country clubs and a celebrity chefs restaurant in Kenosha, Wis., 40 miles south of Milwaukee. The Johnsons were fed prime rib and fancy desserts and heard promises of 12 percent returns on sure-thing investments.

title: Bowersox Still Uncertain for American Idol
description: Crystal Bowersox, the American Idol semifinalist whose sudden illness on Tuesday resulted in the shows swapping the performances of its female and male contestants this week, may miss Wednesdays broadcast as well, the Idol executive producer Ken Warwick said.

title: Estate Planning as a Family Conversation
description: FOR many people, estate planning is both a private matter and a morbid topic  not something that parents and their adult children want to discuss. While having these conversations takes a lot of courage, they can help avoid surprises, lead to better financial planning and promote family harmony.

title: Obama Calls for Up or Down Vote on Health Care Bill
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, beginning his final push for a health care overhaul, called Wednesday for Congress to allow an up or down vote on the measure, and sketched out an ambitious  and, some Democrats said, unrealistic  timetable for his party to pass a bill on its own within weeks.

title: The Online Lineup
description: THE SKINNY Sales of skin care products and services with expert advice from a founder, Lauren Fornes, an esthetician. Recent beauty sales on the Skinny have included Tammy Fender, Lisa Hoffman Beauty and International Orange Spa.

title: When Life Insurance Is More Valuable as Cash
description: THE children are grown. Each spouse  or a surviving spouse  has enough assets to last a lifetime. Yet a life insurance policy is still in force. It could be used to make gifts to those children now, a down payment on an inheritance, in effect.

title: Answers About Education Tax Credits and Deductions: Part 1
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: One-Touch Shopping, for Members Only
description: LINDSAY GOEWEY is an ideal member of HauteLook, a private sales Web site: shes acquisitive, organized and online all the time. And Ms. Goewey, 27, loves a good deal, especially on cosmetics from some of her favorite brands like Stila or Smashbox, or brands she hasnt tried yet but says she certainly would for 50 percent off.

title: Russian Olympic Chief Quits
description: MOSCOW  The president of Russias Olympic Committee has become the first official to heed President Dmitri A. Medvedevs demand for resignations after the poor showing by Russian athletes at the Winter Games in Vancouver.

title: For Shift to Roth I.R.A., Know the Pitfalls to Avoid
description: CONVERTING a traditional individual retirement account to a Roth I.R.A. is a widely discussed financial planning tool right now, but the mechanics can be tricky. The process is new to many people, because until this year, you were shut out of a Roth if your adjusted gross income was more than $100,000.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Bufori Geneva
description: Introduced on Tuesday: Bufori Geneva sedan

title: Answers From a Graffiti Artist
description: Following is the first set of answers from Lee Quiones, an artist who emerged from the subway art movement of the 1970s.

title: Cuban Black Beans
description: 11/2 green peppers, stemmed and seeded

title: More Like, How to Fake It
description: After three episodes, a critical consensus has so far eluded HBOs latest episodic offering, How To Make It In America. But even the haters seem unable to resist I Need a Dollar, the shows opening theme song (embedded above) by the West Coast soul singer Aloe Blacc. Life is random, says Julian Farino, the series director and one of its executive producers. That song seems to be one of the things that people have responded to most about our show.

title: Burnt Offerings
description: With a very few exceptions like microwave cooking, which was discovered when an engineer was fooling around with a radar set that melted a chocolate bar in his pocket, most kitchen accidents belong in the trash. I hate mistakes when Im cooking, although Ive certainly made enough of them. I am forever oversalting the oatmeal or scorching the butter or flipping pancakes into unnatural postures, and each time I want to kick the stove and walk away. The only thing stopping me is my 5-year-old.

title: At the Capitol, Remembering Murtha
description: The late Representative John P. Murtha was praised as a courageous defender of the military, his constituents and colleagues in a memorial ceremony in the Capitol today.

title: Now Is a Perfect Time to Reconstruct a Nest Egg
description: THE turbulent economy of the last two years has left retirement accounts across the nation like beaches after a coastal storm  severely eroded.

title: Chinas Cyberposse
description: The short video made its way around Chinas Web in early 2006, passed on through file sharing and recommended in chat rooms. It opens with a middle-aged Asian woman dressed in a leopard-print blouse, knee-length black skirt, stockings and silver stilettos standing next to a riverbank. She smiles, holding a small brown and white kitten in her hands. She gently places the cat on the tiled pavement and proceeds to stomp it to death with the sharp point of her high heel.

title: Reusing Comic Book Images: Homage or Theft?
description: The controversy over Nick Simmons, and whether he inappropriately appropriated images from other manga series to create his own, is a familiar one to comic book readers.

title: Paris: My Old Lady
description: With the song Crimson and Clover playing at Rochas this afternoon, I guess it was pretty clear we were back in the 60s. Ah, man. As usual, Marco Zanini brings a fine sense of color to everything, now with crystal tones of blue, pink and yellow with leopard and square-toed shoes with a kooky sparkle heel that jutted out, giving a sense of motion. The clothes were sweet and wearable, but it was a weird trip. Why now?

title: On Second Night, Leno Again Beats Letterman
description: Jay Leno had a solid second night back on The Tonight Show on Tuesday night, thanks in part to a special opening monologue from his lead guest, Sarah Palin.

title: At Blackstone, a Rebound and More Transparency
description: Is the Blackstone Group on the rebound after the excesses of the credit boom and bust? Chris Kotowski, an analyst at Oppenheimer, thinks so, upgrading his rating on the private equity firms stock to outperform on Wednesday on signs that Blackstone will be able to earn more of its performance fees faster than expected.

title: Lets Talk About It: Discussing the Science and Politics of Global Warming
description: Overview | What have you heard about global warming in the news lately? Is the scientific evidence for global warming in question? Are politicians and world leaders doing enough to curb carbon emissions? What does this winters unusually cold and snowy weather have to do, if anything, with global warming? In is lesson, students hold a mock talk show on issues related to the science and politics of global warming.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Ghosn Optimistic About Electric Future
description: GENEVA  Electric vehicles will not only reduce emissions, but they may also help solve another big problem facing Europes car industry: too many factories. At least that was the assertion of Carlos Ghosn, chief executive of Renault and Nissan, in a discussion with journalists at the Geneva auto show on Wednesday.

title: SmartMoney Deal Expands Role of Journal Editor
description: In taking sole control ofSmartMoney, the News Corporation is also expandingthe influenceofRobert J. Thomson, the top editor of The Wall Street Journal, who will oversee the editorial side of SmartMoney.

title: A Leader of G.M. Is to Retire
description: DETROIT  Robert A. Lutz, the outspoken former Marine fighter pilot behind many of the most eye-catching and popular vehicles that General Motors has introduced over the last decade, intends to retire May 1, the company said Wednesday.

title: Casting Call: Large-Eared Elephant Wanted?
description: Disney Theatrical Productions and Stephen Daldry, the Tony Award-wining director of Billy Elliot: The Musical, are developing an adaptation for the stage of the 1941 classic movie Dumbo, a Disney executive said on Wednesday afternoon.

title: A Note On Climate Policy (Very Wonkish)
description: Basically a clarifying note to myself (pdf), trying to make sense of some big disputes among serious people (as opposed to the nonsense arguments that dominate public debate).

title: Ballet Theater to Spend the Fall Focusing on the Mouse King and Sugarplum Fairies
description: American Ballet Theater says it will skip its regular two weeks of performances this coming fall and use the time to rehearse its new Nutcracker production, which will run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. After 10 years of fall performances at New York City Center, Ballet Theater moved to Avery Fisher Hall in October. No fall home has been decided on for 2011, said Rachel S. Moore, the companys executive director. Were looking at lots of different places, she said. Ms. Moore said that the one-time costs of creating sets and costumes for the Nutcracker, which is being choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky, also precluded fall performance this year. Overall, Ballet Theater will stage an equal number of performances, Ms. Moore said. The Wall Street Journal reported the skipped fall weeks on Wednesday. The company will continue with its spring performances at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: 10th Person Pleads Guilty in Galleon Insider Case
description: A former vice president of Atheros Communications pleaded guilty on Wednesday to conspiracy and fraud charges in the Galleon Group insider trading case, Reuters reports.

title: Getting the Most Out of Twitter
description: A COMMON reason given by those who have yet to try Twitter: I have nothing to say.

title: Waiting On Strasburg
description: Washington Nationals fans and fantasy baseball owners who are eagerly awaiting the major league debut of the right-hander Stephen Strasburg, the top draft pick from last June, will most likely have to wait a bit longer.

title: Rove on Iraq: Without W.M.D. Threat, Bush Wouldnt Have Gone to War
description: Karl Rove, the chief political adviser to President George W. Bush and architect of his two successful campaigns for the White House, says in a new memoir that his former boss probably would not have invaded Iraq had he known there were no weapons of mass destruction there.

title: The Trouble With Milan
description: This season the road from the airport lounge to the fashion runway has been particularly short. After the 36 Hour Race through the London shows, we survived a hectic and hysterical Fashion Weekend in Milan, where the calendar of presentations had been collapsed into three days of overlapping shows, impossible delays and events that went way into the night without any breaks for lunch or a sit-down dinner.

title: Chase (Sort of) Restores Lost Credit Card Rewards
description: Chase used to offer a Cash Plus card that offered 5 percent cash back for purchases made in everyday categories like gas stations, grocery stores and drugstores and 1 percent back on all other spending. But it stopped marketing the card in 2006.

title: Senators Want Buy American Rule in Stimulus
description: Four Democratic senators are calling on the Obama administration to halt spending on a renewable energy program in the economic stimulus package until rules are in place to assure that the projects use predominantly American labor and materials.

title: House of Style
description: Phillip Lim Age: 36 Occupation: Designer Next Project: A full line of men's shoes for the fall, including utility boots and animal-print sneakers inspired by the photographer Peter Beard.

title: Appeals Court Backs Landmarks Commission on Designations
description: A court decision chastising the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission for its failure to take action on certain landmark designation requests and calling for new expedited procedures has been reversed on appeal.

title: Russian Orchestra Tour: From the Bus to the Stage
description: When the great orchestras of Europe glide through the United States on tour, they stay at elegant hotels like Le Parker Meridien near Carnegie Hall, play in grand spaces like Symphony Hall in Boston and can receive more than $100 a day in meal money.

title: Bilton on ABC: Dos and Donts of Digital Etiquette
description: On Wednesday, I debated the dos and donts of digital etiquette with Diane Sawyer, the ABC anchor.

title: Obamas Remarks on Health Care
description: Following is a text of President Obama's speech Wednesday on the need to overhaul of the country's health care system, as released by the White House:

title: Why Old People Should Love Immigrants
description: Earlier today Casey B. Mulligan wrote about how the entry of more women into the work force has helped sustain the solvency of Social Security, which has been otherwise stressed by the size of the retiring baby boom generation and longer life expectancies.

title: The Man Who Clicks With 7-Year-Olds
description: THE name Marty Hyman may mean nothing to you. But if you, your children or grandchildren have gone to private schools in and around Manhattan over the last 30 years, chances are youve either smiled for Mr. Hyman or written him a check.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Infiniti M35 Hybrid
description: Introduced on Tuesday: Infiniti M35 Hybrid

title: Developing Nations Setting Torrid Pace for Mergers
description: NEW DELHI  As both companies and countries in the West and Japan stumble under debt and fear, a new enthusiasm for deals has already emerged this year in India, China and other developing countries.

title: Rangels Leave May Not Be Temporary
description: After Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, sent a letter to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday morning requesting a leave of absence from his post as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, the presiding officer of the House announced that the resignation is accepted.

title: Dessay Leaves Mets Hamlet
description: Natalie Dessay has withdrawn as Ophlie from the Metropolitan Operas production of Hamlet, by Ambroise Thomas, because of illness, the Met said on Wednesday. Marlis Petersen, who was to have sung one performance, on April 9, will take her place for the first six shows  on March 16, 20, 24, 27, 30 and April 2. Another soprano, as yet to be announced, will sing the last two performances, on April 5 and 9. Simon Keenlyside sings the title role. The Met has not staged the work since 1897.

title: Handling Investments and Investors Fears
description: DANIEL DUNN has been on Wall Street for 25 years, but his route to investments was nontraditional. After earning a degree in clinical psychology from Pace University, he worked at an inpatient ward at a mental hospital on Staten Island and then moved through various careers, at one point selling advertising for a radio station.

title: Street Art Thats Finding a New Address
description: FOR the current fifth-anniversary exhibition at his New York gallery Jonathan LeVine has filled it with works by 35 artists, most of whom he represents. The space is in Chelsea, but theres no cerebral conceptualism, cool abstraction or painterly gesture on view.

title: Pop Goes the Street
description: A look at the world of pop surrealism, narrated by Jonathan LeVine, a gallery owner, and the artists WK and Doze Green.

title: Monitoring Your Childs Friendships
description: Sometimes its the kids who need help navigating the social shoals of elementary school. Sometimes its the parents.

title: The Voices of Fibromyalgia
description: People who suffer from fibromyalgia experience problems beyond the pain caused by their illness. Their condition is little understood and hard to explain, and often they are disbelieved by doctors. Even friends and loved ones may express skepticism toward the fibromyalgia sufferer, who, burdened with inexplicable pain, may cancel social plans, miss work and recoil from physical affection because it hurts too much.

title: The Saturday Night Live Presidential Reunion
description: We were happy enough at the start of this Funny Or Die video to see the Saturday Night Live alumna Maya Rudolph playing Michelle Obama  just to see Ms. Rudolph playing anyone, really. But beyond those first few crucial seconds, theres a skit reuniting almost every surviving S.N.L. cast member who has ever played a United States president: Fred Armisen as Barack Obama; Will Ferrell as George W. Bush; Darrell Hammond as Bill Clinton; Dana Carvey as George H. W. Bush; Dan Aykroyd as Jimmy Carter; and even Chevy Chase as Gerald Ford.

title: Matching Life Experience With New Careers
description: HEALTH navigator? Conflict coach? Pollution mitigation outreach worker? These emerging jobs arent household terms yet, but they are a natural fit for older people looking for new career opportunities, said Phyllis Segal, vice president at Civic Ventures, a nonprofit research group based in San Francisco.

title: Corporate Deal Makers Head to Emerging Markets
description: As both companies and countries in the West and Japan stumble under debt and fear, a new enthusiasm for deals has emerged this year in India, China and other developing countries, Heather Timmons and Vikas Bajaj of The New York Times report from New Delhi.

title: What Were Reading
How Much Can You Stick on Flickr?
description: Q.

title: Fixing the Wi-Fi on iPod Touch
description: Q. The icon on my iPod Touch shows that Im connected to my home wireless network, but I cant open Web pages or do e-mail. What do I do?

title: Upstate Democrat Retiring Amid Allegations of Misconduct
description: Representative Eric J. Massa, an outspoken freshman Democrat from a Republican-leaning district in upstate New York, abruptly announced Wednesday that he would retire, as he faced allegations that he had harassed a member of his staff.

title: What States and Cities Are Doing to Help Small Businesses
description: While Washington debates how to help the countrys struggling small businesses, states and municipalities have stepped up with an array of initiatives to stanch closings and save jobs.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, March 3
description: There are some faces that you dont need to see in a news photograph. Her braided corona instantly identifies Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko of Ukraine, seen in Slide 7 as she left the Parliament after a vote of no confidence in her government. And Candy Holmess joy in obtaining her marriage license in the District of Columbia (Slide 10) is evident enough.

title: Portraits of a Lady | Baron Adolph de Meyer
description: At the turn of the century, magazine and catalog illustrations of the latest fashion collections were rather dry, using models who acted more like cutout dolls. It took the work of Baron Adolph de Meyer to loosen up fashion editorial with challenging portraits in the pages of Vogue, Vanity Fair and Harpers Bazaar. A rare showing of more than 100 of his society portraits, commercial fashion photography and still lifes recently opened at Robert Miller Gallery (through April 3; robertmillergallery.com).

title: Trump State Park Fired. Trump Displeased.
description: Although he is known for his high-rises, resorts and golf courses, Donald J. Trump helped create a little-known state park in northern Westchester County, donating the land for public use in 2006.

title: Oscars Box Office Bump
description: As we approach the inexorable glitz hole of what one of our commenters memorably calls a dog wedding, its worth taking a step back to examine what exactly an Oscar nomination means to a movie. (Its also worth noting that people in Hollywood actually have dog weddings.) Theres prestige, sure, and the conventional wisdom holds that small films get a much-needed box office bump from awards attention. But it turns out so do blockbusters.

title: Film and Fashion: Just Friends
description: JEN KAO has seen Avatar  twice. Ms. Kao, a New York designer known for filmy knits and aggressive black leather, plans to infuse her next collection, in September, with some of that movies violent colors and savage frills.

title: From California, Chinese Solar Maker Looks East
description: Yingli, the Chinese solar module maker that captured nearly a third of the California market last year, has struck a deal to supply a New Jersey developer with more than 10 megawatts of photovoltaic panels.

title: Joanna Newsom, the Changeling
description: LARK CAMP is a weeklong gathering of folk musicians held each summer in the Mendocino Woodlands, on the California coast, 150 miles north of San Francisco. Part music-and-dance academy, part freewheeling hoedown, Lark Camp brings together specialists in American and world-music traditions  Cajun fiddlers, hula dancers, Andean panpipe experts, Galician accordionists  who teach workshops and lead late-night jam sessions around campfires beneath the stretching redwoods.

title: Unions Plan Protests Against Big Banks
description: ORLANDO  In an action it hopes would create jobs and increase economic fairness, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced on Wednesday that it will sponsor two Weeks of Action against the nations major banks.

title: Striking Poses
description: I am cursed to be in this Mother Hubbard body, Alice Neel once remarked of her grandmotherly image. The artists sensitivity to nuances of style and gesture informs the portraits in Alice Neel: Painted Truths, a retrospective opening on March 21 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. Since her portrait work was largely uncommissioned and did not require that she flatter the sitter, you get a sense of how people really looked, says Barry Walker, who, with Jeremy Lewison, curated the show. Thats as true for the cheerful Fuller Brush man and Dachau survivor who showed up on her doorstep in 1965 as it is for the art-world elites who (eventually) posed for her  including the Factorys Ritta Redd and Jackie Curtis and Andy Warhol himself, seminude and scarred. (Neel was notorious for sweet-talking her subjects out of their clothes.) When faced with truly stylish subjects, like the art-world players John Gruen and Jane Wilson and their daughter, Neel focused on the psychological  the self-assured couple and the young girl, hunched like a figure out of Munch  but she didnt neglect the clothes. The paintings pet name: Six Patent Leather Shoes.

title: Taming a Child by Setting Her Free
description: Language is exalted as the miracle maker of The Miracle Worker, the potential means of salvation for a knowledge-starved deaf and blind girl named Helen Keller. One word, and I can put the world in your hand, Helens teacher tells her with fervor. Odd, then, that the sadly pedestrian new production of William Gibsons 1959 biographical drama is by far most effective when it is wordless.

title: A Last Bow at the Oscars for Walters
description: On Oscar night its a tradition: The stars break down and weep  and thats before they know if theyve won or lost.

title: After Two Cy Youngs, Lincecum Finally Meets Griffey
description: PEORIA, Ariz.  Tim Lincecum was 4 years old when Ken Griffey Jr. made his major league debut in 1989 for the Seattle Mariners, Lincecums local team. Lincecum starred at Liberty High School in Renton, Wash., and then at the University of Washington, before winning the last two National League Cy Young Awards for the San Francisco Giants. Still, he had never met Griffey until Wednesday.

title: Films Influence on Fashion, Then and Now
description: Costumes can be protagonists, as in these Hollywood classics.

title: Why His Face May End Up in Websters
description: SOMETIMES you hear a word for the first time and think: Of course. How better to describe Paris Hilton than as a celebutante or the frequent tabloid target Alec Baldwin as the bloviator? (Thanks, New York Post!)

title: Musical Instruments: Now You See Em, Now You . . .
description: Lovers of historic musical instruments are living on a roller coaster. Weeks after the Victoria & Albert Museum in London permanently shut down its renowned collection on the subject, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York reopened its musical instrument gallery after eight months of refurbishing.

title: A New York Snowcation
description: A bus load of skiers and snowboarders have been reveling in the record snowfall this winter.

title: G.M.s Vocal Vice Chairman Flies Off Into Retirement
description: DETROIT  Following a 47-year career in the car business that earned him a reputation as an innovative but outspoken maverick, Bob Lutz will retire from General Motors on May 1. The announcement came after a major reorganization that G.M. announced on Tuesday.

title: Twitter Ban Lifted by Carnival Cruises
description: Carnival Cruise Lines has reversed a rule that sought to prevent travel agents from mentioning the companys name or its trademarks on social media sites like Facebook and Twitter.

title: Winter Training: Faster and Safer Indoors?
description: PAUL THOMPSON, a fast marathon runner and cardiologist at Hartford Hospital in Connecticut, finally broke down this year and bought a treadmill. At age 62, he had had it with running on icy mornings when temperatures were in the single digits.

title: 2 Bermuda Reinsurers Agree to Merge
description: Two reinsurance companies based in Bermuda  the Max Capital Group and Harbor Point   announced Wednesday afternoon that they had agreed to merge, forming a combined company that would be renamed Alterra Capital Holdings.

title: In Americas Gyms, More Than a Touch of Gray
description: ITS 8:30 on a Tuesday morning at Island Fitness in Coronado, Calif., and the gyms ambience is about to be transformed almost as markedly as was the 98-pound-weakling-turned-muscle-man in the old comic book ads.

title: Researchers Identify Fossil of Dinosaur-Eating Snake
description: The discovery of a snake near an egg is by no means unusual, but in this case, the snake was 67 million years old  providing scientists with new information about how snakes in the dinosaur era lived, and what they ate.

title: Use of the Zone Attacks Perceptions and Ego
description: Man-to-man defense is the red meat of college basketball, with players held accountable on every possession. They crouch  sometimes so low they can slap their palms on the floor  as if defending against a threat more dangerous than an opponent with a basketball.

title: Iraq Elections: Voter Profile
description: Michael Kamber talks with Iraqis as they get ready for Sunday's Parliamentary elections.
