title: Is It Ever O.K. to Snoop on Your Spouses E-Mail?
description: In the tradition of Jenna Worthams posts on Internet etiquette, Nick Bilton over on the Bits blog dove into two thorny topics  the dos and donts of sending text messages during dinner and the ethics of riffling through the e-mail and text messages of a spouse or significant other  in a discussion with Diane Sawyer of ABC.

title: A Survivors Tale From Chile
description: Karina Murga, 27, was born and raised in Constitucin, Chile, where she lived with her mother, daughter and other family members until Saturday. Early that morning, when the 8.8 magnitude earthquake struck Chile and badly damaged Constitucin, Karinas six-year-old Carla was staying with her godmother, Cristina Vergara, and her godmothers son, Jorge Zurita.

title: Paris Preview
description: After a long, cruel winter, Paris is awakening to spring. Check out these magical photo exhibitions and enchanted storefronts.

title: A Plan to Send Flight Data Somewhere Off the Plane
description: Investigators of a French airline accident and aviation agencies from 44 other European countries plan to ask the International Civil Aviation Organization to change the way planes transmit information while flying over oceans. The hope is to prevent airliners from vanishing without leaving clues about what happened.

title: A Closer Look at Windows Live
description: Every time Microsoft pitches me on some Windows Live product, I groan. What the heck is Windows Live? I mean, what is it this week?

title: San Franciscos Overtime Pay Exceeding Expectations
description: At a budget committee meeting on Wednesday, Deputy Controller Monique Zmuda presented to the Board of Supervisors her latest report on the citys overtime expenditures [PDF]  including pending payments to a firefighter who logged 1,053 hours of overtime in the first 193 days of this fiscal year.

title: Documentarian Struggles to Climb Mount Weinstein
description: LOS ANGELES  Intrepid documentarians have spied on a mass dolphin slaughter (in The Cove), faced off against the food industry (in Food, Inc.) and braved the heights of Mount Everest in the sort of antique tweeds worn by men who died there in the 1920s (in The Wildest Dream).

title: Education on the Companys Dime
description: ROBIN ROUSE just turned 50 and is thinking ahead to retirement from I.B.M. She loves her job in the companys Cambridge, Mass., office, but she is also honing her film-writing skills, with the company helping to pay for classes.

title: In Iraq, Voters Are Optimistic, but Cautious
description: In Baghdad, Michael Kamber interviewed Iraqis about their outlook on the upcoming election. On the streets, the mood is subdued but cautiously optimistic that the election would come off without major violence. Many appear somewhat cynical that the election will bring a quick change in their lives.

title: Congressional Pay Cut Gains Support
description: An increasing number of lawmakers are pushing to dock their own salaries by 5 percent in an effort to show that Congress is prepared to sacrifice as the economy stumbles.

title: Variations on a Theme
description: A look inside the artist Marina Abramovics SoHo loft and her home in upstate New York.

title: Tammy Wynette
description: Virginia's in the House

title: Stand by Your Singer and Her Art
description: Jimmy McDonough wasnt one of Tammy Wynettes lovers. He didnt know her, except from afar. Yet he has managed to arrange a tryst with her in some No-Tell Motel of the spirit, achieving an intimacy that many biographers covet but few enjoy. For evidence of what happens when biographer and subject dont click so perfectly, compare Mr. McDonoughs sweeping yet uneasy portrait of Neil Young, Shakey, an authorized book eager to please its subject, with his freewheeling approach in Tammy Wynette to the late, lamented, conveniently elusive Tragic Country Queen.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Etiquette, Tapes and the F1 Key
description: This week on the Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein chats with Jenna Wortham of The New York Times about online etiquette questions involving work, home and heartbreak.

title: Judge Gives General Growth 4-Month Extension
description: 8:25 a.m. | Updated Read an expanded version of this story here.

title: Why Size Matters
description: Speaking of blurring the line between bloggers and politicians, Ezra Klein and Congressman Paul Ryan just had an interesting online exchange about Ryans remarks at last weeks health care summit. The Wisconsin congressman, you may recall, accused partisans of the pending legislation of disguising the real cost of the bill, which may total $2.3 trillion over 10 years once all the subsidies are phased in. Klein responded that yes, the bill might cost $2.3 trillion in its second decade, but over that period it either raises or saves $2.95 trillion, for a net deficit impact of negative $650 billion. Ryan, he suggested, was using the classic This Is A Big Number technique to imply that the bill is financially irresponsible, when putting the number in context would show just the opposite.

title: Excerpt: 'Who do You Think You Are?'
description: The NBC show traces the family trees of celebrities like Sarah Jessica Parker.

title: A Miniature World Magnifies Dwarf Life
description: KUNMING, China  Chen Mingjings entrepreneurial instincts vaulted him from a peasant upbringing to undreamed-of wealth, acquired in ventures ranging from making electric meters to investing in real estate. But when he was 44, the allure of making money for moneys sake began to wane. He wanted to run a business that accomplished some good.

title: Is Your Family Tree Just a Shrub?
description: At this point theres probably no stopping the genealogy craze, which for a few decades now has been causing people to go rooting around in their familial past, trying to find out who gave birth to the person who gave birth to the person who was related to the person who gave birth to them. And on Friday night this happy cult may sign up a bunch of new members when an addictive little program called Who Do You Think You Are? has its premiere on NBC.

title: From Snowy to Snowier
description: During last weeks near-record snowfalls, many New Yorkers said enough. But Central Parks 30 inches werent enough for some.

title: Positive Test for Sanofi Prostate Cancer Drug
description: A new drug being developed by Sanofi-Aventis extended the lives of men with advanced prostate cancer in a clinical trial and could become a new last-ditch treatment, researchers reported Wednesday.

title: Fallen Angels
description: There was a time in the 1990s when angels were impossible to escape. Guardians, muses, articles of trade, they covered T-shirts and bathroom accessories, bloomed on restaurant walls and peered from the edges of book jackets. Lately they may seem to have drifted away, but theyve merely wandered into the literature of self-help and healing. It is now possible to buy How to Hear Your Angels, Working With Angels, In the Arms of Angels and Angels 101, as well as angel dictionaries, encyclopedias and art books.

title: The Blobs Arent Talking
description: TAOS, N.M.

title: A Choreographer Recycling and Reusing, but Always Reinventing
description: In its current season at City Center, the Paul Taylor Dance Company is presenting three works by Mr. Taylor each evening: 18 in all, spread over 16 performances. He could arrange them as six unvarying triple bills, each of which would have two or three performances. That would be more convenient for this citys busy dancegoers.

title: Robert Kennedy Items Removed From Police Exhibit
description: Evidence from the 1968 assassination of Robert F. Kennedy at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles  including the bloody clothes he was wearing when he was shot  has been removed from an exhibition at a Las Vegas casino in response to objections from his family, his son Maxwell Taylor Kennedy said Wednesday.

title: Footnote
description: Natalie Dessay, below, has withdrawn as Ophlie from the Metropolitan Operas production of Ambroise Thomass Hamlet, because of illness, the Met said on Wednesday. Marlis Petersen, who was to have sung one performance, on April 9, will take her place for the first six shows  on March 16, 20, 24, 27, 30 and April 2. Another soprano, yet to be announced, will sing the performances on April 5 and 9. Simon Keenlyside sings the title role.

title: Financier to Head Kennedy Center Board
description: David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder and managing director of the Carlyle Group, one of the worlds largest private equity firms, has been selected as the next chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, the center announced on Wednesday. In a telephone interview Mr. Rubenstein, 60, said he hoped to attract younger audiences  people who dont have hair color like mine  to the center. He added that he also sees taking the post as a chance to help combat the increasing divide in Washington between Republicans and Democrats, since the arts help bring people together." Mr. Rubenstein, a Washingtonian who has been on the Kennedy Center board since 2004, will succeed the financier Stephen A. Schwarzman after the May board meeting. Mr. Rubenstein helped start the 23-year-old Carlyle Group, which now manages more than $87 billion from 19 offices around the world. He serves on the boards of about 30 major institutions, including the Smithsonian Institution, Duke University, Johns Hopkins University, the University of Chicago, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. I do intend to narrow down the philanthropic commitments I have, Mr. Rubenstein said.

title: Little Buddy Heading to the Big Screen
description: Televisions best-known three-hour tour is about to get its own two-hour movie adaptation (well, maybe two and a half hours when you factor in commercials and previews). A film version of Gilligans Island, the classic 1960s CBS sitcom about seven castaways on an uncharted desert isle, is being prepared at Warner Brothers by producers who include the series creator Sherwood Schwartz, Variety reported. While vintage pop-culture properties do not always make the best movies  see the film versions of Dukes of Hazzard, The Brady Bunch, Leave It to Beaver, The Honeymooners, et al.  the Gilligans Island movie need not be a total washout; for one thing, the Variety report said that the producers were seeking to cast Michael Cera, above, the Juno and Arrested Development star, as the titular bumbling first mate.

title: Flying Elephant on Broadway?
description: Disney Theatrical Productions and Stephen Daldry, the Tony Award-wining director of Billy Elliot: The Musical, are developing an adaptation for the stage of the 1941 classic animated movie Dumbo, a Disney executive said on Wednesday afternoon. Mr. Daldry approached Disney Theatrical several months ago with a concept for a Dumbo musical, and they are now in the very initial stages of shaping those ideas, according to the executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the company does not comment on projects at such an early stage. No creative team  composers, book writers, designers, and so on  has been assembled, the executive said, but doing so would probably be the next step. Dumbo, of course, already comes with several songs from the movie, including Baby Mine  which was nominated for the Academy Award for best song  as well as Casey Junior and When I See An Elephant Fly. The film won the Oscar for best original score. It is too early to say when the musical, if ultimately realized, would come to Broadway, or if it would start out in London as Billy Elliot did (Mr. Daldry is British) or in another major theatrical city other than New York, the executive said. Lets put it this way, Dumbo will not be on Broadway in the 2010-11 season, because its simply in the very early stages, the executive said. The New York Post on Wednesday reported Disneys interest in developing Dumbo for the stage, though The Post said that Mr. Daldry had passed on the project because he and Disney could not come to terms. The Disney executive said that Mr. Daldry has always been aboard. "This is Stephens idea, and hes very passionate about it, the executive said.

title: Executive Casualties at War-Game Maker
description: The runaway success of the video game Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 has given way to corporate hostilities. On Tuesday the heads of the game studio Infinity Ward, which produces the Call of Duty games for the publisher Activision Blizzard, abruptly left that company under unclear circumstances, Reuters reported. Activision said that Jason West, the Infinity Ward president, and Vince Zampella, the studios chief executive, had both departed. In a statement and in a regulatory filing reported by Reuters, Activision said it was investigating breaches of contract and insubordination by two senior employees at Infinity Ward, but did not name the employees. The game publisher also said it was starting its own business unit to produce future Call of Duty titles, and that the decision was unrelated to the exits of Mr. West and Mr. Zampella. Infinity Ward, which released the original Call of Duty game in 2003, was acquired by Activision that same year. Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, which was released in November, became one of the best-selling games of all time, grossing an estimated $310 million in sales in its first day of release and selling more than 12 million copies over all. Activision has two more Call of Duty games planned for 2010 and 2011, neither developed by Infinity Ward.

title: Turks, Kurds, Armenians: View From a Small Town
description: In 2005, Christopher de Bellaigue, a British journalist, installed himself in a remote, forbidding Turkish town and, by so doing, acquired an anguished intimacy with the regions peoples and their secret and mythic pasts. This extraordinary intervention  which can be read as old-fashioned Orientalism or, more generously, as a globalized conscience courageously at work or, most accurately, as a bit of both  has a reflexive subplot, namely de Bellaigues own intellectual and moral odyssey, which is of an unusually vulnerable and romantic character.

title: Ballet Theater to Skip Fall Season
description: American Ballet Theater says it will skip its regular two weeks of performances next fall and use the time to rehearse its new Nutcracker production, which will be staged at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. After 10 years of fall performances at City Center, the company moved to Avery Fisher Hall in October. No fall home has been decided on for 2011, said Rachel S. Moore, the companys executive director. Were looking at lots of different places, she said. Ms. Moore said that the one-time costs of creating sets and costumes for the Nutcracker, which is being choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky, also precluded fall performances this year. Over all Ballet Theater will stage an equal number of performances, Ms. Moore said. The Wall Street Journal reported the skipped fall weeks on Wednesday. The company will continue with its spring performances at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Sade Soldiers on Atop Billboard Chart
description: Sades Soldier of Love (Epic) is No. 1 on Billboards album chart for the third week in a row. It sold 127,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its three-week total to 820,000. Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) holds at No. 2 with 118,000 sales, and Johnny Cashs American VI: Aint No Grave (American/Lost Highway), said to be the last of Cashs prolific late sessions with Rick Rubin, opens at No. 3 with 54,000. Also on this weeks chart, the Black Eyed Peas E.N.D. (Interscope) is No. 4, with 50,000 sales, Lady Gagas Fame (Interscope) is No. 5 with 48,000, and Lil Waynes Rebirth (Cash Money/Universal) is No. 6 with 38,000.

title: End of a Chatty Era
description: After nearly 30 years of pre-Oscar interview specials, Barbara Walters will present her final one on Sunday night.

title: Bets Are Hedged for a Racing Showdown
description: The Apple Blossom Invitational potentially is a race for the ages: Rachel Alexandra, the reigning Horse of the Year, squaring off for the first time against Zenyatta, the undefeated mare and Breeders Cup Classic winner. The money is there  a $5 million purse. A neutral site has been secured, vital in this meeting of East versus West  Oaklawn Park in Arkansas.

title: Library Science
description: One day, apparently before the rise of Google Book Search, Marilyn Johnson made an odd request at the New York Public Library. She needed to find the symptoms of an imaginary illness called information sickness, which she recollected from a 1981 novel by Ted Mooney, Easy Travel to Other Planets. She couldnt find her own copy, so a team of librarians went spelunking in the stacks, wearing miners helmets, as Johnson tells it. They surfaced with a copy preserved, strangely enough, on microfilm, and soon Johnson was reading the dimly remembered passage in which a woman keels over, blood gushing from her nose and ears as she raves about disconnected facts. When the woman recovers from her fugue state, she says: I was dazzled. I couldnt tell where one thing left off and the next began.

title: Stimulus Programs That Roll at Night
description: ON a recent Thursday night in the Adams Morgan neighborhood of Washington, two D.J.s Shea Van Horn and Tommy Cornelis  were filling the basement lounge of Napoleon, a bistro, with French electro and house music. The occasion was a monthly party called Maison, and the room was packed: gay men in their 20s, a clutch of American University law students, a preening reality TV star (Paul Wharton) and Omar Popal, the 31-year-old owner of the upstairs restaurant.

title: 6 More Iranian Activists Reported Arrested
description: At least six human rights advocates were reported to have been arrested in Iran on Wednesday, dampening hopes that the government was easing its campaign of arrests ahead of the Iranian New Year on March 21.

title: HCAs Latest Surprise for Its Bondholders
description: March 5, 2:04 p.m. | Updated: HCA and another analyst have taken issue with parts of Gimme Credits analysis of HCAs bond sale. This revised post includes their comments.

title: So Whos Next? Patti Smith and Others
description: Two mature women paid the best tributes to Pete Townshends songs in The Music of the Who: 21 acts performing a selection each on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Joint Chiefs Chairman Readjusts Principles on Use of Force
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, laid out new principles Wednesday for how to use the military in meeting contemporary threats, saying that overwhelming force can be counterproductive if used recklessly.

title: Meredith Vieira Extends Today Contract
description: Meredith Vieira, a host of the Today show on NBC whose contract was set to expire in September, has extended her contract by one year, a person briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

title: A Proposal for Reining In Credit Card Fees
description: The Federal Reserve today announced a proposal that seeks to protect credit card customers from unreasonable fees for paying late or exceeding their limits.

title: Pop Singer Arrives With a Bundle of Gizmos
description: Theres not much you can say against the laser harp. At the Highline Ballroom on Tuesday night a beam of green light shot up from the floor, then fanned out into eight individual rays. The tiny synth-pop singer Little Boots, wearing a gold lam gown and face mask, played the melody of her song Earthquake by moving her hand among the streams of light; each time she blocked one, it triggered a synthesizer pitch, and she could alter its tone by lowering or raising her hand on each beam.

title: College Degrees Without Going to Class
description: Online courses have been around for nearly two decades, but enrollment has soared in recent years as more universities increase their offerings. More than 4.6 million college students (about one in four) were taking at least one online course in 2008, a 17 percent increase over 2007.

title: What Were Reading: A Customer Strikes Back and an Odd Mayoral Campaign
description: Wednesdays roundup of interesting tidbits from around the Web, selected by technology reporters and editors at The New York Times:

title: RealNetworks Drops Fight to Sell DVD Copying Software
description: RealNetworks gave up Wednesday on its battle to sell RealDVD, software that allowed consumers to easily copy the content of DVDs to their computers.

title: Soldiers Stories
description: In a nasty, dark little room beneath British Army headquarters in Cairo, a bored Lieutenant Lawrence methodically extinguishes a match between his fingers.

title: Hurtin Words
description: Sometimes its hard to be a biographer. Tammy Wynette is known as the queen of country music, a legend and a drag queen staple. The first country artist to go platinum, with more than 20 No. 1 hits, she is beloved and rightfully respected, the Elvis of the Opry, a tiny wisp of a woman who went from beauty school to record sales of more than $30 million, a Horatio Alger hero in sequins. Her appeal springs primarily from two wells: her hardscrabble story and her heartbreaking voice, an idiosyncratic, affecting warble of longing and regret. After youve read Tammy Wynette: Tragic Country Queen, Jimmy McDonoughs rollicking if reverential biography, the voice remains unimpeachable. The story, not so much.

title: Virtual Village
description: How do you write an English village novel  if you really want to do such a thing? First, you have to create a character who is a retired major. Yes, create. Who will live in a house called Rose Cottage. Oh, all right, lets make it Rose Lodge. In a village. Of course. Where the local landowner is an earl. Well settle for a lord. Who receives American visitors. In loud tweeds. And theres a golf club. Naturally.

title: Acceleration Incidents Cited on Repaired Toyotas
description: Federal regulators said Wednesday that they had received 10 reports of Toyota vehicles accelerating unexpectedly after they were repaired at dealerships.

title: U.S. Team Wont Race In Formula One in 2010
description: The first Formula One team based in the United States since the 1970s is not going to make it to the starting grid.

title: The Talk of the (Seedy Side of) Town
description: In the annals of injustice, as The New Yorker might phrase it, the obscurity into which St. Clair McKelway has fallen amounts to a literary crime. His writing for the magazine rivaled that of his far better-remembered colleagues, Joseph Mitchell and A. J. Liebling, both of whose careers he was instrumental in promoting. From 1936 to 1939, he served as The New Yorkers managing editor in charge of fact (as opposed to fiction) pieces. During those crucial years he played a major role in solidifying the magazines nonfiction style  the choreography, as Ben Yagoda describes it in About Town, his history of The New Yorker, of the extraordinary number of facts the writer had collected. Today hes all but forgotten.

title: Behind the Scenes: Altered and Out
description: 12:30 a.m., Thursday | Updated A writer identifying himself as Stepan Rudik has sent a link to the photograph in question, explaining that what was excised in the competition version was a small section of a foot that can be seen under the fighters wrapped hand. He added, I dont argue the decision of the WPP jury.

title: A Bit More on Nujood
description: I was inspired to write about Nujoods case when I read her book, but the backdrop is my growing concern about Yemen itself. As Al Qaeda finds itself under more pressure in Pakistan and Afghanistan, it may see Yemen as a nice refuge. Indeed, there are signs that that is already beginning to happen. And since the Yemeni governments authority weakens at the capitals city limits, and the president has other priorities (such as holding his country together), its not a bad spot for extremists.

title: My Leningrad, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Passing Both Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Californians Compete for a Shot at Redistricting
description: LOS ANGELES  Here in California, Democrats have just one candidate for governor (and he has already done the job), and state lawmakers from both parties seem incapable of passing even modest legislation without a meltdown.

title: Gambit in Texans Battle to Unseat the Governor
description: HOUSTON  The confetti had barely settled at the victory parties after the Texas primaries on Tuesday when the Democratic nominee for governor, Bill White, took off the gloves and went after Gov. Rick Perry.

title: Michael Foot Dies at 96; Led Britains Labour Party
description: Michael Foot, who led the British Labour Party in the early 1980s, and, after failing to broker a peace between its left and right wings, presided over its crushing defeat at the hands of Margaret Thatcher in the 1983 general election, died Wednesday at his home in Hampstead, north London. He was 96.

title: Share-a-Cab Program Draws Few Riders
description: Dalbir Singh did not know where to go on Wednesday when he arrived at the corner of East 72nd Street and Third Avenue, seeking one of the Taxi and Limousine Commissions new share-a-cab stands.

title: Dont Wait; Bid Positively
description: In Mondays column South opened two clubs, strong, artificial and forcing. North had five spades to the king and five diamonds to the king-queen. But because she and her partner had agreed that a response of two spades would guarantee at least a six-card suit, she was forced to start with two diamonds waiting. This bid usually hides zero to seven high-card points but might be made with a stronger hand when the partnership values for a positive response are not held.

title: Town Finds Good Neighbor in Nuclear Plant
description: VERNON, Vt.  A storm knocked out Kathleen Halveys power for eight hours last Wednesday, an event she found both disruptive and prescient.

title: Investigating Tiny Voices at Air Tower
description: Children love airplanes! It probably seemed like a perfectly good idea to an air traffic controller at Kennedy International Airport to bring his children to work last month  heck, this country has a whole day set aside for that sort of thing.

title: Mr. Not-Quite Isnt Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Proposes Deal on Handling of Detainees
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Lindsey Graham wants to make a deal on detainees with President Obama. If the White House agrees to the bargain, it would be a defining moment for the administration  and could transform how the government deals with terrorism suspects.

title: In Governors, the Averages Arent Good
description: If there were one story line in our endless tale of exploding governors, it would be simpler to decode. Instead, its like a political version of Clue. Mr. Spitzer in the hotel room with the hooker. Mr. Rowland in the cottage with the swag. Mr. McGreevey, well, you get the idea.

title: Ultimate Bush Insider Lifts Veil on Presidency
description: WASHINGTON  Karl Rove, the chief political adviser to President George W. Bush and architect of his two successful campaigns for the White House, says in a new memoir that Mr. Bush probably would not have invaded Iraq had he known there were no unconventional weapons there.

title: Waterworks Opens Its New Manhattan Showroom
description: IN the beginning  or at least long, long ago  there were pink toilets. Sometimes blue, sometimes maroon. And lo, Barbara Sallick  blessed be Her name among high-end developers, daughter of Samuel Grogins of the Nutmeg Plumbing Supply Company of Danbury, Conn., and wife of Robert Sallick, who worked for Her father  did look around and say, Bathrooms dont really need to be blue, pink or maroon and In Europe, they are so much more advanced.

title: House Votes to Protect Pupils Against Abusive Discipline
description: In a move to provide the first comprehensive protections for children against abusive disciplinary actions by schools, the House on Wednesday easily approved a bill to restrict the use of forcible restraint and seclusion, in which children are held down, drugged or isolated in a locked room to control their behavior.

title: Shifting Soil Threatens Homes Foundations
description: STEVEN DERSE, the owner of a corporate travel business in Nashville, cannot feel his house move, but he can hear it. Its an eerie creaking sound, he said, and it echoes throughout his two-story Georgian-style house.

title: Preparing to March Over Education Cuts
description: Ramon Quintero, a geography major at the University of California, Berkeley, hopes his 1979 Toyota mini-motor home becomes more than the place he slept in last semester to save rent money and more than just a mural on wheels.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 998 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: U.S. Fears Election Strife in Iraq Could Affect Pullout
description: WASHINGTON  The deadly suicide bombings in Iraq on Wednesday highlight the central quandary facing President Obama as he tries to fulfill his campaign pledge to end the war there: Will parliamentary elections, scheduled for Sunday, throw the country back into the sectarian strife that flared in 2004 and delay the planned American withdrawal?

title: Ads Posted on Facebook Strike Some as Off-Key
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook, the worlds biggest social network, is selling more ad spots to big companies like Wal-Mart Stores, Procter & Gamble and PepsiCo.

title: No-Child Law Is a Highlight of Hearing on Education
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of Education Arne Duncan is presiding over the rollout of the largest competitive grant program in his departments history, a vast expansion of the governments direct loan program for college students and sweeping new expenditures on failing schools, teacher quality and other big initiatives.

title: Valentine Visits Mets; Fans Ask Him to Stay
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Bobby Valentine stood on the top step of the Mets dugout at Champion Stadium, just as he had done many times before. But this time he was wearing a black track suit instead of a uniform, and he was chatting amiably with Manager Jerry Manuel.

title: The Busiest Day of N.H.L. Trading, but No Blockbusters
description: Two Olympians, defensemen Ryan Whitney of the United States and Lubomir Visnovsky of Slovakia, were dealt for each other Wednesday at the N.H.L. trade deadline. It was the busiest trading day in league history, but few significant players were involved as teams struggled to maneuver under the salary cap.

title: From Karim Rashid, a Soft-Edged Sconce With an Icy Glow
description: When the New-York based designer Karim Rashid was asked to design a sconce for ITRE, an Italian lighting manufacturer, he said, I wanted to get out of the square and cylindrical shapes.

title: Yanks Begin Auditions for Their No. 2 Hitter
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In Joe Girardis ideal lineup, the No. 2 hitter would have some speed and a high on-base percentage, and also be able to hit for power.

title: Murky Candidacy Stokes Iraqs Sectarian Fears
description: BAGHDAD  A politician widely accused of running death squads might not be expected to have an easy time running for public office.

title: Hand-Etched Tableware
description: The shapes I make evolve from what I have needed or wanted in my house, said Lisa Neimeth, a 46-year-old ceramicist in San Francisco. When she bought a 60-inch round dining table, she said, she thought a Lazy Susan would be a worthwhile addition. But shopping for one proved to be dismaying. They were pretty tacky, made of laminated wood or plastic, she said. So she made her own, hand-etching drawings on them, or pressing found objects like rocks and branches into the material as she does with her tableware, below. Her ceramics range in price from $15 for a bowl, 5 inches in diameter, to $300 for a Lazy Susan, 20 inches in diameter. Information: (415) 682-0599 or lneimeth.com.

title: A New Home for Secondhand Rose, a Vintage Wallpaper Shop
description: Suzanne Lipschutzs vintage-wallpaper shop, Secondhand Rose, has been a fixture of downtown Manhattan since 1965. Now, thanks to the recession, it has moved uptown  and upstairs  to a fifth-floor shop on Fifth Avenue.

title: A New Sample-Sale Web Site
description: Snappy Tuna covers the whole experience, from prepping a meal to getting it out the door, said Marcus Greinke of his new Web site, the latest in a growing number built on the sample-sale model. Snappy Tuna specializes in well-known kitchenware and tabletop brands that are discounted up to 60 percent off retail prices, for three days only. Items for sale will include specialty foods, espresso machines and Le Creuset cookware (Menus Mini Magma Stone candleholders, above, will sell for $20, compared with $43 at retail). The site is being introduced on March 20, when users can sign up for a free membership and invite friends to do the same. If one of those friends then makes a purchase, Snappy Tuna will issue the referring user a $25 credit. Information: snappytuna.com.

title: My Buildings Protocol, Altered in a Flash
description: LITTLE LOUIE was a star at my Upper West Side apartment building, where he worked as a doorman. Every day, he parked his red Harley-Davidson outside the front entrance. I always enjoyed looking for it as I walked down the block, but last Thanksgiving, it wasnt there.

title: Repeal of Dont Ask, Dont Tell Policy Filed in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, independent of Connecticut, introduced a bill on Wednesday to repeal the ban on openly gay service members in the military, but at a hearing later in the day Republican lawmakers questioned why lifting the ban was necessary.

title: Optimistic Mariners Ready for Run at Angels
description: PEORIA, Ariz.  No teams hit more home runs last season than the Yankees and the Philadelphia Phillies, who met in the World Series. Cliff Lee, who won twice in that series, understands that reality.

title: My Last Letter From Portugal: U.S. Women Win Algarve Cup
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States womens national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp in Carson, Calif. Averbuch has been filing to the Goal blog during her trip to Portugal.

title: Upper Deck Settles Suit
description: Upper Deck will pay Major League Baseball Properties a substantial but undisclosed amount of money for issuing three card sets since last year without a license, according to the settlement of a federal lawsuit. The company will also pay baseball $2.4 million to settle previous debts.

title: Many Potential Successors if Rangel Retires
description: Representative Charles B. Rangels decision to relinquish the coveted chairmanship of the House Ways and Means Committee has raised a once-unthinkable possibility: that after 39 years in Congress, he will not seek re-election this year.

title: Japan Offers New Plan in Okinawa Dispute
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government has approached United States officials with a tentative proposal for resolving a festering dispute over an American air base in Okinawa, the Japanese news media reported on Thursday.

title: Sets for the Artist Marina Abramovics Dramatic Life
description: FOR Marina Abramovic, a 63-year-old Yugoslavian-born performance artist, the star is a potent symbol, and it makes frequent appearances in her work. Ms. Abramovic, whose retrospective, Marina Abramovic: The Artist is Present, opens this month at the Museum of Modern Art, constructed and set a large star on fire in an early piece, lying down inside it. During another widely publicized performance, she carved a star around her navel in what she describes as an anti-Communist act.

title: Sidney Crosbys Medal-Winning Gear Is Missing
description: PITTSBURGH  It is not certain who has possession of Bobby Thomsons Shot Heard Round the World from 1951. The whereabouts of the ball that Wilt Chamberlain used to score his 100th point in 1962 remains in dispute.

title: Darwin Foes Add Warming to Targets
description: Critics of the teaching of evolution in the nations classrooms are gaining ground in some states by linking the issue to global warming, arguing that dissenting views on both scientific subjects should be taught in public schools.

title: Concerns Over Metal on Metal Hip Implants
description: Some of the nations leading orthopedic surgeons have reduced or stopped use of a popular category of artificial hips amid concerns that the devices are causing severe tissue and bone damage in some patients, often requiring replacement surgery within a year or two.

title: Upper Deck Settles Suit but Will Distribute Cards
description: Upper Deck will pay Major League Baseball Properties a substantial but undisclosed amount of money for issuing three-card sets since last year without a license, according to the settlement of a lawsuit announced Wednesday. The card company will also pay baseball $2.4 million to settle previous debts.

title: As Use of  Metal-on-Metal Hip  Implants Grows, Studies Raise Concerns
description: About a decade ago, just as a new generation of metal-on-metal artificial hips were starting to be used, some studies noted their potential to produce high levels of metallic ions, causing what were thought to be allergic reactions in some patients.

title: Divorced Before Puberty
description: Its hard to imagine that there have been many younger divorces  or braver ones  than a pint-size third grader named Nujood Ali.

title: Failing to Fall
description: The narrator of Chaucers poem, The Book of the Duchess, cannot sleep. As his fitful thoughts come and go, he lies awake. He hasnt slept for so long, he fears he may die of insomnia. But what is the reason for his sleeplessness? Myselven can not telle why, he says.

title: Tables and Turkish Towels for Sale
description: As the Conran Shops move downtown to ABC Carpet & Home gets closer, the discounts get steeper, and starting today, all sale items will be marked down even further, up to 75 percent off the retail price, until the store closes on March 15 (Vincent Martinezs Sis dining table, originally $1,850, is $463; a black Perspex console table, originally $2,250, is $563; Tod Brachers side tables, below, originally about $1,000, are $250); 407 East 59th Street (First Avenue), (212) 755-9079 or conranusa.com.

title: Mariners Counting On Milton Bradley
description: PEORIA, Ariz.  The Seattle Mariners won 85 games last year while scoring the fewest runs in the American League and pitching to the lowest earned run average. They are built for their spacious ballpark, Safeco Field, with outstanding defense as their primary strength.

title: Bloggingheads: G.M. vs. Goldman
description: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Timothy Carney of the Washington Examiner discuss government bailouts.

title: Book on Spitzers Downfall Sets Off Angry Replies
description: ALBANY  Nearly two years ago, a disconsolate Eliot Spitzer opened the door of his Fifth Avenue apartment and greeted his senior adviser and old friend, Lloyd Constantine, with these words: Welcome to a Greek tragedy.

title: Fears of Lawlessness Prompt Show of Force in Chile
description: LOS NGELES, Chile  At night, residents huddle around bonfires and guard their streets with torches and sticks, ready to repel outsiders who might try to break into their darkened homes.

title: L.A. Consequential
description: LOS ANGELES  Not since the Beach Boys were in peach fuzz and crew cuts has it been so safe to live and play in the City of Angels. Believe it: you are more likely to be murdered in Columbus, Ohio, or Tulsa, Okla., than in the nations second most populous city.

title: Former Pakistani Officer Embodies a Policy Puzzle
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  With his white turban, untrimmed beard and worn army jacket, the man known uniformly here by his nom de guerre, Col. Imam, is a particular Pakistani enigma.

title: Honda Classic Back Atop the Pecking Order
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Not in the last three decades, since the corpulent entertainer known as the Great One was tooling around the fairways of the Inverrary Country Club in a golf cart equipped with a wet bar, has there been a pro-am day like the one Wednesday at the Honda Classic at the PGA National Resort and Spa.

title: Lawsuits Renew Questions on Immigrant Detention
description: When the Obama administration vowed to overhaul immigration detention last year, its promise of more humane treatment and accountability was spurred in part by the harrowing treatment of two detainees who died in the Bush years.

title: White House Offers Bill to Restrict Big Banks Actions
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration put forward legislation on Wednesday to rein in the size and scope of the nations largest banks. But the proposal faces strong resistance in Congress, where lawmakers have shown little appetite for adding to the prolonged debate on overhauling financial regulations.

title: Justices Weigh Claims Over Torture in Somalia
description: WASHINGTON  After the Supreme Court heard an hour of technical arguments Wednesday about whether foreign officials may be sued in the United States over torture claims, one of the plaintiffs in the case stood on the steps outside and recalled what had happened to him in Somalia in the 1980s.

title: Reprieve Sought for Space Shuttles
description: Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, introduced a bill in Congress on Wednesday to extend operations of NASAs space shuttles until replacement rockets become available. The bill would also direct NASA to continue developing a new generation of rockets and spacecraft, which could include the Constellation program that President Obama has proposed canceling. The shuttles are scheduled to be retired this fall. They were to be replaced by rockets and a crew capsule being developed under the Constellation program, which was to return astronauts to the Moon. The Obama administration, instead, has proposed turning to commercial companies for transport to Earth orbit.

title: Wallace Stevens in New York
description: Before Wallace Stevens became a great poet known for his "verbal ebullience and New England spareness," he was a journalist beating the pavement for the New York Evening Post. Those early years spent in the city informed his later work, and, beginning today, you can see how when New York University and the Poetry Society of America present "Wallace Stevens, New York, and Modernism." The conference, which runs through March 6 and is free and open to the public, includes readings, talks and presentations by literary luminaries like Mark Strand, Edward Hirsch, Elizabeth Willis and many more.

title: Collecting Like Koons
description: Not all of us can amass an art collection like Jeff Koons. The pop artist has works by Manet, Picasso and Poussin piled up, salon-style, on the walls of his Upper East Side home, not to mention an 1873 Courbet over his flat-screen television. But for those aspiring collectors working on a slightly smaller scale, the Guggenheim is the place to be tonight. The museum is auctioning off 200 works by artists, architects and designers from the exhibition "Contemplating the Void: Interventions in the Guggenheim Museum." The auction, a finale to the museum's 50th anniversary celebrations, will benefit the museum's exhibition programming. First preview the work and then take in a performance by Animal Collective, the artist Danny Perez and Transverse Temporal Gyrus, featuring original recorded music created specifically for this event. The late show at 9 p.m. is sold out but there are still tickets available for the early show at 4:30 p.m. The auction items will be sold online from March 4 through 18 at charitybuzz.com/guggenheim.

title: Gimme an H
description: "It's easy to feel alive with possibility, or delusional, at the new Herms store for men, which welcomes wealth in all its glory and repugnance," writes Jon Caramanica. This store, which opened last month across Madison Avenue from the flagship, "is a thoughtful balance of expert craftsmanship and luxury kitsch, a four-floor clubhouse that somehow manages the feel of a high-end department store." Mr. Caramanica suggests picking a desired persona, say a disheveled and raffish Julian Schnabel or Robert Redford in "Out of Africa," and making the fantasy a reality with a few choice pieces, like a rough linen-cotton blend blazer with soft suede beneath the collar. "Soon I was writing scenes of my new life in my head, most ending with a quick nuzzle from Olatz as I come in the door at Palazzo Chupi, before we sneak upstairs for an assignation on her signature crest-appliqud Egyptian cotton sheets." The store is filled with other aspirational items. "Most dazzling is one of the store's showpieces, a chocolate leather baseball jacket perforated in an H pattern, wearable by rappers and Mediterranean tourists, but probably not you."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 19 about the tracing of a series of online attacks on Google and other American corporations to computers at two educational institutions in China misstated I.B.M.s relationship to an international computer programming competition recently won by students at one of the institutions, Shanghai Jiaotong University. The competition, known as the Battle of the Brains, has been sponsored by I.B.M. since 1997, but its history dates back to 1970. It was not organized by I.B.M.

title: Its Polluted, but the Canal Is Home, and Inspiration
description: The rain had stopped; the streets were empty. A block from the Gowanus Canal, a woman called Terri squinted into the headlights of passing cars, searched for clients and found none.

title: The Democrats Choice
description: Republicans lock-step opposition to comprehensive health care reform seems to be as much a matter of politics as principle. But either way, they have made clear that there is no dialogue or any possible compromise that will persuade them to change their minds.

title: Political Policing
description: The controversy swirling around Gov. David Paterson has fallen on a long-festering problem in New Yorks state government: the State Police. Whatever else comes out of this political mess, the Legislature must move decisively to remake the department, which sometimes has seemed as much an instrument of cover-up and vendetta as a functioning law-enforcement agency.

title: Ex-Chairman Rangel, Pushed From Below
description: Representative Charles Rangel had a bit of a surprise to offer as he grudgingly surrendered his gavel as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. The powerful lawmaker, admonished for breaking House ethics rules, insisted that he first told Speaker Nancy Pelosi of his willingness to step aside months ago when the investigation began into various allegations of misbehavior.

title: Cleaning the Gowanus
description: The Environmental Protection Agencys decision to designate Brooklyns Gowanus Canal as a Superfund site clears the way for a federally mandated cleanup of one of the nations most polluted waterways. Mayor Michael Bloombergs administration had proposed a voluntary cleanup in hopes of avoiding the Superfund label. The federal approach is better  slower perhaps, but more comprehensive and far more likely to get done.

title: How to Treat Those Who Aid Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Backlog of Mining Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dutch in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: The Paterson Scandal and Domestic Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Speech for Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Health Insurance Mandate With a Choice
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: And the Gender-Neutral Oscar Goes To...
description: Pasadena, Calif.

title: New Yorks Choking Loophole
description: NEW YORKERS have heard a stream of grave accusations this week that our governor tried to obstruct a domestic assault case against his aide David Johnson. But one element of this story has received less attention than it deserves: After Mr. Johnsons girlfriend called 911 and reported that he had ripped off her clothes, thrown her against a dresser and choked her, Mr. Johnson was not even arrested.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the outcome of the Republican primary for governor of Texas described incorrectly the location of a polling place, Thomas C. Clark High School. It is in San Antonio; it is not in a wealthy suburb.

title: Traders Seek Out the Next Greece in an Ailing Europe
description: Is Spain the next Greece? Or Italy? Or Portugal?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the stabbing death of Aregawi Gebre-Yohannes, an opposition candidate in Ethiopias coming elections, referred incorrectly to Birtukan Mideksa, an opposition leader, who is serving a life sentence on charges of fomenting violence in the aftermath of the disputed 2005 elections. Birtukan Mideksa is a woman.

title: Literally
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Anything can happen in a Thursday puzzle, and todays looks ominous right from the start. The grid has an unusually high count of 40 black squares. Is this some wildly original high-concept puzzle that will take ages to figure out?

title: Story Prize Is Awarded to Mueenuddin
description: The Pakistani-American author Daniyal Mueenuddin was named the winner of the Story Prize on Wednesday night for his collection In Other Rooms, Other Wonders, the awards organizers said in a news release. Mr. Mueenuddins work, a series of eight interconnected stories about the power dynamics surrounding the estate of a landowner in Pakistan, was chosen from among 78 books entered by 53 publishers and imprints. Mr. Mueenuddin receives $20,000 with the prize; awards of $5,000 each went to the finalists Victoria Patterson, for her collection Drift, and Wells Tower, for Everything Ravaged, Everything Burned. The Story Prize, given annually to a collection of short fiction written in English, has previously been awarded to Edwidge Danticat, Jim Shepard and Tobias Wolff, among other authors.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a surprising reversal by the education historian Diane Ravitch of almost every position she once took on American schooling misstated the number of books she has either written or edited since leaving government in 1993. It is 18, not 5. (That is how many she has written.)

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about the United States victory in the four-man bobsled at the Vancouver Games, its first gold medal in the event in 62 years, misidentified the pilot of the team that won Olympic gold in 1948, in St. Moritz, Switzerland. He was Francis Tyler  not Patrick Henry Martin, a pusher on the sled.

title: Corrections
description: An appraisal on Dec. 31 about David Levine, the caricaturist for The New York Review of Books who died on Dec. 29, misidentified the object the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein is shown kicking away in a Levine drawing from 1969. It is an academic cap, not a book. (A reader pointed out the error in a recent e-mail message.)

title: Westchester Snowstorm Is Bonanza for Tree Removers
description: OSSINING, N.Y.  The unusually prolonged, nasty storm across Westchester County last week took an immediate toll. People and businesses were left without power, homeowners saw their property damaged and commuters had to navigate mazes of blocked roads.

title: Trusted Adviser or Stock Pusher? Finance Bill May Not Settle It
description: You have probably seen the television commercial, the one where you seem to be watching an intimate conversation between family members. But at the end, you learn that the conversation was actually between a broker and his client.

title: New Panel on Charter May Revisit Term Limits
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday rolled out a roster of longtime loyalists, educators, political operatives and community leaders to serve on a 15-member charter review commission that is expected to alter the citys term limits law.

title: Corrections
description: The Vital Statistics column on Tuesday, about rising birthrates, misstated the percentage of single babies born prematurely in the year under study and referred incorrectly to premature births among twins and triplets. Among single babies born in the United States in 2007, 1 in 9 (11.1 percent) were premature  not 2 in 10. And 1 of 8 twins, and 1 of 3 triplets, were born very prematurely (before 32 weeks of gestation)  not prematurely (before 37 weeks).

title: Great Fun With the Guessing Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It has been a good week for the LeBron James tea-leaf-reading club, chock full of hints, innuendo and breathless intrigue.

title: Russia: Leniency for Journalists Killer
description: Ibragim D. Yevloyev, a police officer convicted of fatally shooting an opposition journalist in August 2008, began serving a two-year sentence of house arrest on Wednesday after Ingushetias Supreme Court ruled that the original penalty, two years in a penal colony, was too harsh. The decision infuriated friends of the victim, Magomed Y. Yevloyev, and prompted a protest from the Committee to Protect Journalists.

title: Roster Switch Lifts Knicks, by Leaps and Bounds
description: Dismantling the Knicks after this season has always been the plan. But even Coach Mike DAntoni seemed a bit shell-shocked recently when discussing his teams inept play.

title: Shutting Off of Sprinklers Is Cited in Fire at Courthouse
description: Part of the sprinkler system in the basement of a Manhattan courthouse was illegally disconnected, allowing a fire that erupted there to grow before firefighters arrived to control it, the authorities said Wednesday.

title: At Death-Threat Trial, Internet Radio Host Says F.B.I. Encouraged Rants
description: The family of a federal judge had just been brutally murdered. And as Harold C. Turner remembered it, it seemed an opportune time for the F.B.I. to make use of his secret role as a confidential informant.

title: Editors Note
description: A commentary published on Feb. 7, 2008, in the Arts section discussed the impact of the recently deceased Maharishi Mahesh Yogi on the Beatles and their music. The article mentioned in passing Alexis Mardas, known as Magic Alex, who worked on various inventions for the Beatles in the late 1960s and traveled with the group to the Maharishis ashram in India in 1968. While expressing skepticism about his work as an inventor during that period, the article did not accuse Mr. Mardas of engaging in fraudulent dealings or criminality, either then or at any subsequent time.

title: Corrections
description: EDITORS' NOTE

title: For Movie Stars, the Big Money Is Now Deferred
description: LOS ANGELES  When Wolfgang Puck lays out the annual post-Oscar banquet in Hollywood on Sunday, he might want to think about doggie bags.

title: Canada: Parliament Reopens
description: Canadas Parliament, temporarily shut down two months ago by Prime Minister Stephen Harper, resumed work on Wednesday. Mr. Harper had said he wanted to recalibrate his governments economic agenda. But opposition parties charged that Mr. Harper shut down the legislature to avoid uncomfortable questions about Canadas treatment of Afghan detainees and to concentrate on gaining favorable publicity for the Winter Olympics that ended in Vancouver, British Columbia, on Sunday. The shutdown killed all legislation making its way through the parliamentary process. The new session began with Governor General Michalle Jean reading a speech outlining the governments broad legislative agenda, which includes spending cuts.

title: Controversial Architect Is Barred by City
description: Robert M. Scarano Jr., a Brooklyn architect who has long been criticized by community groups for flouting zoning laws, was barred by the Department of Buildings on Wednesday from filing construction plans  threatening, at least temporarily, his ability to work as an architect in the city.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 3, 2010

title: For a Restaurateur to Be, a Vegetable Garden That Wont
description: In the beginning, before fish, before man, there was a garden. And the earth brought forth vegetation, beautiful to behold, sustenance for the body. And it was good.

title: Honduras: Letter on Opponent Attacks
description: Human Rights Watch said Wednesday that attacks on opponents of last years coup in Honduras have continued since a newly elected government took office. In a letter to the Honduran attorney general, Luis Alberto Rub, the human rights group said that three people had been killed and eight had been detained and attacked over the past month in what appeared to be politically motivated episodes. Most of the victims were members of the National Popular Resistance Front, a coalition of labor and other social groups that protested the coup. Human Rights Watch said that a unit of the attorney generals office was researching some of the cases, but said that investigators had faced several obstacles in the past to investigate cases of alleged human rights abuses.

title: Rodriguezs Return to Field Clouded by Questions Off It
description: A few minutes before the Yankees first spring training game Wednesday, their starting lineup was introduced at Steinbrenner Field in Tampa, Fla. Derek Jeter came first, followed by Curtis Granderson and Mark Teixeira.

title: Plenty of Ads to Go Around on Oscar Night
description: SOME months back, with the national mood more Up in the Air than Up, there were doubts about ABCs ability to sell commercial time during its presentation of the coming 82nd annual Academy Awards. Those worries were exacerbated by the low tune-in  36.9 million viewers  for the 2009 show.

title: Leaving the Dorm Behind
description: Inside the bachelor pad that was transformed from Craigslist mishmash to sophisticated living space.

title: From Bachelor Pad to an Adults Home, for $8,000
description: COLIN KELLY, a 2008 Columbia law school graduate, had furnished the living room in his apartment in the financial district much the same way he did his student housing. I dont get anything until I need it, Mr. Kelly, 27, told this reporter on a visit to his apartment not long ago. And when I get it, I get the cheapest thing.

title: Belatedly, Voter Explains Why He Chose Cabrera Over Mauer for M.V.P.
description: PEORIA, Ariz.  When the Twins Joe Mauer accepted his American League Most Valuable Player award at the New York baseball writers dinner in January, he joked in his speech that he should have had a better series in Seattle.

title: Gene Chenault, Who Changed Rock Radio, Dies at 90
description: Gene Chenault, who with his business partner, Bill Drake, reshaped rock radio in the 1960s with prepackaged programming that delivered more music and fewer commercials to hundreds of stations, creating the automated format common today, died on Feb. 23 in Tarzana, Calif. He was 90 and lived in Encino, Calif.

title: F.D.A. Cracks Down on Nestl and Others Over Health Claims on Labels
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday released 17 warning letters to food manufacturers, making good on a vow to crack down on misleading labels on food packages.

title: Theodore Cross Dies at 86, a Champion of Civil Rights
description: Theodore L. Cross, a publisher, investor and entrepreneur who also had parallel careers as a writer on civil rights issues and a noted photographer of birds, died on Sunday in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 86 and had homes in Princeton, N.J., and on Sanibel Island, Fla., and Nantucket.

title: Arnold Beichman, Political Analyst, Dies at 96
description: Arnold Beichman, a prominent political analyst, author and newspaper columnist known for being ardently anti-Communist, died Feb. 17 in Pasadena, Calif. He was 96 and lived in Naramata, British Columbia.

title: Vieira Agrees to Continue With Today Till Fall 2011
description: NBCs prime time is still a problem, but at least the network can rest assured that its morning show is safe for another year.

title: Robert Crafton III, Bassist and Rapper, Dies at 47
description: Robert Crafton III, a bassist, songwriter and rapper whose rhythms and rhymes helped the 1980s hip-hop group Newcleus redefine the sound of electro-pop, died on Feb. 23 in Brooklyn. He was 47.

title: European Court Ready to Hear Yukos Case
description: MOSCOW  Yukos Oil had a poor track record defending its rights in Russian courts. Once the largest company in the country, it fell out of favor with the government of Vladimir V. Putin, then the president, in 2003 and within four years had been bankrupted and sold at auction.

title: Beware: Activists Are on the Hunt
description: Activist shareholders are back  and for good reason. As the proxy season heats up, pot-stirrers like Carl Icahn and Ron Burkle are raising a fuss at companies like Genzyme and Barnes & Noble. Easy pickings from the credit bubbles bursting may be gone. But the activists remain a formidable bunch.

title: Word of the Day | snicker
description: snicker \sni-kr\ noun and verb

title: Cautious Steps Expected on Bank Liquidity in Europe
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank is likely to outline additional steps on Thursday to siphon off more of the huge amounts of cash it provided to banks during the financial crisis, while carefully trying to avoid upsetting the still-fragile system and economic recovery.

title: Traders Seek Europes Next Greece
description: Is Spain the next Greece? Or Italy? Or Portugal?

title: Mall Operator Given Extra Time to Reorganize
description: A federal judge on Wednesday granted General Growth Properties four more months of exclusivity to file its bankruptcy reorganization plan, giving the company, a mall operator, some breathing room as it fends off an unsolicited $10 billion takeover bid from the Simon Property Group.

title: U.S. Team Wont Race in Formula One in 2010
description: USF1, which was to be the first Formula One team based in the United States since the 1970s, will not make it to the starting grid. USF1, based in Charlotte, N.C., was granted a franchise last summer in the expectation that it would begin competition in 2010, but it has been shut down less than two weeks before the start of the season. A request by USF1s founder, Ken Anderson, to retain its franchise but delay entry until 2011 was rejected by F.I.A., Formula Ones governing body.

title: Who Helped When the Great Ship(s) Went Down?
description: WHO thought only of themselves and who were more likely to help women and children among the people on board when the famous ships the Titanic, above left, and the Lusitania, above right, went down?

title: In Iraq, Early Vote Is Marred by Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq opened its polls early on Thursday for hundreds of thousands of soldiers and police officers responsible for protecting the countrys electorate, and they came under assault themselves.

title: Moderate Quake Rattles Taiwan
description: BEIJING  A moderate earthquake shook southern Taiwan on Thursday, knocking out electric service to more than half a million customers and causing a fire in a textile factory, although injuries appeared to be limited, government agencies said.

title: 2009 Paycheck for Wellss Chief More Than Doubles
description: Wells Fargo, the fourth largest United States bank by assets, paid its chief executive, John Stumpf, compensation worth $21.3 million for 2009, a package that probably makes him the highest-paid American bank executive, according to materials filed with regulators, Reuters reported.

title: White House Offers Bill to Restrict Big Banks Actions
description: The Obama administration put forward legislation on Wednesday to rein in the size and scope of the nations largest banks. But the proposal faces strong resistance in Congress, where lawmakers have shown little appetite for adding to the prolonged debate on overhauling financial regulations, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: Sony Researches 3D
description: The development of high definition TV didnt need much research to determine if consumers would like it; if the price was right, who wouldnt want to watch a sharper TV image?

title: Trusted Adviser or Stock Pusher? Reform May Not Settle It
description: You have probably seen the television commercial, the one where you seem to be watching an intimate conversation between family members. But at the end, you learn that the conversation was actually between a broker and his client.

title: Cautious Steps Expected on Bank Liquidity in Europe
description: The European Central Bank is likely to outline additional steps on Thursday to siphon off more of the huge amounts of cash it provided to banks during the financial crisis, while carefully trying to avoid upsetting the still-fragile system and economic recovery, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

title: MySpace Co-Founder Buys MindJolt
description: For his second act, MySpace co-founder Chris DeWolfe, who resigned as chief executive. of the social networking platform last April, is sticking with the social sphere.

title: Beware: Activists on the Hunt?
description: Activist shareholders are back  and for good reason, Reuters Breakingviews says. As the proxy season heats up, pot-stirrers like Carl C. Icahn and Ron Burkle are raising a fuss at companies like Genzyme and Barnes & Noble. Easy pickings from the credit bubbles bursting may be gone. But the activists remain a formidable bunch.

title: SmartDate Hooks Up With V.C.s
description: SmartDate.com, a social dating site, has attracted $2.2 million from 360 Capital Partners, PaidContent reported.

title: China Says It Is Slowing Down Military Spending
description: BEIJING  Chinas official military budget will rise by just 7.5 percent in 2010, a government spokesman said Thursday, a rate that is about half the official increase in recent years and the first to fall below 10 percent since 1989.

title: Mesofacts
description: Facts (such as population size) that change gradually over time.Writing for The Boston Globe, Samuel Arbesman introduced readers to a third kind of fact in between those that are fixed (the height of Everest) and those in constant flux (the temperature): facts that change slowly.

title: Greece Embarks on New Debt Issues
description: Greeces debt agency announced Thursday that it would issue 8 billion euros in bonds with a coupon of 6.1 percent to mature in 2015, a day after its government announced new austerity measures worth 4.8 billion euros to battle its rampant deficit.

title: Will Elliotts Novell Offer Lure Other Bidders?
description: A Novell buyout is long overdue, Breakingviews says. The software makers shares have languished for 20 years, yet it generates healthy profit and has no debt.

title: Peugeot Will Not Take a Stake in Mitsubishi
description: The French carmaker PSA Peugeot Citron will not take a stake in Mitsubishi Motors of Japan, the companies said Wednesday, but will continue seeking ways to cooperate.

title: Showcase: An African Panorama
description: Take a generous serving of fresh art. Season liberally with food.

title: European Court Ready to Hear Yukos Case
description: Yukos Oil had a poor track record defending its rights in Russian courts. Once the largest company in the country, it fell out of favor with the government of Vladimir V. Putin, then the president, in 2003 and within four years had been bankrupted and sold at auction.

title: Power Cuts From Drought Will Hit Manila
description: MANILA  This capital city and several neighboring provinces will experience blackouts in the coming days as the country grapples with a drought that has devastated more than a dozen provinces, drying up rivers and reducing the water levels in lakes behind hydroelectric dams.

title: Its Not Easy Being Green
description: Video | Insect eludes frog in slow-motion:

title: Have You Lost Faith in Government?
description: Several scandals about public officials have broken lately, amid an already-fraught political climate. Do such scandals undermine your faith in government?

title: In Europe, a Meeting With Banks Over Default Swaps
description: Raising the possibility that there were inherent problems in the market for credit default swaps, the European Commission said Wednesday that a meeting would soon be called to discuss the swaps and their links to sovereign debt.

title: Rubenstein to Succeed Schwarzman at Kennedy
description: 7:12 a.m. | Updated Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chief of Blackstone Group, is passing a philanthropic baton to rival private equity chief, David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder and managing director of the Carlyle Group, The New York Timess Robin Pogrebin writes.

title: Pearson Said to Shortlist Bidders for I.D.C.
description: Pearson, the British publishing group, has shortlisted three private equity teams and one trade player as bidders for the financial market data provider Interactive Data Corporation, The Financial Times reported.

title: Zale Puts 12 New York Leases Up For Sale
description: Zale is looking to sell the leases on as many as 12 of its New York City jewelry stores in an apparent move to shore up its finances, Reuters reported.

title: Facebook in No Rush For I.P.O., Report Says
description: Facebooks chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, is in no rush to take the popular social-networking site public, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: USF1 Dream Definitely Over  For the Moment
description: The Fdration Internationale de lAutomobile, which governs the Formula One series, has now announced it clearly: the USF1 team will not make it to the grid this year. It may not even make it next year. The F.I.A. will start a process to open a grid spot to a team next year. Indeed, that means that if USF1 considers trying for next year, it will likely have competition from Stefan GP.

title: A Grittier Side of Paris, from Doisneaus Lens
description: The line wraps around the block as what seems like every Frenchman in the city waits to see the work of the bard of picturesque Paris  otherwise known as the beloved French photographer Robert Doisneau  at the Fondation Henri Cartier-Bresson (2, impasse Lebouis, 75014; 33-1-56-80-27-00; henricartierbresson.org).

title: Greece Moves Ahead With Bond Sale
description: Greece said Thursday that it was planning to offer new 10-year benchmark bonds to refinance its huge public debt, in a move that will test the governments  and the European Unions  credibility with investors.

title: Hong Kong Exchange Says 4Q Net Profit Up 3%
description: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing, or HKEx, the worlds second-largest exchange operator by market value, reported lower-than-expected quarterly earnings and warned of intense competition around the world, Reuters said.

title: Touching the Wi-Fi Network
description: Q.

title: WaMu Shareholders Push for Annual Meeting
description: Shareholders of Washington Mutual have filed a complaint against the savings bank holding company for not convening an annual shareholders meeting for nearly two years, Reuters reported, citing court documents.

title: State Street Pays Departing Chief $5.4 Million
description: Directors of State Street paid the departing chief executive, Ronald Logue, $5.4 million as the cash portion of his incentive compensation for last year, the company said in a securities filing on Wednesday.

title: Nortel Gets O.K. to Sell Division to Genband
description: Nortel Networks has been cleared to sell nearly all of its carrier voice over Internet protocol (VoIP) and Application Solutions business globally to Genband for $282 million, The Associated Press reported.

title: Brain Science vs. Criminal Law
description: Todays idea: Advances in neuroscience put it increasingly in conflict with criminal law: If all our mental states can ultimately be reduced to neurophysiological conditions, and there is really no such thing as free will, how can people be held accountable for crimes?

title: American Idol: The Top 10 Women
description: Like Willis Reed at Madison Square Garden in 1970, Crystal Bowersox emerged during the introductory segment of Wednesday nights American Idol, an apparition-turned-real that held promise for the rest of the night. On Tuesday, shed been hospitalized, and it wasnt clear if shed be able to perform. Idol executives said that if she couldnt pull it off, shed be eliminated  the fair decision, but for a season already on the brink of mediocrity, a potentially devastating one.

title: TV Industry Faces Drastic LED Shortage
description: According to a new report from the iSuppli research firm, the television industry will soon experience an acute undersupply of LEDs, the solid-state lighting source used in LCD TVs to create superior video imagery compared to standard LCD TVs, which use fluorescent lamps.

title: Why, Exactly, Are Big Banks Bad?
description: Simon Johnson is a professor at M.I.T.s Sloan School of Management and a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.

title: Prudential and A.I.G. Said to Outline Cuts
description: Any job losses from Prudentials planned $35.5 billion acquisition of the American International Groups Asian insurance arm will be mainly in back-office operations and not among sales forces, the companies chiefs told staff in Asia, sources informed Reuters.

title: Elpida Snags Some of Spansions Flash Assets
description: Elpida Memory, the Japanese maker of memory chips, said Thursday that it had agreed to buy some of Spansions flash-chip technology assets, including its research and development facility in Milan and intellectual property rights, Bloomberg News reported.

title: 5 Easy Ways to Learn Grammar With The New York Times
description: For our first guest post, weve invited the good people at Grammarlogues, a software- and Web-based tool founded on the premise that grammar matters most when it has meaning beyond a set of memorized rules, to write about ways to use The Times to bring grammar lessons to life. Come tell us how you make grammar come alive, below!

title: Stampede Kills Scores in India
description: NEW DELHI  Thousands of villagers who came to a popular ashram in northern India for a free meal on Thursday were caught in a stampede, which left more than 60 dead.

title: Literary Mourning: Thoughts on Barry Hannah
description: Its strange, the way we mourn our writers. We react to the news of their passing, typically, by rushing out to buy their books. Volumes that have sat on shelves for years, gathering dust and perhaps remainder stickers, are suddenly carried off in stacks. For many writers, especially those in midcareer or of midrange repute, death is the best (and last) great sales push they ever get. I like to think of the posthumous book purchase as an example of what Raymond Carver called a small good thing, offered up as consolation and condolence for those yet living, part of the same chain of motive that fills homes in mourning with casseroles and pies.

title: Court Rules Against UBS Investors in Madoff Case
description: A Luxembourg court ruled on Thursday that investors who lost money to Bernard L. Madoff through a fund set up by UBS cannot seek compensation directly from the Swiss bank, Reuters reported.

title: Can Wild Bison Repopulate the Plains?
description: After three years of meetings and study, a broad array of conservation groups, government scientists and other experts on North American wildlife policy have produced a road map for restoring some large free-roaming populations of bison in the North American plains. The hurdles are many, with one of the biggest simply finding ways to acquire broad stretches of land that can accommodate the wandering species. Another is consolidating a maze of local, state and federal policies that treat the animals in different ways. Many Western states, for instance, classify bison as livestock and not wildlife, the report authors say, hampering how they can be managed in the wild. Heres the full report on restoring bison. (The video above is courtesy of the Wildlife Conservation Society.)

title: Toyota Back on Insurance Institutes Top Safety Picks List

description: Increased Fees Help Poor Students | Steve Boilard of the California Legislative Analysts Office said that university fee increases allow subsidy of needy students. Students of California State University and the University of California whose families earn at least $70,000 annually are footing the bill that makes it possible for those earning less to pay no tuition. On Thursday, students, teachers and others will protest budget cuts and fee hikes around the state. At some elementary schools in San Francisco, parents plan to take their children out of class to participate. [The San Jose Mercury News, SF Public Press]

title: Istithmar Cedes Times Square Building to Danske Bank
description: Istithmar World, a unit of Dubai World, has handed over a prime New York residential building to Danske Bank after failing to pay its mortgage, a daily in the emirates reported on Wednesday. It was the loss of Istithmars second property in Manhattan since December.

In addition, R.I.M. did not sue Sharp over patent infringement; Kodak was named in the suit.

title: Balenciaga: Domestic Studies
description: At the start of his career at Balenciaga, in the late 90s, Nicolas Ghesquiere was often fascinated by sports and science fiction, childhood hobbies. Then he explored the couture traditions of the houses founder, Cristbal Balenciaga. In recent years, older and more mature, he has been captivated by images of the future, sometimes blending them with the past. Along the way he established separate lines, for knits, silks and limited editions, that helped to make Balenciaga profitable, but when it comes to the collections he presents in Paris, there has almost always been a sense of a designer free to create. That was again the invigorating experience this morning at the Htel de Crillon, on a specially installed white laboratory floor, where Mr. Ghesquiere showed a highly textured collection that looked well beyond the fall of 2010.

title: Germany Sentences 4 in Terror Case

title: Feeling For  Fancy Footwork

Maria Cornejo, for example, teamed up with George Esquivel, the West Coast cobbler, to create the shoes for her first mens-wear collection. The result was a simple oxford with a leather stripe slashed diagonally across the front. It was as if she had translated her sculptural clothing style into footwear.
