title: S.B.A. Readies Remedy for Bias Against Women in Federal Contracting
description: The Small Business Administration on Tuesday unveiled a proposed rule that would finally implement a law intended to increase the share of federal contracts to women-owned firms. The law, originally passed by Congress in 2000, allows federal agencies to set aside contracts for small businesses owned by women in industries that the S.B.A. determines are underrepresented with respect to Federal procurement contracting.

title: Whats in Your Facebook Ads?
description: While working with Brad Stone on his story about Facebooks odd ads, I became curious about the apparent randomness of the ads I was seeing on the site. To borrow a line from Morrissey, they said nothing to me about my life. Some ads used information from my Facebook profile just to get my attention, like Free gifts for men in Brooklyn! But where was the precise demographic targeting that is the great promise of Web marketing?

title: For Your Viewing Pleasure | In-Room Entertainment
description: Anne Pasternak, the director of the public arts organization Creative Time, claims she has never watched porn on pay-per-view in a hotel room. But it is such a no-brainer for a hotel to have a good art channel! she insists. And now, with the introduction of the Standart Video Series, the Standard Hotel will add exactly that to its list of in-room entertainment. Curated by Creative Time, this art channel will feature a seasonal menu of works by cutting-edge artists of various visual persuasions. In the first batch alone, guests will have their choice of action/adventure (the Neistat Brotherss Yougurt vs. Gasoline), political thriller (Bruce High Quality Foundations faux-Marxist critique of the art world, Leau de Vie un Film de Jean-Luc Godard) and drama (Lee Waltons FBook, What My Friends Are Doing on Facebook). Marilyn Minters high-definition Green Pink Caviar, with its macro views of slurping tongues, comes the closest to actual porn. The videos will be available for your viewing pleasure at all four Standard Hotel locations. Best of all, theyre free. So dont be shy about watching Martha Colburns Triumph of the Wild 17 times. It wont show up on your bill.

title: Levin to Replace Rangel as Ways and Means Chairman
description: 12:00 p.m. | Updated  Representative Sander M. Levin, a liberal Michigan Democrat, will replace Charles B. Rangel of New York as the chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi told the Democratic caucus Thursday morning.

title: On the Road With the Moscow State Radio Symphony Orchestra
description: If its Thursday, it must be Columbia, Mo. The schedule of the Moscow State Radio Symphony Orchestra, on a marathon United States tour, calls for a two-hour drive from St. Louis, then a concert Thursday evening at the Jesse Auditorium at the University of Missouri. The program, as usual for this tour, is all Russian: RimskyKorsakovs Tsars Bride Overture; Rachmaninoffs Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini, Op. 43, with Alexander Sinchuk as piano soloist; and Rimsky-Korsakovs Scheherazade suite. title: Egypt Overturns Death Sentence in Stars  Murder

I wont believe that theres real trouble with the governor until I hear that hes told his staff hes hiking on the Appalachian Trail.

title: James Cameron Defends Author of Disputed Hiroshima Book
description: Nobody ever said that James Cameron changes his mind easily. And for now, Mr. Cameron, the Avatar and Titanic filmmaker whose instincts have been proved right on one or two occasions, says he still plans to produce a movie about the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, even though a book about the subject that he optioned has been withdrawn by its publisher amid questions about its accuracy.

Authorities say they got suspicious when five of the planes landed at a Toys R Us parking lot.

title: In Search of a Jewish Narnia
description: Why is there no Jewish Narnia? Thats the provocative question raised by Michael Weingrads essay on Judaism and fantasy novels, published in the inaugural issue of the Jewish Review of Books. Note that Weingrad is talking about fantasy as a genre, not the use of the fantastic as a literary tool. (So the existence of Kafka and Isaac Bashevis Singer does not disprove his thesis.) And note, as well, that the piece is not entitled Why Are There No Jewish Fantasy Novelists? To the extent that Weingrad raises that question, hes pretty easily refuted. But really hes raising a deeper issue, one that goes to the nature of the genre itself: Why are there no works of modern fantasy that are profoundly Jewish in the way that, say, The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe is Christian? Why no Jewish [C.S.] Lewises, and why no Jewish Narnias?

title: When Parents Know Too Much
description: When my son had some funky test results after a medical check-up last year, his doctors first advice to me was dont Google it. I did anyway, of course, and he was right. Googling was a bad idea.

title: The Priest
description: As an Anglican archbishop who spent decades working to defeat apartheid and is widely considered the moral conscience of South Africa, what do you make of your countrys current president, Jacob Zuma, who is in the headlines again for fathering a child out of wedlock?  I think we are at a bad place in South Africa, and especially when you contrast it with the Mandela era. Many of the things that we dreamt were possible seem to be getting more and more out of reach. We have the most unequal society in the world. We have far too many of our people living in a poverty that is debilitating, inhumane and unacceptable.

title: New Supermarket in Neighborhood That Needs One
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs Sisyphean efforts to get New Yorkers to replace their passion for French fries with an appreciation of salads is making progress: Harlem is getting a supermarket specializing in lower-priced fruits and vegetables.

title: Billy Elliot Leaps Into South Korea
description: When your musical about an aspiring young dancer in a British coal-mining town has proved a hit in Britain, America and Australia, where do you take it next? Thats right: South Korea.

title: Nine to Know: Team Streaks
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: Are Doctors to Blame for Rising Costs?
description: In a recent editorial in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Howard Brody, a bioethicist at the University of Texas Medical Branch, described the notion that doctors are innocent bystanders in the cost crisis as a myth and knocked the American Medical Association for addressing the issue with little more than calls for medical malpractice reform.

title: WaMu Bankruptcy Hearing Delayed as Talks Go On
description: The judge in the Washington Mutual bankruptcy case is postponing a hearing as the bank tries to resolve disputes with JPMorgan Chase and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, The Associated Press reports.

title: Is Any Job Better than Unemployment?
description: Is any employment, no matter how low-paying and potentially degrading, better than no job at all?

title: Now Screening | Aquilano Rimondi
description: The fall 2010 collection from Aquilano Rimondi at Milan Fashion Week.

title: For Some City Schools, a Really Quick Turnaround
description: Updated March 5, 11:30 a.m. |Edward R. Murrow High School in Midwood, Brooklyn, has long been one of the most popular schools in the city. Like any school, it has some shortcomings  some say that with nearly 4,000 students its easy to get lost in the crowd. But its hard to imagine calling it a failure.

title: $100 Million in Stimulus Funds for Green Tech
description: The Department of Energy announced this week that $100 million in stimulus funds would be distributed to help accelerate innovation in green technology.

title: Laws for Sale
description: Plaintiffs lawyers must be holding their heads a little higher when they walk into P.T.A. meetings and neighborhood parties these days, knowing that corporate lobbyists have overtaken them as the most despised professionals in America. Lobbyists have never been especially popular, of course; even their most sympathetic pop-culture portrayal, in the book and better-known movie Thank You for Smoking, focused mostly on their moral depravity. As a candidate, Barack Obama made a point of vowing to banish them from the White House. (This proved considerably harder to do than it was to say, mostly because it turns out that lobbyists in Washington are like Baathists in Baghdad; if you send them all home, there arent enough people left who know anything about running a government.) In the past year, though, antilobbyist fervor has grown even more intense, as hope for a new governing era has given way to frustration with a divided capital and a dysfunctional Congress.

title: A Top Paterson Aide Quits
description: In the latest upheaval for the Paterson administration, the governors communications director, Peter E. Kauffmann, resigned Thursday afternoon.

title: Halladay Shines in Phillies Debut
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Jets flew overhead. Players were introduced along the foul lines. Fans sat bundled in long-sleeve shirts and coats. If you averted your gaze from the palm trees swaying in right field, it felt a little like the World Series. The Phillies and the Yankees warmed the hearts of snowbirds everywhere Thursday at Bright House Field, engaging in a World Series rematch  and, perhaps, a possible preview.

title: Health Gains for Grown Up Soccer Players
description: Being a soccer mom usually means carpooling kids to games and watching them play. But new research shows that women who join in the fun and kick around a soccer ball can dramatically improve their bone and heart health.

title: Judiciary Panel Clears Justice Nominee  Again
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee moved forward the nomination of Dawn E. Johnsen as head of the Justice Departments Office of Legal Counsel by a party line vote today, the latest step in what may be another protracted attempt to push her nomination through the Senate.

title: Whats Your Reading History? Reflecting on the Self as Reader
description: Overview | What does it mean to be literate? How do our reading experiences shape who we are? In this lesson, students reflect on a formative reading experience and use it as a springboard for tracing their reading lives by creating timelines to reflect past and present experiences. They culminate the personal reading history project through reading, writing and/or discussion.

title: Study Says Undersea Release of Methane Is Under Way
description: Climate scientists have long warned that global warming could unlock vast stores of the greenhouse gas methane that are frozen into the Arctic permafrost, setting off potentially significant increases in global warming.

title: Optics
description: When President Obama responded to the failed Christmas airliner bombing while on vacation in his native state of Hawaii, some Republicans claimed it was bad optics. Hawaii to many Americans seems like a foreign place, the Republican strategist Kevin Madden told CNN. And I think those images, the optics, hurt President Obama very badly.

title: Good Taste That Outlives the Tents
description: If city parks wore a size, Bryant Park was long a 2. Now it has shed its haute self, hosting its final Fashion Week, the twice-yearly shows with private tents, velvet ropes and supermodels, last month. But although fashionistas at this sylvan Midtown spot are history, fashion is not. All along West 40th Street, on the southern edge of the park, the clothes-conscious woman can find intriguing wardrobe enhancements, some of them one-of-a-kind.

title: Red Carpet Showdown
description: More linkage: over at New York magazines Vulture blog, their red carpet critics, the Fug Girls, have produced a slideshow of the fashion match-up theyre most anticipating on Sunday, between the ingnues Anna Kendrick and Carey Mulligan.

title: Now Screening | Dries Van Noten
description: The fall 2010 collection from Dries Van Noten at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Referees Heavy Workloads a Concern for Some Coaches
description: After Connecticut forward Gavin Edwards blocked Scoop Jardines layup with the score 65-65 last month against Syracuse, a referee waved off the play and gave a timeout to the Orange with 36.6 seconds left, even though the Huskies had already rebounded the ball.

title: Shelf Life
description: People who reject e-books often say they cant live without the heft, the texture and  curiously  the scent of traditional books. This aria of hypersensual book love is not my favorite performance. I sometimes suspect that those who gush about book odor might not like to read. If they did, why would they waste so much time inhaling? Among the best features of the Kindle, Amazons great e-reader, is that theres none of that. The device, which consigns all poetry and prose to the same homely fog-toned screen, leaves nothing to the experience of books but reading. This strikes me as honest, even revolutionary.

title: Adopting the Right Approach
description: Adopting the Right Approach

title: Ahead of the Vote, Views From Voters
description: In the holy city of Kufa, the streets were also festooned with campaign signs of every shape and size. Many of the candidates here are male clerics, but there are also a number of signs for female candidates, piously staring out at from beneath hijabs. Throngs of Shiite pilgrims, many from Pakistan, Iran and Iraq, walked through the streets toward the shrine of Imam Ali.

title: For Many House Democrats, Cost Is the Concern
description: Everybody paid attention when President Obama, in a speech at the White House on Wednesday, said now is the time to make a decision and the United States Congress owes the American people a final vote on health care reform.

title: A Winter of Discontent for Flying
description: Just how bad have this winters snowstorms been for the major airlines? About four times worse than usual, according to FlightStats, a company that follows statistics on the airline industry.

title: Radar Claims Two John Roberts Exclusives; One of Them Isnt True
description: For about an hour Thursday, a corner of the Web lit up with a shocking headline: U.S. Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts Considering Stepping Down.

title: The Goats-and-Garden Writing Program
description: Heres Daniyal Mueenuddin last night, telling the Story Prize director Larry Dark why running a farm in Pakistan has been good for his fiction: One of the problems for writers is that they live as writers, and that doesnt give them any material. It would be a good idea, if you wanted to start an M.F.A. program, to start one with goats and a garden.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Audi A8 Hybrid
description: Introduced on Tuesday: Audi A8 Hybrid concept

title: Talking About Global Warming in the Classroom
description: Global warming and how  or whether  to teach it has been a hot topic on NYTimes.com over the last 24 hours.

title: Founding Father?
description: Thanks to Russell Shorto (Feb. 14) for writing such an interesting and disturbing article about the Texas State Board of Educations latest meetings. I think that there are much larger questions to be addressed when thinking about local and default national curriculum guidelines. Questions like What is history? and How should education happen in a democracy? force us as a country, as policymakers and as educators to think about our larger goals in designing our education system and the curriculum that is taught. Do we want to indoctrinate students of all ages into thinking that our countrys history provides a clear and simplistic narrative, or do we want to pose difficult, challenging questions to students while giving them access to legitimate opinions and sources? If we are truly educating our youth to be active citizens in a democracy who can think for themselves, teaching must encourage students to grapple with multiple perspectives, ask provocative questions and develop theories that can be supported with evidence.

title: Peoples Congress Gets to Work in China
description: BEIJING  If Chinese media reports are correct, the standing committee of Chinas national legislature will vote on changes to the state secrecy law at its annual meeting, which began Friday in Beijing. The revisions have been in the works for 14 years.

title: Great Performers
description: Why are the women in the Great Performers series all ornaments to the men? On the magazines cover, Zo Saldana is literally painted into a costume that frames the reserved, respectable head of Sam Worthington. Penlope Cruz and Daniel Day-Lewiss photo repeats this message. In the Colin Firth and Julianne Moore photo, he is the stable center, and she is the decorative periphery. If this is about taking these performers seriously, why are only the men accorded that privilege?

title: Do-It-Yourself Genetic Engineering
description: A complex subject cannot be mastered without patience and faith in oneself in the face of failure. As described in Jon Mooallems article (Feb.14), allowing students an opportunity to direct their own research encouraged by synthetic biology is the best way to teach science at all levels. Teaching science without nurturing student exploration, including blind alleys and that rare moment of discovery, is akin to a music class in which students learn how to read the notes but are not given a chance to experience performance.

title: Is Citi Special? Pandit Blames Short-Sellers
description: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroups chief executive, has little love for short-sellers. He told the Congressional Oversight Panel on Thursday that they were in part responsible for the banks near-collapse in the fall of 2008 and that they exploited fear to make money by betting that Citis stock price would keep falling.

title: Inside the List
description: SPRING FLOWERS: The hardcover nonfiction list is pretty much frozen solid, but new books are busting out all over on the fiction side. Fantasy in Death, the latest crime thriller by J. D. Robb (a k a Nora Roberts), enters at No. 1, followed by Kim Harrisons Black Magic Sanction (No. 3), Danielle Steels Big Girl (No. 5) and Apple Turnover Murder (No. 11), the latest in Joanne Flukes series of culinary mysteries. (Dont panic: the recipe for the title dish says its fine to use commercial puff pastry dough.)

title: On Dance: Voguing at the Whitney
description: Strike a pose, theres nothing to it.

title: Pursuing Happiness
description: The melting snow and approaching spring bring thoughts of propriety, street level struggles and what can be done in these final days of National Procrastination Week.

title: On Language
description: In Grant Barretts On Language column (Feb. 14), he speaks of the beautiful-sounding phrase cellar door. I suppose that one absurd explanation is as good as any other. I was always taught that its beauty is explained by its proximity to the sound and the meaning of the French sentence: cest lheure dor (it is the golden hour).

title: Backstage: Paris Fashion Week
description: Scenes from backstage at the Rochas and Fatima Lopes shows during Paris fashion week.

title: Home Fires: On Seeing
description: In my most recent post I wrote that I watched movies. Some people wrote in to ask why I would use the words watch, see or view. I would like to elaborate on this a little for those readers.

title: Kendall Claims N.F.L. Proposal Would Mean 18 Percent Pay Cut
description: Updated 6:10 p.m.

title: Harvesting the Sun
description: FPL, one of the nation's largest utilities, is building a large solar thermal plant to provide extra power to one of its existing gas-fired power plants in Martin County, Fla. The project is a way for FPL to cut its natural gas use, reduce carbon emissions and lower the cost of installing solar power generation.

title: Mets Invite Calero to Spring Training
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets signed the right-handed reliever Kiko Calero to a minor league contract and invited him to major league spring training.

title: Surviving Hollywoods Slings and Arrows
description: The event, held in a private home high in the Hollywood Hills on Wednesday night, was intended to celebrate African-American women in film. And there was certainly merriment. Gabourey Sidibe got a standing ovation from the likes of Ruby Dee and Alfre Woodard for her nomination for Precious: Based on the novel Push by Sapphire.

title: The Morning Skate: Booths Fight Not a Generic Scrap
description: As fights go, this one on Wednesday night wasnt much

title: Photo of the Week
description: Visitors watch whale sharks swim at the Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium, in Okinawa, Japan.

title: House Adopts $15 Billion Plan to Spur Job Growth
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Thursday approved a $15 billion measure intended to spur job creation by granting tax breaks to businesses that hire workers, as Democrats, bracing for new jobless figures, tried to show that Congress was doing something about stubborn unemployment.

title: One Reason Lizards Have Ears: To Eavesdrop
description: Lizards are not the most loquacious of animals. Aside from the geckos, they dont vocalize to communicate with other members of the same species.

title: Scorecard | Dries Van Noten Wins!
description: Scorecards going to Paris! Its only opening day of of this nine-day fashion week extravaganza, and already the critics seem happier amid all the gothy black and genre-bending reference making that the City of Light has to offer. A word of advice to later showers: archive digging is totally cool. Just take a lesson from Dries Van Noten and make sure your New Look looks new  with swaths of sweatshirting, say  rather than overly literal British-schoolgirl-in-Paris.

title: Chart: Joy Orbisons EP
description: Joy Orbison is a London-based dance producer and D.J. with the moody dubstep genre. The artist Andrew Kuo dissects his EP, The Shrew Would Have Cushioned the Blow, out now on the Aus label:

title: House Republican Postpones Resignation to Vote Against Health Care Bill
description: Representative Nathan Deal, Republican of Georgia, who announced his retirement on Monday, said that he would postpone his departure so that he could stay in Congress to vote against the Democrats big health care legislation.

title: Anti-Mainstream Museums Mainstream Show
description: The New Museums exhibition of artworks from the collection of Dakis Joannou, one of its trustees, has arrived. The project did not sound like a good idea when it was announced last fall. Seeing it up close does not change that.

title: Packing Heat, and a Grudge
description: Sometimes, in one of theaters more undervalued romantic story lines, an actor meets a set and  flash!  chemistry happens. The opening image of Christopher Walken in Martin McDonaghs Behanding in Spokane is such a perfect, demented marriage of character and environment that you cant help grinning like a fool.

title: Good Taste That Outlives the Tents
description: If city parks wore a size, Bryant Park was long a 2. Now it has shed its haute self, hosting its final Fashion Week, the twice-yearly shows with private tents, velvet ropes and supermodels, last month. But although fashionistas at this sylvan Midtown spot are history, fashion is not. All along West 40th Street, on the southern edge of the park, the clothes-conscious woman can find intriguing wardrobe enhancements, some of them one of a kind.

title: A.I.G. Nears Resolution of Tax Issue in Deal for Unit
description: 4:43 p.m. | Updated The American International Group moved closer to the $15 billion sale of a second major life insurance unit on Thursday after the Internal Revenue Service indicated that it would rule favorably on a tax issue that had stymied the deal, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

title: Nick Johnson Misses Game With Back Stiffness
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Nick Johnson is aware of the perception that he is injury-prone, and getting scratched from the lineup Thursday with a stiff lower back will hardly change that reputation.

title: The World According to Gaga
description: In the contemporary fashion dialogue, no celebrity is paid more lip service than Lady Gaga. Such is her reach that the Global Language Monitor recently revealed that Lady Gaga topped the list of the most searched fashion terms, with no pants a close third. The Moment recently caught up with the fashion plate du jour, who was surprisingly candid and dressed in mufti  an outfit of checked shirt, black tights and vertiginous heels that brought to mind Mary-Kate without the grande nonfat latte  to talk about everything from her new gig as a mouthpiece for M.A.C. and its AIDS fund to her constantly referring to herself in the third person.

title: Jobless Rates Dropped a Tad in January
description: The unemployment rates for New York City and the state dipped in January amid signs that the waves of layoffs triggered by the financial crisis may be subsiding.

title: At Ease in T-Shirts or Suits, and With the Medieval or Modern
description: The young, hip JACK Quartet has proved it can play a gig at a club. The first time I heard this brilliant ensemble was in October 2008 at Le Poisson Rouge in Greenwich Village. That night the players  young men in jeans and T-shirts  gave viscerally exciting performances of the complete works for string quartet by the thorny modernist composer Iannis Xenakis. The mostly young listeners, seated at tables sipping drinks, were eager to experience what must have seemed completely out there, modern music.

title: Tied to a Time and Place, but Not a Single Style
description: Killing time between songs during a concert at the Allen Room on Wednesday night, Gabriel Kahane brightly announced that he had just signed a lease on an apartment in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn. What might have been a throwaway moment somehow felt significant for close watchers of Mr. Kahane, a singer, multi-instrumentalist and composer. Many of his best songs deal with a time and a place vividly sketched with what seems like an almost bewildering ease, then used as an anchor for reflections that can be achingly direct and personal.

title: Bush Official Defends Lawyers Under Attack for Detainee Work
description: 6:37 p.m. | Updated A former Justice Department official who led the Bush administrations courtroom defense against lawsuits filed by Guantanamo detainees is denouncing attacks on Obama administration appointees who previously helped such prisoners challenge their indefinite detention without trial.

title: Sound-View Homes in North Carolinas Waterfront
description: WHAT Waterfront second-home community.

title: Swinging on the Hudson: An Unlikely Haven for Jazz
description: MARLBORO, N.Y.

title: Malaysian Memories
description: Marshall Auerback recalls the great debate over capital controls for Malaysia, back in 1998. I remember it well.

title: A Magical History Tour on 2 Routes
description: In its program at the Morgan Library & Museum on Wednesday evening, the St. Lukes Chamber Ensemble focused mainly on two corners of the repertory that, in audience building, are growth industries these days. Most of the first half was devoted to Baroque music, specifically Purcell, played in a style that embraces the spirit of the period-instrument world. The rest of the concert was given over to accessible music composed within the last century and included a premiere, a neo-Romantic rarity and a post-Minimalist classic.

title: Optimism to Pierce Any and All Winter Blues
description: Kapow! Marilyn Mayes new show, In Love Again, at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, is a blast of pre-springtime energy that defies the laws of nature in the happiest way. Ms. Maye may be over 80, but to borrow the argot of grizzled show business pundits on a talent search, this thrush is going places.

title: If You Can Stand Up, Who Cares if Surfs Up?
description: HONOLULU

title: Sanya Richards and Aaron Ross
description: CATCHING one of the worlds fastest women is no easy task, but when Aaron Ross first glimpsed Sanya Richards, he vowed to his mother: Im going to get her.

title: Tender Mercies in Deadly Combats
description: Lar Lubovitchs second Joyce Theater program is something of a hybrid: half jazz, half moody duets, with two generally upbeat jazz works from the first program book-ending a pair of premieres.

title: Whats a Nice Girl Doing in This Hole?
description: Into the dark you tumble in Alice in Wonderland, Tim Burtons busy, garish and periodically amusing repo of the Lewis Carroll hallucination Alices Adventures in Wonderland. Its a long fall turned long haul, despite the Burtonian flourishes  the pinch of cruelty, the mordant wit  that animate the Red Queen (Helena Bonham Carter) and the porker that slides under her feet with a squeal. I love a warm pig belly for my aching feet, the queen tells Alice. Played by Mia Wasikowska, Alice looks a touch dazed: she seems to have left her pulse above ground when she fell down the rabbit hole of Mr. Burtons imagination.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, March 4
description: For those who live where voting is pretty much taken for granted, it is bracing to see people exulting after casting a ballot. Joao Silva, photographing for The Times, caught such a moment (Slide 3) on Thursday. In Slide 2, he also captured something of the peril involved. Election-related conflicts and preparations were also recorded in Khartoum, Sudan (Slide 8) and in Lom, Togo (Slide 9).

title: House Panel Says Armenian Deaths Were Genocide
description: WASHINGTON  The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted narrowly on Thursday to condemn as genocide the mass killings of Armenians early in the last century, defying a last-minute plea from the Obama administration to forgo a vote that seemed sure to offend Turkey and jeopardize delicate efforts at Turkish-Armenian reconciliation.

title: Lights, Gadgets and Video Create a Technological Id
description: The distinctive shaftway connecting the two levels of the Chocolate Factory in Queens is the theatrical gift that keeps on giving. Its only a matter of time until some enterprising artist eschews this Long Island City theaters larger stages and makes an entire show in the confines of that brick-lined space.

title: Parkinsons Limits Ability to Read Emotions
description: Imagine talking to another person and realizing you couldnt tell whether he was angry, sad, fearful or disgusted.

title: Food Products Recalled for Salmonella
description: Thousands of processed food products - from chilis to hot dogs to dips - contain an ingredient that federal food regulators say was contaminated with salmonella, although so far only a few dozen have been recalled because most were cooked before being sold.

title: Answers From a Graffiti Artist, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of answers from Lee Quiones, an artist who emerged from the subway art movement of the 1970s.We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

title: At Platinum, the High Cost of Living in Bermuda
description: Being forced to live in Bermuda probably wouldnt be viewed as a hardship for many people  particularly at this time of year. But at Platinum Underwriters Holdings, its enough to warrant extremely generous housing allowances for the reinsurance companys top executives.

title: Random Acts of Comedy, Women Only
description: Those who would see The Wonder and focus on its flaws are the same type of killjoys who would eat ice cream then whine about the calories. While theyre certainly free to grumble, theyre also spoiling a treat.

title: An End Run Around Lawyers in Tavern on the Green Case
description: Saying that five months of wrangling over the legal corpse of Tavern on the Green have accomplished little, a federal judge on Thursday ordered an end to the landmarks bankruptcy reorganization.

title: An Evening of Brahms Becomes a Memorial
description: Before a chamber music recital at the 92nd Street Y on Wednesday evening billed as Leon Fleisher and Friends, the violinist Jaime Laredo dedicated the concert to David Soyer, the founding cellist of the Guarneri String Quartet, who died on Feb. 25.

title: The Militarys Movie Man Weighs In on The Hurt Locker
description: So it seems like The Hurt Locker lawsuit has stirred up enough interest to make people forget about the movies other controversy, over the authenticity of its depiction of military behavior and techniques. On Wednesday, the Bagger spoke with Lt. Col. Gregory Bishop, the Armys Los Angeles-based entertainment liaison, whose office helps promote a better understanding of the military through your local entertainment complex. But the Army did not have an official part in The Hurt Locker.

title: S.E.C. Charges Psychic With Securities Fraud
description: 7:36 a.m. | Updated More from The New York Times here.

title: Paterson Still Governor, for Now
description: Gov. David A. Paterson will be governor on Friday. After that? He will not say.

title: Letter: El Greco at the Prado
description: To the Editor: Re Touring the Prado at Warp Speed (Feb. 14): Surely there should be at least a few minutes devoted to El Greco on a 45-minute spin around the museum. I was surprised there was no mention of the artists works (more than 30) now on display. This is one of the worlds most important and comprehensive collections of El Greco.

title: Letter: Willa Cathers Santa Fe
description: To the Editor: I thought it was interesting that the author of The Art of Being Santa Fe (Feb. 7) visited the city because hed read D. H. Lawrences paeans to New Mexico. Others of us set our sights on New Mexico because of Willa Cathers Death Comes for the Archbishop. Cather wrote movingly about the land and the strands of humanity that came together in that little corner of the world.

title: Letter: Vietnam Beer (60s Style)
description: To the Editor: Re In Vietnam, Traveling an Unlikely Beer Trail (Feb. 21): Russ Juskalian neglected to mention Beer 33. During my work in Vietnam in the 60s, this sharp, tangy rice-based beer was almost the only beer available outside the PX. One of the few Vietnamese words I ever learned was 33. Some months ago I revisited Vietnam and was chagrined to see that 33 no longer existed but had morphed into 333. Still pretty good beer.

title: American Idol': Whos Going Home?
description: Predictions are an iffy proposition  even some noted American Idol authorities went 0-for-4 last week.

title: Billy Elliot Leaps Into South Korea
description: When your musical about an aspiring young dancer in a British coal-mining town has proved a hit in Britain, America and Australia, where do you take it next? Thats right: South Korea. The producers of Billy Elliot: The Musical said that a Korean-language version of the show, adapted from the 2000 Stephen Daldry film, would play in Seoul starting in August after years of planning that began long before Billy Elliot won the 2009 Tony Award for best musical. In a telephone interview on Thursday Eric Fellner, a co-chairman of Working Title Films, which produced the Billy Elliot movie and its stage incarnations, said that the company was approached about foreign versions of the musical about five years ago, just as the original West End show was starting up. Local actors have been hired for the South Korean cast, including a team of four young Billys, and some dialogue or other minor elements may be changed to suit the hometown crowd. But over all the show will remain intact, and the shows American design and construction team has built the sets for the Seoul production. Mr. Fellner said that a Japanese version of the Billy Elliot musical was being prepared for the summer of 2011, and talks were continuing with German and Dutch producers.

title: Sarah Palin and Tony Blair Working on Book Projects
description: While Sarah Palin completes a swing through the West Coast, she is keeping busy with more than just talk-show appearances. HarperCollins, which released her best-selling memoir Going Rogue, said that Ms. Palin is writing a second, as-yet untitled book that would be a celebration of American virtues and strengths, and include selections from classic and contemporary readings that have inspired her, according to a statement reported by The Associated Press. For a take on politics from the other side of the Atlantic, Tony Blair, above left, has offered more details on his coming memoir, which Random House signed up in 2007 (at an advance of nearly $9 million) and which will be released by its Alfred A. Knopf imprint in September. Mr. Blair, the former British prime minister, said that the book, to be called The Journey, would give his perspectives on the lead-up to the Iraq war, peace negotiations in Northern Ireland and his relationship with his successor, Gordon Brown. I have tried to write a book which describes the human as much as the political dimensions of life as prime minister, Mr. Blair said in a statement.

title: Idol, and Bowersox, Doing Just Fine
description: A two-hour edition of American Idol, featuring performances from the top 10 women  including Crystal Bowersox, who was recovering from an unspecified illness and whose status was uncertain right up until air time  helped Fox claim yet another ratings victory on Wednesday night. Idol attracted 23.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates, while CBS was runner-up with its crime shows Criminal Minds (13.2 million) and CSI: NY at 10 (12.5 million). NBC finished third with a lineup that included Mercy (6 million) and a two-hour Law & Order: SVU (8.3 million). ABC was fourth with its comedy lineup followed by The Oprah Winfrey Oscar Special (4.4 million).

title: Julia Cho Wins Playwriting Award
description: Julia Cho, below, was named a winner of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, an award for female playwrights, on Wednesday evening, its organizers said in a news release. Ms. Cho, who was previously nominated for her plays The Piano Teacher and 99 Histories, won the prize for The Language Archive, a new work about a linguist with an unraveling marriage, that was commissioned by Roundabout Theater Company and is to have its world premiere at the South Coast Repertory in Costa Mesa, Calif., this month. The award comes with $20,000 as well as a signed print by Willem de Kooning.

title: New York Landmarks Agency Is Upheld on Appeal
description: A state appellate court has overturned a lower court ruling that had chastised the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission for failing to act on certain landmark designation requests and had called for new expedited procedures. In reversing the November 2008 decision by Justice Marilyn Shafer of the New York State Supreme Court, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled on Feb. 25 that there was no statutory requirement that the commission adhere to a particular procedure in determining whether to consider a property for designation. As a result, the ruling stated, the court erred in holding the commissions conduct arbitrary and capricious with respect to five properties. The appellate court also ruled that the Citizens Emergency Committee to Preserve Preservation, which filed the lawsuit against the commissions top officials, failed to demonstrate standing to sue.

title: HBO Will Play Game of Thrones
description: If youve been longing for an epic fantasy to help fill the gap between Peter Jacksons Lord of the Rings movies and the maybe-someday remake of Dune, HBO may have rolled the saving throw you needed. On Tuesday the cable channel said it had officially ordered Game of Thrones, a new series based on George R. R. Martins Song of Ice and Fire fantasy novels. The best-selling book franchise, which began in 1996 with A Game of Thrones, chronicles the dynastic conflicts among several families on the mythical continent of Westeros. The principal cast of the HBO series, which will run 10 episodes, features no less than 17 members, including Mark Addy, above left; Sean Bean; Peter Dinklage; Jennifer Ehle, above right; Iain Glen; and Lena Headey; as well as Tamzin Merchant (of Pride and Prejudice) as the heroine Daenerys Targaryen. Production on the series is to begin in Ireland in June; a premiere date has not been set.

title: James Cameron Defends Hiroshima Book Author
description: Nobody ever said that James Cameron changes his mind easily. And for now Mr. Cameron, the Avatar and Titanic filmmaker, says he still plans to produce a movie about the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, even though a book about the subject that he optioned has been withdrawn by its publisher amid questions about its accuracy. The publisher, Henry Holt & Company, said that it would stop shipping and printing copies of The Last Train From Hiroshima by Charles Pellegrino, a nonfiction account of the World War II mission to drop an atomic bomb on Hiroshima and of the bombings victims. That decision came after the accounts of Joseph Fuoco, a source for the book who is characterized as a substitute flight engineer on the mission, were contradicted by scientists, historians and veterans. In an e-mail message to The Associated Press, Mr. Cameron defended Mr. Pellegrino. All I know is that Charlie would not fabricate, Mr. Cameron wrote, so there must be a reason for the misunderstanding. He added that his movie does not have a shooting script and no decision has been made to proceed in the short term.

title: Correction: 36 Hours in Vieques
description: The 36 Hours column on Feb. 21, about the island of Vieques, Puerto Rico, included outdated information regarding Red Beach, one of the beaches that has been improved since the Navy left. Red Beach reopened in December after work was done to improve the road, but it has since been closed for additional work; no reopening date has been set.

title: Rural Retreat
description: Rural Retreat

title: The Body, Visible and Invisible, in Three Parts
description: In Blocks of Continuality/Body, Image and Algorithm, the choreographer Koosil-ja creates a complicated technological landscape to help uncover what she refers to as the visible and invisible aspects of the body. To accomplish this, she relies on a few tools  a live processing method for generating movement and an interactive 3-D environment.

title: Love and Faith in the Time of the Inquisition
description: This is such stuff as dramas are made on: forbidden love, outlawed religion, burnings at the stake. But Conviction, an Israeli play about a Catholic priest who falls in love with a Jewish woman during the Spanish Inquisition, remains tepid.

title: Pets on Planes May Inflame Allergies
description: Allowing pets to travel on airplane cabins poses a health threat to passengers with allergies to animals, according to a Feb. 16 editorial in the Canadian Medical Association Journal.

title: Two Missing as Boat Capsizes in Jamaica Bay
description: The Coast Guard said on Thursday that it was searching in a broad area of Jamaica Bay for two missing people whose 10-foot-long boat overturned in the morning near the eastern end of Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Downsize Your Enthusiasm
description: Downsize

title: Now Screening | Balenciaga
description: The fall 2010 collection from Balenciaga at Paris Fashion Week.

title: The Perverse Pleasures Underneath The Ordinary
description: Who could resist such an invitation? The city street is dark and deserted. The buildings are empty. There are no witnesses. A lone man carrying a briefcase, after a long day at the office perhaps, approaches a subway staircase. Out of the subterranean gloom, a giant human hand protrudes, its index finger beckoning the office worker, inviting him into the depths. His eyes are wide with astonishment, his face showing the hint of a grin, as if the bizarre, illicit invitation were not entirely unwelcome.

title: Michelin Stars and Other Honors
description: LAuberge du Vieux Puits in Corbires in the southwest of France has joined the ranks of restaurants with three stars in the latest Michelin red guide to France, which was published this week.

title: Off the Menu: Il Laboratorio del Gelato
description: Il Laboratorio del Gelato will be opening a new location on the Lower East Side in June thats five times larger, with as many as 60 flavors, later hours and a few seats inside.

title: Panoramic Vision Back From Tour of Spain
description: Joaqun Sorolla, the Spanish painter, sketched costumed villagers and arid roads around his homeland in the 1910s. He was preparing for a huge commission: Archer Milton Huntington, a railroad heir in New York, had requested murals for an octagonal gallery at his new museum, the Hispanic Society of America on Broadway at 155th Street in Washington Heights. Sorolla exhausted himself at his Madrid studio clambering around ladders to finish the canvas panorama, Vision of Spain, about 230 linear feet of hilltop towns, folk dancers, church processions, bullfighters and fishermen.

title: Met Show Completes Its Set of Bronzinos
description: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art opened The Drawings of Bronzino, in January, it was able to secure 59 of this Florentine masters 60 known drawings. Now it can boast it has them all.

title: Art in Review
description: BACK TO HAUNT THE HELL OUT OF YOU

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

title: Closing of Rest Stops Stirs Anger in Arizona
description: PHOENIX  The people of Arizona kept their upper lips stiff when officials mortgaged off the states executive office tower and a Daily Show crew rolled into town to chronicle the transaction in mocking tones. They remained calm as lawmakers pondered privatizing death row.

title: Classical and Opera Listings
description: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

title: For Gamers Who Are All Ears
description: When it comes to engaging in virtual combat, the sonics make all the difference: the crackle of video game gunfire, the resonating boom of bazookas, the drip-drip-drip of water in a silent room as you stalk the enemy.

title: Spare Times
description: OPEN REHEARSALS FOR HAMLET

title: When Troubled Cops Cross the Thin Blue Line
description: Brooklyns Finest burrows deep into a rough corner of the Borough of Kings, and also into the collective memory of generations of meaty, emotional movies about New York City cops in trouble. The picture is set in the present, though you might not guess as much from the bad-old-days-level body count and the Sidney Lumet (Prince of the City, say, or Q and A) aura hanging around the three suffering, ethically compromised policemen at its center.

title: Ahoy From Nudes, a Pirate and Scrooge McDuck
description: He stands proud and tall, the pirate. With a parrot on each shoulder and a barrel of rum at his side, he braves a fresh breeze that lifts his coattails and his long beard. Although he has two mirror-bright eye patches, he seems to survey an imaginary horizon. Despite his two wooden legs and hooks for both hands, he seems undaunted, ready for more high seas adventure.

title: Rock and Pop Listings
description: POP

title: Theater Listings: March 5  11
description: Previews and Openings

title: Do You Know Your Critical Number?
description: I believe that to create long-term sustainability in a company, community or country, you have to have the guts to face your biggest weaknesses. And one of the best ways Ive found to do this is by creating incentives that help everyone on your team tackle that goal together.

title: Venerable, Small and Lots on Paper (Including Napkins)
description: New Yorks two biggest art fairs are going double or nothing: The Art Show, the annual exhibition of the Art Dealers Association of America, now coincides with the Armory Show. Expect lots of head scratching and crosstown traffic; the Art Show is at the Park Avenue Armory, while the Armory Show is at Piers 92 and 94.

title: End Run Around Lawyers in Tavern Bankruptcy
description: From Glenn Collins at Diners Journal:

title: The Oldest Cultural Institution in New York
description: The New York Society Library has hosted lectures by Poe and Emerson.

title: An Abundance of Room, an Absence of V.I.P. Gloss
description: You might have thought that New York had reached the saturation point in contemporary-art fairs, but no. A new one has just arrived. Its called Independent. And it is housed, quite attractively, in the old Dia Center for the Arts space in Chelsea, lately home to the utopian X Initiative.

title: American Didnt Plan to Kill, Italy Judges Say
description: ROME  An American college student and her sometime Italian boyfriend convicted in the 2007 killing of a British college student in Italy acted without premeditation or rancor, according to a 427-page document released on Thursday by the two judges in the closely watched case.

title: Movie Listings
description: MOVIES

title: A Brush With a Beatle
description: PETER TOWNSEND figured out pretty quickly that his home at 1 White Street in TriBeCa came with a very special pedigree. Within days of moving in back in 1976, he started receiving mail addressed to John Lennon and Yoko Ono, c/o Nutopian Embassy.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this article incorrectly referred to a teragram being 1.1 billion tons. It is 1.1 million tons. The version also incorrectly said that the East Siberian Arctic Shelf is east of the Bering Strait. It is west of the Bering Strait.

title: Where Fusty Is Fabulous
description: THE oldest cultural institution in New York? Perhaps the Metropolitan Opera? Nope, 1880. The Metropolitan Museum? 1870. The New-York Historical Society? 1804.

title: A New Plot Twist in Cussler Case
description: The longstanding legal dispute between the author Clive Cussler and Crusader Entertainment took a new twist on Wednesday when a California appeals court reversed a lower court order that Mr. Cussler pay Crusader $5 million for alleged bad faith dealings over the movie Sahara. The appeals court upheld the trial court in rejecting Mr. Cusslers claim that he was owed $8.6 million by Crusader. The ruling, which came from a three-judge panel of the second appellate district in Los Angeles, sent the long-standing dispute between Mr. Cussler and Crusader back to the lower court to determine who, if anyone, had actually prevailed in the case. That determination will affect the assignment of responsibility for legal costs.

title: Fairy-Tale Land
description: The Kingdom of the Little People, a $115 million universe in miniature, is set amid rolling hills and peaceful lakes in southern Chinas Yunnan Province.

title: The Newest Hybrid Model
description: INDIANTOWN, Fla.  In former swamplands teeming with otters and wild hogs, one of the nations biggest utilities is running an experiment in the future of renewable power.

title: Curiouser and Curiouser Cinema Adventures in Wonderland
description: On Friday, Walt Disney releases its latest film adaptation of Alice in Wonderland, a 3-D version with the directorial pedigree of Tim Burton, a high-wattage cast that includes Johnny Depp and Anne Hathaway, and a budget big enough to fund innumerable mad tea parties. It may not be exactly what Lewis Carroll  the pen name of Charles Lutwidge Dodgson  had in mind when he wrote his Alice novels in the 1860s and 70s, but then again, his source material has sent directors down all different kinds of rabbit holes over the years.

title: The Navi Take On the Tar Sands
description: Another day, another effort to ride on the coat tails of Avatar. But unlike most of the groups that have projected their issues on the movie  feminists who feel the male avatars are more buff than their female counterparts, antismoking advocates, conservatives who bristle at its depiction of religion  the latest bunch is squarely in support of the movie.

title: For Greece, Bond Sale Is Step Back From Disaster
description: Having won support from the European Union for its new austerity budget, Greece cashed in its chips with investors Thursday, completing a long-awaited bond sale that gave a lift to its embattled government finances and bolstered other peripheral European countries that share the euro, Landon Thomas Jr. and David Jolly of The New York Times report.

title: Is Home-Court Advantage Really About the Ball?
description: Its a mantra for players, coaches and commentators everywhere: Playing on the road is hard.

title: Drunken Rages, Bad Deeds: Hedda Wont Be Happy
description: In the annals of drawing room theater, few offstage developments are as pivotal to a plays outcome as the party Judge Brack gives for George Tesman in Hedda Gabler. What the newlywed Hedda learns of the evening Brack has spent with George, her husband, and Eilert Lovborg, her one-time heartthrob, propels the second half of Ibsens classic 1890 drama.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: THE PAPER BAG PLAYERS GREAT MUMMY ADVENTURE

title: Art About Food, in the Oxford American
description: A new copy of the Oxford American just showed up in the Diners Journal mailbox, guest edited by our occasional colleague John T. Edge.

title: Photos of the Moment | Faces and Places
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: What Were Reading: Inside the Minds of Steve Jobs and Mark Zuckerberg
description: Thursdays roundup of interesting tidbits from around the Web, selected by technology reporters and editors at The New York Times:

title: Three Arrested at Hunter College Protest
description: Three protesters were arrested Thursday afternoon outside Hunter College in Manhattan during a demonstration involving more than 150 people.

title: Swiss May Give Animals Free Lawyers
description: Barely three months after Swiss voters approved a measure to restrict the rights of Muslims to build minarets, they return to the polls on Sunday to consider expanding the rights of animals to get free legal representation.

title: Quarterback Carousel? Let the Speculation Begin
description: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating, among other statistical pursuits, at NFLStatAnalysis.net.  He also contributes at classactsports.com.

title: A Saint Among Sinners, With Operatic Dreams
description: Harlem Aria, a follow-your-dreams fable of surpassing sentimentality, opens with the words Once upon a time and closes by noting that the heros destiny has not yet been written. In between, the tale of Anton (Gabriel Casseus), a slow-witted laundry worker, unfolds with the speed and treacliness of molasses rolling uphill.

title: Redskins Rev the Engines for Cap-Free Free Agency
description: UPDATED 7:20 P.M.

title: Haiti's Enduring Creativity
description: Though the arts were impacted by the Jan. 12 earthquake in Haiti many artists are already responding to the disaster with music.

title: Mother of All Potholes? No, but One Worth Noting
description: As potholes go, New Yorkers certainly have seen worse, and in more inconvenient locations. This one on Staten Island sat on a quiet, little-traveled street, lined with neat two-story homes. About two feet wide and an inch or two deep, the gravelly gap was no car-eating chasm, and frankly, it had been easily avoided by knowing residents who had grown wise to its ways.

title: Psychic Powers
description: Can you imagine telling your friends and family that you lost a couple of hundred thousand dollars because you trusted it to someone who assured you he had psychic powers to forecast the market?

title: Another Look at a New Bank Tax
description: As my colleague Steven Greenhouse wrote yesterday, there are renewed calls of late for some kind of new bank tax or, as the Obama administration has proposed, a financial crisis responsibility fee, to extract money from banks that were took taxpayer money.

title: Obama Takes Health Care Deadline to Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, beginning a full-court press for his health care overhaul, met Thursday with insurance industry executives and House Democrats as party leaders on Capitol Hill struggled to figure out whether they could meet the presidents timetable for enacting legislation within a few weeks.

title: Market Defies Fear of Real Estate Bubble in China
description: SHANGHAI  The spacious duplex comes with crocodile-skin bedposts, hand-carved bronze doors inlaid with Swarovski crystals  and a $45 million price tag.

title: In Paris, Risks Bring Rewards
description: Paris

title: Outside the Abbeys Fortified Walls, a World of Fairy Girls and Beasts
description: There is a lot to look at in The Secret of Kells. Nearly every frame of this 75-minute animated feature is dense with curlicued and cross-hatched patterns and figures. Your eye travels over Celtic crosses and through forest glades, studies architectural schematics and drinks in delicately washed landscapes. The human characters come in a variety of shapes and hues. Some are cute, some are sinister, some angular, some roly-poly. A few resemble science-fiction robots, while others look like pixies out of Japanese anime.

title: Stealthy Insights Amid Short Phrases
description: Kay Ryans poems are as slim as runway models, so tiny you could almost tweet them. Their compact refinement, though, does not suggest ease or chic. Her voice is quizzical and impertinent, funny in uncomfortable ways, scuffed by failure and loss. Her mastery, like Emily Dickinsons, has some awkwardness in it, some essential gawkiness that draws you close.

title: Peacekeepers to Withdraw From Parts of Congo
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The United Nations will begin withdrawing peacekeeping troops from Congo by June to hand control of the countrys security back to the Congolese, officials with the United Nations mission to Congo said Thursday.

title: Report Urges Cuts in Mail Delivery
description: The United States Postal Service, facing a $238 billion budget deficit by 2020, should consider cutting delivery to as few as three days a week, the consulting firm McKinsey & Company recommended in a report this week at a postal conference in Washington. Options also included expanding business lines and restructuring retiree health benefits. The service, projecting that mail volume will drop 15 percent in the next decade as consumers switch to electronic communications, is pressing Congress to change a law requiring delivery six days a week and limiting post office closings.

title: Census Confidentiality Assured
description: The Justice Department reassured minority leaders in Congress on Thursday that confidential personal information gathered in this years census count would not be shared with the Department of Homeland Security or other federal agencies. In a letter, Assistant Attorney General Ronald Weich wrote that no provisions of the 2001 antiterrorism legislation known as the USA Patriot Act override a law that bars census officials from disclosing protected information. Last September, the Congressional minority caucuses asked Justice Department officials to clarify the law, concerned that illegal immigrants would not participate in the count if their identity information could be turned over to immigration agents.

title: Target Practice
description: Sam Lipsytes third novel, The Ask, is a dark and jaded beast  the sort of book that, if it were an animal, would be a lumbering, hairy, cryptozoological ape-man with a near-crippling case of elephantiasis.

title: A.I.G. Moves Closer to Sale of Alico
description: The American International Group moved closer to the $15 billion sale of a second major life insurance unit on Thursday after the Internal Revenue Service indicated that it would rule favorably on a tax issue that had stymied the deal, people briefed on the matter said.

title: The Drama of How the Race Is Run
description: WHAT does it mean to manufacture drama? The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences thought it knew when it announced last year that the number of Oscar nominees for best picture would be doubled, to 10 from 5. We will be casting our net wide, Sidney Ganis, then the Academys president, said at the time. It was a blatant move to create more buzz around an already artificial buzz machine, an appeal to populism and a gambit to boost ratings. (Our partners at ABC are very, very happy, Mr. Ganis added.)

title: Earmarks Abuse Feared After Ethics Panel Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  When Democrats regained control of Congress three years ago, one first step to combat what they called the culture of corruption in Washington was to tighten restrictions on earmarks  the notorious financial set-asides that had become a symbol of political favor trading.

title: Lawmakers From Coal States Seek to Delay Emission Limits
description: WASHINGTON  Coal-country lawmakers moved Thursday to impose a two-year moratorium on potential federal regulation of carbon dioxide and other climate-altering gases.

title: Collective Imagination
description: Among the trends emerging for fall are big cat spots, seen at Rochas, Dries Van Noten and Thursday at Balmain. Theres also a bit more gold around this season, thanks to Balmain, which opened with a long gold dress and had gold leather pants and sparkling gold pinstripes on a black pantsuit.

title: A Wall Street Witch Hunt
description: One of the darkest days in the illustrious 141-year history of Goldman Sachs was September 19, 2008, when investor confidence in Wall Street was at its nadir and Lloyd Blankfein, Goldmans chief executive, called John Mack, then the top man at Morgan Stanley. Mack was struggling to keep Morgan Stanley afloat in the wake of the collapse of Bear Stearns, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and American International Group. Goldman could have been the next to fail if Morgan Stanley did not pull through. You have to hang on, because Im 30 seconds behind you, Blankfein told Mack. Two days later, the Federal Reserve allowed both Goldman and Morgan Stanley to become bank holding companies, ending an era on Wall Street but likely saving our banking system.

title: Europe Offers $273 Million in Aid for a Gas Pipeline From Turkey to Austria
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission took steps on Thursday to avoid future crises over supplies of natural gas, as new evidence emerged that another of its main energy goals  encouraging biofuels  might need to be revised.

title: Jobless Rate for January Dips Slightly in New York
description: Unemployment rates for New York City and the state dipped in January, providing a faint signal that the waves of layoffs set off by the financial crisis may be subsiding.

title: Judges Approval Is Sought in 2 Lawsuits From 9/11
description: More than eight years after the Sept. 11 attacks, a federal judge in Manhattan has been asked to approve settlements in two of the last remaining wrongful-death lawsuits.

title: Releasing Prisoners Early Due to Costs
description: Monica Davey, Chicago Bureau Chief of The Times, discusses the backlash against states that are cutting costs by releasing prisoners early.

title: Predicting Winners by Hunch and History
description: WITH the Academy Awards almost upon us, Friday is most likely your last chance to get in on that office Oscar pool. Knowing youd love nothing more than to get a leg up over the guy in the next cubicle, we here at The New York Times have done a bit of number crunching to inform your last-minute choices. That is, if you believe in the predictive power of the precursor awards, that seemingly never-ending parade of accolades from all sorts of official-sounding groups.

title: Haitian Singer and His Guitar Fight Urge to Weep
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  His pack of Comme Il Faut cigarettes was almost depleted. The smell of rotting garbage on the street and fried pork from a stall next to his tent filled the air in Place St. Pierre. Some children looked at his crutch and grew silent. Beken, one of Haitis most gifted musicians, exhaled a veil of smoke.

title: For Greece, Bond Sale Is a Step Back From Disaster
description: LONDON  After pledging to mend its profligate ways, Greece took a crucial step on Thursday toward raising the billions needed to pay its bills and contain the crisis threatening the euro.

title: Utah Anti-Abortion Bill Citing Reckless Act Is Withdrawn
description: DENVER  A sweeping anti-abortion statute in Utah that would have allowed up to life in prison for a woman whose fetus died from her intentional or reckless behavior was withdrawn by its sponsor on Thursday and will be revised to be narrower in scope.

title: Do the Oscars Undermine Artistry?
description: Updated, March 5, 1:40 p.m. | Anna Everett, a professor of film and media studies, joins the discussion.

title: Vatican Enmeshed in Gay Sex Allegations
description: ROME  A singer in an elite Vatican choir and a jailed Italian public works executive who served as a papal usher were let go by the Vatican this week amid allegations that they were involved in what prosecutors believe was an organized network of gay prostitution, Italian news media reported.

title: Two Pentagon Police Officers Shot; Gunman Killed
description: WASHINGTON  Two police officers at the Pentagon were wounded Thursday evening when a man walked up to the entrance of the complexs subway station and, without a word, opened fire on them, Pentagon officials said.

title: A Game of Resisting the I.R.S.
description: If ever there was an area of taxation that needed simplification, it is the American corporate income tax. Companies end up filing tax returns containing thousands, or even tens of thousands, of pages.

title: Hoping Sanctions Work but Readying Gas Masks
description: JERUSALEM  Preparations for a strike against Irans nuclear program are as evident as ever: the introduction of an attack drone capable of flying hundreds of miles, the frequent open talk of a possible attack, the distribution of new gas masks to the public.

title: Roberto Barbon, Japans First Latin Baseball Player, Still Feels at Home
description: ASHIYA, Japan  Many of the more than 900 foreigners who have played here over the 73 seasons of Nippon Professional Baseball have had careers analogous to the countrys famed cherry blossom: they burst open with an awing brilliance and then, just as suddenly, withered away. Some, despite great fanfare, never blossomed at all.

title: A House Democrat Reconsiders
description: As Democrats make a final push to adopt health care legislation, House leaders are scrambling for every single vote. Now a House Democrat who opposed the health care legislation in November says it appears to be moving in the right direction, signaling a potential change in his vote.

title: Teachers Suspended Over Role Model Choice
description: LOS ANGELES  His name has not been released, so it was not possible Thursday to ascertain what an elementary school teacher here was thinking when he pinned a photo of O. J. Simpson on the shirt of a second-grader who was marching in a Black History Month parade.

title: Local Chileans, Feeling at Loose Ends, Try to Connect After Disaster
description: It is human nature to seek succor in times of duress, so it makes sense that since a devastating earthquake struck Chile, one shop selling bread and one selling wine have emerged as key centers of comfort for the small Chilean population in the New York region.

title: NASA Chief Denies Talk of Averting Obama Plan
description: In response to reports that he was looking for a Plan B to address Congressional concerns, the head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said Thursday that he was not backing away from the Obama administrations proposal to reshape the nations human spaceflight program.

title: School Is Linked To Visa Fraud
description: MIAMI  More than 80 people have been arrested in connection with a language school here that the government says was a front for the sale of fraudulent applications for student visas, immigration authorities said Thursday.

title: Tireless Employees Get Their Tribute, Even if Its in Felt and Polyester
description: A POPULAR new reality series on CBS, Undercover Boss, shows senior managers working incognito as everyday employees. As for employees who are not secretly C.E.O.s, they have champions, too, in marketers that are devoting ad campaigns to workers.

title: Halladay Hopes to See Yanks Again, in October
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Jets zoomed overhead. Players were introduced along the foul lines. Fans sat bundled in coats and long-sleeved shirts. If you averted your gaze from the palm trees swaying behind the right-field fence and toward the Cy Young Award-winning starters on Thursday, it felt more like fall classic than spring training.

title: Chilean Officials Lower Death-Toll Estimate
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Chilean emergency management officials announced Thursday that they had significantly overestimated the death toll from last weekends earthquake, lowering the figure from about 805 people to about 279.

title: Imam Snared in Terror Plot Admits He Lied to the F.B.I.
description: A Queens imam who became entangled in a terrorism plot against New York City when he warned one of the planners that he was under government surveillance pleaded guilty on Thursday to a reduced charge of lying to federal officials.

title: Clicker Redesigns Its Online Video Guide
description: When Viacom announced this week that it would pull The Daily Show and The Colbert Report from Hulu, the popular video hosting site, many online video viewers were understandably upset. Even though the videos wont disappear from the Internet and will still be viewable on each shows Web site, moves like this continue to fragment content online, making it more difficult for consumers to navigate a growing diaspora of video.

title: Paterson Loses Aide and Consults Lawyer
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson lost another top administration official on Thursday, when his communications director announced that he could no longer in good conscience continue in that role for the governor.

title: A Name, I Want Revenge, Fits 2 Squabbling Owners
description: At best moderately talented, the 3-year-old colt Dontsellmetofelons does not figure to win Fridays fifth race at Santa Anita or go on to do anything to make a name for himself, at least on the racetrack. Although the horse may not be that noteworthy, his name is.

title: Rash of Scandals Tests Democrats at Sensitive Time
description: WASHINGTON  The ethical woes facing Democrats are piling up, with barely a day passing in recent weeks without headlines from Washington to New York and beyond filled with word of scandal or allegations of wrongdoing.

title: For Psychic, Suit Came as Surprise
description: He calls himself Americas Prophet, a psychic, trained by Nepalese monks in the art of time travel, who can foretell the future of the stock market.

title: Report Finds 36 Died Under Assisted Suicide Law
description: SEATTLE  At least 36 terminally ill people died last year after taking lethal medication prescribed by doctors under Washington States new physician-assisted suicide law, according to a state report released Thursday, the first since the law went into effect a year ago.

title: A Transit Plan Brings Hoots and Hate
description: The Loews Paradise Theater, a sumptuous picture palace on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, opened in 1929 with a talkie called The Mysterious Dr. Fu Manchu. The most recent offering, on Wednesday night, might well have been called The Great Bus and Train Disaster. It was not a movie. Sadly, this was reality.

title: Flavoring Ingredient Recalled; Risk of Illness Seen as Low
description: Thousands of processed foods  from soups to hot dogs to dips  contain a flavoring ingredient contaminated with salmonella, but government food safety officials say most affected products are safe because cooking, either before or after sale, eliminates the risk.

title: Delahunt to Leave Congress
description: The retirements keep on coming.

title: Oscar Parties
description: Will a rogue producer ruin "The Hurt Locker" in its bid for Best Picture? Will dark horse "Inglourious Basterds" take home a surprise win? Will Alec Baldwin sing? This Sunday all our questions will be answered when the hype and hoopla comes to an end at the 82nd Annual Academy Awards. Thankfully there are plenty of opportunities in the city to watch the results. NYC & Co. is co-hosting the city's first-ever viewing party with the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Starting at 7 p.m. at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall, cocktails and hors d'oeuvres will be served followed by a live broadcast. The Juilliard Jazz Ensemble will perform music from Oscar-winning films. Tickets are available at lincolncenter.org. For a less fancy, more campy showing head to Joe's Pub where the annual Murray Hill party will take place with comedians spoofing this year's films. (Murray will be playing Mo'nique from "Precious" and Julia Child from "Julie and Julia.") For foodies, the chef Donatella Arpaia is throwing a shindig for the little gold man at her restaurant Mia Dona. For $25, guests can sip on a blue Avatar cocktail and munch on a tasting menu featuring meatballs, white-bean bruschetta and more. And in Brooklyn, mixologist Julie Reiner is hosting a party with an actual red carpet at her establishment, Clover Club. Entry is free, and you're encouraged to dress up.

title: Feats of Strength
description: Titus Andronicus clearly has a few nerds in its ranks. The "fuzz-loving indie-rock" band, writes Amanda Petrusich, stole its moniker from the title of one of Shakespeare's earliest tragedies, and then named its full-length debut ("The Airing of Grievances") after a fictional holiday featured on an episode of "Seinfeld." "But, while it's prone to (friendly) borrowing, Titus Andronicus also has ideas of its own: the band's new album, 'The Monitor,' is packed with gleeful rock songs. Go listen on Saturday night at the Bowery Ballroom where the band will be performing with Parts and Labor, the Babies and Cloud Nothings, beginning at 8 p.m.

title: Animation Upstart
description: One Oscar category to keep an eye on this year is animation. Though Pixar's "Up" is the obvious front-runner, there will be a lot of people rooting for "The Secret of Kells." The movie, an independent film by Tomm Moore, is a hand-drawn labor of love made for only about $8 million. Mr. Moore grew up and still lives in Kilkenny, Ireland, a one-cathedral town of a few thousand people about an hour and a half south of Dublin. "If," writes Melena Ryzik, "artistically, 'The Secret of Kells' is a throwback to the era of animation before computer-generated imagery, its promotion is pure digital age, forgoing the pricey ads and flashy parties that Academy Award campaigns are traditionally built on in favor of cheaper social media and savvy targeted marketing. It was a lark, and it worked." The movie, which opens today in New York, follows the adventures of a boy  a young monk in training  as he works with an illuminator to finish the Book of Kells, the Latin manuscript transcribed by Celtic monks around A.D. 800 and considered an Irish national treasure. "Rich with pagan myth and Jungian symbolism, the movie is lavishly illustrated to mimic the perspectiveless style of pre-Renaissance art: it's not exactly lightweight fare." It is also Mr. Moore's first feature.

title: Boat Capsizes in Queens; 2 Are Missing
description: Two people are believed to have fallen overboard in Jamaica Bay on Thursday morning when a 10-foot-long boat overturned near the eastern end of Far Rockaway, Queens, the authorities said.

title: Trade Center Financing Rift Still Wide as Deadline Nears
description: With a deadline approaching, the Port Authority and the developer Larry A. Silverstein have so far been unable to resolve their longstanding differences for rebuilding ground zero, with the authority getting a chilly reception to its latest proposal.

title: Internet Radio Host Testifies His Violent Words Were All Talk, No Action
description: Federal prosecutors on Thursday sought to portray Harold C. Turner, the incendiary radio talk show host, as a white supremacist whose racist and at times violent rhetoric predated his recruitment as a paid government informant and continued after the Federal Bureau of Investigation dropped him for what it called serious control problems.

title: Setting Chiles Past Aside, a City Welcomes Soldiers
description: CONCEPCIN, Chile  They may have arrived a couple of days late, and carrying a painful legacy from Chiles past, but to an emotional lvaro Ramrez, the presence of some 6,000 troops here on the streets of Chiles second largest city was a godsend.

title: Cuban Defector Joins the Cincinnati Reds With Much to Learn
description: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  Aroldis Chapman uncoiled his loose, wiry frame, and the $30.25 million fastball exploded from his left hand. It crashed into the right leg of another top prospect for the Cincinnati Reds, Todd Frazier, who shouted and crumpled to the dirt. Trainers helped him off the field.

title: Suspicious and Angry, a Shiite Clerics Followers Await the Iraqi Vote
description: KUFA, Iraq  Sentiments seethed like the weather Thursday near the Kufa Mosque, terra sancta for the followers of Moktada al-Sadr. Under a sky cast in shades of ocher by a sandstorm, the militant clerics men struggled to sort truth from rumor in the campaign for Sundays election that has put them on the defensive.

title: Canada Wonders Whether Olympic Hockey Gold Will Lend Shine to Prime Minister
description: OTTAWA  Prime Minister Stephen Harper demurred Monday when asked at a news conference to comment about what impact Canadas buoyant post-Olympic Games mood might have on his political future.

title: Heads of 12 Fed Districts Press to Keep Central Bank, and Their Role, in Place
description: WASHINGTON  As Congress haggles over a broad overhaul of the nations financial regulations, officials at the Federal Reserve have mounted a highly public effort to maintain, and perhaps even expand, the central banks regulatory powers.

title: Michigan Lawmaker Steps Up at Ways and Means
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Sander M. Levin, a liberal Democrat from Michigan and a bookish expert on trade policy, stepped into the powerful post of chairman of the Ways and Means Committee on Thursday as Democrats averted an internal battle over replacing Charles B. Rangel of New York.

title: Critics Cry Shame, and Transit Agency Pleads Poverty
description: For the last week, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Jay H. Walder, has listened to angry outbursts and insults from New Yorkers who are furious over the agencys proposed cuts to bus and subway service.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 999 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: 2010 Iraqi Elections: Early Voting
