description: In early voting for Iraq's parliamentary elections, Iraqi security forces turned out to vote. But attacks near polling stations left the guardians themselves vulnerable as they cast their ballots

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 4, 2010

title: Prosecutor in Manhattan Will Monitor Convictions
description: The Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., announced Thursday that he would start a program to safeguard against wrongful convictions, addressing one of the most talked-about topics during his campaign for the office.

title: Governor Gets Help From Lawyer of Spitzers
description: Gov. David A. Paterson has sought the help of a veteran lawyer with a decent track record when it comes to helping someone in that office.

title: I.M.F. Help for Greece Is a Risky Prospect
description: Greece skirted disaster this week by persuading investors and politicians that it is finally on track to fix its finances. But even before the dust settles, the government is setting the stage for a potential conflict with Germany, France and other European governments that may raise doubts about the sustainability of the euro project.

title: Early Voting Begins in Iraq
description: Early voting for parliament opened for thousands of soldiers and police officers in Iraq, but was marred by attacks on polling stations.

title: Cancer Kills Many Sea Lions, and Its Cause Remains a Mystery
description: For 14 years, since they first reported that a disturbing proportion of deaths among rescued California sea lions were caused by metastatic cancer, researchers have been trying to pinpoint the source of the illness.

title: Recovery? Yes, a Little
description: Slowly, signs of confidence are returning to the regions housing market. The latest Case-Shiller index data shows that Bay Area home prices in December were up 4.8 percent from 12 months earlier. Real estate agents report seeing multiple offers again, including on foreclosed properties, which made up 36.6 percent of all homes sold in the area in January, according to MDA DataQuick.

title: Unheralded Brazilian Faced Long Road to First Tee
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  The first round of the Honda Classic seemed to be unfolding as usual on a blustery, bright and chilly Thursday afternoon at PGA National Resort. Starched flags snapped behind the grandstand at the 18th green. An international player was tied with a recent qualifying school graduate for the lead over a South American and the only American player to win here in the past five years.

title: Give Some Relief
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  We havent heard from todays constructor, Louis Hildebrand, since 2005. Welcome back!

title: Local Versions of Europes Everyday Wines
description: Terms like brutal and worst year in history were tossed around with the release of 2009 sales figures at the nations largest wine industry trade show, a few weeks ago in Sacramento.

title: An Agent of Evictions, Surprised by the Humanity She Sees
description: In the dark hours when people learn they are losing their homes, it is Susan J. Parkers face they see, her hand that proffers the eviction notice, her voice they hear: Youve been served.

title: Massachusetts: Congressman to Retire
description: Representative Bill Delahunt, Democrat of Massachusetts, will retire from Congress at the end of his term. Senator John Kerry issued a statement Thursday night that lamented his colleagues decision, which had been reported earlier on The Boston Globes Web site. Mr. Delahunt, 68, was first elected in 1996 to represent the 10th District, which runs from Quincy to Cape Cod.

title: Baseball Officials Studying How to Implement H.G.H. Test
description: Major League Baseballs top drug-testing official confirmed Thursday that M.L.B. was studying starting blood tests for human growth hormone in the minors and that obtaining the kits required for the tests was not going to be a significant problem.

title: Bloggingheads: I'll Wait for the Movie
description: Walter Kirn, left, author of Up in the Air, and Susan Orlean of The New Yorker discuss how books become films.

title: Putting High Takeover Premiums in Perspective
description: Takeover premiums in the United States this year have surged to levels not seen in nearly a decade. Acquirers have paid an average of about 40 percent above market prices to get their quarry. Investors on the receiving end shouldnt get too excited, though. Rather than reflecting ebullience, it looks as if healthy companies are pouncing on laggards while they can.

title: Few Signs of Olympic Warmth but Lots of Fire at Garden
description: The era of Olympic good feeling is officially over, as demonstrated by the Rangers prickly 5-4 overtime loss to Pittsburgh on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. There was plenty of ill feeling, both on the ice between the teams and in the stands directed at the home club, as the Rangers blew a 4-2 lead and allowed 23 of the games last 24 shots.

title: The Carpetbaggers 2010 Oscar Predictions
description: Melena Ryzik, a.k.a. the Carpetbagger, has spent more than three months following the news and nonsense of Hollywoods awards season. Now she uses all that knowledge to offer her intelligence on who will emerge victorious Sunday night and why.

title: Inquiry Into Toyotas Fixes
description: Federal safety regulators said on Thursday that they were investigating cases of unintended acceleration in Toyotas that have already been repaired as the number of such reports grew to 60.

title: Three Strikes Against Ford
description: To the Editor:

title: Trials and Error
description: Congressional Republicans often say that the United States should use every legal means to combat terrorism  and they are right, which makes it deeply puzzling that they want to deprive the government of the single most effective way of bringing terrorists to justice.

title: Senator Bunnings Universe
description: So the Bunning blockade is over. For days, Senator Jim Bunning of Kentucky exploited Senate rules to block a one-month extension of unemployment benefits. In the end, he gave in, although not soon enough to prevent an interruption of payments to around 100,000 workers.

title: A.I.G., Greece, and Whos Next?
description: As Greece has tottered on the brink of fiscal chaos, threatening to drag much of Europe down with it, Wall Streets role in the fiasco has drawn well-deserved scorn.

title: Dont Ask, Dont Tell, Dont Change
description: Lake Oswego, Ore.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: The Wal-Mart Hippies
description: About 40 years ago, a social movement arose to destroy the establishment. The people we loosely call the New Left wanted to take on The Man, return power to the people, upend the elites and lead a revolution.

title: A Chance for the Bluefin
description: There finally may be a reprieve for the bluefin tuna of the Mediterranean and eastern Atlantic, which are spiraling rapidly downward toward commercial extinction. On Wednesday, the Obama administration endorsed a ban on international trade in these fish. It must use all of its influence to get the European Union and others to follow.

title: Reasons Not to Keep U.S. Troops in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: A Place Where Open and Honest Discussions Are in Style
description: In bright red letters, Rons Barber Shop is printed on the glass front at 6058 West North Avenue on Chicagos far West Side. A bumper sticker is plastered on the shops back door with a message to the community: Stop. Killing. People.

title: Environmentalist Prods Fellow Blacks to Join in Her Crusade
description: No one can accuse Naomi Davis of lacking ambition. She wants simultaneously to rebuild black America and save the planet  one neighborhood at a time. She knows she cannot do either alone. Her plan is to recruit and train an army. A green army.

title: Whirlwind of a Day for Mets, Not Just on the Field
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Japanese pitcher Hisanori Takahashi walked into the Mets clubhouse at 8:01 a.m. Thursday after a two-day adventure in the Dominican Republic and initiated the longest and most noteworthy day in spring training.

title: Taste of the Majors Fuels Quest for Comeback
description: Kerry Wood, Mark Prior, Billy Petrick.

title: Recycling Recyclers of Program That Failed
description: While Mayor Richard M. Daley has changed tactics on residential recycling in an effort to build public participation in the program, that has not stopped him from recycling some of the politically connected people with prior experience at his once-vaunted Blue Bag plants.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the reasons that Harold E. Ford Jr., a former congressman from Tennessee, abandoned his bid to challenge Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York misspelled, in some editions, the given name of the leader of Naral Pro-Choice New York, who grilled Mr. Ford on his abortion rights voting record. She is Kelli Conlin, not Kelly. The article also misidentified the New York neighborhood that includes the headquarters of the Stonewall Democrats, who met with Mr. Ford. It is Greenwich Village, not Chelsea.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery results in some editions on Thursday misstated the dates of the drawings. The numbers under the date March 4 were actually drawn on March 3, and the numbers under March 3 were drawn on March 2.

title: U.S. Warns of Malaria Risk in Haiti
description: Seven emergency responders, three Haitian residents now in the United States and one American traveler are known to have caught malaria in Haiti after the Jan. 12 earthquake, United States health officials said Thursday. Malaria is endemic throughout Haiti, so Haitians now living outdoors and relief workers are at substantial risk for the disease, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Tuesday about a federal judges order that mentally ill people be moved out of large, institutional housing and into their own homes misidentified the government to which the order was directed. It is New York State, not New York City.

title: Russia: Looking Ahead on Georgia
description: Russias prime minister, Vladimir V. Putin, met with a prominent member of Georgias opposition on Thursday in Moscow and expressed hope for improved relations between Russia and Georgia more than a year and a half after they fought a brief war. I expect that, relying on those who want normal relations with Russia, we can restore our relations to pre-crisis levels, Mr. Putin said in his meeting with Nino Burjanadze, a former ally of the Georgian president, Mikheil Saakashvili, but who is now one of his most vehement critics. Russian officials have ruled out negotiating with Mr. Saakashvili, whose term ends in 2013.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Friday about the arrest of a custodian at Kings County Hospital Center on charges of sexually assaulting a mentally disabled patient misstated the date that a settlement in a lawsuit over conditions at the psychiatric unit was reached and referred incorrectly to the oversight called for by a consent decree. The settlement was reached on Jan. 7, not Jan. 8, and the Department of Justice and the suits plaintiffs  not a federal judge  will monitor conditions at the unit. The oversight error also appeared on Jan. 8 in an article in some editions about the settlement.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Itineraries pages on Tuesday about the increase in the price of airline tickets because of government fees and taxes misstated the increase in the effective tax rate from 1993 to 2008. A study showed that it increased to 16 percent of the average fare in 2008, from 11 percent in 1993; it did not increase by 11 percent. The article also misstated some figures on the Air Passenger Duty in Britain and the increase to take effect on Nov. 1. The current duty is 45 in economy class, which will rise to 60, not 90, on Nov. 1. The current duty in premium cabins is 90, not 60, and that fee will rise to 120 on Nov. 1.

title: Arum Says Boxings Return to Yankee Stadium Is Set
description: Bob Arum promoted the last boxing match at the old Yankee Stadium, back in 1976 when Muhammad Ali beat Ken Norton. Now, Arum and Top Rank Boxing will promote the first fight in the new Yankee Stadium, between Miguel Cotto and Yuri Foreman on June 5.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about The Secret of Kells, which has been nominated for the Academy Award for best animated feature, referred incompletely to its screenings in the United States and misidentified at one point the city where it ran for a week to qualify for Oscar consideration. As the article noted elsewhere, the weeklong run was in Burbank, Calif., not Los Angeles. In addition to that run and screenings at some festivals in New York, it was also shown at the Mostly British Film Festival in San Francisco. (A review of the film, which opens today in Manhattan, appears on Page C6.)

title: Corrections
description: An art review last Friday about William Kentridge: Five Themes, at the Museum of Modern Art, misidentified the composer whose music accompanies the installation I am not me, the horse is not mine. The work was inspired by The Nose, an opera by Dmitri Shostakovich that Mr. Kentridge has directed and designed, but the music is by Philip Miller, not Shostakovich.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Michael Foot, who led the British Labour Party in the early 1980s, misstated part of the name of an organization he helped found. It is the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, not the Committee for Nuclear Disarmament.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Jets Land Antonio Cromartie
description: The Jets confirmed late Thursday night that they had agreed in principle with the San Diego Chargers to acquire cornerback Antonio Cromartie for a conditional 2011 draft pick.

title: Modesto Cartagena, Hero of Korea, Is Dead at 87
description: Modesto Cartagena, who was cited for heroism in the Korean War while fighting in an Army regiment composed almost entirely of soldiers from Puerto Rico and acclaimed for its bravery, died Tuesday at his home in Guayama, P.R. He was 87.

title: Division Over Paterson, Even Among Backers
description: Late Thursday evening, amid signs that support for Gov. David A. Paterson was crumbling in black political circles, the Rev. Al Sharpton convened a meeting at Sylvias, the fabled Harlem restaurant where he often holds court.

title: Panthers Cut Losses, and Delhomme
description: It is a rare day when an N.F.L. starting quarterback is released, but the Carolina Panthers are expected to send Jake Delhomme packing Friday, taking advantage of the lack of a salary cap to dump a player they gave an ill-advised contract extension to just a year ago. The Panthers still owe Delhomme almost $13 million. Thedecision was first reported by Fox Sports.

title: Thomas H. Pigford, Nuclear Engineer, Is Dead at 87
description: Thomas H. Pigford, an independent-minded nuclear engineer who was recruited by the federal government for his advice on major nuclear accidents and nuclear waste, died Saturday at his home in Oakland, Calif.. He was 87.

title: Word of the Day | masochist
description: masochist \ma-s-kist, ma-z- also ma-\ noun

title: Bears Become Front-Runners for Peppers
description: Defensive end Julius Peppers, the prize of the 2010 free-agent class, is expected to visit the Chicago Bears on Friday, making the Bears the clear front runners to land the elite pass rusher. The Bears are not usually active in free agency, but they are without draft picks in the first and second rounds this season because they traded them away to acquire quarterback Jay Cutler last off-season.

title: Finding a Good Table Wine and Other Highlights From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: Vino di Tavolo, the Wine for Our Times | The appeal of wines of the European countryside, their freshness, their blended verve and low prices, are on the minds of California wine makers right now. High-end wine sales dropped significantly in 2009. Jason Haas, who runs his familys Tablas Creek Vineyard in Paso Robles, says he is trying to find a way to make appealing table wines with approachable price tags, even though the price of land in the Bay Area tends to get in the way. He sells his own fine version of a red Ctes du Rhone, called Ctes de Tablas, for around $20. Good table wines may remain rare, but new ones are on the way, often made from less-than-fashionable varieties in less-than-fashionable places.

title: Robert T. McCall, Space Artist, Dies at 90
description: Robert T. McCall, an artist whose fervor for space exploration found expression in his six-story-tall mural at the National Air and Space Museum and two postage stamps canceled on the Moon, died on Feb. 26 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 90.

title: The Worst Job in the World? She Loves It
description: I first encountered Susan J. Parker while writing a column about a family in foreclosure being evicted in Redwood City. It was her job as a process server to deliver papers to the familys matriarch ordering everyone off the property. Fridays column takes a look at her work in this housing-centered recession.

title: News Quiz | March 5, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Orbitz Worldwide Names 2 New Directors
description: Orbitz Worldwide, the online travel retailer, said Thursday that it had named Martin Brand and Brad Gerstner to its board of directors, effective immediately, Reuters reported.

title: Heads of Fed Districts Press to Keep Bank in Place
description: As Congress haggles over a broad overhaul of the nations financial regulations, officials at the Federal Reserve have mounted a highly public effort to maintain, and perhaps even expand, the central banks regulatory powers, Sewell Chan reports for The New York Times.

title: Passion About Fashion
description: WHO are the designers who have been inspired by Avatar to create clothes collections like those pictured above?

title: Panelists Question Citis Government Guarantee
description: The chief executive of Citigroup told a government panel on Thursday that no financial institution should be too big to fail and that he was aggressively moving to break up the bank and rein in excessive risk-taking, Eric Dash writes in The New York Times.

title: Iceland Set to Vote Down Anglo-Dutch Deal
description: Icelanders are set to reject the terms for repaying Anglo-Dutch debts in a referendum on Saturday, forcing new negotiations with creditors and delaying financial aid the country needs to fix its shattered economy, Reuters reported.

title: Colonial to Sell Up to $50 Million of Stock
description: Colonial Properties Trust said Thursday that it filed paperwork that would allow it to sell up to $50 million worth of its common shares through an at-the-market offering, in which a broker executes a sale at the best price currently available, The Associated Press reported.

title: Qatar and Singapore Get Behind Pru Deal
description: GIC, which is Singapores biggest sovereign wealth fund, and Qatar Holding have committed to underwrite a significant portion of Prudentials $20 billion rights issue, Reuters reported.

title: Hong Kong Bourse Outlines Renminbi-Based Strategy
description: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing will offer Chinese renminbi-denominated products and plans to become a primary channel for investing by Chinese nationals overseas, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Adenyo Lassoes $26.9 Million
description: Adenyo, a maker of software for mobile advertising campaigns, took in $26.9 million in a round made up of institutional and private placement funding, PaidContent  reported.

title: BAE Sells 10% Stake in Defense Firm Saab
description: Defense contractor BAE Systems said Friday it has sold a 10.25 percent stake in Swedish defense company Saab for 1.066 billion kronor ($149 million), as part of an ongoing divestment process, The Associated Press reported.

title: Putting High Takeover Premiums in Perspective
description: Takeover premiums in the United States this year have surged to levels not seen in nearly a decade. Acquirers have paid an average of about 40 percent above market prices to get their quarry. Investors on the receiving end shouldnt get too excited, though. Rather than reflecting ebullience, it looks as if healthy companies are pouncing on laggards while they can, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: A Plan B for Hong Kongs Stock Exchange?
description: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange is the worlds second-biggest by market capitalization. Call it the China factor. Yet as the mainlands own exchanges get bigger, Hong Kong cant count on winning prize listings forever; its time for a Plan B, Breakingviews says.

title: China Premier Details Economic Plan
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said Friday that the nation would expand social spending, bolster lending, curb inflation and meet its traditional 8 percent economic growth target in 2010, but he cautioned that China still confronted a very complex situation in the wake of the global financial crisis.

title: Glencore Buys Back Prodeco, Still Mulling Partner
description: Glencore, the Swiss-based commodity trader, bought back its prized Prodeco coal operations in Colombia from mining group Xstrata, and is still talking to possible partners, Reuters reported, citing a source close to the deal.

title: Gunman at Pentagon Linked to Anger Against U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The gunman who opened fire at an entrance to the Pentagon on Thursday, injuring two police officers, harbored a deep-seated anger toward federal authorities and may have believed that the government staged the Sept. 11 attacks, officials said Friday.

title: Jupiter Moving Toward an I.P.O.?
description: Jupiter Asset Management, the British fund firm, is renegotiating its loans with investors, ahead of a possible listing, The Financial Times reported.

title: Clicker Redesigns Its Online Video Guide
description: From Nick Bilton at Bits:

title: Tip of the Week: Twitter for Windows 7 Help
description: Need quick, fast help for a particular Windows 7 issue on that new computer? Microsofts customer service team has taken to Twitter for brief replies and links to technical support documents on the companys site. Just visit twitter.com/MicrosoftHelps and post your question after you log in or create your own free Twitter account.

title: On Final Campaign Day, Iraqi Leader Lists Gains
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki used the last day of Iraqs election campaign on Friday to make a detailed and at times pugnacious case to be re-elected to an office he acknowledged that he could lose.

title: In Testimony, Brown Says Iraq War Was Right Decision
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown made a long-awaited appearance on Friday before a high-level inquiry into the Iraq war, defending the Labour governments decision to invade alongside American troops but questioning United States planning for the aftermath.

title: The Four Antis
description: Nickname for protesters in Hong Kong, based on the four things their critics say they oppose  authority, government, establishment and tradition.

title: Britains Bonus Tax May Reap 2.5 Billion
description: Britains one-time tax on bank bonuses could bring in more than 2.5 billion ($3.7 billion) to the governments coffers this financial year, according to a survey of banks conducted by The Financial Times.

title: Strong Aftershocks Strike Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  As Chile worked to restore utilities to areas ravaged by last Saturdays earthquake, two strong offshore tremors jolted the countrys southern coastline on Friday morning striking close to the epicenter of the first devastating quake.

title: In Season: Artichokes in Rome
description: In late February, Romes most venerated vegetable, the carciofo romanesco, enters its peak season. This globe-shaped artichoke has been cultivated in the region since antiquity, but its novelty has not worn off. On the contrary, Romans are more hungry than ever for their native carciofi, enjoying them in several traditional forms. Here are some recommendations on where to sample the tasty dish in its variety of incarnations.

title: Cromartie Comes With a Trouble Tag
description: The Jets acquired Antonio Cromartie because he could become the perfect complement to Darrelle Revis. Character was apparently not a big consideration.

title: Wells Chiefs Pay Raises Questions, Czar Says
description: Pay czar Kenneth R. Feinberg believes the compensation paid to Wells Fargos chief executive for 2009 raises serious questions, he told CNBC on Thursday.

title: Trustee Sues Former Thornburg Execs for Theft
description: Four top executives of Thornburg Mortgage improperly paid themselves handsome bonuses just before the mortgage lender filed for bankruptcy last year, and stole money and ideas from Thornburg to secretly launch a new firm, the bankruptcy trustee in charge of liquidating the lender alleged in a lawsuit, Reuters reported.

title: A.I.G.s Swaps With European Banks May Linger
description: Insurancelike guarantees that the American International Group wrote on more than $100 billion in assets held by European banks could remain on the insurers books longer than anticipated, Reuters reported, citing a regulatory filing.

title: Tribune Creditors Sue Banks Over Buyout
description: A group of Tribune Company bondholders have sued the banks that financed Samuel Zells 2007 leveraged buyout, claiming that the banks loaded the media company with debt knowing it would eventually push the firm into bankruptcy.

title: 2010 Iraqi Elections: Early Voting
Bad Films Are Us
description: Todays idea: We enjoy bad films more intensely than we enjoy good ones because they are like us, a professor says. Our lives are like bad movies.

title: Wake Up!
description: Wake up, wake up, you sleepy head.

title: Terra Firmas Suit Against Citi Delayed
description: A U.S. judge said he would rule by the end of March on whether to grant a request by Citigroup to move a lawsuit by Terra Firma Capital Partners to London, in a dispute over the buyout shops acquisition of theEMI Group, Reuters reported.

title: Stray Questions for: Sam Lipsyte
description: Sam Lipsyte is the author of several works of fiction; his new novel, The Ask, has just been published.

title: How Much Fraud and Abuse Is There in U.S. Health Care?
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Hedge Funds Care a Bit More This Year
description: One barometer of how hedge fund managers are feeling about the health of the industry is just how wide theyre willing to open their wallets for charity.

title: Geneva Auto Show: 2011 VW Touareg and Touareg Hybrid
description: 8:07 a.m. | Updated

title: Sampler: Hollister Man Is Dead After Pentagon Shooting, and Education Protests Are Mostly Peaceful
description: A Day of Mostly Peaceful Protests | Thousands of students, parents and faculty members, angered by cuts in state financing for education and increases in college fees, protested across the state Thursday. Although some demonstrations were confrontational, and 150 people were arrested after they stopped traffic on Interstate 880 in Oakland, most of the protests were peaceful. How are we going to save the future if we cant even get into our classes? Reid E. Milburn, the president of the Student Senate for California Community Colleges, said at a protest in Sacramento. [The New York Times]

title: Spitzers Lawyer Takes Governors Call
description: Gov. David A. Paterson has sought the help of a veteran lawyer with a decent track record when it comes to helping someone in that office.

title: Perks of Being in the Iraqi Parliament
description: With only two days left until Sundays parliamentary election, one might reasonably ask why anyone would be willing to endure public contempt and risk assassination to hold a seat in a body that even its own members say has done little to improve the country during the past few years.

title: Up Front: Joseph ONeill
description: Joseph ONeill is probably best known for his third novel, Netherland, which the Book Review selected as one of its 10 Best Books of 2008; in his review, Dwight Garner called it the wittiest, angriest, most exacting and most desolate work of fiction weve yet had about life in New York and London after the World Trade Center fell. ONeill has also been a published poet and, until 2000, a lawyer as well.

title: Greece: We Dont Want to Be Europes Lehman
description: Deficits can pave the wave to popularity in politics, at least in the short run, and they tempt even the most conservative parties to spend big.

title: One Less Distraction While Driving
description: As my colleague, Matt Richtel, has pointed out in a number of articles, sights, sounds and activities that can distract a driver continue to grow. But Mini, the car company owned by BMW, has just introduced one new feature that may actually decrease driver distraction.

title: And the Oscar Goes to... Next!
description: Melena Ryzik reports from "Meet the Oscars," a public exhibit that brings Oscar statuettes to New York City.

title: Cars of the Future, Indeed
description: GENEVA

title: Video: And the Oscar Goes To Next!
Ten Ways to Teach the Oscars
description: Here are some ideas for bringing this years Academy Awards season and Oscar-nominated films and performances into your classroom.

title: A Very Old-School S.U.V. With Useful New Tricks
description: TESTED 2010 Jeep Wrangler Unlimited Rubicon 4x4

title: That Mild-Mannered Car of Steel
description: HUDSON, N.Y.

title: An Actor Takes His Place on a Stage of a Different Sort
description: THE actor Edward Herrmann has played F.D.R. in Eleanor and Franklin, Nelson Rockefeller in Nixon," Anderson Pearson in The Practice and the oldest intern in Greys Anatomy. But a role he enjoys as much as any of those is serving as master of ceremonies for the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance.

title: A Heinz 57 Selection on the Block
description: THE Amelia Island concours weekend in Florida is ratcheting up its commercial side.

title: Franco-American With an Aftertaste
description: WHAT WAS IT? The 1983-87 Renault Alliance was the Pep Le Pew of subcompacts, a stinker born of Renaults short-lived alliance  hence the name  with American Motors.

title: Jobless Rate Holds Steady, Raising Hopes of Recovery
description: The American economy lost fewer jobs than expected last month, bolstering hopes that the worst may finally be over in the wrenching event known as the Great Recession.

title: Seeing Things | Studio Visit: Alison Berger
description: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.

title: The Community-Mad Men Crossover Written Just for Us
description: With Alison Brie doing double-duty on AMCs Mad Men and NBCs Community, it was only a matter of time before the two shows intersected  we just never anticipated it would happen like this. Its moments like this one from Thursday nights episode of Community when were fairly certain the television set is talking directly to us.

title: The Fans Are Disappointed, but Is That a Crime?
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: The Early Word: Unemployment at 9.7%
description: Despite fears that the nations unemployment rate could climb back into double digits because of the heavy snowstorms in February, the latest figures show that it remained nearly steady at 9.7 percent last month.

title: Should Doctors Share the Cost Cutting?
description: In the latest Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen writes about the ethical obligations of doctors in the health care overhaul, and whether cutting costs is one of them.

title: China Premier Details Economic Plan
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao crafted a portrait of a China on a steady course toward greatness on Friday, telling his nations unelected legislature that the government could expand social spending, increase lending, pour money into strategic industries and still meet its traditional 8 percent economic growth target in 2010.

title: Now Screening | Gareth Pugh
description: The fall 2010 collection from Gareth Pugh at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Turkey Criticizes House Committee Vote on Armenian Killings
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys foreign minister said Friday that the vote by a Congressional committee in Washington condemning the mass killing of Armenians early in the last century as genocide would damage ties with the Obama administration and set back reconciliation efforts between Turkey and Armenia.

title: Is the Recovery Losing Steam?
description: How you view todays jobs report depends on snow.

title: Surprisingly Strong Job Figures
description: The jobs report today is encouraging in a number of ways, and should make the double-dip recession crowd at least pause.

title: Now Booking | The Arch Hotel in London
description: When the Arch Hotel opened for business in London in late January, on the heels of reports that Britain had finally nudged out of recession, it suggested that perhaps the crash would soon be a distant memory. Indeed, the new 82-room hotel in the Marble Arch neighborhood feels like a museum dedicated to precrisis town house living: Occupying nearly a block of remodeled Georgian manses close to Hyde Park, the hotels discreet front doors give way to interiors so perfectly appointed  white orchids blooming in green glass bowls, plump sofas by the designer Tom Dixon set around a fireplace  that the effect is almost clinical.

title: Apple iPad to Arrive in Stores on April 3
description: Apple announced on Friday that the Wi-Fi versions of its long-awaited iPad will arrive April 3 in stores in the United States. The models that can tap into AT&Ts 3G wireless data network will be available in late April.

title: Comparing This Recession to Previous Ones: Job Losses
description: Source: Bureau of Labor StatisticsHorizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: Markets Find the Upside of the Jobs Report
description: A better-than-expected snapshot of unemployment in the United States lifted Wall Street on Friday, reinforcing hopes that the job market  and the broader economy  might be gaining strength.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Road Trips
description: Our hardcover list sees plenty of action this week. The new collected editions include a story based on a video game (No. 2, Halo), the latest chapter in a superheros long-running saga (No. 3, Starman) and more high jinks for a mercenary (No. 10, Deadpool). In X Marks the Spot, Deadpool heads to San Francisco for a visit with the X-Men, who are less than thrilled with his arrival.

title: A Childs Allergies Are Serious but Can Be Treated Effectively
description: IT starts with a telltale sniffle, itchy eyes and an occasional cough. You think your little one is getting a cold, but the cold never comes while the runny nose seems never to leave.

title: Roves Boldface Names Edition
description: Writing the White House memoir is a time-honored way of setting the record straight  or even spinning history a little bit. It also has the side benefit of allowing the aide-turned-author to finally unload.

title: Apple iPad Hits Stores April 3; Preorders Begin March 12
description: Our sister blog, Bits, reports that the Wi-Fi versions of Apples iPad tablet computer will go on sale April 3, with the 3G versions available later that month.

title: Off the Job
description: My first bout of unemployment began in October 2008, about a month after the Lehman Brothers collapse. Losing my job as a proofreader in the financial district was serious, but I didnt think anything too terrible was going to happen to me. I tend to land on my feet. I see myself as hopeful, if not optimistic. For years I scraped by with one day job or another, mostly gypsy clerical stuff. In social upheavals, however, the gypsies are the first to go.

title: Complaint Box | Yes, Brilliant Parent, We Hear You
description: We see them everywhere. And if were being honest, we have all had the same frightening and ignoble urge to smash their heads in with a brick. I am speaking about those smug and uber-informative moms and dads who do their parenting in public places  aggressively and at the top of their highly educated lungs. They are easy to recognize, decked out in natural fabrics and larded up with the self-importance that comes from foisting teachable moments on an unsuspecting public.

title: Saving Money During Allergy Season
description: Pollen and dust mites may make you sniffle and sneeze. But its the medical bills that really leave parents teary-eyed during allergy season.

title: Friday Reading
Do You Want a Frittata?
description: Eggs are great for breakfast, but they can be even better for a quick and easy dinner. In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman extols the virtues of the oven-baked frittata.

title: Famine in a Restaurant Ad? Luck Runs Out for Dennys
description: The Dennys restaurant chain had been enjoying a wave of positive publicity after its most recent offer of free breakfasts, made in commercials that ran during the Super Bowl on Feb. 7. But a subsequent spot has earned the wrath of many consumers.

title: Game Change
description: Stuff thats spot on. More

title: Suspected Pentagon Gunman Outlined Theories Online
description: Updated | 2:01 p.m. As my colleagues Thom Shaker and Ian Urbina report, police and F.B.I. investigators are examining writing, audio and video thought to have been posted on the Web in recent years by the gunman who opened fire outside the Pentagon on Thursday night.

title: T-Pain Tips His Hat to Freaknik: The Musical
description: History has proved that you can make a hit musical out of just about anything, from the plight of French peasants in early-19th-century France to a bunch of mewling, moonlight-contemplating cats. But can you make one about Freaknik, the popular but controversial Atlanta party of the 1980s and 90s that was eventually shut down amid concerns about overcrowding, violence and the degradation of women? T-Pain is about to find out.

title: Rocking the Oscar Vote
description: Since the Bagger has weighed in with her predictions and Janet Roberts has offered some handy tips for guessing winners, we thought wed take a look at how readers are voting and what they are saying on our interactive Oscar ballot.

title: Raising Money for Haiti Is Childs Play
description: Gavin Santana, 7, busily mashed Play-Doh through a plastic octopus stencil to make green hair. He noted that he is usually Puerto Rican, but also Irish, so he picked green for good luck.

title: Goodson, a Late Bloomer, Peaks at the Right Time
description: Clarence Goodson of the United States switched from frontline target man to backline general in college, and that move might be the genesis of his World Cup career.

title: Temporary Help Bouncing Back
description: 4:30 p.m. | Updated

title: Answers About Education Tax Credits and Deductions: Part 3
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Weekend Competition: Keep Calm & Sloganize
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share their favorite slogans from advertising, politics, media and the rest.

title: Beep Beep, Beep Beep, No: Lennon Car Commercial Angers Fans
description: Presumably, this wasnt what John Lennon meant by instant karma: a European automobile commercial in which that singer is featured has drawn swift outrage from fans, as well as a rapid defense from his son Sean Ono Lennon.

title: Ukraines Leader Visits Russia
description: MOSCOW  Ukraines newly inaugurated president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, arrived in Moscow on Friday promising a sharp turn in his countrys relations with Russia, five years after the Orange Revolution chilled formerly close ties between the two neighbors.

title: University Rejects Pellegrino Claim in Degree Dispute
description: The university that Charles Pellegrino, the embattled author of The Last Train From Hiroshima, claimed had awarded and then stripped him of a Ph.D. issued a statement late Thursday saying that it utterly rejects his claims as baseless and defamatory.

title: Car Commercial Angers John Lennon Fans
description: From our colleagues at Arts Beat:

title: The Second Law Strikes Back
description: Last week we discussed the papaya battery, an utterly simple device whose geometry apparently creates a temperature difference where there was none before, thus violating the Second Law of Thermodynamics and creating potentially unlimited energy. In the field of thermodynamics, which abounds in apparent paradoxes, this is one of the most delicious paradoxes ever. Devices like the papaya battery, based on ellipsoids and parts of spheres, have been known to science since at least 1959 (J.C. Fallows in New Scientist) and have been discussed in the scientific literature in cutting-edge journals like the Journal of Statistical Physics and Physics Bulletin under the names Ellipsoid Paradox and Chinese furnace which interested readers can google.

title: Now Screening | Rick Owens
description: The fall 2010 collection from Rick Owens at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Richard Ravitch, Political Pinch-Hitter
description: An interactive timeline of Richard Ravitch's life and career.

title: Tribunal Strikes Back Against the Empire for Snoop Dogg
description: If Britain can countenance a meeting between Queen Elizabeth II and Lady Gaga, and permit Miley Cyrus to dance in leather hot pants for Her Majesty, then surely it can allow Snoop Dogg back into the country. That rappers long-running battle to be allowed within British borders took a turn in his favor this week when a tribunal there said it was wrong for him to have been denied entry into Britain three years ago, Reuters reported.

title: House Panel Wants More Safety Records From Toyota
description: DETROIT  Lawmakers investigating Toyotas big recalls said on Friday that they were not satisfied the automaker had thoroughly investigated whether a faulty electronic system could be the cause of sudden unintended acceleration in its vehicles.

title: Debt Is a Political Issue
description: Earlier this week I gave a talk about the state of the crisis at Princetons Plasma Physics Lab, and one audience member asked a really good question: if the problem is that interest rates are at the zero lower bound, why should we worry about government borrowing? After all, doesnt that mean that the government can borrow at a zero rate?

title: The Week Ahead| Mar. 7  Mar. 13
description: Dance

title: Correction: Hes Had Work: Preserving the Face of a Revolution
description: An article last Sunday about the play Lenins Embalmers, at the Ensemble Studio Theater in Clinton, misstated the circumstances of the death of the poet Vladimir Mayakovsky, whose verse Lenin lived! Lenin lives! Lenin will live! was for decades recited by Soviet schoolchildren. Mayakovsky committed suicide in 1930; he did not die in the gulag.

title: Now Sipping | High (Fashion) Tea at the Ritz
description: Theyve only been pouring the most confidential cuppa in Paris for two weeks, but a reservation is already a good idea if you want to snag a table at the citys ultimate la vie en rose Saturday-afternoon hideaway: high tea at the Ritz Hotel from 3 p.m. to 6 p.m. The real surprise? Its already just as popular with the local Prada posse as it is with the hotels home-team Chanel ladies. (Oh, and there are a lot of men in the room, too.)

title: Popcast: Peter Gabriel, Danny Gokey and More
description: This week: Jon Pareles on Peter Gabriels album of orchestral cover songs; Jon Caramanica reviews the new release from the American Idol alum Danny Gokey; and Ben Sisario on whats happening on the pop charts. Sia Michel is the host.

title: The Cap Is Off, but the Champagne Doesnt Flow
description: You may want to peek out the window occasionally today to make sure everything looks the same, to see if the cataclysmic universe shift that happened overnight had any visible effects. At 12:01 a.m., the National Football League officially no longer had a salary cap. If there are pieces of the sky on your lawn, please send them to Roger Goodell, c/o N.F.L. Headquarters, 280 Park Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017.

title: Editors Choice
description: WILLIE MAYS: The Life, the Legend,  by James S. Hirsch (Scribner, $30.) In his long, fascinating account, Hirsch concentrates mostly on the baseball brilliance, reminding us of a time when the only performance-enhancing drug was joy.

title: Paperback Row
description: CHEEVER: A Life,  by Blake Bailey (Vintage, $16.95.) A page of good prose remains invincible, John Cheever said shortly before his death in 1982, and he wrote many of them. Baileys stunningly detailed biography, as our reviewer, Geoffrey Wolff, called it, examines the ties between Cheevers unhappy life (alcoholism, sexual ambivalence) and his fiction with nerve and tact. Bailey is as good an interpreter of Cheevers stories and novels as I have read, Wolff said.

title: As Crises Mount, Patersons Public Support Erodes
description: Gov. David A. Patersons public support continues to plummet with each fresh revelation, but according to a poll conducted on Wednesday and Thursday, more voters in the state wanted him to finish his term than resign.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Mini Connected
description: This week at the Geneva auto show, where the new Mini Countryman crossover made its auto-show debut, Mini also introduced a new electronic infotainment system, called Mini Connected  as if there werent enough going on inside the pie-plate speedometer of a Mini.

title: Columbus Symphony Makes Severe Cutbacks
description: The Columbus Symphony Orchestra has taken drastic action to stay in business. It said on Friday that it had lopped off 13 weeks of its season, translating into a 23-percent pay cut for its musicians and $1.5 million reduction of its $9 million budget next year. Its season will now run for 25 weeks instead of 38. The orchestra said that its reduction, which was negotiated with the musicians, will eliminate three paid weeks of vacation for the players, five weeks of playing for BalletMet and Opera Columbus performances; and five weeks of special one-off concerts. Subscription concerts will be preserved, the orchestra said. The Columbus Symphony, a high-quality regional orchestra in Ohios capital, has been struggling financially for several years. The cutbacks are a particularly draconian example of trimming going on around the orchestra world amid the recession.

title: About That Garden  a Postscript
description: The day after Josh Levine told me I could not grow a decent vegetable garden because of the towering Norway maple blocking the southern sun, I received an e-mail message from him with a list of plants that grow in dense shade. He had downloaded the list from a Web site called Plants for a Future. I excerpt the list below, truncated and condensed.

title: Reyes to Return to New York for More Testing
description: Friday, March 5, 11:47 a.m. | New Information on Reyess Condition

title: Correction: Getting a Little Help to Go Out All Alone
description: An article last Sunday about a class that specializes in solo performances misspelled, at one point, the surname of a prominent monologist. He is Mike Daisey, not Daisy. The article also mischaracterized Why Solo Performance Matters, which Mr. Daisey wrote. It is a talk that he has given at performing arts festivals; it is not the name of a show.

title: Misclassifying a Certificate
description: Q.

title: Fair Game | Playing It Safe at the Armory
description: At the opening of the Armory Show last night, sellers (gallery owners) and buyers (collectors) alike agreed that this seasons fair was both safe and straightforward. And with the prices just right, it was quickly becoming successful. One harried collector breathlessly arrived at Emmanuel Perrotin Gallerys booth asking for the price of Peter Coffins Napoleonic sculpture. ($350,000  and two of the three were already sold.) David Schnells imposing landscape paintings were drawing a crowd of buyers at Berlins Eigen Art. Theyre not crazy expensive and his work has progressed, explained a young collector, who pointed to a large 8 x 10 canvas that was apparently going in the low six figures. There was more solid work by artists like Sean Landers, Mickalene Thomas and Josephine Meckseper.

title: Breast-Feeding the Wrong Baby
description: It was comedy when Pam Halpert mistakenly nursed another new mothers baby in a dark hospital room on The Office last night.

title: Maintenance Costs Through the Roof?
description: Q.

title: Post-Soviet Yearning
description: Driving by a certain decrepit five-story apartment building in the Russian city of Perm in the late 1990s, you would never have imagined you were passing a locus of magic and transcendence. There had been no heat or working toilets in the building for months, and no running water; most of the tenants had stopped receiving their salaries and pensions. Feral, abandoned children hovered in packs around uncollected refuse heaped outside the building. But Gina Ochsner, traveling there at least imaginatively, has paused at the address, peered into the courtyard and come away from it with a novel of startling, redemptive beauty.

title: Oh, Gods
description: What, if any, is the desirable intersection of the finite and the infinite, the mortal and the divine? Thats the question John Banville asks in his latest novel. Or perhaps that metaphysical query is only a bluff. Perhaps what The Infinities is really about is how much you can get away with if youre a genius, a game-changer, a master (literally) of the universe.

title: The Party Circuit, L.A. Edition
description: LOS ANGELES Enough with the heavy stuff. Its Oscar weekend: time to party.

title: The Bootleg Diaries
description: Max Watmans description of one of the liquor-distilling experts he interviews in Chasing the White Dog also applies to the author himself: He hobbies hard. In the grips of a passion for homemade spirits, Watman fumblingly assembles a rudimentary still, violating federal law and risking death by explosion or ergot (a poisonous fungus). Such dangers make him anxious, but Watman has the enthusiasts capacity for losing himself in recondite detail. He lovingly catalogs the ingredients of a whiskey mash on display at a supply store in upstate New York: crystal six-row malted barley, torrefied wheat, Maris Otter, Belgian candy sugar, flaked maize, amylase enzymes. He minutely recounts his distillation experiments, but the tone is less instructional than slapstick. After three sips, my mouth was numb, he says about one of his early batches of whiskey. He eventually makes some respectable applejack.

title: Off the Menu: A Payard Cafe in the Village
description: Franois Payard will open a bakery-cafe this summer in Greenwich Village, a change in neighborhood and style from the Upper East Side patisserie and restaurant he closed last summer after a rent dispute.

title: What Next, Upfront, Part Deux?
description: Television loves spinoffs, as any fan who followed, say, the creation of The Jeffersons and Maude from All in the Family could attest. Now a television company is planning a spinoff of sorts for a presentation to advertisers of coming programming.

title: Stanford Considers Bringing R.O.T.C. Back
description: Jimmy Ruck, a Stanford University junior, wakes up at 5:20 a.m. so he can make the 15-mile journey to Santa Clara University, where he attends training as part of the Reserve Officer Training Corps, or R.O.T.C. It begins at 6:15. Promptly.

title: Travel Deals: 300 Asia Hotels on Sale
description: Starting this Sunday, the Accor hotel group is offering 50 percent off rooms in 16 countries throughout Asia. The Three-Day Super Sale covers about 300 Accor hotels, which includes brands like Sofitel, Etap Hotel, Novotel and ibis.

title: Now Screening | Balmain
description: The fall 2010 collection from Balmain at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Porsche 911 GT3 R Hybrid Stores Power in Flywheel Generator
description: GENEVA  Porsche will give its new 911 GT3 R Hybrid racecar, which was unveiled here on Tuesday, a trial by fire in the 24 Hours on the Nordschleife of Nrburgring race in Germany in May. The intent, Porsche says, is to develop the cars potentially breakthrough technologies that could give drivers race-winning bursts of power and equally valuable gains in fuel economy.

title: Free Agency So Far: No Cap on Lessons Learned
description: It is 12 hours into N.F.L. free agency and what have we learned?

title: Correction: Hes Had Work: Preserving the Face of a Revolution
description: An article last Sunday about the play Lenins Embalmers, at the Ensemble Studio Theater in Clinton, misstated the circumstances of the death of the poet Vladimir Mayakovsky, whose verse Lenin lived! Lenin lives! Lenin will live! was for decades recited by Soviet schoolchildren. Mayakovsky committed suicide in 1930; he did not die in the gulag.

title: Kronos Quartet: An Eclectic Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Photos of the Moment | Tour de France
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Meryl Streep: Transcending the Screen
description: To the Editor

title: Just Grin and Cook It
description: For a charity auction, I donated dinner for six, to be prepared and served at our home. I like the high bidder, but dont know her well. Weve discussed the date and menu, and shes given me a guest list. I had assumed that my partner and I would join the party, but now Im not so sure. My friends say no way, but my partner said he would go out if were not sitting down to eat. What do you recommend?

title: Alice in Wonderland: The Definitive Version
description: To the Editor:

title: Iceland Voters Set to Reject Debt Deal
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  After the dust began to settle last year  after the banks failed, the currency collapsed, the stock market crashed and the government fell  the dazed inhabitants of Iceland woke up to another unpleasant problem: They owed, it seemed, some $5.3 billion to more than 300,000 angry people in the Netherlands and Britain.

title: Q. & A.: First Steps for Would-Be Rabbit Ranchers
description: Here are some final answers to readers questions about rabbits and backyard farming from Novella Carpenter, who is featured in Kim Seversons article about eating rabbit. Diners Journal would like to thank Ms. Carpenter and all the readers who participated in this exchange.

title: Nelson-Atkins Museum Turns to East Harlem for New Director
description: The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., which completed a critically praised expansion in 2007 and has been adding aggressively to its collections as part of an extended 75th anniversary celebration, has looked to New York for its next leader, choosing Julin Zugazagoitia, the director of El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem.

title: The Reading Life: Mississippi Without Barry Hannah
description: Word of Barry Hannahs death hit a lot of people hard this week, nowhere more so than in Oxford, Miss., where Mr. Hannah lived, wrote and taught for nearly three decades. He was an institution there, a living embodiment of that citys reputation as a cerebral but rowdy literary nerve center.

title: Tharp Is Back Where the Air Is Rarefied
description: TWYLA THARP opened the door of her Upper West Side penthouse on a snowy morning wearing an emerald-colored sweatshirt, its hood pulled firmly over her silver hair. Ms. Tharps no-nonsense way of looking out at the world becomes less intimidating the better you know her. On this particular morning, with her enormous eyes magnified and peering intently behind round glasses, she had the air of a cute green owl about to rob a bank.

title: An Adagio for Strings, and for the Ages
description: SAMUEL BARBERS Adagio for Strings begins softly, with a single note, a B flat, played by the violins. Two beats later the lower strings enter, creating an uneasy, shifting suspension as the melody begins a stepwise motion, like the hesitant climbing of stairs. In around eight minutes the piece is over, harmonically unresolved, never coming to rest. If any music can come close to conveying the effect of a sigh, or courage in the face of tragedy, or hope, or abiding love, it is this.

title: Help for First-Time Buyers
description: LOOKING for a fixed-rate mortgage with a competitively low interest rate, but armed with only 3 percent for a down payment, a low credit score and a modest annual income?

title: Skin Fruit
description: A look at the New Museums exhibit of works in the collection of Dakis Joannou.

title: When Not to Accept Comments
description: Transparency is a political value more easily praised than practiced. The Internet provides politicians with a seemingly direct line to voters and a way to bypass the filter of the media, yet online, transparency is always a potential liability. Because while you can control the message, you cant control how people will respond to it.

title: RCN to Sell Itself for $1.2 Billion
description: RCN, the cable operator, said on Friday that it had agreed to sell itself to the private equity firm ABRY Partners for $1.2 billion, including debt, as the leveraged buyout industry continues to get back to business.

title: The World as Their Canvas
description: Theres nothing like sitting by the fire with a good book, except maybe sitting by the fire with a good map  or better yet, a good book about maps. Ive noticed an upsurge in cartographic interest these days, especially for maps value as conceptual artwork. They can be maps of the designers mind as well as maps of terrain, concerned not just with topography but with typography too. Some maps have gone down in design history as milestones of visual erudition, like Harry C. Becks London Underground map (1931-33) or Herbert Bayers World Geo-Graphic Atlas (1953), an exemplary marriage of information, art and design. But many maps are made only as art for arts sake. In recent years, various exhibitions, catalogs and books have been devoted to assaying the cartographic arts and crafts. Four new books cover all aspects of maps and mapping, from navigation to contemplation, and two others touch on maps as well.

title: Mark Jaccom
description: As of April 21, Mr. Jaccom, 54, will become the chief executive of the tristate hub of Colliers International, a full-service commercial real estate brokerage company that recently announced a merger with FirstService Real Estate Advisors, including FirstService Williams. Mr. Jaccom was the chief executive of FirstService Williams.

title: Paris Review Names New Editor
description: Lorin Stein, an editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux whose youth belies his influence in the publishing industry, was named the editor of The Paris Review, the prestigious literary magazine, its board of directors said on Friday.

title: Group Hug | Paris
description: Theres a spirit of bricolage running through this season, as if designers wanted their clothes to convey as many possibilities as possible. Why not, for example, give a sweater a fur sleeve, or a tailored jacket a knit shoulder? Its a trick we saw over and over both in Milan and New York, but it takes a remix master like Dries Van Noten to make such combinations seem purposeful rather than whimsical. Van Notens mens-wear-inspired jackets came not just with contrasting sleeves, but with a 50s hourglass nipped waist; pastoral florals on ladylike dresses and skirts were treated with punky splashes of paint, which the designer described as rebel realist prints; neo-grunge sweatshirts happily coexisted with leopard print furs, rich brocades and military parkas reminiscent of the 70s.

title: The Heat Over Bubbling Arctic Methane
description: One of the great challenges in assessing the meaning of changes in Arctic climate and other environmental conditions is putting todays observations in long-term context. This is as true for the bubbling emissions of methane from the frozen, but warming, sea bed as for sea ice around the North Pole. Two recent studies of methane emissions from frozen sea-bed sediments, including one published in Science and described in The Times today, found substantial bubbling flows of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, were reaching the atmosphere.

title: Watchdog Group Urges Paterson to Resign
description: The latest organization calling for the resignation of Gov. David A. Paterson is Common Cause/New York, the government watchdog group. Common Cause said Friday that the governor should put the welfare of New York State ahead of his own personal concerns and resign. The group said that the turmoil surrounding the governor was distracting attention from the states urgent fiscal woes.

title: Living in Vinegar Hill
description: Vinegar Hill, a Brooklyn hamlet a few blocks long and a few wide,  is nudged into a corner of the waterfront that seems, at least in part, forgotten by time.

title: Looking for Meaning in the James Number Switch
description: Much has been made about LeBron Jamess filing paperwork with the National Basketball Association on Tuesday to change his jersey number from 23 to 6. James said the change would be made out of respect for Michael Jordan, who wore No. 23 for most of his career. (For a brief time after his return to basketball after a stint in the minor leagues Jordan wore No. 45.)

title: Geneva Auto Show: 10 Best? Tough Choices
description: From an apparent record number of new model introductions at this years Geneva auto show (how many? I lost track at 100) which ones stand out? Ten best? Thats about as tough a choice as winnowing down the American Idol cast of thousands. At least I didnt have to hear any of them sing. To wit, heres the list:

title: The Little Town That Prices (Almost) Forgot
description: THE Brooklyn waterfront, once upon a time, was seen as a place where artists and artisans lived and worked, basking in cheap rents, old architecture and a sweet sense of isolation. But lately that reality has changed. Market-rate condominium towers and luxury conversions dot the Kings County coastline, their presence telegraphing a need for a higher income bracket.

title: CF Begins Tender Offer for Terras Shares
description: CF Industries Holdings took its renewed fight for control of Terra Industries directly to its rivals shareholders on Friday with a $4.7 billion tender offer.

title: Do All Small Businesses Need a Mobile Strategy?
description: At the Mobile Premier Awards  an international competition for mobile start-ups held last month at the Mobile World Congress  the message was clear: Web sites are old school, and mobile is a growing requirement for every industry and business.

title: Taiwan Quake Cuts LCD Production
description: While it may be the least of Taiwans worries, its worth noting that that islands earthquake on Thursday has significantly cut into the production of LCD panels. Two of the largest panel manufacturing plants, owned by Chi Mei Optoelectronics and HannStar Display, had to close their lines until it becomes clear that the plants can safely reopen.

title: Uncle Sams Payrolls
description: Local government may be shedding workers, but the federal government is growing.

title: Change Happens in Oakland, and Ellis Has Seen It All
description: PHOENIX  Lewis Wolff, the owner of the Oakland Athletics, stood beside his teams dugout Friday morning at Phoenix Municipal Stadium. He was dressed in an As golf shirt, green-and-gold mesh shorts, white socks and sneakers, drinking coffee from a Styrofoam cup. A genial, white-haired grandfather of three, his name will not be confused with Steinbrenner.

title: On the Street | The Loop
description: A lot of New Yorkers chase off the winter blues with cleverly tied scarves or variations on the scarf.

title: New Housing in Midtown, for a Song
description: ON 43rd Street off Eighth Avenue is a new seven-story building that offers low-income housing and affordable rehearsal space, which are both in short supply. The structures existence is the result of two seemingly unrelated events: a decades-old ruling against the owners of a flophouse that once stood on the site, and the purchase of development rights from a nearby theater declared a landmark.

title: Must See: They Look Like Ants From Here
Unity Elusive as Iraq Grasps Trappings of Democracy
description: BAGHDAD  Glumly, Qais Sharaa peered through his barbershop at the collage of posters in Firdos Square, where a statue of Saddam Hussein once presided and the vocabulary of democracy now prevails. Nationalists applauded unity and former insurgents swore their fight was behind them. One poster sported the unlikely portrait of an unveiled woman, in gold jewelry and lipstick, running as a candidate for the countrys most ardently religious party.

title: High Low | Rachel Pally Swimsuit at Anthropologie, $98
description: Lately, all I do is daydream about a warm, sunny respite from the wet, gray weather weve been having in New York. Luckily, Im heading to Palm Springs, Calif., in a few weeks for some poolside lounging and vintage shopping. This Rachel Pally bathing suit from Anthropologie will be the perfect addition to my trip. It has a conservative cut so you dont reveal too much, and its vintage style conjures up an image of a soigne Babe Paley sitting by the pool with sunglasses on her head. Not bad for under $100.

title: Shopping a Reality Show
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Theres a story today in the entertainment trade papers that Sarah Palin is shopping a reality show with the producer of Survivor, Mark Burnett. Thats why she quit being the governor of Alaska. I find it strange that Sarah Palin would be shopping a reality show considering the fact that she hasnt shown much interest in reality.

title: News From the Car Industry
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: More crazy news from the car industry. An executive at G.M. is blaming his companys 1.3 million car recall on a parts supplier owned by Toyota. Im just waiting for people to start blaming everything on Toyota. Its like the unemployment rate, the Kennedy assassination, global warming.

title: No Endangered Status for Plains Bird
description: WASHINGTON  The Interior Department said Friday that the greater sage grouse, a dweller of the high plains of the American West, was facing extinction but would not be designated an endangered species for now.

title: God I Pray Youre Not Like Me
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Former governor George W. Bush is writing a book, writing a book. How about that, about his eight years in the White House. Its all part of his war on literacy.

title: Nothing Like Reconciliation to Foster Divisions
description: Arguably, the most divisive issue on Capitol Hill these days is the parliamentary maneuver called budget reconciliation, which Democrats are planning to use to finalize their major health care legislation over the furious objection of Republicans.

title: Book Review Podcast: Danielle Trussoni and Joseph ONeill
description: This week: Danielle Trussoni, author of the novel Angelology; Joseph ONeill on Turkey and its ethnic conflicts; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Colonoscopy Revealed No Polyps
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: More problems for the auto industry. General Motors announced this week theyre recalling 1.3 million compact cars here in North America to address a power steering problem. Apparently, since President Obama took over the company, all the cars are veering to the left.

title: A Dose of Oscar Newbie Trivia
description: LOS ANGELES There is plenty of well-known trivia about this years crop of historic Oscar contenders: Kathryn Bigelow (The Hurt Locker) is only the fourth woman to be nominated for best director, for example, and would be the first to win. Lee Daniels, the director of Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire, is the first black man to direct a best picture nominee (and would be the first to win). Avatar would be the first sci-fi movie to win best picture (ditto District 9, although it wont). But with the extra-long season, theres been time to dig up bits of information about Oscar newbies:

title: Minstrels in the Court of the Kingpin
description: Los Angeles

title: Answers From a Graffiti Artist, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of answers from Lee Quiones, an artist who emerged from the subway art movement of the 1970s.

title: Iraqi Elections: Voter Profile
description: Stephen Farrell meets a voter and a candidate in the Sunni stronghold of Adhamiya.

title: Five Heart Bypasses
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: Home and Album
description: WHEN Arash Yomtobian, a recently minted college graduate, landed a job with Lehman Brothers in August 2007, he felt as if he stood on the brink of a rosy future.

title: CNN Geography Lesson
description: Video | Say aloha to embarrassment:

title: Book Review Podcast: Danielle Trussoni and Joseph ONeill
description: This week: Danielle Trussoni, author of the novel Angelology; Joseph ONeill on Turkey and its ethnic conflicts; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: New York's Art Fairs
description: The Art Show, the annual exhibition of the Art Dealers Association of America, now coincides with the Armory Show.

title: Securing the Peace in Liberia
description: Women of the United Nations police and peacekeeping forces that entered Liberia after the civil war have inspired a new generation of Liberian women to don uniforms.

title: No Enchanted Evenings in This Pacific Warfare
description: MIDWAY through the first hour of Band of Brothers, HBOs 2001 mini-series about a company of paratroopers during and after D-Day, theres a scene on a troop ship thats jampacked with new recruits on their way to hard fighting in the European theater. Right now some lucky bastards headed for the South Pacific, one soldier says to another, envious. Hes going to get billeted on some tropical island sitting under a palm tree with six naked native girls helping him cut up coconuts so he can hand-feed them to the flamingos.

title: Grand Illusions
description: THE Millionaires Magician does not like doing magic every waking moment. He goes to cocktail parties or dinners and everyone expects lamps to levitate and cards to materialize inside wine bottles. It gets excessive.

title: Mercedes-Benz ESF 2009 Tests Future Safety Technology
description: MONTVALE, N.J.  Just before heading back home to Germany following a short tour of the United States, Mercedes-Benzs ESF 2009 experimental safety vehicle made one last pitstop before a gaggle of American reporters in northern New Jersey. It offered a tantalizing glimpse of more than a dozen different systems designed to make driving (and crashing) safer.

title: Problems Aside, Rangel Expects Key Endorsement
description: Representative Charles B. Rangels Washington woes are not hampering his re-election plans in New York  at least not yet.

title: Russia Says Burnt Body May Belong to Militant
description: MOSCOW  After federal forces descended on a dusty farming village in the southern republic of Ingushetia, Russian authorities said Friday that they had retrieved a burnt corpse, possibly of Aleksandr Tikhomirov, a charismatic militant leader. He has been linked to a series of bloody bombings in the last year, including one of a luxury train to St. Petersburg in November that killed 26 people.

title: Germany Makes No Financial Pledge to Greece
description: BERLIN  As protesters upset with sharp cuts in Greeces budget clashed with the police in Athens on Friday, talks here between Greek and German leaders ended with Germany making no public offers of financial support.

title: Need to Rebook Your Flight? Please Hold.
description: With airlines preemptively canceling more flights in anticipation of bad weather, another bottleneck has formed: airline call centers.

title: A Jewish Ritual Collides With Mother Nature
description: Last Saturday morning, as a blizzard sputtered out its last squalls over Passaic, N.J., Chaya Leah Smolen sent her husband and several children off to synagogue. She issued the children a message that might seem to contradict the essence of winter motherhood: do not carry any tissues.

title: Model-morphosis | Rick Owens
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Jac Jagaciak from IMG Model Management before (top, bottom) and after makeup by Aaron de May and hair by Luigi Murenu. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

title: From France With Romance, and Broad Tastes
description: SINCE they met as schoolboys in Versailles, a suburb of Paris, the members of the French indie-pop group Phoenix  the singer-songwriter-guitarist Thomas Mars, the bassist Deck DArcy and the guitarists Christian Mazzalai and Laurent Brancowitz  have considered themselves a gang of misfit aesthetes. In the decade theyve worked together, their music has blended a mysterious French charisma with a broad American accessibility; they sing in English, but its hard to say about what. Their fourth studio record, Wolfgang Amadeus Phoenix (Glassnote), released in May, brought their widest exposure, with sold-out concerts and performances on Saturday Night Live and Late Show With David Letterman. In January the group won a Grammy for best alternative album, and its brand of easy, insider-y cool has also found an outlet in commercials and fashion shows.

title: Chasing the White Dog
description: On Top of Old Smoky

title: The Infinities
description: Of the things we fashioned for them that they might be comforted, dawn is the one that works. When darkness sifts from the air like fine soft soot and light spreads slowly out of the east then all but the most wretched of humankind rally. It is a spectacle we immortals enjoy, this minor daily resurrection, often we will gather at the ramparts of the clouds and gaze down upon them, our little ones, as they bestir themselves to welcome the new day. What a silence falls upon us then, the sad silence of our envy. Many of them sleep on, of course, careless of our cousin Aurora's charming matutinal trick, but there are always the insomniacs, the restless ill, the lovelorn tossing on their solitary beds, or just the early-risers, the busy ones, with their knee-bends and their cold showers and their fussy little cups of black ambrosia. Yes, all who witness it greet the dawn with joy, more or less, except of course the condemned man, for whom first light will be the last, on earth.

title: Speaking of David Paterson
description: Six of the people who know him best talk about the experiences that have shaped the new governor of New York.

title: Nothing Like Reconciliation to Foster Division
description: At our Prescriptions blog, colleague David M. Herszenhorn find that not only Republicans and Democrats are talking about reconciliation.

title: Major Pettigrews Last Stand
description: Chapter 1

title: New York Again Has Highest Union Membership Rate in U.S.
description: More than a quarter of New Yorks wage and salary workers belonged to a union last year, according to a recent Labor Department report. Thats the highest rate of any state in the nation.

title: What Were Reading
The Morning Skate: A Stolen Point by Lundqvist, a Tribute to Halligan
description: Henrik Lundqvist stole a point last night for the Rangers and if they make the playoffs, it would be worth remembering this 5-4 overtime loss to the Penguins (Jeff Z. Kleins Times story here). Lundqvists 50 saves, and especially his third period and overtime in which the Penguins outshot the Rangers, 23-1, were the story of the game.

title: J.J. Abrams, Irelands Favorite Son
description: LOS ANGELES  What better way to spend an evening than with a bunch of Irishmen, a dressed-down Tom Cruise, in blue jeans and a navy sweatshirt, said when he presented J. J. Abrams, the producer of his next film, Mission: Impossible IV, with an award at the Oscar Wilde: Honoring the Irish in Film party last night in Los Angeles. (Yes, you read that right.) Mr. Cruise introduced the decidedly non-Irish Jeffrey Jacobs Abrams as James Jacob OAbrams.

title: Fans Stick By Warriors Despite Struggles
description: When an N.B.A. team is regularly in playoff contention it can, unsurprisingly, expect to draw large numbers of fans. But its highly unusual when a team is perennially bad, perhaps even historically bad, and can still draw a healthy crowd.

title: Undercover Agents in the Hospital
description: At the Economix blog, Princeton economist Uwe E. Reinhardt ponders a proposal by Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, to deploy undercover agents posing as patients in an effort to ferret out fraud by doctors and hospitals.

title: Experienced Hands, Still Valued
description: WATERTOWN, Mass.

title: How to Get a Free Gym Workout
description: Heres one idea for saving on gym costs: use free gym passes to continuously test different gyms.

title: Now Showing | The Bold and the Beautiful
description: This is a big week for gallery openings, but three shows in particular caught my eye. At Julie Saul, Further Illuminations includes recent gouache paintings by Maira Kalman, a longtime contributor to T, whose quirky, lyrical and observant paintings have been the basis of a wildly popular nytimes.com blog. At Demisch Danant, theyre partying like its 1989. Wild Animals offers a selection of postmodern designs  mostly from the 1980s, by people like Ron Arad, Philippe Starck, Tom Dixon and Christian Germanaz  that are by turns decorative and startling. And at the Heller Gallery, de Rigeur, an exhibition of new work by the artist Beth Lipman, features two large installations. Bride consists of a 10-foot-tall dessert stand filled with glass objects in various states of order and chaos, while the autobiographical work The Whatnots refers to the Victorian furniture used to display collectibles; Lipmans bear pieces of black glass refer to the mourning jewelry of the period.

title: Gearing Up for the iPad
