description: Only a short time ago, if you typed iPad accessories into the Google search engine, youd be asked, Did you mean iPod accessories?

title: G.M. Plans to Reinstate 661 Dealerships
description: DETROIT  General Motors, seeking to avoid a protracted legal battle as it focuses on increasing sales, said on Friday that it planned to reinstate 661 dealerships cut last year as part of its bankruptcy reorganization.

title: A New York Hard-Sell for an Ancient British Home
description: The British possess many traits enviable to New Yorkers: the capacity to brew a better cup of tea, the decorum not to brag loudly about their bonuses in Midtown restaurants and a history rich with kings and queens who inspire trashy novels and Hollywood movies. But they fall short in one area: brash self-promotion, especially when it comes to real estate.

title: After Jerky Swings, the Economy Begins to Look Nice and Boring
description: A DEEP recession and the credit crisis led to extraordinary falls in the American economy and perhaps even greater disruptions in financial markets.

title: Miracle Worker Producer Warns That Show Could Close
description: The producers of the Broadway revival of The Miracle Worker have tried almost every avenue available to them to sell tickets to that play, which opened Wednesday at Circle in the Square Theater. They cast high-profile stars, including Alison Pill as Annie Sullivan and the Little Miss Sunshine star Abigail Breslin as Helen Keller; they hired an up-and-coming director, Kate Whoriskey, to direct the project. Then they waited for opening night, and hoped that universally glowing reviews would materialize by morning.

title: Miller, Vonn Donate Equipment For Good Causes
description: The stars of the 2010 American Olympic ski team are putting their gear to charitable use.

title: Stringer Resets Expectations for Rutgers
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  This is C. Vivian Stringers 39th season as a womens basketball coach, but she is not so rigid that she refuses to tinker with imperfections, even big ones. About a month ago, for example, she told her players to forget about running the offense  her offense.

title: Death Bear Will See You Now
description: SUNDAY morning we sat at Dianas dinette table in Park Slope, Brooklyn, waiting for Death Bear. We considered making him breakfast, but decided not to, thinking he would probably just come in, take the stuff and leave.

title: A Female Approach to Peacekeeping
description: MONROVIA, LIBERIA  When darkness comes to Congo Town, women in crisp uniforms take the streets, patrolling with Kalashnikov rifles and long, black hair tucked into baby-blue caps.

title: First Ladys Gown Goes to the Smithsonian
description: Next week, Michelle Obama will preside at a ceremony where shell donate to the Smithsonian the flowing winter white gown she wore to the inaugural balls in 2009.

title: Learning How to Hedge Yourself, and Not Just Your Portfolio
description: HOW much are your working years worth? Or put another way, what is the impact of joblessness on your financial future?

title: A Veteran High School Counselor Responds to a Report Critical of the Profession
description: The Choice received 100 comments on a report by the research organization Public Agenda that described widespread dissatisfaction with high school guidance counselors. Many of the comments were from counselors themselves, who took issue with the report and who, like the researchers who compiled it, sought to put the predicament of the modern-day counselor in perspective. To continue this dialogue, I asked one of those counselors to write a short rebuttal essay for The Choice. He is Robert Bardwell, director of guidance at Monson High School, a public school in Massachusetts.  Jacques Steinberg

title: Protests in Greece
description: Masked youths attacked the leader of Greece's biggest union and stoned police officers Friday in an outbreak of violence over cutbacks proposed by the prime minister.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Twyla Tharp, A.O. Scott, Martin McDonagh and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: How Friendships Change After Baby
description: I cant get that sappy, sing-song ditty out of my head: Make new friends, but keep the old, one is silver and the other gold.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Last Looks
description: How will this years Geneva auto show be remembered? Most likely as the show in which Porsche and Ferrari brought out their exotic hybrids. But those cars werent the only stars in an unexpectedly vibrant show.

title: A Campy Spirit for Film Independent
description: LOS ANGELES  As a warm-up to the big show on Sunday, indie filmmakers (and the actors that love them) have Film Independents Spirit Awards, which celebrate their 25th anniversary on Friday with a splashier party on a rooftop in downtown Los Angeles, in lieu of the usual beach-side digs in Santa Monica. By all accounts it is one of the most fun nights of awards season  IFC will televise it live  and the Bagger is excited to be there, tweeting away. To get a sense of what to expect, we recently spoke with another newbie, the shows host, the comedian and actor Eddie Izzard.

title: Mets Will Send Reyes for Testing on Thyroid
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets pushed back shortstop Jose Reyess spring training debut indefinitely Friday, deciding instead to send him to New York for further medical tests Monday on his thyroid gland.

title: Speaking Not as an Armenian
description: Congress has invariably refused to take any serious measure against genocide while it is underway. So is it progress that the House Foreign Affairs Committee voted yesterday to condemn the 1915 genocide of Armenians? Is it worthwhile for Congress to deal with genocide at some level, even if its 95 years late?

title: Another Deal Grab Bag: Astellas, CF, Airgas and More
description: Theres talk once again  this time much more hopeful  of a return to M.&A. I am still skeptical for the reasons I noted in my year-end review.

title: Still Going One on One and Giving No Ground
description: Every once in a while someone says something amazing in the HBO documentary Magic & Bird: A Courtship of Rivals. Usually its Larry Bird.

title: Congressman Accused of Harassment Resigns
description: Representative Eric J. Massa, a freshman Democrat from upstate New York who is under investigation for harassing a male aide, said on Friday that he would resign from the House.

title: Seldom-Heard Symphony Resurfaces as a Novelty
description: For his current extended visit to New York, the conductor Riccardo Muti is on a mission, it would seem, to reclaim neglected works. At the Metropolitan Opera he is conducting a revelatory performance of Verdis Attila, a new production that opened last month and a company premiere of this early Verdi opera.

title: Pictures of the Day: Friday, March 5
description: In Athens, strikes hit schools, hospitals and public transportation. Police used tear gas on rioters as Parliament adopted its latest austerity package. Seven police officers were injured in the protests, among the most violent since Greeces financial crisis hit, and at least five demonstrators were arrested.

title: Dior Runway Show
description: John Galliano presents the fall 2010 collection.

title: Cruising or Fired Up, an Unchanging Language
description: The tenor saxophonist Houston Person began his first set at the Jazz Standard on Thursday night at a cruising tempo, suggestive of nonchalance and fond routine, of winding down after an honest days work. He phrased the melody of his opening tune, Duke Ellingtons Do Nothing Til You Hear From Me, about a beat behind the rest of the band. His off-the-cuff elaborations were pithy, infused with blues feeling, and he made them seem necessary.

title: Scorecard | Balenciaga Wins!
description: Is it for alliterative purposes (Balenciaga Beats Balmain) that the fashion week schedule once again placed Pariss two resurgent couture giants of the New Look era head to head, Scorecard wonders? In any event, in this season of pared-down minimalist dressing, Christophe Decarnins gilded-to-the-max showing looked new and innovative  almost. That is, until critics thought back to Nicolas Ghesquires neoprene-newsprint-packing material-puffa fest from the morning, which fast-forwarded us all into fashions future.

title: A Sense That Now Is the Time
description: A LOOK at the strategies of buyers venturing into the market shows Westchester as no longer being in free fall, but still poised too precariously for watchers to be sanguine about substantial improvement.

title: World Cup With an Accent on TV in United States
description: Blimey! Perhaps the network known as ESPN (which began life as the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network) should change its name to the ENGLISH  Sports Programming Network.

title: Photos of the Moment | Party Circuit
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Skye Parrott.

title: White House Postpones Picking Site of 9/11 Trial
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Friday that a decision on where to prosecute Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks would not be made for weeks, following a flare-up in the debate about whether that trial should take place in civilian court or before a military commission.

title: Into the Oscars
description: If you want to understand the frantic, costly and bizarre campaign to win an Oscar, read Mark Harriss brilliant feature in New York Magazine from early last month. But if youre foolish enough to be interested in handicapping this years results, read Hendrik Hertzberg on the new voting scheme that accompanied the expansion of the Best Picture nominees to 10. It tells you all you need to know to pick the winner:

title: New Rules Trouble Some Defense Lawyers for the Poor
description: Last month, the mayors office unveiled new guidelines for assigning public defenders to represent indigent criminal defendants. Now, some defense organizations are voicing their displeasure, fearing that the new rules will take work from experienced lawyers and overburden less experienced ones.

title: Scenes From the Demonstrations Over Education Cuts
description: In the Bay Area on Thursday, it was hard to go anywhere without running into people marching or a teacher handing out flyers, all part of the national protest over education cuts, as we wrote in a continually updated blog post.

title: Rolling Waves and Rolling Homes
description: THE side-by-side oceanfront plots at the Montauk Shores condominium park are steps from the prime surfing at Ditch Plains Beach. One sliver holds a vintage trailer, known as the green monster, that is on the market for $495,000. The other has an unheated 300-square-foot cottage, with one bedroom and a sleeping loft, listed at $635,000. Peter Moore, an agent at the Corcoran Group, who with his wife, Lois, listed the properties, suggested that, with warmer weather in the offing, they should be snapped up together, by somebody that loves to surf  and with deep pockets.

title: Greens Get a Boost Under the Glow of the Supermarket
description: Gene E. Lester, a plant physiologist with the Department of Agricultures Agricultural Research Service in Weslaco, Tex., was in the produce aisle of his local grocery store when a thought occurred to him.

title: In New Jersey, the Telephone Challenge
description: THE phone, once a real estate agents primary  well, only  mode of communication with a client, is making a comeback of sorts in these lean times.

title: Scientists Propose a More Efficient Way to Make Ethanol
description: Producing ethanol from corn is relatively easy: the corns abundant sugars are readily fermented into alcohol. But using what is essentially a food crop to produce fuel has been criticized as a misuse of resources that can harm both agriculture and the environment.

title: Surveys and Polls Galore Before the Oscars, But None Can Predict How to Win Your Office Pool
description: Before the Super Bowl, advertising, marketing and media companies typically release the results of polls, surveys and analyses about the commercials during the big game. With signs pointing to a possible large upturn in viewership for the Academy Awards, to be broadcast by ABC on Sunday, there is a similar outpouring of data related to Oscar and movie ads.

title: Massa Says Hell Resign on Monday
description: Representative Eric Massa, Democrat from upstate New York, abruptly announced this afternoon that he would resign effective Monday  rather than simply not seek re-election as he had said earlier this week  because of an ethics inquiry.

title: On Assignment: Into the Maw at Marja
description: Using one another as pillows, like a family huddled together for warmth in a house without heat, most of the Marines were catching a little sleep before their mission was to begin. But one sat wide awake at the edge of their huddle.

title: Now Popping Up | Markt and Smithshop
description: Traditionally the province of Fifth Avenue, Times Square or, lately, the Port Authority bus terminal, the pop-up shop has been slowly migrating to a more unorthodox setting: the art world. To wit, the perennially veiled A Shaded View on Fashion blogger Diane Pernet has curated Markt, a fashion-centric installation now in its second incarnation at New Yorks Scope Art Fair. The exhibition spotlights (and sells) the work of burgeoning designers, including Sandra Backlund, Lamija Suljevic and Six Scents Parfums. In addition to Backlunds horsehair vest and Suljevics brocade dresses, fairgoers can purchase a video work from electroclashers Chicks on Speed and digitally generated photographic illustrations from Hormazd Narielwalla now through Sunday.

title: Wedding Plan: Jump a Broom or Eat Goat?
description: LIKE weddings, wedding movies have their traditions: the dress is white and, usually, so are the characters.

title: Report of Boat Capsize Looking Murky
description: The day after high school students reported seeing a boat with two people on board capsize in the freezing waters of Jamaica Bay on Thursday, setting off a frantic search, nothing about the accident was certain  including whether there was anyone on the boat, or even whether there was a boat.

title: Starless Ensemble Plays Shine, With Limits
description: For the third time this season, the Off Broadway theater Playwrights Horizons has received rave reviews for a production, Clybourne Park, and has added performances to meet audience demand. What Playwrights doesnt have are tiny casts led by movie stars, the formula that many Broadway producers consider essential for a play to make money in an era of high ticket prices and stiff competition.

title: Hunters Revel in the Sounds of Silence
description: A BEDROOM door: Thats what Meghan Galewski and James Gonzalez wanted most.

title: Coyotes Take a Turn in the N.H.L.s Safety Net
description: In 2003, Jeff Holbrook, the chief spokesman for the Buffalo Sabres, received a call from the teams finance department. Could he ask the coach to extend practice by half an hour?

title: Sunday Preview
description: In the summer, Tuscany is full of Americans.But as Danielle Pergament recently discovered,the best time to visit may be wintertime, when the landscape is surprisingly green, locals fill the cafes, and the cuisine is at its best.

title: The Renter Roadblock
description: IT seemed like a smart idea at the time.

title: We Three Things | In Stitches
description: We Three Things is a roundup of three items from the current visual landscape that share a common theme. Shapton, a former art director of the New York Times Op-Ed page as well as an author (Important Artifacts and Personal Property From the Collection of Lenore Doolan and Harold Morris, Including Books, Street Fashion, and Jewelry), illustrator and publisher, connects the dots.

title: Timing a Move After a Lease Expires
description: Q.

title: When in Doubt, Add Chocolate
description: FOR years I thought that the deeper, darker and more ganache-like a chocolate pudding was, the more I would like it. I wanted pudding as dense as a chocolate truffle and just as rich.

title: Photos of the Moment | Florian and Storytailors
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Catiere.

title: A Meeting of Giselle and Hasselhoff
description: There are several narrators in David Neumanns Big Eater, which flits from one subject to the next with a slapdash efficiency that can also be theatrically cloying. But the character described in the program as the man in the woods is the most affecting. Played by Frederick Neumann  of Mabou Mines and Mr. Neumanns father  he is shown intermittently throughout the evening-length work on video, as he makes his way through nature.

title: Byrd Defends Use of Reconciliation
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, 92, Democrat of West Virginia and a fierce protector of Senate rules and precedents, is defending the Democrats plan to use a parliamentary maneuver called budget reconciliation to finalize major health care legislation.

title: Making Another Dive Into Evils of the Deep
description: It used to be easier to make video game sequels.

title: Amanpour Is Mentioned as a Candidate for ABCs This Week
description: Christiane Amanpour of CNN may be the newest name on ABCs list of This Week candidates.

title: Columbus Symphony Makes Severe Cutbacks
description: The Columbus Symphony Orchestra has taken drastic action to stay in business. It said on Friday that it had lopped off 13 weeks of its season, translating to a 23-percent pay cut for its musicians and a $1.5 million reduction of its $9 million budget next season. Its season will run for 25 weeks instead of 38. The orchestra said that its reduction, which was negotiated with the musicians, will eliminate three paid weeks of vacation for the players, five weeks of playing for BalletMet and Opera Columbus performances; and five weeks of special one-off concerts. Subscription concerts will be preserved, the orchestra said. The cuts are a particularly draconian example of the trimming going on around the orchestra world after the recession.

title: New Yorker to Head Museum in Kansas City
description: The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., which completed a critically praised expansion in 2007 and has been adding aggressively to its collection as part of an extended 75th anniversary celebration, has looked to New York for its next leader, choosing Julin Zugazagoitia, right, the director of El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem. Mr. Zugazagoitia (pronounced zoo-gah-zah-GOY-tee-a) will replace Marc F. Wilson, one of the nations longest-serving museum directors, who last year announced his decision to retire after 28 years and after shepherding a $385 million capital campaign to strengthen the museums endowment and transform its Beaux-Arts complex with a glass-block addition by the architect Steven Holl. Mr. Zugazagoitia, 46, has run El Museo for almost eight years, a period of sweeping change for a small institution founded in 1969 as a haven for Puerto Rican culture. It has expanded its mission to focus more generally on Latino and Latin American art and under Mr. Zugazagoitias leadership it has substantially increased its budget, endowment, donations and audience. The museum reopened last fall after its own makeover, a $35 million renovation that added a new facade and courtyard and modernized its galleries. Sarah F. Rowland, chairwoman of the Nelson-Atkins board, said that the museums search committee had chosen Mr. Zugazagoitia from a field of about a dozen finalists because his training and temperament are exactly what we had been looking for  his commitment to the arts is so broad. Mr. Zugazagoitia said that he was excited about the chance to take over an encyclopedic museum, the breadth and depth of whose collection is astounding.

title: Paris Review Editor
description: Lorin Stein, an editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux whose youth belies his influence in the publishing industry, was named the editor of The Paris Review, the prestigious literary magazine, its board of directors said on Friday. Mr. Stein, 37, has edited several high-profile authors at Farrar, Straus; in 2007, three of the five fiction finalists for the National Book Award were works he edited. As editor of The Review, Mr. Stein will succeed Philip Gourevitch, the author and journalist who announced in November that he was stepping down. In a telephone interview on Friday, Mr. Stein said: Part of what The Review is for me is not just a place for writers to publish things and for readers to read them, but at its best it can be a gateway drug. My whole life has been in the shadow of that experience.

title: Lennon Auto Ad Angers Some Fans
description: A European automobile commercial featuring John Lennon has drawn swift outrage from fans, as well as a rapid defense from his son Sean Ono Lennon, below. The commercial, for the Citron DS-3, which is being promoted with the slogan Anti Retro, includes footage of John Lennon criticizing peoples nostalgia for the 1960s and 70s. In the ad, which began showing in Britain in February, he says, Once a things been done its been done. He adds: Looking backwards for inspiration, copying the past  how is that rock n roll? Do something of your own. Start something new. The BBC reported that the commercial drew the ire of viewers who said that the singers widow, Yoko Ono, was exploiting his image. On Twitter, Sean Ono Lennon wrote: I realize why people are mad. But intention was not financial, was simply wanting to keep him out there in the world.

title: New Plot Twist in Cussler Case
description: The longstanding legal dispute between the author Clive Cussler and Crusader Entertainment took a new twist this week when a California appeals court reversed a lower court order that Mr. Cussler pay Crusader $5 million after a ruling that he had acted in bad faith in dealings over the movie Sahara. The appeals court upheld the trial court in rejecting Mr. Cusslers claim that he was owed $8.6 million by Crusader. The ruling, which came on Wednesday from a three-judge panel, sent the dispute back to the lower court to determine who, if anyone, had actually prevailed in the case. That determination would affect the assignment of responsibility for legal costs. Mr. Cussler filed suit against Crusader in 2004, asserting that it had violated its contract with him in making a film based on his novel Sahara and its fictional hero Dirk Pitt. Crusader then filed a cross-complaint that accused Mr. Cussler of contractual violations.

title: The Surrendered
description: Chapter 1

title: A Blow to Britains Snoop Dogg Ban
description: The rapper Snoop Doggs long-running battle to be allowed into Britain took a turn in his favor this week when a tribunal there said it was wrong for him to have been denied entry into the country three years ago, Reuters reported. In 2006, a public disorder at Heathrow Airport involving members of Snoop Doggs entourage resulted in the rappers arrest, and his being denied a visa to enter the country in 2007 when he arrived on a tour with Sean Combs. The travel restriction on Snoop Dogg, above, was lifted in 2008 but challenged twice by Britains Border Agency, whose decision was deemed wrong by an Asylum and Immigration Tribunal. The agency said on Friday that it was disappointed by the tribunals decision in this case, and would consider an appeal.

title: CBS Best on Idol Night
description: Despite competition from Foxs American Idol results show, CBS eked out a first-place finish in Thursdays prime-time ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, the lineup of Survivor at 8 p.m. (12.7 million), CSI at 9 (15.6 million) and The Mentalist at 10 (14.8 million) helped CBS average the most viewers over all, even as Foxs Idol, at 8, delivered the largest audience of the night (19.3 million) and continued to dominate among viewers 18 to 49. Fox lagged behind in the 9 p.m. hour, however, as Kitchen Nightmares drew 8.1 million viewers, lowering the networks average. ABC placed third with new episodes of Greys Anatomy (11.8 million) and Private Practice (7.7 million), while NBC ranked fourth.

title: Chic in Review | Desmond Tutu, Designer
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Trippy 60s in a Guggenheim Time Machine
description: Let no one forget that Animal Collective is an arty, experimental band. Its 2009 album and EP, Merriweather Post Pavilion and Fall Be Kind (both on Domino), brought the band within hailing distance of pop, using intelligible vocals and blissful electronic hooks. But so far this year Animal Collective has largely set aside songs in favor of sound collages and visual-arts collaborations.

title: Ex-Building Inspector Charged With Selling Training Certificates
description: A former city building inspector was arrested Friday and charged with selling scores of safety-training certificates to be used by New York construction workers who never completed the required training, federal prosecutors and the citys Department of Investigation said.

title: Emmy Awards Will Be Live on Both Coasts
description: The East Coast and the West Coast will be able to watch the Emmy Awards together this year.

title: 2010 Iraqi Elections: Voter Profile
description: Full Coverage

title: For Lighting, an Exception to Buy American
description: The Department of Energy has waived a buy American requirement for government projects receiving money from last years stimulus bill so that recipients can purchase energy-efficient lighting products for public buildings and roadways.

title: Chicken and Vegetable Cobbler
description: Mark Bittman simplifies the chicken pot pie.

title: How to Top Chicken Pot Pie
description: CHICKEN pot pie, like so many other dishes, was a way to stretch chicken by encasing it in less expensive, more filling dough.

title: The Spirit of Freaknik Comes to TV
description: Growing up in Florida in the 1980s and 90s, Faheem Najm was too young to attend Freaknik, the annual spring party that drew hundreds of thousands of revelers to Atlantas parks and colleges, and eventually sent them spilling out into its streets.

title: Its Proxy Season: Will You Vote?
description: Its proxy season, that time of year when shareholders  big and small  get to vote on various corporate issues.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 5
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include Gov. David A. Paterson, a suburban mother who is fulfilling a dream, snow, and the Gowanus Canal.

title: Fake Former Presidents Use Comedy for a Cause
description: The kings of presidential comedy were reunited last weekend  with a little nudge from the chairwoman of the Congressional Oversight Panel.

title: Amiable Tramp Drifting Through Postwar Japan
description: DO you have to be Japanese to appreciate Tora-san? Evidently not, since that amiable drifter, played by Kiyoshi Atsumi in 48 films (a record for most appearances by an actor in a single role) made between 1969 and 1995, has enough of a following in the West for an American distributor, the admirable independent company AnimEigo, in Wilmington, N.C., to begin issuing the Tora-san films on DVD. The first volume contains the first four features in the series: Tora-san, Our Lovable Tramp (1969), Tora-sans Cherished Mother (1969), Tora-san, His Tender Love (1970) and Tora-sans Grand Scheme (1970).

title: Taking on the Wilderness, Both Without and Within
description: Wolves seem to be having something of a moment. In January there was Clash: Encounters of Bears and Wolves on PBSs Nature, which looked at how the reintroduction of wolves into Yellowstone National Park has given the grizzlies there competition. Last month came the movie The Wolfman, with Benicio Del Toro as the man-beast. And on Sunday the Smithsonian Channel offers Running With Wolves, a film about Gudrun Pflueger, who has been researching wolves in British Columbia and Alberta, Canada, for years.

title: Delahunt Makes Retirement Official
description: BOSTON  Democratic Representative Bill Delahunt officially announced on Friday that he would not seek re-election, setting off what is sure to be a frenzied race for his seat.

title: A New Global Sound: Synth, Soul and Sample
description: Four years ago, when Jason Derlo was a competitor in the long-running amateur-night talent competition at the Apollo Theater, one of his go-to numbers was Love, by Musiq Soulchild. That song from 2000, one of the first breakthrough moments of neo-soul, was slow and decorous and no-frills, the choice of a young R&B singer uninterested in testing himself.

title: Greece Wont Sell Islands to Cover Debts
description: After meeting Germanys chancellor, Angela Merkel, in Berlin on Friday, Greek Prime Minister George Papandreou rejected calls from German politicians to resolve his countrys debt crisis by selling off some Greek islands.

title: Pitfalls of the Spirit Awards
description: LOS ANGELES Before we head off to the Spirit Awards, we thought it would be worth looking into how exactly those flibbertigibbets get awarded. While the voting is not as complicated as the Academys preferential ballot system, there are some pitfalls, as Steve Pond described in the Wrap.com.

title: Little Help in Japan for Owners of Toyotas With Acceleration Problems
description: TOKYO  Feeling her Toyota Mark X station wagon lurch forward at a busy intersection, Masako Sakai slammed on the brakes. But the pedal had gone limp, she said. Downshifting didnt seem to work either.

title: Celtic Tale Becomes Video Game for the Stage
description: You dont have to be an old fuddy-duddy to realize that experimental theaters fervent embrace of multimedia, which produces all kinds of innovative, fascinating work, has its drawbacks.

title: When You Make a Falsecard, Do It Without Hesitation
description: Perhaps the hardest part of finding an effective falsecard is thinking of the play in the first place. The second-hardest is making the falsecard in tempo; any pause risks giving the game away.

title: Setting Wind Power Records in Texas
description: Texas, the nations wind-power leader, set a new record for wind generation this morning, when  at 6:37 a.m.  about 19 percent of the electricity on the states main grid was supplied by turbines.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 5
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Scenes From a Nomination
description: Clips of the acting nominees and best picture nominees for the 2010 Academy Awards.

title: In Her Opinion...
description: Joan Riverss comments about celebrities red-carpet looks at recent awards shows.

title: Bears Are Big Spenders in Free Agency
description: Now the N.F.L. knows what happens during free agency without a salary cap: the Chicago Bears turn into the Washington Redskins and the Redskins morph into the Bears.

title: Flawed Security Exposes Vital Software to Hackers
description: McAfee, a leading maker of Internet security software, warned this week that software systems used by many companies to store and manage their intellectual property are being actively targeted by hackers and are in need of significantly increased security focus.

title: For Older Workers, a Longer Job Search
description: Older workers are much less likely to be unemployed than younger workers. But when older people do lose their jobs, theyre likely to be out of work for much longer than their younger counterparts.

title: Voting Your Shares May Start to Matter
description: What would happen if all the small investors banded together and cast their ballots during proxy season, the time of year when all shareholders get to vote on corporate issues? How much of an impact would they have?

title: Cravath Is Allowed to Keep Advising Air Products
description: 12:28 a.m. | Updated It wont decide the ultimate course of the battle between Air Products and Chemicals and Airgas, but a Friday afternoon ruling by Chancellor William B. Chandler III of Delawares Court of Chancery gives Air Products and its principal legal adviser a victory to crow about.

title: Taxicab Confessions
description: I slid over toward the man in the gray suit, making sure not to look him in the eye. Between us lay only a few inches of cushion and an awkward silence. Ive never done this before, I said, though it wasnt entirely true. Id feel less awkward if  could I ask your name?

title: For NBCs Community, a Dramatic (and Funny) Announcement of a Second Season
description: This is what it looks like when your television show is renewed for another year.

title: Old-Fashioned Bulwark in a Tide of Foreclosures
description: TO walk the streets of Brownsville and East New York, Brooklyn, is to see neighborhoods ravaged by foreclosure, homes boarded up and marshals notices taped to doors. Yet in the midst of this pain sit several swaths of well-tended homes, about 3,000 in all, each with a driveway and statuary and garden. Not one of their owners has lost a home.

title: Disney-Cablevision Dispute Takes a Personal Turn
description: The distribution spat between the Walt Disney Company and the cable provider Cablevision started to look more like a spat between two chief executives on Friday, one day before Cablevisions contract to carry the ABC station in New York City was set to expire.

title: Former Book Designer Says Good Riddance to Print
description: A recent blog post by Craig Mod, a self-titled computer programmer, book designer and book publisher, offers a thoughtful and distinctive perspective on the move of books from paper to interactive devices like Apples iPad.

title: Pen Down, Brain Off
description: Rebecca Steads novel When You Reach Me won the Newbery Medal in January for the most outstanding contribution to childrens literature of 2009. The book is set on the Upper West Side, where Ms. Stead, 42, grew up and still lives with her husband, Sean OBrien, a lawyer, and her sons, Eli, who turns 9 on Monday, and Jack, 11. ELISSA GOOTMAN

title: For NBCs Community, a Dramatic (and Funny) Announcement
description: Dan Harmon, an executive producer of NBCs Community, filmed himself telling his cast that the freshman year sitcom had been picked up for a second season  but only after pretending to deliver bad news about its demise. He uploaded the video Friday afternoon:

title: Male Bonding, Over Meatballs
description: Located at 84 Stanton Street, on a busy block of the Lower East Side, this month-old restaurant likes to keep things simple: It serves meatballs  naked meatballs, sauced meatballs, meatballs pressed on buns, meatballs on the side  but, only and exhaustively, two-ounce, spicy, homemade balls of meat. People love meatballs, said Michael Chernow, a co-owner, stating what to many is the obvious. Theyre simple, fun, familiar, and they bring you back to home. ALAN FEUER

title: Not Your Banks Bailouts: Stores Too Loved to Fail
description: The bike store had become a wine bar. The new apartments were breathtakingly expensive. Then kids from the neighborhood formed a protective guard around a gnarly old candy store on Avenue A and Seventh Street in Manhattan.

title: A Plush Boudoir Welcomes the Curious
description: OYSTER BAY

title: Reviving the Exotic to Critique Exoticism
description: Lalla Essaydi: Les Femmes du Maroc, an exhibition at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum, draws attention to one of the most interesting if puzzling developments in contemporary art: a revival of exotic, often historical imagery of people from faraway places in the name of a critique of exoticism.

title: At Caramoor, a Focus on Songs of the Belle poque
description: LEGEND has it that, after writing Fascination in 1904, Maurice Ravel sold it for quick cash and collected no royalties, leaving its authorship in dispute. Today, in any case, it is often thought of more as a crooners staple or a musical prop (as in Billy Wilders 1957 farce Love in the Afternoon) than as a work of art.

title: Uncommon Insight, Coming From a Dog
description: You may want to ask yourself whether you can trust a confessed dog fanatic to review  Sylvia,  the Long Wharf Theaters current attraction. So I want to reassure you that I am sometimes not completely entranced by plays, movies and books about my favorite animal. Sometimes.

title: Killing Pythons, and Regulating Them
description: Florida officials are stepping up efforts to deal with the  python population in the Everglades, measures that include a special hunting season that begins on state lands on Monday. But wildlife officials say that the big snakes, which prey on a number of threatened and endangered species from wading birds to wood rats, have reproduced faster than hunters can kill them.

title: Jewish Film Festival Grows to Extravaganza
description: ANYBODY can download a film from the Internet, says Harriet J. Dobin. So in her first full year as director of the Hartford Jewish Film Festival, she has done more than winnow some 100 entries down to 30 features and shorts. She has used the selections, which will be screened starting March 13, as a framework for related events  talks, concerts, parties  that give people a reason not to sit at home.

title: A Cafe Learns to Bake
description: The breads, pastries and other treats at the newly opened Cidade Caf in Ossining  all made on the premises and reasonably priced  have already attracted a following.

title: Mannerly Italian With a Few Surprises
description: LIMONCELLO, whose lemon yellow and white striped awnings might be more at home on Capri than in Mamaroneck, now occupies the building where Ye Olde Tollgate Steakhouse once thrived. To call Limoncello a throwback would be unkind, but aspects of this new-traditional Italian remind me of venerable restaurants with names like Manaros and Ninos, with their formal waiters, veal Marsala and big plates of spaghetti. I mean this as a compliment.

title: Miami Board Looks to Close Two Hospitals
description: MIAMI  At risk of running out of money in May, Miamis public health care system is considering closing two of its five hospitals and laying off 4,487 employees  a third of its work force, the chief executive said Friday.

title: An Authentic Neapolitan Taste
description: In a town brimming with pizza parlors, Marzanos, a Neapolitan pizzeria that opened in November, is a standout.

title: Amid Italian Classics, a Few Surprises
description: THOUGH there are many Italian restaurants in Connecticut, the cuisine is so rich and varied that the arrival of a new one is still an event.

title: Biscotti for a Variety of Tastes
description: Of the nine kinds of biscotti made at Marzullos Pasticceria in Williston Park, one in particular reminds Gandolfo Marzullo of his native Sicily.

title: Tastes of Turkey, From the Sea
description: KUMKAPI, a Turkish restaurant that opened in Hewlett in December, is named for a section of Istanbul known for its fish restaurants. Remember that when you order: Seafood is definitely the way to go here.

title: G.M. Plans to Reinstate 661 Dealerships
description: General Motors said Friday that it planned to reinstate 661 dealers that it cut last year as part of its bankruptcy reorganization, The New York Timess Nick Bunkley reports.

title: Bollywood Soars Toward Hollywood
description: MUMBAI

title: A Vibrant Culture of Food Blogging
description: AT Bistro 55, an upscale restaurant in Rochelle Park, the staff is accustomed not only to customers talking on cellphones, but also to people using phones to take pictures of the food, according to Lorenzo Catlett, the general manager.

title: Rivers Takes Aim at Stars Outfits at Oscars
description: JOAN RIVERS was not impressed with the flouncy tea-length Zac Posen dress that Tina Fey sported at the Golden Globes earlier this year. I hope she was going for laughs, because she got them, Ms. Rivers pronounced. She looked like a decorative toilet seat cover. Nor did she admire the purple Bottega Veneta gown that Sandra Bullock wore to the same event: It looked like Princes old prom dress. And Adam Lambert, all glammed up in Dolce & Gabbana at the Grammys? She got right to the point: If Elvis and Elvira had a kid, this would be it. He looks like a gay Col. Sanders. Yes, the sage of the red carpet is back.

title: Oscar Casts Its Glow on a Regular Guy
description: LOS ANGELES

title: For Auto Towns, Emissary Is Ambassador of Hope
description: MORAINE, Ohio  Few places are more emblematic of the rise of American manufacturing, and its gradual decline, than this once-bustling industrial suburb of Dayton  within sight of the hill from which the Wright Brothers first tried to fly their innovative contraption, even before Kitty Hawk.

title: The Cavalry Cant Save Them
description: Paris

title: Liz Cheneys Al Qaeda Seven
description: While its unclear whether its been Dick Cheneys health problems or relatively low profile in recent weeks, but the left side of the blogosphere hasnt had much to say about its Republican bte noire lately. So imagine the relief when another member of Cheney family decided to step into the breach:

title: Massachusetts Democrat Wont Seek 8th House Term
description: BOSTON  Representative William D. Delahunt, a seven-term Democrat, announced Friday that he would not seek re-election, setting off what is sure to be a frenzied race for his seat.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: In Paris, Daring to See the Bright Side
description: Paris

title: Women in Uniform
description: As modern peacekeeping has evolved, the number of female police officers in U.N. missions around the world has doubled during the past five years.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Sport Recoils From a Punch and Its Publicity
description: WACO, Tex.  Shortly after noon Friday, Brittney Griner unfolded herself from the passenger seat of a two-door Honda sedan driven by her Baylor teammate and fellow freshman Kimetria Hayden. Without a hitch in her conversation or her step, Griner disappeared behind the doors of the Ferrell Center and into the cocoon spun by her college basketball family.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Clinton Presses Region to Recognize Honduras
description: MEXICO CITY  Secretary of State Hillary Clinton ended a five-day tour of Latin America Friday with a lightning trip to Guatemala, where she promised Central American presidents more help to fight drug trafficking and repeated her call for more countries to recognize the new government of Honduras.

title: A Cover Ad That Mimics a Newspapers Front Page
description: The entire first page of The Los Angeles Times on Friday was an ad that looked, in part, like the front page of The Los Angeles Times, as the newspaper again tested the accepted limits on where ads can be published and how they can blur the boundary with news.

title: Ex-Leader Is Top Rival to Premier in Iraq Vote
description: BAGHDAD  The serpentine career of Ayad Allawi, who served briefly as Iraqs interim prime minister five years ago, has taken another unlikely turn: a secular Shiite with little taste for campaigning, he stands a strong chance of winning the most votes in Sundays parliamentary elections as the leader of a coalition that is attracting deep support from Sunni Muslims.

title: Knicks and Nets Are Two Halves of an N.B.A. Hole
description: Kenny Smith developed his point-guard skills on the blacktops of Queens and drew his basketball conscience from Midtown Manhattan.

title: Consumer Groups Urge Regulation of Nonbank Financial Institutions
description: WASHINGTON  While much of the Congressional debate over consumer financial protection has focused on banks, lawmakers have been grappling behind the scenes over whether and how to regulate payday lenders, debt collectors, check-cashing outlets, title and installment lenders and even pawnbrokers.

title: Willie Randolphs Arm Finally Gives Out
description: PHOENIX  The Oakland Athletics Ben Sheets was not the only person in uniform here Friday recovering from surgery on a torn right flexor tendon. The other was Willie Randolph.

title: Dysfunction Displaces Work in Distracted Albany
description: ALBANY  To wander into the grand pile of stone that is the State Capitol, to walk its cavernous sandstone and marble halls, is to find an absurdist play in its third act.

title: Paterson Insists Hell Clear His Name
description: Gov. David A. Paterson insisted Friday that he had no plans to step down as his staff tried to carry on the business of state amid a fiscal crisis and the cloud of multiple investigations.

title: Disney and Cablevision Snipe at Chiefs in Contract Talks
description: The distribution spat between The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision started to look more like a spat between two chief executives on Friday, a day before Cablevisions contract to carry the ABC station in New York City was set to expire.

title: $400 Hourly to Get Them Off the Sofa
description: Lesley Mitler, a longtime recruiter for Wall Street and a former C.P.A., is a practical person, someone who describes herself as risk-averse. Why, then, did she decide that midrecession would be the right time to build a new luxury service?

title: Ex-Building Inspector Is Charged With Fraud
description: A former city building inspector was arrested on Friday and charged with selling scores of safety-training certificates to be used by New York construction workers who never completed the required training, federal prosecutors and the citys Department of Investigation said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about concerns that a House ethics committee report could expose the earmark process to greater abuses misstated the political party of Representative Jeffrey Flake of Arizona, who has introduced measures to impose a moratorium on earmarks. He is a Republican, not a Democrat.

title: In What Can We Trust?
description: Note: Dick Cavett is filling in for Gail Collins, who is on vacation.

title: Home Fires: Cut the War Film Some Slack
description: This is the fourth in a five-part series, Retelling the War, in which veterans discuss how books, movies and other tales of combat shaped their perceptions of themselves and of war.

title: European Buyers of Airbus Plane Agree to Cover Its Cost Overruns
description: PARIS  European Aeronautic Defense and Space, the parent company of Airbus, said Friday that buyers of its A400M military transport plane had agreed to a 10 percent price increase, a measure that will help cover substantial cost overruns and allow the troubled project to continue.

title: U.S. Aiding Somalia in Its Plan to Retake Its Capital
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The Somali government is preparing a major offensive to take back this capital block by crumbling block, and it takes just a listen to the low growl of a small surveillance plane circling in the night sky overhead to know who is surreptitiously backing that effort.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Beliefs column last Saturday, about criticism of the argument made by Marc A. Thiessen, a Roman Catholic and former speechwriter for President George W. Bush, that waterboarding suspected terrorists is permitted under Catholic Church teachings, misstated in some editions where one of those critics, the philosopher Christopher O. Tollefsen, referred to the 1993 encyclical Veritatis Splendor. He cited the encyclical in a telephone interview; he did not make the reference in an essay in the online magazine Public Discourse.

title: Tenor Adopted and Disowned by Yankees Leaves Town
description: Ronan Tynan became a walk-on Yankee star in 2000, when he stepped onto the field with his artificial legs and clarion voice and belted out God Bless America during the seventh inning stretch of important games.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the High & Low Finance column on Friday, about corporate resistance to the Internal Revenue Services efforts to get more information about companies tax returns, misstated the right an opposing side has to subpoena documents prepared for litigation. Those documents normally cannot be subpoenaed, not the reverse.

title: Corrections
description: Schedule information on Friday with an art review of the Civil Rights solo show by Craig Norton at Jim Kempner Fine Art in Chelsea included outdated information on the closing date. The show has been extended and will run through March 14; it does not end today.

title: Corrections
description: An art review on Friday about the Independent contemporary-art fair, at 548 West 22nd Street in Chelsea, misstated the surname of an artist who has a film piece displayed by the Parisian gallery gb agency. He is Robert Breer, not Breen. In some copies, a picture caption with the review included an erroneous credit. The picture on the left, showing a still from the film Con Leche by Jordan Wolfson, was from the Johann Knig gallery; it was not by Michelle V. Agins of The New York Times. (The picture on the right, of a work by Jeppe Hein, was by Ms. Agins.)

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Congressman Accused of Harassment Resigns
description: Representative Eric J. Massa, a freshman Democrat from upstate New York who faces an investigation after being accused of harassing a male aide, said Friday that he would resign next week.

title: Never Too Many Fans
description: TINSLEY MORTIMER was literally sparkling, thanks to her pink Dior dress with glittering bows at the shoulders. Her long blond hair was, as usual, set in carefully placed curls. She had rings on her fingers, though her left ring finger was now empty.

title: Two Officers Are Charged in Robbery at Warehouse
description: The two men waving pistols and police badges at workers inside a warehouse stocked with perfume in New Jersey last month were not fibbing when they yelled, N.Y.P.D.! Hands up! according to the authorities.

title: Hoping to Graduate From Guards to Gauguins
description: The guards at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are easy to ignore, and that is not totally by accident. Their blue uniforms, red clip-on ties and thick plastic identification cards do not distract the eye from the stunning works they are paid to protect.

title: One Familys Two Old World Bakeries Battle Over a Modern Prize
description: There are two Italian bakeries that bear the name Artuso, one in Yonkers and one in the Bronx, that are redolent of certain Old World fragrances  the anise, sesame and rum that fill their cannoli, sfogliatelle and other pastries.

title: Seeking a Future for a Symbol of a Grander Past
description: DETROIT  The last train pulled away more than 20 years ago from Michigan Central Station, one of thousands of see-through buildings here, empty shells from more auspicious times.

title: Haitians in U.S. Double Up to Take In Their Own
description: Carmelle Lajoie shared her house in Queens with her husband, their four children, her brother and her mother. That was before she took in her 11-year-old niece, an American citizen who was airlifted from Haiti after the earthquake in January.

title: Owner of Crane Company Faces Manslaughter Charges
description: The owner of a crane company has been indicted on manslaughter charges in connection with a crane collapse in 2008 that killed two construction workers, a law enforcement official and a lawyer briefed on the case said Friday.

title: Autonomy of Consumer Watchdog Is in Dispute
description: As Congress and the White House battle over the outlines of an agency to protect consumers from deceptive financial practices, their biggest hurdle is figuring out how independent it should be.

title: Why the Rainmaker Is Now the Gatekeeper
description: YOU probably wont be finding Julianna Smoot wearing Comme des Garons, showing up at New York Fashion Week or posing for Vogue and Vanity Fair. And at least for now, you wont find her posing or doing interviews at all.

title: South Africa: A.N.C. Denounces Unions Allegations
description: In an escalation of venomous feuding within the alliance that has governed South Africa since 1994, the African National Congress denounced with contempt on Friday allegations leveled by the trade union federation Cosatu that some in the A.N.C. were seeking to oust President Jacob Zuma. The A.N.C. leads the alliance. The trade unions, which have long complained that their policy views are ignored, have made their dissatisfaction increasingly public, particularly with A.N.C. leaders they regard as corrupt.

title: Inside Scientology
description: A tour of the Church of Scientologys international spiritual headquarters in Clearwater, Fla.

title: Senecas See Comeback Over Sale of Cigarettes
description: There is a relatively short list of people who like mail-order cigarettes: teenagers, adults evading sales taxes and the Seneca Nation of Indians of western New York, which dominates the national market.

title: Ex-Mayor Gets 15 Years for Bribery; City Pays Price
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Residents here were not terribly surprised on Friday when Larry Langford, the former mayor, was sentenced to 15 years in prison and fined $360,000 by a federal judge, ending a long-running bribery case that shook local government and state Democratic politics.

title: What May Accumulate in the Mouth
description: The Hoosier Folk-Child!  Rich is heIn all the wealth of poverty!

title: In Illinois, Race Is Set for Governor
description: CHICAGO  A full month after votes were cast in a primary, the race for governor was at last set here Friday. The campaign will pit a conservative downstate Republican lawmaker against the sitting Democratic governor, who must overcome a dire state budget gap as well as memories of the ousted Democratic governor Rod R. Blagojevich.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Mortgage column last Sunday, about alternatives to foreclosure being offered by some banks, referred incorrectly to a senior vice president at Wells Fargo. The official, J. K. Huey, is a woman.

title: A Writer Invites Russia to Engage Its Painful Past
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

title: Corrections
description: The Living In article last Sunday, about Kew Gardens, Queens, misidentified the express subway station two stops west of Kew Gardens. It is Forest Hills, not Flushing. The article also misstated the number of holes at the Forest Park golf course. There are 18, not 9.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 5, 2010

title: U.S. Sees a Terror Threat; Pakistanis See a Heroine
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Relations between the United States and Pakistan often have a through-the-looking-glass quality, where almost nothing appears quite the same from the other side. The latest example is the case of Aafia Siddiqui.

title: Israel: Police and Palestinians Clash at Holy Site
description: The Israeli police and Palestinian youths clashed at a Jerusalem holy site on Friday after the youths threw stones at Jewish worshipers, according to the police. About 15 officers were lightly injured, a police spokesman said, while Palestinian news agencies reported up to 50 youths slightly hurt. The confrontation occurred at the plaza known to Muslims as the Holy Sanctuary and to Jews as the Temple Mount. Tempers have flared and rocks have been thrown in Jerusalem and in the West Bank city of Hebron since an Israeli declaration that two holy sites in the West Bank would be renovated as part of a group of Israeli national heritage sites.

title: Bloggingheads: Down With Avatar!
description: Walter Kirn, author of Up in the Air, and Susan Orlean, author of The Orchid Thief, discuss blockbusters vs. smaller films.

title: Mets Prospect Emerges in the Span of Seven Outs
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The expectation surrounding Jenrry Mejia took a quantum leap forward Friday when Mets Manager Jerry Manuel and the pitching coach Dan Warthen made it clear that they think Mejia has the talent to pitch in the major leagues this year.

title: Australian Court Finds Damages in a Vioxx Case
description: Mercks Australian unit failed to warn a doctor about heart risks associated with its painkiller Vioxx, a court in Melbourne found, and might be ordered to pay almost 290,000 Australian dollars ($261,000) in damages. The Federal Court awarded the amount to Graeme R. Peterson, 59, in a case against Merck Sharpe & Dohme (Australia), the plaintiffs law firm, Slater & Gordon, said Friday. The court found that Vioxx contributed to Mr. Petersons heart attack in 2003, according to the judgment. Merck said in a statement that it would appeal. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., withdrew Vioxx in 2004 after a study showed it doubled the risk of heart attacks and strokes.

title: Andrew Jaffe, Who Brought Clios to Adweek, Is Dead at 71
description: Andrew Jaffe, who presided over the expansion of the advertising trade magazine Adweek and helped revitalize the industrys venerable Clio Awards, died on Feb. 26 in Norwalk, Conn. He was 71 and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Nets Laud Future Newark Home as a Bridge to Brooklyn
description: NEWARK  For a team that has won 6 of its 61 games this season, the future is all the Nets have.

title: Met Guards Are True Artists
description: An exhibition at a gallery on Central Park West in Manhattan features works created by guards from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Saved by the Coast Guard
description: To the Editor:

title: Does the Mideast Need a Therapist?
description: To the Editor:

title: Refereeing the Health Care Debate
description: Even before the health care showdown begins, Republican lawmakers have begun questioning the fairness of the Senate parliamentarian, the obscure but well respected career expert who must referee from the wings when points are challenged in floor debate.

title: How the Tea Party Is Not Like the New Left
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics and Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: The Battle Over Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: To the Editor:

title: If You Bring in the Cops
description: United States and NATO troops have chased most of the Taliban out of the Afghan city of Marja. The fighting was hard. But what comes next will surely be harder  leaving behind an honest and competent Afghan administration that can win back the loyalty of local people.

title: So Much for Jobs, Jobs, Jobs
description: It is possible to put a positive spin on the jobs numbers for February, released on Friday. The unemployment rate, though still elevated at 9.7 percent, held steady. The economy shed 36,000 jobs last month, but the pace of job loss is moderating. An average of 27,000 jobs have been lost each month over the past four months, compared with 727,000 jobs a month, on average, over the same period a year earlier.

title: Trading Away Productivity
description: Washington

title: Justice for Judges
description: New York judges have not seen a pay raise since 1999, not even a token cost-of-living increase. They have justly complained about it. Legal scholars have pointed out how damaging it is to the cause of justice. Editorial pages, like this one, have denounced lawmakers baldly political tactic of linking the salaries of judges to their own.

title: Cops vs. Kids
description: If you dont think the police in New York City need to be reined in, consider the way the cops and their agents are treating youngsters in the citys schools.

title: Sheets Brings New Mind-Set to As Team in Need of Change
description: PHOENIX  Every day he reports to work at Phoenix Municipal Stadium, Ben Sheets greets his fellow Oakland Athletics this way: Good morning, champions! His teammates, who are coming off a last-place finish in the American League West, love him for it.

title: Shaky Starts for Yankees Phil Hughes and Joba Chamberlain
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain battled a stomach illness for three days, and his pitching statistics were sickly Friday in his first exhibition appearance this spring.

title: Giants Sign Rolle to Strengthen Their Secondary
description: The Giants, apparently concerned about Kenny Phillipss ability to return from a left knee injury, signed the Pro Bowl safety Antrel Rolle to a five-year contract Friday night.

title: Amid Record Low Scores, Player Takes High Road
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  High on the list of things unlikely to happen again any time soon at the brutal Champion Course at PGA National? How about a quartet of golfers each tying the course record in tournament conditions?

title: Trendspotting | Suits Off the Rack
description: Not much in fashions panoply has the cool authority of a trouser suit  or its potent sex appeal.

title: Suits Off the Rack
description: NOT much in fashions panoply has the cool authority of a trouser suit  or its potent sex appeal. In the mid-1990s, during his tenure at Gucci, Tom Ford was quick to mine the pantsuits allure, executing variations with a 70s-tinged rock-star air. At Balmain in Paris this week, Christophe Decarnin reprised that rock n roll theme, placing his louche stamp on strong-shouldered, hip-slung versions in banker stripes for day, and Lurex streaks for evening.

title: Raimund Abraham, Architect With Vision, Dies at 76
description: Raimund Abraham, an architect who was known primarily for his visionary drawings of mostly unrealizable projects but whose Austrian Cultural Forum, a slim skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan completed in 2002, was hailed as one of the most exciting New York buildings in decades, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 76 and lived in Manhattan and Mazunte, Mexico.

title: Ruth Kligman, Muse and Artist, Dies at 80
description: Ruth Kligman, an abstract painter who for decades seemed to know everyone and be everywhere in the art world and who was the lone survivor of the 1956 car crash that killed Jackson Pollock, her lover at the time, died Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chain Disdain
description: News Parody | From The Onion:

title: Obama Urges Action on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama pressed Congress on Saturday to finish its work on health care, dismissing criticism from Republicans as he sought to build a case that the legislation would be friendly to families and small businesses.

title: Russian Oddka
description: Mondo Video | Its singing in the shower meets Lawrence Welk meets the Slavic world and its gone viral. Hes quite possibly the Russian Rick Astley:

title: State of the Bengals: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Classic Ad: Nash Ambassador
description: In the Automobiles section this Sunday, Richard S. Chang writes about a radio host in upstate New York, Rich Conaty, and his 1950 Nash Ambassador Custom, a fine example of the companys superstreamlined Airflyte styling in the postwar years. Mr. Conatys obsession with Nash automobiles began when he was a boy in Queens, hooked on the Superman television series:

title: The Saturday Word: Back to Health Care
description: This was supposed to have been the year that Democrats focused on jobs, but after passing a jobs bill Thursday and relishing Fridays better-than-expected unemployment numbers, lawmakers have resumed their full-fledged health care brawl.

title: Nine to Know: Jason Bay
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: 2010 Iraqi Elections: Why I Will Vote
description: BAGHDAD  I didnt vote in the 2009 provincial elections. I think I was busy, or I didnt really care. This time is different. The vote will decide who rules the country for the next four years  the first to lead, in theory, without American soldiers. Your vote is golden, Iraqis are being told. I really believe that, despite my disappointment with Iraqi leaders and all the chaos of the political process here.

title: Bloc Takes On Entrenched Kurdish Parties in Iraq
description: KIRKUK, Iraq  A third political movement is waging a surprisingly strong challenge in Iraqs autonomous Kurdistan region, threatening decades of domination here by two entrenched and, many say, corrupt parties.

title: A Vote Before Easter
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Im not sure if you guys have heard the latest update on healthcare reform, but Democrats are saying they hope to get a final healthcare vote before Easter. Well, I dont know. Two resurrections is a lot to hope for, dont you think?

title: Her Own Reality Show
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Sarah Palin is getting her own reality show. Its going to be called So You Think You Can See Russia?

title: Two Hosts This Year
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: They have two hosts this year for the Academy Awards. Who says Obama isnt creating jobs?

title: The Price of Lobster
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: As you may have heard, the House has passed a $15 billion jobs bill. Thats the good news. The bad news? All those new jobs, fixing Toyotas.

title: Allison Braley and Scott Thompson
description: Allison Moran Braley and Scott Anthony Thompson were married Saturday in New York. Kim Kirkley, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at the Manhattan Penthouse.

title: Vanessa Menkes, Alexander Orlofsky
description: Vanessa Rachel Menkes and Alexander Stephen Orlofsky were married Saturday evening in Miami Beach. Rabbi Robert A. Davis officiated at the Miami Beach Resort and Spa.

title: Kirsten Menkes and Jamie Firsten
description: Kirsten Alexandra Menkes and Jamie David Firsten were married Saturday evening by Rabbi David Cooper at the Canon Theater in Toronto.

title: Sarah Siegel, Adam Lubow
description: Sarah Siegel, a daughter of Elizabeth Siegel and Edward Siegel, both of Shaker Heights, Ohio, is to be married Sunday to Adam Lubow, the son of Lynn and Greg Lubow of Tannersville, N.Y. Cantor Diego A. Mendelbaum is to officiate at the Villa Montaa Beach Resort in Isabela, P.R.

title: Jennifer Parnes, Anthony Jones
description: Jennifer Lynn Parnes and Anthony Christopher Jones were married in Brooklyn Saturday evening. Rabbi Allen Block officiated at Stage Six at Steiner Studios in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Karen Salomon, Buckley Ratchford
description: Karen Rachel Salomon and Buckley Thomas Ratchford were married Monday in New York. Tulis McCall, a minister of the Universal Brotherhood Movement, officiated at the couples apartment.

title: With Haitian Schools in Ruins, Children in Limbo
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Thousands of schools in and around this devastated capital could remain closed for months or never reopen, according to Haitian and United Nations education officials. That leaves vast numbers of children languishing in camps or working in menial jobs as they struggle to survive.

title: Palestinian Sees Lesson Translating an Israelis Work
description: JERUSALEM  Six years ago, when violence was the order of the day here, Elias Khourys 20-year-old son, George, was killed in a Palestinian terrorist attack. The Khourys are Palestinian, so the murder of George  who was out for a jog and shot from behind by gunmen in a car  produced an apology. Sorry, the killers said, we assumed the jogger was a Jew.

title: Now Screening | Junya Watanabe
description: The fall 2010 collection from Junya Watanabe at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Philippine Rebels Kill 11 Soldiers
description: MANILA  Eleven soldiers were killed and several others were wounded Saturday in a firefight with Communist guerrillas in a province south of Manila, Philippine Army officials said.

title: Elyssa Goldberg, Jeffrey Ruzal
description: Elyssa Beth Goldberg and Jeffrey Howard Ruzal were married Saturday evening at the University Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Elliott J. Cosgrove officiated.

title: Gail Schultz and Henry Smokler
description: Gail Gussie Schultz and Henry Samuel Smokler were married Saturday at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. Rabbi Andrew S. Davids officiated.

title: Message Maven Finds Fingers Pointing at Him
description: WASHINGTON  David Axelrod was sitting at his desk on a recent afternoon  tie crooked, eyes droopy and looking more burdened than usual. He had just been watching some genius on MSNBC insist that he and President Obamas other top aides were failing miserably and should be replaced.

title: Loryn Wolff, Elliot Sperber
description: Loryn Allison Wolff and Elliot Jason Sperber were married Saturday evening at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Michael A. White performed the ceremony.

title: Haiti's School Problem
description: The earthquake that leveled much of Port-au-Prince left Haiti's already fragile educational system in shambles.  A few schools have reopened, but class remains out of reach for most students.

title: The Mother Figure of Morne Lazarre
description: Rea Dol leads an effort to feed and care for the people of Morne Lazarre, a poor neighborhood in Port-au-Prince.

title: Photos of the Moments | On With the Shows
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Olga Ramos and Felipe Azenha
description: Olga Enid Ramos and Felipe Saes Azenha were married Friday evening in Miami Beach. The Rev. Joaquin Perez, an Apostolic Catholic priest, officiated at the Miami Beach Botanical Garden.

title: Split Decisions
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  George Bredehorn returns with another of his Split Decision challenges.

title: The Posting Hour
description: You know youve scaled the ranks of the sleepless elite when your editor notices the berserker late night time-stamps on your Facebook posts and asks you to contribute to a forum on insomnia. How flattering! How alarming! Isnt it remarkable that, despite how isolated and alone we feel in our wakefulness, our numbers are so great we warrant our own special exploration? Fellow night owls, we have arrived. Three hoots for the weary.

title: Lauren Pestronk, Adam Wilner
description: Lauren Danielle Pestronk, a daughter of Isabel Pestronk and Jimmy Pestronk of Upper Saddle River, N.J., was married Saturday evening in New York to Dr. Adam Jeremy Wilner, the son of Nicole M. Wilner and Dr. Alan H. Wilner of Hicksville, N.Y. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated at the Mandarin Oriental New York.

title: Margot Lowenstein, Jonathan Simmons
description: Margot Allison Lowenstein, a daughter of Rochelle Lowenstein and Douglas Lowenstein of Chevy Chase, Md., was married Saturday evening to Jonathan David Simmons, the son of Jeffrey Simmons of Newtown, Pa., and the late Judith Simmons. Rabbi Elliot M. Strom officiated at Halcyon House, a historic house in Washington.

title: Candice Smith, Scott Dias
description: Candice L. Smith and Scott E. Dias were married Saturday at All Saints Episcopal Church in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Sherod Mallow, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Skis That Provide Grip When Waxes Dont Work
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  As large, wet snowflakes fell onto the finish area at the cross-country skiing venue at the Vancouver Olympics, Tjere Smevold appeared to be more than a little exasperated. Although he is the chief ski waxing technician at Swix, the Norwegian company that dominates that business, he said there was only one solution for the days conditions, and it did not involve any of his waxes.

title: Lets Dig In
description: In the mid-1990s, when I still lived in Washington, I equated sanity with an old pair of paddock boots. I would put them on whenever I returned from covering the collections. They were part of a general cosmopolitan rumpledness I affected in order to stay in touch with the girl who once thought she wanted to marry a farmer (or a vet) and have five children and lots of dogs.

title: U.S. Enriches Companies Defying Its Policy on Iran
description: The federal government has awarded more than $107 billion in contract payments, grants and other benefits over the past decade to foreign and multinational American companies while they were doing business in Iran, despite Washingtons efforts to discourage investment there, records show.

title: A 96-Team Tournament? Now Thats Madness
description: It is never a surprise when sports officials act out of greed  the outrageous prices at New Yorks two subsidized ballparks, the gouging at the coming World Cup of soccer in South Africa, for example.

title: Straightening the Record
description: Dorothy Jane Mills was supposed to feel honored last Monday when the Society for American Baseball Research included her husband, Dr. Harold Seymour, in the inaugural class of the organizations new de facto Hall of Fame. She was supposed to feel thankful that her assistance with Seymours seminal three-volume history of baseball, published sequentially from 1960 through 1990, would be acknowledged during his induction.

title: Photos of the Moment | Wig Out
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Skye Parrott.

title: Profiting From Iran, and the U.S.
description: The New York Times identified 74 corporations that have done business both in Iran and with the U.S. government over the last decade.

title: Ahmadinejad Calls 9/11 A Big Fabrication
description: Perhaps concerned that his repeated suggestions that the Holocaust might not have happened have become less shocking over time, Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, upped the ante on Saturday, telling intelligence officials in Tehran that the destruction of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, was staged.

title: Coach Did Odd Jobs on Way to a Top Job
description: RICHMOND, Va.  When the Richmond mens basketball team gathered at midcourt during a recent practice, it was difficult to discern the head coach from his players.

title: Model-morphosis | Lanvin
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Edita Vilkeviciute from DNA Model Management before (top, bottom) and after makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

title: The Swaps That Swallowed Your Town
description: AS more details surface about how derivatives helped Greece and perhaps other countries mask their debt loads, lets not forget that the wonders of these complex products arent on display only overseas. Across our very own country, municipalities, school districts, sewer systems and other tax-exempt debt issuers are ensnared in the derivatives mess.

title: Letting Women Reach Women in Afghan War
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif.  The Marines in a recent cultural awareness class scribbled careful notes as the instructor coached them on dos and donts when talking to villagers in Afghanistan: Dont start by firing off questions, do break the ice by playing with the children, dont let your interpreter hijack the conversation.

title: Overseer of Boxing, Supporter of M.M.A.
description: Melvina Lathan, the chairwoman of the New York State Athletic Commission, has a passion for boxing that began in vitro, she says, and would lead her to be a judge of 83 championship fights around the world.

title: Photos of the Moment | Backstage Bash
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: G.M. and Ford Channel Toyota to Beat Toyota
description: Milford, Mich.

title: A Spring Training Pilgrimage Amid Changing Times
description: Decades ago, friends of my parents in New York would book an annual spring trip to Florida, brimming with anticipation about baseball adventures ahead. The fun of the trip was its casual itinerary, with a stop at the Pittsburgh Pirates base in Bradenton and a drive up to St. Petersburg, where the Mets camp was.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 7
description: Sundays talk shows hold no surprises as the political guests talk about (drum roll, please) health care and the 2010 midterm elections.

title: The Real Take on Methane and Warming
description: With a valuable reality check on Arctic methane in the climate context, Realclimate.org (in this case David Archer) illustrates the value of having scientists step into the uncomfortable, but unavoidable, arena of direct public communication. In the post, Dr. Archer, who has tested his chops with a couple of books for general audiences (I forgive him for recycling Global Warming: Understanding the Forecast, the title of my 1992 book on climate ;-) , tries out a nice analogy relating carbon dioxide and methane emissions to various troubles that can endanger a driver:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Precious Dominates a More Staid Spirits Awards
description: LOS ANGELES In a bit of Oscar presaging, Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire and Crazy Heart were the big winners at Film Independents Spirit Awards on Friday. Precious took best feature, best director for Lee Daniels, best first screenplay (Geoffrey Fletcher), best actress (Gabourey Sidibe) and best supporting actress (Muh-nique, as the presenter, Pierce Brosnan, called MoNique). Crazy Heart won best first feature and best actor for Jeff Bridges, who did double-duty by performing a song from it. Mr. Bridges and Muh-nique are Oscar locks; Ms. Sidibe has been much-nominated this season but has rarely made a trip to the podium, so it was especially sweet for her.

title: No Road Map Necessary
description: I WAS born in South Korea. When I was 2, my family, including my grandparents, emigrated to Brazil for a better life. My father saw more opportunity there.

title: Pinstripes Then, Now and Forever
