description: Goose Gossage, the former Yankees relief pitcher who was inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 2008, spends much of his time making appearances around the country with Wish You Were Here Productions and sharing stories with other retired players like David Cone, Don Larsen, Graig Nettles and Mickey Rivers. Every February, he heads to the Yankees training camp to work as a special instructor. JOE BRESCIA

title: In Basra, Iraqi Shiites Face Off Again
description: BASRA, Iraq  Two years ago, Uday Awad was in prison after having been arrested along with Shiite militia members during street battles here against government security forces. Though he was never charged with a crime, he said Iraqi Army officers tortured him over a seven-month period.

title: Reports Say Afghan Official in Showcase City May Have Criminal Background
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As the United States and its Western allies renewed their commitment to the Afghan war in recent months, they stressed that it cannot be won without good government. They reiterated that stand in recent weeks as allied troops flooded the city of Marja, setting it up as a showcase for a new strategy of taking territory, then holding it through strong local leadership.

title: An Office? Shell Pass on That
description: This interview with Meridee A. Moore, founder of Watershed Asset Management, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant. Watershed is a $2 billion hedge fund based in San Francisco.

title: Villegas Surges Ahead at the Honda Classic
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Rarely does the thin edge between potential and performance snap into focus the way it has at the Honda Classic, and not even the thick smoke wafting over the PGA National Resort and Spa from a controlled burn in a nearby state park could obscure the story line Saturday.

title: Neither Men Nor Mice
description: LAST fall, while working with corporate women across various industries, job levels and generations, an age-old issue re-emerged at a near-fever pitch. Women were obsessed about being labeled a bitch, and to a degree I hadnt seen since the 1990s.

title: Getting Older Without Getting Old
description: FACEBOOK now has more than 400 million active users, up from only 50 million as recently as 2007. If social networking still resembled a young, hip downtown nightclub scene  one day a site is hot, the next its not  we might expect the crowds to decamp soon. Facebook would become another Friendster, still around but ghostly, forgotten by most.

title: The Corporate Side of Snooping
description: ITS easy to understand how Washington reporters can become jaded. They are constantly being spun by the same gang of politicians and lobbyists who dominate the nations capital.

title: Paris: Body Mapping
description: Funny that I should mention lumps and bumps, the Comme des Garons collection from the late 90s, in the last post: Rei Kawakubos fall 2010 show seemed to transplant that concept to a new view of human anatomy and inner strength. Inside decoration, Ms. Kawakubo said backstage of coats and sheer black tops clustered with shapes that brought to mind muscles, kidneys and brain matter. Or maybe those channeled and bunched skirts were meant to evoke intestines. Either way, the show was fascinating and well done.

title: Tarnishing Hockeys Golden Moment
description: Enjoy hockeys Olympic moment while its still aglow because its luster is beginning to fade. Instead of looking forward to the splendor of the worlds best players again representing their nations in 2014 in Sochi, Russia, the N.H.L. is leaning toward secession from the Winter Games.

title: Prime Number
description: 197: The amount, in thousands of dollars, that the typical married couple at age 65 should expect to spend on uninsured health care costs over the rest of their lives, according to the Center for Retirement Research at Boston College. This total includes insurance premiums, out-of-pocket costs and home health care costs, but it does not include nursing home care. Including the cost of nursing home care, typical lifetime health care costs shoot up to $260,000, the center estimated.

title: Bad in School? Detention With Mozart
description: Disciplinary problems at a school in Derby, Britain, have dropped by about 60 percent since the school began piping classical music into a detention room for troublesome students, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reported. But music lovers are complaining that the school is alienating students from the music of Mozart, Ravel and other giants. Brendan ONeill, author of a recent essay, Weaponizing Mozart in Reason Magazine, told the CBC that the school was using great achievement to whack people across the head. The headmaster, Brian Walker, said the music has relaxed his students. I am sure that, with some of them, sitting in silence listening to the music lets them reflect more about the reasons they are in detention, he told The Daily Mail.

title: The Kite Makers
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

title: Quotations of the Week
description: Its a long way to Phoenix from here. Bonnie Chapman, a waitress at the Golden Nugget, a restaurant in Wickenburg, Ariz., explaining why business has picked up since the state closed its highway rest stops in a desperate move to solve a budget gap.

title: New York Isnt Silicon Valley. Thats Why They Like It.
description: The two dozen or so people arranged around wooden tables, warming their hands and bellies with steaming mugs of coffee and plates of homemade biscuits, looked like just another Sunday brunch set in New York. But members of this group had braved knee-deep snow to gab about cutting-edge ideas and as they introduced themselves the roll call sounded like a Whos Who of digital start-ups: Foursquare, Hot Potato, Six Apart, Flickr, Flavorpill, Trust Art, Vimeo.

title: A Connoisseur of Awards Show and Depressing Films
description: LOS ANGELES Though it may be a while before he takes home any mainstream trophies, John Waters is an awards-show addict. I voted in the Oscars, the Spirit Awards, the Writers Guild, the Directors Guild, the Razzies, he told the Bagger Friday night at Film Independents Spirit Awards. I voted in every awards there are.

title: Correction: The Cost of Doing Nothing on Health Care
description: An article last Sunday about the cost of doing nothing to change the health care system misstated when health care premiums are likely to be nearly a quarter of a typical familys income. A premium of $24,000, projected for 2020, is a quarter of what a family is expected to earn then, not of what it earns today.

title: Yankees Cervelli Sustains a Concussion
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Yankees catcher Francisco Cervelli was taken to a Tampa-area hospital for a precautionary CT scan Saturday afternoon after he sustained a concussion when he was hit in the head by a pitch.

title: Lessons at Indian Hospital About Births
description: TUBA CITY, Ariz.  After less than two hours in the maternity ward, with her boyfriend, his mother and a nurse-midwife by her side, Jacquelynn Torivio gave birth to a five-pound, five-ounce son with his grandmothers dimples and a full head of shiny black hair.

title: A Squandered Talent Claimed by the Street
description: Michael Chatfield was largely unknown outside of his neighborhood. He did not play high school basketball, and his college career consisted of one unremarkable season at a junior college in Oklahoma.

title: Arabia: Inshallah, Obama
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia

title: The Moral Ambiguity of Looting
description: The law, in its majestic equality, wrote the 19th-century novelist Anatole France, forbids the rich as well as the poor to sleep under bridges, to beg in the streets and to steal bread.

title: A Farewell to Europe? Not So Fast
description: IN 2008, during the worst of the financial crisis, portfolio diversification was of little help to stock investors as equity markets fell almost in lock step around the world.

title: Giants and Rolle Have Leadership in Mind
description: He is an outstanding person who will bring leadership, versatility and more big play ability to our secondary.  General Manager Jerry Reese

title: The Up-or-Down Vote on Obamas Presidency
description: WEDNESDAYS health care rally was one of President Obamas finest hours. It was so fine it couldnt be blighted even by his preposterous backdrop, a cohort of white-jacketed medical workers large enough to staff a hospital in one of the daytime soaps that refused to be pre-empted by the White House show.

title: Mom, Apple Pie and Mortgages
description: FOR decades, the federal government has subsidized housing  particularly owner-occupied housing. This has been especially true during the continuing financial crisis, with Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and the Federal Housing Administration propping up the housing market by issuing guarantees for investors on most new mortgages.

title: Democrats Need a Rally Monkey
description: Wake Up and Stand Up. So urges the bold motto of a seedling movement calling itself the Coffee Party, a leftish alternative to the Tea Party movement.

title: Seoul Police Link 1,700 Pairs of Shoes to 2 Feet
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In South Korea, where people often remove their shoes before entering homes, restaurants or funeral parlors, it is a nagging problem: people walking off with others shoes, either by mistake or, sometimes, intentionally.

title: Bob Biniak, a Member of Skateboardings Z-Boys, Dies at 51
description: Bob Biniak, a leading member of the Zephyr Skate Team, a California group whose aggressive, surfing-inspired approach to skateboarding during the 1970s reinvented the sport and was celebrated in two films, died Feb. 25 in Jacksonville Beach, Fla., where he was visiting friends. He was 51.

title: Schools Shake-Up Is Embraced by the President
description: A Rhode Island school boards decision to fire the entire faculty of a poorly performing school, and President Obamas endorsement of the action, has stirred a storm of reaction nationwide, with teachers condemning it as an insult and conservatives hailing it as a watershed moment of school accountability.

title: Irans Ace (or Deuce): Its Oil Reserves
description: Diplomacy and energy are never far apart in the Persian Gulf. So, as American officials seek new international sanctions against Iran this week, its probably wise for them to remember how much the worlds global energy map has changed over the past decade.

title: Chinas Bank Chief Says Currency Is Unlikely to Rise
description: BEIJING  Chinas central bank governor indicated Saturday that the government was unlikely to detach the value of Chinas currency from that of the dollar anytime soon, echoing Prime Minister Wen Jiabaos statement on Friday that exchange rates would remain basically stable for now.

title: Mad as a Hatter: The History of a Simile
description: Is the Hatter mad?

title: Russia Confirms Killing of Militant Leader in Raid
description: MOSCOW  Russia confirmed Saturday that its forces had killed the militant leader Aleksandr Tikhomirov, who under the name Said Buryatsky is believed to have trained suicide bombers in the North Caucasus. And Russian officials said they had proof that his organization was behind the bombing of a luxury train in November.

title: How Jerry Brown Became Governor Moonbeam
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On Tuesday, when Jerry Brown  Californias once and would-be-future leader  declared he was running to win back his old job, he brought with him more than questions about his age (71) and his record of political service (40 years and counting).

title: Egyptian Leaders Surgery in the News Is News Itself
description: CAIRO  Egypts longtime president, Hosni Mubarak, was recovering in a hospital in Germany on Saturday night after what doctors called a successful operation to remove his gallbladder, according to Egypts official MENA news agency.

title: Algebra in Wonderland
description: Oxford, England

title: The Unbearable Lightness of Leading
description: One oddity of the report: Mr. Obama weighed 179.9 pounds with his shoes and workout attire on, which is not the usual way to measure a patients weight.

title: Between Germany and Greece, a Chorus of Sturm, Drang and Pathos
description: In recent days, novel solutions to the Greek debt crisis have surfaced, though perhaps not the constructive ones European leaders desperate to hold their struggling union together were hoping to hear.

title: Reconciling With the Past
description: WITH President Obama and Congressional Democrats intent on one last push for health care reform, the main Republican talking point is outrage over the likely use of the reconciliation process to pass a separate House-Senate compromise. The Republicans best hopes of killing health reform rest on the use of a filibuster in the Senate. But bills considered under reconciliation cannot be filibustered and therefore can pass the Senate by a simple majority vote.

title: Amateur Video Shows Flooding in Chile After Last Weeks Earthquake
description: Amateur video, shot in the coastal town of Penco, Chile last Saturday has emerged showing the impact of a tsunami triggered by the 8.8 magnitude earthquake:

title: Home Fires: Narrative and Memory at War
description: This is the last of a five-part series, Retelling the War, in which veterans discuss how books, movies and other tales of combat shaped their perceptions of themselves and of war.

title: The Pulse: Stroger Makes It Official Dynastys Days Are Past
description: First, Todd Stroger, the Cook County Board president, lost the backing of the mostly white Democratic power structure that he and his father had served for decades. And now, not long after his failed run for another term, Mr. Stroger has also given up the right to lead the political foot soldiers who long served his familys South Side political dynasty.

title: Clock Ticking on Disney-Cablevision Talks
description: Three million cable customers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will see their ABC station go to black (or something like it) early Sunday morning unless The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision either strike a deal or extend their tense contract negotiations.

title: The Pulse: In the Recession, Proposing a Moratorium on Fix-Ups
description: Complaints from businesses about a city zoning department demand that they install costly decorative fences and make other costly changes has prompted the City Council to consider a moratorium on the fix-up program.

title: Timeline: Scientology
description: As it has expanded across the United States and the world, Scientology has drawn controversy.

title: Leaving the Church, But Not the Faith
description: A lifelong Scientologist, Christie King Collbran worked for the Sea Org, the elite corps who help run the Church. But, after 13 years, she grew disillusioned with the Church's leadership and left.

title: Carp Solution Could Provide Financial Benefits
description: Proposals to block Asian carp from invading the Great Lakes have largely focused on the costs and inconvenience of closing off Chicago-area waterways into Lake Michigan. But now business and environmental groups are exploring a possible upside: a broadly based infrastructure investment that would benefit much of northern Illinois.

title: An Award to Tie the Room Together
description: LOS ANGELES Jeff Bridges will never live down the Dude, nor does he want to.

title: Defectors Say Church of Scientology Hides Abuse
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Raised as Scientologists, Christie King Collbran and her husband, Chris, were recruited as teenagers to work for the elite corps of staff members who keep the Church of Scientology running, known as the Sea Organization, or Sea Org.

title: Come to Order
description: Cest moi! Cest moi! The angels have choseTo fight their battles below,And here I stand, as pure as a prayer,Incredibly clean, with virtue to spare,The godliest man I know!Cest moi! as sung by Franco Nero

title: Henri Salmide, 90, Dies; Germans Defiance Saved a French Port
description: PARIS  Henri Salmide, a former German naval officer who defied orders to blow up the French port of Bordeaux in 1944, died on Feb. 23. He was 90 and lived in Bordeaux.

title: For Aldermen, a 50-50 Chance Theyll Look Good
description: If youre not doing anything the evening of March 19, you might consider a visit to the Johalla Projects Gallery in Wicker Park for the opening of the Aldermen Project: 50 Aldermen/50 Artists show.

title: Making Tough Choices for Higher Education
description: James Warren is a longtime Chicago journalist and the publisher of The Chicago Reader.

title: Journalistic Shoplifting
description: ZACHERY KOUWE, a Times business reporter for a little over a year, resigned last month after he was accused of plagiarizing from The Wall Street Journal. An internal review of his work turned up more articles  he said he was shown four  containing copy clearly lifted from other news sources.

title: Letters: Reining in the Swaps
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: An Airwave Auction
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of Office, but Still the Toast of the Town
description: Willie L. Brown Jr. was a poor boy from Texas when he made his way to San Francisco at 17. He went on to become one of the most powerful politicians in California, serving for three decades in the State Assembly, including 15 as speaker, before leaving politics in 2004 after two terms as mayor of San Francisco. During his time in office, he was equally adept at making back-room deals and smiling his way through various red-carpet events with swarms of reporters and photographers. Now 75, a columnist for The San Francisco Chronicle and as gregarious as ever, Mr. Brown remains one of the citys most influential and nattily dressed figures. (His words have been edited and condensed.) GERRY SHIH

title: Fretting About the Last of the Worlds Biggest Cats
description: Could this Chinese Year of the Tiger be the last one with actual tigers still afoot in the worlds wild?

title: Pete Stark Is Often His Own Worst Enemy
description: Long before he first ran for Congress nearly four decades ago, Pete Stark was not one to fit in. Dont expect him to change now.

title: A Germanic Interlude at the Spirits
description: LOS ANGELES So, as we were saying, Jeff Bridges will never live down the Dude. Not only did he make a Big Lebowski reference on stage at the Spirit Awards on Friday, he displayed some of that characters trademark chill-ness after the show ended. The Bagger and Mr. Bridges were walking and talking when we were interrupted by a man with a microphone and a video camera, an attractive woman in a gown standing to his side.

title: Colleges and Schools Try to Do More With Less
description: When San Francisco State Universitys theater arts department commissioned Mark Jackson to adapt and direct a production of Romeo and Juliet, he came up with the unusual idea of creating a version of the tragedy for 14 actors, all cast in the role of Juliet. But because of budget cuts at the university, less money is available for items that affect the look of a production, like sets, lights and costumes. So to save on wardrobe, Mr. Jackson has had to readjust his core creative concept: now he has just eight actors for his new show, Juliet.

title: Willie Brown and Other Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Pages
description: Sunday Routine: Willie Brown | Willie L. Brown Jr. was a poor boy from Texas when he made his way to San Francisco at 17. He went on to become one of the most powerful politicians in California, before leaving politics in 2004 after two terms as mayor of San Francisco. Now 75, Mr. Brown remains one of the citys most influential and nattily dressed figures.

title: A Jets Reverse: Kerry Rhodes Shipped to Arizona
description: That recent statement from the Jets Mike Tannenbaum about keeping Kerry Rhodes?

title: Now Screening | Dior
description: The fall 2010 collection from Dior at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Man Trying to Break Up a Fight Is Killed in the Bronx
description: A Bronx man who the police said was trying to be a good guy by breaking up a fight early Saturday was fatally stabbed by one of the people involved in the fight, according to the authorities.

title: Signs of a Thaw in the Wardrobe Recession
In Harlem, Epicenter for Charter Schools, a Senator Wars Against Them
description: When hundreds of parents went to Albany last month to rally for charter schools, they were greeted by a parade of politicians offering encouragement and promises.

title: Picture This: A Nose on the Loose
description: It has become commonplace at the Metropolitan Opera for directors and designers of new productions, especially modernist high-concept ones, to be lustily booed by a sizable contingent of the audience during opening-night ovations.

title: Obama Wields Analysis of Insurers in Health Battle
description: WASHINGTON  To bolster the case for a far-reaching overhaul of the health care system, the Obama administration is seizing on a new analysis by Goldman Sachs, the New York investment bank, recommending that investors buy shares in two big insurance companies, the UnitedHealth Group and Cigna, because insurance rates are up sharply and competition is down.

title: Now Screening | Lanvin
description: The fall 2010 collection from Lanvin at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the rise of Islamic militancy among the frustrated youth of Pakistan omitted a passage at the continuation in some copies. The full passage should have read:  The situation is now quite confusing, said Tariq Parvez, director of the National Counterterrorism Authority in Islamabad, Pakistans capital. We can no longer talk in terms of organizations. Now its a question of like-minded militants. The result has been deadly. In 2009, militant attacks killed 3,021 Pakistanis, three times as many as in 2006. (The full article is at nytimes.com/world.)

title: Correction
description: A map last Sunday with the This Land column, about the skier Hannah Kearney, who won the first gold medal for the United States in this years Olympics, mislabeled, in some copies, the state in which her hometown of Norwich is located. As the article noted, it is Vermont, not Florida.

title: Young Grandmaster-to-Be Bows to Formidable Older Foe
description: Older chess players are not an endangered species, but there is no doubt that chess is increasingly dominated by young men (and women). The worlds top-ranked player is 19, and more prodigies are emerging everywhere.

title: The Mets Future Suddenly Feels Far From Barren
description: VIERA, Fla.  One of the enduring traditions of sports is the art of casting blame on former coaches, executives and players for whatever went wrong in the past. Certainly, the Mets are not immune to that tendency, with everyone from Davey Johnson, Bobby Valentine and Joe McIlvaine to Jim Duquette, Willie Randolph and most recently Tony Bernazard being tagged with guilt for various failures after they left.

title: Patricia Travers, Violinist Who Vanished, Dies at 82
description: At 11, the violinist Patricia Travers made her first solo appearance with the New York Philharmonic, playing Lalos Symphonie Espagnole with a purity of tone, breadth of line and immersion in her task, as a critic for The New York Times wrote in 1939.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Lanvin
description: Suzy Menkes discusses putting women first and the Winter 2010 collection with Lanvin's star designer, Alber Elbaz.

title: N.H.L. Will Discuss Hits to Head at Annual Meeting
description: When N.H.L. general managers convene for their annual three-day meeting Monday in Boca Raton, Fla., one item on the agenda will occupy most of their time: what, if anything, to do about hits to the head.The general managers will see several presentations, one the result of two years of independent medical study, as they seek to make policy recommendations to the league on the controversial issue.

title: A Banking Battleground
description: Despite the power of big banks, small institutions still dominate huge swaths of the country and hold nearly half of bank deposits overall.

title: Departing Chilean President Defends Governments Actions After Quake
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A week after this country was devastated by an 8.8-magnitude earthquake, President Michelle Bachelet defended her government against charges that it had put politics before peoples needs.

title: Do We Need a Gender-Neutral Oscar for Acting?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spread of Superbugs
description: Until three months ago, Thomas M. Dukes was a vigorous, healthy executive at a California plastics company. Then, over the course of a few days in December as he was planning his Christmas shopping, E. coli bacteria ravaged his body and tore his life apart.

title: Dreaming the Possible Dream
description: The thing I love most about America is that theres always somebody who doesnt get the word  somebody who doesnt understand that in a Great Recession youre supposed to hunker down, downsize and just hold on for dear life. I have a couple of friends who fit that bill, who think a recession is a dandy time to try to discover better and cheaper ways to do things. They both happen to be Indian-Americans  one a son of the Himalayas, who came to America on a scholarship and went to work for NASA to try to find a way to Mars; the other a son of New Delhi, who came here and found the Sun, Sun Microsystems. Both are serial innovators. Both are now shepherding clean-tech start-ups that have the potential to be disruptive game changers. They dont know from hunkering down. They just didnt get the word.

title: Catholics and Evangelicals, Engaged in Relief Work
description: To the Editor:

title: If Reform Fails
description: As the fierce debate on President Obamas plan for health care reform comes to a head, Americans should be thinking carefully about what happens if Congress fails to enact legislation.

title: Nuclear Policy in a Changed World
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tea Partys Stance on Government Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Voters in Iceland Reject Repayment Plan
description: LONDON  Icelands voters expressed their outrage on Saturday against bankers, the government and what they saw as foreign bullying, overwhelmingly rejecting a plan to pay $5.3 billion to Britain and the Netherlands to reimburse customers of a failed Icelandic bank.

title: Igawa Working to Be Pitcher Yankees Thought He Was
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Kei Igawa and his big price tag arrived from Japan three years ago, he occupied a dressing stall on the main row in the locker room at Yankees training camp.

title: A Banking Battleground
description: For the last year, big banks have grabbed a huge share of the headlines, and of federal bailout funds. But they don't - yet, at least - hold all of the nation's money. Small banks still dominate huge swaths of the country and hold nearly half of bank deposits over all.

title: Paterson Rewards Redemption With a Pardon
description: Gov. David A. Paterson announced on Saturday that he had pardoned a man whose rise from poverty and street crime in Chinatown to success as an information technology executive was about to end in deportation.

title: Iraq's Parliamentary Elections
description: In the final hours before the first Parliamentary elections in four years, the race in Iraq is still too close to call.

title: Correction
description: The Evening Hours column last Sunday misidentified the guest shown with Heather Mnuchin at the Winter Ball held by the Directors Council of the Museum of the City of New York on Feb. 23. She is Ulla Parker, not Coralie Charriol Paul.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Jets Trade Kerry Rhodes to Arizona Cardinals
description: On Friday, Jets General Manager Mike Tannenbaum said the Jets would pay a $2 million roster bonus next week to keep safety Kerry Rhodes on the team. Then he uttered the key words: unless something happens.

title: Correction
description: The Deconstructed feature last Sunday, about Electronic Benefit Transfer cards, which replaced paper food stamps, referred incorrectly to the average monthly allotment in New York City and to the amount of time it takes to get a card. The allotment is $289 per household, not per individual, and applicants usually get cards within a month after requesting them  not the same day.

title: Lull in N.F.L. Signings as Teams Reassess Capless Market
description: With the biggest names counting their riches after a frenzied first day of free agency, the N.F.L. caught its breath Saturday.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the actress Diane Keaton referred incompletely to the creation of the Annie Hall look. While Ms. Keaton is closely identified with the look, Ruth Morley was the costume designer for the film and the two women collaborated on the style; Ms. Keaton did not single-handedly invent the look.

title: Reader Comments on my Antibiotics Column
description: My Sunday column is about the diminishing effectiveness of antibiotics, and the concern that our agricultural policies (stuffing livestock with antibiotics) will entail huge public health costs. The rise of antibiotic-resistance is well-known (its a great example of evolution), and was recently documented by my Times colleague Andrew Pollack in the case of gram-negative bacteria.

title: Could Plagiarism Software Have Spared The Times an Embarrassment?
description: Craig Silverman, the editor of Regret the Error, a Web site that reports on accuracy and honesty in the press, says most plagiarism by journalists is caught only when someone complains. Thats what happened last month at The Times, which had to endure the mortifying experience of having a bitter cross-town rival, The Wall Street Journal, point out the theft of half a dozen passages from one of its news articles.

title: Video: Iraqs Parliamentary Elections
Vows: Margot & Jon
description: Margot Lowenstein and Jon Simmons met at a dinner, after which they began spending time together. But where he saw romance, Margot saw only friendship. Jon soon proved her wrong.

title: Detroits Iconic Ruins
description: Detroit is debating how best to save Michigan Central Station, a gracious relic of the industrial age that has been idle and deteriorating for more than 20 years.

title: The Real Contest Occurred After the Game
description: ALBANY  The MAAC quarterfinal game between top-seeded Siena and ninth-seeded Manhattan did not leave too much to talk about. Manhattan (11-20) jolted out to a 12-point lead over Siena (25-6), talked a bit of trash and then turned in a listless second-half performance in a 78-61 loss.

title: Queens Man Charged With Assaulting 13-Week-Old
description: A 23-year-old man was charged with assaulting his 13-week-old daughter, whose injuries included 17 fractured ribs and a lacerated liver.

title: As Iraq Tallies Vote, U.S. Says Pullout Plans Are on Track
description: BAGHDAD  Defying a sustained barrage of mortars and rockets in Baghdad and other cities, Iraqis went to the polls in strength on Sunday to choose a new Parliament meant to outlast the American military presence here.

title: Boys and Girls High Wins First P.S.A.L. Title Since 1979
description: Among the rosary beads, folded hands and fiery flames tattooed into Boys and Girls High School guard Mike Taylors skin are the words Lights Out on his left shoulder. On Saturday afternoon at Madison Square Garden, Taylor said they served as a reminder for him and his team in the Public School Athletic League championship game against Cardozo High.

title: Sex Offender Allowed to Live Near School
description: A convicted sex offender has moved into a home across the street from Wildwood Elementary School in Piedmont, infuriating parents, who are asking school officials and the police why the 2006 state law mandating a minimum distance of 2,000 feet between schools and the residences of sex offenders is not being enforced.

title: The Knicks Make the Nets Look Like a .500 Team
description: Every once in a while, the basketball gods show scheduling mercy. The clouds on otherwise dreadful seasons parted a fourth and final time this season for the Knicks and the Nets when they met Saturday night, guaranteeing one team a victory.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 6, 2010

title: WABC Returns to Cablevision
description: 8:49 p.m. | Updated The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision announced they had agreed in principle to a new contract governing WABC about 15 minutes after the Academy Awards telecast started on Sunday night.

title: Iraq Elections: Courting African Iraqis
description: BASRA, Iraq During the past few weeks, most of the countrys major political candidates or their aides have come to Zubair, a poor, mainly-Sunni neighborhood on the outskirts of this oil-rich Shiite city, to campaign to a population that is as disaffected as any in Iraq.

title: A Sex Offender, a School and the Law That Cannot Keep Them Apart
description: Sundays Bay Area Report features an article about an East Bay communitys bewilderment as a convicted sex offender is allowed to move into a home across the street from an elementary school.

title: No Deal on ABC Is Reached by Disney and Cablevision
description: The Walt Disney Company at 12:01 a.m. on Sunday pulled its ABC station from Cablevision  potentially leaving about three million cable customers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut without access to the Academy Awards  after failing to reach an agreement with the cable provider on a new contract.

title: Iraqi Elections  Change in Kurdistan?
description: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq  Go, go to vote, for renewal and change starts a song that has rallied voters, particularly the young, around the political movement trying to end the decades-long domination of the two parties in Iraqs Kurdistan region in Sundays elections.

title: Iona Knocked Out of MAAC Tournament
description: ALBANY  A season of progress for the Iona Gaels ended earlier than expected on Saturday night. Sixth-seeded Niagara knocked off third-seeded Iona, 68-64, sending the Gaels home early from the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament and leaving their postseason future uncertain.

title: Iraqi Election  Music Videos and Propaganda
description: Full Coverage

title: Iraqi Elections: Live-Blogging Election Day
description: 12:44 a.m. Monday, Iraq |Curfew

title: In Spring, Hong Kong Festivals Bloom
description: Hong Kongs cultural calendar is dry as a desert most of the year. Then comes spring, and with it, a festival of festivals. Along with the Hong Kong Arts Festival, which continues through March 28, there are a handful of major events dedicated to film, literature and other media, all happening in the next month or so.

title: Tigers in Peril
description: Could this Chinese Year of the Tiger be the last one with actual tigers still afoot in the worlds wild?

title: A Good Cry for Delhomme and the Panthers
description: I wear my heart on my sleeve. This is me. Jake Delhomme, choking back tears

title: Joy Amid Destruction
description: Those with skills, strength and luck will be the ones to thrive after Haitis destruction, while small, handmade treasures will bring some measure of joy.

title: Iceland Voters Reject Repayment Plan
description: Icelands voters expressed their outrage on Saturday against bankers, the government and what they saw as foreign bullying, overwhelmingly rejecting a plan to pay $5.3 billion to Britain and the Netherlands to reimburse customers of a failed Icelandic bank, Sarah Lyall reported in The New York Times.

title: Hamilton Almost Quit Formula One
description: It was one of the many Formula One scandals last year, the first of the racing season. It was the Lewis Hamilton lying incident, when the reigning world champion told a story to the press about what happened on track at the Australian Grand Prix that differed from what he told the racing stewards during an inquiry afterward.

title: Now Screening | Comme des Garons
description: The fall 2010 collection from Comme des Garons at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Iraqis Vote in Spite of Attacks
description: In a pivotal test of Iraq's democracy, Iraqis went to the polls in large numbers despite a wave of bombings across the country.

title: The Message From Planet Jim
description: Inside James Camerons head, theres a place called Planet Jim (a description provided by one of his minions in the video clip below). It is a fundamentally extraterrestrial place in the purest sense of that word  ranging from the oceanic abyss to the depths of outer space. It is often depicted in shades of James Cameron blue. The largest audience in the history of entertainment has been there now, thanks to Avatar. His ability to captivate so many people has led him to the Academy Awards ceremony tonight with nine Oscar nominations.

title: President Obama Congratulates Iraqis on Vote
description: In a statement released by the White House Sunday morning, President Obama praised Iraqis resolve as they defied a wave of bombings across the country and turned out to vote in parliamentary elections that are seen as a crucial test of Iraqs democracy nearly seven years after the American-led ouster of Saddam Hussein.

title: Photos of the Moment | Rainbow Connection
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Visual Books
description: Images from the books under review in Steven Hellers Visuals column.

title: Photos of the Moment | Viktor & Rolf
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Life for a Rule 5 Pick: Thanks for Coming, Now Leave Your Cap
description: TUCSON  Zach Kroenkes career appears to have followed a fairly steady course. Drafted by the Yankees in 2005, he pitched at each level of their farm system, from the Gulf Coast League to Class AAA, earning regular promotions. A left-handed reliever, he is 25-15 with a 3.30 earned run average in five seasons.

title: Clashes Kill Dozens in Central Nigeria
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Dozens of villagers in central Nigeria were killed early Sunday, victims of apparent reprisal attacks over recent clashes between Christians and Muslims. A government spokesman said there were more than 300 dead, but that figure that could not be independently verified.

title: Now Screening | Viktor & Rolf
description: The fall 2010 collection from Viktor & Rolf at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Rookies on the Awards Circuit Slog
description: LOS ANGELES Confession: In her civilian life, the Bagger goes out approximately seven nights a week, but four months of non-stop Carpetbagging, in heels, has taken its toll, and we crashed a bit on Saturday, a rare rainy day in Los Angeles. A nap was in order, which meant we missed things like a tea for MoNique, attended by Oprah and Alfre Woodard, where everyone wore pearls and white gloves. (O.K., so we werent invited anyway.)

title: Crossover Nightmares
description: The Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky is one of the most vocally gifted, sophisticated and charismatic singers around. Hes a favorite at the Metropolitan Opera and has an international following as a superb classical artist. So, I never imagined that one day I would be forced to use foam rubber noise-reduction ear plugs to listen to him.

title: And the Razzie Goes to
description: Sandra Bullock may not beat out Meryl Streep Sunday night for a best actress Oscar, but shes already racked up one victory this weekend. On Saturday, Ms. Bullock accepted in person the dubious honor of worst actress at the Razzie Awards for her role in the comedy All About Steve.

title: The Singer-Songwriter Known as Sparklehorse Is Dead at 47
description: Mark Linkous, a singer-songwriter whose music, released under the name Sparklehorse, was renowned in the indie-rock and alt-country worlds for its dark, allusive themes and fragile beauty, committed suicide on Saturday in Knoxville, Tenn. He was 47.

title: Consumer Groups Urge Regulation of Nonbank Finance
description: While much of the Congressional debate over consumer financial protection has focused on banks, lawmakers have been grappling behind the scenes over whether and how to regulate payday lenders, debt collectors, check-cashing outlets, title and installment lenders and even pawnbrokers, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports.

title: Viewing the Iraqi Elections Across the Middle East
description: Were Arab leaders and voters disappointed, angered, or inspired by what appears to have been a successful vote in Iraq? The answer appears to be none of the above. While newspapers from the Arab world made mention of the elections, many led their Web sites with news of the weekends fighting in Jerusalem.

title: A Tame Night for the In the Loop Gang
description: LOS ANGELES Theres not much that can be reprinted from our dinner with the cast and writers of In the Loop, mainly because we were laughing too much to write stuff down. A British satire about a certain war in the Middle East, nominated for a screenplay Oscar, In the Loop is known for its bawdiness. The dinner, on Saturday night, was more tame  just a few jokes about Hitler as a motivational speaker and Jeff Bridgess mustache being the best part of Crazy Heart  you know, the usual. And Armando Iannucci, a screenwriter and the director, did note that when Miramax executives wanted to buy In the Loop after its Sundance premiere last year on the condition that the filmmakers re-edit it, he told them to go expletive themselves.

title: Qaeda Operative Arrested in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An operative of Al Qaeda believed to be an American was arrested in the sprawling southern city of Karachi in recent days by Pakistani security officials, Pakistani officials said Sunday.

title: New York Isnt Silicon Valley. Thats Why They Like It.
description: The two dozen or so people arranged around wooden tables, warming their hands and bellies with steaming mugs of coffee and plates of homemade biscuits, looked like just another Sunday brunch set in New York.

title: Rural Pride and Poverty and a Hens Empty Nest
description: Ron Rash was the seasoned author of nine books of fiction and poetry before his 10th, the stunning 2008 Serena, established him as one of the best American novelists of his day. With its stark Appalachian setting, piercing language and coolly ferocious title character, Serena was a big book filled with bleakly beautiful details. Mr. Rashs artistry was blinding enough to eclipse his craftsmanship.

title: Alice Grabs Imax Screens From Avatar
description: LOS ANGELES  The hunger for 3-D pictures, a blockbuster publicity campaign and curiosity about another madcap performance from Johnny Depp pushed Alice in Wonderland to a stratospheric No. 1 at the weekend box office.

title: Two Men Who Adore Her, One Woman in the Middle
description: Melissa Erricos formidable beauty is probably the most persuasive element in the Irish Repertory Theaters revival of George Bernard Shaws breakthrough comedy Candida. It does not require the suspension of any disbelief whatsoever to imagine that Ms. Erricos naturally Victorian gorgeousness  pure white skin, rosebud lips, luxurious tresses, nipped waist and shapely curves  would inspire adoration in men of any number of ages and philosophies. Unfortunately little else in this alternately sluggish and overwrought revival is equally convincing.

title: Waiting and Watching, With Dance Ticket in Hand
description: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team, which wrapped up the Ivy League title and a berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Saturday. As he did last season, Jon has been blogging for The Quad throughout this season. You can also follow him on Twitter.

title: Of Youth, Frocks and Politics: A Not-So-Ordinary Life
description: Next stop Dumbo, for those of you participating in the citys unofficial spring festival of gay theater.

title: Madonna Plays the Muse
description: LOS ANGELES Collaboration. I like being his muse, Madonna told us, explaining her relationship with photographer Tom Munro at a private party and opening last night, to celebrate the photographers first book, a collection of celebrity portraits. (Partial proceeds of of the book will go to Madonnas charity, Raising Malawi, and M.E.A.K.) Madonna, wearing black fishnet stockings, leather skirt and dark sunglasses at 10 p.m. in a dark room, blew off the Weinstein Company party at Soho House and the Summit Entertainment reception for The Hurt Locker at the Mondrian, for the gallery opening, where she spent most of the time on the lap of Steven Klein, another celebrity fashion photographer.

title: Supply, Demand, and Unemployment
description: I hear through the grapevine that the usual suspects at the WSJ have put out something along the lines of Krugman says that unemployment benefits wont raise unemployment, but in his textbook he says they will, neener neener. Are they really that stupid? Probably not  but they you think that you, the reader, are that stupid.

title: Competitive Deflation
description: Rebecca Wilder is right:

title: More Exquisite Insults
description: Jonathan Chait on Mike Allen:

title: Finding Your Roots
description: For more than 2,500 years, mathematicians have been obsessed with solving for x. The story of their struggle to find the roots  the solutions  of increasingly complicated equations is one of the great epics in the history of human thought.

title: Praise of Mary at Eventide Resounds Across 400 Years
description: Normally, classical music groups try to avoid duplicating competitors programming, but this year early-music groups are lining up to celebrate the 400th anniversary of Monteverdis Vespro Della Beata Vergine (Vespers of the Blessed Virgin). The high-energy performance by Boston Baroque at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on Saturday evening was the third in New York since January, with more in the offing.

title: Sharing the Ball, at Any Speed
description: RICHMOND, Va.  When Richmond Coach Chris Mooney was on a recruiting visit to Princeton as a high school senior in 1989, he watched a group of Tigers basketball players in an intense four-on-four game.

title: New CDs
description: BROKEN BELLS

title: Violins Face Off Against Laptops in a Friendly Improvisational Duel
description: Drone chords are accommodating and diplomatic. Theyre the secret handshake between Westerners and Easterners, soft-eyed hippies and aggro noise merchants, improvisers and composers. Theyre also totems, full of their own significance. And bullies.

title: Celebrating the Genius of Balanchine by Viewing It With Fresh Eyes
description: WASHINGTON  The dancing of the Suzanne Farrell Ballet in works by George Balanchine (and, occasionally, other choreographers) is not spectacular. It performs at the Kennedy Center (to which it is attached) for one week each season and then does a little touring; it is a pick-up group to which some dancers return each year like swallows; its roster includes no luminaries of major caliber. If you go to this company expecting the iridescence that Ms. Farrell had as a supreme interpreter, you leave disappointed.

title: Celebrities at the Gate, Weinstein Company Edition
description: LOS ANGELES You know, Im one of the few people who really, genuinely likes Harvey Weinstein, Christoph Waltz, the smoothly villainous Nazi in Inglourious Basterds, said at the Weinstein Company party at the Soho House on Saturday night, just as Mr. Weinstein was passing within earshot.

title: Winner Understood Opponents Psychology
description: Most members of the American Contract Bridge Leagues Hall of Fame are marquis names. A few are lower-profile experts well respected by their peers.

title: A Human Landscape of Rippling Bodies and Meditative Minds
description: Shelley Senter returned to New York last year after a 13-year stretch in California, making her the perfect choreographer to open Back to New York City, the latest incarnation of Platform 2010, Danspace Projects guest-artist-organized series.

title: A Bit Wry and Rough at the Edges
description: Barefoot, his shirt untucked, a hat pulled down over his forehead, the 43-year-old alt-country singer-songwriter Todd Snider looked the epitome of a scruffy modern troubadour ambling along a rutted Southern highway on the way to nowhere.

title: Slaying the Dragon Called Subtlety With Large-Scale Heroics
description: Even the ballads went boom when Muse performed at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. Muse, a three-man English band formed in the early 1990s, never misses a chance for melodrama.

title: 14 Down: Law & Order Rapper
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Ive invited Louis Lana, the division C* champion at the recent American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, to solve todays puzzle, record his time and share a few thoughts. Youll find his report at the end of this post. Joon Pahk and Dan Feyer, the division B and A champions respectively, will do likewise with the Tuesday and Wednesday puzzles.

title: Harrahs Strikes Deal to Push Back Debt Payments
description: 11:59 a.m. | Updated Harrahs Entertainment, the highly leveraged casino operator owned by the private equity firms Apollo Global Management and TPG, has reached a deal with its lenders to push back big payments on its debt load until 2015, Bloomberg News reported on Sunday.

title: Voting Under Fire in Baghdad
description: Sorting out the results of the election may take time, but voters and politicians took the ballot itself as a victory.

title: Stevie Wonder Honored in France
description: Almost 30 years after he was first named to receive the Commander of Arts and Letters award, Stevie Wonder, above, accepted it from the French Culture Minister Frdric Mitterrand on Saturday, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Wonder was first named a Commander in 1981, but his formal decoration had been delayed because of scheduling conflicts. Mr. Wonder dedicated the award, one of Frances highest cultural honors, to his mother, who died in 2006; he said he first came to Paris in 1964 with her. Mr. Wonder was also in Paris to receive a lifetime achievement prize at a musical awards show on Saturday. Mr. Mitterand praised Mr. Wonder as musics familiar genius, Agence-France Presse reported, and Mr. Mitterrand added, as citizen, administrator and culture minister I just called to say we love you.

title: Renewed: 30 Rock, Office and Community
description: NBCs Thursday night sitcoms will all be back for the 2010-11 television season that starts next fall. The network announced Friday evening that it had ordered new seasons of The Office, 30 Rock and Community. Its fourth Thursday sitcom, Parks and Recreation, had already received a renewal order. The Office and 30 Rock, with Tina Fey, above, have turned into hits for NBC, but the renewal was less certain for Community, the freshman sitcom about a community college starring Joel McHale and Chevy Chase. Dan Harmon, an executive producer of the series, filmed himself telling his cast that the series had been renewed, but only after pretending to deliver news about its demise. Im not good at, like, bad news, he intoned, but  dramatic pause  all of you have to work with Chevy again for another season.

title: Bullock Wins Worst Actress Razzie
description: Even before the Oscars began, Sandra Bullock racked up one victory. On Saturday she accepted in person the dubious honor of worst actress at the Razzie Awards for her role in the comedy All About Steve. I think this is an extraordinary award, Ms. Bullock said at the Barnsdall Gallery Theater in Hollywood, The Associated Press reported. And I didnt realize that, in Hollywood, all you had to do was say youd show up, and then youd get the award. If Id known that, I would have said I was appearing at the Oscars a long time ago. Other winners  or losers  included Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen, which took home the worst picture award; worst actor went to all three Jonas brothers for Jonas Brothers: The 3-D Concert Experience.

title: This Summer at Williamstown
description: The Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts has announced its 2010 summer season. This season, the festivals 56th, will be the final one for Nicholas Martin as artistic director. He will direct Thornton Wilders Our Town on the main stage (July 28 through Aug. 8), with a high-profile cast including Becky Ann Baker, Dylan Baker, Jessica Hecht and Campbell Scott as the townsfolk. The festival begins June 30 with a main-stage production of A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, directed by Jessica Stone, with the Tony-nominated actor Christopher Fitzgerald. Beginning June 23 Judy Gold will perform her new one-woman play, Its Jewdys Show, on the Nikos Stage, a follow-up to her 25 Questions for a Jewish Mother. Also in the lineup, Amy Herzogs After the Revolution, a new play about three generations of a radical leftist family, which was developed from the festivals fellowship project last summer, and Samuel J. and K., by Mat Smart, also to be presented on the Nikos Stage.

title: Precious Dominates Spirit Awards
description: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire and Crazy Heart were the big winners at Film Independents Spirit Awards on Friday. Precious took best feature, best director (Lee Daniels) , best first screenplay (Geoffrey Fletcher), best actress (Gabourey Sidibe) and best supporting actress (Muh-nique, as the presenter, Pierce Brosnan, called MoNique). Crazy Heart won best first feature and best actor for Jeff Bridges, who did double duty by performing a song from it. An Education won best foreign film. (500) Days of Summer, which was shut out of the Oscar race, won best screenplay. Woody Harrelson won best supporting male for The Messenger and the Coen brothers were given the Robert Altman award, though they didnt show to pick it up. Roger Ebert, who with his wife, Chaz, sponsored a prize for young filmmakers, got a standing ovation; his clip reel of witheringly negative reviews was one of the funniest parts of the evening. The Indie Spirits, in their 25th year, are known as the looser precursor to the Oscars, but they seem to have grown more staid as they have gained in stature. This year instead of being held in a tent by the beach in Santa Monica, the event was glammed up and held in ... a tent above a car park, as the host, Eddie Izzard said.

title: WNET.org Cancels Worldfocus
description: WNET.org, the New York public broadcaster, is canceling Worldfocus, its weeknight newscast seen on public television stations, effective April 2. It will have been on the air for 18 months. The show won several awards for its international news coverage but began without all its financing in place and never attracted enough corporate and foundation support to be sustainable. Neal Shapiro, the president and chief executive of WNET.org, acknowledged a shortfall of a few million dollars in a statement Friday announcing that Worldfocus was being shut down, adding, We had the misfortune of launching a brand new program into the teeth of the recession. Worldfocus was anchored first by Martin Savidge and now by Daljit Dhaliwal. It was an important project for Mr. Shapiro, who was criticized by some internal critics who said he had diverted resources to support it, leading to extensive layoffs elsewhere at WNET. Mr. Shapiro denied any link. WNET.org said that some Worldfocus resources would go to the WNET-produced Need to Know, a new program that joins PBSs Friday night public-affairs lineup in May.

title: The Oddball Shapes of Ken Price
description: A look at the artists ceramics and sculptures.

title: The National Enquirer Earns Some Respect
description: The call came into The National Enquirers Los Angeles tip line  the kind advertised in the supermarket tabloid with the promise Well Pay Big for Your Celebrity Gossip  in late September 2007. The message was that a woman named Rielle Hunter had been hinting at an affair with John Edwards, then a candidate for president.

title: Ask a Theater Historian
description: We are no longer taking questions for this feature.

title: Oscar Parties and the Pentagon Papers Man
description: Daniel Ellsberg, the subject of the Oscar-nominated film Daniel Ellsberg: The Most Dangerous Man in America and a newbie at the Oscars, has been trying to get a hang of the Oscar party circuit since he arrived in Los Angeles on Tuesday. He told us by e-mail that hes having a blast.But he was having some trouble getting into any parties.

title: A.I.G. to Sell a Major Life Insurance Unit to MetLife
description: 6:28 a.m. | Updated  The American International Group confirmed Monday that it had sold a life insurance unit to MetLife for about $15.5 billion, including $6.8 in cash.

title: Live Blogging the Oscars
description: The Carpetbagger is at the 82nd annual Academy Awards in Hollywood Sunday evening and will be filing updates all evening. Check back here regularly for dispatches from the red carpet, announcements of the winners and commentary from special guest stars, including A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critic of The New York Times.

title: Educated and Fearing the Future in China
description: As Chinas economy recovers, employers are competing to hire  low-skilled workers, but many of Chinas best and brightest, its college graduates, are facing a long stretch of unemployment.

title: Adjusting to Reality
description: THE danger of having the government regularly disperse hundreds of billions of dollars is that we can grow careless about how we spend a mere $14 billion. A case in point is a plan to pay out checks to everyone receiving Social Security, Supplemental Security Income and disabled veteran benefits. The reason? To compensate them for not receiving a cost-of-living adjustment this year.

title: Breaking the Story That Isnt
description: Reporters have always kept an eye on other reporters. For a journalist, the only thing more interesting than what you are working on is what your competitor is working on.

title: No Leeway Given in Picking Dalai Lama
description: BEIJING  The new governor of Tibet said Sunday that the Dalai Lama did not have a right to choose his successor however he wanted, but instead must abide by the requirements of Tibetan Buddhist tradition, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported.

title: Now Screening | Givenchy
description: The fall 2010 collection from Givenchy at Paris Fashion Week.

title: China Blames U.S. for Strained Relations
description: BEIJING  The blame for friction in Chinese-United States relations does not lie with China, and it is up to the United States to take steps to repair the frayed ties, Chinas foreign minister repeated Sunday.

title: State of the Browns: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Good Housekeeping Puts on a Show to Celebrate Women
description: AMONG the impresarios of the theater, there are David Merrick, Harold Prince, Leland Hayward and Good Housekeeping.

title: Afghanistans President Receives a Mixed Reception in a Visit to Newly Won Marja
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  Once a Taliban refuge, Marja has come a long way since the Marines invaded four weeks ago, so much so that the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, arrived Sunday with top American and Afghan officials to speak to several hundred residents crammed inside a mosque.

title: EBay Highlights Conservation as a Benefit of Buying Used
description: Want to do your part to save the environment? Buy a leather handbag.

title: G.I.s, New to Iraq, Hear the Election Explosions
description: BAGHDAD  Youre hearing a lot of booms out there, Lt. Ryan P. Alexander told his soldiers, briefing them ahead of their platoons anticipated operation as mortar fire and explosions rained on Baghdad early on Sunday while Iraqis began voting in the parliamentary elections.

title: Most in Chiles Capital Unhappy With Quake Response
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Most Chileans here in the capital are not satisfied with their governments response to the devastating earthquake last month, saying the government of departing President Michelle Bachelet was late and inefficient in delivering aid and in re-establishing order, according to a poll published Sunday by a leading Chilean newspaper.

title: Rapid Rise of Children With Cellphones
description: The proportion of children with cellphones has nearly doubled since 2005, an increase driven in large part by boys, according to Mediamark Research and Intelligence, a market research company.

title: How Pandora Slipped Past the Junkyard
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Tim Westergren recently sat in a Las Vegas penthouse suite, a glass of red wine in one hand and a truffle-infused Kobe beef burger in the other, courtesy of the investment bankers who were throwing a party to court him.

title: Job Market Stabilizes for Business Students
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  For two years in a row, Kwame Yankson, a business school student at the University of Virginia, has sent a flurry of rsums to investment banks. He has cold-called Wall Street recruiters. And he has landed coveted interview slots.

title: Absorbing the Blows That Buffet Europe
description: QUIMPER, France  HB-Henriot is one of the oldest companies in France, an artisanal producer of faence  hand-painted glazed earthenware  since 1690. The company was founded here in Brittany for its waterpower and riverbed clay.

title: Delayed No More, Takahashi Puts On a Show for the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It is a good thing the Mets were finally able to get that work visa for Hisanori Takahashi.

title: A Local Street and a Lesson in History
description: MILLTOWN, N.J.

title: U.S. Hopes Exports Will Help Open Closed Societies
description: WASHINGTON  Seeking to exploit the Internets potential for prying open closed societies, the Obama administration will permit technology companies to export online services like instant messaging, chat and photo sharing to Iran, Cuba and Sudan, a senior administration official said Sunday.

title: Bloomberg Says a Soda Tax Makes Sense
description: As the battle over the state budget and the looming multibillion-dollar gap becomes more intense, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has stepped up his call for the Legislature to pass a penny-per-ounce tax on soda to stave off major service cuts to education and health care.

title: Dispute Heats Up Over Proposed New Fees for Playing Songs on the Radio
description: Kesha may be the voice of her hit single Tik Tok, but when her royalty check arrives for its play on the radio, the money is for her role as co-writer of the song.

title: Their Reasons for Optimism
description: Aspiring bankers and administrators offered their thoughts on why some students are attracted to banking despite the industry's downturn.

title: At Church, Paterson Vows to Stay in Office
description: Speaking before a church congregation in Brooklyn, Gov. David A. Paterson declared on Sunday that he was the victim of innuendo and lies and that he would finish his term to fulfill the mission in which God placed me.

title: Ian Kennedy Looks Back
description: TUCSON  Ian Kennedys last start in the major leagues was on Aug. 8, 2008. It was a night that colored many fans perception of him. He gave up five runs in two innings of a 10-5 loss in Anaheim, Calif., and when he met with reporters afterward, he insisted he had made good pitches and was not upset.

title: A.I.G. Sells Unit to MetLife
description: The American International Group agreed Sunday to sell a second major insurance unit, this one to MetLife for about $15.5 billion, the two companies confirmed Monday. It was the second deal the insurer has struck in one week, raising about $51 billion to repay its taxpayer-financed rescue.

title: U.S. Reaches Out to Tokyos Real Power
description: TOKYO  Even as Japans new leaders have promised to transform the way the nation is governed, they have left one thing unchanged: the prime minister, like many before him, is backed by a shadowy leader who is widely seen as really running the country.

title: All-Star Catcher Crouches, Waiting for the Offers to Roll In
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  On the cover of the Minnesota Twins 2010 Record and Information book, a gigantic image of Joe Mauer  in full catchers gear  rises like Paul Bunyan amid blue sky and wispy clouds above the teams new ballpark and the Minneapolis skyline.

title: Sunnis Go to Polls, This Time, to Retain a Voice
Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about President Obamas efforts to get health-care legislation enacted misstated the television network on which Representative Bart Stupak, a Michigan Democrat, said in an interview that Mr. Obama had to be more flexible on tightening provisions on abortion in the bill. It was Fox Business Network, not Fox News.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about metal-on-metal hip replacements misidentified the Minnesota city that is home to the Mayo Clinic, where doctors say they have treated patients over the last year for problems related to metal debris from the devices. The clinic is in Rochester, not Minneapolis.

title: The Hurt Locker Wins Big at Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hurt Locker, a little-seen war film with big backing from the critics, pushed past Avatar and other crowd-pleasers to win the best picture Oscar at a Sunday night ceremony here, while its director, Kathryn Bigelow, became the first woman to win the directing award.

title: Juggling Act for Obama in Filling Fed Board Openings
description: WASHINGTON  To fill three seats on the Federal Reserves board of governors, the Obama administration is balancing seemingly contrary needs.

title: S.U.V. Hits 5, Killing One, in Church Parking Lot
description: A sport utility vehicle suddenly accelerated while backing up in a church parking lot in Brooklyn on Sunday afternoon, killing a woman and injuring four other people, including two children, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about plans by the Canadian filmmaker Barry Avrich to make a documentary about Harvey Weinstein, the co-founder of Miramax Films, referred incompletely to the distribution history of Mr. Avrichs documentary about the entertainment kingpin Lew R. Wasserman, The Last Mogul. It was released in 2005 in four theaters in the United States by ThinkFilm and Kino, and two more in Canada by Alliance Films. It was not released solely by ThinkFilm in just two theaters in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Spare Times entry on Friday about rehearsals of Hamlet at the World Financial Center omitted the name of the organization for which Debra Simon is artistic director. It is arts>World Financial Center.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an art review on Friday about the Armory Show, at Piers 92 and 94 in Manhattan, misstated the given name of the artist whose sculpture of a dog lifting its leg is displayed at the Hauser & Wirth booth. He is Richard Jackson, not Paul.

title: Seton Halls Bobby Gonzalez Is a Divisive Figure in the Big East
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J.  In Bobby Gonzalezs first season as Seton Halls mens basketball coach, he likened his loyalty to his players to a scene from A Bronx Tale, in which a local crime boss galvanizes his neighborhood cohort to defend his bar from a motorcycle gang. After showing the bloody sequence on a television in the locker room before a game, Gonzalez smiled.

title: Obscure Budget Proposal Threatens Senior Centers
description: The Bloomberg administration is scrambling to come up with contingency plans to close as many as one-fifth of the citys 321 senior centers after being caught off guard by an obscure state budget proposal that would slash the centers financing by nearly 30 percent.

title: Trial Is Elusive in an Assemblymans Drunken-Driving Case
description: It had been 14 months since Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV was arrested on a charge of drunken driving, and the judge had just about had it.

title: A Charlie Chan Film Stirs an Old Controversy
description: The revival of a 42-year-old documentary on the fictional Chinese detective Charlie Chan has reignited the controversy surrounding that character specifically and, more generally, the portrayal of Asian-Americans in Hollywood.

title: For Juveniles in Family Court, Judges Seek Safer Alternatives to Prison
description: Standing to address Judge Daniel Turbow in Family Court in Brooklyn, a city prosecutor confidently listed the reasons why the 16-year-old boy in the courtroom should be sent upstate to a juvenile prison.

title: Locked, Loaded, and Ready to Caffeinate
description: For years, being able to carry a concealed handgun has been a sacred right for many gun enthusiasts. In defending it, Charlton Heston, the actor and former president of the National Rifle Association, used to say that the flock is safer when the wolves cannot tell the difference between the lions and the lambs.

title: Oscar Night Suspense, Then Poof! Cables Back
description: There was buy an antenna. There was squeeze in front of the computer (really hard with 20 or 30 guests, and munchies). There was find a friend  any friend  in Manhattan. There was, alas, go to the in-laws.

title: College Acts to Disregard Fiscal Need in Admissions
description: At a time when some colleges are favoring applicants who do not require financial aid, Hamilton College in upstate New York has decided to swim against that tide.

title: Hamilton College Adopts a Need Blind Admissions Policy
description: Applicants can now add Hamilton, a small liberal arts institution in Clinton, N.Y., to the small roster of colleges and universities that pledge to be need blind in their admissions decisions.

title: Mets College of Catchers Convenes
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Every morning around 8, the school bell rings in the Mets clubhouse, the catchers gather in their seats, and class begins.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 7, 2010

title: Cable Channel to Offer Giant Octopi and Big Cats
description: Cable channels usually get their start in the United States, then branch out to the rest of the world. But this month, the News Corporation will import a foreign channel full of shows about a subject that knows no borders: natural history.

title: Designed by Whom? Often It Was a Guess
description: You can count on the Oscars for a night of epic glamour meant to pump adrenaline into viewers veins. As for fashion  the kind that pushes boundaries and fires creative minds  its advent on the red carpet is as rare as an ice storm in Belize.

title: UConn Advances by Tying Record, and Shrugs
description: HARTFORD  The Connecticut womens basketball team tied its N.C.A.A. record for consecutive victories Sunday by winning its 70th straight game. Not that Coach Geno Auriemma was, or is, counting. The surest way to stop such a streak, he said, is to start worrying about it.

title: Program Will Pay Homeowners to Sell at a Loss
description: In an effort to end the foreclosure crisis, the Obama administration has been trying to keep defaulting owners in their homes. Now it will take a new approach: paying some of them to leave.

title: Slug on the Tracks
description: President Obama has repeatedly insisted that there is no reason why Europe or China, rather than the United States, should have the worlds fastest trains, and since coming to office he has committed the country to developing a high-speed rail network of its own.

title: For Web and Public TV, Brief Films That Dramatize Issues
description: ITVS is best known for its financing of documentaries, many of which appear on PBSs Independent Lens series. But beginning on Monday, the organization will present a series of brief, fictional films that cast social issues into the future, in the hopes of drawing a younger audience not necessarily interested in public television.

title: Deal to Save Everglades May Help Sugar Firm
description: When Gov. Charlie Crist announced Floridas $1.75 billion plan to save the Everglades by buying out a major landowner, United States Sugar, he declared that the deal would be remembered as a public acquisition as monumental as the creation of the nations first national park, Yellowstone.

title: Wartime Pope Has a Huge Fan: A Jewish Knight
description: LONG BEACH, N.Y.  At home here on Long Island, he is Gary L. Krupp, medical equipment dealer, now retired after a career of ups and downs. He shares one car and a small house in a no-frills neighborhood with his wife, Meredith, and wryly describes himself as an average schlemiel, just a Jewish kid from Queens.

title: Villegass Perfect Week Ends With 5-Stroke Win
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  With a dramatic flourish and a triumphant gesture, Camilo Villegas of Colombia brought his storybook week to a climactic finish Sunday, winning the Honda Classic by five strokes over Anthony Kim with a birdie on the 72nd hole that brought the huge, partisan gallery to its feet.

title: Major League Baseball to Stream ESPN Events
description: Major League Baseballs Internet unit is moving farther away from its roots on the diamond. It plans to announce on Monday that it has struck a deal to take over the job of streaming live events online for ESPN.

title: At Cline, a Tough Follow-Up
description: Paris

title: Rangers Take What They Can From Loss
description: At this point in the Rangers desperate season, aesthetics are beside the point, as demonstrated by their wild 2-1 overtime loss to the Buffalo Sabres on Sunday night at Madison Square Garden. The Rangers would have preferred to take 2 points from the game, but they were fortunate to get 1.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Diamondbacks Count on Rotation Revamped in Trade
description: TUCSON  The rain that wiped out most Cactus League games Sunday was late to arrive at Tucson Electric Park. But it was windy and raw for the start of the Arizona Diamondbacks game with the Colorado Rockies, and several times, starter Ian Kennedy blew on his right hand.

title: Experimental Clocks Tell Straphangers if the Wait May Soon Be Over
description: Heading downtown on the subway the other day, Nerissa Campbell bounded to the edge of an A train platform and assumed the standard straphangers stance: neck craned, back hunched, eyes peering down a dark tunnel. Where on earth was that train?

title: Versatility, Sometimes a Little Too Much
description: PARIS

title: At the Last Minute, a Disney-Cablevision Truce
description: The Oscar statuette became a pawn in a public brawl between the Walt Disney Company and Cablevision on Sunday, a dispute that prevented more than three million viewers from watching the beginning of the Academy Awards show until a tentative agreement restored the signal 14 minutes into the telecast.

title: As N.F.L. Free Agency Opens, a Big Splash and Smaller Ripples
description: The N.F.L.s plunge into the great unknown of a season without a salary cap yielded some unexpected results in the first three days of free agency  anybody heard from Jerry Jones lately?  but also some of the big deals that assured us that even the drive to save money for a lockout could not entirely snuff out the blood lust for victory.

title: Arkansass Senator in Middle, Hit on All Sides
description: HELENA, Ark.  When the subject of Senator Blanche Lincoln came up at a womens luncheon last week at the historic Pillow-Thompson House in this Mississippi River town, there was an awkward pause in the chatter.

title: The Escalating Price of Politics
description: A hugely cynical Republican Party memo on the care and feeding of big donors disdains them as ego-driven check writers who can be bought by access to power and vanity tchotchkes. The memo, obtained by Politico.com, is exceptional for its candor about the crassness of the multibillion-dollar politicking industry.

description: To the Editor:
