description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey and the Army
description: The recent arrest or detention of dozens of Turkish military officers for alleged coup plotting could signal a significant shift in power from the tarnished army to civilian leadership. These cases could help strengthen Turkish democracy  provided the government and the judiciary scrupulously apply the rule of law.

title: Are You or Have You Ever Been a Lawyer?
description: In the McCarthy era, demagogues on the right smeared loyal Americans as disloyal and charged that the government was being undermined from within.

title: The Anti-Abortion Message to Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Importance of Being Counted
description: In mid-March, the Census Bureau will mail census forms to the nations 134 million households. With 10 questions, the form is one of the shortest in the history of the decennial count, dating back to 1790. But will people fill it out and mail it back? They should.

title: Should the Olympics End Their Globetrotting?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mass-Market Epiphany
description: Mysticism is dying, and taking true religion with it. Monasteries have dwindled. Contemplative orders have declined. Our religious leaders no longer preach the renunciation of the world; our culture scoffs at the idea. The closest most Americans come to real asceticism is giving up chocolate, cappuccinos, or (in my own not-quite-Francis-of-Assisi case) meat for lunch for Lent.

title: An Irish Mirror
description: Everyone has a theory about the financial crisis. These theories range from the absurd to the plausible  from claims that liberal Democrats somehow forced banks to lend to the undeserving poor (even though Republicans controlled Congress) to the belief that exotic financial instruments fostered confusion and fraud. But what do we really know?

title: Biologics Boondoggle
description: EVERYONE knows that an easy way to save money on medicines is to buy generics rather than brand-name drugs. Makers of generics estimate that over the past decade they have saved the American health care system about $734 billion. Yet, we continue to spend more on drugs  in part because of the increasing use of so-called biologic medicines, which cost, on average, 22 times as much as ordinary drugs. In 2008, 28 percent of sales from the pharmaceutical industrys top 100 products came from biologics; by 2014, that share is expected to rise to 50 percent.

title: An Educators Change of Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Nothing Flashy, but Sienas Rossiter Gets the Job Done
description: ALBANY  Siena forward Ryan Rossiter is nothing if not self-aware. With a 6-foot-9, 234-pound frame that looks as if it could still use a few sandwiches, Rossiter has become a favorite target of opposing student sections on the road.

title: Strangers in the Net, Exchanging Glances
description: ARE social networking sites bringing us together, or only fake bringing us together?

title: Suicide Bomber Rams a Pakistan Building
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  A suicide bomber rammed an explosives-laden truck into the main gate of a safe house used for interrogation by the Pakistani military in the city of Lahore early Monday. The explosion killed at least seven people, including guards, the police said, and flattened the building.

title: Accounts, People & Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Sure-Fire Crowd Pleaser: Reining in Wall Street
description: For President Obama and Congressional Democrats, public opinion this past year has mostly gone in the wrong direction  on his job performance, on health care and economic stimulus, on midterm elections.

title: Sure-Fire Crowd Pleaser: Reining in Wall Street
description: For President Obama and Congressional Democrats, public opinion this past year has mostly gone in the wrong direction  on his job performance, on health care and the economic stimulus, on midterm elections.

title: At Manhattan College, the Memories of Gonzalez Are Not So Fond
description: To illustrate just how difficult Bobby Gonzalez was to manage when he coached at Manhattan College from 1999 to 2006, Athletic Director Bob Byrnes told a story about the bus company Manhattan used to travel to games.

title: A Handy Road Map for the Final Weeks
description: This really is the home stretch in the health care debate.

title: At 10 Years, A Magazine Finds Time To Celebrate
description: The project was not real simple.

title: Officials Step Up Enforcement of Rights Laws in Education
description: Seeking to step up enforcement of civil rights laws, the federal Department of Education says it will be sending letters in coming weeks to thousands of school districts and colleges, outlining their responsibilities on issues of fairness and equal opportunity.

title: Philip Langridge, British Operatic Tenor, Dies at 70
description: Philip Langridge, an English tenor who was renowned for roles by Benjamin Britten and was an eloquent interpreter of Handel, Mozart, Schubert, Janacek and Stravinsky, died in England on Friday. He was 70 and lived near Guildford, southwest of London.

title: Aaron Cohen, Official and Engineer With NASA, Dies at 79
description: Aaron Cohen, an engineer who worked on the spacecraft used in the Apollo moon program and who later, as director of the Johnson Space Center, helped NASA recover after the Challenger explosion, died Feb. 25 at his home in College Station, Tex. He was 79.

title: Word of the Day | insularity
description: insularity \in(t)-su-lr, -syu-, in-sh-lr\ noun

title: Why Does JPMorgan Trade at Book Value?
Mark Linkous, Leader of Sparklehorse Band, Dies at 47
description: Mark Linkous, a singer and songwriter whose music, released under the name Sparklehorse, was renowned in indie-rock and alt-country circles for its haunted, allusive themes and fragile beauty, committed suicide on Saturday in Knoxville, Tenn. He was 47.

title: Supersizing the Show (Austerity Is So 2009)
description: The Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday night was one enormous Hollywood stimulus package. Not one host but two, 10 best picture nominations instead of five, two tributes to dead film luminaries and even an unexplained homage to the horror film, a genre that is very much alive. (Of course, the costly Avatar, with the biggest worldwide grosses of all time, was the ultimate public works project: W.P.A. in 3-D)

title: Looking Ahead
description: IN WASHINGTON The prime minister of Greece, George Papandreou, below, will speak at the Brookings Institution about his countrys economic situation and other topics (Monday). Mr. Papandreou is also scheduled to meet with President Obama at the White House (Tuesday).

title: How-To Hamlet
description: "If you happen to be walking through the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan in the next several weeks," writes Steven McElory, "be aware that a sword fight may erupt near you." If so, do not panic; you are actually seeing actors from the New York Classical Theater production of "Hamlet," starring, in the title role, Justin Blanchard, who will be rehearsing at the 3.5-acre center through March 25. The company, which has held open rehearsals in Battery Park and Central Park for years, is hoping to lure viewers by giving them a sneak peak at the process of how theater gets done. "Throughout the season, the company will use an empty storefront at 1 New York Plaza as a production office and costume shop. Passers-by can wander into the office and observe costume fittings, take part in scheduled discussions with members of the creative staff and even  if they are so inclined  learn about more mundane aspects of putting on a show, like sending out mailers and doing paperwork."

title: Grace Notes
description: Suzan-Lori Parks' new play "The Book of Grace" is about a young man returning to South Texas to confront his father. It will premiere at The Public Theater later this month. Get an early look at the show when the writer of "365 Plays/365 Days" and "Topdog/Underdog" appears tonight at the 92nd St. Y for a conversation.

title: The Nose Knows
description: William Kentridge, writes Anthony Tommasini, "belongs at the Met." The South African artist directed the company's production of Shostakovich's early opera "The Nose," which opened on Friday, and his sets and videos that animate the staging "received the heartiest bravos." The choice of Mr. Kentridge is another example of how Peter Gelb, the company's general manager, has made it a priority to recruit directors from theater and film. "With Mr. Kentridge, whose work can now be seen in an extensive exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, Mr. Gelb has brought in a major visual artist. Stop-action animation and theatrical design are central to Mr. Kentridge's work, and he has unleashed his imagination on Shostakovich's bitterly satirical and breathless opera." The music is intriguing, too: "you are not likely to hear a more insightful, ornery and, when appropriate, achingly poignant account of Shostakovich's still-shocking score than the performance the conductor Valery Gergiev drew from the Met orchestra and chorus and the large cast: some 30 artists, singing about 80 solo roles." Tonight a lecture about the production will be held at the Opera house beginning at 6.

title: Gates and Afghan Leader Review Plan for a Kandahar Offensive
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates met here on Monday with President Hamid Karzai and Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal to review plans for a major American-led offensive in the city of Kandahar, the spiritual heart and birthplace of the Taliban, an operation General McChrystal indicated could get under way this summer.

title: Disney-Cablevision Fight Is Far From the Last
description: The tentative agreement between The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision for WABC is just the latest in a string of recent feuds between media giants over transmission fees.

title: Juggling Act to Fill Fed Board Openings
description: To fill three seats on the Federal Reserves board of governors, the Obama administration is balancing seemingly contrary needs, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: Kraft Said to Face Inquiry Over Cadbury Plant
description: Kraft Foods is being investigated by British regulators on whether the company misled employees and investors in its battle to take over Cadbury, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: China Said to Plan Nullifying Loan Guarantees
description: China plans to nullify all guarantees local governments have provided for loans taken by their financing vehicles, a sign of increasing concern about the credit risks in such debt, Bloomberg News reported.

title: News Quiz | March 8, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Readers Comments on the Academy Awards
description: As Hollywood gathered to celebrate its finest at the 82nd annual Academy Awards, NYTimes.com readers and Twitter users weighed in on the Cablevision-Disney dispute, the pacing and presentation of the ceremony and the triumph by Kathryn Bigelow, director of The Hurt Locker.

title: Academy Award Winners
description: "The Hurt Locker," Jeff Bridges and Mo'Nique were among the winners at the 2010 Academy Awards.

title: Pakistan Government Site Is Attacked
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  A suicide bomber rammed an explosives-laden truck into the main gate of a safe house used by one of Pakistans security agencies for the interrogation of suspects in Lahore early on Monday.

title: In Deal on Everglades, a Dream Is Deferred
description: When Gov. Charlie Crist announced Floridas $1.75 billion plan to save the Everglades by buying out a major landowner, United States Sugar, he declared that the deal would be remembered as a public acquisition as monumental as the creation of the nations first national park, Yellowstone.

title: Art Off Guard
description: WHO have created a new art journal called Sw!pe Magazine: Guards Matter, along with an accompanying art exhibit? WHO is the artist who created the painting pictured above?

title: Q. and A. With Manhattan Athletic Director Bob Byrnes
description: Seton Hall mens basketball Coach Bobby Gonzalez, who has become a divisive figure in the Big East, took his first head-coaching job at Manhattan under Athletic Director Bob Byrnes. The two worked together for seven years before Gonzalez went to Seton Hall. Byrnes talked on Saturday night about the challenges of managing Gonzalez and how he was happy with his departure despite Manhattans on-court success during his tenure.

title: After MetLife Deal, A.I.G.s Next Step Is Unclear
description: As DealBook reported Sunday, the American International Group agreed to sell a second major insurance unit, this one to MetLife for about $15.5 billion. It was the second deal the insurer has struck in one week, raising about $51 billion to repay its taxpayer-financed rescue.

title: When Is Looting Morally Okay?
description: If crushed bodies were the enduring images of Haitis earthquake, the most memorable ones of Chile have been of looting, writes Donald G. McNeil Jr. When are desperate people entitled to help themselves? And to what? Tell us what you think, below.

title: Iraq Election Video: Voting Day
description: ELECTION DAY

title: An Office? Shell Pass on That
description: In The New York Timess most recent Corner Office Q&A, Adam Bryant talks with Meridee A. Moore, founder of Watershed Asset Management, a $2 billion hedge fund based in San Francisco.

title: Shell and PetroChina Bid $3 Billion for Coal Gas Firm
description: Arrow Energy of Australia said Monday that it had received a takeover offer worth about $3 billion from a company owned by Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina, the state-run gas and oil giant.

title: Indian Group Essar Said to Mull London I.P.O.
description: Essar Group, the Indian conglomerate, is working towards an $8 billion (5.3 billion) listing of its oil and power businesses in London, The Sunday Telegraph reported.

title: Global Hedge Fund Assets Now Total $1.89 Trillion
description: Global hedge fund assets rose 10 percent in the second half of 2009 to hit $1.89 trillion by the years end, Hedge Funds Review reported, citing a new survey from Hedge Fund Intelligence.

title: Why Does JPMorgan Trade at Book Value?
description: Jamie Dimon needs an even better postcrisis, Breakingviews says. The chief executive of JPMorgan Chase runs one of the only major banks in the United States that did not post a quarterly loss during the crash.

title: Farkas Said to Agree to Deal for Centerline Holding
description: Andrew Farkas, the American real estate investor, has agreed to a deal to buy Centerline Holding, a provider of financial and asset management services in real estate, by investing $100 million in equity in the company, The Wall Street Journal reported. Mr. Farkas will also assume $180 million of Centerlines debt, the newspaper said.

title: Posterous Receives $4.4 Million
description: Posterous, the blogging platform that would like to be to posting what Google is to search, has received $4.4 million in new financing, in a round led by Redpoint Ventures Trinity Ventures and a group of angel investors, PaidContent reported.

title: Sure-Fire Crowd Pleaser: Reining in Wall Street
description: For President Obama and Congressional Democrats, public opinion this past year has mostly gone in the wrong direction  on his job performance, on health care and economic stimulus, on midterm elections.

title: Quake Kills 51 in Eastern Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  At least 51 people died when an earthquake of 6.0 magnitude struck early Monday in eastern Turkey, officials in the region said.

title: How Pandora Slipped Past the Junkyard
description: Tim Westergren recently sat in a Las Vegas penthouse suite, a glass of red wine in one hand and a truffle-infused Kobe beef burger in the other, courtesy of the investment bankers who were throwing a party to court him.

title: Paris: Minimalism Talks
description: Yesterday was a pretty interesting and confusing day. First, there was the Cline show, where Phoebe Philos slim, terse coats with high necks and off-center buttons caught my attention. The designer means business; the clothes are sharp, graphic and intelligent  we like all those qualities and they seem particularly desirable now.

title: On Assignment: A Perilous Route to Marja
description: A concrete corner of a demolished building juts from the earth out of what appears to be the middle of nowhere. (Slide 8.) In its sturdy solitude, perhaps  at another time or place  it could be a monument to a great war, a solemn reminder of destruction and loss. But on this day it provided cover from sniper fire. Or shade. Or both. This is Marja.

title: Prudential Accelerates Hong Kong Listing
description: Prudential, the British insurer, said it had brought forward its planned listing on the Hong Kong stock exchange, and now aimed to complete the move before it offers its bumper $21 billion rights issue in May, Reuters reported.

title: Got Comments?
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared their beloved and beloathed slogans.

title: HBOS Investment Portfolio Set to Sell, Report Says
description: The remains of the investment portfolio of the British mortgage lenderHBOS could be sold this week, and the private equity group Coller Capital believed to be in the best position to buy what is left, The Sunday Times reported.

title: Bidders Said to Line Up for Anglos Zinc Assets
description: Anglo American, the global miner, said it had received strong interest in its zinc assets, but would not confirm that Vedanta Resources and HudBay Minerals were the front-runners to acquire them, Reuters reported.

title: F.D.I.C. Said to Urge Pension Funds to Invest Banks
description: United States regulators are encouraging public pension funds that control more than $2 trillion to inject capital directly into the banking system by buying failed lenders, Bloomberg News reported, citing people briefed on the matter.

title: Awareness Rises, but Women Still Lag in Pay
description: Companies in the United States, Spain, Canada and Finland lead the world in employing the largest numbers of women from entry level to senior management, according to a report published Monday by the World Economic Forum.

title: A Dutch Novel Celebrated at 150
description: The opening lines of the satirical novel Max Havelaar are so well-known in Dutch that even a relatively new arrival to the Netherlands, with scant knowledge of the countrys literary tradition, can recite them by memory: Ik ben makelaar in koffie, en woon op de Lauriergracht, no. 37. Translation: I am a coffee broker, and live at No. 37 Lauriergracht. A simple declarative statement to open up one of the first works in any language to bring an exploitative colonial system under moral scrutiny; the novel has since become a cornerstone of the literary tradition of the Netherlands. Eduard Douwes Dekker, or Multatuli as he is known, finished writing the book 150 years ago. This year, a couple of events mark that anniversary.

title: Dont Bother Bill Polian With the Probabilities
description: At a sports analytics conference at M.I.T. on Saturday, Bill Polian, the Colts president, said he thought Bill Belichick made the right call on the infamous 4th-and-2 play in Indianapolis. But according to him, All of the statistical analysis thats done over the course of a season means nothing.

title: A Running of the Bulls in March?
description: Bulls may get more room to run this week on the anniversary of the March 2009 lows  if United States stock investors see more signs of stability after Fridays rally on smaller-than-expected job losses, Reuters reported.

title: Dubai Debt Deal Reported Due This Week
description: Dubai World, the troubled state-owned conglomerate, expects to put its debt plan to creditors as early as this week, but the final proposal is being delayed by efforts to accurately value the assets of Nakheel,  its real estate unit, Reuters reported, citing bankers.

title: Citi Exec to Join Morgan Stanley, Report Says
description: Gary Shedlin, who was most recently chairman of Citigroups investment banking effort for financial institutions, focusing on client relationships, is departing to join Morgan Stanley , Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

title: Ford Adds Security and Other Features to Sync
description: The Internet is coming to cars  and so are security systems to keep viruses and hackers out.

title: Q&A: Making Movies in Windows 7
description: Q.

title: Bank of New York Mellon Snaps Up BHF Unit
description: Bank of New York Mellon may continue shopping around for more deals, even after it sewing up its second acquisition of the year.

title: Schools Nonfiction Problem (True Story)
description: Todays idea: Too much Harry Potter and Twilight? Educators say the young should read more nonfiction to soak up knowledge of the real world and truly master language.

title: JPMorgan Tops List of Biggest Hedge Fund Managers
description: JPMorgan Chase is the king of the hedge fund castle, at least in terms of heft, according to a recent ranking by Pensions and Investments magazine.

title: Whats at Stake in Conference Tournaments
description: Atlantic Coast (March 11-14, Greensboro, N.C.) Duke is the favorite to be the fourth No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Maryland, Clemson, Florida State, Wake Forest and Virginia Tech should all be in, but Georgia Tech probably needs to win at least two games in the conference tournament.

title: Santander Said to Lead Bids for RBOS Branches
description: Banco Santander of Spain is leading the bids to acquire 320 bank branches in Britain from the Royal Bank of Scotland, The Times reports, without citing sources.

title: The Worlds Best Countries for Women
Senate Tackles Jobs Package
description: Even the supposedly easy stuff is turning out to be hard for Congressional Democrats.

title: CCMP to Acquire Infogroup, Report Says
description: CCMP Capital Advisors, a private equity firm, has agreed to acquire Infogroup,  a data and marketing company, for roughly $460 million, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

title: Sampler: Funeral Fund to Settle, and Solar Panels for Alcatraz
description: The Origins and Evolution of the Moonbean Name | Jesse McKinley explores the history of a nickname for Jerry Brown, which was given to him in 1976 by Mike Royko, the syndicated Chicago columnist who later asked that people stop using it. With Mr. Brown announcing last week that he would seek to become Californias next governor, the Governor Moonbean sobriquet was resurrected by some as a description of someone who is unpredictable. Mr. Brown, who is the states attorney general, said the name, to him, symbolized other qualities, like being creative and not hidebound to the status quo. He added: Moonbeam also stands for not being the insider, but standing apart and marching to my own drummer. And Ive done that. [The New York Times]

title: Why Wont People Share?
description: Wondering why the citys cab-sharing experiment fizzled last week? A few Upper East Side residents offered a theory: location, location, location.

title: Fact, Fiction and Kapuscinski
description: Last week, news of the publication in Poland of Kapuscinski Non-Fiction, a new biography of the legendary Polish foreign correspondent Ryszard Kapuscinski, sparked a series of reports in the English-language press that treated the book as an expos that revealed the author of The Emperor, The Soccer War, and Shah of Shahs as a liar who passed off fiction as journalism.

title: Toll From Religious and Ethnic Violence in Nigeria Rises to 500
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Officials and human rights groups in Nigeria sharply increased the count of the dead after a weekend of vicious ethnic violence, saying Monday that as many as 500 people  many of them women and children  may have been killed near the city of Jos, long a center of tensions between Christians and Muslims.

title: Speed Read for Monday, March 8
description: Here are some highlights from Mondays edition of The New York Times:

title: Oscars: Red Carpet Fashion
description: Looks from the red carpet before the 82nd Academy Awards at the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles.

title: Media Equation: What If Your Publication Becomes the Story?
description: In his Media Equation column, David Carr asks what happens when your own newspaper or magazine becomes the story. One recent example involved The New York Times, which was working on stories about New York Gov. David A. Paterson. The actual stories, when they ran, were nothing like the wave of rumors that preceded them. And thats just one recent example.

title: The Early Word: Iraqs Election and Health Care
description: Its back to the daily grind in Washington, but all eyes are turned toward early election returns in Iraq, although final results arent expected for days.

title: Nissan Recalling 600,000 Trucks
description: Nissan is recalling about 598,000 trucks, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: The Wrong Marx
description: Incoming | Help yourself to some Marxist-Socialist humor by Jesse Eisenberg on McSweeneys.net:

title: Cast of Hair Sings Goodbye
description: When Sasha Allen began singing Aquarius, the opening number of Hair: The American Tribal Love-Rock Musical, on Sunday afternoon, it was hard to tell at first whether the teardrop was just a bit of sparkly makeup under her left eye. As she got deeper into the song and the cast joined in behind her, though, it was clear that it was a welling, uncontrollable tear. Followed by many others, it glistened down her cheek. Elsewhere chins quivered. When the song was done, Ms. Allen was wiping her eyes, the audience was on its feet for the first of several standing Os, and many in the young, exuberant cast were openly sobbing.

title: Submit Your Funny Caption
description: Booming Suburb | Tell us whats going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned images were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. The latest funniest captions are at right.

title: Ford Adds Security and Other Features to Sync System
description: From our colleagues at Gadgetwise:

title: Hesitation on Wall Street Leaves Shares Flat
description: Lacking a clear consensus about the strength of the recovery, Wall Street fell into a seesaw pattern on Monday.

title: A Jewish Kid From Queens Becomes a Vatican Ally
description: At home here on Long Island, he is Gary L. Krupp, medical equipment dealer, now retired after a career of ups and downs. He shares one car and a small house in a no-frills neighborhood with his wife, Meredith, and wryly describes himself as an average schlemiel, just a Jewish kid from Queens.

title: Candidates Speculate on Results of Iraq Vote
description: BAGHDAD  Even before the votes were tallied, Iraqs candidates and coalitions began positioning themselves in an evolving political landscape on Monday. Some claimed victory, and a few conceded defeat in an election on Sunday that the top American officials here called a milestone that kept the withdrawal of American troops on pace.

title: U.S. Airports Expand Passenger Full-Body Screening
description: According to the Associated Press, the Transportation Security Administration announced nine more U.S. airports that will receive body-scanning technology: Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; San Jose, Calif.; Columbus, Ohio; San Diego; Charlotte, N.C.; Cincinnati; Los Angeles; Oakland, Calif.; and Kansas City.

title: Strike Ban to Lift at Lufthansa
description: According to Bloomberg, Lufthansa pilots who walked out last month in a dispute over pay and job guarantees have said they will not strike when a court ban ends today, as long as talks continue. The German airline grounded hundreds of flights from Feb. 22 to 25 even as a labor court ordered pilots to end a planned four- day walkout after one day.

title: Another View: The Best Way to Protect Borrowers
description: Patricia A. McCoy, a law professor at the University of Connecticut, makes the case for setting up an independent Consumer Financial Protection Agency.

title: Shaved, From New York, Its Zach Galifianakis
description: It was the most surprising cultural moment of the weekend. (Other than The Hurt Locker upsetting Avatar at the Academy Awards, of course.) The comedian Zach Galifianakis had spent the duration of his Saturday Night Live hosting gig with his familiarly furry beard in tow  only to appear for the final skit of the evening with only a mustache.

title: The Minimalist March
description: A clean, linear silhouette was the story at Stella McCartney this morning. Minimalism must be catching, like the common cold. Ms. McCartneys showopened with a sleek, notched, above-the-knee coat in taupe wool (shown with bare legs and beige patent sling-backs) and moved to graphic camel and black striped tops with slacks. There were some interesting color mixes  a structured vest/top in burnt orange wool over a salmon turtleneck with black stirrup pants  and some see-through panels here and there. Shifts were super short, possibly as short as a sexy Balmain dress, and that worked against the clean message.

title: Ask About the Gowanus Canal
description: This week, Jack S. Nyman, the director of the Steven L. Newman Real Estate Institute at Baruch College, City University of New York, responded to readers questions about the development, economics and the future of the Gowanus area.

title: Photos of the Moment | Life From Paris
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Greg Kadel.

title: Unemployment Rising as Portugal Plans Cuts
description: Portugal said on Monday that the number of people making an initial request for an unemployment check rose to 22,323 in January from 12,346 in December, nearly doubling as the country prepared to impose an austerity program to tame its budget deficit.

title: The Oscars Kanye Moment Explained
description: Its the incident thats already being called the Kanye West moment of the 2010 Academy Awards: when Music By Prudence was named the winner of the award for best documentary short, Roger Ross Williams, a producer and the director of the film, took the stage and began giving his acceptance speech.

title: The Limits of Rahmism
description: AS A DOZEN or so top White House officials gathered in Rahm Emanuels corner West Wing office one morning in early January, the presidents political director, Patrick Gaspard, reported on the latest poll numbers in Massachusetts. With less than two weeks until a special Senate election, the Republican candidate was gaining momentum  just nine percentage points behind the Democrat in a new Rasmussen survey. The Democrats were in danger of losing the seat held for nearly half a century by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Scuba-do!
description: In the 1964 film Goldfinger, James Bond emerges from the sea and removes his scuba suit, only to reveal a party-perfect tuxedo underneath. This spring, Bond could simply wear his neoprene to the casino. Gucci translated the scuba look into leather vests and jackets, Dsquared showed neoprene life vests, and Italo Zucchelli at Calvin Klein transformed the utilitarian wet suit into modern outerwear.

title: Monday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: How a Lawyer Can Help You Sell Your Business
description: In my guide to selling a business, I recommend that no one consider either buying or selling a business without seeking the advice of a certified public accountant and a lawyer. I recently had the opportunity to chat with Harry Styron, who has been practicing law for 20 years, about the ownership-transfer process.

title: Biden Visits Mideast to Push Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. began a five-day visit to the Middle East on Monday, part of a concerted American effort to restart Israeli-Palestinian peace talks and keep Israel focused on relying on sanctions against Irans nuclear program rather than on unilateral military action.

title: Three Proven Steps to Advance the Worlds Women, on International Womens Day
description: Today is International Womens Day, and in fact the 100th anniversary of International Womens Day. Its a date that is much better known abroad but is beginning to get more traction in the U.S. as well.

title: No Free Lawyers for Most Swiss Animals
description: On Sunday, voters in Switzerland overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to appoint lawyers to represent abused animals in court in every region of the country. As The Lede explained last week, only Zurich currently employs a lawyer to speak for animals.

title: Lending Scheme to Bring Solar to Cambodias Poor
description: With access to solar-powered energy products for Cambodias rural poor extremely limited, the solar energy company Kamworks and the Cambodia Mutual Savings and Credit Network are partnering to provide low-interest loans to customers hoping to outfit their homes with solar panels, while Kamworks will provide and install the equipment.

title: Domingo Has Polyp Removed From Colon
description: Placido Domingo disclosed his medical problem on Monday: a localized malignant polyp in his colon. A spokeswoman said surgeons used laparoscopic surgery to remove the polyp and that Mr. Domingo was released from Mount Sinai Hospital on Sunday. He is expected to fully recover, said the spokeswoman, Nancy Seltzer. On Feb. 22, she said Mr. Domingo, 69, a busy tenor, conductor and opera company manager, would undergo preventive surgery after suffering sharp abdominal pain. At the time, she declined to provide details on the nature of his ailment, citing Mr. Domingos privacy. Doctors have required at least six weeks of rest, and Mr. Domingo hopes to return to the stage on April 16, depending on how fast he heals, in Verdis Simon Boccanegra at Teatro La Scala in Milan, the spokeswoman said Monday.

title: Quote Unquote | Better Than Sex
description: Gabourey Sidibe on the gorgeous Marchesa gown she wore to the Oscars. We cant argue there.

title: Boy in Bronx Dies in 2nd Hit-Run Accident in 23 Hours
description: For the second time in less than 24 hours, a person was killed by a hit-and-run driver in the city.

title: Junta Says Election Law Is Complete in Myanmar
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Myanmar said Monday that a long-awaited election law was complete, paving the way for the countrys first elections in two decades, a major step toward what the junta bills as its route toward democratic rule.

title: Brake Override in Action: Stomach-Churning, but Effective
description: On Thursday, I looked at the history and examined some technical elements behind an electronic brake override system, which has been in the news quite a bit lately since Toyotas nightmare with sudden unintended acceleration. Soon after writing that post, I got a demonstration of an override system at work.

title: Plagiarism Suit Against Avatar Is Dismissed in China
description: Well, at least the weekend wasnt a total loss for James Cameron. He didnt go home on Sunday night with as many Academy Awards as expected for his hit film Avatar, and not all the Oscar winners from the film remembered to call him a visionary at the podium. But he wont have to share his Avatar profits with a Chinese writer who said the movieplagiarizedhis work.

title: Travel Deals: $10 JetBlue Flights from New York
description: In celebration of JetBlues 10th anniversary, the airline is offering $10 fares on all remaining seats between Kennedy Airport in New York and the airlines first 10 destinations. Travel must be booked online by midnight tonight, Central Time, for travel tomorrow or Wednesday, March 9 or 10.

title: Winters Greens
description: This time of year many of us scratch our heads when opening that box of delivered produce, wondering if theres anything new to make with the greens inside.

title: Children With Cellphones
description: The technology section of the Times reports that the proportion of children with cellphones has nearly doubled, from 11.9 percent in 2005 to 20 percent in 2009.

title: Rejection of Technologies Wont End Debate
description: World soccers governing body moved from consideration to decisiveness Saturday, abandoning experiments with technology and firmly ruling out the use of video review or goal-line sensors.

title: For Patersons Aides, Business Almost as Usual
description: ALBANYOn Friday, Morgan Hook, one of Gov. David A. Patersons press aides, held a brief conference call at 1 p.m. with the dozens of public information officers scattered around state agencies and departments in Albany. Such calls are usually led by the governors communications director, Peter E. Kauffmann  who resigned on Thursday.

title: Retired General Is Picked for T.S.A.
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has chosen a retired Army intelligence officer, Maj. Gen. Robert A. Harding, to lead the Transportation Security Administration, a job officials call the most important unfilled position in the administration.

title: Jailed for Taking Kids to Jury Duty
description: Carmela Khury was called for jury duty in a Michigan murder trial, and she was having a complicated morning. Her mother, who had been watching Khurys 8-month-old son and 3-year-old daughter, needed emergency oral surgery, and then the backup baby sitter fell through after Khurys husband had already left for work.

title: White House Easter Egg Debut
description: GLENSIDE, Pa.  To everyone who has been waiting with bated breath for the unveiling of the design of this years White House Easter egg, your wait is over.

title: Haitian Up
description: Toughen up  a phrase coined by medics in Haiti in the aftermath of the January 2010 earthquake.

title: Featured Recipe: Spare Ribs With Olives, Lemon and Rosemary
description: Sometimes you snack on olives, and  if youre adventurous  you might marinate them and pick at them more often. But when you start cooking with olives, you get an entirely different view of them. In this dish they play a lead role, adding their distinctive salty bitterness to the lovely combination of acidic lemon and piquant rosemary, all of which bring life to the rich but somewhat one-dimensional flavor of pork.

title: Another Court Date, Another Delay
description: The drunken-driving case against Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV was delayed again Monday because the arresting officers wife was having a Caesarean section.

title: Photos of the Moment | Stella McCartney
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Vazquez Makes Spring Debut vs. Phillies
description: TAMPA, Fla.  If Thursdays scintillating World Series rematch wasnt enough for you, we have a rematch of the rematch playing out at George M. Steinbrenner Field on Monday afternoon. Javier Vazquez, making his spring debut, is scheduled to face a rather complete Phillies lineup in his first test.

title: Should Scientists Fight Heat or Stick to Data?
description: Some leading lights in environmental science have been pushing their colleagues, and institutions like the National Academies, to come out swinging against the ongoing barrage of assaults from organized opponents of restrictions on greenhouse gases and climate skeptics/contrarians/denialists/realists (pick your label depending on your worldview).

title: A Kanye Moment at the Oscars
description: This would probably be what the producers consider an unintentional watercooler moment. In what probably put his film on the map more than winning the Oscar itself, the short documentary winner Roger Ross Williams got Kanyed when accepting his award for Music by Prudence. As Mr. Williams, the director, was making his speech, Elinor Burkett, the producer, jumped onstage with him and began talking over him, shades of Kanye West interrupting Taylor Swift at the Video Music Awards last year. Salon has the back story: the two have been fighting for a year; there was a lawsuit about the creative control of the film that was settled out of court. Ms. Burkett, who lives in Zimbabwe, where the movie was shot, claims she gave Mr. Williams the idea for the project, a charge he disputes. In any case they didnt talk in advance to determine who would be the one person to come onstage to accept the award. (The Academy allows only one person to speak.)

title: Old Jokes Home: The Oscars Gags That Wouldnt Die
description: There was something about the running repartee between Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin at Sundays Academy Awards show that had a certain timeless quality to it  which is to say, many of their jokes sounded as if they could have been written at any time and for any occasion since the invention of the talkie.

title: Monday Puzzle: Fun on Display
description: Today we have some light fun based on the standard seven-segment number display used in digital LCD and LED clocks and calculators. The idea for this puzzle and some of the questions in it come from Dr. Kurt Eisemann, an emeritus mathematics professor from San Diego.

title: What MetLife Got in Its Alico Deal
description: In agreeing to buy one of the American International Groups foreign life insurance units, MetLife got a bit more than an insurance operation.

title: Greek Tragedy
description: The Greek prime minister, George Papandreou, is in Washington today. He wants to do something about credit-default swaps, which let those horrid hedge funds bet that his country will go broke.

title: Answers About Education Tax Credits and Deductions: Part 4
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Part 1: Answers on Historically Black Colleges and Universities
description: More than 100 American institutions are classified by the government as historically black colleges and universities through a formal program intended to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.

title: Plagiarism Suit Against Avatar Is Dismissed in China
description: Well, at least the weekend wasnt a total loss for James Cameron. He didnt go home on Sunday night with as many Academy Awards as expected for his hit film Avatar, and not all the Oscar winners from the film remembered to call him a visionary at the podium. But he wont have to share his Avatar profits with a Chinese writer who said the movie plagiarized his work.

title: Voluntary End-of-Life Measures Banned at Catholic Hospitals
description: In the book I discussed last week, Zoe FitzGerald Carters Imperfect Endings, a woman growing increasingly incapacitated from Parkinsons disease deliberately stops eating and drinking so she can die in her home with her children and grandchildren nearby. Its a controversial decision, both within her own family and in the society at large, but its a legal one  and a personal one that doesnt require any bureaucracys blessing.

title: Hands-Off Approach Is Getting Perilous
description: Normally, it is not easy to draw parallels between Nascar and the N.H.L. Culturally, they are about as far apart as Lady Gaga and Bing Crosby. As sports, the only similarity is that sweat is involved. In both, however, significant factions have a hearty belief in frontier justice, that the inmates should not only have keys to the asylum but also plan the menu. Players should police their own game, or in the words of Nascars vice president for competition, Boys, have at it.

title: Kurt Busch Survives Late Crashes to Win in Atlanta
description: The Kobalt Tools 500 at Atlanta Motor Speedway on Sunday might be better remembered for the ongoing feud between Carl Edwards and Brad Keslowski than the winner, Kurt Busch. According to The Associated Press, the feud can be traced to a race last year at Talladega, in which Keslowski won after colliding with Edwards. In Atlanta on Sunday, the two made contact twice. The first incident came early and sent Edwards to the garage. He emerged late in the race (and more than 150 laps down from the leaders). With three laps to go, he clipped Keslowskis car at 190 miles and hour. Keslowskis car launched into the air, flipped and crashed in front of the grandstands. Nascar ordered Edwards to stop his car. Thats not cool, Keselowski said afterward. He could have killed someone in the grandstands. Nascar will decide on Monday whether to discipline Edwards. (The Associated Press)

title: Are Disney/ABC and Cablevison Begging People to Cut the Cord?
With The Cove Victorious at Oscars, Japanese Village Defends Itself
description: The day after The Cove won the Academy Award for best documentary, the Japanese fishing village in that film said its dolphin-hunting practices were legal, and that the movie was unfair to its fishermen.

title: In a Polarized Court, Getting the Last Word
description: WASHINGTON

title: Why Notre Dame Has Succeeded Without Harangody
description: Zach Hillesland, a contributor to The Quad over the past two years, played forward at Notre Dame before graduating last year. He now works in academic services for student-athletes at Notre Dame.

title: Now Screening | Ann Demeulemeester
description: The fall 2010 collection from Ann Demeulemeester at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Loud-Talking Parents Get a Talking To
description: What could be worse than sitting next to a loud cellphone-talker on the train? A loud-talking, overeducated parent who schools his or her child in public, according to Susan Goldberg, the writer of the past weekends Complaint Box in the Metropolitan section.

title: Outsourcing Breakups
description: In Up in the Air, a fictional company got paid to fire other peoples employees. Now iDUMP4U, a real company, gets paid to dump other peoples significant others.

title: Q&A With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Jefferson Burruss joined GSD&M Idea City, Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group, as executive producer in the integrated production department. He had been director for digital and online at the Los Angeles office of DDB Worldwide, also part of Omnicom.

title: Women Who Drink Gain Less Weight
description: Dieters are often advised to stop drinking alcohol to avoid the extra calories lurking in a glass of wine or a favorite cocktail. But new research suggests that women who regularly consume moderate amounts of alcohol are less likely to gain weight than nondrinkers and are at lower risk for obesity.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Group Hug 2
description: Two days ago, Junya Watanabe held a military parade of long green coats and parkas, not unlike the ones seen at Dries Van Noten a few days before. Then, all of a sudden, as if possessed by some primordial, unspoken understanding, every fashion editor and her assistants assistant began wearing  you guessed it  olive green, military-inspired gear. Some have already sunk their manicured claws into pre-fall samples; others scoured their closets for long-forgotten fatigues; one editor drove to a vintage military store in Montparnasse immediately after the Watanabe show, and handed the second-hand loot to the driver, so that he could throw it into the washing machine to achieve that elusive degree of casual distress.

title: This Brand Doesnt Mind Being in the Soup
description: The world was treated to a terrific game when the United States and Canadian hockey teams played each other at the Winter Olympics. But Canadians and Americans can cooperate, too, as demonstrated by a campaign for a venerable brand.

title: What Were Reading
Houston, We Have Face-Lift
description: Here is a question Ive been pondering for some time now: Is there any moral high road to be taken when it comes to plastic surgery? Does one get anypoints for not yielding to the unforgiving demands of our culture and its disdain for the stigmata of age by letting ones DNA play itself out? Does it make one a better  a more profound  person? Would we love Catherine Deneuve more if she had consented to letting us see her age onscreen? Do we love her less for trading in her fragile beauty for a plumped-up, smoothed-out visage that tells us little about the content of her character? And what has happened to the whole category of aesthetics that once went by the name of ravaged beauty? Women like Simone Signoret and Melina Mercouri, who wore the wreckage of their former glory  their nasolabial folds, lined foreheads and slack jawlines  proudly. Then again, perhaps you are one of the lucky ones, someone destined to age with a complex grandeur, like Georgia OKeeffe; how will you ever know if you run for the scalpel the minute you spot a crows-foot around your eyes or a marionette line above your lips?

title: New Discovery Series Will Have a Seven-Channel Debut
description: To promote its sweeping new nature series Life, the Discovery Channel will share the first episode with six of its sister channels. A total of seven cable channels owned by Discovery Communications will simultaneously show the first episode of Life on Sunday, March 21, the company announced Monday.

title: Now Screening | Stella McCartney
description: The fall 2010 collection from Stella McCartney at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Investment Predictions May Haunt a Psychic
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Start Me Up: The Alley Returns
description: Silicon Alley, hobbled after the dot-com bust a decade ago, appears to be making a comeback. As my colleague Jenna Wortham reports in Sundays Times, Manhattan is again an appealing place for digital start-ups and the investment companies that jolt them to life.

title: I.B.M. Opens Energy Lab in Beijing
description: In another sign of Chinas emergence as an epicenter of green technology, I.B.M. has opened a lab in Beijing to develop smart grid software for the global market.

title: Stomach Bug Hits Cruise Ships
description: Attention cruisers: A stomach virus is going around.

title: Childhood: 1 in 4 Parents Link Autism to Vaccines
description: Most parents believe that vaccines protect their children against disease, but one in four think some vaccines cause autism in healthy children, and nearly one in eight have refused at least one recommended vaccine, a new study has found.

title: Aging: Cognitive Decline and Hospitalization
description: Older people are more likely to suffer a decline in their cognitive abilities after being hospitalized for an illness than they would otherwise, a new study reports.

title: Cornyn Still Backs Crist in Florida Senate Race
description: Senator John Cornyn, the Texan who is heading the National Republican Senatorial Committee this election cycle, stuck by his endorsement of Gov. Charlie Crist in Floridas Republican Senate primary on Monday  but just barely.

title: Helix Energy Seeks to Sell Oil and Gas Business
description: The Helix Energy Solutions Group, an oil services provider, said Monday that it was planning to sell its entire oil and gas business in order to transform itself into a contracting services company focused on deepwater wells and subsea construction, The Associated Press reports.

title: Sleep: Study Finds Many Are Too Tired for Sex
description: Too tired for sex? You are not alone.

title: Obama Turns Up the Volume in Health Care Bid
description: PHILADELPHIA  President Obama challenged wavering members of his party on Monday not to give in to political fears about supporting health care legislation, asserting that the urgency of getting a bill through Congress should trump any concern about the consequences for Democrats in November.

title: Now Screening | Junya Watanabe
description: The fall 2010 collection from Junya Watanabe at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Rivera Feels Delicious
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Derek Jeter and Alex Rodriguez are in Bradenton, Fla., this afternoon, and in about two weeks they are scheduled to take a much longer trip, to Port Charlotte. Mark Teixeira played Sunday in Fort Myers. On Friday, Andy Pettitte will pitch against Washington in Viera, about 130 miles away.

title: Retired Players Call for Union Lawyers Dismissal
description: A group of retired N.F.L. players, including Fred Dean and Joe DeLamielleure, sent a letter to players union chief DeMaurice Smith on Friday calling for the firing of the unions top lawyer, Richard Berthelsen.

title: The Claim: A Glass of Wine With Dinner Aids Digestion
description: THE FACTS

title: Five Questions About When the Rain Stops Falling
description: As a heatwave battered London last year, Ben Brantley wrote that Andrew Bovells play When the Rain Stops Falling offered sweaty theatergoers regular tastes of something cool and wet.

title: Vice President Biden Visits Israel
description: Jane Bornemeier speaks with Jerusalem bureau chief Ethan Bronner about the trip's focus on persuading Israel to help in efforts to impose sanctions on Iran.

title: M&T Banks Flight Plan for Chief Executive
description: Allied Irish Banks has held a stake in the Buffalo-based M&T Bank since 2003 and Robert G. Wilmers, M&Ts chairman and chief executive, has been on A.I.B.s board since then. But in the preliminary proxy that M&T filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, M&T disclosed a new perk for Mr. Wilmers: travel to A.I.B.s board meetings on a corporate jet.

title: From a Small Stable, Big Derby Dreams
description: Alexis Barba put her head on her pillow on Friday without a worry in the world  at least about her horses. Two of her colts were running at Santa Anita, and she was certain that both were healthy, talented and ready.

title: Strike Could Cause Delays at UK Ports, Airports
description: Officials say a two-day strike by British public sector workers could cause disruptions at ports and airports.

title: Karl Rove's New Memoir
description: Peter Baker of The Times discusses Karl Rove's new memoir. The former White House adviser wrote that had the Bush administration known there were no weapons of mass destruction, there may not have been a war in Iraq.

title: Greek Leader Wants to Restrict Speculative Trades
description: WASHINGTON  The Greek prime minister called on Monday for the United States and the European Union to crack down on speculative trading, arguing that exotic bets had driven up Greeces borrowing costs and threatened its effort to ease its debt crisis.

title: Stirling Moss Injured in Accident
description: Stirling Moss, the greatest driver never to have won the Formula One world drivers title, was injured in an accident at his home. Moss broke both of his ankles and some bones in his feet and damaged his vertebrae in a fall down three floors in his home in London when an elevator he installed in his own home malfunctioned.

title: Excerpt: 'The Pacific'
description: The HBO mini-series from the team behind "Band of Brothers" focuses on the Pacific theater of World War II.

title: Paterson Has Not Scheduled Meeting to Discuss Investigation
description: Gov. David A. Paterson said on Monday that he had not yet scheduled a meeting with the attorney generals office to discuss its investigation of his administrations handling of a domestic assault case in which one of the governors top aides was implicated.

title: Who Will Hire Me? Creating 21st-Century Rsums
description: Overview | How has the traditional approach to creating and sharing a rsum changed with the advent of technological tools and the Internet? How can technology be used to enhance a rsum and represent a persons abilities? In this lesson, students reflect on their talents, achievements and experience and create two rsum versions  traditional and technology-enhanced  to learn how best to showcase their talents and ambitions.

title: Scientists See Fresh Evidence of More Water on the Moon
description: The top of the moon is icy, too.

title: Advertisement for Premium Saltines
description: This Canadian commercial is the basis for the new Premium Saltines campaign in the United States.

title: Taking Flash in a Basketball Pass to Ohio State
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Samantha Prahalis, a long-haired linebacker, would rush on a slant, knocking runners off their feet and absorbing quarterbacks. At 60 pounds and 10 years old, she was slight but slippery, slaloming her way into the backfield for five or six tackles a game behind the line of scrimmage. To the prepubescent boys she played against, Prahalis was the predator; they were the prey. The defense that she headed was known as Monster 52.

title: Oscar Ratings Highest Since 2005
description: Continuing a trend of super-sized TV ratings for big-ticket events, the Academy Awards drew an average audience of 41.3 million viewers Sunday night, the award shows best performance in five years.

description: Boston is about to get a bit of the Bowery.

description: Should this hit to the head yesterday by the Penguins Matt Cooke on the Bruins Marc Savard be against the N.H.L. rules?

title: Ground Zero Hotel Wants to Attract 9/11 Tourists
description: Looking down into the construction site where the World Trade Center once stood, some might see a place shadowed by death. But for the company opening the World Center Hotel, the propertys location on the edge of the site of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks is a selling point.

title: Counting Outsourced Greenhouse Gas Emissions
description: One of the stickiest points in international climate change negotiations is how to account for carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions produced to make goods that are then sold for export. Should the producing country be held to account for those emissions? Or does the consuming country bear some responsibility for counting those emissions?

title: How to Handle Your Investing Overconfidence
description: Overconfidence is a very serious problem, but you probably dont think it affects you. Thats the tricky thing with overconfidence: the people who are most overconfident are the ones least likely to recognize it. We tend to think of it as someone elses problem.

title: Oil and Gasoline Prices Begin to Creep Up
description: HOUSTON  Crude oil and gasoline prices are inching up again.

title: Almonds for Calcium?
description: Q. I have read that almonds are a good source of calcium and also that they can block calcium absorption. Which is correct?

title: Lured by a Hint of Spring, Diners Flock Outdoors
description: The snow has barely finished melting. The buds on the trees are clenched shut. . But the sidewalks are already dotted once again with tables, chairs and New Yorkers determined to get a taste of Paris along with their lunch.

title: Shes Still Unusual | Cyndi Lauper
description: Warning: This post contains spoilers.

title: Too Tired for Sex
description: Whats happening in bedrooms across America? Not much, according to new research.

title: Sometimes Brothers Can Be Too Protective of a Sister
description: When it comes to Renaissance-era tales of forbidden love set in Italy, Juliet had it easy.

title: Hey, Friend, Do You Like My Sad Story?
description: I recently liked a story about five people dying in an explosion in Connecticut.

description: Wow. Bruce Bartlett says that David Malpass is exploring a run for the Senate. Jonathan Chait says most of what needs to be said about Malpasss track record.
