description: Readings. (doc)

title: Photos of the Moment | Sacr Blur
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Catiere.

title: From Street Corners to the Oscar Stage
description: LOS ANGELES  The Cinderella narrative got quite a workout on Oscar night. Onstage at the show, Oprah Winfrey called Gabourey Sidibe a real-life Cinderella; Christoph Waltz was a foreign Cinderella, eine Aschenputtel; and The Hurt Locker was the little Cinderella that could.

title: New York Auto Show Preview: Acura TSX Sport Wagon
description: Finally! Acura will introduce its handsome TSX Sport Wagon at the New York auto show at the end of March, the company announced Monday. The all-new wagon will go on sale in the fall as a 2011 model, Acura said, confirming its announcement last October.

title: What Are You Carrying?
description: In eastern Congo, the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof learned first hand how difficult a woman's burden can be.

title: Variety Lets Go of 2 of Its Top Critics
description: Neil Stiles, the president of Variety, said the entertainment industry trade paper was cutting from its staff two of its most prominent writers  the film reviewer Todd McCarthy and the theater critic David Rooney.

title: Six to Be Honored for Contributions to the City
description: One day, as a student at City College, Julius Berger noticed a professor fumbling with a microscope while trying to focus it with his fingers.

title: Lives Scarred by Horrors of Korean War
description: Horrifying things have happened to the three main characters in Chang-rae Lees searing new novel, The Surrendered  things, much like the decision forced upon the heroine of William Styrons Sophies Choice, that will burn their souls and forever warp the course of their lives.

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, March 8
description: Officials and human rights groups in Nigeria said Monday that about 500 people had died in weekend ethnic violence near the central city of Jos, considerably more than what had initially been reported. The first two pictures in our slide show were taken in the nearby village of Dogo Nahawa by Akintunde Akinleye, photographing for Reuters.

title: Greek Leader Wants to Restrict Speculative Trading
description: The Greek prime minister called on the United States and the European Union on Monday to crack down on speculative trading, saying that exotic market bets had driven up Greeces borrowing costs and threatened its effort to ease its debt crisis, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: Vain Glorious | Salon Treatment
description: Sally Hershberger knows a thing or two about beach hair, having worked on countless photo shoots with Herb Ritts, Steven Meisel and Annie Leibovitz. I cant stand it when hair doesnt have any movement to it, says the celebrity stylist, who is also an avid water-skier. Of course, it helps to have an ocean breeze  not to mention one of Hershbergers legendary $800 haircuts. But the next best thing, and a heck of a lot cheaper, might very well be her new line of Salon styling products. Theres Texture Blast, which Hershberger says gives insane volume; Smooth Fix, for that non-greasy red-carpet-worthy shine; Luxe Layers for blowouts; and Shape Up for  what else  body building. Erin Bogart, a colorist in Hershbergers New York salon who specializes in surfer hair  strategically streaky with sun-kissed tips  digs the Mineral Spray for that saltwater treatment without the salt.

title: For Iran, Enriching Uranium Only Gets Easier
description: In the Iranian desert, at a sprawling industrial site ringed by barbed wire and antiaircraft guns, a shift in the enrichment of uranium is producing global jitters because it could shorten Irans path to the acquisition of nuclear weapons.

title: Bidding War Pits Pfizer And Teva
description: The executives at some generic drug companies have a new catchphrase: Theres no place like Ulm. Theres no place like Ulm.

title: Sneezes, Hiccups, Laughs and a Chamber Group
description: Suggesting that advances in technology have had an impact on classical music is stating what has long been obvious. As the piano was improved, Beethoven and Chopin produced works that tapped into its new possibilities. Novel implements afforded further expressive potential: Ravels saxophone, Strausss wind machine, Respighis phonograph and Varses magnetic tape. The sampling keyboard, which can digitally reproduce any sound, was a revolution unto itself.

title: Lessons From Frogs
description: Oh, the lessons to be learned from the male Peruvian poison frog, also known as Ranitomeya imitator.

title: Doctor Leads Quest for Safer Ways to Care for Patients
description: Dr. Peter J. Pronovost, 45, is medical director of the Quality and Safety Research Group at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, which means he leads that institutions quest for safer ways to care for its patients. He also travels the country, advising hospitals on innovative safety measures. The Hudson Street Press has just released his book, Safe Patients, Smart Hospitals: How One Doctors Checklist Can Help Us Change Health Care from the Inside Out, written with Eric Vohr. An edited version of a two-hour conversation follows.

title: How Little They Know the World
description: Well, it seems that Republicans are going all in on the idea that a big reason we have high unemployment is that unemployment benefits reduce the incentive to seek work. Aside from the sheer cruelty, its really bad economics, but whatever.

title: A Little Black Box to Jog Failing Memory
description: PITTSBURGH  On a cold, wet afternoon not long ago, Aron Reznick sat in the lounge of a home for the elderly here, his silver hair neatly combed, his memory a fog. He could not remember Thanksgiving dinner with his family, though when he was given a hint  turkey  it came back to him, vaguely, like a shadow in the moonlight.

title: Massa Says Health Care Stand Contributed to His Resignation
description: Representative Eric Massa, Democrat of New York, who is resigning from Congress amid allegations that he sexually harassed a staff member, now says he believes that House Democratic leaders wanted to force him out of office because he voted against the Democrats health care legislation.

title: Where Women Do Most of the Hard Work
description: One of the puzzles of the developing world is that women frequently do some of the hardest physical labor. Hauling water, for example, is womens work in culture after culture. And anybody who has tried to haul a couple of buckets of water four miles from the nearest well know how excruciatingly heavy water becomes after a few hundred yards.

title: C.F.T.C. Settles Bank of Montreal Trading Case
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said Monday that it had settled the charges against the supervisor of a Bank of Montreal natural gas trader who cost the bank around 680 million Canadian dollars (about $660 million United States) after the trader was accused of mismarking and misvaluing the banks natural gas trading book for years.

title: Massa Exits, but Also Blames Health Care Stance
description: Representative Eric Massa, the Democrat from upstate New York who has said he will resign office effective this afternoon in the wake of an ethics inquiry, is also now claiming that his vote against health care legislation has contributed to his problems. He now asserts that Democrats wanted him out of office because he opposed their health care proposals.

title: Going Global, Stateside
description: Training to communicate across cultures has long been part of the preparation for executives moving overseas to work. But now, the training is increasingly for employees who may never leave the country, yet will work closely with companies and people around the world.

title: Violence Is Not Religiously Motivated, Nigerian Archbishop Says
description: Updated | 7:07 p.m. As my colleague Adam Nossiter reports, hundreds of Nigerians were killed this weekend in ethnic violence near the city of Jos, in central Nigerias Plateau State.

title: To Keep Moving, Look Beyond the Physical
description: I have long known (though Ive yet to give up trying) that it is almost impossible to motivate smokers to quit for good by regaling them with the health hazards of tobacco. And now Ive been told by readers of last weeks column, Even More Reasons to Get a Move On, that repeated sermons on the health benefits of physical activity may get some folks started but are unlikely to keep them at it.

title: David Foster Wallace Papers Are Bought
description: The private papers of the writer David Foster Wallace, above, who committed suicide at 46 in 2008, have been acquired by the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin. The archive contains drafts of books, stories, essays, poems, letters and research, including the handwritten notes for Infinite Jest, the novel that first gained him attention. There is also a copy of his dictionary, in which he circled words, and heavily annotated copies of books by Don DeLillo, Cormac McCarthy, John Updike and others. Mr. Wallaces writing journal, which includes personal reflections, story ideas, names and plots, as well as articles on boredom, tax shelters and credit-card fraud are also included.

title: Lupone to Appear With City Ballet
description: Shes done Broadway, now its on to the ballet. On Monday, New York City Ballet announced that Patti LuPone, below, will make her New York City Ballet debut in a new production of The Seven Deadly Sins as part of the companys 2011 spring season. The Tony-nominated director and choreographer Lynne Taylor-Corbett, who has previously choreographed two works for the company, Mercury in 1992 and Chiaroscuro in 1994, will create the new production. The Seven Deadly Sins, a sung ballet in seven scenes, was composed by Kurt Weill to a German libretto by Bertolt Brecht in 1933 and was first performed in Paris and produced, directed and choreographed by George Balanchine. The ballet features a character portrayed by both a singer and dancer. Ms. LuPone will be the singer; a dancer has yet to be announced. The original production featured Lotte Lenya as the singer and Tilly Losch as the dancer. Balanchine revived the work in 1958 with Allegra Kent in the role of the dancer. The schedule of performances and the rest of the 2011 spring season will be announced later.

title: Lyondell Says Its Plan Is Better Than Reliance Bid
description: LyondellBasell Industries says it rejected a takeover bid by Reliance Industries because it has a superior reorganization plan that would leave the chemical maker valued at about $15.2 billion, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Against Oscars, Rival Networks See No Gold
description: CBS, NBC and Fox struggled in the ratings on Sunday opposite ABCs coverage of the Academy Awards, which dwarfed all other shows with an audience of about 41 million, the biggest in five years. According to Nielsens estimates, CBS was runner-up on the night, earning its most viewers at 8 p.m. with a new episode of The Amazing Race, which drew 8.1 million. Fox ranked third with a lineup of mostly reruns, including two episodes of The Simpsons at 8 and 8:30 (4.8 million). NBC finished fourth with Dateline from 7 to 8:30 (5.8 million) followed by the 2003 movie Bad Boys II, which averaged 3 million viewers.

title: The Bowery in Boston
description: Boston is about to get a bit of the Bowery. The Bowery Presents, the company that puts on concerts at the Bowery Ballroom, Terminal 5 and other spaces in New York, has signed a long-term deal with the Royale club in Boston to be the exclusive presenter of live music there. The Royale, which until recently was called the Roxy, is a 1,000-capacity space on Tremont Street with an open floor and a U-shaped balcony. Known to Boston clubgoers as a late-night dance haunt, the Royale will be outfitted for live music and have about 100 concerts a year, said Jim Glancy, a partner in the Bowery Presents. The Royale will be the companys first space outside the New York region. (It also helps run the Wellmont Theater in Montclair, N.J.) The Bowery will open a small office in Boston to run the Royale shows and book events for larger spaces. Its a fantastic market, Mr. Glancy said. The type of music we book totally lends itself to Boston. That music is mainly rock, but as at Webster Hall in New York the Royale will continue to put on its own dance events independent of the rock shows. (After renovations the Royale will have its official reopening on Saturday, a dance night.) The first announced concert booking for the Royale is the reunited Public Image Limited on May 4 and 5, but Mr. Glancy and another Bowery partner, John Moore, said they expected to book others in April.

title: Plcido Domingo Is Released After Surgery
description: Plcido Domingo, left, disclosed his medical problem on Monday: a localized malignant polyp in his colon. Nancy Seltzer, a spokeswoman, said surgeons used laparoscopic surgery to remove the polyp and said Mr. Domingo was released from Mount Sinai Hospital in New York on Sunday. He is expected to recover fully, Ms. Seltzer said. Last month she said Mr. Domingo, 69, a busy tenor, conductor and opera company manager, would undergo preventive surgery after suffering sharp abdominal pain while in Tokyo. At the time she declined to provide details about his ailment, citing Mr. Domingos privacy. Doctors have required at least six weeks of rest, and Mr. Domingo hopes to return to the stage on April 16, depending on how fast he heals, in Verdis Simon Boccanegra at Teatro La Scala in Milan, Ms. Seltzer said Monday.

title: Northrop and EADS to Drop Bid for Tanker
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said on Monday that it would not bid for a $40 billion contract to build aerial refueling planes for the Air Force, leaving its rival, Boeing, as the likely winner of one of the Pentagons largest contracts.

title: Avatar Plagiarism Suit Dismissed in China
description: James Cameron didnt go home on Sunday night with as many Academy Awards as expected for his hit film Avatar, and not all the Oscar winners from the film remembered to call him a visionary at the podium. But he wont have to share his Avatar profits with a Chinese writer who said the movie plagiarized his work. A court in Beijing has thrown out a lawsuit brought by the writer Zhou Shaomou, who said that the film closely resembled his novel The Legend of the Blue Crow, which he wrote in 1997 and published online in 1999, The Global Times of China reported. The author said his novel and Avatar shared 80 percent of their material, and was seeking 8 percent of the movies total revenue. A Chinese representative for 20th Century Fox, which released the film, told The Global Times that the story line for Avatar was first devised in 1995, two years before Mr. Zhou wrote his novel.

title: Architectural Records Saved at Last Minute
description: The archives of the architectural firm that designed the World Trade Center have been rescued from shredding at the 11th hour. The firm, Yamasaki Associates, in Troy, Mich., was founded in the 1950s by the modernist architect Minoru Yamasaki, who in addition to the Twin Towers designed the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles. Mr. Yamasaki died in 1986, and his office was closed in January. Ted Ayoub, one of the last employees of the firm, contacted the Society of Architectural Historians, which in turn contacted the State Historic Preservation Office in Michigan. Mark Harvey, Michigans state archivist, assembled a crew to drive a truck from Lansing to Troy, with one days notice, to save the archive from being shredded.

title: Oedipus Has iPhone (and Rage)
description: Near the end of Blind, moments after the half-naked main character has had feverish sex with his mother, then choked her to death (per her wishes) after she crushed his eyeballs with her thumbs midcoitus, he crawls across the floor to the telephone, somehow dials, reaches a maid in his palace and, in bloody pain, asks, Could you come up here, please?

title: Character Study | Say It In French
description: The actor Gaspard Ulliel does a one-man show, piling on the best of the seasons nouvelle vague looks. More

title: Pandora: In the Middle of the Music
description: How will we listen to music on the Internet in the future?

title: For Lil Wayne, 3rd Time Is Not the Charm
description: As the rapper Lil Wayne made his final public appearance as a free man for at least the next eight months, he was greeted by a chaotic scene in front of a Manhattan criminal courthouse on Monday afternoon.

title: The A-to-Z Cure
description: One thing I do when I cant sleep is play alphabet games. I try to list various things from A to Z: countries, rock groups, prescription drugs, movies, books, celebrities whose first and last names begin with the same letter you get the idea. I dont mind repeating categories from one night to another. Diseases might seem to be an unlikely insomnia game category, but for some reason, its one of my favorites. I like to combine ailments that terrified me in childhood (lockjaw) with ones that I didnt know about until I was an adult (Ebola). And there are certain ailments that are never, ever on the list. Ever.

title: Obama Cheers the Crimson Tide
description: After returning from a health care speech near Philadelphia on Monday, President Obama greeted members of the University of Alabama football team, the national champions for the 2009 season.

title: Counting on Clicks to Finance the Battle Against AIDS, Malaria and Tuberculosis
description: To help average Americans do something to fight AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, several foundations and travel companies, in cooperation with the United Nations, are starting a campaign to allow travelers to donate $2 every time they pay for a flight, a rental car or a hotel room.

title: Coaches vs. Cancer Final Round Is Set
description: The final round of the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic, to be held Nov. 18 and 19 at Madison Square Garden, will feature Pitt, Texas, Maryland and Illinois, organizers said. Tickets go on sale Tuesday at noon and are available through Ticketmaster at (866) 448-7849 or Ticketmaster.com.

title: Speed Reading of DNA May Help Cancer Treatment
description: Researchers at Johns Hopkins University have developed a way to monitor the progress of a patients cancer treatment using a new technique for rapidly sequencing, or decoding, large amounts of DNA.

title: Defibrillators, 1948
description: Ventricular fibrillation  uncontrolled fluttering of the heart that can lead to death within minutes  was a phenomenon well known as early as 1850. In fact, it was known that an electric current could start these abnormal contractions in a healthy heart.

title: Sex Offender Offers to Speed Efforts to Move From Piedmont
description: The Bay City News reported Monday that James F. Donnelly, a convicted sex offender who is living in his sisters home near an elementary school in Piedmont, has told the local police that he is trying to speed the process of moving back into the home he owns in San Francisco.

title: CCMP Capital to Buy InfoGroup for $460 Million
description: The private equity firm CCMP Capital Advisors said Monday that it had agreed to buy the database provider InfoGroup for roughly $460 million cash, The Associated Press reports.

title: Infection Defense May Spur Alzheimers
description: For years, a prevailing theory has been that one of the chief villains in Alzheimers disease has no real function other than as a waste product that the brain never properly disposed of.

title: Culture Shock | A Taste of Japan Off the 405
description: I couldnt fly to Japan for the weekend. But from LAX, it was only a 10-minute drive to Torrance, Calif., which might be the next best thing. Home to the American subsidiaries of both Honda and Toyota, Torrance has thousands of Japanese residents. And now it has a hotel  the Miyako Hybrid  designed specifically for Japanese business travelers. (The hybrid in the name is meant to suggest that, like a hybrid car, the hotel is energy efficient.) By staying there, I hoped to recapture some of the excitement I felt during my first trip to Japan, in 1989, when I didnt want to sleep, lest I sacrifice a minute of exploring.

title: Iraq Election  Viewed From Basra, and Dubai
description: BASRA, IraqAfter the polls closed Sunday evening my brother Othello called me from Dubai, where he lives.

title: When a Scratch or a Nosebleed Turns Into a Flood
description: My friend Dr. Eileen Costello still remembers her terror at the baby who was brought into her office bleeding.

title: LuPone to Appear With City Ballet
description: Shes done Broadway, now its on to the ballet. On Monday, New York City Ballet announced that Patti LuPone will make her New York City Ballet debut in a new production of The Seven Deadly Sins as part of the companys 2011 spring season. The Tony-nominated director and choreographer Lynne Taylor-Corbett, who has previously choreographed two works for the company, Mercury in 1992 and Chiaroscuro in 1994, will create the new production. The Seven Deadly Sins, a sung ballet in seven scenes, was composed by Kurt Weill to a German libretto by Bertolt Brecht in 1933 and was first performed in Paris and produced, directed and choreographed by George Balanchine. The ballet features a character portrayed by both a singer and dancer. Ms. LuPone will play the singer; a dancer has yet to be announced. The original production featuring Lotte Lenya as the singer, and Tilly Losch as the dancer. Balanchine revived the work in 1958 with Allegra Kent in the role of the dancer. The schedule of performances and the rest of the 2011 spring season will be announced at a later date.

title: Cupcakes, Burgers and Stilettos at the Vanity Fair Party
description: Unlike the folks over at Gawker, the Bagger actually had a ticket to the Vanity Fair party on Sunday night. (Not trying to rub it in or anything; our night also ended at one of Los Angeless finer impound lots, where the employees didnt bat an eye at us showing up to collect our car in our Oscar gown. Love L.A.)

title: Fiorina Files for Senate and Gets Slammed
description: Updated Even as Carly Fiorina officially filed papers on Monday to run in the Republican primary for the Senate seat held by Barbara Boxer, the Democratic incumbent, Ms. Fiorina faced a broadside from a Packard relative whos supporting a rival.

title: Advertisement for Premium Saltines
description: This Canadian commercial is the basis for the new Premium Saltines campaign in the United States.

title: The Cultural Tides of Far Rockaway
description: The struggling congregation at St. Mary Star of Sea Church in Queens has been revived by the immigrant population.

title: Vazquez Sharp in Spring Debut
description: TAMPA, Fla.  One pitch into Mondays game and the Phillies led. Jimmy Rollins hit a fastball from Javier Vazquez high and deep over the right-field fence.

title: Fake Nostalgia for a Pre-Therapy Past
description: Old Gus sat on his customary bar stool in the corner, tossing down the bourbon and tossing out the barbs.

title: The Cultural Tides of Far Rockaway
description: Since the 1960s, the 152-year-old parish of St. Mary Star of the Sea has come to embody the cultural shifts in Far Rockaway, Queens, caused by new waves of Catholic immigrants.

title: Before Children Saw Therapists
description: Before therapists and medication, were kids better off working out mental health problems for themselves?

title: A Setting Sun?
description: Puertollanos brief solar boom has turned bust, pointing to the delicate policy calculations needed to stimulate nascent solar industries and create green jobs.

title: Model-morphosis | Giambattista Valli
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Joan Smalls from IMG Model Management before (top, bottom) and after makeup by Val Garland and hair by Orlando Pita. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

title: The Long and Short of Shostakovich, and Jazzy Ravel
description: Both the concise and the verbose sides of Shostakovich were represented on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, where Vladimir Jurowski conducted the London Philharmonic Orchestra in Five Fragments and the Symphony No. 4.

title: Muscular Renditions of Bach, Schubert and Debussy
description: The French cellist Jean-Guihen Queyras has made appealing recordings for Harmonia Mundi and other labels, including two collaborations with the inventive, sometimes idiosyncratic pianist Alexandre Tharaud. The two players are in many ways kindred spirits, and on Sunday afternoon Mr. Queyras made his New York recital debut at the Frick Collection, with Mr. Tharaud accompanying him.

title: The Academy Smiles With Both Faces
description: This article was reported by Brooks Barnes, Michael Cieply and Melena Ryzik and written by Mr. Barnes.

title: Police Kill Man Holding Fake Gun
description: A police officer shot and killed a 22-year-old man who pointed what appeared to be a gun at the officer outside of a public school near Gerritsen Beach in Brooklyn on Monday, according to the police. The police later said the man was holding an imitation pistol.

title: Madison Avenue's Moon Shot
description: Selected aviation industry advertisements that revisit a time when outer space reigned.

title: After Cancer, Removing a Healthy Breast
description: For decades, advocates have fought to protect women from disfiguring breast cancer surgery, arguing that it was just as effective to remove only the cancerous tissue rather than the whole breast.

title: Reaching for the Stars When Space Was a Thrill
description: It was  Mad Men  meets  Flash Gordon.

title: Pondering Good Faith in Publishing
description: Book publishers have long seen themselves as the gatekeepers of literary culture. But when theyre not looking, the truth has a way of being left at the door.

title: Interpreters Fate in a Broken Afghanistan
description: This film is selected as a Critics' Pick.

title: Photos of the Moment | Le Backstage
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: J.J. Putz: No Hard Feelings for the Mets
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  There was a sight here on Monday that Mets fans had hoped to see often last season: J.J. Putz pitching a scoreless inning. He did it for his new team, the Chicago White Sox, who signed him for $3 million in December.

title: From the Limn Company, an Old-School Affirmation
description: Throughout the 2009-10 season, the 92nd Street Y has been celebrating 75 years of showcasing dance. Those 75 years have made it the oldest institution in the United States to be presenting dance in the same location, and they are years in which the choreographers Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey, Charles Weidman, Hanya Holm, Jos Limn, Pearl Lang, Katherine Dunham, Agnes de Mille, Erick Hawkins, Jerome Robbins, Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor, Alvin Ailey and Anna Sokolow have worked there.

title: Surgeon Questions Care of Rodriguez by Doctor Under Investigation
description: A Toronto-based doctor under investigation for possibly distributing performance-enhancing drugs in the United States told The Associated Press on Monday that he treated Alex Rodriguez for an inflamed hip last year.

title: Revealed: The Secrets of the Handsome Mens Club
description: However you felt about the comic sensibilities of the Academy Awards ceremony itself, youd have to be a sourpuss on the order of George Clooney not to have enjoyed the Jimmy Kimmel Live episodethat immediately followed the Oscars, especiallythe skit in which Mr. Kimmel finds himself the leader of a cabalistic group called the Handsome Mens Club.

title: Building Safer, but Cheaply, in Quake Zones
description: That a modest earthquake in eastern Turkey on Monday took dozens of lives (probably many more than todays estimates) speaks to the importance of basic information on safer construction for masons, mayors and builders in seismic hot zones in rural regions as well as fast-growing cities.

title: General Growth May Tap Investors for $4 Billion
description: 9:38 p.m. | Updated General Growth Properties confirmed receiving a proposal from Fairholme and Pershing in a statement Monday evening.

title: Backstage Beauty | High-Brow Makeup
description: The eyebrow moved into view as a beauty focal point during the spring 2009 shows: models at Marni had theirs filled in with mauve powder and punctuated with a bold, brown line, while at Diesel Black Gold, brows were painted blue. Next came the bleached-brow craze of fall 2009, which, while not an office-appropriate look, probably generated a spike in the sales of Jolen Crme Bleach. This spring is clearly time to put down the tweezers, thanks to the likes of Alexander Wang, whose models sported thick brows scored with pencil. And looking ahead to fall 2010, the brow is bolder than ever, whether aggressive or playful.

title: Her Thoroughly Modern Music Inspired by Gospel and Opera
description: The theater composer Jeanine Tesori is such an artful chameleon that an audience unfamiliar with her work would be hard pressed to connect her disparate musical styles to the same hand. What do the zippy ersatz-1920s show tunes of Thoroughly Modern Millie have in common with the pre-Motown and New Orleans-flavored proto-funk of Caroline, or Change? And how are these connected to the high-gloss style of her songs from Shrek the Musical? The short answer is that theyre not really.

title: Why So Many Superheroes Are Drawn to New York
description: Theres a cool-sounding panel in Midtown Tuesday evening on New York City as character, inspiration and player in the universe of superhero comics. Its called New York, the Super-City. We asked the moderator, Peter Gutirrez, to pick a few images and say a few words.

title: Womens Day at the White House
description: President Obama, invoking the marital dictum that a husband will never get in trouble for saying that his wife is smarter, honored International Womens Day on Monday by, first of all, poking fun at himself.

title: David Foster Wallace Papers Go to University of Texas
description: The private papers of the writer David Foster Wallace, who committed suicide at 46 in 2008, have been acquired by the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin. The archive contains drafts of books, stories, essays, poems, letters and research, including the handwritten notes for Infinite Jest, the novel that first gained him attention. There is also a copy of his dictionary, in which he circled words, and heavily annotated copies of books by Don DeLillo, Cormac McCarthy, John Updike and others. Mr. Wallaces writing journal, which includes personal reflections, story ideas, names and plots, as well as articles on boredom, tax shelters and credit-card fraud are also included. As part of the deal, Mr. Wallaces publisher, Little, Brown and Company, is donating editorial files related to the author. Material for The Pale King, the novel that is being assembled posthumously by Mr. Wallaces editor, will be sent to the center after the books scheduled publication in the spring of 2011.

title: Bright Start for Maine
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Working with a strict limit of 40 pitches, the right-hander John Maine threw only 1 2-3 innings in the Mets 11-2 victory over the Marlins on Monday. After he threw his 39th pitch, he was taken out to ensure the health of his shoulder, but Manager Jerry Manuel said he was delighted with the effort.

title: Harry Reid Makes It Official: Hes Running
description: For all the headaches of running the United States Senate, the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, wants to keep his job.

title: Fish Soup and Bad Weather, Across the Decades
description: The forecast is continually gloomy in When the Rain Stops Falling, a sorrow-sodden family drama by Andrew Bovell that opened on Monday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. Nobody in Mr. Bovells time-skipping saga, sensitively directed by David Cromer (Our Town), is ever far from an umbrella, making this Lincoln Center Theater production entirely apposite for the citys long, strange and soggy winter.

title: A View From the Bridge Recoups Investment
description: Updated The critically acclaimed Broadway revival of A View From the Bridge, starring Liev Schreiber and Scarlett Johansson, has recouped its entire initial investment of $2.3 million, the producers announced on Monday afternoon.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Scorecard | Lanvin Wins!
description: Cue: lighting, thunder and a cavalcade of libertine equestrians. This is Paris, folks, where fashion is performance  so far be it for John Galliano to forgo an opportunity for a bit of costume drama. Yet while Scorecord knows the Christian Dior designer had critics convinced that his redingotes looked positively Regency-era, the Lanvin auteur Alber Elbaz quietly staged an Out of Africa moment on Friday that was at once authentically tribal-chic  and modern.

title: Covering Little Ears (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Variety Lays Off Two Critics in an Overhaul
description: Todd McCarthy, Varietys chief film critic, and David Rooney, its chief theater critic, lost their jobs on Monday amid a broad reorganization and staff cuts at the entertainment industry trade paper.

title: Toyota Says Its Repairs Work, Done Properly
description: Toyota said on Monday that some cases of sudden unintended acceleration still occurring in vehicles that had been repaired might have been the result of fixes being done incorrectly.

description: To the Editor:

title: Minimalism, and Plenty of It
description: Paris

title: House Democrat Says Party Drove Him From Office
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Eric J. Massa, a Democrat from upstate New York accused of sexually harassing a male aide, charged in a radio interview over the weekend that Democratic Party leaders were behind an effort to drive him out of office and that the White House chief of staff was the son of the devils spawn.

title: Democrats Choose Nominee for Murtha Seat
description: Mark Critz, who served on the staff of Representative John P. Murtha of Pennsylvania, is set to be the Democratic nominee in the May 18 special election to replace Mr. Murtha.

title: Hurt Capital of New York Wins No Oscar
description: As the clock slipped past midnight and turned into Monday in the East, the producers of The Hurt Locker accepted their richly earned Academy Award for best picture.

title: A $15.2 Million Week for Broadway
description: Broadway box offices grossed a total of $15.2 million last week, a fairly typical performance for the first week of March as the spring theater season starts unfolding, according to show-by-show grosses provided by the producers on Monday.

title: The 2007 Burgundies Pose a Puzzle for the Experts
description: IN the hierarchy of recent vintages of red Burgundy, few will place 2007 among the elite. On first glance the wines seem too pale, too light, maybe even a trifle diluted. Fans of dense, powerful pinot noirs packed with fruit flavors may well wave off the 07s with barely a glance and a sip.

title: European Activists Sue Over Biofuels Studies
description: Environmental lawyers and activists on Monday sued the European Commission for failing to release studies investigating the impact of biofuels on the environment.

title: What Were Reading: Conans Twitter Buddy and New York in Pixels
description: Mondays roundup of interesting items from around the Web, selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times:

title: The Anonymous, the Rediscovered and the Camouflaged
description: Paris

title: An Awards Show in Fast Forward
description: LOS ANGELES  So while the ratings were good for the Oscar telecast  the best since 2005, in the days before we could distract ourselves by Twittering through the boring parts  the reviews were not so kind. Though the hosts, Alec Baldwin and Steve Martin, got decent marks as personalities, their material, except for a parody of Paranormal Activity, was deemed stiffer than a Botox joke. Hosting the show is an odd experience because youre out there, but it isnt about you, Mr. Baldwin wrote on The Huffington Post.

title: Shower of Aid Brings Flood of Progress
description: SAURI, Kenya  In the past five years, life in this bushy little patch of western Kenya has improved dramatically.

title: Sony Ericsson Extends Deal as WTA Lead Sponsor to 2012
description: The Sony Ericsson WTA Tour said Monday that Sony Ericsson would remain the tours lead sponsor for two more years, the latest in a string of high-profile deals that suggest the market for sports sponsorships is thawing.

title: Yankees Gamble on Nick Johnson
description: TAMPA, Fla.  For someone who has sprained his right wrist, strained his left wrist, injured his right hand, strained his back, fractured his cheekbone, bruised his heel, broke his femur, damaged the tendon sheath in his right wrist and strained his right hamstring, Nick Johnson does not consider himself unlucky. Go to Las Vegas with him, and youll see.

title: New Trial Granted in 5 Murders in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  Throwing out what had been a trophy verdict for the district attorneys office, a judge here on Monday granted a new trial for a man who was convicted last summer of killing five people in 2006.

title: After the Iraqi Elections
description: Anthony Shadid and Stephen Farrell discuss Sunday's vote and what it says about the current health of Iraq's political system and the country's future.

title: Hand-Me-Down Memories? Not Here
description: AROUND the time I graduated from college, my parents sold the house I grew up in. It came as a shock to me to learn that my bedroom, which I had always assumed would be preserved for future generations to visit  sort of like a Presidential library with a Bobby Sherman poster on one wall  was being dismantled.

title: Paterson Finds Friends at a Forum on the Budget
description: When Gov. David A. Paterson goes out in public these days, the questions he typically faces from the news media are about resignation (Are you stepping down, governor?) or the various legal and ethical inquiries shadowing him (Did you violate your oath to uphold the law, governor?).

title: Mejia Continues to Impress
description: JUPITER, Fla.  If anyone is looking for signs indicating that 20-year-old Jenrry Mejia will indeed be the Mets eighth-inning setup man, Manager Jerry Manuel might have found them Monday.

title: Justices to Hear Case of Protest at Marine Funeral
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether the father of a Marine killed in Iraq may sue protesters who picketed his sons funeral with signs that read God Hates You and Thank God for Dead Soldiers.

title: Brought to U.S., Man Is Charged With Aiding Somali Terrorists
description: A man has been brought to the United States from Nigeria to face charges that he provided money to a Somali terrorist group  and that he received military training from that group.

title: Unions to Rally to Build Towers at Ground Zero
description: The citys construction unions plan to hold a lunchtime rally at ground zero on Tuesday in an effort to break the deadlock between the Port Authority and the developer Larry A. Silverstein over building speculative office space on the 16-acre site.

title: For Marketers, a Different Set of Oscar Winners
description: IT is rare to see an actress on the Oscar red carpet wearing her gown from the previous year. Why, then, were there so many retreads among the commercials that appeared on Sunday during the ABC coverage of the 82nd annual Academy Awards?

title: Putting Google to the Test in Translation
description: Google has poured resources into improving its automatic translation service. Here are some quick comparisons of human translations and computerized versions from Google and two competitors.

title: Berlins Airport: Shining Beacon or Waste of Money
description: BERLIN  To get Berliners arguing, bring up the new $3.4 billion airport rising just beyond the limits of this hip but economically strapped metropolis.

title: The Maestro of Weekend Meal Delivery
description: Mark Goreczny, 23, respects his elders  all 17,713 of them. They are too frail or disabled to walk to the grocery store, too poor to order takeout, so Mr. Goreczny makes sure they get a free hot meal delivered to their door on weekends and holidays and during emergencies like blizzards, when the city governments weekday meal delivery program shuts down. As the program officer for the nonprofit group Citymeals-on-Wheels, Mr. Goreczny is a kind of postmaster of chow, helping to coordinate a complex delivery system that pauses for neither snow, nor rain, nor his friends weekend plans.

title: Googles Computing Power Refines Translation Tool
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  In a meeting at Google in 2004, the discussion turned to an e-mail message the company had received from a fan in South Korea. Sergey Brin, a Google founder, ran the message through an automatic translation service that the company had licensed.

title: Region Unimpressed by Balloting in Iraq
description: CAIRO  Elections across this region have long been viewed as not much more than window dressing to tidy up the image of authoritarian leaders and absolute monarchs eager for greater legitimacy.

title: Video: Iraq Elections, Voting for the Future
Critics' Picks: 'Aliens'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at James Cameron's 1986 film about a group of Marines landing on a planet infested with hostile alien creatures.

title: Budget Boogeyman Stalks New Yorks Summer Camps
description: It took a rainy day and the right job to show Christopher Rivera, then a 16-year-old who lived in a public housing complex on the Lower East Side, that he had something to say, and that when he said it people might actually listen.

title: Mexico Oil Politics Keeps Riches Just Out of Reach
description: VENUSTIANO CARRANZA, Mexico  To the Mexican people, one of the great achievements in their history was the day their president kicked out foreign oil companies in 1938. Thus, they celebrate March 18 as a civic holiday.

title: Womens Soccer League Stays Optimistic
description: Year 2 of the Womens Professional Soccer league began with the opening of preseason training camps last weekend. The regular season opens April 10.

title: The Source of Obamas Trouble
description: The Obama administration and Democrats in general are in trouble because they are not urgently and effectively addressing the issue that most Americans want them to: the frightening economic insecurity that has put a chokehold on millions of American families.

title: Ignominious Streak Nears an End
description: Hawks guard Jamal Crawford is preparing to finally shed the N.B.A.s scarlet letter. Crawford, an adept scorer who causes few locker-room problems, seems to be an unlikely person to hold the leagues longest current streak of playing in the most games without appearing in the playoffs.

title: Uganda: Rains Displace Thousands
description: More than 10,000 people have been displaced and hundreds of thousands put at risk in eastern Uganda as torrential rains continue after fatal mudslides swept away villages near the Kenyan border last week. The confirmed death toll from the mudslides has risen to 104, and more than 300 people are presumed dead.

title: Public Pension Funds Are Adding Risk to Raise Returns
description: States and companies have started investing very differently when it comes to the billions of dollars they are safeguarding for workers retirement.

title: Senate Panel to Investigate Deaths at Long-Term Care Facilities
description: The Senate Finance Committee has opened an investigation into patient deaths and allegations of substandard treatment at long-term care hospitals, small specialty medical centers that treat chronically ill patients.

title: In Jury Selection for Hate Crime, a Struggle to Find Tolerance
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Over the last several days, Justice Robert W. Doyle has heard the typical excuses from potential jurors. One woman mentioned her husbands medical problems. Another woman complained about her back.

title: The Dark Side of Home Subsidies
description: Home ownership in the United States ranks up there with motherhood and apple pie. The government has championed it for decades through tax breaks, mortgage guarantees and, most recently, the herculean task of keeping Americans in their homes after the housing market collapse. But government subsidies of the American Dream also have a darker side: when things head south, taxpayers end up stuck with the costs.

title: Experts Urge Keeping Two Options for Terror Trials
description: WASHINGTON  Leading Congressional Republicans are arguing that getting tough on terrorism means trying all foreign terrorism suspects before military commissions. But national security officials who served in the Bush administration say that taking away the criminal justice option would weaken the governments hand.

title: A Nonfrivolous Suit
description: Supporters of tort reform  and late-night comedians  like to make fun of what they say are frivolous lawsuits. One they particularly like to lampoon is the case of the woman who sued McDonalds after she was scalded by too-hot coffee. What they dont talk much about is just how hot the coffee was or that the 79-year-old woman was hospitalized with severe injuries. The two sides ultimately settled.

title: Solar Industry Learns Lessons in Spanish Sun
description: PUERTOLLANO, Spain  Two years ago, this gritty mining city hosted a brief 21st-century gold rush. Long famous for coal, Puertollano discovered another energy source it had overlooked: the relentless, scorching sun.

title: New Plan for Mall Operator to Exit Bankruptcy
description: The largest shareholder and the largest unsecured creditor in the mall operator General Growth Properties intend to enhance the companys reorganization plan to emerge from bankruptcy as an independent company, the company confirmed Monday night.

title: Texas Instruments Raises View on Profit
description: Texas Instruments, the chip maker, said on Monday that profit and sales in its current quarter would be at the high end of its forecasts, helped by increasing demand for phone systems and industrial machinery.

title: Defending the Dolphins
description: When "The Cove" won the Oscar for best documentary on Sunday, the star of the film and dolphin activist Ric O'Barry held up a sign while the producer, Fisher Stevens, was giving his acceptance speech. It read "Text Dolphin to 44144," which automatically signs people up to receive information about the fight against the dolphin hunting practices in a Japanese village, on which the film is based. Tonight you can learn more about the issue at Asia Society where the documentary will be shown. A panel discussion will follow the screening with Louie Psihoyos and Mr. O'Barry, and moderated by New York Times reporter Andrew C. Revkin.

title: Chaos of War
description: "With 'The Surrendered,'" writes Michiko Kakutani, "Chang-rae Lee has written the most ambitious and compelling novel of his already impressive career  a symphonic work that reprises the themes of identity, familial legacies and the imperatives of fate he has addressed in earlier works, but which he grapples with here on a broader, more intricate historical canvas." The backdrop is the chaos of the Korean War and Mr. Lee chronicles the "cruel, heartbreaking events of war with harrowing, cinematic immediacy, making palpable the excruciating violence and the huge footprint it leaves on people's lives." Tonight, the author will be at Barnes & Noble on Broadway and 66th Street.

title: Breaking Through
description: "'The Temperamentals,' Jon Marans's eminently likable docudrama about gay identity in the age of Eisenhower, begins with a classic vision of mid-20th-century uniformity: five guys in off-the-peg suits, as anonymous as the standard-issue, metal-frame chairs on which they're seated," writes Ben Brantley. "Discovering what lurks beneath gray flannel is both the theme and the story-propelling engine of 'The Temperamentals,' which chronicles the creation of the Mattachine Society, the breakthrough gay-rights organization. And in Mr. Marans's play the journey to such knowledge is hardly (you should pardon the expression) a straight line." The characters in the drama, currently at New World Stages, are based on real people and "lovingly incarnated by a cast led by Thomas Jay Ryan and Michael Urie."

title: Shell Joins PetroChina in an Offer in Australia
description: Arrow Energy of Australia said Monday that it had received a takeover offer worth about $3 billion from a company owned by Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina, the government-run gas and oil giant.

title: Nascars Call for Aggressiveness Is Met by a Crash
description: In the midst of a ratings and attendance slump, Nascar went back to its bad-ol-boy roots this season in the hope that more aggressive driving would draw fans back to the sport. The message to the drivers before the start of the season was a simple one.

title: Throwing Exit-Row Seats Into the For Sale Bin
description: CONSIDER the exit-row seat, that prize catch of the frequent-flying business traveler because it offers extra legroom.

title: For Iraqi Voters, a Dizzying Democracy
description: Baghdad

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 8, 2010

title: For Lil Wayne, Third Sentencing Date Yields a Year at Rikers
description: The rapper Lil Wayne made his final public appearance as a free man for at least the next eight months on Monday afternoon, greeted by a chaotic scene in front of a Manhattan courthouse.

title: W.P.S. Optimistic After Its Off-Season Shuffling
description: Year 2 of the Womens Professional Soccer league began with the opening of preseason training camps last weekend. The regular season opens April 10.

title: Holder of a Title, Yes, but Not a Heisman
description: IM a former member of USA Boxings national team. I joined when I was 15 years old, and before that I never thought Id go anywhere. By the time I was 21, I had visited 23 countries. All that travel changes a person for the better.

title: In Chiles Capital, Damage Is Inside and Invisible
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  From outside, there is no sign that the century-old building where Cecilia Painaqueo lived with her four children was damaged by one of the strongest earthquakes ever recorded. But inside her second-floor apartment, the bedroom walls collapsed and the wooden ceiling buckled.

title: Feds Reach May Be Curbed Under Plan
description: Several high-ranking members of the Senate Banking Committee have reached a tentative consensus on a plan that would strip the Federal Reserve of regulatory powers over all but the very largest banks, those with more than $100 billion in assets, people briefed on the negotiations said on Monday night.

title: Canadian Doctor Brings a Sudden Chill to Yankees Carefree Spring
description: Bradenton, Fla.

title: State of the Ravens: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Frank Williams, Architect of Skyscrapers, Dies at 73
description: Frank Williams, an architect whose sleek towers incorporating crisp geometric shapes in many of their facades made a significant mark on the New York skyline, died on Feb. 25 in Manhattan. He was 73.

title: Oscar Winners Try to Keep Whale Off Sushi Plates
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  It is sport among black belt sushi eaters here to see just how daring ones palate can be. But even among the squid-chomping, roe-eating and uni-nibbling fans, whale is almost unheard of on the plate. It also happens to be illegal.

title: The Big Easts Big Spenders? Just Check Out the Standings
description: When the mens Big East Conference tournament expanded to 16 teams last year, the prevailing notion was that the move would give coaches a shot to save their jobs and allow players a chance, albeit an unlikely one, at a charmed five-day run for an N.C.A.A. tournament bid.

title: 11 Down: Chewy Confection
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  We have another guest solver with us today  Joon Pahk, a physics teacher at Harvard and the division B* champion at the recent American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. His comments appear at the end of the post.

title: Bloggingheads: Money for Nothing
description: William D. Cohan, left, author of House of Cards and a contributing columnist to The New York Times, and John Gillespie, author of Money for Nothing, discuss the mismanagement of corporate boards.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Monday with an article about the turnover by Myanmars military junta of state-owned assets to private businesses misidentified a junta member shown in the center of the photograph as he greeted U Tay Za, a Myanmar businessman who may benefit from the privatization. He is Maj. Gen. Thein Swe, the transport minister, not Senior Gen. Than Shwe, the top leader, who was not in the photograph.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 27 about rising thefts of oysters along the Atlantic coast in France misstated the size of the Ernea II, the boat that French gendarmes were using to patrol the oyster beds along Arachon Bay. It was 10 meters long, not 11 feet.

title: Do You Miss Him Yet?
description: I know youre not supposed to, but I just love to say I told you so.

title: So Wheres Consumer Protection?
description: If six of the biggest banking industry lobbying groups are in perfect lockstep on an issue, do they most likely have the best interests of consumers at heart?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Saturday with an article about the gunman who opened fire on Thursday at an entrance to the Pentagon, wounding two police officers before he was killed by the police, misstated, in some editions, the surname of the chief of the Pentagon Force Protection Agency. He is Richard Keevill, not Keevil.

title: District Attorney Blames Greed in Fatal Crane Collapse
description: As the owner of a New York City crane company pleaded not guilty to manslaughter charges on Monday, several lawyers said it was rare for a company owner to face such serious charges in connection with a fatal accident.

title: Critics Picks Video: Aliens
description: Long before there were Navi, there was Aliens. A. O. Scott looks back at James Camerons 1986 science fiction film that explored imperialism and gender politics, among other themes. Mr. Scott calls the films main character, Ripley (Sigourney Weaver), a manifestation of Mr.Camerons improbable but undeniable feminist streak. Please share your thoughts on Aliens. Do you prefer it to Avatar?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a wraparound ad in The Los Angeles Times that simulated a front page misidentified the post held by Geneva Overholser, who commented on the ad. She is director of the journalism school at the Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism at the University of Southern California, not director of the overall school, which is led by a dean.

title: Record Win for UConn; Moral One for the Irish
description: HARTFORD  Notre Dame was within 10 points of Connecticut with less than four minutes to play Monday, which qualifies as a real barnburner for the Huskies. An uneasy buzz began to swirl inside XL Center.

title: Police Kill Man Carrying a Fake Gun at a School
description: A 22-year-old man was fatally shot by the police outside a Brooklyn elementary school on Monday afternoon after he pointed a fake gun at an officer, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday referred imprecisely to the character in Inglourious Basterds played by Christoph Waltz, who won the award for best supporting actor. The Nazi officer he plays speaks four languages, not two. In some copies the article also misstated part of a comment by Ben Stiller, who wore makeup to appear like a Navi in Avatar when he presented the award for best makeup. He said that it seemed like a better idea in rehearsal, not at the time.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about Baylor University center Brittney Griner, who was suspended for two games for punching Jordan Barncastle of Texas Tech in a womens basketball game on Wednesday, may have left an incorrect impression. Although it showed the two players involved in the altercation, it was from a different game, on Feb. 17.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about the architect Raimund Abraham misidentified the location of one of his homes. It is in Mazunte, Mexico, not Mexico City.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Chart on Sunday, about the use of reconciliation to pass bills, misidentified the majority party in Congress in 1997. The Republicans controlled both houses, not the Democrats.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Suicide Raises Legal Issues in Indian Artifacts Cases
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Every persons life is a mix of the things revealed and unrevealed, secrets spilled or kept. Ted Gardiner, who committed suicide last week, was no exception.

title: Pierre Is Again a Starter, Ready to Face the Doubters
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Every morning in spring training, Chone Figginss alarm clock wakes him up at 5:30. And every morning at the same time, he hears the garage door open and his roommate, Juan Pierre, leave for work. So when does Pierre wake up?

title: State Insurance Experts See Flaw in Obamas Plan to Curb Health Premiums
description: WASHINGTON  At the heart of President Obamas drive to rein in health costs is a proposal for federal review and regulation of health insurance premiums, with a new agency empowered to block excessive rate increases.

title: Loose Ends From Tampa (and Bradenton)
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Joe Girardi met with reporters in his office after Mondays 7-5 victory against Philadelphia, he hadnt yet heard the result from the split-squad game against the Pirates. Told that four pitchers had combined to throw a one-hitter, Girardis first words were: I hope we won. Did we win?

title: Obama Plans Florida Forum to Discuss NASAs Future
description: President Obama will spell out his vision for the future of American astronauts in space at a conference that the administration is planning for Florida next month.

title: A Milestone for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqis Vote
description: Final results from Iraqs parliamentary election may not be available for days, but this much we can already say for sure: Iraqs citizens once again showed tremendous courage and determination, defying bombs and a flawed pre-election process to cast their ballots.

title: Television Is Not Free and Does Not Want to Be
description: The proliferation of free media on the Internet seems to have convinced an entire generation that the old hacker slogan from a quarter-century ago, information wants to be free, can be an organizing principle for the information economy of the future.

title: Voting-Machine Flaws and Paper Ballots
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Absence of Health Care Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: The Emotion of Reform
description: We all have our emotional hot and cold spots. If you asked me about the New York Mets, youd see a glow in my eyes. If you asked me about banking reform, words might come out of my mouth, but youd notice me nodding off midsentence.

title: Healthy Solution: Taxing Sodas
description: Seldom does one idea help fix two important problems, but a proposal to tax sugary soft drinks in New York State is just that sort of 2-for-1 solution. The penny-per-ounce tax on sodas and other sweetened drinks is a way to raise desperately needed money for the city and state in a bad economy. It also could help lower obesity rates, which have soared in recent years.

title: Hawks Johnson, Free Agent to Be, Lurks as a Prize Without the Hype
description: Joe Johnson wonders what if. The course of the N.B.A. might have been altered when he broke an orbital bone near his left eye in the playoffs five years ago.

title: Siena Rallies to Capture Third Straight MAAC Title
description: ALBANY  Fairfield Coach Ed Cooley did not hesitate when he was asked about the daunting task of playing top-seeded Siena on its home court in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament championship game.

title: Man Killed and Girl Hurt in Shooting Outside a Grocery
description: A 24-year-old man was killed and a 10-year-old girl was wounded in the arm in a shooting outside a grocery store in Brooklyn on Monday night, the authorities said.

title: Obama Turns Up the Volume
description: President Obama challenged wavering members of his party on Monday not to give in to political fears about supporting health care legislation, asserting that the urgency of getting a bill through Congress should trump any concern about the consequences for Democrats in November.

title: Letters Capture Grief for President Kennedy
description: BOSTON  Days after President John F. Kennedy was killed, Dr. Ira Seiler sat at his desk and wrote a letter of condolence to his widow, Jacqueline Kennedy.

title: Even Orphanages Spawn Orphans in Haiti
description: Photographer Lynsey Addario has spent most of the last 10 years photographing major conflicts and humanitarian crisis, but she hesitated to go to Haiti immediately after the earthquake.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,002 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Nan Martin, an Actress Known for Her Strong Roles, Dies at 82
description: Nan Martin, a veteran stage, television and film actress whose Broadway credits include J.B. and Under the Yum-Yum Tree and who played Ali McGraws snooty mother in the film Goodbye, Columbus, died on Thursday at her home in Malibu, Calif. She was 82.

title: Fiorentina Wins, but Bayern Munich Is Through
description: 5:07 p.m. |Fiorentina Wins, but Bayern Advances

title: Dr. Barton Childs, Who Studied Inherited Diseases, Is Dead at 93
description: Dr. Barton Childs, a founder of pediatric genetics and an important contributor to the understanding of inherited diseases, died on Feb. 18. He was 93, lived in Baltimore, and taught at Johns Hopkins University for nearly 70 years until shortly before his death at its hospital.

title: General Managers Mull Ban on Some Hits to Head
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  The N.H.L. general managers opened their annual meeting Monday leaning toward recommending a rule change that would penalize some hits to the head deemed legal under current rules.

title: K-Rod Returns to Camp
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez returned to work Monday after being partly quarantined with conjunctivitis in both eyes. Rodriguez contracted the illness more than three weeks ago, when he was home in Venezuela, but could not completely shake it, he said, until this past weekend.

title: Netherlands: New Building for World Court
description: The International Criminal Court on Monday unveiled the design for its new headquarters, a sprawling campus of six buildings on the outskirts of The Hague. The Dutch government has donated the land, the former site of military barracks, and the member countries of the court are to share the estimated $125 million cost. The worlds first permanent criminal court is expected to move from its current buildings in 2015. A Danish firm, Schmidt, Hammer, Lassen, one of three finalists, won the design competition, which had drawn 171 entries from around the world.

title: News Quiz | March 9, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Good News for Cervelli
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Francisco Cervelli, who sustained his second concussion in four months Saturday when he was hit in the head by a pitch, was cleared Monday by the Yankees medical staff to resume physical activity. Cervelli was examined Monday by a neurologist, and all testing came back clean, the Yankees said.

title: Public Pension Funds Are Adding Risk to Raise Returns
description: States and companies have started investing very differently when it comes to the billions of dollars they are safeguarding for workers retirement.

description: WHO is Vice President Biden meeting with this week in the Middle East?

title: Bidding War Pits Pfizer Against Teva
description: The executives at some generic drug companies have a new catchphrase: Theres no place like Ulm. Theres no place like Ulm.

description: collateral \k-la-t(-)rl\ noun and adjective

title: Photos of the Moment | NY NY Party in Paris
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: So Wheres Consumer Protection?
description: The fate of the proposed consumer protection agency remains the biggest question mark in the proposed overhaul of the finance industry, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: Former Deutsche Trader May Soon Open a Fund
description: A former Deutsche Bank executive is planning to start a hedge fund that would capitalize on mispriced securities in the Asian equity and credit markets, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

title: China Airline Plans $1.6 Billion Share Issue
description: Shares in China Southern Airlines jumped to a 21-month high on Tuesday after the company announced plans to raise as much as 10.75 billion renminbi ($1.57 billion) through the issue of new shares in Shanghai and Hong Kong to repay its debts, news services reported.

title: Trenta
description: Starbucks new 31-ounce cup for iced coffee and tea, named after the Italian for thirty.

title: Sanofi and Merck Announce Animal Health Venture
description: Two of the worlds biggest pharmaceutical companies said Tuesday they are uniting their animal health businesses in a deal to become the top dog in the veterinary industry, The Associated Press reported.

title: Carlyle Taps Ex-Morgan Stanley Trading Chief
description: 8:01 a.m. | Updated The Carlyle Group confirmed on Tuesday that it has hired Michael Petrick, Morgan Stanleys former chief of trading and sales and known as Mitch, as its global head of credit alternatives and capital markets, a new position that will oversee 24 funds and $19 billion in assets.

title: DoubleVerify Pockets $10 Million
description: DoubleVerify, an online advertisement monitor, has nabbed $10 million in a second round of funding led by Institutional Venture Partners, PaidContent reported.

title: Tough Times for Venture Capitalists?
description: It seems that investors arent showing venture capital firms the money.

title: China Steps Toward the Dollar, Away From Gold
description: China, the worlds biggest holder of foreign exchange reserves, renewed its commitment to the U.S. Treasury market on Tuesday but said it would be wary of substantially boosting its gold holdings.

title: A Boost for Contingent-Capital Deals?
description: Ever since the financial crisis struck, regulators the world over have argued for an overhaul of bank capital. So-called contingent capital, which can absorb losses while keeping a bank in business, was promoted as a solution in the United States and elsewhere.

title: Six Flagss C.F.O. Takes Stand in Bankruptcy Battle
description: Six Flags put its chief financial officer on the stand to defend its reorganization plan against attacks by some bondholders, with ownership of the theme park company at stake, Reuters reported.

title:
As Biden Visits,
Israel Unveils Plan for New Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  Hours after Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. vowed unyielding American support for Israels security here on Tuesday, Israels Interior Ministry announced 1,600 new housing units for Jews in East Jerusalem. Mr. Biden condemned the move as precisely the kind of step that undermines the trust we need right now.

title: Hesitation on Wall Street Leaves Shares Flat
description: Lacking a clear consensus about the strength of the recovery, Wall Street fell into a seesaw pattern on Monday.

title: Showcase: A Quiet Bridge to Young Victims
description: When shes at work, Mariella Furrer sits on the floor. She doesnt move, and rarely speaks.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Caps Finally Lose at Home
description: Two games on Monday, including the Capitals trying to extend their club-record home winning streak to 15 against a Dallas side that has lost all three games since the Olympic break. Home teams listed first:

title: Leibovitz Said to Sign Deal With Colony Capital
description: The celebrity photographer Annie Leibovitz has arranged a deal with a private equity firm to sort out her debts, The Financial Times reported.

title: Where Do You Stand on Unconcealed Handguns?
description: Lately, the debate over gun control and the rights afforded by the Second Amendment have focused on the specific issue of unconcealed weapons. What do you think about the open-carry movement?

title: Microchip Tech Raises Bid for Silicon Storage
description: Microchip Technology on Monday raised its purchase price for Silicon Storage for the second time, in a move to trump a competing bid from a private-equity firm for the maker of flash memory cards used in digital cameras and MP3 players, The Associated Press reported.

title: The Film Department Cuts I.P.O.
description: The Film Department Holdings cut the size of its planned initial public offering by 30 percent Monday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Liberty International Announces Split
description: Liberty International, Britains biggest shopping mall owner, said Tuesday that it was going ahead with a plan to split its portfolio into two separate listed companies, as it battles to bounce back from the worst property crash in decades, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Greenberg to Testify on A.I.G.s Gen Re Deal
description: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of theAmerican International Group, will testify on Wednesday over a sham transaction involving the insurer and a unit of Warren E. Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway, a judge ruled.

title: N.Y. Fed to Expand Firms for Reverse Repos
description: The United StatesFederal Reserve is taking an additional measure to lay the groundwork to drain excess bank reserves, as it seeks to remove some of the $1 trillion in cash it injected during the global credit crisis, Reuters reported.

title: Police Kill Bali Nightclub Bombing Suspect
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Counterterrorism forces have shot and killed one of Southeast Asias most-wanted Islamic militants, Indonesias president said Wednesday.

title: U.A.E. Government to Support Dubai
description: The United Arab Emirates finance minister said Tuesday that the federal government would support Dubai as it grapples with a $26 billion debt restructuring and expects the matter to be resolved soon, Reuters reported.

title: Betting on Atlanta
Alex Rioss Recovery From .199
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The neatest thing I saw at Mondays Mariners-White Sox game was second baseman Chone Figgins ranging up the middle, diving to spear a Juan Pierre grounder and whipping a throw to first for an out.

title: Under Glass: The Arcades of Paris
description: From the mid-19th century onward, as a wealthy middle-class discovered the joys of shopping, architects built a network of glass-roofed arcades  the Paris Galleries  on the edges of the vast central food market known as Les Halles.

title: Daimler Sells Stake in Tata Motors
description: Daimler says it has sold all of its shares in Indias Tata Motors to various groups of investors through the capital markets, The Associated Press reported.

title: Shanks Says It Ended Talks With Carlyle
description: Shares in the Shanks Group fell the most in nine years in London trading after the company reported the end of takeover talks with a fund managed by the United States leveraged-buyout firm Carlyle Group, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Doubts About Digital Natives
description: Todays idea: Assumptions about the rise of a cognitively different generation of digital natives may be wrong, an article says.

title: Krugman: An Irish Mirror for the Crisis
description: Everyone has a theory about the financial crisis, Paul Krugman writes in his latest Op-Ed piece in The New York Times. These theories range from the absurd to the plausible  from claims that liberal Democrats somehow forced banks to lend to the undeserving poor (even though Republicans controlled Congress) to the belief that exotic financial instruments fostered confusion and fraud. But what do we really know?

title: Q&A: Sweep Out Old System Restore Files
description: Q.

title: British Report Criticizes Initiative
description: Peter Mandelson, the British business secretary, has come under fire after a parliamentary committee released a report accusing his department of doling out more than 300 million ($448 million) to poorly performing venture capital funds, according to press reports.

title: Merkel and Juncker Take Swipe at Credit Default Swaps
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Tuesday that the European Commission may have to decide on whether and how to regulate credit default swaps, the derivatives that traders have been using to bet against the ability of certain European countries to pay their debt.

title: Paulson and Soros Like NovaGold
description: It seems that both John Paulson and George Soros have a good feeling about NovaGold Resources prospects.

title: YSL: Atonement
description: In one of his early collections for Saint Laurent, the designer Stefano Pilati worked Christian symbols into his clothes, including the outline of a cross in the back of a coat. So it wasnt surprising that people again saw religious references in his fall 2010 show: the many somber capes, yoked white blouses with full sleeves, the preponderance of black, hats that brought to mind a nuns cap, and the gold chains from which dangled a single figure (in fact, a silhouette of a woman). The press notes referred only to the protection elements in the show, most obviously the clear plastic rain covers over some of the tailored pieces. But, of course, religion is protection, too.

title: Kroll Auction Said to Draw P.E. Bids
description: Marsh & McLennan is shopping its Kroll corporate investigations unit, including to private equity firms like the Carlyle Group, Apax Partners and General Atlantic, The Financial Times reports, citing unnamed sources.
