description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, March 9
description: Here are some highlights from Tuesdays edition of The New York Times:

title: Euro Unity? Its Germany That Matters
description: Ten years after the euro, its still all about Germany, which isnt the way it was supposed to be, Celestine Bohlen of Bloomberg News writes in her latest column.

title: Red Pencils Ready?
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Red Pencils Ready?
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Samurai Shopper | Kiss and Makeup
description: Nicolas Degennes is a rock star. Hes not in a band, though he spends loads of time backstage. He does live gigs, but his only instruments are buckets of savoir-faire and a genius for innovation. Degennes is the artistic director of Givenchys Le Makeup. Hes the inventor of Phenomeneyes, that mold-breaking mascara with the mace-like, spiked applicator. He travels in very arty circles, and I bet he brings the house down wherever he goes. Women love him. Men love him, too. Its because he talks to people, not at them. He also listens, makes eye contact, smiles. Hes unaffected, un-jaded, un-snobby. For a Frenchman, this is nothing short of miraculous.

title: Regarding The Nose': An ArtsBeat Discussion
description: The Nose, an opera by Dmitri Shostakovich that had its premiere in Leningrad in 1930 and is based on a short story by Nikolai Gogol written in 1836, is one of the Metropolitan Operas new shows this season. As well as alchemy involving three different genres four if you include stagecraft  the production bridges three centuries. It has the added element of direction and co-design by the contemporary South African artist William Kentridge, which involves video animations and a fair bit of 21st-century technology.

title: Caution Rules as Major Indexes Inch Forward
description: On the one-year anniversary of the stock markets plunge to 12-year lows, Wall Street found itself at another crossroads. This time, the question for investors was not so much whether the economy would turn around, but just how strong a recovery would be.

title: Energy Department Defends Funding of Foreign-Owned Renewables Projects
description: Amid mounting criticism, the Energy Department last week defended its allocation of stimulus funding to foreign companies developing renewable energy projects in the United States.

title: Airline Luggage Went Unscanned in Denver
description: Denver airport officials say hundreds of bags were loaded onto airplanes in late December without being run through security scanners.

title: Election Reaction From Around Iraq
description: Full Coverage

title: Japan Says It Allowed U.S. Nuclear Ships to Port
description: TOKYO  Japan ended decades of denials on Tuesday by confirming the existence of secret cold war-era agreements with Washington that, among other things, had allowed American nuclear-armed warships to sail into Japanese ports in violation of Japans non-nuclear policies.

title: Jury Selection in L.I. Killing Raises Larger Issues
description: Jury selection in the case involving the killing of Marcelo Lucero, a 37-year-old Ecuadorean immigrant stabbed to death in November 2008 in Patchogue on Long Island, has brought up issues larger than the usual excuses to avoid jury duty.  Prospective jurors have repeatedly pointed to their views on Latino immigration to be dismissed from the case.

title: JetBlue and Delta Seek Exemption from Tarmac Time-Limit Rule
description: JetBlue and Delta want temporary exemptions from a new U.S. government rule that will limit the time passengers can be held on the tarmac. They say delays caused by the closure of the main runway at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York could cost them millions of dollars in fines.

title: Uproar in India Over Female Lawmaker Quota
description: NEW DELHI  The upper house of Indias Parliament passed a bill Tuesday that would amend the Constitution to reserve one-third of the seats in Indias national and state legislatures for women, after the measure stirred two days of political chaos that could whittle the governing coalitions majority to a dangerously thin margin.

title: Reporter Breaches Amsterdam Airports Security
description: PARIS  Dutch airport officials announced new security measures on Tuesday, after a Dutch investigative journalist reported smuggling a refilled liquor bottle through the heightened security checks at the airport where a young Nigerian boarded a flight for the United States on Dec. 25 with explosives in his underwear.

title: Europe Is Said to Close Debt Sales to Wall Street
description: European Union nations are shutting major Wall Street banks out of their debt sales, The Guardian reports. No large American bank ranks among the top nine leading the sales of sovereign bonds, according to data from Dealogic.

title: Googles Toolkit for Translators Helps Feed Its Machine
description: Te Taka Keegan, a university lecturer in New Zealand, is betting that Google can help him preserve the Maori language of his ancestors.

title: Early Word: The Push Continues
description: President Obama continued his fervent push to bring about a comprehensive overhaul of the health care system on Monday, traveling to suburban Philadelphia in the latest attempt to lobby skeptical Democrats.

title: Another View: Vice Chancellor Strine Gets It Right
description: Manan Shah and Benjamin M. Grossman, attorneys at Jones Day, argue that Delaware has a better legal approach to corporate governance and executive compensation than Washington.

title: Post-Oscars, Letterman Has His Own Elinor Burkett Moment
description: Congratulations, Elinor Burkett: youre not only an Academy Award recipient, youre also a running joke.

title: App of the Week: M.L.B.s Utility Player
description: Just in time for the first pitch, MLB.com has released its 2010 At Bat phone apps, with versions for the iPhone and BlackBerry Storm 1 and 2 and Android phones.

title: Icebergs at 11 OClock!
description: Paris is cold enough this week but Karl Lagerfeld decided to make it a bit colder this morning at Chanel with a misting set of icebergs seeming to float in an Arctic-blue sea. The setting was the Grand Palais, and the bergs were hidden from the audience under a huge wooden box that mechanically rose when the show started. It was a lavish production, needless to say, with classic tweeds, cute knits and thick fur chaps dragged through the enormous wading pool by the models. All the fur, by the way, was fake. Any comment about climate change and melting ice caps was probably unintended. The Ice Hotel in Sweden provided inspiration. When asked backstage if he had ever visited the hotel, Mr. Lagerfeld, dressed in a Dior peacoat and bleached jeans with a vintage Cartier stickpin in his black tie, shivered and said no.

title: In Defense of Up in the Air
description: The biggest loser Sunday night at the Oscars wasnt Avatar. It was Up in the Air, which was shut out in every category after looking like a shoo-in for a statuette when it first came out. The backlash against Jason Reitmans movie seemed to build steadily across the last couple months, and it took an interesting form: It attacked what seemed like the films greatest strengths, casting them as artistic liabilities instead.

title: Post-Oscars, Letterman Has His Own Elinor Burkett Moment
description: Congratulations, Elinor Burkett: youre not only an Academy Award recipient, youre also a running joke.

title: Now Wearing | Fashion Victims
description: Fashion doesnt get more vividly macabre than RP/Encores line of taxidermy accessories. The artist Reid Peppard makes ghoulish bow ties and pendants from an assortment of rodents and birds collected from the London streets by her cat, Panasonic, and other eagle-eyed friends. I get texts saying: Ive just found a dead pigeon on Old Street,  says the 23 year-old Californian, whose beastly collections have names like Vermin, Park and Pet. It takes chutzpah to wear my work, so most of my customers are men. Still, her creations have been commissioned for Lady Gaga, and the Balenciaga designer Nicolas Ghesquire has posted her work on his Facebook page. So next time youre on the checkout line, wear a bow tie with a dead mouse and watch the crowds part  it casts a whole new light on the term killer accessory.

title: Health Care Resurrection
With CR-Z, Honda Will Find Out if U.S. Is Ready for a Sporty Hybrid
description: Americans dont want sporty hybrids.

title: Greens Gain Nutrients in the Supermarket
description: This sounds too hilarious and ridiculous to be true, yet it appears to be so: spinach and other greens actually increase their nutrient levels in supermarkets, because photosynthesis continues even after harvest, and (of course) even under artificial light.

title: Ryan and the Zonkers
description: When I was in college, we sat around eating, among other things, Screaming Yellow Zonkers; they werent especially tasty, but the copy on the boxes was fun. Among the instruction was the Disappearing Zonkers Trick:

title: How We Got Everyone Focused on Cash Flow
description: In my last post I talked about how, every year, we pick a critical number or ratio to improve. This year, were focusing on cash flow. The idea is to pick a metric that weve been doing poorly on, compared with our competition, and turn it around. We do that by tying everyones bonus plan to our performance.

title: Second Pension Fund Sues Goldman Over Pay
description: Goldman Sachs Group was sued on Monday by a large union pension fund that accused the Wall Street investment bank of overpaying its executives, Reuters reported.

title: Quote Unquote | Shoulder Pads Optional
description: John Galliano defines style to Vogue UK. Well pass on the McDonalds. But the next time Tom Brady wears Manolo Blahniks we will be the first to tune in.

title: Congo Dam Projects Evolve and Draw Critics
description: BHP Billiton, the Australian company that is one of the worlds largest mining companies, appears set to build a $3.5 billion hydroelectric plant in the Democratic Republic of Congo to power a $5 billion aluminum smelter.

title: Foursquare Introduces New Tools for Businesses
description: 11:10 a.m. | Updated Corrected the name of the AJ Bombers restaurant.

title: No Phoning in the Library, Except to Send Donations
description: If you want to make a donation to the Brooklyn Public Library, you can do it in a text message. This method of fund-raising has helped recently in earthquake-ravaged Haiti, but officials believe it is the first time a library has given it a try.

title: A Major Space Conference
description: Monologue |  Monday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Everyone watch the Oscars last night? Big night for The Hurt Locker, which of course is a film about the war in Iraq, which, I guess explains why Obama called the director and was like, How did you end it?

title: Connecting Autism and Vaccines
description: In todays Science Times, Roni Caryn Rabin reports that one in four parents thinks some vaccines cause autism in healthy children. Read the full article.

title: Not Nearly as Bad
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Record ratings for the Oscars last night. Kathryn Bigelow won best director for her film about the Iraq war. But in her speech, she forgot to thank the two people without whom this film could never have been made  Bush and Cheney.

description: Remember, warns the title character of a long-running Broadway musical, there are worse things than a shattered chandelier.

title: For New York City Opera Season, Bernstein, Strauss and New Works
description: The struggling New York City Opera, operating with a slender financial cushion, announced plans on Tuesday for another stripped down, five-production season but said it would add a series of concert performances.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Get Your Fresh, Delicious Whale Meat Here
description: Whale meat sushi is pale pink, fatty, and extremely hard to find, probably because it is extremely illegal. But the filmmakers who made The Cove, which just won an Oscar for best documentary feature, know where to find it. They ran a sting operation at The Hump in Santa Monica which led to a federal investigation that looks likely to end in charges against the restaurant, Jennifer Steinhauer reports.

title: Superheroes Fill-In
Sampler: Napa Wineries Face Foreclosure Risk, and Easing Polar Bear Depression
description: Im Gay, Republican Lawmaker Says | State Senator Roy Ashburn, Republican of Bakersfield, told a radio program Monday that he is gay, making him the first openly gay Republican legislator in Sacramento. Im gay, he said. Those are the words that have been so difficult for me for so long. Mr. Ashburn, whose confession appeared to come out of his arrest last week in Sacramento for suspicion of drunken driving, said he had voted against gay rights measures because that is what he believed his constituents wanted. On the Senate floor on Monday, colleagues of both parties shook his hand and slapped his back. [The Sacramento Bee]

description: GMAC, the onetime General Motors finance arm that was bailed out by the federal government, said on Tuesday that its chief financial officer, Robert S. Hull, will leave to pursue another career opportunity.

description: American skiing star Bode Miller hoped his right ankle, injured in December, would make it through the Vancouver Olympics and the World Cup season.

description: Researchers at I.B.M. and Stanford University said Tuesday that they have discovered a new way to make plastics that can be continuously recycled or developed for novel uses in health care and microelectronics.

title: Whale Meat on the Menu, in California
description: March 20 | Updated  It appears that intense public pressure and adverse publicity have prompted the owners of the Hump Restaurant, caught serving whale sushi, to shut it down. The restaurant was famed for exotic dishes, including serving fish alive:

title: An Idol Winner, Two Months Ahead of Schedule?
description: All American Idol contestants not named Crystal Bowersox, you might as well pack it in now, if the Idol judge Simon Cowell has his way. He has put his thumb on the scale in favor of Ms. Bowersox, a plucky 24-year-old semifinalist from Elliston, Ohio, who were totally hoping runs away with the whole ball of wax. (Though were warming up to Siobhan Magnus, too.)

title: Video of Poker Heist Makes Berlin Gang Look Amateurish
description: Three days after a chaotic armed robbery during a high-stakes poker tournament in Berlin was caught on video, police are searching for five suspects, according to the Berliner Zeitung, a newspaper in the German capital.

title: New Palm OS 1.4 Adds Video
description: Some Palm owners may have noticed that there is an update called Web OS 1.4 offered for the phone. If you havent downloaded it, you might want to. It adds some nice new features. If it hasnt shown up, Ill tell you how to get it.

description: Mom, cmon, lets go, Nicole whispered into my ear.

title: Ten Tax Breaks for Parents
description: Theres one benefit to having children besides the joy they can bring you: tax breaks.

title: Another Missed Opportunity for Takahashi
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  For the second time this spring it appears Hisanori Takahashi will miss out on a chance to start, although that opportunity will come at some point before spring training is over. Takahashi, the Mets Japanese left-hander, was originally scheduled to start last Wednesday in Orlando but his inability to get a visa in time canceled that opportunity. The Mets were concerned he would be too tired.

title: UConn and the Common Good
description: To start, it should be noted that the Connecticut womens basketball team has been linked to no nefarious doctors in Canada. It did not intentionally cause a Nascar crash, nor has it been suspended by the N.H.L. for crushing someones head. It played no apparent role in the global financial crisis.

title: The Big East Divide
description: According to the latest numbers available from the U.S. Department of Education, here are what the 16 Big East universities spent on mens basketball from July 2008 through June 2009. Nine have programs in the Football Bowl Subdivision.

title: The Cove Moves to the Dragons Lair
description: LOS ANGELES  Long version of the Worlds Shortest Oscar Acceptance Speech was the subject line of a message that Louie Psihoyos, the director of the Oscar-winning documentary The Cove, about a secret dolphin-killing ground in Japan, sent around to friends on Monday. We made this film to give the oceans a voice, it begins, going on to highlight the problems of oceanic pollution and ask the people of Japan to watch the movie.

title: Climate Goal Is Supported by China and India
description: WASHINGTON  China and India formally agreed Tuesday to join the international climate change agreement reached in December in Copenhagen, the last two major economies to sign up.

title: Why a Big Mac Costs Less Than a Salad
description: 1:35 p.m. | Updated

title: Elsewhere: Soccer World Cup Slang
description: Ahead of the soccer World Cup in South Africa, Vivienne Hambly provided Guardian readers with a handy guide to South African slang terms.

title: Ravaged Nigerian Village Is Haunted by Latest Massacre
description: DOGO NA HAWA, Nigeria  Nightmare images haunt this dusty sun-baked village, fresh memories of tall young men emerging from darkness to slash the unarmed with long knives in a frenzy of ethnic and religious hatred.

title: Drought Has Venezuela Looking at Alternatives to Hydropower
description: A severe drought in Venezuela appears to be pushing the countrys president, Hugo Chvez, to ramp up efforts to diversify the countrys energy portfolio.

title: Editor Is Fired After Criticizing Chinese Registration System
description: BEIJING  A top editor of a weekly newspaper who recently called for the reform of Chinas onerous household registration system, which restricts where people can live, has been forced out of his job in a fresh warning that journalists who boldly challenge government policy face retribution.

title: See You on the Dark Side of the Courtroom: Pink Floyd Sues Label
description: Had EMI paid closer attention to the skeptical lyrics of Pink Floyds Have a Cigar  not to mention the better part of that groups back catalog  it might have known that the band is not endlessly trusting of record labels.

title: How Low Can You Go?
description: The dropped crotch is shaping up as the new decades most influential trouser trend. But as pant fronts fall, even dedicated followers of fashion are hard pressed to describe the differences between dhoti, samurai, Zouave and harem pants. Some critics claim the dropped crotch screams fashion victim, but in fact it owes its exaggerated form to utility. Designed for easy movement and comfort in hot climates, its an unexpectedly practical wardrobe addition. And you never have to worry about a wedgie.

title: Even in Internet Era, Artists Benefit From Record Label Support, Study Contends
description: All you pop-star wannabes, take note: making it big isnt cheap.

title: Twins Nathan Has Torn Ligament
description: Twins closer Joe Nathans season is in doubt after it was disclosed Tuesday that he has a significant tear of the ulnar collateral ligament in his right elbow.

title: Lazy Sunday, Live From New York
description: Remember back, if you will, to a simpler time when you watched TV on TV and your unemployed friends didnt flood your work inbox with mildly funny Web videos. To a time otherwise known as the B.L.S. era  Before Lazy Sunday.

title: Hoyer Dismisses Massas Claims as Untrue
description: The House majority leader, Steny Hoyer, rebuffed as untrue the claim by former Representative Eric J. Massa that Democrats conspired to oust him over his opposition to the health care bill.

title: Producer Pleads Guilty in Letterman Extortion Case
description: Updated, 3:16 p.m. | Robert Halderman, the man accused of trying to extort $2 million from David Letterman, pleaded guilty on Tuesday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan and will serve six months in jail.

title: Meet and Greet | Chanels Laetitia Crahay
description: Laetitia Crahay talks like a hurricane, passionately blustering her way through a stream of gabbling about what she loves and hates. And she pretty much loves or hates everything. Since she started working with her fashion-school-dropout classmate Olivier Theyskens to set up his renegade brand in 1997, she has turned herself into one of the most creative forces in fashion. Now 33, she heads up accessories and jewelry at Chanel, and is the artistic director of Maison Michel, the tiny millinery firm that Chanel invested in in 2006 as part of an effort to preserve traditional craftsmanship in Paris.

title: Pressed by Charters, Public Schools Try Marketing
description: Rafaela Espinal held her first poolside chat last summer, offering cheese, crackers and apple cider to draw people to hear her pitch.

title: K-Rod Throws and Has Big Thoughts
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  For the first time in over a weekm Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez threw off a mound, and he was so excited afterward that he was thinking about a certain famous plaque.

title: Man to Plead Guilty in Letterman Extortion Case
description: Robert Halderman, the man accused of trying to extort $2 million from David Letterman, is expected to plead guilty on Tuesday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan and will serve six months in jail, according to two people briefed on the case.

title: Another Celebrity Speaks Out for Consumer Protection Agency
description: Who knew the Consumer Financial Protection Agency would become celebrities new cause clbre?

title: New York Times Names New Communications Chief
description: The New York Times Company named Robert H. Christie as its new communications chief on Tuesday. He had been the chief spokesman for Dow Jones & Company, a unit of News Corporation.

title: Automakers and Airplanes, and Privacy
description: When the top bosses of the three Detroit automakers flew their private jets to a meeting in Washington in November 2008 to ask the government for bailout money, they received a lambasting from politicians and excoriating coverage in the media. Sixteen months later, the fallout is being felt beyond the auto industry.

title: Rock and Roll All Nite, Potty Every Day: Kiss Band Mates Plan a Kids Show
description: They call him Doctor Love. They call his partner the Starchild and, occasionally, the Bandit. And as of now, they can call Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley, the lead singer and the rhythm guitarist of the rock band Kiss, something else: childrens show producers.

title: Awards for Costume and Set Designers
description: The veteran Broadway and film costume designer Albert Wolsky, who has two Academy Awards to his credit for All That Jazz and Bugsy, will receive the T.D.F./Irene Sharaff lifetime achievement award next month at a ceremony that will honor several other designers as well. The Theater Development Fund, the not-for-profit group that runs TKTS and has an extensive collection of costumes for rent, announced the recipients of the design awards on Tuesday.The other honorees are:  Ming Cho Lee, who will receive the Robert L. B. Tobin Award for sustained excellence in theatrical design. Mr. Lee, who first worked on Broadway as a technical assistant for the musical Happy Hunting during the 1956-57 season, was the set designer for the original Broadway production of Mother Courage and Her Children in 1963 and more than 20 other Broadway shows, including the musicals Billy and Two Gentleman of Verona and the play K2, for which he won a Tony Award for his set design of a ledge on the famous mountain. Alejo Vietti, who will receive the young master award recognizing his work as a costume designer in New York and regionally, including the Off Broadway productions Nightingale and Rooms: A Rock Romance. John David Ridge, who will receive the artisan award. Mr. Ridge is a Hollywood and theater costume designer who was nominated for a Tony for best costume design in 1999 for the revival of Ring Round the Moon.

title: Making Stuffed Mushrooms
description: I associate stuffed vegetables with two very different milieus: southern France and the red-sauce Italian restaurants of my childhood. The first is a place of ros wine, summer squashes, tomatoes, onions and little peppers, all filled with herb-scented vegetable stuffings, and sunshine. The second is, or was, a place of quart bottles of Hoffman soda, veal parmigiana, dim, reddish light  and stuffed mushrooms.

title: Erin Callan: the Greta Garbo of Wall Street
description: Whatever happened to Erin Callan? The former chief financial officer of Lehman Brothers, known for her overachieving star quality and limited financial experience, was pushed out in June 2008, a few months before the firm imploded. Ms. Callan resurfaced for a bit at Credit Suisse and then just seemed to fall off the face of the earth.

title: House Considers Judges Impeachment
description: The House will take up the impeachment on Friday of a Louisiana federal judge accused of seeking and accepting bribes and perjury, the majority leader, Steny Hoyer, said on Tuesday.

title: A Storehouse to Help Those Who Help the Poor
description: A low-slung building along a desolate industrial stretch of Port Morris is packed to the rafters with everything from office furniture, dishes, clothing, books and toiletries  all stockpiled by the international Christian relief group World Vision.

description: Somehow, the partners in the new Satay Junction found a way to shoehorn 16 seats at tables into the sliver that once housed Lassi at 28 Greenwich Avenue (at 10th Street).

title: The First Player I Ever Met
description: MESA, Ariz.  Bob Dernier was the first baseball player I ever met. I was 7 years old and he was the rookie leadoff hitter for the Philadelphia Phillies. He was signing autographs at Magarity Chevrolet in Flourtown, Pa. I could not fathom the idea that Bobby D. was right down the street in my hometown.

title: Ohio State Employee Kills Co-Worker, Then Self, Police Say
description: An Ohio State University custodian who had been told he was being fired killed a co-worker and wounded another before killing himself early Tuesday morning at a university maintenance building, officials said.

description: Q.

title: Cisco Unveils One Router to Rule Them All
description: 11:26 a.m. | Updated  Added comment from Juniper.

title: State Submits to a Study of Test Scores
description: It is an annual ritual: the State Education Department releases the latest results of its standardized math and reading tests, showing dramatic improvements at nearly every level. Critics and skeptics cry foul, pointing out that the results on national tests are much less rosy.

title: Part 2: Answers on Historically Black Colleges and Universities
description: More than 100 American institutions are classified by the government as historically black colleges and universities through a formal program intended to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.

title: Notre Dame Considers Not Going It Alone
description: On what could be a slow basketball day at the Big East mens basketball tournament, the biggest news on Tuesday may have come from Notre Dame Athletic Director Jack Swarbrick. With the Big Ten and the Pacific-10 considering expansion, he said, Notre Dame is being forced to consider giving up its football independence, among a range of options.

title: The Morning Skate: Will Head Check Ban Take Shape as a Triangle?
description: How might the N.H.L. general managers, who continue their meetings Tuesday in Boca Raton, Fla., define what is, and what is not, an illegal shoulder check to the head? One glimpse into their thinking after the first day was provided by the Hockey Hall of Fame coach Scotty Bowman, interviewed on FAN 590 radio in Toronto on Tuesday morning by Gord Stellick and Elliotte Friedman.

title: Andy Richter Isnt Finished With Jay Leno Yet
description: Andy Richter, the normally genial comedian and longtime sidekick to Conan OBrien, has finally found someone who pushes him too far. And that someone is Jay Leno.In a conversation on Tuesday on Live With Regis and Kelly, Mr. Richter made it clear he was still upset about the recent late-night shake-up at NBC that returned Mr. Leno as the host of The Tonight Show, leaving Mr. OBrien  not to mention Mr. Richter  out of a job at the network.

title: Facebook Will Allow Users to Share Location
description: Starting next month, the more than 400 million Facebook users could begin seeing a new kind of status update flow through their news feed: the current locations of their friends.

title: Israel Intends to Build Civilian Nuclear Plants
description: PARIS  Israel, widely believed to have nuclear weapons and possessing no oil, said on Tuesday that it intended to develop civilian nuclear plants for energy, offering to build one as a joint project with Jordan, under French supervision.

title: On the Causes of Climate Deadlock
description: For years, theres been a building drumbeat of criticism of the media for failing to tell the climate story right, and thus perpetuating public disengagement and, in turn, allowing elected officials to relax and avoid pushing for meaningful actions to blunt greenhouse emissions.

title: Iraqi Officials to Begin Releasing Vote Tallies on Wednesday
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs electoral commission said Tuesday that it would announce partial results of parliamentary elections on Wednesday, providing an incomplete picture of the vote that will nevertheless provide the broad outlines of the countrys political landscape.

title: Inside Out | Shades of Grandeur
description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

title: Power Button Wins Condom Wrapper Design Contest
description: The NYC condom package design contest wrapped up Tuesday. After tallying more than 15,000 online votes, the New York Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced that a design by a Queens man showing a power button would adorn six million limited-edition free condoms set for release this year.

title: Leibovitz Reaches Deal With Private Equity Firm
description: The photographer Annie Leibovitz, whose messy finances almost cost her the rights to her work and her homes last year, has reached an agreement with Colony Capital, a Los Angeles firm not known for bailing out artists, to help her restructure her debt, The Financial Times reported Tuesday.

title: Sorgi Goes From Backing Up One Manning to the Other
description: The Giants needed a backup for quarterback Eli Manning, who hasnt missed a game since becoming the starter on Nov. 21, 2004. They turned to the player who is better prepared to be an unused backup than anybody else in the N.F.L.

title: Sabathia Struggles in Second Start
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In his second start last spring, the Tigers hammered C.C. Sabathia for five runs and six hits in one and two-thirds innings. It was a spring training game, so he did not think the results, however poor, would be a big deal. The next day, one headline on the Internet read, Sabathia Already Has Fat in Fire.

title: Romance in the Desert
description: LOS ANGELES Which magazine will be first to assign cute profile of wacky editor-couple Bob Murawski and Chris Innis? the Baggers spendthrift pal Jon Caramanica tweeted on Oscar night. And lo and behold, this is close enough. New York magazine offers a Q.&A. with the Oscar-winning editing winners, who got married after working on The Hurt Locker.

title: A Rough Rollout for Smart Meters in Texas
description: So-called smart electric meters, heralded as vital for an energy-conscious era, are having a rough rollout in Texas.

title: Not Just for Laughs: a Consumer Lending Salvo
description: 4:16 p.m. | Updated The fight in Congress over the creation of a Consumer Financial Protection Agency has spread from the East Coast to the West Coast, with movie and television stars promoting the agency and challenging the Wall Street banks and their lobbyists in Washington.

title: South Florida Rolls in Big East Opener
description: Time after time, the South Florida junior guard Dominique Jones got out on the fast break and finished at the rim against DePaul. He approached from all directions, absorbing fouls and charging hard at a soft Blue Demons zone when the Bulls settled into a halfcourt set.

title: Consequences of an Airport Kiss
description: Theirs was a whirlwind New York City Christmas, but while true love is timeless, vacations are not. Sadly, it came time for one of the lovebirds to fly home to California, and the other, Haisong Jiang  love-struck as if Cupid hit him not with an arrow, but with a two-by-four to the head  saw his beloved to the security line at Newark Liberty International Airport.

title: Photos of the Moment | All That Glitters
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Gag Order or Not, Youre Fired
description: Updated, 4:51 p.m. | With the testimony over and closing arguments done, it would seem that Harold C. Turner would have little to do except wait for a federal jury to decide whether he was guilty of threatening the lives of three appellate court judges.

title: Regarding The Nose': Consider the Prig
description: Today on ArtsBeat three New York Times critics  Anthony Tommasini, chief classical music critic; Roberta Smith, art critic; and Dwight Garner, book critic  are discussing the music, the art and the literary threads of The Nose. Daniel J. Wakin, classical music reporter for The Times, is moderating.You can read the previous posts here.

title: Meacham of Newsweek in Talks for Weekly PBS Show
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning editor of Newsweek, Jon Meacham, is negotiating to add a television job to his schedule. He is in final talks to be the co-host of a new PBS Friday night public affairs series called Need to Know, said several executives with knowledge of theproduction who declined to be named because the contractshad not beensigned.

title: First Ladys Inaugural Gown Installed
description: At a ceremony inside the National Museum of American History, Michelle Obama recalled shedding the bitter cold from watching the inaugural parade once she donned her Jason Wu gown for the evening balls.

title: Spartacus Is Delayed While Star Is Treated for Cancer
description: The Starz cable channel said on Tuesday that it will delay production on the second season of its original series Spartacus: Blood and Sand so that the actor Andy Whitfield, who plays the title character, can begin treatment for non-Hodgkins lymphoma.

title: Panasonic Adds Micro Four Thirds Cameras
description: Update: April 19, 4:11 p.m.| Panasonic today released pricing for its upcoming Micro Four Thirds cameras. The Lumix DMC-G2 will cost $800 and the Lumix DMC-G10 is priced at $600. Both will be available in late May.

title: Barclays and Royal Bank Study U.S. Banking Scene
description: Barclays of Britain and Royal Bank of Canada are reportedly looking for banks to acquire in the United States.

title: Yves Saint Laurent Revisited
description: Suzy Menkes visits the first retrospective exhibition of Yves Saint Laurent's work at the Petit Palais in Paris and speaks with Pierre Berg, the couturier's lifetime partner.

title: State of the Steelers: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Regarding The Nose': Kovalyov Gets Some Love
description: Today on ArtsBeat three New York Times critics  Anthony Tommasini, chief classical music critic; Roberta Smith, art critic; and Dwight Garner, book critic  are discussing the music, the art and the literary threads of The Nose. Daniel J. Wakin, classical music reporter for The Times, is moderating.You can read the previous posts here.

title: More on Mommy Friends
description: When I stop to think about it, I shouldnt have been so surprised that two posts this week sparked such deep and thoughtful conversations here about friendship. (You can read them here and here.) After all, I learned firsthand when my son was born that friendships can sustain you and disappoint you as your life transforms.

title: Answers About Education Tax Credits and Deductions: Part 5
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Vain Glorious | A Scar Is Born
description: In the play Time Stands Still (at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater through March 27), Laura Linney plays Sarah Goodwin, a war photographer badly injured by a bomb blast in Iraq. From the beginning, the director, Daniel Sullivan, and Linney knew that Goodwins visible scars would be an important facet of the production, so the actress suggested calling in Mindy Hall, an accomplished (and as of this past Sunday night, Academy Award-winning) makeup artist who Linney had worked with on four films, including Kinsey. I knew Mindy would be able to come up with something a) the theater would be able to afford, b) that would look realistic and c) that I would be able to put on myself, Linney said. Applying the extensive shrapnel marks to her face, arm and leg has become something of a pre-performance meditation for the actress. I love the quiet time it gives me before every show, she says. I tend to get to the theater early anyway, but this gives me an excuse to get here even earlier. And you know, its just me alone. It becomes a sort of starting point.

title: Letterman Offers a Comment on Extortion Case
description: David Letterman released a statement through his spokesman Tom Keaney, following the court appearance on Tuesday byRobert Halderman, in which he pleaded guilty to an effort to extort Mr. Letterman and received a sentence of six months in prison.

title: Airport Built, Its Time to See if the Traffic Comes
description: The first new international airport in the United States in more than decade is set to open in May near Panama City, Fla., a community of 37,000 people on the states panhandle. That is no small feat given the environmental, regulatory and financial hurdles involved in building runways and terminals, as well as community opposition to planes flying overhead.

title: Debating the Nuclear Waste Problem
description: With Nevadas Yucca Mountain facility apparently out of the picture as a nuclear waste repository, government nuclear experts say interim measures might be needed for a very long time.

title: A City View, Johannesburg
description: Adam Levy's penthouse apartment overlooks the Nelson Mandela Bridge in downtown Johannesburg.

title: Student Rates for the Young at Heart
description: EVEN if your college days are a distant memory, its possible to travel on a student discount over spring break this year.

title: Bringing a Taste of New York to Johannesburg
description: JOHANNESBURG  Adam Levy was a teenager growing up in Melrose, a whites-only suburb in northern Johannesburg, when Nelson Mandela was released from prison 20 years ago. Today Mr. Levy  much like the city itself  has traded the racial restrictions of the apartheid era for a far more colorful (and cultural) urban existence.

title: Browns Cut Quarterback Anderson
description: Clevelands new football guru Mike Holmgren is putting his imprint all over the Browns, terminating the contract of the former starting quarterback Derek Anderson on Tuesday.

title: Vatican on Defense as Sex Scandals Build
description: ROME  Defending itself against a growing child sexual abuse scandal in Europe, one that has even come close to the brother of Pope Benedict XVI, the Vatican said Tuesday that local European churches had addressed the issue with timely and decisive action.

title: Protesters Picket Insurance Lobby
description: Its protest season again in Washington.

title: Godzilla Haiku
description: Incoming | Found at tumblr.com:

title: Now Showing | The World According to Gursky
description: Since medieval times, the desire to make maps of the world remains a story of both necessity and art. If the recent surge of books about maps is any indication, cartographic art is for all ages. How better to visualize human history and keep track of ones empire while contemplating opportunities for expansion? Andreas Gurskys latest body of work pushes his penchant for wide-angle photography to encompass the ever-increasing scope of his Weltanschauung, or worldview. Verging on 13 feet by 8 feet, Gurskys photographs are cinematic in scale, and their exhibition at Gagosian in Beverly Hills, Calif., is apt for a town filled with connoisseurs of cinematography (and movie moguls who can afford them).

title: A Travel Blog for the Hipster Set?
description: Does the world really need another travel blog? Perhaps, if you like offbeat travel articles written by novelists and poets who view travel through their idiosyncratic artistic lens.

title: LifeLock Settles With F.T.C. Over Charges of Deception
description: WASHINGTON  LifeLock, the company that broadcast its chief executives Social Security number as part of its claim that it could protect anyone against identity theft, agreed on Tuesday to pay $12 million to settle charges that it misled consumers about the effectiveness of its service.

title: Madison Square Park, 11:54 A.M.
Telling Tales Out of School: What Education Systems Reveal About Culture
Daniels Offers Advice to Republicans
description: Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana offered a piece of advice to fellow Republicans: Lay down the philosophical swords to begin rebuilding the party and tackle the nations immense challenges. But he urged Republicans to not become too emboldened by the discontent in the electorate.

title: Caricatured Commentary: Minstrel Meets Modern
description: In Neighbors, a simultaneously overheated and undercooked new play thats part of the Public Theaters Lab program, the young playwright Branden Jacobs-Jenkins tries to trace in bold strokes how the poisons spread by disgraced racial stereotypes continue to contaminate American culture and the American family.

title: The Secret to Having Happy Employees
description: About 10 years ago I was having my annual holiday party, and my niece had come with her newly minted M.B.A. boyfriend. As he looked around the room, he noted that my employees seemed happy. I told him that I thought they were.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, March 9
description: It is a departure for Pictures of the Day to open with a black-and-white image. It is also a departure for this particular photographer: Luke Sharrett, a prolific New York Times intern. He said he had only transmitted black-and-white files two or three times in the seven months he has been working in The Timess Washington bureau. But Mr. Sharrett said that Tuesdays occasion  the burial in Arlington National Cemetery of Cpl. Jacob H. Turbett, a Marine who was killed Feb. 13 in Helmand Province in Afghanistan  warranted the somber cast of monochrome.

title: Where the Jobs Are
description: Job openings rose in January, according to a new Labor Department report. As a result, the number of unemployed workers per available job dipped slightly to 5.4, from about 6 workers per job opening in December:

title: Maps, Competition and Monserrates New Logo
description: Charts, graphs, logos, maps: With so much information bombarding us at every second, good visual shorthand is increasingly essential, for both communication and our general sanity.

title: Israelis Against Israeli Settlements
description: Update | Wednesday | 10:01 a.m.  On Wednesday morning an article and video report by my colleagues Isabel Kershner and Reem Makhoul on a dispute over homes in East Jerusalem discussed in this blog post was published on our Web site.

title: Ode to Burgundy
description: As some of you may have guessed from my column this week in the newspaper, I love Burgundy. I love to drink it, think about it, talk about it and write about it.

title: Noble Savages | A Mens Tea Party
description: A mens tea party seemed like a fantasy. But as the snow melted, these boys were happy to gather at Nightwoods woodworking studio near the Brooklyn Navy Yard for strong, earthy teas and late-afternoon snacks.

title: The Gender Wage Gap, Around the World
description: In honor of International Womens Day, which was Monday, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Developments Factblog has been dissecting data on womens role in the world.

title: A Reluctance to Ride the Market
description: As they set their energy budgets for next year, the owners of hundreds of buildings in New York will be eligible to join Con Edisons hourly pricing plan for electricity service, broadening a program that allows customers to monitor electricity usage as it changes over a day and pay rates that reflect that data.

title: Miracle Worker Keeps the Faith
description: After saying on Friday that the Broadway revival of The Miracle Worker might close unless ticket sales improved, the lead producer of the show said on Tuesday that it would continue running even though the box office remained slow over the weekend.

title: Flu Shots in Children Can Help Community
description: An unusual study done in 49 remote Hutterite farming colonies in western Canada has provided the surest proof yet that giving flu shots to schoolchildren protects a whole community from the disease.

title: A Talk With Charles Thacker, the Turing Winner
description: This is the big week for awards  in computing as well as movies. The Turing Award, often called the Nobel prize of computer science, was announced on Tuesday and the 2009 winner was Charles P. Thacker.

title: Regarding The Nose': And the Eye, and the Ear
description: Today on ArtsBeat three New York Times critics  Anthony Tommasini, chief classical music critic; Roberta Smith, art critic; and Dwight Garner, book critic  are discussing the music, the art and the literary threads of The Nose. Daniel J. Wakin, classical music reporter for The Times, is moderating. You can read the previous posts here.

title: Divining the Academys Intent
description: LOS ANGELES  Now that everyones had a chance to shake off his or her red carpet hangovers  telltale signs include an aversion to bright lights and publicists  the post-mortems are rolling in. Why did The Hurt Locker beat Avatar? The demographics of the Academy are one reason, as the Baggers pals Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply reported on Tuesday. At Time.com, Richard Corliss adds the shock of the new  the memberships rejection of cinematic innovation  to his list of reasons.

title: PBS Considers Editor of Newsweek as Host
description: The editor of Newsweek, Jon Meacham, is negotiating to add a television job to his schedule. He is in final talks to be a host of a new PBS Friday-night public affairs series called Need to Know, said executives familiar with the production who wanted to stay anonymous because the contracts had not been signed. The co-anchor for the program, which begins May 7 at 8:30 p.m., is expected to be Alison Stewart, formerly of The Bryant Park Project, NPRs short-lived morning show, and before that anchor of The Most on MSNBC. The new series will be produced for PBS by WNET.org of New York from a new street-side studio at Lincoln Center. Mr. Meacham, who won the Pulitzer last year for his book American Lion: Andrew Jackson in the White House, is not leaving the magazine, said a Newsweek spokesman, Frank DeMaria.

title: Firm to Help Restructure Annie Leibovitz Debt
description: The photographer Annie Leibovitz, right, whose messy finances almost cost her the rights to her work and her homes last year, has reached an agreement with Colony Capital, a Los Angeles firm, to help her restructure her debt, The Financial Times reported on Tuesday. Under the deal, Colony  which manages about $30 billion in assets, mostly in real estate  will become Ms Leibovitzs only creditor and will help her market her catalog of celebrity-heavy photographs. Ms. Leibovitz averted a foreclosure last summer after she missed a deadline to repay $24 million in loans she owed to Art Capital Group, a lender that used the rights to her photos and her real estate as collateral. Art Capital sued her in July 2009, saying she had not paid hundreds of thousands of dollars due under its agreements with her. Colony, which also controls the rights to the Neverland Ranch in California, told The Financial Times that it plans to manage sales of Ms. Leibovitzs photographic holdings and pursue other business ventures for her so that she can concentrate on her career.

title: View From the Bridge Recovers Its Investment
description: The critically acclaimed Broadway revival of A View From the Bridge, starring Liev Schreiber and Scarlett Johansson, has recouped its initial $2.3 million investment, the producers announced. The 14-week limited engagement began preview performances at the Cort Theater on Dec. 28 and opened on Jan. 24. It is scheduled to close on April 4. Shows that have enjoyed similar runaway box-office success and recouped so far this season have included the new play A Steady Rain, starring Hugh Jackman and Daniel Craig, and a revival of Hamlet with Jude Law in the title role. New commercial productions lacking major stars, like the plays Brighton Beach Memoirs, Oleanna and Superior Donuts and the musicals Finians Rainbow and Ragtime, closed without recovering the upfront spending by producers and their investors.

title: Seeing in the Dark
description: For me, sleep has never come easy  perhaps because Ive never let it.

title: Spartacus Is Delayed as Star Has Cancer
description: The Starz cable channel said on Tuesday that it would delay production of the second season of its series Spartacus: Blood and Sand so the actor Andy Whitfield, left, who plays the title character, can begin treatment for non-Hodgkins lymphoma. Starz said in a news release that Mr. Whitfield discovered the cancer during a routine checkup and that his doctors have stated his condition is very treatable and was detected in its early stages. Starz began showing Spartacus, an action series about that Roman slave turned revolutionary, in January. The show quickly became a hit for the cable channel, drawing record ratings for its debut and seeing its audience grow.

title: The Dark Side of the Courtroom
description: Had EMI paid closer attention to the skeptical lyrics of Pink Floyds Have a Cigar  not to mention the better part of that groups back catalog  it might have known that the band is not endlessly trusting of record labels. Instead, EMI found out the hard way when Pink Floyd filed suit against the label in a dispute over how its online royalty payments and marketing costs for its music are calculated, Reuters reported. In a hearing at High Court in London on Tuesday, Robert Howe, a lawyer for Pink Floyd, said that a clause in the bands contract expressly prohibited the unbundling of its songs in any configuration other than how they were originally produced and released. Mr. Howe said that EMI believed this applies only to the physical product and doesnt apply online, adding that the argument makes no commercial sense. Pink Floyd first signed with EMI in the late 1960s, going on to record hit prog-rock albums like The Dark Side of the Moon and motivating the sale of millions of black light lamps and posters. The band more recently renegotiated its contract in the late 1990s, when online retailers like iTunes were still in their infancy. Reuters said that sales of Pink Floyds back catalog are exceeded only by another popular British combo: the Beatles.

title: Kiss Colleagues Plan Kids Show
description: They call him Doctor Love. They call his partner the Starchild and, occasionally, the Bandit. And now they can call Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley, the lead singer and the rhythm guitarist of the rock band Kiss, something else: childrens show producers. Mr. Simmons and Mr. Stanley, above from left, have had collaborations like the songs Hotter Than Hell, Love Gun and Lick It Up, but now they have a deal with the Canadian production company E1 Television to create a show for young viewers that will also serve as a merchandising tie-in, The Hollywood Reporter said. The show, a comedy series yet to be titled, will be produced and distributed by E1. In a statement to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Simmons said: Kiss continues to be the juggernaut of licensing and merchandising, from Kiss M&Ms to Kiss Dr Pepper. Kiss is a band, but also the only music brand.

title: Men Takes Charge
description: The CBS sitcom Two and a Half Men attracted its largest audience in three years on Monday, leading the nights ratings with 17.5 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. CBS won the night over all, benefiting not only from its 9 p.m. ratings for Two and a Half Men but also from The Big Bang Theory, the nights second-highest-rated show with 16.3 million viewers, at 9:30. Fox was runner-up on the night, leading the 8 oclock hour with House (12.8 million), which edged ahead of CBSs other comedies. But Foxs 24 lagged behind at 9 with 8.9 million viewers. ABC ranked third with its two-hour special, The Bachelor: Jason and Mollys Wedding (9.3 million). At 10, ABCs Castle (9.1 million) outperformed NBCs Law & Order (5.2 million) but trailed CBSs CSI: Miami (11.9 million). NBC placed fourth on the night..

title: Coffee Grounds + Spores = a New East Bay Business
description: Last year, in an ethics class at the University of California, Berkeleys Haas School of Business, Alex Velez and Nikhil Arora heard a visiting lecturer mention that women in Colombia and parts of East Africa were growing mushrooms from coffee grounds to fight malnutrition.

title: Carlyle Said to Seek Buyers for Arinc
description: The private equity firm Carlyle Group has hired Goldman Sachs to seek buyers for Arinc, its military contracting and aviation business, Bloomberg News reports, citing unidentified people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Designer Potholes
description: There is the time of year when the swallows return to San Juan Capistrano and the mud daubers to Luckenbach, Tex. There is the season of the cherry blossom  and the season of the pothole.

title: St. Johns Eliminates a Fading UConn
description: For all the athleticism that UConns lineup brought into Tuesdays game against St. Johns, it was the units collective apathy that was most striking on the court.

title: Fashion House Opens Hotel in Milan
description: Italian fashion designers continue to moonlight as hoteliers. There is the Hotel Missoni, which opened in Edinburgh last year, and the Hotel Armani, expected to open this month in Dubai. The latest is the Maison Moschino, which opened in Milan in late February.

title: H.P. Barks, Then Bites Apple on the iPad
description: Such is the hype around tablet computers that Hewlett-Packard and Apple have taken to beating each other up over products that no one can even buy yet.

title: Imaginarium of Mr. Arsham
description: In Daniel Arshams world, nothing is what it seems. A smooth wall suddenly looks as if it is being stretched like fabric. A solid white cube gives the impression that its been eaten away. An Arcadian landscape populated only by a kangaroo is invaded by a rectangular slab that hovers in midair. A gouache rendering of Le Corbusiers modernist monastery La Tourette is pictured inside a cave. Arshams work blurs the lines between art, architecture and performance, and explores issues of natural versus manufactured or intention versus happenstance. It has attracted impressive collaborators  Merce Cunningham, the choreographer Jonah Bokaer and the fashion designer Hedi Slimane  as well as the art dealer Emmanuel Perrotin. Arshams third solo exhibition at Perrotins Paris gallery, Animal Architecture, opens on March 20. And to think, hes only 29.

title: Live Updates From the Big East Tournament
description: Four games are on the schedule Tuesday at the Big East mens basketball tournament. The Timess Pete Thamel and Kevin Armstrong, along with Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward, will provide analysis and updates throughout the day. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comment section below. The schedule:

title: Gates Tours Market in Former Taliban Town
description: NOW ZAD, Afghanistan  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates took a stroll on Tuesday through a village market in this former Taliban sanctuary in Helmand Province, but the lone street of shops was so sleepy that it looked as if everyone had been told to stay home.

title: Alabama-Style Rap, Without the Punches
description: Sweaty, drinking from a pitcher of beer and spilling his syllables in rapid, often inscrutable fashion, the Alabama rapper Yelawolf was doing the absolute best he could on the stage at Brooklyn Bowl on Monday night, given the circumstances. After he finished playing one of the standout tracks on Trunk Muzik, his latest mixtape  an unprintably titled song with a beefy, bellowing chorus, horn stabs and military-march drums  he was vexed.

title: Beady Eyes That Just Cant Help It
description: The word taxidermy derives from two innocent Greek roots  taxis (arrangement) and derma (skin)  that when combined suggest something slightly sinister. Taxidermy was Norman Batess hobby in Psycho. Jeffrey Dahmer, the serial killer, practiced it on his neighbors pets. In horror movies, taxidermy often crowds the walls, derangement made manifest.

title: Back Together, and It Seems Like 1993
description: Sometimes the only way to take a measure of a band is hearing it play a gig. Most times, actually. But Harvey Milk, from Athens, Ga., seems a special case.

title: The Lithium Chase
description: For many years, few metals drew bigger yawns from mining executives than lithium, a lightweight element long associated mostly with mood-stabilizing drugs.

title: Strolling Through Castles and Labyrinths
description: The concert presented by Max Lifchitz and his North/South Chamber Orchestra at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night was billed as a 30th-anniversary gala. Since founding North/South Consonance in 1980, Mr. Lifchitz, a Mexican-born composer, conductor and pianist, has devoted copious effort to promoting the work of composers underserved elsewhere, through a regular series of concerts in New York and on CDs released by North/South Recordings.

title: First Lady to Hit Graduation Circuit
description: Michelle Obama is scheduled for a bit of a graduation tour this spring, with three commencement speeches on her itinerary.

title: House Hunting in ... England
description: FOUR-BEDROOM TWO-AND-A-HALF-BATH HISTORIC HOUSE IN SURREY

title: Still Life
description: Chapter 1: Schwendeman's Taxidermy Studio

title: Six Months in Jail for Letterman Plot
description: Saying that he felt great remorse for what I have done, a former CBS producer pleaded guilty on Tuesday to trying to extort $2 million from David Letterman by threatening to reveal details about affairs that Mr. Letterman had with members of his staff, including a former companion of the producer.

title: Fighting a War of Words About a Lot of Words About a War
description: A momentous passage in American journalism strides stiffly across the stage of New York Theater Workshop in Top Secret: The Battle for the Pentagon Papers, a fact-packed drama by Geoffrey Cowan and Leroy Aarons, journalists with distinguished careers that have extended into academia and other realms.

title: Christies Wins Bid to Auction $150 Million Brody Collection
description: After a four-month battle between the auction giants Sothebys and Christies, the art collection of the Los Angeles philanthropist Frances Lasker Brody will be sold at Christies in New York in May. Valued at well over $150 million, it includes a 1932 painting by Picasso that is considered a seminal work from one of the high points of that artists career. Also coming to auction are rare examples by Giacometti, Matisse and Braque.

title: Iranian Filmmaker Speaks Out on Prisoners
description: Abbas Kiarostami, a celebrated Iranian filmmaker who has won numerous international awards for films like Close-Up and Through The Olive Trees, published an open letter in a Tehran newspaper on Tuesday calling for the release of Jafar Panahi and Mahmoud Rasoulof, two directors recently detained by the authorities.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Ex-Trader of Taking Kickbacks
description: A former stock loan trader at Morgan Stanley and Bank of America in New York received well over $100,000 of cash kickbacks by steering orders to other brokerage firms, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday, Reuters reports.

title: Historic Building in Surrey
description: A four-bedroom two-and-a-half bath historic house in Surrey, England, is on the market for 999,950 pounds ($1.5 million).

title: I Tickled Aide, but That Was All, Massa Says
description: Updated, 6:21 p.m. | Representative Eric J. Massa, who resigned from Congress amid allegations of sexual misconduct, vehemently denied any wrongdoing during a television appearance on Tuesday even as he described having tickle fights with staffers in a house they shared.

title: Same Phantom, Different Spirit
description: LONDON  To think that all this time that poor old half-faced composer hasnt been dead at all, just stewing in his lust for greater glory. Being the title character of The Phantom of the Opera, the most successful musical of all time, wasnt enough for him. Oh, no. Like so many aging stars, he was determined to return  with different material and a rejuvenated body  to the scene of his first triumph. So now hes back in the West End with a big, gaudy new show. And he might as well have a kick me sign pasted to his backside.

title: Scorecard | Cline Wins!
description: Whether we care to admit it, its clear that the weekends catwalk spectacular had a little competition from another international promenade  of the red plush variety. So today Scorecard asks: What show made editors not regret catching the early-morning Oscars telecast from Paris? The showmen duo Viktor & Rolf presented Kristen McMenamy on a rotating runway in a carapace of 23 layers that gave new definition to the idea of 3-D dressing, while at the more tightly edited Cline showing, fashions own Kathryn Bigelow, Phoebe Philo, made chic severity approachable. And the award goes to.

title: Lohan Sues E*Trade Over Super Bowl Ad
description: Lindsay Lohan is suing E*Trade Financial over a popular television commercial that made its debut during Super Bowl XLIV and has appeared subsequently during coverage of the Winter Olympics and other programs.

title: Somalia Food Aid Bypasses Needy, U.N. Study Says
description: As much as half the food aid sent to Somalia is diverted from needy people to a web of corrupt contractors, radical Islamist militants and local United Nations staff members, according to a new Security Council report.

title: Properties for $175,000
description: Properties in Heber City, Utah, Seneca Falls, N.Y., and Milwaukee.

title: What You Get for ... $175,000
description: HEBER CITY, UTAH

title: A Female Parliamentary Majority in Just One Country: Rwanda
description: As my colleague Lydia Polgreen writes, the upper house of Indias Parliament passed a bill on Tuesday that would amend the Constitution to reserve a third of the seats in Indias national and state legislatures for women. Such a provision may sound extreme, but it is nothing new: According to the Quota Project, about half of the worlds countries currently use some type of electoral quota for their national legislatures, in some cases enforced by political parties. (India has previously experimented with quotas for women in local elections.)

title: Tacos in the Morning? Thats the Routine in Austin
description: Austin, Tex.

title: State Police Losing Its Second Chief in Two Weeks
description: The New York State Police lost its second leader in a matter of days on Tuesday when the agencys acting superintendent, Pedro J. Perez, announced that he would retire, effective Friday.

title: Sidewalk Standoff in East Jerusalem
description: An Israeli court case finds that land owned by a Palestinian should be turned over to Jews who claim it was an ancestral home.

title: A New Frontier for Indie Rock, Down in Mexico
description: It was a scene of classic do-it-yourself Brooklyn concert promotion: In a small apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant, a dozen young workers who could pass for American Apparel models crowded onto sofas one afternoon last week, typing furiously on laptops as they completed preparations for a rapidly approaching indie-rock festival.

title: All Ramps and Spirals and Mosquito Landings
description: PARIS  Theres something both touching and disturbing at the heart of Claude Parent: Graphic and Built Works, a marvelous exhibition at the Cit de lArchitecture et du Patrimoine, Pariss architecture museum, and it has to do with what the show tells us about our diminished cultural expectations.

title: New Honor for the Designs That Get Movies Moving
description: LOS ANGELES  Can an introduction be an art form? The people who hand out film awards are beginning to think so.

title: Obama Tries to Give Energy Bill a Push
description: President Obama, who is still hoping to get an energy bill through Congress this year, met Tuesday at the White House with lawmakers from both parties to try to push the process along.

title: In Leno-Letterman Ratings Competition, a Split Decision
description: The ratings competition between Jay Leno and David Letterman got much tighter on Mr. Lenos second Monday night back on NBCs Tonight Show.Mr. Lenoeked out a win over Mr. Letterman among total viewers, but among the viewer groups that NBC considers the real measure of success, Mr. Letterman was the winner.

title: Plunging Into Uncharted Depths of Character
description: THE actress Elizabeth Marvel was 30 and newly arrived in Los Angeles a decade ago, after years on the New York stage, when producers of her CBS television series The District, began making a very Hollywoodish demand: Get Botox.

title: A New Anthology of Gastronomica Magazine
description: The Gastronomica Reader (University of California Press, $39.95), an anthology of more than 40 essays from the thought-provoking food magazine of that name founded in 2001, edited by Darra Goldstein, is a volume to browse and absorb.

title: Jazzman Turns 80, Pondering Musics Metaphysics
description: Ornette Coleman is sitting at a table in the middle of his spacious loft, a fourth-floor aerie above the garment district bustle on West 36th Street in Midtown Manhattan.

title: N.H.L. General Managers Nearer to Acting on Some Hits to the Head
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  N.H.L. general managers moved closer Tuesday to recommending measures to penalize certain shoulder checks to the head, league officials said.

title: Abbott to Buy Facet Biotech for 67% Premium
description: Abbott Laboratories announced late Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Facet Biotech for a net price of $450 million in cash, in a move aimed at expanding its drug pipeline, including for treatments for multiple sclerosis.

title: Attacking Lawyers From the Right and Left
Bank of America to End Debit Overdraft Fees
description: In a move that could bring an end to the $40 cup of coffee, Bank of America said on Tuesday that it was doing away with overdraft fees on purchases made with debit cards, a decision that could cost the bank tens of millions a year in revenue and put pressure on other banks to do the same.

title: Some Unsettled Ghosts of Theater Past
description: ON a bitter Friday night last month about 50 people gathered in LaGuardia Community Colleges main theater for a workshop presentation of The Really Big Once, Target Margin Theaters new show exploring the making of Tennessee Williamss 1953 play Camino Real. The result of an intense collaboration with the director Elia Kazan, Camino Real, with its carnivalesque mix of characters like Don Quixote, Camille, Casanova and Lord Byron, was a spectacular flop on Broadway. It received scathing reviews, closed within two months and haunted both men with what ifs for years to come. And yet this dreamlike play has endured, inspiring generations of experimentally minded theater artists.

title: Alexander McQueens Final Show
description: Today, in a gilded salon in Paris, small groups of editors were invited to view the 16 pieces that Alexander McQueen had been working on before his death a few weeks ago. Artworks by Jean Fouquet, Sandro Boticelli, Stephan Lochner, Hans Memling, Hugo van der Goes and Hieronymus Bosch were captured digitally and transferred onto red, gold and silver dresses embellished with ornate embroideries. At this point, not much more can be said about the brilliance of McQueens work  consider, for example, a plumed dress for which each individual feather was painstakingly covered in gold leaf. Here is a slideshow of McQueens final collection.

title: Trendspotting | Futuristic Visions
description: Designers in Paris seemed tuned to a frequency from cyberspace, steeped in sci-fi references.

title: Variety Is Sued Over a Bad Review
description: Publishing a bad film review is one thing. Charging the filmmakers to promote the movie and then panning it may be quite another.

title: R2D2 Would Love It
description: DESIGNERS in Paris this week seemed tuned to a frequency from cyberspace, so steeped were they in sci-fi references. Some paid homage not only to Tron Legacy, the forthcoming Disney release, and its companion video game, but to television fare like Caprica. Others found inspiration in vintage films like  Blade Runner  and even  Metropolis.

title: Can Sackcloth Have Fur Trim?
description: PARIS

title: Cheap and Tasty on the East Side
description: WHEN looking for Manhattans latest in cheap and tasty food, the East Village and Lower East Side have always been good places to start. New spots pop up all the time, catering to the areas young eaters, who often have just a few bucks in their pockets. Some recent arrivals are very good.

title: Retro Modern
description: First things first. Marc Newson goes to the fridge of his newly designed kitchen. Do you want a drink? he asks, and pulls out a lager. Its 7 p.m. His wife, the stylist Charlotte Stockdale, is just putting their 2-year-old to bed. Hes unwinding. Tomorrow morning he flies to Italy to finish work on the speedboat hes designing for Riva.

title: What Were Reading: Barbie, Steve and Carly
description: Tuesdays roundup of interesting tidbits from around the Web, selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times:

title: Fresh Pork Rinds and Lard Dough at the Greenmarket
description: In the interest of not letting anything go to waste, Flying Pigs Farm in Shushan, N.Y., near Vermont in the Battenkill River Valley, has started selling fried pork rinds  chicharrones  along with meat and sausages from its heritage pigs. These tangled strips, below, are crisp, decidedly porky and salty, perfect for munching just as they are with beer. Stored airtight, they will keep for several days without losing their crunch.

title: Bee Desserts Opens in the West Village
description: Little moist, chocolate-covered honey cakes wrapped in foil are the signatures at Bee Desserts, a cafe and bakery that Claudia Steves opened a few weeks ago. It replaced La Palette, a spot she owned for several years.

title: Keith McNally Opens Pulinos Bar & Pizzeria
description: For nearly two years Keith McNally has been performing one of his usual scavenging jobs for Pulinos Bar & Pizzeria: exposing old brick and installing vintage light fixtures, wired glass, a new old tin ceiling and bottles  brown spirits, not wine, here  along the walls. The restaurant has 110 seats inside. During construction, deliveries were addressed to Kate Pulino, Mr. McNallys project manager. And the name stuck.

title: Strip House
description: EVERYTHING is new in New York save for that which is old, and when something goes from one to the other, the transition can be sudden and surprising: a wet foal thats suddenly distinguished and large, a horse that rides with the weight of history on its back.

title: Decaf With Pedigree and Flavor
description: AT coffee drinkers high school, the decaf crowd always sits at the losers table.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: New York Is Finally Taking Its Coffee Seriously
description: NEW YORK used to be a second-string city when it came to coffee. No longer.

title: A Glossary of Coffee Terms
description: AFFOGATO

title: Granderson Excited to Face Former Teammates
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Curtis Granderson said he had three games marked on his mental calendar. The first comes Wednesday, when he returns to Lakeland, Fla., to play the Tigers for the first time since being traded in December.

title: An Eviction Stirs Old Ghosts in a Contested City
description: JERUSALEM  Having been removed in favor of Israeli nationalist Jews, members of the Palestinian Ghawi family have been sheltering this winter in a tent on the sidewalk opposite their home of more than five decades in the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah.

title: Not That Kind of Strip House
description: My restaurant review this week is of Strip House, the Greenwich Village steakhouse that opened a full decade ago in the space that was Asti, an Italian restaurant with singing waiters. (The restaurant had a role in the Tom Hanks movie, Big.)

title: Dining Events From March 10 to 16
description: Talking Beef

title: Upset by U.S. Security, Pakistanis Return as Heroes
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A tour of the United States arranged by the State Department to improve ties to Pakistani legislators ended in a public relations fiasco when the members of the group refused to submit to extra airport screening in Washington, and they are now being hailed as heroes on their return home.

title: On Rabbits as Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Toyotas Are Safe (Enough)
description: Several months ago, a 63-year-old Harvard professor lost control of his 2005 Toyota Highlander, crashed into another car and died, along with two family members. Now the government is trying to decide whether Highlanders of this vintage are prone to sudden acceleration and should be added to the lengthy Toyota recall list.

title: Mad Men Dolls in a Barbie World, but the Cocktails Must Stay Behind
description: AFTER three seasons, Mad Men, the television series about advertising in the 1960s, has attained a level of popular-culture cachet. There have been magazine cover articles, calendars and an episode of The Oprah Winfrey Show all devoted to it, spoofs on The Simpsons and Saturday Night Live, and even a Mad Men category on Jeopardy.

title: Pennsylvania Woman Tied to Plot on Cartoonist
description: WASHINGTON  A Pennsylvania woman who called herself JihadJane was tied Tuesday to an alleged assassination plot against a Swedish cartoonist who depicted the prophet Muhammad atop the body of a dog.

title: Health Cares Obstacle: No Will to Cut
description: For anyone who cares about medical costs  which is to say anyone who cares about the take-home pay of American families or about the budget deficit  President Obamas health reform plan is a terribly mixed bag.

title: In Ad, Democrats Cite G.O.P. Indifference to High Health Costs
description: Democrats are using examples of soaring health insurance premiums to link Republicans to the problem side of the health care equation.

title: Hooping Already Has Its Own Jane Fonda
description: LIKE millions of Americans, Marisa Tomei used to play with a Hula-Hoop as a child. And like most of those same Americans, she hadnt hooped since.

title: Ex-Congressman Describes Tickle Fights With Aides
description: Former Representative Eric J. Massa of New York, who resigned from Congress amid allegations of sexual misconduct, vehemently denied any wrongdoing during a television appearance on Tuesday, even as he described having tickle fights with staff members in a house they shared.

title: European Leaders Call for Crackdown on Derivatives
description: Goldman Sachs had a bright idea for its clients: buy credit-default swaps  those controversial instruments that helped trip up the American International Group  in case certain nations ran into financial trouble.

title: Breezy Love, or the Sacking of the Bees
description: Birds do it. Bees do it. Beetles, bats and light summer breezes do it.

title: A Small Scandal Overshadows a Big One, and a Governor Gets Breathing Space
description: It was late on Tuesday afternoon of last week when a lawyer turned to a man named Matthew Nelson, who had been testifying under oath at the office of the State Commission on Public Integrity.

title: New Rules Sought on TV Retransmission
description: Trying to prevent the kind of brinkmanship that had ABC removing its affiliate station from millions of New York area homes hours before the Oscar broadcast, a group of television providers asked the government Tuesday to revamp the rules governing the retransmission of stations.

title: Champagne Bubbles Are Extra
description: WHEN the world was young, there was a phenomenon loosely referred to as the Magical World of Television. Pains were taken to dazzle the eye. Chandeliers appeared extra-prismatic, with mescaline auras.

title: Times Co. Appoints a Corporate Spokesman
description: The New York Times Company named Robert H. Christie as its senior vice president for corporate communications on Tuesday, hiring him away from Dow Jones & Company, the News Corporation unit that publishes The Wall Street Journal.

title: Rollins Puts Away His Crystal Ball
description: Kissimmee, Fla.

title: Broad Plan Urged to Fight New Yorks Fiscal Crisis
description: ALBANY  New York could borrow billions of dollars to address its urgent budget shortfall and a financial review board would be established to impose new discipline on future spending under a five-year financial rescue plan that Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch will present Wednesday.

title: Santana, Though Rusty, Passes Test
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The early signs for Johan Santana were not very good Tuesday, but as Mets fans may recall, Santana is a lot more reliable in September than in March.

title: Francisco Cervellis Concussion Has Yanks Attention
description: TAMPA, Fla.  For the most part, Francisco Cervelli had a normal day Tuesday. In the morning, he stretched with teammates on a back field and played catch with Jorge Posada, took batting practice in the indoor cages and worked out with a medicine ball in the weight room.

title: Film Review at Heart of Suit Against Variety
