description: LOS ANGELES  In a step that is unusual even for litigation-heavy Hollywood, the maker of Iron Cross, a small independent film that has yet to find a distributor, charged in a complaint filed on Tuesday that the trade paper Variety had damaged the movie.

title: Red Sox to Cubs, Millar Embraces Another Challenge
description: MESA, Ariz.  The Chicago Cubs clubhouse opened to reporters at 8 a.m. on Tuesday at HoHoKam Park, but Kevin Millar was not available. He was gathering his teammates for a version of American Idol, with Millar as a judge.

title: Delay on Arms Pact Slows Reset of U.S.- Russia Ties
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama got on the telephone with President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia last month, he was under the impression that they were finally close to wrapping up a long-delayed arms control treaty that he had originally expected to sign in December.

title: Health Care Reform and the Doc Fix
description: The Democrats health care reform plan uses some accounting gimmicks that are fair game for criticism, as I note in my column this week. That said, though, one of the most common criticisms strikes me as pretty flimsy.

title: David Kimche, an Israeli Adept as Spy and Diplomat, Dies at 82
description: JERUSALEM  David Kimche, a former Israeli spymaster and senior diplomat who was involved in some of the countrys most delicate foreign escapades, including the Iran-contra affair, which shook the Reagan administration in the 1980s, died on Monday at his home in Ramat Hasharon, a suburb of Tel Aviv. He was 82.

title: St. Johns Rolls On, With No Fight From UConn
description: The saddest thing about the floor-burn victory by St. Johns on Tuesday is that it may not count for much. Connecticut was so apathetic that there is almost no way to gauge just where St. Johns is at the moment.

title: Reyes Gets Encouraging News From Specialists
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets shortstop Jose Reyes has received encouraging news about the tests on his thyroid gland, his agent said Tuesday night.

title: Paging Mr. Herman!
description: In his original 1985 review of "Pee-wee's Big Adventure," Vincent Canby wrote that the film "is the most barren comedy I've seen in years, maybe ever. It introduces motion picture audiences to a popular California comic named Pee-wee Herman, who seems to have put together his public personality by ransacking the wardrobes of his betters." Mr. Canby goes on to add, "Like Marcel Marceau, he appears to be physically slight and he often wears lipstick, but, unfortunately, he won't stop talking and  worse  laughing at his own gags. Like Jacques Tati, he wears pants that are too short, and like Jerry Lewis, he behaves as if he were a child trapped inside the body of a man. Like them all, he desperately wants to be funny but, unlike them, he isn't." Well, many fans of Paul Reubens, who has recently begun to perform again in Los Angeles, may choose to disagree. Tonight the Museum of Modern Art is screening the film, Tim Burton's feature debut.

title: Triple Steps
description: "It's hard to think of a better modern/contemporary triple bill than Merce Cunningham, William Forsythe and Maguy Marin," writes Claudia La Rocco, "And hard to think of a company better suited to tackling such diverse choreographers than the Lyon Opera Ballet." This week the company returns to the Joyce Theater for the first time in more than 15 years. Go especially to see "Beach Birds" (1991), which makes the program "a must-see event; any chance now to see Cunningham's choreography seems precious, as his own company is in the early stages of its farewell international tour before disbanding in 2012. Soon, it seems, repertory ensembles like Lyon will be the main way in which we see Cunningham's miraculous dances live."

title: Java Huts
description: New Yorkers can finally raise their chins when discussing their city and coffee in front of their West Coast brethren. "New York used to be a second-string city when it came to coffee," writes Oliver Strand. "No longer. Over the last two years, more than 40 new cafes and coffee bars have joined a small, dedicated group of establishments where coffee making is treated like an art, or at least a high form of craft." Head to places like the Bluebird Coffee Shop in the East Village, where "the espresso is so plush and bright that it tastes sweet on its own" or Third Rail Coffee in the West Village, which features "elaborate designs in the cappuccino's foam." Or try unusual spots like Saturdays Surf in SoHo and Moomah in TriBeCa. The coffee awakening means that "New Yorkers can now drink coffee that is made from some of the best beans available in the United States and freshly roasted in town." We'll drink to that.

title: Another House Democrat Demands Abortion Restrictions
description: Representative Dan Lipinski, Democrat of Illinois, warned party leaders on Tuesday that he would vote against major health care legislation if it does not include tight restrictions on the use of federal money for insurance coverage of abortions.

title: In Swirl of Paterson Scandal, 2nd State Police Superintendent Quits
description: The acting superintendent of the New York State Police announced his retirement Tuesday, becoming the second senior agency official to leave office since it was revealed that the agency had intervened in a domestic abuse case involving a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson.

title: In Illinois, Democrats Widen the Net
description: CHICAGO  This place is desperate to shed its political reputation for cronyism, insiders and backroom deals, a way of life once boiled down by a ward boss this way: We dont want nobody nobody sent.

title: Retaliation in Nascar Draws Only Probation
description: After imploring drivers to be more aggressive on the racetrack this season to help rebuild fading fan support, Nascar reinforced that message Tuesday by issuing a slap-on-the-wrist three-race probation to Carl Edwards for deliberately wrecking Brad Keselowski on Sunday at Atlanta Motor Speedway.

title: State Agrees to Let the City Finish Brooklyn Bridge Park
description: After months of wrangling, state officials have agreed to let New York City finish building  and paying for  Brooklyn Bridge Park, in the hope of speeding its progress.

title: Excerpts: Applications for No. 2
description: Applicants to be the Illinois Democrats' lieutenant governor nominee reflect a diversity of often unconventional qualifications for office.

title: With Warning, a Hip Device Is Withdrawn
description: A unit of Johnson & Johnson, just months after saying it was phasing out an artificial hip implant because of slowing sales, has warned doctors that the device appears to have a high early failure rate in some patients.

title: Another Rise in City Pupils Graduating in Four Years
description: For the fifth year in a row, New York City students on-time graduation rates have increased, showing small but steady gains, rising to 59 percent last year from 46.5 for the class of 2005, according to figures that state and city education officials released on Tuesday.

title: Minister Withdraws as Investor in Aqueduct Casino
description: The Rev. Floyd H. Flake, one of New Yorks most influential black pastors, announced on Tuesday that he had removed himself as an investor in the company that was chosen by Gov. David A. Paterson to build and operate a casino at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 9, 2010

title: An Italian Antiheros Time to Shine
description: ROME  By at least one amusing new metric, Michelangelos unofficial 500-year run at the top of the Italian art charts has ended. Caravaggio, who somehow found time to paint when he wasnt brawling, scandalizing pooh-bahs, chasing women (and men), murdering a tennis opponent with a dagger to the groin, fleeing police assassins or getting his face mutilated by one of his many enemies, has bumped him from his perch.

title: G.O.P. Sounds Out a Democrat for Governor
description: The Republican nomination for governor, which had for months seemed all but locked up by former United States Representative Rick A. Lazio, became a more unsettled contest on Tuesday when top New York Republicans met with the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, as a potential challenger to Mr. Lazio.

title: As Fed Eases Loan Aid, Policy Challenges Arise
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  The Federal Reserve has terminated nearly all of the extraordinary lending programs it created in 2007 and 2008 to combat the credit crisis. But it now faces critical decisions in coming months about when and how to tighten monetary policy, according to two Fed officials.

title: Offense Leads the Way as Seton Hall Moves On
description: Seton Hall guard Jordan Theodore has developed a reputation for being a whirl on the court. On Tuesday night, he was a steady hand, hitting all four of his 3-point attempts as his number was constantly called by Coach Bobby Gonzalez.

title: Rodriguez Says He Is at Ease Amid Scrutiny
description: Alex Rodriguez said Tuesday that although federal investigators want to meet with him about his ties to a Canadian doctor who is under investigation for possibly distributing performance-enhancing drugs, he was at ease with the situation.

title: Its New York. Its the Stadium. Its the Pinstripe Bowl.
description: There was no welcome mat for sour thoughts at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday when the Yankees announced that the newest postseason college football game, the New Era Pinstripe Bowl, will be played there on Dec. 30.

title: U.N. Honors the 101 Who Served and Died in Haiti
description: UNITED NATIONS  It took nearly 15 minutes to read the full roll call of the dead, as a photograph of each person, with the years of their birth and death, flashed on a screen in the darkened hall. White candles flickered on a dais covered with white hydrangeas, orchids and lilies.

title: New York Triathlon Blocks Club From Using Similar Name
description: Apparently there is room for only one New York City Triathlon group in this town.

title: In Britain, a Debate Over Care for the Elderly
description: LONDON  Every Tuesday, Janet Isobel Bishop walks the few blocks from her rented one-bedroom apartment in Notting Hill to a painting course, followed by tai chi lessons. The classes are paid for by the British government, just like the weekly one-hour visits she receives from a caregiver, who also helps her clean her home.

title: 11 Down: Cricketers Need
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Our final guest solver this week is Dan Feyer, winner of the 2010 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. His notes about todays puzzle appear below.

title: Willie Davis Is Dead at 69; Was Sniders Successor
description: Willie Davis, who succeeded Duke Snider as the center fielder for the Los Angeles Dodgers and used his blazing speed to steal 20 or more bases 11 straight years, led the National League in triples twice and set a record of three stolen bases in a World Series game, was found dead on Tuesday at his home in Burbank, Calif. He was 69.

title: Henry Wittenberg, Champion Wrestler, Dies at 91
description: Henry Wittenberg, an Olympic gold and silver medalist who became one of Americas greatest amateur wrestlers while he was a New York City police officer, died on Tuesday at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 91.

title: No. 1 UConn Improvises to All-Too-Familiar Tune
description: HARTFORD  Kalana Greene, Connecticuts senior guard, does not run up and down a basketball court as much as she bounces on the soles of her blue high-tops, fiercely vaulting from one spot to another, often displaying exquisite timing.

title: 2 Reports of Trouble in Stopping Priuses
description: Just as Toyota was trying to reassure customers about the effectiveness of its recalls, two new reports of unintended acceleration emerged this week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Iraqs parliamentary elections on Sunday misstated a comparison in voter turnout to the last parliamentary elections, held in December 2005. The turnout on Sunday was lower, not higher. (Precise figures from Iraqs election commission, which were not available until Monday, showed 62 percent of eligible voters cast ballots on Sunday, while 76 percent did in December 2005.)

title: Attacks on Detainee Lawyers Split Conservatives
description: A conservative advocacy organization in Washington, Keep America Safe, kicked up a storm last week when it released a video that questioned the loyalty of Justice Department lawyers who worked in the past on behalf of detained terrorism suspects.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about United States government contracts and other benefits received by companies doing business in Iran misstated the date Honeywell, the aviation and aerospace company, notified the State Department that, while a British subsidiary would finish a refinery project in Iran, it would not undertake new projects there. It was January 2009, not last January.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 1 about attempts by Mohamed ElBaradei, the Egyptian diplomat and former director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, to press Egypts leadership for more political freedoms after returning to his country misstated the year that the government first allowed challengers to run against President Hosni Mubarak, who has ruled for nearly 29 years. It was 2005, not 2006.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the future of catcher Joe Mauer, who is in the final year of his contract with the Minnesota Twins, erroneously attributed a distinction, in some copies, to Tony Oliva, who played for the Twins in the 1960s and 1970s. While Oliva was one of baseballs top hitters, he is not in baseballs Hall of Fame.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday night, in citing past ceremonies where there was a sense of drama leading up to the award for best picture, misidentified the film that won that award at the ceremony in 2005. It was Million Dollar Baby, not Crash, which won the following year.

title: New York's Best Coffee
description: Where to find great coffee in the city, day after day.

title: Corrections
description: The TV Watch column in some copies on Monday, about the broadcast of the Academy Awards ceremony, which included a tribute by James Taylor to stars who had died in the past year, erroneously included Jean Simmons among those who died in 2009. She died this year, in January.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on Monday with a fashion column about what female stars wore to the Academy Awards ceremony misidentified an actress in a silver outfit. She was Kate Winslet, not Amanda Seyfried. A credit in some copies misspelled the given name of the photographer who took the picture of Zo Saldana. He is Andrew Gombert of the European Pressphoto Agency, not Andre.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a video on the Funny or Die comedy Web site (funnyordie.com) that features presidential impersonators from Saturday Night Live and was intended to promote financial reforms referred imprecisely at one point to the involvement of the Congressional Oversight Panel. As the article noted elsewhere, the video was partly a result of a conversation between the director Ron Howard and Elizabeth Warren, chairwoman of the panel. No one else from the panel was involved.

title: Applying for an Illinois Election
description: Monica Davey, Chicago Bureau Chief of The Times, discusses the Democratic Party's unusual tactic of soliciting online applications for the lieutenant governor nomination.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Andrew Jaffe, who presided over the expansion of the advertising trade magazine Adweek, misstated the history of the Clio Awards, which Mr. Jaffe took over for BPI Communications in 1997. Wallace A. Ross, who founded the awards in 1959, sold them in 1972; his company did not administer the Clios when ceremonies were disrupted and canceled in 1991.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about the nuclear engineer Thomas H. Pigford misspelled the surname of one of his stepdaughters. She is Janvrin Demler, not Janvrin Deler.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A One-Track Senate
description: THE Senate is badly gummed up. Major policy initiatives  health care reform and financial regulation, to name but two  are stalled in endless negotiations. Theres a big reason for this torpor: the filibuster. But theres a solution: the filibuster. Dont be confused. The two arent the same.

title: Pilgrim Non Grata in Mecca
description: I was tempted to turn my abaya into a black masquerade cloak and sneak into Mecca, just hop over the Tropic of Cancer to the Red Sea and crash the ultimate heavens gate.

title: Meet the Candidate: A Convicted Abuser
description: Former State Senator Hiram Monserrates story would seem to rule him out of any race for public office.

title: In Support of Scientology
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Use the New York Police Dept. Database
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Advisers
description: To the Editor:

title: Darwin, Climate and the Skeptics
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Up to Iraqis Now. Good Luck.
description: Of all the pictures I saw from the Iraqi elections last weekend, my favorite was on nytimes.com: an Iraqi expatriate mother, voting in Michigan, holding up her son to let him stuff her ballot into the box. I loved that picture. Being able to freely cast a ballot for the candidate of your choice is still unusual for Iraqis and for that entire region. That mother seemed to be saying: When I was a child, I never got to vote. I want to live in a world where my child will always be able to.

title: The Great Prostate Mistake
description: Tucson

title: Saving the Post Office
description: Many Americans rely on six-days-a-week mail delivery and expect to have a post office just around the corner. But if the United States Postal Service is going to survive the transition to the Internet age  without requiring billions of dollars of federal subsidies  Congress must allow it to cut some services, close some offices and make other sensible changes.

title: Laws, Lies and the Abortion Debate
description: It has been three years since the Supreme Courts conservative majority abruptly departed from precedent to uphold a federal ban on a particular method of abortion. Emboldened, foes of reproductive freedom are pressing new attacks on womens rights and health.

title: An Advocate for Equal Justice
description: Providing poor defendants effective appointed counsel is more than a constitutional obligation. It is a concrete measure of the nations commitment to equal justice under law. Yet indigent defense offices across the nation have been allowed to sink into crisis. They have fallen victim to insufficient financing, overwhelming caseloads and a slew of policies that hamper effective representation.

title: The Fired Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: John Thorbjarnarson, a Crocodile and Alligator Expert, Is Dead at 52
description: Lets say you are a boy who collects frogs and snakes from a neighborhood bog and who keeps a spectacled caiman and boa constrictor as pets. Further, you take the boa into the family pool to cavort, although the human swimmers might have used a different verb.

title: Q&A: Shirley Tafoya, President of Travelzoo North America
description: Whenever I offer tips on cheap travel deals, one name keeps popping up on the blog comments: Why is Travelzoo not mentioned in this article? Theres simple reason: I never got around to checking out the site. That is, until last week, when I was poking around the Web.

title: A Consumer Bill Gives Exemption on Payday Loans
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Bob Corker, the Tennessee Republican who is playing a crucial role in bipartisan negotiations over financial regulation, pressed to remove a provision from draft legislation that would have empowered federal authorities to crack down on payday lenders, people involved in the talks said. The industry is politically influential in his home state and a significant contributor to his campaigns, records show.

title: Airbuss Parent, Still Confident, Blames Cost Overruns for Net Loss in 2009
description: PARIS  Huge cost overruns at two of its biggest aircraft programs pushed European Aeronautic Defense and Space into a steep loss for 2009. But EADS, the parent company of Airbus, expressed confidence on Tuesday that new financing for its A400M military transport plane and a recovery in demand for commercial aircraft would help restore it to profitability this year.

title: Eurotunnel Eked Out Profit in Tough 09
description: PARIS  The Eurotunnel Group said on Tuesday that it managed a profit in 2009, despite repercussions from a 2008 fire and the disastrous breakdown of Eurostar trains at the height of the year-end travel season.

title: After Victory Over Disney, Group Loses Its Lease
description: For a few days last fall, the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood celebrated a big victory: the tiny advocacy group had successfully pushed the Walt Disney Company to offer full refunds to everyone who had bought the companys popular Baby Einstein videos from June 2004 to September 2009.

title: Federation Updates Its Drug Policy. Why?
description: The World Chess Federation, the governing body of the game, released new antidoping rules for players on Tuesday. The rules replace, or update, previous guidelines.

title: Statues Seem Ready to Leap, but Police Say They Wont
description: They stand about six feet tall and look like naked human beings. Over the next few days, 27 of them will be scattered across rooftops and ledges of buildings in Midtown Manhattan  including the Empire State Building  as part of a public art exhibition.

title: Florida Ponders Tax as Tool to Aid Family-Values Films
description: MIAMI  The movie Bait Shop had too much boozing to earn the extra rebate from Floridas family friendly program of incentives for film production. Confessions of a Shopaholic was, well, just too violent.

title: Krogers Sales Rise, but Profit Declines 27%
description: The Kroger Company said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 27 percent as rising health care and labor costs offset a 7 percent increase in sales.

title: Parliamentary Hurdle Could Thwart Latest Health Care Overhaul Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  The White House and Democratic Congressional leaders said Tuesday that they were bracing for a key procedural ruling that could complicate their effort to approve major health care legislation, by requiring President Obama to sign the bill into law before Congress could revise it through an expedited budget process.

title: Q. and A. With Ken Nye of Ninth Street Espresso
description: After reading Oliver Strands exploration of the dozens of new places in New York serving meticulously crafted coffee, you might be dying for a cup. Or you might find yourself wondering about the intricacies of great espresso, the secrets of roasting and what it takes to run a top-tier coffee bar. Ken Nye at Ninth Street Espresso can take care of your thirst for knowledge and coffee.

title: Time to Celebrate? Not in a Big Way
description: Anniversaries are a good time to reminisce. The global stock market rally is now a year old  the lows were hit on March 9, 2009  and that certainly brings back memories. Its easy to see why the MSCI World Index has surged 71 percent in that period.

title: Google Opens App Store for Business Software
description: Google on Tuesday introduced an online store for business applications in an effort to further push its own suite of productivity software into companies and to compete with Microsoft.

title: Google Maps Adds Directions for Cyclists
description: Cycling enthusiasts tend to be a passionate bunch. So it is not surprising that there are lots of questions about biking information on Google Maps forums. One group, called googlemapsbikethere.org, has collected more than 51,000 signatures asking Google to add biking directions to its maps.

title: MGM Said to Be Considering a Prepackaged Bankruptcy
description: With about 10 days to go before the next round of bids are due, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is still considering other options to help reorganize its almost $4 billion debt load. The options include a potential stand-alone bankruptcy plan, people with direct knowledge of the matter said Tuesday.

title: Word of the Day | whorl
description: whorl \hwor(-)l, wor(-)l, (h)wr(-)l\ noun

title: A Push to Supplement Tuesday Voting With Weekends
description: SAN FRANCISCO  San Francisco would become an electoral test tube under a proposed ballot measure to establish a second day of voting in next years general election, the Saturday before the traditional Tuesday in November.

title: Many Nations Passing U.S. in Education, Expert Says
description: One of the worlds foremost experts on comparing national school systems told lawmakers on Tuesday that many other countries were surpassing the United States in educational attainment, including Canada, where he said 15-year-old students were, on average, more than one school year ahead of American 15-year-olds.

title: Bruce J. Graham, Chicago Architect Who Designed Sears Tower, Dies at 84
description: Bruce J. Graham, whose integration of modernist design and sophisticated engineering in buildings like the John Hancock Center and the Sears Tower transformed the skyline of Chicago and reasserted the citys pre-eminence as a world architectural capital, died on Saturday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 84.

title: Loss Dims Future of Rutgers Coach
description: With Rutgers 69-68 loss to Cincinnati on Tuesday night in the first round of the Big East Tournament, the school now faces a decision on the future of Coach Fred Hill.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Night of the Comebacks
description: Nine games on Tuesday, and six of them were comeback victories. Home teams listed first:

title: MGM Said to Consider Prepackaged Bankruptcy
description: With about 10 days to go before the next round of bids are due, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is still considering other options to help reorganize its almost $4 billion debt load. They include a potential stand-alone bankruptcy plan, people with direct knowledge of the matter said Tuesday, Michael J. de la Merced reports in The New York Times.

title: Edgar Wayburn, a Leader in Saving the Wilderness, Dies at 103
description: Edgar Wayburn, a physician who joined the Sierra Club to take a burro trip and then went on to become a major figure in the conservation movement, leading campaigns that preserved more than 100 million wild acres, died Friday at his home in San Francisco. He was 103.

title: Irish Rethinking Football Independence
description: Calling the state of college sports the most unstable he has seen in 29 years, Notre Dame Athletic Director Jack Swarbrick said Tuesday that the Irish were considering giving up their football independence.

title: Correction
description: An article last Wednesday about Blue Bottle Coffee opening a coffee bar and roaster in Brooklyn misstated its Web address. It is bluebottlecoffee.net, not bluebottle.net.

title: Is the Fred Hill Era Done at Rutgers?
description: It was hard to listen to Rutgers Coach Fred Hill early Wednesday morning and not think that he sounded a bit delusional. Hill has won 13 Big East games in his four years as Rutgers coach. His team finished No. 14 in the league this year and wont be playing in any postseason games after going 15-17.

title: Letters of Condolence From 1963
description: WHO wrote letters of condolence to Mrs. Kennedy in the months after John F. Kennedys assassination in 1963? WHO went through the archives of those letters to publish 250 of them?

title: News Quiz | March 10, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Apollo Said to Buy Citis Real Estate Unit
description: Apollo Management agreed to buy Citigroups real estate investment unit in a move that would more than triple the value of the private-equity firms property assets, a person with knowledge of the deal told Bloomberg News on Tuesday.

title: Time to Celebrate? Not in a Big Way
description: Anniversaries are a good time to reminisce, Breakingviews says. The global stock market rally is now a year old  the lows were hit on March 9, 2009  and that certainly brings back memories.

title: In Europe, Calls for Crackdown on Derivatives
description: Goldman Sachs had a bright idea for its clients: buy credit-default swaps  those controversial instruments that helped trip up the American International Group  in case certain nations ran into financial trouble.

title: Wintrust Raises $182.9 Million in Offering
description: Wintrust Financial, which operates community bank subsidiaries, said Tuesday it sold 5.8 million shares in a public offering that netted about $182.9 million, The Associated Press reported.

title: As Fed Eases Loan Aid, Policy Challenges Arise
description: The Federal Reserve has terminated nearly all of the extraordinary lending programs it created in 2007 and 2008 to combat the credit crisis. But it now faces critical decisions in coming months about when and how to tighten monetary policy, according to two Fed officials.

title: Equity One to Launch Stock Offering
description: Equity One, the shopping center owner, said Tuesday it would sell 4.2 million shares of stock in a public offering, The Associated Press reported.

title: What Signs of Seasonal Change Are You Seeing?
description: The temperature in New York City has nudged above 50 for five days in a row now, and after a winter of record snow, many New Yorkers are feeling giddy. What signs of seasonal change are you seeing where you live? What is your reaction to them?

title: Geely Said to Lock in Volvo Financing
description: Zhejiang Geely Holding, the Chinese carmaker that struck a deal with Ford in December to by its Swedish unit Volvo, has finally secured the necessary financing, people with knowledge of the matter told DealBook.

title: V.C.s Shower FirstRain With Financing
description: FirstRain, an investment research service, has landed a $7.3 million tranche of an expected $8.8 million financing round, VentureBeat reported, citing a regulatory filing.

title: Todacell Rings Up Another $1 Million
description: Todacell, a smartphone advertising network, has rounded up an additional $1 million to top off an existing $1 million round that the start-up landed in June, PaidContent reported.

title: Zhang Hongs Letter About His Editorial
description: This letter, by Zhang Hong, a Chinese journalist who was fired after writing an editorial that criticized Chinas household registration system, was released Tuesday to selected Chinese and foreign journalists and translated by the New York Times Beijing bureau.

title: Citi Brings Former Tribridge Manager on Board
description: Citigroup has tapped a former hedge fund manager at Tribridge Investment Partners, John Liptak, to lead the banks Asia- Pacific distressed and special situations group, Bloomberg News reported, citing an internal memo.

title: Citi Said to Plan $2 Billion Securities Sale
description: Citigroup, seeking to bolster capital after repaying bailout funds to the Treasury, is selling trust-preferred securities as rising investor demand drives borrowing costs to near the lowest in almost five years, Bloomberg News reported.

title: U.S. Regulators Said to Tell Banks to Keep Cash
description: While banks like JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs have enough liquidity to consider raising dividends or buying back stock, regulators have told U.S. banks to preserve their cash for the moment, The Financial Times reported, citing unidentified sources.

title: American Idol: A Place Holder Departs?
description: Let me start with a positive: this will be Paige Miless last week on American Idol. Thats good news  for her, for the viewers, for the Idol system that allowed her to make the top 24 without properly vetting her in the court of popular opinion. Despite Simons continued insistence that Ms. Miles has one of the best voices of this season, shes been inconsistent and charmless, and her rendition of Smile this week was awkward and shaky, a final affirmation of her place-holder status.

title: Gartmore Swings to Profit in 2009
description: Gartmore Group, the London-based fund manager that went public in December, returned to profit in 2009 and said it was seeing strong inflows into its hedge funds, according to press reports.

title: Love Never Dies
description: Photos from Andrew Lloyd Webbers sequel to The Phantom of the Opera.

title: Showcase: God Is in the Details
description: Godless? New York? Please. The city where Mitzvah Tanks patrol the streets and subway evangelists shout Hallelujah over the roar of trains and supplicants eke out nooks in which to place their prayer rugs and face the Kaaba at Mecca; the city where St. Pats is both an event and a landmark? God (or at least one mans self-proclaimed interpretation) is evident outside Trinity Church at the head of Wall Street. And there are New Yorkers who would look at this simple sidewalk shadow and see a heavenly manifestation. God, you might say, is everywhere.

title: Stanford and Madoff Groups Team Up for Lobby
description: Who should pay for the lies told by swindlers and the mistakes made by their investors?

title: Palestinians Hold to Plan for New Talks
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Palestinian leaders meeting with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. here on Wednesday harshly condemned Israels decision, announced a day earlier, to add 1,600 housing units for Jews in East Jerusalem, but they gave no indication that they would stay away from the approaching indirect peace negotiations with the Israelis.

title: Caution Rules as Major Indexes Inch Forward
description: On the one-year anniversary of the stock markets plunge to 12-year lows, Wall Street found itself at another crossroads. This time, the question for investors was not so much whether the economy would turn around, but just how strong a recovery would be, The New York Timess Javier C. Hernandez reported.

title: Airport Built, Its Time to See if the Traffic Comes
description: The first new international airport in the United States in more than decade is set to open in May near Panama City, Fla., a community of 37,000 people on the states panhandle. That is no small feat given the environmental, regulatory and financial hurdles involved in building runways and terminals, as well as community opposition to planes flying overhead.

title: C.E.O. Bonuses Fell 22% In 2009, Study Says
description: U.S. consumer, financial and technology companies slashed bonuses for their chief executives by more than half in 2009, a leading firm that tracks pay data said on Tuesday, as companies moved to more closely tie executive pay to performance.

title: A.I.G. Said to Devise New Formula for Bonuses
description: The American International Group will soon adopt its new forced ranking system to determine bonuses and rate employee performance, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Digital Billboards: A View From the Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Britains Northern Rock Returns to Profit
description: Northern Rock, the nationalized British mortgage lender, said on Wednesday that it returned to profit in the second half of 2009 as interest income rose and losses on loans fell, The Associated Press reported.

title: Paris: McQueen Was Here
description: Someday there will be a retrospective of the fashion of Alexander McQueen, and if it ends with the 15 pieces shown here in a small salon the survey will indeed feel complete. The final collection of the designer, who committed suicide on Feb. 11, saw him returning to the historical past, in particular medieval symbols of faith and morality.

title: Finance Reform Bill May Exempt Payday Lenders
description: Senator Bob Corker, the Tennessee Republican who is playing a crucial role in bipartisan negotiations over financial regulation, pressed to remove a provision from draft legislation that would have empowered federal authorities to crack down on payday lenders, people involved in the talks said. The industry is politically influential in his home state and a significant contributor to his campaigns, records show.

title: Walking the ArtWalk in Hong Kong
description: Hong Kongs biggest gallery crawl snakes through the city on March 17, when 62 galleries open their doors for the 10th annual ArtWalk (hongkongartwalk.com), an entertaining evening of art, food and drink that raises money for local charities. Tickets, which cost 430 Hong Kong dollars ($56.50, at 7.60 Hong Kong dollars to the U.S. dollar) and are on sale at six sites around town, listed on the events Web site, offer access to participating galleries, the bulk of them in and around SoHo, a short walk from the Central district. And 56 area restaurants, each one teamed with a gallery, will offer finger food, wine and beer. John Batten, the organizer of ArtWalk, is expecting a similar crowd to last years event, which drew about 2,000 visitors.

title: Questions Answered: Invented Languages
description: In January, co-vocabularists were invited to pose questions to two experts in the field of invented languages: Paul Frommer (the developer of Avatars novel tongue, Navi) and Arika Okrent (author of In the Land of Invented Languages).

title: Making a Killing on Death Bonds?
description: In an unusual type of bond deal that might have had even Freud pondering its morbid implications, companies like the American International Group, Bank of America and GE Capital issue discounted bonds to buyers who have teamed up with someone who is about to die, The Wall Street Journal reports.

title: Music Without Octaves
description: Todays idea: An alternative musical system has attracted adherents around the world seeking to move beyond the basic building blocks of Western music and to discover how the brain learns a musical language.

title: More Wires in Galleon Probe, Report Says
description: Federal prosecutors wired several cooperating witnesses in the Galleon Group insider trading case in order to obtain information on other targets of the investigation, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Partial Iraq Vote Results Expected Thursday
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs electoral commission is expected to announce partial results of parliamentary elections by Thursday, a United Nations official said, offering an incomplete picture of the vote that will nevertheless provide the broad outlines of the countrys political landscape.

title: U.S. Defense Chief Visits Saudi Arabia to Bolster Effort Against Iran
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates told the royal family of Saudi Arabia on Wednesday that the United States wanted to help build up the kingdoms military defenses against the growing threat of Iran, but also needed its help in pressing for new United Nations sanctions on Tehran.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Michael Moorcock
description: Michael Moorcocks science fiction and fantasy novels include the Cornelius chronicles and the Eternal Champions series, featuring the character Elric of Melnibon. His second Hawkmoon novel, The Mad Gods Amulet, will be published in April.

title: China Mobile Puts $5.8 Billion Into Pudong Bank
description: China Mobile, the worlds largest mobile carrier, said it would pay $5.8 billion for 20 percent of Shanghai Pudong Development Bank and would jointly develop mobile finance and e-commerce businesses with the bank, Reuters reported.

title: Suspects Death Leads to Questions on Indonesias Border Security
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The fugitive Islamic militant killed by Indonesian security forces traveled to Indonesia from the Philippines within the last few months, police officals said on Wednesday, an admission that raised concerns about the countrys ability to keep known terrorists from moving across its borders.

title: Did the Minimum Wage Increase Destroy Jobs?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: For Buyout Shops, a Decade to Spend Capital?
description: Buyout shops may have some trouble unloading the half-trillion dollars sitting in their coffers, waiting for deals.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, March 10
description: Here are some highlights from Wednesdays editions of The New York Times:

title: Sampler: Second Election Day Proposed in San Francisco, and San Jose Voters to Decide on More Gambling
description: San Francisco Considers Two Polling Days | A proposed ballot measure would make San Francisco an electoral test tube  by adding a second day of voting  the Saturday before the Tuesday  in general elections held in November. Other states like Louisiana have similar programs but not for the biennial general elections. Alex Tourk, a political consultant who is organizing the campaign for the measure, said he wanted to increase access to the polls and make it easier for people with work and child care issues to vote. Weekday voting creates barriers, he said. The proposal needs 7,178 signatures from registered voters to qualify for Novembers ballot. [The New York Times]

title: The Book Wears a Jacket
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: Lone Star Puts Korean Bank Back Up for Sale
description: The private equity fund Lone Star plans to resume selling a $3.9 billion majority stake in Korea Exchange Bank, K.E.B. said, in what would rank as South Koreas biggest banking deal to date, Reuters reported.

title: The Early Word: Jobs Vote, Health Push
description: A $140 billion jobs bill that would provide tax breaks for businesses and extend unemployment aid through December is up for a vote on the Senate floor Wednesday.

title: Rhodes Criticizes Jets; Anderson Criticizes Browns Fans
description: Kerry Rhodes and Derek Anderson may have a little extra motivation the next time they face their former teams.

title: Wal-Mart Is Top GPS Destination, Says One Report
description: To understand societal trends and where America is going, you dont necessarily need to conduct a census. All one may have to do is look at how people use their GPS devices.

title: The Futures So Bright
description: One day, genetic researchers may be able to manipulate cow cells into growing cruelty-free in-vitro leather, or even magical disembodied hamburgers. But in the meantime, theyve been teaching Joris Laarman  the science-obsessed Dutch designer whose computer-generated Bone Chair caused a frenzy among collectors in 2007  how to put their experiments to good use. Laarmans new biomorphic furniture, on view now at the New York gallery Friedman Benda, includes a lamp coated in genetically modified hamster cells that have been engineered to light up like those inside a firefly. Housed in a glass dome fed liquid nutrients and an enzyme, the lamp glows without electricity. If products can be grown in a lab, we wont have to use natural resources, Laarman says. Its the most perfect production method there is. Granted, the lamps cells run according to their own biorhythm, charging during the day and emitting light at night  so theres no on and off switch. But hey, anythings better than compact fluorescents.

title: California to Regulate Most Potent Greenhouse Gas
description: Starting in 2011, California will regulate emissions from electric utility equipment of the gas sulfur hexafluoride  commonly called SF6. It is typically used in high voltage transmission systems in circuit breakers, switches and insulation, according to a recent California Air Resources Board announcement.

title: Second State Police Superintendent Resigns
description: The acting superintendent of the New York State Police announced his retirement Tuesday, becoming the second senior agency official to leave office in a matter of days, since it was revealed that the agency had intervened in a domestic abuse case involving a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson.

title: Market Rises on Sense That Worst Is Behind Big Financials
description: A renewed sense that Wall Streets biggest financial companies had endured the worst of the economic downturn helped lead the stock market higher on Wednesday.

title: Corey Haim, Actor, Has Died
description: 12:53 p.m. | Updated Corey Haim, an actor whose status as a teenage heartthrob of the 1980s gave way to harsh adult realities of substance abuse and rehabilitation, has died, the Los Angeles Police Department said on Wednesday. He was 38.

title: WWS 543, March 10
description: Notes. (pdf)

title: Spider-Man Musical Loses Its Mary Jane
description: The long delays hindering the anticipated Broadway musical Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark has claimed another casualty: The actress Evan Rachel Wood, who was set to play Mary Jane Watson in the show, has dropped out because of a scheduling conflict, according to a statement from the Spider-Man producers.

title: Albertas Tar Sands and the Dead Duck Trial
description: In an Alberta court, the oil sands giant Syncrude Canada has entered the second week of a high-profile case brought by federal and provincial prosecutors over the widely publicized deaths two years ago of 1,600 migrating ducks that were trapped in the toxic sludge floating on one of the companys vast tailings ponds.

title: Terra Deems CFs New Bid Superior to Yaras Offer
description: Terra Industries said on Wednesday that it had deemed a new $4.7 billion takeover offer by CF Industries Holdings superior to a $4.1 billion deal it had already signed with Yara International of Norway.

title: Panel Proposes Single Standard for All Schools
description: A panel of educators convened by the nations governors and state school superintendents proposed a uniform set of academic standards on Wednesday, laying out their vision for what all the nations public school children should learn in math and English, year by year, from kindergarten to high school graduation.

title: Lost Watch: Able Was I Ere I Saw Elba
description: Warning: This post contains spoilers.

title: Google Maps Adds Biking Routes
description: Starting today, Google is offering biking routes in 150 American cities in Google Maps, giving travelers another way to see the sites. According to the Gagetwise blog, Google Maps will also offer a view geared for cyclists that will display bike-friendly routes. A mobile version is likely to follow soon, said Shannon Guymon, a product manager for Google Maps Directions. Read more

title: Model-morphosis | Valentino
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Jacquelyn Jablonski from Ford Model Management before (left, right) and after makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Luigi Murenu. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Iranian Leader and Gates Trade Jabs in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Iranian president visited Kabul on Wednesday and shot back at American allegations that Iran was providing support to Afghan insurgents, accusing the United States of playing its own double game.

title: Broken Record: Music Chief Is Out at EMI
description: The troubled music company EMI announced Wednesday that Elio Leoni-Sceti, the chief executive of its recorded music division, would step down at the end of the month. The company gave no reason for Mr. Leoni-Scetis unexpected departure.

title: Foreign Leagues May Be Players Trump Card
description: Is it time to rethink the summer of LeBron James?

title: Helped by Olympics, NBC Nightly News Has a Big February
description: How many new viewers did the Winter Olympics deliver to NBCs nightly newscast? About a million, Nielsen numbers indicate.

title: The Drop Stops: Patersons Poll Numbers Level Off
description: Gov. David A. Patersons approval rating among voters is as low as it has ever been, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released Wednesday.

title: From Arms to Entitlements
description: Over the past four decades, the amount of money the United States spends on Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security has more than doubled as a share of the economy. In 1970, the federal government spent 3.8 percent of gross domestic product on these programs. By 2007, the percentage had risen to 8.2 percent.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Columbus Rallies for a Tie in Concacaf Champions League
description: Do blond strikers have more fun and score more goals?

title: How Oscar Found Ms. Right
description: KATHRYN BIGELOWS two-fisted win at the Academy Awards for best director and best film for The Hurt Locker didnt just punch through the American movie industrys seemingly shatterproof glass ceiling; it has also helped dismantle stereotypes about what types of films women can and should direct. It was historic, exhilarating, especially for women who make movies and women who watch movies, two groups that have been routinely ignored and underserved by an industry in which most films star men and are made for and by men. Its too early to know if this moment will be transformative  but damn, it feels so good.

title: Retro Modern
description: First things first. Marc Newson goes to the fridge of his newly designed kitchen. Do you want a drink? he asks, and pulls out a lager. Its 7 p.m. His wife, the stylist Charlotte Stockdale, is just putting their 2-year-old to bed. Hes unwinding. Tomorrow morning he flies to Italy to finish work on the speedboat hes designing for Riva.

title: Increasing Yields and Decreasing Fertilizer Waste on Subsistence Farms
description: A new agricultural technology that cuts nitrogen fertilizer waste in half while increasing rice yields is spreading quickly in Bangladesh and is being investigated by 15 other nations, including more than a dozen in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Oscar Winners Plot Next Moves
description: We know, we know, youre still hungry for Oscar news. The Bagger will help you deal with that craving for a few more days. Our first dish: The Los Angeles Times rounds up the future plans of some of the winners.

title: Rodriguez Says Lawyers Are Scheduling Interview With Authorities
description: Alex Rodriguez said Wednesday that his lawyers were working on scheduling an interview with federal authorities who are investigating a Canadian-based doctor suspected of distributing performance-enhancing drugs. Rodriguez said he hoped the interview would be in Florida and not Buffalo, so it would not interfere with his preparation for the season.

title: Brown, Senator and G.O.P. Star, Will Write Memoir
description: Scott P. Brown, the Republican politician from Massachusetts who pulled out a surprise victory in January to win the United States Senate seat long held by the Democrat Edward M. Kennedy, will write a memoir about his life and political career, the publisher HarperCollins said on Wednesday. Mr. Brown, who served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives and State Senate before defeating Martha Coakley, the attorney general and Democratic candidate, in a special election, said he would write about his family background and ascent to office, as well as his values and policies of interest to him. I am humbled to have the opportunity to share my personal story in hopes to inform, encourage and inspire others, Mr. Brown said in a statement.

title: White House Spars With the Chief Justice
description: The White House is hitting back against criticism from Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. on Tuesday, when he complained about the political scene surrounding the State of the Union speech when President Obama criticized a Supreme Court decision on campaign financing.

title: Answers About the Gowanus Canal
description: Following is the first set of responses from Jack S. Nyman, the director of the Steven L. Newman Real Estate Institute at Baruch College, City University of New York.

title: Geely Said to Lock In Volvo Financing
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Concocting a Cure for Kids With Issues
description: If youre the parent of a child whos having trouble learning or behaving in school, you quickly find yourself confronted with a series of difficult choices.

title: Tycoon Wins Libel Suit in Ex-Spys Murder Case
description: Boris A. Berezovsky, a self-exiled Russian tycoon, won a libel suit in London on Wednesday against a Russian satellite broadcaster that had linked him to the murder in 2006 of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a onetime aide and former K.G.B. operative who was poisoned with a rare radioactive isotope.

title: South Park at 200: Trey Parker and Matt Stone Apologize to No One
description: Maybe the secret to longevity isnt clean living or exercise, but anger. In its 13 years, South Park, the Comedy Central animated series, has thrived on a diet of vitriol  usually directed at it by the targets of its willfully crude satire. In recent seasons the show has taken aim at Tom Cruise and the Church of Scientology, Kanye West (before he imploded at the MTV Video Music Awards) and Avatar (saddling it with the uncomplimentary nickname Dances With Smurfs before it opened); and been protested by organizations from the Catholic League to the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation.

title: Photos of the Moment | Gallic Chic
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Q. and A.: The Economics of Coffee Bars
description: Ken Nye, owner of Ninth Street Espresso, responds to readers questions about coffee and coffee bars:

title: Yoink if You Want Free Stuff
description: Your spring cleaning and refurnishing efforts could get some help this year from Yoink, a new iPhone app and Web site which lists items nearby that are free for the taking.

title: Purple, Pink, Green
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: The White House unveiled its official eggs for the 2010 Easter Egg Roll on April 5. The official eggs come in purple, pink, green and, why are we talking about Easter eggs instead of health care?

title: Rove on Rove: A Conversation With the Former Bush Senior Adviser
description: Karl Rove, the former senior adviser and deputy White House chief of staff under President George W. Bush, on Tuesday published a memoir, Courage and Consequence: My Life as a Conservative in the Fight. The Times caught up with him in New York to talk about democracy in Iraq, the impact of the C.I.A. leak case and questions about his mothers suicide and his fathers sexual orientation. This is an edited transcript:

title: Live Updates From the Big East Tournament, Day 2
description: Four more games are on the schedule Wednesday at the Big East mens basketball tournament. The Timess Pete Thamel and Kevin Armstrong, along with Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward who is now an academic adviser in the athletic department, are at Madison Square Garden and will provide analysis and updates throughout the day. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comment section below. Georgetown 69, South Florida 49Marquette 57, St. Johns 55

title: An Elaborate Hoax
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: In the morning here at CBS, they have The Early Show. Tomorrow on The Early Show, host Harry Smith is having a live colonoscopy. I know what youre thinking: Finally, real breakfast fun. Here we go. Bring it on.

title: Ex-N.Y. Investment Officer Pleads Guilty to Corruption
description: The former chief investment official for New York States comptrollers office pleaded guilty on Wednesday to a felony for his role in steering investment opportunities in the states pension fund to firms connected to former state officials.

title: Tourism is Way Down
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Well, big changes announced today for the next Indianapolis 500. All the cars will be Toyota Priuses.

title: Planet Green Moves Away From Its Eco Theme
description: The two-year-old Planet Green cable channel doesnt want to be defined by a single color anymore.

title: Not Noticing That Youre Pregnant
description: These stories make the news every so often, and each time I see one I marvel anew.

title: Courtside Fan Has a Hand in the Game
description: As if the Toronto Raptors did not have enough to worry Tuesday night, playing the Los Angeles Lakers at the Staples Center, guard Jose Calderon also had to battle a fan sitting courtside for possession of the ball.

title: The New Yorker and New York Set the Pace in National Magazine Awards
description: Once again, The New Yorker and New York magazine lead in the running for the annual National Magazine Awards, with each magazine named 10 times in the list of finalists released on Wednesday. National Geographic, whose critical acclaim has grown in the last few years, is a seven-time finalist, followed by Esquire, GQ and Wired with six each; and The New York Times Magazine and Vanity Fair with five apiece.

title: Most Believe God Gets Involved
description: When the American Idol judge Simon Cowell recently predicted the departure of the contestant Jermaine Sellers, the young singer shook his head in disagreement. I know God, he replied, pointing upward.

title: Home Before He Knew He Was Pardoned
description: On Tuesday night, four days after Gov. David A. Paterson announced that he had pardoned a young information technology executive who had risen from immigrant poverty and street crime in Chinatown, the executive, Qing Hong Wu, still unaware of the pardon, was released from a New Jersey immigration jail where he had been facing deportation.

title: Kevin Millars Unconventional Path to the Pros
description: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  One of the reasons Kevin Millar felt comfortable playing in Chicago  where he will try to end another teams tortured legacy  was his familiarity with Gary Hughes. It was Hughes, a special assistant in the Cubs front office, who signed Millar into professional baseball.

title: Democrat Drops Out of Race for Murtha Seat
description: Barbara Hafer, a former Pennsylvania treasurer, has withdrawn from the race for the House seat long held by John P. Murtha, according to multiple published reports.

title: Queen B
description: She may be a fashion-world legend, but Joan Burstein, whose groundbreaking London emporium Browns turns 40 this year, isnt one to rest on her laurels. She presides over six locations, including a free-standing shoe salon and a mens shop, where she continues to introduce customers to the latest and greatest designers. I like to think I have a good instinct, but Im still learning every day, she says. These are much more challenging times, but they are also a lot more interesting. More

title: Horse Owner Convicted of Animal Cruelty
description: Ernie Paragallo, a prominent thoroughbred breeder and owner, was convicted on 33 charges of animal cruelty Wednesday morning for starving and neglecting his horses on his Hudson Valley farm.

title: Sheen Headed Back to Two and a Half Men
description: The hit CBS comedy Two and a Half Men, which has lately been down one man, will be back to full staffing next week. A publicist for Charlie Sheen told The Hollywood Reporter that the actor would return to the CBS show on Tuesday after he exits a rehabilitation facility and appears Monday in an Aspen, Colo., court to face domestic abuse charges.

title: Faith No More Kicks Off Williamsburg Concerts
description: The first summer concert at the Williamsburg waterfront this season will be epic, in at least one sense of the word: the reunited Faith No More will perform its first East Coast show in more than a decade on July 5 at North Eighth Street and Kent Avenue on the East River in Brooklyn, the Open Space Alliance for North Brooklyn said on Wednesday.

title: Does Lack of Insurance Kill?
description: How many people die because they lack health insurance has been a matter of debate recently.

title: How to Drive a Zamboni
description: Nick Kurczewski, an automotive journalist, takes a step-by-step course on how to drive an ice-resurfacer at the Battery Park City Ice Rink in Lower Manhattan.

title: Views of JihadJane Were Unknown to Neighbors
description: The Pennsylvania woman linked this week to an alleged terrorist plot involving militant Muslims was not known in her neighborhood for extreme religious views. There were no religious books or hangings in her apartment, several neighbors said, and she never spoke about her religion.

title: Top 10 U.S. Value Cities
description: Looking for a cheap vacation? Try Atlanta.

title: Safe in Bed?
description: Early on Christmas morning in 2004, a staff member walked into Harry Griph Sr.s room at the New Perspective assisted living facility in Brookfield, Wis., and found that Mr. Griph had died.

title: Its Budget Time, and New Yorkers Are in Full Protest
description: Ever since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled on Jan. 28 a budget proposal that he warned would be full of difficult choices, the usual protagonists and antagonists have been gradually ramping up for an annual ritual at City Hall that involves protests, hearings and more protests.

title: U.S. Charity Is Attacked In Pakistan; 6 Are Killed
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Six Pakistani employees of the American Christian charity World Vision were killed Wednesday and seven others were wounded in an attack on the aid groups offices in a remote village in northern Pakistan.

title: California Utility Regulators Not Quite Ready for Fuel Cells
description: While Google, Wal-Mart and other corporations have embraced fuel cells, California regulators have turned down requests from the states two biggest utilities to install the technology.

title: The Perils of March
description: Today we are forming a support group for sports downtrodden figures, the insulted and the injured. It will add more college basketball coaches in the coming days (Roy Williams, come on down!) as conference tournaments crush their N.C.A.A. tournament hopes. They can be welcomed by Connecticuts Jim Calhoun, if he can muster the energy for a hug. Mike Dunleavy, ignominiously fired twice in one season by the Clippers, has plenty of energy but still may be venting it all at the teams owner, Donald Sterling.

title: Chevys New Lightweight Corvette: The Z06 Carbon Limited Edition
description: Chevrolet introduced a new Corvette model Wednesday that is, according to General Motors, the most nimble-footed of the breed. Known as the Z06 Carbon Limited Edition, this latest Vette is positioned in the gap between the top-of-the-line ZR1 and the less pricey Z06.

title: Backstage: John Galliano
description: Backstage scenes at the John Galliano fall 2010 show in Paris.

title: Doctor Leaves UBS for Citis Health Care Team
description: Dr. Aradhana Sarin is leaving UBS to join Citigroups global health care investment banking team in New York, according to an internal memo obtained by DealBook. Ms. Sarin will be a managing director in the group, reporting to Bill Clark, Michael Hill and Chris Hite.

title: The New Collectibles
description: To have and hold on to. More

title: Furs Rebound on New York Runways
description: At New York Fashion Week, fur became a trend because of a marketing campaign.

title: 12-Hour Dostoyevsky Play on Tap for Lincoln Center Festival
description: The Lincoln Center Festival, one of the cultural highlights of New York City in summertime, will mount two North American premiere productions on Governors Island in July: A 12-hour marathon performance of The Demons, the director Peter Steins adaptation of the Dostoyevsky novel, and a theatrical re-imagining of Pier Paolo Pasolinis novel and film Teorema, by the director Ivo van Hove.

title: Cautiously Optimistic on Ground Zero Project
description: As Gov. David A. Paterson was taking questions on Wednesday morning from members of a Lower Manhattan business group, one audience member wanted to know what, if anything, he was doing about the bureaucratic impasse that has stalled development at the former World Trade Center site.

title: Former Hevesi Aide Pleads Guilty in Corruption Case
description: ALBANY  David J. Loglisci, the former chief investment officer of the state pension fund, pleaded guilty to a felony violation of state securities law in state court Wednesday morning and is cooperating with Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomos investigation into pension corruption, Mr. Cuomos office said.

title: Credit Card Rewards for Volunteers
description: If you hold an American Express card, volunteering can do more for you than make you feel good about yourself. It can give you credit card reward points.

title: Wall Street Journal Sheds a Restaurant Critic
description: Raymond Sokolov, who has reviewed restaurants for The Wall Street Journal since 2006, is leaving the paper. Mr. Sokolov said his editors had told him The Journal was abandoning restaurant criticism, and asked him to report on food trends instead. After thinking it over, he said, he declined this new beat.

title: Alston Explains Unexplained Exit From Heat
description: Veteran guard Rafer Alston said he isnt second-guessing last weeks abrupt decision to leave the Miami Heat.

title: The Rockefeller Republican Health Care Bill
description: Ezra Klein has been getting some grief for two almost back-to-back blog posts: In the first one, he tried to persuade skeptical progressives that the health care bill represents an enormous leftward shift for American social policy, only to turn around in the second post and suggest that conservatives are insane for freaking out about such a perfectly moderate, not-at-all left-wing piece of legislation. Trying to resolve the apparent contradiction, he writes:

title: For Iraqis, Suffering Is a Reason to Vote
description: Full Coverage

title: Answers From a Theater Historian
description: Following is the first set of answers from Marc Robinson, the author of The American Play: 1787-2000. More answers will be posted tomorrow.

title: Granderson Gets a Ride in the Jetermobile
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Curtis Granderson got a ride back with some new friends from Mondays game in Bradenton. Derek Jeter was driving. Alex Rodriguez rode shotgun.

title: Connecticut Sues Moodys and S.&P. Over Ratings
description: Connecticuts attorney general sued Moodys Investors Service and Standard & Poors on Wednesday over ratings that they issued on risky investments, The Associated Press reports.

title: Swedish Artist Has His Ax Ready
description: Three years ago, after Danish cartoons mocking the Prophet Muhammad enraged Muslims around the world, a Swedish artist named Lars Vilks had trouble finding a gallery willing to show his satirical drawing of the prophets head on the body of a dog. On Wednesday, it was suddenly hard to avoid Mr. Vilkss drawing in Sweden  several Swedish newspapers published it, one day after seven people were arrested in Ireland in connection with a plot to kill him.

title: Spitzer Documentary on Tribeca Film Festival Lineup
description: A work-in-progress viewing of a documentary about Eliot Spitzer, the former New York governor, directed by Alex Gibney, an Academy Award winner for Taxi to the Dark Side, will be shown as a special event at the Tribeca Film Festival, its organizers said on Wednesday. In a news release, the festival said the documentary will explore the hidden contours of this tale of hubris, sex and power with unique access to friends and enemies of the ex-governor.

title: Profile in Style | Pierre-Alexis Dumas
description: Despite the fact that his surname is practically synonymous with a Gallic sense of understated elegance, Pierre-Alexis Dumas, the artistic director of one of the oldest and most prestigious family-owned companies in France, doesnt have much patience for most peoples idea of luxury. When you start to use that word, youre pretty desperate, he says. I have seen so-called luxury products that have failed miserably after three weeks. We are a quality manufacturer. My concern in life is, What does quality mean and how do you achieve it? Its a question that Dumas, 43, has been tackling all his life, though it was only in 2006 that he took over the creative reins of Herms from his father, Jean-Louis. I grew up in Herms, so I always relate it to family and home, something thats very natural and intimate, Dumas says. For me, Herms is about the mystery and miracle of life. More

title: Zamboni Driving Lessons
description: It might have an exotic Italian name, but any similarities between a Zamboni and the glamorous world of Ferrari and Lamborghini ends there. A Zamboni is ponderously slow and definitely not street legal. Its job is to clean and smooth the surface of an ice rink.

title: No Noise Is Good Noise
description: Do artificial intelligence and Beyonce have a future together?

title: Chicken Pot Pie Gets Simplified
description: I have nothing against chicken pot pie; in fact I love it. But honestly, I probably havent made it in 10 years, because if Im going to make a crust, Im going to use it for dessert. Here, then, is chicken pot pie re-envisioned as chicken cobbler, with a super-fast biscuit topping (and, IMHO, better filling).

title: Ex-Hevesi Aide Pleads Guilty in Pension Case
description: From Danny Hakim at City Room:

title: 'Maria Abramovic Presents'
description: An excerpt from a performance art workshop with the artist that was part of the 2009 Manchester International Festival in England. (Video courtesy of the Foundation for Art and Creative Technology)

title: District Attorney Raids Construction Office in Manhattan
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office raided the offices of Lehr Construction early Wednesday, seizing project records, bidding documents and other records as part of a growing investigation into the interior construction industry.

title: Q. and A.: What About Snobbish Baristas?
description: Ken Nye of Ninth Street Espresso responds again to more readers questions about coffee and coffee bars.

title: Obama Pledges U.S. Aid to Haiti
description: WASHINGTON  As the United States military steadily reduces its presence in Haiti, President Obama pledged on Wednesday to remain committed to providing financial assistance and humanitarian relief to help Haitians rebuild and recover from their devastating earthquake two months ago.

title: When You Can Claim a Credit for the Babysitter
description: In a Bucks post on Tuesday about 10 tax benefits available for parents, one break mentioned was a tax credit of up to 20 to 35 percent, depending on income, of qualifying child care expenses for children age 12 or younger (or older children incapable of caring for themselves).

title: Wizards Drama Continues
description: Drama, thy name is the Washington Wizards.

title: An Oscar Bounce for The Hurt Locker
description: Just what effect does an Oscar have? For The Hurt Locker, it should be a palpable one this weekend. The film, which has actually never left theaters since it opened in a very few in June 2009, will open in an additional 35 on Friday, in major markets like New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, San Francisco, Dallas, Houston, Washington D.C., Seattle, Denver, Detroit, Minneapolis and San Diego, as well as in 30 more in Canada. That will take its total in North America to 348 theaters; for comparisons sake, Avatar is playing in 2,163 theaters (although Tim Burtons Alice in Wonderland has scooped up most of its 3-D screens), and Crazy Heart in 1,274. The distributors of The Hurt Locker decided on the modest expansion in order not to cannibalize DVD sales and rentals, where the best picture winner has already been doing well. It has sold 780,000 copies (including digital downloads), and since its release on Jan. 12, has landed in the Top 10 rental list each week.

title: Oscars Analysis | Leading Men
description: In years past weve bitten our upper lips when watching Hollywoods royalty attempting their creative black tie options, with their tricky vests, shiny suits and odd colored neckties. This year it seems that most of the male attendees at Hollywoods biggest bash of the year looked to their elegant predecessors when getting ready for their walk down the red carpet.With very few exceptions, our leading men have finally gotten the memo that suit-y straight ties are no substitute for the classic bow tie when hitting the Academy Awards.

title: Liz Cheney Critiques Justice Department
description: A conservative advocacy organization in Washington, Keep America Safe, kicked up a storm last week when it released a video that questioned the loyalty of some Justice Department lawyers.

title: Science Academies to Assess Climate Assessors
description: May 3, 8:35 a.m. | Updated  The Interacademy Council has named the committee membership.

title: Jones, Disgraced Sprinter, Is Joining the W.N.B.A.
description: Calling it a new part of my journey, the former sprinter Marion Jones signed a contract to play for the Tulsa Shock of the W.N.B.A. on Wednesday. She is resurrecting an athletic career derailed by her admission that she used performance-enhancing drugs and by a prison sentence for lying about it to federal investigators.

title: Fixing Kids With Vision Therapy
description: In The New York Times Magazine article Concocting a Cure for Kids With Issues, Judith Warner writes about a controversial practice called vision therapy, in which some optometrists say they can treat learning disabilities. She reports:

title: Sebelius to Insurers: Its Not Too Late to Work Together
description: Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, pleaded with insurance companies on Wednesday to scrap their campaign against President Obamas health care bill and to work with the White House to pass it.

title: 3-D Helps Push Global Film Revenues Higher
description: Global movie box-office receipts rose 7.6 percent last year, to $29.9 billion, while the domestic box-office was up more than 10 percent, to $10.6 billion, according to an annual statistical report released on Wednesday by the Motion Picture Association of America.

title: Mobile Apps That Outperform Web Sites
description: Since the great app rush began, Web companies have scurried to build mobile apps. In some cases, they have realized that their services are better suited to cellphone screens than computers.

title: Part 3: Answers on Historically Black Colleges and Universities
description: More than 100 American institutions are classified by the government as historically black colleges and universities through a formal program intended to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.

title: Ford Figo Brings Cool to India
description: Ford is betting a large part of its future on a revamped lineup of small cars, such as the 2010 Ford Figo. In colloquial Italian, the name means cool. But apart from the cute name and low price tag, the Figo wont directly translate to boosting Fords small car sales in North America. That task belongs to the Ford Fiesta subcompact, which arrives this spring.

title: Obama Announces a Crackdown on Health Care Fraud
description: President Obama will use a visit to Missouri this afternoon to announce a new plan to crack down on fraud and waste in government health programs, including Medicare and Medicaid.

title: New Study Sorts Through Obama-Muslim Myth
description: A new academic study finds that Americans who believed during the 2008 campaign that Barack Obama was a Muslim generally held tight to that misconception, despite efforts by the media, fact-checking Web sites and his own campaign to debunk the myth.

title: Georgetown Ends South Floridas Dream
description: South Florida came to the Big East tournament feeling as if it belonged.

title: Fashion Feels Furs Warm Embrace
description: LAST month, Johnny Weir, the United States figure skater, switched one of his costumes for the Vancouver Olympics after he said he received threats from anti-fur activists for accessorizing his already colorful wardrobe with just a touch of white fox. At almost the same moment, fashion designers in New York were showing fall collections with so much fur that they seemed to collectively stick a thumb in the eye of political correctness.

title: Drilling Down, Possum and Economics Edition
description: There are many ways to drill down into a neighborhood.

title: 2 Multinationals Pull Back From Iran
description: Royal Dutch Shell and Ingersoll-Rand this week became the latest major corporations to announce they would cease or cut back business operations in Iran.

title: Sebelius to Insurers: Its Not Too Late to Work Together
description: At our sib-blog Prescriptions, our colleague Robert Pear outlines the appeal made by Secretary Kathleen Sebelius of Health and Human Services to insurance companies on overhauling health care.

title: Single Parents, Around the World
description: A sizable minority of children in rich countries live with just one parent  a parent who is likely to be female, and also likely to be working.

title: Allergies Acting Up? The Plays the Thing
description: Overview | How does the immune system react to allergens, causing allergy symptoms in some people? How can children, parents, doctors and communities respond to allergies, both mild to severe? In this lesson, students conduct a one-question interview to gather data on how much their classmates know about and are affected by allergies. Then, they work in groups to create a play to teach one another, and others in the school community, about allergies, including how the immune system works in people with and without allergies.

title: Backstage: Hermes
description: A look back stage at the Hermes fall 2010 show in Paris.

title: Now Reviving | Ellesse
description: The resurrection of a long-forgotten label is one of fashions favorite pastimes. (I am still waiting for NAF NAF and Gitano to rise from the ashes.) Now, more than 50 years after its inception, the Italian sportswear label Ellesse has been reborn. Although Ellesse was primarily tied to skiing and tennis throughout the 70s and 80s, the former sneaker designer Mauro Massaroto has reimagined the label as hyper-colored cool clothes that jibe with the current frenzy for all things 90s. I am slightly besotted with the womens half of the collection. Instead of plaids, flannels and bike shorts, Massaroto (along with the sneaker designer Patrizio Carlucci) go instead for the skater/club kid/track-suits-from-the Salvation Army vibe of the grunge decade. An abundance of velour, stripes, beanies and a baby blue-marigold-fire orange palette are straight out of an X-Girl ad campaign from my junior year of high school. (That is quite possibly my highest form of praise.) Already on my must-have-immediately list:

title: New Cirque du Soleil Show Is Delayed Again
