description: An article on Dec. 28 about legal battles among mobile phone companies implied incorrectly that lawsuits filed by Nokia last October and November against Apple, Samsung, LG and eight other competitors involved patent disputes. While Nokia is involved in numerous patent cases, the lawsuit filed against Apple was the only one of that group involving intellectual property issues. The others involved allegations of price-fixing for LCD screens.

title: Corrections
description: A fashion column on Monday about what female stars wore to the Academy Awards ceremony misidentified the designer of MoNiques dress. It was by Tadashi Shoji, not Tom and Linda Platt, who have designed gowns for MoNique for many years.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph in some editions on Wednesday with an obituary about the architect Bruce J. Graham was published in error. It showed the John Hancock Tower in Boston with sailboats in the foreground, a building Mr. Graham did not design. He designed the John Hancock Center in Chicago.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about the actress Nan Martin misspelled the given name of a surviving son in some editions. He is Zen Gesner, not Zan.

title: Three Airlines Near Deal for an Expanded Alliance
description: BRUSSELS  European antitrust regulators on Wednesday took a step toward approving an expanded alliance between British Airways, American Airlines and Iberia after the airlines offered to give up landing and takeoff slots at airports serving London and New York.

title: Notre Dame Bounces Back to Eliminate Seton Hall
description: The coaching philosophy of Notre Dames Mike Brey once revolved around scoring 100 points. But an injury to the star forward Luke Harangody nearly a month ago forced the Irish to have an extreme makeover.

title: A Last Chance for the Trade Center to Rise Again
description: AFTER years of false starts and broken promises, we have reached a defining moment in the rebuilding of the World Trade Center. By Friday, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the sites developer, Larry Silverstein, must make a choice: Will they broker a compromise that allows them to move forward with rebuilding the historic heart of our city? Or will they allow their dispute to return to arbitration, condemning the World Trade Center site to years more of delays?

title: Braking Bad
description: Marina del Rey, Calif.

title: Caution: No Stops for Miles ... and Miles
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Strengthen the Afghan National Police
description: To the Editor:

title: After You
description: Recently, I have been considering the four-way stop. It is, I think, the most successful unit of government in the State of California. It may be the perfect model of participatory democracy, the ideal fusion of first come, first served and the golden rule. There are four-way stops elsewhere in the country. But they are ubiquitous in California, and they bring out a civility  let me call it a surprising civility  in drivers here in a state where so much has recently gone so wrong.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 3 about Hank Rosenstein, an original member of the New York Knicks, using information provided by the team and other sources, incorrectly described the ethnic makeup of the 1946 Knicks team that played in what is considered the first N.B.A. game. Six of Rosensteins teammates, not seven, were Jewish; Stan Stutz was not.

title: Antitrust and Your Vote
description: When the nations largest voting machine manufacturer, Election Systems and Software, acquired the voting machine business of Diebold, the nations second-largest manufacturer, it set off alarms for anyone who cares about election integrity. The combination meant that 70 percent of the nations voting machines would be provided by just one company.

title: Todays Tea Partier: A Different Kind of Radical
description: To the Editor:

title: What Ground Zero Needs
description: Ground zero is no longer the depressing place it was a few years ago. The important public structures are starting to take shape  the memorial to the victims, Santiago Calatravas birdlike transportation hub, and 1 World Trade Center (the centerpiece once known as the Freedom Tower), 20 stories high and climbing.

title: On the Leadership of the President
description: To the Editor:

title: Diplomacy 102
description: Vice President Joseph Biden Jr. used rare and decidedly undiplomatic language on Tuesday to upbraid Israel after it announced plans to build 1,600 new housing units in a Jewish neighborhood of East Jerusalem. I condemn the decision. ..., he said in a statement.

title: Shelley Duncan Starts Over
description: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  They are not related. But Shelley and Eric Duncan have a lot in common besides their last name. Both were high draft picks by the Yankees, Shelley in the second round in 2001, Eric in the first round in 2003. Both have finally moved on  Shelley to the Cleveland Indians, Eric to the Atlanta Braves.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Correction
description: An article last Thursday about Marty Hyman, a photographer who specializes in school class pictures, misstated his age. He is 64, not 67.

title: In Battle for No. 5 Starter, Results Dont Matter Yet
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  One of the first things Manager Joe Girardi said about his evaluation of the No. 5 starter candidates was that statistics would play only a small role. As for why, witness how Phil Hughes approached his fourth-inning matchup with Ryan Raburn of the Detroit Tigers on Wednesday.

title: Drone Strikes Kill 21 in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Two drone strikes since Monday in North Waziristan have killed at least 21 people, possibly including a top local commander, said a Pakistan security official and residents of the area, a stronghold of Al Qaeda and the Taliban.

title: Oklahoma Freshmen Ready for N.B.A.? Coach Doesnt Think So
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. Theres been plenty of whispers about whether the Oklahoma freshmen Tommy Mason-Griffin, a point guard, and Tiny Gallon, a power forward, could leave for the N.B.A.

title: Africa, Here We Come
description: My Thursday column announces that Mitch Smith from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln has won my fourth annual Win-a-Trip Contest. Ive posted his winning essay below.

title: Battery Ventures Raises a Fresh $750 Million
description: The venture capital industry may be shrinking, but Battery Ventures is growing.

title: Barclays Has an Appetite for a U.S. Bank
description: The trans-Atlantic ambitions of Barclays, the British bank, are moving to another level. Barclays became a big player on Wall Street by snapping up Lehman Brothers American operations after the firm collapsed in September 2008. The revelation that it is interested in buying a United States bank suggests it wants to become a familiar face on Americas Main Street, too.

title: TARP Panel Finds Fault With GMAC Bailouts
description: WASHINGTON  A Congressional panel, in a report to be released Thursday, questioned the need for the Treasury Departments $17.2 billion bailout of GMAC as the company dealt with the collapsing mortgage market in 2008 and 2009.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Buffalos Tall Rookie Humbles Dallas
description: Five games on Wednesday, including a virtuoso performance from the leading Calder Trophy candidate. Home teams listed first:

title: Word of the Day | malcontent
description: malcontent \mal-kn-tent\ noun

title: Senate Passes Bill That Would Extend Unemployment Benefits
description: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  The Senate on Wednesday approved a $138 billion measure that would extend unemployment benefits and provide additional aid to states in lawmakers second major effort this year to help the economy.

title: Enigmatic Louisville Falls to Cincinnati
description: The most effective Louisville Cardinal on the Madison Square Garden court Wednesday was once told to transfer by Coach Rick Pitino when he was a sophomore. Back then, Edgar Sosa was slapped with the label of being selfish, sloppy and simply too much to put up with.

title: Corey Haim, Actor, Dies at 38
description: Corey Haim, an actor whose status as a teenage heartthrob of the 1980s gave way to substance abuse and rehabilitation as an adult, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Burbank, Calif. He was 38.

title: Decision Awaits Oklahoma Guard
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  At last years Big 12 tournament, the buzz was whether Oklahoma shooting guard Willie Warren would leave for the N.B.A. draft.

title: Jones Makes W.N.B.A. Comeback
description: The former sprinter Marion Jones signed a contract to play for the Tulsa Shock of the W.N.B.A.

title: News Quiz | March 11, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: New Strike Paralyzes Greece
description: ATHENS  Most international travel was halted and public services thrown into disarray on Thursday as thousands of Greek workers protesting austerity measures staged a general strike and joined demonstrations in the capital that turned violent.

title: Battery Ventures Raises a Fresh $750 Million

title: The Scottsboro Boys
description: Images from the musical by John Kander and Fred Ebb.

title: Ex-Goldman Banker Urges Regulation
description: For 18 years, Gary G. Gensler worked on Wall Street, striking merger deals at the venerable Goldman Sachs. Then in the late 1990s, he moved to the Treasury Department, joining a Washington establishment that celebrated the power of markets and fought off regulation at almost every turn, Graham Bowley reports in The New York Times.

title: Judge Rules N.Y.C. Owns the Name of Tavern
description: From Glenn Collins at Diners Journal:

title: Finance Bill to Include Agency to Track Financial Risk
description: Senate Banking Committee members from both parties said on Wednesday that they had agreed to include in their regulatory overhaul bill a new Office of Research and Analysis that would provide early warnings of possible systemic collapses, Edward Wyatt and Sewell Chan report in The New York Times.

title: Breakfast of Austinites
description: WHAT city, according to this article, trumps all other American cities when it comes to the breakfast taco? WHAT is in a breakfast taco? WHAT do you usually eat for breakfast?

title: Bank of China Plans New Hong Kong Issue
description: Bank of China wants to issue additional Hong Kong-listed H shares as soon as possible, in an offering equal to 20 percent of its existing H share capital, the banks chairman said Thursday, Reuters reported.

title: American Idol': The Top 8 Men
description: The short version: Casey James > Lee Dewyze > Michael Lynche > Todrick Hall > Andrew Garcia > Tim Urban > Alex Lambert > Aaron Kelly.

title: BP Buying Devon Energy Assets for $7 Billion
description: BP said Thursday that it would pay Devon Energy $7 billion for assets in Brazil, Azerbaijan and the Gulf of Mexico, and that the two firms would form a joint venture to develop an oil sands project in Alberta, Canada.

title: How Would You Sell Your School to Potential Students?
description: Because of the growth in charter schools, some New York City public schools are beginning to feel they need to market themselves to draw interested students and parents, according to this article. If you were in charge of marketing your school to local families, what aspects of it would you highlight? How?

title: A Place to Bet Real Money on Movies
description: Think that this springs Robin Hood movie will be a blockbuster at the box office? Next week you will be able to put your money on it, Joseph Plambeck reports for The New York Times.

title: Baltic Trading Flat in Debut
description: Shares of Baltic Trading closed down slightly Wednesday after remaining virtually flat during the companys trading debut, The Associated Press reported.

title: Eyeblaster Takes Another Shot at I.P.O.
description: Eyeblaster, an online advertising company, is making another run at the public markets. The company said Wednesday that it is planning an initial public offering, though it did not disclose an expected size or price range, The Associated Press reported.

title: Thailand Braces for Political Rallies in Capital
description: BANGKOK  Thailands seemingly unending political crisis is likely to reach another moment of tension this weekend with huge opposition rallies that organizers say they hope will paralyze the city and bring down the government.

title: TARP Panel Finds Fault With GMAC Bailouts
description: A Congressional panel, in a report to be released Thursday, questioned the need for the Treasury Departments $17.2 billion bailout of GMAC as the company dealt with the collapsing mortgage market in 2008 and 2009, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

description: Idolization of the Colombian writer Gabriel Garca Mrquez.

description: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

title: Barclays Next Stop: Main Street, U.S.A?
description: The trans-Atlantic ambitions of Barclays, the British bank, are moving to another level. Barclays became a big player on Wall Street by snapping up Lehman Brothers American operations after the firm collapsed in September 2008.

title: Time for BofAs Moynihan to Walk the Walk?
description: Brian Moynihan can talk the talk, Reuters Breakingviews says. He made a good impression on Wednesday in his first solo presentation since becoming chief executive of Bank of America at the start of the year.

title: Lucid Imagination Takes $10 Million
description: Lucid Imagination, a commercial vendor of open source search technologies, has landed $10 million in a second round of funding, VentureBeat reported.

title: Market Up on Sense That Worst Is Behind Banks
description: A renewed sense that Wall Streets biggest financial companies had endured the worst of the economic downturn helped lead the stock market higher on Wednesday.

title: Now Screening | Herms
description: The fall 2010 collection from Herms at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Viterra Cooks Up Deal for Dakota Growers Pasta
description: Viterra is offering to buy Dakota Growers Pasta for $240 million, a deal that would put Viterra, a Canadian food processing and grain handling company, into the spaghetti business.

title: China Caps Bankers Bonuses
description: China has tightened controls on pay for its top bankers, joining global efforts to try to limit financial risks by linking longer-term performance more closely to compensation, The Associated Press reports.

title: Lawsuits, Poker and a Boutique Banks Death
description: In September 2008, as Lehman Brothers was breaking into a million pieces, a young investment bank was pushing up through the rubble.

title: CA Acquires Nimsoft for $350 Million in Cash
description: CA, the technology management software company, said on Wednesday that it was buying Nimsoft for $350 million in cash.

title: Private Equity Executive Pushed to Join Senate Race
description: Encouraged by state and national Republican Party leaders, Dan Senor, an author, private equity executive and Defense Department adviser in the last Bush administration, is seriously considering a political challenge against Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, The New York Timess Michael Barbaro reported, citing three people told of the discussions.

title: HSBC Says 15,000 Hit by Swiss Data Case
description: HSBC Holdings said the theft of Swiss client data at the heart of a recent tax dispute with France was vastly larger than it had previously acknowledged, involving at least 15,000 clients, David Jolly reported in The New York Times.

title: At a London Show, Changing the Rules of Design
description: The artist, designer and architect Ron Arad first made a splash in 1981 when, inspired by Marcel Duchamps found objects, he bought a couple of red leather car seats salvaged from an old Rover car, attached them to metal frames and called the result Rover Chair. Over the years, similar reinventions of everyday objects followed. Now, through May 16, the first major show in London of the Israeli-born, London-based creative maverick is on display at the Barbican Center (Silk Street; 44-207-638-4141; barbican.org.uk).

title: Unexpectedly, EMI Moves to Replace Top Exec
description: The struggling British music company EMI announced on Wednesday that Elio Leoni-Sceti, the chief executive of its recorded music division, will step down at the end of March after less than two years in the job, The New York Timess Joseph Plambeck reported.

title: Three Airlines Near Deal for an Expanded Alliance
description: European antitrust regulators on Wednesday took a step toward approving an expanded alliance between British Airways, American Airlines and Iberia after the airlines offered to give up landing and takeoff slots at airports serving London and New York, The New York Timess James Kanter reported.

title: In Early Tally, Tight Iraq Race Deepens Splits
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs major coalitions were locked in a surprisingly close race on Thursday, in initial results from elections that deepened divisions across a fractured landscape. Candidates were quick to charge fraud, heightening concerns whether Iraqs fledgling institutions were strong enough to support a peaceful transfer of power.

title: A.I.G.s Taiwan Sale Stalls on Regulations
description: The American International Group has managed to agree to jumbo asset sales this month, but a smaller disposal  that of its Taiwan life insurance unit, Nan Shan Life  remains in regulatory limbo, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: Canadian Developers Lose Wind Subsidies
description: From Lars Kroldrup at Green Inc.:

title: Tullett Prebon in Deal Talks
description: Tullett Prebon of Britain said on Wednesday that it was in preliminary discussions with a third party, sending shares in the financial firm up more than 25 percent.

title: Karzai Meets With Top Officials in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan met with Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani here on Thursday in a show of public friendship, even as the two sides tried to work through underlying tensions over how to deal with the Taliban militants who use the countries lawless border region as a sanctuary.

title: Greece, the Latest and Greatest Bubble
description: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, is the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

title: Fate vs. Will in Afghanistan
description: Todays idea: The Afghan war revives an ancient intellectual debate: Can individual agency prevail over determinism  the belief that historical, cultural, ethnic, economic, and other antecedent forces determine the future of men and nations?

title: An Uzbek Mogul Goes High-Tech
description: Alisher B. Usmanov, an Uzbek from a tiny village near the Kyrgyz border, has led the most improbable life, according to a Forbes profile  by Anita Raghavan.

title: G.M. Chief Says U.S. Will Make Money on Bailout
description: General Motors will pay back roughly $8 billion in debt to the United States and Canada before June and could go public in a way that would allow taxpayers to make a profit on the bailout, the automakers chief executive, Ed Whitacre, said on Wednesday.

title: Virtual Reality War
description: My battalion commander, Lt. Col. Michael Kurilla, gave the directive that my squad leaders, platoon sergeant, and myself had heard countless times: my platoon was to cordon and search a neighborhood that intelligence had indicated might be the whereabouts of a high value target.

title: Q&A: The Safety of Unsecure Networks
description: Q.

title: N.F.L. Prospects Have No Privacy on Internet. And Neither May You.
description: We used to be able to reinvent ourselves. So much of our lives are now wide open. If we arent sharing it, our friends are. Parry Aftab, executive director of WiredSafety.org

title: BofA Under Pressure to Shrink, Report Says
description: Regulators have told Bank of Americas chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, and other executives that the largest U.S. bank by assets must become much smaller, Fox Business Networks Charlie Gasparino reported.

title: Macquarie Said to Want Expanded U.S. Presence
description: The Macquarie Group, Australias largest investment bank, may snap up more U.S. assets and wants to add more bankers in the United States to advise energy, industrial and technology companies, Bloomberg News reported, citing an interview with a top company executive.

title: Porsches Stealth Debut
description: Almost as amazing as the specs on the Porsche 918 Spyder plug-in hybrid concept is the fact that Porsche managed to keep the car under wraps until its world debut last week at the Geneva Auto Show.

title: Samsung Life I.P.O. Gets Approval
description: The South Korean bourse approved an estimated $4 billion initial public offering by Samsung Life Insurance on Thursday, paving the way for what is likely to be the countrys biggest share float in May, Reuters reported.

title: Sampler: Drug Cases Dismissed in San Francisco and Can a Big House be Green?
description: More Evidence Found in Santa Clara | Public defenders in Santa Clara County are waiting to see how the cases of accused sex offenders may be affected by the district attorneys office effort to gather new evidence from the Santa Clara Valley Medical Center. Some new material, known as intake forms, collected by the centers sexual assault response team were discovered this week. The discovery comes after last years revelation that the center had 3,000 videotapes of medical exams of children who were alleged victims of assault. The videotapes have already led to the release of a man convicted earlier and have put other convictions at risk. An appellate court ruled two years ago that hospital examiners were part of the prosecution team and that the district attorneys office was responsible for making sure evidence was turned over to defendants. Im sure they were dismayed at the discovery, and Im glad to see they are jumping on it, said the public defender, Mary Greenwood. We hope and believe the defense perspective will be solicited about the value of what else they find. [The San Jose Mercury News]

title: New Strike Paralyzes Greece
description: Most international travel was halted and public services thrown into disarray on Thursday as thousands of Greek workers protesting austerity measures staged a general strike, Niki Kitsantonis reports in The New York Times.

title: In Hedge Funds, More Closings Than Openings
description: Hedge fund closings outpaced starts in 2009, the second year in a row that more funds shuttered than opened, Pensions & Investments reported, citing new data from Hedge Fund Research.

title: Speed Read for Thursday, March 11
description: Here are some highlights from Thursdays edition of The New York Times:

title: Geithner Said to Warn E.U. on Fund Regulation
description: The U.S. Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, has written to the European Commission warning that plans to regulate hedge funds and private equity firms could cause tensions with Washington, The Financial Times reported.

title: In Bond Auction, Signs of Confidence in Portugal
description: Portugal sold more bonds than initially planned Wednesday  at a lower borrowing cost than the previous similar issue  suggesting markets were becoming more confident after the country outlined its strategy to cut a ballooning fiscal gap, Reuters reported.

title: Sins of Son and, Perhaps, Father in a Brooklyn Court
description: The phone call came from jail, a sons plea for help that would sorely test a fathers judgment. The son begged his father to retrieve money from a safe that the son said contained tens of thousands of dollars in lottery winnings that would cover the cost of a lawyer.

title: First Data Chief to Join K.K.R. as Adviser
description: First Data, the credit card processor, said on Thursday that its chief executive had stepped down to take an advisory role at its corporate owner, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

description: Sight Gag | Maybe youve heard about Garfield Minus Garfield, a strip in which Garfield is deleted, lending it a strange, existential poignancy. Now try the Garfield Randomizer, which breaks up Garfield panels and randomly reassembles them. Weirdness ensues:

title: Pimco Chief Addresses Sovereign Debt Mess
description: Mohamed A. El-Erian, whose company runs the worlds biggest mutual fund, said deteriorating public finances might affect the global economy more than was currently realized, Bloomberg News reported, citing a piece in The Financial Times.

title: A Different Route to Corn-Based Fuel
description: Jack Huttner, the executive vice president of Gevo, a five-year old company in Englewood, Colo., would like to take over an ethanol plant and, using the same base ingredients that go into corn-based ethanol  corn and natural gas for fuel  manufacture a different molecule: isobutanol.

title: Arguments Against Dolphin Slaughter
description: Louis Psihoyos, the former National Geographic photographer who won an Oscar on Sunday for The Cove, his first documentary film, sat down for a conversation with me at the Asia Society on Tuesday on various aspects of the ongoing slaughter of dolphins in Japan and his teams work exposing the serving of Sei whale meat at The Hump, a sushi restaurant in Santa Monica, Calif. Heres video of the discussion:

title: Gates Meets With Ruler of Emirates on Iran
description: ABU DHABIDefense secretary Robert M. Gates met here on Thursday with the crown prince of the United Arab Emirates as part of an intensifying American effort to build up defenses with Arab allies and contain Irans military might in the Persian Gulf.

title: U.N. to End Some Deals for Food to Somalia
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  The United Nations World Food Program announced Thursday that it would not give any new contracts to three Somali businessmen who have been accused of diverting food aid to Islamist militants and that the agency would welcome an independent investigation into its Somalia operations.

title: Strike Disrupts Airports, Subways and Other Transit in Greece
description: Most international travel was halted, and public services thrown into disarray on Thursday as thousands of Greek workers protesting austerity measures staged a general strike.

title: Fifty-One Herbert Hoovers
description: More than a year ago I coined a phrase that seems to have made its way into the econolexicon; writing about how cutbacks at the state and local level would tend to undermine fiscal stimulus at the federal level, I said that we had fifty Herbert Hoovers.

title: China Increases Security in Tibet to Prevent Protests
description: BEIJING  For a second straight year, the Chinese government has increased security across parts of the vast Tibetan plateau to dissuade any Tibetans from holding protests this week to mark the anniversaries of ethnic uprisings. Witnesses who have spent time recently in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, and other Tibetan areas of western China say there are more police and paramilitary forces on the streets, some of them bearing automatic weapons.

title: Intel Goes Mad as Big-Event TV Strategy Continues
description: One of the most notable trends on Madison Avenue so far this year is the embrace of so-called big event television by advertisers, which are seeking to run commercials during the live coverage of major programs like the Grammys, the Super Bowl, the Winter Olympics and the Academy Awards.

title: Is Sexual Anorexia the Flip Side of Sex Addiction?
description: A panel of experts joined the Consults blog recently to answer readers questions about sex addiction. Here, Dr. Drew Pinsky responds to one reader who wonders why too little sex isnt given the same attention as too much.

title: Fed Joins A.I.G. Loss-Sharing Pact With MetLife
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is joining the American International Group in a loss-sharing agreement that is part of the insurers sale of its American Life Insurance Company unit to MetLife, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Obama Outlines Drive to Raise U.S. Exports
description: President Obama on Thursday announced a broad effort to promote American goods overseas, hoping to bolster competitiveness abroad and create jobs in the United States.

description: Pistons starting guard Rodney Stuckey feels fine, but his playing status for the rest of the season is very much in doubt.

title: The Early Word: Health Care Huddle
description: After a late-night meeting on Wednesday, the House Democratic leadership was expected to begin dealing with its membership this morning on the latest compromises forged over the health care legislation.

title: In Legal Ruling, EMI Told, Hey, Label, Leave Those Tracks Alone
description: 4:50 p.m. | Updated  Finally: score one for the wealthy rock stars. A British court ruled in favor of Pink Floyd  on Thursday, saying that EMI, its longtime record label, could no no longer sell songs from its concept albums as individual singles on the Internet, Reuters reported.

title: Now Screening | Miu Miu
description: The fall 2010 collection from Miu Miu at Paris Fashion Week.

title: At Brown, Expanded Interest in Business Education
description: Brown University is known for many things: its core-less curriculum, its freewheeling ethos of diversity and inclusion, and its popularity as a destination for fictional characters on teenage soaps.

title: Answers From a Theater Historian, Part 2
description: A second set of answers from Marc Robinson, the author of The American Play: 1787-2000.

title: Democrats Push Ahead on Finance Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats said on Thursday that they would go it alone in an effort to pass an overhaul of financial regulation, increasing the likelihood of a bitter partisan showdown.

title: March Madness: The Geek Edition
description: For some of us, the annual arrival of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament comes in March with mixed emotions: we love seeing adversaries pitted against one another in winner-take-all matches. But we have no idea who the competitors are, possibly because we spent too much time growing up reading fantasy and science fiction novels when we should have been playing sports. (At least, thats what our gym classmates said.) Finally, theres a tournament for our crowd.

title: Thursday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

description: Katie Lee cooks her signature burgers in her West Village townhouse for Frank Bruni.

title: The Ruff Stuff
description: Its a great moment to flounce around.

title: Dodd to Offer New Version of Regulatory Overhaul
description: 12:27 p.m. | Updated The New York Timess Sewell Chan provides an update with more news about the financial regulatory bill.

title: How to Cook Up a Food Celebrity
description: It could have been the Cannes film festival, the way the water glittered in the background and the fans swarmed their favorite stars and the photographers clicked and clicked. One of those photographers, scruffy and lavishly tattooed, appeared suddenly as Katie Lee walked from her grand hotel, where the events organizers had ensconced her in a junior suite on a high floor, toward the temporary city of beachfront tents where her presentation would take place.

title: Aftershocks Jolt Chile as New President Is Sworn In
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Chiles new president, Sebastin Piera, was minutes from being sworn in on Thursday when major aftershocks struck the central coast of this earthquake-ravaged country. But less than an hour after being inaugurated, he appeared on television to announce that troops, relief supplies and even Mr. Piera himself would be heading immediately to the quake zone.

title: Ontarios Clean Water Tech Cluster
description: In a major speech on future policy directions this week, Ontarios government has announced plans to position the province as North Americas clean water technology capital.

title: Obligatory Twilight Saga: Eclipse Trailer Post
description: So far, our favorite line is when Jacob says to Bella, I will fight for you until your heart stops beating. If that happens, Jacob, maybe youre not fighting hard enough?

title: The Stove as a Steppingstone
description: Donatella cooks!

title: Hamas Releases British Journalist
description: GAZA  A British journalist was freed here on Thursday after being held for 25 days by the Hamas authorities.

title: Woman Assaulted in Midtown Bar
description: Updated, 5:33 p.m. | The police are investigating a brutal beating of a 30-year-old woman early Thursday in a bathroom stall of a Midtown bar, the police said. A law enforcement official described the woman as a pediatric nurse from Connecticut.

title: Conan OBrien Announces Details of National Tour
description: 12:49 p.m. | Updated Responding a huge surge of demand, Mr. OBrien has informed fans that he will add second shows in New York, Chicago and Boston. The second New York appearance at Radio City will be on June 2. The second Chicago date, at the Chicago Theater, is May 20. The second Boston appearance at the Wang Theater is set for June 5.

title: Microsofts Free Sync Service
description: Last week, I wrote about an underpublicized gem in Microsoft's Windows Live suite of free online and offline services and programs: SkyDrive. It's a free, 25-gigabyte virtual hard drive on the Internet, accessible from any computer.

title: Can We Afford to Continue Serving Small Clients?
description: In my last post, I laid out three main business challenges that Ill be focusing on over the next few months, and I promised to elaborate on each of them. Today: increasing sales.

title: Conan OBrien Announces Details of His National Tour
description: The fans of Conan OBrien will not have to wait much longer  though they may have to wait in long lines  to see their favorite late-night comedian perform again: starting April 12 in Eugene, Ore., Mr. OBriens 30-city tour, with national and international stops, is on.

title: Israeli Ad Riffs on Dubai Assassination
description: Updated | Friday | 8:12 a.m. To illustrate the slogan We offer killer prices, an Israeli supermarket chains new commercial will feature surveillance camera images of actors dressed like the suspects accused of assassinating a Hamas official in Dubai in January, The Associated Press reported.

title: Smokers Are Supposed to Quit
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Hey, today is No Smoking Day, where smokers are supposed to quit cigarettes for the day. Or as Sasha and Malia call it, Daddys in a Really Bad Mood Day.

title: Fishing in Rivers and Lakes
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Some Web sites are saying the Obama administration may ban fishing in rivers and lakes. The new fishing rules havent been announced yet, so Im not sure whats really going on. On Fox News, theyre saying, Obama wages jihad on fishing. On NPR, theyre saying, Obama protects aquatic unicorns.

title: Limbaugh Leaving
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Earlier today, the president of Haiti was at the White House to meet with President Obama. He said the people of his country need jobs, they need places to live, and they need health care. And then the president of Haiti spoke.

title: Phillies Long View Saw Past Two Aces
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.

title: Biden to Leave Mideast Amid Unease
description: TEL AVIV  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. came to Israel early this week to promote new Israeli-Palestinian peace talks and tighten the bonds between Israel and the United States. He left Thursday amid increased uncertainty over the nature and timing of those talks and with a sense of unease hanging over the American-Israeli relationship.

title: Fiat Names VW Marketer to Lead U.S. Return
description: Fiat, returning to the United States market late this year, has named Laura J. Soave, VWs general manager of experiential marketing, to head its operations in North America, reports Reuters. She reports directly to Sergio Marchionne, chief executive of Fiat and the Chrysler Group.

title: Is Green Insurance Worth the Price?
description: Insurers are increasingly offering insurance discounts if you already own an environmentally friendly home or car as well as additions to standard policies that cover the costs of going green when renovating after a loss.

title: All You Need Is Luxe
description: Midway through Imagine: John Lennon, the 1988 documentary, Lennon and his new bride, Yoko Ono, are seen prancing through a London airport clad in matching white pantsuits. As The Ballad of John and Yoko plays in the background  the tune in which Lennon bemoans that he and Ono are criticized for looking like two gurus in drag  viewers get a glimpse of a media-savvy peacock. The worlds constant gaze was clearly wearying for Lennon, but that was O.K. because he didnt always take himself seriously. He knew how to have a good time and how to work a look.

title: Agency Weighs the Need for a Black Box in Cars
description: DETROIT  Federal safety regulators, who allowed auto companies to voluntarily install event data recorders on their vehicles a few years ago, are now looking into whether the systems should be required, the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said on Thursday.

title: No One Writes Like a Dame: Judi Dench to Publish Memoir
description: It only makes sense that Judi Dench, after accumulating a lifetimes worth of theater, film and television credits that could easily fill up a book, should finally write one. St. Martins Press said it had acquired a memoir from Ms. Dench, called And Furthermore, that will detail her professional and private lives, according to a press release from the publisher. Though she has lately come to be known for her role as M in the James Bond franchise, and as Queen Elizabeth in Shakespeare in Love (for which she won an Academy Award for just a few minutes of screen time), Ms. Dench will cover the breadth of her acting career in the memoir, from her start with Englands Old Vic theater company in 1957, to joining the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1961 to playing Sally Bowles in Cabaret in the 1968 London production (not to mention her performances in Hay Fever, A Little Night Music, Amys View, A Midsummer Nights Dream and the television series A Fine Romance and As Time Goes By). St. Martins said it would publish And Furthermore (along with, were sure, a healthy index) in October.

title: Q&A: Heading for the Vuelta Bike Race in Spain
description: Q.

title: Investors Bet on Betaworks, a New York Tech Incubator
description: As I recently reported, there are many indications that the start-up culture in New York has flickered back to life.

title: Home Efficiency Program Poised for Growth
description: A widely praised program to encourage homeowners to add solar panels and make their houses more energy efficient is on the verge of a ramp-up.

title: Live Updates From the Big East Tournament, Day 3
description: Four more games are on the schedule Thursday at the Big East mens basketball tournament. The Timess Pete Thamel and Kevin Armstrong, along with Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward who is now an academic adviser in the athletic department, are at Madison Square Garden and will provide analysis and updates throughout the day. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comment section below.

title: New Site Unmasks Chatroulette Players
description: I have a confession to make. Im addicted to Chatroulette, the buzz-generating Web site created by a Russian teenager that pairs anonymous strangers with each other in a video chat room.

title: Artifacts | 80s Repro Men
description: Art has always had its icons, and they didnt just come from the church. Popular mythology made idols of van Gogh, Pollock and Basquiat, while entrepreneurial types like Warhol, Hirst and Murakami went ahead and branded themselves. Now comes an exhibition that offers a fresh  as in nervy  perspective on the New York stars of the 1980s, whose reactive work not only created a new fashion for art collectors to follow but changed the game for other artists as well.

title: A Jostled Princess, a Heavy Crown
description: TOKYO  When an official at the Imperial Household Agency suddenly announced last week that 8-year-old Princess Aiko was refusing to go to school because of bullying, he did more than just disclose a mundane problem facing a member of Japans ancient and secretive monarchy.

title: A Pair of Cable Upfront Pitches Suggests a Better Mood on Madison Avenue
description: Are the stars out tonight? They were on Wednesday night and Thursday morning, at a pair of cable upfront presentations that seemed to indicate an improvement in the long-gloomy mood on Madison Avenue.

title: (Plenty of) Time to Reflect on the Irish Offense
description: So, while Notre Dame elbowed its way back into college basketballs consciousness by shoving aside Seton Hall in the Big East mens basketball tournament, it gave everyone time to think. Thats because, in its now distinctive un-mad March style, the Irish create large gaps of unused time between baskets. While the retro style might be pure brilliance by Notre Dame Coach Mike Brey, as some like Yahoos Jason King suggest, it was absolutely necessary, writes Stewart Mandel of SI.com, or everyone in Golden Dome land would still be fixating on scrubbing those messy footprints Charlie Weis left all over its football program. Because Notre Dame was going nowhere fast until Brey discovered he could bore opponents into oblivion.

title: Answers About the Gowanus Canal, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of responses from Jack S. Nyman, the director of the Steven L. Newman Real Estate Institute at Baruch College, City University of New York.

title: Merlin Olsen, Football Star, Commentator and Actor, Dies at 69
description: Merlin Olsen, the Hall of Fame tackle who anchored the Los Angeles Rams Fearsome Foursome, the line that glamorized defensive play in the National Football League, died early Thursday at a hospital in Duarte, Calif. He was 69.

title: Switching to Grass-Fed Beef
description: Whats the nutritional difference between beef from animals raised on grass compared with animals fattened in feedlots?

title: A New Unit for (Saved) Power
Conan OBrien Embraces Team Coco  Poster and All
description: With Thursdays announcement of Conan OBriens 30-city tour, the former late-night comedian is fully embracing his online fan base, Team Coco.

title: Aqueduct Casino Deal is Dead
description: Gov. David A. Patersons office announced on Thursday that the company he had chosen to build and run a casino at the Aqueduct racetrack could not pass muster with state licensing officials and would not be awarded the lucrative contract.

title: Red Carpet Hara-Kiri and a Trip to Prison
description: More tidbits from the not-quite-overflowing post-Oscars grab bag:

title: Could Tomlinson Sign With the Jets?
description: When the Jets released Thomas Jones after he declined to take a pay cut, the prevailing analysis was that Jones may have slowed at the end of last season, but the Jets were losing an experienced veteran who was a tremendous locker-room presence. Might they be trying to lure someone just like Jones to replace him?

title: Michael Psilakis Has Left Anthos
description: The chef Michael Psilakis has left the haute Greek restaurant Anthos, where he garnered his best reviews and a Michelin star, as he and his business partner Donatella Arpaia increasingly head in opposite directions.

title: Holder Did Not Disclose Briefs on Enemy Combatant
description: WASHINGTON  During his confirmation last year, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. failed to notify the Senate that he had signed several briefs urging courts to reject President George W. Bushs claim that he had the power to imprison an American citizen as an enemy combatant, the Justice Department acknowledged Thursday.

title: Photos of the Moment | Louis Vuitton
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Gensler Criticizes Wall Street for Resisting Reforms
description: Gary Gensler, the chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, chided Wall Street on Thursday for resisting calls to make over-the-counter derivatives markets more transparent, arguing major reforms are required after the recent financial crisis, Reuters reports.

title: Tale of Botched Traffic Operation Increases Russians Mistrust of Moscow Police
description: MOSCOWStanislav Sutyagin was driving with a friend on Moscows busy ring highway last week when the traffic police stopped him and several other drivers and ordered them to block the road with their cars. A short time later, another car speeding along the highway plowed into them.

title: Holder Failed to Disclose Brief on Detainee Policy
description: During his Senate confirmation hearings last year, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. failed to disclose that he had signed a brief urging the Supreme Court not to uphold President Bushs claim that he could imprison an American citizen as an enemy combatant, the Justice Department acknowledged on Thursday.

title: Sending Money Electronically to a Friend: Why Its Hard
description: When I covered consumer banking at The Wall Street Journal five years ago, banks and their technology providers said the next big thing was online, person-to-person interbank transfers  allowing people to send money from their bank accounts to someone elses account at another bank.

title: Paint Never Dries
description: Unflattering nickname for Andrew Lloyd Webbers latest musical Love Never Dies.

title: Chinas Swan Song
description: Todays markets are being somewhat roiled by news of accelerating inflation in China, leading to worries that China will have to tighten monetary policy. But, you know, thats not what China is supposed to do in this situation.

title: Beck in Brooklyn, and Other Historic Moments
description: Revealing the citys past in the urban layers of its present is a frequent and appealing subject for those in the local Internet-o-sphere.

title: Skepticism Abounds on the 2010 Plan
description: Everyone has an opinion on the Knicks cap-clearing, roster-purging, swing-for-the-fences free-agent quest. Even N.B.A. players are weighing in, albeit indirectly.

title: House Votes to Impeach Judge
description: The House voted unanimously on Thursday to impeach a Louisiana federal judge for a range of ethical transgressions.

title: The Hour Approaches for Stage Version of A Time to Kill
description: Though its still a bit of a mystery why its taken this long for one of John Grishams books to be translated into a play, the identity of the theater company that will present the first stage adaptation of his work has been revealed. Arena Stage, the Washington, D.C., company, will put on a stage version of A Time to Kill as part of its 2010-11 season.

title: Beckham Grabs the Scarf, but Not the Reins, of Protest
description: It was a highly significant game in the Champions League knockout match between Manchester United and AC Milan last night and Wayne Rooney continued his devastating form with two more goals in what is a 30-goal season so far. Nani made one of the assists of the tournament to set up Rooneys second, curling the ball into his teammates path with the outside of his foot. The 4-0 defeat exposed AC Milan as an aging, blunt shadow of its former team, increasingly reliant on Ronaldinhos capricious flashes of brilliance.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Mother
description: Bong Joon-ho, the South Korean director, narrates a scene from his film.

title: Beware of Greeks Getting Gifts?
description: Markets are getting slightly more bullish on Greek debt  and Peter Boone and Simon Johnson are crying bubble. Im not so sure, but I think their argument highlights something else: the possibility of multiple equilibria in sovereign solvency.

title: More to Do, and Less to Do It With
description: Money and personnel for the Civilian Complaint Review Board  the independent agency that investigates allegations of police abuse  are in steep decline. The boards budget has been cut by more than $3 million in the last three years.

title: Letter: Scott Brown
description: Future historians may well include two Browns from New England who altered the arc of social justice in America: John Brown, the abolitionist whose words and deeds provided the backbone and impetus for the Civil War and an end to slavery; and Scott Brown, the newly elected Republican senator from Massachusetts, who may well be noted as the one whose opposition to national health-insurance reform (despite voting for similar legislation in his home state) ended the last best chance for health care for all. Historians will also note the paradox of Scott Brown unexpectedly replacing Edward M. Kennedy  the greatest champion of the view that health care is a right and the craftsman of the legislation that Brown eventually defeated  and taking a seat once held by Kennedys brother John F. Kennedy, whose chief published work was Profiles in Courage, a 1950s book that examines various senators who took courageous, principled positions and votes in opposition to their party.

title: Season Begins, Schumacher Dominates
description: BAHRAIN  The Formula One season officially began today as the teams prepared for the Bahrain Grand Prix on Sunday and the drivers met with the media and worked with their engineers.

title: This Takes the Cake
description: On her blog, Rose Levy Beranbaum writes about a not-very-sweet experience at the Breslin.

title: Elizabeth Greig and Jason Extein
description: ELIZABETH GREIG and Jason Exteins first date, in December 2006, occurred the night before she left for what until then had been her chief passion: improving medical care in Haiti.

title: When Siblings Fight
description: On a high branch of my family tree is the story of two brothers who had the first of a lifetime of fights over a shared bicycle when they were young  then stopped speaking completely by the time they were adults.

title: Should the U.S. Provide a Ponzi Scheme Bailout?
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Changes Likely to Phantom Sequel for Broadway Run
description: It seemed like almost everyone whos anyone in the Broadway theater biz was in London this week for the opening of Love Never Dies, Andrew Lloyd Webbers sequel to The Phantom of the Opera, which has been running in New York for 22 years and about 9,200 performances.

title: Harry Gives Em Hell
description: Wow. Harry Reids letter to Mitch McConnell.

title: Five Countries Fall Behind on European Renewable Energy Goals
description: The European Commission said on Thursday that five countries were failing to meet goals for renewable energy but that they could make up their quotas by buying electricity from North Africa and the Balkans.

title: The 2010 Iraqi Parliamentary Elections
description: On March 7, Iraqis voted for representatives in the 325-member Parliament. It was only the second parliamentary election since Saddam Hussein was deposed in 2003.

title: Is Green Insurance Worth the Price?
description: Is it worthwhile to pay extra for a policy add-on that lets you rebuild after a loss with more eco-friendly materials and appliances? Our colleagues at the Bucks blog explore the issue.

title: After Tearing Down Roster, Indians Try to Rebuild
description: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  The last World Series began with a special kind of misery for fans in Cleveland. The starting pitchers, C. C. Sabathia and Cliff Lee, had been teammates on the Indians just 16 months earlier. Each won an American League Cy Young Award, only to be traded in the swift overhaul of a team that had nearly won a pennant.

title: Learning to Keep Patients Safe in a Culture of Fear
description: One afternoon during my training, I watched as one of my closest friends, another surgery resident, was led into the office of the department chief. A week earlier she had been on call when a patient developed a rapid and irregular heart rhythm. He became unconscious and would have soon died if my friend had not stepped in and resuscitated him.

title: Photo of the Week
description: A man stands on the beach during a snow storm in Barcelona, Spain.

title: Taxes and the Ryan Plan
description: In the last few days, there have been a series of liberal attacks on the tax proposals in Paul Ryans fiscal roadmap. For the most part, theyve been based on this Tax Policy Center report, which suggests that the Ryan version of the tax code would only raise revenue equal to 16.8 percent of G.D.P., rather than the 19 percent thats required, under the roadmaps assumptions, to keep the budget balanced. Heres the statement Ryan issued in response:

title: U.S. Report Describes Worsening Human Rights in Iran and China
description: WASHINGTON  At a time of heavy international pressure on Iran, the State Department said on Thursday that the human rights situation there had degenerated since the disputed presidential election last year.

title: K.K.R. Names 4 Top Executives in Asset Management Arm
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts appointed four top executives within its six-year-old asset management arm. They will be responsible for its distressed credit and and leveraged finance operations.

title: Syracuse Has a Scare in Loss to Hoyas
description: Top-seeded Syracuse had squandered a 9-point second-half lead and trailed No. 8 Georgetown by 6 points with just over five minutes remaining in their Big East tournament quarterfinal when the Oranges bad day got worse.

title: Slim Leads Gates in Billionaire Race
description: According to Forbes magazine, Carlos Slim Hel, the son of a Lebanese immigrant to Mexico who has become a major shareholder in and lender to The New York Times, is now the worlds richest man.

title: Patchwork Pension Plan Adds to Greek Debt Woes
description: ATHENS  Vasia Veremi may be only 28, but as a hairdresser in Athens, she is keenly aware that, under a current law that treats her job as hazardous to her health, she has the right to retire with a full pension at age 50.

title: Elliott Denies It Plans to Sell Novell Units
description: 6:06 p.m. | Updated Elliott Associates denied late Thursday that it was planning to sell any of Novells businesses if Novell accepts its unsolicited $2 billion bid, disputing a report by Bloomberg News.

title: Meeting the Needs of Haiti
description: With the spring rains approaching in Haiti, the United States and humanitarian organizations are working to prevent a second disaster.

title: Palestinians Honor a Figure Reviled in Israel as a Terrorist
description: EL BIREH, West Bank  Dozens of Palestinian students from the youth division of Fatah, the mainstream party led by President Mahmoud Abbas, gathered here on Thursday to dedicate a public square to the memory of a woman who in 1978 helped carry out the deadliest terrorist attack in Israels history.

title: Lessons From the Disaster?
description: A stronger sense of coordination and planning, Mr. Shah said, could improve relief efforts for the next global crisis.

title: Too Good to Be True? Considering the Reading of Nonfiction in School
description: Overview | What are the differences between fiction and nonfiction? How do we read texts of these two types differently? In this lesson, students reflect on their experiences reading nonfiction works in school, compare reading fiction to reading nonfiction and develop reading strategies. Finally, they investigate and recommend nonfiction titles appropriate for their school curriculum.

title: Can We Afford to Rescue the World?
description: The United States invests in places that are important to the country's national security interests. The government should work in partnership, he said, not patronage.

title: Moving Beyond Haiti
description: Mr. Shah hopes to turn his focus on rebuilding US AID by making scientific and technological advances in health, education and food security.

title: The Global Image of America
description: The image of the United States around the world has improved, he said, but "we have a long way to go to reach people."

title: A Youthful Leader
description: Dr. Shah, who turned 37 this week, declined to say whether his age offers an advantage or disadvantage.

title: Encouraging Doctors to Report Mistakes
description: One of the first steps for keeping patients safe is to change the culture in which doctors are asked to report the mistakes they make, writes Dr. Pauline Chen in todays Doctor and Patient column.

title: Depressions Upside
description: The propositions juxtaposed by Jonah Lehrer are not mutually exclusive. Depression, as framed in his article, could be an adaptive tendency to rethink decisions and mull over past events, thereby increasing focus. When severe, however, depression could be regarded as a brain disease and the inability to stop repetitive thinking could be seen as a symptom.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 28 about the benefits of depression misstated the name of a university in Australia where studies have been done on the subject. It is the University of New South Wales, not South Wales.

title: Her Two Faces: Belter and Crooner
description: When the British musical theater star Clare Burt was a little girl, she recalled on Wednesday evening, she was so infatuated with the idea of Manhattan that she adopted a New York accent and pretended to be American. Her bluff was called when people asked her from what part of the city she came, and she navely replied Carnegie Hall.

title: The Concierge | Paris for Lovers
description: Christine Muhlke, T Magazines food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.

title: The Femivores Dilemma
description: Four women I know  none of whom know one another  are building chicken coops in their backyards. It goes without saying that they already raise organic produce: my town, Berkeley, Calif., is the Vatican of locavorism, the high church of Alice Waters. Kitchen gardens are as much a given here as indoor plumbing. But chickens? That ups the ante. Apparently it is no longer enough to know the name of the farm your eggs came from; now you need to know the name of the actual bird.

title: Investors Bet on Betaworks, a New York Tech Incubator
description: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

title: Republicans Call for Further Inquiry Over Massa Case
description: Trying to keep the pressure on over the messy case of former Representative Eric J. Massa of New York, House Republicans on Thursday demanded that the House ethics committee look into whether Democratic leaders took appropriate steps once they learned of complaints of inappropriate behavior by Mr. Massa.

title: Student Loan Overhaul Is Ensnared in Health Care Debate
description: As Democratic Congressional leaders and the White House struggle to finish the details of major health care legislation, House Democrats are desperately trying to prevent another of President Obamas top legislative priorities  an ambitious overhaul of student loan programs  from becoming a casualty of the health care battle.

title: Births to Minorities Are Approaching Majority in U.S.
description: In the latest sign of the nations shifting racial and ethnic composition, births to Asian, black and Hispanic women in the United States are on the verge of surpassing births to non-Hispanic whites.

title: Vain Glorious | Pitanguys New It Cream
description: Who: Dr. Ivo Pitanguy, one of the worlds most famous plastic surgeons.

title: Off the Train, a Motley Hub
description: The heart of South Norwalk, Conn., rows of buildings from the late 19th and early 20th centuries on Washington and South Main Streets, packs a lot into a compact area. The upper floors of the buildings have artists studios, and, at street level, the collection of restaurants, shops and galleries is diverse enough to please anyone who makes the ride  only an hour or so  from Grand Central Terminal on the Metro-North Railroad ($19.50 round-trip on weekends, $10 for children). Its all within an easy walk of the station, too  including the Maritime Aquarium, the one relatively new building in the group and the one that enables grown-ups to enjoy browsing and shopping while still entertaining the children.

title: Hoffmanns Wednesday: Hockey Night in Minnesota
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Jamie Hoffmann said he didnt see the 15-second clip of the hockey team at his old high school in New Ulm, Minn., featured on ESPNs top plays. He didnt need to. He watched the whole game.

title: Executive Departures at Clean Energy Firms
description: The past week has brought a spate of executive departures at renewable energy start-ups, with the president of SolarReserve, a power plant builder, and the chief executives of Clipper Windpower and Aurora Biofuels stepping down.

title: Like Beltran, Reyes Could Miss Start of the Season
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jose Reyess hyperthyroid condition is not considered serious and no medication is being prescribed to treat it, the Mets said Thursday, but he is still a likely candidate to begin the season on the disabled list.

title: Microsofts Free Sync Service
description: Last week, I wrote about an underpublicized gem in Microsofts Windows Live suite of free online and offline services and programs: SkyDrive. Its a free, 25-gigabyte virtual hard drive on the Internet, accessible from any computer.

title: The Blogging of the Candidate
description: After years of sitting in a room in Southern California writing a blog for Slate magazine, youre planning to challenge Senator Barbara Boxer in the Democratic primary in California in June. What led you to get into politics?   Ive been a blogger since 1999, and it hasnt done the job. In California, the Democratic Party is worse than it was when I started. The only thing left is the interest groups. It used to be a functioning party independent of labor, and now that has atrophied.

title: Europe and U.S. Quarrel Over Hedge Funds
description: The European Union on Thursday rebutted criticism by the United States of its plans to tighten the rules on hedge funds, even as Britain sought to water down the regulation to safeguard its own financial sector, James Kanter of The New York Times reports from Brussels.

title: Cuomo Hands Paterson Case to an Ex-Judge
description: ALBANY  Facing growing political pressure, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday appointed an independent counsel to take over his offices investigation into the Paterson administrations response to a domestic violence case.

title: Vehicle Built in 1935 as a Flying Car Goes on Sale
description: A contraption built in 1935 to be a flying car is going on the auction block this weekend, reports Wired Autopia, but there is no evidence that the vehicle ever got off the ground.

title: Part 4: Answers on Historically Black Colleges and Universities
description: More than 100 American institutions are classified by the government as historically black colleges and universities through a formal program intended to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.

title: More on Happy Employees
description: In my last post, I wrote about my desire to have happy people working for me. Perhaps I could have been clearer when I said that I fire unhappy people. Instead of unhappy, I probably should have said disrespectful (to others, not me), incompetent, unreasonable, undependable, irresponsible, unproductive, dysfunctional (I did say that one), angry, whiny or mean  and beyond a managers ability to repair (actually, I said that, too). I think most people understood the context of my post, but there were a few comments or questions that required a response.

title: Starbucks Fans Can Become Baristas on Foursquare
description: Beginning Thursday, latte addicts who visit Starbucks outlets can get more than just a caffeine fix. They will also be rewarded on Foursquare with a barista badge.

title: Thank You For Being Her Friend: Online Campaign Helps Betty White Onto Saturday Night Live
description: Call it a victory for democracy or peer pressure, but either way its happening: Betty White, the 88-years-young Mary Tyler Moore and Golden Girls star will host Saturday Night Live on May 8, a pre-Mothers Day episode that will also feature appearances from six veteran female SNL cast members.

title: A Ballet Expatriate Returns Home
description: ANGEL CORELLA has been a star at American Ballet Theater since he joined it in 1995 as a fresh-faced 19-year-old who had until then been a corps de ballet dancer in his native Spain. There were few choices at home for an aspiring ballet dancer. The Victor Ullate Ballet, which Mr. Corella joined at 15, was a small Madrid troupe; the national ballet company was renamed the Compaa Nacional de Danza in 1990 when the contemporary dance choreographer Nacho Duato was appointed director. So when Mr. Corella entered the International Ballet Competition in Paris and won first prize, he promptly decamped to New York.

title: Nuggets Expect Karl Back Quickly After Surgery
description: Nuggets coach George Karl missed Wednesdays game against at the Timberwolves, remaining in Denver for cancer treatment.

title: Close Collaborators With Little in Common
description: IN 2003 the New York choreographer Yasuko Yokoshi met a woman who changed her life. A relationship had brought her to Tokyo for a year, and she was at loose ends. I wanted to chill out, she said. I thought it would be interesting to learn traditional Japanese dance  to just kind of kill time.

title: Woman Killed by Train at 77th Street, Police Say
description: Updated, 5:34 p.m. | The police are now saying that the person fatally struck by the train was a woman, not a girl. Inspector James Murtagh, a police official at the scene, said she was in her 40s. He did not offer further details.

title: Christians Urged to Boycott Glenn Beck
description: 4:51 p.m. | Updated Last week, the conservative broadcaster Glenn Beck called on Christians to leave their churches if they heard any preaching about social or economic justice because, he claimed, those were slogans affiliated with Nazism and Communism.

title: Israel Charges 2 Soldiers in Gaza War Case
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military prosecutor charged two Israeli staff sergeants on Thursday with instructing a 9-year-old Palestinian boy to open several bags the soldiers suspected were booby-trapped during Israels military campaign in Gaza just over a year ago.

title: Citigroups Chief Is Optimistic on Profit Growth
description: Citigroup is moving from controlling damage to pursuing increased profits. Vikram S. Pandit, Citis chief executive, laid out ambitious targets for growth on Thursday afternoon, saying the banks return on assets should rise to 1.25 to 1.5 percent in the near future, from the current 1.15 percent. But the bank would not comment on when it would hit those goals or how it would deal with the billions of dollars of bad securities that remain as part of its Citi Holdings.

description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

description: After years of delays and lawsuits, officials broke ground Thursday afternoon on $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn.

title: Media Decoded: Without Ads, Who Needs Critics?
description: Right after the Oscars, Variety, the trade bible of Hollywood, let go of their chief film critic, Todd McCarthy, a move got the thumbs down from a host of observers. What in the world was it thinking? Lets discuss.

title: Deal Gives New Life to Overhaul of Student Loans
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic Congressional leaders struck a tentative agreement on Thursday that breathes new life into President Obamas proposed overhaul of federal student loan programs.

title: Irish Arts Center Open Day
description: St. Patricks Day is coming soon and the libations will surely be flowing around town this weekend, but there is more to Irish culture than that, you know. On Sunday afternoon the Irish Arts Center in Clinton presents its annual Open Day, a free sampler of Irish culture.

description: AROUND TOWN

title: Scorecard | Alexander McQueen Wins!
description: Four weeks to the day after Scorecard learned the tragic news of Alexander McQueens passing, on the day originally slotted by the Fdration Franaise for his runway showing, the designers final collection was shown in presentation in the rococo environs of PPRs 18th-century headquarters. With golden feathers, paillettes and embroidery topping prints digitally constructed from the religious iconography of Old Masters, it was a beautiful requiem to a creative genius who made anything else look very much of this world.

title: Switzerlands Quirky Transportation Museum
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  The extraordinary popularity of Genevas auto show, which ends this weekend, may seem a bit odd, given Switzerlands lack of an automobile industry, not to mention its world leadership in gasoline-free forms of transportation, its longtime ban on motor sports and its traditional support of odd laws like the early 1970s edict outlawing Rolls-Royce hood ornaments (because they might hurt pedestrians).

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO  (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series Dora the Explorer and Go, Diego, Go! have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Childrens Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diegos Animal Rescue Center and Doras Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.20100311

title: Aesops Fables
description: What goes around comes around, the triumphant Wolf says sneeringly to the Fox. This may not be Aesops wording, but it succinctly captures his message. It also neatly describes the action at the Circle in the Square Theater, where that ancient Greeks sly and savvy animals are running through the aisles, up and down the stairs and onto the stage in Aesops Fables, a new childrens musical directed by Theodore Mann and presented by the theater schools Alumni Ensemble.

title: After a Taliban Ambush in Afghanistan
description: After an Afghan checkpoint was ambushed by Taliban fighters, two wounded Afghan security officers were transported to the Armys Combat Outpost Pirtle King, near the village of Tsunek, in northeast Kunar Province. A medevac helicopter took them from there to Jalalabad. Moises Saman, who took this photograph, discussed the opportunities and perils of covering the war as an unembedded photographer in A Perilous Route to Marja (Lens, March 8).

title: A U.S. Moment for Yves Klein
description: Yves Klein, the radical French artist who died in 1962 when he was only 34, has been something of an enigma to Americans. Individual works have occasionally turned up in museum shows in this country, and Upper East Side galleries like Gagosian, Michael Werner and L&M Arts have displayed his work. In contrast to Europe, where several institutions have held shows of his art, such exhibitions have been rare here.

title: Vocabulary Size
description: Trying to convince speakers of English that they need to expand their vocabularies is one of the oldest strategies for selling word books. The very first English dictionary, A Table Alphabeticall, published in 1604, stated on its title page that its approximately 2,500 words (most of them relatively obscure) were intended for the benefit and help of ladies, gentlewomen or any other unskillful persons. For the next 100 years, most published dictionaries were concerned with helping the verbally unsophisticated (or at least the insecure) feel more comfortable with their verbal repertories. These early dictionaries were filled only with hard words and did not bother with defining cow or apple, reasoning that everyone knew what words like that meant. Instead they sought to explain to the uninitiated the meaning of terms like desticate (to cry like a rat) and antipelargy (the reciprocal love children have for their parents).

title: Art in Review
description: MILTON AVERY

title: Off the Train, a Motley Hub
description: The heart of South Norwalk, Conn., rows of buildings from the late 19th and early 20th centuries on Washington and South Main Streets, packs a lot into a compact area. The upper floors of the buildings have artists studios, and, at street level, the collection of restaurants, shops and galleries is diverse enough to please anyone who makes the ride  only an hour or so  from Grand Central Terminal on the Metro-North Railroad ($19.50 round-trip on weekends, $10 for children). Its all within an easy walk of the station, too  including the Maritime Aquarium, the one relatively new building in the group and the one that enables grown-ups to enjoy browsing and shopping while still entertaining the children.

title: Theres a New Deal at Roosevelts Dorm
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Franklin Delano Roosevelt hardly did any homework as a Harvard undergraduate. While enrolled in classes like General Paleontology and English Letter Writers, he concentrated on editing the school newspaper, dating debutantes and collecting stuffed birds. His roommate, Lathrop Brown, who later was a one-term congressman from Long Island, managed the football team and earned mostly Ds.

title: Russia Boots Space Tourists
description: Russia says it will no longer allow tourists to accompany astronauts onboard its shuttle missions to the International Space Station.

title: Muslims, Too, Perished in Nigerian Violence
description: This month, the dead were Christians.

title: Taking It With You in Ancient Egypt
description: You cant take it with you. Or so you think if you are an enlightened citizen of the modern world. All your earthly possessions and attainments arent going to do you a bit of good after youve gone.

title: That American Dream: Scheme and Scramble
description: Restraint proves a virtue of  and a shrewd if necessary choice for  Children of Invention, a modestly scaled, quietly effective independent movie about a struggling single mother and her two children. Directed and written by Tze Chun, making a fine feature debut, the movie offers both a familiar tale of immigrant striving and a topical look at what it means to be working and poor in America while hanging onto a badly frayed thread. Yet while the politics are there, you might be too busy choking back tears to notice.

title: Leaps of Faith to Transcend Urban Angst
description: A flourishing member of a precious and nearly extinct species has been sighted on Broadway, looking remarkably vital and sure of itself for a creature so often given up for dead. Next Fall, which opened Thursday night at the Helen Hayes Theater, is that genuine rara avis, a smart, sensitive and utterly contemporary New York comedy. The question now is whether theatergoers will recognize that Next Fall embodies something theyve been sorely missing, perhaps without knowing it, for years.

title: F.C.C. Ponders Action on Cable Fee Disputes
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said the agency was considering changes to ensure that cable television customers do not lose access to broadcast stations because of fee disputes between broadcasters and cable companies.

title: A Vote to Change Some Cocaine Sentences
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today to reduce the discrepancy that has existed for more than two decades in federal penalties for possession of crack cocaine and powder cocaine.

title: Remembering Merlin Olsen, the Football Player
description: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down. Merlin Olsen died of cancer at age 69 on Thursday.

title: Marquette Outshoots Villanova to Reach Semifinals
description: Marquette and Villanova squared off in a shootout Thursday afternoon as both guard-oriented offenses shot freely. For Villanova, it was Corey Stokes, best known as the Bayonne Bomber, connecting on 6 of 7 3-pointers for 22 points. For Marquette, it was Darius Johnson-Odom, a southpaw who made 5 of 7 from that range for 24 points.

title: No National Tour for Carnage
description: The producers of God of Carnage, the winner of the 2009 Tony Award for best play and a critical and commercial hit on Broadway, have decided not to mount a national tour of the production at this point, concerned that it would not run in enough weeks to make a tour financially worthwhile.

title: Always Outrageous, Frequently Disturbing
description: How German was Otto Dix? The question echoes through the retrospective of Dixs unforgiving art, the first show of its kind ever held in North America, at the Neue Galerie. The answer delivered by this completely engrossing yet sadly flawed exhibition is: deeply, madly, truly.

title: The Chic of Araby
description: Looking for fashions new frontier? Go east, young man.

title: The Prof Stuff
description: Like many online services, Rate My Professors, the engrossing professor-ranking site, seems at first to be a companion to offline life. Real-life students take real-life classes and hand down judgments of real-life professors in a virtual forum. The site invites reviewers  whose identities as students are never given or verified  to give numerical rankings, from 1 to 5, in four categories: easiness, helpfulness, clarity and the reviewers interest in the subject matter before they took the class. You can also assign professors chili-pepper icons if you think theyre good-looking. Even the losers have a place. Professors can rebut bad reviews and upload protest videos under the feeble rubric Professors Strike Back.

title: Museum Sets Grand Stage for Strings and Horns
description: THE oboes and clarinets and flutes and bassoons stand upright, like stalks in a vegetable garden. A motley sisterhood of keyboard instruments  virginals, clavichords, harpsichords  squat on platforms and tables. Curvaceous Strads and voluptuous viols seem to rest seductively against the walls. Oddballs lurk: the sea-dragon-shaped bassoon, the accordion disguised as a cello, the foot-long miniviolins.
