title: Treading Softly Around a Minefield of Emotions
description: Ivy (Zoe Kazan), present in virtually every frame of The Exploding Girl, Bradley Rust Grays sweet and tentative new film, is home from college for the summer, back in a New York suffused with leafy green in the daytime and red neon at night. Her life is fairly uneventful  she hangs out, works with some children, talks on her cellphone, goes to a party or two, visits a doctor who monitors her epilepsy  but nonetheless complicated.

title: Time Bandits
description: As a manager at a large company, I work far more than the required 40 hours a week but report only 40. If I reported my actual hours, I could be penalized financially for letting my projects run overbudget. Company policy states that intentionally submitting inaccurate time reports is an integrity issue. I see why this forbids claiming to have worked when I did not, but is there a problem with simply declining to mention some hours when I did work? NAME WITHHELD, NEW JERSEY

title: Man Leaves Midtown Bar
description: A video clip of an individual leaving the Social bar on 8th Avenue Thursday morning.

title: New U.N. Climate Change Group Is All Male
description: Women at some environmentally conscious nonprofits are indignant that a new group overseeing financing for a United Nations climate change effort has 19 members  none of them women.

title: Photos of the Moment | Its a Wrap!
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Not Your Typical Alpine Hut
description: Gleaming like a metallic glacier at almost 10,000 feet above sea level, the new Monte Rosa Mountain Hut, which opened on March 10, is so mesmerizing that even its impressive view of the Matterhorn seems secondary.

title: Small Michigan Television Station Is Priced to Sell on eBay
description: You dont need pockets as deep as Comcasts to get into the TV business. Or even be a millionaire, apparently.

title: Scarred Bodies, Entwined Souls
description: Out of a mathematical conceit the Italian writer Paolo Giordano has drawn a mesmerizing portrait of a young man and woman whose injured natures draw them together over the years and inevitably pull them apart.

title: The Solitude of Prime Numbers
description: Alice Della Rocca hated ski school. She hated getting up at seven-thirty, even during Christmas vacation. She hated her father staring at her over breakfast, his leg dancing nervously under the table as if to say hurry up, get a move on. She hated the woolen tights that made her thighs itch, the mittens that kept her from moving her fingers, the helmet that squashed her cheeks, and the big, too tight boots that made her walk like a gorilla.

title: Fierce Love: Better Not Make This Mom Angry
description: The last monster to run wild through Bong Joon-hos imagination was an enormous creature from the watery deep. A different menace storms through Mother, the fourth feature from this sensationally talented South Korean filmmaker, though she too seems to spring from unfathomable depths. Unlike the beast in The Host  a catastrophic byproduct of the American military  the monster in Mother doesnt come with much of a backstory, which suggests that she is a primal force, in other words, a natural.

title: Dancing Around Death, With Elephant in Room
description: Restarting the Seattle grunge band Alice in Chains after the death in 2002 of its lead singer and frequent lyricist, Layne Staley, was a matter of delicate positioning. Jerry Cantrell, the guitarist who founded the band with Mr. Staley and now writes nearly all its material, had to blend respect, mourning and pragmatism. At Terminal 5 on Tuesday, the second sold-out show of a two-night stand, Mr. Staleys name was not mentioned onstage, but his absence was central.

title: Friend Request
description: Last winter, in the middle of my intern year, I became Facebook friends with a young man who was dying in the intensive-care unit. An investment banker in his mid-20s, he thought he was healthy until a fluttering in his chest and swollen ankles took him to a doctor. Now he was in the I.C.U. with a rare cardiac condition and the vague possibility of a transplant.

title: Japanese Master of the Hard Shake Comes to Town
description: Though living and working half a world away, the Japanese bartender and cocktail-shaking philosopher Kazuo Uyeda has managed to inspire many a Manhattan barroom argument. Most of them have centered on what is called the hard shake, an ornate and controversial method of shaking drinks devised by Mr. Uyeda.

title: Performance Art Preserved, in the Flesh
description: With the opening on Sunday of Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present, a long-building energy wave of performance art hits the Museum of Modern Art full force. The show is a four-decade survey of work by one of the fields most visible and magnetic figures. And its combination of stressed-out flesh in documentary films and live bodies, some nude, in the galleries, makes pretty radical fare for this institution.

title: Theater Listings: March 12  18
description: THEATER

title: Once Shocking, Now Poetic
description: Considering how revolutionary Surrealist photography was in the years before World War II, what with its double-exposing, montaging, solarizing and other techniques, it may seem paradoxical that nostalgia would be the mood suffusing Twilight Visions: Surrealism, Photography and Paris at the International Center of Photography. But it makes sense.

title: A Shift Away From Linear Thinking
description: Paris

title: French Film Spotlight
description: Images from films appearing in the 2010 Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series.

title: Ray Charles Musical Will Open in November
description: The new production Unchain My Heart, The Ray Charles Musical is scheduled to begin preview performances on Broadway on Oct. 8 and open on Nov. 7, directed by Sheldon Epps and with a book by Suzan-Lori Parks, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright of Topdog/Underdog, the lead producer Stuart Benjamin said on Thursday.

title: The Diners Journal Bake Sale Bake Off
description: Its always a great day here at Diners Journal when baking and politics meet.

title: Inside the List
description: ABRAHAM LINCOLN, AX SWINGER: Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter, Seth Grahame-Smiths follow-up to the surprise smash hit Pride and Prejudice and Zombies, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4, and not everybody is happy about it.

title: Feeling Trapped By Stepchildren
description: Speaking of siblings, Colleen K.,, a 25-year-old mother from Davenport, Iowa, is looking for some advice. Not only is she raising her own three sons, ages 5, 2 and 9 months, but she is also trying to be a part-time parent to her four step-children.

title: Entertaining With a Folksy Palette of Despondency
description: Heres another depressing song, Stephin Merritt of the Magnetic Fields said at Town Hall on Wednesday night, to a murmur of something like delight. His disclaimer doubled as a statement of principle and, on some level, as low-impact shtick.

title: Upper Broadway as a Young Boulevard
description: THIRTY years ago, Broadway north of 96th Street was a vibrant but shabby area, its Hispanic groceries and Chinese restaurants mixed with declining Edwardian apartment houses and S.R.O. hotels.

title: Battlegrounds on Tiny Specks of Earth
description: At wars end, the cabbie wont take money from the Marine returning home from the Pacific. I might have jumped into Normandy but at least I got some liberties in London and Paris, the driver, a veteran of D-Day, says pityingly. You gyrenes, you got nothing but jungle rot and malaria. Welcome home.

title: Samsung Unwraps a New E-Book Reader
description: Samsung unwrapped its long-awaited e-book reader for the American market this week, and its a curious combination of useful features and an important missing feature.

title: Glimmerglass Opera Hires Francesca Zambello
description: Francesca Zambello, a busy opera and musical theater director whose work has ranged from Disneys Little Mermaid to Wagners Ring cycle, has been hired as the general and artistic director of the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., the company said on Thursday. Ms. Zambello will succeed Michael MacLeod, who said in February he would leave this year after five seasons. Ms. Zambello, who is also artistic adviser to the San Francisco Opera, has directed productions at the Metropolitan Opera, the Royal Opera House in London, the Paris Opera and other major companies. Glimmerglass presents four productions a summer.

title: Timing of Obama Indonesia Trip Questioned
description: With President Obamas health care bill hanging in the balance, the White House is facing intensifying questions about whether Mr. Obama should take his planned trip to Indonesia and Australia next week.

title: Broadway North of 96th Street
description: Broadway north of 96th Street is an eclectic mix of several types of architecture from the past century.

title: Glimmerglass Opera Hires a New Artistic Director
description: Francesca Zambello, a busy opera and musical theater director whose work has ranged from Disneys Little Mermaid to Wagners Ring cycle, has been hired as the general and artistic director of the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., the company said on Thursday. Ms. Zambello will succeed Michael MacLeod, who said in February he would leave this year after five seasons. Ms. Zambello, who is also artistic adviser to the San Francisco Opera, has directed productions at the Metropolitan Opera, the Royal Opera House in London, the Paris Opera and other major companies. Glimmerglass presents four productions a summer.

title: St. Olaf to New York: White to Host SNL
description: Call it a victory for democracy or peer pressure, but either way its happening: Betty White, above, the 88-years-young Mary Tyler Moore and Golden Girls star, will be hosting Saturday Night Live on May 8, a pre-Mothers Day episode also featuring appearances from six SNL alumnae. Though a popular Facebook campaign helped build Ms. Whites cause, Lorne Michaels, the SNL creator and executive producer, said Thursday that the grass-roots movement wasnt the sole reason for the booking. The depth of feeling for her at the show and particularly among the women who are coming back was very deep, Mr. Michaels said in a telephone interview. He added that he had concerns given the shows grueling schedule, and as a solution invited the former SNL performers Tina Fey, Amy Poehler, Maya Rudolph, Rachel Dratch, Ana Gasteyer and Molly Shannon to appear, too. Ultimately, he said, Ms. Whites age wouldnt prevent her from participating fully. Mind you, at our show, Pardos 92, he said, referring to the announcer Don Pardo. A couple people in wardrobe are older than him. So shes a spring chicken in our world.

title: EMI Is Told, Hey, Label, Leave the Tracks Alone
description: Finally: score one for the wealthy rock stars. A British court ruled on Thursday in favor of Pink Floyd, saying that EMI, its longtime record label, could no longer sell songs from the bands concept albums as singles on the Internet, Reuters reported. On Tuesday, a lawyer for Pink Floyd argued in a High Court hearing in London that the bands contract expressly prohibited the unbundling of its songs in any configuration other than the way they were originally produced and released. Judge Andrew Morritt sided with the band, saying its contract was designed to preserve the artistic integrity of the albums, according to Reuters. In a statement, EMI said, Were huge fans of Pink Floyd, whose great catalog we have been representing for more than 40 years, and continue to represent exclusively and internationally.

title: Idol Guys Win a Night
description: Performances from the top eight male singers on American Idol lifted it to No. 1 in the prime-time ratings Wednesday. According to Nielsens estimates, Idol drew 20.5 million viewers at 9 p.m., enough to ensure Fox led the night over all even as the network garnered a much smaller audience at 8 for Human Target (7.8 million). CBS ranked second, gaining 13.1 million viewers at 9 for Criminal Minds and 11 million at 10 for CSI: NY, but fewer in the 8 p.m. hour for its comedies The New Adventures of Old Christine (7.9 million) and Gary Unmarried (6.8 million). NBC placed third on the night with Mercy at 8 (6.3 million) and two installments of Law & Order: SVU, a rerun at 9 (5.4 million) followed by a new episode at 10 (8.6 million). ABC finished close behind NBC in fourth place with its comedy lineup from 8 to 10, including the standout Modern Family at 9 (8.9 million), while ABCs Ugly Betty struggled at 10 with just 4.1 million viewers.

title: The Names Knight. Pat Knight.
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  After Texas Techs 80-68 loss Thursday to Kansas in the Big 12 quarterfinals, the Red Raiders were laughing in the locker room.

title: Conan OBrien Announces Details of National Tour
description: The fans of Conan OBrien will not have to wait much longer  though they may have to wait in long lines  to see their favorite late-night comedian perform again: starting April 12 in Eugene, Ore., and including dates at Radio City Music Hall on June 1 and 2, Mr. OBriens 30-city tour is on. And if the title is any indication, it will also be sending a message about how Mr. OBrien, above, and his Team Coco feels about his abrupt departure from NBCs Tonight Show in January. The name: The Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television Tour. The title refers to Mr. OBriens settlement with NBC, which included a provision that he cannot appear on television again until after Sept. 1. But there is no prohibition against going onstage and doing a live show, which is what Team Coco (the name bestowed by rabid fans upset by his leaving NBC) has planned, including some regulars from Mr. OBriens old cast, like his sidekick, Andy Richter, and members of his Tonight Show band. Mr. OBrien announced the details in a message to his followers on Twitter on Thursday morning. Team Coco also sent out a release in which Mr. OBrien described his reasons for doing the tour. It was either a massive 30-city tour or start helping out around the house, Mr. OBrien said.

title: What Were Reading: A Nobel Peace Prize for Us All?
description: Thursdays roundup of odds and ends from around the Web, selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times:

title: Cirque Du Soleil Show Is Delayed Again
description: Somewhere in New York, the Allman Brothers Band must be having a good ol Southern laugh: the long-gestating Cirque du Soleil show Banana Shpeel, whose planned February start at the Beacon Theater pushed the band from its traditional annual residency there, said on Wednesday that it was once again postponing its start date, and will begin performances on April 29. In a news release, Cirque du Soleil said it was turning the production duties for the show over to Marty Schmelky  that is, the fictional producer played by Jerry Kernion in the poorly received Chicago run of Banana Shpeel. Mr. Schmelky (or someone playing him) said in a statement that the show still needs more time to ripen. (His pun, not ours.) The start date for Banana Shpeel has already slipped (O.K., that is our pun) from Feb. 4 to Feb. 25 to March 17 and now to April 29.

title: The Hour Approaches to Stage A Time to Kill
description: Though its still a bit of a mystery why its taken this long for one of John Grishams books to be translated into a play, the identity of the theater company that will present the first stage adaptation of his work has been revealed. Arena Stage, the Washington company, will put on a version of A Time to Kill as part of its 2010-11 season. The play, which will be written by Rupert Holmes (Curtains, Drood) and produced by the New York theater impresario Daryl Roth, will be adapted from Mr. Grishams 1989 novel, about murder, rape and racism in rural Mississippi, and not the 1996 film version directed by Joel Schumacher. In the novel its possible to go to many different locations in the audiences imagination, said Molly Smith, the artistic director of Arena Stage, in a telephone interview on Thursday. Mr. Holmess adaptation, she said, is very focused in the courtroom, and that will intensify the action of the entire piece, so that the audience really becomes the jurors, and at other points are voyeurs on the action. It will run from May 6 through June 19, 2011.

title: The Eddie Jordan Job Watch
description: There are phrases that should signal job security trouble for any embattled N.B.A. coach.

title: Fresh Fish, Frozen Angler
description: Quetico Provincial Park, Ontario

title: The Works of 10 Abstract Expressionists for Under $5
description: The United States Post Office issued 10 Abstract Expressionist stamps on Thursday. They depict paintings by 10 artists  Joan Mitchell and the usual male suspects, you might say  and look bright and energetic and very abstract. Theyre not the first stamps based on modern paintings, or even Abstract Expressionist ones, but the edition is the first to concentrate on these artists as a group. Seeing them made me feel protective. I was even compelled to offer a talking point to the woman who at the Post Office who sold them to me: if she got any guff about them she could mention that the paintings are all at least 50 years old. She seemed impressed. Theyre not new at all, I said, somewhat defensively. Theyre classics.

title: Social Networking Apps That Network
description: So many people get messages from Facebook, Twitter and AIM that it makes sense to consolidate the communications, rather than opening a different app each time. Thursdays PhoneSmart column reviews iPhone apps for that task.

title: South by Southwest: A Virtual Playground in Austin
description: Every March, thousands of entrepreneurs and digital types descend on Austin, Tex., for South by Southwest Interactive. Theyre hoping to get a glimpse of some of the newest Web and mobile innovations, and perhaps to sample some tacos.

title: Dealing With Fraud by Denial
description: Years after Charles Ponzi was imprisoned for a fraud that cost victims millions of dollars in 1920, the state of Massachusetts determined it had recovered all the assets it could, and began to distribute them to victims, who stood to receive less than 30 cents for each dollar they invested.

title: Iraq Elections: Early Results Suggest Very Tight Race
How to Choose the Right Apple iPad for You
description: If you are not interested in Apples coming iPad and have no intention of buying one, then you may want to skip this post. But if youre already readying your tent and fold-up chairs to wait outside an Apple store for the companys latest offering, then please read on.

title: Our Town Is Yours, Too
description: ANYONE who has attended or visited the MacDowell Colony, the nations oldest artists colony, has daydreamed about owning property in Peterborough. Quaint New Englanders with clapboard exteriors and regal Federal-style homes line quiet country roads. Whitewashed steeples, covered bridges and the preserved 18th-century buildings of its downtown rise against the mountainous backdrop that characterizes the Monadnock region.

title: Baylor vs. Texas: This One Is Personal
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The night session of the Big 12 tournament quarterfinals opens this evening with No. 2 seed Kansas State facing No. 7 Oklahoma State.

title: Paul Taylor Dance Company
description: Perhaps the two books on Paul Taylor currently in preparation will finally reveal something about a choreographer who has worked hard to be inexplicable.

title: The Rationale Behind CAs Deal for Nimsoft
description: CAs $350 million acquisition of Nimsoft, a performance software company, is its third purchase of the year, but this could arguably be its most important, analysts at the 451 Group said in a report to its clients on Thursday. The deal gives CA, which sells technology management software mostly to large corporate clients, an opportunity to expand to a growing market of smaller clients.

title: Sorting Through the Apple iPad Options
description: Thinking about ordering an Apple iPad on Friday?

title: How Do You Say Jersey Shore in Russian?
description: Anastasia Kurinnaya, shod in a pair of black Aldo booties with five-inch heels, stepped carefully down the 10 rickety plywood stairs that led from the coat check into the grimy basement of Passion, a popular Russian dance club on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: A Rebel, Brooding and Smoking His Way Out of Bourgeois Normalcy
description: In Remember Me love means never having to say youre sorry, particularly to the audience. The star, as if you didnt know, is Robert Pattinson, the moody vampire heartthrob from the Twilight series, a conceivably promising, certainly watchable actor in need of an immediate acting intervention. Along with working double time as one of the movies executive producers and its biggest bait, he plays Tyler, a dreary melancholic who poses and broods in this lugubrious romance cum family melodrama about a boy (sad) and a girl (also sad) who heal (eventually) while steaming up the sheets (discreetly). Along the way, many people die but few matter: most are just part of the warm-up act as well as the means to a shamelessly exploitative end.

title: Voices of Performance
description: Excerpts from interviews with the performance artists Marina Abramovic, Joan Jonas and Alison Knowles.

title: When Laid-Back, Low-Key Is Just the Ticket
description: Killington, Vt.

title: National Book Critics Circle Award Winners Announced
description: 8:19 a.m. | Updated  The British author Hilary Mantel was awarded the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction at the New Schools Tishman auditorium on Thursday night for Wolf Hall, a historical novel about the court of Henry VIII and centered on the kings adviser, Thomas Cromwell.

title: Does the Size of a School Matter?
description: View a larger map of the 28 schools that will close under the Kansas City districts Right-Size plan (via www.nbcactionnews.com )

title: Teamwork Wins Wars and Operas
description: Valery Gergiev has been the artistic and general director of the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg for 22 years. The Mariinsky orchestra, an ensemble that passes on traditions, artistic identity and even instruments from generation to generation, has formed a bond with Mr. Gergiev. When things are working well, the orchestra and the conductor bring out the best in each other.

title: Gazoo Cervelli Opts for Extra Protection
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Francisco Cervelli has a new nickname: Gazoo.

title: More Layoffs at BusinessWeek
description: As the new Bloomberg BusinessWeek editor Josh Tyrangiel makes plans for revising the magazine, hes also cutting back on staff.

title: American Held in Yemen After Shootout
description: Sharif Mobley, a 26-year-old from suburban New Jersey who moved to Yemen two years ago, was arrested there last week in a sweep of suspected militants, according to a spokesman for Yemens embassy in Washington. After his arrest, Mr. Mobley complained of being ill and was transferred to a hospital in the Yemeni capital, Sana, the spokesman added. He then tried to escape and killed a security guard before being recaptured after a shootout.

title: How Shall We Know Him? Through His Dances and More
description: Two books on the choreographer Paul Taylor are in preparation. One is a critical study by Angela Kane, whom the Paul Taylor Dance Company lists as its historian; the other is an authorized biography by Suzanne Carbonneau. Both of these scholars have followed Mr. Taylors choreography for years, enjoying close access to him and his associates. Its fair to expect that their treatments will be sensitive, intelligent, responsible.

title: Haiti: Kidnappers Free Aid Workers
description: Five days after they were kidnapped in the Port-au-Prince area, two Swiss women, aid workers for Doctors Without Borders, were released unharmed on Wednesday night.

title: The First 2,000 Wins Are the Hardest
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  There was more significance to Kansas 80-68 victory against Texas Tech on Thursday than just advancing to the Big 12 tournament semifinals.

title: Beethoven and Franck, With Sparkle From Muti
description: For the final week of his visit with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, Riccardo Muti is conducting a peculiarly balanced program devoted to Beethovens Violin Concerto, as enduring a work as youll find, and Francks Symphony in D minor, a score that has always struck many listeners as diffuse and bombastic. Oddly, at the first performance, on Wednesday evening, Mr. Muti made the Franck seem more vigorous and exciting than the Beethoven.

title: BP to Pay Devon $7 Billion for Fuel Assets
description: LONDON  BP, the British oil giant, agreed on Thursday to pay Devon Energy $7 billion in cash for oil and gas assets in Brazil, the Gulf of Mexico and Azerbaijan, seeking to increase production.

title: Cost of F-35 Has Risen 60% to 90%, Military Says
description: The projected cost of Lockheed Martins new Joint Strike Fighter has increased 60 to 90 percent in real terms since 2001, blowing well past a level requiring the program to be revamped, Pentagon officials said Thursday.

title: China Takes February Inflation Signals in Stride
description: BEIJING  Even with a jump in consumer prices in February, there were no signs of a change in Chinas economic policy course as it continued its strong recovery, economists and government officials said Thursday.

title: The Unequal Impact of San Franciscos Fire-Rehire Plan
description: When San Francisco issued 17,474 pink slips to workers across nearly every city department, on Friday, what was not immediately clear was the disproportionate impact of the move, which hit 98 percent of workers in accounting and information-technology jobs while affecting about four percent of transit workers.

title: What a Charming Loser, What TV-Sharp Kids
description: Beginning with the paranoid, conspiracy-mongering brother on the alien-attack series Invasion and continuing with the slacker best friend of the soul-hunting hero on Reaper, Tyler Labine has made a specialty of playing lovable misfits who rise to the occasion.

title: A Marine Searches for Meaning in the Sands and Steel Rain of Iraq
description: Here is the truth about being a Marine that you wont find on the local news. Were loud. We drink too much, fight too much and swear too much. Truth be told, our rifles are the only things we think about more than sex.

title: To Take on Botox, Rival Tries Rebate
description: Allergan and Medicis Pharmaceutical are the Coke and Pepsi of vanity medicine.

title: Take Five: A Childrens Circus Troupe and a Concert in Honor of Female Composers
description: Wondering what to do this weekend? We have you covered:

title: Kidnapping Melodrama
description: Stolen, Anders Andersons dual kidnapping melodrama of tormented fathers a half-century apart, searching for their lost sons, plays like a middling episode of Law & Order: SVU, drawn out an extra half-hour and embellished with pretentious literary and cinematic flourishes. The dads, Detective Tom Adkins (Jon Hamm), whose 10-year-old son is snatched outside a diner on the Fourth of July 2000, and Matthew Wakefield (Josh Lucas), whose boy is abducted from a car in 1958 while Matthew is having a stand-up quickie with a floozy, are photographed to look almost alike.

title: Earthquakes Burdens Weigh Heavily on Haitis Elderly
description: LOGNE, Haiti  Junie Sufrad, 110 years old, stopped suddenly as she described what life was like in the Haitian countryside before electricity, paved roads and cars.

title: Azile Saint Vincent de Paul
description: A panoramic view of the Azile Saint Vincent de Paul nursing home in Logne, Haiti.

title: Luxury Models Carry BMW and Volkswagen to a Year of Profits
description: FRANKFURT  Luxury car sales that improved during the fourth quarter helped both BMW and Volkswagen post annual profits on Thursday. But VW continued to struggle when it came to the sale of lower-price cars.

title: Ground Zero Workers Reach Deal Over Claims
description: A settlement of up to $657.5 million has been reached in the cases of thousands of rescue and cleanup workers at ground zero who sued the city over damage to their health, according to city officials and lawyers for the plaintiffs.

title: Walking Down the Comedic Aisle
description: Alternately rancid and ridiculous, strident and sickly sweet, Our Family Wedding offers plenty thats old, borrowed and blue; its the something new thats missing.

title: Boards Decision to Close 28 Kansas City Schools Follows Years of Inaction
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Like so many other public school parents, Reshonda Sanders felt confused on Thursday as she tried to comprehend why nearly half of the schools here, including her own alma mater, are to close for good at the end of the year. As the mother of two high school students, she was well aware of the districts struggles.

title: Bank Revises Number Affected by Data Theft
description: PARIS  HSBC said on Thursday that the theft of Swiss client data at the heart of a recent tax dispute with France was much larger than it earlier acknowledged.

title: Death Squad
description: Of all the crimes that sullied the record of the United States military in Iraq  the torture of prisoners at Abu Ghraib, the killings of 24 Iraqi men, women and children by Marines in November 2005 in Haditha  the murder of an entire Iraqi family in the village of Yusufiya may rank as the most chilling. On March 12, 2006, United States soldiers were summoned to a small house in the heart of the insurgent-filled Triangle of Death south and west of Baghdad, where they discovered the charred remains of a 14-year-old girl who had been raped, shot to death, then burned with kerosene, along with the bodies of her 6-year-old sister and her parents. At first the killings were attributed to a feud between Iraqis, but after a soldier came forward with information he had gleaned from comrades, the Army arrested the real perpetrators: four soldiers from Bravo Company, a casualty-plagued unit in the Armys First Battalion, 502nd Infantry, 101st Airborne Division. Press attention centered on the groups ringleader, Pvt. Steven Green from Midland, Tex., a petulant loner and a hard-drinking druggie according to Newsweek, who was afflicted by a seething, seemingly random rage. Despite Greens repeated troubles with the law, he had easily enlisted in an Army hurting for recruits and breezed through basic training. Before his deployment, Green made no secret of his bloodlust, reportedly telling one neighbor, Im gonna go over there and kill em all.

title: Report Details How Lehman Hid Its Woes
description: It is the Wall Street equivalent of a coroners report  a 2,200-page document that lays out, in new and startling detail, how Lehman Brothers used accounting sleight of hand to conceal the bad investments that led to its undoing.

title: Rapid Rise in Seed Prices Draws U.S. Scrutiny
description: During the depths of the economic crisis last year, the prices for many goods held steady or even dropped. But on American farms, the picture was far different, as farmers watched the price they paid for seeds skyrocket. Corn seed prices rose 32 percent; soybean seeds were up 24 percent.

title: Airline Group, Citing Emerging Markets, Lowers Loss Forecast
description: A leading airline trade group cut its forecast for industry losses this year in half on Thursday because of what it said was a stronger-than-expected economic recovery in emerging markets, especially in Asia and Latin America.

title: Woman Hired as Coach
description: Calvin Coolidge High School in Washington made the rare move of hiring a woman, Natalie Randolph, to coach its football team. Randolph, who has two years experience as an assistant at another area high school, H. D. Woodson, and played four seasons in the Independent Womens Professional League, will be introduced at a news conference at the school Friday.

title: Ukraines President Forms a Coalition in Parliament
description: MOSCOW  The new Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, put together a coalition in Parliament on Thursday, allowing him to consolidate control over the government and avoid new elections that could have created renewed political instability.

title: Highway Deaths Are on the Decline
description: The number of highway deaths in the United States fell nearly 9 percent in 2009, according to a preliminary estimate from the Department of Transportation, and the drop since 2005 is 22 percent.

title: Delay Sought on Dismissal of Catalano Case
description: Federal prosecutors asked a Buffalo court to postpone its decision about whether to dismiss the case against Mary Anne Catalano, the assistant to Anthony Galea, the Toronto doctor who is suspected of providing performance-enhancing drugs to professional athletes.

title: New Earmark Rules Have Lobbyists Scrambling
description: WASHINGTON  Jolted by a sudden tightening of the rules, lobbyists and military contractors who have long relied on lucrative earmarks from Congress were scrambling Thursday to find new ways to keep the federal money flowing.

title: U.S. Falters in Screening Border Patrol Near Mexico
description: Federal anticorruption investigators continue to struggle to keep up with the screening of newly hired United States law enforcement officers working on the Mexican border and have fallen far behind in checking current employees as well, federal officials testified on Thursday.

title: More Than Words
description: In Peter Hansons dishy documentary Tales From the Script, 46 screenwriters (4 women and 42 men, if youre wondering) gab agreeably about the tribulations of their profession.

title: Obama Lists Who Will Get Prize Money From Nobel
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has made good on a promise to give his $1.4 million in Nobel Peace Prize money to charity, releasing on Thursday the names of the organizations that will benefit.

title: Kansas Center Has Some Fans in Texas
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Kansas center Cole Aldrich is often compared to the Boston Celtics Hall of Famer Kevin McHale because both hail from Minnesota.

title: Up Front: Joshua Hammer
description: As Newsweeks Jerusalem bureau chief from 2001 to 2004, Joshua Hammer covered Iraq extensively, embedding with United States troops as the insurgency spiraled out of control, he explained in an e-mail message.

title: Outraged by Glenn Becks Salvo, Christians Fire Back
description: Last week, the conservative broadcaster Glenn Beck called on Christians to leave their churches if they hear preaching about social or economic justice, saying they were code words for Communism and Nazism.

title: Talks to Address Trade in Tuna and Ivory
description: Marathon negotiations on protecting the planets endangered species open on Saturday in Qatar with tensions bubbling over efforts to ban trade in bluefin tuna and to reopen exports of elephant ivory from Africa.

title: Lexus, a Toyota Brand, Avoids Taint From Recalls
description: It has been a rough few months for Toyota because of its three big safety recalls. But the automakers luxury division, Lexus, appears to have avoided much of the fallout.

title: Board Extends Deadline for Everglades Land Deal
description: OKEECHOBEE, Fla.  Facing legal challenges and growing deficits, South Florida water officials on Thursday gave themselves six more months to finance a controversial $536 million purchase of land from United States Sugar for the Everglades.

title: Domestic Dramedy
description: White on Rice is an Asian-American domestic dramedy thats determined to be as culture-neutral as possible. To that end the director, Dave Boyle, who wrote the screenplay with Joel Clark, avoids the genres most common markers: the obsession with food, the meddling grandparents, the no-future family business. Unfortunately, whats left is bland and only occasionally funny. An arrested-development comedy grafted to a wan indie story of a family drifting apart, it would be entirely predictable were it not for the weird shifts in tone and an implausible crisis involving a kitchen knife that pushes the story toward its conclusion.

title: Getting Obama Right
description: Who is Barack Obama?

title: Mortgage Bonds  Make a Comeback
description: The market for private-label mortgage bonds in the United States might be ready for revival.

title: Take This Job and Write It
description: Joblessness may be hovering around 10 percent, with some 29 million Americans out of work or searching for full-time employment, but theres one group of people whose persistent alienation from regular employment has emerged as a particularly serious problem. I refer, of course, to novelists.

title: Winter Games Yield Forecasting Insights
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Winter Olympics and the coming Paralympic Games here have generally not been blessed with wintry weather. But an elaborate weather forecasting service that has been operating for nearly four years meant that the unwelcome conditions were not a surprise.

title: Instant Ads Set the Pace on the Web
description: Time is now on the side of online advertisers.

title: Train Kills Woman Trying to Retrieve Bag
description: A 48-year-old woman was hit and killed by a No. 6 train in an Upper East Side subway station on Thursday afternoon after she dropped her bag on the tracks and jumped down to go after it, the police and witnesses said.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: TOO MUCH MONEY  By Dominick Dunne.  Crown, $26.

title: Playing the Odds of Love
description: If youre going to make a romantic comedy called Shes Out of My League about a schlubby nice guy and a pneumatic blonde, the last thing you want is for the audience to be left thinking: Hes right. Shes way out of his league.

title: Rejected on Dance Floor, Man Beats Woman in Bar Restroom
description: It was about two hours before closing time early on Thursday at Social, a Midtown bar, when the man approached a woman as she danced.

title: Killing by Numbers
description: Statistically as well as temperamentally, the serial killer is almost exclusively an American phenomenon. So while its disconcerting to find one of these psychos traipsing around Oslo in Jo Nesbos thriller THE DEVILS STAR (Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99), its fascinating to watch this Norwegian author adapt our homegrown monster to a foreign culture.

title: If Extortion Is Bad, So Is Predation
description: Soon after the man who had tried to extort money from him pleaded guilty to attempted grand larceny, David Letterman pronounced himself satisfied with the outcome. The Manhattan district attorneys office, he said on his late-night show, handled the case professionally, skillfully and appropriately.

title: Pre-existing Conditions
description: Its like that old joke: A priest, a minister and a rabbi are discussing the beginning of life. The priest says it begins at conception. The minister says it begins at birth. And you? they ask the rabbi. When do you believe life begins? He gives a shrug. When the kids move out and the dog dies.

title: A Word About the Wise
description: There are two things I would hope for in a book about wisdom. First, some intellectual enlightenment as to what wisdom really is. Second, some practical ideas on how to be wiser in my own life. This book was a letdown in both respects. Yet reading it proved to be far from a waste of time.

title: After 12 Holes of Near Perfection, Allenby Feels the Blue Monsters Bite
description: DORAL, Fla.  As the southeast winds howled across the Blue Monster Course at Doral Resort and Spa, a ball-striking clinic was going on at the W.G.C.-CA Championship. The golfer putting on the exhibition was Robert Allenby, the lean Australian who is perhaps the purest hitter on tour.

title: Trouble in the Village
description: When the liveliest character in a movie is the heroines pet turtle, you know youre in for some seriously stately filmmaking, and Delta does not disappoint. Set in a village on the edge of the Hungarian Danube, this visually demonstrative, emotionally constipated drama observes the fallout when a towheaded prodigal son (Felix Lajko) and his frail younger sister (Orsolya Toth) decide to become better acquainted.

title: Bundles of Funnies
description: As the modern-day American newspaper comic strip slowly chokes to death, done in by shrinking spaces and exhausted franchises, its more vibrant ancestors are living in renewed luxury. Comic strips are the most ephemeral kind of art; each installment is intended to last only as long as a single days paper. Now, though, virtually every major American strip of the past century or so is being reprinted in its entirety in handsome, well-designed editions, with better reproduction than it had the first time around.

title: Time, It Turns Out, Isnt on Their Side
description: A YEAR ago, I wrote about a job fair at the Sheraton in Midtown Manhattan, where over 5,000 mainly white collar, middle-aged jobless men and women waited in the cold for more than two hours, hoping to find work. The turnout was a sign of desperate times; until then, the organizer, Tory Johnson, whos been conducting these fairs in 10 cities for a decade, had never had more than 2,000 people at one of these events.

title: Hidden Meanings
description: Sixty-five years after Anne Franks death in Bergen-Belsen, she remains so iconic that objects associated with her have become powerful symbols in themselves. Seedlings from the horse chestnut tree that grew outside the Franks hiding place and that Anne could see and took comfort from are to be planted at places like the World Trade Center memorial site and Central High School, the desegregation landmark in Little Rock, Ark. And yet many people have trouble really seeing Anne Frank, preferring to treat her, too, as a symbol  sometimes of universal experience, sometimes of the 1.5 million Jewish children killed in the Holocaust.

title: A Veteran Judge, Never a Prosecutor, Is Seen as Well Suited to Investigate the Governor
description: The new chief investigator who stepped into the spotlight in place of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday was a judge for a quarter century, not only in title but also in temperament.

title: Democrats Struggle to Finish Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  House and Senate Democratic leaders struggled Thursday to stitch together pieces of a final health care bill as rank-and-file Democrats demanded more information about the contents of the bill and its cost.

title: A Trailblazer of Civil Rights Dies Forgotten
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Neighbors were chagrined last week when the police here found the body of a 75-year-old woman who had frozen to death, alone in her house, during unexpectedly frigid weather.

title: Full Throttle
description: Engaging and appealing? Absolutely. Nonfiction? Not exactly. Young readers might at first assume that Amelia Earhart: This Broad Ocean, by Sarah Stewart Taylor, is factual, since elements like the bibliography in the back tend to suggest that. But the reader has to work a bit to filter fact from fiction in this entertaining account of Earharts stay at Trepassey, Newfoundland, before she crossed the Atlantic Ocean in 1928.

title: Obama Links Immigration Overhaul in 2010 to G.O.P. Backing
description: President Obama said Thursday that he would proceed with an overhaul of the immigration system this year if he could attract substantial Republican support. But a leading Republican who supports an overhaul said an immigration bill could not go forward if the president used a legislative shortcut sidestepping Republicans to pass his health care bill.

title: Childrens Bookshelf
description: 1001 CHILDRENS BOOKS YOU MUST READ BEFORE YOU GROW UP  Edited by Julia Eccleshare.  Universe. $36.95. (All Ages)

title: Crosbys Puck Is Produced; Answers Arent
description: Sidney Crosbys stick and gloves from Canadas gold medal victory in the Olympics were found Wednesday, and the mystery of their disappearance was innocent enough  they had been misplaced.

title: Unlikely Rider Steers Long Shot Onto Derby Trail
description: Paul Atkinson spent his mornings last summer combing the backstretches of Southern California racetracks looking for a horse to ride. Any horse would do. Atkinson was 39 at the time and coming off an injury, and had never had much luck around the track anyway.

title: The Frozen Unknown
description: When European merchants, navigators and chancers began searching for a northern sea route from the Atlantic to the Pacific, Henry VIII was still a bachelor. The mazy waterways were navigable for a scant three months a year, and as late as 1819 only two white men had seen the north coast of Canada. By the time a wooden ship finally pushed through, an indifferent world was looking elsewhere. But the fabled Northwest Passage has returned to the news pages as a warming climate unlocks its deep channels, allowing access to hydrocarbons below the seabed. Anthony Brandt anchors his robust new history, The Man Who Ate His Boots, in that modern context.

title: Imitation of Life
description: Taxidermy evokes hunting cabins and mounted white-tailed deer, pheasants in flight and lacquered largemouth bass  kitschy trophies memorializing a good kill  but in Still Life, Melissa Milgrom proves that the truth is more complicated and far more interesting. The people in these pages strive to imitate nature with a fidelity that verges on pathological, which requires not only a drawerful of glass eyes and fake polar bear claws but also artistic talent and encyclopedic scientific knowledge. The goal is the illusion of life.

title: A 12-Hour Play, and Endless Bragging Rights
description: Every theater season has its must-must-must-see show, the snob hit that separates the true sophisticates (at least in their own minds) from the cultural chaff. New York will have a doozy of a contender this July: a 12-hour production of a grim Dostoyevsky novel that will be performed only twice, in Italian (with English supertitles), in a warehouse on Governors Island, reachable only after a ferry trip and a 20-minute walk.

title: Cabrera Tries to Eliminate Damaging Behavior
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Miguel Cabreras locker in the Tigers spring training clubhouse is a few feet from the office of Manager Jim Leyland and directly in Leylands view.

title: Obama Social Secretary Ran Into Sharp Elbows
description: WASHINGTON  Long before the State Dinner party crashers and the tension with her White House colleagues and the strain in her relationship with the first lady, Desire Rogers began to understand she was in trouble when David Axelrod summoned her to his office last spring to scold her.

title: Clarence Thomas, Silent but Sure
description: Lets hear it for Justice Clarence Thomas.Notice that I did not say lets hear from Justice Thomas. February 22 was the fourth anniversary of the last time Justice Thomas asked a question during an argument. His silent presence on the bench has evolved into a weirdly compelling example of performance art.

title: Tundra Songs
description: Winter isn't quite over, at least not according to the Kronos Quartet. On Saturday night, the Kronos presents "Tundra Songs," a program of music by composers from near the Arctic Circle. Allan Kozinn writes, "The quartet's guests are the Inuit throat-singer Tanya Tagaq, the Swedish band Hurdy Gurdy (Stefan Brisland-Ferner and Totte Mattsson, who use a computer to process the sound of a hurdy gurdy) and Ritva Koistinen, who plays the Finnish kantele (a triangular string instrument)." Go to Zankel Hall at 10 p.m. to listen.

title: Magnetism
description: "For someone who detests playing live," writes Ben Sisario, "Stephen Merritt of the Magnetic Fields is an unfailingly charming entertainer, breezing through his repertory of caustic bonbons and performing his role as M.C. with perfect drollery." It's not too late to catch the band at Town Hall. Its third and final concert will be tonight.

title: The Man Behind the Nose
description: There is a William Kentridge moment going on in New York right now. The South African artist has a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art and his opera directorial debut, "The Nose," about a bureaucrat who awakens one morning to find his nose missing, with music by Dmitri Shostakovich, is a hit at the Metropolitan Opera. Today, go hear from the man himself at the New York Public Library, where Mr. Kentridge will be participating in "Learning from the Absurd: A Conversation with William Kentridge." Mr. Kentridge will discuss Gogol, Shostakovich, and his own creative process. Hosted by Paul Holdengrber.

title: Bloggingheads: Nigerias Failed Schools
description: Dayo Olopade, left, of The Root and Eliza Griswold of the New America Foundation discuss the failures of education in Nigeria.

title: Upsets Continue as Irish Beat Pitt
description: The upsets continued into the night session at the Big East tournament as No. 2-seeded Pittsburgh fell to No. 7 Notre Dame.

title: A New Face in the Health Care Debate
description: Senate Democratic leaders on Thursday sought to put a human face on the health care debate, and a cute face at that.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 11, 2010

title: For Haitian, Mission Is to Mend Fences With Diaspora and Streamline Aid
description: His mission is arguably one of the most important facing the Haitian government: reach out to members of Haitis global diaspora, estimated at two million people, and harness their newly urgent desire to help their country. Yet Edwin Paraison, Haitis minister of Haitians living abroad, is quick to acknowledge that he was handicapped even before he started.

title: Arizonas N.C.A.A. Streak Quietly Ends
description: LOS ANGELES  As the buzzer sounded, signifying Arizonas 75-69 loss to U.C.L.A. in the first round of the Pacific-10 tournament, the Wildcats solemnly followed their coach, Sean Miller, off the court in a single-file line.

title: After Years of Controversy, Ceremonial Shovels Come Out
description: Inside a tent in the Prospect Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn on Thursday afternoon, the mayor and the governor mingled with celebrities and titans of business, nibbling knishes served in martini glasses, to celebrate the long-delayed groundbreaking of the basketball arena that will be the cornerstone of the Atlantic Yards project.

title: 19 Across: This Old House Topic
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  I was rushed for time and decided to test the Wordplay multiple-choice generator, a new program The Times has developed for crossword blogging. I calibrated it for themeless and set it to come in at around 200 words. The answers in italics are the ones I agree with the most.

title: SEC Hopes to Show It Has More Than Kentucky
description: NASHVILLE  It was a dreadful five hours for the Southeastern Conference here Thursday afternoon as one of the leagues marquee players, South Carolinas Devan Downey, had a disappointing finish to his career and one of its marquee teams, No. 15 Tennessee, had a near-disastrous start to its postseason.

title: A New Chapter for Bankruptcy
description: THE Obama administration introduced a plan this week to encourage defaulting homeowners to sell their houses at a loss, the latest in a long line of reform packages promising to break the logjam of underwater mortgages. But without major changes to the bankruptcy system, such measures wont aid the American families torn apart by the economic upheavals of the last two years.

title: Slot Machines at Aqueduct? No, Not Yet
description: The states tortured eight-year quest to install a limited casino at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens has failed for the third time, with the governors office announcing Thursday that its chosen bidder would not be awarded the contract.

title: Afghan Tribal Rivalries Bedevil a U.S. Plan
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  Six weeks ago, elders of the Shinwari tribe, which dominates a large area in southeastern Afghanistan, pledged that they would set aside internal differences to focus on fighting the Taliban.

title: Bye Bye Bagger
description: The Carpetbagger says goodbye to awards season.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Gary L. Krupp, an outspoken Jewish supporter of the Vaticans position that Pope Pius XII, the pontiff during World War II, did all that he could to save Jews from the Holocaust, misidentified the employer of the Rev. John T. Pawlikowski and misstated the organizational title of Rabbi Eric J. Greenberg, two critics of Mr. Krupps research. Father Pawlikowski is a professor of social ethics at the Catholic Theological Union in Chicago, not the University of Chicago, and Rabbi Greenberg is the director of interfaith affairs at the Anti-Defamation League, not the associate director.

title: California: Pledge of Allegiance Is Ruled Constitutional
description: A federal appeals court panel ruled Thursday that the Pledge of Allegiance does not violate constitutional rules separating church and state. The opinion, written by Judge Carlos T. Bea, stated that the phrase one Nation under God does not turn this patriotic exercise into a religious activity. A different three-judge panel from the same court reached the opposite conclusion in 2002, but the United States Supreme Court reversed it in 2004 on technical grounds. In a biting dissent, Judge Stephen R. Reinhardt, who sided with the majority in 2002, wrote that Congress added under God to the pledge in 1954 for unconstitutional religious purposes.

title: A Way to Bail Out New York
description: New York State is facing a $9 billion budget deficit in the coming fiscal year  a calamitous shortfall that is likely to get worse before it gets better. The states credit rating is at risk, and painful budget cuts are inevitable.

title: Poverty in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Reform Myths
description: Health reform is back from the dead. Many Democrats have realized that their electoral prospects will be better if they can point to a real accomplishment. Polling on reform  which was never as negative as portrayed  shows signs of improving. And Ive been really impressed by the passion and energy of this guy Barack Obama. Where was he last year?

title: Finally, Theyre Embarrassed
description: House Democrats are suddenly in a rush to ban corporate earmarks, those just-for-our-donors legislative favors that benefit everybody but the taxpayers. It is the right thing to do, but it is also a classic case of closing the barn door just in time for Election Day.

title: Driving by the Numbers
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Unemployment Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Haiti, Two Months Later
description: With every day that passes in the mud and rubble of Haiti, the failures of the relief effort are heartbreaking. There are four main strands to the campaign to make sure 1.2 million homeless people are sheltered and safe as the weather turns fierce. All are inadequate.

title: Should I Get the Prostate Cancer Test?
description: To the Editor:

title: Preserving Reasonable Gun Limits
description: After serious setbacks to sensible gun control, the top court in Massachusetts on Wednesday made it clear that the Second Amendment does not bar states from protecting children and others against the risk posed by unsecured guns in the home.

title: The Armenian Genocide
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about agreements by China and India to join an international pact to address climate change misstated the number of countries that have formally agreed to be covered by the accord. So far 107 have agreed, not nearly 200.

title: Defendant Changes Identity and Walks Out of Court
description: It was supposed to be a routine court appearance: Freddie Thompson, who had been arrested in a string of robberies, was to appear before a judge on Staten Island to be arraigned on Wednesday. But before the hearing, he claimed to be another defendant  one facing a considerably less serious charge of marijuana possession  and managed to fool the authorities, the police said.

title: After Rainout, Yankees Hoping to Play Friday
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees can deal with one rainout. But two? If their game Friday against Washington in Viera is postponed  thunderstorms are in the forecast  the Yankees will have to overhaul their pitching plans.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 10 about disquiet in some developing Asian nations over Chinas swift economic growth misstated the trade balance between China and the 10 Southeast Asian countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, from January through September 2009. The most widely cited figures show the Asean countries together ran either a trade surplus of several hundred million dollars with China or a deficit of up to $2.33 billion; the Asean countries over all did not have a deficit of $74 billion with China. (Different factors can be used in calculating the amount of trade, leading to the wide range.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message shortly after the article was published; this correction was delayed for research.

title: Tomlinson to Visit Jets, Who Have an Opening
description: When the Jets released Thomas Jones after he declined to take a pay cut, the prevailing analysis was that he might have slowed at the end of last season. But the Jets lost an experienced veteran who was a tremendous presence in the locker room. Might they be trying to lure someone like Jones to replace him?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the release of Qing Hong Wu, an immigrant detainee who was pardoned by Gov. David A. Paterson for offenses committed when Mr. Wu was 15, misstated the timing of his reunion with his mother and other relatives. It was 11 p.m. Tuesday, not Wednesday.

title: Some Binghamton Faculty Push for Exit From Division I
description: In the first formal protest of the scandal surrounding the Binghamton University mens basketball team, a group of faculty members is collecting signatures to recommend that the university leave Division I athletics.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Thursday about Robert M. Scarano Jr., a Brooklyn architect who was barred from filing construction documents with New York City, misstated part of the address of one of his buildings, in East New York, Brooklyn. It is 145 Snediker Avenue, not Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about increasing demand for lithium, an element that is crucial for the lithium-ion batteries favored for hybrid and electric cars, referred incorrectly to another battery used in such vehicles. That battery is known as nickel-metal hydride, not hybrid.

title: Mortification Man
description: THIS month Ben Stiller, who has appeared in nine movies that have earned more than $100 million in domestic grosses, served as honorary chairman of Film Independents Spirit Awards. The incongruity was not lost on Mr. Stiller, who had some fun with it onstage. I think it says volumes about the organizers of this event that even though Ive been in over 350 studio movies during the last five years, he said, the Spirit Awards were bold enough to say, You, Ben Stiller, epitomize our core values.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Bank of Americas decision to stop charging overdraft fees on debit purchases misstated Citibanks overdraft policies. Citibank has never charged overdraft fees on one-time debt purchases or A.T.M. transactions; it did not recently modify its policy to appease critics.

title: FAME School Gets Extension of Its Charter Despite Audit
description: A Fremont charter school that was the subject of a highly critical state audit will be allowed to operate, despite a continuing review by the Alameda County district attorneys office.

title: After Millions Spent, a New Food Destination Beckons, but Drivers Beware
description: Harriet Street in San Franciscos South of Market district is easy to miss. With its ragged flats, modern lofts, a car repair shop and a community center, it is one of those gray mixed-use blocks typical in this part of town.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about ESPNs choice of the Internet arm of Major League Baseball to handle its streaming video described incorrectly the technology used by Move Networks, which had been providing that service. It uses its own technology, which is compatible with several online video formats; it does not use Microsofts Silverlight format.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about the Egyptian cleric Mohamed Sayed Tantawi misstated the name of a book about Egypt in which Mr. Tantawi is discussed and also misspelled the given name of its author. The book is No God but God: Egypt and the Triumph of Islam, not There Is No God but God, and the author is Geneive Abdo, not Genevieve Abdo.

title: Hotels Make Sure These Souvenirs Dont Spoil
description: All sorts of items are left in hotel rooms. But at places like the Hotel Vitale in San Francisco, housekeepers are likely to find half-eaten wheels of cheese, fresh flowers and, depending on the season, artichokes, grapes or heirloom tomatoes.

title: Johnny Alf, a Father of Bossa Nova, Dies at 80
description: Johnny Alf, an influential Brazilian songwriter, pianist and singer whose delicately swinging music was a precursor to the bossa nova, died on March 4 in Santo Andr, Brazil, just outside So Paulo. He was 80 and lived in So Paulo.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Willie Davis, who succeeded Duke Snider as the Los Angeles Dodgers center fielder, erroneously credited Davis with franchise records in several categories. His career totals in those categories were records for the Los Angeles Dodgers only, not for the Dodger franchise, which was originally located in Brooklyn. Zack Wheat, not Davis, holds the franchise records for hits, at-bats, triples and total bases; Pee Wee Reese holds the record for runs; Duke Snider holds the record for extra-base hits. The obituary also incorrectly described one of Daviss World Series accomplishments. He stole three bases in one game in the 1965 Series, not three bases in one inning.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,005 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Doris Haddock Is Dead at 100; Walked for Campaign Finance Reform
description: Doris Haddock was almost 89, stoop-shouldered but stiff-spined, when she laced up her sneakers, threw on a backpack and began trekking 3,200 miles across the country on New Years Day in 1999  a one-woman march for campaign finance reform that started in Pasadena, Calif., and ended on the steps of the Capitol in Washington 14 months later.

title: Will Auburn Get a New Coach for Its New Building?
description: NASHVILLE  Auburn is building a new arena on its campus, but Coach Jeff Lebo might not have a chance to coach there. Lebo finished his sixth season at Auburn here Thursday night with a 78-69 loss to Florida in the first round of the Southeastern Conference tournament.

title: The Girls Who Kicked in Rocks Door
description: THE most striking thing about The Runaways, a new film about the trailblazing bad-girl rock band from the 1970s that spawned Joan Jett, is how authentic it feels. The clubs are properly scuzzy. The dialogue is properly raunchy. The actors can properly sing. The hair is fried and feathered, the skin spotty from weeks of running on little but potato chips and estrogen. From the adrenaline rush of performing to the monotony of rehearsal, its a vivid snapshot of life on the road for ambitious teenagers who are constantly told that rock n roll is the sport of men. (And thats their own manager talking.)

title: Notre Dame and Harangody Catch the Bus
description: While he sat out with a knee injury for nearly three weeks, Luke Harangody watched the transformation of his team and his reputation.

title: An Independent Woman, Nobly Suffering in Silents
description: SHE was perhaps the biggest female star of the silent era. Her dark, depthless eyes gazed from the covers of influential fan magazines, projecting a nobly suppressed pain and longing; in the stories inside, she  or her ghost writers  advised the emerging independent American women of the 1920s on matters of fashion and home dcor. She regularly topped the popularity polls, outdistancing rivals like Gloria Swanson, Pola Negri and Mary Pickford. She and her husband, the producer Joseph Schenck, founded their own production company in 1917; by 1924, The New York Times was identifying her as the highest salaried screen actress.

title: From Denmark, Hacker Punk and Hit in Tow
description: AMERICAN cinemas debt to its foreign-born directors is like sea travels debt to the starry night. From Fritz Lang to Ang Lee, filmmakers have come fleeing political oppression, limited opportunity, even bad taste. Far fewer have been driven from their native shores by overwhelming success and the feeling that they had nowhere to go but down.

title: Kansas State Coasts in the Big 12
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. Kansas State Coach Frank Martin accomplished a new feat with his teams 83-64 romp of Oklahoma State on Thursday night in the Big 12 tournament quarterfinals.

title: Gardner Bunting Way Into Girardis Good Graces
description: TAMPA, Fla.  First, the bad news about Brett Gardners spring. He is batting .143 in 14 at-bats. Now, the good news. Both of his hits came on bunt singles, which is exactly what Joe Girardi and the Yankees want to see more of.

title: Budget Woes Have Schools Expecting the Worst
description: In Elgin on Monday night, it is not going to matter who is bluffing, winning or losing in the heated debate under way in Springfield over the states gargantuan budget hole.

title: Toyotas Ills Wont Help G.M.s Sales, Lutz Says
description: WARREN, Mich.  Robert A. Lutz, a General Motors vice chairman, spent much of his nine years at the company trying to persuade people that its vehicles were just as good as Toyotas.

title: White Women Influencing Shift to Minority-Majority Nation
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Enforcement of Landscape Ordinance Comes at a Bad Time
description: For the owner of a Humboldt Park auto repair shop who lost 25 percent of his sales this year, paying $50,000 to fix up the parking lot of his business to comply with the citys landscaping ordinance would be difficult.

title: Word of the Day | unprecedented
description: unprecedented \n-pre-s-den-td\ adjective

title: What to Do With an Empty Storefront? A Makeshift Art Gallery
description: As the recession takes its toll on retailing, empty storefront windows throughout the Chicago area are turning into pop-up art galleries, the result of an opportune alignment of interests among artists, landlords and chambers of commerce.

title: State Regulators Shut Down a City Bank, LibertyPointe
description: State banking regulators on Thursday evening shut down the troubled LibertyPointe Bank, whose chairman, Shaya Boymelgreen, built more than 2,400 apartments in New York City in the last decade. The failure was the 27th in the nation this year but the first in the city in more than a decade, regulators said.

title: A Familiar Face at the Garden
description: The stars came out at the Big East tournament on Thursday.

title: West Virginia Pulls One Out
description: Cincinnati Coach Mick Cronins order was concise. Find Butler! Find Butler! Find Butler! he yelled each time West Virginia had the ball, referring to the Mountaineers star senior, DaSean Butler.

title: Administration Said to Settle on No. 2 at Fed
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has settled on Janet L. Yellen, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, to serve as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, a senior administration official said on Thursday night.

title: In Fridays Bay Area Report: Whos Minding the School?
description: FAME and the Limits of Charter School Oversight | The Alameda County Board of Education, in a 5-to-0 vote Tuesday, extended the charter of Fremonts FAME Public Charter School for another five years, even as the countys senior district attorney said the financial practices that prompted a highly critical state audit were still under review. The situation underscores the paradox of charter-school oversight: The same freedoms that allow these schools to serve as laboratories of new educational practices also give them unusual financial and managerial latitude. The Alameda County school superintendent praised the school  its formal name is Families of Alameda for Multi-Cultural/Multi-Lingual Education  for providing a needed service for students. Nonetheless, the superintendent, Sheila Jordan, said in interviews that FAMEs executive director, Maram Alaiwat, might have engaged in inappropriate activities involving school finances. In addition, three of four members of the schools board last year, including Ms. Alaiwat, had relatives who either worked there or did business with the school. Experts disagreed on whether, and when, the public school systems that authorize charters could intervene.

title: A Neighorhoods Revival Smothered By Parking Rules
description: With the sun beaming down, the lunch crowd sipped caf au lait and noshed on les tartines de pain and quiches maison. Festive rouge umbrellas dotted the courtyard as the waiter talked about the slow-cooked specialty of the house, boeuf bourguignon.

title: Hooping It Up
description: WHO is the Academy Award-winning actress who was instantly hooked when she tried Hula-Hooping for fitness?

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Sharks Set Record With 3rd Straight Rally
description: Ten games on Thursday, including a record-breaking performance from the West-leading San Jose Sharks. Home teams listed first:

title: A Comeback for Mortgage Bonds?
description: The market for private-label mortgage bonds in the United States might be ready for revival, Breakingviews says.

title: Administration Said to Settle on No. 2 at Fed
description: The Obama administration has settled on Janet L. Yellen, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, to serve as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, a senior administration official said on Thursday night.

title: News Quiz | March 12, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Democrats Push Ahead on Finance Bill
description: Democrats said on Thursday that they would go it alone in an effort to pass an overhaul of financial regulation, increasing the likelihood of a bitter partisan showdown, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: Report Shows How, Collapsing, Lehman Hid Woes
description: It is the Wall Street equivalent of a coroners report  a 2,200-page document that lays out, in new and startling detail, how Lehman Brothers used accounting sleight of hand to conceal the bad investments that led to its undoing.

title: Poll Shows Vast Majority for More Wall St. Regulation
description: An overwhelming majority of Americans wants Wall Street subjected to tougher regulation in the aftermath of the bank bailout and the bonus scandals that have rocked the U.S. financial sector, according to a Harris poll released on Thursday, Reuters reported.

title: A Bidding War for Terra?  Yara Demurs
description: Yara International, the Norwegian fertilizer company, says it will not increase its offer to acquire American competitor Terra Industries after Terras board chose to favor a higher bid from CF Industries, Reuters reported.

title: InfoGroups Founder Resigns From Its Board
description: The founder of database provider InfoGroup has resigned from the companys board, The Associated Press reported.

title: What Are Your Favorite Keepsakes From Childhood?
description: In her column this week, Michelle Slatalla writes about throwing away her daughters childhood mementos in preparation for a move across the country. What artifacts from your childhood  keepsakes from the person you used to be  do you still have? Why?

title: Abu Dhabis Raine Deal Deepens Hollywood Ties
description: An Abu Dhabi state investment fund said on Thursday that it was buying a piece of a young investment house focused on sports and show business, raising the Gulf city states bet on the entertainment industry.

title: Playbor
description: The increasingly blurred distinction between online play and labor.

title: Farallon Plans Shake-Up, Report Says
description: Farallon Capital Management, the hedge fund with $21 billion in assets under management, is reorganizing its house, with plans to refocus the lions share of its investing on credit wagers and risk arbitrage, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Japanese Coast Guard Arrests Anti-Whaling Skipper
description: TOKYO  The Japanese Coast Guard on Friday arrested an anti-whaling activist from New Zealand who had boarded a whaling ship in the southern Antarctic last month.

title: Board Extends Deadline for Everglades Deal
description: Facing legal challenges and growing deficits, South Florida water officials on Thursday gave themselves six more months to finance a controversial $536 million purchase of land from United States Sugar for the Everglades.

title: Pink Floyd Wins Court Battle With EMI Over Downloads
description: The British rock band Pink Floyd won its court battle with EMI on Thursday, with a ruling that prevents the record company from selling single downloads on the Internet from the groups concept albums, Reuters reported.

title: Respect Your Elders
description: Infantilism may be a fashion perennial, but if the blogger Ari Seth Cohen had his druthers, every season would be a senior moment. As the founder and editor of Advanced Style, a Sartorialist for the superannuated set, he chronicles the stylish and often eccentric get-ups of a crowd thats largely ignored by the fashion system. My eyes have always been drawn to older people, said Cohen, 28. And from a style point of view, I find them more interesting because they are of an age where they dont have to impress anyone and can wear what they want. In addition to shots of stylish senior citizens on the street, the site features tributes to timeless style icons, including Iris Apfel and Fleur Cowles. The hardest part of showing that true chic does not dim with age? Trying to explain what a blog is.

title: Twin Suicide Attacks Hit Military Sites in Pakistan
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Two suicide bombings in quick succession rocked an army convoy patrolling a busy market in a heavily guarded, army-controlled area on Friday, the second deadly assault on Lahore in less than a week.

title: South by Southwest: A Virtual Playground in Austin
description: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

title: Leaving Green: Execs Quit Clean Energy Firms
description: Go to Item from Todd Woody at Green Inc.:

title: Sensata Closes Higher After Years Biggest I.P.O.
description: Shares in Sensata Technologies Holding closed up slightly Thursday after raising $568.8 million in the biggest initial public offering so far this year, The Associated Press reported.

title: Chicago Exchange Files for $300 Million I.P.O.
description: The last major private exchange left in the U.S., the Chicago Board Options Exchange, filed for an initial public offering of up to $300 million Thursday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Reading and Rating the Roethlisberger Coverage
description: It has been a week since Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger was accused of sexual assault. Heres a sampling of the news media coverage:

title: At Paris Fair, Antiques and Ham (Yes, Ham)
description: The modern incarnation of the oldest antiques fair in France, held at the picturesque le des Impressionnistes (Impressionists Island) on the outskirts of Paris, is turning 40 this year. The National Antiques, Bric-a-Brac and Ham Fair, as it is known, starts today and runs through March 21, bringing together an eclectic mix of paintings, furniture, secondhand goods and regional food items.

title: Cinemark Raises $660 Million for 3-D
description: Cinemark Holdings, a movie theater operator, said late Wednesday that it would boost the number of 3-D screens it operates to between 1,100 to 1,300 by the end of the year, up from 400, after a major round of financing came through, The Associated Press reported.

title: Norris: Dealing With Fraud by Denial
description: Years after Charles Ponzi was imprisoned for a fraud that cost victims millions of dollars in 1920, the state of Massachusetts determined it had recovered all the assets it could, and began to distribute them to victims, who stood to receive less than 30 cents for each dollar they invested.

title: Simon Feels No Pressure to Raise Bid for Rival
description: The chief executive of the Simon Property Group said on Thursday a revised plan by the management of General Growth Properties to emerge from bankruptcy would not put pressure on his company to sweeten its own $10 billion offer, Reuters reported.

title: The Battle Over the Exit Sign
description: Todays idea: American exit signs are out of sync with the rest of the world because they rely on text, not imagery, and are red, not green. That may be gradually changing, an article says.

title: To Control Health Care Costs, Trace the Spending
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Popcast: Broken Bells, SXSW Preview and More
description: This week: A review of the new CD by Broken Bells, a collaboration between Dangermouse and James Mercer of the Shins; a concept album from outlaw country artist Shooter Jennings & Hierophant; plus a preview of the bands and parties at this years SXSW festival.

title: Stray Questions for: Jo Nesbo
description: Jo Nesbo is a Norwegian novelist; the latest thriller in his Harry Hole series, The Devils Star, has just been published in the United States.

title: The Origins of Lehmans Repo 105
description: As The New York Timess article on the court-appointed examiners report on Lehman Brothers makes clear, perhaps the most newsworthy element to pop out of the inquests 2,200 pages is an accounting trick known as Repo 105.

title: Tip of the Week: Baseball Schedules
description: With Opening Day less than a month away, fans of Major League Baseball can start planning those trips to the ballpark. To download a copy of your favorite teams schedule and load it right into your Outlook, iCal or Google Calendar, visit www.mysportscal.com/mlb.html.

title: Why Did the Teddy Bears Cross the Road?
description: Animation | Answer: to visit their Dada on the other side:

title: Goldmans Flamand Said to Start His Own Fund
description: Pierre-Henri Flamand, the London-based head of the largest internal hedge fund of Goldman Sachs, is leaving the investment bank to launch his own hedge fund firm, according to press reports.
