title: Former Boston Provident C.F.O. Pleads Guilty to Fraud
description: A former trader and chief financial officer of the hedge fund Boston Provident has pleaded guilty to charges to two schemes to defraud the firm, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Whitmans Funds May Present Conflicts, Report Says
description: Meg Whitman, the billionaire Republican gubernatorial candidate in California, has invested her personal fortune in private equity and hedge funds, as well as in oil, gas, health care and other concerns seeking to influence state policy, The Los Angeles Times reported, citing an economic-interest disclosure filed by the former eBay chief.

title: Brian Pitman, Former Lloyds Chief, Dies at 78
description: Brian Pitman, the banker who led Lloyds TSB to become one of Europes largest financial groups, has died at age 78, the British Bankers Association said Friday. Mr. Pitman died Thursday following a heart attack earlier in the week, The Associated Press reported.

title: Turning Off the Phone After 20 Years on Call
description: Nancy E. Ryan, a longtime top deputy in the Manhattan district attorneys office best known for leading the reinvestigation of the Central Park jogger case, will end her tenure in the office Friday.

title: Sampler: Attorney General to Investigate San Francisco Crime Lab, and More Californians Apply to Out-of-State Universities
description: Its Official: Gavin Newsom to Seek No. 2 Seat | We are announcing formally today that I am jumping into the race for lieutenant governor, San Franciscos mayor, Gavin Newsom, told KCBS on Friday morning. This confirmed a report in The San Francisco Examiner that the mayor, after dropping from the race to become governor, planned to officially declare for office. I really feel deeply that my responsibilities at home can be met in the context of this race, Mayor Newsom told KCBS, referring to his wife and baby daughter. In the June 8 primary, Mr. Newsom, 42, will face Janice Hahn, a Los Angeles councilwoman. On Thursday, Mr. Newsom reported his latest campaign contributions, which included $6,500 apiece from Mark and Susie Buell, who have been major contributors to Democratic candidates for national office, and $4,950 from Peter Ragone, his former press secretary. [KCBS, The San Francisco Examiner]

title: Video: Bye Bye Bagger
New York Catches Up to London as Finance Center
description: From DealBook colleague Julia Werdigier:

title: K.K.R. Files for an N.Y.S.E. Listing
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Friday officially sought a listing on the New York Stock Exchange, the final step in its years-long effort to become a publicly traded private equity firm.

title: Yellen To DC
description: Good news: Janet Yellen will be the Feds new #2. Shes open-minded, a good counterweight to the inflation hawks who think that any day now well be partying like its 1979. Shes also a distinguished scholar, with much of her work in New Keynesian macro.

title: Made in the U.S.A.: Efficiency Materials
description: While solar and wind manufacturers struggle to fend off Chinese competition, energy efficiency equipment seems to have no such problem.

title: Lighten Up
description: The Takeaway Yes, were painfully aware of how important it is to maintain structure in our lives, especially these days. But what about the boredom that comes with it? Fortunately, loosening up doesnt mean you have to look like a slob; this springs tailoring is refreshingly, well, untailored.

title: From New York to Texas, a Seinfeld Odyssey
description: When Otis Raring began searching for a new car, he had some specific needs. He and his wife, Trisha, have two young children and are expecting a third. A minivan seemed like a good choice, but Mrs. Raring wanted one that looked a bit sportier than average. They settled on a Honda Odyssey  the Touring edition. Preferably in black, which she thought made the Odyssey look even less minivanlike.

title: Solar Power Up Your iPhone
description: Amended 3/19/2010 to correct the name of the company

title: Debt And Transfiguration
description: Carmen Reinhart has a new working paper out (subs. req.) thats an extremely valuable resource: more than 100 pages of charts showing the history of debt and banking crises in many countries; sample above. Ill be keeping this one ready to hand for years to come.

title: The Early Word: Unlikely Pairing?
description: Health care and student loans  together again for the first time?

title: U.S. Retail Sales Rose in February
description: February was hardly an ideal month for retailers: snowstorms blanketed many parts of the country, and car dealerships faced an uproar over safety concerns.

title: Why I Prefer External Chargers
description: From todays mailbag:

title: New Federal Subsidies for Drug Purchases
description: For about one million low-income Medicare recipients, some good news: its just gotten easier to qualify for the federal Extra Help program, which provides more generous prescription drug benefits.

title: Cooking Tips: Oats, Garlic and Tomatoes
description: Several readers had questions for the Consults blogs about healthful cooking methods. Here Harold McGee, The Curious Cook columnist for The New York Times and the author of On Food & Cooking: The Science & Lore of the Kitchen, offers expert advice on storing oats and tomatoes and the best way to crush garlic.

title: The Marriage Ref Curbs Everyones Enthusiasm
description: There hasnt been much of a honeymoon period for The Marriage Ref, the new NBC comedy-reality series created by Jerry Seinfeld. Though the show, in which celebrities meddle in real-life marital fights, has gotten good notice from some critics (in The New York Times Alessandra Stanley wrote it was funny, despite a cheesy game show premise) and scored healthy ratings, other critics and online commenters would prefer to serve it with divorce papers. But at least the show still has the support of its celebrity panelists, right? Right?

title: Q. and A.: Espresso at Home
description: Ken Nye of Ninth Street Espresso responds again to more readers questions about coffee and coffee bars.

title: Tough Enough
description: Josh Brolin, in the next few months, you will be starring in three movies: in Jonah Hex, out June 18, you play a western antihero with a tragic past; in Wall Street 2: Money Never Sleeps, you are a Gordon Gekko-like villain; and in Woody Allens new movie, You Will Meet a Tall, Dark Stranger, you play . . .

title: Mandelas Ex-Wife Says Interview Didnt Happen
description: JOHANNESBURG  Winnie Mandikizela-Mandela on Friday issued a statement denying that she had given an interview to Nadira Naipaul, the wife of the writer V. S. Naipaul, in which she was quoted making harsh statements about her former husband, Nelson Mandela, the first democratically elected president of South Africa.

title: Israelis Block Palestinians From Holy Site
description: Updated | 10:24 a.m. On Friday, Israeli police prevented young Palestinian men from praying at a holy site in Jerusalem, and Israels military imposed a temporary ban on travel by Palestinians from the West Bank into Israel. The security crackdown comes after recent clashes following Friday prayers in Jerusalem.

title: Speed Read for Friday, March 12
description: Here are some highlights from Fridays edition of The New York Times:

title: The NBC Sale (the 30 Rock Version)
description: A little over three months since Comcast agreed to buy a majority stake in NBC Universal from General Electric, the deal finally got the 30 Rock treatment it was bound to get.

title: Letters: Armrest Battles
description: To the Editor: Regarding, Excuse Me, Is This Seat Taken? (Feb. 28): My daughter, who arrived recently on a Delta flight from Las Vegas, told us that she had spent most of the flight in the aisle because of an oversize seatmate. No one offered to find her another seat since the plane was full, nor did anyone offer to refund her fare or cut the price to half since she did not have more than half a seat.

title: Cost of Stadium Reveals Tensions in South Africa
description: NELSPRUIT, South Africa  Come June, soccers World Cup will be hosted by South Africa. Though only 4 of the 64 games are to be played here in Nelspruit, a $137 million stadium was built for the occasion. The arenas 18 supporting pylons reach skyward in the shape of orange giraffes. At nightfall, their eyeballs blink with flashes of bewitching light.

title: Leno Engineers a Rerun for the Turbine Car
description: BURBANK, Calif.

title: Turnabout: Questions for a Show Host
description: From an interview with Jay Leno:

title: Lots of Web Traffic in Such a Tiny Town
description: THE images on the Flickr slide show serve up a comforting slice of mid-20th-century Americana: the local bankers slinky 56 Lincoln Premiere reflects the summer sun outside the hardware store on Main Street. A spit-shined Divco truck delivers fresh milk from the Borden dairy. On the towns outskirts, where rents are low and hot-rodders use the county road as a dragstrip, a custom 55 Ford gets a set of loud pipes at a one-bay speed shop.

title: Less Motor, More Grip, and It All Makes Sense
description: ONCE upon a time  say, around 2004  the 340-horsepower S4 was Audis 8-cylinder answer to the mighty BMW M3. It seemed pretty crazy at the time, a little car like an A4 running around with a V-8 under the hood.

title: Pell Grants Would Rise Under Congressional Deal
description: Federal education officials had warned this week that the millions of college students who rely on Pell grants might see those scholarships cut by 60 percent if Congress failed to act on President Obamas student loan overhaul. Through a tentative deal reached among Congressional Democrats on Thursday, that disastrous situation no longer appears on the near horizon, my colleagues David M. Herszhenorn and Tamar Lewin report in todays Times.

title: In Limbo, Until a Startling Reunion
description: Mike Quashie, 79, once the strapping Limbo King, came to a Bronx nursing home weak and lonely, until he ran into a nurse there who used to dance in his troupe in the 1960s.

title: School Safety Agent Charged in Drunken-Driving Death
description: Updated, 1:23 p.m. | An off-duty school safety agent was charged with aggravated vehicular homicide and driving while intoxicated after a one-car accident in the Bronx on Thursday night that killed a passenger.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Manga Making News
description: New titles sit atop each of our lists this week. The hardcover edition of Kick-Ass, by Mark Millar and John Romita Jr., collects the eight-issue mini-series that chronicles what would happen, in the real world, if a teenager tried to fight crime. The answer, at least at the beginning, is excruciating injuries. The over-the-top adventure, published by Marvel Entertainments Icon imprint, uses adult language and depicts intense and bloody violence; the highly anticipated film version opens in theaters on April 16.

title: Health Costs of California Air Pollution
description: Filthy air in California cost federal, state and private health insurers $193 million in hospital costs, according to a RAND Corporation study released last week.

title: Movin On Up
description: When flat-panel televisions first hit the market, the joke was that while they were so thin that you could actually hang them on the wall, virtually nobody ever did.

title: High Altitude
description: The middle-aged woman lay in the intensive-care unit, observing the tumult around her. At least I wont die alone, she said to herself. She squeezed her husbands hand. Though she hadnt felt well for more than a month, it was not until earlier that day that it occurred to her that she might be dying.

title: Start Your Engines
description: Despite their 29-year age gap, Clark Gable and Steve McQueen had a few things in common  rural Midwestern upbringings, motorcycle obsessions, nicknames beginning with King of  but their cars werent one of them. Gable had a rather big, lavish 1935 Duesenberg JN with a boxy nose and external side pipes, while McQueens favored status symbol was a sleek 1957 Jaguar XK-SS Roadster, above. Blame World War II: After the war, these little sporty European cars seemed much more appealing, says Ronald Labaco, co-curator of The Allure of the Automobile, which opens March 21 at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. In addition to putting visitors within spitting distance of both stars former rides,the show traces the cultural and political influences on car design from the 30s to the mid-60s  considered the golden age of auto craftsmanship. Among the Mercedes-Benzes and Porsches that seemed ahead of their time, there are cars from long-defunct companies like Duesenberg and Tucker, which, despite their glamour, found themselves drowning under the excesses of bygone eras. Sound familiar?

title: Excerpt: 'Sons of Tucson'
description: The Fox sitcom follows a loser who is hired by three boys to pretend he is their father.

title: Terra Finally Accepts CF Industries Takeover Bid
description: After more than a year, the Forever War is over. CF Industries Holdings will acquire Terra Industries, a rival fertilizer maker, for $4.7 billion, the two companies said in a joint statement on Friday, ending one of the longest takeover battles in recent memory.

title: Checking Up on the New Years Check List
description: Lets check in on my New Years To-Do List:

title: Friday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: 1904: Bouillabaisse
description: This appeared in a Times article called Bouillabaisse and Chowders: An Eel-Soup Digression  Who Now Get the Best Vegetables and Fruits  A Dear Fish Market. The author is unknown. You may halve the amount of oil if you find it alarming.

title: 2010: Olive-Oil-Poached Cod With Saffron-Blood-Orange Nage
description: By Sang Yoon, the chef at Fathers Office in Los Angeles

title: Diners Journals Bake Sale Bake Off
description: While some school systems are banning junk food, New York seems to be encouraging it, by banning home-baked goods at bake sales in favor of Doritos and other wholesome items. As Kim Severson reports in Diners Journal, a protest against this inanity is scheduled at City Hall next week.

title: Deciding on Care for Elderly Parents in Declining Health
description: TWO years ago my father, then 83, became very ill. Until then, he had been living alone in a pleasant one-bedroom apartment on the Hudson River, an hours drive from my home in Brooklyn.

title: Video: Ten Minutes With Rajiv Shah
description: Dr. Rajiv Shah had been on the job for less than a week overseeing the United States Agency for International Development when a devastating earthquake struck Haiti.

title: What You Did for Love (of Theater)
description: In Fridays article about tough-to-obtain to theatrical events, including to so-called snob hits that become the talk of the cocktail party circuit, some theatergoers and directors recalled the lengths that people would go: Paying $1,000 for an online scalped ticket, sleeping out all night in Central Park. What show was the toughest ticket to snag for you, and what lengths did you go to get it?

title: Yassky Nominated to Head Taxi Agency
description: Updated, 2:25 p.m. | Former City Councilman David Yassky has been nominated by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to head the citys Taxi and Limousine Commission, the mayor announced Friday morning on his weekly radio program.

title: San Francisco Mayor Is Seeking States No. 2 Job
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Declaring his candidacy for a job whose very power he questioned, Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco said Friday that he was running for lieutenant governor of California.

title: Recipe Redux: Bouillabaisse, 1904
description: In 1988, The New York Times ran the Le Bernardin chef Gilbert Le Cozes famed recipe for bouillabaisse, with its 13 steps and 25 ingredients. And that was pretty much the symbolic end for the Marseillaise fish stew: over the years, chefs made it so complicated that no one actually wanted to eat it, let alone source all the fish and cook it.

title: Nissan NV: Automakers First Commercial Vehicles for U.S.
description: Nissan introduced a line of commercial work vans this week in high-roof and standard configurations. At first glance, the Nissan NV cargo vans, with their high-roof design, look like competition for Fords Transit Connect. Theyre not. The Transit Connect, which Ford began selling in the United States last year, is an economical light-duty van with 135 cubic-feet of cargo space. The Nissan NV1500, NV2500 and NV 3500 are medium and heavy-duty commercial vehicles that can handle more than twice the payload of a Transit Connect.

title: Weekend Competition: Park Your Car in Harvard Yard
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share the words and phrases that signal social background or class.

title: A Dispute on Using the Koran as a Path to Jesus
description: January was an ugly month in Malaysia. At least 10 churches were firebombed or vandalized, as was a Sikh temple. Severed boars heads  particularly offensive to Muslims, who are not supposed to eat pork  were found on the grounds of two mosques. The cause of this inter-religious strife was a court battle over whether non-Muslims may use the Arabic word Allah to refer to God.

title: Climate Change Threatens Migratory Birds, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  Changes in the global climate are imposing additional stress on hundreds of species of migratory birds in the United States that are already threatened by other environmental factors, according to a new Interior Department report.

title: Not Much Hope in New Gaming Sales Report
description: The latest video game sales figures offer all kinds of hell for the gaming industry: overall sales for February were down 15 percent from the same month last year, according to a report from NPD, a market research firm. About $1.26 billion in gaming hardware, software and accessories were sold, down from $1.48 billion in February 2009.

title: A Bathroom by a Stairwell
description: Q.

title: The Darkness of Otto Dix
description: Images from an exhibition of the artists work at the Neue Galerie.

title: Adding Partners to Co-op Shares
description: Q.

title: Tee Time
description: In the introduction to Ripped: T-Shirts From the Underground (Universe, $30), the no-wave diva Lydia Lunch traces the history of the T-shirt from its silver screen progenitors (Marlon Brando and James Dean) to a London clothing shop called Sex. It was there, circa 1975, that the promoter Malcolm McLaren and the fashion visionary Vivienne Westwood transformed four juvenile delinquents who had been caught on numerous occasions pilfering overpriced T-shirts into the Sex Pistols.Thirty-five years on, the D.I.Y. iconography of underground music endures, so much so that the 200 vintage tees in Ripped  from acts like Gary Numan, Dead Kennedys, Talking Heads and Plasmatics  look oddly familiar, no doubt thanks to what the book calls the onset of ironic consumerism.

title: Carpeting Rules Laid Out in Bylaws
description: Q.

description: Tearing a page from Michael Huynhs playbook, Jean-Georges Vongerichten has opened his second restaurant in three weeks, ABC Kitchen.

description: Todays Patient Money column explores the costs and options for caring for an aging family member.

title: Of Tax Interest for Tenants
description: Q.

title: A Vision of Governors I. as a Tanglewood Moments Away
description: This summer theatergoers will walk a mile, more or less, for a 12-hour performance on Governors Island, the 172-acre former military base off Lower Manhattan. What about music lovers?

title: Calling All Bake Sale Bakers
description: The Dining section of the Times wants your recipes. Its a response to the way parents are responding to the ban that New York Citys Department of Education has put on home-baked goods in schools, which is in turn a response (or overreaction, depending on your point of view) to the fact that you cant determine the nutrition content of Grandmas Toll House cookie recipe.

title: Coping With the Stigma of Tourettes
description: Dr. Robert A. King and Dr. James F. Leckman of the Yale School of Medicine recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about Tourettes syndrome. Here, Dr. Leckman and Dr. King respond to readers asking about living with the strange movements, tics and vocalizations of Tourettes, which can be socially difficult and, in some cases, lifelong.

title: Making Sense of the Census: Ideas for Classes Across the Curriculum
description: Note: The article we are using for this lesson comes from the March 15, 2010 issue of The New York Times Upfront. Upfront is a news magazine for teens published by Scholastic in partnership with The New York Times.

title: Death Pursues Her
description: Chang-rae Lee is fond of words like accrete and accrue, words that try to name the slow, almost imperceptible processes by which experience acquires weight, mass and, if youre lucky, meaning. Life, gathering, reads one full sentence in his ferocious and lyrical new novel, The Surrendered, and you couldnt ask for a better two-word description of what good fiction aspires to. This novel, his fourth, gathers life greedily, hungrily, but with a certain stealth: Lee doesnt bolt it all down at once, as the refugee children in his story do. The Surrendered, his largest, most ambitious book, is about the horrors of war and the sorrows of survival, yet its manner is quiet, watchful, expectant, as if everyone, including Lee himself, were waiting to see what might accrue.

title: Vonn Wins 3rd Straight World Cup
description: For the first time in a long time, Lindsey Vonn felt no pressure in the race start house. There was no momentous import to the outcome of Fridays World Cup super-G in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany. She did not have to race at all. The last competitor in the field, Vonn was told just before she was to ski that she had already won her third successive World Cup overall championship.

title: Police Identify Woman Killed by Subway Train
description: Updated, 2:57 p.m. | The 48-year-old woman who was crushed to death by a subway train on Manhattans Upper East Side on Thursday afternoon has been identified as Rose M. Mankos, the authorities said. She was a lawyer who had previously worked for the state.

title: Stimulus Makes People Bad at Math
description: How many people make math errors on their individual income tax returns each year?

title: The Woman Who Influenced the Influential Choreographers
description: Trisha Brown, Yvonne Rainer, Meredith Monk and many others studied under her. Merce Cunningham worked with her too. Its hard to overestimate the influence the dancer and choreographer Anna Halprin has had on New York dance, even though shehas made a point of staying far from the city.

title: Off the Wall
description: Blank space is a blank canvas for Ji Lee. Im interested in exploring areas like the back of business cards and ceilings  why are they left empty? says the renegade graphic designer, who is currently working as creative director of Googles branding and marketing unit, the Creative Lab. To fill the void above, Lee creates miniature upside-down interiors that he calls parallel worlds, placing them on domestic ceilings (on commission) and corporate offices (on the sly). Decorating ceilings was a common art form that somehow got lost through the reductionism of modernism, he says. The Lilliputian lairs are meticulously furnished with objects that tell a story about the room and its imaginary owner. One installation shows the apartment of a rocker, complete with a guitar, amp, microphone and Jimi Hendrix poster. Another, installed in a home with two small children, features a petit bourgeois living room with velvet sofas and tiny glass cabinets filled with strange furry objects made of cat hair. The kids love it, Lee says. Thats the greatest compliment. Go to pleaseenjoy.com.

title: The Fiction of Memory
description: Consider the state of literature at the moment. Consider the rise of the memoir, the incidences of contrived and fabricated memoirs, the rash of imputations of plagiarism in novels, the overall ill health of the mainstream novel. Consider, too, culture outside of literature: reality TV, the many shades and variations of documentary film, the rise of the curator, the rise of the D.J., sampling, appropriation, the carry-over of collage from modernism into postmodernism. Now consider that all these elements might somehow be connected, might represent different aspects of some giant whatsit that will eventually constitute the cultural face of our time in the eyes of the future. That is what David Shields proposes in Reality Hunger: A Manifesto. He further argues that what all those things have in common is that they express or fulfill a need for reality, a need that is not being met by the old and crumbling models of literature.

title: Pushing for Hella to Count, in a Big Way
description: In an age when reality television appearances, leaked sex tapes and tickling can be routes to celebrity, a student at University of California, Davis, has entered the spotlight through a scientific endeavor.

title: Complaint Box | Theyre Stealing My Sky
description: We left Manhattan for Brooklyn in 1997. Even then, before it was the rage, it felt like a destination. We kept track of all the things the neighborhoods of Brooklyn had over the metropolis of Manhattan: actual diversity, affordable restaurants, more parking and less pretension. But the best thing, no doubt, every time, was the sky. Brooklyn had sky. Not a sliver of something gauzy above narrow, vertical avenues, but a big sky, clear and vivid, like they brag about in Montana (or maybe New Jersey). The kind of sky with horizons and sunsets and stars. A movie-screen ceiling under which anything could happen.

title: Abuse Scandal in Germany Edges Closer to Pope
description: BERLIN  A widening child sexual abuse inquiry in Europe has landed at the doorstep of Pope Benedict XVI, as a senior church official acknowledged Friday that a German archdiocese made serious mistakes in handling an abuse case while the pope served as its archbishop.

title: Butchers and Saints
description: The villains of history seem relatively easy to understand; however awful their deeds, their motives remain recognizable. But the good guys, those their contemporaries saw as heroes or saints, often puzzle and appall. They did the cruelest things for the loftiest of motives; they sang hymns as they waded through blood. Nowhere, perhaps, is this contradiction more apparent than in the history of the Crusades. When the victorious knights of the First Crusade finally stood in Jerusalem, on July 15, 1099, they were, in the words of the chronicler William of Tyre, dripping with blood from head to foot. They had massacred the populace. But in the same breath, William praised the pious devotion . . . with which the pilgrims drew near to the holy places, the exultation of heart and happiness of spirit with which they kissed the memorials of the Lords sojourn on earth.

title: The Identity Thief
description: I live in a town house complex, across from a woman who has become a friend. She copies me constantly  exact replicas of my clothing, furniture, bath towels, artwork, even cookbooks. Its driving me nuts!

title: Rain Forces Mets to Revamp Pitching Schedule
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets game against the Twins in Fort Myers on Friday was canceled. The Mets drove two hours and 45 minutes across the state through heavy downpours, and within 20 minutes of their arrival, the game was called off. So they got back on the buses for the nearly three-hour return.

title: Surfing's New Wave of Aerialists
description: Competitive surfing is undergoing a major change as a new breed of young surfers introduce amazing aerial tricks that have only been recognized in recent years.

title: A Day of Surprises at the First Practice Sessions in Bahrain
description: BAHRAIN  The feeling around the paddock at the Bahrain Grand Prix is that this is a weekend of a thousand stories in Formula One. Where to start? I cant decide, so I wont. Instead, here are the main points as they occur to me, a roundup of interesting facts and events, in no particular order:

title: Surfings Next Generation Takes to the Air
description: Last spring, on a green wave in the Mentawais, a chain of islands off the west coast of Indonesia, Jordy Smith performed perhaps the most sublime aerial in the history of surfing, a back flip while spinning one and a half times. Video of the flip, known as a rodeo clown, went viral when Yahoo posted it in June.

title: Wright Arrest Is the Newest Heat Quandary
description: The Miami Heat appear to be playing a bizarre game of Survivor as the season winds down. The roster keeps fluctuating, with players being bounced from the lineup for reasons having nothing to do with injuries.

description: The New York Times's Frugal Traveler, Matt Gross, travels with his one-year-old daughter to San Francisco and shows us his special techniques and gears for a baby traveler.

title: Woods Keeps Golf Guessing
description: Who knew a few months ago that Tiger Woods rumors would become such a cottage industry?

title: India and Russia Build Ties With Pacts
description: NEW DELHI  India and Russia signed a series of agreements on nuclear, space and military issues on Friday, after a visit by Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

title: India Luxury Vacations on Sale
description: If your ideal trip to India has you staying in an opulent room in a mystical setting and being treated like royalty, a set of packages just introduced by the elegant Oberoi Hotels & Resorts is worth a look.

title: City Moves to End a Bronx Olfactory Nightmare
description: Barbara White no longer dries her clothes outside. Lucretia Jones has stopped holding backyard barbecues. Tanya Fields keeps her windows shut tight year-round.

title: Even High-Score Borrowers at Risk of Mortgage Default
description: A HIGH credit score wont necessarily insulate borrowers from the home-foreclosure crisis, according to a new study from FICO, which creates the credit-scoring formula used by most lenders.

title: China Issues Another Warning to Google on Enforced Censorship of the Internet
description: BEIJING  One of Chinas top Internet regulators warned bluntly on Friday that any move by Google to stop censoring its Chinese search engine would be irresponsible and would draw a response from Beijing.

title: Not a Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearts in Darkness
description: On finishing Marti Leimbachs Man From Saigon, a novel about an American reporter, Susan Gifford, sent to Vietnam by a womens interest magazine in 1967, my first thought was that in 2010, at a time when the United States finds itself engaged in a complex, controversial multifront conflict that has now gone on for nearly a decade, Vietnam has at last become a safe artistic choice.

title: Editors Choice
description: ANGELOLOGY,  by Danielle Trussoni (Viking, $27.95.) With a smitten art historian at her side, the young nun who is the heroine of Trussonis rousing first novel is drawn into an ancient struggle against the Nephilim, hybrid offspring of humans and heavenly beings.

title: Paperback Row
description: DONT CRY: Stories,  by Mary Gaitskill (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.) Gaitskill commands her readers attention as few fiction writers can, Kathryn Harrison said in the Book Review, and the reasons are on display here in her third collection of stories. Gaitskills characters may go in for shopping, gossip or romance, but their experience is always surprising and sometimes cruel. In their dreams as well as in reality, those characters, especially the women, are often hurt and humiliated. Harrison praised the fierce artistry of Gaitskills writing and its introduction of the sublime into the sordid.

title: Whos to Blame at Lehman?
description: I am still working my way through the huge bankruptcy examiners report on Lehman Brothers, and may have more to say later.

title: Erin Go 3-D: Celebrate St. Patricks Day With U2
description: What do you think of when you think of St. Patricks Day? The Irish? Absolutely. Music? Almost certainly. Bowling? Um, maybe. A motion-picture technique that uses stereoscopic photography to create the illusion of increased depth? Huh?

title: Plastic Logic Delays Its Que Tablet
description: Plastic Logic, the 10-year-old spin-out from Cambridge University, said on Friday that it was delaying its $800 professional document- and book-reading device, the Que, until this summer. At the Consumer Electronics Show, the company said it would start selling the large, thin reader in April.

title: Your Dot: A Bison Encounter
description: Dale R. McIntyre of Bartlesville, Okla., a frequent contributor, sent in the following description of a bison encounter as a comment on my piece exploring a plan to rebuild wild bison populations in the West. I thought it was worth highlighting as an example of a powerful personal interaction with the planets other inhabitants and would love to use this Your Dot post as an invitation to others to describe experiences theyve had that have changed how they think or behave in relation to the wider environment.

title: Ex-Lehman C.F.O. Criticizes Repo 105
description: With much of Wall Streets attention focused on Lehman Brotherss use of an unusual accounting practice to temporarily lighten its balance sheet, a former chief financial officer of the firm told Bloomberg Television on Friday that the maneuvers were unacceptable.

description: To the Editor:

title: Single Parent (for a Week) in San Francisco
description: For a week in January, my daughter, Sasha, then 13 months old, and I visited San Francisco  alone, without her mother. We went to museums, ate burritos and generally had a lovely time, all detailed in this weekends Travel section cover story, Frugal San Francisco. It was exhausting, yes, and Sasha may not remember anything specific from it, but Im glad we had the opportunity to embark on the adventure.

title: Saint Lloris, Savior of Les Bleus
description: The lasting image from Frances anemic, controversial, but ultimately successful campaign to qualify for the 2010 World Cup will be the un-penalized handball by Thierry Henry that helped Les Bleus slip by Ireland in a two-match playoff last November.

title: Traffic Fatalities Drop to Record Low
description: The number of people who died last year in motor vehicle accidents in the United States dropped to a record low in 2009, the Transportation Department announced Thursday. The death count, estimated to be 33,963, was 8.9 percent lower than in 2008.

According to The New York Post, Tigers hired former President Bushs press secretary, Ari Fleischer to help with his PR campaign. Is that the guy you want in charge of your approval rating? Id hire Clintons guy. Thats the one with some experience in that particular area.

description: MY mother, Bea, had always been a bit of a drama queen, so her behavior at the end  the gasping and flailing and crying out incessantly  didnt surprise me. I remained brutally aloof; I felt prepared.

title: Pakistan Army Digs In on Turf of the Taliban
description: MAKEEN, Pakistan  From a forward base in the bare brown foothills of the soaring mountains of South Waziristan, Pakistani soldiers fired artillery at insurgents sheltering in scrub across the valley. Smoke blotted the sky as the soldiers set ablaze houses once used by the Taliban to hide caches of heavy weapons.

title: Brazilian Airlines to Post Legroom Ratings
description: Brazilian airlines will soon be required to inform travelers how much legroom to expect on their flights. The countrys National Civil Aviation Agency has developed a five-tiered ranking system that takes effect in March 2011.

title: Ousted at Variety, Critic Heads to New York Film Festival
description: Todd McCarthy, the veteran film reviewer for Variety who was let go from that position on Monday, will not be idle for very long. On Friday the Film Society of Lincoln Center said Mr. McCarthy had joined the selection committee of the New York Film Festival.

description: The "Community" star will appear in a Comedy Central stand-up special.

title: Book Review Podcast: Jim Frederick and Luc Sante
description: This week, Jim Frederick, the author of Black Hearts, discusses an Iraqi tragedy; Luc Sante explains David Shieldss mind-bending manifesto, Reality Hunger; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Texas Conservatives Win Curriculum Change
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  After three days of turbulent meetings, the Texas Board of Education on Friday approved a social studies curriculum that will put a conservative stamp on history and economics textbooks, stressing the superiority of American capitalism, questioning the Founding Fathers commitment to a purely secular government and presenting Republican political philosophies in a more positive light.

description: Just how overburdened are the nations immigration courts? A powerful new online tool lets anyone crunch government data to check the backlog of pending cases by court, state and nationality.

description: NASHVILLE  Just before the start of the Kentucky-Alabama quarterfinal in the Southeastern Conference mens basketball tournament, the public-address announcer said, Welcome to Bridgestone Arena in Nashville, Tennessee.

title: A Lawman, Polite and Ready to Shoot
description: THERE are a few ways to discern that Raylan Givens, the character at the center of the FX series Justified is an Elmore Leonard creation. Although he is a deputy United States marshal in a very contemporary milieu, he wears a big old cowboy hat, and his pistol, which he carries in a side holster, comes out only when he gets down to business. Regardless of the circumstance, he doesnt spend a lot of time waving it around, but when it does reveal itself in a flash, the bodies tend to fall around him. Oh, and one other thing: As played by Timothy Olyphant, the steely gaze of a lawman with mortal tendencies is replaced with a courtly manner and a twinkle of mirth in his eye. In fact just about everybody in Justified displays very good manners while doing some very ill-mannered things.

Living in Old Hill, Conn.
description: Old Hill, a well-to-do enclave of Westport,  is as unequivocally aged as its name indicates. But the landscape feature that most obviously asserts itself is water: ponds like Nashs and Cypress, and other pools too small to be named.

title: Now Online | T Mens Fashion Spring 2010
description: Spring has nearly sprung, and here at T we have a glide in our stride. And its not just the prospect of good weather. In an increasingly homogenous world, its nice to be reminded that there are creative types out there who are prepared to take the heat. This weekends issue of T celebrates eccentric energy, wherever we can find it. Biomorphic lamps, off-the-wall rooms, rodent bow ties, lo-fi rock-band T-shirts, untailored tailoring and John Lennons nonconformist cool all get their moment in the fashion sun. Elsewhere, we enter the artist Daniel Arshams imaginarium, where sleight of hand is the house specialty; Jonathan Wingfield interviews the musician Matthew Herbert, who can make you dance to the sound of slaughtered chickens; and Armand Limnander meets Pierre-Alexis Dumas, Hermss artistic director, who is making the venerable French house more relevant than ever. To cap it off, we profile two actors burning up the screen: our cover star Josh Brolin and the French actor and recently announced Chanel poster boy Gaspard Ulliel, who channels the seasons Nouvelle Vague look in a shoot by Paolo Roversi. No wonder were hot to trot.

title: Student Loan Bill Opposed by Group Packed With Ex-Clinton Aides
description: This wasteful spending was first identified by President Bill Clinton, Representative George Miller, Democrat of California and chairman of the Education and Labor Committee, declared on Thursday at a news conference in the Capitol.

title: Pelosi Predicts a Health Bill Within 10 Days
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker Nancy Pelosi mobilized House Democrats on Friday for a final effort to pass an overhaul of health care, predicting approval in the next 10 days with help from President Obama, who delayed a trip abroad to try to win over wavering Democrats.

title: Book Review Podcast: Jim Frederick and Luc Sante
description: This week Jim Frederick, the author of Black Hearts, discusses an Iraqi tragedy; Luc Sante explains David Shieldss mind-bending manifesto, Reality Hunger; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Formula One Begins 60th Season High on Promise
description: Giuseppe Farina won the first Formula One championship in 1960 in a supercharged Alfa Romeo. He won three out of the seven championship races in North America and Europe. This year, the championship will have 19 races on six continents, including five in Asia and two in the Middle East, where the season will begin and end.

title: TV vs. Off Broadway: TV Wins, Slightly Delaying The Kid
description: The new Off Broadway musical The Kid has moved its first preview performance and opening night by a few nights to accommodate the television shooting schedule of its star, Christopher Sieber, who will be filming a pilot, the producers announced on Friday.

title: Off the Menu: Bomboloni
description: The stars at David Ruggerios latest entry on Columbus Avenue, opening on March 17, are Italian filled doughnuts called bomboloni.

title: Newsom Bids for Lt. Gov. Post in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Declaring his candidacy for a job whose very power he questioned, Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco said that he was running for lieutenant governor of California on Friday.

title: Do I Deserve a Refund?
description: Ive received a number of e-mail messages today related to my column on Buyer Denial and the fraud at CMKM Diamonds. Several do not approve of my writing. One begins:

title: Israelis and Palestinians Clash in Jerusalem
description: Despite the efforts of Israeli police, Palestinians surged into an alley in Jerusalem heading to the complex known to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary and to Jews as the Temple Mount. The first picture is by Jim Hollander, who also shoots the Running of the Bulls in Pamplona.

title: Over the Moon About the Water
description: IF the dates on the small signs affixed to facades are to be believed, Old Hill, a well-to-do enclave of Westport, is as unequivocally aged as its name indicates.

description: The Swiss banking giant UBS has stepped up its lobbying to pass a treaty with the United States that would resolve a dispute over tax-evading clients, amid signs that the deal is running into trouble in Parliament.

description: The First Crusade and the Capture of Jerusalem, 1095-99

title: Nelsons Support May Depend on Student Loan Changes
description: Of all the grief Democrats have taken in the health care debate, perhaps no aspect of it caused greater heartburn than the extra Medicaid money for Nebraska that Senate Democratic leaders inserted into their bill in hopes of locking in the support of Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska.

description: ARE the outlines of an ambitious swing-set-and-slide area lifting sales at One Brooklyn Bridge Park?

title: Excerpt: 'Justified'
description: The FX series is based on a character created by Elmore Leonard.

description: Delphi and Norman Harrington have lived for nearly three decades in a mazy apartment on West 90th Street off Broadway.

title: Last of 5 Parts: Answers on Historically Black Colleges and Universities
description: More than 100 American institutions are classified by the government as historically black colleges and universities through a formal program intended to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.

title: Part Library, Part Salon, Part Cast Party
description: AS far as is known, Tennessee Williams never set foot in the mazy apartment on West 90th Street off Broadway where Delphi and Norman Harrington have lived for nearly three decades. Yet when you wander through these rooms, you feel that Williams, whose works are drenched in memories, might have felt deeply at home here.

title: A Warm Winter for Rentals
description: IN the depths of winter, there were big flurries of rental activity at several of New Jerseys more luxurious apartment buildings  which came as a bit of a surprise even to the brokers and developers.

title: Now Cruising | Singalong at Sea
description: Nodding to his band, Lyle Lovett turns to face the audience and begins to pick out a rippling guitar riff. Cheers erupt as soon as the crowd recognizes the song. It is, after all, the one theyve been waiting to sing along with:

title: Appeals Court Upholds Access Rules for Cable TV
description: WASHINGTON  A United States appeals court on Friday upheld a Federal Communications Commission rule that forbids cable companies that also own programming channels from refusing to allow competitors to also offer those channels.

title: Killer Heels
description: Soldiers of fashion wont be marching in combat boots come spring. Five-inch heels are more like it, and these by Gianvito Rossi for Altuzarra have just enough ammo to stop enemy combatants dead in their tracks. $1,130. At Barneys New York; (212) 826-8900.

title: The Going Gets Tougher
description: THOUGH the economy appears to be stabilizing, the market for financing remains tight.

title: Does the Gifted Label Get In the Way of Developing Real Potential?
description: This weeks question comes from guest blogger David Shenk. Mr. Shenk is the author of The Genius in All of Us: Why Everything Youve Been Told About Genetics, Talent and IQ Is Wrong.

title: In Connecticut, a Moratorium on Affordable Housing
description: THE Town of Oxford has declared an 11-month moratorium on applications for affordable-housing developments, a strategy that the lawyer for a developer poised to build such housing calls plainly illegal.

title: When the Kids Come Out to Play
description: IN the world of the contemporary symphony orchestra, youth is not so much a stage of life as it is a battle cry. Youth orchestras! Young conductors! At times it begins to seem that nothing else counts.

title: Wow Factor Optional
description: WITH a price limit of $350,000 for an apartment of at least two bedrooms, Reba Frankel knew she would get few, if any, extras.

title: Jeffrey Katz
description: Mr. Katz, 62, is the chief executive and principal owner of Sherwood Equities Inc., which has developed and manages more than $3 billion in commercial real estate.

title: Travel Deals: World Expo in Shanghai
description: With an expected attendance of 70 million, this years World Expo in Shanghai  which runs May 1 to Oct. 31  will most likely mean higher hotel rates in the city. But good deals can still be found.

title: The Last-Minute Ad Campaigns
description: In an 11th-hour barrage, both sides in the health care debate are pouring millions of dollars into last-minute television commercials aimed at influencing the votes of members of Congress.

title: In Defense of the Singing Hamlet
description: AMBROISE THOMASS Hamlet returns to the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night, no doubt to be furiously denounced once again as a travesty of Shakespeares tragedy. Composed in 1868 as a five-act French grand opera with all the trimmings and not seen at the Met since 1897, Hamlet invariably seems to get bad press, especially in Anglo-Saxon countries. Pretentious and wearisome, summed up a critic for The New York Times after the Met premiere in 1884. Weve always known that something was rotten in the state of Denmark, snarled the British critic Edward Seckerson after seeing a revival of the opera at Covent Garden in 2003, and now we know what it is. Perhaps the most devastating brushoff came from the French music historian E. Destranges, who, on the occasion of the composers centenary in 1911, sniffed that Thomas had done little more than deposit music on Shakespeare.

title: Three Officers Face Reprimands Over 2008 Battle
description: WASHINGTON  A military investigation into the 2008 battle of Wanat, one of the deadliest days of the war for American forces in Afghanistan, is expected to result in serious letters of reprimand for three officers who were in command positions, Pentagon and military officials said Friday.

title: The Importance of the Name on the Door
description: A rose by any other name, sure, but has it really taken this long to get a woman partners name added to that of a top law firm?

title: Au Revoir, Paris Fashion Week
description: The Paris shows ended on a high, thanks in no small part to Karl Lagerfeld, who imported a massive iceberg from Scandinavia as the backdrop for his furry Chanel coats and boots, iceberg-blue Angora knits and tweedy suits  not to mention full arctic bear ensembles. Even the bags played on the theme  some of them, in fact, turned out to be hot water bottles. Chanel is one of the few labels that have weathered the crisis well and, thankfully, Lagerfeld uses its considerable resources to constantly up the ante when it comes to creating a visual spectacle.

title: Seton Park, the Bronx, 11:30 A.M.
Now Where Was I ...
description: THE Governors Ball at the ballroom adjoining the Kodak Theatre in Los Angeles  the obligatory first stop for Oscar winners and nominees before they hit the real party scene  was in full swing last Sunday night. Jeff Bridges was deep in conversation with his Crazy Heart co-star Maggie Gyllenhaal, who held, reverentially, his best-actor Oscar. Meryl Streep laughed with Alec Baldwin (over Steve Martins joke about her Hitler memorabilia, perhaps?), while Lauren Bacall (Betty!) held court looking every inch the Lifetime Achievement Award winner she is.

title: Carl E. Taylor, Leader in Global Health Care, Is Dead at 93
description: Dr. Carl E. Taylor, an architect of a 134-nation agreement that established primary health care as a universal right, died on Feb. 4 in Baltimore. He was 93.

title: Rose Meets Immovable Howard (Again), Hurts Wrist (Again)
description: The first time Bulls guard Derrick Rose drove the lane and was bowled over by Magic center Dwight Howard, he chalked it up to just another basketball play.

title: Farewell to All That
description: Its true: the Bagger has hung up her red carpet heels, metaphorically at least. (In reality we still have about five pairs under our desk.) Our first Oscar season was a long and eventful one; all the changes, hoopla and brouhaha made it tough to prepare for and all the more interesting to cover, not that we had anything to compare it to.

title: We Made It Ourselves | Organic Smokehouse Butter
description: In her column, We Made It Ourselves, Charlotte Druckman writes about restaurants and small businesses with interesting house-made treats.

title: The Week Ahead| Mar. 14  Mar. 20
description: Art

title: Americas Top Phone Makers? Not Who You Think
description: Who makes the most popular phones in America? Its not Apple, BlackBerry, Palm or Nokia. According to the market research firm Strategy Analytics, Samsung was the the leader in the United States with 26 percent of the total cellphone market in 2009.

title: 12-Hour Play: Scalpers Are Salivating
description: The last ticket available to the general public was sold at about 3:30 p.m. on Friday for The Demons, a 12-hour production in Italian of the Dostoevsky novel that the acclaimed German director Peter Stein will mount this July  in two performances only  at a remote warehouse on Governors Island.

title: Limbo King Finds a New Home and an Old, Familiar Face
description: In 1959, a strapping young Trinidadian named Mike Quashie emigrated to New York and helped ignite the limbo dance craze. He became a darling of the citys society set, a fixture of the downtown fashion scene and a sort of left-field rock icon.

title: Obama to Push Health Care Overhaul in Ohio
description: President Obama will travel to Strongsville, Ohio, on Monday afternoon, continuing his push for sweeping health care legislation, the White House announced on Friday.

title: Honey, Dont Bother Mommy. Im Too Busy Building My Brand.
description: BALTIMORE

title: Textbooks a Texas Dentist Could Love
description: My colleague James McKinley reports that the Texas Board of Education voted on Friday to approve a social studies curriculum that will put a conservative stamp on history and economics textbooks, stressing the role of Christianity in American history and presenting Republican political philosophies in a more positive light.

title: Now Screening | Damaged Goods
description: If youve never ever imagined porcelain figurines acting out a trenchant class struggle, thats probably because youre not the British ceramics prankster Barnaby Barford. Porcelain can be something of a dainty medium, but Barfords playful, often perverse arrangements  he cuts and remakes mass-market and antique porcelain figurines  turn Hallmark Store staples into subversive art objects. In Barfords adorable first film, Damaged Goods (screened above), a maidenly tchotchke takes a tumble. Will she go the way of Humpty Dumpty? Nine new works from the film are on view at the David Gill Galleries on Loughborough Street in London through March 20.

title: When Will Location-Based Coupons Take Off?
description: How many times have you heard the prediction that one day, businesses like coffee shops will send us coupons on our mobile phones when we walk by?

title: Protecting Your Privacy on Google Buzz
description: Last month, we published a primer on Google Buzz, the new social networking service that stirred controversy by building the network automatically from a Gmail users e-mail and instant-message correspondents.

title: A Father-Daughter Vacation
description: In the Travel section of the Times, the Frugal Traveler writes about a low-budget, bonding trip to San Francisco with his one-year-old daughter, Sasha.

title: Republicans Named to Deficit Panel
description: Congresss Republican leaders on Friday named six lawmakers to the bipartisan debt-reduction commission that President Obama created, and the anti-tax hardliners among them suggest that there are high hurdles to forging agreement by December on proposals to arrest the unsustainable growth of projected deficits.

title: What Do Banks Really Want?
description: THESE days, lenders have a long list of what they want to see in a building and in a prospective borrower. One potential obstacle is your credit history. Here are a few things you should know about your credit:

title: City Critic | Eagles in Inwood?
description: Ariel Kaminer goes on a birding expedition in New York.

title: Has This Taboo Lost Its Power?
description: IS America having a hand-wringing moment over what President George W. Bush called the one-fingered victory salute?

title: Paris Recap | Food for Thought
description: The long week of fashion shows in Paris was like a series of well-cooked dishes: some in a minimal, nouvelle style, deliciously light and ethereal on the palate; some quite heavy in the French bourgeois tradition, with a lot of foie gras and sweetbreads; others more exotic, vegetable masalas with many ethnic spices, from Morocco to India. But by the end of the week, as an international audience of sheiks, oligarchs, Thai queens and Dutch conquistadors finished their supper, it did not add up to a sumptuous meal. Lets just say there was no new taste sensation.

title: Loan Modification Program Starts to Get Some Traction
description: After a dismal start, the Obama administrations antiforeclosure efforts are finally gaining some traction. But the results are still paltry when set against the vast sea of homeowners in trouble.

title: Video Shows Aftermath of Lahore Bombings
description: As my colleague Waqar Gillani reported from Lahore on Friday, at least 43 people were killed and more than 100 wounded in a series of bombings.

title: IPhone Battery Replacement: DIY or Not?
description: Amended 3/12/2010 to clarify shipping procedures

title: The Morning Skate: The Head Check Proposal and the Cooke Ruling
description: As expected since November, when the N.H.L. general managers last met and some hawks changed their hard line on penalizing checks to the head, that group proposed this week that blindside hits be subject to a minor or major penalty and supplementary discipline. In November we called it a half-step in the right direction.

title: Gillibrand Still Trying to Win Over Bloomberg
description: WASHINGTON  He gripes about her in private conversations with his aides and her colleagues on Capitol Hill. He has yet to take up her invitation to sit down for dinner. And his political team is constantly shopping for potential candidates to oust her.

title: How Important Is It for a Red Wine to Be a Dark Color?
description: One of the most striking characteristics of the 2007 red Burgundies is their relatively pale color. The particular conditions of this vintage compelled most winemakers to treat their grapes with a light hand. That is, they did not try to extract lots of color and tannin from the grapes. As a result, you can easily hold a glass of a 2007, even a grand cru wine, and see your fingers through the wine on the other side of the glass.

title: WaMu Settles With JPMorgan and F.D.I.C.
description: Washington Mutual said Friday that it had reached a settlement with JPMorgan Chase and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that is expected to bring Washington Mutual about $6 billion and help resolve its bankruptcy. But the deal could leave WaMus shareholders out in the cold, Reuters reports.

title: Record Number of Tax Filers Owed No Taxes in 2008
description: A record number of federal individual income tax filers in 2008 owed no taxes, according to an analysis of Internal Revenue Service data conducted by the Tax Foundation.

title: Cabbies Gouge Passengers Out of Millions, Agency Finds
description: Updated, 6:00 p.m. | For the past two years, thousands of taxi drivers overcharged passengers a total of more than $8 million by switching the meter to double the rate, the Taxi and Limousine Commission said Friday afternoon.

title: Arrest Stokes Concerns About Radicalized Muslims
description: WASHINGTON  The arrest in Yemen of a New Jersey man accused of joining Al Qaeda is the latest in an alarming string of cases involving radicalized American Muslims, a trend some experts link to the duration of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Hurdles Still Remain for Ground Zero Settlement
description: Sgt. Dawn Sorrento says she looks on the years since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks as a blur of doctors visits, ambushes by illnesses she had never heard of and growing resentment toward the city that challenged her injury claims.

title: Fish That You Can Invite to a Dinner Party
description: FISH can be finicky dinner-party fare, especially for the distracted cook. Step away for a moment to sip your cocktail and your fillets might go from pearly to parched.

title: A Look at the Examiner in the Lehman Case
description: The unsealing of a high-profile report on the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers was the culmination of an exhaustive  and lucrative  12 months of detective work by Anton R. Valukas and his Chicago law firm, Jenner & Block, The Wall Street Journal reports.

title: A Move to Protect Low-Wage Workers
description: A coalition of labor unions, immigrant advocacy groups and nonprofit organizations in New York announced their support on Friday for newly introduced legislation that would greatly increase penalties against employers that violate minimum-wage and overtime laws.Supporters of the bill, known as the Wage Theft Prevention and Responsible Employer Protection Act, say that wage violations are all too common because penalties for such violations are small under New York law and because employers that break the law face little likelihood of getting caught.

title: A Tale of Two Obamas
description: Saturday Night Live hasnt pulled many punches in its treatment of President Obama but Fred Armisens impersonation of him has lacked, for some,  the definitive quality that SNL predecessors like Darrell Hammond and Dana Carvey brought to their presidential impressions. (You can check out nearly all of the SNL presidents in a recent Funny or Die video.)

title: Lehman Kept Billions Off Books
description: The bank used accounting gimmicks to hide its weakness in the months before its bankruptcy, a report says.

title: Is Capitalism a Bad Word?
description: The Texas Board of Education voted today to make changes sought by conservatives in the states social sciences curriculum, James C. McKinley reports.

title: UBS Pushes Swiss Officials for an End to Tax Dispute
description: The Swiss banking giant UBS has stepped up its lobbying to pass a treaty with the United States that would resolve a dispute over tax-evading clients, amid signs that the deal is running into trouble in Parliament, The New York Timess Matthew Saltmarsh reports.

title: Sunday Preview
description: Are the hills too steep for a stroller? Are the costs too high for a dad on a budget? Matt Gross, who writes the Frugal Traveler column, finds high style on a low budget in San Francisco  this time with his 1-year-old daughter as his travel companion.

title: Chic in Review | Commander Karl
description: Binns, TomNow designing handbags and T-shirts. Love!

title: Construction on a Small Scale
description: Once I had the name, Elgin Park, that inspired how I would grow and photograph the town, said Michael Paul Smith, referring to the community that is the subject of his wildly popular Flickr portfolio.

title: Scorecard | Louis Vuitton Wins!
description: Through four international fashion weeks  we may as well just call it Fashion Month  Scorecard has been your trusty guide, reading nearly every review from English-language critics. 240 shows and 1,802 reviews later, were happy to report that Marc Jacobs, who took us all over the rainbow with his pared-down dissertation on Americana for his namesake line back in New York, has landed. So what are they wearing in the merry old land of  Paris? Well, for one, these Dorothys arent your de rigueur twiggy teens but real women (O.K., Victorias Secret Angels and 90s supermodels) with breasts and hips. Thats a casting tactic Miuccia Prada seems quickly to have forgotten.

title: Oklahoma State Ready to Move Forward
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. Oklahoma States Travis Ford was hardly concerned that his team may not bounce back in the N.C.A.A. tournament after its 83-64 blowout loss to No. 9 Kansas State on Thursday night in the Big 12 tournament quarterfinals.

title: Suspect Held in Attack on Woman in Bar Bathroom
description: Updated, 6:18 p.m. | The police have taken a suspect into custody in the vicious attack of a 29-year-old pediatric nurse from Connecticut who was beaten and left bleeding and unconscious in a bathroom stall at a Midtown Manhattan bar, the authorities said Friday evening.

title: Sony Adds Motion Control to the PS3
description: Sony unwrapped PlayStation Move this week at the Game Developers Conference 2010 in San Franciscio and says it will be available this year, most likely in the fall.

title: What Were Reading
Mommy Is Busy Blogging
description: Once upon a time mothers gathered over backyard fences and shared. Now they gather at places like Motherlode, over virtual cups of coffee, trading worries and secrets with friends they will probably never see.

title: In an All-Riley Show, Peace, From the Mouths of Babes
description: The Kronos Quartet is ensconced at Carnegie Hall for a Perspectives series that explores the expansive, stylistically borderless repertory for which this ensemble is known, with master classes and a program by student quartets along the way. The group made a down payment on this minifestival in November, when it performed Tan Duns Ghost Opera and the pageantlike Chinese Home during Carnegie Halls festival of Chinese music. But the series got under way in earnest on Thursday evening, with a program of Terry Rileys music at Zankel Hall.

title: Will New Financial Bill Satisfy Democratic Critics?
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, could face stiff opposition from some vocal members of his own party if his revised bill on financial regulation does not go far enough to curb the problem of banks that are too big to fail.

title: A Trip Through Time and Fashion
description: The denizens of Dear Emissary, ... might almost be characters in  by turns  a Jane Austen novel, a Fassbinder film or a punk music video. But almost doesnt count in art, and Walter Dundervills new dance-theater work, which opened on Wednesday night at the Chocolate Factory in Queens, largely and pleasurably escapes neat associations to float in its own strange in-between logic.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Files for Listing on Big Board
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Friday officially sought a listing on the New York Stock Exchange, the final step in its years of work to become a publicly traded private equity firm.

title: At the Guggenheim, the Art Walked Beside You, Asking Questions
description: A few Saturdays ago, a teenage visitor to the Guggenheim Museum, a girl in a black beret, slid open the door to the Aye Simon Reading Room and peered in at a group of people in animated conversation. Is there something going on in here? she said.

title: A Movable Feast Has Its Advantages
description: THE New Jersey Symphony Orchestra performs at seven locations throughout the state, rather than being tethered to a single performance space. That is a distinct advantage, in the eyes of Jacques Lacombe, the orchestras new music director.

title: A Chrysalis for Writers in an Old Train Stop
description: SLEEPY HOLLOW

title: Complex Colors in Simple Settings
description: Gilberto Gil promised a very simple concert at the Nokia Theater on Thurday night: just a trio with Mr. Gil and his son Bem Gil on guitars, with his longtime arranger Jaques Morelenbaum on cello.

title: Playing a Game of Whos the Adult Here?
description: One question has to be going through audiences minds during Kimberly Akimbo at the Schoolhouse Theater: How old is Ruth Reid?

title: Ousted Variety Critic Joins New York Festival
description: Todd McCarthy, the veteran film reviewer for Variety who was let go from that position on Monday, will not be idle for very long. On Friday the Film Society of Lincoln Center said Mr. McCarthy had joined the selection committee of the New York Film Festival. In a telephone interview, Mr. McCarthy said that in fact he had been offered the position by Richard Pea, the program director of the film society, before the Variety separation took place. That was all done, Mr. McCarthy said, and then Monday, this came down. On the selection committee Mr. McCarthy joins Mr. Pea, the film critics Melissa Anderson and Dennis Lim (who is also a contributor to The New York Times) and Scott Foundas, the film societys associate program director, who received some of his earliest review assignments at Variety from Mr. McCarthy. Mr. McCarthy said it was still possible he could contribute freelance work to Variety.

title: Of Suffragettes and Seamstresses
description: SOUTHAMPTON

title: Problems for New Orleans Art Show
description: Prospect, the New Orleans art biennial that began in 2008 (which included Mark Bradfords Mithra), winning critical praise and generating millions in tourist income for its hurricane-battered home, has become entangled in fund-raising and administrative problems that are jeopardizing its future, The Times-Picayune of New Orleans reported Thursday. The ambitious event, which installed the work of more than 80 artists at sites throughout New Orleans, ended up badly over budget after the bills came due in 2008, owing more than $1 million more than it had raised. Late last month, its founding director, Dan Cameron, announced that the next iteration of the event, Prospect.2, would be postponed until the fall of 2011 from this November because of fund-raising shortfalls. The Times-Picayune reported that several directors who joined the biennials board in 2009 to help shore up the finances and raise money for Prospect.2, stepped down in February because of differences with Mr. Cameron over how the project should be managed. Two people with knowledge of the board resignations, who spoke on condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the situation, confirmed the basic account of the problems to The New York Times. The Times-Picayune reported that the biennials executive director, Barbara Motley, a theater owner who was hired last year to oversee the administrative side of the event so that Mr. Cameron could focus on selecting artists and helping them to realize their works, had also resigned. Ms. Motley told the newspaper that she believed in organizational charts and management protocols while Mr. Cameron was much more organic in his approach to management.Earlier this month the Contemporary Arts Center in New Orleans announced that it would not renew Mr. Camerons contract as its part-time visual arts director. The centers director said it needed someone to work full-time to oversee its art exhibitions. Mr. Cameron did not respond to telephone and e-mail messages left for him today.

title: Making Music With Plastic
description: EAST ORANGE

title: Book Critics Circle Presents Awards
description: The British author Hilary Mantel was awarded the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction at the Tishman Auditorium of the New School on Thursday night for Wolf Hall, a historical novel about the court of Henry VIII that centered on the kings adviser Thomas Cromwell. Ms. Mantel had already won the 41st-annual Man Booker Prize last fall for the book. The board of the National Book Critics Circle, a nonprofit group of more than 600 professional book reviewers, cited Ms. Mantel for a work that was original in voice and ambitious in style. Richard Holmes won the nonfiction award for The Age of Wonder: How the Romantic Generation Discovered the Beauty and Terror of Science. Blake Bailey won the biography award for Cheever: A Life. Diana Athill won the autobiography award for Somewhere Towards the End: A Memoir. The poetry prize went to Rae Armantrout for Versed, and the criticism prize was awarded to Eula Biss for Notes From No Mans Land: American Essays.

title: Ray Charles Musical to Open in November
description: Unchain My Heart, the Ray Charles Musical is scheduled to begin preview performances on Broadway on Oct. 8 and open on Nov. 7, the lead producer, Stuart Benjamin, said on Thursday. It will be directed by Sheldon Epps with a book by Suzan-Lori Parks, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright of Topdog/Underdog. The musical, which had a developmental production at Pasadena Playhouse under the title Ray Charles Live! in 2007, imagines Charles, at his last live recording session, where stories from his life pour out and mix with his best-known hits that will be featured in the show. A spokeswoman for the production said that Unchain My Heart represents the first musical book-writing effort by Ms. Parks, whose plays also include Venus, In the Blood and her newest, The Book of Grace, which is now in preview performances at the Public Theater. Mr. Benjamin, who worked with Charles for years and produced the Academy Award-winning film Ray, said the production would run at a Shubert Organization theater to be announced later.

title: As Its Arms Makers Falter, Russia Buys Abroad
description: MOSCOW  Ask a Russian what the country makes well, and the answer, more often than not, will be the Kalashnikov rifle.

title: No to a God of Carnage Tour
description: The producers of God of Carnage, the winner of the 2009 Tony Award for best play and a critical and commercial hit on Broadway, have decided not to mount a national tour of the production, concerned that it would not run enough weeks to make a tour financially worthwhile. An executive involved in the production, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss tour plans, said the producers had been mulling a national tour for months and lined up some great actors for the possible production. (The executive declined to name them.) While some theaters nationally were considering a Carnage tour for a spot in their 2010-11 subscription seasons, the producers decided that not enough theaters in major cities would be available for a tour that would need to last at least 26 weeks to make the show profitable. Instead, once Carnage closes on Broadway  it opened on March 22, 2009, and is running indefinitely  the play will probably be licensed to regional theaters that can then mount their own productions.

title: CBS Wins, Despite Idol
description: CBS edged past Fox in the ratings on Thursday night even as an episode of Foxs American Idol that sent home four contestants garnered the largest audience in prime time. According to Nielsens estimates, 19.1 million viewers watched American Idol at 8 p.m., but CBSs back-to-back crime shows CSI (16 million) at 9 p.m. and The Mentalist (15.4 million) at 10 p.m. won their time slots; CBSs Survivor also earned a solid 12.1 million opposite Idol. Fox finished second with a lineup rounded out by Kitchen Nightmares (7.6 million). ABC was third with new episodes of Greys Anatomy (11 million) and Private Practice (7.9 million). NBC placed fourth as its new series The Marriage Ref (6 million) began to lose the luster on its wedding band.

title: In the Pew, Peace and Reflection
description: Linda I. Gibbs, 50, one of the citys six deputy mayors, has a portfolio that includes homelessness, child welfare, aging, hospitals and juvenile justice. On Sundays, she mostly sticks to more cheerful pursuits in Brooklyn. Ms. Gibbs lives in a loft in Brooklyn Heights with her husband of 17 years, Tom McMahon, 55, a government relations consultant, and their two children, Ryann, 16, and Leo, 14. JULIE BOSMAN

title: N.F.L. Study Raises Questions About FieldTurf
description: Some reason for concern for the new Giants and Jets stadium at the Meadowlands: the N.F.L.s Injury and Safety Panel has found that the rate of anterior cruciate ligament injuries is 88 percent higher in games played on FieldTurf than on grass. The new Meadowlands stadium will have FieldTurf, the cushy synthetic turf that players usually love.

title: Through Irish Eyes, America as Evildoer
description: It is a refreshing change to have Tom Molloy, an Irish artist, commenting on America at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum. While some of the art in the show is a little dated, dealing with events during the presidency of George W. Bush or earlier, it offers museumgoers an all too rare opportunity to see how an artist in another part of the world sees us. The result is not flattering.

title: Judging Obamas Pep Rally
description: Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr., who had a little first-hand knowledge of cantankerous Supreme Court justices, once wrote that stupidity often saves a man from going mad. If true, theres a great deal of sanity involved in the growing rift between President Obama and the conservatives on the high court. What began with a ruling in First Amendment case and escalated with a simple shake of Justice Samuel Alitos head

title: Dump Fannie and Freddie, G.O.P. Lawmaker Urges
description: Senate Democrats may have ended negotiations with their Republican counterparts over the financial regulatory bill, but House Republicans remain active and vocal in the debate.

title: The Skyline, Where Eagles Roam
description: New York is getting wild again. The cabaret laws are still strict, and the smoking ban is still in place. But in the last few weeks there have been sightings throughout the boroughs of creatures more commonly seen on the Discovery Channel.

title: Seeing the Forest Through the Dreamscape
description: A woman (Elizabeth DeMent) explodes onto the stage and across it. She punctuates this entry with three identical but peculiar jumps, each one ending pow! with one leg extended sideways and the torso lurching the opposite way. The combination of precision and looseness is arresting. Furious, wild and absolutely focused, the whole body is making a potent gesture. You immediately follow it as both psychological revelation and wildlife documentary.

title: Texas Is Looking for Answers
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The handshake between Texas Coach Rick Barnes and Baylor Coach Scott Drew was brisk Thursday night after the Bears won, 86-67, in the Big 12 quarterfinals to beat the Longhorns for a third time this season.

title: Disney Cost-Cutting Fells Zemeckis Company
description: Walt Disney Studios pulled the plug on Robert Zemeckiss motion-capture company on Friday, the latest in a string of cost-cutting moves. ImageMovers Digital, which is based near San Francisco and employs 450 people, will slowly wind down production over the next few months.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE VIRTUAL SENIOR CENTER is what you get when you partner a Microsoft cyberseniors program with the formerly sleepy Benjamin Rosenthal Senior Center on Kissena Boulevard in Queens. New cameras, monitors, microphones and Internet connections allow half a dozen homebound senior citizens to join in all the action in the center  mah-jongg, bingo, flirt sessions. And, using donated computers, they recently began logging on to the Web for the first time. It completely woke me up, said Adele Lerner, 103, who now talks to her daughter in California every morning by Skype and watches Sabbath services streaming live from a synagogue in Manhattan. Another participant, Milton Greidinger, 86, said the connection had enabled him to find old friends, chat with college girls and order groceries from FreshDirect. Its like going from comatose to back to life again, Mr. Greidinger said.

title: What Were Reading: A Cook, a Slacker, Some Bubbly and Fall Colors
description: Fridays roundup of interesting Web links, as selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times:

title: California Speaker Promises Change
description: LOS ANGELES  The new speaker of the California Assembly, John A. Prez, said he will cut the Assemblys budget by 15 percent, that a Republican lawmaker who wanted to be the Lt. Governor but failed to get confirmed by the Democratically-controlled legislature will have a better shot on his watch, and that being the first openly gay head of a state assembly is historic, but not dispositive concerning his approach to governing.

title: Two Bands Nurtured in a Garden State of Mind
