description: In the middle of The Monitor, the new album by Titus Andronicus, comes the desperate ramble Theme from Cheers. Its an unhappy song, with the earnest, wired singer Patrick Stickles detailing a love affair with an uncompromising mate: New Jersey.

title: Nine to Know: Nomar Garciaparra
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: His Next Act: Driving Out Apartheids Ghost
description: CAPE TOWN  Athol Fugard, the renowned South African playwright, paced at the edge of a plywood stage, rubbing his head and listening intensely to two actors run through their lines. Rehearsals for his new play, The Train Driver, had begun.

title: Student Loan Provisions May Ease Passage of Health Care Bill
description: Many House Democrats reacted enthusiastically on Friday to the word that a proposed overhaul of student loan programs would be included with major health care legislation in an expedited budget package to be offered in Congress.

title: 3-Family Home for Sale (One Family Included)
description: FOR sale: three-family home on a lovely and quiet block of Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Its charms include basement storage space, proximity to the subway and the Polish bakeries of Manhattan Avenue, and the makings of a quaint backyard.

title: Whos the Best Mommy of Them All?
description: We all know them. We avoid them on playgrounds. We shudder at their comments on parenting Web sites. They are the perfectly nice women who turn into mothers with strong opinions about how to raise children. Whether its VBAC vs. Caesarean, breast milk vs. formula, disposable vs. cloth or wraps vs. strollers, these moms know what they think and will stop at nothing to show you the light.

title: Carriage Horses Have Their Day at City Hall
description: Manhattans carriage horses may soon get an annual five-week vacation and safer working conditions, while their drivers receive a 47 percent pay raise  their first increase in more than 20 years.

title: A Bronx Island in Many Roles, Even as Itself
description: CITY ISLAND, a tiny and curious enclave in the Bronx, has a cinematic history that is long, if not quite storied: Parts of a 1912 rendition of Shakespeares  Richard III,  believed to be the oldest surviving complete American feature film, were shot there.

title: Clinton Rebukes Israel on Housing Announcement
description: WASHINGTON  In a tense, 43-minute phone call on Friday morning, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that Israels plan for new housing units for Jews in East Jerusalem sent a deeply negative signal about Israeli-American relations, and not just because it spoiled a visit by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: 3 Rulings Find No Link to Vaccines and Autism
description: In a further blow to the antivaccine movement, three judges ruled Friday in three separate cases that thimerosal, a preservative containing mercury, does not cause autism.

title: White House Weighs Talks With Taliban After Afghan Successes
description: WASHINGTON  With American troops pouring into insurgent strongholds in Afghanistan and the United States succeeding in killing insurgent leaders with drone attacks in Pakistan, the Obama administration is beginning to consider whether it has gained the upper hand sufficiently to justify an effort to begin talks with the Taliban.

title: Senate Abortion Restrictions Are Sufficient, Catholic Group Says
description: According to the National Catholic Reporter, Catholics in Alliance for the Common Good, a Washington-based advocacy group, sent a letter to members of Congress on Friday urging support for the Senate-passed health care bill and expressing its view that the bill contains sufficient provisions to prevent the use of federal money to pay for insurance coverage of abortions.

title: Iraq Election May Leave Kirkuk Status Uncertain
description: KIRKUK, Iraq  Early election results appear to reflect a hardening of divisions between Kurds, Arabs and Turkmens in northern Iraq, potentially complicating efforts by the United States and the United Nations to forge a compromise over the oil-rich city of Kirkuk  a prize claimed by both Iraqs semiautonomous Kurdistan region and the central government.

title: Woman Hit by a Train Is Identified
description: The 48-year-old woman who was crushed to death by a subway train on the Upper East Side of Manhattan this week has been identified, the authorities said Friday.

title: Grapevine Moth Forces Quarantine for Part of Napa Valley
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The states most lucrative crop, grapes, has yet another insect enemy.

title: He Could Sell a Bridge Over the East River
description: The Lifetime movie Who Is Clark Rockefeller? slips by easily enough. The story of how the German chameleon Christian Karl Gerhartsreiter fooled successive flocks of Americans with his invented personas, culminating in Clark Rockefeller, fictional scion of Americas most blue-blooded family, is a natural for the network.

title: The Obesity-Hunger Paradox
description: WHEN most people think of hunger in America, the images that leap to mind are of ragged toddlers in Appalachia or rail-thin children in dingy apartments reaching for empty bottles of milk.

title: Television in Review
description: THE GUARD

title: The Week in Pictures for March 12
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include the Atlantic Yards groundbreaking ceremony, Lil Waynes sentencing, and auditions for a reality show about the Russian population in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.

title: For That Post-Workout Hunger
description: To get an idea what kind of shape the Woodbridge-based restaurant chain Muscle Maker Grill is in, consider its recent growth: only two years ago, Colonia was its sole location. Now there are 18 Muscle Maker Grills, stretching from Toms River to Edgewater, according to Robert E. Morgan, the companys chief operating officer.

title: Good News, Comrades! Stalin Has a Job for You
description: Lenins Embalmers, at Ensemble Studio Theater, will not teach you specifically how to embalm yourself so that admirers eight decades later will be able to pay their respects directly to your lifelike face. It will, however, teach you to beware the living, especially those in seats of power who issue orders that carry the whiff of crazy.

title: Just One Flight Up to Join a Towns Revival
description: ABOVE: the name has a nice ring to it, and its apt for more than one reason.

title: Sometimes a Penalty Double May Make an Average a Top
description: The winners of the North American Open Pairs on Thursday in Reno, Nev., were Doug Doub of West Hartford, Conn., and Frank Merblum of Bloomfield, Conn. They also won this title in 2001 and were second in 2003.

title: Where Root Beer Is the Draw
description: Plenty of Westchester restaurants carry beers from Captain Lawrence Brewing Company, an excellent microbrewer in Pleasantville. But only Pumpernickel offers what is possibly my favorite product from the brewery: root beer on tap, made according to the restaurants proprietary recipe.

title: Thai Traditions, Made for Sharing
description: TUCKED into a residential area a few blocks south of Sleepy Hollows main thoroughfare, Tyrynda Thai practically glows with the warmth of its aromatic Thai cuisine and welcoming staff.

title: In Lehmans Demise, Some Shades of Enron
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: New York Cabs Gouged Riders Out of Millions
description: About 3,000 New York City taxi drivers routinely overcharged riders over two years by surreptitiously fixing their meters to charge rates that would normally apply only to trips outside the five boroughs, according to the citys Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: As the Budget Ax Swings Again, There May Be No Way to Avoid the Pain
description: It is the job of New Yorks social services workers to insist that the sky is falling.

title: The Evolving Challenge of Keeping Kosher
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Resurgence on the Right Puts Gingrich Back in Style
description: WASHINGTON  Newt Gingrich still relishes stirring the pot of the culture wars.

title: Like Fast Food, Just Better and Slower
description: AT La Bottega Italian Gourmet, customers who order panini, as Michael Parente, of Lynbrook, did recently, can expect to wait for it. Mr. Parente watched a cook behind the rustic take-out counter slice speck, a type of Italian ham, layer it on ciabatta with fontina cheese and arugula, and place it in the panini press until the cheese melted and the bread crisped.

title: One on One: Andrey Ternovskiy, Creator of Chatroulette
description: Andrey Ternovskiy, a polite, excited and eager Russian high school student, scoured the Internet trying to find a Web site that allowed random video chats with strangers. When he realized a site like that didnt exist, he decided to build it. Three months and tens of millions of users later, the 17-year-old is wandering around New York City and (soon) San Francisco talking to investors and programmers about where to take his project next.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Save Station Agent Jobs, 3 House Democrats Urge
description: Three House Democrats have written a letter to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority arguing that the planned layoffs of hundreds of station agents could compromise the security of the subways in New York City and asking the agency to seek an alternative mechanism for closing the budget gap.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 12
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Women Making Gains on Faculty at Harvard
description: Five years after Lawrence H. Summers, then the president of Harvard University, suggested that innate differences might explain why women are less successful in science and math careers than men, Harvard is, in some ways, a different place.

title: An Olfactory Nightmare May End in the Bronx
description: Barbara White no longer dries her clothes outside. Lucretia Jones has stopped hosting backyard barbecues. Tanya Fields keeps her windows shut tight year round.

title: For the Dishwashers Sake, Go Easy on the Detergent
description: IVE been writing on some weighty topics lately  too little money, too many choices, too few jobs. Its time, I decided, to move on to some questions that haunt me almost every day.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Richard Stites, Historian of Russian Culture, Dies at 78
description: Richard Stites, who opened up new territory for historians with a landmark work on the Russian womens movement and in numerous articles and books on Russian and Soviet mass culture, died on Sunday in Helsinki, where he was doing research. He was 78 and lived in Washington.

title: Where Some Envision Czars End, Church Sees Building Site
description: MOSCOW  Visitors from around the world have turned an isolated ravine in central Russia into a pilgrimage site in recent years. They arrive to gaze at the unadorned earth where the Bolsheviks, in one final act to defile the dynasty that they toppled, are believed to have dumped the remains of Czar Nicholas II and his family in July 1918.

title: Japan: Finance Official Reveals Secret Payment to U.S.
description: Japans finance minister said Friday that an investigation revealed that Tokyo had secretly agreed with Washington to shoulder extra costs of Okinawas 1972 return to Japan beyond the $320 million stipulated in a treaty. The investigation was part of a push by the Democratic Party government to expose secret pacts made with Washington in the 1960s and 1970s by the Liberal Democrats, whose half-century grip on power the Democrats ended last summer. The finance minister, Naoto Kan, left, said the inquiry had discovered that Tokyo paid $85 million more for the relocation of American military bases on the island.

title: A Scam as Easy as 3-1-1
description: By flooding the citys 311 line with phony building complaints, someone has put thousands of homeowners in Queens under a state of bureaucratic siege.

title: Youthful Pop, Cheek and Crowd Surfing
description: The choreographer Juliette Mapp, the current guest curator of Danspace Projects Platform 2010 initiative, has emphasized the importance of presenting an intergenerational array of artists in Back to New York City. Next week comes the inimitable octogenarian Elaine Summers; on Thursday night the youngsters had the run of the place, when Katy Pyle and Jen Rosenblit, both in their 20s, presented new work.

title: Exalting 20 Years of Rock, Babies and Cheerleaders
description: For any choreographer working in New York, reaching the 20-year mark is no small feat. For Jody Oberfelder, such an anniversary is occasion to look back in a two-act program, Heads or Tales, which highlights dances created throughout her career. Lesson learned: Perhaps the only thing Ms. Oberfelder cares about more than a cartwheel is a headstand.

title: Five Years After an Incendiary Remark, Signs That Harvard Is More Welcoming to Women
description: Some readers of The Choice may be too young to remember the brush fire that Lawrence H. Summers, then the president of Harvard University, touched off in 2005, when he suggested that innate differences might explain why women are less successful in science and math careers than men.

title: The Netherlands: Amsterdams Mayor Wins Party Post
description: Job Cohen, the popular mayor of Amsterdam, on Friday became the new leader of the Dutch Labor Party, leaving him well placed to become the countrys next prime minister after the June general elections. The government collapsed in February when the Labor Party quit the governing coalition over the continued Dutch military presence in Afghanistan. The 2,000 Dutch soldiers, part of the NATO contingent fighting the war, were scheduled to return home at the end of the year, but after entreaties from the United States, the leading Christian Democrats tried to extend the Dutch military presence. A long cabinet debate prompted the left-of-center Labor Party to walk out, necessitating new elections. Under Mr. Cohen, the Labor Party hopes to regain ground and win enough votes to form the next government.

title: Heartthrobs Blog Challenges Chinas Leaders
description: SHANGHAI

title: Tea Party Avoids Divisive Social Issues
description: For decades, faith and family have been at the center of the conservative movement. But as the Tea Party infuses conservatism with new energy, its leaders deliberately avoid discussion of issues like gay marriage or abortion.

title: On the Street | In Paris
description: A fresh language for 21st-century dress popped up here and there during the Paris fashion shows.

title: Beltran Remains Confident in Mets Despite Loss of Key Players
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Carlos Beltran planned to call Jose Reyes on Friday to offer support and encouragement as Reyes sat in New York waiting for his overactive thyroid gland to return to normal. Beltran offered similar hope and encouragement for a team that appears as if it will start the 2010 season with the same shortcomings that derailed its 2009 campaign.

title: History of an Abuse Case
description: The Munich Archdiocese acknowledged mishandling an abuse case in the late 70s and early 80s, when the pope served as its archbishop. Information about the priest in the case was provided by the archdiocese, who identified him only with the letter H.

title: Senate Backs Ban on Mail-Order Cigarettes in Setback for Tribe
description: WASHINGTON  By a unanimous vote, the Senate on Thursday passed a bill to eliminate mail-order cigarettes, a victory for public health advocates and a defeat for the New York Indian tribe that dominates the business.

title: Effort to Widen U.S. Internet Access Sets Up Battle
description: The Federal Communications Commission is proposing an ambitious 10-year plan that will reimagine the nations media and technology priorities by establishing high-speed Internet as the countrys dominant communication network.

title: Federal Panel Finds Bias in Ouster of Principal
description: A federal commission has determined that New York Citys Department of Education discriminated against the founding principal of an Arabic-language public school by forcing her to resign in 2007 following a storm of controversy driven by opponents of the school.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,006 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

title: New Numbers for Swine Flu
description: About 12,000 Americans died from swine flu between its emergence last April until mid-February, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimated on Friday. While swine flu is still being transmitted at low levels and some people still die of it, the third wave that experts had said was possible has not emerged, and is looking unlikely. Seasonal flu activity has been unusually low this winter, suggesting that the H1N1 swine flu strain crowded out the usual seasonal H1N1 and H3N2 strains. Little of the third seasonal strain, influenza B, which usually arrives late in flu season, has been seen in the United States. Swine flu has infected 42 million to 86 million people, the C.D.C. estimated.

title: Climate Change Adds to Bird Stress
description: Changes in the global climate are imposing additional stress on hundreds of species of migratory birds in the United States that are already threatened by other environmental factors, according to a new Interior Department report. The departments annual State of the Birds report shows that nearly a third of the nations 800 bird species are endangered, threatened or suffering from population decline. For the first time, the report adds climate change to other factors threatening bird populations, including destruction of habitat, hunting, pesticides, invasive species and loss of wetlands. The report said oceanic and shore birds were among the most vulnerable to climate change because of rapidly changing marine ecosystems and rising sea levels.

title: Earliest Return Seen for Woods Is Masters
description: DORAL, Fla.  Tiger Woods, who has been absent from tournament golf since mid-November, will not return to competition before the Masters tournament at the Augusta National Golf Club in mid-April, according to two people with knowledge of his comeback plans.

title: Facebook Helps Social Start-Ups Gain Users
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The only thing more challenging than deciphering the names of all the social-minded Web sites battling for attention at the South by Southwest technology conference here  Brizzly, Vicarious.ly, Stalqer, Quora and so forth  would be the chore of signing up for each one individually.

title: Insurer and Hospital System Reach Accord
description: A contract dispute between one of the countrys largest insurers and a major New York City hospital system has been settled, officials said Friday, ending the prospect that tens of thousands of New Yorkers would be cut off from their doctors and the hospitals they use.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an examiners report detailing accounting maneuvers used by Lehman Brothers to conceal its perilous finances described incorrectly in some editions the assets that were temporarily shuffled off its books. They were mostly high-quality securities that could be easily accepted by other banks, according to the examiners report; they were not troubled and mostly illiquid real estate holdings. The article also misstated in some editions the status of some Lehman executives in the aftermath of the banks collapse. They are defendants in civil suits, not plaintiffs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Bank of Americas decision to stop charging overdraft fees on debit purchases misstated Citibanks overdraft policies, and a correction in this space on Friday contained a misspelling that affected its clarity. Citibank has never charged overdraft fees on one-time debit  not debt  purchases or A.T.M. transactions; it did not recently modify its policy to appease critics.

title: Marilyn Gittell, Advocate for Local School Decisions, Dies at 78
description: Marilyn Gittell, a political scientist and education reformer who in the 1960s was an outspoken advocate of decentralizing New York Citys public school system, died on Feb. 26 at her home in Manhattan. She was 78.

title: Corrections
Republicans Name 6 to Debt-Reduction Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Republican leaders in Congress on Friday named six lawmakers to the bipartisan debt-reduction commission that President Obama created. The presence of antitax hard-liners among them suggests the hurdles to forging agreement by December on proposals to arrest the unsustainable growth of projected deficits.

title: Is the U.S. Following in Romes Footsteps?
description: David Brooks: Dick, Im just back from a gruelingfive days during which I took 11 flights  everywhere from Florida to Tucson to Atlanta to Denver to Raleigh (O.K., I watched Duke crush North Carolina at Raleigh-Durham so that wasnt so bad).

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about digital technology to help people with Alzheimers disease and other memory disorders rendered the name of a device incorrectly and referred incorrectly to its marketing. The device, a wearable digital camera that can take hundreds of pictures without the users having to click the shutter, is the SenseCam, not Sensecam. Vicon, the British company that licenses the technology from Microsoft, is selling its version of the SenseCam only to researchers; it has not said it plans to market the device to young people interested in logging their lives and posting the results to Web sites.

title: Dont Tickle Me, Bro!
description: Welcome to Ticklegate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about aviation industry advertising in the early years of the space age misstated the year of the Apollo 13 mission, in which the crew of a crippled spacecraft was brought safely back to earth. It was 1970, not 1969.

title: 10 Years Later, Working Toward a Better Count
description: Kulwinder Singh, a 52-year-old Punjabi Sikh who works as a tow-truck operator, approached a young community organizer who was taping a promotional poster for the 2010 census to a wall inside his temple in Richmond Hill, Queens. Mr. Singh looked perplexed.

title: Corrections
description: A dance entry in the listings on Friday about the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival misstated who will be performing this weekend. Daniel Charon, Gwen Welliver and Nancy Bannon, in a program curated by Doug Varone, are presenting works with their own troupes; the company Doug Varone and Dancers is not performing.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the Food column in The Times Magazine omitted a measurement in a recipe, and a correction in Sundays magazine misstates the issue in which the error occurred. The recipe omitted the amount of raw corn kernels needed in Lantern Cracker Jack; it is one-third of a cup. The recipe appeared in the Feb. 28 issue of the magazine, not the March 7 issue.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Violations Are Cited in Generics
description: As American consumers increasingly turn to generic drugs as a way to reduce their medical costs, the continued manufacturing problems of one generic maker stand out.

title: I.R.S. Says Its Audits of Wealthy Are Rising
description: The Internal Revenue Service is intensifying its scrutiny of wealthy Americans.

title: 37 Down: NASAs Opportunity
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Ive long held the suspicion that the NW corners in Times themeless puzzles are made a bit tougher to thwart a quick toehold. Not always, mind you, but more often than not.

title: Paul Ryans Redistributionism
description: Perhaps inspired by my criticisms of Paul Ryans proposed tax reforms, Jonathan Chait has a long post about how Ryans roadmap clarifies the essence of the Republican Partys approach to domestic policy issues, which involves opposition to the downward redistribution of income. Noting that Ryan has said kind words about Ayn Rand, he writes that the core of the Randian worldview, as absorbed by the modern GOP, is a belief that the natural market distribution of income is inherently moral, and the central struggle of politics is to free the successful from having the fruits of their superiority redistributed by looters and moochers. And he argues: Every major element of Ryans plan reflects this commitment  Ryan would retain some bare-bones subsidies for the poorest, but the overwhelming thrust in every way is to liberate the lucky and successful to enjoy their good fortune without burdening them with any responsibility for the welfare of their fellow citizens.

title: Fates Message to the Mets Sounds Familiar
description: Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: A Culture of Corruption
description: So far, there have been six guilty pleas in Attorney General Andrew Cuomos investigation of the real and potential abuses surrounding New Yorks $129 billion public pension investments. The most important and revealing of these came Wednesday, when David Loglisci, the former chief investment officer of the pension fund, admitted flatly that he had violated state securities law.

title: Findings on Lehman Take Even Experts by Surprise
description: For the year that it took the court-appointed examiner to complete his report on the demise of Lehman Brothers, officials from Wall Street to Washington were anticipating it as the definitive account of the largest bankruptcy in American history.

title: Bloggingheads: Does Israel Need Peace?
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and David Frum of FrumForum debate Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

title: Editorial: Republicans Wanted
description: On Thursday, President Obama held meetings on immigration reform with immigrant advocates and labor and religious leaders, with Senators Charles Schumer and Lindsey Graham, and with the Congressional Hispanic Caucus. He came out reiterating his unwavering commitment to comprehensive immigration reform.

title: Big Brother in Blue
description: The speaker of the New York City Council and the head of the Councils Public Safety Committee are calling on Police Commissioner Ray Kelly to get rid of his huge, noxious database of completely innocent New Yorkers who are stopped, questioned and often frisked by the police.

title: His Day in Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard Times for Retirees
description: To the Editor:

title: Pick Your Side
description: After spending months searching for a bipartisan consensus on financial regulatory reform, Senator Christopher Dodd, chairman of the banking committee, is expected to unveil his own bill on Monday, without one Republican supporter.

title: Wonders of Math, Through the Looking-Glass
description: To the Editor:

title: Diversions of Food Aid in Somalia
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama, Jobs and Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Something Worse Than Inaction
description: The Obama administration has always had a backup plan in case Congress failed to pass a broad climate change bill. The Environmental Protection Agency would use its Clean Air Act authority to regulate greenhouse gases. Regulation, or the threat of it, would goad Congress to act or provide a backstop if it did not.

title: Another Bump in the Mideast Road
description: To the Editor:

title: The Age of Concrete
description: Minneapolis

title: Fed Helped Bank Raise Cash Quickly
description: They were considered the dregs of Lehman Brothers  bottom of the barrel, as one banker put it.

title: Netflix Cancels Contest After Concerns Are Raised About Privacy
description: Netflixs $1 million contest for the best method to improve its movie recommendations was such a research and business hit that, when the winners were declared last September, the company immediately announced plans for another one.

title: Suspect Arrested in Attack in Midtown Bars Restroom
description: The police arrested a suspect on Friday in the attack on a 29-year-old woman who had been beaten and left bleeding and unconscious in a restroom stall at a Midtown bar, the authorities said.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 12, 2010

title: Increase Expected in Heavy Equipment Sales in China
description: Komatsu, the Japanese heavy equipment maker, said Friday it expected sales in China to rise by half as the countrys 10 percent growth rate drives demand for resources like coal and iron ore. Sales in the year starting April 1 are expected to rise by 40 to 50 percent from the current year, Kazuhiko Iwata, the president of the companys mining division, said. Mining machinery sales account for about 30 percent of Komatsus construction equipment division revenue, which is forecast to be 1.3 trillion yen ($14 billion) this year.

title: Pacquiaos Challenger Clottey Follows in Footsteps of Warriors
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Even here, with Saturdays welterweight title fight in Cowboys Stadium, with nearly 45,000 seats sold, with Manny Pacquiao defending his latest world championship, the fight that fell apart looms over the proceedings.

title: Justice Dept. Tells Farmers It Will Press Agriculture Industry on Antitrust
description: ANKENY, Iowa  The attorney general, Eric H. Holder Jr., traveled to the heart of Midwestern farm country on Friday to declare that the Obama administration was serious about rooting out anticompetitive practices in agriculture.

title: Its Own Advisers Oppose Consumer Role for the Fed
description: WASHINGTON  As the Senate contemplates creation of a consumer financial protection agency within the Federal Reserve, opposition to the idea has emerged from an unexpected quarter: the Feds Consumer Advisory Council.

title: Tennessee Defeats Mississippi to Reach SEC Semifinals
description: NASHVILLE  Brian Williams, the Tennessee center from the Bronx, suggested there were always subplots in the Vols basketball program, disagreements over who owned the brand. Whose team was it, anyway?

title: Picking Up Momentum, Hoyas Roll Into Title Game
description: Marquettes margin of error is about as small as its 5-foot-8 point guard, Maurice Acker. Undersize and handicapped by a roster short on overall talent, Coach Buzz Williamss team has grown into a contender among the Big Easts bullies based on efficiency and feistiness.

title: Teach for the World Vs. Peace Corps
description: My Thursday column proposing Teach for the World attracted a range of comments and criticisms. One blog noted that the beneficiaries would essentially be American kids and argued that if the aim is to build language and cultural skills, why not do more to expand the Peace Corps? Others noted that if we want to improve education in poor countries, the obvious way to do that is to build local capacity by training teachers  or, I would argue, by deworming kids as has worked so well in Kenya or expanding the conditional cash grants that have been tremendously successful to promote education in Mexico.

title: Players Suspension Ends, but Baylor Falters
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  At the first mention of her name Friday night, Baylors Brittney Griner exhaled deeply, as if she had been holding her breath for the past nine days.

title: Rachel Alexandras Security Guard Is Also Pursuing  Ph.D.
description: NEW ORLEANS  It started with an ad on Craigslist, and has led to moonlight yoga sessions in dusty barns on racetracks from here to New York. There is a free-spirited woman involved, a Ph.D. dissertation as well as a horse. Actually two horses, really famous ones.

title: Granderson Sets a Course to Another Side of Hitting
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Kevin Long started analyzing videotape of Curtis Grandersons at-bats last November. At the time, Granderson was still playing for Detroit.

title: Midseason Move Re-energized Mavericks
description: DALLAS  In the heat of the moment, in the heat of his shower stall, Mark Cuban mentally dangled his index finger over an imaginary big red button.

title: Fulfilling a Vision: Biking 250 Miles of the Bay Trail in Five Days
description: Last September, Stephanie and Tim Reed biked out their Oakland front door and pedaled to the Bay Trail, a 21-year effort to create a continuous, 500-mile hiking and biking trail along the shoreline of the San Francisco Bay, linking the areas nine counties. With 298 miles completed, the trail is a work in progress with pieces added in chunks, each addition attended by some civic hoopla. Last November, a deal between Chevron and the East Bay Regional Parks District will add two more miles along Point Molate in Richmond, The San Francisco Chronicle reported.

title: Els Tinkers With Game and Takes Lead at Doral
description: DORAL, Fla.  Ernie Els has made some minor adjustments to his stance in the past week that have yielded major results at the W.G.C.-CA Championship, vaulting him into the lead at the halfway point of the $8.5 million limited-field event at the Doral Resort and Spa.

title: Mountaineers and Hoyas Are a Step From the Top
description: A day after West Virginias football coach suggested the university was considering leaving the Big East, another one of its teams took a step closer to winning the conferences basketball championship.

title: Tomlinson Spends Day With Jets
description: Running back LaDainian Tomlinson followed a full day of meetings with Jets officials with dinner Friday night with Coach Rex Ryan and General Manager Mike Tannenbaum. Tomlinson planned to spend the night  there were no late flights available to the West Coast after dinner  but his itinerary for Saturday was unclear.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Brodeur Solves Pens Yet Again
description: Six games on Friday, highlighted by a clash between the two top clubs in the Atlantic Division. Home teams listed first:

title: How Jay Lenos Car Collection Grows
description: Think of comedian Jay Leno not as a car collector, but as the patron saint of lost automotive causes.

title: Why Tomlinson and Not Thomas Jones?
description: As Judy Battista reported:  LaDainian Tomlinson followed a full day of meetings with Jets officials with dinner Friday night with Coach Rex Ryan and General Manager Mike Tannenbaum. Tomlinson planned to spend the night  there were no late flights available to the West Coast after dinner.

title: Kissinger Hospitalized in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Henry Kissinger, the former United States secretary of state, was hospitalized here because of stomach pains on Saturday. But his condition has quickly improved, said a spokesman for Yonsei Universitys Severance Hospital in Seoul.

title: Elgin Park, a Nice Place to Visit
description: I discovered the small (very small) town of Elgin Park the same way millions of others around the world have: someone forwarded me a link to a Flickr slide show. The subject line was Cars of the past  real or models?

title: The Saturday Word: Education Overhaul
description: President Obama will on Monday give Congress an outline for overhauling No Child Left Behind, the controversial education policy former President George W. Bush put in place in 2002.

title: A Quick Reminder
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Hey, just a quick reminder. Daylight savings time begins this weekend. Everybodys setting their clocks ahead an hour, okay? Or if you are Congressman Eric Massa, you are wishing you could set them back about a week.

title: Two Million Potholes
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Good news. New York City has filled two million potholes. Now, the bad news is those are the only things that were slowing down the Toyotas.

title: Priuses for Entertainment
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the phrase In God We Trust  you know on our dollar bills  is constitutional. There was a lawsuit to have In God We Trust removed from our money. To give you an idea how bad the shape the dollar is in, you know who wanted In God We Trust taken off? God. He said, I dont want to be associated with this economy!

title: Vettel on Pole as Team Strength Becomes Clearer
description: The first qualifying session of the Formula One season clarified a few things that we had only been able to guess about after winter testing last month. There are clearly four teams in the fight for the championship, as predicted, as all the drivers from Red Bull, Ferrari, McLaren and Mercedes made it into the top 10 during the seasons first qualifying session, at the Bahrain Grand Prix today.

title: Seeing Handpicked as a Bad Thing
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Brad Ellsworth will avoid a primary fight to become the Democratic candidate for the Senate in Indiana, which should be good news for him. But Republicans are preparing to cast him as the tainted product of shadowy dealings in smoke-filled rooms.

title: Andretti Praises Formula One Expansion
description: Mario Andretti visited the Bahrain Grand Prix paddock today as part of the 60th anniversary celebrations of the Formula One world championship.

title: Womens Rights as a Security Issue
description: Hillary Clinton has been pushing hard to reframe womens rights from soft issue to security issue. Obviously thats partly because soft issues are shunted aside, while the security issues are discussed in the Situation Room and get billions of dollars thrown at them. In an interview with Andrea Mitchell released today, Clinton put it this way:

title: Kristine Gomez, Thomas Crosby
description: Kristine Louise Gomez, a daughter of Nancy OConnell Gomez and Ralph A. Gomez, both of Miami, was married Saturday evening to Thomas Lincoln Crosby, the son of Linda E. Watt of New York and Benjamin L. Crosby III of Punta Gorda, Fla. The Rev. Thomas L. Brackett, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Cocoplum Womens Club in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Debbie Almontaser: The Path to Resignation
description: A timeline of key dates, from Ms. Almontaser's appointment as principal of the Khalil Gibran International Academy to her resignation and subsequent fight to be reinstated.

title: Ann Vincola and Alan Votta
description: Ann Patavino Vincola and Alan S. Votta were married Saturday at the Church of God of Prophecy in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Bernie Levesque, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Jill Rosenberg, Charles Jainchill
description: Jill Rosenberg and Charles Howard Jainchill were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Mark Mallach at Temple Beth Ahm Yisrael in Springfield, N.J.

title: Battle Over a Brooklyn School
description: The story of the Khalil Gibran International Academy, New York City's first Arabic-language school, and the people at the center of a fight for and against it.

title: Matthew Fornataro and William Dooner
description: Matthew Thomas Fornataro, a son of Kathleen F. Fornataro and Anthony V. Fornataro of Lewisburg, Pa., is to be married Sunday to William Robert Dooner, the son of Laurie J. Dooner and William C. Dooner of Toms River, N.J. Daniel J. Furmansky, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Washington.

title: Amanda Wittenstein, Jeffrey Shackelton
description: Amanda Marin Wittenstein, the daughter of Vicki Oransky Wittenstein and Andrew A. Wittenstein of Brooklyn, was married Saturday evening to Dr. Jeffrey Brett Shackelton, a son of Donna Jean Shackelton and Scott H. Shackelton of Reno, Nev. Rabbi Matthew Gewirtz officiated at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in Manhattan.

title: Laura Freeman, Joshua Gordon
description: Laura Elizabeth Freeman, the daughter of Marsha A. Freeman of Minnetonka, Minn., and Harvey A. Freeman of Eagan, Minn., was married Saturday evening to Joshua Jady Gordon, the son of Nancy S. Gordon and Mark N. Gordon of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Marjorie Berman officiated at the Hyatt Regency at Penns Landing in Philadelphia.

title: Marni Weiss, Michael Friedlander
description: Marni Weiss, the daughter of Stephanie and Richard Weiss of Westhampton, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Michael Friedlander, a son of Suzanne and Leslie Friedlander of North Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Mark Wildes is to perform the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: Lindsay Hoag and Edward Telleria
description: Lindsay Kelly Hoag and Edward Robert Castro Telleria were married Saturday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston. The Rev. Victor H. Kazanjian Jr., an Episcopal priest and the dean of religious and spiritual life at Wellesley, officiated.

title: Emily Stolzenberg, Matthew Shapiro
description: Emily Judith Stolzenberg, a daughter of Merle P. Stolzenberg and Alan M. Stolzenberg of Morgantown, W.Va., is to be married Sunday to Matthew Abraham Shapiro, a son of Mary E. Shapiro and Howard Shapiro of Menands, N.Y. Rabbi Debora S. Gordon is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Berith Sholom in Troy, N.Y.

title: Arrests in Europe Expose ETAs Ties to Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The shadowy underworld of Basque exiles in this city is coming under sharp scrutiny after recent arrests in Europe and an indictment this month from one of Spains top judges asserting that Venezuelan intelligence officials were involved in training Basque separatists and Colombian guerrillas in Venezuela.

title: Samantha Wolfert, Justin Gref
description: Samantha Ann Wolfert, the daughter of Laurie Wolfert and David Wolfert of New York, was married Saturday evening to Justin Sine Gref, the son of Karen Vogel Gref and Richard Gref of Darien, Conn. Rabbi Jonathan Stein officiated at the St. Regis Hotel in New York, with Cantor Bruce Ruben taking part.

title: Fearing Drug Cartels, Reporters in Mexico Retreat
description: REYNOSA, Mexico  The big philosophical question in this gritty border town does not concern trees falling in the forest but bodies falling on the concrete: Does a shootout actually happen if the newspapers print nothing about it, the radio and television stations broadcast nothing, and the authorities never confirm that it occurred?

title: Ilana Sausen, Eytan Seidman
description: Ilana Rose Sausen and Eytan Daniel Yosef Seidman are to be married Sunday at Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph I. Eisenbach will officiate, with Rabbi Abraham I. Zigelman, a great-uncle of the bride, taking part.

title: Sara Lavipour, Scott Hansen
description: Sara Satin Lavipour and Scott Aron Hansen were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Robert N. Levine at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

title: Jennifer Wallner, Adam Saltzman
description: Jennifer Victoria Sophia Wallner and Adam Marc Saltzman are to be married Sunday at the Westward Look Resort and Spa in Tucson. Rabbi Billy Lewkowicz is to officiate.

title: Chuck Berry Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon always have an interesting quote awaiting us in their acrostics. Its also often revealing or amusing, and sometimes both. Todays is guilty on all three fronts, and it actually made me chuckle out loud, which is a more refined version of laughing out loud, as befits a New York Times puzzle.

title: Blagojevich Lawyers Want Trial Delay
description: CHICAGO  Lawyers for the ousted governor of Illinois, Rod R. Blagojevich, say they need more time to wade through millions of pages of documents and hundreds of hours of secretly recorded telephone calls in preparation for his federal corruption trial.

title: Vatican Sees Campaign Against the Pope
description: ROME  As new details emerged on allegations of child sexual abuse by a priest in the Munich archdiocese then led by Pope Benedict XVI, the Vatican spoke out on Saturday against what it called an aggressive campaign against the pope in his native Germany.

title: Some Palestinian Jordanians Lose Citizenship
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Muhannad Haddad grew up here, went to school here, got a job in a bank here and traveled to foreign countries with a passport from here. Then one day the authorities said he was no longer Jordanian, and with that one stroke they took away his citizenship and compromised his ability to travel, study, work, seek health care, buy property or even drive.

title: A Candidate Finds Much Changed, and Little
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the 32 years since Lowell Darling, an artist, last ran for public office in California, Ronald Reagan was elected president, a bodybuilder was elected governor and the entire state has toddled perilously close to fiscal disaster.

title: Landrieu Offers Support for Health Care Legislation
description: Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana and at one point a skeptic of sweeping health care legislation, has written an opinion article in The Shreveport Times in which she makes a strong case in favor of moving forward with a bill.

title: Prime Number
description: 48: The percent of births in the United States to minority mothers in the 12 months that ended July 2008, according to an analysis of Census Bureau data by Professors Kenneth M. Johnson of the University of New Hampshire and Daniel Lichter at Cornell University. The 50 percent benchmark could be reached as soon as this year, demographers say. Over all, the Census Bureau estimates that minorities will constitute a majority of the nations population in about three decades and a majority of Americans under 18 in about a decade.

title: Prime Number
description: 0.3: The percentage increase in retail sales in February, surprising Wall Street analysts, who had predicted a decline of 0.2 percent. The number was even better  0.9 percent  when volatile car and gasoline sales were excluded. Sales have increased for four of the last five months and are on track for a 5.8 percent annual growth rate. The surprise gain highlighted a sense that spending habits were changing. The amount of money Americans kept in savings fell in January, and consumer borrowing increased for the first time in a year.

title: A German Town Battered by Potholes Holds Out Its Hat
description: Hit any potholes lately? Brace yourself for more.With a bad winter behind us and the economy only beginning to shake off its long recession chill, many state and local governments are struggling to find money to fix record numbers of potholes.

title: Why Would the N.C.A.A. Expand Its Tournament? Its About the Money
description: Former President Bill Clinton sat courtside at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, chatting with the Big East commissioner, John Marinatto. Inevitably, the conversation turned to the potential expansion of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Thrift and Shrewd Moves Again Make  Rockies Contender in N.L. West
description: TUCSON  The Colorado Rockies stormed into the 2007 World Series, winning 21 of 22 games, but they were not really ready to be there. As quickly as they reached the summit, they tumbled.

title: Quotations of the Week
description: My question to them is: When is the right time? If not now, when? If not us, who? President Obama, on those seeking to delay a health care overhaul.

title: Issue of Presidency Endangers Iraqs Tenuous Balance
description: BAGHDAD  Few doubted that the choice of the countrys next prime minister would prove to be one of the most intractable disputes in forging a new government to lead Iraq as the American military withdraws.

title: New Fraud Cases Point to Lapses in Iraq Projects
description: Investigators looking into corruption involving reconstruction in Iraq say they have opened more than 50 new cases in six months by scrutinizing large cash transactions  involving banks, land deals, loan payments, casinos and even plastic surgery  made by some of the Americans involved in the nearly $150 billion program.

title: Correction: The Moral Ambiguity of Looting
description: An article last Sunday about the morality of dealing with looting in times of disaster incorrectly stated that a blackout in 1965, which did not bring disorder to New York, resulted instead in a baby boom nine months later. There was no baby boom. A widespread belief that there had been one originated with a New York Times article, nine months after the blackout, reporting that some New York hospitals were experiencing higher than normal numbers of births; later scientific studies, however, found no evidence of a statistically significant spike in the birth rate.

title: After the Earthquake, a Military Chile Can Love Again
description: At Gen. Augusto Pinochets funeral, one of his grandsons, an Army captain also named Augusto Pinochet, gave a eulogy so defiant and aggressive that he was cashiered the next day. Earlier, as the general lay in state in his dress uniform and Chileans filed by his casket to pay their last respects, the grandson of another general, assassinated by Pinochets secret police, spat on the former dictators cadaver full in the face.

title: Ellen Murphy and Billy Cheung
description: Ellen Irene Murphy, the daughter of Janis Murphy and William T. Murphy of Garden City, N.Y., was married in Manhattan Saturday evening to Billy Lap Kwan Cheung, the son of Man San Cheung of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Hon Leung Cheung. The Rev. Richard E. Hasselbach, a priest affiliated with CITI Ministries, officiated at the Yale Club of New York City.

title: Katherine Cocca, Nathaniel Bates
description: Katherine Camille Cocca, the daughter of Vicki I. Cocca and Stephen L. Cocca of Gowanda, N.Y., was married Saturday to Nathaniel Bates, a son of Deborah Wood Bates and Timothy D. Bates of Noank, Conn. The Rev. Daniel Warren, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Brierwood Country Club in Hamburg, N.Y.

title: In Hard Times, Lured Into Trade School and Debt
description: One fast-growing American industry has become a conspicuous beneficiary of the recession: for-profit colleges and trade schools.

title: English Fans Find an Unlikely Love for a Yank
description: LIVERPOOL, England  Beside the gallant city park in perhaps the worlds most zealous sports neighborhood, an unanticipated love has sprouted this winter and ripened into wistfulness this weekend.

title: Tweeting From Courtside at St. Johns
description: Last August, St. Johns became the first university to give a news media credential to someone who would cover a team entirely on the social networking forum Twitter. Peter Robert Casey, a basketball fan with more than 56,000 followers at twitter.com/peter_r_casey, has followed Coach Norm Roberts and the mens basketball team. With no background in journalism, he was nervous about taking on the assignment, but surprised at how he was received.

title: Africas Gift to Silicon Valley: How to Track a Crisis
description: Could wiki technology find Osama bin Laden?

title: A Star in Japan, Only a Prospect With the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Japanese television network J Sports is planning a broadcast that features Hideki Matsui, an iconic Japanese baseball star, and Hisanori Takahashi, a left-handed pitcher for the Mets.

title: Illegal Prescription Discovered for Actor Found Dead
description: LOS ANGELES  Investigators say that an illegal drug prescription for Corey Haim, the actor who died unexpectedly last week, was found during an investigation of a fraudulent drug ring responsible for thousands of illegal pharmaceutical sales.

title: Debate Grows on Nuclear Containment of Iran
description: For a few months in the mid-1960s President Johnson and his aides secretly weighed bombing Chinas nuclear sites  perhaps seeking Soviet help  rather than let Mao get the bomb. Then the costs of starting another war in Asia sank in and they decided to try containment  living with a threatening regime while deterring its most dangerous moves.

title: Parliamentarian in Role as Health Bill Referee
description: WASHINGTON  In the fall of 1968, a serious dark-haired young man arrived in the capital to do what serious young men here do: study law. Alan S. Frumin was calm, analytical and possessed of a dry wit. To his classmates, one trait stood out. He was a whiz at mastering the mind-numbing rules of civil procedure.

title: Jordans No. 23 Just Isnt the Retiring Type
description: By virtually all accounts, LeBron James is an admirable adult who will bring honor to whatever team signs him for next season.

title: Prisoner Is Captured in Manhattan
description: A robbery suspect on Staten Island who took on the identity of a fellow prisoner facing less serious criminal charges to trick the authorities into freeing him has been captured by detectives, the police said.

title: Womens Rights in Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: When Scholarship and Tribal Heritage Face Off Against Commerce
description: OXFORD, Ala.  Overlooking the Interstate and an outdoor shopping mall here stands a sad little hill, bald but for four bare trees and a scattering of stones.

title: As Health Vote Awaits, Future of a Presidency Waits, Too
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, had a little political advice last week for President Obama and the Democrats: Dont pass the presidents health care legislation because you would risk losing in the midterm elections.

title: Improving a Lineup at a Lower Price
description: When a team looks to become more efficient, removing the teams two highest-paid players would hardly seem like a good start. But for the Orlando Magic, there is evidence to support doing just that.

title: Tea-ing Up the Constitution
description: WASHINGTON  Brash and young though it is, the Tea Party movement has already added something distinctive to contemporary political discourse. It has made the Constitution central to the national conversation.

title: Tomlinson Heads Home to Weigh His Options
description: Running back LaDainian Tomlinson  who spent all day Friday being wooed by the Jets  flew back to San Diego on Saturday morning to consider his options. Tomlinsons departure is undoubtedly a disappointment for the Jets, who had pulled out all the stops, complete with a tour of the new stadium at the Meadowlands, in hopes of getting Tomlinson to sign on the dotted line before he left town.

title: The Author of Red Badge Loved the Game More Than His Studies
description: English literature scholars and historians have long known that football played a major role in Stephen Cranes development of his Civil War novel, The Red Badge of Courage. Crane told early reviewers he had been coaching and playing quarterback on a team in northern New Jersey while finishing his manuscript.

title: Mark Twain, Baseball Fan, Had an Eye for a Short-Stop
description: River rafting and billiards, sure. But who knew that the creator of Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn was a devotee of baseball?

title: Justice Dept. Lawyers Under Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Driving Miss Saudi
description: In other capitals of the world, it would not have been an extraordinary scene.

title: Taking a Nip Out of the Tuck
description: Are Americans experiencing plastic surgery fatigue?

title: Obama Calls for Major Change in Education Law
description: The Obama administration on Saturday called for a broad overhaul of President George W. Bushs No Child Left Behind law, proposing to reshape divisive provisions that encouraged instructors to teach to tests, narrowed the curriculum, and labeled one in three American schools as failing.

title: Explosions Rock Afghan City, Killing Dozens
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least four strong explosions rocked Kandahar on Saturday evening, causing buildings to collapse and killing dozens of people, according to Afghan and American officials.

title: Its Sports Empire Crumbling, Russia Scrambles
description: MOSCOW  A month ago, Russias biggest challenge in preparing to serve as host for the 2014 Winter Olympics seemed to be just mustering the resources to build the facilities in Sochi, a downtrodden Soviet-era resort town. Now, a new anxiety is gripping the country: if its athletes perform as badly as they did in Vancouver last month, Russia could be humiliated in its own backyard.

title: The New Rove-Cheney Assault on Reality
description: THE opening salvo, fired on Fox News during Thanksgiving week, aroused little notice: Dana Perino, the former White House press secretary, declared that we did not have a terrorist attack on our country during President Bushs term. Rudy Giuliani upped the ante on ABCs Good Morning America in January. We had no domestic attacks under Bush, he said. Weve had one under Obama. (He apparently meant the Fort Hood shootings.)

title: Troy Tulowitzki, the Derek Jeter of the Rockies
description: When people asked Joe Torre about Derek Jeter, Torre would invariably mention that veterans looked to Jeter for leadership when Jeter was only a rookie. There was just an aura about Jeter, a sense that he naturally accepted the responsibility of being his teammates focal point. Setting an example was never forced, and it was not a burden.

title: This Reggie Miller Is the Straw That Stirred the Garden
description: Is the ESPN documentary Winning Time: Reggie Miller vs. the New York Knicks a hoax? Did the playoff series that it depicts between the Knicks and the Indiana Pacers actually occur or are its claims of a snarling, slicker-heartland rivalry as dubious as U.F.O.s in Area 51?

title: Apples Spat With Google Is Getting Personal
description: IT looked like the beginning of a beautiful friendship.

description: The Mets never know what to expect from Oliver Perez. One day he dominates the Yankees or the Phillies and the next outing, he gives up eight runs to the Pirates.

title: Private Equitys Trojan Horse of Debt
description: WHENEVER savvy private equity firms sell debt in the companies they own, buyer beware.

title: British TV Ads Flaunt Their Arty Side
description: In a recent British television commercial for the Barclaycard credit card, an office worker strips down to his briefs, saunters past his co-workers and enters a storage closet, where he jumps down a chute and sets off on a wild water-slide ride across an urban landscape, sailing down the sides of buildings, whizzing past shoppers and sloshing through a public library to the sound of the 1976 Bellamy Brothers hit Let Your Love Flow. When his joyously soggy ride comes to an end, he says, Can you get me a towel?

title: The Office Skirmish: How to Avoid Round 2
description: Q. You recently had a big argument with a co-worker. Though you managed to end it, you still feel uncomfortable around this person. Should you try to discuss it or pretend it never happened?

description: Moscow

description: MY father owned several furniture stores, including one in Hollidaysburg, Pa., our hometown. He worked seven days a week, but my two brothers and sister and I always knew that we were the most important thing to him.

title: Cabbies Cheat? Riders Express No Surprise
description: For Robert Carrizzo, the daily commute from his Midtown office to the Staten Island Ferry is typically filled with precise rituals. But there is always one irritating question mark: the cost of the taxi ride.

title: Three Good Hires? Hell Pay More for One Whos Great
description: This interview with Kip Tindell, chief executive of the Container Store, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: How Mens Overconfidence Hurts Them as Investors
description: MEN and women invest differently, a growing body of research has found. And in at least one important respect, women may be better at it.

title: U.S. Woman Held in Plot Is Released, Family Says
description: LEADVILLE, Colo.  An American woman whose family feared that she may have become a radicalized Muslim was detained in Ireland last week in connection with a plot to assassinate a Swedish cartoonist.

description: The Haggler gets a thank-you video from a (very) young fan.
