description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Capturing the Moments of Customer Frustration
description: IN politics, they say the problem is never the crime; its the cover-up. Well, the Haggler has a corollary for consumerland: its never the manufacturing mistake, its the utterly appalling customer service that follows the manufacturing mistake.

title: Obama and Medvedev Talk About Arms Treaty
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia moved closer to agreement Saturday on a long-stalled arms control treaty that would slash the active nuclear arsenals of both countries by more than one-quarter, officials from both countries said.

title: Great Time to Buy (Famous Last Words)
description: ITS a great time to buy a home.

title: Andre Peel, Rescuer of Allied Airmen, Dies at 105
description: Andre Peel, a highly decorated French resistance figure who helped save dozens of American and British airmen shot down over France during World War II, died on March 5 in the English village of Long Ashton, outside Bristol. She was 105.

title: Book Binding
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  I really liked this puzzles theme, which has an elegant, extra angle to it.

title: An Express Lane From Camera to Computer
description: HIGH-SPEED data communication isnt so speedy by the time it reaches your video player or smartphone.

title: Talking About Bargaining and H.G.H.
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets players attended a union meeting Saturday morning led by Michael Weiner, the executive director of the players association, who said he spent most of the time preparing the players for the next collective bargaining session, which is almost two years away.

title: A Dream for Music, but Labels Nightmare
description: THE Apple iPad, which goes on sale April 3, will access video, applications and Web sites wirelessly  no cords or cables needed. But to move your trusty old music collection onto this wonder gadget and take it with you to work, or on vacation, youll have to pull out a U.S.B. sync cable, plug the device into your PC and transfer those music files over.

title: Managed Care: Get Used to It
description: WE may soon know whether Congress will approve some version of President Obamas health care plan. No matter what the outcome, there will be an unacknowledged monster lurking in the room: managed care.

title: Letters: Homeownerships Future
description: Homeownerships Future

title: Correction
description: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about the growth of Internet start-ups in New York City misattributed a quotation. It was Chris Dixon, a co-founder of the recommendation service Hunch, not Caterina Fake, another co-founder, who said, "We are definitely doing our part to get the ecosystem going. And the article misspelled the surname of the founder of Hot Potato, a social networking start-up focused on live events. He is Justin Shaffer, not Schaffer.

title: Expanding the Pool: What Coaches Think
description: Many models for an expanded N.C.A.A. tournament have been suggested, and a few coaches have their own ideas about what the tournament should look like.

title: Partying to Change the World
description: Maybe the most common question I get from readers is: What can I do?

title: Op-Classic, 1999: Israels Best Friend
description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

title: Rays of Hope in Battling an Agonizing Disease
description: It wasnt until Ileana Peralta was in junior high school that she summoned the courage to Google her own disease.

title: Taking Walks on the Wild Side
description: Janet Kessler, a 60-year-old, self-taught naturalist, leaves her cozy cottage in the Noe Valley section of San Francisco before dawn several days a week and walks to parks and other open spaces in hope of spotting coyotes, owls and other wildlife. Since she began photographing coyotes in the city three years ago, she has taken pictures of 11 different coyotes in four city parks. She wrote a small book  Myca of Twin Peaks  about one of the coyotes. Her work is chronicled on her Web site, urbanwildness.com. On a recent hike, she shared her views on animals and humans. (Her words have been edited and condensed.) SUSAN SWARD

title: A Time to Consider Local Fuel Fees
description: Democrats in the Legislature threw a fiscal lifeline to public transit last week, bolstering financing for buses and trains at a time when the state is cutting just about everything else.

title: National School Standards, at Last
description: The countries that have left the United States behind in math and science education have one thing in common: They offer the same high education standards  often the same curriculum  from one end of the nation to the other. The United States relies on a generally mediocre patchwork of standards that vary, not just from state to state, but often from district to district. A childs education depends primarily on ZIP code.

title: Sox Grow Players Better Than the Cubs Do
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

title: Taking a Look at Poverty From an Affluent Suburb
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Learning From Lehman
description: On top of everything Lehman Brothers did before it collapsed in 2008, nearly toppling the financial system, it now seems that it was aggressively massaging its books.

title: Support Network Seeks to Grow Biotech Companies
description: Dr. Boris Pasche had worked for years with a battery-operated device to treat insomnia, but as he followed his research, he discovered that electromagnetic radiation from the apparatus might slow or stop tumor growth in some cancer patients, and he thought he could perhaps build a business around the idea.

title: The Pulse: Veterans Channel Weighed for Cable Access Network
description: Military veterans' groups are working with the Chicago City Council on a project that would start a local cable access television channel dedicated to veterans' issues.

title: The Pulse: Paralympic Hockey Team Has Chicago Flavor
description: When he was young, Andy Yohe wanted to play hockey in the Olympics some day. But after he lost his legs in 1994, he gave up that dream.

title: Robbers Make Off With Gems and Cash in Diamond District
description: Two men armed with a pistol robbed a jewelry store in the heart of Manhattans diamond district on Saturday, stealing gems and money after binding three employees and a customer, the authorities said.

title: The Pulse: Obama Comes Under Fire From the City Council
description: President Barack Obama was the target of sharp criticism last week from an unlikely place: his hometowns City Council, where all members save one are fellow Democrats.

title: Nebraska Finds Unbeaten Season Is Just Out of Reach
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  It was hard for the third-ranked Nebraska womens basketball team to feel too bad about the demise of its undefeated record. After winning its first 30 games, Nebraska lost to Texas A&M, 80-70, on Saturday in the semifinals of the Big 12 tournament at Municipal Auditorium, leaving top-ranked Connecticut as the only team with a perfect record.

title: Wherever You Are, a Game Is Just a Point and Click Away
description: Though chess is one of the worlds oldest games, it is perfectly suited for the Internet age. Boards and pieces are easily displayed on computer screens, and the game is played all over the world. It is not surprising, then, that online chess has boomed.

title: Ray of Hope in Battling Disease and Highlights of Sundays Bay Area Pages
description: New Technologies Provide Hope | Those with Epidermolysis bullosa go through life with much of their bodies wrapped in gauze, like a burn patient. The disease is caused by the lack of the collagen gene that makes the glue that tethers layers of skin together; it makes skin seem as fragile as a butterflys wing. A handful of doctors in the United States who deal with EB are experimenting with some of the most advanced technologies in medicine  gene therapy, stem cell therapy and bone marrow transplantation  as a means of eventual treatment.

title: Justices Will Prevail
description: Washington

title: Kenneth Dover, a Provocative Scholar of Ancient Greek Literature, Dies at 89
description: Kenneth Dover, an eminent scholar of ancient Greek life, language and literature who became known for his willingness to break longstanding taboos in print, from his frank descriptions of sexual behavior (both the Greeks and his own) to his baldly stated desire to bring about the death of a vexing Oxford colleague, died on Sunday in Cupar, Scotland. He was 89.

title: Yanks Montero Looks to Claim Squatters Rights
description: TAMPA, Fla.  At home in Venezuela, Jesus Montero loves to hang around his fathers auto repair shop. As a boy, he learned how to take apart and reassemble engines, and he loves how cars purr afterward. When he is finished, they inevitably go faster.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Jan. 31 about alternative dining experiences in Westchester County included erroneous information from a partner in Table Local Market of Bedford Hills about the occasional dinners held there, and about the size of its storefront. The owners were forced to end their music evenings  not the dinners themselves  because they lacked the appropriate permits; the dinners are still held about four times a year. They draw fewer than 50 people, not as many as 100. And Table occupies 2,000 square feet, not 700 square feet.

title: Corrections
description: A review in some editions last Sunday of the play Sylvia at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven referred incompletely to one of its stars, Karen Ziemba. She is a Tony Award winner (in 2000, for Contact) as well as a four-time nominee.

title: Blocks by Mississippi St. Put It in Position for a Bid
description: NASHVILLE  Mississippi State center Jarvis Varnado wants to be the second man off the floor. He is the patient shot blocker, the big man who watches, waits for the shooter to jump, and then swats.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 14
description: Good Sunday morning. The heat is on. Speaker Nancy Pelosi has pledged to deliver a complete health care bill to Mr. Obamas desk in 10 days. And with this deadline in mind, White House officials and Congressional whips are out to make their final points on Sundays talk shows.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about the Hartford Jewish Film Festival misstated part of the name of a documentary about the Jewish contribution to basketball. It is The First Basket, not The Last Basket.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about Michael Chatfield, a playground basketball legend who was fatally shot in October at age 31, incorrectly described the Queensbridge housing development in Long Island City, Queens, where he grew up. It is the largest public housing project in North America, not the largest housing project.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the jobs that Chris Mooney worked before becoming head coach of the University of Richmond mens basketball team omitted part of the name of a previous employer. Mooney taught English and coached at Lansdale Catholic High School in Pennsylvania, not at Lansdale High School. (The public Lansdale High School was incorporated into the North Penn School District in 1956.)

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the Food column in The Times Magazine omitted a measurement in a recipe, and a correction in Sundays magazine misstates the issue in which the error occurred. The recipe omitted the amount of raw corn kernels needed in Lantern Cracker Jack; it is one-third of a cup. The recipe appeared in the Feb. 28 issue of the magazine, not the March 7 issue.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Sunday about the violinist Patricia Travers misspelled in some editions the name of the maker of one of the instruments she played as a child prodigy. He was Guarneri del Ges, not Guarnari del Ges.

title: Huskies Rally to Claim Pac-10 Title
description: LOS ANGELES  When Washington took the court Saturday afternoon, the Huskies were not sure if they had done enough over the previous four months to earn a berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about how this years Oscars race highlights the evolving viewing habits of moviegoers misstated a word in the name of the organization that administers the awards. It is the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (not Pictures). The article also referred imprecisely to the overall audience of this years Super Bowl. It is the most widely watched program in the United States, not the most-watched broadcast ever.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 28 about the new Fox show Sons of Tucson misstated, based on an interview with the shows producers, the year that Justin Berfield, an executive producer, first read the script for the pilot. He read it in 2008, not 2006.

title: Corrections
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Jayhawks Finally Justify Top Billing
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  When the N.C.A.A. mens tournament bracket is released Sunday, Kansas will almost certainly be the top overall seed. But during the Jayhawks first two victories in the Big 12 tournament, they were often more lackluster than impressive, leaving some doubt about what may be college basketballs most complete team.

title: Out of Ruin, Haitis Visionaries
description: In a disaster, you focus on lives first, all else later. When the earthquake hit Haiti in January, the news was about the dead and missing, miraculous survivals, towns smashed to bits.

title: The Thrill of Science, Tamed by Agendas
description: A science museum is a kind of experiment. It demands the most elaborate equipment: Imax theaters, NASA space vehicles, collections of living creatures, digital planetarium projectors, fossilized bones. Into this mix are thrust tens of thousands of living human beings: children on holiday, weary or eager parents, devoted teachers, passionate aficionados and casual passers-by. And the experimenters watch, test, change, hoping. ...

title: Your Reality TV
description: In a new poll, more than 60 percent of respondents said televising Supreme Court proceedings would be good for democracy. We agree, but the court seems determined to keep its work out of the publics eye.

title: The Gowanus Canal
description: To the Editor:

title: A Well-Deserved Oscar
description: To the Editor:

title: Lost in the Shorthand
description: A RECENT New York Times Magazine article about the Texas State Board of Education said it was driven by a bloc determined to advance a Christian agenda.

title: Nascars 190-M.P.H. Beanball
description: Asheville, N.C.

title: Driving Drunk in Jerusalem
description: I am a big Joe Biden fan. The vice president is an indefatigable defender of U.S. interests abroad. So it pains me to say that on his recent trip to Israel, when Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahus government rubbed his nose in some new housing plans for contested East Jerusalem, the vice president missed a chance to send a powerful public signal: He should have snapped his notebook shut, gotten right back on Air Force Two, flown home and left the following scribbled note behind: Message from America to the Israeli government: Friends dont let friends drive drunk. And right now, youre driving drunk. You think you can embarrass your only true ally in the world, to satisfy some domestic political need, with no consequences? You have lost total contact with reality. Call us when youre serious. We need to focus on building our country.

title: A Break in the Action
description: In a welcome distraction from the sneakered treadmill called March Madness, Brendan Olinkiewicz stepped to the foul line for the Shelter Island (N.Y.) Indians. It was the final minute of his final year, and Brendan had never scored a varsity point in his high school career.

title: The Rise of Superbugs and the Abuse of Antibiotics
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Guard of Curators Steps Up
description: THE mouth of a giant monster, its razor-sharp teeth glaring overhead and its tongue forming a long red carpet, ushers visitors into the Tim Burton retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Although the intentionally lighthearted chronicle of the filmmakers work received only mixed reviews when it opened in November, Mr. Burtons fans dont seem to care. More than 450,000 people have already attended the show, and by the time it closes on April 26, attendance is expected to exceed that of recent blockbusters like the museums Van Gogh: The Colors of the Night last year and Dali: Painting and Film, in 2008.

title: New Yorks Met, Replicating Art Works Bit by 3-D Bit
description: JUST off the Astor Court in the Metropolitan Museum of Arts sprawling Asian collections, an unobtrusive door is cut into a white wall, a door most patrons probably never notice. But behind it, up a narrow staircase leading into the oldest part of the museum, one of the newest and most innovative practices in the fields of sculptural conservation and scholarship has been taking shape.

title: Teenage Girls Explore Their Lives Through a Cameras Eye
description: TWO months ago, a dozen teenage girls with no formal photography experience were given professional cameras and told to document their world growing up in New York City. Right away, the results were startling.

title: Rachel Alexandra Loss Imperils Showdown
description: NEW ORLEANS  This was supposed to be an exhibition for Rachel Alexandra, an opportunity for the reigning Horse of the Year to take a lap before an adoring public. She would clear her lungs, limber up her muscles and take another important step toward a showdown with the undefeated mare Zenyatta next month in Arkansas.

title: A Fellow South African Tracks Down Els at Doral
description: DORAL, Fla.  The west-facing windows in the upstairs restaurant at the Doral Resort and Spa give diners a panoramic view of the Blue Monster courses 1st and 18th holes in the W.G.C.-CA Championship. As the tournament director Eddie Carbone looked out at the scene Saturday, he was smiling at the lines of fans streaming onto the course and into the grandstands at the 18th green.

title: Unearthing Lost Treasures in California
description: WHEN the Watts riots swept Los Angeles in 1965, Noah Purifoy, an artist who was in the thick of things as the director of the Watts Towers Arts Center, quickly took to the streets with a friend. Their mission was to gather debris  charred railroad ties, wood from burned-out houses, melted scraps of neon signs and other wreckage that could serve as raw material for sculpture. The resulting artworks soon went on tour throughout the country in a group show, 66 Signs of Neon.

title: Restoring a Museum Piece, a Jungle Gym That Once Flew
description: THE Grumman F9F Cougar had seen better days, some of them flying in Navy fighter squadrons in the 1950s. But then it was retired and ended up spending years in a park in New Jersey as perhaps the worlds coolest jungle gym.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 13, 2010

title: The Best Tour Guide May Be in Your Purse
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Amid the Monets, Setting the Stage for Romance
description: WHEN Blake Cohen decided to propose to his girlfriend, Clarissa Lee, there were a couple of obvious possibilities for popping the question.

title: Long-Separated Portraits, on a Wall Together at Last
description: HARTFORD

title: Your Comments on my Beads Column
description: My Sunday column is about BeadforLife, an organization I first heard about a couple of years ago as a leader in enterprise solutions to poverty. I dont usually write about just one group, but BeadforLife appealed to me both as a great yarn and because they are taking some innovative approaches  such as starting savings accounts, promoting entrepreneurship and of course deworming kids. BeadforLife also tries to listen to Ugandans, measure its results and tweak its model constantly  all good approaches. And of course, it offers Americans a way to get engaged other than just writing checks.

title: Vows: Laura & Josh
description: Laura Freeman and Josh Gordon met at college. Five years later, Josh proposed to Laura at a restaurant in Rome, where tucked inside a dessert menu was a photo album filled with their memories.

title: What, Me Worry? Aceves Plays It Cool
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Alfredo Aceves said he has better things to worry about than how his competition is faring. Like what?

title: Intense Wind and Rain Blast the New York Region
description: A combination of driving winds and intense rains left nearly half a million customers without power, was blamed for three deaths, and created serious obstacles to traveling distances both short and long around the New York metropolitan area on Saturday.

title: Teams on the Bubble Will Hope for the Best
description: When the N.C.A.A. tournament mens field is announced starting at 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, these teams are among those on the edge of their seats.

title: One Analysis of the Google Buzz Mess
description: AUSTIN, Tex. When Google introduced a new social networking feature called Buzz last month, it hoped that users would leap at the chance to share content with the people they e-mailed with most often. But instead, the company found itself facing a firestorm of angry users and awash in criticism from privacy advocates and bloggers.

title: Late Drive Gives West Virginia Its First Big East Title
description: West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins grew up in Midvale, Ohio, where he likes to say there are 500 people, 2 stop lights and 9 bars. His favorite story about the hardscrabble attitude he developed there involves climbing into a locals pickup truck with no rear-view mirrors.

title: In Dallas, a Blueprint Gallinari Can Follow
description: DALLAS  The comparison is imperfect, and the path carved by one is not necessarily navigable by the other. But there are strong similarities in height, skill and pedigree, enough that Dirk Nowitzki may provide Danilo Gallinari with a rough template for N.B.A. success.

title: Dodd to Unveil a Broad Financial Overhaul Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee will unveil on Monday a proposal to revamp the nations financial regulations that would empower shareholders to have advisory votes on executive pay and to nominate directors for the boards of public companies through company proxy ballots, several people briefed on the draft legislation said Saturday.

title: Big Victory for Knicks, if Thats Possible
description: DALLAS  The Knicks banished logic long ago, along with their playoff hopes and their pride, so there was no rational way to explain their sudden passion or the seemingly inverted numbers on the scoreboard Saturday night.

title: Relentless From Start, Pacquiao Retains Title
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As Manny Pacquiao dispatched another welterweight contender in the easy manner of a sparring session, the talk turned immediately and emphatically to Floyd Mayweather Jr. As expected. Once again.

title: No Decision Yet From Tomlinson
description: Running back LaDainian Tomlinson  who spent all day Friday being wooed by the Jets  flew back to San Diego on Saturday to consider his options. Tomlinsons departure was a disappointment for the Jets, who had pulled out all the stops, complete with a tour of the new stadium at the Meadowlands, in hopes of getting him to sign. Tomlinson has also expressed interest in joining the Vikings.

title: Henry Kissinger Is Released From Hospital in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Henry Kissinger, the former United States secretary of state, was released from a hospital on Sunday after treatment for stomach pains, said a spokesman for Yonsei Universitys Severance Hospital in Seoul.

title: The Hoyas Frustrations All Roll Into One Game
description: Austin Freeman, typically a placid presence for Georgetown, slumped his shoulders after one second-half lapse on defense, then grew so agitated the next trip down the court he expressed his disdain for the Hoyas effort vocally and with his hands.

title: An Inauspicious Return to the N.H.L. for Chelios at 48
description: Defenseman Chris Chelios, a 48-year-old veteran of 25 N.H.L. seasons, played in his 26th last week. He was recalled by the Atlanta Thrashers from their Chicago Wolves farm team, where his plus-34 mark was one of the best in the American Hockey League. Chelios is the second-oldest player in league history; Gordie Howe played for Hartford in 1980 at 51.

title: Stage Scenes: Elizabeth Marvel
description: A look at some of the actresss past stage performances.

title: Chinese Leader Defends Currency and Policies
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao sharply defended Chinas currency and trade policies on Sunday against what he called foreign finger pointing, charging instead that developed countries seek to force unfair changes in those policies just for the purposes of increasing their own exports.

title: Matthew Vaughn Takes Action
description: Matthew Vaughn, the director of "Kick-Ass," discusses his approach to the action in the film.

title: State of the Bills: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Flower Power at a Mumbai Market
description: If Mumbais fumes have left you craving a whiff of nature, take a walk through the Dadar flower market, where you can inhale the sharp scent of marigolds and glimpse the immensity of Indias flower trade.

title: Saving Ryans Privatization
description: So, for a few weeks Rep. Paul Ryan was the toast of the punditocracy; his Roadmap was hailed as the serious Republican response to Americas fiscal problems. But it turns out, predictably, to have been a Potemkin plan: it wouldnt balance the budget, even after two generations. What it would do is massively redistribute income upward, raising taxes and slashing benefits for most Americans, while providing huge tax breaks for the top 0.1 percent of the population.

title: Israel, China, America
description: In debates over what to do about Chinas currency manipulation, one constantly hears the refrain that we dont dare alienate the Chinese, because they own so much of our debt. What would happen if they took their dollar holdings, equal to around 10% of US GDP, and switched them into other currencies?

title: Inspiration, on Display
description: ART exhibitions are flourishing across the country. Here is a selection of the latest offerings:

title: Stupid Smelly Mutants
description: Thats the translation one reader proposed when I used the phrase Oderint dum Metuant in a column.

title: Sunday Notebook: Inauspicious Return for Chelios
description: Defenseman Chris Chelios, a 48-year-old veteran of 25 N.H.L. seasons, played in his 26th last week. He was recalled by the Atlanta Thrashers from their Chicago Wolves farm team, where his plus-34 mark was one of the best in the American Hockey League. Chelios is the second-oldest player in league history; Gordie Howe played for Hartford in 1980 at 51.

title: To Attract a Crowd, Scour Your Demographics
description: WHEN the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston wanted to create galleries for a display of Asian art a few years back, it wasnt sure where or how to start.

title: Small Donations in Large Numbers, With Online Help
description: LAST fall, when the Neversink Valley Area Museum in Cuddebackville, N.Y., set out to raise $11,000 for architectural renderings of a new building, museum officials turned to strangers for fund-raising using the Internet.

title: An Arts Crawl, All in a Browser
description: SITTING in the lounge at Heathrow Airport last month, MoMAs chief curator at large and P.S. 1s director, Klaus Biesenbach, did a quick tour of some artists studios, logging on to Studio Visit, a new site that lets artists and collectives exhibit their works on the Web.

title: Groundbreaking Partnership Unites Decades of Research
description: MOST people associate museums with art and artifacts, not research libraries. But many of New Yorks most prestigious museums have extensive collections of books and papers. Four of them  the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum and the Frick Collection  have combined forces to share resources, save money and make their holdings more accessible to the public.

title: The Art of the Deal Helps Spread Great Art
description: LATE last month , the High Museum in Atlanta announced that two masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance  Titians Diana and Actaeon and Diana and Callisto  plus 23 other Venetian works would be coming to town next fall, on loan from the National Galleries of Scotland. It was enough to make art lovers swoon.

title: In Dallas, the Art Is Only Part of the Show
A Conversation With Philippe de Montebello
description: WHEN Philippe de Montebello retired at the end of 2008 after 31 years as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he found himself back where he started: in the classrooms of the Institute of Fine Arts at New York University, the very school where he had earned a masters degree more than 30 years ago.

title: On Safari, Off the Beaten Path in Kansas
description: CHANUTE, Kan.

title: The Sunday Word: Reconciliation Talk
description: The health care debate heads into the fourth quarter Sunday as talk show guests go head-to-head over one of President Obamas top legislative goals.

title: A Master Showmans Old Masters
description: JOHN RINGLING, one of five brothers who created the Ringling Brothers Circus (which later acquired the Barnum & Bailey Circus), was an avid art collector. With a fortune that placed him among the countrys richest men, Mr. Ringling and his wife, Mable, bought thousands of art objects from 1920 to 1930 and created the John and Mable Ringling Museum in Sarasota, Fla., to display them.

title: A Garden With a Profusion of Ideas
description: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa.

title: Breaking Loons
description: Video | From The Onion, old hoarders and other victims of the death of newspapers:

title: A Ferrari 1-2 Victory in Bahrain
description: Updated Monday

title: Diabetes Heart Treatments May Cause Harm
description: Three aggressive treatment strategies doctors had expected would prevent heart attacks among people with Type 2 diabetes and some who are the verge of developing it have proved to be ineffective or even harmful, new studies show.

title: Protests Urge Resignation of Leaders in Thailand
description: BANGKOK  Tens of thousands of protesters poured into Bangkok on Sunday demanding that the government step down in what was one of the largest demonstrations in Thailands recent tumultuous history.

title: Drew Gooden Is Feeling California
description: Since his days as a star at Kansas, Drew Gooden has made an impressive tour of eight N.B.A. teams in eight seasons. In the future, he may want to consider limiting himself to teams that play in California.

title: SXSW: How Kick-Ass Gets Its Kicks
description: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

title: Nine to Know: 20-Game Winners
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives, with his wife (a Red Sox fan) and a daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park.  Bill claims he is Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: Rain and Wind Created a Deadly Storm
description: The scenes of devastation in the New York area were so widespread that some compared what they saw to the worst of natural disasters. Nearly everyone had a storm-related tale, mixing inconvenience and a sense of wonder at forces that effortlessly ripped trees from the ground, roots and all. And there were stories of loss and tragedy.

title: A Ferrari 1-2 Victory in Bahrain
description: From our colleagues at Formula One:

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Grand Homecoming for Canucks
description: Nine games on Saturday, including a vital last-second win in Philadelphia and, in Vancouver, the end of the longest road trip in N.H.L. history. Home teams listed first:

title: Nico Rosberg Receives a Little Help From His Friends
description: SAKHIR, Bahrain  As I walked through the paddock half an hour before the start of the race on Sunday, my peripheral vision and hearing were suddenly accosted by a strange sound and sight. I turned and looked at the back door of the Mercedes garage to see five tall young men in a kind of combination between a rugby scrum and the haka dance of the All-Blacks. They were chanting some strange lyrics and song at the top of their lungs. One of the men was wearing the Mercedes racing outfit and a racing helmet.

title: As Health Vote Awaits, Future of a Presidency Waits, Too
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, had a little political advice last week for President Obama and the Democrats: Dont pass the presidents health care legislation because you would risk losing in the midterm elections.

title: Edward Norton on Edward Norton
description: Playing twins in the action/comedy "Leaves of Grass," Edward Norton discusses his approach to comedic roles.

title: Answers From a Theater Historian, Part III
description: The final installment of answers from Marc Robinson, the author of The American Play: 1787-2000.

title: Senate Republicans Protest Timing of Dodd Bill
description: The Republican members of the Senate Banking Committee on Friday wrote a letter expressing their displeasure with the proposed timetable of Christopher J. Dodd, the committees chairman, for his bill overhauling financial regulation.

title: Giants and Jets Jostle for Hosting Honors at Stadium Opener
description: The Giants and Jets have always been uneasy neighbors and business partners. Now, with the $1-billion-plus stadium they have built together about to open, they cant even agree about how the host for the stadium opener will be determined.

title: Learning From Lehman
description: On top of everything Lehman Brothers did before it collapsed in 2008, nearly toppling the financial system, it now seems that it was aggressively massaging its books.

title: China Issues Warning to Major Partners of Google
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities have warned major partners of Googles China-based search engine that they must comply with censorship laws even if Google does not, an industry expert with knowledge of the notice said Sunday.

title: Fleshing Out Life in Remote China
description: There are documentaries that set out to explain the world, to shape the chaos of experience into coherent stories or compelling arguments. This kind of movie  dominant just now in American nonfiction filmmaking  performs the journalistic work of advocacy, investigating problems and engaging the sympathy or the outrage of viewers.

title: Lessons in Love From the London Stage
description: 12:55 p.m. | Updated  LONDON  To watch Judi Dench fall in love these days is to fall in love all over again with Judi Dench. True, the object of her affection may be  not to put too fine a point on it  an ass. But playing Titania in Peter Halls hit production of A Midsummer Nights Dream at the Rose Theater here, Ms. Dench makes it clear that in acting, what really counts isnt whom one loves but how one loves.

title: Alice Wins the Box Office Weekend
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood suffered its first major flop of the year over the weekend with the debut of the expensive Iraq thriller Green Zone, which sold an anemic $14.5 million in tickets at North American theaters.

title: Parsing Premier Wen
description: So, heres what I understand from Wen Jiabao: America must avoid a double-dip recession while also eliminating its budget deficits and, of course, doing nothing to weaken the dollar  because unlike China, we only want a weak currency so as to increase our exports.

title: Powerless Princeton
description: Or so I hear. Trees down, no electricity for the next few days, a total mess.

title: A Stunning Landscape, Seen Mostly From Afar
description: Interminably gorgeous and tediously impressive.

title: Cooperative Energy, Complete With Crowd Surfing
description: The choreographer Juliette Mapp, the current guest curator of Danspace Projects Platform 2010 initiative, has emphasized the importance of presenting an intergenerational array of artists in Back to New York City. This week the inimitable octogenarian Elaine Summers arrives; last Thursday the youngsters had the run of the place, when Katy Pyle and Jen Rosenblit, both in their 20s, presented new work.

title: Netanyahu Offers Apology, but No Shift in Policy
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told his cabinet on Sunday that the ill-timed announcement of new housing plans for a Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem during a visit by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. last week had been regrettable and hurtful.

title: From the Top of the World: Warmth Amid Ice
description: In its Perspectives programs Carnegie Hall encourages the musicians in the spotlight  the composers, soloists or ensembles in charge of each series  to present not only their own work but also other music that fascinates them. For an omnivorous ensemble like the Kronos Quartet, that invitation was bound to be a boon to listeners with adventurous tastes. You can see from the groups repertory that its collective interests are stylistically borderless.

title: 20 Years of Babies and Cheerleaders
description: For any dance company working in New York reaching the 20-year mark is no small feat. For the choreographer Jody Oberfelder such an anniversary is occasion to look back in a two-act program, Heads or Tales, which highlights dances created throughout her career. Lesson learned: Perhaps the only thing Ms. Oberfelder cares about more than a cartwheel is a headstand.

title: At Home With Disney and Miss Saigon
description: A bright, utilitarian voice that sweeps across continents as it conjures the aspirations of the inner princesses in millions of nice young women from Manila to London: no, its not Celine Dion, but Lea Salonga, the demure 39-year-old Philippine star whose autobiographical show, The Journey So Far, opened a three-week engagement at Caf Carlyle on Tuesday evening.

title: Microtonal Fluctuation in Moods of All Colors
description: There was microtonal mayhem at Bargemusic on Friday night during the adventurous Flux Quartets performance in the Here and Now series.

title: Bizarro Health Reform Arguments
description: As health reform moves to its final, make or break vote  I think its going to go through, but Ill be hanging on by my fingernails all week  Republicans are still denouncing it as a vast, evil government takeover. But they have a problem: Obamacare is very much like the Massachusetts health reform, which was not only implemented by a Republican governor, but by a governor who is a serious contender for the 2012 presidential nomination.

title: Selection Sunday: Mens N.C.A.A. Tournament Field
description: 9:51 p.m. |Analyzing the Field

title: Argentines Take Lebhar Title Thanks to a Second-Day Surge
description: The two-day Lebhar Imp Pairs was won on Saturday at the Spring Nationals in Reno, Nev., by Pablo Lambardi and Pablo Ravenna from Argentina. They only just qualified for the second day but then scored 89.7 international match points to take a 38.88-imp lead into the final session. They gained another 24.95 imps to win by 15.42 over Jon Baldursson and Thorlakur Jonsson from Iceland. Third were Nader Hanna and Robert Lebi from Canada.

title: Investors Who Foresaw the Meltdown
description: The global financial crisis of 2008, which economists estimate could result in several trillion dollars of losses and which has already cost American taxpayers billions of dollars in government bailouts, was triggered not by war or recession but by a crazy, man-made money machine, built on flawed mathematical models that most financial executives did not really understand themselves. Greedy and heedless, Wall Street firms had been turning subprime mortgages  loans made to people with low creditworthiness or little documentation  into exotic, toxic financial products that they made a fortune laundering and reselling, and they were enabled in doing so by the very ratings agencies that were supposed to police risk. The insanity of this growing and highly leveraged trade in mortgage derivatives continued even as the quality of the underlying loans grew increasingly dubious, even as it became increasingly likely that the American housing bubble was going to pop.

title: Square Dancing
description: I bet I can guess your favorite math subject in high school.

title: Panic in Georgia After a Mock News Broadcast
description: MOSCOW  Some people placed emergency calls reporting heart attacks, others rushed in a panic to buy bread and residents of one border village staggered from their homes and dashed for safety  all after a television station in Georgia broadcast a mock newscast on Saturday night that pretended to report on a Russian invasion of the country.

title: Storm Sweeps Through Metropolitan Region
description: Crews swept across the metropolitan region to remove fallen trees and to restore power to several hundred thousand homes following a devastating storm.

title: New CDs
description: GORILLAZ

title: Maastricht Treasure Hunt Lures Collectors
description: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands  This small Dutch city may be known for its winding cobblestone streets, quaint town square and a church dating as far back as the sixth century, but it is also home to a cavernous convention center where, every March, about 70,000 art lovers flock for the European Fine Art Fair. A supersize event in many ways, this years edition has been notable for a few standout sales amid the absence of big-ticket items.

title: Two Drug Slayings in Mexico Rock U.S. Consulate
description: LA UNIN, Mexico  Gunmen believed to be linked to drug traffickers shot a pregnant American consulate worker and her husband to death in the violence-racked border town of Ciudad Jurez over the weekend, leaving their baby wailing in the back seat of their car, the authorities said Sunday. The gunmen also killed the husband of another consular employee and wounded his two young children.

title: Metal Variety: Death, Doom, Black and Cars
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Yob, the three-man doom-metal band from Eugene, Ore., played a show here at Skullys on Saturday night that left you wondering when youd heard something as good, and when you might again. It was all graceful molasses cohesion, moving in focused minor-key riffs and strong processional grooves from the bassist Aaron Reiseberg and the drummer Travis Foster, lighted up by Mike Scheidts fat, fuzzed guitar tone. His solos were creeping abstraction with a plan, an almost visual display of cathedral-echo notes, bending and decaying and transforming.

title: One Is Not Enough
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Fred Piscop is back with another Monday puzzle and Im here to give you my 20 cents worth. Thats enough to cover inflation and, fitting in with todays theme, its a PARADIGMS. What, I cant do those jokes too?

title: Super Race Is Off, and Its a Wise Decision
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Browns Send Quinn to Broncos
description: Remember how bright the future looked for the Cleveland Browns two years ago, when they had Derek Anderson coming off a Pro Bowl season and a first-round draft pick in Brady Quinn waiting in the wings?

title: At the Corner of Grit and Glamour
description: During the past few years Chelsea became a one-stop-shopping destination for high-style contemporary architecture as well as high-end art, and the results can be depressing. For every significant building that went up, the neighborhood seemed to produce a half-dozen or so inferior knockoffs. The feeling on the streets now is the same as it is in most of the galleries: the sheer amount of work, and the mediocrity of most of it, can make the effort of sorting out the good from the bad too painful to contemplate.

title: GLAAD Media Awards Honor Behar and Nixon
description: Joy Behar and Cynthia Nixon were among the honorees at the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamations media awards in New York on Saturday night. The top award for excellence in media was presented to Ms. Behar, a host of The View on ABC and The Joy Behar Show on the HLN network, for her contributions to increasing the visibility of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people. Ms. Nixon received the Vito Russo Award, given to an openly lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender media professional who has promoted equal rights. Honors also went to ABCs Brothers and Sisters for outstanding drama series, and Lifetimes Prayers for Bobby, starring Sigourney Weaver and Ryan Kelley, above, for outstanding television movie or mini-series. Other winners included Colman Domingos Boy and His Soul, for Broadway and Off Broadway theater, and The New York Times, which received an award for overall newspaper coverage, as well as prizes for the writers Frank Rich, Tara Parker-Pope and Benoit Denizet-Lewis.

title: Royal Opera in London to Stage Anna Nicole
description: According to the BBC, the Royal Opera House in London plans to stage the world premiere of Anna Nicole, based on the life of the former Playboy model Anna Nicole Smith, right, who went from impoverished Texas waitress to oil tycoons widow to reality television celebrity. The new work is from the composer Mark-Anthony Turnage and the writer Richard Thomas, a creator of Jerry Springer: The Opera. The BBC reported that Mr. Thomas said the production would end with Smiths death, from a prescription-drug overdose in February 2007 in the midst of lawsuits over her husbands fortune and the paternity of her daughter. The production is scheduled to open on Feb. 17 with the Dutch soprano Eva-Maria Westbroek in the lead and Antonio Pappano conducting.

title: Avatar: Release and Repeat
description: Avatar may soon be booked for a second run at digital and Imax 3-D theaters this summer. According to The Hollywood Reporter, James Cameron is in discussions with Fox to work out a re-release of the film, possibly with additional scenes that were cut from the original. In New York on Thursday, Imaxs chief executive, Richard L. Gelfond, said that Mr. Cameron had about 40 minutes of extra material. Only about 10 minutes of film could be added, though, to keep under the 170-minute maximum length a movie can be released in analog Imax theaters. But that is just the amount Mr. Cameron has said he could easily push through postproduction for a directors cut or for the DVD release, including a scene in which Jake Sully further proves himself to the Navi people, and another surrounding a native festival. Avatar was taken out of 3-D theaters to make way for the opening of Disneys Alice in Wonderland. At a demonstration of 3-D TV in New York last week, Mr. Cameron told USA Today, The word were getting back from exhibitors is we probably left a couple hundred million dollars on the table as a result.

title: Judi Dench Memoir Is Set for October
description: It only makes sense that Judi Dench, below, after accumulating a lifetimes worth of theater, film and television credits that could easily fill a book, should finally write one. St. Martins Press said it had acquired a memoir from Ms. Dench, called And Furthermore, that described her professional and private lives, according to a press release from the publisher. Though she has lately come to be known for her role as M in the James Bond franchise, and as Queen Elizabeth in Shakespeare in Love (for which she won an Academy Award for just a few minutes of screen time), Ms. Dench covers the breadth of her acting career in the memoir, from her start with the Old Vic theater company in 1957. St. Martins plans to publish And Furthermore in October.

title: Permitted to Play, Avery Fuels Rangers
description: The enigmatic legend of Sean Avery grew a little larger Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

title: In the Wings
description: The producers of Glee Live! In Concert! have added shows to tour dates, Playbill reported. In New York a matinee on May 28 and an evening performance on May 30 have been added to Radio City Music Hall dates, while in Los Angeles an additional matinee and evening show have been scheduled for May 22 at the Gibson Amphitheater. ... Emerging Artists Theater has announced the return of Penny Penniworth, Charles Dickenss lost epic, by Chris Weikel. Performances of this limited Off Broadway run will be Sept. 8 through Oct. 3 at TADA Theater on West 28th Street in Manhattan (emergingartiststheatre.org). ... Second extensions have been announced for Jonathan Reynoldss Girls in Trouble (now running through April 11 at the Flea Theater in TriBeCa) and for The Jackie Look, with Karen Finley (through April 24 at the Laurie Beechman Theater in Manhattan).

title: Disney Cost-Cutting Fells Zemeckis Company
description: Walt Disney Studios on Friday pulled the plug on ImageMovers Digital, the motion-capture company run by Robert Zemeckis, above right, the latest in a string of cost-cutting moves. ImageMovers Digital, which is based near San Francisco and employs 450 people, will slowly wind down production during the next few months. Mr. Zemeckiss Christmas Carol was a big disappointment for Disney, and despite his pioneering work in motion-capture technology, he has been leapfrogged in the genre by James Cameron and Avatar. But Disney said that two extensive movie projects from Mr. Zemeckis, the comedy Mars Needs Moms! and a remake of Yellow Submarine, would move ahead.

title: Tomlinson Agrees to Join Jets
description: When LaDainian Tomlinson completed his visit with the Minnesota Vikings last Thursday, he left with a Vikings jersey in hand. On Sunday, he accepted something of far greater value from the Jets  a two-year contract to become their newest running back and perhaps complete his Hall of Fame career with them.

title: Livingstons Comeback Is Bright Spot for Wizards
description: WASHINGTON  The Washington Wizards season has long been disappointing, disheartening and even felonious (see: Arenas, Gilbert; Trades; Salary Purging). But for a fan base seeking any glimmer of hope, there is one in the comeback of Shaun Livingston, the prodigy point guard whose career was derailed by devastating injuries.

title: A Smidgen of Sympathy for a Diva on the Skids
description: A previously unknown Tallulah Bankhead  the fabulous monster as crackerjack comic  is revealed to the world in Matthew Lombardos play Looped, which stars Valerie Harper as that troubled actress in her twilight moments. As she lurches around the recording studio where the play is set in 1965, unable to finish the last bit of work on what will prove to be her final film, Tallulah barks out punch lines with the skill of a stand-up comic with decades of Borscht Belt experience, despite the half-bottle of Scotch flowing through her veins.

title: Night Lights, Blankets and Lullabies
description: I remember a lamp that stood on the floor in the opened doorway to the bedroom where my sister Liv and I slept. My mother put it there every night so the darkness would never be total. This is an old memory and around it are the usual fogs that dim recollection, but the light offered the hope that blackness would not snuff out the visible world entirely during my anxious transition to sleep.

title: A Plan in Britain to Block Sites Offering Pirated Music
description: To the consternation of Internet companies and civil liberties groups, lawmakers in Britain are seeking to punish those who illegally copy music.

title: Socialists Lead in Early Voting in France
description: PARIS  The governing party of President Nicolas Sarkozy appeared to be beaten by the opposition Socialists on Sunday in a first round of regional elections marked by a record abstention, according to partial official results released Sunday night.

title: Report Faults U.S.s Efforts at Transparency
description: WASHINGTON  In his first full day at the White House almost 14 months ago, President Obama declared openness and transparency to be touchstones of his administration, and he ordered federal agencies to make it easier for the public to get information on the workings of government.

title: Shaken Afghan City Seeks More Support From Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A day after five lethal bombs shook Kandahar, officials appealed Sunday to the central government to send more security forces and expand intelligence gathering in the southern province, underscoring the increasing violence and lawlessness in the city.

title: Duplicating Federal Videos for an Online Archive
description: WASHINGTON  Dust off a disc. Maybe its video of a Bob Hope Christmas show, or maybe its the Apollo 11 moon landing. Insert a blank disc. Duplicate.

title: The Push-Back on Charter Schools
description: Two recent New York Times articles have described opposition to the thriving charter school movement in Harlem. An influential state senator, Bill Perkins, whose district has nearly 20 charter schools, is trying to block their expansion. Some public schools  in the neighborhood are also fighting back, marketing themselves  to compete with the charters.

title: A PBS Offering, Earth Days, Will Be Seen on Facebook First
description: PBSs American Experience has sent its documentary Earth Days on a film festival and 40-city theatrical tour for the last year, before its television broadcast in April. Now the 102-minute film about the origins of the American environmental movement, from director Robert Stone, is planning for another outlet, a presentation on the social networking site Facebook. Users will be able to watch communally and interact with the filmmaker and the American Experience executive producer Mark Samels in real time.

title: Pacquiaos Focus Turns From Boxing to Politics
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The future of Manny Pacquiao  in politics, in boxing, in acting, singing or whatever whim he pursues next  remains clouded. Even his proposed megafight against Floyd Mayweather Jr. stands on shaky footing, far from reality despite worldwide intrigue.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Nears Deal for Tommy Hilfiger
description: Phillips-Van Heusen, the big clothing conglomerate that owns Calvin Klein, is near a deal to buy Tommy Hilfiger, once a leading purveyor of colorful preppy clothing, for about 2.2 billion euros ($3 billion) in cash and stock, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday night.

title: Tallying the Votes in Iraq
description: As the Iraqi election authorities trickle out results from the March 7 parliamentary election, delays, allegations of fraud and conspiracy theories are fueling public frustration.

title: Frustration Grows in Iraq at Slow Pace of Vote Tally
description: BAGHDAD  At a vote-counting center in eastern Baghdad, a dozen men representing various political parties sat on a stage in a school gymnasium on Sunday, monitoring the counting of ballots.

title: To Stop Crime, Share Your Genes
description: New Haven

title: New Jersey Schools Brace for Governors Next Round of Cuts
description: LINDEN, N.J.  When classes let out at 3 p.m., 85 children in a state-subsidized program at Lindens School No. 1 head down the hall for three more hours of reading, math games, homework help and stepping lessons.

title: In N.C.A.A. Pools, Picking Underdogs Is Overrated
description: Some people think that the way to win the office pool in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament is to pick the promising underdogs to win  and they believe they know which underdogs to pick. But two psychology professors have this advice for them: dont bet on it.

title: Beckhams Achilles Tendon Totally Torn, According to Surgeon
description: Mon., March 15, 3:56 p.m. |Update: Totally Torn

title: Taking On China
description: Tensions are rising over Chinese economic policy, and rightly so: Chinas policy of keeping its currency, the renminbi, undervalued has become a significant drag on global economic recovery. Something must be done.

title: Bees in the City? New York May Let the Hives Come Out of Hiding
description: Kathleen Boyer suspects the mailman.

title: Kentucky Keeps Emotions, and Opponents, in Check
description: NASHVILLE  After back-to-back games in a rowdy atmosphere at the Southeastern Conference mens tournament, No. 2 Kentucky looks less fragile. The Wildcats, who depend on several freshmen who are wound with emotion, could have come unhinged many times this weekend but managed themselves in the tournament caldron.

title: With Financial Reform Bill, a Test for Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats will press forward this week on legislation to overhaul the nations financial system in a critical test of whether Washington can pass reform.

title: Bidders Lined Up for a Casino in the Future
description: With Albanys dysfunction searing their fortunes and reputations, why is the same small group of companies insistent on trying to build and run a slot machine casino at a rundown racetrack in southern Queens?

title: City Tries to Shut Club It Says Flouts Smoking Ban
description: The Bloomberg administration is moving closer to shutting one of the largest and busiest nightclubs in the city, as part of an aggressive new strategy to revoke the operating licenses of clubs that health officials believe promote smoking.

title: Political Levers Lock Into Gear in Election Year
description: CAIRO  Egypts parliamentary elections are still months away, but the arrests have already started.

title: A Quiet Evening, Waiting for the Next Angry Man
description: WASHINGTON

title: Saving U.S. Water and Sewer Systems Would Be Costly
description: WASHINGTON  One recent morning, George S. Hawkins, a long-haired environmentalist who now leads one of the largest and most prominent water and sewer systems, trudged to a street corner here where water was gushing into the air.

title: China Uses Rules on Global Trade to Its Advantage
description: HONG KONG  With Chinas exports soaring, even as other major economies struggle to recover from the recession, evidence is mounting that Beijing is skillfully using inconsistencies in international trade rules to spur its own economy at the expense of others, including the United States.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 14, 2010

title: More Than Onerous
description: After a year of national debate, a handful of House Democrats who oppose abortion may be the ones to decide whether health care reform goes forward or not.

title: The Feds Responsibility
description: Congress passed legislation last year intended to protect consumers from the credit card industrys most deceptive and unfair practices. The main provisions finally went into effect last month. But the Federal Reserve still has to write new rules intended to stop companies from bleeding customers dry with exorbitant fees for late payments, with charges for exceeding the credit limit, or with any other penalty fee or charge. Under the statute, the Fed must write rules to ensure that these fees and charges are reasonable and proportional.

title: For Philippine Family in Politics, Land Issue Hits Home
More Parity Atop the Bracket, but Less Talent on the Bubble
description: The N.C.A.A. revealed the 65-team field for its mens basketball tournament on Sunday amid vigorous discussions about significantly changing this rite of March by adding 31 teams. Yet the assembling of this years field was perhaps defined by the undistinguished nature of the teams on the tournaments bubble.

title: Citys Public Housing Agency Gets $305 Million in Aid
description: The citys largest landlord has secured desperately needed financing that could help steer it out of the red.

title: Telling Friends Where You Are (or Not)
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  As Jordan Viator roams the conference rooms, dimly lit bars and restaurants here at the South by Southwest Interactive conference, she often pulls out her cellphone and uses the Foursquare service to broadcast her location.

title: Yoga License Rebellion May Soon Claim Victory
description: When the state notified yoga studios that the instruction of yoga teachers would soon fall under government oversight, the last thing it expected was a battle.

title: Serious Study in the Bars of Hoboken
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: Woman Is the Youngest to Cross an Ocean Alone
description: Katie Spotz completed her mission Sunday, becoming the youngest person to row an entire ocean solo, and the first American to row a boat without help from mainland to mainland. After 70 days 5 hours 22 minutes in the Atlantic, Spotz, 22, arrived Sunday in Georgetown, Guyana, in South America.

title: Jets Say Thanks to Jones  in Kansas City Newspaper
description: The bad news for running back Thomas Jones: The Jets wanted him to take a pay cut after he rushed for more than 1,400 yards last season and when he declined to do so, they cut him. Now, hes with the rebuilding Kansas City Chiefs instead of a team that made it to the A.F.C. Championship game last season.

title: Millions Spent to Sway Democrats on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  The yearlong legislative fight over health care is drawing to a frenzied close as a multimillion-dollar wave of advertising that rivals the ferocity of a presidential campaign takes aim at about 40 House Democrats whose votes will help determine the fate of President Obamas top domestic priority.

title: Forget Goofing Around: Recess Has a New Boss
description: NEWARK  At Broadway Elementary School here, there is no more sitting around after lunch. No more goofing off with friends. No more doing nothing.

title: Trade Papers Struggling in Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES  Variety, the show business bible, was born nearly 105 years ago when young Sime Silverman, by his own account, was fired by The Morning Telegraph for a review in which he declared a new theatrical sketch by a performer who happened to be one of the papers advertisers N. G. (No Good).

title: Make the Bracket Big Enough for Everyone to Have a Shot
description: Floyd Kerr was halfway back from his trip to Winston-Salem, N.C., on Sunday, on schedule to reach Baltimore just in time for the Selection Sunday broadcast.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about pensions in Europe gave an incorrect figure for Germanys current debt as a percentage of gross domestic product. It is 71.9 percent, as the accompanying chart said, not 69 percent.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article on Tuesday about the publication of a book containing about 250 of the more than one million condolence letters received by Jacqueline Kennedy following the assassination of her husband misspelled the surname of the photographer. He was Robert Knudsen, not Kundsen.

title: A Cable Powers Global Reach
description: Rupert Murdochs deputy, Chase Carey, looked out on the cable television landscape last fall and found a rival he wanted to emulate. Discovery Communications, he said, is a road map of where Id like to be.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column on Friday about technology that allows marketers to direct instant online ads at specific Web users misspelled the given name of a Google executive in some editions. He is Neal  not Neil  Mohan.

title: Talking Back to Your TV, Incessantly
description: Back in 1988, Joel Hodgson, a funny guy in Minneapolis, came up with a local television show called Mystery Science Theater 3000. In the goofy plot, a janitor was launched into space by a couple of evil scientists and marooned there, forced to watch an endless run of exceptionally bad B-movies.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Whats On Today television highlights on Wednesday about Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers movies on the Turner Classic Movies channel misidentified the film in which the song Cheek to Cheek is performed. It is Top Hat, not The Gay Divorce.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about new research on Alzheimers disease referred incorrectly to a substance used in an experiment to determine whether the protein beta amyloid  a chief villain in Alzheimers  also had a role in fighting infection. As noted in the articles previous sentence, the substance, Candida albicans, is a yeast, not a bacterium.

title: Deal Is Near for the Sale of Hilfiger
description: Phillips-Van Heusen, the clothing conglomerate that owns Calvin Klein, is near a deal to buy Tommy Hilfiger, once a leading purveyor of colorful preppy clothing, for about 2.2 billion euros, or $3 billion, in cash and stock, people briefed on the matter said Sunday night.

title: Cactus League Cluster Has a Cozy Feel
description: Bob Apodaca, the pitching coach for the Colorado Rockies, moved through the autograph line outside the clubhouse door at Hi Corbett Field in Tucson earlier this month. He signed for everybody, posing for photographs and making small talk.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Willie Davis, who succeeded Duke Snider as the Los Angeles Dodgers center fielder, erroneously credited Davis with franchise records in several categories. His career totals in those categories were records for the Los Angeles Dodgers only, not for the Dodger franchise, which was originally located in Brooklyn. Zack Wheat, not Davis, holds the franchise records for hits, at-bats, triples and total bases; Pee Wee Reese holds the record for runs; Duke Snider holds the record for extra-base hits. The obituary also incorrectly described one of Daviss World Series accomplishments. He stole three bases in one game in the 1965 Series, not three bases in one inning.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Peter Graves, Mission: Impossible Star, Dies at 83
description: Peter Graves, the cool spymaster of televisions Mission: Impossible and the dignified host of the Biography series, who successfully spoofed his own gravitas in the Airplane! movie farces, died on Sunday. He was 83.

title: Complaints About Banks Soar. Odd?
description: Consumers filed 42 percent more complaints about banks last year than they did in 2008, according to the Council of Better Business Bureaus. That is a highly unusual rise in complaints; the only two industries that generated more complaints last year  cellphone and television providers  had only single-digit increases over 2008.

title: Obama Administration Pushes Back on Abortion Claims
description: The abortion issue in the health care debate has mostly focused on how to prevent federal money from being used to pay for insurance coverage for the procedure. But in recent weeks, groups that want to outlaw abortion have sought to build opposition to the legislation by asserting that it would also expand the availability of abortions through government-financed community health centers.

title: Contractors Tied to Effort to Track and Kill Militants
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Under the cover of a benign government information-gathering program, a Defense Department official set up a network of private contractors in Afghanistan and Pakistan to help track and kill suspected militants, according to military officials and businessmen in Afghanistan and the United States.

title: A Brief, but Failed, Pass at Bipartisanship
description: In 1981, as Christopher J. Dodd reached the Senate, two members of the Harvard Negotiation Project published the best seller Getting to Yes.

title: Improving Rail Service in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Its My Party, and You Have to Answer
description: Hartford

title: Haitis Do-It-Yourself Recovery
description: Port-au-Prince, Haiti

title: Letters to J.F.K.s Widow
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywoods Political Fictions
description: Americans believe in evil, but were uncomfortable with tragedy. We accept that there are wicked people in the world, with malice in their hearts and a devil whispering in their ears. But the idea that many debacles flow from choices made by decent, well-intentioned human beings is more difficult for us to wrap our minds around.

title: Taxi-Sharing in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: The Gowanus Canal Cleanup: A Community View
description: To the Editor:

title: The Early Release of Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: In Tomlinson, Jets Add Another Big Name and Security for Backfield
description: When LaDainian Tomlinson completed his visit with the Minnesota Vikings last Thursday, he left with a Vikings jersey in hand. On Sunday, he accepted something of far greater value from the Jets  a two-year contract to become their newest running back and perhaps complete his Hall of Fame career with them.

title: A.I.G. May Cut Bonuses by About 30%
description: The American International Group will pay about $46 million in retention bonuses on Monday, or about 30 percent less than previously scheduled, a person with direct knowledge of the arrangements said.

title: Accounts, People & Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: The Verb Treatment for an Investment House
description: COMPUTER users searching online for information say they are Googling. Commercials running in states like Michigan and Ohio suggest that shoppers go Krogering. But what will investors make of a campaign that proposes they start Vanguarding?

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include industrial production for February (Monday); import prices for February and housing starts for February (Tuesday); producer price index for February (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims, consumer price index for February, fourth-quarter current account deficit, Conference Board leading economic indicators for February, and Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index (Thursday).

title: This TV Station Could Be Yours for $550,000
description: You dont need pockets as deep as Comcasts to get into the TV business. Or even be a millionaire, apparently.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: With Maine as Linchpin, Rotation Remains a Mystery
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Of the many questions surrounding the Mets pitching staff, John Maine remains one of the biggest. Johan Santana and Oliver Perez, like Maine, are returning from injuries that cut short their seasons last year. But they have long-term contracts, more dominating pitches and expectations of throwing like aces.

title: Robert Carter, Priest and Gay Activist, Dies at 82
description: The Rev. Robert Carter, who in the early 1970s was one of the first Roman Catholic priests in the country to declare publicly that he was gay and who helped found the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, died on Feb. 22 in the Bronx. He was 82.

title: Auditor Could Face Liability in Lehman Case
description: Lehman Brothers may have collapsed a year and a half ago, but fallout from its demise has created a potential legal liability for its former accounting firm, Ernst & Young.

title: Robert Rodriguez on 'Predators'
description: Robert Rodriguez, the producer of "Predators," previewed some of the film at SXSW and discussed some of the new characters.

title: Most Online News Readers Use 5 Sites or Fewer, Study Says
description: The audience for news online tends not to stick to a single site  that much has been known for years. But a new study says that even with a vast array of digital choices, promiscuous news consumption goes only so far.

title: Deal for South American Oil Fields Extends Chinas Global Quest for Energy
description: Cnooc, Chinas top offshore oil explorer, said on Sunday that it had secured a South American beachhead by agreeing to pay $3.1 billion in cash for a stake in one of the largest Argentine oil explorers, with fields in Argentina, Bolivia and Chile.

title: A Book Attacking Capitalism Gets Sales Help From a Fox Host
description: Revolutionary movements do not spread by contamination but by resonance, write the anonymous authors of The Coming Insurrection, a call to overthrow capitalism that first appeared in France in 2005 and was recently published in translation in the United States.

title: A National Measure, Inextricably Enmeshed With Local Interests
description: WASHINGTON  Take a glance at the political map, and it makes perfect sense that President Obama will open the most critical week in his push for major health care legislation with a visit on Monday to the Walter F. Ehrnfelt Recreation and Senior Center, in Strongsville, Ohio.

title: In Ending a Slump, Els Merges Past and Present
description: DORAL, Fla.  Every time things became tight Sunday  and there were several  Ernie Els did what he used to do back when the living was easy and he was a dominant player in his 20s and his 30s, winning tournaments and hoisting trophies around the world. He gathered himself, summoned the resolve that defined him and did what had to be done to win.

title: Skype Is Poised for a Big Initial Stock Offering
description: Skype looks to be Silicon Valleys best hope for a blockbuster initial stock offering in 2010. With Facebook apparently determined to stay private until next year, Skype is in prime position to steal the scene with a quick flip. Moreover, as a result of clarifying copyright issues and rewriting its code to attack the business market, the company may be worth twice the $2.75 billion it was valued at when eBay sold all but 30 percent of its stake in Skype last year.

title: A.I.G. May Cut Bonuses by About 30%
description: The American International Group will pay about $46 million in retention bonuses on Monday, or about 30 percent less than previously scheduled, a person with direct knowledge of the arrangements said, Mary Williams Walsh reported in The New York Times.

title: In Lehman Report, a Vindication of Short-Sellers?
description: The Lehman Brothers bankruptcy examiner must be popular at the hedge fund Greenlight Capital, Reuters Breakingviews says. David Einhorn, the funds founder, had criticized the Wall Street firms finances and accounting before it failed in September 2008.

title: Australia Welcomes China Report on Rio Tinto Deal
description: Australia on Monday welcomed a report by China clearing Rio Tinto and the Australian government of blame for the collapse of a $19.5 billion tie-up between Chinalco and Rio Tinto last June, Reuters reported.

title: Progress Expected on Rescue Plan for Greece
description: When finance ministers from the 16 euro-zone countries meet Monday to discuss loan guarantees or loans for Greece, they are expected to strike a delicate balance by giving much-needed clarity on how a bailout could be structured while not making a rescue inevitable, Stephen Castle reports in The New York Times.

title: Arrow Energy May Reject $3 Billion Bid
description: Arrow Energy of Australia plans to reject a $3 billion joint takeover offer from Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina as too low, the Australian Financial Review reported. Analysts said that move could prompt the bidders to return with a higher, hostile bid.

description: Goldman Sachs Group and JPMorgan Chase, two of the biggest traders of over-the-counter derivatives, are exploiting their growing clout in that market to secure cheap funding in addition to billions in revenue from the business, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Book Review: Investors Who Saw Crisis Coming
description: The global financial crisis of 2008, which economists estimate could result in several trillion dollars of losses and which has already cost American taxpayers billions of dollars in government bailouts, was triggered not by war or recession, but by a crazy, man-made money machine, built on flawed mathematical models that most financial executives did not really understand themselves, The New York Timess Michiko Kakutani writes in her review of Michael Lewiss new book The Big Short: Inside the Doomsday Machine.

description: UBS, the Swiss bank that last month reported a third consecutive annual loss, paid 54.9 million Swiss francs ($51.8 million) in bonuses and other awards to executive board members for 2009, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Trichet Sides With Advocates of Crackdown
description: With political momentum building in Europe to crack down on what many see as risky financial practices, the European Central Bank president, Jean-Claude Trichet, threw his weight behind the movement Friday by forcefully criticizing the banking industry, The New York Timess Jack Ewing and Julia Werdigier reported.

title: The Originals | Gary Card
description: I had a lot of fun with child kidnapping, says the set designer, illustrator and T contributor Gary Card, speaking of his recent campaign for Comme des Garons that involved adapting dark Victorian childrens stories. And people turning into horses and slugs and things  that got my imagination ticking. The London-based Card, 28, covers the High Street with clients that include Liberty, Stella McCartney, Adidas, Herms and Top Shop. What I love about my job is I have the opportunity to make both art and commercial products, and something else that can be a little bit stranger and more off-beat, he says. In a recent foray into fine art at the London gallery Spring Projects, he exhibited a gigantic cave made out of white Plasticine, which was then sculpted into 3,000 tiny headsso you walked through this strange vortex of little white faces staring at you. In appearance, Card suggests a cross between David Hockney and the British avant-garde pop star Patrick Wolf. But the creative chameleon, who wants to design furniture next, shrugs off the comparison. My personal style is whatever I find on the floor, really.

The effort failed when it was opposed by state officials beholden to car-owning commuters. Below, you can read a Dot Earth postcard from Mr. Komanoff, describing his experience there (he shot the photo in a traffic jam):

title: Tribeca Film Festival Adds Movies From Gibney, Winterbottom, Burns and Turlington Burns

On Monday the New York festival announced that among the films it had added to its lineup were new works by Edward Burns (The Brothers McMullen) and his wife, Christy Turlington Burns. Fortunately for the couple, the two movies wont be in competition with each other: Mr. Burnss film Nice Guy Johnny, a comedy-drama about a young man and his uncle, will play in the festivals Encounters program; Ms. Turlington Burnss documentary No Woman, No Cry, which tells stories of childbirth from around the world, will be shown in its Discovery program.

In the latest case, a claim by a professor at the University of Nottingham in England that he has found proof that a play from the 1700s contains reworked material of Shakespeares has gained a qualified endorsement from the Arden Shakespeare, a scholarly anthology of that playwrights work.
