title: The Originals | Telfar Clemens
description: A boyhood spent in Liberia seems like one of the least exotic things about the 25-year-old designer and D.J. Telfar Clemens, a minimalist who has found inspiration in the strangeness closer to home. It was really weird  its like a melting pot of every different culture, Telfar says of LeFrak City, Queens, where he was born. My family still lives in the same apartment. The development was originally 100 percent Jewish, so theres a lot of black and Jewish mix. And Red Hook, Brooklyn, where he currently lives, has kind of like an urban pirate feel, he says. Somehow those influences come out in his designs as unisex garments made from soft jersey fabric that practically snuggle with the body. My work is utilitarian, he says. Anyone can put it on, female or male, and everything is adjustable so you can tie it in a different way for a different body type. Clemenss signature line, as well as his diffusion range, Un.Der T, are available in downtown boutiques and will soon be sold on telfar.net. Coming up for the man who gave the world a two-piece unisex swimsuit? Ive always been into sportswear, but I really want to incorporate sportswear with formal wear this season.

title: Story Lines to Watch: The 1 and the 16
description: Their N.C.A.A. pedigrees could not be much more different  a No. 1 seed that is a perennial figure in the tournament and the vagabond No. 16 seed making its N.C.A.A. tournament debut  but Arkansas-Pine Bluffs reward if it wins the play-in game will be a date with top-seeded Duke.

title: More on Mommy Blogs
description: When three huge oak trees crashed to the ground behind my house on Saturday, taking our lights and Internet with them, there were about 20 comments on the link to the Mommy Bloggers article. When I was finally able to sign back on this morning there were more than 90, with everyone seemingly angry at someone  other bloggers, those who would question bloggers, The Times, Motherlode, one another.

title: Mancessions, Around the World
description: Weve written before about how men have borne the brunt of the job losses in this recession in the United States. This is largely because they are more likely to be employed in industries that are sensitive to the business cycle (like manufacturing and construction). Women are more disproportionately employed in industries that generally withstand downturns better (like health care, education and government work).

title: South by Southwests Location-Based Allure
description: Decoder is in Austin, Texas, at the interactive portion of South by Southwest, or SxSW as it is known to its adherents and sponsors. The broad sweep of the conference arrays over music, film, and interactive media for nine days, and right now, we are in the early days, which is mostly deep programming for digital types. We decided to share some of the weekend events in one long post, which is known as a heave in journalistic parlance, but given some of what will take place in the wee hours on Sixth Street  a bar-strewn ribbon in the middle of the city that rival New Orleans Bourbon Street  lets just call it a riff that is a little on the long side.

title: Case of the Missing Building Numbers
description: In most of this country and much of the world, buildings have numbers on them on the outside. The numbers correspond to the buildings street address. For example, the building at 100 Main Street will often have the numeral 100 affixed to it. These numbers are used to identify the building and to help people find it.

title: When Hollywood Gets It Right
description: Since my column today uses the release of Paul Greengrasss Green Zone as an occasion to complain about how Hollywood cant seem to capture the complexities and ironies of real-world politics, it seems worthwhile to mention a few recent exceptions to this rule. This will be a short list: Stephen Frears The Queen is on it, so is Alexander Paynes Election (yes, it takes place in a high school whats your point?), and so is the portrait of Baltimores mayoral politics on David Simons The Wire. (The character of Clarence Royce, the compromised incumbent, is a particularly good example of how a storyteller can be fair to a fundamentally unsympathetic figure.) David O. Russells great Three Kings doesnt feature any politicians, but it captures the tragic ironies of our involvement in Iraq with more clarity and sensitivity than any of the movies made about the second Gulf War. Neither Oliver Stones Nixon nor Mike Nichols Primary Colors are particularly successful movies, but both make a good-faith effort to portray polarizing figures from our recent past in shades of gray, rather than just black and white. (About the rest of Stones forays into political subjects, the less said the better.) And one of the reasons so many people praised  and overpraised  the political themes in The Dark Knight, I suspect, is that even an attempt at political ambiguity (and in a superhero movie, no less) seemed impressive, given how rarely Hollywood goes in for anything save caricature.

title: UBS Discloses Further Tax Inquiries
description: UBS of Switzerland said Monday that authorities in Britain, Canada and Australia were investigating the banks offshore business in the wake of revelations that it had helped American customers evade their taxes for years, The Associated Press reports.

title: ShoWest Changes Its Name to CinemaCon
description: ShowWest, the annual convention and trade show for those in the movie theater business, is renaming itself CinemaCon, Daily Variety reported on Monday.

title: Another Lehman Accounting Trick Ending in 105
description: Lehman Brothers apparently thought 105 was a magic number, at least according to the bankrupt investment banks court-appointed examiner.

title: Table for One, Please
description: Healthy dinners for one person can be a challenge. Sitting down at a table alone and savoring a meal prepared for oneself seems to be a foreign concept to singles with empty refrigerators, accustomed to eating on the run. Even those who do cook are likely to be put off by recipes sufficient to feed four or six.

title: The Battle for On-Demand Music Services Moves to the Phone
description: The fight for unlimited and on-demand music services is heating up, and the battlefield has moved to the phone.

title: The High Low | Cole Haan Loafers, $99
description: What: Cole Haan Heritage Loafers (Perforated Shawl, Brush Off Tassel, Sport Tassel)

title: Paging Jerry Lewis: French Awards Ceremony Briefly Turns Into Slapstick Comedy
description: While a French cabinet official was accidentally stabbing Marion Cotillard at an awards ceremony in Paris, Tim Burton took a stab at American cultural sensibilities on Monday.

title: The Claim: Zinc Can Help Fight Off Ear Infections
description: THE FACTS

title: Can Zinc Prevent Ear Infections?
description: As every parent knows, earaches are one of the most common and painful afflictions in children. But can the mineral zinc, long popular for fighting colds, prevent middle ear infections?

title: Privacy and the Smart Grid
description: Some technology policy organizations are worried that smart meters pose a potential threat to privacy. Steve Lohr at the Bits blog has the details.

title: Erik Bates | Part 1
description: Erik Bates and five other high school seniors are blogging their college admissions experience on The Choice.

title: That Boxer Blimp Video
description: We linked earlier today to the new Web video that Carly Fiorina, one of the Republican candidates for Senate, unveiled against Senator Barbara Boxer at the California G.O.P. convention this past weekend.

title: For Renters, Solar Comes in Shares
description: What happens if a renter wants solar power?

title: Prognosis: Health Risk for Kidney Donors Is Low
description: Having only one kidney does not appear to affect the long-term survival of live kidney donors, and the risk of dying from the surgery itself is very low, according to new research published in the March 10 issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: What Were Reading
description: For women who work, marriage makes no difference.

title: Hazards: Report Finds High Rate of Herpes in U.S.
description: One in six Americans aged 14 to 49 are infected with genital herpes, making the virus  herpes simplex 2  one of the most common sexually transmitted diseases in the United States, according to a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: China Has Traffic, Too
description: Here, with your daily dose of traffic schadenfreude, is Charles Komanoff, veteran New York City transportation analyst and founder of the pro-pedestrian group Right of Way, with a postcard from Guangzhou, China. Here, even a month-old bus rapid transit system that already attracts half as many bus passengers as New York City Transits is unlikely to unsnarl the citys crippling congestion. Read the full article at Dot Earth.

title: At Xavier, Nun Works Out Players Academic Side
description: By some measures, the success of the Xavier mens basketball team rests not with a sharpshooting guard or a ball-hawking forward. Rather, it rests largely with a 5-foot-4, white-haired 77-year-old nun not afraid to rap on dormitory doors or to call players before dawn to ask about missed classes or late assignments.

title: Reform Bill Adds Layers of Oversight
description: WASHINGTON  The 1,336-page bill to overhaul financial regulation that Senate Democrats put forward on Monday with the backing of the Obama administration calls for Washington to play a more active role in policing Wall Street.

title: Obama Tries to Personalize the Health Care Bill
description: STRONGSVILLE, Ohio  Declaring that every argument has been made on his health care overhaul, President Obama sought to seal the deal with Congress and the American people Monday by focusing on a single patient: a self-employed cleaning woman who dropped her costly insurance plan and just discovered she has leukemia.

title: Democrats Appeal to G.O.P. on Financial Overhaul
description: 2:37 p.m. | Updated Senate Democrats, with the backing of the Obama administration, took a big step forward on Monday toward adopting the most sweeping overhaul of financial regulations since the Depression. The Democrats also called on Republicans to join them to adopt the measure, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: A Classic Kaiser, Two Brothers and a Chevy Big Block
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The Goodguys Rod and Custom Association is a coast-to-coast-and-back-again series of car shows staged by the association, a hot-rod and custom car owners group. At the inaugural Spring Nationals here at the WestWorld showgrounds, there were a couple of thousand show cars with dramatic, sometimes flaming paint jobs and often looking very little like they did when they rolled off an automakers assembly line.

title: Ohioans Lukewarm to Obama and Health Care
description: Barack Obama traveled to Ohio today for a health care rally at a senior center, facing a state as well as an age group that are not especially warm toward his efforts on the issue.

title: Taking Ownership: Correlating Individual Learning to Standards
description: Overview | Should schools across the nation share one set of academic standards for English, math and literacy in science and social studies? How would a rewriting of standards transform American education and the experience of individual students? In this lesson, students learn about academic standards and consider the proposal of new national standards. They then perform a self-assessment, correlating the proposed or existing standards to their own knowledge and skills, and develop personal learning plans to achieve greater mastery.

title: Readers Look Up and Down at Brooklyn Development
description: Like many Brooklynites, Andrew Cotto moved to the borough because it was a destination with actual diversity, affordable restaurants, more parking and less pretension. He felt little remorse for leaving Manhattan behind, especially its crowded skyline.

title: The Salman Rushdie Digital Archive
description: A video about the Salman Rushdie digital archive created by Born Digital Archive Working Group at Emory University Libraries.

title: A Brand With Teeth
description: At one point in A Good Year, Ridley Scotts unlikely adaptation of the Peter Mayle novel, the British investment tycoon Max Skinner (played by Russell Crowe) challenges the vintner on his French estate to a game of tennis. Pointing to the laurel logo on the left breast of his shirt, Skinner intones, Fred Perry, throwing down the frog-vs.-lobster gauntlet. His French opponent then flips his sweaty visor around to reveal a bright green crocodile logo. Ren Lacoste, he replies. Game on.

title: Iran Plans to Execute 6 Arrested in Protests
description: Six people arrested in December protests will be put to death, Iranian authorities announced Monday, in what appeared to be strong warning to the opposition ahead of a traditional annual celebration.

title: A Play About Darfur
description: My previous research assistant, Winter Miller, is and was a playwright. A very persistent one. She had done a fabulous job supporting my work, and she became increasingly interested in writing a play about Darfur  so she asked if she could come along on a trip to the Chad/Darfur border with me, back in 2006.

title: Vernon Jordan Gets a Big Payday From Lazard
description: 5:01 p.m. | Updated Need another sign that Wall Street is on the upswing? Just look at the preliminary proxy that Lazard filed late Friday afternoon with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Travel Deals: Hotel Discounts for April and Beyond
description: Marriott is offering 40 percent off at 10 resorts in the Caribbean and Mexico. Rates start as low as $89 a night at the CasaMagna Marriott Puerto Vallarta, and just $98 a night at the St. Kitts Marriott Resort. Book by March 31 for travel between April 1 and Sept. 30. Use the code LLF when making reservations at ParadiseByMarriott.com or (888) 727-2347.

title: Story Lines to Watch: Coaches
description: Two coaches helped by their teams appearances in the N.C.A.A. tournament, one on the rise and one whose job security appeared to have rested on making the tournament.

title: Farewell, Sweet Shorty; Welcome Home, Rascally Augie
description: For my husband, Arthur, and me, Shorty was The One. He was a dachshund, one of those breeds that you either get or you dont.

title: Added Pain When the Patient Cant Talk
description: SCOUT usually wakes me up around 6 a.m. She licks my face or brings me her squeaky duck, taunting me to chase her with a guttural, Arrrh, arrrh.

title: Urban Flight in Haiti
description: The Jan. 12 earthquake sent hundreds of thousands of Haitians back to their rural hometowns, many of which struggle to accommodate the sudden surge in population.

title: Union Chief Warns Hell Back Independent Candidates Against Democrats Opposed to Health Care
description: In an effort to increase pressure on Democrats to vote for the health care bill, Andy Stern, president of the Service Employees International Union, warned on Monday that his powerful union would back some independent candidates this fall against House Democrats who vote against the bill.

title: Fund-Raisers Push Wavering Democrats on Health Care
description: A loose coalition of political fund-raisers have been reminding Democratic congressmen, many of them freshmen and still undecided over health care legislation, just whats at stake in the battle  including, perhaps, their re-elections.

title: Its Not Just the Economy
description: It has been easy for the last year and a half to blame the difficult small-business environment on the financial crisis and the slow recovery. A big rebound does not seem in sight for most businesses, at least not in the near future. After looking at my business and speaking to other small-business owners, I have come to the conclusion that the problem is not just the economy but also some profound changes that have been progressing for years.

title: Pro-Kremlin Party on Top, but Opposition Gains Seats
description: MOSCOW  The pro-Kremlin party, United Russia, has again dominated regional elections, according to preliminary results released Monday, though opposition parties have made slight gains in a vote that has been seen as a test of President Dmitri A. Medvedevs call for greater political pluralism in Russia.

title: Friskies Advertisement
description: In a new ad campaign, a pet goes on a fantastic journey by eating Friskies cat food.

title: A Tough Audience in Ohio, Polls Show
description: In choosing to take his health care campaign to Ohio on Monday, President Obama was all but guaranteed to find a skeptical audience, if recent polls are any guide. But maybe that was part of the plan. Read the full story at The Caucus.

title: Nutrition: Rise in Soda Price Linked to Better Health
description: New research provides evidence that proposed taxes on soft drinks may make young people healthier.

title: Dolls as a Parenting Tryout
description: The health classes at my sons high school have been walking around carrying water bottles with tennis-ball heads that are dressed in babylike outfits. It is the schools way of showing teenagers that real infants are a responsibility for which they are not prepared; they are required to keep their babies with them at all times, filling out logs of how often the newborns are fed, changed and soothed back to sleep.

title: With Twitter as the Messenger, Brisk Sales for Conan OBrien Tour
description: Conan OBrien has almost sold out his nationwide comedy tour  and all it took was a few Twitter messages.

title: At South by Southwest, Its Not Just About Location
description: The technology reporter Jenna Wortham has been covering the ins and outs of the South by Southwest music and technology conference in Austin, Tex., including an article Monday about location-based services.

title: How I See Things Right Now
description: Hey, its spring break  and Im recuperating from a very nasty cold.

title: Obamas C.D.C. Director, Wielding a Big Broom
description: ATLANTA  No federal health agency changed more during the Bush administration than the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It got new buildings, new managers and an entirely new operating structure.

title: The Rental Car Squeeze
description: Tried renting a car lately? In some cases, travelers say, the final bill is double or even triple the amount they thought they had agreed to.

title: Delivering Nitric Oxide, in Bandages and Socks
description: Nitric oxide is a reactive gas that plays a role in many body processes. In the circulatory system, for example, it acts as a signal that promotes the relaxation of smooth muscle around blood vessels, causing them to dilate, which improves blood flow.

title: Justice Stevens Weighs Retirement Date
description: Justice John Paul Stevens will soon decide whether he will stay on for another Supreme Court term, the justice told Jeffrey Toobin of The New Yorker.

title: A Risk of Poisoning the Deepest Wells
description: Fertilizing the oceans with iron has been proposed as a way of fighting climate change. The idea is that iron will promote blooms of phytoplankton that will remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere through photosynthesis. When the phytoplankton dies and sinks, the carbon will effectively be sequestered in the deep ocean.

title: Attention, Please! This Is a Zzb Frzzkd Sxpldts!
description: With no warning, the mysterious sirens, accompanied by garbled instructions, startled the residents who live near the Columbia Street waterfront and in nearby Brooklyn neighborhoods sometime after 9 a.m. Monday.

title: Continental Airlines to Charge for Food
description: Continental Airlines plans to end free hamburgers, barbecue and sandwich rolls for many of its passengers in favor of a food-for-sale program that mirrors what other carriers are already doing.

title: Where a Meal Can Cost a Fortune, 99 Pizza Catches On
description: The signs at the corner of Ninth Avenue and West 41st Street have an unbelievable, you-gotta-be-kidding quality, like free beer or affordable housing  99 Fresh Pizza. Like many things in New York City, they are also too good to be true. They are off by a penny, as one slice actually costs one dollar.

title: Shortest Railway Reopens, 9 Years After Fatal Accident
description: A downtown Los Angeles funicular rail line that shut down nine years ago after a deadly accident resumed service Monday with modern braking technology.

title: Scientists Defend Climate Panel and Seek Changes
description: Letter-signing campaigns are not necessarily an effective way to shift attitudes on scientific institutions like the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, given that any entrenched camp in the climate policy fight can pull together heaps of signatures from people with PhDs.

title: The Science Behind a Supersonic Jump
description: Felix Baumgartner will face known and unknown risks when he attempts to break the sound barrier in a jump from inner space later this year.

title: Mental Melodies
description: Q. Why do I find some of the melodic themes playing in my mind for several days after a concert?

title: When the Only Hope Is a Peaceful Ending
description: This is a very personal story of living gracefully with a fatal diagnosis. When I wrote Jane Brodys Guide to the Great Beyond, I had no idea that Id be putting its precepts into practice in my immediate family within a year of publication. But as I said in the book, You never know. You never know when your time will be up, and so it is best to prepare for the end sooner rather than later.

title: German Priest in Church Abuse Case Is Suspended
description: MUNICH  The priest at the center of a German sexual-abuse scandal that has embroiled Pope Benedict XVI continued working with children for more than 30 years, even though a German court convicted him of molesting boys.

title: A Fatal Diagnosis, Followed by Goodbyes
description: In Tuesdays Science Times, Personal Health columnist Jane Brody writes about her husbands final days with Stage 4 lung cancer. She begins:

title: Obama in Ohio to Push Health Care Plan
description: At the opening of what promises to be a week of intense politicking, President Obama arrived in Ohio to declare that every argument has been made on his proposed health care overhaul and that it was time for its passage by Congress. Doug Mills of The Times caught the quiet scene(s) on the tarmac at Cleveland-Hopkins International Airport shortly before Mr. Obamas appearance at a boisterous gathering in Strongsville.

title: Recalling the Craze for a Game of Chance
description: WOODY ALLEN joked in Annie Hall that after he was thrown out of New York University for cheating on a metaphysics final, his mother, a high-strung woman, locked herself in the bathroom and took an overdose of mah-jongg tiles.

title: The Highest Parachute Jump Ever
description: John Tierney of The Times discusses "Fearless Felix," who has jumped off the world's tallest building and is now attempting to break the speed of sound.

title: For Obese People, Prejudice in Plain Sight
description: As a woman whose height and weight put me in the obese category on the body-mass-index chart, I cringed when Michelle Obama recently spoke of putting her daughters on a diet. While Im sure the first ladys intentions are good, Im also sure that her comments about childhood obesity will add yet another layer to the stigma of being overweight in America.

title: ABE, Pioneering Robotic Undersea Explorer, Is Dead at 16
description: ABE, a nomadic adventurer that plumbed the worlds oceans on its own, forever changing the way scientists explored the seafloor, was lost at sea March 5 off southern Chile. The autonomous underwater vehicle was about 16 years old and in the off-seasons was stored in Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Growing Up With an Excess of Mothers Is Liable to Give a Boy a Complex
description: Lisa Grunwalds Henry House is a Garp of a guy, a male child raised in and warped by a quirky, intensely female domestic situation. Born in 1946 and then placed in an orphanage, he becomes the darling of a college home- economics department at a time when baby wrangling is that departments primary concern.

title: Now Showing | Mumbai Fashion Week
description: In America, critics regularly lament the Faustian bargain magazines and designers have entered into with Hollywood, whereby celebrities are used to boost both image and sales in exchange for free clothes and steep fees. But in India, where Bollywood is the most significant cultural force, fashion has to kowtow to celebrity on a regular basis in order to exist at all.

title: Why Phillips-Van Heusen Is Buying Tommy Hilfiger
description: The Monday announcement of Phillips-Van Heusens $3 billion deal for Tommy Hilfiger puts to rest weeks of speculation that the two clothing companies were in deal talks.

title: It Aint Pretty No More: See Paul Schraders Outline for Raging Bull
description: Once Robert De Niro gave his career-spanning collection of papers and artifacts to posterity, it was only a matter of time before the filmmaker Paul Schrader, his screenwriter on Raging Bull and Taxi Driver, got into the ring, too.

title: Twitter to Offer Service That Ties Into Other Sites
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Twitter is aiming to expand its reach on the Web.

title: Cleanup Begins in Storms Wake
description: On the wall of a windowless auditorium in Manhattan, color-coded maps of the New York region filled two large screens, showing the Consolidated Edison customers who did not have electricity.

title: In Tight Times, Revisiting Discretionary Spending
description: ALBANY  It is as regular as swallows returning to Capistrano: Every year, no matter how large the states deficit or how steep the cuts to critical government services, the Legislature dishes itself a healthy serving of pork. Tens of millions of dollars in earmarked state grants go to favored nonprofits, museums, cultural organizations and Little Leagues, with each check credited to the lawmaker or lawmakers who arrange it.

title: Seamlessly Wedding Cuban Rhythm to American Jazz
description: Bobby Carcasss is a singer, trumpeter, pianist, conguero and connector in Cuban jazz. As a bandleader, big-band sideman and a founder of the first jazz festival in Cuba, in 1980, hes spent his career attending to the equal relationship between the guaguanc-rumba-guaracha spectrum and the swing-jazz-blues spectrum.

title: Alcohol Cited in 2008 Russian Crash
description: MOSCOW  A pilots drunkenness was a contributing cause of a commercial airline crash in Russia in 2008, Russian prosecutors said Monday, reaching a conclusion extraordinarily rare in airline crash investigations.

title: Tree That Survived 9/11 Absorbs Another Blow
description: It was yards from the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001. Against all odds, it survived.

title: In Cancer Fight, Teenagers Dont Fit In
description: Simone Weinsteins ordeal with cancer started in the most banal way: she was tired. She had a hard time getting up in the morning, and did not even have the energy to hang out with her friends.

title: The Stigma of Being Fat
description: In Tuesdays Science Times, Harriet Brown discusses how, in a time of public acceptance and tolerance of differences, the stigma of being obese may be at an all-time high:

title: Death of the Bookplate?
description: Forget the death of the book. It turns out we have an even bigger problem: the death of the bookplate.

title: Procter Goes Greener With Friendly Persuasion
description: The consumer products giant Procter & Gamble is bringing a sustainability initiative to the United States that takes a different tack from those introduced by competitors like Clorox and S.C. Johnson.

title: Ex-Chief of Park Ave. Bank Charged With Bailout Fraud
description: A former president of the Park Avenue Bank in Manhattan was charged on Monday with fraud, embezzlement and bribery in what the authorities called the first criminal case of trying to defraud the federal governments bank bailout program, Benjamin Weiser and Eric Dash report in The New York Times.

title: With Cancer, Lets Face It: Words Are Inadequate
description: Were all familiar with sentences like this one: Mr. Smith died yesterday after a long battle with cancer. We think we know what it means, but we read it and hear it so often that it carries little weight, bears no meaning. Its one of the clichs of cancer.

title: Women and Breast Cancer (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Raising a Glass of Red (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Therapy for Children (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Enrichment Riddle (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: High-Speed Rail Gains Traction in Spain
description: ABOARD THE AVE  Carlos Martnez and his colleagues were enjoying soda and sandwiches in the bar, having chosen not to watch a film   Appaloosa,  with Ed Harris  that was playing on overhead screens. They barely seemed to notice the arid landscape whizzing by or the digital display reflecting their speed, which hovered around 186 miles per hour.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Friends of Eddie Coyle
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Peter Yatess 1973 film The Friends of Eddie Coyle, starring Robert Mitchum as the title character, a down-on-his-luck, small-time gun dealer in Boston. Mr. Scott calls the film, based on George V. Higginss novel, a lost classic of the 1970s.

title: Drug Helps Diabetics, Trial Finds
description: An inexpensive, generic anti-inflammatory drug from the aspirin family helped patients in a clinical trial manage their Type 2 diabetes and lower their blood sugar, adding to evidence that inflammation plays a role in diabetes, and possibly pointing to new therapeutic approaches to the disease.

title: Classical Azeri Poetry in Song, From a Team of Father and Daughter
description: The words Alim Qasimov sang on Friday night at Asia Society were nearly five centuries old, written by a poet from Baghdad, Muhammad Fuzuli, who proclaimed, Let my miserable heart burn in the fire of love. The poetrys longing, pain and spiritual seeking became raw and immediate, arriving in bursts of improvisation that made every phrase leap out.

title: The Happiness Stuff That Makes Embraceable Music Irreplaceable
description: You dont have to be depressing to be deep. The upside-down notion that happy, energetic music may be more profound than Mahleresque harmonic gloom is suggested by a scene from Walter Rimlers 2009 biography, George Gershwin: An Intimate Portrait (Music in American Life), quoted by the piano man Mark Nadler in Gershwin ... Here to Stay, the wonderfully buoyant tribute he is performing with K T Sullivan at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

title: A New Leader for Cinema Industry
description: ShoWest, the annual convention and trade show for those in the movie theater business, is renaming itself CinemaCon, Variety reported on Monday. This years convention began on Monday in Las Vegas and runs through Thursday. The gathering customarily includes film previews and briefings on the state of the movie industry. Dan Glickman, who is leaving his post as chairman and chief executive of the Motion Picture Association of America, is expected to recap his tenure with the trade association on Tuesday, Variety reported. Mr. Glickman has been replaced on an interim basis by Bob Pisano, who has been the associations president.

title: House Budget Committee Approves a Reconciliation Bill
description: By a vote of 21 to 16, the House Budget Committee on Monday advanced a budget reconciliation bill to the next stage of the legislative process.

title: Despite Improvements, Lack of Access to Toilets Still Presents Health Risks
description: Open defecation  which the World Health Organization describes as the riskiest sanitation practice of all  is on the decline in many countries, according to a report released Monday by the W.H.O. and Unicef.

title: A Supersonic Jump, From 23 Miles in the Air
description: Ordinarily, Felix Baumgartner would not need a lot of practice in the science of falling.

title: French Award Painful for Actress
description: While Frdric Mitterrand, the French culture minister, was accidentally stabbing Marion Cotillard at an awards ceremony in Paris, above, Tim Burton took a stab at American cultural sensibilities on Monday. When Mr. Mitterrand presented Ms. Cotillard, the Academy Award-winning star of La Vie en Rose and Nine, with a pin making her a chevalier in the Order of the Arts and Letters, he mistakenly stuck it too far through her blouse. Agence France-Presse reported that Ms. Cotillard winced and almost fell off her silver stilettos, but Mr. Mitterrand offered her an arm for support. (She is expected to make a full recovery.) Mr. Burton, whose film Alice in Wonderland opens in France next week, was similarly honored  without injury  and said in his acceptance remarks that he had always felt a very special place here in my heart for France. Mr. Burton added: I always felt the French were looking for the poetry, looking for the meaning, looking for the things that I was trying to do. Thats something that doesnt really happen in America.

title: Carstanjen: Champ. Trump: ALSO-RAN.
description: A Sunday night matchup of reality-show executives was hardly a horse race as an expletive-tossing Donald Trump was whipped by Bill Carstanjen, the chief operating officer of Churchill Downs. According to Nielsens estimates an episode of the CBS series Undercover Boss featuring Mr. Carstanjen drew 13.3 million viewers, making it the most watched program of the night and beating the season premiere of The Celebrity Apprentice (8.3 million), the Donalds long-running NBC show. CBS won the night over all with a lineup rounded out by 60 Minutes (11.7 million), The Amazing Race (10.2 million) and Cold Case (10.2 million). ABC was runner-up with programs that included Desperate Housewives (11.8 million). NBC was third, getting a so-so start from its new game show Minute to Win It; its debut drew 4.6 million viewers and a second episode was watched by 7.2 million. On fourth-place Fox, the premiere of Sons of Tucson (4.5 million) had an even worse showing.

title: Shakespeare Canon: New Ammunition?
description: An assertion by a professor at the University of Nottingham in England that he has found proof that a play from the 1700s includes reworked material of Shakespeares has gained a qualified endorsement from the Arden Shakespeare, a scholarly anthology of his work. The university said on Monday that a new edition of the play, Double Falsehood, or the Distressed Lovers by Lewis Theobald, an 18th-century scholar and Shakespeare editor, would be published on March 22 as part of Ardens Third Series of Shakespeares works. Theobald had said the play was based on three lost Shakespeare texts, a contentious claim that may now be backed up by the work of Brean Hammond, a professor of modern English literature at Nottingham. In his book, also called Double Falsehood, Mr. Hammond says he has found evidence linking that play to Cardenio, a lost collaboration between Shakespeare and John Fletcher that was performed in 1613. Richard Proudfoot, general editor of the Arden Shakespeare, said in a statement that the inclusion of Double Falsehood is our most controversial decision. He added, That it represents in some form the otherwise lost play of Cardenio, by Fletcher and Shakespeare, is a sufficiently sustainable position to recommend publication in Arden 3 of Lewis Theobalds avowedly thorough 18th-century adaptation, thus making it accessible for the first time in 250 years.

title: TriBeCa Film Festival Rounds Out Schedule
description: The Tribeca Film Festival announced on Monday that among the films it had added to its lineup were new works: one by Edward Burns (The Brothers McMullen) and another by Christy Turlington Burns, his wife, left. Fortunately for the couple the two movies wont be competing against each other. Mr. Burnss film Nice Guy Johnny, a comedy-drama about a young man and his uncle, will play in the festivals Encounters program; Ms. Turlington Burnss documentary, No Woman, No Cry, which tells stories of childbirth from around the world, will be shown in its Discovery program. Other films the festival announced on Monday include Last Play at Shea, a documentary about Billy Joel, the New York Mets and the final season of Shea Stadium in Queens; My Trip to Al Qaeda, a documentary by Alex Gibney (Taxi to the Dark Side), based on Lawrence Wrights one-man play of the same title; and Visionaries, a documentary by Chuck Workman on the history of avant-garde cinema. This years Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 21 through May 2.

title: Bordeaux Uncorked
description: One of Frances most traditional cities, Bordeaux is loosening up, with an infrastructural face-lift and experimental new restaurants and boutiques.

title: High School Reunions Fake Marine Is Sentenced
description: The man who attended the reunion of the Alhambra High School class of 1988 had not seemed the military type, but arrived at a reunion celebration with the uniform and decorations of a Marine officer, as we described in the Bay Area blog last November.

title: SXSW: Going to the Movies and Hopefully Getting In
description: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

title: Comics Collectible Acquired, and Savings Depleted, in a Flash
description: Superman and Batman have helped form our images of the ideal hero, so it makes sense that copies of the comic books in which they made their first appearances sold for record prices. Action Comics No. 1, where Superman made his debut, went for a cool $1 million, while Detective Comics No. 27, which featured the first adventure of Batman, went for $1.07 million.

title: A Souvenir of Caesars Killing
description: If youre the man who organized the assassination of Julius Caesar, your enduring rewards include delivering a funeral oration in a Shakespeare play, a portrayal on Broadway by Denzel Washington and a place in the mouth of Satan (according to Dantes Inferno, anyway). If you merely took part in the murder, at least you got a nice souvenir. On Monday  the Ides of March, naturally  the British Museum in London put on display a gold coin given to one of Caesars assassins that may have been worn as a memento by the boastful killer, The Guardian reported. The coin, above, which was struck soon after Caesars murder in 44 B.C., depicts on one side the head of Brutus, and on the other, two daggers and the hat of a freeman, a symbol of the conspirators belief in the Roman republic instead of the tyranny that Caesar represented to them. The Guardian said that about 60 silver versions of the coin survive, but only 2 gold ones were believed to still exist  one of which is now believed by experts to be a fake.

title: Lawman Returns to Kentucky, Facing Bad Guys and Skeletons
description: Justified opens with a clever piece of misdirection. At first, all we can see is the big Stetson hat of Raylan Givens, the United States marshal played by Timothy Olyphant, as he climbs some stairs. It seems to promise a Western setting  a Texas street or a Utah canyon. But as he reaches the top step, palm trees come into view, and then cabanas, and then the rooftop pool of a Miami Beach hotel. The only cowboys here are of the cocaine variety.

title: Southern Women, Mostly Older but Not Wiser
description: Youve got pickup trucks, big hair and church services where worshipers speak in tongues. So what is a reference to Herman Wouks Marjorie Morningstar (nice prewar Jewish girl from Central Park West) doing here, against a backdrop of a map of the Carolinas?

title: A New Source for Student Loans
description: President Obamas plan to have the government provide loans directly to students instead of using commercial lenders was resurrected on Thursday, when Democratic leaders agreed to bundle it into an expedited budget package along with the health care overhaul. Now, the student loan measure, which had been unlikely to pass on its own, could be passed in the Senate along with the health care measure by a simple majority vote.

title: Portraits, Snapshots and Even a Play
description: Gwen Welliver, Daniel Charon and Nancy Bannon each danced with Doug Varones company for more than 10 years. But their own work, as seen in a program organized by Mr. Varone at the 92nd Street Y on Friday night, reveals startlingly disparate styles and influences. So different, in fact, that Ms. Bannons piece was a play rather than a dance.

title: Charles Moore Dies; Depicted Rights Battles
description: The photographs are still shocking.

title: Culture of Past Eras: Dance, Chant and Song That Span the Centuries
description: As pretexts so often do, this one quickly wore thin. Early Music Exposed, a daylong festival at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday, ostensibly celebrated the reopening of the Andr Mertens Galleries for Musical Instruments after an eight-month closing and what the museum calls a refreshed presentation of the Western instrument collection.

title: C-Span Puts Full Archives on the Web
description: WASHINGTON  Researchers, political satirists and partisan mudslingers, take note: C-Span has uploaded virtually every minute of its video archives to the Internet.

title: New Signature Theater, Close to the Old
description: It is a far cry from the freestanding performing arts center, designed by Frank Gehry, that was supposed to be the Signature Theater Companys new home at ground zero and that was expected to cost $700 million.

title: Anti-Abortion Group Targets House Democrats
description: Americans United for Life, an anti-abortion group, is planning a major print advertising campaign to pressure rank-and-file House members to vote against the Democrats big health care legislation unless it includes tighter restrictions on insurance coverage for abortions.

title: A Chance to Listen to the Future at the Met
description: The Grand Finals Concert of the Metropolitan Operas National Council Auditions, the most prestigious voice competition in North America, has drawn the attention of company managers, artist representatives and opera insiders for more than 50 years. For the voice buffs in the audience, it is always fascinating to hear the young finalists and try to sort out, along with the panel of judges, who among them will be the stars of tomorrow.

title: Dreams Die Hard, Even in Palookaville
description: Happy in the Poorhouse is a big, sloppy kiss of a family drama delivered with the warmth and gusto of an overly affectionate aunt.

title: Special Cover
description: If you think back to the New York fall shows, ages ago, the main coat story was some combination of wool and fur. In Europe, we became aware of volume and texture (the scale of collars at Burberry and Prada, the sweep of the great coats at MaxMara, the smooth cap of the hooded fur vests at Rick Owens, the fuzzy fakes at Chanel). Jean Paul Gaultier made a good show of classic tailoring at Herms; Phoebe Philo zeroed in on the high collar at Cline.

title: One on One Interviews: Who Should Be Next?
description: Over the last two months, Ive been interviewing various people in technology for a series called One on One. The posts have included the following technology mavens:

title: Sands Resort Complex to Open in Singapore
description: Singapore isnt exactly lacking for high-end lodging, but the Las Vegas Sands hopes to top them all with its new Marina Bay Sands Resort, which features a dizzying array of luxury offerings.

title: Fending Off Digital Decay, Bit by Bit
description: Among the archival material from Salman Rushdie currently on display at Emory University in Atlanta are inked book covers, handwritten journals and four Apple computers (one ruined by a spilled Coke). The 18 gigabytes of data they contain seemed to promise future biographers and literary scholars a digital wonderland: comprehensive, organized and searchable files, quickly accessible with a few clicks.

title: Supportive, Loving Band of Bigots
description: Kiss Bessemer Goodbye sounds at first like a bittersweet story of parental love and the necessity of letting go. But theres something ugly going on in this likable if shaky one-act, Repertorio Espaols newest production.

title: A Host of Mummies, a Forest of Secrets
description: In the middle of a terrifying desert north of Tibet, Chinese archaeologists have excavated an extraordinary cemetery. Its inhabitants died almost 4,000 years ago, yet their bodies have been well preserved by the dry air.

title: Pelosi: Its Not About Abortion or Immigration
description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi held a news conference with childrens advocates at the Capitol on Monday to push for the Democrats sweeping health care legislation.

title: A Different Kind of Housing Puzzle
description: OK, Im still evaluating the Dodd proposal for financial reform. But heres my puzzle: the bill, as I understand it, calls for an independent Consumer Protection Agency, with a director directly appointed by the president, but one that is housed at the Fed.

title: Why Make the Longest Jump?
description: Should Felix Baumgartner take a supersonic jump from a helium balloon 23 miles above the Earth? lf so, why?

title: Curveball
description: I never thought of it that way: Ryan Avent says that my advocacy of a get-tough approach to the renminbi is just like the Bush administrations push for war with Iraq.

title: For Cooler Chips, Follow the Grooves
description: For electronics engineers who want to make faster chips, heat is a big hurdle. More calculations mean more electrons moving through semiconductor material, which generates more heat.

title: Corporate Debt Coming Due May Squeeze Credit
description: When the Mayans envisioned the world coming to an end in 2012  at least in the Hollywood telling  they didnt count junk bonds among the perils that would lead to worldwide disaster.

title: Lifes Journeys, a Lot Less Mysterious
description: I AM 11.6 miles from my destination, otherwise known as a lamp repair store, and according to the Maps app on my iPhone, it should take me 15 minutes to drive there.

title: Correction: Tuscany Without the Crowds
description: The cover article on March 7, about Tuscany in winter, misidentified the type of fruit that was seen on the bare branches of trees in the garden at La Foce, a 15th-century villa there. They were persimmons, not oranges.

title: Correction: Buenos Aires for Those Who Shun Steaks
description: An article on March 7 about vegetarian restaurants in Buenos Aires misidentified the neighborhood in which the restaurant Kensho is located. It is in Villa Ortzar, not Boedo.

title: Europe Creates an Apparatus to Provide Loans to Greece
description: BRUSSELS  Finance ministers from the 16 countries using the euro as their currency said Monday they were ready to help rescue Greece.

title: Readers Tips for Home Appliance Use
description: What follows is a sampling of e-mail messages written in response to Alina Tugends Shortcuts column on Saturday, which offered some tips on the proper use of home appliances like washing machines and dishwashers. The No. 1 tip, from repair people and appliance experts, was to use less soap.

title: Answers Begin to Emerge on How Thalidomide Caused Defects
description: The word phocomelia means seal limb. It describes an extremely rare condition in which babies are born with limbs that look like flippers.

title: The Vast World of the Tiny, Arranged From A to Z
description: The minuscule, a narrow gate, opens up an entire world. This is both Hugh Raffless epigraph and the last line of his miraculous book Insectopedia, as inventive and wide ranging and full of astonishing surprises as the vast insect world itself.

title: What Were Reading: Facebook vs. Google, BlackBerry vs. iPhone
description: If the Internet is like a box of chocolates, here are the nougats and creams that the technology reporters and the editors of The New York Times have been eating on Monday:

title: Indian Cabinet Backs Foreign Schools
description: MUMBAI, India  The Indian cabinet approved a bill on Monday that would allow foreign universities to set up campuses in the country, a major break with a previous policy in which outside institutions were seen as a threat to the education system.

title: Twitter Keynote Gets Thumbs-Down  on Twitter
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A keynote interview with Evan Williams, Twitters chief executive, created a stir during the South by Southwest Interactive conference here on Monday  but it may not have been what conference organizers had in mind.

title: Q. and A. on Church Sex Abuse Scandal
description: With a sexual abuse scandal once again testing the Roman Catholic Church  this time raising questions about Pope Benedict XVIs handling of the matter  reporters for The Times are answering readers questions about the developments.

title: Lehman Estate Proposes Reorganization Plan
description: The bankruptcy estate of Lehman Brothers on Monday proposed an initial reorganization plan that would lift the remains of the investment bank out of Chapter 11.

title: Rebelling Against the Commonly Evasive Feminine Care Ad
description: A COMMERCIAL for U by Kotex, a new line from the 90-year-old feminine care brand, opens with an actress in her early 20s who says, How do I feel about my period? I love it.

title: Pragmatisms Gift
description: Pragmatic is a compliment sometimes paid to politicians (Barack Obamas supporters describe him that way), and it is often used as an honorific indicating a person of common sense who knows how to get things done. Pragmatic is also related (at least etymologically) to pragmatism, the name of a distinctively American philosophy that emerged in the early decades of the 20th century in the work of William James, John Dewey and C.S. Peirce. Pragmatism may or may not be an ethical program depending on whose version you are reading, but it always emphasizes the resources of historically given institutions and practices and de-emphasizes the role played in our lives by supra-historical essentialisms (God, faith, truth, reason, brute fact, overarching theory) even to the extent sometimes of denying their existence.

title: Owe Someone Money? Just Bump Your Phones
description: People have predicted the death of cash and checks for a long time. But there are certain transactions  like paying a friend back for dinner or buying vegetables at the farmers market  for which they remain essential.

title: UConn Women Are Good for the Game
description: It has become fashionable to say that Connecticuts 72-game winning streak is bad for womens basketball, as if greatness can be as choking and stifling as weeds.

title: Rebuilt Synagogue Is Caught in Disputes Over Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  In what appeared to be a case of unfortunate timing, Israel officially inaugurated a rebuilt synagogue in Jerusalems Old City on Monday, entangling what was intended to be a festive cultural event with the diplomatic row over new Israeli construction in the contested territory.

title: An Insistence on Safety in Filling Exit-Row Seats
description: LIKE most business travelers, Richard M. Owens has occasionally sat in an exit-row seat on an airplane and wondered what he would do in a real emergency. He got to find out, he told me, on a harrowing approach into Miami about five years ago.

title: Medicaid Patients Left in the Lurch
description: The community of Flint, Mich., already reeling from unemployment, is now suffering the effects of state cuts to Medicaid, the government insurance program for the poor and disabled.

title: Visionary Was Forgotten, but Not by One Devotee
description: Things dont get done easily in New York. Dont plan, for example, on catching a train at Moynihan Station anytime soon. That replacement for the sepulchral Pennsylvania Station has been discussed for a couple of decades, but talk trumps action. Plenty of other examples of inertia could be cited. Choose your favorite.

title: Goal at Deutsche Telekom: More Women as Managers
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europes largest telecommunications company, said Monday that it would more than double the number of women who are managers within five years, becoming the first member of the DAX 30 index of blue-chip German companies to introduce gender quotas.

title: Bit by Bit, Coming to Terms With His Elfin Self
description: YONKERS

title: Key New York Suit Calls Public Defender Programs Inadequate
description: A class-action suit to be argued next week in New Yorks highest court has become a test of a national strategy by civil liberties groups to challenge what they say are failed public defender programs in many states.

title: A Superorganized Traveler Who Once Forgot Something
description: IM usually an impeccable business traveler.

title: Defendants Fresh From War Find Service Counts in Court
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  When Judge Robert C. Chambers handed down Timothy Oldanis federal sentence for selling stolen military equipment on eBay, he gave the former Marine a break.

title: Cleaning a Canal, but Not Writing About It
description: Christos Tsiamis, 59, grew up in the Greek port city of Patras and spent his summers swimming in the Ionian Sea. These days, Mr. Tsiamiss attention is consumed by a less alluring body of water: the Gowanus Canal, which this month was designated a Superfund site. Mr. Tsiamis, a 22-year veteran of the Environmental Protection Agency, is the project manager charged with determining just how contaminated the Gowanus is, and how best to clean it up. A chemical engineer with a masters degree from Columbia University, Mr. Tsiamis, who splits his time between Manhattan and Eastchester, N.Y., is also a poet who has published four books of poetry in his native tongue.

title: A Perpetual Urban Problem: Buildings Without Numbers
description: In most of this country and much of the world, buildings have numbers on the outside. The numbers correspond to the buildings street address, and are used to identify the building and help people find it.

title: Ethiopia: Opposition Criticizes Verdict in Killing
description: A leader of Ethiopias opposition alliance on Monday criticized a court verdict in the stabbing death of an opposition parliamentary candidate, accusing the ruling party of intimidating a key witness. The candidate, Aregawi Gebre-Yohannes, was killed March 2 at his restaurant in the Tigray region. The opposition said the candidate was killed by supporters of the ruling party. The killer, Tsegie Berhane, was sentenced last week to 15 years in prison, said Shimeles Kemal, a government spokesman. Mr. Tsegie was granted leniency because he had confessed, Mr. Shimeles said, adding that the accused was not a member of a party. It was an arranged and orchestrated court, said Gebru Asrat, a leader of the Arena party, part of the opposition alliance. He said witnesses who testified had been involved in the killing.

title: Moodys Says U.S. Debt Could Test Triple-A Rating
description: The gold-plated credit rating of the United States  an article of faith across America and, indeed, around the world  may be at risk in coming years as the nation copes with its growing debts.

title: The Health Care Letdown
description: Washington

title: Student Is Accused of Stealing and Selling Valuable Historic Letters
description: William John Scott is a freshman at Drew University. He studies political science. He plays defense on the lacrosse team. He describes himself on Facebook as a night person who likes to party.

title: Chile Braces for a Major Economic Slowdown
description: TALCAHUANO, Chile  Just a few weeks ago, some 2,000 fishermen who ply the waters of this port city for sardines and mackerel were busy mending their nets and testing their rigs in preparation for the start of the four-month fishing season.

title: Ex-Chief of Park Avenue Bank Charged With Bailout Fraud
description: A former president of the Park Avenue Bank in Manhattan was charged on Monday with fraud, embezzlement and bribery in what the authorities called the first criminal case of trying to defraud the federal governments bank bailout program.

title: Array of Hurdles Awaits New Education Agenda
description: In the blueprint for overhauling federal education policy that President Obama sent to Congress on Monday, his administration seeks to confront some of the major educational challenges that have developed during the eight years that President George W. Bushs No Child Left Behind law has been a powerful influence on the nations public schools.

title: U.S. Is Reining In Special Operations Forces in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the top American commander in Afghanistan, has brought most American Special Operations forces under his direct control for the first time, out of concern over continued civilian casualties and disorganization among units in the field.

title: Altogether Ooky
description: Charles Addams, "in his mischief," writes Edward Rothstein, "makes the illicit an enchanting, almost whimsical aspect of daily life; we descend into his realm with the same half grin as that doomed office worker, our darker natures finding pleasure in allusions to misery. We enter a world so perverse even wind-up toys commit suicide, bitter matrons ask in department stores to be directed to 'blunt instruments,' and beams of light bearing divine illumination stream from the heavens only to shine on television antennas." That enchantment clearly resonates today. A musical comedy on Broadway about the Addams family's escapades is in previews, the Museum of the City of New York has a major collection of Addams drawings on display and a book "The Addams Family: An Evilution" has been released. Tonight find out more about the man behind Morticia, Gomez, Uncle Fester, Lurch and the others when Kevin Miserocchi, the executive director of the Tee and Charles Addams Foundation and the author of the book, discusses his work at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Sing Into Spring
description: "Singers reign at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola this month and next, appearing with first-rate backing bands," writes Nate Chinen. Tonight, Barbara Carroll kicks off Jazz at Lincoln Center's Sing Into Spring Festival, "practicing her brand of literate jazz cabaret with help from the clarinetist and tenor saxophonist Ken Peplowski, the bassist Jay Leonhart and the drummer Alvin Atkinson." Ms. Carroll performs through March 21; the festival runs through May 2.

title: Performance Art in Times Square
description: You're going to the Marina Abramovic retrospective, "The Artist is Present," at the Museum of Modern Art and you still don't know who Ulay is? Get up to speed on the German-born performance artist who influenced and collaborated with Ms. Abramovic. Creative Time is presenting three of her films on MTV's huge outdoor screen in Times Square from March 14 to April 14. The first two films, "Light/Dark" (1977) and "Rest Energy" (1980) feature Ulay, Ms. Abramovic's former lover. In the first film, the two kneel opposite each other and then take turns slapping each other at a quickening pace; in the second, they stand opposite each other and "slowly lean apart until they are held only by the tension of a loaded bow that is held between them  its arrow pointed directly at Ms. Abramovic's heart." The final film, "Dissolution," (1997) shows Ms. Abramovic whipping her own back. Watch the films and then go see the artist herself in the flesh.

title: The Spirit of Sympathy
description: Human beings, the philosophers tell us, are social animals. We emerge into the world ready to connect with mom and dad. We go through life jibbering and jabbering with each other, grouping and regrouping. When you get a crowd of people in a room, the problem is not getting them to talk to each other; the problem is getting them to shut up.

title: As Medicaid Payments Shrink, Patients Are Abandoned
description: FLINT, Mich.  Carol Y. Vliets cancer returned with a fury last summer, the tumors metastasizing to her brain, liver, kidneys and throat.

title: Residents Grapple With Storm Damage
description: A vicious weekend storm that tore through the metropolitan area left flooding and fallen trees in its wake.

title: Rodriguez Puts on His Glasses, and Mets Like What They See
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets had no shortage of injuries last year, including wounded hips, elbows and knees.

title: Triumph for Drug to Straighten Clenched Fingers
description: It took half a century. But a tiny drug maker on Long Island has finally found a potentially lucrative use for its only medicine: straightening clenched fingers. And, if research proves successful, treating a condition that causes bent penises.

title: Bringing Movement Back to Clenched Hands
description: As her fingers began curling toward her palm, Karen Mercaldo lost the ability to play the piano, knit and paint. She would poke herself in the eye when washing her face. She could not even wear her wedding ring.

title: Mexico Is Warned on Drug Detector
description: MEXICO CITYThe British government has notified Mexico that a handheld device widely used by the Mexican military and police to search for drugs and explosives may be ineffective, British officials said.

title: Race for Monserrates Old Senate Seat Winds Down
description: During a forum in Jackson Heights, Queens, last Thursday, candidates for a vacant State Senate seat were given a chance to question one another. One of them, Hiram Monserrate, addressed his leading opponent, Jos R. Peralta, as Jos. Mr. Peralta addressed him as Mr. Monserrate.

title: Jets Ryan Tries to Flatten a Persistent Opponent
description: Rex Ryan was screaming at the official from the sideline. His prospective surgeon was watching on television, afraid he would lose a patient before he could help him.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 15, 2010

title: Mistress of Edwards Ends Silence on Affair
description: WASHINGTON  In an interview with GQ magazine, Rielle Hunter talks publicly for the first time about her relationship with former Senator John Edwards, which began during his presidential campaign.

title: The Days After
description: The latest election results in Iraq point to a heated and possibly lengthy power struggle between the Shiite coalition led by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and the rival secular slate led by Ayad Allawi.

title: Michael Jackson Estate Signs Deal With Sony
description: Nine months after Michael Jacksons death, his estate has signed one of the biggest recording contracts in history, giving Sony, Mr. Jacksons longtime label, the rights to sell his back catalog and draw on a large vault of unheard recordings.

title: In Ireland, a Hearing on a Plot to Kill a Swedish Cartoonist
description: WATERFORD, Ireland  A late-night court hearing Monday in this quiet Irish town gave new glimpses into the case that American and Irish prosecutors are pursuing against a group of Muslims on both sides of the Atlantic suspected of plotting to kill a Swedish cartoonist who depicted the Prophet Muhammad atop the body of a dog.

title: Bloggingheads: Death Optional
description: Mike Treder, left, of the Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies and Massimo Pigliucci of Lehman College debate radical life extension.

title: Not Happy to Simply Be There
description: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team, which is seeded 12th in the East Region and will face No. 5 Temple on Friday in Jacksonville, Fla. Jon has been blogging for The Quad throughout this season. You can also follow him on Twitter.

title: Charges and Countercharges of Financial Misdeeds Rile Unions Leadership
description: At first, it seemed like a straightforward matter. Jim McLaughlin, who had led the operating engineers union local in Southern California for 17 years, was reviewing some expense accounts and grew convinced that his locals apprenticeship coordinator had charged more than $2,000 in improper expenses to the apprenticeship program.

title: At Lehman, Watchdogs Saw It All
description: Almost two years ago to the day, a team of officials from the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York quietly moved into the headquarters of Lehman Brothers. They were provided desks, phones, computers  and access to all of Lehmans books and records. At any given moment, there were as many as a dozen government officials buzzing around Lehmans offices.

title: Amid Democratic Impatience, Senators Move on a Jobs Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate cleared the way on Monday for final Congressional approval of a Democratic plan to spur job creation as Democrats grew impatient with delays in enacting what they hope is the first in a series of economic measures.

title: UConn Prepares for Historic Trip
description: Connecticut has played in every N.C.A.A. womens basketball tournament since 1989 and has always had the luxury of playing at least one tournament game a year  and sometimes as many as four  in its home state, before its sizable and adoring fan base.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a spy network, according to military and business officials, composed of private contractors in Afghanistan and Pakistan established by Michael D. Furlong, a Defense Department official based at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio, misidentified the branch of the military in which Mr. Furlong had once served as an officer. It is the Army, not the Air Force.

title: Corrections
Corrections
description: An article on Monday, about a sales spike for a French book called The Coming Insurrection after it was mentioned by the Fox News host Glenn Beck gave an incomplete title for Christopher Balfe. While Mr. Balfe commented on Mr. Becks behalf for the article, he is president and chief operating officer of Mercury Radio Arts, Mr. Becks production company; he is not a spokesman for Mr. Beck.

title: Galaxy Will Begin to Feel Beckhams Loss in July
description: David Beckhams injury will affect the Los Angeles Galaxy on and off the field.

title: Corrections
description: The Patient Money column on Saturday, about finding housing and care for elderly parents, rendered incorrectly the name of the law firm of Robert S. Bullock, who commented on the availability of Medicaid for nursing home care. It is the Elder and Disability Law Center, not the Elder Law and Disability Law Center.

title: Arnall Patz, a Doctor Who Prevented Blindness, Is Dead at 89
description: Dr. Arnall Patz, an ophthalmologist whose research upset medical convention but ended up saving countless babies from blindness, died on Wednesday at his home in Pikesville, Md. He was 89.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a Congressional panel that questioned the need for the Treasury Departments bailouts of GMAC in 2008 and 2009 gave an incomplete figure for the overall amount of the governments financial package. It totaled $17.2 billion. (The word billion was omitted.)

title: Corrections
description: An art review on Friday about To Live Forever: Art and the Afterlife in Ancient Egypt, at the Brooklyn Museum, referred incorrectly to the presence of mummies in the exhibition. There is in fact one on display. The review also referred imprecisely to the treatment of organs in some mummifications. They were removed and preserved and then either permanently stored in jars that were entombed with the body, or put back in the body. They were not stored in jars and then returned to the body.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 7 about the emergence artists in the Pop Pluralism movement misstated the name of a clothing store in San Francisco that houses a chandelier by Adam Wallacavage. It is RVCA, not RVKA.

title: Rewriting History in Texas
description: The Texas Board of Education, notorious for its past efforts to undermine the teaching of evolution in public schools, has now moved to revise the social studies curriculum to portray conservative ideas and movements in a more positive light and emphasize the role of Christianity in the nations founding.

title: The Battle Over Textbooks in Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Civil Rights in Education
description: In a little more than a year in office, Education Secretary Arne Duncan has used his bully pulpit and a burgeoning discretionary budget to focus state governments on school reform as never before. Mr. Duncan has now promised to energize the Education Departments Office of Civil Rights, which has done a poor job in recent years of enforcing federal laws that protect poor, minority and disabled students from discrimination.

title: The Dream of Clean Coal
description: To the Editor:

title: Workers Crushed by Toyota
description: California has been very, very good to Toyota. It is one of the largest markets in the world for the popular Prius hybrid. Nearly 18 percent of all Toyotas sold in the U.S. are sold in California. The state has showered the company with benefits, including large-scale infrastructure improvements for its operations and millions of dollars for worker training. California is one of the key reasons that Toyota is the wealthiest carmaker on the planet.

title: Surviving on a Fixed Income
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Shortchanges the Indians
description: Last December, after 13 years of lawsuits and painful negotiations, the federal government and representatives of hundreds of thousands of American Indians finally reached a settlement of claims that reached back to the 19th century. Only one more hurdle stood between the Indians and the $3.4 billion that the government agreed to pay them: Congress, which was required to sign off on the agreement.

title: Ways to React to New Housing in East Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the many questions surrounding the Mets pitching staff this season misstated the number of games John Maine won in the 2006 playoffs. It was one, not two.

title: Immigration Offer Draws Few Haitians
description: Within days of the devastating earthquake in Haiti on Jan. 12, the United States government declared that Haitians living illegally in the United States were eligible for temporary protected status, a special immigration designation that temporarily allows them to work here legally.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Katie Spotz, who at 22 became the youngest person to row an entire ocean solo, misstated the location of Georgetown, Guyana, in South America, her arrival point on Sunday, in relation to Cayenne, French Guiana, her original destination. It is about 400 miles northwest of Cayenne, not northeast.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about West Virginias 60-58 victory over Georgetown on Saturday in the championship game of the Big East mens basketball tournament misstated West Virginias seeding. It was third, not fourth.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 5 about first-round play at the Honda Classic in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., erroneously attributed a distinction to the golfer Oliver Wilson, who was tied for third place at the time. He was not the 2007 Honda champion  that was Mark Wilson.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Charles Moore, Rights-Era Photographer, Dies at 79
description: Charles Moore, a photographer who braved physical peril to capture searing images  including lawmen using dogs and fire hoses against defenseless demonstrators  that many credit with helping to propel landmark civil rights legislation, died on Thursday in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 79.

title: One in the Woods
description: The path to ABC Business Schoolwas paid for by a lucky sign:Alterations, Qualified SeamstressInquire Within.

title: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inducts New Members
description: Slouched against the lectern at the 25th annual Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony, a shirtless Iggy Pop snarled, I am the worlds forgotten boy.

title: How the Midmajors Reel In Those Stars
description: Dave Telep evaluates high school basketball players for a living. While most fans watch the N.C.A.A. tournament to root for their alma mater or to follow their brackets, Telep sees a referendum on his professional opinion.

title: Does Woody Johnson Have a Right to Be Upset About Goodells Coin Flip?
description: The roommates arent getting along. And they havent even moved in yet.

title: Putting Games Online to Try to Satisfy Majority
description: If a flaw existed in CBSs coverage of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, it was the regionalization of games  especially in the first four days.

title: Giants Get First Game at New Stadium
description: Years from now, the host of the first game at the new football palace in the Meadowlands will be a mere footnote. Right now, though, the right to host that game  and bask in the spotlight that will accompany it  has laid bare the arms-length relationship between the two New York teams that will share the stadium and that jointly hope to win the right to stage the 2014 Super Bowl.

title: 2 Mets Make Case, but Fifth Starter Is Still a Mystery
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Two leading contenders for the fifth spot in the Mets rotation pitched on Monday, but neither did anything to clarify who would win the job. Fernando Nieve gave up two runs and five hits with no strikeouts in three innings, and Jon Niese allowed three runs and four hits with two strikeouts.

title: Der Scutt, Modernist Architect, Dies at 75
description: Der Scutt, an architect who designed several of the most prominent buildings in Manhattan  including Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue and the vast One Astor Plaza overlooking Times Square  died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: Defining the Great Midmajor Player
description: The recruiting analyst Dave Telep of scout.com and his intern, Drew Cannon, conducted a study two years ago that showed what makes a great midmajor player. They came up with nine categories, defining the best players who are not in the six power conferences.

title: Given Chance, Knicks Douglas Makes the Most of It
description: PHILADELPHIA  Mike DAntoni started the season with his old reliable, Chris Duhon, at point guard. He briefly replaced him with Nate Robinson, then switched back to Duhon before Sergio Rodriguez and Tracy McGrady inherited the job.

title: Yellen May Prove Less Than Dovish
description: Janet Yellen has a reputation as a monetary dove. After all, she thought deflation a risk when she became president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco and has suggested inflation may be too low now. But Ms. Yellen displays hints of talons beneath her feathers that could change the way the central bank does business.

title: Protesters Dump Blood at Thai Government Site
description: BANGKOK  Blood was spilled on Tuesday, the third day of mass demonstrations in Bangkok, but not in the way that many had feared.

title: Word of the Day | bait
description: bait \bat\ noun and verb

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Sunday about an examiners report on accounting maneuvers that concealed Lehman Brotherss perilous financial condition repeated an error from the news article on which it was based. The editorial and the article, which was published on Friday, incorrectly described assets that were temporarily shuffled off Lehmans books. They were highly liquid securities, according to the examiner, not troubled assets.

title: As Concussions Toll Lingers, an M.L.S. Career May Yield
description: Alecko Eskandarian recently posted this message on Twitter: I have a new PS3 and FIFA 10. I havent used myself in a video game in ages and this is gonna be fun. But if my character has a concussion Im gonna be ticked.

title: News Quiz | March 16, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Second to Nun
description: WHO is the 5-foot-4, white-haired 77-year-old nun who keeps the Xavier mens basketball team in line academically? WHO plays that role in your life?

title: Defining the Great Midmajors Players
description: In Tuesdays New York Times, Pete Thamel broke down an analysis directed by a national talent evaluator that found striking trends in physiques and skills among midmajors players.

title: Junk Bond Avalanche Looms for Credit Markets
description: When the Mayans envisioned the world coming to an end in 2012  at least in the Hollywood telling  they didnt count junk bonds among the perils that would lead to worldwide disaster, Nelson D. Schwartz writes in The New York Times.

title: How Polite Are You?
description: Do you R.S.V.P. when people ask you to events? Do you turn off your cellphone at the movies and the theater? Wipe your sweat off machines at the gym? Refrain from talking loudly in public on your phone? Tell us how polite you think you are, and describe what breaches of etiquette drive you crazy.

title: MagnaChip Eyes $250 Million I.P.O.
description: MagnaChip Semiconductor, which recently emerged from bankruptcy protection, on Monday filed its intent to raise as much as $250 million in an initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

title: At Lehman, Watchdogs Saw It All
description: Lehman Brothers executives werent the only ones in the building when they were moving billions of dollars in liabilities off their books at the end of each quarter with magic accounting. So were the Feds, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: Financial Engines Prices Above Range in I.P.O.
description: Financial Engines, the portfolio manager and advisory firm, raised about $127.7 million after pricing above its expected range in its initial public offering Monday, Reuters reported.

title: Chinas Redgate Seeks $43 Million in I.P.O.
description: The Chinese advertising company Redgate Media Group will attempt to raise $43 million during an initial public offering this week, The Associated Press reported.

title: Jewish Museum London
description: Images from the newly expanded museum.

title: Barclays Said to Have Sought UBS Over Lehman in 2008
description: Barclays, which acquired Lehman Brothers North American assets in its global push to expand, actually had its eyes on other prey, The Financial Times reports.

title: Does Dominion Deal Put Consol at Risk?
description: Consol Energy is joining the shale gas party. And its $3.5 billion deal to buy assets from Dominion Resources looks like a bargain. But the investors who knocked Consols share price are rightly skeptical, Breakingviews says. By hedging its energy bets, the coal company risks confusing investors and sealing in a conglomerate discount, the publication argues.

title: Dow Manages to Turn Higher at the Close
description: Uncertainty seemed to greet investors wherever they turned on Monday.

title: Europe Creates Apparatus to Provide Greece Loans
