description: Finance ministers from the 16 countries using the euro as their currency said Monday they were ready to help rescue Greece, The New York Timess Stephen Castle reported.

title: PepsiCo Adds to Buyback Plan
description: PepsiCo said Monday that it would buy back up to $15 billion worth of its own common stock through June 2013, The Associated Press reported.

title: Michael Jacksons Estate Signs Sweeping Contract
description: Nine months after Michael Jacksons death, his estate has signed one of the biggest recording contracts in history, giving Sony, Mr. Jacksons longtime label, the rights to sell his back catalog and draw on a large vault of unheard recordings, The New York Timess Ben Sisario reported.

title: A.I.G. Closes Transatlantic Holdings Offering
description: The American International Group said Monday it closed a secondary public offering of Transatlantic Holdings for about $452 million, The Associated Press reported.

title: Oncaps Deal for Sports Supply May Hit Hurdles
description: Sport Supply Group, a sporting goods supplier in Dallas, said Monday that it had signed a deal to sell itself to private equity firm Oncap Management Partners, a unit of Canadas Onex, for around $170 million, The Dallas Morning News reported.

title: EU Puts Off New Rules for Hedge Funds
description: E.U. finance ministers delayed a decision on new rules for hedge funds Tuesday in a reprieve for Britain, which fears that too-tight regulation could drive the industry from London, James Kanter reports in The New York Times.

title: Nonmilitary Solutions
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.  The war couldnt feel farther away. New Haven today is deafeningly quiet  it is Spring Break here, so the student throngs have mostly fled to warmer climes. The final days of class were filled with excited chatter of travel and merriment; other concerns paled in comparison.

title: The Envelope, Please: Six Applicants for the Class of 2014 Tell Their Own Stories
description: Much of the anxiety of waiting by the mailbox to retrieve decision letters from the nations most selective colleges has  like so much of the admissions process  gone digital in recent years. Whether an envelope is considered fat or thin is more likely measured in bytes. And yet, the day that decisions are formally released by many of the most competitive institutions, whether by e-mail or United States mail, remains as it always has: April 1.

title: The Car-puccino
description: A car that runs on leftover coffee grounds.

title: Awash in Nervous Anticipation
description: When I am not reading Calvin and Hobbes or watching ice hockey or drinking coffee, I am nervously anticipating the results of my college applications. And let me tell you, the worst part of the pre-college experience is not the essays or the rush to meet the deadlines. It is the waiting. It is in this miserable, hellish period that I scrutinize my accomplishments and failures; quantify myself into SAT scores and G.P.A.s, and wonder with growing horror why the numbers dont add up.

title: A Missed Deadline Provides a Costly Lesson
description: Applying to college has been nerve-racking enough, but I inadvertently made my own admissions process even worse. On my very first application I missed an important deadline  to the school I considered my safety, the University of Texas at Austin. And now I worry I may not get in anywhere else. Allow me to explain.

title: Calpers Votes to Speak Out More Often
description: The board of Californias giant public pension fund voted Monday to remove the limit on the number of shareholder proposals it can issue to companies in its portfolio, The Associated Press reported.

title: Doubts About Diversity Training
description: Todays idea: Though diversity training has been widely embraced by corporate America, theres little evidence so far that it works, sociologists find.

title: Renault and Daimler Said to Discuss Share Swap
description: Renault and Daimler, the two European carmakers long in talks to collaborate more extensively, may be considering going as far as a share swap, Max Warburton, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, said Monday.

title: Shrinking Detroit Back to Greatness
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: On the Wings of an Unusual Exhibition
description: We know that birds can make music of a sort: birdsong. But what about something with a little backbeat?

title: Wind Turbine Factory to Create 1,000 Jobs, Backers Say
description: From John Collins Rudolf at Green Inc.:

title: Twitter to Tie More Into Other Sites
description: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

title: Former Schering Executives Take Reins at Bausch
description: Two former top executives of drug maker Schering-Plough were named on Monday as leaders of privately owned eye-care company Bausch & Lomb, Reuters reported.

title: Former A.I.G. Employees Might Sue Over Payouts
description: Several former American International Group employees might sue the insurer after it gave them less retention bonus money than they should have received, Reuters reported, citing lawyers for the employees.

title: Home Charging for Electric Vehicle: Costs Will Vary
description: By the end of the year, at least five plug-in cars, including the Nissan Leaf and Chevrolet Volt, are expected to be on the market. And as electric vehicles roll out, their owners will be wiring their homes to accommodate what is called Level 2 charging. The wall-mounted 220-240-volt boxes can recharge an E.V.s batteries in four to eight hours.

title: Sampler: Pleasanton Must Grow, and Pink Slips for Teachers
description: The Number of Californias Uninsured Is Up | The states unemployment rate has led to a 28 percent jump in the number of the people who are uninsured to 8.2 million in 2009, from 6.4 million in 2007, according to a report from the University of California, Los Angeles. Among those under age 65, 24.3 percent were uninsured in 2009. [The Los Angeles Times]

title: Hedge Funds May Pull in $222 Billion This Year
description: Hedge funds across the globe could pull in $222 billion in fresh capital in 2010, Bloomberg News reported, citing a new survey by Deutsche Bank.

title: In Deutsche Report, Billions for Risk-Takers
description: Deutsche Bank says it made net income of 5 billion euros ($6.9 billion) in 2009 and that it expects the banking market to progress slowly toward a new form of normality this year and next, The Associated Press reports.

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, March 16
description: Highlights from media coverage in Tuesdays New York Times:

title: Q&A: Powering a Laptop Overseas
description: Q.

title: Steady Fed Policy Provides Scant Impetus for Investors
description: The Federal Reserves decision to keep interest rates near zero helped lead the Dow Jones industrial average to a sixth day of gains on Tuesday. But the enthusiasm was restrained, disappointing those who had hoped low rates would give the market reason for a new upward thrust.

title: The Early Word: Crunch Time
description: Well, thats one way to get health care legislation passed.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: High-Speed Rail Gains Traction in SpainThe Alta Velocidad Espaola, or AVE, has made train travel in Spain the way to go, both environmentally and in comfort and convenience.

title: U.S. Housing Starts Slowed by Blizzards
description: Home building slowed in February as snowstorms stopped construction in some of the countrys largest markets, a Commerce Department report indicated Tuesday.

title: Re-Tooling Albertas Energy Royalties
description: After a year of intense criticism from the energy industry and its political rivals, Albertas embattled Conservative government last week announced it would ease up on provincial royalties in a bid to kick-start investment and create more jobs, especially in the natural gas and conventional oil sectors.

title: Former Bank Chief Is Charged With Bailout Fraud
description: Charles J. Antonucci Sr., a former president of the Park Avenue Bank in Manhattan, was charged on Monday with fraud, embezzlement and bribery in what the authorities called the first criminal case of trying to defraud the federal governments bank bailout program.

title: State of the Jets: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Passing Health Care Legislation, Tucked in a Rule
description: As they push for a climactic vote on major health care legislation, House Democratic leaders face a bit of a conundrum: rank-and-file lawmakers detest the Senate-passed health care bill, and yet before the Democrats overall proposal becomes law, the House somehow has to find a way to approve that Senate bill.

title: Hot Role For White-Hot White
description: Hey, Betty White, how about leaving some work for the rest of Hollywood? Sure, Ms. White, the 88-year-old comedy phenomenon, could have packed it in after her run on The Mary Tyler Moore Show, or called it a career after the success of The Golden Girls (and the not-quite-success of its spinoff Golden Palace). But no: she is now set to appear in a newseries for TV Land called Hot in Cleveland, The Associated Press reported. The show stars three other comedy veterans of a different generation  Valerie Bertinelli (of One Day at a Time), Jane Leeves (Frasier) and Wendie Malick (Just Shoot Me)  as Los Angeles migrs who end up in Cleveland. Ms. White, who plays the caretaker of the house they live in, was originally set just for the pilot episode. But as she enjoys a career resurgence that includes agig hosting on Saturday Night Live in May, Ms. White was bumped up to a series regular. Hot in Cleveland will start showing on TV Land in June, by which time we fully expect Ms. White to be president of the channel.

title: Online Hate Sites Grow With Social Networks
description: Terrorists and racists are turning to online social networks and depending less on traditional Web sites, according to a new report on digital terror and hate speech.

title: Colbert Reports He Anointed San Franciscos Unwilling Messiah
description: Remember Raj Patel? The man who wrote The Value of Nothing then went on a book tour and returned to find himself declared a messiah? It had the same effect on his e-mail in-box that a burst pipe has on a wooden floor  it buckled and nearly collapsed.

title: Testing Obama, at Home and Abroad
description: WASHINGTON  In the last days of the 2008 presidential campaign, Joseph Biden warned that It will not be six months before the world tests Barack Obama like they did John Kennedy. The young new president, his running mate declared, would face crisis, a generated crisis, to test the mettle of this guy.

title: Apple Hires Wearable Computing Engineer
description: Apple has hired Richard DeVaul, a veteran of the wearable computing field and co-founder of AWare Technologies, a technology company focused on creating products for the fitness and wellness markets.

title: Dads in the Delivery Room
description: A few months ago, a French obstetrician suggested that if fathers really wanted to help their partners in the delivery room, they would just stay away. They may think they are helping, Dr. Michael Odent said, but they are probably only making the mothers stressed, slowing their production of the hormone oxytocin, which results in a prolonged labor and an increased risk of Caesarian section.

title: Israel Objects to U.S. Construction Demands
description: JERUSALEM  The discord between the United States and Israel over Jewish building in East Jerusalem deepened Tuesday with Israeli officials saying they would reject demands by Washington and expressing anger over the public upbraiding of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu by the Obama administration.

title: Artists Arrive on Governors Island
description: This week, nearly 30 visual and performing artists are moving onto Governors Island, the beginning of a year-round artist studio program organized by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. In the newly renovated Building 110, artists will have the use of 20studios, two rehearsal areas and a large exhibition space with views of Lower Manhattan and New York Harbor. The residencies run from March to July and from August to December; the public can have access to the studios from June to mid-October. The cultural council was selected by the Governors Island Preservation and Education Corporation after a competitive request for proposals.

title: China Fails to Dispel Mystery About Missing Dissident
description: HONG KONG  Chinas foreign minister waded into the mystery over the disappearance more than a year ago of one of the countrys most prominent human rights lawyers, but his remarks on Tuesday shed little light on the lawyers fate.

title: Modernism on a Chain
description: There comes a point in some long-term relationships when gifts of gold and silver jewelry are replaced by those of chrome and leather furniture. The romantic impulse behind giving the gift of Eames isnt any less sincere. Its just a different kind of intimacy.

title: Lincoln on Why God Made Erasers
description: Did Honest Abe make an honest error?

title: A Midmajor Study
description: This is a copy of the report, commissioned by Dave Telep, the national recruiting director of Scout.com, and researched and written by Drew Cannon in the summer of 2009, analyzing 32 players who made first-team all-league in midmajor conferences. The full report is below, and as a PDF here. Read more about the report and the players in Pete Thamels article.

title: Drug Giants Lag Where Sales Boom, Study Says
description: The leading drug makers need to move quickly to adapt to a new world order in which some emerging markets are set to overtake some established national markets in pharmaceutical sales, according to a report issued Tuesday.

title: Blame for Democrats  and Republicans
description: Democrats awoke on Tuesday to a double-barreled shot of criticism on two of the nations leading op-ed pages over lack of bipartisanship in the health care debate.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Multi-Culti
description: For the designer Miguel Adrover, getting dressed is a sociological experiment.

title: Catholic Bishops Renew Criticism of Abortion Restrictions
description: With the abortion issue still roiling the health care debate on Capitol Hill, the president of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops has issued a statement criticizing the Senate-passed legislation as insufficient in setting restrictions on the use of federal money for insurance coverage of abortions.

title: Called for an Overhaul
description: Monologue |  Monday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: In his weekly radio and Internet address, President Obama called for an overhaul of the No Child Left Behind law. It will now be called The World Needs Janitors, Too.

title: Even the Taliban Move Their Clocks Ahead
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Everybody changed their clocks this weekend for daylight savings. So you move it ahead. And even the Taliban move their clocks ahead. They moved it up to the 11th century. So thats good.

title: Broad Street, Lower Manhattan, 8:40 A.M.
A Compostable Chips Bag Hits the Shelves
description: One of the obvious environmental downsides of eating chips is the packaging. Billions of bags hit dumpsters every year.

title: The 2.0 Report | Williamsburg Is the New Williamsburg
description: Should you find yourself wandering the streets of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, these days,you might be reminded of another Williamsburg, the restored historic village in Virginia. With shops like the Brooklyn Kitchen, where you can learn how to pickle vegetablesand butcher your own pig, and Rye, where you can sip an old-fashioned at the 100-year-old oak bar, the neighborhood hasnt quite returned to colonial times  but chances are your server will have facial hair and woolens that would do an 18th-century blacksmith proud. There are glass blowers (Michael Anchin Glass Company), perfume makers (CBI Hate Perfume) and illegal urban beekeepers whove set up shop in East Williamsburgwith that same can-do spirit that got us to the New World in the first place. While you might not hear the resounding fife and drums of our founding fathers, the bars on Bedford Avenue are jammed with Bunyan-bearded hipsters who look as if they moonlight in a fiddle band. And the spirit of Patrick Henry lives on in these Brooklynites, whose call to arms is Give me bike lanes or give me death!

title: Bright Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Bright Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Two Brain Trusts
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Thank you for coming on the Ides of March. You know, this is March 15. It was on this day in 44 B.C., Julius Caesar met his end. He was stabbed in the back by members of the Senate, ironically, while pleading for health care.

title: Photo Tip: Slowing a Babbling Brook
description: I was going through some old (really old) e-mail the other night and stumbled across an exchange with a helpful Olympus product manager that taught me an important lesson about photography.

title: Sheen Pleads Not Guilty in Domestic Violence Case
description: The actor Charlie Sheen pleaded not guilty to domestic violence charges in an Aspen, Colo., court on Monday, The Associated Press reported, setting the stage for a trial and leaving unanswered questions about how Mr. Sheen will continue to take part in his CBS sitcom, Two and a Half Men.

title: Cabling Your Mac
description: NewerTech, a Mac accessories maker, has a new solution to make it easier to get video with resolution as high as 1080p from your recent-generation Macintosh onto a big flat screen TV (or any modern digital set).

title: Epley Said to Leave Deutsche for Nomura
description: Mark Epley, head of Deutsche Banks team that caters to private-equity firms, is leaving to take a job at Nomura Holdings, a person with knowledge of his plans told Bloomberg News.

title: Citi Said to Shore Up Proprietary Trading Group
description: Never mind the calls from Washington to limit proprietary trading, the business of banks making financial bets using their own capital.

title: Postcard From the Arctic Sea Ice
description: For several years, Rhett Herman, a physics professor at Radford University, has been leading students on an expedition each spring break to study the condition of the sea ice off the coast near Barrow, Alaska. A blog of this years trip and photos and journals from previous trips are online. Below you can read a Dot Earth postcard Dr. Herman sent last week (theyve just returned home). Ill be adding some of the students post-trip thoughts in the comments section. The photo below, by Dr. Herman, shows students using an OhmMapper to generate a cross section view of the ice beneath their feet. (Mythianne Shelton hauling the gear, Susan Christopher at the tail end of the array and Jason McLarty nearby.)

title: Ocean Adventure Fill-In
description: Go to related article

title: By Ancient Ruins, a Gay Haven in Cambodia
description: IT was 10 p.m. in Siem Reap, and while most tourists were tucked in after a long, hot day exploring the temples of Angkor, things were just getting going at a bar called Linga. Pairs of European men in their 30s and 40s wearing unbuttoned collared shirts and checkered krama scarves sipped fruity cocktails and jostled for space with the young Khmer crowd, who huddled around small tables in anticipation of the main event: the Saturday night drag show.

title: City Health Board Agrees to Require Letter Grades for Restaurant Cleanliness
description: The New York City Board of Health voted Tuesday to rate cleanliness in the citys more than 24,000 restaurants with publicly posted letter grades, adopting a controversial plan proposed 14 months ago by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

title: Case Study | Got Your Pickleback
description: Three years ago, Reggie Cunningham, a young rogue in my employ who balladeers about town under the nom de rap of the Mr. Move, asked me to check out the bar where he worked in outer Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The Bushwick Country Club had all the amenities: a trash-strewn backyard featuring a derelict miniature-golf course, Christmas bulbs strung up for lighting, stout in a Styrofoam cup and a staff comprised of what one Yelper described as an odd assortment of pirates and misfits. I kinda liked it. It had a gritty, improvisational feel; if you were there, it was probably not by accident.

title: Rural Haiti Struggles to Absorb Displaced
description: FOND-DES-BLANCS, Haiti  Before the earthquake that changed everything, Chlotilde Pelteau and her husband lived a supremely urban existence. A cosmetics vendor and a mechanic, they both enjoyed a steady clientele and a hectic daily routine, serenaded by the beeping cars and general hubbub of Port-au-Prince.

title: Capital Export, Elasticity Pessimism, and the Renminbi (Wonkish)
description: I got a little snippy with Ryan Avent yesterday over the remminbi issue; I guess I dont like being compared to Donald Rumsfeld. In any case, however, I think it would be useful for me to explain how I think about the current China syndrome, and why I believe that most of the responses I hear are missing the point. In what follows, Ill focus on three questions: the macroeconomics of Chinese currency intervention, the fallacies of elasticity pessimism (which Ill explain when I get there), and the political economy issue of how to deal with Chinese intransigence.

title: How the Lehman Report Was Made
description: For Lehman Brothers court-appointed examiner, Anton R. Valukas, to finish his exhaustive report on the decline of the investment bank and its accounting practices, the lawyer reviewed by his own estimate about 34 million pages of e-mail, a tiny fraction of the 350 billion pages he and his team had at their disposal.

title: Video of Thai Blood-Spilling Protest
description: Opponents of the Thai government, who are known for the red shirts they wear to protests, poured buckets of their own blood under the gates of the prime ministers office on Tuesday, as my colleague Thomas Fuller reports from Bangkok.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Another Devils Milestone, and a Big Late Win for Detroit
description: Only three games on Monday, including the titanic showdown at the Saddledome between the two clubs straddling the Western post-season cutoff line. Home teams listed first:

title: F.C.C. Questioned on Its Far-Reaching Plan to Expand Broadband Access
description: Federal regulators on Tuesday made public the details of their ambitious policy to encourage the spread of high-speed Internet access. But their 376-page proposal, the National Broadband Plan, was met with a chorus of questions, even from the staunchest advocates of its goals.

title: New Book Serves Up a Fresh Side of Julia Child
description: Whether you followed Julia Child voraciously from the 1961 publication of her first cookbook or only just discovered her through the 2009 movie Julie & Julia, a new book is promising a fresh look at the life and career of the beloved chef and author, told through her correspondence with a longtime friend.

title: Back to School, and Right Back on Vacation
description: The dawn of the new school year means all kinds of traditions  freshly sharpened pencils, new backpacks, tales of summer camp and road trips. This year, it also means two extra days of vacation.

title: Finding a Method to the N.C.A.A. Madness
description: The affliction is common at this time of year, perhaps even epidemic. It is short-lived, by necessity, but can seriously sap productivity, energy, the ability to focus on anything but the empty bracket staring back at you on the computer screen. Perhaps you even double your agony by trying to pick both the mens and womens tournaments  hey, double the chance at the iPad!  and find yourself doubled over with emptybracketitis.

title: New Tools for Financial Planning Advice
description: Personal finance tools have traditionally acted as money manager and financial product advocate. Now, a couple of new tools claim another role: financial planner.

description: 5:42 p.m. |Inter Milan 1, Chelsea 0: Inter Advances on Aggregate, 3-1

title: Objection Withdrawn, John Grisham Embraces E-Books
description: John Grisham, the blockbuster writer of legal thrillers and until now a holdout against e-books, is entering the digital age.

title: Nomuras European Chief Plans to Retire
description: From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague:

title: Bring On the Bees
description: New York Citys board of health voted Tuesday to lift a ban against beekeeping, legalizing the hives of hundreds of residents who have tended bees in defiance of the law.

title: A Choice of Headlines
description: By this time next week well have seen huge headlines about health care. These headlines will either read Democrats do it!, followed by various Republicans and their apologists complaining that what the Dems did wasnt nice, or Democrats  losers again, followed by Republicans going bwahahaha.

title: Does Universal Health Care Discourage Abortions?
description: Does universal health care reduce the abortion rate?

title: Statements by an Artist, for the Palms of Strangers
description: For more than 30 years now, sharp-eyed New Yorkers have been finding them on ledges, windowsills and store counters  poker-chip-size coins that reveal themselves to be something far more mysterious than loose change.

title: Raita
description: Mark Bittman makes a thick, rich cucumber dip using homemade yogurt cheese.

title: Fatwa Flashing
description: The issuing and counter-issuing of conflicting fatwas  Islamic religious rulings.

title: Tournament Tipoff
description: The Times's college sports reporter Pete Thamel breaks down some of the major themes emerging from the N.C.A.A. men's tournament bracket.

title: Obama Restores Former Pentagon Line of Succession
description: WASHINGTON  It is a morbid theme, but one that no superpower can ignore. So the Obama administration has quietly reviewed, and revised, the sequence in which Pentagon civilian officials would take command should Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates die unexpectedly, say in a surprise attack.

title: A Serious Savory Breakfast
description: For whatever reason  I ran out, I had other grains to eat, maybe I was a little tired of it  I went through most of the winter without eating oatmeal for breakfast. And when I began again, the first morning I turned to maple syrup, which seems the default. But on day two, I woke up with one of those odd cravings, one of those bizarre certainties about what I was going to have for breakfast. The most amazing thing  to me, at least  was that Id never made this before, yet I knew it was going to be perfect.

title: Catching Up on Health Care
description: Updated: Protesters descended on parts of the Capitol grounds today, voicing their opposition to health care legislation that is under debate in the House. Some organizers belonged to the Tea Party movement, and some demonstrators were focusing on vulnerable Democratic lawmakers facing tough re-election bids in conservative districts.

title: When Tics Appear Later in Life
description: Tourettes syndrome, marked by uncontrollable urges to move the body or vocalize, can be a lifelong sruggle for some. Dr. Robert A. King and Dr. James F. Leckman of the Yale School of Medicine recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about Tourettes. Here, they respond to readers asking about the long-term course of the syndrome.

title: ArtsBeat: John Grisham Overcomes His Aversion to E-Books
description: As Motoko Rich is reporting on our sister blog, ArtsBeat, the blockbuster author John Grisham, a longtime holdout against e-books, has agreed to allow the Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group to release digital versions of 23 of his backlist titles. This is one of our most exciting e-book initiatives to date, Sonny Mehta, chairman and editor-in-chief of Knopf Doubleday, said in a statement, and is certain to usher in a new generation of Grisham readers and e-book adopters. Read more.

title: The Magnificent Seven
description: Coming soon to a saloon (or brasserie) near you.

title: Emery and Grenier to Star in Gabriel for Atlantic Theater
description: For its final main-stage production of the 2009-10 season the Atlantic Theater Company announced on Tuesday that the veteran New York actors Lisa Emery and Zach Grenier would lead the cast of Gabriel, Moira Buffinis play about the German occupation of the Channel Islands in World War II, and that David Esbjornson had signed on to direct.

title: Bolstered by Finance Unit, G.E. May Raise Dividend
description: General Electric, which cut its common stock dividend last year for the first time since the Great Depression, may increase it next year and repurchase stock for the first time since 2008 because of a snapback at its GE Capital finance unit, the companys chief financial officer, Keith S. Sherin, said Tuesday, according to Bloomberg News.

title: An Alternative to Chemotherapy Takes Venture Competition
description: This past weekend, Carnegie Mellon Universitys Tepper School of Business and the Donald H. Jones Center for Entrepreneurship held its McGinnis Venture Competition for start-ups that bring new technologies to market. Three entrants each won $20,000 seed finance offers and $20,000 worth of legal and business consulting services in their respective competition tracks: life sciences, clean tech and general technology.

title: App of the Week: A Reason to Use the Phone in the Car
description: While I would generally never encourage you to use a mobile phone in your car, Im going to make an exception.

title: Gibran Academy Principal Quits
description: Updated, 1:23 p.m. | The principal of the citys only Arabic-language public school has abruptly stepped down in the middle of the year.

title: Will It Pass? The Odds on Health Care
description: Updated, 6:40 p.m. |  Jacob S. Hacker, a political science professor at Yale, joins the discussion.

title: Its Still a Beautiful Day in His Neighborhood
description: PITTSBURGH  Nationally, it may seem that in the seven years since Fred Rogerss death, the legacy of Americas favorite neighbor has waned.

title: New Jersey Governor Proposes Deep Spending Cuts
description: TRENTON  Christopher J. Christie, the first Republican elected governor of New Jersey in 12 years, unveiled a $29.3 billion budget on Tuesday that relies almost exclusively on spending cuts to reverse the sagging fortunes of a state he sees as battered by the recession and choking on its tax burden.

title: A Television Project That Might Make Steve Jobs iRate
description: If Steven P. Jobs wants relief from one of his more merciless satirists, a television set may not be the best place to turn. On Tuesday, the cable channel Epix and the studio Media Rights Capital said they had struck a development deal for a new series called iCon, to be written by Dan Lyons, a Newsweek contributor who has sent up the Apple chief executive on his popular blog, The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs, and in his novel Options: The Secret Life of Steve Jobs  A Parody. The project, which Epix described in a news release as a savage satire centering on a fictional Silicon Valley CEO whose ego is a study in power and greed, is being overseen by Larry Charles, the director of Borat, Religulous and Brno and a veteran writer and producer of Seinfeld and Curb Your Enthusiasm; the half-hour, single camera series will be produced by Media Rights Capital.

title: Doctors and Patients, Not Talking About Weight
description: Doctors recognize obesity as a health problem. So why is it so hard for them to talk to their patients about it?

title: For Return, Woods Picks Place Hes at Ease
description: An outpouring of support from peers, sponsors and officials greeted the announcement by Tiger Woods that his self-imposed exile from golf would end at the Masters in April  a first step in a return to normalcy on the competitive side of his life.

title: The Womens N.I.T. Gets Expansion Fever
description: There is a new twist to this years Womens National Invitation Tournament: the field is expanding to 64 teams.

title: Patrick Wilson on 'Barry Munday'
description: Patrick Wilson discusses his unique comic role in "Barry Munday."

title: Greenberg on Two Years After Bears Fall
description: It seems almost like a footnote in history now, but on March 16 two years ago, JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy Bear Stearns for $2 a share.

title: In Mexico, Promises Do Little to Ease a Citys Pain
description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico  In the six weeks since gunmen killed 15 people in a working-class neighborhood here, the police, the governor, psychologists and even the presidents wife have descended.

title: Hoyer Defends Controversial House Procedure
description: The House majority leader, Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, defended on Tuesday the use of a procedural tool that would allow the House to pass a sweeping health care bill without a direct up-or-down vote on the legislation.

title: New Baseball Announcers for TBS
description: TBS, which cut its ties to Chip Caray last November, said on Tuesday that a three-man rotation would replace him on its Sunday afternoon regular-season baseball broadcasts: Dick Stockton, Brian Anderson and Ernie Johnson.

title: A Recipe Secret Wrapped in a Towel
description: THE so-called Greek yogurt that has become popular in recent years is neither a special kind of yogurt nor uniquely Greek. Its simply yogurt from which much of the water has been removed, a concoction that in its thickest form can be called yogurt cheese. You can find yogurt cheese in every country that has a history of yogurt making. In addition to being thicker and richer when eaten straight, it makes superior spreads and dips.

title: Roasted Eggplant-Yogurt Cheese Dip
description: 1 large eggplant or a few small ones

title: Africas Largest Wind Project Advances
description: Kenyas Lake Turkana Wind Power project  set to become Africas largest wind farm  looks to be back on track after securing financing through a new shareholding structure.

title: Q&A: A Spring West Coast Trip
description: Q.

title: Under Fire, Reporters Befriend Afghan Frog
description: Stuart Webb, a cameraman for Britains Channel 4 News embedded with British troops in Afghanistan, filed a video blog post on Tuesday that showed how he and a colleague, Alex Thomson, attempted to keep their cool while pinned down in a stream during a firefight  by making friends with a frog.

title: Vain Glorious | Elizabeth Ardens Feminist Lipstick
description: What: Elizabeth Arden Limited Edition Anniversary Lipstick in Red Door Red.

title: Tournament Tipoff: Mens Bracket Steeped in Drama
description: As the teams in the field of 65 prepare for their opening matchups and fans across the country work on perfecting their office pool bracket, The Timess Pete Thamel examines the relative strengths of this years bubble crop and wonders: Which No. 1 seed got a raw deal? Will the tournament expand its field next year? How will that affect the way the 2010 tournament will be remembered?

title: Under Fire, Reporters Befriend Afghan Frog
description: Stuart Webb, a cameraman for Britains Channel 4 News embedded with British troops in Afghanistan, filed a video blog post on Tuesday that showed how he and a colleague, Alex Thomson, attempted to keep their cool while pinned down in a stream during a firefight  by making friends with a frog.

title: Know the Score: Looking at South Africa Through the Lens of the World Cup
description: Overview | How is its history of apartheid continuing to affect life and politics in South Africa? How can South Africa best address the range of concerns regarding its hosting of the World Cup? In this lesson, students consider South Africas history and the legacy of apartheid along with news about the upcoming World Cup. They then engage in a simulation to generate policy recommendations for the South African government, with respect to hosting this international event.

title: N.F.L. Picks New Chairmen for Panel on Concussions
description: The N.F.L. further distanced itself from its tumultuous past regarding concussions on Tuesday by selecting two new co-chairmen for a renamed policy committee and accepting the resignation of one of that groups most prominent members.

title: Using Cellphone Signals to Track Cars When GPS Cannot
description: The idea that one can locate and track just about anything  your car, your dog, your spouse  using GPS is part of popular lore. Unfortunately (or fortunately, depending on your point of view) thats not true. GPS signals can be obscured or blocked.

title: A Video Explanation of Repo 105
description: Repo 105 from Marketplace on Vimeo.

title: Trailer: 'Le Donk and Scor-zay-zee'
description: A trailer for "Le Donk and Scor-zay-zee," the new comedy from the director Shane Meadows screening at South by Southwest and available on demand.

title: Fed Affirms Plan to End Mortgage Intervention
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve on Tuesday affirmed its plan to stop buying mortgage-backed securities, expressing a degree of confidence that it could eliminate that pillar of support without undermining the nations economic recovery.

title: Monserrate and Peralta Hit the Polls in State Senate Race
description: The early-morning vote by candidates is a long-standing political ritual, a chance to enjoy the warm embrace of other voters with news cameras in tow.

title: David Simon's "Treme"
description: A scene from the pilot "Treme," based in the New Orleans neighborhood of the same name.

title: Obama and Kaine Meet for Political Lunch
description: President Obama has sought to play down the political aspects of the health care debate, telling audiences again and again in recent days: I dont know about the politics, but I know whats the right thing to do.

title: The Beer Belly of America
description: Conservatives know it as the American heartland. Elitist liberals know it as flyover country. But to serious drinkers, the Midwest should perhaps be known as the beer belly of America.

title: Ahoy, Matey | Lets Get Nautical
description: A new group of yachts is catering to the boating crowds appetite for adventure and design. The 105-foot Necker Belle catamaran (virginlimitededition.com;$88,000 a week), refurbished last year by Sir Richard Branson, has a wine cellar, an outdoor movie theater and a three-person submersible for exploring reefs and wrecks. Reflecting the new emphasis on exploring remote waters, Cape Race (right; mvcaperace.com; $2,000 to $3,000 per person per week) is a converted fishing trawler  outfitted with six generous cabins and a mahogany-paneled saloon  that can cross the Atlantic twice without refueling. And the Panthalassa (camperandnicholsons.com; $200,000 a week), a 184-foot ketch with off-white interiors by Foster & Partners, has an oval stairway that brings sunlight to the lower level, where staterooms are paneled in leather and bathrooms tiled in black marble.

title: Cedar Fairs Last-Minute Change of Heart
description: Talk about a wild ride. The amusement park operator Cedar Fair announced on Monday night that it had postponed Tuesday mornings meeting for unit holders to vote on the companys acquisition by Apollo Management, saying it wanted to provide more time to solicit votes and proxies. For those unit holders who have already made the trip up to Sandusky, Ohio, for the meeting, they will have a relatively long wait. The meeting is postponed until April 8. Perhaps Cedar Fair will placate these unit holders with some free amusement park tickets in the interim.

title: The Connoisseur | Buying Time
description: In the universe of fine watches, time moves slowly. Serious European collectors and a growing cadre of wrist-conscious Americans concern themselves exclusively with watches powered by a spring technology invented more than 300 years ago. If it needs a Duracell, a watch snob isnt interested.

title: Nebraska, the Unknown Womens No. 1 Seed
description: Its an interesting theory: Nebraskas womens basketball team is the No. 1 seed in Kansas City regional of the N.C.A.A. tournament, yet the Huskers feel like an underdog.

title: Obama to Appear on Fox News
description: President Obama will give a rare interview on Wednesday to Fox News, the cable network that a top administration official once accused of being a political arm of the Republican Party.

title: Bronx Pawnshop Offers Cash and Condoms
description: Talk about a stimulus plan.

title: SXSW: Patrick Wilson and a Manic Munday
description: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

title: Offshore Wind a Boon to the Shipping Industry
description: With ocean-going trade slackening amid the global recession, shipping companies and shipyard operators in Europe are finding the offshore wind industry to be a welcome ally in weathering the bad times.

title: The Affluence Trap
description: From a John Lanchester essay on the prospects for Britains economy:

title: The Morning Skate: Will the N.H.L. Fast-Track the Blindside Head Check Rule?
description: Supplemental discipline has dominated many hockey conversations this season, the latest being Alex Ovechkins two-game ban following his boarding of the Blackhawks Brian Campbell on Sunday. Campbell broke a collarbone and several ribs when he was slammed against the boards. This morning on Toronto radio Fan 590, Scotty Bowman told Gord Stellick and Don Landry (audio here) he attributed plays like Ovechkins to post-lockout rules that prohibit defensemen from holding up forecheckers.

title: Pressure Grows in U.S. Over Chinas Currency
description: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress from both parties sought on Tuesday to put more pressure on China to allow an increase in the value of its currency, saying Beijings policy of holding the value down to give China an edge in export markets was holding back job creation in the United States.

title: Googles Doodles
description: Imagine that you and a fellow Stanford computer science grad have just been given a $100,000 check to bankroll a new business. The Burning Man festival is coming up, and you both want to go. What do you do? If youre Googles Sergey Brin and Larry Page, you make a rough sketch of the wooden effigy thats burned at the festival, add it to your Web site as an as an Out of Office sign and set off for the Nevada desert.

title: Director of Tate Modern Is Leaving
description: Vicente Todoli, who has run the Tate Modern in London for most of the young institutions existence, has decided to step down, the museum said Tuesday.

title: For a Few Female Riders, a Saturated First Race
description: Wind whipped sheets of frigid water across Riverside Drive Saturday morning as about 20 female cyclists shivered up to the starting line for their first race, the Grants Tomb Criterium, a short-course race around the New York landmark.

title: A Little Birthday Music for Sondheim
description: From Broadways prodigious boy wonder to its beloved aging monarch: For Stephen Sondheim, whose forthcoming 80th birthday on March 22 was celebrated in a thrilling concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening, it must have seemed like a hop, skip and a jump from one to the other. Inside the hall, where the mood was more exhilarated than elegiac, an unspoken question hung in the air: Where did all that time go?

title: Democratic Party Chairman Optimistic on Health Care Vote
description: This is the right thing to do, but its also good politics, Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said Tuesday after a private lunch with President Obama.

title: Googles Doodles
description: Imagine that you and a fellow Stanford computer science grad have just been given a $100,000 check to bankroll a new business. The Burning Man festival is coming up, and you both want to go. What do you do? If youre Googles Sergey Brin and Larry Page, you make a rough sketch of the wooden effigy thats burned at the festival, add it to your Web site as an as an Out of Office sign and set off for the Nevada desert.

title: Funeral Homes Violate Citys Pricing Rules
description: Dying is already a notably expensive proposition. But many funeral homes in the city make it even more expensive than it should be, the Department of Consumer Affairs said Tuesday.

title: Extended Monotony
description: Time to celebrate: It has now been a year since the Federal Reserves Federal Open Market Committee began pledging to keep interest rates exceptionally low for an extended period.

title: Colorado Caucuses: Just the Beginning
description: Democrats and Republicans hold precinct caucuses in Colorado tonight, the next step in a chain of events that will eventually lead to nominees for both Senate and governor.

title: Off the Menu: Tartinery Nolita
description: A little French homage to the great Parisian bread baker, Lionel Poilne, opened on Tuesday. Tartinery Nolita specializes in the kind of open-face sandwiches called tartines in France. All are made on toasted Poilne bread, flown in from Paris, and some are inspired by the cookbook, Les Meilleures Tartines de Lionel Poilane, by Mr. Poilne, who was killed in 2002 when the helicopter he was piloting crashed.

title: What Were Reading
There Will Be Floods
description: Far from any talk of the coming floods  rearranging deck chairs?  the Carroll Gardens Diary shouts out the much-unloved Board of Standards and Appeals, the independent city agency charged with resolving zoning issues, for a decision late last week preventing the construction of additional town houses as part of a Carroll Street development.

title: Off the Menu: Fatty Cue
description: Some mac and cheese or cornbread with your barbecue? Not at Fatty Cue, opening March 23 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Try the celery ribbons with yuzu and preserved Chinese cabbage instead.

title: How Value Investing Paid Off in the Crisis
description: The value investing thesis, championed by the Columbia University professors Benjamin Graham and David Dodd in the 1930s, was simple: find cheap stocks being sold below their intrinsic value, buy them, and then sell them when the market wakes up.

title: Its the Bricks That Make Butler Basketball Special
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Hinkle Fieldhouse looks like a red-brick airplane hangar, rising above the neighboring houses at one corner of the Butler University campus. And when a basketball game is played there, the cheers spill through its cracks and its leaky roof and its high windows.

title: House Hunting in ... Egypt
description: A SIX-BEDROOM SIX-BATH HOUSE IN NABQ, SINAI PENINSULA

title: M.I.T. Researchers Create Molecular Chips
description: Before you read on, take a guess what the image above might be. Go on, Ill wait.

title: More From Glaeser on Americas Shrinking Cities
description: If you enjoyed Edward L. Glaesers post this morning on right-sizing the declining city of Detroit, check out his interview on The Takeaway about how American cities adapt to shrinking populations. He is joined by Hunter Morrison, an urban planner in Youngstown, Ohio.

title: Another String Group Unleashes Its Inner Rock Band
description: Watching Brooklyn Rider play music from its new CD, Dominant Curve, at the colorfully lighted Angel Orensanz Foundation on Monday evening  just a few days after seeing the Kronos Quartet at Zankel Hall  it was hard not to think about how string quartets have revamped their image in the last quarter century.

title: Once for Insiders Only, an F1 Guide Goes Online for All
description: One of the greatest bits of news to come out of the weekend in Bahrain was that fans finally have access to the most authoritative and certainly the best guide to Formula One statistics online.

title: Renewing an Old Idea: Common Good
description: The British historian Tony Judt is dying, slowly and painfully, from a variant of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (A.L.S.), better known as Lou Gehrigs disease. He has written matter-of-factly about his condition  he is now, essentially, a quadriplegic  in The New York Review of Books. At some point he will be able to communicate only by blinking an eye. For now he is dictating his words to assistants.

title: Portobello and Fried Egg Panino
description: I came up with this recipe one night after putting my son to bed. I had fed him before his soccer practice, too early for me, and by the time he was bathed and in pajamas, I was starving. I looked in the refrigerator and found some portobello mushrooms left over from another recipe test, and I knew I had something to work with. Fifteen minutes later, I sat down to this open-faced sandwich with a little salad on the side  a simple, light and utterly satisfying late supper. Its a good meal to make when you notice that the portobellos in the refrigerator have seen better days.

title: Seeing Change in Neighborhoods, Through a Pint Glass
description: When Peter OHanlon opened the Blarney Bar in downtown Jamaica, Queens in 1965, he served a mostly white clientele, including the union leaders and members who held their meetings in the back room.

title: Bridge Over the Visa Moat for Musicians Trying to Enter the U.S.
description: Of the 2,000 bands at the annual South by Southwest Music and Media Conference this week in Austin, Tex., more than 500 are from outside the United States. And to help make their way through the byzantine process of obtaining an American visa, about 200 of them have sent their paperwork, their prayers and $600 to one tiny office on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: Followers of Sadr Emerge Stronger After Iraq Elections
description: BAGHDAD  The followers of Moktada al-Sadr, a radical cleric who led the Shiite insurgency against the American occupation, have emerged as Iraqs equivalent of Lazarus in elections last week, defying ritual predictions of their demise and now threatening to realign the nations balance of power.

title: SXSW: At the Festival, in Your Home
description: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

title: Wine Bargains of the Loire Valley
description: AMONG the many wonderful, distinctive red wines in the world, those from the Loire Valley may well get the least respect in proportion to their superb quality.

title: Pairings: Stir-Fry Duck With Mushrooms and Broccolini
description: The last time I was in Chinon, I had lunch at a charming restaurant, Au Plaisir Gourmand. The name is fitting: Chinon was the birthplace of Rabelais, who valued indulgence at the table. We began with andouilles (tripe sausages) and continued with livre  la royale (hare stuffed with foie gras), as we poured more than one bottle of Chinon. I have never made either dish. But with these wines I still want something bold, earthy and luscious. Did someone say Asian? Starting with duck breast, sliced thick enough to be succulent in a stir-fry, I added mushrooms, broccolini and musky oyster sauce. Unless you worship at the table of Rabelais, the recipe is more than ample for two.

title: A Home in Sinai
description: A six-bedroom six-bath house in Nabq, on the Sinai Peninsula, is on the market for 3.5 million Egyptian pounds ($640,000).

title: Study Finds Almost 1 in 4 Uninsured in California
description: The number of uninsured adults and children in California swelled by 28 percent between 2007 and 2009, according to a new report by researchers at the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Ill Fares the Land
description: Introduction: A Guide for the Perplexed

title: Fabulous Dead People | Millicent Rogers
description: In this new monthly column, Fabulous Dead People, T looks back at the movers and shakers who once had the temerity and gall to break all the rules, so that todays fashion faithful can break theirs.

title: Debriefing the Bahrain Grand Prix
description: By the time the engine in Sebastian Vettels Red Bull soured (on lap 34 of 49 looong laps) while he was leading the Bahrain Grand Prix on Sunday, it looked as if Fernando Alonsos Ferrari was finally closing the gap  something that would have injected real excitement into the final laps of a race that had so far been more like a conga line.

title: Landmarks Worldwide Go Green on St. Patricks Day
description: According to Bloomberg, the London Eye, the Sydney Opera House and the Empire State Building in New York will go green Wednesday in a St. Patricks Day promotion by Ireland to lure tourists back after visitor numbers slumped to a five-year low.

title: Alexander Hamilton Was Always At War With Eastasia
description: Oh, my. Dick Armey invokes the Federalist Papers on behalf of the tea party movement:

title: More Julia Child, as Told Through Her Letters
description: Whether you followed Julia Child, right, voraciously from the 1961 publication of her first cookbook or only just discovered her through the 2009 movie Julie & Julia, a new book is promising a fresh look at the life and career of the beloved chef and author, told through her correspondence with a longtime friend. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt said that on Dec. 1 it will release a book called As Always, Julia: The Letters of Julia Child and Avis DeVoto, containing nearly 15 years of correspondence between Ms. Child and Ms. DeVoto, the cook and writer who helped land Ms. Childs original manuscript for Mastering the Art of French Cooking at the publisher Alfred A. Knopf. The letters, written from 1952 to 1965, begin not long after Ms. Child began teaching cooking to American women in Paris and chronicle her travels across Europe with her husband, as well as the development and publication of Mastering the Art of French Cooking.

title: Art as Accountability
description: Daniel Larison didnt much care for my column on Monday. Heres his retort to my complaint about Hollywoods simplistic takes on recent U.S. foreign policy:

title: Properties for $350,000
description: Homes in Boise, Idaho, Chester, S.C., and Jackson Miss.

title: Betty White Lands a Hot Role
description: Betty White, the 88-year-old comedy phenomenon, could have packed it in after her run on The Mary Tyler Moore Show, or called it a career after the success of The Golden Girls (and the not-quite-success of its spinoff Golden Palace). But no: she is now set to appear in a new series for TV Land called Hot in Cleveland, The Associated Press reported. The show stars three other comedy veterans of a different generation  above from left, Jane Leeves (Frasier), Ms. White, Valerie Bertinelli (of One Day at a Time) and Wendie Malick (Just Shoot Me)  as Los Angeles migrs who end up in Cleveland. Ms. White, who plays the caretaker of the house they live in, was originally set just for the pilot episode. But as she enjoys a career resurgence that includes a gig hosting on Saturday Night Live in May, Ms. White was made a series regular. Hot in Cleveland will start showing on TV Land in June.

title: What You Get for ... $350,000
description: BOISE, IDAHO
