description: From the Formula One blog:

title: TV Project Might Make Steve Jobs Irate
description: If Steven P. Jobs wants relief from one of his more merciless satirists, a television set may not be the best place to turn. On Tuesday the cable channel Epix and the studio Media Rights Capital said they had struck a development deal for a new series called iCon, to be written by Dan Lyons, a Newsweek contributor who has sent up Mr. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple Computer, on his popular blog, the Secret Diary of Steve Jobs (fakesteve.net), and in his novel Options: The Secret Life of Steve Jobs  A Parody. The project, which Epix described in a news release as a savage satire centering on a fictional Silicon Valley C.E.O. whose ego is a study in power and greed, is being overseen by Larry Charles, the director of Borat, Religulous and Brno and a veteran writer and producer of Seinfeld and Curb Your Enthusiasm. No date was given for when iCon will have its debut or when it might be available on iTunes.

title: City Center to Begin $75 Million Renovation
description: City Center, dedicated by Mayor Fiorello La Guardia in 1943 as Manhattans first major performing arts center, is embarking on a $75 million renovation and restoration of its landmark neo-Moorish building on West 55th Street.

title: For Asia, Some Familiar Hallways
description: ASIA is beginning to look a lot more like America  at least when it comes to hotels.

title: No Comment
description: Yes, I know that comments have disappeared. Its some kind of WordPress issue, and will presumably be resolved soon.

title: A Fresh Look for a Landmark in Macao
description: DOWN a crooked lane across from a shabby beauty shop, the old Macao mansion known as the Mandarins House always seemed to have space for newcomers knocking at its gate. Built around 1869, the house and its 60-odd rooms started to fill with renters after 1920. As more tenants moved in, parlors were subdivided, doors were added, staircases were moved. When still more came, they built shacks in the garden.

title: Taiwans Steaming Pools of Paradise
description: THERE is nothing quite as bracing as the smell of rotten eggs in the morning.

title: Iraq Elections: Sadr and His Rivals
description: Stephen Farrell of the Baghdad bureau speaks with Anthony Shadid about the first results of the parliamentary elections that took place March 7 and the vote's consequences on the Shiite coalition.

title: In Vietnam, Cauldrons on Every Corner
description: YOU like congealed pigs blood? my travel companion asked, pulling me over to a street cart in Ho Chi Minh City. Before I could answer, two bowls of chao, a rice porridge bobbing with slices of pork sausage and cubes of coagulated blood, were plopped in our hands.

title: New Life in Old Hong Kong
description: WAN CHAI used to be best known among foreigners as an area crowded with seedy bars and massage parlors, but it remained popular for locals, filled with historic tenement blocks, old-fashioned street markets by day and youngsters shooting hoops after school. Now, the Hong Kong neighborhood is thriving, as a nascent cultural scene emerges and as young creative types and entrepreneurs alike are being lured by cheaper rents.

title: 36 Hours in Phuket, Thailand
description: THE teardrop-shaped island of Phuket has long been known for its dazzling beaches and naughty night life. But for many, it was the catastrophic Asian tsunami in 2004 that finally placed Phuket on the map. Recovery has been swift, and in recent years the island has firmly reasserted itself as a premier beach resort in southern Thailand, with a growing crop of luxury hotels, top-notch restaurants and even a thriving art community.

title: BlogTalk: RedState and Virginia Thomas
description: Erick Erickson, publisher of RedState.com, one of the leading conservative blogs, is joining the MSM, as the right-leaning blogs like to refer to the mainstream media.

title: Restaurant Review: Prakash, in Mumbai
description: Decades ago, a recipe for sabudana vada sealed the fate and fortune of Prakash.

title: Hotel Review: Aman at Summer Palace in Beijing
description: THE BASICS

title: His Motives May Vary, but, Alas, Actaeon Is Doomed to Suffer the Same Fate
Spreading the Wealth for a Full-Bodied Bach
description: It is, you might think, the season for Bach Passions in New York. Though high-profile performances of the monumental St. Matthew Passion, especially, have abounded in recent years, those who list such events at The New York Times have not yet turned up one.

title: The Reds of the Loire
description: Alright, all you fans of Loire reds, come out from wherever you are hiding. Thats right, I mean both of you!

title: Tate Modern Loses Director
description: Vicente Todoli, who has run the Tate Modern in London for most of the young institutions existence, has decided to step down, the museum said on Tuesday. Mr. Todoli, 51, took over the directorship in 2003 after running the Serralves Museum of Contemporary Art in Oporto, Portugal. He said in a statement that he felt the time had arrived for a pause in his career, one that he had initially meant to take before the opportunity to direct the Tate Modern came along. Under his stewardship, the museum, which opened in 2000 in a converted power station on the south bank of the Thames, has organized several major exhibitions that have sought to redefine early modernism, including shows of the work of Kandinsky in 2005 and Duchamp, Man Ray and Picabia in 2008.

title: John Grisham Embraces E-Books
description: John Grisham, the writer of blockbuster legal thrillers and until now a holdout against e-books, is entering the digital age. In a statement on Tuesday the Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group, a division of Random House, said it would release 23 of Mr. Grishams backlist titles, starting with A Time to Kill and including Ford County, the authors most recent book, a collection of stories, as e-books. According to Random House, his books have sold more than 250 million copies worldwide. Mr. Grisham had previously hesitated to release his books in e-book form because of concerns about piracy, pricing and the effect of digital editions on physical bookstores.

title: Filing Those Tax Returns, With Help From the City
description: As rain and wind pelted Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn on Saturday, Julitta Joseph, 66, a sales associate at a Kohls department store, lugged a small black rolling suitcase up a flight of stairs to the office of a social-services nonprofit.

title: Ex-Congressman Enters Race to Unseat Gillibrand
description: As Joseph J. DioGuardi shook hands with friends and supporters at his announcement for his United States Senate bid Tuesday morning, he joked that he had two women to overcome: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand and his daughter, Kara DioGuardi of American Idol fame.

title: Kucinich to Announce His Position on Health Care
description: Representative Dennis Kucinich, Democrat of Ohio, voted against the House health care bill in November because he prefers a fully government-run, Medicare-for-all approach. He felt the Democrats bill simply did not go far enough to eliminate the mostly private, employer-sponsored health insurance system.

title: On Language With Ben Zimmer
description: For more than 30 years, William Safire talked back to Americans about how they went about talking. He founded our On Language column in February 1979 and proceeded to write tens of thousands of words about phrases (fashionable and not), usages (proper and not), roots (definitive and not) and his own donnish taste  not! Bill was a democrat  very small d  with a passion for everyday discourse and a desire not for the last word but for a conversation about conversation. Long before the Internet came along (and provided him with a fresh trove of linguistic stuff), he built a Web-like community of language mavens who fed him tips, amplified, hondled (thats for you, Bill!) and filled in from time to time when he took his summer vacation.

title: Concentrate on the Workout? No, Thanks.
description: WHEN Tina Podlodowski, a public affairs consultant in Seattle, goes to the gym to run on a treadmill, she often brings her Kindle and immerses herself in a mystery novel.

title: Answers About New Consumer Laws: Part 1
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Colicchio & Sons
description: TOM COLICCHIO came out of the kitchen at Colicchio & Sons the other night wearing a short-sleeved dishwashers shirt and a white apron. His black clogs were scuffed beneath his jeans, and there were burn marks on his forearms. He appeared tired, his angry eyes more sunken than usual.

title: Xobni Arrives on the BlackBerry
description: For Outlook users who are addicted to Xobni, an add-on service that organizes and searches e-mail messages and contacts, it has been frustrating to use Xobni-less e-mail on smartphones.

title: The History of the Jewish Star in the Realm of the Union Jack
description: LONDON  One of the first objects you see in the newly expanded Jewish Museum London, which opens on Wednesday, is also one of the museums oldest: the remains of a 13th-century Jewish ritual bath (a mikvah) uncovered during a 2001 construction project in the City of London. As seen here, it is a bit too robustly reconstructed, its age and fragmentary character mollified with the use of modern materials and mirrors mounted like rays above its well.

title: Putting a Price on New Financial Rules for Banks
description: The strength and scope of financial regulatory changes being debated around the world appear to be the biggest swing factors in gauging the profitability of the investment banks, according to a new industry research report from Oliver Wyman, a global consulting firm, and Morgan Stanley.

title: Rediscovering Salsa, the Soul of Mexico in a Bowl
description: ITS not easy being a Mexican restaurant in the United States. Some customers are outraged if the menu doesnt have burritos; others, if it does. Some see authenticity when chips and salsa arent on the table; others see a rip-off.

title: Chocolate-Covered Wine Grapes Offer a Sip in Every Bite
description: The chocolate-covered dried wine grapes recently introduced at Bissingers  a centuries-old confectioner that started in Paris and opened in St. Louis in 1927  are lushly delicious and excellent to nibble after dinner with the last sips of red wine or with a glass of vintage port. Children may like them, although it should be noted that they have been infused with shiraz before being dipped in dark chocolate.

title: A French Chili Sauce With a Mind of Its Own
description: The pungent piment dEspelette chili defines French Basque cooking as much as anything. Its the main flavoring in the vibrant Bixi Bixia sauce. White wine vinegar, olive oil, garlic and herbes de Provence round out the ingredients. Use it for the grill, as a dip for bread or as a lively finish for cooked seafood, poultry, omelets, meat or white bean soup.

title: Kaffeeklatsch
description: To the Editor:

title: Decaf to Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Taco With Your Java?
description: To the Editor:

title: One Man, Four Women and a Roman Holiday
description: The ladies who lunch in Gianni Di Gregorios luminous sliver of a film, Mid-August Lunch, are Roman women in their 80s and beyond who have gathered in a small condominium in the Trastevere neighborhood. The modest apartment is the home of Gianni (Mr. Di Gregorio), an unemployed 50-something bachelor, and his 93-year-old mother, Valeria (Valeria De Franciscis).

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: Anella
description: 222 Franklin Street (Green Street), Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 389-8100.

title: The Meatball Shop
description: 84 Stanton Street (Allen Street), Lower East Side, (212) 982-8895, themeatballshop.com.

title: Southeast Asia Is Inspiration at Fatty Cue in Brooklyn
description: SOME mac and cheese or cornbread with your barbecue? Not at Fatty Cue, opening March 23 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Try the celery ribbons with yuzu and preserved Chinese cabbage instead.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Onstage Cuisine

title: On the West Side, Coffee and Doughnuts the Italian Way
description: Having weathered a nightmare of construction delays that cost him nearly a year, David Ruggerio will finally open his latest entry on Columbus Avenue, on March 17. The stars at this handsome little storefront are the bomboloni  Italian filled yeast doughnuts that give the place its name. They are usually about the size of golf balls or a little larger, but in Mr. Ruggerios hands they are more substantial puffy pillows about two and a half inches in diameter. The shop offers a dozen fillings, many injected to order, including chestnut, raspberry, Sicilian pistachio, apple and peanut butter, in addition to plain custard. Panini, soup, hot and cold coffee drinks (including flavored lattes) and gelati in fewer flavors than the bomboloni round out the menu.

title: Kitchen Gadgets Take the Fast-Food Mentality Into the Home
description: CHICAGO

title: Taking the Bake Out of Bake Sale
description: IN one corner: Reduced Fat Cool Ranch Doritos, Lindens Chocolate Chip Minis and Stacys Cinnamon Sugar Pita Chips. In the other: homemade pumpkin bread, pink cupcakes and spinach tofu empanadas.

title: A Goat Cheese With a Cinderella Story
description: If you think of goat cheese as soft, fresh and mildly tangy, think again. In some ways goat cheeses popularity has led to a certain dumbing down, making it a delicate spread, muffling its strongly assertive potential. But a new goat cheese from Quebec, called Le Cendrillon, coated with ash (Cendrillon means Cinderella in French), demands attention. A soft-ripening cheese that loses it chalky core and takes on a satiny texture and a more pungent, mouth-filling mineral flavor as it ages, it is meant to be put on the cheese board, at room temperature, not in a salad with beets.

title: Simon Prepares New Offer for General Growth
description: 6:47 p.m. | Updated The Simon Property Group is preparing to raise its $10 billion offer for General Growth Properties in a bid to overcome a rival plan proposed by the bankrupt mall operator in concert with Brookfield Asset Management, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

title: Jailed Sri Lankan Opposition Leader Calls Charges Against Him Bogus
description: Four months ago, Gen. Sarath Fonseka was the commander of Sri Lankas army, hailed as a national hero by the countrys Sinhalese majority for putting an end to the long, bloody rebellion by Tamil separatists. Two months ago, after retiring, General Fonseka was barnstorming the country as a presidential candidate. Today, having been arrested just days after failing to win the presidency, he sits in a small room at a military facility in the Sri Lankan capital of Colombo, under armed guard, reduced to communicating with the world through handwritten statements smuggled out for him.

title: The Perils of Pay Less, Get More
description: As a society gets richer, its tax rates tend to rise.

title: Salsa Verde
description: 3 tablespoons vegetable oil

title: Salsa Roja
description: 2 pounds ripe plum tomatoes (or 1 28-ounce can tomatoes)

title: The Future of the Deficit
description: The Heritage Foundation has put together some good historical numbers on the kinds of spending that the federal government does. Those numbers appear alongside my column this week.

title: Obama to Attend Yet Another Health Rally
description: If the Republican criticism of the Democrats health care bill is relentless, President Obama seems intent on being tireless.

title: 2 Convictions in a Program With Mexico
description: LOS ANGELES  Two men caught smuggling marijuana at an Arizona border crossing have been sentenced in a Mexican court to 10-year prison terms under a pilot program that sends some Mexican criminal suspects back home for prosecution.

title: Meals With a Top Chef
description: Colicchio & Sons is the subject of my restaurant review this week. The space used to be Craftsteak, and it retains some of that steakhouse brawn. The food is crazy-good throwdown fare that shows Tom Colicchio, the restaurants chef and an owner, to be at the top of his game. Its worth heading over to Chelsea to give it a try.

title: Loving Molly, and Getting Her to the Stage
description: THE Texas columnist and humorist Molly Ivins was an outspoken critic of those she saw as nincompoops in politics and big bidness. Ivins, who also wrote books like Molly Ivins Cant Say That, Can She? and, with Lou Dubose, Shrub: The Short but Happy Political Life of George W. Bush, was feisty and controversial, a mix of bonhomie and sheer audacity. In short, a character.

title: Divide and Diminish
description: This week, I want to dust off my crystal ball and make a prediction: in the future, the biggest land animals will be smaller than they are now.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,374 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,008 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: The Fine Art of Selling a Show
description: REMEMBER when a poster with a little French street waif or a pair of cats eyes was enough to sell a Broadway show? Now, with advertising trying to stand out on television, the Internet and mobile devices, choosing the right Broadway campaign often means finding a look that is flexible enough for different platforms, and one that also catches attention quickly.

title: Ad Evolution: 'La Cage aux Folles'
description: A look at some of the rejected poster art for the coming Broadway revival.

title: Hartford and Discover to Repay TARP Money
description: 7:41 p.m. | Updated Two more big companies  the Hartford Financial Services Group and Discover Financial Services  are preparing to pay back the billions of dollars that they received from the governments banking bailout.

title: When Kimmel Visits Letterman, the Subject Is Leno
description: The topic in a guest appearance by one late-night host on another late-night hosts showTuesday nightis how much fun theyve had recently making fun of a third late-night host  as in Jay Leno.

title: Excerpt: 'Breaking Bad'
description: Bryan Cranston narrates a scene from the season premiere of the AMC drama.

title: Somalias President Assails U.N. Report on Corruption
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Somalias president on Tuesday blasted a recent United Nations report that characterized the governments security forces as ineffective and corrupt and said that as much as half the food aid to the country was routinely stolen.

title: Iraq Elections: Sadr and His Rivals
Alaska: Aerial Wolf Hunt Begins
description: State employees began an aerial wolf hunt on the Yukon border on Tuesday in what officials describe as an effort to preserve caribou for shooting by hunters. Officials at the adjacent Yukon-Charlie Rivers National Preserve argued against the hunt, saying that the wolves have had a particularly hard winter and need to recover. The state plans to kill as much as 80 percent of the local wolf population in the next week, or 185 wolves; there are an estimated 46,500 caribou. Since 2006 the state has regularly granted hunting licenses or assumed the task itself in planes or helicopters.

title: Europes Public Broadcasters Ask Lawmakers to Make It Easier to Offer Programs Online
description: PARIS  European public broadcasters are calling on lawmakers to make it easier to offer their programming over the Internet, saying cumbersome copyright practices restrict their ability to develop new digital services and prolong the fragmentation of the European television landscape.

title: Using the Kitchen as a Happy Place Where Couples Bond
description: IN Midtown Manhattan on Thursday, Tupperware will produce a publicity event in which Rick Goings, the kitchenware companys chief executive, will show Reggie Bush, the New Orleans Saints football player, and Peter Facinelli, the actor who stars in the Showtime series Nurse Jackie and in the Twilight films, how to prepare a meal using only food, Tupperware products and a microwave oven.

title: Greece Eager for Details on Loans From Europe
description: BRUSSELS  Greece received a welcome vote of confidence on Tuesday from the rating agency Standard & Poors for its deficit-reduction efforts, but the country was still pressing for details on a new loan rescue package from fellow euro-zone members, which remain divided over how it might work.

title: Rock the Vote, Classic Car Style
description: Are you partial to Packards, or are Pacers more your speed? Do you pine for 1960s Detroit muscle, or does your heart weep for a Saab? Let your voice be heard.

title: Simon Is Expected to Raise Bid for Mall Operator
description: The Simon Property Group is preparing to raise its $10 billion offer for General Growth Properties, the bankrupt mall operator, in an effort to overcome a rival plan proposed by General Growth in concert with Brookfield Asset Management, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Leaders Lavishness Gives Rise to Lifestyle Audits
description: JOHANNESBURG  Jacob Zuma, the president of South Africa, has 20 children, three wives and a fiance. Recently, the matter of how he supports this large and widely dispersed family has been vigorously questioned.

title: Ailing Euro Seen as a Signal of Deeper Woes on Continent
description: FRANKFURT  It used to be easy to sum up the way European business executives viewed exchange rates: a strong dollar was good; a strong euro was bad.

title: Lehman Hid Money With Help of Global Rules
description: Lehman Brothers now notorious Repo 105 scheme depended on forum shopping. The investment bank wasnt able to persuade its lawyers in the United States that the relevant repurchase agreements constituted real sales. So it routed them through its British subsidiary. That meant they came under the British legal system, and the law firm Linklaters was able to opine that the transactions counted as sales.

title: Iranians Defy a Ban in a Display of Dissent
description: Iranians defied a ban on events marking a traditional festival on Tuesday, turning an annual celebration into a show of antigovernment sentiment.

title: Vatican Official Says Rising Number of Sexual Abuse Cases Could Overload Staff
description: ROME  As hundreds of new allegations of sexual abuse surface in the German church alone, a top Vatican official acknowledged Tuesday that, with only 10 people handling such cases, his office might not be adequate for the task.

title: Ex-G.M. Chief Is Hired by AlixPartners
description: Fritz Henderson, the General Motors chief executive who oversaw the carmakers quick trip through bankruptcy, has been hired as a contractor by AlixPartners, the consulting firm that worked with him on the companys Chapter 11 plan, according to a court filing made on Friday.

title: In a Victory for London, Europe Delays Hedge Fund Rules
description: BRUSSELS  European Union finance ministers delayed a decision on new rules for hedge funds Tuesday in a reprieve for Britain, which fears that onerous regulations could drive the industry from London.

title: Iran Unlikely to Develop a Nuclear Weapon This Year, Petraeus Says
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. David H. Petraeus said Tuesday that Iran would not develop a nuclear weapon this year, but that the country still remained the greatest threat to stability in the Middle East and Central Asia.

title: Sex Assault Reports Rise in Military
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of Defense released an annual report on Tuesday showing an 11 percent increase in reports of sexual assault in the military over the past year, including a 16 percent increase in reported assaults occurring in combat areas, principally Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: As Lawmakers Grapple With Financial Overhaul, They Call for More Studies
description: When in doubt, conduct a study.

title: Hurdles Beyond Cash Remain for Fordham
description: Soon after Fordhams trustees announced last month that the university would infuse a significant amount of money into its mens basketball program, Athletic Director Frank McLaughlin received an e-mail message from a former classmate. The writer said he had stopped donating to the team because he was disappointed with its lack of progress. But upon hearing the news, he changed his mind.

title: China: Film Star Responds to Accusations on Quake Charity
description: Zhang Ziyi, a star of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, and the best-known Chinese actress internationally, has denied accusations that she committed fraud while trying to raise money for victims of the devastating earthquake that hit Sichuan Province and surrounding areas in 2008. Ms. Zhangs statements, published Tuesday in The China Daily, were the first by her on a scandal that has riveted many Chinese in the last few months. Chinese Internet users, after scouring public records, have accused Ms. Zhang, who also starred in Memoirs of a Geisha, of failing to fully donate $146,000 of her own money that she had pledged to the Chinese Red Cross. They also say she has never handed over $1 million that she said she hoped to raise from foreign donors. Ms. Zhang, above, said in the interview that a communication glitch led to her donating only $123,000 of her own money, and she asserted that she had donated the rest since the shortfall came to light.

title: Underwater Cable an Alternative to Electrical Towers
description: Generating 20 percent of Americas electricity with wind, as recent studies proposed, would require building up to 22,000 miles of new high-voltage transmission lines. But the huge towers and unsightly tree-cutting that these projects require have provoked intense public opposition.

title: Opportunity in a Fight With Israel
description: WASHINGTON  For President Obama, getting into a serious fight with Israel carries obvious domestic and foreign political risks. But it may offer the administration a payoff it sees as worthwhile: shoring up Mr. Obamas credibility as a Middle East peacemaker by showing doubtful Israelis and Palestinians that he has the fortitude to push the two sides toward an agreement.

title: Sticking by Her Teammates
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Kelsey Griffins escape, which she had been diagramming in her mind for three years, came close to fruition during her junior season at Nebraska.

title: Phoenix Meets the Wrong End of the Boom Cycle
description: PHOENIX  Perhaps it was just a matter of time, but three years after this citys housing market collapsed in spectacular fashion, commercial real estate has followed it off the cliff.

title: Church Turned Club Is Now a Market
description: What is perhaps Manhattans best-known former house of worship will be reborn this spring as the Limelight Marketplace, with 35 upscale boutiques and restaurants within its lancet-windowed walls on Avenue of the Americas in Chelsea.

title: How Privacy Vanishes Online
description: If a stranger came up to you on the street, would you give him your name, Social Security number and e-mail address?

title: Bush Voice in Iraq Eyes U.S. Senate Run
description: In the next few days, a man named Dan Senor is likely to announce that he will be a candidate in the Republican primary for the United States Senate, and New York will be granted a chance to revisit the making of surreal history.

title: End of Life as We Know It
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  In an effort to do our part and help save the planet, the New York Times crossword is going green with a theme appropriate to the day. I have some notes from the constructor, who happens to also be my co-blogger. He has this week off, so now we can talk about him behind his back.

title: States Rights Is Rallying Cry for Lawmakers
description: Whether its correctly called a movement, a backlash or political theater, state declarations of their rights  or in some cases denunciations of federal authority, amounting to the same thing  are on a roll.

title: The Legacy of Mister Rogers
description: Images and memories of Fred Rogers abound in Pittsburgh, where he lived and worked.

title: City Restaurants Required to Post Cleanliness Grades
description: The New York City Board of Health voted Tuesday to rate cleanliness in the citys more than 24,000 restaurants with publicly posted letter grades, adopting a controversial plan proposed 14 months ago by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

title: Hoping to Sell, Team Owners Face a New Opponent: Recession
description: As a basketball player, Michael Jordan ruthlessly exploited his opponents weaknesses. As a businessman, he is now trying to exploit the financially troubled sports world by buying the money-losing Charlotte Bobcats of the National Basketball Association for about $25 million less than they sold for in 2002.

title: Ex-Analyst Grubman Is Said to Sell His Townhouse
description: Jack Grubman, the former Salomon Brothers analyst who was banned from the securities industry for improper stock touting, has sold his Manhattan townhouse for $19.6 million, The New York Observer reported Tuesday, citing unnamed sources.

title: Head of Arabic-Language School Resigns
description: The principal of the citys only Arabic-language public school stepped down abruptly on Tuesday, just days after a federal commission determined that the city had discriminated against the schools founding principal by forcing her to resign after a flurry of controversy.

title: Senate G.O.P. Leader Finds Weapon in Unity
description: WASHINGTON  Before the health care fight, before the economic stimulus package, before President Obama even took office, Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican minority leader, had a strategy for his party: use his extensive knowledge of Senate procedure to slow things down, take advantage of the difficulties Democrats would have in governing and deny Democrats any Republican support on big legislation.

title: After 3 Suspected Suicides, Cornell Reaches Out
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  All weekend, Cornell Universitys residential advisers knocked on dorm rooms to inquire how students were coping.

title: Democrats to Watch on the Health Care Vote
description: If all of the current 431 House members vote, Democrats will need 216 to pass the legislation. The vote tally is now 218.

title: Alicia Keys State of Mind
description: Not to knock Jay-Z, but we kind of prefer Alicia Keys's solo version of "Empire State of Mind." It's hard not get all goose-bumpy when she belts, "These streets can make you feel brand new, bright lights will inspire you." So, who wouldn't want to be there when the performer sings those lyrics to her hometown? Hear them tonight when Ms. Keys plays Madison Square Garden beginning at 7:30 p.m. We're hoping for a combined surprise guest appearance from both the "hova" and Stephen Colbert.

title: Judging the Judge
description: Most people know Tom Colicchio as the chief justice of the "Top Chef" Supreme Court. But before he was a celebrity presiding over a hit reality show and restaurants in New York, Las Vegas and Los Angeles, he was a cook. "And at Colicchio & Sons," Sam Sifton writes, "He is running his kitchen at a level that New Yorkers have not been able to experience since his days at the helm of Gramercy Tavern, the restaurant he opened with Danny Meyer in 1994. For the moment, anyway, Mr. Colicchio's is the must-try New York menu. His restaurant isn't perfect. But it is exciting. And the food is terrifically good." Mr. Sifton suggests ordering the tasting menu, which features sophisticated composed plates. "There are elements of French technique to the cooking here, as well as an appreciable Italian devotion to ingredients. There are Indian flavors, and central European ones; there are nods also at Spain, at the Greenmarket, at North Africa. The result is a menu with an aesthetic that is entirely American. It appropriates all that has come to it, without apology."

title: Break a Record
description: The most bananas to fit in a pair of pants at once; the most cocktail umbrellas to fit in hair in one minute; the tallest drawing of a midget  have we gotten your attention yet? All of these records were set at previous events hosted by the World Record Appreciation Society. Tonight, head to Joe's Pub to witness more and come up with your own records to break. An eclectic mix of performers will be there, like Ella Morton, who holds the record for the longest time hula hooping on one leg, and Jim Juvonen, who performs the fastest recitation, in order, of every prime number between 0 and 200, not to mention Eliot Gazer, who can perform the most bench presses of a live dog in one minute. Yep. That's right. He did.

title: Violence Prompts Debate Over Medical Marijuana
description: SEATTLE  A shooting and a beating death linked to medical marijuana have prompted new calls by law enforcement officials and marijuana advocates for Washington State to change how it regulates the drug and protects those who grow and use it.

title: Kevin Towers Tries for a Nicer Ring
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Kevin Towers wears a National League championship ring from 1998, with SD on the face, a reminder that he built a World Series team as general manager of the San Diego Padres. But the wounds from losing that series, to the Yankees in a sweep, remain.

title: Move Across Hudson Further Isolates Immigration Detainees
description: When federal authorities shut down New York Citys only immigration detention center last month, and sent most of its detainees to a county jail in New Jersey over protests by their advocates, Obama administration officials stressed that the jail was only a short drive from the city.

title: Democrats Consider New Moves for Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  As lawmakers clashed fiercely over major health care legislation on the House floor, Democrats struggled Tuesday to defend procedural shortcuts they might use to win approval for their proposals in the next few days.

title: Winter Ball Never Sleeps or Shivers at Metrodome
description: MINNEAPOLIS  As winter in the Midwest trudged on, with mounting snow and unrelenting cold, a former baseball coach at Augsburg College proved remarkably popular among his ex-peers.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 16, 2010

title: Latest Storms Struck Hard at the Unlucky, More Than Once
description: The storms that whipped through the region over the past three weeks have left a bizarre dividing line between two neighbors in a quiet Westchester County town.

title: Perfect Together: Tiger Woods and Augusta
description: Tiger Woods and Augusta National.

title: Ron Lundy, a Rock D.J. in New York, Is Dead at 75
description: Ron Lundy, who wrapped his on-air exuberance in a soft Southern drawl during more than 30 years as a rock n roll D.J. in New York City, died Monday in Oxford, Miss. He was 75 and lived in Bruce, Miss. (population 2,097).

title: Christian Soldiers
description: Last Friday night a New York Times headline underwent an online transformation. The article formerly known as A Christian Overture to Muslims Has Its Critics acquired a new billing: A Dispute on Using the Koran as a Path to Jesus.

title: Paterson Aide Is Said to Ignore Subpoena
description: ALBANY  A senior aide to Gov. David A. Paterson failed to respond to a subpoena from a state ethics commission requiring him to testify about his role in obtaining World Series tickets last year from the Yankees for Mr. Paterson and others who attended a game with the governor, the commissions chairman said in a statement issued on Tuesday.

title: The Red Bulls Are Finally Ready to Open the Arena of Their Dreams
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The first thing you notice about Red Bull Arena is how big it appears from the outside. As you approach the stadium, the new home of the Red Bulls of Major League Soccer, it rises on the horizon like a giant floating silver souffl. The stadium looks as if it could easily hold 50,000 fans, maybe more.

title: Sellouts at New Stadium Are Next Battle for Jets and Giants
description: Now that a coin flip has determined that the Giants, not the Jets, will play the first regular-season game at the teams new $1.6 billion stadium at the Meadowlands, the next question is whether each team will sell out.

title: Budget Cut for Fence on U.S.-Mexico Border
description: Citing a plague of cost overruns and missed deadlines, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said Tuesday that she would cut millions of dollars intended for a high-tech virtual fence along the Mexican border that has produced little more than headaches for the federal government.

title: Terror Suspect Likely to Change Plea
description: WASHINGTON  A Chicago man accused of helping to scout out Mumbai, India, in preparation for a rampage by a Pakistani terrorist group that left 163 people dead in 2008 is expected to plead guilty on Thursday.

title: Monserrate Loses Bid to Regain Seat
description: Hiram Monserrate, who was expelled from the State Senate after being convicted of assaulting his companion, was handily defeated on Tuesday by Jos R. Peralta in a special election in Queens for Mr. Monserrates former seat.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Monday about a report on President Obamas efforts to make the workings of the federal government more transparent misstated the conclusions of the report by the National Security Archive, a private research group. The report criticized the efforts of federal agencies, saying they had made slow and erratic progress in implementing Mr. Obamas goals; the report did not criticize the goals themselves.

title: Administration Seeks Converts to Education Plan
description: Facing intense resistance from teachers unions, the Obama administration has begun trying to persuade union leaders, teachers and the public that its proposals for overhauling federal education policies are good for teachers and for public schools.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the first interview by Rielle Hunter regarding her relationship with former Senator John Edwards referred imprecisely to the cancer that Mr. Edwardss estranged wife, Elizabeth, is battling. While the cancer has metastasized to her bones, it began as breast cancer, not as bone cancer.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 26 about Congressional scrutiny of President Obamas space program misidentified the Senate panel where the NASA administrator, Maj. Gen. Charles F. Bolden Jr., testified on Feb. 24. It was the Science and Space Subcommittee of the Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation  not the Subcommittee on Commerce, Justice and Space.

title: Big Insurance Rate Increase for Pennsylvania Poor
description: Facing a sharp rise in costs, Pennsylvania has almost doubled the monthly bill for a state health insurance program for poor people who do not qualify for Medicaid and are on a waiting list for a less costly option.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Tuesday about the obstacles facing President Obamas blueprint for overhauling federal education policy misstated part of the name of the organization headed by Dennis Van Roekel. Mr. Van Roekel is president of the National Education Association  not the National Teachers Association.

title: Tomlinson Is New Part for Evolving Jets Offense
description: In a span of nine days, the Jets released Thomas Jones, a veteran running back coming off his most productive season, and signed LaDainian Tomlinson, a veteran running back coming off his least productive season.

title: Obama to Take Questions From Fox News

Mankos, a Manhattan lawyer, misidentified the law school from which she graduated. It is New York Law School, not New York University Law School.

title: Corrections

While it is in Valley Stream, it is known as the Gibson station  not as Valley Stream station. (There is a second station in the village by that name.)

In general, the ad page counts were for the magazines April issues  not March  with the exception of National Geographic Traveler, Islands and Spa. The counts for National Geographic Traveler and Islands were for their March issue, and Spa was a double March/April issue.

title: Lets Fight Over a Big Plan
description: Underlying the latest U.S.-Israel spat over settlements is the deeper  real  problem: There are five key actors in the Israeli-Palestinian equation today. Two of them  the Palestinian Prime Minister Salam Fayyad and the alliance of Iran, Hamas and Hezbollah  have clear strategies. These two are actually opposed, but one of them will shape Israeli-Palestinian relations in the coming years; indeed, their showdown is nearing. I hope Fayyad wins. It would be good for Israel, America and the moderate Arabs. But those three need their own strategy to make it happen.

May we never forget where we came from. Nearly all of us were Mexicans once. That is: the new immigrants, poor and reviled, propelled by hope and hunger into Americas prickly embrace.

title: Short Hops, Low Fares, Around Asia
description: A long, long time ago  way back in the mid-1990s  when I was living in Southeast Asia, getting around the region was a frustrating process. If I wanted to visit Cambodia, Id take a bus from wherever I happened to be  usually Bangkok or Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam  and though it never cost more than $6, the daylong ordeal was always so painful I swore Id never do it again. Then, a few months later, Id do it again.

title: Corrections

The comment  that it was not enough to shock the team into harmony  was a paraphrase of Williamss views, not a direct quotation.

title: Corrections

That division did not fight at Iwo Jima. The review also misstated the role of Col. Lewis B. Puller in the division. While he was a senior officer, he was not the divisions commander.

title: From Start, Johnson Fit Profile Yankees Wanted

title: Corrections

title: Corrections

title: Corrections

title: Water From Above and Deep Down Below
description: Water undergirds the streets of New York. The Manhattan gridiron plan of 1811 created a dense network of 155 crosstown streets that linked the East and Hudson Rivers over land. And deep below the pavement, enormous water tunnels supply the city. New Yorkers may not ordinarily be conscious of such things, but whether coping with a blustery November day at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street (above) or last weekends pummeling, they know that water is still a powerful force.

title: Lehman Hid Money With Help of Global Rules
description: Lehman Brothers now notorious Repo 105 scheme depended on forum shopping, Reuters Breakingviews says. The investment bank wasnt able to persuade its lawyers in the United States that the relevant repurchase agreements constituted real sales. So it routed them through its British subsidiary. That meant they came under the British legal system, and the law firm Linklaters was able to opine that the transactions counted as sales.

title: Clean Your Plate
description: Piero Fornasetti famously adorned his dinnerware with more than 350 variations of a single face: that of the 19th-century singer Lina Cavalieri, known as operas greatest beauty. On the other hand, should you set your table with a new MexICON Platter from the design studio DFC Mexico City, you might discover a slightly more startling sight  the face of the telecommunications magnate Carlos Slim, say, or the eyepatch-wearing 70s soap star Catalina Creel, who resembles an old woman turning into a fly, according to the DFC co-founder Tony Moxham. He and Mauricio Paniagua, known for trippy creations like their three-foot-tall table in the shape of a grasshopper, conceived the series as homage to Fornasetti while introducing the world to their hometown heroes. The rest of the cast includes the poet Pita Amor, the architect Luis Barragn (left) and  the lookers of the bunch  the actors Andrs Garca and Vernica Castro. The group originally included Diego Luna and Salma Hayek, Moxham says, but we took them out because theyre not as legendary. Available at thefutureperfect.com.

title: Editor Suggests Robert Mugabe Should Have Endorsed British Nationalists

title: How Much Of The World Is In a Liquidity Trap?
description: As Ive written many times in various contexts since the crisis began, being in a liquidity trap reverses many of the usual rules of economic policy. Virtue becomes vice: attempts to save more actually make us poorer, in both the short and the long run. Prudence becomes folly: a stern determination to balance budgets and avoid any risk of inflation is the road to disaster. Mercantilism works: countries that subsidize exports and restrict imports actually do gain at their trading partners expense. For the moment  or more likely for the next several years  were living in a world in which none of what you learned in Econ 101 applies.

The brothers talked about their 50-year history and their recent appearance at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony, and if you dont think Mr. Fallon worked in a few references to his Saturday Night Live skit, The Barry Gibb Talk Show, you dont know Jimmy.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, March 17
description: Highlights from Wednesdays media coverage in The New York Times:

title: Shelf Life | House Proud
description: The unlovely term vernacular architecture describes some of the most unusual buildings ever created by man, from Mongolian yurts and adobe pueblos to igloos, Irish sod houses, and Iranian desert towns. Many of these structures (like a tree-house that soars 140 feet above the West Papuan rain forest) lie at the frontiers of the imagination, while others (like a shanty in Manila held together with urban waste) wed prefer to forget. The forthcoming book Buildings Without Architects (Rizzoli; $23) presents them all as works of grassroots ingenuity. Written by John May, who authored the official history of Greenpeace, the book pegs modish keywords like energy-efficient and sustainable to ancient buildings, most of which were made of stuff thats been around since prehistoric times: wood, reed, earth and clay. A house built with used Heineken bottles is a curious exception.

title: Americans in Edinburgh
description: Elevator Repair Service, the New York theater ensemble that has inventively transformed novels and films into stage productions like Gatz (based on The Great Gatsby) and The Sound and the Fury (April Seventh, 1928), will have a world premiere of its new work, The Sun Also Rises, at the Edinburgh International Festival in August. Based on the Hemingway novel, the production is one of several by American artists that will be featured at Edinburgh, which has dedicated this summers festival to exploring modern-day cultures of the New World. Among the other artists in the spotlight will be the New York-based Wooster Group, presenting Vieux Carr, a play by Tennessee Williams; the composer and choreographer Meredith Monk, in her festival debut with Songs of Ascension, which uses music, movement and film to examine spiritual enlightenment; and the theater auteurs Lee Breuer and Bob Telson, who will mount their Gospel at Colonus, a reimagining of Sophocles Oedipus at Colonus that had a two-month run on Broadway in 1988 starring Morgan Freeman and an array of soul and gospel singers. The festival is scheduled to run Aug. 13 to Sept. 5.

title: Starting Over in Lexington: Turning the Plant on Its Head
description: A few months ago, I wrote about our experience buying a mining equipment manufacturer based in Lexington, Ky. I received quite a few comments at the time from readers expressing a mix of encouragement, skepticism and curiosity about how things would work out after we began teaching our new associates there how to practice open-book management.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Treme'
description: David Simon and Eric Overmyer discuss a scene from their upcoming HBO series, set in New Orleans.

title: The HBO Auteur
description: It was a bright, warm, blue-skied December afternoon in Central City, New Orleans, and in this neighborhood of humble shotgun houses and overgrown empty lots, a convoy of white trucks and trailers idled incongruously while unmarked police cars blocked intersections nearby. On any other morning, a police presence would have meant more bad news: in a city that has one of the highest homicide rates in the United States, this neighborhood  roughly a mile from the French Quarter  has a murder rate that, in recent years, has hit quadruple that of the city as a whole. This morning, however, the 20 drivers, as well as 80 other crew members who hefted and humped a boggling array of gear at the tumbledown corner of Second Street and South Liberty, had anything but murder in mind: they were six hours into a day of filming the third episode of Treme, David Simons new HBO drama  co-created by the seasoned television writer and producer Eric Overmyer  which is set in post-Katrina New Orleans and will make its debut on April 11. The production was only two scenes into the six on the call sheet; at that pace, they were looking at a 15-hour marathon  yet another in the 11-day ultramarathon that shooting an hour of episodic television on location can demand. As the novelist George Pelecanos, a staff writer on Treme, told me of the years he spent on set as a writer-producer on The Wire, Simons breakthrough series: If you got out with a 12-hour day, that was the luckiest day of the series. Try doing that for seven months straight. Only young people can do it. You dont see many people in their 50s carrying around lights.

description: WASHINGTON  In a rare bipartisan vote, the Senate approved and sent to President Obama on Wednesday a bill intended to spur employment by providing businesses with incentives to hire new workers  an approach that Congressional Democrats hope to repeat.

title: The System (Sort of) Works
description: Obviously the health care endgame has become a pretty ugly business, but having dissented from the liberal anguish over our broken government when the threat of the filibuster was forcing supporters of health care reform to count to 60 in the Senate, allow me to dissent as well from the conservative dyspepsia over the Democratic Partys unprecedented use of various parliamentary maneuvers (today, reconciliation; tomorrow, deem and pass; the day after that, blue steel) to get the House and Senate bills reconciled and through. I think its a good thing that the countermajoritarian customs of the Senate, as adapted by the minority for a more ideological age, have made it very difficult to pass a sweeping overhaul of Americas de facto constitution. But I also think its appropriate that there exists, for an extremely determined but not-quite-super majority, mechanisms that allow legislators to overcome these hurdles and push a controversial piece of legislation through. Hard but not absolutely impossible seems like the right bar to set for a bill of this nature. I wish the Democrats had chosen a different path, but in the end, we live in a republic, not a direct democracy: If our elected representatives can really muster enough votes, within the rules, to pass health care legislation even after everything thats happened if they believe that strongly, in other words, that this is absolutely and without question the right policy for America then they have every right to go for it. It may be their funeral, but its certainly their prerogative.

title: Tribecas Most Wanted: Ice Cube Brings Football Documentary to Film Festival
description: Ice Cube  a man whose feelings on Los Angeles and its environs are already well documented in song  will have the debut of his new movie about the L. A. Raiders football team at the Tribeca Film Festival, the festivals organizers said on Wednesday. The documentary, called Straight Outta L.A., chronicles the move of the Raiders from Oakland to Los Angeles in 1982, over the objection of the National Football League, and how the team inspired its new hometown and the burgeoning hip-hop scene. The film, which was produced as part of ESPN Films 30 for 30 series, will be shown as the opening movie of the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Film Festival on April 23, and will be shown May 11 on ESPN. The full Tribeca festival runs from April 21 through May 2.

title: Beware the Snap Draft Decision at the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Jonathan Givony is the founder of DraftExpress.com, a Web site dedicated to scouting and analyzing the top basketball players in the world outside of the N.B.A.March 19, 2006. Auburn Hills, Mich. An anonymous 7-footer by the name of Patrick OBryant caps off an incredible N.C.A.A. tournament weekend with a career-high 28 point performance, badly outplaying the projected first-round pick and his fellow seven-footer Aaron Gray. His 13th-seeded Bradley team just took down the Big East powerhouse Pittsburgh, after upsetting fourth-seeded Kansas two days earlier.

title: African Assembly
description: Johannesburgs Arts on Main complex, with its stylish mix of tenants, has quickly become a culture hub since it opened last summer, bringing life back into the heart of a neglected central business district. The project, the brainchild of the 27-year-old developer Jonathan Liebmann (whos currently converting a nearby factory into a hotel in time for this summers World Cup), occupies five redone warehouses around a central courtyard (above left) on the corner of Main and Berea Streets. The complexs anchor is the studio of the celebrated South African artist William Kentridge, whose presence has helped draw an elite group of chefs, designers and gallery owners.

title: Celebrating Sondheim
description: Photos from a birthday concert for the composer Stephen Sondheim.

title: The Hunt for 216 Votes
description: The Times has published a useful chart describing the Democrats whose votes may make or break health care legislation as it comes up again in the House. Its worth a close look. Find it here.

title: Irish Cardinal Ashamed of Handling of 75 Abuse
description: DUBLIN  The besieged leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland said Wednesday that he was ashamed of the role he played decades ago in handling accusations of child sexual abuse against a priest who went on to sexually assault scores of children, and he hinted that he might bow to calls for his resignation.

title: Take Classy Photos
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: You guys see the GQ pictures of John Edwards mistress, Rielle Hunter? Today, she called them repulsive, and says she trusted GQs photographer to take classy photos. Yeah, because anytime Im on a bed in nothing but dress shirt and underwear next to a Dora the Explorer doll, I think, This is gonna look classy.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Malena Watrous
description: Malena Watrous is a frequent contributor to the Book Review. Her first novel, If You Follow Me, was published this month.

title: A Close Vote
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Congress is getting ready to vote on President Obamas health care bill. Its going to be a close vote. The House Democrats say it could be a real tickle fight.

title: Significant Inconsistencies
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Toyota is starting to fight back. Today, they cast doubt on the story of that guy  remember the guy last week that said his Prius accelerated out of control on the freeway? They said they found significant inconsistencies in his story. And let me tell you something, thats embarrassing when a car dealer calls you a liar.

title: Violence on the Oncology Ward
description: Ive read about hospital nurses dealing with violence at work, but I always told myself that was something that happened in the emergency room or the psych ward. In oncology, I reasoned, we have relationships with our patients, and I have always felt safe with them.

title: Demons and Demonization
description: The usual suspects have been attacking Obama for demonizing insurance companies; but saying that people do terrible things isnt demonization if they do, in fact, do terrible things.

title: Bachus Calls for Inquiry Into Lehman
description: A Republican legislator has called for a hearing into a court-appointed examiners report on Lehman Brothers, and specifically about regulators failure to uncover accounting gimmicks used by the failed investment bank, Reuters reported.

title: March (Money) Madness
description: 11:51 a.m. | Updated

title: Boston Art Heist Marks 20th Anniversary
description: Most art-museum robberies are the stuff of low comedy, not high crime, and the goods are eventually returned to the walls. But the 1990 heist at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston  in which paintings and drawings worth well more than $300 million were taken  has long been the exception.

title: OMG Magic Garden Reunion!
description: Before there was freak-folk, there were Carole and Paula. Some of the happiest  O.K., maybe not happiest; most retrospectively poignant?  moments of City Rooms collective childhood were spent parked in front of Channel 11 passively frolicking in their Magic Garden, hanging on our pigtailed hosts every strum, watching them pluck koanlike riddles from the Chuckle Patch and get fresh with the ur-freak Sherlock the Squirrel, waiting vainly to be shouted out on the hi-to-Johnny-and-Sally-and-Sue segment.

title: Why Youd Rather Ride With a Woman Than a Man
description: From our colleagues at Freakonomics:

title: Taliban Hit Back in Marja With a Campaign of Intimidation
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban have begun waging a campaign of intimidation in Marja that some local Afghan leaders worry has jeopardized the success of an American-led offensive there meant as an early test of a revised military approach in Afghanistan.

title: Lawmakers Car Costs Taxpayers $2,900 a Month
description: Its no secret that lawmakers lease cars that are paid for by taxpayers. But Representative Emanuel Cleaver of Missouri recently raised eyebrows with his mobile office.

title: Tea for Two: Dame Edna Everage and Michael Feinstein
description: The stunt-loving producer David Merrick must have smiled from behind the pearly gates last fall. That was when a war of words between Dame Edna Everage and the singer and piano man Michael Feinstein over titles for their new Broadway shows (Its All About Me for her, All About Me for him) was discovered to be a hoax coordinated to promote  via carefully timed press releases  a production the two would star in together.

title: A Virtual Tour of the Biennial, Twitter (and Cameras) Allowed
description: If youve wanted to visit the Whitney Biennial but do not live near New York or work a job where youre never allowed to leave your desk (ahem), the museum and WNYC radio are collaborating on a virtual tour that you can follow from your computer or other Web-enabled device.

title: G.M. May Make Profit in 2010, New C.F.O. Says
description: General Motors has a reasonable chance of turning a profit this year, but the car maker is still a work in progress, the companys new chief financial officer said on Wednesday, according to press reports.

title: Stupak Ally in House Approves Senate Abortion Restrictions
description: Representative Dale Kildee, Democrat of Michigan and a strong opponent of abortion, announced on Wednesday that he was satisfied with the provisions in the Senate-passed health care bill that seek to limit the use of federal money for insurance coverage of abortion.

title: Panel for Better Air Travel Security
description: Frustrated by the long waits, confusion and seeming contradictions of airport security? The U.S. Travel Association, a nonprofit group that represents the industry, has assembled a Blue Ribbon Panel for Frictionless Security to create a vision for a secure, efficient and customer-friendly air travel security screening process.

title: Answers About New Consumer Laws: Part 2
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: SXSW: Sharing Space With a Hubble Astronaut
description: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

title: Alaa Time
description: On the very last night of Paris collections, at close to 9:30, the Azzedine Alaa show got underway before a small crowd in his studio in the Marais. Drinks and hors doeuvres were passed. The designers St. Bernard was shown to his ample bed in the kitchen and the models hit the improvised runway in the showroom.

title: Now Screening | Movie Night at Crosby Street
description: In a previous life, I saw a lot of movies in screening rooms. There was something about sinking into a cool leather lounger in the hush of a Midtown high-rise that made every film seem better than it actually was. I thought Nurse Betty was terrific. Mel Gibsons Payback? Loved it.

title: A Lawyer Who Represents a Friend May Have an Unhappy Client
description: Last May, Efrain Gonzlez Jr., a former New York state senator, appeared with his lawyer in Federal District Court in Manhattan and pleaded guilty to conspiracy and mail fraud.

title: Doses of Perspective
description: It is one of those days when perspective seems ready to run off the rails, as helpless as the poor guy going 65 miles per hour on the New Jersey Turnpike on a day when the 90 m.p.h. pack is in a particularly foul mood. Yes, actual humans were professing to feel badly that the poor, disrespected Masters would be sullied by Tiger Woodss return. The whining about N.C.A.A. seeds and matchups was almost deafening.

title: Stanford Knows the Drop From No. 1 Can Be Steep
description: Most schools would celebrate being a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. womens tournament, but Stanford (31-1) is keeping calm about being the top team in the Sacramento regional.

title: Are Green Consumers Less Trustworthy?
description: The Guardian newspaper picked this up recently, and it also makes an appearance in the most recent issue of Conservation magazine: people who buy green products may be, on the whole, more likely to steal and cheat when given the chance.

title: Answers From a Film Scout
description: Following is the first set of responses from Nick Carr, who for the past five years has worked as a film location scout in New York, combing the streets for every type of locale imaginable for use in feature films and on television.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Raul Esparza to Join Anyone Can Whistle
description: Raul Esparza, a four-time Tony Award acting nominee for both musicals and plays, has been cast as the leading man, the mysterious J. Bowden Hapgood, in the coming City Center Encores! production of the Stephen SondheimArthur Laurents musical Anyone Can Whistle, Encores! officials said on Wednesday.

title: Tournament Tipoff: Making the Picks
description: With the opening round of the men's N.C.A.A. tournament fast approaching, The Times's Pete Thamel navigates through the field of 64.

title: Quote Unquote | Go Figure
description: Gisele Bndchen discusses how she was able to model immediately after giving birth to her son Benjamin. Her secret? Gisele is superhuman.

title: Making Regular Yogurt Greek
description: The excitement over Greek yogurt  the ultra-thick, ultra-expensive kind  inspired me to produce a column about making it yourself. Im not talking about making yogurt, though; Im talking about making Greek-style yogurt from any regular yogurt. The process is simple and easy, and the results are perfect. See this weeks Minimalist column.

title: Senator Leahys Photo Spread
description: Many people know that Senator Patrick Leahy, the Democrat from Vermont, is an avid photographer.

title: Young Curators Speak
description: Four young Manhattan curators, all in their 30s, talk about their jobs and bringing art to the next generation of museumgoers.

title: Irish Cardinal Apologizes to Abuse Victims
description: Updated | 5:19 p.m. In a St. Patricks Day homily and in a televised statement to reporters on Wednesday, Cardinal Sean Brady, the leader of Irelands Roman Catholics, apologized to victims of sexual abuse and to all those who feel I have let them down.

title: Red Bulls Coach Likes One Young Defender in Particular
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Thirty years ago, Hennes Weisweiler of Germany came to the United States to coach the Cosmos and found a young, little-used defender, Jeff Durgan, sitting on the bench. Weisweiler took a liking to the big and rugged player from Washington State and made him a starter.

title: Ex-Lehmanites: Repo 105 Outrage Inspires Giggles
description: To many observers, the revelation of Lehman Brothers use of an aggressive accounting technique, Repo 105, to make its balance sheet look $50 billion lighter is an outrage.

title: Workman Hires a New Publisher
description: Workman Publishing, an idiosyncratic independent publisher of titles ranging from the blockbuster What to Expect series to novels like Water for Elephants and The Reliable Wife, has started a succession plan by naming Robert S. Miller, currently president of HarperStudio, as group publisher.

title: G.M. Tinkers With Augmented Reality System for Cars
description: The research and development labs of General Motors have been working closely with several universities, including Carnegie Mellon University and the University of Southern California, to build an augmented reality system that could assist motorists in difficult driving situations.

title: The Making of the President, Then and Now
description: The campaign book deserves to die, and it is doing its duty.

title: Student Crossword | War Puzzles
description: What country joined the Allies in August 1916, declaring war on Austria-Hungary? If you know the answer, put it in #45 across.

title: Houston Rises Again, Cooling Penderss Hot Seat
description: HOUSTON  When Tom Penders was approached to become the University of Houston mens basketball coach six years ago, he bolted to the nearest elevator.

title: At Tammany Hall, Irish Bosses Ran a Well-Oiled Machine
description: A half-century ago, as the Democratic machine, its best days behind it, was being successfully challenged by reformers, Daniel Patrick Moynihan wrote an eloquent essay entitled When the Irish Ran New York. Its particularly appropriate to recall Mr. Moynihans nostalgic musings not merely because of St. Patricks Day, but because nowadays it appears as if no one is running New York.

title: G.M. Has Reasonable Chance of Profit This Year, Its Chief Finance Officer Says
description: DETROIT  General Motors has a reasonable chance of earning a profit this year, the carmakers chief financial officer, Christopher P. Liddell, said Wednesday.

description: If you cant bear to read the GQ interview itself, just read Hanna Rosins take on the Edwards mistresss religion of the self:

title: Another Top Paterson Aide Resigns
description: Marissa Shorenstein, Gov. David A. Patersons press secretary and acting chief spokeswoman, resigned on Wednesday. She becomes the fifth top state official to resign in the wake of a scandal over the Paterson administrations handling of a domestic violence incident.

title: Xobni Arrives on the BlackBerry
description: At our sibling blog, Bits, Claire Cain Miller reports on the introduction of Xobni Mobile for BlackBerry devices, which will be welcome news for Outlook users who are addicted to Xobni, an add-on service that organizes and searches e-mail messages and contacts.

description: The Timess Pete Thamel chose the teams he expects to advance to the Final Four and championship games in Indianapolis after a game-by-game analysis of round one and the regions in this years N.C.A.A. tournament.

description: This season, stylish travelers are indulging their pastoral fantasies.

description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime and securities law for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Cracks Bedevil Bloombergs Driveway
description: A wave of snowstorms has produced tire-devouring potholes and gaping cracks in roadways across the city.

title: Patrick McCarthy to Leave Cond Nast
description: Patrick McCarthy, the chairman and editorial director of Cond Nasts Fairchild Fashion Group and de facto editor of the fashion magazine W, will leave the company at the end of the year.

title: Jetstar to Expand Routes and Reduce Fares
description: Bloomberg is reporting, Jetstar, a budget carrier and subsidiary of Qantas, plans to expand international routes and lower some fares while also reducing costs, its chief executive said.

title: Keeping Abe, and the Rest of Us, Honest
description: Abraham Lincoln wrote the letter, an election year paean to the Methodist church, in 1864, at the height of his rhetorical powers, after the Gettysburg Address and before his second inaugural speech. Yet to the modern eye, the letter suffers from some all-too human flaws.

title: Ludacris Takes Over at No. 1 on Billboard Charts
description: New on the Billboard album chart this week: Lucadris, Gorillaz, Jimi Hendrix and a new project by members of Gnarls Barkley and the Shins.

title: Broadway Star to Opera Star, All in a Day
description: 2:17 p.m. | Updated  Plantation owner by day; regal ghost by night. Its not a pitch for a bizarre comic-book hero  its the Saturday schedule for David Pittsinger, who may need some super-powered vocal cords to pull it off.

title: Good Wife Watch: Doubts Worth Puzzling Over
description: Tuesday nights episode of The Good Wife was one of the best, in no small part thanks to Martha Plimpton, who was back in the role of Patricia Nyholm, a manipulative lawyer for a greedy (of course) insurance company. This time, she was helping her client weasel out of covering the costs of emergency surgery on a womans unborn son  using her own plump, healthy newborn as a prop.

title: Talk Deeply, Be Happy?
description: Would you be happier if you spent more time discussing the state of the world and the meaning of life  and less time talking about the weather?

title:
Obama Delays Trip as Report Aids Final Push
on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  As House Democrats geared up for a possible vote on Sunday to pass health care legislation, the Congressional Budget Office issued an analysis allowing them to point to significant cost savings in the decades ahead, and President Obama postponed a planned trip to the Pacific to keep pressing for approval.

title: Cant See the Road? G.M.s Next-Gen Head-Up Display May Help
description: General Motors is working on a head-up windshield display system that will reportedly make it easier for drivers to see where theyre going when they cant see where theyre going.

title: Minute Man | Andrew Block
description: In the second part of our guide to capitalizing on your good taste with an investment-grade watch, T asked Andrew Block, the executive vice president of Tourneau, some time-pressing questions.

title: Israel Seeks to Mend Rift With the U.S.
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli officials said Wednesday that efforts were under way to calm tensions with the Obama administration and come up with a formula to defuse a diplomatic crisis over building in contested East Jerusalem.

title: Late for Mass, but With a Good Excuse
description: When Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly arrived a few minutes late to St. Patricks Cathedral for Mass on Wednesday morning, Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan gently ribbed him for being tardy.

title: British Ads Ignore Uncertainties of Climate Change, Watchdog Agency Finds
description: A British advertising watchdog this week criticized a government poster campaign publicizing the dangers of climate change  the latest setback in efforts to raise awareness of the issue.

title: The Hurt Locker Through a Baghdad Lens
description: BAGHDAD  It was Election Day in Iraq and Oscar night in America. It was my sixth day in Baghdad, and like many of the soldiers I was with, it was my first hitch here.

title: SXSW: The Music Onslaught Begins
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  As the recording business implodes, the South By Southwest Music and Media Festival sprawls. Im just arriving for this years four-day frenzy of bands, bands, bands  day parties, night showcases, after parties, Webcasts, YouTube follow-ups  punctuated by conversations and breaks for barbecue. I brought a list of prospective bands to see that will be impossible to fulfill and that will probably get tossed away by Friday as more likely candidates come up.

title: N.B.A. Board Approves Jordans Purchase of the Bobcats
description: The N.B.A. board of governors on Wednesday unanimously approved Michael Jordans purchase of the money-losing Charlotte Bobcats from Robert L. Johnson. The acquisition placed a $275 million value on the team, and Jordan is increasing his small stake to a majority one.

title: Travel Deals: Free Train Travel in Ireland
description: For travelers 66 years or older, Tourism Ireland is offering a Golden Trekker Pass: four days of unlimited free train travel on Irish Rail.

title: Schapiro Says S.E.C. Is Looking Beyond Lehman
description: As details have emerged about how the accounting tactics of Lehman Brothers helped bring about the firms demise, Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, confirmed on Wednesday that the agency was investigating other several companies actions in the run-up to the financial crisis of 2008, The Associated Press reports.

title: Is Passing the Health Care Bill Really a Bad Idea?
description: Gail Collins: David, when I went off on vacation I left you to converse with Dick Cavett. Really, what could be more fun? All the while I was gone I was imagining what a great time the two of you were having. Well, O.K., not all the time. But the thought definitely occurred.

title: Merkel Urges Tougher Rules for Euro Zone
description: FRANKFURT  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, adopting a harsher tone toward Greece than the one expressed by some other European leaders, said Wednesday that Europe needed better rules to police its members, and she tacitly endorsed a proposal to eject wayward countries from the group of countries that use the euro.

title: Muslim Scholar, Formerly Barred, Coming to New York
description: A prominent Muslim academic barred from the United States for six years under the Patriot Act will speak at a panel at Cooper Union next month, his first public appearance since the restriction was lifted.

title: Seton Hall, in Turmoil, Fires Gonzalez
description: Seton Hall dismissed Bobby Gonzalez on Wednesday, ending his tumultuous four-year tenure as mens basketball coach a day after an ignominious first-round loss in the National Invitation Tournament and the arrest of a player who had been kicked off the team.

title: District by District, Data on Health Care
description: Say youre a House Democrat, wondering whether to vote for President Obamas health care bill. Representative Henry A. Waxman has some data for you.

title: Obama: Everything Is on the Line
description: President Obama has sent an e-mail message thanking members of his Organizing for America group for their efforts in building support for the Democrats health care legislation.

title: Illinois Senate Candidate Mines Health Care Opposition
description: Representative Mark Kirk, the Illinois Republican who is hoping to win Barack Obamas former seat in the United States Senate, told supporters last week that he intended to lead the effort to repeal President Obamas health care legislation if it passes.

title: SXSW: No Parking on the Dance Floor
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Its not garage rock, just rock in a parking garage, as Broken Bells starts its SXSW run in the concrete surroundings of the Red River Garage. (Tonight the group performs on NPR from Stubbs.) On its album, Broken Bells is the collaboration of James Mercer from the Shins and Danger Mouse from Gnarls Barkley. Onstage, its a seven-man band, and even though theyre striving to replicate the arrangements on the album, down to the oozy keyboard effects, its flesh-and-blood players and bigger crescendos help the songs escape the subdued studio production. The songs are still morose about many human failings, but not so withdrawn, a shading that makes a differencemore psychedelic, less studied. And it doesnt hurt that, strange but true, this garage has better acoustics than some SXSW clubs.

title: Can a Recovering Sex Addict Have Sex?
description: When a panel of experts recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about sex addiction, one reader asked whether a recovering sex addict can ever have sex again. Sexual addiction therapist Joe Kort responds.

title: Fed Fights to Keep Oversight of Banks That Arent Big
description: WASHINGTON  Officials at the Federal Reserve are trying to alter a Senate proposal that would focus the Feds regulatory attention on the nations biggest banks and strip away its powers over small and medium-size banks.

title: The Morning Skate: Head Check Rule Fast-Track Gains Momentum
description: The effort by a group of N.H.L. general managers to accelerate the approval process on the proposed new rule against blindside checks to the head gained momentum yesterday.

title: Testing 1, 2, 3: Creating Quizzes to Gauge Science Knowledge
description: Overview | How can quizzes be used as learning tools and assessments? What is the educational value of not only taking a quiz, but also creating one? Are there significant differences between interactive and traditional quiz formats? In this lesson, students take an online quiz, then create their own quizzes about scientists or science-related topics. They then take one anothers quizzes and consider their efficacy for introducing a new topic, reviewing material and assessing knowledge in a graded exam.

title: McChrystal Disagrees With Holder: Bin Laden Is Wanted Alive
description: Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the top commander of American and NATO troops in Afghanistan, contradicted the attorney general on Wednesday when he said that actually, the military still wants to capture Osama bin Laden alive.

title: Now Showing | The Original Diva
description: In a world where Miley Cyrus is considered a diva, a stroll through Maria Callas: A Woman, a Voice, a Myth is a refreshing detour. Now here is a woman who was both talent and tempest.

title: Your Dot: Climate Concerns
description: Heres another Your Dot installment, highlighting a couple of readers views of the climate-energy challenge. Robert Robinson, from upstate New York, echoes concerns expressed here by Robert Brulle, a sociologist at Drexel University, who notes that slow environmental changes are absorbed by society incrementally in ways that work against calls for substantial shifts in policy. Len Arends of San Bruno, Calif., compares rising human awareness of a looming problem driven by an unnecessary dependency to the situation of a person entering the first step of a 12-step rehab program.

title: Paterson Says Gillibrand Threw Him Under the Bus
