description: When Gov. David A. Paterson appointed a little-known junior congresswoman named Kirsten E. Gillibrand to the United States Senate last year, he probably expected it to be the beginning of a beautiful relationship.

title: How to Prepare Your Business for Succession
description: WHEN his father died in 2006, Allen Frechter thought that his work as executor of the estate would be fairly straightforward.

title: Shopping With Charlotte Moss
description: The interior designer shopped Manhattan's Upper East Side for china and decorative pieces for the table.

title: Do You Have a Succession Plan?
description: Small-business owners who do not have a succession plan, Ian Mount writes in a just published small-business guide, create a time bomb that can not only destroy their companies but also tear apart their families. A lot of families fight and fight until the business is gone, said Jim Clay, who heads the trusts and estates department at the law firm Morrison Fenske & Sund in Minnetonka, Minn. It eats up everyones inheritances.

title: Texts Without Context
description: In his deliberately provocative  and deeply nihilistic  new book, Reality Hunger, the onetime novelist David Shields asserts that fiction has never seemed less central to the cultures sense of itself. He says hes bored by out-and-out fabrication, by myself and others; bored by invented plots and invented characters and much more interested in confession and reality-based art. His own book can be taken as Exhibit A in what he calls recombinant or appropriation art.

title: Words, Version 2.0
description: A bookshelf for further reading:

title: Major California Solar Project Moves Ahead
description: California regulators on Wednesday recommended that the states first new big solar power plant in nearly two decades be approved after a two-and-half-year review of its environmental impact on the Mojave Desert.

title: Appreciating Your Value as You Age
description: AGING is an indiscriminate leveler. You might have been a shapely bombshell who made heads turn. You might have honed your intellect and rsum and let looks take a backseat. Still, most of us will pass a mirror one day and wonder who is that stranger with the droopy eyelids.

title: Waiting for CBO
description: Vladimir and Estragon are getting pretty antsy waiting for the CBO score on the reconciliation package

title: Its Hip to Be a Young, Creative Urbanite!
description: Many would like to see the hipster  the word, to say nothing of the person behind it  go the way of the dodo. Only problem: those who would retire the word cant help using it.

title: Setting a Spring Table
description: CHARLOTTE MOSS, the interior designer, is so intrigued with entertaining that years ago she bought Jacqueline Kennedys handwritten notes about entertaining at the White House.

title: Bernanke Defends Feds Banking Oversight Role
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, urged Congress on Wednesday to let the Fed keep all of its banking oversight, arguing that information gleaned from that process helped the central bank guide the economy, The Associated Press reports.

title: Credit Where It Isnt Due
description: Im not usually interested in White House intrigue, and Im no Kremlinologist, but it does seem bizarre to claim that Democratic consolidation behind Obamacare is a vindication for Rahm Emanuel, of all people.

title: Democrats Press Ahead With Student Loan Overhaul
description: The drive to pass health care legislation intersected on Wednesday with calls for President Obamas proposed overhaul of the student loan system.

title: Violence Follows Fires at Tombs in Uganda
description: Crowds took cover at the Kasubi tombs near Kampala on Wednesday as the army and the police fired at demonstrators. Reuters reported that Ugandan security forces killed two people and wounded five after fire destroyed the royal tombs. The 19th-century Tombs of Buganda Kings at Kasubi are listed as a world heritage site by Unesco. It is a major example of an architectural achievement in organic materials, principally wood, thatch, reed, wattle and daub, the citation says. The sites main significance lies, however, in its intangible values of belief, spirituality, continuity and identity.

title: The Most (and Least) Expensive Vehicles to Insure
description: The Porsche Carrera 911 GT2 two-door coupe is the most expensive 2010 vehicle to insure, according to a new ranking of average premiums for 2010 models that Insure.com released this week.

title: 4 Banks Face Trial in Italy Over Interest-Rate Swaps
description: An Italian judge on Wednesday ordered JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, UBS and a banking unit of the German company Hypo Real Estate Holding to stand trial for fraud in their handling of interest-rate swaps acquired by the city of Milan in 2005, The New York Timess Eric Sylvers reports from Milan. The trial of the four banks, as well as 11 of their employees and two former city officials, will begin May 6.

title: Dances With Wolf
description: Martin Wolf apparently shares my views about the trouble with Chinese currency policy  and throws Germany into the mix. The difference is that he uses stronger language!

title: Suspicion of Arson at Royal Tombs Fuels Deadly Clashes in Uganda
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  Riots erupted at venerated burial grounds in Uganda on Wednesday, and witnesses said that police officers shot and killed three protesters.

title: A Family Triangle of Archetypes Amid the Sandbags of America
description: There is, for the record, a real kitchen sink in Suzan-Lori Parkss Book of Grace, an ambitious, intriguing and annoying play that both embraces and explodes an assortment of theatrical clichs. That sink comes with the other furniture you expect in vintage dramas about American families with Problems that warrant capital Ps: stove, refrigerator, television, sofa, browbeaten wife in bathrobe.

title: New Finding Puts Origins of Dogs in Middle East
description: Borrowing methods developed to study the genetics of human disease, researchers have concluded that dogs were probably first domesticated from wolves somewhere in the Middle East, in contrast to an earlier survey suggesting dogs originated in East Asia.

title: Amelia Island Concours Weekend Is All Grown Up
description: The Amelia Island concours weekend in Florida had a considerably different feel this year. After 15 years, it feels like its all grown up.

title: High-End and High-Speed in Spain
description: All aboard a luxury train from Madrid to Barcelona.

title: The Calm Men Who Bring You Exotic Animals
description: There are moments in Life, the Discovery Channels follow-up to the widely acclaimed nature series Planet Earth, when a viewer cant help wonder: How in the world did they capture that on camera?

title: ABC and Amanpour Close to Deal for This Week
description: ABC News is close to concluding a deal to install the longtime CNN foreign correspondent Christiane Amanpour as the new host of its Sunday political discussion show This Week.

title: Olympian Weighs In on Eat Like Olympians
description: One of the biggest sponsors of the coverage of the Vancouver Olympics on NBC Universal last month was McDonalds, which ran a couple of commercials for Chicken McNuggets dozens of times. The spots invited viewers to eat like Olympians and promised that you dont have to be an Olympic athlete to eat like one.

title: Google and Partners Seek TV Foothold
description: Google and Intel have teamed with Sony to develop a platform called Google TV to bring the Web into the living room through a new generation of televisions and set-top boxes.

title: Berkeley Scientists Herbicide Studies Raise Corporate Hackles
description: Accusations are flying over the latest University of California, Berkeley study on the effects of a widely-used weed killer on amphibian sexuality.

title: Monserrate Reflects a Day After Losing
description: Hiram Monserrate is fully aware that there are a lot of people who wished that his failure to regain his old State Senate seat in a special election in Queens on Tuesday would seal his political career. And he really doesnt care.

title: A Hundred Years of Gifts From Finland
description: Finland is pretty hot at the moment, musically speaking. Where nonspecialists once began and ended their lists of great Finnish composers with Sibelius, now Einojuhani Rautavaara, Magnus Lindberg and Kaija Saariaho are creating some of the most inventive and compelling works being written anywhere.

title: Neanderthal Stars in Smithsonian Exhibit
description: The Smithsonians National Museum of Natural History is opening a new permanent exhibit exploring human evolution over six million years.

title: Opening Arguments
description: The authors of Face It arent the first to note that modern women are in a bind.

title: Connecting to a Culture Using 4 Wheels
description: RYAN WASHINGTON, 21, said he can perform over 100 gravity-defying tricks on his skateboard, which has given him a place of honor at the local skate park. There is no limit to what you can do on a piece of wood with plastic wheels, he said. Whenever I master a trick, I feel like I am on top of the world.

title: City Operas Former Director Tracks the Tumult and Breaks Down the Buzz
description: The New York City Opera is never far from the thoughts of Julius Rudel, who was its general director and principal conductor for 22 years, until he stepped aside in 1979, making way for Beverly Sills. I recently met Mr. Rudel, still lively and avuncular at 89, for an interview in his apartment on Central Park West. And the first thing he showed off was his collection of framed sketches of memorable sets from City Opera productions he had conducted. The pictures adorn an entire wall next to his piano.

title: BlogTalk: OBamas Roots and Health Care
description: We have to start with a nod to St. Patricks Day, where in Washington there is no pause from politics. Today, when President Obama and the prime minister of Ireland, Brian Cowen, attended the annual luncheon on Capitol Hill, he managed to get in a few laughs about his own Irish roots and to link the holiday to the current health care debate by invoking the names of Ronald Reagan, Tip ONeill and the late Senator Ted Kennedy.

title: Pop Sensibilities, Along With Some Quirky Flair
description: Its easy to imagine Larry Keigwin choreographing a Beyonc video, even if you didnt know he got his start as a backup dancer on Club MTV. Please dont mistake that for faint praise (who doesnt love her Single Ladies?), only a nod to this witty stylists pop sensibilities.

title: Who Needs Wall Street?
description: Mike Mayo is a veteran of six Wall Street banks. In the wake of the streets disaster, he found refuge at a boutique brokerage and has lately taken to startling his peers with the question What part of Goldman Sachs is good for the country?

title: Maker of Tylenol Explains Actions Taken to Alleviate Musty Smell of Pills
description: The Johnson & Johnson unit that drew criticism and a federal warning letter in January on the grounds of mishandling quality control problems with Tylenol says it has taken steps to prevent similar incidents in the future, according to documents newly posted on the Web site of the Food and Drug Administration.

title: A Grain Silo Reborn
description: Eighty feet up, 240 tons of concrete and steel in Olomouc, Czech Republic.

title: Wachovia to Pay $160 Million in Drug Money Case
description: The Wachovia Bank, a unit of Wells Fargo, has agreed to pay $160 million to settle a federal criminal case accusing it of laundering Mexican drug money, Reuters reports.

title: Living Against the Grain in the Czech Republic
description: OLOMOUC, CZECH REPUBLIC   RADIM KRALIK and his wife, Barbora Kralikova, live in a modern concrete box on top of a 1943 grain silo, a stark contrast to the neo-Gothic spires that dominate this small city about 175 miles east of Prague.

title: Steamed Quinoa, White Bean Salad With Sage and Pan-Fried Winter Squash
description: This is a very simple, satisfying plate of food that relies on foods from the pantry and vegetables that store well. The quinoa and bean recipes make more than one serving. Both are good keepers, so you can eat the leftovers for lunch or dinner the next day. Pan-cooked winter squash has become a favorite in our house; itll satisfy any cravings you might have for fries.

title: The Greening of the White House
description: Even at the White House, theres no escaping the color green, from the South Lawn to events throughout the day and night.

title: Audio: Searching for Truth at SXSW
description: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

title: A Mash-Up Culture: Ten to Watch
description: Sampling, mash-ups, redubs and collages are hardly new. In the early 60s, William Burroughs and Brion Gysin popularized the use of decoupage or cut-ups, pioneered by the Surrealists, as a non-linear creative technique that could be used with words, sounds and images. And with his 1966 movie Whats Up, Tiger Lily? Woody Allen redubbed a Japanese spy film, turning it into a story about a dangerous quest to find the recipe for the worlds greatest egg salad.

title: Living Proof
description: In Friesach, the picture-perfect Austrian town halfway between Vienna and Venice, in the Carinthian Alps, there is a bar that changed my understanding of the word schnapps.

title: This Prince: What a Piece of Work
description: The Metropolitan Opera under general manager Peter Gelb is defining itself through the choice and quality, however debatable, of its ambitious new productions. Yet bringing successful existing productions of overlooked works to the Met is just as important to the companys artistic mission, not to mention a safer bet. And few operas have been as overlooked as Ambroise Thomass Hamlet.

title: Previous Taxi Fraud Cases, but No Red Flags
description: Two New York taxi drivers were convicted in 2008 of swindling passengers by charging higher rates meant for out-of-town trips, but city officials failed to follow up with a broader investigation that might have revealed the scheme to be far more widespread.

title: China's Economic Growth on the Rise
description: Marcus Mabry and Liz Alderman of The Times discuss whether the Yuan is undervalued in Asia.

title: Part Concert, Part Talk Show, All Escapism
description: For more than a decade Jo Dee Messina has been in the business of Oprah-fied country, singing songs of empowerment and escape with an eye for psychological detail and a firm sense of dignity. Shes been wronged, and if you dont mind, shed like to talk about it.

title: Back to the Futurists
description: I have always been intrigued by the work of Fernand Lger. His tubular, mechanical paintings from the early 1920s captured his fascination with Futurism yet also his fear of new machines.

title: Changing the Vaticans Response to Abuse
description: As the sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church continues to unfold, Pope Benedict XVI said he would issue a letter to Irish Catholics on Friday to help repentance, healing and renewal.

title: Body Shop Begins a Campaign Against Sex Trafficking
description: Retail stores are typically happy, shiny lands of make-believe, the better to woo shoppers into opening their wallets and purses. Then there is the Body Shop.

title: What Were Reading
On the Guggenheims Walls, and Now on Yours
description: THIS month, the offerings at Charitybuzz, an auction site that helps nonprofit groups raise money, include a guitar autographed by the Rolling Stones, a dinner prepared by Emeril Lagasse and 193 pieces from an exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum.

title: For Israel and America, a Disagreement, Not a Crisis
description: Washington

title: I Want One
description: A Chicago Manual of Style purse: be the envy of all your style- and correctness-obsessed book-industry friends!(Via Brainiac.)

title: Obama: Not Worried About House Procedural Moves
description: President Obama on Wednesday dismissed Republican criticisms of the parliamentary tactics Democrats may use to push his health care bill through Congress, saying he doesnt spend a lot of time worrying about what the procedural rules are.

title: Curator of Collections and Connections
description: IT was a quiet weekday afternoon last month on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, but the ground floor of the brownstone that houses the China Institute was humming. Employees were bustling around with tape measures and installation plans as they readied the institutes gallery for the show Confucius: His Life and Legacy in Art. Willow Weilan Hai Chang, the gallery director, stood in a corner of the tiny two-room exhibition space, talking about that philosopher and his influence on Chinese society.

title: Reducing the Anxiety of Paying Online
description: Last year, 92 million people bought things online using credit cards, debit cards and services like PayPal and Google Checkout. Millions of others paid bills and wired money electronically from bank accounts with just a few clicks.

title: On HGTV, Fixing Homes and Hearts
description: The Grants are getting a divorce, Ian Kleier says after studying the gossip pages at the kitchen table of his Park Avenue apartment. His wife, Michele, is not surprised. I had my suspicions, she says, and starts to list the warning signs while scrambling eggs for the girls, the couples trio of white Maltese. Ian cuts her off. Its not a pretty divorce, and I think you should jump right on top of it.

title: Acting Leader of Nigeria Dissolves His Cabinet
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The acting president of Nigeria, Goodluck Jonathan, dissolved his cabinet on Wednesday in the strongest assertion yet of his authority over a country where his rule has been challenged.

title: Episcopalians Confirm a Second Gay Bishop
description: A majority of bishops and dioceses of the Episcopal Church have approved the election of the churchs second openly gay bishop, the Rev. Mary D. Glasspool, a decision likely to increase the tension with fellow Anglican churches around the world that do not approve of homosexuality.

title: From an Artist of Anxiety, an Ink-Stained Memoir
description: Jules Feiffer has always been adept at using satire to trace the links between our public and private anxieties, our political and personal preoccupations. In more than four decades of cartoons for The Village Voice, in films like Carnal Knowledge, plays like Grown-Ups and Little Murders and numerous books, hes given us snapshots of neurotic families and neurotic singles, and a panoramic view of an America reeling from the social and political convulsions of the 1960s and 70s, Vietnam, the disillusionments wrought by the Kennedy assassinations, Watergate, the Reagan and Clinton years, the gender wars and the fragmentation of the nuclear family.

title: A Shorter Parade Means Less Green for Some on St. Patrick's Day
description: For a French restaurant with a fairly patrician customer base, Demarchelier, on East 86th Street at Madison Avenue, saw a fair amount of trade on Wednesday from the green T-shirt crowd. In the bar area, Irish music blared and plastic foam cups of beer were raised.

title: A Shorter Parade Means Less Green for Some on St. Patricks Day
description: For a French restaurant with a fairly patrician customer base, Demarchelier, on East 86th Street at Madison Avenue, saw a fair amount of trade on Wednesday from the green T-shirt crowd. In the bar area, Irish music blared and plastic foam cups of beer were raised.

title: Playing It Cool With a Jawbone in Your Ear
description: The word apps, of course, is short for applications, which means programs. But until 2007, nobody used the term apps except the people who wrote them  programmers. It wasnt until the iPhone came along that apps became shorthand used by normal people.

title: Detroit Plan Would Close 45 Schools
description: In a continuing overhaul of one of the most troubled school systems in the nation, officials in Detroit on Wednesday announced a plan to close 45 of 172 public schools at the end of the academic year. The move is the latest in a string of efforts aimed at rescuing an academically failing district in the midst of a financial crisis.

title: More Cash to Go to a Hall Than to Haiti
description: Lang Lang, the celebrity pianist; Christoph Eschenbach, the conductor; and the Schleswig-Holstein Festival Orchestra are taking the stage at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night in a concert trumpeted as a fund-raiser for the earthquake-ravaged Haiti. But what ticket buyers may not realize is that far more of their dollars will go toward concert-hall rent and marketing than to anyone in Haiti, with the biggest chunks going to stagehands and newspaper advertisements.

title: Geodesics on Globes
description: Konrad Polthier of the Free University of Berlin illustrates the non-uniqueness of locally shortest paths on the surface of an imaginary planet.

title: Backing Into Forward
description: Chapter 1: Boy Cartoonist

title: Finding the Brighter Side of a Dark Schubert Cycle
description: An evening based on Schuberts Winterreise seems an unlikely antidepressant. But Rick Burkhardt, Alec Duffy and Dave Malloy give this gloomy song cycle an amusing theatrical makeover in Three Pianos at the Ontological-Hysteric Theater at St. Marks Church.

title: A U.S. Debut for a Dutch Design Duo
description: Tubular benches made from coiled steel frames covered in tennis balls and old blankets given new life as colorful rugs are among the unorthodox furnishings by Atelier Remy & Veenhuizen that will be on view at Industry Gallery in Washington. Hands On, an exhibition opening March 20, is the first solo show in the United States for the Utrecht studio founded by Tejo Remy, a designer associated with the influential Dutch company Droog, and Ren Veenhuizen.

title: Lighting and Furniture Sales
description: Hable Construction is offering a 25 percent online discount on its brightly patterned storage items and decorative accessories during March (throw pillows, below, originally $125, will be $93.75 when the code marchon is entered at checkout); information: hableconstruction.com.

title: Road Test: Mops
description: The Process

title: Let Your Conscience Do the Walking in Green Pages
description: Several new books extolling the virtues of green living provide information for readers of all commitment levels.

title: An Expert on Choice Chooses
description: SHEENA IYENGAR, the S. T. Lee professor of business at Columbia University, was home from work the other day, dressed in a cream-colored twin set and a sparkly gold pencil skirt. She was seated at the head of a long cherry dining table she designed with her husband, Garud Iyengar, a financial engineer who is also a professor at Columbia, in the living room the two had decorated in earthy colors with a mix of furniture found at auction, in India and at a store in downtown Manhattan. There was a clear point of view  a consistent style or discernible taste, if you will  that linked all the objects in the room, including Dr. Iyengars outfit.

title: A Model Apartment Dressed to the Nines
description: THE place smelled terrific. There were Jo Malone candles and tight little bunches of pink roses and calla lilies in short glass cylinders. The beds were freshly made. The stereo was on, but softly.

title: Eva Zeisel Prints With Wings
description: When David Reid, left, and James Klein, the Long Island City ceramicists behind the KleinReid studio, were given the opportunity to meet one of their design idols, Eva Zeisel, center, they had no idea the encounter would lead to a lasting relationship. But more than a decade after their first meeting in 1999, the three continue to collaborate on a series of projects. Their latest, on sale today, is a limited-edition set of prints of reticulating shapes with classic Zeisel themes of wings and sprouts. The series is called Lovers Suite because when we worked on the original porcelain pieces, Eva said, Oh, you want them to make love, Mr. Klein said. Its a graphic description of how two forms interact so they mirror each other. They balance each other, and they come together to create something new and beautiful.

title: Bus Route Signs Roll on as Vintage Fabric
description: In England, bus route signs were once printed on rolls of calico cloth.

title: On Dance: NY Export: Opus Jazz
description: The city of New York has always served as a kind of living set. And while movies and television have dominated this breathing back lot, dance has used it to its artistic advantage too. Trisha Brown sent a dancer down the side of a building in 1970 and more recently the choreographer Nomie Lafrance mounted a piece in a Brooklyn apartment.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Matters of right and wrong are at the heart of this months crop of new books: What do we owe our fellow human beings at moments of crisis? What happens when authority figures turn a blind eye to the bad behavior of those under them? And, of course, when confronted by slave-holding vampires, is it worth risking the future of the nation?

title: Crowdsourcing the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: There are 9.2 quintillion possible outcomes to the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

title: TheStreet.com Says It Faces an S.E.C. Inquiry
description: TheStreet.com, the finance Web site founded by Jim Cramer, disclosed in a regulatory filing on Wednesday that it is the subject of an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission that began this month.

title: Irish Celebrate Despite Shamrock Shortage
description: Having been particularly hard hit by the global financial crisis, which helped bring about the popping of a local real estate bubble, Ireland has been struggling to regain its footing, and redefine its identity, now that it is no longer an emerging economic powerhouse.

title: First Fans Bracket Is All Business, No Politics
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama selected Kansas to win the N.C.A.A. championship. He presented his bracket on Wednesday at the White House as he took a break from the health care debate, which is one of the few things that has kept him from watching as much basketball as he hoped to this season.

title: A Geodesic Highway
description: Konrad Polthier illustrates that geodesics are the natural generalization of straight lines.

title: Just in Time for Play Ball, Apps for the Baseball Afflicted
description: Quick, look around the office. Do people appear to be staring into their iPhones with a bit more intensity than just a few weeks ago? Remember how information technology administrators blocked all the fantasy-baseball Web sites in years past?

title: What to Do When Gmail Overflows
description: Q. My Gmail account has filled up to 97 percent of my free allotment. I am too cheap to pay for more space. Is there a way send all this to another Gmail account as backup and free up space? Help, I only have a few days to spare!

title: Ludacris Tops Hendrix
description: New on the Billboard album chart this week: Ludacris, Gorillaz, Jimi Hendrix and a new project by members of Gnarls Barkley and the Shins. Ludacriss Battle of the Sexes (Def Jam) enters the chart at No. 1, with 137,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, followed by Plastic Beach (Virgin), the first album in five years by Gorillaz, which sold 112,000. With a new album of unreleased material and a pile of reissues, Hendrix makes a run on this weeks chart. Valleys of Neptune (Legacy), a new release with rare studio sessions, landed at No. 4 with 95,000 sales, and four newly reissued Hendrix titles  Are You Experienced?, Axis: Bold as Love, Electric Ladyland and First Rays of the New Rising Sun  charted between No. 44 and No. 67. Gary Allans new Get Off on the Pain (MCA Nashville) opens at No. 5 with 65,000 sales, and the self-titled debut album by Broken Bells, with Danger Mouse and James Mercer of the Shins, bows at No. 7; released by Columbia, it sold 49,000 copies in its first week. Last weeks No. 1, Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville), fell two spots to No. 3 with 106,000.

title: Heldentenor Foundation Is Closing Shop
description: Lauritz Melchior, the greatest heldentenor of his day and a supreme Wagner singer of the 1920s, 30s and 40s, knew how tough it was to find his kind of voice, so he set up a foundation in 1964 to seek them out.

title: Ral Esparza Joins Anyone Can Whistle
description: Ral Esparza, a four-time Tony Award nominee for both musicals and plays, has been cast as the leading man, the mysterious J. Bowden Hapgood, in the coming City Center Encores! production of the Stephen Sondheim-Arthur Laurents musical Anyone Can Whistle, Encores! officials said on Wednesday. Mr. Esparza (Speed-the-Plow, Company) will play opposite the previously announced Sutton Foster (Thoroughly Modern Millie) in the revival, which will also star Donna Murphy as the corrupt mayor of a financially bankrupt town. The original 1964 production of Anyone Can Whistle, which featured Angela Lansbury in her Broadway musical debut, drew mixed reviews for its somewhat absurdist storytelling and ran for only nine performances. The Encores! revival is scheduled to have five performances April 8 to 11.

title: 20th Anniversary of a Boston Art Heist
description: Most art-museum robberies are the stuff of low comedy, not high crime, and the goods are eventually returned to the walls. But the 1990 heist at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston  in which paintings and drawings worth well more than $300 million were taken  has long been the exception. The biggest art theft in American history, it turns 20 on Thursday, with the whereabouts of a Vermeer painting, three Rembrandts (including his only known seascape; above is its empty frame) and a Manet still unknown. Investigators and the museum are trying new tactics to recover the works, The Associated Press reported. The F.B.I. has resubmitted DNA samples recovered in the case for updated testing, and a longstanding $5 million reward offered by the museum is being publicized anew, with the use of two interstate highway billboards to advertise it. The statute of limitations for prosecuting the thieves  two men who masqueraded as Boston police officers  has long since passed, and federal officials have held out the possibility of immunity, in exchange for information, for anyone subsequently involved in the theft.

title: Lloyd Webbers Picasso Finally Set for Auction
description: After the resolution of a four-year-old claim by a German academic that a 1903 Picasso painting had been sold under duress to the Nazis in the mid-1930s, Christies announced on Wednesday that it would auction the work, Portrait of Angel Fernndez de Soto (The Absinthe Drinker),  right, in London on June 23. The portrait, from Picassos Blue Period, depicts his friend Angel Fernndez de Soto seated at a cafe table, shrouded in tobacco smoke. The Andrew Lloyd Webber Foundation, which the composer founded to benefit theaters and actors, is selling the work, which it bought at Sothebys in 1995 for $21.9 million. Christies was to have sold the painting in New York in November 2006 to benefit the foundation, but it was forced to withdraw it 24 hours before the auction after the collector Julius H. Schoeps filed a lawsuit saying that it had been forcibly sold by his great-uncle, Paul von Mendelssohn-Bartholdy, a Jewish banker in Berlin. Three years ago Christies expected it to bring $40 million to $60 million. Now, after a settlement between the heirs and the foundation, the auction house believes it can fetch around $60.9 million.

title: Duncans Swipe at the N.C.A.A.
description: Education Secretary Arne Duncan took another swing at the National Collegiate Athletic Association and top college basketball programs Wednesday, reiterating a call he made in January to ban from postseason play teams that fail to graduate at least 40 percent of their players.

title: Movie by Ice Cube at TriBeCa Festival
description: Ice Cube  a man whose feelings on Los Angeles and its environs are already well documented in song  will have the debut of his new movie about the Los Angeles Raiders football team at the Tribeca Film Festival, the festivals organizers said on Wednesday. The documentary, Straight Outta L.A., chronicles the move of the Raiders from Oakland to Los Angeles in 1982 over the objection of the National Football League, and how the team, which returned to Oakland in 1995, inspired its new hometown and the booming hip-hop scene. The film, produced as part of ESPN Films series 30 for 30, will be shown as the opening movie of the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Film Festival on April 23.

title: Singers Busy Day: Hamlet and South Pacific
description: Plantation owner by day; regal ghost by night. Its not a pitch for a bizarre comic-book hero  its the Saturday schedule for David Pittsinger, who may need some super-powered vocal cords to pull it off.

title: Can Karpov Be President of Chess Federation?
description: The former world champion Anatoly Karpov announced on Saturday that he was running for president of the World Chess Federation.

title: Banks Face Fraud Charges in Deals Involving Milans Debt
description: MILAN  An Italian judge Wednesday ordered JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, UBS and a banking unit of the German company Hypo Real Estate Holding to stand trial for fraud in their handling of interest rate swaps acquired by the city of Milan in 2005.

title: Lagerfeld to Help Tods With Its Hogan Brand
description: PARIS  Karl Lagerfeld has a new world at his feet: The Italian company Hogan, part of the Tods footwear empire, said Wednesday that it had signed the designer for a special collection.

title: Change Comes to Myanmar, but Only on the Juntas Terms
description: PYAPON, Myanmar  In the dried mud of the Irrawaddy Delta, workers are welding together the final pieces of a natural-gas pipeline that the countrys ruling generals say will keep the lights on in Yangon, Myanmars main city, after years of debilitating blackouts.

title: Lehmans Bankruptcy Bill Hits $678.5 Million
description: The bankruptcy tab just keeps growing for Lehman Brothers. The investment firm, which is in the process of liquidating, paid its bankruptcy advisers and lawyers a total of $678.5 million in the 17 months since it collapsed in September 2008, Bloomberg News reports, citing a regulatory filing by the firm.

title: N.H.L. May Prohibit Blind-Side Head Checks This Season
description: NEWARK  As the N.H.L. moved to speed its proposed rule against blind-side checks to the head for possible passage this season, the man whose actions fueled the effort, the Penguins Matt Cooke, sat unfazed in his dressing-room stall at the Prudential Center on Wednesday.

title: How Smart Could I Make My Dumb Manhattan Apartment?
description: SOMEBODY in my apartment is not very smart, and since I live alone, it is obviously the machines.

title: Smart Home Devices You Can Set Up Without Calling in the Pros
description: Home automation has been around as long as worlds fairs, but the latest developments  making homes more energy efficient, controlling security on the Internet and running everything off a smart phone  have resulted in more powerful systems that are easier to install and cost less.

title: SAP Bosses Say Its Now Pedal to the Metal
description: Pop quiz: Youre the new chief executive of a software maker that has been ridiculed ad nauseam for being years late with a product. What do you do?

title: German Call for Austerity Has Europe Grumbling
description: PARIS  Across Europe, from profligate Greece to newly strait-laced Ireland, countries are promising deep, painful cuts in public spending even as they face the likelihood of a new recession.

title: Relax, Legal Scholars: Bobbleheads Are Safe at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN  The oldest item in Yale Law Schools rare book collection is a 1,000-year-old fragment of a medieval manuscript bound inside an Italian guidebook for notaries. The newest is a bobblehead doll depicting William H. Rehnquist, 16th chief justice of the United States.

title: Time Seems Right for Paypal to Fly
Files Logging Scout Abuse Are a Focus in Civil Trial
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Files kept secret for decades that detail hundreds of claims of child sexual abuse by troop leaders of the Boy Scouts of America are at the center of a civil court case that began here Wednesday.

title: I Need to Vent. Hello, Facebook.
description: WHAT is the sound of an awkward silence on Facebook? If you have to ask, then you probably dont have friends like James Gower and Ashley Andrews, high school sweethearts from Spring, Tex., who are both 22 and engaged to be married this May.

title: Programmers Are Indicted in Madoff Case
description: Two former computer programmers at Bernard L. Madoffs firm were indicted Wednesday by a federal grand jury in Manhattan.

title: V.A. Is Fined Over Errors in Radiation at Hospital
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Wednesday announced its second-largest fine ever against a medical institution  $227,500  after finding that the veterans hospital in Philadelphia had caused an unprecedented number of radiation errors in treating prostate cancer patients.

title: Pentagon Sees a Threat From Online Muckrakers
description: To the list of the enemies threatening the security of the United States, the Pentagon has added WikiLeaks.org, a tiny online source of information and documents that governments and corporations around the world would prefer to keep secret.

title: Promising a Rose Garden
description: With the weather finally warming up in the capital after a long, snowy winter, the White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs, joked during his regular press briefing the other day that, like class, we should move this outside.

title: Economic Overhaul in Myanmar
description: Joseph Kahn, deputy foreign editor, talks to a Times reporter in Myanmar about the changes that are happening in the country.

title: World Bank Urges China to Bolster Rates and Let Currency Rise
description: HONG KONG  The World Bank recommended higher interest rates and a stronger currency for China on Wednesday, as it raised growth forecasts for the country. Chinas rapid economic growth has led to expectations of rising inflation and concerns that a bubble is building in the property industry.

title: The CFDA Awards Finalists
description: I popped on my BlackBerry and  voila!  there were the finalists for the 2010 Council of Fashion Designers of America awards. So many bold-faced names competing for attention

title: As Deflation Fears Persist, Japan Eases Monetary Policy
description: TOKYO  In a bid to shore up a deflation-plagued economy, Japans central bank eased monetary policy further Wednesday by increasing a loan program for banks.

title: Animal Abuse as Clue to Additional Cruelties
description: Responding to growing evidence that people who abuse animals often go on to attack humans, states are increasing the penalties for animal cruelty and developing better methods for tracking convicted offenders.

title: Drone Strike Said to Kill a Leader of Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON  A strike by an unmanned drone last week killed a senior commander of Al Qaeda who had played a significant role in planning the killing of Central Intelligence Agency operatives in late December at a base in Afghanistan, according to American officials.

title: In the End, Conduct Is What Counts
description: Providence, R.I.

title: Haiti: Children Reunited With Families
description: The 33 Haitian children taken from their earthquake-damaged homes by American church members in January were reunited with their biological families on Wednesday, officials said. The children, who ranged in age from 4 months to 12 years, were cared for at the SOS Childrens Village in the capital, Port-au-Prince, while social workers investigated their backgrounds. Nine of the 10 Americans arrested by the Haitian authorities while trying to take the children to the Dominican Republic were later released. The leader, Laura Silsby, remains in custody.

title: Martinez, an Understudy, Is Playing Like a Star
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  The Mets put an entire story line on the team bus on Wednesday, sending all three contenders for the starting center-field job on the three-hour trip here to face the Boston Red Sox.

title: Rosneft Stock Falls on Fear of Seizures
description: MOSCOW  Shares in Russias state oil company, Rosneft, slumped Wednesday after the company was said to have warned its trading partners that a British court could seize assets under a lawsuit filed by former executives of Yukos Oil.

title: France: Female Ex-Minister to Join Acadmie Franaise
description: Simone Veil, 82, a Holocaust survivor who became a French minister and president of the European Parliament, will become the sixth woman to enter the Acadmie Franaise on Thursday. The state-sponsored body oversees French language and usage. The ceremony will be attended by President Nicolas Sarkozy and former President Jacques Chirac and will be televised live. Ms. Veil, who also served on the Constitutional Council, is considered responsible for legalizing abortion in France as minister of health in 1975 and is one of the most popular women in the country.

title: Ukraine: Venue Offered for Arms Talks
description: Ukraines new president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, has offered Kiev as a location for the United States and Russia to sign a revamped nuclear arms reduction treaty, once it has been agreed to. Though the peace agreement is unrelated to Ukraine, having the treaty formally signed in Kiev, the capital, would be rich in symbolism for a country whose recent internal politics became a tug of war between Russia and the West for economic and political influence. Mr. Yanukovich, though he is generally viewed as leaning heavily toward Russia, has promoted the idea of Ukraine as bridge between East and West, rather than a country that falls readily within either sphere of influence. Russian officials welcomed the offer; the United States would prefer Prague, where President Obama gave a speech on disarmament last year, Ukraines new foreign minister, Kostyantyn Gryschenko, said Wednesday.

title: An Apparel Underdog Outfits a No. 15 Seed
description: PITTSBURGH  Amid the Nike swooshes and Adidas three stripes that dominate the N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments, it may be hard to spot the logo of a little-known company that is squeezing its foot in the door of the $4 billion sports-apparel industry.

title: Little Police Protocol for Out-of-Control Cars
description: SAN FRANCISCO  How does a police officer deal with a driver behind the wheel of a possible runaway vehicle? Probably the same way the officer would deal with any other high-speed pursuit.

title: A Small Victory in Afghanistan
description: Last week Defense Secretary Robert Gates visited the district of Now Zad in Afghanistans volatile Helmand Province. To many, it probably didnt seem like significant news. Gates reportedly went no farther than a 100 meters outside the forward operating base and there were fully armed Marines posted at short intervals not far from where he was walking. They had probably been in position for at least 24 hours before Gates arrived and the area was likely swept for explosives and insurgents multiple times in the days prior to his arrival.

title: Austria: Choir Faces Abuse Allegations
description: Eight former members of the Vienna Boys Choir have called an abuse hot line set up by the choir to report that they were sexually abused while they were members of the group, according to Tina Breckwoldt, who is overseeing the hot line. The choir opened the hot line after a local newspaper reported last week that two former choir members claimed that they had been sexually abused while in the choir decades ago. The callers who made the claims, which included accusations of sexual and physical abuse, ranged in age from 33 to 72, Mrs. Breckwoldt said. Some of the alleged perpetrators may have been boys in the choir at the time, she said. The eight calls had been received as of Wednesday. In an open letter on its Web site, the Vienna Boys Choir said that any abuse constituted an injustice that we deeply regret.

title: Governments Turn to Stealth Taxes to Fill Gaps
description: France, promising to improve the environment, is planning to introduce a carbon tax. In Finland, where the government says it wants to improve diets, taxes are back on candy and soft drinks. Similarly, Denmark has added tobacco and some fatty foods to the list of taxed products.

title: The Purists
description: Quite a week for Dennis Kucinich, the liberal Democratic congressman who had been threatening to do to health care what Ralph Nader did to Al Gore in 2000.

title: Familiar Series
description: Notepad: When this puzzle is done, the answers will include a familiar series of 38 Across (minus the middle square). Connect the squares of this series in order with a line, starting with the circled square. The resulting image will be a pair of 38 Across (WITH the middle square). In addition, the clues all share a feature that provides an additional hint to the puzzles theme.

title: For Early Rounds at Masters, Woods + Two = Delicate Task
description: When Tiger Woods returns to tournament golf at next months Masters, which two golfers will be his opening day playing partners  some would say three-ring circus sideshows  during what is expected to be the most scrutinized round of golf ever?

title: Lawmakers Say Needs of Rural Schools Are Overlooked
description: An Oklahoma senator complained that federal rules on teacher credentials had driven thousands of experienced educators out of rural schools. A North Carolina lawmaker complained that formulas for distributing federal education money favored big-city districts at the expense of poor students in small towns.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Recycling a Hard Drive
description: In this weeks Tech Talk podcast from The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein is in a spring cleaning mood. She talks about how to recycle an old computer hard drive into an external backup device. All it takes is a screwdriver and the right enclosure.

title: Clinton to Meet With Russian Leaders on Arms Control Talks
description: SHANNON, Ireland  With the United States and Russia still haggling over the fine print of a long-delayed arms control pact, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton left Washington on Wednesday for high-level meetings in Moscow, as the Obama administration tried to push the talks across the finish line.

title: Deficit Hawk Returns, Much to His Partys Dismay
description: WASHINGTON  Former Senator Alan K. Simpson, the co-chairman of President Obamas bipartisan commission for reducing the mounting federal debt, figures that with the country in danger of going to the bow-wows, he has bigger things to worry about than whether Rush Babe and other conservative critics are babbling into the vapors that he is not Republican enough for the job.

title: China Drawing High-Tech Research From U.S.
description: XIAN, China  For years, many of Chinas best and brightest left for the United States, where high-tech industry was more cutting-edge. But Mark R. Pinto is moving in the opposite direction.

title: Montanas Star Guard Has Taken the Ball, and Life, in His Hands
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  When Anthony Johnson carried the ball into the Weber State frontcourt, with the clock winding down and Montanas season in his hands, it was not the first time he had to think quickly and ride his instincts.

title: Comparing the House and Senate Financial Reform Bills
description: President Obama and Congress have vowed to enact the farthest-reaching overhaul of regulations since the Depression.

title: Linen, Kindly and Cruel
description: LAST week the cold finally broke, which meant the arrival of the first flash of calf on the streets in months. Breathability mattered again, and so the youngish shoppers fancy turned lightly, and with much hesitation, to thoughts of linen.

title: U.S. Mulls Own Plan for Mideast Talks
description: WASHINGTON  The angry exchanges between the United States and the Israeli government have rekindled a White House debate over whether  and when  President Obama should propose an American plan to form the basis of negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians, senior administration officials said Wednesday.

title: "Benihana" by Hyatt and Funny or Die
description: In a series of Web videos from the comedy site Funny or Die, Hyatt will emphasize what can go wrong when people choose the wrong hotel or meeting planner.

title: "Ultra Lounge" by Hyatt/Funny or Die
description: In a series of Web videos from the comedy site Funny or Die, Hyatt will emphasize what can go wrong when people choose the wrong hotel or meeting planner.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Tuesday about state cuts in funding for Medicaid referred imprecisely in some editions to the response of patients whose doctors have dropped out of the program and no longer treat them. While some patients have chosen to forgo health care, they have not themselves dropped out of the Medicaid program.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 10 about new security measures at Amsterdams Schiphol airport imposed after Alberto Stegeman, an investigative journalist, reported that he had smuggled a refilled liquor bottle through its screening system, misspelled the name of an aviation school in Daytona Beach, Fla., where Robert Raffel, a security expert who complimented Mr. Stegeman for having imaginatively uncovered a weakness in the system, is a professor. It is Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, not Emory-Riddle.

title: The Funny Side of What Can Go Wrong at the Big Meeting
description: WITH the country in a grim mood about corporate America, Hyatt is adding some humor to its marketing in an effort to get companies to hold meetings again.

title: Rio de Janeiro Is in Fight Over Brazils Oil Riches
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The battle over Brazils newfound oil riches is heating up.

title: Cant-Miss Prospect May Make It After All
description: EL PASO  When the basketball world first met Derrick Caracter, in July 2001, he was 13 years old, 6 feet 8 inches and carried around a stuffed orangutan named Ollie.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the deep spending cuts planned by Gov. Christopher J. Christie of New Jersey referred incorrectly to his call for new $310 deductibles and a doubling of some drug co-payments. Those measures would apply to participants in a state prescription-drug plan for the elderly and disabled, not to Medicaid patients.

title: Bloggingheads: Grading Obama's Strategy
description: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Noam Scheiber of The New Republic evaluate President Obamas strategy on health care reform.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Thursday about a raid by Manhattan prosecutors on the offices of Lehr Construction as part of an investigation into the interior construction industry referred erroneously to Lehrs criminal record. Although the company was investigated previously for its role in a bid-rigging scheme, and its owners pleaded guilty to bribery in 1998 in connection with that case, a plea agreement allowed the company to avoid charges; it did not plead guilty.

title: Alex Chilton, Rock Musician, Dies
description: 10:48 a.m., March 18 | Updated Alex Chilton, the mercurial if influential rock musician, whose work spanned an eclectic gamut from the soul songs of the Box Tops to the multiple incarnations of his pop band Big Star, died on Wednesday. He was 59 and lived in New Orleans.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Wednesday, about a new advertising strategy for Tupperware, misstated the date, in some copies, for a publicity event in Midtown Manhattan featuring the football player Reggie Bush and the actor Peter Facinelli. It is today; it was not held on Wednesday.

title: At Villanova, Wrights Style Is Part Flash, All Candor
description: VILLANOVA, Pa.  In July 2007, Villanova guard Scottie Reynolds, then coming off a rookie-of-the-year season in the Big East, played for Wildcats Coach Jay Wright with the United States team in the Pan-American Games in Rio de Janeiro. During one practice, Reynolds, a meek shooter, failed to perform a defensive drill correctly three times. After the third try, Wrights silver tongue turned into a leather whip in front of the team.

title:
Planned Switch
to G.O.P. Stirs New York Governor Race
description: ALBANY  A governors race that seemed all but settled is about to be upended again, by a popular Democrat from Long Island who is set to announce that he is switching parties. The move is certain to excite Republican leaders pessimistic about their partys hopes this fall.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Tuesday, about Jets Coach Rex Ryans recent bariatric surgery to help him lose weight, misidentified the organization that fined him $50,000 for a gesture he made in January in response to heckling by Miami Dolphins fans. He was fined by the Jets, not by the National Football League.

title: Studios and Cable Unite in Support of Video on Demand
description: LOS ANGELES  Movie studios, battling a steep decline in DVD sales, have decided the moment has finally come to get out the megaphone for video-on-demand services.

title: Muslim Scholar, Formerly Barred, Is to Speak in New York
description: A prominent Muslim scholar barred from the United States for six years under the Patriot Act will speak on a panel at the Cooper Union next month, his first public appearance in this country since the restriction was lifted.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Tuesday about the Grand Finals Concert of the Metropolitan Operas National Council Auditions misidentified, at one point, the soprano who sang selections from Mozart and Wagner. As the review noted elsewhere, she is Rachel Willis-Sorensen  not Leah Crocetto, another soprano in the competition.

title: The Flooding Returns, and With It, the Questions
description: BOUND BROOK, N.J.

title: Arthur H. Christy, Special Prosecutor, Is Dead at 86
description: Arthur H. Christy, who as the first special prosecutor under a new ethics law in 1979-80 pursued allegations that Hamilton Jordan, the chief of staff in the Carter White House, had used cocaine at Studio 54, the Manhattan disco, died on March 12 in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 17, 2010

title: Feel Ragged? Renew at This Cafe
description: SWEAT SHOP, a tiny new cafe near a trendy stretch of Paris, had barely opened its doors last week when it faced its first fashion emergency. A young woman brought in a teddy bear that had been worn to pieces.

title: Corrections
description: The cover article in todays Museums special section about the new generation of museum curators misstates the surname of an artist whose satirical prints were included in A Womans Wit: Jane Austens Life and Legacy, an exhibition that recently closed at the Morgan Library & Museum. He is James Gillray, not Kilroy. Also, a short profile on Page 28 about one of the curators, Samantha Rippner, misidentifies the educational degree she obtained in 2003. It was a masters degree  not a doctorate.

title: The Cheat: The Upper (and Lower) Crust
description: At first glance, it is the easiest recipe in the world, a marvel of the Sunday-morning ridiculous: grate potatoes into a pan with butter. Turn them golden brown over medium heat. Serve with eggs, toast, sausage.

title: And on the Sabbath, the iPhones Shall Rest
description: THE Fourth Commandment doesnt specifically mention TweetDeck or Facebook. Observing the Sabbath 3,000 years ago was more about rest and going easy on ones family  servants and oxen included.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 12 about the Martin and Osa Johnson Safari Museum in Chanute, Kan., refers to its licensing agreement with American Eagle Outfitters for the companys Martin + Osa clothing stores. After the section went to press, American Eagle announced that it was closing the stores.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Details Given on Cuts by Christie to Schools
description: Fifty-nine of New Jerseys wealthiest school districts would receive no direct state aid for their operations next year  in effect, a 100 percent cut  under the governors proposed budget, according to state figures released on Wednesday.

title: What Were Reading: Girls Talk, Dodd Attacks and Geeks Drink
description: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times jumped from drinking and eating to watching the nighttime sky on Wednesday. In between, there was Twitter and Foursquare and Bing. Another typical day.

title: N.F.L. Ready to Consider Overtime Rule
description: The N.F.L. competition committee proposal to alter overtime rules for the postseason is likely to be the headline event of the three-day league meeting that begins Monday in Orlando, Fla.

title: Access, Access, Access
description: First, a question: When in American history did life expectancy improve the most?

title: The Revolution Will Be Wearable
description: PARIS

title: Economical and Effective, Chamberlain Stakes Claim
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain could probably have pitched his way out of the rotation with a poor outing Wednesday against the Philadelphia Phillies. Instead, Chamberlain breezed through four innings, tightening the most important position battle in the Yankees spring training.

title: Sex Scandals to Learn By
description: Lets consider the story of Representative Eric Massa, a freshman Democrat from upstate New York who made headlines recently when he resigned from office amid talk about sexual harassment of male staffers.

title: Larger Cash Shortfall Is Projected in Albany as Fiscal Year Nears End
description: ALBANY  New York will end the fiscal year on March 31 with at least $2 billion less in cash on hand than originally projected, the states comptroller said Wednesday, burdening lawmakers with another headache and making the prospect of achieving a budget agreement before the next fiscal year begins even more dim.

title: The Beat Goes Online, Minus the Glitz
description: IN the magazine world, there has traditionally been no more glamorous place to work than Cond Nast. Brandon Holley can attest to that.

title: Another Aide to Paterson Steps Down
description: ALBANY  The exodus of top aides from the Paterson administration continued on Wednesday when Marissa Shorenstein, the governors press secretary and acting chief spokeswoman, resigned and, like other departing senior advisers, implicitly raised questions about the administrations conduct.

title: Letters
description: Who Needs Fur?

title: Despite Criticism, Jets Owner Says He Still Trusts Goodell
description: Woody Johnson, the Jets owner, tried to move on from the controversy he stoked this week by saying Wednesday that he never meant to question Commissioner Roger Goodells integrity when he criticized the secret coin flip that determined that the Giants would host the first game in the teams new stadium.

title: Taxi Agency Missed Scope of Cheating on Fares
description: Nearly two years before the Taxi and Limousine Commission uncovered a widespread scheme to overcharge passengers, city officials investigated two similar cases in which cabbies were found guilty of the same fraud.

title: He Asked. They Told.
description: Los Angeles

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Joan Rivers incorrectly identified a government health insurance program in a reference to Ms. Riverss reluctance to retire even though she is 76. Her age makes her eligible for Medicare, not Medicaid.

title: Foundation Promotes Art as Well as Sole Trustee
description: Like the abstract painter who created it, the Judith Rothschild Foundation has never had a very high profile in the art world. Ms. Rothschild, who died in 1993, established the foundation in her will and assigned a friend the mission, as trustee, of using her collection of artworks by masters like Matisse and Mondrian to promote underappreciated artists  a category in which she included herself.

title: Law Dictates Who Decides on Care for the Incapable
description: It is one of those medical quandaries often faced by families dealing with older and dying parents: Who makes decisions for patients who cannot make their own and have not left written instructions?

title: A Politically Feasible Jet
description: There has been yet another setback in the Air Forces long, agonizing process to replace its fleet of Eisenhower-era aerial refueling planes. Northrop Grumman and its European partner, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, dropped out of the competition this month, charging that the new contract specifications are tilted against their much larger Airbus A330 in favor of Boeings 767.

title: Using Generic Drugs to Save Lives Worldwide
description: To the Editor:

title: Honest Food Labels
description: Dr. Margaret Hamburg, the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, has said one of her priorities is to improve the information on food package labels. Her new crackdown on dishonest nutritional claims by food manufacturers is a welcome sign that she means business.

title: Out of the Darkness
description: When the sun finally rises, this will be a gray day, a great slab of flint laid across the plains. But the sun is still an hour off, and the snow is salting down just east of Riverton, Wyo. My eyes are straining for sight in the void out there, looking to see what emerges first from the darkness. The answer is the blackest objects  the old tires that ranchers sometimes place beside their cattle guards and the cattle themselves, black Angus stirring in a creek bottom. The cattle look as though they were bred black just so humans could find them easily in the gloom.

title: Who Is at Fault, the Driver or the Carmaker?
description: To the Editor:

title: Running for Obamas Old Seat, and Set on Derailing His Plans
description: Representative Mark Steven Kirk, the Illinois Republican who is hoping to win Barack Obamas former seat in the United States Senate, has told supporters he intends to lead the effort to repeal President Obamas health care legislation if it passes.

title: Everglades Land Purchase
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Bad News Is No News
description: Lagos, Nigeria

title: Mr. Obama and No Child Left Behind
description: President Obamas blueprint for reworking the No Child Left Behind Education Act of 2002 has good ideas, but it doesnt have anything close to the rigor that the word blueprint would suggest. Whether the presidents plan will strengthen or weaken the program will depend on how the administration fleshes out the missing details  and how Congress rewrites the law.

title: The Health Debate: Crunch Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense Cites Entrapment in Terror Case
description: The man accused of masterminding a plot to blow up two synagogues in the Riverdale section of the Bronx was offered $250,000 by a paid government informant for his effort, according to papers filed in court on Wednesday by defense lawyers.

title: Ambulances Delay May Be Issue in L.I. Hate-Crime Trial
description: The 911 call came in at 11:55 p.m. on Nov. 8, 2008. Marcelo Lucero, an Ecuadorean immigrant, had been stabbed in the chest near a train station in the Long Island village of Patchogue. The nearest hospital, Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center, was three miles away. Mr. Lucero appeared to be alive when the Patchogue Ambulance Company arrived at the scene, his eyes opening upon being moved and his breathing fast and labored, according to ambulance company documents.

title: Amazon Threatens Publishers as Apple Looms
description: Amazon.com has threatened to stop directly selling the books of some publishers online unless they agree to a detailed list of concessions regarding the sale of electronic books, according to two industry executives with direct knowledge the discussions.

title: In Biathlon, War Veteran Revels in Latest Challenge
description: As a boy growing up in California and then Texas, Andy Soule was not much of an athlete.

title: Court Says Parents Can Block Sexting Cases
description: In the first federal appeals court opinion dealing with sexting  the transmission of sexually explicit photographs by cellphone  a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit ruled Wednesday that parents could block the prosecution of their children on child pornography charges for appearing in photographs found on some classmates cellphones.

title: Illinois: No Delay for Blagojevich Trial
description: A federal judge refused on Wednesday to delay the June 3 corruption trial of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois. Judge James B. Zagel of Federal District Court denied a request by defense lawyers to postpone the trial until Nov. 3 so they could have more time to review the evidence. He also dismissed their concerns that the trial could be affected by a case before the United States Supreme Court involving the denial of honest services. Mr. Blagojevich has pleaded not guilty to charges that he schemed to sell or trade the Senate seat once held by President Obama and used his power to illegally pressure political campaign donors.

title: The Author Speaks
description: The photographer Jeff Sheng discusses his book, "Don't Ask, Don't Tell."

title: Celtics Put Brakes on the Knicks Modest Momentum
description: BOSTON  After identity shifts and concerns about compatibility and complacency, the prospects of a Knicks revival this season have long been scuttled.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,375 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American Wednesday:

title: Barbaros Brother to Race in Florida Derby
description: Hoping to follow the same path that led his famous brother to the Kentucky Derby, Lentenor was among 11 horses entered Wednesday for the Grade I Florida Derby on Saturday.

title: Manager Tested Positive for Cocaine Last Season
description: The drug test given to Texas Rangers Manager Ron Washington last season that revealed the presence of cocaine was part of a testing program that managers, coaches and clubhouse personnel have been subjected to since shortly after the Mitchell report was released in December 2007.

title: Henriettas Hash Browns
description: 4 medium Yukon Gold potatoes

title: Scrambled Eggs With Trout Roe
description: 6 tablespoons unsalted butter

title: Annotate and Share Notes Using an E-Book Reader
description: Samsung recently introduced its long-awaited e-book reader for the American market, and while it has useful features, a big one is missing.

title: A Broader View of Health Care
description: My Thursday column argues that the crucial element of health care reform is its effort to increase access to the uninsured. Of course, I think its also crucial to hold down costs  that helps assure access in the long run  and I think that the Obama plan will help curb costs in the long run. I would have loved to see tort reform part of the package, but even the legislations promotion of research into which medical interventions work will over time presumably lead to some cost savings.

title: HTC Disagrees Strongly With Apples Patent Claims
description: HTC, the Taiwanese electronics manufacturer, is stepping forward and publicly addressing allegations made by Apple that it infringed on 20 patents related to the iPhone.

title: James Nachtwey Fights TB, With Pictures
description: James Nachtwey is known for his compelling images of human suffering. He has captured genocide, disease and starvation. Absorbing so much devastation through the lens would numb many photographers, but Mr. Nachtwey is undaunted.

title: Study Finds College Graduation Gap Between Hispanic and White Students
description: A new study by the American Enterprise Institute, a nonprofit research organization, finds that the percentage of Hispanic students who graduate from college in six years or less continues to trail that of white students. The researchers found that 51 percent of Hispanic students who start college go on to obtain a bachelors degree within six years, compared with 59 percent of white students.

title: Barriers Found to College Degrees for Hispanics
description: The percentage of Hispanic students who graduate from college in six years or less continues to lag behind that of white students, according to a new study of graduation figures at more than 600 colleges.

title: Last-Minute Soprano Saves the Opera
description: A week before the opening of a rare production of "Hamlet" at the Metropolitan Opera, the soprano Natalie Dessay withdrew because of illness, and the German soprano Marlis Petersen stepped in to play the role of Ophlie.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Devils Sweep Season Series From Pens
description: Three games on Wednesday, highlighted by the Devils utter mastery this season over the Penguins. The fans in Newark ended the game chanting, You cant beat us! On the grimmer side, the Blackhawks lost a defenseman to injury after a questionable hit for the second straight game. Looks like Colin Campbell will have to throw the book at Anaheims James Wisniewski, as he did against Washingtons Alex Ovechkin for hurting Brian Campbell. Home teams listed first:

title: A Lost Bet, and a Familiar Name
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Isaiah Thomas appears to be aptly named. Other than being left-handed, Thomas, the Washington Huskies point guard, has many of the same qualities of his Hall of Fame namesake  diminutive, determined and not the least bit afraid to get in an opponents face.

title: H. M. Koutoukas, Author of Surrealist Plays, Dies at 72
description: H. M. Koutoukas, a prolific playwright who helped create Off Off Broadway theater in the 1960s with a wildly surreal style of drama, died on March 6 at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Tebow Throws for Scouts
description: The former Florida quarterback Tim Tebow completed his first public workout with his new throwing motion Wednesday in Gainesville, Fla., hoping to impress N.F.L. general managers, coaches and scouts. Tebow threw dozens of passes to three former teammates during a 30-minute workout.

title: Rangers-Islanders in 3D
description: MSG Network will show next Wednesdays Islanders-Rangers game in 3D, the first time a hockey game has been carried in the technology, the network said. It will be available to Cablevision subscribers and offered to other providers.

title: Miguel Delibes, Prolific Spanish Writer, Dies at 89
description: MADRID  Miguel Delibes, a prolific and much-honored Spanish novelist who explored human nature through the lives of common folk living in the rich Castilian countryside, died on Friday in his home in Valladolid, Spain. He was 89.

title: SXSW: Four-Word Reviews
description: Freelance Whales: Could be Lemmys breakfast.

title: Wayne Collett, Track Medalist Barred Because of a Protest, Dies at 60
description: Wayne Collett, a runner who won a silver medal for the United States in the 1972 Munich Olympics and who was then judged to have acted so disrespectfully during the medal ceremony that the International Olympic Committee barred him as a competitor for life, died Wednesday. He was 60 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Word of the Day | wizardry
description: wizardry \wi-z(r)-dre\ noun

title: The Cornell Team Enjoys the Ride
description: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team, which is seeded 12th in the East Region and will face No. 5 Temple on Friday in Jacksonville, Fla. Jon has been blogging for The Quad throughout this season. You can also follow him on Twitter.

title: Looking Ahead: Day 1
description: EAST

title: Chinas Role in Clean Energy
description: American companies are expanding their clean energy manufacturing facilities in places like China, where labor is cheap and incentives are strong.

title: City Opera
description: Tonight, New York City Opera opens its spring season with Chabrier's seldom-staged "L'Etoile," "a comic work in the style of Offenbach's opras bouffes," writes Vivien Schweitzer. "Mark Lamos's colorful production is inspired by Toulouse-Lautrec and features cancan choreography by Sen Curran." Put on your best "Moulin Rouge!"-inspired outfit and go watch the production, conducted by Emmanuel Plasson, featuring a cast that includes the tenor Jean-Paul Fouchcourt as King Ouf, "who enjoys executing his subjects, and Jennifer Zetlan as Laoula, the princess who is supposed to marry Ouf but falls in love with a poor peddler." Of course. Tonight's gala performance begins at 7.

title: News Quiz | March 18, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Ivanchuk, Carlsen Lead at Amber
Vodou and Rock n Roll
description: The group Bonga and the Vodou Drums of Haiti is led by the percussionist Gaston (Bonga) Jean-Baptiste. "This Haitian ensemble," writes Amanda Petrusich, "plays mizik rasin, a beguiling mix of traditional Haitian vodou and American rock 'n' roll. Much like the hill-country blues of Mississippi, mizik rasin is built around a hypnotic rhythmic pulse; traditional chants mix with mbira, conch, didgeridoo, cello, reeds, brass, vocals and more." Go to hear the results for free at 8:30 p.m. at the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center.

title: Tell Me a Story
description: If you didn't get enough of the emerald shade on St. Patrick's Day, head to Housing Works Bookstore Caf for the Moth StorySlam! where the theme will be all things green tonight. For the uninitiated, The Moth is a not-for-profit storytelling organization that was founded in New York in 1997 by a poet and novelist who happens to be named George Dawes Green. At the slams, stories are scored by three teams of audience-member judges, and a winner is announced. We're hoping for at least one story devoted to Kermie.

title: Lehman Allowed to Delay Bankruptcy Disclosure
description: A United States bankruptcy judge said on Wednesday that Lehman Brothers could delay until mid-April filing a detailed disclosure statement for its proposed plan to end its bankruptcy, Reuters reported.

title: The Book of Grace
description: Photos from the new play by Suzan-Lori Parks.

title: One of These Has to Be Right
description: There are only 9.2 quintillion possible outcomes to the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. So it makes sense that someone had to come up with a formula to figure out which is the most likely. Yahoo has built a new tool to find this years winner. Hop on over to the Bits blog to see how Predictalot works and comment on why its all wrong and your school is going to win it all.

title: What Can Strangers Learn About You Online?
description: An article from the Technology section warns that the oceans of personal minutiae we all publish on Facebook, Twitter and Flickr can be used to reassemble your identity, even down to your social security number. How much could your online identity tell others about you? How well have you protected yourself?

title: Fed Fights to Keep Oversight of Banks That Arent Big
description: Officials at the Federal Reserve are trying to alter a Senate proposal that would focus the Feds regulatory attention on the nations biggest banks and strip away its powers over small and medium-size banks, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

title: Bernanke Sees U.S. Backing Fannie, Freddie Debt
description: Current Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac mortgage-backed securities are likely to retain United States government backing should Congress create a new system for financing homes, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Ben S. Bernanke said on Wednesday, Reuters reported.

title: Hedge Fund Rules Arent Dead, Minister Says
description: Hedge funds and private equity may have won a short reprieve after European Union finance ministers agreed to delay a decision on new rules for the industry, but the proposals arent dead, Jean-Paul Gauzes, a French member of the European Parliament, told Bloomberg News.

title: Schapiro Says Lehman Report Will Be Helpful
description: A Lehman Brothers bankruptcy examiners report will help securities regulators in their investigation of large financial firms involved in the Wall Street meltdown, a top regulator said on Wednesday, Reuters reported.

title: Basel III Rules Will Ease, SocGen Tells Investors
description: Socit Gnrale, Frances second-largest bank by market value, is telling investors that regulators are likely to soften new rules for lenders as governments seek to avoid stifling the economic recovery, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Chatting About Chatroulette
description: WHO is the teenager in the picture above?

title: Geely Said to Eye Londons Black Cab Maker
description: Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, the Chinese carmaker seeking to buy Volvo, may take control of Manganese Bronze Holdings, maker of the iconic London black cab, the British company said.

title: Videoplaza Reaps $5 Million
description: Videoplaza, which makes software to help publishers optimize the distribution of their video ads, has rounded up $5 million, VentureBeat reported.

title: For N.J. Fund, a Little More Hedge in Its Bets?
description: New Jerseys $67 billion pension fund is considering a move to increase its hedge fund investments, as it tries to improve its returns through a decreased reliance on the stock market, Bloomberg News reported, citing a memo prepared for a meeting of the State Investment Council later this week.

title: Theravance to Sell 7.5 Million Shares in Offering
description: Theravance, a drug developer, said Wednesday it would sell 7.5 million shares of stock to raise money for general corporate purposes, The Associated Press reported.

title: Magick Man | Kenneth Anger
description: For a man who has spent two-thirds of a century actively pushing himself into the unearthly realm, the filmmaker Kenneth Anger has a pretty firm grasp of the minutiae of the earthly one. Hes 82, he reckons, but when we stop to speak during a break in the schedule of his whirlwind European tour  hes in London for a show based around his filmsInauguration of the Pleasure Dome and Invocation of My Demon Brother at Sprth Magers in London, a collaboration with Valentino for its autumn-winter show in Paris, and a celebrated guest appearance at the AV festival in Newcastle  he has a recall for the details, facts and figures that make up his constant stream of historical anecdotes and gossip that would put Rain Man to shame.

title: Rosneft Stock Falls on Fear of Seizures
description: Shares in Russias state oil company, Rosneft, slumped Wednesday after the company was said to have warned its trading partners that a British court could seize assets under a lawsuit filed by former executives of Yukos Oil, The New York Timess Andrew E. Kramer reported.

title: Merkel Urges Stricter Rules for Euro Zone
