description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, adopting a harsher tone toward Greece than the one expressed by some other European leaders, said Wednesday that Europe needed better rules to police its members, and she tacitly endorsed a proposal to eject wayward countries from the group of countries that use the euro, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

title: Programmers Indicted in Madoff Case
description: Two former computer programmers at Bernard L. Madoffs firm were indicted Wednesday by a federal grand jury in Manhattan, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Finras Enforcer Is Stepping Down
description: Susan Merrill, the head of enforcement at the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, which polices the brokerage industry, is stepping down after less than three years in the job, Reuters reported.

title: N. Korea Is Said to Execute Finance Chief
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has arrested and possibly executed its top financial official as it struggles to contain chaos set off by its botched attempt to halt inflation through a radical currency revaluation, according to news reports Thursday in South Korea.

title: Lagerfeld to Help Tods With Its Hogan Brand
description: Karl Lagerfeld has a new world at his feet: The Italian company Hogan, part of the Tods footwear empire, said Wednesday that it had signed the designer for a special collection.

title: AOL Goes Local With $10 Million V.C. Fund
description: AOL said Wednesday that it was putting together a $10 million venture capital that would invest in start-up businesses targeting local space, as the newly liberated company continues its bet on local content, PaidContent reported.

title: Investors Buy Dana College in Nebraska
description: Dana College will soon join the handful of private colleges that have been sold in recent years and converted from nonprofit organizations to for-profit corporations, The Associated Press reported.

title: Woe Is Womens Lit
description: Todays idea: Is womens fiction plagued by misery lit, obsessed with bereavement, child abuse and rape? Or chick lit, obsessed with Prada handbags and landing the perfect catch? Or is it torn between the two? British writers have at it.

title: Major California Solar Project Advances
description: From Todd Woddy at Green Inc.:

title: Buyout Shops Said to Considers WestLB Unit
description: The Blackstone Group, the Apollo Group and Colony Capital are said to be considering the purchase of WestLBs real estate finance unit, The Financial Times Deutschland reported.

title: Teva to Acquire Ratiopharm for $5 Billion
description: 8:41 a.m. | Updated Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, the global leader in generic drugs, said Thursday that it had reached a deal to acquire the German generic drug maker Ratiopharm, ending a nine-month battle that had pitted it against at least two other bidders, Natasha Singer reports in The New York Times.

title: Blackstone Said to Lead China Agricultural Deal
description: A consortium led by the Blackstone Group has agreed to invest about $600 million in a Chinese agricultural company ahead of its planned Hong Kong listing, Reuters reported, citing sources with knowledge of the deal.

title: Casas de Mentira
description: Houses that lie  buildings that from the outside appear to have survived Chiles February earthquake, but which are destroyed or unsafe inside.

title: Comerica Exits TARP; Hartford Raises $1.95 Billion
description: Comerica, a regional bank, on Wednesday said it had repaid $2.25 billion of federal bailout money, while Hartford Financial Services Group said it sold $1.95 billion of stock to help repay $3.4 billion of its bailout funds, Reuters reported.

title: Musics Small Stakes at South by Southwest
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Theres not just one South by Southwest, but several. Music people who arrived on Tuesday and Wednesday overlapped with attendees of the film and interactive (read: Internet start-up) conferences, and to some degree the happenings at all of these things are pretty similar: over-branded parties, free-flowing liquor, networking by text message.

title: Germany Eyes Spy Plan Aimed at Currency Speculators
description: Germanys finance minister said that the country may have to employ spies to track currency speculators, as political pressure increases in Europe to gauge the effects of recent speculation on Greek debt and the euro, Bloomberg News  reported.

title: Iran Dispute Becomes Focus of Clintons Russia Trip
description: MOSCOW  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and Russias foreign minister clashed publicly Thursday over an announcement that Russia would complete a nuclear power plant in Iran this summer.

title: Merkel Calls on Brown to Change Hedge Stance
description: Angela Merkel, chancellor of Germany, said in a speech before the German Bundestag on Wednesday that the country was on the path to decide on important new banking rules, and criticized Britains position on proposed hedge fund regulation.

title: Greece Says Cuts Threatened if EU Doesnt Help
description: Greeces prime minister warned his European Union partners on Thursday that he would not be able to make planned deficit cuts unless the country can borrow money more cheaply  and said he would prefer not to have to turn to the International Monetary Fund for help, Reuters reported.

title: Will the U.S. Become the Next Ireland?
description: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, is the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

title: U.S. Citizen Is Released From Prison in Myanmar
description: BANGKOK  A pro-democracy activist from Myanmar who is a naturalized American citizen was released from prison a month after a court sentenced him to five years of hard labor, the United States Embassy in Yangon said Thursday.

title: Q&A: When GMail Overflows
description: Q.

title: In Rome, Revisiting the Spoils of War
description: Roman generals were among the worlds first art collectors. As they captured one Greek city after another, they looted its artistic treasures. Triumphantly, they returned to Rome and paraded their loot  shiploads of marble and bronze statues  through the Forum, where spectators could marvel at its elegance and beauty. These sculptured war trophies served both as visual metaphors for a vanquished enemy, as well as precious symbols of a culture the Romans aspired to surpass.

title: N.F.L. Overtime Proposal: Keep It Simple?
description: A few thoughts on the N.F.L.s overtime proposal, then a look at the issues the leagues owners will consider next week in Orlando:

title: Porsche Tops in Dependability Study
description: Jaguar executives are most likely sitting around sighing and saying, It was nice while it lasted.

title: Investors Interested in GMACs ResCap
description: Some big name investors are reportedly kicking the tires of GMACs troubled residential mortgage unit, Residential Capital.

title: U.K. Regulators Plan Puts It On the Attack
description: The Financial Services Authority, Britains securities regulator, said that it would hire more than 400 staff to step up supervision of the largest financial institutions while requiring an almost 10 percent increase in its annual budget, in a plan for this year and next released Wednesday.

title: With the Lure of Generous Aid, Oklahoma State Beckons
description: The challenges of the impending college application process made themselves far too evident when our ACT proctor instructed, Now fill in the bubbles to select four schools to which you would like your scores sent. It was March of my junior year, and I had scarcely seen four colleges in my life, let alone reviewed their application guidelines and exact mileage away from my front door.

title: Sampler: Boxers Opponents Gain Ground and Police Have Few Protocols for Out-of-Control Cars
description: Boxers Opponents Gain Ground, Poll Says | A new Field Poll shows that the three candidates hoping to unseat Senator Barbara Boxer have gained ground. Senator Boxer, who is in her third term, trails Tom Campbell, a former congressman, 44 to 43 percent, and leads Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, 45 to 44 percent. The survey of 748 likely voters was taken this month and has a margin of error of plus-or-minus 3.7 percentage points. Senator Boxer leads Assemblyman Chuck DeVore, a Republican from Irvine, 45 to 41 percent. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: RandomDorm: Chatroulette for the College Set
description: Taking a dizzying spin through the video chat service Chatroulette can be highly entertaining  you might stumble onto a celebrity or an impromptu performance by a pianist.

title: Sleep-Deprived and Fighting a Terrible Case of Senioritis
description: The college admission process is a messed-up, tangled web of lies and secrecy that can drive you insane. If, by writing for this blog, I can help one sleep-deprived anxious senior  someone stressing about a decision that can (and will) change his or her life  to know that he or she is not alone, then my efforts will be worthwhile. But I guess I should start by telling you a little bit about myself.

title: The Problem Is Stagnant Pay, Not Stagnant Water
description: On a good day, the unpleasant byproducts of human existence simply flow tepidly beneath their noses.

title: Dow Keeps Streak Alive on a Mixed Day
description: Signs of strength in manufacturing helped lead the Dow Jones industrial average to an eighth day of gains on Thursday, despite worries about tighter monetary policy in the United States and lingering debt woes in Europe.

title: Teva to Acquire Top German Generics Maker for $5 Billion
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries is already the worlds leading generic-drug maker, including the United States market.

title: Unexpectedly, Barnes & Noble Names a New Chief Executive
description: In a surprise move, Barnes & Noble named William Lynch, president of the companys Web division, as chief executive, replacing Steve Riggio, who will remain as vice chairman.

title: Gaza Rocket Attack Into Israel Kills a Thai Worker
description: GAZA  A foreign worker in Israel was killed Thursday by a rocket fired from the Hamas-controlled Palestinian territory of Gaza, according to the Israeli military, soon after the arrival here of the European Unions top foreign policy official.

title: Police Said to Arrest Ex-Chairman of Irish Bank
description: The former chairman of Anglo Irish Bank, Sean FitzPatrick, was arrested Thursday in connection with an investigation into financial fraud, according to a person close to the investigation.

title: Young Hostage Freed After Wide Hunt
description: PARIS  From the video, it might have seemed a moment as unexceptional as it was fond  a boy playing soccer with his father on a sunlit lawn, sending messages of affection back home to his mother.

title: The Early Word: Health Care Score
description: Washington has spent many a morning during the year-long health care debate, awaiting the Congressional Budget Office score on one iteration of the bill or another.

title: Huge Dai-ichi I.P.O. Could Lift Japanese Market
description: If all goes well, on April 1, the Japanese insurance group Dai-Ichi Mutual Life will issue the worlds largest initial public stock offering since Visas listing two years ago, raising around $12 billion, The New York Timess Bettina Wassener reports.

title: Irish Police Said to Arrest Former Head of Bank
description: The former chairman of Anglo Irish Bank, Sean FitzPatrick, was arrested Thursday in connection with an investigation into financial fraud, The New York Timess David Jolly reported, citing a person close to the investigation.

title: Speed Read for Thursday, March 18
description: Highlights from Thursdays media coverage in The New York Times:

title: Aluminum Maker Eyes Solar Industry
description: Alcoa, the aluminum giant, is testing a new type of solar technology that the company said it believed will lower the cost of renewable energy.

title: Prices of Consumer Goods Hold Steady, Indicating That Inflation Is at Bay
description: The price of consumer goods held steady in February, the government reported Thursday, the latest sign that near-zero interest rates and billions of dollars in stimulus money had yet to set off inflation.

title: Springtime for Hip-Hop
description: Video Classic | Mel Brooks holds a Nazi party:

title: Air France Attendants May Strike
description: According to Bloomberg, Air France flight attendants plan to go on strike from March 28 through March 31 if they cannot reach agreement on working conditions that will accompany proposed changes in services on medium-haul flights in France and Europe, their union said Wednesday.

title: Whack-a-Banker, the Arcade Game
description: For those unhappy with government efforts to discipline the big banks, theres always Whack-a-Banker:

title: A Turkish Builder on Istanbuls Deadly Buildings
description: Ali Agaoglu, a billionaire developer in Turkey, caused a stir last year when he admitted that his familys company and most other developers routinely used inappropriate materials duringa building boom in Istanbul in recent decades, creating enormous vulnerability because of the long history of powerful earthquakes in the sprawling city.

title: Stagflation Versus Hyperinflation
description: Im a bit late to this, but Mike Kinsley has an odd piece in the Atlantic in which he confesses himself terrified about future inflation, even though theres no hint of that problem in the real world. Hes not alone: there are a lot of voices predicting imminent hyperinflation in 2009, make that 2010 (and yes, I am keeping a record).

title: Boehner to Bankers: Stand Up to Punk Staffers
description: Opponents of Senator Christopher J. Dodds financial regulation overhaul bill are talking tough, telling bankers how displeased they are without mincing words.

title: Thai Protests to Continue
description: BANGKOK  Antigovernment demonstrators said Thursday that they would continue their protests at least through the weekend as efforts to mediate the standoff faltered. The mass demonstration, which this week drew tens of thousands of farmers and other protesters, has prevented Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva from entering his office. Protesters, who are known as the Red Shirts, are demanding that the government step down and that elections be called. They said they would parade through Bangkok on Saturday in large convoys of pickup trucks.

title: Piano Man
description: Attention, Chopin fans: On March 1, the 200th anniversary of the Polish composers birth, a new permanent exhibition opened at the Chopin Muzeum in Warsaw. Designed by the Milan firm Migliore + Servetto Associated Architects, the installation displays some 500 items, from musical manuscripts to the composers cuff links.

title: The Chamber Polls for Opposition on Health Care
description: 12:14 p.m. | Correction Appended

title: Some Honda Air-Conditioners Dying a Slow Death
description: As she drives her 2002 Honda CR-V on hot days in Southern California, Joan Giglione is steamed. The problem is her cars air-conditioning  or rather, its lack of air-conditioning.

title: Museum Innovations Around the World
description: The special Museums section in todays edition of The New York Times takes a look at innovations from around the world, including art of the Americas in Boston, exploring Africa in Kansas, a new breed of audio tours and much more.

title: An Easy Way From PC to TV
Thursday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Jaws, Claws and Randy Whales: Bringing Discoverys Life to Life
description: When Planet Earth appeared on the Discovery Channel in 2007, it presented a sweeping nature epic that doubled as perhaps the best commercial for high-definition television ever produced.

title: Q.& A. With HBO Sports President on Magic & Bird
description: When Magic Johnson approached HBO Sports around 18 months ago about making a documentary about his relationship with Larry Bird, it took them two seconds to get on board, said Ross Greenburg, president of HBO Sports.

title: Lets Hear it for the Boys
description: Four whove designed for women cross over. Will it work?

title: Hevesi Adviser Rebuts Pension-Fraud Charge
description: The Hevesi-era pension scandal appears to be heating up again.

title: SXSW: Blessings and Black Angels
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  As the musical portion of South by Southwest got under way, we got several bracing reminders that we werent in Kansas, or the interactive segment of the conference. First, the door at Emos where the blog BrooklynVegan had set up shop looked as if it were under siege. At 3 p.m. on Wednesday, just hours into what will be many long days and nights of music, people were baking in the sun on the sidewalk and waiting for a shot at seeing the New Jersey rock band Titus Andronicus, those distortion purveyors who took their name from Shakespeares bloodiest and most vengeful work.

title: Report Says China Sold Bad Vaccines to Hospitals
description: HONG KONG  A newspaper article by one of Chinas best-known investigative reporters has reawakened a controversy over whether provincial authorities improperly stored vaccines in rooms without air-conditioning, rendering them ineffective, and then let them be administered to children.

title: Where Does U.S. Foreign Aid Go?
description: In the midst of a post skewering of the militarization of United States foreign aid, William Easterly and Laura Freschi have produced this striking pie chart:

title: Last Footfall in Nepal
description: THE path is wide, the terrain easy, yet I keep losing my footing, tripping over stones and my own feet because I cant watch the trail. My eyes refuse to leave the white mountain filling the sky before me, the 24,786-foot Himalayan peak Annapurna III. It dominates the horizon as surely as a sunset does, but with millenniums-old glaciers ringing its crest like a necklace of diamonds, it feels more dazzling than even the brightest setting sun.

title: Tribeca Festival Announces Short Films
description: The New Tenants, which won the Academy Award for live action short earlier this month, will be among the 47 movies to be shown in the Tribeca Film Festivals short film lineup, along with works directed by Kirsten Dunst, Domenica Scorsese and others, the festivals organizers said on Thursday. The New Tenants, written by David Rakoff (Fraud, Dont Get Too Comfortable) and directed by Joachim Back, tells the darkly comic story of two men who meet their unusual neighbors as they move into a New York apartment; it will play on the festivals Hard Core program. Other films announced include Bastard, written and directed by Ms. Dunst (Spider-Man), about a couple in a desert motel; Roots in Water, directed by Ms. Scorsese and written by Richard Nelson, about two siblings dealing with the death of their mother; and A .45 at 50th, a documentary directed by Joshua Bell and John Cromwell, in which the actor James Cromwell (The Queen) recounts his experience with the Black Panther Party. This years Tribeca Film Festival runs April 21 to May 2.

title: Report Finds Shift Toward Extended Families
description: The extended family is making something of a comeback, thanks to delayed marriage, immigration and recession-induced job losses and foreclosures that have forced people to double-up under one roof, an analysis of Census Bureau figures has found.

title: Warren Buffett Rocks Out
description: He is the biggest of financial rock stars. Now it looks like Warren E. Buffett just wants to rock out.

title: A Call to Jihad in an American Accent
description: CNN has obtained and broadcast parts of a new audio recording that its sources say was made by Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born Muslim cleric with an online following and links to several terrorist plots.

title: Final Bill Will Reduce Deficit, Hoyer Says
description: House Democrats, gearing up for a possible vote on Sunday to pass health care legislation, pledged that the details they were about to publish would produce significant cost savings in the decades ahead.

title: Call It Top Short-Order Cook
description: For all of you who ever wished youd thought of Applebees first, heres your chance.

title: Knicks Get a Sneak Peek at Giddens
description: BOSTON  The Knicks roster much of the past two seasons has been a revolving door, and each players contract status has been scrutinized more than his status as a player.

title: The Architecture of Secularism
description: Last week, inspired by the highly-regrettable religious architecture of Claude Parent, Rod Dreher wrote about his perverse fascination with ugly churches. This week, as if by way of counterpoint, Catesby Leigh has a lovely piece about Duncan Stroik, the architect (and Notre Dame professor) behind two new Catholic churches, one in Wisconsin and one at Thomas Aquinas College in California, that actually dare to look like churches  rather than, say, the dreadful Jedi fortresses that pass for cathedrals in Los Angeles and Oakland.

title: German Archbishop  Expresses Shame Over Scandal
description: BAD STAFFELSTEIN, Germany  The leader of the Catholic Church in Bavaria expressed deep shame on Thursday for cases of sexual molestation that have shaken the home region of Pope Benedict XVI, and said he was in favor of changing German law so that church officials would have a greater duty to report suspected child abuse to prosecutors.

title: Timeless | Give Her the Slip
description: The Barneys fashion director Julie Gilhart goes for clothes with a conscience.

title: Deutsche Bahn Mulls Cash Offer for Arriva
description: Deutsche Bahn, the company in charge of German railways, said Thursday that it was in talks to acquire the British transportation company Arriva.

title: No Gang War, but a Turf Battle Nonetheless
description: Updated, 2:59 p.m. | For athletes who gather at the Queensboro Oval on the Upper East Side, the plot of clay-covered ground has long brought out a competitive edge. But debate over a  Parks Department plan  to dedicate the oval to tennis courts year-round has turned tennis and softball players against each other, with both sides crying foul.

title: Obama Calls Jobs Bill a First Step
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama signed a jobs bill into law on Thursday, but declared that the measure, which is intended to spur employment by providing businesses incentives to hire new workers, is by no means enough.

title: Final Bill to Cost $940 Billion Over 10 Years
description: The Congressional Budget Office has released a preliminary analysis of the Democrats final health care package (pdf) that puts the overall price tag of new insurance coverage provisions at $940 billion over 10 years, just below the $950 billion goal set by President Obama.

title: Our Computers, Ourselves: Imagining the Digital Lives of Authors and Characters
description: Overview | How do our computers and their contents both reflect us and shape us and how we think and work? What can a writers method and work space illuminate about the authors works? In this lesson, students imagine and simulate the computer desktop, files and Internet habits of a writer or literary character in order to better understand his or her life and/or works.

title: SXSW: Chlo Sevigny Plays Nice
description: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

title: An Exciting First Weekend for N.B.A. Scouts
description: With the majority of the top prospects on the 2010 DraftExpress mock draft in action this weekend, the N.C.A.A. tournament is one of the most active times on the N.B.A. scouting calendar for talent evaluators. Here are the player they will be watching and what they will be looking for:

title: My Journey to the Tourney
description: Zach Hillesland, a contributor to The Quad, is a former Notre Dame forward who is now an academic adviser in the universitys athletic department.

title: Paterson Claims He Was Articles Source
description: Updated, 1:37 p.m. | ALBANY  In a radio town hall appearance this morning in New York City, Gov. David A. Paterson claimed that he was the one who first told the news media that he had talked to a woman involved in a domestic violence complaint against one of his top aides.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: HAPPY  A Memoir.  By Alex Lemon.  Scribner, $25.

title: Building a Community of Commenters
description: In our opening manifesto almost a year ago, we declared rather grandly that we wanted Lens to become the center of a community of readers who are not just interested in photojournalism  in the broadest sense of visually chronicling the world around us  but actively involved in some way or other.

title: Gay Men and Lesbians Barred From Some Clinical Trials
description: Gay men and lesbians are barred from taking part in many clinical trials that deal with sexual functions and occasionally from other studies as well, researchers are reporting.

title: The Lou Gehrig of Opera
description: The news that the Lauritz Melchior Heldentenor Foundation is going into retirement, like an aging singer whose career is over, is a reminder of the amazing life of the foundations namesake, the Lou Gehrig of opera. Melchior had a set of brass lungs  one way of describing that rare breed, the heldentenor or heroic tenor, a man with the stamina and power to soar above an orchestra for many hours in an evening.

title: Health Care Bill Estimates Out
description: David M. Herszenhorn and Robert Pear are reporting out the details of the latest scoring of the health care legislation, as well as monitoring developments among Democrats and Republicans as they move toward a vote in the House possibly late this weekend.

title: When Is the Worst Time to Go to the Hospital?
description: During staff cutbacks, hiring freezes and every July when a new class of interns hits the wards, hospital workers everywhere ask themselves one question:

title: Grass Fed | Homeburgers
description: Im sure it was desperation the first time: friends coming over, nothing planned, nothing in the cupboard. What to serve? Burgers and oven-baked fries, cans of beer. Done. Everybody had a good time. Then, on Christmas morning shortly thereafter, the craving for burgers animal-style hit, and me and my girl griddled some up, which seems like a fine tradition to carry forward.

title: The Worst Time for a Hospital Visit
description: This week in Doctor and Patient, I write about how four factors  hospital occupancy, weekend admissions, nurse staffing and the seasonal flu  can not only increase the risk of dying in a hospital but can also interact in variable ways.

title: Infidelity Month
description: Curious nickname for February 2010, during which sales of British tabloids were boosted by a slew of allegations concerning celebrity adultery.

title: SXSW: Having a Moment with Carolina Chocolate Drops
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  We had no idea what Carolina Chocolate Drops were, but came to see them as a reminder of the beauty of home cooking. To call them a string band does not really do justice to the flying instruments, the role changes and the strong and sometimes dangerous singing of Rhiannon Giddens at the Galaxy Room on Wednesday. Combing elements of scat and hillbilly yodels, the Drops, as we will call them now that we are friends, were playful with the crowd but seemingly dead earnest in leading a singalong of a Hi-ho, diddly-eye-o nature, replete with what looked like clog dancing, although we could not see anybodys shoes through the mass of bodies. It was our first having a moment moment of the festival.

title: Looking Hard at Looking Good
description: Such a subjective thing, beauty.

title: A Tech-Filled Life, Without Power
description: My family has now been without electricity, heat or hot water for five days. I gotta tell you: it's getting old.

title: SXSW: Singular Noun, Full Band
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  South by Southwest hasnt gotten into full gear when you can still walk down E. Sixth Street without a pair of fullbacks. Thats how it was on Wednesday night, when not every club had lines waiting outside. There were major draws aroundthe rapper Nas and NPRs lineup headlined by Spoon (from Austin) along with the Walkmen and Sharon Jonesbut I generally skip bands Ive seen before at SXSW. After some duds, I was rewarded.

title: Bathroom Humor Fans Rejoice: A Captain Underpants Spin-Off
description: To the joy of millions of young readers and the consternation of untold numbers of foes of the poop fiction genre, a spinoff of the Captain Underpants series will be released in August, Scholastic announced on Thursday.

title: The Road to Distraction
description: O.K., America, ready, set ... stop working! Its the first day of the first round of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, the greatest worker productivity drain since the dawn of working (followed closely by the second day of the first round). It is our unique cultural phenomenon that the entire business world finds it acceptable for your day to be completely derailed agonizing over the fate of Butler and getting intimately acquainted with the field goal percentage of Robert Morris. Let the upsets begin!

title: Faces of the Dead
description: Nearly nine years passed before American forces reached their first 1,000 dead in the war in Afghanistan. The second 1,000 came just 27 months later, after a troop surge in 2010.

title: A Shoe Factory Home
description: The architect Josephine Rooney Duval and her husband live in a 100-year-old former shoe factory standing empty in Paris's 14th Arrondissement.

title: Democrats Prepare to Unveil the Final Bill
description: House Democratic leaders are holding a news conference now to trumpet the new cost analysis of their health care legislation.

title: Depression in Teenagers
description: In light of the story yesterday about three apparent suicides at Cornell University, it seemed like a sadly appropriate time to post a question from Elizabeth, a reader who is worried about her teenage son. In an e-mail message she writes:

title: Monitoring Your Parents Falls
description: Anyone of a certain age remembers the old commercials with an elderly woman shouting Ive fallen and I cant get up!

title: Theater Talkback: The Accents the Thing
description: LONDON  Its only when you come to this city and hear British actors playing Americans that you realize how funny we all talk. Im kidding, of course, but after listening to the peculiar nasality of some of the accents in the Old Vic revival of John Guares Six Degrees of Separation, I found myself wondering whether the twang-free voice Id always assumed Id been speaking in sounded so very peculiar to the British. Ive been working on something grander-sounding and mid-Atlantic ever since.Accents can cause unusual problems for actors. First-class training doesnt necessarily instill the ability to master different voices; its a particular aptitude that comes more naturally to some than others. I adored Patti LuPones darkly funny performance as Mrs. Lovett in the recent Broadway revival of Sweeney Todd, but I have never before heard an Englishwoman of any class or period  fictional or otherwise  speaking with quite the same quirky intonations. (Video of Ms. LuPone and the rest of the cast of the Broadway revival of Sweeney Todd is here.)

title: SXSW: The Music and Its Makings
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Minimalism had an impish side with Hauschka, a pianist and composer from Dsseldorf who performed with a string quartet at the hushed Central Presbyterian Church on Wednesday night. Hauschka, the stage name of Volker Bertelmann, builds his repeating structures with a Romantic ear  pensive minor chords, inviting melodic lines, slow-cresting dynamics  and, sometimes, a foundation of rock rhythm. Even with their echoes of Philip Glass, the pieces were ingenious and exquisite.

title: Q&A: Vegetarian Options in Tokyo
description: Q.

title: Concentrating Photovoltaic Project Under Way at California College
description: The nations first big concentrating photovoltaic power plant is under construction in the California desert.

title: Drawn From Life
description: Truth in the matter of memoir has always seemed evanescent and, more often lately, either elusive or absent. Memories of the self are often in service of other agendas, including the settling of scores and the creation of a hero where a mere man once stood.

title: Dostoyevsky and Me
description: To study first-year French is to enter a world of savoir-faire, beauty and romance. Instructive filmstrips show master chefs whisking halos of caramelized sugar; or Versailles woodworkers restoring antique marquetry; or Gallic lovers in deux chevaux, illustrating how to go and to be while tooting off for a weekend in Marseille. But this is not the world of Russian 101. In Russian 101, you get grainy black-and-white photos of concert halls closed for repairs, and you learn bitter dialogues like this one:

title: SXSW: More Four-Word Reviews
description: Nas/Damian (Junior Gong) Marley: Surprise! Bob samples galore.

title: The Whores Secret
description: Some stories need to be told in a whisper. Blooms of Darkness, the Israeli writer Aharon Appelfelds majestic and humane new novel, takes place in an unnamed Ukrainian city during World War II. As the Germans begin liquidating the citys Jewish population, Julia, a pharmacist whose husband has already been sent to a labor camp, smuggles her 11-year-old son, Hugo, out of the ghetto. Their journey through the sewer pipes leads them to a house on the outskirts of town, where Julia entrusts Hugo to the care of an old friend, Mariana, before taking flight herself. Mariana, as Hugo will discover, is a prostitute, while the house  known simply as the Residence  is a brothel catering to the Nazi occupiers. For the next year and a half, Hugos world will contract to the bedroom in which Mariana cossets, neglects and ultimately seduces him, and the closet in which he hides when her clients come knocking.

title: Sins of the Capitalist
description: Of all the characters Sebastian Faulks introduces in A Week in December, his ambitious, entertaining and often scathingly angry new novel, two merit special attention: a young Muslim plotting to attack a London hospital, and a hedge fund manager betting that Englands staunchest bank is about to fail. Guess which one is the villain? If you said the billionaire, give yourself a gold star  assuming you can still afford one. (Have you seen the price of gold lately?) It tells you everything you need to know about the politics of this book, and the reflexive populism of our time, that the capitalist is more reliably loathsome than the jihadist.

title: At Close Range
description: For the last 45 years, John McPhee has come out with a work of narrative nonfiction about every year and a half. The quantity impresses, but not nearly so much as the quality. McPhee has a nearly cultish following among nonfiction writers, who admire his quirky choice of subjects  often unheralded virtuosos of their own particular domain (a headmaster, a barge captain), or such intimidatingly large topics as the formation of the earth (four books on geology; collected together as Annals of the Former World, they won a Pulitzer Prize). We envy his powers of description, the way he transforms technically complex subjects into something readers can hold in their hand and examine at close range. And, perhaps above all else, we marvel at the pains he takes with structure, approaching his subject from oblique angles, slowly building tension, sometimes seeming to wander, but always propelling his narratives forward.

title: Nuts and Dolts
description: Paranoia is a bipartisan temptation. Amid last Augusts town hall frenzy, there was a stir over a poll showing that roughly a third of Republicans believed that Barack Obama had been born outside the United States. Liberals trumpeted the finding as proof of the Republican bases slide into madness. But conservatives had a rebuttal: As recently as 2007, they pointed out, polls showed that a third of Democrats believed George W. Bush knew about 9/11 in advance.

title: Mr. Goldman Goes to Washington
description: When offered the job of Treasury secretary in the spring of 2006, Henry M. Paulson Jr., who was then the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, turned it down. President Bush had half a term in office left, the economy appeared strong, and there seemed little the next secretary could accomplish. But then, Paulson had second thoughts  Do you really want to be 75 and telling people, I could have been Treasury secretary? a friend asked  and finally agreed to take the job on condition he be granted more power and visibility than Bushs previous secretaries.

title: Studio Visit | Ryan McGinley
description: Ryan McGinley knows from adolescence. As the chronicler of (usually naked) misspent youth, the 32-year-old photographer has made a not-insignificant career out of capturing and exalting this most evanescent of states. T dropped by McGinleys Chinatown HQ for a sneak peek of Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere, his new exhibition of black-and-white nudes, which opens tonight at the Team Gallery in SoHo.

title: Promised Land
description: My parents bought their first house in 1960, six years after emigrating from Ireland. Theyd grown up with a fierce sense of place  of land, family, history  and they were determined to recreate that sense for their children. That little house in the middle of a nondescript block on Detroits East Side was going to be their home forever.

title: Tokyo Vice
description: When I started to read David Peaces new novel, I had, frankly, absolutely no idea of what was going on. The opening line: In the occupied city, you are a writer and you are running. As it turns out, the idea of running  step by step-step by step  is endlessly, mind-numbingly repeated and reworked in this novel. A writer is running, clutching the manuscript of a book that refuses to be written, toward the Black Gate of Tokyo, where something of an occult nature is going on. Both the reader and the fictional writer  is it David Peace himself?  are tightly wound in something intensely claustrophobic. I felt as if I were lost, not in Tokyo, but in a particular kind of pulp fiction fantasy.

title: How to Be Brilliant
description: Youve probably heard it at one time or another: Most of us use only 10 percent of our brains. More factoid than fact, a claim of unknown provenance and dubious accuracy, the idea sticks around because of the enduring appeal of its underlying premise. Wed all love to think that were in possession of tremendous untapped potential, of latent mental powers just waiting to be activated. It seems so convenient, like falling in love with the person youre already married to, or whipping up dinner from whats already in your kitchen. You dont have to leave home, or even change out of your pajamas.

title: PEN International Fest Announces Line-Up
description: Authors will temporarily give up the writing life for the speaking life when PEN American Center launches its weeklong Voices Festival of International Literature on April 26. Familiar literary stars like Toni Morrison and Salman Rushdie (the festival chairman) are part of the lineup, as are musical performers like Patti Smith and Natalie Merchant, who have recently tried their hands at book writing.

title: Breaking Down Rudy Gays Game
description: Zach Lowe writes for CelticsHub.com. He grew up in Connecticut watching the Bird-era Celtics with his father and hating Chuck Person. He now lives in Manhattan and dreams of a day in his adult lifetime when the Celtics and Knicks are both elite teams.

title: Answers From a Film Scout, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of responses from Nick Carr, who for the past five years has worked as a film location scout in New York, combing the streets for every type of locale imaginable for use in feature films and television.

title: Citing Health Care Vote, Obama Delays Asia Trip
description: President Obama has called off his trip to Australia and Indonesia, deeming it necessary to stay in Washington to push for passage of the health care legislation up for a vote later this weekend in the House.

title: Jerome B. York, Former Auto Executive, Dies at 71
description: DETROIT  Jerome B. York, the financial expert who warned General Motors of a looming financial disaster and aided the billionaire investor, Kirk Kerkorian, in efforts to drive up the price of Chrysler stock, died on Thursday. He was 71.

title: First Couple of Irans Opposition Post Video Messages for Persian New Year
description: One year after President Obama used the Web to send a video greeting to the Iranian people on the occasion of the Persian New Year, Nowruz, the first couple of Irans opposition have posted defiant messages on Facebook to mark the holiday.

title: The Womens Field Should Beware Notre Dame
description: Despite how it seems, there isnt a law that every story about the womens N.C.A.A. tournament story has to include the words Tennessee or Connecticut.

title: So Maven Me, Dudes
description: Marc Jacobs is again in the running for CFDAs womens designer of the year, and top accessory maker as well; his fall collection of beautiful and modest clothes makes him deserving. Ditto Donna Karan who has sharpened up her collections in recent seasons. And Alexander Wang is fast building a brand.

title: Germany Backtracks on European Rescue for Greece
description: The onus for resolving Greeces financial crisis appeared to move closer to the International Monetary Fund on Thursday, as Germany distanced itself from any bilateral or European support for the Greek government, The New York Timess Matthew Saltmarsh reports.

description: The Pennsylvania woman accused of recruiting men on the Internet to wage jihad in southern Asia and Europe pleaded not guilty Thursday to all counts in federal court in Philadelphia.

title: Tiger Deaths Raise Alarms About Chinese Zoos
description: BEIJING  The local authorities in northeastern China recently took control of a 10-year-old zoo where 11 rare Siberian tigers starved to death, and they are sending experts to try to save the remaining 20 or so tigers, three of which are in critical condition.

title: Jerome B. York, Key Adviser on Auto Deals, Dies at 71
description: Jerome B. York, the sharp-eyed financial expert who warned General Motors of a looming financial disaster and aided the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian in efforts to drive up the price of Chrysler stock, died Thursday. He was 71.

title: Israeli Suggests Steps to Aid Peace Talks
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, under intense pressure from the United States to settle a diplomatic dispute over Jewish settlements, called Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton late Thursday to propose what he called a package of mutual confidence building steps to be taken by Israelis and Palestinians to help restart peace negotiations.

description: The Times's Marcus Mabry and David M. Herszenhorn discuss whether a new Congressional Budget Office analysis will help Democrats get enough House votes to pass the final package of legislation to overhaul health care.

title: DeLamielleure Slams Brees Stance on Retired Players Benefits
description: N.F.L. Hall of Fame member Joe DeLamielleure has been an outspoken advocate for improving benefits and care for his fellow retired players, unleashing his take-no-prisoners style on everyone from the late union leader Gene Upshaw to his current target: Saints quarterback Drew Brees, who is taking an increasingly high-profile role in union matters.

title: Facebook Fan Pages Need Security Upgrade, Says Victim
description: You dont have be Britney Spears to attract online imitators and tormentors. Two weeks ago, a British security researcher, Graham Cluley, discovered a fake fan page on Facebook in his name and using his photo. Creepily, it appeared to have been created by someone calling himself Fred West, apparently in homage to a notorious British serial killer.

title: U.N. Rejects Export Ban on Atlantic Bluefin Tuna
description: Delegates at a United Nations conference on endangered species in Doha, Qatar, soundly defeated American-supported proposals on Thursday to ban international trade in bluefin tuna and to protect polar bears.

description: Southeast Asias first Universal Studios theme park opened Thursday in Singapore as the city-state vies to become a top regional tourist destination.

title: Hot Stuff
description: Hmm. When the Northeast had an unusually snowy winter, it proved that global warming was a myth. But when temperatures are much higher than usual for mid-March  crickets chirping.

title: Prosecutors Describe Hunt for Hispanic Victim
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  In a packed Long Island courtroom, a prosecutor laid out in chilling detail the sport that she said the defendant and his friends had made out of attacking Hispanic men.

title: Preview: 'Todd Margaret'
description: "The Increasingly Poor Decisions of Todd Margaret," a new comedy beginning on IFC this fall, was created by and stars David Cross.

title: Trust, Underwater
description: In 2004, newly married and having decided to embark on the next phase of adulthood, my wife and I bought a house. This was back in the delirious days of multiple offers and outlandish escalation clauses, when you had to bring your checkbook with you to an open house, just in case someone else tried to buy the place while you were poking around the attic. I called a mortgage broker somewhere in Florida, and she was thrilled to hear from me, practically breathless. I felt as if I were the 10,000th customer to come through line at the Safeway, my arrival heralded by streamers and sirens and all kinds of free stuff falling from the rafters. Did we want a five-year adjustable-rate loan or maybe even rates adjusted on a monthly basis? Why not just pay just the interest rather than the principal? Did we also need a bridge loan for a few months, to hold us over from one house to the next? How about a second trust''  that is, two mortgages instead of one  so we could put less money down, maybe even as little as 5 percent of the purchase price while avoiding the penalty of private mortgage insurance? We might as well open a home equity line of credit on top of the mortgage, she said, so we could borrow another six-figure sum with the tear of a perforated check. Countrywide, the nation's largest lender, would happily give us that free, and, hey, you never knew when you might decide to add a skylight over the kitchen, or maybe a stone turret.

title: Milestones: Hillary Rodham Clinton
description: An interactive timeline of Hillary Rodham Clintons life and career.

description: House Democrats have posted the revisions to their major health care legislation on the House Rules Committee Web site.

description: It has been a entertaining N.H.L. season with some exceptional performances and compelling story lines (although Rangers fans are permitted to grumble in disagreement). But sadly, were forced again and again to return to the topic of dangerous play, especially involving contact with players heads, and the leagues response. In many cases, the N.H.L. cannot seem get out of its own way.

title: McLaren Unveils MP4-12C Production Model
description: McLaren, one of the most successful teams in Formula One history, has spun off a company to sell road cars. McLaren Automotives first entry, the MP4-12C, is a two-seat, midengine supercar powered by a twin-turbocharged V-8. The car goes on sale in the first half of 2011 for about $200,000.

title: Greenspan: The Fed Failed to Gauge the Bubble
description: In his most detailed examination of the causes of the financial crisis, Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman, acknowledged that the Fed failed to grasp the magnitude of the housing bubble but argued that its policy of low interest rates from 2002 to 2005 did not cause the problem, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reported Thursday.

title: Coburn Warns Vote-Switchers on Health Care
description: There are senators who use their power to block bills and nominations in the Senate, and then there is Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma.

title: Answers About New Consumer Laws: Part 3
description: Updated

title: Now Shopping | SCADs of Good Things
description: Savannah, Ga., isnt only about Girl Scouts, Paula Deens calorie-bomb cooking or the intrigue of John Berendts Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil. The city is also home to a thriving design scene spawned in large part by the Savannah College of Art and Design. While SCAD, as the 30-year-old college is known, built its reputation as one of the countrys leading design schools, its administration wisely snapped up a number of big, beautiful (and, lets not forget, historic) buildings that faced probable demolition. As a result, its schools, lecture halls and administrative buildings are seamlessly woven into Savannahs urban fabric, making the college an integral part of the city and revitalizing several once-derelict neighborhoods.

description: Q.

title: Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, Noon.
description: On Match Day at Mount Sinai School of Medicine, students learned where they will spend their residencies  in Jacqueline Kamraths case, New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: Virgin America Plans Flights to Orlando, Toronto
description: Virgin America is going to Disney World. The airline today announced new daily nonstop flights to Orlando from Los Angeles and San Francisco beginning in August. One-way fares will start at $149 and $199 respectively.

title: Setback for European Carbon Market
description: Some trading in carbon dioxide credits came to a halt on two exchanges this week  a new crisis for the European Unions fledgling system for curbing greenhouse gas emissions.

title: A Tech-Filled Life, Without Power
description: My family has now been without electricity, heat or hot water for five days. I gotta tell you: its getting old.

title: Angry Young Man
description: Its Cinco de Mayo in San Jose, Calif., and our man Paul  pundit, cynic, iconoclast  pummels a Mexican at a march for immigration reform, for which infraction hes charged with a hate crime and hauled off to jail. And so begins What We Are, Peter Nathaniel Malaes first novel, with twofold irony: First, Pauls father is a Samoan immigrant, which, in this story, inoculates his son against cultural prejudice. Second, in 2006 immigration reform was largely about paths to United States citizenship for illegals, the assumption being that they wanted to stay. Not so much Paul. He is a first-generation American who lives in a country he cannot stand, and spends much of his time railing against everyone in it, himself included. One of this novels organizing tensions is how to reconcile misanthropy with a sense that taking a stand  for people, for values  can suffuse your life with meaning. For Paul, whose heritage is mixed, there is the added problem of how to straddle cultures while still forging an identity of his own. From Page 1, his biggest gripe is that he has no story, no position and, more worrisome, no heart.

title: The Pasta Cure
description: When we find ourselves coping with pain, the kitchen can become our therapist, food our source of comfort. The joy of cooking was certainly the salve that soothed the emotional wounds that the journalist Paula Butturini endured as she and her husband suffered bullets, police beatings and a battle with depression that almost tore their marriage apart. Butturini tells her story through the lens of food  its restorative powers and its capacity to trigger the brain to remember and hope in times of tragedy and challenge: And like a potter centering clay on a spinning potters wheel, the mere act of cooking centered me, Butturini writes in Keeping the Feast, her blunt and brave memoir. It kept me close, available, ready to help, kept us fed, kept me sufficiently focused on present tasks so that I wouldnt panic about the future, kept me going through the slow passing of a string of bad days, weeks and months.

title: Summers Slams Boehners Punk Staffers Comment
description: In recent months, Lawrence H. Summers, the director of the National Economic Council in the Obama administration, has kept a relatively low profile and rarely assumes the public role of a White House attack dog.

title: In New Health Care Package, Drug Makers to Pay More
description: 6:14 p.m. | Updated

title: Is Apple Throwing Its Hat Into the Location Ring?
description: As I recently reported, location-based services are quickly becoming the newest territory that companies are hoping to lay claim to.

title: Old Dominion Provides Tournaments First Upset
description: NEW ORLEANS  There was plenty of precedent for Old Dominion upon entering the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament as a No. 11 seed. Other Colonial Athletic Association teams had made noise in the tournament from the same position as the Monarchs. In 2006, George Mason was a No. 11 seed for its magical run to the Final Four, and so was Virginia Commonwealth a year later when it upset Duke in the first round.

title: Raids Aim to Find Killers of 3 in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  They carry both American passports and high-caliber weapons, making them the perfect cross-border assassins. They confuse the authorities by using a coded language that blends English, Spanish and the Aztecs ancient tongue of Nahuatl. The threat of prison is no big fear for members of the Barrio Azteca street gang, because they consider the cellblock to be home.

title: Going Dutch | Stumptown Coffee in Amsterdam
description: Stumptown Coffee Roasters is setting up shop in Amsterdam. Or, to be specific, a pop-up shop, which will open on May 1. Duane Sorensen, the owner of Stumptown Coffee Roasters, said he was approached by Sid Lee, a Montreal-based creative agency with a branch in Amsterdam that happened to have a spare La Marzocco espresso machine kicking around in a little-used storefront. Sorensen flew to Amsterdam with seven Chemex coffee brewers and some beans; he returned with the keys to a shop thats his through the end of July.

title: I Am in Control, Mr. Pancho
description: A truckload of wood arrived from Connecticut with old beams (circa 1900) taken from a Bronx warehouse and red cypress (1890) from a North Carolina wood mill. The next morning, three new guys showed up at the site with insurance, equipment, English and enthusiasm: Juan and Onis Saldaa are brothers, Favian their nephew.

title: Fredettes 37 Points Lift Brigham Young
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Jimmer Fredette, the junior guard for Brigham Young who seems as if he can score from anywhere, had finally been caught. He was fouled hard enough in the second overtime of the Cougars N.C.A.A. tournament game against Florida on Thursday that he fell to the floor in a sweaty heap.

title: Viacom Says YouTube Ignored Copyrights
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Pointing to internal YouTube e-mail messages, Viacom said in a court filing that the video sites founders turned a blind eye when users uploaded copyrighted clips so they could amass a big audience and sell the company quickly.

title: Movie Listings
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

title: SXSW: About That Long-Awaited Superchunk Record
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  While we were waiting for Spoon to take the stage at Stubbs for a much chatted and Twitted about set, Ana Marie Cox of GQ magazine introduced us to Mac McCaughan, a founder of Merge, Spoons label, and more famously, a founder of Superchunk, which remains a fetish object and prototype of indie rock even though its last full-length studio album came out in 2001.

title: Another View: A Primer on Asset Manager Spin-Outs
description: Ashvin Rao of Lehman Brothers Holdings and Jane McDonald and Christopher Machera of Weil, Gotshal & Manges examine the complexities of spinning out asset management businesses.

title: Vistas, Tacos and Bowling
description: Once claimed by the Dutch in the 1600s, the gigantic neighborhood of Sunset Park is now home to Brooklyns Chinatown, an expanding Mexican community and possibly the citys coolest bowling alley. Stretching 30 blocks from Green-Wood Cemetery on the northern edge to the border of Bay Ridge, the entire neighborhood is impossible to get to know in one stop. A good way to start is by getting off the D, M, N or R train at 36th Street, southwest of Park Slope, and exiting on the Fourth Avenue side.

title: Gutierrez to Vote Yes
description: Representative Luis V. Gutierrez, Democrat of Illinois, said on Thursday that he would vote in favor of the Democrats health care legislation. Mr. Gutierrez had threatened to oppose the measure because he did not like provisions in the Senate-passed bill that would bar illegal immigrants from purchasing insurance through new government exchanges, even if they paid the full cost with their own money.

title: Live Updates From the Mens N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Live updates and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Pete Thamel in Providence, Thayer Evans in New Orleans and Billy Witz in San Jose will give updates, and Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward, will offer analysis about the games from South Bend, Ind. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comments section below.

title: Two on a Seesaw
description: Some egos, particularly in this business we call show, are way too big and unruly to share a spotlight. I mean that in the nicest possible way, to use a disclaimer often employed by the great Dame Edna Everage. It is, as it happens, Dame Edna of whom I am speaking.

title: Robert Morris Does Everything but Win
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  When Villanova Coach Jay Wright met Robert Morris Coach Mike Rice in the postgame handshake line Thursday, he greeted him with a statement that was so honest it might have sounded insincere.

title: Good Timing
description: In the dizzying run-up of watch technology of the last 10 or 15 years, the size of watch cases, the number of diamonds on them and the staggering intricacy of their complications were matched only by the astronomical sums the timepieces commanded. It was in the midst of this spinning tourbillon of activity that a few people tried something a lot simpler, a lot cheaper and a lot more colorful. With neon-bright hues, stretchy silicone bands and novel faces, the new 80s-inspired watches could have been worn by bands like the Thompson Twins or the Human League. They all but sing, Dont you want me, baby?

title: The Future of Memory
description: Gizmodo, the technology blog, has a fascinating series this week about memory. Titled Memory [Forever], the blog takes a look at the topic from multiple angles, including memory and our brains, how the Internet remembersand the memory inside computers.

title: Asian Art on View, Tea on the Table
description: With the demise last year of the decade-old International Asian Art Fair, New York dealers have formed competing consortiums to promote walking tours of their galleries during the traditional spring Asia Week. Through next weekend, anyone interested in Asian art can ring the doorbells of galleries, mostly in town houses on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and normally open only by appointment, and climb creaky stairs to learn about luxuries produced during the last five millenniums.

title: Fess Parker, Davy Crockett and Daniel Boone Star, Has Died
description: Fess Parker, whose television portrayal of Davy Crockett, the American frontiersman, catapulted him to stardom in 1954-55 and inspired one of Americas greatest merchandising fads, in which hundreds of thousands of children wore coonskin caps, died on Thursday. Mr. Parker, who went rustic once again in the 1960s and played Daniel Boone for a new generation of young television watchers, was 85.
