description: Three members of a family in Richmond Hill, Queens, have been indicted on charges that they stole $1.75 million from 19 fellow West Indian immigrants by falsely promising to help them obtain green cards and bargain deals on federally seized property in New York City and Florida, the Queens district attorney announced on Thursday.

title: Lehman Now Seeks $11 Billion From Barclays
description: Lehman Brothers, which is being liquidated in bankruptcy, said Thursday that it was now seeking a total of $11 billion from Barclays of Britain, including a $5 billion windfall that the firm contends that Barclays received when it bought Lehmans North American brokerage, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Writing Stiffs
description: A 2008 study of the creative economy from the National Endowment for the Arts reported that full-time writers and authors earned a median annual salary of more than $50,000.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

title: Lost Soldiers
description: Just kids. You step into the barracks thinking big, burly and deep-voiced. And what you get are chubby faces and halfhearted mustaches and voices still cracking, boys hurried into uniforms and handed heavy guns. Sept. 11 was junior high, fifth grade even, a half a lifetime ago. Megan Fox is everywhere, plastered above the bunks, the best that Maxim can offer. Junk food, too, sent A.P.O. (Army Post Office) from home: powdered Gatorade and M&Ms and teriyaki jerky. Underwear and socks. Love you, bro, scrawled a sister from California on a care package to Ramadi, Iraq. Muwah!

title: That Drug Kingpin Cancer Patient and Guilty Pleasure of a Bad World
description: The first decade of the 21st century has been a boom time for murderers on television. James Gandolfini as the mobster Tony Soprano (The Sopranos), Michael Chiklis as the rogue cop Vic Mackey (The Shield), Bryan Cranston as the schoolteacher and meth kingpin Walter White (Breaking Bad): Theyre among the most honored television performances of the era, representing 6 of the last 10 Emmy Awards for lead actor in a drama. (And another, Michael C. Hall as the forensics expert and serial killer Dexter Morgan, has been an Emmy nominee and recently won Golden Globes and Screen Actors Guild Awards.)

title: The Immigrant, Radical and Notorious Women of Washington Square
description: Saturday is the first day of spring, which makes this weekend an opportune time to get outside and take a stroll. Instead of just roaming aimlessly, though, how about a walking tour? A wide variety of tours is available on any given weekend in New York, and the number of options usually swells as the weather warms up. One tour in particular this weekend seems especially worth noting, as it also dovetails with Womens History Month.

title: Anne-Marie Hess and David Rabkin
description: THE relationship between Anne-Marie Hess and Dr. David Rabkin has always been poetry in progress.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Thats Not a Rap Sheet
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: Stately Grounds and Atari-Hued Lanes
description: Once claimed by the Dutch in the 1600s, the gigantic neighborhood of Sunset Park is now home to Brooklyns Chinatown, an expanding Mexican community and possibly the citys coolest bowling alley. Stretching 30 blocks from Green-Wood Cemetery on the northern edge to the border of Bay Ridge, the entire neighborhood is impossible to get to know in one stop. A good way to start is by getting off the D, M, N or R train at 36th Street, southwest of Park Slope, and exiting on the Fourth Avenue side.

title: Books Cook!
description: In the Atlantic Theater Companys latest production Will Seefried tells young audiences that each numbered storybook propped onstage has an ingredient hidden behind it. Shout five numbers, he says, and he will mix those concealed items and eat them.

title: On Character: Bryan Cranston in 'Breaking Bad'
description: The actor discusses a scene from the season premiere of the AMC drama.

title: A Once Proud Bank, Brought Low
description: Landmark distinction couldn't save the Mount Morris Bank building in Harlem.

title: Party Central | The Runaways After-Party
description: Scenes from the after-party for the premiere of The Runaways in New York.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO  (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series Dora the Explorer and Go, Diego, Go! have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Childrens Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diegos Animal Rescue Center and Doras Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.20100318

title: Indonesia Is Left Waiting for Obamas Trip
description: Boys trained a racing pigeon Thursday in Matraman, the district of Jakarta, Indonesia, in which Barack Obama spent some of his childhood. Indonesians anticipating the presidential visit  whether happily or angrily  will have to wait a few more months, as Mr. Obama postponed his planned Pacific trip a second time to concentrate on trying to pass health care legislation.

title: Judge Bans Sites Quick Posts of Wall St. Research
description: A federal judge on Thursday banned a financial Web site, TheFlyontheWall.com, from issuing immediate news about analysts reports from Wall Street firms, often before that information was shared with the firms clients, Reuters reports.

title:
Democrats Say Health Bill Will
Pay for Itself in the Long Run
description: WASHINGTON  House Democrats initiated a 72-hour countdown Thursday on their yearlong effort to overhaul the health care system, unveiling a nearly final version of the legislation that promptly won additional support with a promise that the bill would more than pay for itself over the next decade.

title: A Liberal Price Cut
description: THE worldly and the clever gathered at the dinner parties that William F. Buckley Jr. and his wife, Pat, gave in their Park Avenue maisonette. Yet even though the chairs in the formal dining room are still covered in chartreuse leopard print, it has been quite a while since anyone but a broker or a prospective buyer has spent much time there.

title: Roasted Red Pepper Filled With Tuna
description: This recipe is an adaptation of a classic Provenal dish. Until recently, I was in denial about the fact that I could no longer get two servings from one can of tuna. When I used to make this dish years ago, tuna was sold in 6 1/2-ounce cans. Now I get a 5-ounce can for the same price, and there are only 3 or 4 ounces of tuna in that can.

title: SXSW: Imperfect Harmony
description: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

title: On the Road With Seekers and Other Dharma Bums
description: Finally, officially, Saturday is spring, when  I paraphrase Chaucer  tender shoots rise, surprised birds sing, and we hit the road in search of our hearts desire. The art world has its own version of such a trek. Its called Asia Week, and it too kicks off on Saturday, sending devotees hiking around Manhattan in search of galleries with special shows (more than three dozen this year) and museums with Asian fare.

title: Latest Bill Raises Medicaid Rates for Primary Care Doctors
description: The Democrats health care legislation, the latest version of which was unveiled on Thursday, would broadly expand Medicaid, the federal-state insurance program for low-income Americans.

title: Room for a Bakers Dozen
description: Room for a Bakers Dozen

title: A Once Proud Bank, Brought Low
description: IT is hard to give up hope on an old friend who is brain-dead, but there is no indecency in performing an early inquest on the 1883 Mount Morris Bank Building, at Park Avenue and 125th Street. Now slashed from six scrumptious red-brick-and-brownstone stories to one, its hardly more than a flutter on a hospital monitor.

title: More Gods, Saints and Epic Flying Heroes
description: Anyone interested in Buddhist sacred art will want to sample some of these special, open-to-the-public exhibitions in Manhattan for Asia Week.

title: California May Ban Smoking in State Parks
description: What is believed to be the United States most far-reaching plan to ban smoking in state parks went before the State Assembly on Thursday, proposed as a way to get cigarette butts off the beach, eliminate secondhand smoke and reduce the threat of wildfires.

title: Two High-Level Departures at Harpers
description: 5:25 p.m. Updated with comment from Paul Ford.

title: No Longer Saddled With a Pied--Terre
description: No Longer Saddled

title: Maybe Hell Move to a Hotel
description: Maybe Hell Move to a Hotel

title: Updating the Status of Labor Talks
description: Derek Fisher of the Los Angeles Lakers, the president of the players association, spoke briefly with Off the Dribble last week about the status of the continuing labor negotiations.

title: SXSW: Shedding Nerddom, Gaining Independence
description: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

title: A Blue Dog Switches His Vote to Yes
description: Representative Bart Gordon, Democrat of Tennessee and a member of the fiscally conservative Blue Dog coalition, has said that he will vote in favor of the health care legislation. Mr. Gordon opposed the House version of the health care bill in November.

title: Headfirst Down the Slopes, on an Airboard
description: Jeffersonville, Vt.

title: Tele-Tunes
description: Video | TV music medley, in the time it takes for a station break:

title: Serenity Point Beach Development
description: WHAT Small oceanfront second-home community.

title: March Madness on the iPhone
description: As briefly mentioned in Thursdays Phone Smart column, the CBSSports NCAA March Madness On Demand app ($10) has hit the iPhone, giving users live video of every game in the tournament.

title: Landmarcs Marc Murphy on the Question of Grades for Restaurant Cleanliness
description: On Tuesday the New York City Board of Health voted to rate cleanliness in the citys restaurants with publicly posted letter grades, adopting a plan proposed 14 months ago by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

title: Why Even Bother Trying to Connect?
description: Hurt people hurt people. This nugget of therapy talk is passed from one character to another in Noah Baumbachs Greenberg, offered as an explanation, an excuse and a sort-of apology. While those four words dont quite sum up the whole of the human condition, they might stand as a concise summary of Mr. Baumbachs recent movies. The battling pair of married (and then divorced) writers in The Squid and the Whale, the warring sisters in Margot at the Wedding  they and their loved ones walk through life nursing psychic wounds and brandishing metaphorical knives.

title: Murray State Beats Buzzer, and Vanderbilt
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Cutting down the nets may be troublesome for Murray State, whose guard B. J. Jenkins gashed his hand with scissors after his team won the Ohio Valley Conference tournament.

title: Polanski Lawyers Cite New Allegations of Judicial Misconduct
description: LOS ANGELES  Lawyers for the film director Roman Polanski, under house arrest in Switzerland awaiting possible extradition to the United States, filed an appeals petition on Thursday revealing the existence of sealed testimony about secret dealings between high-ranking prosecutors and a judge in the 33-year-old sex crimes case.

title: Where Kipling Reared Mowgli (in Vermont)
description: Dummerston, Vt.

title: Hiking the Annapurna Circuit
description: The legendary 150-mile Annapurna Circuit trek circles the Annapurna massif in Nepal.

title: Kyochon Tries to Get It Right
description: What do you do if you spent $2 million on a fried chicken restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, after already having more than 1,000 outlets under your belt, and then have customers tell you that you did not get it right?

title: Universals Strategy Tests Lower Price on New CDs
description: The Universal Music Group, the worlds largest music company, announced plans on Thursday to test broadly whether lower prices  $10 or less  on new CDs will attract consumers who have cut back on buying CDs in recent years.

title: Center Wont Play Syracuses First Game
description: BUFFALO  Syracuse center Arinze Onuaku walked comfortably through the HSBC Arena Thursday evening, but he said that his strained right quadriceps will prevent him from playing in the N.C.A.A. tournaments opening round against Vermont.

title: TriBeCa Festival Shorts
description: The New Tenants, which won the Academy Award for live action short this month, will be among the 47 movies in the Tribeca Film Festivals short film lineup, along with works directed by Kirsten Dunst, Domenica Scorsese and others, festival organizers said on Thursday. The New Tenants, written by David Rakoff (Fraud, Dont Get Too Comfortable) and directed by Joachim Back, tells the darkly comic story of two men who meet their unusual neighbors as they move into a New York apartment; it will play on the festivals Hard Core program. Other films announced include Bastard, written and directed by Ms. Dunst (Spider-Man), about a couple in a desert motel; Roots in Water, directed by Ms. Scorsese and written by Richard Nelson, about two siblings dealing with the death of their mother; and A .45 at 50th, a documentary directed by Joshua Bell and John Cromwell in which the actor James Cromwell (The Queen) recounts his experience with the Black Panther Party. The festival runs April 21 to May 2.

title: Design Contract Signed for Moynihan Station
description: The architecture firm Skidmore, Owings & Merrill has signed a contract with the Moynihan Station Development Corporation to start design work on the first phase of the new Moynihan Station, the firm announced on Thursday. The project, which was proposed by and later named for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, calls for converting the Beaux-Arts James A. Farley Post Office  across Eighth Avenue from Pennsylvania Station  into a train station. Skidmore has been working on the project since the 1990s, producing several versions of it. Phase 1 includes extending the west-end concourse beneath the post office to allow access to additional tracks, improving platform ventilation and signal work and upgrading the connector between the post office and Penn Station under 33rd Street. The project will also add two entrances flanking the post offices grand stair on the west side of Eighth Avenue, along with escalators and elevators leading to Amtrak platforms.

title: Pen International Fest Announces Lineup
description: Authors will temporarily give up the writing life for the speaking life when PEN American Center begins its weeklong Voices Festival of International Literature on April 26. Familiar literary stars like Toni Morrison, above left, and Salman Rushdie (the festival chairman) are part of the lineup, as are musicians like Patti Smith and Natalie Merchant, who have recently tried their hands at book writing. A few authors are pairing up to interview each other: Ms. Smith and Jonathan Lethem, above right; Colum McCann and Roddy Doyle; and Shirley Hazzard and Richard Ford. Jean-Philippe Toussaint, Philippe Djian, Richard Price and Barry Gifford to talk about how their books were made into films. Popular events are back, like the Translation Slam, which pits contestants against one another as they translate a single work into a different language, and the PEN Cabaret, with Ben Okri, winner of the Man Booker Prize; Ariel Dorfman; and Ms. Merchant.

title: Good News for Fans of Bathroom Humor
description: To the joy of millions of young readers and the consternation of untold numbers of foes of the poop fiction genre, a spinoff of the Captain Underpants series will be released in August, Scholastic announced on Thursday. The Adventures of Ook and Gluk, Kung-Fu Cavemen From the Future, by Dav Pilkey, is the first in a four-book deal. In the graphic novel, written by the fictional characters George Beard and Harold Hutchins, Ook and Gluk are caveboys in Ohio in 500,001 B.C. who battle an evil corporation from the future and wind up in A.D. 2222. I think fans of Captain Underpants will be very happy with this new book, Mr. Pilkey said in a written statement. It has all the action, laffs and ridiculousness that children love, plus all the unapologetic irreverence and questionable potty humor that grumpy curmudgeons love to complain about. While Captain Underpants will not appear in the first book, he will be in two of the four, Scholastic said. Tracy van Straaten, vice president for publicity at Scholastic, said the first book would have a printing of one million copies, joining 45 million copies in print of Mr. Pilkeys eight Captain Underpants books, featuring a superhero in briefs and a red cape. First out in 1997, the books became best sellers despite complaints by some parents and educators about their bathroom humor.

title: Virtual Biennial, Twitter (and Cameras) Allowed
description: If youve wanted to visit the Whitney Biennial but do not live near New York or you work a job where youre never allowed to leave your desk (ahem), the Whitney Museum of American Art and WNYC radio are collaborating on a virtual tour. On Tuesday, the museum and WNYC will offer what they are calling a private, curator-led Twitter tour of the biennial, above, the organizations said in a news release. At its Web site (wnyc.org), WNYC is seeking social-media-savvy listeners, eight of whom will be chosen to comment on the exhibition using Twitter and Facebook, as well as the photo-sharing site Flickr. (As anyone who has been reprimanded for taking a photograph at the Whitney will know, the museum is bending its rules for the occasion.) The rest of us can follow the virtual tour on these Web sites and pose questions to Gary Carrion-Murayari, a curator of the biennial, on Twitter at @WNYCculture, @whitneymuseum or @cmonstah, the Twitter feed of the WNYC contributor Carolina Miranda.

title: Look, Kids: A Way to Slip Pokmon Past Mom
description: Countless children who do not carry a wallet, do not carry a cellphone and do not even have keys to their own house make sure to carry a Nintendo portable game machine with them wherever they can. And for the few places they cant (oh, I dont know, school?), Nintendo has now delivered the ultimate solution  or perhaps the ultimate problem.

title: Thank You, Friends: A Few More Thoughts About Alex Chilton
description: Among the stray details and remembrances of Alex Chilton, the rock musician of Box Tops and Big Star renown who died on Wednesday, that I couldnt quite fit into the obituary for him:

title: Piano and Voice Salute Chopin, Schumann and Those They Inspired
description: Emanuel Ax could easily have celebrated the joint 200th anniversaries of Chopin and Schumann with a series of solo piano recitals. Instead, in three programs at Carnegie Hall, he tried something fresher.

title: The Next Stage for Fela!: Olivier Theater in London
description: While the West End has been home to the commercial runs of many successful Broadway musicals, the nonprofit National Theater in London on Thursday announced a rare undertaking for its stages: a production of the new Broadway musical Fela! later this year that will star the two actors who now alternate in the title role in New York.

title: For Bronx Community Organizer, Work and Life Were One
description: One winter day in the mid-1970s, Jim Buckley, a young tenant organizer in the Bronx, went to the offices of Con Ed to try to get an apartment buildings lights turned back on.

title: Pomp and Pyrotechnics on Point
description: On Wednesday night at City Center, ngel Corella, one of American Ballet Theaters stars, was at his most brilliantly charming. The occasion was the New York debut of his own ballet company  Ballet Corella Castilla y Len, from Spain. He had choreographed the first ballet, String Sextet, as a showcase for the virtuosity of many other dancers. The programs next offerings, Walpurgisnacht and Sunny Duet, were short 20th-century Soviet Russian vehicles for further virtuosity. The audience responded lustily to every dancer and the many, many displays of bravura.

title: Chilling, but Its Not the Bataan Death March
description: Correction appended | For 65 years, this Associated Press photograph of Allied prisoners of war carrying their fallen comrades on makeshift stretchers has been the visual embodiment of the Bataan Death March, in the early months of World War II.

title: Theater Listings: March 19  25
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Cross-Cultural Rhythms Amid Relaxed Chemistry
description: Jim Black, the drummer and de facto leader of Pachora, was a force in constant motion at Rose Live Music in Brooklyn on Wednesday night. The hummingbird churn of his fingers on a dumbek, or goblet drum, was punctuated by an array of passing textures: the startled cough of a cymbal grasped in midcrash, or the hurried rustle of a shaker, or the deadening whomp of a detuned floor tom. Mr. Black, with his busy amalgam of Balkan and Middle Eastern rhythms, was working in a mode both familiar and dated. Were Pachora. Were from the 90s, he said cheerily at the start of the bands first set.

title: Idol Elimination Leads the Night
description: Lacey Brown became the first of the final 12 American Idol contestants to be eliminated as the hourlong results episode on Wednesday drew 20.1 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The show was the top-rated program on the night, lifting Fox to No. 1 in prime time. CBS ranked second with a lineup of mostly repeats. CBSs Criminal Minds, at 9, drew 7.6 million viewers, and CSI: NY, at 10, drew 7.5 million. NBC was third, finishing close behind CBS and leading the 10 p.m. hour with Law & Order: SVU (9.5 million), while ABC placed a distant fourth.

title: Wait, Wait, Dont Torture Me
description: Updating a famous psychological experiment first conducted in the 1960s by researchers at Yale University, French documentary producers managed to trick dozens of people  who were told that they were taking part in a pilot for a new game show that, in fact, never existed  into administering what seemed like painful electric shocks to a fellow contestant.

title: Proving Their Mettle in the Men-Only Era of Rock
description: The Runaways, which takes place mainly in Southern California in the mid-1970s, evokes its moment and milieu with affectionate, almost uncanny fidelity. Its a sun-baked teenage wasteland of muscle cars and hamburger stands, and the two young 21st-century movie stars who play the main characters seem to fit right in. Dakota Fanning and Kristen Stewart, who are Cherie Currie and Joan Jett, lead singer and guitarist for the band that gives the movie its name, were born a long time after the book had closed on the real-life Runaways, but the seriousness and self-confidence with which they tackle their roles goes a long way toward establishing a sense of authenticity.

title: Fortunes Improve for Miracle Worker
description: After two weeks of doubts about the financial viability of the Broadway revival of The Miracle Worker, its producers have completed a new round of financing that will allow the play to keep running through mid-April in hopes of appealing to spring vacation theatergoers.

title: The Casuals
description: Its all in the jeans  and khakis. More

title: Photo of the Week
description: Tourists take photos in front of the Parthenon in Athens.

title: Doctor Asserts Church Ignored Abuse Warnings
description: ESSEN, Germany  The German archdiocese led by the future Pope Benedict XVI ignored repeated warnings in the early 1980s by a psychiatrist treating a priest accused of sexually abusing boys that he should not be allowed to work with children, the psychiatrist said Thursday.

title: Baylor Clears Its First Hurdle
description: NEW ORLEANS  As the No. 3 seed in the South Region of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, Baylor is a trendy darkhorse pick to make the Final Four.

title: Kansas State Outmuscles North Texas
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  North Texas won 11 straight games before swooping into the N.C.A.A. tournament, but it discovered Thursday that opponents like Florida Atlantic, Florida International, Denver and Houston Baptist are a little less formidable than Kansas State.

title: Bake-In! Lower Manhattan, 4 P.M.
description: Wielding pans and signs that read I love my Moms oatmeal cookies and No Doritos, no Pop-Tarts, children and their parents gathered near City Hall Thursday afternoon to protest the new bake sale rules in New York City public schools, which prevent students from selling home-baked goods during school hours.

title: Searching the Bones of Our Shared Past
description: WASHINGTON  Our species has undergone a significant evolutionary change in the last 150 years. This is scarcely a sigh on the scale of long-term hominin evolution, some six million years of transformation that is the main concern of the impressive David H. Koch Hall of Human Origins, which opened this week at the Smithsonians National Museum of Natural History. But without this recent, subtle, quick change, this $20.5 million exhibition would hardly have been possible.

title: Character and Career, Both Alive
description: IN the first two seasons of the AMC drama Breaking Bad, Jesse Pinkman has been party to acts of larceny, blackmail, murder and other felonies; lost his girlfriend as a result of her drug abuse; and fallen back so hard on his own addiction that he eventually ended up in rehab. As Jesse, a seedy, selfish drug maker and dealer endures these hardships, Aaron Paul, the 30-year-old actor who plays him, could hardly be happier.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Lines Up Behind the New Bill
description: In a telephone news conference on Thursday, Richard Trumka, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.s president, said that the federations executive council had voted overwhelmingly to press Congress to enact the health care legislation.

title: Il Duce as Young Lover: The Making of a Dictator
description: The mass loves strong men, Benito Mussolini once said. The mass is female. In Vincere, a sustained, alternatingly exhausting and aesthetically exhilarating howl of a film, the veteran Italian director Marco Bellocchio brilliantly personalizes Mussolinis rise to power through a fictional retelling of his seduction and catastrophically violent betrayal of his reputed first wife, Ida Dalser. Like much of Italy, Dalser abandoned herself to him body and soul. The films title  a reference to a popular Italian Fascist song  means to win, as in to defeat, vanquish, surpass. Win, win, win! Fascist soldiers would sing, as Il Duce aroused the populace. At any cost!

title: St. Marys Flexes Muscles in a Soft Region
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  All season, as West Coast basketball toiled in obscurity and futility, St. Marys reigned as perhaps the sports top program west of the Rocky Mountains. The Gaels finished second in the West Coast Conference regular-season standings, upset Gonzaga in the league tournament final, and looked like a dangerous team in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Bauhaus Meets Venice Beach
description: Josef Albers/Ken Price, a thrilling exhibition at the Brooke Alexander Gallery in SoHo, can make you feel as if your eyes were attached to a bigger, more perceptive brain. It brings together the work of two great artists in a way that enables you to see both more clearly.

title: What Were Reading: Hacked Cars and E-Books for the Mac
description: Hacker Disables More Than 100 Cars Remotely  Wired.comNick Bilton says: In Austin, Tex., more than 100 Web-connected cars were disabled by a disgruntled 20-year-old hacker.

title: Paired Artists, All Around Town
description: The Manhattan shows mentioned in the article:

title: The Shrine Down the Hall
description: Seven years after the beginning of the Iraq war  and with U.S. troop deaths in Iraq and Afghanistan exceeding 5,000  a look at some of the bedrooms America's young war dead left behind.

title: A Subtle Mix of Traditional and Modern Gestures
description: At the start of Yasuko Yokoshis Tyler Tyler, a woman in a long, full skirt enters with slow, almost ritualistic pacing and places a tiny toy piano on the floor. A man (Kuniya Sawamura) in traditional costume kneels close to her and begins to move with subtle twistings and dippings of the upper body as she sings in Japanese.

title: A Peek at an Interactive Magazine for the Apple iPad
description: 11:30 p.m. | Correction. A single issue of the VIVmag is $6.

title: Planting a Johns Flag in a Private Collection
description: Less than two months before Christies will be selling one of Jasper Johnss signature Flag paintings, the hedge fund billionaire Steven A. Cohen privately scooped up a larger and earlier example of that artists seminal image. He bought it from Jean-Christophe Castelli, son of Leo Castelli, Mr. Johnss legendary dealer. The younger Mr. Castelli inherited the painting from his father, who died in 1999.

title: Summers Slams Boehners Punk Staffers Comment
description: From Sewell Chan at The Caucus:

title: Interlopers on the Skyline
description: LONDON

title: The Vote Count
description: What are the odds for passage of the reconciliation bill in the House? At the end of Thursday, The Times counted 196 votes for the legislation, 199 against, and 34 still undecided. Find the full tally here.

title: Married to Their Colorful Histories
description: When Nathanael West, the author of the comic-grotesque novels Miss Lonelyhearts (1933) and The Day of the Locust (1939), died in a car crash in 1940, at 37, it didnt surprise anyone who knew him. He was a notoriously bad driver, the kind of guy whod blow through 11 straight red lights or take his eyes off the road to talk to someone in the back seat.

title: Financial Tuneup': A Live Event
description: Some of you may remember a column I wrote last year recommending that we all take an entire day each year to knock off our list of financial to-dos.

title: In a Battle of the Exes, the Punches Are Pulled
description: At the beginning of The Bounty Hunter, Nicole and Milo  shes a reporter for The Daily News, played by Jennifer Aniston; hes a former New York City police officer, played by Gerard Butler, who now plies the unglamorous trade that gives the movie its name  are divorced. It is obvious enough that this condition will reverse itself by the end, but it would have been better for everybody concerned, the audience most of all, if they had just stayed split.

title: Ask Anthony Shadid About the Iraq Elections
description: Preliminary Results

title: Lonelyhearts
description: Chapter 1

title: A Troubled Victory for Villanova
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  From the outside, the Villanova program doesnt look particularly stable. The second-seeded Wildcats trailed virtually the entire game against No. 15 Robert Morris in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament on Thursday, had lost five of seven games heading into the N.C.A.A.s and have dealt with a flurry of off-court problems.

title: Live Updates From the N.C.A.A. Tournament, Part II
description: Live updates and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Pete Thamel in Providence, Thayer Evans in New Orleans and Dave Caldwell in Oklahoma City gave updates, and Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward, offered analysis about the games from South Bend, Ind. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comments section below.

title: Insurers Large Public Offering Could Lift Japanese Markets
description: HONG KONG If things go according to plan, the Japanese insurance group Dai-Ichi Mutual Life on April 1 will stage the worlds largest stock market debut since Visas listing two years ago.

title: Democrats Focus on McConnell in TV Ad
description: Pouncing on an article by The Timess Carl Hulse and Adam Nagourney about Senator Mitch McConnells strategy for a Republican blockade on health care (and other legislative matters), the Democratic National Committee has released a new ad.

title: Prius Computer Raises Doubts in an Account of a Crash
description: Federal safety regulators investigating the crash of a Toyota Prius in suburban New York said Thursday that the cars computer showed no evidence of braking by the driver at the time of the crash.

title: Hacker With Ink on Back and Big Chip on Shoulder
description: Tattoos and body piercings must be pretty far-out stuff in Sweden, the land of midnight sun, icy blondes and enough twisted thinking to plump up three best-selling mystery novels. From the way that most people look at the inked, pierced form of Lisbeth Salander, the main attraction in the movie adaptation of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, the first book in Stieg Larssons so-called Millennium Trilogy, you might even think that our girl had a swastika stamped on her forehead rather than a few modest rings hooked through her nose  you know, like a cow ready for market or, given the murderous milieu, slaughter.

title: ABC Lures Christiane Amanpour From CNN to Be the Host of This Week
description: ABC News announced Thursday that it had poached one of CNNs biggest stars, Christiane Amanpour, and named her the host of This Week, the networks Sunday morning public affairs program.

title: A Father-Daughter Bond, Page by Page
description: MILLVILLE, N.J.

title: Judge Denies JPMorgan $28 Million in Fees
description: Questioning Fees In Takeover Deals

title: Old and New Media Coexisting Nicely, Thank You
description: IT was not that long ago when Madison Avenue believed that Web video  also known as webisodes, online video and Web series  would replace television, or at least put a big dent into the ability of TV to reach consumers.

title: The World Is Your Oyster? Wrong
description: To thank me for helping them, my neighbors invited me for Sunday brunch. While we were dining, the waiter placed two dozen oysters on the table. My hosts told me they were just for the hostess, and I couldnt have any. I was dumbfounded!

title: Citing Recession, U.S. Again Presses China on Revaluing Currency
description: BEIJING  Chinas reluctance to allow the value of its currency to rise is a real concern to both the United States and the countrys other major trading partners and could be subject to negotiations in coming weeks, the American ambassador to China said on Thursday.

title: A Hands-On Approach to Health Care Reform
description: To audiences starved for quasi-medical gore, the gruesome Repo Men should help fill the void left by Nip/Tuck, the recently concluded FX series whose weekly ritual centerpiece showed the slicing of flesh (with perky musical accompaniment) in the cause of beauty . The blood count is higher in Repo Men, a dystopic satire, adapted from Eric Garcias novel The Repossession Mambo (Mr. Garcia wrote the screenplay with Garrett Lerner) and set 20 years in the future in a generically grungy megalopolis.

title: High-Octane Offense Takes Mercyhurst to Womens Frozen Four
description: More than any other player on the top-ranked Mercyhurst College womens ice hockey team, center Vicki Bendus struggles to juggle the hours in her day.

title: Leaving Office Early, at a Cost to Taxpayers
description: Democracy is a form of worship, H. L. Mencken said at his acerbic best. It is the worship of jackals by jackasses. And to think that Mencken, who died in Baltimore in 1956, reached that conclusion without the benefit of having observed politics as it is practiced these days in New York.

title: Germany Backtracks on Europe Rescue for Greece
description: After weeks of backing a European rescue for the financially troubled Greece, Germany shifted course on Thursday, signaling that help should come from the International Monetary Fund rather than Greeces neighbors.

title: Lost in Social Minefields Without a Proper Clue
description: Few moviegoers are as demanding as young readers confronted with a film adaptation of a book they love. The makers of the Harry Potter and Twilight franchises live in terror of the judgment of such audiences, who often demand literal fidelity to the text in question. The minor liberties and omissions of the recent movie version of The Lightning Thief provoked withering scorn, at least from a certain fifth grader I know. As for Diary of a Wimpy Kid  lets just say that its better that I went to the screening alone.

title: Two House Democrats Take Opposite Sides
description: Democratic lawmakers continued to stake out positions on the big health care legislation on Thursday.

title: Gov. Sanford Accepts Fine in Ethics Case
description: Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina agreed Thursday to pay $74,000 to settle charges that his personal travel and campaign spending violated state ethics laws, but he continued to deny wrongdoing.

title: Butler Takes a Page From Hoosiers
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Faced with a helter-skelter pace and case of the tournament jitters, the Butler Bulldogs took a deep breath and channeled their inner Jimmy Chitwood.

title: Polanski Appeal Alleges More Secret Dealings by Judge in 77 Case
description: LOS ANGELES  Lawyers for the film director Roman Polanski, under house arrest in Switzerland awaiting possible extradition to the United States, filed an appeals petition on Thursday revealing the existence of sealed testimony about secret dealings between high-ranking prosecutors and a judge in the directors 33-year-old sex crimes case.

title: More Teams Would Ruin a Great Thing
description: Providence, R.I.

title: A Flurry of Calls After a Paterson Aides Domestic Dispute
description: The dispute had ended, and his companion had called 911, saying she had been a victim of domestic violence. Sometime before 10 p.m. on Oct. 31, David W. Johnson left the Bronx apartment he shared with the woman and began making a series of phone calls.

title: Behind the New U.S. Terror Cases
description: Several terrorism cases in recent months have involved American citizens or residents, many from backgrounds that do not fit the expected profile of a jihadist.

title: A Return to Neil Youngs Stage
description: As concert documentaries go, both Neil Young: Heart of Gold (2006) and the new Neil Young Trunk Show are luxury goods. Beautifully lighted and meticulously recorded, they look and sound like several million bucks.

title: Lazio Goes After New Challenger in Governors Race
description: ALBANY  The campaign for the Republican nomination for governor was blown wide open on Thursday as the partys presumptive frontrunner, Rick A. Lazio, lost key support after a last-minute entry into the race by a conservative Long Island Democrat.

title: Many Calls for Avoiding a Repeat of Bank Bailouts
description: WASHINGTON  The idea of requiring giant banks to develop contingency plans that would spell out their orderly demise in a financial crisis gained support on Thursday from major international regulators.

title: Life Under a Tyrant, Even After Escaping
description: Mystery, violence, appalling repression, colorful spectacle, a dictator in a jumpsuit  its no wonder North Korea has become an increasingly popular subject for documentary makers. In Kimjongilia, the director, N. C. Heikin, sets herself apart by adding a new element to the mix: interpretive dance.

title: Play-by-Play Is Just Part of the Job at Cornell
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The Badger Network was set up and spread out over a courtside table at Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena. There was an array of digital boxes and a pile of headphones neatly in place when Cornells Barry Leonard rolled in with all of his gear, stuffed in one bag.

title: Bloomberg Is Quietly Ending a Charitable Program
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, New York Citys richest man and biggest philanthropist, is quietly pulling the plug on an unusual program that has poured nearly $200 million of his fortune into nonprofit groups across the five boroughs, in a sign of major change under way in his charitable giving plans.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 18, 2010

title: Safety Issues Linger as Nuclear Reactors Shrink in Size
description: MOSCOW  When the Soviet Union introduced its Alfa class submarine  at the time, the worlds fastest  the subs were the bane of American sailors. Now, the reactors that powered those submarines are being marketed as the next innovation in green power.

title: Pole Positions
description: It may not be an official Olympic sport yet, but tonight a group of artists will make the case that pole dancing isn't just an excuse for Carmen Electra to hawk an aerobic video on television or Elizabeth Berkeley to awkwardly dance on a movie screen. Beginning at 7:30 p.m. at Symphony Space, twelve of the best pole dancers in the United States will, according to the United States Pole Dancing Federation, "show off acrobatic skills and dance moves on 12-foot poles. All competitors perform with remarkable grace and technique, evidently showing the beauty of this sensual dance and fitness form." There is, surely to the disappointment of at least a few, absolutely no nudity involved.

title: Art Dealer Pleads Guilty in $120 Million Fraud Case
description: A once-prominent art dealer pleaded guilty on Thursday to a $120 million fraud scheme, admitting he sold paintings he did not own and at least once sold fractional shares of a painting that added up to more than 100 percent.

title: Barnes & Noble Promotes the Head of Its Web Division to Chief Executive
description: Determined to stake out a strong digital future, Barnes & Noble on Thursday named William Lynch, president of the companys Web division, as chief executive, succeeding Stephen Riggio, who will remain as vice chairman.

title: Donor to Democrats Pleads Guilty to $292 Million Fraud
description: A once-wealthy businessman and prominent donor to Democratic candidates pleaded guilty on Thursday to stealing hundreds of millions of dollars to buy property in Westchester County, donate to charity and give money to political campaigns.

title: Allons-y au Cin
description: All you Franco-cinephiles relax. It's not too late to catch one of the films in Rendez-Vous with French Cinema  the annual festival in its 15th year ends this weekend. "In a Gallic cinema renowned for its appreciation of women," writes Stephen Holden, "this year it is the men's turn in the spotlight." On Friday you can see one of the best, Vincent Lindon, in "Mlle. Chambon." In the film, "Mr. Lindon's character is a happily married mason who fights his attraction to his son's refined, violin-playing teacher (a fluttery Sandrine Kiberlain) whom he meets when he fixes a window in her home. This mild-mannered class study suggests a discreetly buttoned up 'Lady Chatterley's Lover.' "

title: Brooklyn Noise
description: The Brooklyn group Excepter "specializes in electronic diddles and jerky, mesmerizing noise compositions: this is the sound your stomach might make if you ate a computer," writes Amanda Petrusich. If that wasn't reason enough, go to hear Malkuth, Hidden Fees, Hey Breaker Quintet and D.J. Tres Ills, who will also be performing at Glasslands Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Saturday.

title: The Universe Up There
description: American space-flight technology has certainly changed in the almost 50 years since Alan Shepard went aloft, and so has filmmaking technology. But Hubble 3D, the latest Imax space movie, makes clear that one science has stood stubbornly still: that of the voice-overs for these types of documentaries.

title: Oversight Agency Bars Provident Brokerage Firm
description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said Thursday that it had expelled Provident Asset Management from the industry as part of a broader investigation into sales by brokers of unsuitable or fraudulent investments to retail customers.

title: Perez Gains Some Converts
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Here are three words you dont normally see in a sentence together: Oliver, Perez and consistency. Despite his reputation as an erratic pitcher, Perez is slowly starting to win converts, at least in the Mets clubhouse.

title: At Midnight, All the Doctors
description: Im a sleep doctor. Silence. There is a pause in the conversation, which is common.

title: Lehmans Demise, Dissected
description: What if the biggest rewards on Wall Street went to those who thwarted dangerous and excessive risk-taking instead of to those who enabled, approved or simply ignored it?

title: A Company Races to Keep a Drug Patent
description: It has been called a case of being a day late and a billion dollars short  potentially one of the costliest blunders in drug industry history. But a court decision this week might be a reprieve for the company involved.

title: Photographer, Camera, Subjects
description: They say you should never look directly into the sun  unless youre the star of a teeny-tiny indie and need an excuse to squint and experience visions. Such is the case with Alex Santiago (Nando Del Castillo, strongly recalling a young Peter Gallagher in looks if not acting skills), the dissatisfied fashion photographer at the heart of Shutterbug. Alex is the kind of narcissist who halts in the middle of a lovers tiff to take candid shots of his sputtering girlfriend; were I her, he wouldnt require the sun to make him see spots.

title: Hummels Slip Sent Purdue Sliding Down South Bracket
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  It looked like little more than a slip, a buckled knee and a player falling gently to the floor. There was little indication on Feb. 24 how much the season-ending injury to Purdues Robbie Hummel would have repercussions across college basketball.

title: Hostages at the Diner
description: A cheapie hostage drama with a lot more swagger than substance, The Killing Jar strains to wring tension from a tired premise and an airless script.

title: In Health Vote, Democrats Weigh Success vs. Survival
description: WASHINGTON  In the homestretch of the health care debate, one obvious question being asked across the capital is whether Speaker Nancy Pelosi will find 216 votes to pass the bill. For a group of particularly jittery Democrats, the better question may be this: Who will be allowed to slip away?

title: Clinton and Obama: High Profile Partners
description: President Obama surprised nearly everyone when he picked Hillary Rodham Clinton as his Secretary of State. But they again surprised nearly everyone by forging a partnership of sorts.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on March 6, 1945, for a photograph distributed by The Associated Press that became one of the most widely published images from World War II, described the scene incorrectly, according to new information provided by The A.P.

title: After a Bitter Campaign, Forging an Alliance
description: WASHINGTON  On a snowy Thursday shortly before her weekly meeting with President Obama last month, Hillary Rodham Clinton got a distressing phone call: her husband, Bill Clinton, was in a hospital with chest pains and needed an urgent heart procedure.

title: Woods Buildup Begins With a Familiar Image
description: Tiger Woods will be back on television this weekend during the Transitions Championship, bashing the air with a right-hand uppercut fist pump. The appearance will be brief, almost subliminal, but the statement will be unmistakable, the image powerful.

title: For Indias Newly Rich Farmers, Limos Wont Do
description: NOIDA, India  Bhisham Singh Yadav, father of the groom, is stressed. His rented Lexus got stuck behind a bullock cart. He has hired a truck to blast Hindi pop, but it is too big to maneuver through his village. At least his grandest gesture, evidence of his upward mobility, is circling overhead. The helicopter has arrived.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the effect of the financial crisis on sales of professional sports franchises misstated the amount Michael Jordan is paying to buy the Charlotte Bobcats of the National Basketball Association. It is $275 million  not $300 million, which is the sum Robert L. Johnson paid for the expansion team in 2002.

title: The Praise of Chimney-Sweepers
description: I never travel without my diary. One should always have something sensational to read in the train.

title: Two Families Are Drawn Together by Bouts With Cancer
description: BUFFALO  While out at the Church Street Tavern down the road from the University of Vermont after a February game, Matt Hahn, an assistant mens basketball coach with the Catamounts, got to talking with Jon Fjeld, the father of a player. Hahn, who helped recruit Fjelds son, Evan, had seen the elder Fjeld around town and knew he had a condominium by a nearby lake, where he and his wife, Susan, stayed.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on March 2 about an inquiry into a possible military coup attempt in Turkey that has highlighted the divide between the Islamic-inspired government and the countrys secular elite misspelled the given name of a Turkish preacher who leads an Islamic network that some critics say has undue influence on Turkish law-enforcement. He is Fethullah Gulen, not Fetullah.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a report by the Pew Center on the States on prison populations misstated two of the reports findings. The report found that as of Jan. 1, the population of state prisons was nearly four-tenths of one percent less than it had been a year ago, not 6 percent less. The report also found that in the same period the population of federal prisons rose by 3.4 percent, not by nearly 7 percent.

title: A Bronx Tale, With Bait
description: A professionally executed farce of the yelling-family variety, City Island revolves around a blue-collar clan with more secrets than filters. At the head of the table is Vince (Andy Garcia), a stolid corrections officer and clandestine acting student; facing him is Joyce (Julianna Margulies), the wife who wonders where the passion has gone. Add a daughter (Mr. Garcias real-life daughter, Dominik Garcia-Lorido) whos stripping instead of studying and a teenage son (Ezra Miller) who fantasizes about feeding doughnuts to fat women and you have a household that, even by current comedy standards, strains credulity.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on March 9 about a court hearing for a man brought to the United States from Nigeria on charges of aiding a Somali terrorist group, Al Shabab, misstated the year that it began fighting the Somali government. Various experts say that clashes began either in late 2006 or early 2007  not in 2004.

title: Music, Infused With Sorrow and Joy, in Honor of Migrant Dreamers
description: JOHANNESBURG  Hugh Masekela, the legendary trumpeter, blew his horn, sang with bluesy fervor and boogied across the stage on his puffy, 70-year old knees in his Songs of Migration, a revival of the music made by those who came from all over southern Africa to dig for gold and search for work here in the continents great boom town.

title: Arizona Drops Childrens Health Program
description: Arizona on Thursday became the first state to eliminate its Childrens Health Insurance Program when Gov. Jan Brewer signed an austere budget that will leave nearly 47,000 low-income children without coverage.

title: Northern Iowa Ekes One Out Against U.N.L.V.
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Northern Iowa had plenty of time to break a tie with one final shot, and for a few shaky moments as the Nevada-Las Vegas defense converged, it looked as if the Panthers might turn the ball over. Then the ball sailed to Ali Farokhmanesh.

title: Japanese Pitchers Could Beef Up Mets Staff
description: JUPITER, Fla.  One has a guaranteed contract and the other was invited to camp on a minor league deal, but both Ryota Igarashi and Hisanori Takahashi could end up playing critical roles for the Mets this year.

title: F.B.I. Faces New Setback in Computer Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has suspended work on parts of its huge computer overhaul, dealing the agency the latest costly setback in a decade-long effort to develop a modernized information system to combat crime and terrorism.

title: Photo Replay: March 18
description: A view of a day of upsets and tight games in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Irans Opposition Seeks More Help in Cyberwar With Government
description: At a time when the Obama administration is pressing for harsher sanctions against Iran for its nuclear program, democracy advocates in Iran have been celebrating the recent decision by the United States to lift sanctions on various online services, which they say only helped Tehran to suppress the opposition.

title: Turkey: 20 More Detained in Overthrow Plot
description: The police detained about 20 people on Thursday in a continuing investigation into a supposed plot to overthrow the government with the backing of the countrys powerful military. Active and retired military officers, as well as government workers, were among those detained, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency said. The investigation has reached out to once untouchable members of the military, along with secular power brokers, as suspects in a plan to overthrow the governing Justice and Development Party, which is rooted in political Islam. The army has strongly denied that it plotted a coup.

title: Two in Georgia Governors Race Were Accused of Misconduct
description: ATLANTA  Two former high school teachers running for governor in Georgia were suspended from their jobs in the past for sexual misconduct involving students, according to state documents.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about expansion plans of the cable company Discovery Communications misstated the financial performance of its international operations since David Zaslav became chief executive in January 2007. Revenue from Discoverys overseas business increased by about 30 percent during that period; it did not quadruple. (What nearly quadrupled was profit from international operations, which rose to $449.5 million for 2009, from $124.8 million for 2006.)

title: Lawsuit Cites Mishandling of Football Concussions
description: A former Arena Football League player filed a lawsuit Wednesday alleging that a team doctor mistreated his concussions two years ago, resulting in permanent injury.

title: Proposed Changes in the Final Health Care Bill
description: A look at key provisions of the Senate bill and the changes proposed in the reconciliation bill passed by the House Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Thursday about Ambroise Thomass Hamlet, at the Metropolitan Opera, misstated the number of years since it was last performed at the Met. It was 113 years ago, not 103.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday and in some editions on Monday about the actor Peter Graves misstated the history of the television series Fury, in which he starred. It ran from 1955 to 1960 on NBC, not from 1955 to 1959.

title: School Suspensions Lead to Legal Challenge
description: CHOCOWINITY, N.C.  As school let out one day in January 2008, students from rival towns faced off. Two girls flailed away for several seconds and clusters of boys pummeled each other until teachers pulled them apart.

title: Jordan Has the Bobcats; Now Its Rebuilding Time
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  With his $275 million purchase approved by the N.B.A. on Wednesday, Michael Jordan has become the new face of the Charlotte Bobcats. Now comes the hard part: he must remake the image of this troubled franchise both on the court and in the community, where fans have long been jaded about the league.

title: Thailand: Antigovernment Protesters Vow to Continue
description: Antigovernment demonstrators said Thursday that they would continue their protests at least through the weekend, as efforts to mediate a standoff with the government faltered. The protests, which have drawn tens of thousands of farmers and others, have prevented Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva, left, from entering his office. The protesters, known as the Red Shirts, are demanding that the government step down and that elections be called. They said they would parade through Bangkok on Saturday in large convoys of pickup trucks.

title: Washington Upsets Marquette on Last-Second Shot
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  A forgettable night for Quincy Pondexter turned into one with a memorable ending.

title: Big East Is a Bust on a Day of Buzzer Magic
description: PROVIDENCE , R.I.  Just over two decades ago, top-seeded Georgetown avoided N.C.A.A. tournament infamy here by escaping with a 1-point victory against No. 16 Princeton. It is a signature could-have-been moment in N.C.A.A. tournament history, as the No. 1-seeded Hoyas trailed in the final minute and were an Alonzo Mourning blocked shot from defeat.

title: SXSW: Two Takes on the Bronx
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The Bronx, billed as such, is a noisy post-punk band from East Los Angeles, crashing and squalling through hard-headed songs about outcasts and desperate people. But it has an alter ego: Mariachi El Bronx, which released an album last year and showed up Wednesday night at Emos in traditional embroidered mariachi costumes with traditional instruments, from trumpet to guitarron. It performs the Bronxs repertory, but with long-lined melodies and the rhythms of Mexican rancheras and sones. It turns out that Matt Caughtran, the Bronxs lead singer, doesnt have to shout; he can carry a tune. And the Bronx taps a side of Los Angeles that many rock bands ignore.

title: Kentucky Slams Its Way Into Second Round
description: NEW ORLEANS  Before halftime, top-seeded Kentucky had turned the game into a dunkathon. During a 54-second span against overmatched No. 16-seed East Tennessee State, the Wildcats had alley-oops on three consecutive possessions that caused their rabid fans to roar.

title: Despite Gains, Charter School Is Told to Close
description: ALBANY  Accountability is a mantra of the charter school movement. Students sign pledges at some schools to do their homework, and teachers owe their jobs to students gains on tests.

title: 2 Senators Offer Immigration Overhaul
description: Two senators, a Democrat and a Republican, unveiled the outlines on Thursday of a proposal to overhaul the immigration system, which would require illegal immigrants to admit they broke the law before they could gain legal status and require all workers in the United States to carry a biometric identity card to prove that they are eligible to work.

title: Decades Later, Guilty Plea in a 1968 Airline Hijacking
description: On Nov. 24, 1968, Luis Armando Pea Soltren boarded a plane to Puerto Rico at Kennedy Airport. Two hours into the flight, he grabbed a flight attendant and held the blade of a pocketknife to her neck.

title: Notes on Vazquez, Crawford and Jeter
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Carlos Pena of the Rays was 0 for 21 when he stepped to the plate in the second inning on Thursday night at Steinbrenner Field. The Yankees Javier Vazquez dropped his arm angle on a fastball, leaving the pitch too far inside, and Pena pounded it over the right-field wall.

title: Public Hospitals in Miami Tackle Deficit With Pain
description: MIAMI  After warning two weeks ago that it would run out of money within weeks, Miamis public hospital group has cobbled together a stabilization plan that will keep most services intact through the end of September.

title: The Changes in Texass School Curriculum
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Vacancies at the Fed
description: With three of seven seats to fill on the Federal Reserves Board of Governors, President Obama has an opportunity to put the economy in the hands of experts untainted by the failures that led to the financial crisis. In the process, he can help restore public confidence in the Fed as steward of the economy.

title: What to Do When Groupthink Leads to Gridlock
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel and America: A Time of Friction
description: To the Editor:

title: Why We Reform
description: One way or another, the fate of health care reform is going to be decided in the next few days. If House Democratic leaders find 216 votes, reform will almost immediately become the law of the land. If they dont, reform may well be put off for many years  possibly a decade or more.

title: The Broken Society
description: The United States is becoming a broken society. The public has contempt for the political class. Public debt is piling up at an astonishing and unrelenting pace. Middle-class wages have lagged. Unemployment will remain high. It will take years to fully recover from the financial crisis.

title: Upgrading Water Projects: A View From the Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Verge of Reform
description: The best chance in decades of fixing this countrys broken health care system has now come down to whether the Houses Democratic majority will approve the already strong Senate version of the bill  with a promise of some changes.

title: In This (or That) Corner, From Long Island
description: On election night 2005, a beaming Steve Levy stood in a raucous catering hall, soaking in the joy of stunning victories for his Democratic Party. Voters across Long Island had finally tired of Republican misrule and were tossing out its candidates left and right.

title: From Scandal to Example in West Virginia
description: In 2004, the chief executive of a large coal company spent an appalling $3 million to help elect a judge in West Virginia  a campaign that spotlighted the need to reform the way states elect judges. In 2010, the State Legislature there has approved a pilot program of voluntary public financing for two State Supreme Court elections in 2012.

title: One Classroom, From Sea to Shining Sea
description: AMERICAN public education, a perennial whipping boy for both the political right and left, is once again making news in ways that show how difficult it will be to cure what ails the nations schools.

title: A Guilty Plea to 2 Terrorism Charges
description: CHICAGO  A Chicago man pleaded guilty on Thursday to helping plan the terrorist attacks in Mumbai, India, that killed 163 people in 2008.

title: The Many Limbs of Jud
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  A Jud Heathcote love fest broke out this week in Spokane, Wash. Heathcote was the longtime Michigan State coach who led the Spartans (with a gangly guard named Earvin Johnson) to a national championship in 1979.

title: Correction
description: An article in last Sundays Bay Area pages about the Sunday routine followed by Willie L. Brown Jr., the former mayor of San Francisco, misspelled the name of a performer he enjoyed watching. The name of the performer is Bud E. Luv, not Buddy Love.

title: Tobacco Rule Proposed in 95 to Go Into Effect
description: WASHINGTON  Fifteen years after the Food and Drug Administration first proposed banning the sale and marketing of tobacco products to teenagers, top government officials announced Thursday that they would finally put the rule into effect.

title: As Snowboarders Soar, So Does Concern
description: STRATTON, Vt.  One of the uglier crashes of Scotty Lagos snowboarding career occurred last summer during a halfpipe competition in New Zealand. While attempting a Cab 1080  a spin of three rotations  Lago struck his upper body hard on the lip of the halfpipe, sending his hat (he was not wearing a helmet) and goggles flying. He fell 20 feet to the bottom of the pipe, striking the back of his head, and tumbling to a stop.

title: Bill Proposes Increased Aid to the Needy for College
description: The federal government would provide $36 billion in new financing for Pell grants to needy students over the next 10 years under legislation announced Thursday by Congressional Democrats.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Bruins Beat on Cooke but Lose Badly
description: Eleven games on Thursday night, including the game in Boston, at which the Bruins were expected to visit retribution upon the Penguins Matt Cooke for his blindside, concussion-causing hit on Marc Savard 11 days earlier. The Boston writers were certainly calling for blood. Would there be? Home teams listed first:

title: War Memorials With Neatly Made Beds
description: Karina Laus bedroom has not changed. A stuffed teddy bear and floppy-eared rabbit sit on top of her floral bedspread. Angel figurines and framed family photos line her bookshelf and dresser.

title: Rangers Miss a Chance to Gain Some Ground
description: Paul Kariyas best days are behind him, but on Thursday at Madison Square Garden he scored a big goal for the St. Louis Blues that damaged the Rangers increasingly fragile playoff chances.

title: Push to Test for H.G.H. Intensifies
description: The push for the blood testing of athletes was front and center in two sports Thursday, with two championship boxers agreeing to undergo such testing and Major League Baseball reiterating that it was moving forward to do the same in its minor leagues.

title: Nonprofits Add Mentoring to Money to Keep Minorities in College
description: As college admissions season draws to a close, the spotlight has been on students getting a foot in the door. Less attention is paid to how many of todays high school seniors will emerge a few years down the line with diplomas in hand, and what might cause them to veer off track.

title: Many Calls for Avoiding Repeat of Bank Bailouts
description: The idea of requiring giant banks to develop contingency plans that would spell out their orderly demise in a financial crisis is gaining support from major international regulators, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: A Financial Aid Package That Includes Mentoring
description: The New York Timess San Francisco pages on Friday carry a feature article about the East Bay College Fund. It is a nonprofit organization that awards low-income college students $16,000 over four years and provides mentoring to ensure those students go on to graduate.

title: Kansas Puts Away Pesky Lehigh
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Every time Kansas Coach Bill Self got mad at his team Thursday  which was a lot more than expected  he would punctuate the point by hitching up his trousers. Lehigh, its No. 16 seed notwithstanding, did plenty to make Self look mighty uncomfortable.

title: Idaho: Suit Against Ashcroft Proceeds
description: A federal appeals court declined to block a lawsuit seeking to hold former Attorney General John Ashcroft liable for the 2003 arrest of a man under the material-witness statute. Mr. Ashcroft had asked the full United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to rehear a 2009 decision by a three-judge panel in the case of Abdullah al-Kidd, a convert to Islam who spent 16 days in detention in 2003 and more than a year under court supervision. In a concurring opinion, Judge Milan D. Smith Jr. called the treatment of Mr. al-Kidd, former University of Idaho running back who was born Lavoni T. Kidd, "chilling." Eight of the 25 judges who voted signed dissents opposing the decision, which suggests that the United States Supreme Court might take an interest in the case if Mr. Ashcroft appeals.

title: Fess Parker, Who as Davy Crockett Set Off Coonskin Cap Craze, Dies at 85
description: Fess Parker, whose television portrayal of the American frontiersman Davy Crockett catapulted him to stardom in the mid-1950s and inspired millions of children to wear coonskin caps in one of Americas greatest merchandising fads, died on Thursday at his home in the Santa Ynez Valley in California, where he ran a successful winery. He was 85.

title: With Ban on H.I.V. Immigrants Now History, Relief and Revision
description: John Newman fondly recalled the eight years he taught first and second grades in Vallejo public schools  he felt appreciated, and was once named Teacher of the Year. It was the 1990s, before he got sick and was told to leave the United States.

title: Alex Chilton, Influential Rock Singer, Dies at 59
description: Alex Chilton, a mercurial rock musician whose work ranged from the soul songs of the Box Tops to the multiple incarnations of his pop band Big Star, and who left a legacy more easily measured in artistic influence than in commercial impact, died on Wednesday in New Orleans, where he had been living since the 1980s. He was 59.

title: Tennessee Wins Ugly Against San Diego State
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  When Bruce Pearl arrived at Tennessee, he did so in a whirl of up-tempo basketball and high-scoring performances. The Vols have made the N.C.A.A. tournament in five consecutive years under Pearl, although this edition isnt going to rekindle any memories of those run-and-gun teams.

title: Word of the Day | seep
description: seep \sep\ verb

title: Forget Illinois Shutout; Relive Tourneys Past
description: Illinois, the entire state, not just the big university, is 0 for the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament this year. What in the name of George Mikan is going on? A state that prides itself on being the Fertile Crescent of basketball talent  from Cazzie Russell and Isiah Thomas to Dwyane Wade  is shut out of the college games showcase event? What are the odds that every one of Illinoiss 12 Division I basketball schools would sit out this years tournament? Texas, where basketball is a time-killing diversion between football and spring football, has seven schools playing. Hoops hotbeds New Mexico and Utah have two apiece. Our neighbor to the east, with half our population, has three teams playing, and the fabled Indiana Hoosiers arent one of them.

title: Congo: Soldiers Seize Wounded Patients at Gunpoint
description: Government soldiers barged into a hospital in eastern Congo last week, harassed medical workers and removed four wounded patients at gunpoint, Doctors Without Borders[ON] said Thursday. Eastern Congo has recently been hit by an uptick in clashes between government and rebel forces. According to the organization the soldiers accused three patients of being rebels (the fourth was apparently a civilian). "This incident is a violation of basic humanitarian principles; all sick and wounded have the right to medical care," said Philippe Havet, the head of the group's local mission. "After this serious incident, I am afraid they will never be convinced that it is safe for them to seek any medical help." JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

title: One-Liner Childhoods
description: A new Facebook group was formed last summer, well before  Parenthood,  a television series set in Berkeley, made its debut on NBC this month. The group, called Your Mom Is So Berkeley, began as an inside joke among friends who grew up there and came up with one-liners about Berkeley mothers, said Roberto Santiago, 33, the pages creator.

title: Pittsburgh Looks to Raise Profile With N.C.A.A. Run
description: MILWAUKEE  In assessing the profile of the Pittsburgh Panthers basketball team, consider the sports competition in their Steel City.

description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  On a day when the N.C.A.A. tournament put the madness back in March, it did not seem to matter to New Mexico that it nearly frittered away a 14-point lead, that the star forward Darington Hobson injured his wrist or that the Lobos did not score a basket from the field over the final seven minutes.

title: Finding Faith While Making Fine Kosher Wine
description: Jeff Morgan, an author, educator and winemaker in Napa Valley, produces Covenant cabernet sauvignon, Californias finest kosher wine. Covenant, the creation of Mr. Morgan and his backer, Leslie Rudd, began as a challenge. In 2002, the two, both nonpracticing Jews, were at a fund-raiser for a synagogue in Napa when Mr. Rudd asked, Why are kosher wines so bad?

title: Jets Re-Sign Safety Smith
description: Safety Eric Smith signed a one-year tender offer with the Jets worth $1.176 million, keeping him in the competition with the recently signed Brodney Pool and James Ihedigbo to replace Kerry Rhodes in the Jets secondary.

title: Helping Those Who Reach College Get Through
description: According to data from the Oakland Unified School District, just 8 percent of black teenagers entering ninth grade will get a bachelors degree. Only 34 percent of black male students and 44 percent of Latino male students who entered the combined University of California and California State University system in 2001 had graduated six years later. The rate for white men was 62 percent.

title: Time Warner Said to Mull 2nd Bid for MGM
description: Time Warner is considering make a second-round bid of up to $1.5 billion for storied Hollywood studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer ahead of a March 19 deadline, a source familiar with the situation told Reuters on Thursday.

title: What Do You Know About Teen Depression?
description: In reaction to the news about three apparent suicides at Cornell University, the Motherlode blog has posted a Q & A with an expert on the topic of teen depression. Do you know what signs to look for? Can you tell the difference between ordinary teen angst and a more serious condition? What questions do you have?

description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said Thursday that it had expelled Provident Asset Management from the industry as part of a broader investigation into sales by brokers of unsuitable or fraudulent investments to retail customers, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Spun Gold
description: To make the finest suit in the world, you first need the finest wool. Hence Ermenegildo Zegnas Vellus Aureum award, an annual contest organized by the storied Italian suit-making family to find the highest-quality merino wool on the planet. (Vellus Aureum means Golden Fleece in Latin; the prize-winning wool grower receives its fleeces equivalent weight in gold.) Now celebrating its 100-year anniversary, Zegna has woven together samples of the competitions top fleeces since 2002 to create one of the lightest fabrics ever worn: the lots fibers measure 11.1 microns on average, while a human hair averages a whopping 100 microns. Obviously limited by supply (only about 200 feet of cloth is produced) to an edition of 20 and retailing at $22,500, each made-to-order Centennial Vellus Aureum suit takes 18-plus hours to create and passes through more than 330 pairs of hands. Is this the ultimate in mens-wear luxury? Anna Zegna, the image director of the brand, asks rhetorically. Oh, we certainly think so. More

title: Art Dealer Pleads Guilty in $120 Million Fraud Case
description: A once-prominent art dealer pleaded guilty on Thursday to a $120 million fraud scheme, admitting he sold paintings he did not own and at least once sold fractional shares of a painting that added up to more than 100 percent, The New York Timess James Barron reported.

description: Lloyds Banking Group of Britain said on Friday that it expected to report a profit this year, as trading had so far been strong and provisions for bad assets were not as large as previously forecast, The Associated Press reported.

title: Nordic Noir and the Welfare State
description: Todays idea: The shortcomings of the Scandinavian welfare state are central to the Nordic crime fiction now enjoying worldwide popularity, an article says. And the critique comes largely from the left.

description: MOSCOW  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Friday that proposals offered by the Israeli government to settle a diplomatic dispute with the United States were useful and productive, though it was not clear how close Israel had come to meeting American demands.

description: Quite some time ago, I wrote about cooking a beautifully seared, perfectly rare steak without filling your neighborhood with smoke . Its time for the other shoe to drop: the french fries.

description: The city of 100 spires is Pragues best-known moniker. But in a still-chilly March, you might prefer to explore the citys plentiful pasazes, pedestrian shortcuts that boast an improving array of shops, cafes and clubs.

title: Tip of the Week: Cleaning Win7
description: If you want to regularly free space on a PC running Windows 7 system with a minimum of effort, schedule the Disk Cleanup utility to run automatically. Go to the Start menu, to Control Panel and click on System and Security. Click on Administrative Tools, double-click on Task Scheduler and type in your administrator password.

description: The separation of the investment banking and research departments of large lenders just got weaker, according to The Wall Street Journal.

description: If you wanted to assemble a group of collectible cars like an Olympic dream team, it might resemble the show of 18 vehicles included in The Allure of the Automobile, which opens at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta on Sunday.

description: Apax Partners has been in discussions with Polycom, the largest independent videoconferencing equipment firm, about a buyout that could value the company at more than $3 billion, The Financial Times reported.

description: When Ron Dennis left the job of team principal of the McLaren team last year, he said that he would henceforth concentrate on the McLaren Groups plans to build a new sports car.

title: Sampler: Bay Area Home Prices Rise, and San Francisco Fights Proposition 16
description: A Plan for the University of California to Handle Prison Medicine | The University of California would benefit by taking charge of an overhaul of the states prison medical system and creating a centralized system of managed care, according to a report by NuPhysicia, a Texas consultant hired by the state. An estimated $12 billion could be saved over the next decade with the plan, which includes allowing doctors to have access to patient information anywhere and also to see patients via video, state officials said. This is definitely a wholesale reform of the prison health-care system, said Susan Kennedy, Gov. Arnold Schwarzeneggers chief of staff. [The Los Angeles Times]

title: Arrow Energy Suspends Shares as Offer Looms
description: Arrow Energy of Australia asked for trading in its shares to be suspended on Friday, stoking speculation that Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina would sweeten their joint offer for the coal-seam gas producer, Reuters reports.

title: Taliban Arrests Have Halted Early Talks, Former Envoy Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The former top United Nations official in Afghanistan said that recent arrests of high-ranking Taliban figures by Pakistan had severed important secret communications between the Taliban and the West meant to foster peace negotiations.
