description: President Obama and Congressional leaders have vowed to enact the farthest reaching overhaul of financial regulation since the Depression.

title: Steve Roach Goes Batty
description: Ahem.

title: Where Nowhere Is a Crowded Place
description: For about three hours on Thursday night, the intersection of Grand and Greene Streets in SoHo became the crossroads of civilization of a certain sort. Around 1,000 art lovers deluged the opening night party for the latest exhibition by the photographer Ryan McGinley, according to fire officials, who shuttered the gallery while outside, police dispersed the chic hordes.

title: Dows Winning Streak Screeches to a Halt
description: The Dow Jones industrial average was stopped in its tracks on Friday as it tried for a ninth consecutive session of gains, a feat last achieved in 1996.

description: The 72-hour clock has been ticking since early Thursday afternoon, when Democrats released the Congressional Budget Office score and language for their new health care bill. With just over 48 hours before Sundays expected vote, President Obama will give one more health care pep talk at George Mason University late this morning.

title: Who Woulda Punkd It?
description: Menzie Chinn wonders what constitutes a punk staffer, after John Boehner told bankers, Dont let those little punk staffers take advantage of you and stand up for yourselves.

description: One of the biggest culprits in office electricity use may be hiding just under your desk. The fastest way to chew power up is to plug in a space heater, said Michael Cation, the chief executive of the energy efficiency company, Smartebuilding, in an interview in Austin, Tex.

title: 40 Years After a Hijacking, a Guilty Plea
description: On Nov. 24, 1968, Luis Armando Pea Soltren boarded a plane to Puerto Rico at Kennedy Airport. Two hours into the flight, he grabbed a flight attendant and held the blade of a pocketknife to her neck.

title: Off the Menu: Kenmare
description: Joey Campanaro of Little Owl and Market Table is set to open Kenmare in NoLIta on March 22. Located in what used to be Civetta, the two-story space has been given a lighter, Mediterranean look with pale stucco, to reflect Mr. Campanaros menu of dishes like basil gnocchi with short rib ragout, veal cutlet with salsa verde and crispy halibut with chive mashed potatoes.

title: The Daily Show WithGlenn Beck?
description: Were getting dangerously close to threes-a-trend territory, people. Not two months after Jimmy Kimmel performed an entire episode of Jimmy Kimmel Live in the guise of his late-night rival Jay Leno, Jon Stewart devoted the better part of Thursdays Daily Show to an extended impersonation of his Fox News adversary Glenn Beck.

title: Prison, Day 1
description: On a dreary February morning in 2004, my fianc, Larry, and I pulled into the parking lot of the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury, Conn. After years of legal proceedings and more than a decade after I committed a reckless drug-related crime, I was there, at age 34, to surrender myself to the federal government. Before we got out of the car, I stripped off all my jewelry  my seven thin gold engagement rings; the sapphire ring, a family heirloom; the 1950s mans watch that was always around my wrist; all the earrings from the extra holes in my right ear that so vexed my grandfather. I wore jeans, sneakers and a long-sleeved T-shirt. With false bravado I said, Lets do this.

title: Dr. Sunshine
description: In your new book, The Vitamin D Solution, you argue that we have become a culture of sun phobes who fear exposure to direct sunlight and slather on too much sunscreen, which you believe has caused a national epidemic of vitamin D deficiency.  Dermatologists have gone so far as to recommend that you should never walk outside without a sunscreen. The American Academy of Dermatology still has that recommendation that you should never be exposed to one ray of direct sunlight without sun protection.

title: Beep!
description: The beep is an ingenious creation. Like the railroad toot but unlike an old telephone ring, beeps have both a distinct start and finish, marked by the twin plosives b and p, and an elastic center that can generously expand and contract like an accordion: beeeeeeeep. You can create Morse code in beeps. Beeeep beep beep beep. Beep. Beep. Beep beeeep beeeep beep.

description: A shiny new crop of baubles. More

title: I.M.F. Chief Calls for Fire Brigade to Aid European Banks
description: PARIS  Europe should have a fire brigade backed by funds from governments and the private sector to deal with failures of large banks, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund said Friday.

title: No
description: Two of the most basic words in the English language, yes and no, are locked in a constant struggle, embodying abstract forces of agreement and opposition, positivity and negativity, acceptance and denial. Just look at the recent Congressional wrangling over health care reform, where the words have come to stand for much more than simply the up or down votes that legislators may cast. Democrats seeking a final compromise over health care legislation have talked optimistically about getting to yes. I just wish and hope some of my colleagues will be willing to help us get to yes on this, Senator Mark Warner of Virginia said. And a House leadership aide told The Huffington Post, We do have an environment where people can now get to yes.

title: When to Call the Police
description: As the general manager of a local eatery, I discovered that a server was defrauding us. When I confronted him, he didnt actually confess but did offer to repay his ill-gotten gains. I fired him. Must I also report him to the police? Some people have said losing this job is punishment enough, but I think he will steal again at his next restaurant job. Your thoughts? P.S., COLUMBIA, MD.

title: Stressful but Vital: Picking a Nursing Home
description: The decision is one of the hardest you will ever make. Your spouse, parent or another loved one needs care that assisted living or home health care simply cannot provide. You need to choose a nursing home.

title: Consumers Buy More Efficient Refrigerators, but Keep the Old Ones Humming
description: Each year millions of Americans with old, inefficient refrigerators in their kitchens buy new, energy saving ones. That may sound like an efficiency boon, but whats vexing efficiency advocates is that an increasing number of consumers dont actually get rid of the old fridge.

title: Sophisticated Travelers With No Place to Go
description: There is a certain knack for spotting an airport vagrant. He may be well dressed, striding urgently, with neat luggage in tow. He may be a familiar sight  perhaps too familiar.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Force Runs Strong in My Family
description: Two new books this week: The Invincible Iron Man, Vol. 1, enters the hardcover list at No. 3 and Star Wars: Legacy, Vol. 8, lands on the paperback list at No. 8. The Invincible Iron Man collects the first six issues of a new monthly comic book devoted to the armored hero. In the first adventure, he faces off against Ezekiel Stane, an evil genius with Iron Man technology at his disposal. (Hes also the son of Obadiah Stane, the villain in the first Iron Man film, so you know hes got a bone to pick.)

title: Californias New $5,000 E.V. Rebates: Grab Em Fast
description: The good news for California residents is that they can get a rebate of up to $5,000 if they buy a battery electric or plug-in hybrid car in the next few months. The bad news is that theres not a lot to choose from because many of the vehicles, like the Chevrolet Volt, Nissan Leaf and Fisker Karma, wont be available until the end of the year. By then the $4.1 million allocated in the innovative state program may be exhausted, but more cash is probably on the way.

title: The Optimists Blogger
description: In February 2001, a Brown University graduate with the improbably suave name Lockhart Steele took up occupancy in a one-bedroom third-floor walk-up apartment on Rivington Street, near the intersection with Ludlow. The Lower East Side could still claim, just barely, to be a marginal neighborhood. Storefront synagogues and housing projects were still more typical than bars with ostentatiously unmarked doors. The neighborhood was a good fit for Lockhart Steele: they were both, as they say, in transition.

title: Icahn Seeks to Buy All of Lions Gate
description: Carl C. Icahn said on Friday that he was now seeking to acquire all of Lions Gate Entertainment, expanding a tender offer for the film company that originally sought only to expand his stake to 29.9 percent.

title: Friday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

description: What are some easy ways I can transform my home?

title: I.M.F. Chief Suggests Fire Brigade for Europes Banks
description: Europe should have a fire brigade backed by funds from governments and the private sector to deal with failures of large banks, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund said Friday, The New York Timess Matthew Saltmarsh reports from Paris.

title: A Stake in the Sand
description: The sands found Destin first. They started off eons ago, from the Appalachian Mountains, washing their way down the rivers that flow into the Gulf of Mexico. Winnowed to pure, hardy quartz, the sediment moved with the gulfs currents and gathered into the necklace of narrow barrier islands that buffer Floridas Panhandle. Time and tides refined the sand into a soft, sun-bleached powder. By the 1830s, when a Yankee sea captain named Leonard Destin sailed down to the wilderness of the Florida Territory, he discovered beaches as dazzling and white as a fresh blanket of snow. The sight evidently impressed the captain, for his reaction  like that of so many migrants who followed  was to claim a piece of the shore. Destin landed, built a New England Colonial-style house and started a fishing business, becoming the first recorded white settler in the beach town that now bears his name.

title: Inside the List

Chelsea Chelsea Bang Bang, a fresh collection of steaming dish from the comedian Chelsea Handler, blocks Karl Roves Courage and Consequence out of the top spot, while Daniel G. Amens Change Your Brain, Change Your Body lands at No. 3. (Hmm, theres got to be a mash-up in there somewhere.)

title: British Airways Strike Begins, Threatening a Weak Economy
description: LONDON  A three-day strike by some employees of British Airways began Saturday, posing another possible blow to Britains battered economy.

title: Complaint Box | Car Decals
description: I started noticing them a few years ago. They were stuck onto the rear windows of cars and sport utility vehicles, white oval stickers reading OBX. It was puzzling to me. What was OBX? An exclusive private school? A secret society? These letters were all over Bergen County, and inquiring minds (my own) wanted to know: What was OBX and how could I get some?

title: The Singing Hamlet: The French Exception
description: To the Editor:

title: Its a Guy Thing
description: Guys, weve got your playbook. All this time, weve been operating under the mistaken assumption that you were choosing to get all belligerent every time our college boyfriend called, or to tune us out as your eyes became glued to the waitresss breasts showcased in a T-shirt two sizes too small. It stood to reason, we thought, that you could simply choose otherwise, provided, of course, that you wanted to. Now, however, thanks to Louann Brizendine, M.D., author of The Male Brain (Broadway Books), we understand that choosing otherwise isnt an option, because evolution has outfitted you with a brain that is, biologically speaking, not the same model as the one we were issued. (Brizendines Female Brain was published in 2006, should you ever get the urge to consult it.)

title: Correction: Beyond the Jimi Hendrix Experience
description: An article on Feb. 28 about Jimi Hendrix misstated, based on information from Janie Hendrix, the president and chief executive of Experience Hendrix, the nature of the plans for a Rock Band video game featuring music by Hendrix. The makers of the video game say they are currently in discussion to bring more of his music to our platform; there is currently no plan to release a version of Rock Band devoted to Hendrix.

title: Correction: Week Ahead
description: A television entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday about Ugly Americans on Comedy Central misstated the name of a similar television show. It is The Life and Times of Tim, not The Life and Death of Tim.

title: Correction: Week Ahead
description: A pop entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday misstated the name of the song Michael Bubl performed during the closing ceremony of the Winter Olympics. It was The Maple Leaf Forever, not O Canada.

title: SXSW: Mosh Pits on a Bridge at 3 a.m.
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Should we just keep playing until the cops come? John Dwyer, the floppy-haired frontman of Thee Oh Sees, said about halfway into the groups set atop the Lamar Boulevard Pedestrian Bridge. It was after 3 a.m., and the crowd fist-pumped its assent, so Mr. Dwyer bent over his guitar, the lights of downtown flickering behind him, Lady Bird Lake below.

title: Who Put the Gaga in Lady Gaga? Producer Says He Did
description: Fresh from her prison stint in the video for Telephone, Lady Gaga could soon be headed to court  not to face any number of angry grindhouse filmmakers whose works inspired that video, but a lawsuit from a songwriter and producer who says hes the one who gave her that famous stage name. The Associated Press reported that Rob Fusari, who helped write Lady Gaga songs including Paparazzi and Beautiful, Dirty, Rich, filed a $30.5 million lawsuit against the singer, saying she has frozen him out of her career as she has become more successful. Mr. Fusari, who has also worked on hit songs like Will Smiths Wild, Wild West and Destinys Childs Bootylicious, said in his suit that he was first introduced to the singer Stefani Germanotta in 2006, helping to guide her from a rock musician to a dance artist and nicknaming her Lady Gaga, from the Queen song Radio Ga Ga. He said he had received more than $600,000 from Lady Gaga but had not received his full share of song royalties, merchandising revenue and other fees. Representatives for Lady Gaga have not yet responded to the suit, which was filed in a state court in Manhattan.

title: Correction: Street Art Thats Finding a New Address
description: An article on March 7 about the emergence of artists in the Pop Pluralism movement misstated the name of a clothing store in San Francisco that houses a chandelier by Adam Wallacavage. It is RVCA, not RVKA.

title: The Road Not Taken by Marylands Vasquez
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Greivis Vasquez once thought he would spend his college career here. Instead, Spokane could be where it ends.

title: The Soft Steps of Diplomacy
description: Grahamstown, South Africa

title: Boccieri to Vote Yes
description: Under a blazing morning sun that left reporters squinting on the East Front of the Capitol, Representative John Boccieri of Ohio on Friday morning became the latest Democrat to announce that he would support the big health care legislation after opposing the House bill in November.

title: SXSW: A Party in a Parking Lot
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  On Thursday we had a little work to send back to the real world, but the music came and found us. Typing on the patio of the San Jose Hotel, a mile or more away from the heart of SXSW, we heard what sounded like a noisy, well-sung fairy tale spilling over the wall at about 2 p.m. An investigation turned up a minifestival in the parking lot, where Morning Teleportation was playing.

title: Gheorghiu to Substitute for Netrebko in Saturdays La Bohme
description: If youve ever been frustrated by an 11th-hour substitution at the Metropolitan Opera in which a star performer is suddenly replaced by one of seemingly lesser caliber, it may be harder to complain about this particular late change to the lineup: on Friday the Met said Angela Gheorghiu would sing the role of Mimi in Saturday afternoons performance of La Bohme. She is stepping in for Anna Netrebko, who is ill, the Met said. Ms. Gheorghiu, the Romanian soprano, withdrew from the Mets Richard Eyre-directed production of Carmen amid marital problems with her husband, the tenor Roberto Alagna, who starred in that opera; she said last month in a statement that she wanted to be as prepared dramatically as I am musically for the production. But there is evidently no bad blood between her and the Met; Ms. Gheorghiu is currently rehearsing for its coming production of La Traviata, which opens on March 29, and will sing the role of Juliette in Gounods Romo et Juliette for the Mets 2010-11 season.

title: When a Rented Unit Goes on the Market
description: Q.

title: Clean Tech Sector Thriving, Survey Finds
description: The recession has battered investors, but new data suggest that the clean technology sector was largely immune from the global economic collapse.

title: Higher Maintenance for Ground-Floor Unit
description: Q.

title: A Day for the Davids
description: We could spend the day waxing poetic about the beauty and splendor of the 65-team format of the N.C.A.A. tournament, about the charm of its inevitable underdogs and the lure of the bracket. But we dont have to. The first day of the first round of this years tournament did all the talking, whooping, hollering and joyful spilling onto the court for us.

title: E-Mail Evidence in Theft of Historic Letters
description: At the time, the near-dozen e-mail messages that William John Scott exchanged with a rare book dealer in Maryland last month seemed perfectly routine.

title: Acid Test
description: Bits of the Trickster were shot into orbit for the ultimate trip after his death at 75. The Seeker, 78, lives on Maui, where he has gone to die. The Teacher, now 90, finally published a memoir last year. And the Healer, 67, presides over an alternative-health empire, selling items like Weil by Natures Path Organic Banana Manna Pure Fruit and Nut Bars.

title: Good Luck Having a Sleepover Party
description: Q.

title: We Three Things | Head First
description: The Moment is proud to introduce We Three Things by Leanne Shapton, a roundup of three items from the current visual landscape that share a common theme. Shapton  a former art director of the New York Times Op-Ed page as well as an author (Important Artifacts and Personal Property From the Collection of Lenore Doolan and Harold Morris, Including Books, Street Fashion and Jewelry), illustrator and publisher  connects the dots.

title: PenFeds Promise Card: A Decent Product for Those in Debt
description: Over the last several months, many of the biggest credit card companies have raised interest rates and tested new annual fees on some products.

title: Obama Rallies Support for Health Bill in Virginia
description: At his final rally before a historic House vote on health care legislation, President Obama compared the overhaul to Social Security, civil rights and Medicare, and he urged Congress to complete a journey that began with Theodore Roosevelt.

title: How to Choose a Nursing Home
description: Todays Patient Money column explores one of the most wrenching decisions any family can face: choosing a nursing home for a parent, spouse or other loved one when home health care or assisted living is no longer an option. As Walecia Konrad writes:

title: The Sidewalk Ends, But Silversteins Poems Continue
description: The author who gave us The Giving Tree still has a little more left to give: a new volume of poetry and illustrations by Shel Silverstein, the writer and artist of Where the Sidewalk Ends, A Light in the Attic and Falling Up, will be published by HarperCollins Childrens Books in fall 2011, Publishers Weekly reported. Antonia Markiet, a senior executive editor at the imprint, said the new book will contain between 120 and 130 poems by Mr. Silverstein, none of which have been previously published. Ms. Markiet is among the editors who began working with Mr. Silverstein, who died in 1999, in the 1970s (when he was still better known as a writer of songs like A Boy Named Sue and an illustrator of Playboy cartoons that would never find their way into a childrens anthology), and previously edited the authors posthumously published 2005 childrens book Runny Babbit. She told Publishers Weekly that Mr. Silverstein had left a wealth of material in the archives, adding, So many fans still write to us and to Shels family saying how important his work is to them, that the family decided it was the right time to consider another book from that material.

title: Bloggingheads:  Al Qaeda and Afghanistan
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Matthew Hoh, a former State Department official, discuss the connection between Afghanistan and Al Qaeda.

title: The Ex-Husband Who Never Left
description: I SOMETIMES slip and call my ex-husband my husband.

title: Kiwi Captain Learned Premier League Defense in M.L.S.
description: Ryan Nelsen was five years old the last time New Zealand took part in the World Cup finals.

title: Up Front: Jill Abramson
description: During my reporting career in the 1980s and 1990s, journalists succeeded in clawing much further behind the curtain of the national political drama than before, Jill Abramson, The Timess managing editor for news and the author of this weeks feature essay, The Making of the President, Then and Now, recalled in an e-mail message.

title: Obamas Remarks on Overhauling Health Care
description: Following is a transcript of President Obama's remarks at George Mason University on Friday on the need to overhaul health care, as released by the White House:

title: March Madness: Using Tournament Brackets to Debate Academic Questions
description: Overview | How can the sports tournament bracket concept be applied to academic questions? How can competition enliven debate over perennial topics in your curriculum? In this lesson, students use the March Madness bracket structure to decide a question in their field of study, holding a research- and debate-based tournament to determine the winners of each round, until a final winner is declared. Along the way, they write essays about the last two topics standing, use the bracket to organize debates, and, perhaps, share their thoughts on N.C.A.A. tournament basketball.

title: Use Marriott Points for Anything
description: Dont have cash for that hot stone massage? Marriott will let you pay for it with points.

title: Editors Choice
description: BLACK HEARTS: One Platoons Descent Into Madness in Iraqs Triangle of Death,  by Jim Frederick (Harmony, $26.) A riveting account of the flawed leadership, bad luck and virulent personalities that led to the 2006 murder of an entire Iraqi family by American soldiers.

title: Video: Former Rivals Forge an Alliance
description: In The New York Times today, Helene Cooper and Mark Landler look at one of Washingtons most closely watched relationships: the one between President Barack Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton. What they found was a credible partnership. In an online video, these reporters recount some of the moments when these two frenemies inched closer together.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MEDIA RELATIONS DEPARTMENT OF HIZBOLLAH WISHES YOU A HAPPY BIRTHDAY: Unexpected Encounters in the Changing Middle East,  by Neil MacFarquhar.  (PublicAffairs, $15.95.) MacFarquhar, the United Nations bureau chief for The Times, grew up in a Libyan oil town and spent more than 13 years as a correspondent in the Middle East. His knowledge of Arabic and familiarity with the region give him a deep and nuanced understanding of its culture and politics. In this funny (yet penetrating) account about real Arabs, as Thanassis Cambanis described it in the Book Review, he nods to the prejudices about Middle Eastern fanatics and then sets off merrily to dispel them.

title: Democrats Woo Abortion Foes in Push for Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  House Democratic leaders late Friday were exploring the possibility of a deal with abortion opponents that would clinch the final votes to pass major health care legislation, but they faced stiff resistance from lawmakers who support abortion rights.

title: Can Strep Throat Lead to Behavior Problems?
description: Can a bout of strep throat lead to serious behavioral problems like obsessive hand washing or odd tics in children?

title: Case Puts Spotlight on Surrogates Court
description: When opening arguments start in Part 51 of State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Friday, a judge will be sitting in an unusual place: at the defense table.

title: Dutch Reject Claim That Srebrenica Fell Because of Gay Troops
description: Dutch officials have reacted with anger and bemusement to the claim by a retired American general that their nations soldiers failed to prevent the Srebrenica massacre in 1995 in part because the presence of gay troops in the Dutch military had depleted the forces morale.

title: Former Small-Business Owner in Congress to Back Health Care Bill
description: Representative Betsy Markey, an entrepreneur and freshman Democrat from Colorados 4th District, was apparently not swayed by this weeks Chamber of Commerce poll that claimed that her partys health care reform legislation was wildly unpopular among her constituents. On Thursday, Ms. Markey announced that she would back the Senate version of the legislation and the proposed modifications to it.

title: On Character: Bryan Cranston in Breaking Bad
description: Armed with a death sentence and the best meth in New Mexico, Walter White, the protagonist in AMCs Breaking Bad, has become one of the most celebrated characters on television since the series debuted in 2008.

title: Delta Expands Chicago-to-New York Shuttle
description: Starting June 10, Delta Shuttle will fly into Chicagos OHare Airport from La Guardia, expanding a popular route for business travelers. The shuttle will run 11 times daily, replacing less frequent service into Chicago Midway.

title: SXSW: The Beatles Meet the Ukulele
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Lets admit that I am not a huge fan of the Beatles or the ukulele, but the mash-up between the two at Jaimes seemed odd enough for a look on Thursday. Roger Greenawalt, a Brooklynite who has produced the likes of Ben Kweller and the Pierces, is also a ukulele aficionado. Reprising a Brooklyn caper in which he played 185 Beatles songs with 60 singers in 12 hours, he set up shop at SXSW to play the Beatles songbook over two days, this time with the Eggmen, an Austin band, and a number of special guests.

title: The Way Forward for Airgas
description: It will most likely be September. Thats when Airgas is now expected to have its next annual meeting, setting the stage for a showdown. Air Products and Chemicals, which is attempting to acquire Airgas, will attempt to elect its own short slate of directors to the Airgas board at this meeting.

title: Giving Up, but Also Taking On, for Lent
description: WASHINGTON  In his charcoal trousers and navy blazer, the uniform of decades as an executive, John Hisle waited for his 10 a.m. appointment to arrive.

title: The Originals | Rachel Chandler
description: I feel like Im really starting to learn something now, says Rachel Chandler, the 22-year-old New York-based photographer and D.J., of the few months since her recent college graduation. Chandler is developing into a latter-day Kiki de Montparnasse, spending much of her time gallivanting with an international art crowd, all the while making them dance and chronicling their capers in high-demand photos that are regularly featured in Purple Magazine and on Italian Vogues Web site. I know how to work a party, she says. Chandlers personal style is as eclectic as the tunes she spins: a Ralph Lauren cable knit sweater that once belonged to her mother, a mens Dries Van Noten overcoat stolen from an ex, Adidas track pants, her signature blue Belgian loafers. Well, of course I love Rei, Junya and Yohji, she says, but without my parents footing the bill anymore, I have to be resourceful.

title: Clean Your Closet for a Free iPad
description: In the 1960s, my uncle made a good living buying up slightly imperfect Levis and reselling them at a steep discount in poor countries.

title: Taxi-Fraud Refunds Are Unlikely, Mayor Says
description: Cheated riders hoping for refunds from the widespread taxi price gouging scheme may have a tough road ahead  at least according to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Democrat Enters N.Y. Governor Race as Republican
description: ALBANY  Fresh off an announcement that jolted the New York political world, Steve Levy, the Long Island Democrat who abandoned his party to run for governor as a Republican, is working to secure endorsements as he tries to gain an edge in the contest for the nomination.

title: Answers From a Film Scout, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of responses from Nick Carr, who for the past five years has worked as a film location scout in New York, combing the streets for every type of locale imaginable for use in feature films and television.

title: Letters: Tuscany for All Seasons
description: To the Editor: Regarding Tuscany Without the Crowds (March 7): In its catalog of great places to stay in the Val dOrcia, the article didnt mention the beautiful and reasonably priced monastery of SantAnna in Camprena (www.camprena.it), near Pienza. Built in the 15th century and now gracefully restored as an agriturismo, its where the Italian segments of The English Patient were filmed. Last June I spent a wonderful, crowd-free week there for 60 euros (about $80) a night, including breakfast. All the rooms (many of them former monks cells) have splendid views and private baths, and guests have the run of the monasterys garden and grounds. An extra 20 euros buys you a delicious four-course dinner with a jug of wine.

title: FlashForward Watch: Simon Says
description: This post contains spoilers.

description: Marten Mickos, the former chief executive of MySQL, will soon be named the chief executive of Eucalyptus, another open-source software maker.

title: Some Great Matchups
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: You guys excited for March Madness? Had some great matchups so far. B.Y.U. versus Florida. Old Dominion versus Notre Dame. Obama versus Fox News.

title: He Will Vote Yes
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Yesterday was St. Patricks Day. Republicans are now working on declaring March 18 as St. Obama Day. They want to honor the president for driving all the Democrats out of Washington.

title: A New Take on the Old Sabbath Ritual of Unplugging
description: I am typing fast because at sundown (7:20 p.m.), I plan to join in the first National Day of Unplugging and turn my electronic devices off until sundown Saturday. The effort, reported in The New York Times and elsewhere, is the brainchild of Reboot, a nonprofit organization of Jewish professionals who want to adapt the concept of Sabbath traditions to the digital age.

title: So Whats in the Reconciliation Bill, Anyway?
description: The Times has published an interactive graphic comparing the Senate health care bill with the reconciliation provisions unveiled by House Democrats on Thursday. Many of the most controversial provisions of the Senate bill  its restrictions on abortion, for instance  cannot be addressed via a reconciliation bill. But many others were altered. Check out our point-by-point comparison and share your thoughts in the comments section or at Health Care Conversations.

title: Human Origins
description: Photos from a new hall at the Smithsonian Museum of Natural History in Washington.

title: Senate to Drop Backdoor Bailouts From Bill
description: The Senate Banking Committee will remove a provision from the financial regulatory bill that Sheila C. Bair, the chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said could allow for backdoor bailouts, a panel spokeswoman told Reuters on Friday.

title: For Students, a Labor of Love Gets Published
description: The authors of a just-published book are ready for their moment in the spotlight  a book signing on Sunday. They are so ready that, as they talk about how they plunged into the research and organized the material and labored over the writing, it becomes clear that they could hold their own on the C-Span 2 marathon Book TV.

title: SXSW: The Hypnotic Rock of Warpaint
description: Reverb and minor chords are beautiful things for Warpaint, a four-woman band from Los Angeles. The reverb makes the guitars weightless yet enveloping, and when the women use them for high, intertwining, arpeggiated lines, they hint at the gleam of Congolese pop. The minor keys keep the songs pensive and serious. And the songs unfold with architectural clarity, advancing from ethereal to earthy.

title: Book Review Podcast: Jill Abramson and Elif Batuman
description: This week: The Timess Jill Abramson talks about presidential campaign books; the essayist Elif Batuman discusses her adventures in Russian literature; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Updated: Obama to Meet With House Democratic Caucus
description: 4:53 p.m. | Updated  In the higher mathematics of Washington, its usually not a difficult calculation: sending one president to the Capitol is easier, logistically at least, than bringing 253 House Democrats to the White House. And so the easy math has won out: President Obama will meet with House Democrats on Capitol Hill on Saturday, rather than the other way around as the White House had previously announced. The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, is still expected to join them. Presumably, hell walk rather than drive.

title: History Club
description: For years, hotel designers used traditional motifs mainly for contrast  by mixing Louis XIV and Le Corbusier, they seduced trend-seeking travelers with eye-catching compostions. But period promiscuity may be giving way to a new faithfulness. These days, arch has gone back to being a noun, as hoteliers go for real historicism, creating (or recreating) grande dame properties that serve their nostalgia straight up.

title: Garlic Soup for One
description: I love to make myself a small pot of garlic soup. Its my go-to recipe if I feel a cold coming on, but I dont reserve this comforting meal in a bowl just for medicinal uses.

title: A Vegan in Word and Deed
description: FORTY-FIVE minutes after a curtain call for her most recent Broadway play, Alicia Silverstone was searching a restaurant menu for comfort food. She settled on nachos and onion rings to start, and mulled beer selections with two girlfriends who had seen her show that night.

title: A More Healthful Dinner for One
description: When its just you for dinner, whipping up an entire meal just doesnt seem worth the effort. A call to the local Chinese restaurant may seem easier than scrubbing pots and pans, not to mention dealing with a weeks worth of leftovers.

title: Antiquities Once Owned by Met Go On Display in Rome
description: Sixteen Hellenistic silver-gilt objects once showcased at the Metropolitan Museum of Art had their official Italian debut on Friday, at the National Museum of Rome. The pieces are thought to have been looted some 30 years ago from the archaeological site at the ancient Greek colony of Morgantina (modern day Aidone, in eastern Sicily) and were returned to Italy as part of a 2006 agreement between the government and the Met.

title: When Baby Is Allergic to Kitty
description: Parenting is about sacrifice. Rachel Aydt learned that when her sons allergy tests gave stark evidence of what she already suspected  that her beloved boy was having asthma attacks because of her beloved cat. Of course there was only one choice, she writes in a guest post today. But that didnt mean it wasnt a hard one.

Rabbi Harold Kudan is to officiate at the Hotel Orrington in Evanston, Ill.

title: Artifacts | Catherine Opies Girlfriends
description: Catherine Opie knows women. Self-possessed, gender-defying women who favor piercings and tattoos, and run in her butch-lesbian-bondage crowd in Los Angeles. The kind of women who attract stares and sometimes abuse. Their hair-raising, Hans Holbein-inspired portraits in Opies breakout appearance at the 1995 Whitney Biennial, when identity politics were at their height, gave her a notoriety that sent her in pursuit of less polarizing subjects: surfers, California freeways, city skylines, grand western landscapes and even high school football players.

title: Marissa Mittman, Mark Kornblau
description: Marissa Joy Mittman and Mark Adam Kornblau were married Saturday evening at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York. Rabbi Tom Weiner officiated.

title: Philanthropy in the Form of a Fat Cash Prize
description: NOT long ago, a wealthy philanthropist would be content with having a building named after him or her, or simply donating to medical research. But in the last decade, more of the wealthy have been creating prizes in hopes of drawing attention to a particular cause. It doesnt hurt that their names are on the prizes.

title: New Health Bill Permits Children to Remain on Parents Insurance
description: At a rally on Friday at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., President Obama got some of his loudest applause when he talked about a provision in the health care legislation that would allow adult children to remain on their parents health insurance policies until the age of 26.

title: Kisha Cameron and Eric Dingle
description: Kisha Imani Cameron and Eric Lee Dingle were married Friday evening at the Riviera, a caterer in Brooklyn. The Rev. Karim Camara, a Baptist minister and a New York State assemblyman who represents the 43rd District in Brooklyn, officiated.

title: Patron Turns Home Movies Into a Feature
description: HAVING spent the day climbing ancient temples in debilitating jungle heat, Anne Bass didnt want to leave her hotel room again. Not even for a dance recital at Preah Khan, the 12th-century complex that is one of the jewels of Angkor, in Cambodia.

title: French Contenders to Play in Champions League Quarterfinal
description: Could this be the year that a French team wins the European Champions League?

title: Ratzinger Then, Benedict Now
description: It tells you something about the horror of the Catholic sex abuse scandals  where there always seems to be some fresh awfulness to be exposed  that Ive been hesitant to say anything about the allegations surrounding then-Archbishop Ratzingers handling of a sex abuse case in 1980s Germany. As far as I can tell, the future Pope Benedicts role in the case seems to be wildly overstated. But of course theres no way to be sure what tomorrows revelations will bring

Hendrich, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan.

title: Report Claims Iran Arms Taliban

The Channel 4 News report, embedded below, shows arms, including mortars and mines, Afghan officials in the western province of Herat say they intercepted en route from Iran to the Taliban.

description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: A Rare Spirit, a Rarer Eye
description: NECKS craned for a glimpse of Patti Smith as she settled at her customary corner table at Da Silvano in Greenwich Village, a favorite afternoon haunt, earlier this month. The wonder was that the patrons, silver haired and sleekly buffed, could pick her out at all. Ms. Smith was understated, even self-effacing in her mannish jacket, boater shirt and beat-up jeans. Watching her sip hot water and lemon, you could easily have mistaken her for one of any number of androgynous downtown hipsters adopting skinny jeans and boyfriend coats as a low-key urban armor.

title: Stirling Moss Wins Again  From Hospital
description: Stirling Moss, the long retired British racecar driver, has won again  this time from his hospital bed.

title: SXSW: Superchunks Secret Show
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The secret special guest at the Merge Records showcase was not all that secret by the time 7 p.m. rolled around on Thursday night: Superchunk was going to play a rare date. A conga line stretched outside of the Cedar Street Courtyard and down the block.

title: Live Updates From the N.C.A.A. Tournament: Day 2
description: Live updates and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Kevin Armstrong in Buffalo, Joe Lapointe in Milwaukee, John Branch in Spokane, Wash., and Ray Glier in Jacksonville, Fla., will provide updates, and Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward, will offer analysis about the games from South Bend, Ind. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comments section below.

title: Could Icelandic Whale Make Its Way Into Danish Pork?
description: March 20, 11:15 p.m. | Updated A couple of readers have noted a news release from the government of Iceland explaining that the records showing shipments of whale meal to Denmark were in error and the shipments were actually fishmeal. Heres the relevant quote:

title: 76ers in Need of a Makeover
description: Eddie Jordan is in his first and possibly last season as coach of the Philadelphia 76ers. He makes no predictions or else he may have to own up to them. Still, it would have been hard to foresee the 76ers dovetail as much as they have this season.

title: Crawford Leads No. 6 Xavier Past Minnesota
description: MILWAUKEE  Minnesota blocked a lot of Xavier shots but did not make enough of its own Friday afternoon and fell to the Musketeers, 65-54, in a first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game in the West Region. Jordan Crawford led Xavier with 28 points but he did much more than score. In addition to his shooting skills, Crawford, a sophomore from Detroit, showed a well-rounded mix of passing, dribbling and rebounding.

title: The Morning Skate: N.H.L. Gets One Right
description: His eight-game suspension by the N.H.L. for what is commonly called a cheap shot wont be cheap for Anaheim defenseman James Wisniewski.

title: Official Calls for European Solution to Greeces Woes
description: The diplomatic posturing over who should assist financially trouble Greece continued late Friday.

title: MSNBC: Obama Rallies Support
description: At his final rally before a historic House vote on health care legislation, President Obama compared the overhaul to Social Security, civil rights and Medicare. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Remembering Those Awesome 80s
description: JOHN CUSACK didnt need to make a movie about being trapped in the 1980s to know how that might feel. Its almost like a comic nightmare, he said recently of his new film, Hot Tub Time Machine, which for me is a very real nightmare. Every time I flip through the cable, I have flashbacks.

title: Creative Parenting | Family Crafting at the Ace Palm Springs
description: Like a lot of creative parents these days, Karen Kimmel wants a plastic-free, junk-food-free, theme-park-free, all-things-tacky-free life for her family. Which isnt really surprising: shes an L.A.-based installation artist whose gallery shows have turned into projects like a cool stencil kit for kids (available at shops like the LACMA Museum Store, Colette and Little Marc Jacobs); she does outreach projects with places like Oaklands famed Creative Growth Art Center for adults with developmental and physical disabilities; and her husband, James Bond (yes, real name), runs the hipster sneaker stores Undefeated.

title: When Not to Pay Down a Mortgage
description: This week, the Federal Reserve reaffirmed its intention to stop buying mortgage-backed securities, signaling the likelihood that the mortgage rates you can get today are as good as theyre going to be for a long while. Once the Fed stops buying, after all, rates are likely to go up.

title: Sound and Fury
description: To the Editor:

title: Do You Make Extra Mortgage Payments?
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I take another look at the case for making extra mortgage payments.

title: The Poker Bride
description: To the Editor:

title: Borgesian Cartography
description: To the Editor:

title: Dostoyevsky Suggests
description: To the Editor:

title: I Can Has Dictatorship?
description: Sight Gag | Glorious Web captioning for North Koreas Dear Leader:

title: A Man and His Miscellany
description: PASSERS-BY invariably slow down in front of the 19th-century saltbox-style house on Cottage Place where John Foxell, a 65-year-old artist, writer and self-confessed eccentric, has lived for a quarter of a century.

title: Freeze Slows Thaw That Is Swelling Red River
description: FARGO, N.D.  After packing more than a million sandbags and building 20 miles of temporary clay dikes to hold back the surging Red River, swollen from the rapid melting of ice and snow, this city got a lucky break on Friday: a sudden drop to subfreezing temperatures.

title: One on One: Christopher Poole, Founder of 4chan
description: In 2003, while still in high school, Christopher Poole, known online as Moot, started a message board called 4chan. The site includes content that many people find offensive. Nevertheless, or maybe because of it, the site has millions of users and has been responsible for many of the strange memes that have propagated on the Internet, including LOLcats.

title: Early Backer of War, Finally Within Grasp of Power
description: BAGHDAD

title: What the Viacom-YouTube Spat Unearthed
description: The tech world has been riveted over the last 24 hours by the unsealing of thousands of pages of court filings made as part of Viacoms copyright infringement suit against YouTube.

title: Charlie Trotter Leaves Las Vegas
description: Charlie Trotter has closed Restaurant Charlie and Bar Charlie, his two restaurants in the Palazzo hotel and casino in Las Vegas. The restaurants opened in 2008.

title: 'Barber of Seville'
description: A video clips from a performance by Joyce DiDonato at Covent Garden. Courtesy of Virgin Classics.

title: Shes Standing on Her Own Just Fine
description: ONLINE the American mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato calls herself Yankee Diva, one hopes with tongue in cheek. (You can visit her at yankeediva.blogspot.com.) While the characterization suggests some of her pluck and gumption, it leaves untouched her sensitivity, grace and kaleidoscopic sense of fantasy. The whole package came into play last July 4 in London, at the season premiere of Rossinis Barbiere di Siviglia at the Royal Opera House, when Ms. DiDonato slipped and fractured a fibula midway through the first act, grabbed a crutch and finished the show to a standing ovation.

title: BMW Preaches Sustainability in Munich and New York
description: Norbert Reithofer, chairman of BMWs board of management, caused a minor stir this week when he said that the automaker would build front-wheel-drive cars in the future.

title: Chic in Review | Their Cups Runneth Over
description: AnthropologieMoving into the Chelsea Market.

title: Correction: As Plain as the Nose on His Stage
description: An article on Feb. 28 about the artist William Kentridges staging of Dmitri Shostakovichs Nose for the Metropolitan Opera misstated the name of one of his alter egos, a character who has appeared in his video works. It is Soho Eckstein, not Eckstine.

title: Boyd and Bishop to Support House Bill
description: Representative Allen Boyd, Democrat of Florida, who voted against the Houses health care legislation in November, is jumping onto the yes wagon, according to an interview in The Tallahassee Democrat.

title: Pilgrimage and Buddhist Art
description: Images from a new exhibit at the Asia Society.

title: Larry Korman
description: Mr. Korman, 46, is a co-president of Korman Communities.

title: For This Hunter, a Place With Space for Later
description: ITS not uncommon for children to be housed in an apartments tiniest bedroom  maybe a nook, a maids room, a converted dining area.

title: The Humble Egotist
description: IN Ted Dansons hands vanity is the most adaptable  and advantageous  of sins.

title: Less Interest in Interest-Only
description: BORROWERS have had fewer mortgage choices in recent years, and now the list is shrinking further.

title: Purdue Silences the Doubters and Beats Siena
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  For weeks, Purdues bandwagon had emptied. Everyone from a doubting N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee to President Obama  who, like countless others, picked the Boilermakers to be upset in the first round  had persistently downgraded their chances.

title: Sunday Preview
description: The Annapurna Circuit in Nepal is one of the worlds great treks. But by 2012, a road is coming in and the epic hike may be ruined forever.Ethan Todras-Whitehill, a frequent contributor to the Travel section, goes on a 17-day journey that includes a one-day climb over the Thorong La pass, 17,769 feet above sea level.

title: Palestinians Keep Protesting Israeli Plans
description: The exchange of rocks and tear gas continued in the West Bank, as anti-Israeli demonstrations occurred in Lebanon (Slide 5) and Yemen (Slide 6). Bernat Armangue of The Associated Press last led off Pictures of the Day on Feb. 9, with a photo of a Palestinian trying to grab a weapon from a plainclothes Israeli police officer as he was wrestled to the ground.

title: Living in: Sea Cliff, L.I.
description: Sea Cliff bungalows and Victorians often come with water views. Many homes have been carefully restored; as one broker put it, You wont find as much vinyl as in other communities.

title: The Letter by Lehman Whistle-Blower Matthew Lee
description: Few figures have reaped any praise from the court-appointed examiners report into Lehman Brothers. But if theres one person who has looked good in the mess, its Matthew Lee.

title: Remembering the Fallen
SXSW: Band of Horses and Broken Social Scene
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Lets get the business out of the way: Band of Horses killed it on the big stage at Stubbs on Thursday night. Other acts had trouble holding it down at the expansive club  Broken Bells the night before comes to mind  but Ben Bridwell and his mates seemed very happy to be right where they were.

title: At 108, Still Pulsing With Vigor
description: Seventy-two years ago, a 36-year-old German immigrant named Carl Berner moved into a modest single-family house in Middle Village, Queens.

title: The Village of Artful Lodgings
description: ON a drive around Nassau County two and a half years ago, Paul and Jill Haining of Jackson Heights, Queens, fell in love with Sea Cliff, a quirky, gingerbread-laced village overlooking Hempstead Harbor on the North Shore.

title: The Real Brokers of New York, as Seen on HGTV
description: BEHIND every apartment for sale in Manhattan theres a story. And with its new series Selling New York HGTV is hoping to seduce viewers around the country with tales of the citys opulent residential properties and the intense New Yorkers who buy and sell them.

title: This Way There Be Dragons
description: AT first glance How to Train Your Dragon, the new action-adventure film from DreamWorks Animation based on the whimsical childrens book by Cressida Cowell, does not seem to share much with the Coen brothers No Country for Old Men or M. Night Shyamalans Village. But a closer look reveals some similarities. From washed-out landscapes to minimally lighted rooms, the Nordic locations in Dragon feel more lived in and rough edged  more realistic  than one typically finds in animation. This comes from the influence of an outsider, the Oscar-nominated cinematographer Roger Deakins. Best known for his work on A Beautiful Mind, The Shawshank Redemption and Coen brothers films, Mr. Deakins had little experience working in animation, save for some consulting on Wall-E. But as the co-directors of Dragon, Dean DeBlois and Chris Sanders (Lilo & Stitch), were thinking of a way to distinguish their film from other animated work, they decided to bring in someone who could see light in a different way. Below Mr. Deakins, Mr. DeBlois and Mr. Sanders discuss how they achieved the films look.

title: Missouri Outlasts Clemson to Advance
description: BUFFALO  Missouri guard Zaire Taylor likes to describe his teams up-tempo style of play as more organized chaos than helter-skelter. He believes his Tigers operate best in the open floor, capitalizing on run-outs to the rim and pouncing on turnovers.

title: Natures Wonders, From Every Angle
description: Oprah Winfrey is the big-name narrator of Life, an 11-part nature documentary that begins Sunday on Discovery, but the real stars are the camera operators who captured the simply amazing footage, going to rain forests, deserts and just about every other kind of environment to do it.

title: Dodd Seeks U.S. Inquiry Into Lehmans Accounting
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, called on Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Friday to start an investigation of Lehman Brothers over the accounting maneuvers that contributed to its collapse in September 2008. He also said the Justice Department should look at other companies that may have engaged in similar accounting manipulation.

title: On Long Island, Legislating Fairness in Co-ops
description: CO-OP boards have long had the power to reject an application without explanation, leaving buyers and sellers to wonder whether discrimination was a motivating factor.

title: In New Jersey, the For-Sale Signs Are in Bloom
description: MAPLEWOOD

title: Vibraphonist Dazzles, but Without Fanfare
description: Jazz vibraphonists are often firecrackers, crisp and kinetic even when in an introspective mood. Chris Dingman had some moments like that at the Jazz Gallery in the South Village on Thursday night. But in one of the first prominent showcases for his five-piece band, Waking Dreams, he was largely the picture of accommodation and restraint, projecting a kind of adaptive humility.

title: Financing a Fixer-Upper
description: WITH the current spate of foreclosures have come bargain-seeking buyers, seemingly undeterred by broken pipes, falling bathroom tiles and other detritus from the unceremonious departures of former owners. Whether buying for their own use or as an investment, these hunters say the good timing and low prices make the expenditure of elbow grease worthwhile.

title: Another Dish of Reality Television Is Served on a New Jersey Plate
description: Thomas A. Edison, whose research lab was in New Jersey, was largely responsible for bringing electricity into peoples living rooms. David Sarnoff, whose research lab was also in New Jersey, was largely responsible for giving people color televisions to make use of that electricity. On Sunday in the afterlife, both men, after decades in heaven, are expected to be reassigned to hell as a result of the premiere of Jerseylicious, a witless reality show on the Style Network about a beauty salon in Green Brook, N.J., and the vapid people who work there.

title: The Everest Advantage
description: CLOSE your eyes and picture your dream apartment. Do you see light streaming through big open windows? Is there a large kitchen? Nice prewar detail?

title: Young Filmmakers Search for Her Worth Is Rewarded
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  In the movie Tiny Furniture, a young woman named Aura breaks up with her boyfriend, returns home from college, moves in with her wildly successful artist family in a pristine TriBeCa loft, all the while trying to find a place to stand in the world.

title: In Haiti, Mental Health System Is in Collapse
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Inside this citys earthquake-cracked psychiatric hospital, a schizophrenic man lay naked on a concrete floor, caked in dust. Other patients, padlocked in tiny concrete cells, clutched the bars and howled for attention. Feces clotted the gutter outside a ward where urine pooled under metal cots without mattresses.

title: Correction: Review of The Infinities
description: A review on March 7 about The Infinities, a novel by John Banville, misstated the authors relationship to the work of the German writer Heinrich von Kleist. While Banville has adapted work by Kleist, including the play Amphitryon, he has not translated it.

title: Bike Lane Blockers, Beware
description: Excuse me, sir, Barbara Ross said to the driver of a black town car parked on Avenue of the Americas near 37th Street. You are obstructing a bike lane.

title: Painting by Numbers to Make a Sexy Scene
description: In her new Proximity Spiral, the choreographer Stefanie Nelson explores intimacy using numbers  specifically, the Fibonacci sequence, in which each number is the sum of the two preceding it.

title: Plane Janes
description: Were told that there was a magical time long ago when, whatever your seat assignment, flying was first-class. But when did it all end? Last week, Marie Force, the archivist at the Delta Heritage Museum in Atlanta, published an online gallery of photographs of Delta flight attendant uniforms from 1940 to the present. Delta was one of the more conservative airlines, Forcesays. We didnt have hot pants. Still, for almost 40 straight years, the airlines female flight attendants (something called stewardesses) turned heads. In the 1940s, they did it with military-style overseas caps and spectator shoes; in the 50s, with futurist insignias and stiletto pumps; and in the 60s, with A-line topcoats, alligator-print boots, Chanel-inspired jackets with three-quarter-length sleeves and the Delberet, a pillbox hat designed for Delta by Mea Hanauer, a New York milliner. The 70s were all about coo-coo colors, bell-bottom pants, Slavic tunics and, weirdly, a yellow raincoat. And then in the 80s, Delta took a sartorial nosedive that it couldnt recover from until 2001. Return your seat to its upright position, and take a look.

title: Forward Helps Badgers Avoid First-Round Exit
description: JACKSONVILLE  Jon Leuer, a 6-foot-10 Wisconsin forward, did not settle for making the biggest offensive play of the game. He had to make the biggest defensive play, too.

title: Correction: Best Sellers
description: An entry on the paperback advice and how-to best-seller list last Sunday omitted the first part of the title of a book by the staff of Martha Stewart Living. It is Everyday Food: Fresh Flavor Fast.

title: Somehow, Pinstripes Never Fit Arroyo and Cameron
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  After spending eight seasons as the Yankees beat writer for The Times, one of the great upsets is that Bronson Arroyo and Mike Cameron never played for the team. Whenever the Yankees needed help in their rotation, it seemed, Arroyos name would float around as a trade possibility. Same thing with center field and Cameron.

title: Stranger Leaves the Guests Both Shaken and Stirred
description: The funniest thing about T .S. Eliots 1949 play, The Cocktail Party, is that the playwright called it a comedy. At first, it seems as if he meant it, introducing a gathering of urbane, upper-crust Londoners with the style of a frothy drawing-room affair. Scott Alan Evans, the director of the new revival at the Beckett Theater, deserves credit for helping his cast speak its verse, almost unheard of in drama today, with a colloquial wit that comes off rather effortlessly.

title: Otto Dix | Painting the Town Red
description: If fin de sicle Vienna was all black and gold and decadent, Berlin in the aftermath of World War I was a town painted red: the rouge of lips, swollen scar tissue or the last moments at dusk before the horizon slipped into the darkness of night. From time to time, the Neue Galerie reveals to us that seamy alter ego. The new exhibition dedicated to Otto Dix (1891-1969), the long-overdue first retrospective of the artist in North America, makes the scandals and scars of 1920s Berlin seem entirely fresh.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 19
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Modernism for an Egyptian Myth
description: Looking at the program that Christoph Eschenbach and the New York Philharmonic performed at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening, you might think that the only link among the three works was between Bergs Violin Concerto and Schoenbergs arrangement of Brahmss Opus 25 Piano Quartet. Berg, after all, was Schoenbergs disciple, and his concerto combines Schoenbergs 12-tone method with a current of Romanticism that ties it to the Brahms. In the Brahms itself, the musics 19th-century harmonies are tempered by Schoenbergs overtly modernist brass and percussion touches.

title: Federal Judge Orders More Talks on 9/11 Deal
description: The federal judge overseeing litigation between the city and workers at ground zero on Friday rejected a settlement, telling lawyers that it did not provide enough compensation to plaintiffs and needed to be renegotiated under his supervision.

title: Pop History Revealed! Doing Splits!
description: EVEN Michael Jackson couldnt find a copy. In an interview just before Thriller was released in 1982 Mr. Jackson begged a reporter to help him locate a rare videotape of a 1964 James Brown performance because, as Mr. Jackson said, he got so out of himself. Years later the producer Rick Rubin would describe this same appearance as possibly the single greatest rock n roll performance ever captured on film.

title: Female Saudi Poet, Known for Controversial Verses, Reaches Game Show Final
description: A Saudi woman received a death threat last week after she appeared on Poet of Millions, Abu Dhabis version of the game show American Idol  which features aspiring poets instead of singers  and recited a poem attacking clerics for terrorizing people and preying on everyone seeking peace.

title: When Meatloaf Needs a Jolt
description: I LOVE almost everything about meatloaf.

title: Mortals Erring in Realm of the Gods
description: Many opera productions, especially those of small-scale chamber works, have tried to break down barriers between performers and audiences. At the production of Charpentiers French Baroque pastorale Acton, which opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday night, performed by Les Arts Florissants and the conductor William Christie, the mingling of singers and audience members was uncommonly intimate.

title: W. Eugene Smith and the Jazz Loft Project
description: As the Book Reviews photography editor, I often choose pictures for the brief art feature that appears on the page with our Fiction or Nonfiction Chronicle. Usually its a pleasurable undertaking. As we prepared the issue of March 21, however, the necessity of choosing only one lone photograph to illustrate The Jazz Loft Project  Sam Stephensons account of the amazingly rich and original body of work accumulated by the photographer W. Eugene Smith between 1957 and 1965  was somewhat difficult. (In the end, we published not precisely a photograph reprinted in Stephensons book, but a detail from one of those pictures, the portrait of Thelonious Monk above, as it had been marked for cropping by Smith himself.)

title: Walk-Ups on the Market
description: Walk-ups often cost less, or have a special feature.

title: Number of People Living on New York Streets Soars
description: The Bloomberg administration said Friday that the number of people living on New Yorks streets and subways soared 34 percent in a year, signaling a setback in one of the citys most intractable problems.

title: 'The T.A.M.I. Show': The Beach Boys
description: The 1964 concert film was filled with acts that became rock legends but it is only now getting a DVD release.

title: 'The T.A.M.I. Show': Lesley Gore
description: The 1964 concert film was filled with acts that became rock legends but it is only now getting a DVD release.

title: 'The T.A.M.I. Show': Marvin Gaye
description: The 1964 concert film was filled with acts that became rock legends but it is only now getting a DVD release.

title: 'The T.A.M.I. Show': Chuck Berry
description: The 1964 concert film was filled with acts that became rock legends but it is only now getting a DVD release.

title: Chaffetz Accuses Two Democrats of Trading Their Votes
description: The depth of emotion in the health care debate was illustrated by an extraordinary exchange on the House floor on Friday.

title: Undermanned Oakland Cannot Keep Pace With Pitt
description: . MILWAUKEE  For a 14th seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament to upset a No. 3, everything has to go just right.

title: Whos Afraid of Marina?
description: Upstairs from the child-friendly wonderland of the Museum of Modern Arts Tim Burton exhibition, and from the placid, chapel-like room devoted to Monets water lilies, the new Marina Abramovic retrospective can be heard before it is seen, and it doesnt sound inviting. The artists screams and moans roll out from the sixth-floor galleries in endless loops, a warning nearly as clear as the three signs advising that the show ahead may be disturbing for some.

title: On the Subway, V Is for Vanished
description: The V train, a weekday-only service that relieved crowding on the E and F lines and was one of the youngest trains in the New York City subway system, was sentenced to death on Friday. It was 8 years old and divided its time between Queens and Manhattan.

title: Iraqis Gather to Watch Hollywoods Take on a War That Has Enveloped Their Lives
description: BAGHDAD  Simple pleasures are still elusive here, but on a lazy Friday afternoon  a day before the seventh anniversary of the American invasion of Iraq  about a dozen men went to the movies to watch their war.

title: Olive Oil Matzo
description: Mark Bittman makes a flavorful matzo-like bread that was inspired by a Sardinian flatbread.

title: Mistaken Identities and a Madcap Story Fuel an Operas Comic Plot
description: Emmanuel Chabrier has long been remembered primarily for his orchestral work Espaa, but in recent years the spotlight has shifted to Ltoile, his three-act gem of a comic opera. The works charming contours are revealed in Mark Lamoss vibrant production, which returned to New York City Opera on Thursday evening to open the companys spring season.

title: For Families With No Fear of Flying
description: GOVERNMENT CAMP, Ore.

title: Cars and the City, Imperfect Together
description: DONALD ALBRECHT sees New York  a place where driving across town is the answer to the question of how slow can you go, and where drivers dont stop on a dime but park in spaces the size of one  as a motor city whose car culture is central to the identity of the automobile itself.

title: Excerpt: 'Undercover Boss'
description: The reality show has been an unexpected hit for CBS.

title: Murder Most Improvised
description: Judging from the intermission chatter and the gasps at plot twists, few audience members at a recent performance of Dial M for Murder in Northport knew  or remembered  much about the movie based on Frederick Knotts play. The 1954 Hitchcock thriller, starring Grace Kelly, Ray Milland and Robert Cummings, is one of those films that many people (at least those of a certain age) swear theyve seen, though theyre hazy on the details.

title: Now Playing | Band of Sisters
description: The Runaways, the long-awaited biopic about the pioneering 1970s L.A. female rock band, finally makes its debut today. And 35 years later, the rampant sexism the teenage group faced is still squirm inducing. First there was Kim Fowley, the bands obnoxious manager, who insisted that rock n roll was exclusively the sport of men. Then there were the male-dominated music magazines like Creem that dismissed them out of hand and once famously gave them a three-word review: These bitches suck. Add to that the litany of lecherous promoters, bands and hit men who looked to the girls for one thing only, and its no wonder that the Runaways didnt just run for their lives.

title: Lowlifes With a Plan (or So They Think)
description: Theater people may have a different definition of celebrity than people who go to Miley Cyrus concerts or watch Keeping Up With the Kardashians do. So for me, the initial appeal of the Steppenwolf Theater Companys zingy and powerful production of David Mamets American Buffalo at the McCarter Theater Center was seeing Tracy Letts in the flesh.

title: Looking at Souvenirs and Seeing Art
description: GREENWICH

title: Quotations of Vice Chairman Bob
description: Long after the cars he championed have rusted away, some of Bob Lutzs notable quotes may live on in auto industry lore. Here are some examples:

title: A Celebration of Bakelite in the City Where It Was Born
description: Yonkers

title: Wheres the Boss? In Disguise, and at the Top of the Television Ratings
description: The biggest new hit on television is a reality show that did not get a head start in the summer, that remained dormant for half the television season, that seemed to have little chance to appeal to younger viewers, and that had to face formidable competition not only from Desperate Housewives on ABC, but also from three straight weeks of the Winter Olympics on NBC.

title: Reaching Deep Into a Bag of Tricks, Even Magical Ones
description: The word stage-struck isnt generally applied to shows. But it would be hard to find a more apt label for the slap-happy shenanigans in the Yale Repertory Theaters rendition of Carlo Goldonis 18th-century farce The Servant of Two Masters. From the moment a couple of Italian-speaking stagehands open a dusty old trunk on a dark, decrepit proscenium stage, releasing clouds of magically twinkling lights, this production revels in the transformative power of theater.

title: Olive Oil Helps Produce a Classic Flatbread
description: THERE is a wonderful Sardinian flatbread known as carta di musica  sheet music, because it is nearly impossibly thin  that I never thought of making. Something about its ethereal nature made me assume (idiotically, as it happens) that it would be too difficult.

title: A Mozart Piece to Open the Season
description: When David Stewart Wiley raises his baton next weekend to usher in the Long Island Philharmonics spring season, he will be conducting a Mozart piece that is a personal favorite, but one that he has kept in reserve since becoming the orchestras music director in 2001.

title: Olive Oil Matzo
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Less Drama in Detroit as Lutz Leaves the Stage
description: THE departure of Robert A. Lutz as vice chairman of General Motors may provoke an emergency call to the paint department: the color is leaking from G.M.s headquarters.

title: The Low-Hanging Fruit of Saving Fuel
description: ITS been a standard trick among miserly drivers for years: shutting off the engine in stopped traffic and at long stoplights instead of burning gasoline while idling. And it is such a straightforward fuel-saver that shutoff systems  with the addition of automated restart provisions  are a standard feature of todays hybrids.

title: 500 Horsepower, but Not a Guzzler
description: DOWN at the bottom of the specifications sheet for the Porsche Panamera Turbo, past the eyebrow-raising power rating of the 4.8-liter V-8 and beyond the head-spinning acceleration figures (and 188-mile-per-hour top speed), lies a pleasant surprise: this supersedan, with an E.P.A. rating of 15 m.p.g. in town and 23 on the highway, incurs no federal guzzler tax.

title: Singing in Tongues, Some of Them Strung
description: We know why you like Joanna Newsom. The reasons are online: one of every five people with positive thoughts about her, it seems, has recorded them digitally. That shes original, expressive, fearless, beautiful, virtuosic, unaffected, overaffected. That she plays the harp. That shes made the transition from garage-baroque to full folk-rock art song. That she likes words intemperately, tells jokes and wears prairie and bordello dresses.

title: Blooms of Darkness
description: Chapter 3

title: Fridays Vote Count
description: As Friday winds down, The Times counts 203 votes in the House for the health care legislation, 204 against, and 24 still undecided. Find the full tally here.

title: A Health Care Plan So Cheap, They Made Him Raise the Price
description: Hi, America, is it too late to propose a new health care plan? Because Dr. John Muney has an idea. The AMG Medical Group, which he founded last year, offers a $79-a-month buffet of unlimited office visits.

title: The Genius in All of Us
description: Chapter 1

title: The Week in Pictures for March 19
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include a recess coach, pizza slices for a dollar, and storm damage.

title: On the Road, There Are No Sundays
description: Steve Earle and Allison Moorer, married musicians, have had a good year. Mr. Earle, 55, recently received his third Grammy Award, for Townes, an homage to his hero Townes Van Zandt, and Ms. Moorer, 37, just released her eighth studio album,  Crows.  When theyre not off touring the country, they live with their two dogs  Petey, a Chihuahua, and Beau, a blue heeler  on a quiet block off Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village. They are expecting their first child later this month.

title: The Doctor Who Would Be President
description: With the hospitals in Port-au-Prince overwhelmed with trauma patients from the earthquake, Dr. Guy Theodore is picking up the slack in a remote mountain village.

title: His Offense: Taking 2 Seats on a Nearly Empty Train
description: One recent night, Ryan David LaMont settled into the wary peace of a post-midnight journey on the No. 2 train. He was not quite alone, since a few other people were on board, but he had rows and rows of seats to choose from.

title: 4 Women, Discussing Oysters and Men
description: This bivalve-heavy addition to the Mermaid empire  there are Mermaid Inn restaurants serving a broader seafood palette in the East Village and on the Upper West Side  packs them in with a smart, successful trick: $1 oysters at the bar from 5:30 to 7 p.m. (Sundays from 5 to 7 p.m.). Located at 79 MacDougal Street, next door to the ever-mysterious Italian Rifle Club, the oyster bar tends to draw a downtown crowd, including four women who recently got their business degrees and now work together at American Express.

title: Mattel and Facebook Team to Recommend Toys
description: Fisher-Price, a division of Mattel, began an app for Facebook that is best described as a social scrapbook mashed up with a smart toy catalog.

title: Checking the Math on Health Care
description: If the health care reform package makes it through Congress, and we should know sometime on Sunday, much of the credit for its salvation will go to Thursdays report from the Congressional Budget Office that, according to The Timess David M. Herszenhorn, predicted a $940 billion price tag for the new insurance coverage provisions in the bill, and the reduction of future federal deficits of $138 billion over 10 years. It is an article of faith that the budget office resides, pretty much alone among government bodies, in the refined aerie of nonpartisanship, a paragon of technocratic, if not inhuman, objectivity.

title: BlogTalk: Progressives, Public Option and Abortion
description: On the weekend eve of an historic vote on the health care bill, Republican opponents do not at all sound ready to accept defeat. Or rather, they view defeat as victory, because they can use passage by Democrats, if it happens, as a weapon in the midterm elections. (Weve been chronicling all developments on the vote-counting and snags as the House moves toward a vote this coming Sunday on our Prescriptions blog.)

title: Madly March
description: College basketball lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday night, while NBC earned a rare second-place finish thanks to The Office and The Marriage Ref. According to Nielsens estimates, CBS averaged about 10.3 million viewers in prime time for its basketball coverage. NBC earned its best ratings in the 9 and 10 p.m. hours with its new series The Marriage Ref at 10 (7.6 million) following The Office at 9 (7.6 million) and 30 Rock at 9:30 (6.9 million). ABC ranked third for the night just ahead of Fox. A two-hour installment of ABCs science fiction series FlashForward averaged 6.5 million viewers from 8 to 10; a rerun of Private Practice at 10 drew 4.3 million. Fox broadcast repeats of Bones (6.2 million) and Fringe (4.4 million) from 8 to 10.

title: Fortunes Improve for Miracle Worker
description: After two weeks of doubts about the financial viability of the Broadway revival of The Miracle Worker its producers have completed a new round of financing that will allow the play to keep running through mid-April in hopes of appealing to spring-vacation theatergoers. Dini von Mueffling, the wife of the shows lead producer, David Richenthal, said in an interview that new promotional efforts would soon be under way to market the production  which tells the story of a young Helen Keller (Abigail Breslin) and her teacher, Annie Sullivan (Alison Pill)  for parents and children, particularly fathers and their daughters. Ms. von Mueffling said she was overseeing the show while Mr. Richenthal takes care of health issues.

title: Lady Gaga Is Sued
description: Fresh from her prison stint in the video for Telephone, Lady Gaga, above right, could soon be headed to court  not to face any number of angry grindhouse filmmakers whose works inspired that video, but a lawsuit from a songwriter and producer who says hes the one who gave her that famous stage name. The Associated Press reported that Rob Fusari, who helped write Lady Gaga songs including Paparazzi and Beautiful, Dirty, Rich, filed a $30.5 million lawsuit against the singer, saying she has frozen him out of her career as she has become more successful. Mr. Fusari said in his suit that he was first introduced to the singer Stefani Germanotta in 2006, helping to guide her from a rock musician to a dance artist and nicknaming her Lady Gaga. He said he had received more than $600,000 from Lady Gaga but had not received his full share of royalties and other fees. Representatives for Lady Gaga have not yet responded to the suit, which was filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Antiquities, Once the Mets, Go on Display in Rome
description: Sixteen Hellenistic silver-gilt objects once showcased at the Metropolitan Museum of Art had their official Italian debut on Friday at the National Museum of Rome. The pieces, including the one below, are thought to have been looted some 30 years ago from the archaeological site at the ancient Greek colony of Morgantina (modern day Aidone, in eastern Sicily) and were returned to Italy as part of a 2006 agreement between the government and the Met. In recent years Italy has signed similar accords with other American institutions, and archaeologists at Fridays presentation praised such restitutions as indicative of a cultural sea change that recognizes that archaeology is context, according to Malcolm Bell III, a professor at the University of Virginia who helped establish the provenance of the objects, which led to their return.
