In 1981 and 1982 the Met bought the silver hoard from the American dealer Robert Hecht for $2.74 million. Mr. Hecht is currently standing trial in Rome on charges of conspiracy to traffic in looted artifacts.

title: Artists on Governors Island
description: This week nearly 30 visual and performing artists have moved onto Governors Island, the beginning of a year-round artist studio program organized by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. In the newly renovated Building 110, artists will have the use of 20 studios, two rehearsal areas and a large exhibition space with views of Lower Manhattan and New York Harbor. The residencies run from March to July and from August to December; the public can have access to the studios from June to mid-October.

title: Gheorghiu in La Bohme for Ailing Netrebko
description: If youve ever been frustrated by an 11th-hour substitution at the Metropolitan Opera in which a star performer is suddenly replaced by one of seemingly lesser caliber, it may be harder to complain about this particular late change to the lineup: on Friday the Met said Angela Gheorghiu, left, would sing the role of Mimi in Saturday afternoons performance of La Bohme. She is stepping in for Anna Netrebko, who is ill, the Met said. Ms. Gheorghiu, the Romanian soprano, withdrew from the Mets Richard Eyre-directed production of Carmen amid marital problems with her husband, the tenor Roberto Alagna, who starred in that opera; she said last month in a statement that she wanted to be as prepared dramatically as I am musically for the production. But there is evidently no bad blood between her and the Met; Ms. Gheorghiu is currently rehearsing for its coming production of La Traviata, which opens on March 29, and will sing the role of Juliette in Gounods Romo et Juliette for the Mets 2010-11 season.

title: More Silverstein Poems
description: The author who gave us The Giving Tree still has a little more left to give: a new volume of poetry and illustrations by Shel Silverstein, the writer and artist of Where the Sidewalk Ends, A Light in the Attic and Falling Up, will be published by HarperCollins Childrens Books in fall 2011, Publishers Weekly reported. Antonia Markiet, a senior executive editor at the imprint, said the new book will contain between 120 and 130 poems by Mr. Silverstein, none of which have been published. Ms. Markiet is among the editors who began working with Mr. Silverstein, who died in 1999, in the 1970s (when he was still better known as a writer of songs like A Boy Named Sue and an illustrator of Playboy cartoons that would never find their way into a childrens anthology), and previously edited the authors posthumously published 2005 childrens book Runny Babbit.

title: Enticing the Senses, From Stage to Screen
description: Its a different world today, sighed an audience member as dancers, some in shiny, silvery bodysuits or leggings, gently coaxed the public to join an improvised piece full of balloons and good will. It was Thursday night at Danspace Project after a presentation of film and work by Elaine Summers, one of the original members of the Judson Dance Theater.

title: Killer of Malcolm X Is Granted Parole
description: After being turned down for parole 16 times, Malcolm Xs only confessed assassin is about to gain his freedom.

title: U.S. Frees Detainees, but Afghans Anger Persists
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The tribal elders had traveled many hours to reach a windswept Afghan military base on the capitals outskirts to sign their names to a piece of paper allowing them to bring their countrymen home from American detention.

title: Raising Arizona
description: Page, Ariz., has always looked to me as if it might just slip quietly over the edge into the Colorado River or else pick up and drive away. Heading for town over the Glen Canyon Dam  trying not to look to the left, down to Lake Powell, and certainly not to the right, down the 700-foot chasm into the river  I could see that Page was more or less the same as it was when I was a child: a sprinkling of mobile homes and derelict shopping plazas in a landscape formed over 180 million years into a topography of fractured mountain ranges.

title: Irish Town Puzzled by Role in Investigation
description: WATERFORD, Ireland  When two North African men under investigation in an alleged terrorist plot to kill a Swedish artist appeared in the gray pillared courthouse here this week, many native Waterford residents reacted as much with puzzlement as dismay, as if Islamic extremism had no conceivable place amid the tranquillity of this quiet old harbor town.

title: Band Between Buzz and Big Break at South by Southwest
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  In the blog-accelerated time zone that the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference occupies, the cycle of buzz turns so fast that bands caught up in it can find themselves in the paradoxical state of being brand-new and old hat at the same time.

title: The Peoples Court
description: It requires body control, hand-eye coordination, quickness, flat-out speed, endurance and that strange mix of caution

title: Texas A&M Outshoots Utah State
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Texas A&M, making an annual habit of making the tournament and reaching the second round, did it again on Friday by easing past Utah State, 69-53, at Spokane Veterans Memorial Arena.

title: Dessert With an Italian Accent
description: Unless you are well versed in Italian desserts, you might be suspicious of the name Tart & Tufo. Could it be a spelling error? Did the owner of the bright new cafe in Morristown mean tofu instead of tufo?

title: Intense Flavors of Hunan in a Simple Setting
description: STEPPING into the dining room at Fortune Cookie means submitting to flavor: to hot pepper, to garlic, to smoke and meat fat, the earthiness of mushroom, the sharpness of onion. The smell pervades the place; with each dish cooked, another layer of aromatics is added to the ambience of an otherwise forgettable room.

title: Unusual Transformation From Granite to Gnocchi
description: THE second-floor balcony at Esca Restaurant and Wine Bar overlooks a dining room that soars two stories high and is accented with elegant pale marble and tile and one stunning slab of onyx. The bar area, off to the side, is eccentric, with one wall fashioned from concrete to look like the interior of an Italian wine cave. This innovative dcor combines the traditional with the avant-garde. The food seeks a similar fusion; when it hits the mark, it is enjoyable.

title: From a Small Establishment, Tempting Mexican Flavors
description: Padres Mexican Cuisine is the very definition of a hole in the wall. Two tables, each covered by a colorful chili-pepper-patterned cloth, occupy most of the floor space, with a short L-shaped bar and six stools taking up the remainder. Yet despite its diminutive size, the establishment, which is loosely affiliated with the adjacent Gilson Caf Cinema, projects a bright, well-tended look.

title: An Old Standby Reinvents Itself
description: The Meetinghouse, a fixture in this trim hamlet, long took advantage of its status as the only game in town  with lackluster fare and breezy service. But a recent visit revealed a welcome transformation.

title: Crossing Thorong La Pass
description: Thorong La, a daunting 17,769-foot pass, is the highest altitude reached by many trekkers in their lifetime.

title: Big on Puerto Rico and All Its Flavors
description: DON COQUI is big in every way. Its 120-seat dining room takes up much of the second floor of a former industrial building in New Rochelle. Its dishes are so plentiful you could serve four people with some of the entrees. Even its personality is big: It feels like a rocking party on a Friday or Saturday night, with salsa music playing and many diners dressed in their weekend best.

title: Bottles Made for the Nose
description: You only have to inhale Bouk wines to appreciate the Gallic pun in the brands name. Inviting fragrances rise up from each of the four latest releases.

title: Hamptons Perks With a Shorter Ride
description: VENE 56, not far off Exit 56 of the Long Island Expressway in Hauppauge, is halfway between New York City and the Hamptons. That makes the restaurant, which opened in December, a perfect stopping-off place for those heading from the city to the East End. But once they step inside, they may feel as if they have already arrived.

title: Florida Case Blocks Parole for Molester in California
description: MIAMI  A convicted child molester held a young girl captive for more than 15 years in the 1970s and 80s, fathering her baby and forcing her to have four abortions, according to a criminal complaint filed in federal court that blocked his release from prison.

title: Surprising Strength? Dont Discount Offense
description: At the Spring North American Championships in Reno, Nev., when the premier event, the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, ends on Sunday, a team that has never won the title will be crowned.

title: Chinas Growth Shifts the Geopolitics of Oil
description: Last summer, Saudi Arabia put the final bolt in its largest oil expansion project ever, opening a new field capable of pumping 1.2 million barrels a day  more than the entire production of Texas. The field, called Khurais, was part of an ambitious $60 billion program to increase the kingdoms production to meet growing energy needs.

title: The Right to Counsel: Woman Becomes a Test Case
description: FORT EDWARD, N.Y.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Why We Need to Dream
description: When I cant sleep, I think about what Im missing. I glance over at my wife and watch her eyelids flutter. I listen to the steady rhythm of her breath. I wonder if shes dreaming and, if so, what story shes telling to herself to pass the time. (The mind is like a shark  it cant ever stop swimming in thought.) And then my eyes return to the ceiling and I wonder what I would be dreaming about, if only I could fall asleep.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Missing a Son on the Census Form
description: The envelope is larger than the usual, and it certainly got my attention. U.S. Census Form Enclosed, it said in large letters; then YOUR RESPONSE IS REQUIRED BY LAW in even larger ones.

title: More Food Banks Helping to Feed Pets
description: The exploding demand among the needy for food banks is rapidly expanding to desperate pet owners who can no longer afford to feed their animals, according to the Humane Society of the United States.

title: Taking a Childrens Tale to Dark New Depths
description: In John Neumeiers ballet adaptation of The Little Mermaid, the title character undergoes an extreme physical ordeal so that she might live on land. As the orchestra plays a stomping series of cataclysmic chords, a malevolent sea witch wrenches off the mermaids fluid blue costume and leaves her almost naked and shivering onstage. With one of her newly acquired human limbs grotesquely contorted over her shoulder, the former mermaid looks like an insect thats been flayed alive.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,376 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,009 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Congressman Cries Poor, but Lifestyle May Disagree
description: WASHINGTON  Money is so tight, Representative Gregory W. Meeks says, he does not have a savings account with more than a few thousand dollars in it. And yet Mr. Meeks, one of New York Citys most prominent Democrats, lives a life worthy of a jet-setter.

title: Some See a Real Estate Bubble Forming in Canada
description: OTTAWA  Marie-Yvonne Paint, a real estate agent in Montreal, has the kind of problem most of her counterparts in the United States can only dream about.

title: Aid for L.I. Attack Victim Took Time, Court Is Told
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  The man in an alley near a Long Island Rail Road train station was breathing rapidly, lying face up in a pool of blood. His hands and feet shook. He had been stabbed in the chest.

title: Under a New Subway Plan, the V Stands for Vanished
description: The V train, a weekday-only service that relieved crowding on the E and F lines and was one of the youngest trains in the New York City subway system, was sentenced to death on Friday. It was 8 years old and divided its time between Queens and Manhattan.

title: A Poet Who Doesnt Do Lofty
description: AFTER Tina Chang puts her 7-month-old son, Roman, to bed, she pads, barefoot, about three feet over to her office, where a desk cohabits with the changing table. She opens the window to take in the sights and sounds of her neighborhood, Park Slope  men arguing on the street, neighbors sipping wine on fire escapes, apartment lights twinkling. She opens a spiral notebook from the 99-cent store and begins scribbling. One night she started with a recipe for black bean sauce, another with the first line of a rejection letter from a literary journal, another with a to-do list.

title: Appeals Court Rules Fed Must Release Loan Reports
description: A federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Friday that the Federal Reserve Board must release a trove of secret documents identifying financial firms that received public money under a trillion-dollar emergency loan program put in place at the height of Wall Street meltdown.

title: New Efforts on Iran Sanctions Run Into Familiar Snags
description: WASHINGTON  It was Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton who, nearly a year ago, fired the Obama administrations first warning shots about imposing crippling sanctions against Iran.

title: Leading the Nets Cheers, for Everything but Victories
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Marco G. is yelling, because he wants to, because he needs to and because if he stops, someone at the Izod Center just might fall asleep. Youre not supposed to sleep at a professional basketball game.

title: Dont Move! If You Know Whats Good for You
description: Touched is what I am by the number of people who thought I had vanished from this place. And especially by the number who were sorry.

title: Injured Wrist Wont Sideline New Mexicos Hobson
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  X-rays were negative on the wrist New Mexico forward Darington Hobson injured in a hard fall in Thursdays 62-57 win over Montana, allowing him to start in Saturdays second-round East Region game against Washington.

title: China: 4 Face Trial on Organ Trafficking Charges
description: The first Chinese trial involving organ trafficking could take place next month in Beijing, according to a report in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper. Four men have been charged with paying living people for organs and then reselling the organs. If found guilty, the men would be sentenced to at least five years in prison. China Daily reported that last year, about a third of 10,000 organ transplants in China involved living donors, almost six times the number in 2008.

title: U.S. Plans Spot Tests of Organic Products
description: The Department of Agriculture said on Friday that it would begin enforcing rules requiring the spot testing of organically grown foods for traces of pesticides, after an auditor exposed major gaps in federal oversight of the organic food industry.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Wings Hold 8th on Last-Second Goal
description: Four games scheduled for Friday night, with an emphasis on the West  especially that last playoff spot, given that both the Red Wings and Flames were in action. There were some last-second heroics, which only served to make the race tighter. Home teams listed first:

title: Likely Successor Emerges to Lead U.S. Forces in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  The leading candidate to succeed Gen. Ray Odierno as the top American commander in Iraq is Lloyd J. Austin III, an Army lieutenant general who has done two tours in Iraq and currently serves as a senior aide to the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, senior military and civilian officials say.

title: Amendments and Impasse May Hamper Banking Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Banking Committee might face some late nights next week.

title: Health Care Pushes Other Issues to Margins
description: WASHINGTON  One weekend last month, American forces drove into the Marja area of southern Afghanistan, opening the biggest military operation of the Obama presidency. In the five weeks since then, President Obama has made 38 speeches, statements or other public remarks and never once mentioned the operation.

title: As Time Grows Short, the Search for Ayes Narrows to a Dozen or So Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  The Democratic search for health care votes dwindled to a dozen or so lawmakers Friday as the House leadership and the White House sought to cement victory in a vote now set for Sunday.

title: U.S. Basketball Prodigy Quits Israeli Pro Team
description: At halftime of a Maccabi Haifa game nearly a month ago, the American basketball prodigy Jeremy Tyler changed out of his uniform and spent the second half in street clothes. Tyler had not played in the first half, and he watched the rest of the game from the stands.

title: Bloggingheads: You Pass It, You Own It
description: David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate whether passing health care reform would hurt Democrats.

title: Corrections
description: The Vancouver Journal article on Feb. 25, about the apprehension in Vancouver, British Columbia, over large debts accrued because of the Olympics, referred incorrectly to $423 million provided to the organizers by the International Olympic Committee. That amount was the estimated contribution from the I.O.C. for the Games, as reported late in 2009 by the organizers; it was not the amount of emergency funds that the I.O.C. provided to help the organizers break even. (Neither the organizers nor the I.O.C. have disclosed the emergency funds figure.)

title: So Much Light We Could See to the Other Side
description: All fuel and fire, spine left like a bent arrow, dark matter, the teeth as relic, all of our words bitter fruit. Who could have believed we were made like this. The cosmonaut,

title: Adviser in Haiti to Americans Is Captured
description: MEXICO CITY  The Dominican authorities said Friday that they had arrested Jorge Anbal Torres Puello, who acted as a legal adviser for a group of American church members who were detained in Haiti on child abduction charges, even though he himself was wanted on trafficking charges in the United States and El Salvador.

title: At Stuyvesant, Interpreting Parent-Teacher Night
description: They were too old to be high school students, but not old enough to be the parents. They were lingering near Room 236 at Stuyvesant High School, a group of 20 young people, all of them Asian, standing awkwardly together, waiting for the moment when their peripheral but crucial role would become clear to the main characters at the event, the vaunted parent-teacher night.

title: Acorn on Brink of Bankruptcy, Officials Say
description: BALTIMORE  The community organizing group Acorn, battered politically from the right and suffering from mismanagement along with a severe loss of government and other funds, is on the verge of filing for bankruptcy, officials of the group said Friday.

title: Manhattan Judges Trial Raises Thorny Election Law Issues Concerning Gifts
description: The jury in the trial of Nora S. Anderson, a Manhattan Surrogates Court judge, may have to consider a question on which even election law experts disagree: Are candidates allowed to use monetary gifts or loans from friends toward their campaigns?

title: Player Draws Double Takes and Triple Teams
description: College basketball observers sound like naturalists who have spotted something startling in the evolutionary soup when they talk about Baylors Brittney Griner. After watching her for the first time, Michael Cooper telephoned his former Lakers teammate Magic Johnson to say he had seen the female version of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, a Laker whose scoring prowess at U.C.L.A. contributed to the N.C.A.A.s banning the dunk for nine seasons.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about an Interior Department report on environmental threats to the nations migratory birds referred incorrectly to the reasons for the problem. The study did not cite hunting as a factor. For the first time, the department added climate change to other factors, including destruction of habitat, pesticides, invasive species and loss of wetlands. (Interior Secretary Ken Salazar, who commented on the report, noted that commercial hunting had historically been a threat.)

title: How to Say Theater in Yiddish? Two Ways
description: Yiddish theater may have faded since its heyday on the Lower East Side, but it still has enough pep to produce a pesky upstart repertory company, as well as a spirited rivalry between it and a veteran troupe.

title: Nuns Back Bill Amid Broad Rift Over Whether It Limits Abortion Enough
description: WASHINGTON  In breaking publicly with Roman Catholic bishops over the health care bill, a group of nuns has once again exposed the long-running rift between liberal and conservative theology in the Catholic Church.

title: In Fight for Influence, Special Council Election in Brooklyn Is Filled With Intensity
description: Collectible rabbi trading cards have been used as campaign props, and hundreds of voters attended a debate. An 18-year-old candidates jump into politics ended when he was thrown off the ballot after legal challenges from seasoned rivals. There have been allegations of smears and strong-arm tactics to neutralize opposing supporters.

title: Central Bank in India Raises Interest Rates
description: Indias central bank unexpectedly raised interest rates on Friday for the first time in almost two years and said that with inflation at a 16-month high, the need to control prices was imperative.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 6 about weak consumer protection rules in Japan referred incompletely to the history of Toyota recalls in that country. While there have been no recalls in Japan related to floor mats, sticky gas pedals or unexpected acceleration, as there have been elsewhere in the world, there have been some recalls related to problems in regenerative braking systems on hybrid vehicles. (In addition to a recall in Japan earlier this year of Prius cars, Toyota has also recalled the Sai hybrid sedan, sold only in Japan; the Lexus HS250h hybrid, sold in Japan and elsewhere; and the plug-in Prius hybrid for similar braking problems. Those recalls affected some 475,000 cars; the recalls outside of Japan affected about eight million cars.)

title: Altering Tactics, Icahn Seeks All of Lions Gate
description: Carl C. Icahn said on Friday that he was seeking to acquire all of Lions Gate Entertainment, the film company, broadening a tender offer that originally sought to expand his stake to 29.9 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Cornell basketballs one-man radio broadcasting operation misstated the name of the arena in Florida where the team played its first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game. It is Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena, not Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

title: Renewed Support for an Everglades Land Deal, but Cost Is Still in Question
description: MIAMI  Gov. Charlie Crist reaffirmed his commitment this week to the $536 million purchase of 73,000 acres of land from United States Sugar, declaring that it would heal both the Everglades and the coastal estuaries that are vital to Floridas tourist economy.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about people who acted as guides as part of the work This Progress by Tino Seghal at the Guggenheim Museum misstated the surname of one and misspelled the given name of another. A sixth-grader at the School at Columbia University who took part is Solomon Dworkin, not Bender. A junior at Hunter College High School who also served as a guide is Bram Wasti, not Bran.

title: Rio Tinto and Chinalco in Deal for Iron Project
description: HONG KONG  Nine months after they scrapped a $19.5 billion alliance, the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto and Chinalco of China reached a deal Friday to jointly develop an iron ore project in the West African country of Guinea.

title: Watching the Shadows
description: Dean DeBlois and Chris Sanders, the co-directors of "How to Train Your Dragon," discuss the lighting design of the film.

title: Amendments and Impasse May Stall Financial Bill
description: The Senate Banking Committee might face some late nights in the coming week. The committee, which is set to begin consideration of a bill that would overhaul financial regulations, received 359 amendments by the Friday deadline, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: Corrections
description: The Editors Letter on Page 10 this weekend about the new On Language columnist, Ben Zimmer, omits part of the name of an organization to which he belongs. It is the Dictionary Society of North America, not the Dictionary Society of America.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Wayne Collett, an American runner who was barred from competing again in Olympic competition after he was judged to have acted disrespectfully during a medal ceremony in Munich in 1972, misstated the date of an interview with The Los Angeles Times in which he explained and defended his actions. It was 2002, not 1992.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Aperitif + Beer + Cocktails = Tipsy
description: WHEN picking a bar for a round or two after work, most people consider things like proximity to the office, quality of the beer list, or happy hour prices. For a small group of intrepid New York drinkers, however, the chief criterion for the last year has been the bars name. More specifically, the first letter of that name.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed essay on Wednesday, about the Federal Reserve and consumer protection, misidentified the state represented in the House of Representatives by William Delahunt. It is Massachusetts, not Delaware.

title: Cornell Gets to Stick Around
description: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team, which is seeded 12th in the East Region and beat No. 5 Temple on Friday in Jacksonville, Fla. Jon has been blogging for The Quad throughout this season. You can also follow him on Twitter.

title: The Present Is Fine, the Future Can Wait
description: TAMPA  In the first few hours of an extra-long day at Yankees camp, Joba Chamberlain, who could be back in the bullpen when the season begins, engaged Mariano Rivera in a funny and telling back-and-forth.

title: Gonzagas Balance Fends Off Florida State
description: BUFFALO  There was a sense of balance to Gonzagas attack Friday night. Matt Bouldin, the Bulldogs shaggy-haired shooting guard, powered his way past Florida States defenders and reached the paint on drives. Once inside, he joined forces with forward Elias Harris and center Robert Sacre to power up for points. Those three players totaled 43 points.

title: Live Updates From the N.C.A.A. Tournament: Day 2, Part II
description: Live updates and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Kevin Armstrong in Buffalo, Joe Lapointe in Milwaukee, John Branch in Spokane, Wash., and Ray Glier in Jacksonville, Fla., will provide updates, and Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward, will offer analysis about the games from South Bend, Ind. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comments section below.

title: In Bid to Sway Sales, Cameras Track Shoppers
description: The curvy mannequin piqued the interest of a couple of lanky teenage boys. Little did they know that as they groped its tight maroon shirt in the clothing store that day, video cameras were rolling.

title: Now on Video: Your Trip to the Mall
description: A behind-the-scenes look at how retailers are using surveillance video technology to improve their operations.

title: Michigan State Wins War of Words
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  The trash-talking that began days before Michigan State and New Mexico State took to the court on Friday night, as players from both teams engaged in a stirring debate of vocal one-upmanship and sharp-shooting rebuttals.

title: A Window Into Human Trafficking in Texas
description: One of the topics on my to do list this year is more on human trafficking here in the U.S. Ive written a fair amount about the topic in Cambodia, India, Pakistan, but I havent done as much reporting on the issue here in the U.S. Stay tuned!

title: A Ruinous Meltdown
description: A story that is not getting nearly enough attention is the ruinous fiscal meltdown occurring in state after state, all across the country.

title: Could Obama Be Invincible?
description: As we stand at the verge of the historic vote on the health care bill  a signature piece of President Obamas agenda  it feels appropriate to take a look at how he has fared during the long slog that got us here. My quick assessment: remarkably well.

title: The Fishing Lobby Wins Again
description: Thursday was a terrible day for bluefin tuna.

title: Saints Preserve Us
description: On Friday, as Democrats were flopping around madly over the upcoming vote on health care, Speaker Nancy Pelosi noted brightly that it was the feast of St. Joseph the Worker, where we remember and pray to St. Joseph to benefit the workers of America. And thats exactly what our health care bill will do.

title: The Suicides at Cornell
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinian Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Race and Mythology in Drug Laws
description: Congress is trying to undo some of the damage it inflicted more than two decades ago with its frenzied mandating of longer prison sentences for abusers of crack cocaine than for those who abuse the powder version.

title: Fleeing a Sinking Governorship
description: Five top state officials have now fled Gov. David Patersons side, the latest of them being his press secretary. The terms of their departure made it clear that they were either implicated in or appalled by what appears to have been an attempt by Mr. Paterson to suppress charges of domestic violence against one of the his closest aides.

title: Unreality TV: If the Boss Only Knew, He Would Do Something
description: In the premiere of the new CBS show Undercover Boss, Lawrence ODonnell III, the president of Waste Management  the large trash-collection company  disguised himself as a lowly worker. In these tough times, a voice-over declared, hard-working Americans blame wealthy, out-of-touch C.E.O.s, but some bosses are willing to take extreme action to make their businesses better.

title: Create a National DNA Database?
description: To the Editor:

title: Closing an Auto Plant: Toyotas Side of the Story
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Cabdrivers Accused of Overcharging
description: To the Editor:

title: A Foreign Service for Wall Street
description: LAST week, Lehman Brothers bankruptcy examiner released a report showing that the investment firm went to great lengths to hide its shaky finances. In fact, it even managed to evade a team of investigators from the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve who were embedded at Lehman headquarters with the sole purpose of ferreting out accounting sleight-of-hand.

title: So Far, So Good for Duke
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Duke suffocated Arkansas-Pine Bluff with size and togetherness on defense, but that is not going to satisfy the curiosity of the critical masses. The more important issue is if guard Jon Scheyer is working his way out of a shooting slump and if Duke can get meaningful play out of a big man.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 19, 2010

title: Corrections
description: SPORTS

title: Is a DNA Scan a Medical Test or Just Informational? Views Differ
description: Residents of New York State who want to send saliva for DNA testing by 23andMe should do their spitting outside state lines.

title: Consumers Slow to Embrace the Age of Genomics
He Was Served to the Olympians as Food
description: Admiral Halsey notified me,He had to have a berth or he couldnt get to sea.I had another look and I had a cup of teaAnd butter pie. Paul and Lindy McCartney

title: Request to Extend Patent on Blood Drug Is Denied
description: A reprieve from a billion-dollar blunder proved all too brief for the Medicines Company.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Lindsay Hoag and Edward Telleria misspelled the surname of the brides mother. She is Christine E. Letzeiser, not Letzeifer.

title: California: Review Backs Water Limits
description: The National Academy of Sciences said Friday that the scientific rationale behind a decision to protect the endangered smelt, a tiny fish, by restricting the pumping of water from the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta was sound. The Interior Department asked the academy to undertake a review at the request of Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, who would like to find ways to allow drought-plagued farmers to get more water. Growers in Northern California have filed lawsuits contesting the restrictions. The academy essentially affirmed the science and said there were no plausible alternatives to the restrictions. It did acknowledge some uncertainty about whether the triggers for reduced pumping were precisely accurate but emphasized that there was no evidence the triggers were wrong. It recommended further study.

title: Mitre Improves His Chances
description: The veteran Sergio Mitre improved his chances of making the team by striking out seven in five innings while limiting a lineup of mostly Tampa Bay regulars to two runs on two hits.

title: Georgia Tech Solves Anderson and Oklahoma State
description: MILWAUKEE  The junior guard James Anderson of Oklahoma State is one of the best players in college basketball and he very possibly was the best in the Big 12 this season. But Anderson was not even the best player on the floor Friday night when Georgia Tech befuddled him and the Yellow Jackets beat the Cowboys, 64-59.

title: SXSW: Serendipity, and Sometimes Disappointments, in Choosing What to See
description: Maybe some people come to South by Southwest with carefully planned schedules, giving them a definite place to be, hour by blaring hour, but I never do. It may be professional heresy to admit it, but aside from maybe 5 or 6 unmissably newsworthy shows, I never have any idea what Im doing until hours or even a few minutes beforehand, the decision usually made by scanning through crushingly long and unreadable online indexes, sifting through emails, flipping through papers and scribbled notes.

title: Xavier Womens Team Finds Right Mix of Laughter and Wins
description: Xavier has finally elbowed its way into the tiny group of elite teams in womens college basketball. The Musketeers, however, have not given up the light touches developed along the way, like dancing in layup lines or rapping in the locker room moments before Kevin McGuff, their coach, gives a steely pregame speech.

title: Palm Stock Falls After a Disappointing Forecast
description: Shares of Palm Inc., creator of the Pre smartphone, fell the most in more than two years in Nasdaq trading after it forecast sales this quarter that were less than half of analysts estimates. Revenue in the period ending in May will be less than $150 million, the chief financial officer, Doug Jeffries, said after the close of trading on Thursday on Palms third-quarter conference call. That falls short of the $300 million average of estimates compiled by Bloomberg News. The company also reported its 11th consecutive quarterly loss. Shares of Palm, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., fell $1.65, or 29 percent, to $4, on Friday.

title: Retail Sales in Canada Rose in January
description: Canadian retail sales rose in January, as consumers stocked up on home improvement supplies before a federal tax credit expired. Retail sales rose 0.7 percent, to 35.7 billion Canadian dollars ($35.1 billion), Statistics Canada said. Excluding car and parts dealers, retail sales rose 1.8 percent in January, Statistics Canada said. Economists had predicted a 0.5 percent increase, based on the median of 15 estimates.

title: Baylor Coach Stands by His Recruiting Methods
description: NEW ORLEANS  Baylor Coach Scott Drew makes no apologies for his dogged recruiting philosophy.

title: Son of Iran Becomes Unlikely Big Shot for Northern Iowa
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Ali Farokhmaneshs father, Mashala, played volleyball for Iran in the 1980 Summer Olympics, but that was not as prestigious as it might seem. For one thing, Mashala played most of his games on concrete courts. And volleyball players need to dive.

title: Syracuse Crushes Vermont
description: BUFFALO  With one crisp crossover, the Syracuse point guard Scoop Jardine sent the message that No. 16-seed Vermont did not belong on the same court as the top-seeded Orange (29-4) Friday. Nick Vier, the defender on the play, was stood up, stumbled and left helpless as Jardine finished strong to the basket. The feeling of domination remained throughout Syracuses 79-56 win.

title: Calipari Has Fondness for New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  The night before top-seeded Kentucky romped over No. 16 seed East Tennessee State in the opening round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Wildcats Coach John Calipari allowed his team to visit Bourbon Street and the French Quarter.

title: With Knicks Bench Depleted, Rookie Delivers vs. 76ers
description: David Lee did not play Friday night because of tendinitis in his right knee. In his place, Jonathan Bender made his first N.B.A. start in seven years, and departed before halftime with a fractured finger in his left hand.

title: Correction
description: An article on March 7 about new methods for training teachers misstated the size of DePaul University, where one teacher interviewed on the subject studied. It is one of the largest private universities in the Chicago area, with about 25,000 students, not a small one.

title: Obama Offers Engagement in Video Message to Iranians
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama delivered his second message to the Iranian people for the festival of Nowruz, which marks the Iranian New Year, releasing a video on Saturday in which he again offered Irans leaders engagement with the United States.

title: Charles Muscatine, Chaucer Scholar, Dies at 89
description: Charles Muscatine, a scholar who transformed Chaucer studies by turning attention to the French models for Chaucers poetry, and who pursued a side career as an educational reformer after becoming embroiled in the Free Speech Movement at the University of California, Berkeley, died on March 12 in Oakland, Calif. He was 89 and lived in Berkeley.

title: Cal Beats Louisville in Another Blow to Big East
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The ridicule directed at the Pac-10 and its brand of basketball has been quieted for the time being. Not only have the two teams from the Pac-10 won their opening-round games in the tournament, but both victories came against teams from the Big East, which was regarded (at least until the tournament) as the best league in college basketball.

title: Maryland Slowly Takes Control of Houston
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  For a little more than a half, Maryland, a co-champion of the Atlantic Coast Conference, struggled to put away a team that had a losing record in Conference USA.

title: Jane Sherman, Dancer and Writer, Dies at 101
description: Jane Sherman, a writer who not only chronicled the excitement of early-20th-century American dance but also lived through it as a performer, died on Tuesday at the Lillian Booth Actors Home in Englewood, N.J. She was 101.

title: Underclassmen Leave an Unusual Legacy
description: Many of the greatest professional players of the 1970s, 80s and 90s were also among the greatest collegiate players of their eras. Bill Russell, Bob Cousy, Jerry Lucas, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Magic Johnson, Michael Jordan and Isiah Thomas won N.C.A.A. titles before winning N.B.A. titles in their Hall of Fame professional careers. Russell and Johnson even won back-to-back N.C.A.A. and N.B.A. titles.

title: Wake Forests Smith Practices Against the Best
description: NEW ORLEANS  During the summers, Wake Forest point guard Ishamel Smith has honed his skills by playing against New Orleans Hornets point guard Chris Paul.

title: For Baylor, a Reminder of One Who Got Away
description: NEW ORLEANS  Baylor once dreamed of making the N.C.A.A. tournament with the freshman sensation point guard John Wall.

title: Skateboarding Will Be Next for Snowboarding Champion
description: STRATTON, Vt.  In the weeks after winning a second Olympic gold medal in the halfpipe at the Winter Olympics in Vancouver, Shaun White flew to Japan, London, Germany, Chicago and Los Angeles (twice)  all part of an international media tour that kept him away from snowboarding.

title: Santana Is Unperturbed After Second Shaky Stint
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Johan Santana was the face of the Twins during his eight years in Minnesota, and on Friday he squared off against them for the first time since he came to the Mets in 2008.

title: No Gimmicks for Old Dominions Coach
description: NEW ORLEANS  With No. 3 seed Baylor struggling in its opening-round N.C.A.A. tournament win against the triangle-and-two defense that No. 14 seed Sam Houston State employed, Old Dominion Coach Blaine Taylor was asked Friday if his team might use it against the Bears.

title: Switzerland: New Record Set for Speedy Protons
description: Scientists at CERN, the European nuclear research agency, announced Friday morning that they had accelerated beams of protons at the worlds largest particle accelerator, the Large Hadron Collider near Geneva, to energies of 3.5 trillion electron volts. That is a new record, three times the energy of any other machine on earth, and means that the collider, after 15 years and $10 billion, is on the verge of beginning to do physics experiments. Physicists hope to begin colliding the beams by the end of the month.

title: SXSW: Four-Word Reviews From Friday (and One Thursday Leftover)
description: The Coathangers: Cavegrrrls squeal, shake, roar.

title: The Hurt Locker  From Inside a Baghdad Cinema
description: Stephen Farrell and Tim Arango accompanied Iraqis to a Baghdad screening of the Hollywood movie, The Hurt Locker in a literary society in central Baghdad. A video of some of their reactions is above, and Tims story in The New York Times is at Iraqis Gather to Watch Hollywoods Take on a War That Has Enveloped Their Lives.

title: SXSW: A Slide Show
Drawing Inspiration From Who Dat Nation
description: When the basketball left Danero Thomass hands, all Willie Mae Thomas could do was hope and pray.

title: State of the Texans: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Classic Ad: Chrysler New Yorker
description: They dont make pitchmen like they used to. Exhibit A: Jack Jones in this 1975 ad for the Chrysler New Yorker.

title: Pope Offers Apology, Not Penalty, for Sex Abuse Scandal
description: VATICAN CITY  Faced with a church sexual abuse scandal spreading across Europe, Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday apologized directly to victims and their families in Ireland, expressing shame and remorse for what he called sinful and criminal acts committed by members of the clergy.

title: America Is Not Indonesia
description: Urk. The FT publishes yet another dire warnings about the dollar piece  as news, not opinion!  comparing the US dollar to the Indonesian rupiah before the 1997-8 Asian crisis:

title: Looking Ahead: Day 3
description: MIDWEST

title: Saturday Word: Health Care (and Finance)
description: This weekend Washington is abuzz about one thing alone  health care. Mr. Obama is making a personal visit to Capitol Hill to meet with his partys House members this afternoon to wrangle together the remaining votes for the bill Congressional Democrats are increasingly sure they will pass Sunday. (Thats on top of meetings and telephone calls with 64 members of Congress, Robert Gibbs boasted Thursday.)

title: Obama Addresses Iran by Web Video
description: On Saturday, the White House Web site posted a video message from President Barack Obama to the Iranian people as they celebrate the Persian New Year, Nowruz. The video, which is embedded above, was also posted on the White House YouTube channel. A full transcript of the presidents remarks (embedded below) was made available online, along with Persian and Arabic translations.

title: Suns Nash Stays Productive
description: In his fourteenth season in the N.B.A., Steve Nash of the Phoenix Suns entered the weekend tied for the league lead in assists at 11.2 a game, his highest total since the 2006-7 season. Nash did not become a starter until his third season and did not make his first All-Star team until he was 27, but he had piled up 8,255 assists, good for eighth on the career list. If he is able to keep playing at close to his current rate for three more seasons, he has a chance to become the fifth player to record 10,000 assists.

title: My Friends are Coming Over
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: You guys enjoying March Madness? I am so pumped for this weekend. My friends are coming over. Were going to pound some beers, paint our faces, and watch the healthcare vote go down on C-SPAN. Yeah!

title: Thats the Big Thing
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Thank you very much! Welcome to The Tonight Show. Oh, man. You sound like a bunch of congressmen lining up to get all your freebies to vote yes on healthcare.

title: M.L.S. and Players Reach a New Deal
description: 2:12 p.m. |Update

title: Obamas Strong First Round
description: 8:37 p.m. | Updated At least he has health care. By the time President Obama finished his dinner, he had lost half his Final Four (Villanova and Kansas) and the team he picked to win it all (the Jayhawks). Hell be hoping for more favorable results Sunday on multiple fronts. Liz Robbins

title: Would You Pay $20 for Access to a Breast Cancer Cure?
description: It seems safe to describe Andrew Hessel as an unbridled optimist. After all, hes selling $20 shares in a journey toward a personalized cure for breast cancer, which he says could be feasible in the next few years.

title: Stop the Diagramless
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Diagramless puzzles in the New York Times always have themes. Sometimes the themes are hidden. They sneak up on you as you solve the puzzle. Sometimes theyre obvious from the clues, four of which are identical today. Sometimes, theyre both. Hmmm.

title: British Airways Strike Begins
description: LONDON  British Airways cabin crews began a three-day strike on Saturday, disrupting schedules and forcing the airline to cancel 1,100 flights.

title: Stupak Postpones News Conference
description: Representative Bart Stupak, Democrat of Michigan and a leader of the Congressional Pro-Life Caucus, has postponed a news conference that had been scheduled for 11 a.m. on Saturday, a sign that there is still serious maneuvering under way in the fight over abortion language in the major health care legislation.

title: Academic Paper in China Sets Off Alarms in U.S.
description: It came as a surprise this month to Wang Jianwei, a graduate engineering student in Liaoning, China, that he had been described as a potential cyberwarrior before the United States Congress.

title: March Poli-Book Best Sellers
description: Just a few weeks after former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney began ramping up his profile with a speaking/promotional tour, his book, No Apology, debuts in our No. 1 slot on the Caucus best-selling list of political books.

title: Playoff Races Are Quiet
description: The final month of the season is traditionally a time when fans begin to focus their attention toward the bottom of the standings to see who is going to make the playoffs and who is going to be making tee times.

title: U.N. Chief Urges Israel to End Settlement Building
description: JERUSALEM  During a visit to the West Bank city of Ramallah on Saturday, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, called on Israel to cease all settlement construction in the occupied territories.

title: Obama Rallies Democrats in Final Push for Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and House Democratic leaders on Saturday closed in on the votes needed to pass landmark health care legislation, with the outcome hinging on their efforts to placate a handful of lawmakers who wanted the bill to include tighter limits on insurance coverage for abortions.

title: Both Sides Claim Success as Diplomatic Row Wanes
description: JERUSALEM  After 10 days of public quarreling over Jewish building in East Jerusalem, the Israeli government and the Obama administration have each declared victory and started to make up. The Americans believe they have extracted important concessions from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu; the Israelis think they have yielded little.

title: Russian Protests Seeking Ouster of Putin Fall Short
description: KALININGRAD, Russia  Russians held relatively small demonstrations across the country on Saturday to call for the ouster of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, seeking to mobilize discontent over a faltering economy, rising prices and government officials perceived as unresponsive to average people.

title: With Breakdown of Order in Russias Dagestan Region, Fear Stalks Police
description: MAKHACHKALA, Russia  At a certain point last summer, when snipers on rooftops began picking off police officers, Col. Mukhtar Mukhtarovs wife blocked the door with her body and refused to let him leave home in his uniform.

title: Rethinking Sex Offender Laws for Youth Texting
description: In Iowa, Jorge Canal is on the sex offenders registry because, at age 18, he was convicted of distributing obscene materials to a minor after he sent a picture of his penis by cellphone to a 14-year-old female friend who had requested it.

title: Procedural Maneuvering and Public Opinion
description: WASHINGTON  You could forgive Americans for being a little confused. At a moment when Congress is engaged in a crucial debate about overhauling the health care system, the talk from Washington is about self-executing rules, deem and pass, reconciliation, the Slaughter Rule, preliminary C.B.O. scores, final C.B.O. scores  not to mention filibusters, cloture votes, the Byrd Bath and supermajorities.

title: Democrats Edge Closer to 216 Votes
description: Democrats now appear to be within 10 votes of the 216 they will need to pass major health care legislation.

title: Pushing Back at Stereotypes
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Brittney Griner, Baylors 6-foot-8 freshman center, was supposed to deliver her transformative moments by slamming a basketball through the rim, not punching an opponent in the face.

title: Obama Joins the Arm-Twisting
description: President Obama is telephoning individual Democrats to ask for their support of the major health care legislation in advance of his planned visit to Capitol Hill on Saturday afternoon, the White House said.

title: To Soccer Fan, Train Whistle Hits Perfect Pitch
description: Harrison, N.J.

title: A Satirical Site Skewers Chvez and Politics
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  This may be a perilous time to operate a Web site focused on politics here, given President Hugo Chvezs recent push for new controls of Internet content. But one plucky Venezuelan satirical site is emerging as a runaway success in Latin America as it repeatedly skewers Mr. Chvez and a host of other leaders.

title: Officer Shoots Man Wielding Knives
description: A 33-year-old man wielding two large kitchen knives and threatening his neighbors in an apartment building in the Bronx on Friday night was shot and wounded by a police officer after he advanced on the officer and his colleague, the authorities said.

title: Surprises Pan Out for Ohio States Turner
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  While pregnant with her third child, Iris Turner was thrilled to learn that sonograms showed she was going to have her first girl. She chose a name, Aulbri Leanette.

title: Official in China Says Western-Style Democracy Wont Take Root There
description: BEIJING  A Chinese legislative official has said that China will not adopt Western-style democracy, marking a rare instance in which a member of the government here openly rejects Western-style liberal political reforms.

title: Live Updates From the N.C.A.A. Tournament, Second Round
description: Live updates and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Pete Thamel in Providence, Thayer Evans in New Orleans, Billy Witz in San Jose and Dave Caldwell in Oklahoma City will give updates, and Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward, will offer analysis about the games from South Bend, Ind. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comments section below.

title: Arrest in Racial Case at N.J. Wal-Mart
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N.J.  The authorities in southern New Jersey said Saturday that they had arrested a 16-year-old boy for activating a public-address system at a Wal-Mart store last week and ordering all black people to leave.

title: A Minor Leaguer in Limbo Becomes a Slugger With a Future
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  A typical Class AAA baseball team has three kinds of players: those going up, those going down and those in the middle. The ones going up do not stay long. The ones going down have played long enough in the majors to know where they fit. The ones in the middle just get older.

title: Albert J. Rosenthal, Columbia Law Dean, Dies at 91
description: Albert J. Rosenthal, who as dean of Columbia Law School in the late 1970s and early 1980s helped increase the number of women on the schools faculty, died on Wednesday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 91 and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: California Tribe Hopes to Woo Salmon Home
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On Friday night, more than two dozen Native Americans embarked from here on a spiritual mission to New Zealand, where they will ask their fish to come home to California.

title: In Europe, a Young Champion Emerges From Deep Ranks
description: The European Championships showed how much the chess world has changed in the last 20 years.

title: If Woods Plays Well, Retailers Will Smile
description: Tiger Woodss break from golf since late November could not have been timed better for golf retailers. His absence coincided with the months when clothing and equipment sales are slow and discounts move goods during the holidays.

title: Checking In With Chien-Ming Wang
description: VIERA, Fla.  The big news for the Washington Nationals today is that Stephen Strasburg has been sent to minor league camp, as the team had planned all along.

title: Fed Chief Takes Aim at Banks as Obama Pushes Overhaul
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  Giant banks that are perceived as too big to fail are among the most insidious barriers to competition in financial services, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Saturday.

title: As Rules Committee Meets, Democrats Scramble for Votes
description: White House officials and House Democratic leaders worked furiously on Saturday to secure the votes needed to pass landmark health care legislation, with the outcome riding on a small group of lawmakers who want the bill to include tighter limits on insurance coverage for abortions.

title: SXSW: Courtney Love, With Guitar and Tiara
description: Courtney Loves entrance at the Stubbs BBQ amphitheater was her re-entry into rock, and she reveled in it. For Holes first show since 1999, she was wearing a gauzy designer dress, a kind of tiara in her hair, a Rickenbacker guitar and an orange sash that read: BEWARE. In 2010, Ms. Love is an old-school rock star: rich and infamous, a bad girl blurting things out and basking in attention, any kind. Its glorious, its terrible that Im here, she sang in a new song.

title: Davy Crockett, King of the Retail Frontier
description: Fess Parker, who died last week at the age of 85, was catapulted to stardom by his TV portrayal of the frontiersman Davy Crockett.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 21
description: Rank-and-file Democrats and Republicans emerge center stage for Sundays discussion on Democrats health care overhaul as the House prepares to vote on legislation Sunday afternoon with an eye toward Novembers elections.

title: Prime Number
description: 16: The percentage of the United States populationliving in multigenerational families, or nearly 50 million people, according to a Pew Research Center analysis of census data. These households have made a comeback after bottoming out in 1980, when only 12 percent of Americans lived in them. One reason: more adult children share a home with their parents. Another: the big wave of immigration that began around 1970. Immigrants are far more likely to live in such households, which Pew defined as a home with at least two adult generations or with a grandparent and at least one other generation.

title: Quotation of the Week
description: In todays online world, what your mother told you is true, only more so: people really can judge you by your friends.

title: Does Icahn Still Make Them Tremble?
description: HE is a billionaire several times over. He has spent the better part of four decades terrorizing corporate chiefs and battling entrenched boards. His name is emblazoned on a stadium on an island in the East River, a laboratory at Princeton, a science center at the Choate Rosemary Hall school in Connecticut and charter schools in the Bronx.

title: A New Name for a Payroll Tax
description: When is the Medicare payroll tax not the Medicare payroll tax? When its the unearned income Medicare contribution, of course.

title: Surprising Rockets See Promising Future
description: While the nation is fixated on underdogs and upsets in the N.C.A.A. tournament, the N.B.A.s own fairy-tale team is fast approaching midnight.

title: Updated: A Pep Rally for House Democrats
description: 4:07 p.m. |Reid Promises Senate Will Follow Through

title: Those Wall Street Gamblers Might Not Be Bad After All
description: Originally, they were the good guys.

title: St. Marys Knocks Out Villanova
description: PROVIDENCE  In the final minute of No. 10-seeded St. Marys upset of No. 2 Villanova in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Saturday, the Gaels big man Omar Samhan sidled up to Villanovas Corey Stokes while his teammate Matthew Dellavedova iced the game at the free-throw line.

title: New Jersey: A Blue State Deep in Debt Rethinks Whats Important
description: You know taxes are too high when even the liberals root for spending cuts.

title: Magics Unknown Quantity
description: When draft day arrived last summer, Orlando Magic General Manager Otis Smith did not use a scalpel for cosmetic alterations on a roster fresh off an appearance in the N.B.A. finals. He used a jackhammer for a major renovation as the Magic crossed the luxury-tax barrier for the first time and imported five new players. None of them is more integral than the sometimes inscrutable Vince Carter, whom Smith acquired from the Nets.

title: SXSW: Marina and the Diamonds
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  How many of you heard of me two seconds ago, like today? inquired Marina Diamandis, a Welsh-Greek songwriter who bills herself as Marina and the Diamonds, in her set at Lamberts on Friday. Well, thats the point of SXSW.

title: In Iraq, Even a Vote Hints at Violence
description: BAGHDAD  Near a sturdy hedge of pomegranate trees, interspersed with saplings of a citrus grove, a tribal sheik in the once-cauterized landscape of Anbar Province embraced the new in Iraqs elections this month, with a vigilant, perhaps essential eye to the old.

title: U.S. Turns a Blind Eye to Opium in Afghan Town
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The effort to win over Afghans on former Taliban turf in Marja has put American and NATO commanders in the unusual position of arguing against opium eradication, pitting them against some Afghan officials who are pushing to destroy the harvest.

title: Obama Forcefully Makes Case at Capitol
description: 4:23 p.m. |It Is in Your Hands

title: SXSW: The Food Truck Diet
description: AUSTIN, Tex. Eating at South by Southwest requires major multitasking: youre on the run from show to show, scanning text messages, e-mail and Web sites for surprise guests and info on line lengths as you go, dodging bikini-ed Hula-hooping girls and stepping over street singers, trying not to bump into anyone else doing the same. If youre starving, you grab a snack from a pizza or barbecue truck and hope it gets in your mouth and not all over your clothes. All of which may account for the popularity of dinner-hour movie screenings at the Alamo Drafthouse at the Ritz on Sixth Street, where discreet waiters, whispering and ducking down so as not to interfere with movie-watching pleasure, bring you beer and fat Texas burgers (some regulars recommend a side of fried pickles), which you eat from a wooden shelf in front of your comfortable seat. If youre really serious about getting the most out of your badge or wristband, it may be the only sit-down meal you get all week.

description: WASHINGTON  Immigrant advocates, frustrated with President Obamas lack of progress on legislation to overhaul the immigration system, called one month ago for a march in Washington that they said would display the strength of their numbers and would give the president the push he needed to get the debate rolling in Congress.

description: Liz Carpenter, who spent much of her life working the corridors of power in Washington as a newspaper reporter, an aide to Lyndon B. description: We were, briefly, chilled when the credit rating agencies  Moodys, Standard and Poors, and Fitch  warned that they might have to downgrade the triple-A debt of the United States if it failed to bring its budget deficit under control. Then we remembered it was not too long ago that these agencies were tripping over one another to bestow triple-A ratings on many of the incomprehensible financial confections the banks crafted out of mounds of dicey mortgages.

description: TAMPA, Fla.  If he hadnt guessed already, Curtis Granderson learned for real what its like to play for a New York team early Saturday.

In August, the theater company will have been performing for 15 years at the amphitheater set amid oaks and redwoods. Mr. Dooley, 42, lives in south Berkeley with his wife, Kimberly, and their three young daughters. (His words have been edited and condensed.)

title: Obama, Lehman and The Dragon Tattoo
description: THE same week that Lehman Brothers collapsed in September 2008, a Swedish crime novel titled The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo was published in America. The book didnt receive a ton of hype, not least because the author, a journalist named Stieg Larsson, was unavailable for interviews; he had died in 2004 of a heart attack at the age of 50. The mixed Times review appeared in the back pages of the Sunday Book Review. Many more readers were riveted instead by the Lehman article on that mornings front page: A Wall Street Goliath Teeters Amid Fears of a Widening Crisis.

title: The Acorn Sting Revisited
description: THE Times reported Saturday that Acorn, once considered the nations largest community organizing group for the poor and powerless, is on the verge of filing for bankruptcy. It has already ceased operating in many states, including Maryland, where two conservative activists pretending to be a pimp and a prostitute used a hidden camera and recorded Acorn employees advising them on how to conceal the source of illegal income and manage 14-year-old Salvadoran prostitutes in the country illegally: Train them to keep their mouth shut.

title: Who Grades the Graders?
description: While we had mixed feelings about President Obamas plans for reworking the No Child Left Behind Act, he got it right when he called on the states to create credible systems for evaluating teachers and principals. But emulating the small number of schools that already have those systems will not be easy. It will mean creating a new school culture and redefining not just the roles of teachers, but the roles of principals and superintendents.

title: Long Shot Wins One Derby and Heads to a Bigger One
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla.  Beating his fellow long shot Pleasant Prince by a nose at the Florida Derby on Saturday, Ice Box has earned his way into the field for the May 1 Kentucky Derby. He now has the earnings to get into the race and the type of important win on his rsum that suggests he belongs among the elite of the 3-year-old division.

description: STRATTON, Vt.  Shaun White was a no-show in the halfpipe at the United States Open Snowboarding Championships. But several riders demonstrated his influence during the mens halfpipe finals on a warm, sunny Saturday afternoon in the Green Mountains.

title: Now On Deck: Financial Regulatory Reform
description: Giant banks that are perceived as too big to fail are among the most insidious barriers to competition in financial services, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Saturday, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Kissimmee, Fla.

title: Cheryl Miller Can Relate to Griners Frustrations
description: Cheryl Miller was the transformative womens basketball player of the 1980s, and if she once privately bemoaned being born a generation too soon to cash in on her sublime skills, she no longer does. Todays continuous news loop, fed by cellphone cameras, Facebook entries, Twitter feeds and 24-hour cable sports networks like ESPN might have irrevocably scarred Miller before she had a mature into her role as the face of womens basketball.

description: MILWAUKEE  Jordan Crawfords dunk on LeBron James last summer at a basketball camp coincided with the opening of a Twitter account by Crawfords mother.

title: Looking to Make Majors, Just Like His Mitt

But his fielders glove is about to begin its second season in the big leagues, and it almost landed in the Baseball Hall of Fame.

description: Thousands of opponents of the health care legislation circled the Capitol on Saturday waving signs and chanting slogans.

title: My Last Health Reform Column (I Hope!)
description: My Sunday column will be my last one on health care reform in a while  I hope. It looks as if theres a pretty good chance that the reform package will pass, and in that case we can move on to other subjects.

title: In Points and in Ink, Gonzaga Star Leaves Mark
description: BUFFALO  During a timeout of a home game against Oklahoma on New Years Eve, the Gonzaga freshman Kelly Olynyk looked up at the video screen and noticed his teammate Robert Sacre giving thanks to friends and family in a taped message. A fan of Sacres penchant for saying crazy things, Olynyk listened closely. To end, Sacre quoted the popular Dos Equis beer commercials that feature the most interesting man in the world.

title: Walgreen Drops Bid for City Contract After Employee Took Data
description: A Walgreen Co. executive improperly took a competitors confidential financial data, forcing the drugstore giant to withdraw from the bidding for a lucrative contract to provide pharmacy services for the City of Chicago and most local government agencies, the Chicago News Cooperative has learned.

title: Driven Young Man With a Basketball Mission
description: De La Salle and Foreman High Schools battled for the 4A state basketball sectional semifinals March 10 in a packed Maywood gym, but in many ways, the most interesting action was unfolding in the north bleachers. There, two rows up from the floor, Daniel Poneman held court in his usual fashion.

title: In Sundays Bay Area Report
description: Boycott Raises Concerns | Since January, more than 100 cases originally assigned to Judge Andrea Bryan have been transferred to other judges in the San Jose courthouse at the request of the district attorneys office. A California law, mirrored in 18 states, gives parties to a case a one-time right to insist that a judge recuse herself. The legal term is peremptory challenge. Colloquially, it is called papering. But the challenges have stirred up judges in all corners of this courthouse, where personal histories and professional relationships have been intertwined for decades.

title: As Others Fall, No Letting Up For Kentucky
description: NEW ORLEANS  Before top-seeded Kentucky took the court Saturday, Coach John Calipari knew that Kansas, the top overall seed of the N.C.A.A. tournament, had sustained a shocking loss.

title: Kansas State Overcomes a Slow Start

title: Charlie Gillett, Disc Jockey and Historian, Dies at 68
description: Charlie Gillett, who turned his youthful zeal for rock n roll into an influential career by writing one of the first serious rock histories and, as a disc jockey in London, helping to discover talents like Dire Straits and introduce the new genre of world music, died on Wednesday in London. He was 68.

title: Edmund Dinis,  Prosecutor in Chappaquiddick Case, Dies at 85
description: Edmund Dinis, a former prosecutor who lost his bid for re-election in Massachusetts after his handling of the case against Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the accidental drowning of Mary Jo Kopechne on Chappaquiddick Island in 1969, died March 14 in Dartmouth, Mass. He was 85.

title: Stewart L. Udall, Conservationist in Kennedy and Johnson Cabinets, Dies at 90
description: Stewart L. Udall, an ardent conservationist and a son of the West, who as interior secretary in the 1960s presided over vast increases in national park holdings and the public domain, died Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. The last surviving member of the original Kennedy cabinet, he was 90.

title: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: March 20
description: The mens N.C.A.A. tournament produced another round of upsets, while the womens bracket had its share of last-second drama as well.

title: SXSW: This Blog Post Was Brought to You by
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Ive done my share of griping about the prevalence of branding all over South by Southwest, which, good economy or bad, is absolutely everywhere. On banners behind, beside, below and underneath bands as they play. On credential laminates, posters, T-shirts, tote bags, cars, trucks and monitor screens. Even the key card for my hotel room is an advertisement for a music tech company. As visual pitches, they verge on predatory, crowding their way into your every line of sight whether you like it or not. Like the bands, the sponsors at South by Southwest go all out for attention.

title: Rules Committee Approves Terms of Debate
description: The House Rules Committee late Saturday night approved the terms of debate for the Democrats major health care legislation, officially setting the stage for a historic floor fight and a decisive vote on Sunday.

title: Does Icahn Still Make Them Tremble?
description: He is a billionaire several times over. He has spent the better part of four decades terrorizing corporate chiefs and battling entrenched boards. His name is emblazoned on a stadium on an island in the East River, a laboratory at Princeton, a science center at the Choate Rosemary Hall school in Connecticut and charter schools in the Bronx.

title: Q. and A. With Davey Johnson
description: Davey Johnson, a former Mets manager, is a senior adviser to the Washington Nationals. He returned to Manhattan last week to promote a new MSG Network series, The Lineup: New Yorks All-Time Best Baseball Players.The shows will discuss the citys best major league players at each position as well as the top managers. The first of 10 weekly half-hour episodes, to be shown at 10:30 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday, will focus on catchers.Johnson, 67, led the Mets to the 1986 World Series title. His New York winning percentage is .588, putting Johnson among the citys greatest managers: Joe McCarthy (.627), Miller Huggins (.597), John McGraw and Billy Martin (.591), Leo Durocher (.558), Joe Torre (.551) and Casey Stengel (.531).

title: On the Trail of Ghosts in Paris
description: Rumor has it that during World War II, a Frenchwoman who was married to a member of the Resistance was also the daytime companion of a Nazi SS officer. On a cold winters night in Paris, she was meant to meet her husband at midnight on the Pont Marie, a bridge connecting le St.-Louis to the Right Bank. He never showed up and the woman supposedly froze to death. Now her ghost is said to haunt the bridge, eternally waiting for her husband to arrive. This is one of the stories that tourists and locals can discover on the Mysteries of Paris ghost tours (33-1-97-72-18-210; mysteriesofparis.com), which began their regular season earlier this month.

title: Rangers Reversal
description: Much credit for the Phoenix Coyotes amazing on-ice performance must go to General Manager Don Maloney, who was the Rangers assistant G.M. from 1996 to 2007.

title: No Deal Yet for Coyotes
description: The remarkable run of the Phoenix Coyotes, who entered the season under bankruptcy protection and are now operated by the league, continued last week. Going into Saturday nights home date against Chicago, the Coyotes had won seven in a row and were within striking distance of first place in the Western Conference.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: 8 Straight for the Coyotes
description: Eleven games on Saturday, and although most were important, none was more incredible than the one involving the continuing saga of the Phoenix Coyotes, who staged a second straight third-peroid fightback and shootout win  this time against the West-leading Blackhawks. That result left Phoenix within a scant 2 points of the conference lead, with another head-to-head coming up Tuesday in Chicago after a game in Dallas on Sunday. And all this with prospects dimming of the Coyotes being taken off the leagues hands  and their maybe even moving to Canada after all.

title: Evidence in Africa: We Need to Move Together to Walk Together
description: GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa Performance wasnt the focus of Evidence Dance Companys recent State Department-sponsored trip to Africa, even though the company performed on several occasions in Senegal. Rather, the focus  both in Senegal, its first stop, and in South Africa  has been on workshops, classes and discussions, in an attempt to reach people on a one-to-one level. In Dakar, the company gave one free performance, attended by around 1,000 people. In Grahamstown there was also just one show: at the pristine Guy Butler Theater at Settlers Monument, high on a hill on the Rhodes University campus.

title: Girija Prasad Koirala, Former Nepal Premier, Dies at 85

description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Youngsters and hipsters far outnumbered oldsters at South by Southwest, its true, but there were pleasures to be had by those who didnt know from Killer Whales. And those pleasures were at least in some cases easier to come by. While Badge People and Wristband People queued in parallel lines that went round the block hoping to glimpse Zooey Deschanel and M Ward (She & Him) at the Cedar Street Courtyard Thursday night, you could walk right in and hear John Hiatt at La Zona Rosa and two of the three Dixie Chicks at Antones.
