He was not advertising that, stuffed in wads in his pockets and stacked in a money belt around his waist, he was packing $20,000 that friends had staked him to play cards with.

title: When the Mirror Is Your Enemy
description: Many of us are embarrassed or dissatisfied with some body part or other, writes Personal Health columnist Jane Brody in todays Science Times. But what if such self-consciousness about a perceived facial or body defect becomes all-consuming, a kind of obsession or paranoia that keeps the person from focusing on school or work, pursuing normal social activities, even leaving the house to shop or see a doctor?

title: Goodell Wants a Word With Roethlisberger
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell made clear Monday that he was unhappy with the conduct of Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, who is under police investigation after a 20-year-old college student accused him of sexually assaulting her in a Georgia bar. Goodell said that he spoke to the Rooney family, the owners of the Steelers, and planned to speak with Roethlisberger at a later date.

title: Seeing Body Flaws That Arent There
description: In this weeks Personal Health column, Jane Brody explores the strange world of body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D., a condition that leads to self loathing and anxiety over minor imperfections. She writes:

title: Colorado Increases Renewables Requirements
description: In a bid to propel his state to the forefront of the new energy economy, Colorados governor is expected to sign one of the most aggressive renewable energy requirements in the country on Monday afternoon.

title: A Network Storage Drive for Technophobes
description: Some people think NAS is a nasty word, and Jon Christeson is one of them.

title: Bank Panel Clears Bill on Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Banking Committee voted on Monday to send to the full Senate a Democratic bill to overhaul the nations financial system, deferring, for now, an anticipated partisan fight over the legislation.

title: 16w21 Campaign
description: A saucy new campaign for a high-end apartment building in Chelsea includes short videos featuring cosmopolitan dolls.

title: Education, Faith and a Likelihood to Wed
description: The National Center for Health Statistics this month published a new analysis of data on marriage and cohabitation that concentrated on relationships in the context of childbearing.

title: Grassley Wants Obama to Enroll in New Exchanges
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said on Monday that he would propose legislation requiring President Obama and White House officials obtain their health insurance through the government exchanges that will be established under the health care bill Mr. Obama is planning to sign on Tuesday.

title: After Years of War and Abuse, New Hope for Ancient Babylon
description: The most immediate threat to preserving the ruins of Babylon, the site of one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, is water soaking the ground and undermining what is left in present-day Iraq of a great city from the time of King Nebuchadnezzar II.

title: Bank Bailout Tax Gains Support in Europe
description: President Obamas proposal for a direct tax on banks to pay for future bailouts is gathering momentum in Europe, with Germany set to move ahead with its own levy and Britain expected to endorse a similar measure ahead of the Group of 20 meeting next month, The New York Timess Matthew Saltmarsh reports from Paris.

title: A Look Inside the Dollhouse (Care to Buy a Condo)?
description: Selling multimillion dollar apartments in this real estate market may not be any fun, but an ad campaign about a new building still can be.

title: Slim Pickings? You Can Still Eat Well
description: I recently received an e-mail from a reader who cooks on an extreme budget in an area of the country where ingredients are limited. We cant afford a lot of fresh vegetables; its a stretch to buy brown rice instead of white, she wrote. I cook a lot, but I struggle to find new, healthy recipes that use budget ingredients. I immediately set about to do a week of recipes that cost anywhere from $1 or less to $1.50 per person.

title: U.N. Says Dirty Water Kills More Than War
description: More people die from polluted water every year than from all forms of violence, including war, the United Nations said in a report Monday that highlights the need for clean drinking water. The report was released to coincide with World Water Day, which serves as the theme for the opening of the slide show and for our featured post this morning, Little Water, and Less, Along the Jordan.

title: Patterns: Nonmelanoma Skin Cancer Cases Soar
description: The most common cancer in the United States is nonmelanoma skin cancer, but the exact number of cases is unknown because they are generally not tracked by cancer registries. Now, a new study reports that Americans are developing those cancers at record numbers, with 3.5 million cases a year in 2 million people, as of 2006. (Patients with a skin cancer often develop another one within the year.)

title: Car Messages Get a Mixed Reception
description: The ubiquitous yellow Baby on Board signs that swung in the back window of so many minivans have given way to other messages alerting drivers that Yankee fans are on board, and even a Mother-in-Law in Trunk. The latest vehicle signage vogue includes acronym advertisements for vacation spots, like LBI for Long Beach Island or MTK, for Montauk, wrote Anne Marie Valinoti in the weekends Complaint Box in the Metropolitan section. The advertising, however, may be having a negative effect.

title: Global Head of Equities at UBS Steps Down
description: Daniel B. Coleman, the global head of equities of UBS, is leaving the Swiss bank after nearly 24 years and will turn over his duties to Neal Shear, the banks global head of securities, Bloomberg News reports.

title: New York Production Set for Latest Kushner Play
description: Tony Kushners latest play, The Intelligent Homosexuals Guide to Capitalism and Socialism With A Key to the Scriptures, his first epic-sized work about American life since his Pulitzer Prize-winning Angels in America in the early 1990s, will have its New York premiere next spring in a co-production by the Public Theater and the Signature Theater Company, the two theaters announced on Monday.

title: Tuberculosis: Drug-Resistant Strains Still Spreading at Deadly Rates, W.H.O. Report Says
description: Drug-resistant tuberculosis killed about 150,000 people in 2008, and half of all the worlds cases are thought in be in China and India, the World Health Organization said in a report last week.

title: Asked and Answered | David Rathman Rumbles in the Jungle
description: Before there was Mike Tyson versus Evander Holyfield, Mixed Martial Arts bloodsport battles and Rocky I-V, there was 1974s Rumble in the Jungle. The Rumble featured two of boxings greatest icons, Muhammad Ali and George Foreman, pitted in the ring, while the Jungle came courtesy of Zaire (now the Democratic Republic of Congo), where the fight took place. The epic bout inspired The Fight, a book by Norman Mailer, a song by the Fugees and countless ESPN SportsCenter reruns. Now its getting the artistic treatment, courtesy of the watercolorist David Rathman.

title: Baby Fat or Early Obesity?
description: Although most childhood obesity efforts are targeted at schoolchildren, the best time to prevent weight problems may be in early childhood and infancy, reports Roni Rabin in Tuesdays Science Times. She writes:

title: Cablevisions Rainbow Media Said Near a Deal for Gothamist
description: Gothamist, a blog network focused on several large cities (but primarily New York), is close to a sale to Cablevisions Rainbow Media for $5 million to $6 million, the Web site paidContent reported on Monday, citing an unnamed source.

title: Bostons Latest Pan-Asian Restaurant
description: Ginger Park is proving that, yes, the world does need another pan-Asian restaurant. At least Bostons South End thinks so, when its under the apron of Patricia Yeo.

title: A Toddler and Her Thumb
description: Sarah Dille teaches A.P. English to high-school students in Austin, Tex. She also writes a charming blog about being a parent to 2-year-old Nora. Its called Toddler Summer, she tells me, because I started blogging as a summer project last year after school had ended and I wondered what the heck I was going to do with all my newfound free time after trying to balance work and motherhood for nine months. I hadnt yet been home with a toddler long enough to realize that free time really didnt exist.

title: In Five Extra Minutes, a Number of Possibilities
description: So Monday was the day the five-minute grace period started. That gave time-pressed drivers in New York five extra minutes to move their cars after alternate-side regulations take effect.

title: Puzzle Holiday
description: Our Quiz Whiz, Pradeep Mutalik, is taking a well-deserved holiday this week.

title: Health Care Links
description: Megan McArdle offers eight predictions for what health care reform will and wont mean.

title: Bond Markets Trust Buffett More Than Obama
description: More fuel for the fiscal hawks, courtesy of Bloomberg:

title: Banking Panel Sends Financial Bill to Full Senate
description: 5:47 p.m. | Updated The Senate Banking Committee voted 13 to 10 late Monday afternoon to send a proposed overhaul of the nations financial system to the full Senate, a quick vote that reflects a change in strategy by Republicans opposed to the measure, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: BMW to Supply Diesels for Police Car Venture
description: Carbon Motors and the BMW Group announced at a Washington news conference on Monday that the companies had reached an agreement for BMW to supply 240,000 turbo diesel engines for a police car that Carbon Motors would produce called the E7.

title: Ready, Set, Hang: The Heavy Lifting Is On
description: The explosive growth of the art world during the last decade has been fueled by rich new collectors, shiny new galleries and sprawling new museum wings. But the gears and the grease that keep this big machine humming are people who can be generally described with less glamorous adjectives: underpaid, uninsured, overworked and sweaty (not to mention often heavily tattooed, bearded, hung over and painfully burdened by loan payments for their M.F.A. degrees).

title: One Last Nap Amid the Flowers
description: ON the last day of his life, my dog Otto spent the first real morning of spring napping in the garden.

title: Bin Ladens Daughter Allowed to Leave Iran
description: Osama bin Ladens teenage daughter, Iman, has reportedly left Iran  where she had lived under house arrest for eight years with several of her siblings  and is now in Syria, according to a report in Asharq Al-Awsat, a Saudi-owned newspaper newspaper based in London.

title: Staying the Course Makes Sense for Marketers During Crises, Study Concludes
description: For those wondering why Toyota Motor continues to advertise during the current crisis over its reputation, a coming study suggests that such a course of action could be superior to inaction.

title: Cablevision Unit Is Said to Be Interested in Acquiring Gothamist
description: Rainbow Media, a unit of Cablevision, is seeking to acquiring the Gothamist network of blogs, a person familiar with the negotiations said Monday.

title: Star-Heavy Big-Budget Love Story Bucks Trend
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  The Columbia Pictures lot here is decked with poster art for movies due in the coming months.

title: Interview: Sergey Brin on Googles China Move
description: 6:08 p.m. | Updated  Adding more excerpts from interview.

title: From Greenberg to Designing Women
description: With Greta Gerwigs star turn opposite Ben Stiller in Greenberg, the 26-year-old may have graduated from the microbudget mumblecore flicks that first got her noticed. But shes still got enough lo-fi spirit to laugh at herself. We caught up with Gerwig last week for a beauty feature in our coming womens issue, and she related this unfortunate makeup experience from the premiere of Greenberg at last months Berlin Film Festival.

title: Artists Mine Scientific Clues to Paint Intricate Portraits of the Past
description: Somewhere in England, about 600 years ago, an artist sat down and tried to paint an elephant. There was just one problem: he had never seen one.

title: In Canada, Local Stations May Negotiate a Cable Fee
description: OTTAWA  Canadas broadcasting regulator has devised a system aimed at allowing conventional television station owners to negotiate payments from operators of cable and satellite TV systems.

title: In Therapy, Cellphones Ring True
description: Though the interruption may be jarring, I rather welcome the twang of bluegrass or the toll of church bells coming from a patients cellphone during a psychotherapy session. Heres why.

title: The Brooklyn Flea Will Stay at One Hanson, Along With Some New Food Vendors
description: One of the great urban experiences New York offered this winter was the Brooklyn Flea in exile. When the weather turned cold, the market moved indoors to One Hanson Place, bringing along its motley host of antiques dealers, artists, designers, vintage-workboot purveyors andlets get to the point herefood vendors.

title: Phone Chats During Therapy
description: Whether at the movies or the doctors office, cellphone users are often admonished to turn the devices off. But during visits with a therapist, a brief cellphone conversation may offer a useful glimpse into a patients real life, explains Boston psychiatrist Barbara Schildkrout in todays Science Times. She writes:

title: Are Shoppers Fairer?
description: In my Findings column, I discuss a study in Science that found wide cultural variations in concepts of fairness. It was measured by observing people in 15 societies around the world participate in a two-player game in which one player, called the dictator, decided how much of the prize to share with the other.

title: Using Quotas to Raise the Glass Ceiling
description: In 2002, Norway enacted a law requiring that 40 percent of all board members at state-owned and publicly listed companies be women by 2008.

title: Toyota to Replace Accelerator Pedals for Owners Who Are Unhappy With Repairs
description: DETROIT  After reports of sudden unintended acceleration in cars it has already fixed, Toyota has told dealers to provide replacement accelerator pedals to owners unhappy with repairs, a company document showed on Monday.

title: Kushner Play to Open in New York Next Spring
description: Tony Kushners latest play, The Intelligent Homosexuals Guide to Capitalism and Socialism With a Key to the Scriptures, his first epic-size work about American life since his Pulitzer Prize-winning Angels in America in the early 1990s, will have its New York premiere next spring in a co-production by the Public Theater and the Signature Theater Company, the two theaters announced Monday.

title: For Extinct Monsters of the Deep, a Little Respect
description: Here is a quick paleontology quiz. Which group of animals included large, air-breathing predators up to 50 feet long that bore live young, dominated their world for more than 100 million years and were ultimately exterminated by an asteroid 65 million years ago?

title: Playing the Victim
description: In todays Mind column, psychiatrist Dr. Richard A. Friedman explores the puzzling world of self-defeating behavior, when people blame others for their misfortune and feel victimized by bad luck.

title: On Thin Ice
description: Car enthusiasts in rural New Hampshire race for fun on a frozen pond without corporate sponsors or pit crews. This is "poor man's racing."

title: Moral Lessons, Down Aisle 9
description: Like Diogenes with his lamp, researchers have traversed the world looking for an honest man  or, more precisely, for people who act in the same fair, unselfish way toward everyone. If you wish to learn to follow this golden rule, which of these strategies is best?

title: Sixty Years of Pierre Cardin
description: IHT fashion editor Suzy Menkes interviews the fashion icon Pierre Cardin as he celebrates his 60th year in fashion.

title: Celebrating the Delicate Beauty of the Desert Landscape
description: Few architects have invested more time trying to bridge the gap between the high-tech aesthetics of the West and the traditions of the Middle East than Jean Nouvel.

title: Microcosm of Housing Crisis on an Arizona Street
description: CAVE CREEK, Ariz.  The uncertain line between hope and despair divides this exurb of Phoenix, where the trim stucco houses used to sell so briskly.

title: Headed for Auction: Back-Channel Gloom on Revolutionary War
description: Despite King Georges boast that once these rebels have felt a smart blow, they will submit, back-channel messages from British generals and diplomatic officials in America during the Revolutionary War, some of them previously unpublished, turn out to have been decidedly more pessimistic.

title: Hoops Lift CBS
description: CBS led the ratings race on Sunday, aided by its afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament. According to Nielsens estimates, an overrun of the networks coverage lasted throughout most of the 7 p.m. hour, earning nearly 14 million viewers in the time slot. Later in the night 60 Minutes drew just under 13 million viewers, while the CBS reality shows The Amazing Race (12.5 million) and Undercover Boss (13.6 million) kept the network in first place. ABC was runner-up on the night, benefiting from Desperate Housewives (10.8 million), but earning more modest ratings for Extreme Makeover: Home Edition (7.4 million) and Jamie Olivers Food Revolution (6.2 million). NBC ranked third with Minute to Win It (5.2 million) followed by The Celebrity Apprentice (6.9 million). Fox placed fourth with new episodes of its comedies, including The Simpsons (5.7 million) and The Cleveland Show (5 million).

title: Starz Plans Camelot
description: Once, there was a spot, for one brief shining moment that was known as Camelot. And even though that spot was declared, in another context, by a different King Arthur, to be a silly place, that kingdom and its knights are now set to make a serious return on television. On Monday the Starz cable channel said that it was preparing a new series called Camelot, based on the version of the Arthurian legend recounted in Thomas Malorys Morte dArthur. Starz, which has recently found a hit in its sword-and-sandals adventure series Spartacus: Blood and Sand, said Camelot would be written by Chris Chibnall, of the supernatural British dramas Life on Mars and Torchwood, and produced by a team that includes Graham King (The Departed, Gangs of New York) and Morgan OSullivan and Michael Hirst (both of the Showtime period drama The Tudors). The 10-episode series is expected to begin production in June with episodes to start showing in 2011. No cast was announced.

title: An American Presence at the Olivier Awards
description: Several shows set in, born in or coming to the United States received Olivier Awards in London on Sunday night. Spring Awakening, which took top honors at the Tony Awards in 2007, was named best new musical. Katori Halls Mountaintop, which may come to Broadway in the fall, won as best new play. Rupert Goold was named best director for Enron (above, a scene from the play), which is scheduled to begin previews on Broadway next month. In the acting categories, Aneurin Barnard was named best actor in a musical for his performance as Melchior in Spring Awakening; Samantha Spiro was named best actress in a musical for her performance as the title character in Hello, Dolly! Mark Rylance took home the best actor award for his portrayal of a cocky stoner in Jez Butterworths play Jerusalem, and Rachel Weisz won for her Blanche DuBois in the Donmar Warehouses production of A Streetcar Named Desire.

title: Levine Sidelined Again by Back Problems
description: James Levine, right, will miss what would have been his final appearances with the Boston Symphony Orchestra this season because of continuing problems with his back, the orchestra said on Monday. Mr. Levine, the conductor and music director of the Boston Symphony and the Metropolitan Opera, missed the opening of the Carnegie Hall season and major dates at the Met last fall because of an operation to repair a herniated disk. In March he canceled planned appearances at the Berlin Staatskapelle on the recommendation of his doctors, who said he should not travel while they adjusted his medication as part of his recovery from that surgery. In recent years Mr. Levine has also had a cancerous cyst removed from his kidney and had rotator-cuff surgery to repair damage from an onstage fall. The Boston Symphony said that Jayce Ogren would lead its performances March 25 through 27 and that Rafael Frhbeck de Burgos would conduct April 1 through 3 in Boston and on April 5 at Carnegie Hall. A conductor for performances on April 8 through 10 will be announced shortly.

title: Fake Newspaper to Get Real TV Show
description: The Onion, the satirical news organization that broke the fake story that the smoke monster from Lost would receive its own spinoff series and cheekily reported that television critics who praised The Wire had never seen the show, is itself headed to the small screen. On Monday the Independent Film Channel announced that it was developing a television series based on The Onion, the humorous weekly newspaper and Web site (theonion.com), as part of a comedy-heavy slate of new programming. The Onion series, called Onion News Network, will bring the deadpan sensibility of the Web sites popular video clips to a show in the vein of authentic news programs like CNNs Situation Room or Anderson Cooper 360. It just seems to us, CNN, Fox News and MSNBC are already doing such great comedy out there, without a whole lot of competition, said Will Graham, an executive producer of Onion News Network. We thought it was about time that someone really gave them a run for their money. The IFC series is planned for a 2011 debut.

title: Nelson to Vote Against Reconciliation Bill
description: One of the big reasons House Democrats wanted changes to the Senate-passed health care bill was the so-called Cornhusker kickback, which provided extra Medicaid money for Nebraska.

title: Back to Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD Today I flew into the airport that I helped to build nearly 30 years ago. In 1981 I was a new graduate of Baghdad Universitys civil engineering department, and I was appointed a site engineer at the partly-constructed airport.

title: Hip-Hop Punctuates a Benefit
description: Long before the first note was played at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, you could tell it was an unusual occasion. A lively, enthusiastic and uncommonly diverse audience filled the auditorium to capacity, with illicit camera flashes indicating the presence of newcomers and curiosity seekers. The event at hand was a concert meant to raise money for earthquake-ravaged Haiti; the chief attraction was the Chinese piano superstar Lang Lang.

title: From The Jaws Of Defeat
description: Just one more reminder of what a victory Obama and Pelosi pulled off: heres the Intrade price on passage of Obamacare from the aftermath of the Massachusetts election to actual success:

title: Downstream Drugs
description: Q. Have any studies been done on possible environmental risks from drugs used for chemotherapy after they pass through the body?

title: Little Punk Staffers Of The World, Unite
description: OK, now begins the fight on financial reform. We know where the Republican leadership stands: would-be protectors against another crisis are little punk staffers who have no right to dictate to fine, upstanding bankers like the people who, uh, brought the world economy to its knees. Barney Frank has handed out buttons to his staff:

title: Send Us Your Small-Business Health Reform Questions
description: Earlier today, The Agenda answered a question from a small-business owner about how the new health care law  which President Obama will sign Tuesday  might affect his future. That answer, in turn, begat more reader questions (like this comment about the small-business tax credit). The new law is big and complex, and we suspect there are many more questions out there. So if you own a small business, or work for one, we invite your questions about health insurance coverage and the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.

title: Wave of Airline Strikes Sweeps Europe
description: PARIS  Travelers across Europe braced for chaos as a strike by British Airways cabin crew entered its third day on Monday and labor strife spread to other airlines.

title: High-Speed Rail in Tampa: A Fast Train to a Slow Bus?
description: A journey to the beach questions the usefulness of Florida's public transportation plans.

title: Answers on the Health Care Overhaul
description: Insights on how the health care overhaul will affect consumers are provided on the Prescriptions blog, where four Times reporters  Tara Siegel Bernard, Jennifer Saranow Schultz, Ron Lieber and Natasha Singer  answered reader questions. And an earlier post on Bucks offers more details.

title: Taming the Turbulence Inside Pipelines
description: A pipeline may appear calm and quiet on the outside, but inside its a roiling mess. At anything other than low rates of flow, a fluid being transported, like oil, water or natural gas, becomes turbulent.

title: After Mating, Male Pipefish Get Choosy
description: Pipefish, like seahorses and a few other related fishes, are unusual in that its the male that gets pregnant. The female deposits eggs in a pouch in the males body, where they are fertilized and protected and receive nutrients as they develop.

title: Laser Treatment May Work for Cataracts
description: Cataracts are the leading cause of blindness in the world, and are often related to aging. In a common form of cataracts, proteins in the lens change over time, developing chromophores  molecular add-ons that absorb color in the blue part of the spectrum. Chromophores reduce the amount of light reaching the retina (and give the lens a yellow-brown appearance), but they also disrupt the structure of the lens proteins, causing light to scatter.

title: Apollo Seeks $50 Million Offering on N.Y.S.E.
description: Apollo Global Management, the private equity firm led by Leon D. Black, said on Monday that it was seeking a $50 million initial public offering of shares as it aims to migrate to the New York Stock Exchange from Goldman Sachss private market.

title: U.S. Officials Meet Iraqi Leader After Recount Call
description: BAGHDAD  The two top American officials in Iraq met Monday with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki after his endorsement over the weekend of a recount in the parliamentary elections incited fears of a political crisis in a country not accustomed to peaceful transfers of power.

title: On Language and Cancer (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Falling at Mach 1 (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Catching a Catchy Tune (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lung Cancers Toll (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Flock Grows Right at Home for a Priest in Ukraine
description: RUDNO, Ukraine  Let the rest of Europe be convulsed by debates over whether the celibacy of Roman Catholic priests is causing sex abuse scandals like the one now unfolding in Germany. Here in western Ukraine, many Catholic priests are married, fruitful and multiplying  with the Vaticans blessing.

title: "Ultra Lounge" by Hyatt/Funny or Die
description: In a series of Web videos from the comedy site Funny or Die, Hyatt will emphasize what can go wrong when people choose the wrong hotel or meeting planner.

title: "Teppanyaki Chef" by Hyatt/Funny or Die
description: In a series of Web videos from the comedy site Funny or Die, Hyatt will emphasize what can go wrong when people choose the wrong hotel or meeting planner.

title: What Were Reading: iPads Price, EBay Thieves and Palms Decline
description: The tech reporters and editors of The Times found themselves immersed in retail, fashion, real estate and, as always, assessing the power of the Internet.

title: To Get a Good Seat, Check the Chart
description: EACH year for as long as I remember, Ive made sure to hit the miles-flown mark to maintain elite status on at least one airline.

title: Monmouths Addition by Subtraction
description: Less is more. The maxim is truer than ever in horse racing, and this summer Monmouth Park is going to prove it. Beginning May 22, the charming track on the Jersey Shore will offer fewer racing dates but for a lot more money: 50 days with $1 million in purse money up for grabs on each of them.

title: North Korea Says a Detained U.S. Citizen Will Face Trial
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An American citizen arrested in January for illegally entering North Korea will be put on trial, the Norths official news agency reported Monday.

title: Woodss Interviews Short on Time and Revelations
description: In five minutes on ESPN and six on the Golf Channel, Tiger Woods did not say much that was new Sunday night.

title: Google Is Now Searching for Bond Traders
description: Google may be hoping to profit from its vast collection of knowledge. The search giant is seeking to hire bond traders and analysts, according to job postings on its Web site that were unearthed by Business Insider.

title: Bids in Hand, MGM Weighs Its Options
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the beleaguered film studio, said in a statement late on Monday that it had received a number of bids as it tries to reorganize its nearly $4 billion debt load.

title: Apple Adds 2 Publishers to Its Store for E-Books
description: Apples iBookstore on the forthcoming iPad is set to get larger. The company has just signed a deal with two more independent publishers to sell electronic versions of their books on the new device.

title: Rodriguez Will Meet Investigators in Buffalo
description: Alex Rodriguez is scheduled to meet on Friday with federal investigators who want to know about his interactions with Anthony Galea, the Canadian-based doctor whose activities are being scrutinized by a number of federal agencies in the United States.

title: House Ethics Office Gains, Dismissals Aside
description: WASHINGTON  By most measures, it has been a rough year for Leo J. Wise, the first independent ethics cop for the House of Representatives. Lawyers are denouncing him as dangerous, lawmakers are threatening to cut his already limited powers, and a House committee has so far dismissed all but one case in which his office found evidence of wrongdoing.

title: Malawi: Trial of Gay Couple Is Allowed
description: The trial of two gay men accused of unnatural acts and gross indecency, Tiwonge Chimbalanga and Steven Monjeza, will proceed on April 3, a magistrate ruled Monday. The defense had asked for the charges to be dropped. The two men were arrested after holding a public engagement ceremony in December and have been jailed ever since. Homosexuality is a crime in Malawi carrying a maximum sentence of 14 years.

title: U.S. Set to Expand Role in Protecting Air Travelers
description: The federal government is about to take a larger role in protecting airline passengers, starting with a new rule allowing travelers to get off a plane stuck on the tarmac for more than three hours.

title: Cases Brought by the Office of Congressional Ethics
description: The office, which was created in March 2008, recommended 12 cases for further review last year. The House ethics committee dismissed eight of those cases, and three are under review.

title: Italy: Guilt in Britons Death Reaffirmed
description: A man convicted of murdering a British student in Perugia in 2007 participated fully in the crime and sexually assaulted the victim, an appeals court said in reasoning released Monday, the ANSA news agency reported. The man, Rudy Guede, was convicted in 2008 of killing Meredith Kercher, 21. An American college student, Amanda Knox, and her Italian former boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, were convicted last year in the case. In ambiguous language that could have an impact on Ms. Knox and Mr. Sollecitos appeals, the court said Mr. Guede had played his part in the violence that weakened the victims will, until the final tragedy, and also when the knives were brandished, ANSA reported.

title: Yankees Fifth Starter? Two Make Final Cases
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  The whole day was nuts. It started with Joba Chamberlain pitching to five teammates  or was it eight?  at a nearly empty Steinbrenner Field. It ended with Phil Hughes serving three home runs to the Philadelphia Phillies at blustery Bright House Field while insisting he had his best stuff of the spring, an assessment Yankees Manager Joe Girardi eagerly agreed with.

title: Israel: Soldier Is Accidentally Killed
description: An Israeli soldier was accidentally shot dead by fellow soldiers along the Gaza border on Monday in an operation aimed at stopping three Palestinians who were thought to be trying to infiltrate the border fence, an army spokesman said. The three, who were unarmed, were detained. The shooting occurred when a tank team that saw the men along the fence called for reinforcements. The new arrivals thought the soldiers were the infiltrators and shot them. The army has opened an investigation.

title: A Starter for Mighty Kentucky Now Sits on Cornells Bench
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  Mark Coury remembers those Southeastern Conference football Saturdays at Kentucky, the sun splashing down, the smell of barbecue wafting in the autumn air.

title: Roethlisbergers Conduct Draws the Ire of Goodell
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell made clear Monday that he was unhappy with the conduct of Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, who is under police investigation for an alleged sexual assault of a 20-year-old college student in a Georgia bar. Goodell said he had spoken to the Rooney family, the team owners, and planned to speak with Roethlisberger, who has not been charged.

title: Dukes Zoubek Breaks Out at the Conclusion of a Checkered Career
description: Brian Zoubek, Dukes 7-foot-1 center, spent his first three and a half years there dealing with foot injuries that sent his college career onto a path of unfulfilled promise. He had scored more than 2,000 points at Haddonfield (N.J.) Memorial High School and was ranked the 24th-best recruit by Rivals.com.

title: Drivers Pursue Excitement in the Hard Reality of Winter
description: MILTON, N.H.  To Joe Belanger, racing cars on asphalt is simply something to do until the ponds freeze over.

title: Election Looming, Tories Put Posh Foot in Mouth
description: LONDON  What could be more embarrassing for a party trying to change its elitist image than the existence of someone like Sir Nicholas Winterton? A Conservative member of Parliament for the last 39 years, Sir Nicholas wandered disastrously off message recently when he decided to share his thoughts on why legislators should be allowed to travel first class to avoid exposure to the common man.

title: Acorn to Shut All Its Offices by April 1
description: The community organizing group Acorn announced Monday that it would close all its remaining state affiliates and field offices by April 1.

title: Nine to Know: Jorge Posada and Yankee Catchers
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: In Your Pocket
description: Now that weve passed the midpoint of the spring training season, in all camps there is a hole in the calendar. This hole is a rare jewel in the world of major league baseball: a day off from the grind in the land of fun and sun (Arizona or Florida). And a day off could be just what the doctor ordered.

title: Now Screening | Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere
description: Last Thursdays opening for the new Ryan McGinley show at Team Gallery in SoHo was as oversubscribed as it was over-the-top. But in case you missed the art-world mob scene, which ended with The Man closing down the event, T gave out 10 cameras to a bunch of different New York creatives for this exclusive video from the evening, including the dinner and after-party at Indochine. Open bars on us!

title: N.Y.U. Plans to Expand Campuses by 40 Percent
description: New York University is proposing the largest expansion in its history, with a new tower on Bleecker Street and three million square feet of new classrooms, dormitories and offices in the Greenwich Village area. The plans also call for creating a new engineering school in Brooklyn and a satellite campus on Governors Island, complete with dorms and faculty housing.

title: 2 Airlines Reach Deal to Give Up Flight Slots
description: Delta Air Lines and US Airways said Monday that they had agreed to give up 20 pairs of takeoff and landing rights at La Guardia Airport and Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington to gain federal approval for a larger exchange of those rights between the two airlines.

title: The Democrats Rejoice
description: Parties come to embody causes. For the past 90 years or so, the Republican Party has, at its best, come to embody the cause of personal freedom and economic dynamism. For a similar period, the Democratic Party has, at its best, come to embody the cause of fairness and family security. Over the past century, they have built a welfare system, brick by brick, to guard against the injuries of fate.

title: From Russia, With Love
description: "The Soviet-born singer and pianist Regina Spektor, from the Bronx, sings obtuse but plaintive folk songs about love and truth," writes Amanda Petrusich. "Ms. Spektor's wit and wobbly, entrancing vocals transcend the work of many of her anti-folk peers." Go listen to Ms. Spektor tonight. She'll be at Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza at 8 p.m.

title: Tharp on Sinatra
description: There are only two more days left to see "Come Fly Away" before it officially opens at the Marquis Theater on Thursday. Ol' Blue Eyes is the musical inspiration for the latest Broadway production from the choreographer Twyla Tharp, who previously took on Billy Joel, ("Movin' Out") and Bob Dylan ("The Times They Are A-Changin.") Her latest show, about four couples in various stages of love, features original master recordings of Sinatra's voice, a live band and some big names from the dance world, including Holley Farmer, an alumna of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. Go now, when the dancers are at their most energetic.

title: Asia Comes to New York
description: It's Asia Week, "a once-a-year flowering of art at Manhattan auction houses, fairs, galleries and museums," writes Karen Rosenberg. Today, take advantage of the offerings first by checking out one of the many related exhibits, like "Humor in Japanese Art," which showcases satirical paintings, prints and sculpture at the Ukrainian Institute of America, or "Pilgrimage and Buddhist Art," at the Asia Society and Museum, which "explores a tradition that dates from the first century A.D.: journeying to the sites of major events of the Buddha's life. It will include ritual objects and travel accessories, like reliquaries and prayer wheels, that have never been seen in public." The show will help prepare you for "The Buddha," a new documentary that will be shown on PBS on April 7. The film by David Grubin is narrated by Richard Gere and features interviews with the Dalai Lama and notable Buddhists like the poets W. S. Merwin and Jane Hirshfield, as well as Robert Thurman and others.

title: The Mets Setup Role Still Needs Setting Up
description: VIERA, Fla.  Since the first few days of spring training, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel said his biggest concern was finding an eighth-inning setup man. But with less than two weeks before opening day, Manuel still does not know which pitcher or pitchers will fill that critical role.

title: Big Clients Keep Their Head Start
description: Wall Street hates a level playing field. What it loves is an edge, an inside track, that extra something  especially when it comes to information that moves markets.

title: A Tent City
description: Home to at least 44,000 displaced people, the Petionville Country Club in Haiti offers a portrait of entrenched transience.

title: U.S. Proposals for Taxes on Banks to Cover the Bailouts Gain Ground in Europe
description: PARIS  President Obamas proposal for a direct tax on banks to cover the cost of the financial bailout is gaining support in Europe. Germany is set to move ahead with its own levy, and Britain is expected to endorse a similar measure ahead of the Group of 20 meeting next month.

title: One More Birthday Gift for Sondheim: A Broadway Theater
description: After five decades of critically acclaimed work on Broadway, the composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim is receiving a rare laurel and one of the few that had not yet come his way: his name on a Broadway theater.

title: A New Show by Rosie Is Positioned as a Possible Replacement for Oprahs
description: LOS ANGELES  Rosie ODonnells forthcoming talk show will be squarely positioned as a suitable replacement for Oprah Winfrey, her producers said on Monday, adding a new twist in an effort by local stations to revamp their lineups in a post-Winfrey era.

title: Casting Vote, and Now Trying to Sell It Back Home
description: QUINCY, Fla.  Irvin D. Newsome, a retired Greyhound bus driver, says he has been voting for Representative Allen Boyd since as far back as I can remember. But that will change this November, Mr. Newsome vowed Monday, thanks to the decision by Mr. Boyd, a centrist Democrat, to change positions and support the health care overhaul that passed the House on Sunday night.

title: For Democrats, a Win Is a Win
description: PASSAGE of the new comprehensive health care reform bill by Congress may not be the game changer some joyful Democrats are declaring it to be, but it may at least herald a new game for the 2010 midterm elections.

title: Russia to Alter System of Penal Colonies
description: VLADIMIR, Russia  In Russian prisons, the inmates are divided into barracks housing a hundred or so men without regard to the severity of their crimes. At night, a guard locks the door and walks away, leaving first-time offenders and people convicted of nonviolent crimes to fend for themselves in a crowd of gang members, hit men and other career criminals.

title: Turkeys Governing Party Proposes Changes in the Constitution
description: ISTANBUL  Members of Parliament from Turkeys religious conservative governing party proposed constitutional changes on Monday that would make it harder to ban political parties and easier to prosecute military officials in civilian courts.

title: Church Adds More Abuse Cases to Its Inquiry in Germany
description: MUNICH  The investigation into sexual abuse by clergy members in Germany expanded Monday to take in four more priests and two nuns in the Regensburg Diocese in Bavaria after new victims came forward there, the diocese said Monday.

title: Bloggingheads: Mental Bandwidth Scarcity
description: Glenn Loury, left, of Brown University and Sendhil Mullainathan of Harvard University discuss new social science thinking about poverty.

title: Rep. Allen Boyd Jr.
description: Second Congressional District of Florida

title: Nice Address, but Where Is It Really?
description: Too bad Neil Simon stopped with Lost in Yonkers. He might have had a fine time giving Lost in Manhattan a shot. The comedic potential is certainly there. (Actually, my tastes lean more to the dark humor of Martin McDonagh, but he already has his hands full with Spokane.)

title: JetBlue to Move West Within Queens, Not South to Orlando
description: If running JetBlue Airways does not work out, perhaps David Barger could try his hand at professional poker.

title: Taxi Scheme Might Be Smaller Than Commission First Thought
description: The grand New York City taxi fraud may not be as grand as officials first thought.

title: Officer Shot in the Bronx; Assailant Found Dead
description: A police officer was hit at least three times in a shootout on Monday while responding to a 911 call at a housing project in the South Bronx, but was apparently saved by his bullet-resistant vest, law enforcement officials said.

title: A Peaceful Refuge in Brooklyn, and All the Noise It Took to Build It
description: It was a soggy morning, but no rain would fall on the parade, the politicians insisted. On this, the long-anticipated official opening day of Brooklyn Bridge Park, no spirit would be dampened  drizzle or no, they said, it was a sunny, sunny day for New York and the world, a celebration of Brooklyns present, a harbinger of its future.

title: State Senate, Trying to Trim Deficit, Offers Budget Plan Cutting $1.4 Billion From Schools
description: ALBANY  School financing, a perennial third rail of state politics, would be cut by $1.4 billion under a plan put forward on Monday by Senate Democrats trying to plug a budget deficit estimated at $9 billion.

title: After an Injury, Enjoying a Chat in Business Class
description: MY first memory of flying is traveling to Italy when I was about 4 years old. Despite my mothers efforts to ensure a pleasant flight for all passengers, I was a handful. Why not pull on that older mans hair? Why not throw my juice across the cabin while screaming at the top of my lungs? I bet if there had been baby Ambien, my mother might have tried it on me.

title: Disability-Claims Inquiry Concluding for L.I.R.R.
description: The Long Island Rail Road will hire an independent examiner to review its safeguards against abuse of the railroads disability pension system, under an agreement that all but concludes an 18-month state investigation of the extraordinarily high rate of claims by employees of the commuter line.

title: City Reaches $33 Million Settlement Over Strip Searches
description: For the third time in a decade, New York City has agreed to pay millions of dollars to settle a lawsuit stemming from the illegal strip searches of thousands of nonviolent prisoners.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 22, 2010

title: 70 Across: Augustas Home
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Interesting  a giveaway answer that needs to be split into three parts. I like it!

title: Helping His Clients Look Best in Show
description: Dirty dogs become glamour pusses in the hands of Nicholas Lipariti Jr., 26, a lifelong Brooklynite and recently minted dog groomer. Inspired by his mother, who died of lung cancer in the summer of 2008, Mr. Lipariti pursued his dream of working with animals by enrolling in the American Academy of Pet Grooming last summer. He opened a grooming shop, Paws On!, in Gravesend, Brooklyn, but the sputtering economy forced a quick closing. Now he makes house calls, has a loyal client base and works at Puppy City in Gravesend.

title: The Case for Ending the Mortgage Deduction
description: Mortgages should be made less attractive. Thats one lesson of the recent housing bubble and bust. As long as borrowing seems like the easy road to riches, people will do too much of it. But right now in the United States, the tax code encourages many people to take out big mortgages. Thats why its a good idea to put the elimination of the tax deductibility of mortgage interest on the political agenda.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Bringing Up Baby'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Howard Hawks's 1938 screwball comedy "Bringing Up Baby."

title: Americas Development Bank Forgives Much of Haitis Debt
description: MEXICO CITY  Haiti received a boost to its balance sheet on Monday when the Inter-American Development Bank, meeting in the Mexican resort city of Cancn, agreed to forgive $479 million of the countrys $1.2 billion in foreign debt.

title: Dr. James Black, Pharmacologist Who Discovered Beta Blockers, Dies at 85
description: Dr. James W. Black, a Scottish pharmacologist whose discovery of beta blockers and another class of drugs extended the lives of millions of people with heart and stomach disorders and earned him a Nobel Prize in 1988, died on Sunday. He was 85.

title:
Republicans Face Drawbacks of United
Stand on Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Passage of the health care legislation challenges the heart of the Republicans strategy this year: To present a unified opposition to big Democratic ideas, in this case expressed in a stream of bristling anger and occasional mischaracterizations of what the bill would do.

title: The Ongoing Toll From 9/11
description: A House subcommittee has finally begun moving vital legislation to provide long-term health care and compensation for thousands of emergency responders, volunteers and community residents left seriously sickened after the World Trade Center terrorist attack. The 25-to-8 vote cut across regional lines  an encouraging recognition that the 9/11 attack was an assault on the nation and that its victims still need and deserve the nations help.

title: An Absence of Class
description: Some of the images from the run-up to Sundays landmark health care vote in the House of Representatives should be seared into the nations consciousness. We are so far, in so many ways, from being a class act.

title: To Transform Health Care in America
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mideast Strategy: An Egyptian View
description: To the Editor:

title: Shakespearean Deceit and the War in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Benedicts Fragile Church
description: Berlin

title: Real Reform in an Election Year
description: The White House and Democratic leaders in Congress wont have much time to savor their victory on health care reform if they hope to achieve the next big goal: enacting financial regulatory reform before the midterm elections. A year and a half after the countrys banking system nearly imploded, it is still operating under the same inadequate rules and regulations.

title: Two Rallies
description: A few hundred Tea Party-types clustered on the south end of the Capitol on Sunday, trying to kill health care reform, fouling the crisp spring air with shouts of violence and loathing.

title: European Disunion
description: A few weeks ago, a solution to Greeces debt problems seemed close. The Greeks did their part by adopting a tough new austerity program earlier this month. But Europe has not followed through with the needed guarantee that the money Greece must borrow to pay its bills will be safe from default.

title: Corrections
description: Several articles since September about the troubles of the community organizing group Acorn referred incorrectly or imprecisely to one aspect of videotaped encounters between Acorn workers and two conservative activists that contributed to the groups problems.

title: Continuity Pays Off as Twins Keep Mauer
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  The pen Joe Mauer used to sign his eight-year, $184 million contract here Monday belongs to Joel Lepel, the minor league field coordinator for the Minnesota Twins. Lepel was born and raised in Plato, Minn., and has worked for the Twins for 21 years, mostly as a scout. All of the amateur players he has signed, including Mauer, have used the same pen.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,011 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Prescriptions column on Saturday about a provision of the health-care legislation misstated the age at which adult children would be no longer be covered under their parents insurance plans. It is 26, not 27.

title: Next Big Issue? Social Security Pops Up Again
description: WASHINGTON  Now that landmark legislation overhauling the health insurance system is about to become law, addressing Social Securitys solvency could well become the next big thing for President Obama and Congressional Democrats.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the resignation of the principal of the citys only Arabic-language school, the Khalil Gibran International Academy, referred incorrectly to an interview that the schools founding principal, Debbie Almontaser, gave to The New York Post following a controversy over T-shirts with the slogan Intifada NYC that were being sold by an Arab womens group. Ms. Almontaser, who resigned in 2007 shortly after the interview, said she had been pressured by the Department of Education to grant the interview  not to talk about the shirts specifically. (The department denies pressuring Ms. Almontaser to grant the interview.) Because of an editing error, the article and a picture caption gave an outdated location for the school. It is in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, and no longer in Boerum Hill.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about Tiger Woodss decision to resume his golf career at the Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia, where the Masters is held, misstated the history of the clubs membership rules in some editions. After years of pressure, the club eventually opened its membership to African-Americans, but not to women.

title: Corrections
description: A music column on March 15 about the Scion Rock Fest in Columbus, Ohio, where the Oregon-based band Yob played, misidentified the site of the club Rothko, where Yob played when it last came to New York, in 2005. The club, now closed, was on the Lower East Side, not in Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: A review in the Art in Review column on Friday about the Aipad Photography Show New York, at the Park Avenue Armory, misspelled the surname of a photographer who has an electronically animated self-portrait in the show. She is Shirley Shor, not Shore.

title: Lessons for the Democrats, Some Perhaps Cautionary, After a Signal Triumph
description: WASHINGTON  Among the many lessons Democrats have learned from President Obamas 14-month slog through the nations vitriolic health care debate is that there are two ways for a president to do business in hyperpartisan Washington. One is to go small, and partner across the aisle. The other is to go big, and go it alone.

title: Corrections
description: EDITORS' NOTE

title: Indias Woes Reflected in Bid to Restart Old Plant
description: VELDUR, India  Wherever there is a lamp, there is darkness below it, said Bava Bhalekar, a fisherman and local leader in this village roughly a hundred miles south of Mumbai. The tragedy is that while our village has this project, we ourselves dont have electricity.

title: Health Measures Opponents Plan Legal Challenges
description: Officials in a dozen states who oppose the health care bill say they hope to block it in court by arguing that requiring people to buy health insurance is an unprecedented intrusion by the federal government into peoples lives  the equivalent of going a step beyond simply regulating automobiles to requiring people to buy a car.

title: Stimulus Plan for Rail Line Shows System of Weak Links
description: TAMPA  The drive from Orlando to Tampa takes only 90 minutes or so. Despite the short distance, the Obama administration awarded Florida $1.25 billion in stimulus money to link the cities with a fast train to help kick off its efforts to bring high-speed rail service to the United States.

title: F.D.A. Asks Pediatricians to Stop Using a Diarrhea Vaccine for Now
description: WASHINGTON  Federal drug regulators on Monday asked the nations pediatricians to stop giving children a diarrhea vaccine until federal scientists can figure out why the product contains apparently harmless but extraneous pieces of a pig virus.

title: Justices to Weigh Law on Gaining Citizenship via Parents
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide if mothers and fathers may be treated differently in determining whether their children may claim American citizenship.

title: Few Fled Companies Constrained by Pay Limits
description: For months, Wall Street banks and the troubled automakers feverishly protested that their top executives would flee if they were not lavishly rewarded for their talents. New data, however, suggests the departures were more of a trickle than a flood.

title: Ruling Strikes Down Georgias Cap on Malpractice Awards
description: ATLANTA  The Georgia Supreme Court ruled Monday that the state legislature may not limit the amount of money that juries award to victims of medical malpractice.

title: Wolfgang Wagner, Director of Bayreuth, Is Dead at 90
description: Wolfgang Wagner, an opera director and impresario who for more than half a century ran Bayreuth, the international music festival conceived by his grandfather, Richard Wagner  and known most recently for the dynastic power struggle that was more toweringly operatic than anything the senior Mr. Wagner could have written  died on Sunday in Bayreuth, in southern Germany. He was 90.

title: Massachusetts: Ex-Customs Official Faces Jail Over Household Help
description: A former official with the Department of Homeland Security, Customs and Border Protection was convicted Monday of encouraging her housekeeper to stay in the country illegally. Lorraine Henderson, 52, of Salem, oversaw immigration enforcement at airports and other international points of entry in three states until she was suspended because of the charges in 2008. According to the United States Attorneys Office, Ms. Henderson was warned in 2006 that the housekeeper was in the country illegally, and ignored a colleagues warning that she should fire her. Ms. Henderson faces up to five years in prison, three years probation and a $250,000 fine. Sentencing is June 17.

title: Robert M. White, Who Broke Limits in Flight, Dies at 85
description: Robert M. White, who played an important role in the development of manned spaceflight as the first pilot to fly a winged craft into outer space, died Wednesday in Orlando, Fla. He was 85.

title: "Get Jersey Shored" by MTV
description: MTV is promoting the Jersey Shore lifestyle in a series of commercials called "Get Jersey Shored."

title: "Get Jersey Shored" by MTV
description: MTV is promoting the Jersey Shore lifestyle in a series of commercials called "Get Jersey Shored."

title: Betting the Situation Will Not Get Lost in Translation
description: THE Jersey Shore is about to be exported.

title: Word of the Day | anthem
description: anthem \an(t)-thm\ noun

title: Theater to Be Named in Honor of Sondheim
description: After five decades of critically acclaimed work on Broadway, the composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim, below, is receiving a rare laurel and one of the few that had not yet come his way: his name on a Broadway theater. At a gala performance on Monday night of the new Broadway musical Sondheim on Sondheim, the director James Lapine and the musical book writer John Weidman were to announce that Henry Millers Theater, which re-opened on Broadway last fall after a nearly complete overhaul, would be renamed the Stephen Sondheim Theater. According to a statement by Mr. Lapine and Mr. Weidman, a small group of Stephen Sondheim devotees contributed to the Roundabout Theater Companys musical production fund to rededicate the theater in Mr. Sondheims honor. (Neither a list of donors nor the precise sum was disclosed.) Roundabout has a long-term lease to operate and oversee programming for this 1,055-seat theater, on West 43rd Street between Broadway and Avenue of the Americas. Roundabout has produced several of Mr. Sondheims works, including Assassins and Pacific Overtures. Mr. Sondheim, who turned 80 on Monday, has won an Academy Award, several Tony and Grammy awards, and the Pulitzer Prize for drama.

title: News Quiz | March 23, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Big Clients Keep Their Head Start
description: Heres what happened: A while ago, a group of banks sued a Web site called theflyonthewall.com to prevent the site from publishing news headlines about their stock upgrades and downgrades. Last week, Judge Denise Cote, of the United States District Court in New York, ruled in favor of the banks. The decision could have big implications for who gets Wall Streets hottest tips, and when, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: The 411 on SXSW
description: WHO are playing at the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference? WHO is pictured performing in the photo above?

title: Few Fled the Companies Constrained by Pay Limits
description: For months, Wall Street banks and the troubled automakers feverishly protested that their top executives would flee if they were not lavishly rewarded for their talents. New data, however, suggests the departures were more of a trickle than a flood, Eric Dash reports in The New York Times.

title: Its Star Shaky, Baylor Turns to Supporting Cast
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Baylors freshman center Brittney Griner blocked 14 shots Monday night  an N.C.A.A. womens tournament record  but the first person that Coach Kim Mulkey hugged in victory was a junior guard, Melissa Jones.

title: Time Warner Said to Lead MGM Bids Over $1 Billion
description: Time Warner, Lions Gate Entertainment and billionaire Len Blavatniks Access Industries put up rival bids of $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion for studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, sources familiar with the matter told Reuters on Monday.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Profit Beats Quarters Forecasts
description: Phillips-Van Heusen, the apparel maker, posted earnings that beat Wall Street expectations, boosted by the strength of its Calvin Klein brand around the world, Reuters reported.

title: MtyMx Music Festival
description: An ambitious undertaking collected small- and medium-size indie-rock bands and planted them on a little-used stretch of land for three days in Monterrey, Mexico.

title: Somaxon to Launch Offering to Fund Drug Plan
description: Just days after receiving Food and Drug Administration approval for Silenor, biotech company Somaxon Pharmaceuticals made plans to sell four million shares to pay for marketing the insomnia drug, The Associated Press reported.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Wayne Collett, an American runner who was barred from competing again in Olympic competition after he was judged to have acted disrespectfully during a medal ceremony in Munich in 1972, misspelled the given name and surname of the sports information director at the University of California, Los Angeles, where Collett had been a track and field star. He is Marc Dellins, not Mark Dellims.

title: Editors Note
description: The Paul Krugman column on Monday, about the health care bill, quoted Newt Gingrich as saying that Lyndon Johnson shattered the Democratic Party for 40 years by passing civil rights legislation. The quotation originally appeared in The Washington Post, which reported after the column went to press that Mr. Gingrich said it referred to Johnsons Great Society policies, not to the 1964 Civil Rights Act.

title: Four Suspended From Labour Party in U.K. Scandal
description: LONDON  Caught by concealed cameras as they offered to trade influence for cash, three former government ministers have been suspended from Prime Minister Gordon Browns Labour Party, setting off a new political furor Tuesday as Britain edges toward elections.

title: Former MySQL Chief Lands at Eucalyptus
description: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

title: Icahn Raises Stake in Take Two
description: Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, has again added to his stake in Take Two Interactive Software, upping his bet in the struggling video game publisher, Reuters reported.

title: Clean Tech Sector Thriving, Survey Finds
description: From Kristina Shevory at Green Inc.:

title: The Scene | Beirut
description: Lebanons cosmopolitan capital is finally getting its groove back.

title: First Interstate Revs Up for $130 Million I.P.O.
description: First Interstate BancSystem, a bank holding company, is expected to raise about $130 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq Stock Market this week, The Associated Press reported.

title: E*Trade: Deal or No Deal?
description: Analysts appeared divided Monday on what the appointment of a new chief at E*Trade Financial meant for the takeover speculation that has been swirling around the company for some time.

title: Zale Said to Mull Deal With Sun Capital
description: Zale, which expected to have secured funds to steady its finances by late May, is considering a financing proposal from Sun Capital Partners, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Capturing the Elusive Bill Cunningham
description: Bill Cunningham is probably the most honest photojournalist in New York. But he can also be pretty deceptive.

title: Opera Mini Browser, Coming to an iPhone Near You
description: Opera Software on Tuesday announced that it is submitting its Opera Mini Web browser to Apple for use on the iPhone.

title: Do You Support or Oppose the Health Care Reform Bill?
description: On Sunday night, after a year of wrangling, the House of Representatives voted along party lines to approve health care reform legislation. What do you think of the bill? What do you think of the partisanship reflected in the vote? What questions do you have?

title: Brinks Sets Date for Vote on Sale to Tyco
description: Brinks Home Security Holdings said Monday its shareholders will vote May 12 on the companys plan to sell itself to Tyco International, The Associated Press reported.

title: Babcock and VT Recommend $2 Billion Deal
description: Babcock International of Britain, a company involved in ship-building and nuclear power, said Tuesday that it had agreed with the board of VT, a defense services firm, on the terms of a takeover bid worth 1.33 billion.

title: Legg Masons Miller Likes Health Care Stocks
description: Legg Masons Bill Miller, a celebrated value investor, thinks cheap health care stocks should perform well in the next few months now that legislative uncertainty about reform in the sector has been removed, Reuters reported.

title: Human-Flesh Search Engines
description: Chinese vigilantes who seek vengeance via the Net.

title: Regulators Prod L.B. Fosters Portec Deal
description: L.B. Foster, which makes rail and construction products, said Monday it has received a second request for information from U.S. antitrust regulators regarding its proposed acquisition of Portec Rail Products, The Associated Press reported.

title: Muller Says Saab Could List Within a Year
description: Victor Muller, chief executive of Spyker Cars, the Dutch sports car maker that arranged to buy Saab from General Motors this year, said he hoped to list the company within a year, a Swedish newspaper reported Tuesday.

title: State of the Colts: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Handling Holy Week in Rome
description: During Holy Week, multitudes descend on the Vatican, and therefore Rome. Beginning on Palm Sunday (March 28) and continuing until Easter Sunday (April 4), the already numerous springtime visitors will be joined by tens of thousands of pilgrims, eager to participate in the liturgical calendars most important events. Crowds at St. Peters Basilica and the adjacent Vatican Museums are inevitable, but with a bit of planning, avoiding the throngs is possible.

title: Judge Orders Talks in Yellowstone Club Case
description: A U.S. bankruptcy judge has ordered three days of settlement talks in May for the tangle of legal claims arising from the bankruptcy of the ultra-exclusive Yellowstone Club, The Associated Press reported.

title: U.S. Detainee in North Korea Was a Teacher
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An American citizen facing trial in North Korea for entering the country illegally is a Christian who taught English at a South Korean primary school, former colleagues said Tuesday.

title: Berkshire Buys Beer and Wine Distributor
description: Berkshire Hathaway announced late Monday that McLane, its subsidiary, had struck a deal to acquire Kahn Ventures, which distributes wine, beer and spirits in Georgia and North Carolina. The company did not disclose how much it had agreed to pay.

title: The Context of Content
description: Todays idea: Its not just content but increasingly its technological context that shapes how books, music and movies are experienced, a blogger says. And amateur online reviewers are ahead of the curve in recognizing this.

title: Dai-Ichi Life Raises $11 Billion in I.P.O.
description: Dai-ichi Mutual Life Insurance, Japans second-largest life insurer, is set to raise 1.01 trillion yen ($11 billion) after it priced the shares for its initial public offering at $1,553, in the middle of a tentative price range, according to news media reports.

title: Icahn to Push for Sale of Biogen, Report Says
description: Fresh from winning a deal with Biogen Idec to add a director to the biotechnology companys board, Carl C. Icahn has once again turned his attention to the notion of selling off the firm, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Pragmatic Libertarians
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: Google Faces Fallout as China Reacts  to Site Shift
description: Google pushed. Now China is pushing back.

title: Toshiba Eyes Nuclear Alliance With Gates Start-Up
description: Toshiba is in talks with a start-up backed by Microsoft chief Bill Gates to jointly develop advanced nuclear reactors, the Japanese electronics maker said Tuesday, helping send its shares higher, Reuters reported.

title: Will Ellison Go To the Boards for the Warriors?
description: Now that the Golden State Warriors have hung out the for-sale sign, will Oracle chief Larry Ellison make his move on the N.B.A. team?

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, March 23
description: Here are some highlights from Tuesdays editions of The New York Times:

title: New York Auto Show Preview: Camp Jeep Is Back
description: For those off-road enthusiasts whove missed the theme park atmosphere of Camp Jeep at the New York auto show, the news is good: the portable mountains, the fake fallen logs and the steep wedges will return to the Jacob Javits Center for this years show.

title: Sampler: Smoking May Be Banned on Beaches, and School-Time Curfew Proposed in Richmond
description: California to Consider Smoking Ban on Beaches | Smoking on 64 state beaches and 278 parks may be banned if California lawmakers sign a smoking bill into law. Violators will receive a $100 fine. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has not said he will sign the bill, which faces one more vote in the State Senate. But enforcement could be difficult, because the parks system has no money for additional staffing or warning signs, said Roy Stearns, a spokesman for the state parks system. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: Investors Wish List  Said to Anger P.E. Firms
description: A trade group representing private equity investors has fired a shot across the bow of the industry, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: State-Run Bank in Athens Won Big With C.D.S.s
description: Hellenic Post Bank, a lender controlled by the Greek state, bought about 950 million euros worth of credit default swaps, insuring itself against the nations sovereign debt, according to documents seen by Kathimerini, a major Greek daily.

title: At Rio Tinto Trial in China, Door Closes Tighter
description: SHANGHAI  Prosecutors argued for a second day in court that four employees from the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto accepted millions of dollars in bribes and stole commercial secrets from Chinese companies, but the closed nature of the trial made it difficult to assess the nature of the evidence they presented in the high-profile case.

title: British Investor Group Takes Issue With Bank Fees
description: An influential group of of institutional investors in Britain is calling for a re-examination of the advisory fees paid to investments banks in mergers and acquisitions, arguing that in some cases they may be influencing the outcome of takeovers, The Financial Times reported.

title: A Bit About That
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: A Bit About That
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Q&A: When Flash Is on the Fritz
description: Q.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: U.S. Set to Expand Role in Protecting Air TravelersNew rules protecting fliers, including a requirement that passengers be allowed to leave planes stuck on the tarmac more than three hours, will take effect April 29.

title: Dubai Chefs Find Alcohol Ban Distasteful
description: The Dubai authorities plan to step up enforcement of a law enacted in 2003 prohibiting restaurants from using alcohol in food preparation, according to media reports.

title: Obama Family Takes in Addams Family
description: So the Obamas are fierce for Broadway this week: After taking in Memphis on Sunday afternoon, Michelle Obama, her two daughters, Sasha and Malia, and her mother, Marian Robinson, attended another new musical on Monday night: The Addams Family.

title: In Response to California Fuel Regulation, Cargo Ships Chart More Precarious Routes
description: In an apparent effort to skirt a new clean-fuel regulation in California, an increasing number of ships traveling to and from one of the nations busiest port complexes  at Los Angeles and Long Beach  are abandoning a long-established shipping lane, choosing instead to travel along a riskier route that traverses a Navy weapons testing and training area.

title: Senate Democrats Urge School Spending Cuts
description: State Senate Democrats put forward a plan on Monday that would cut school financing by $1.4 billion to try to plug a budget deficit estimated at $9 billion.

title: Wall Street Gets a Little Momentum
description: Investors snapped up industrial and materials stocks on Tuesday, helping the Dow soar to a 18-month high.

title: Volkswagen to Issue $6 Billion in Preferred Shares
description: Volkswagen said Tuesday that it would offer 65 million new shares in an issue that would increase its capital by about 4.5 billion euros ($6 billion).

title: The Early Word: How a Bill Becomes a Law
description: The prospects looked dicey more than a time or two, but President Obama signs into law this morning the health care overhaul that has consumed debate in Washington for months.

title: Breaking Even Worse: Aaron Paul in The Weird Al Yankovic Story
description: In a recent interview, Aaron Paul, an Emmy-nominated star of Breaking Bad, told me he had been searching high and low for his next role, one that wouldnt pigeonhole him as the lovable drug dealer he plays on that AMC series. (In other words, he said, yes, Im definitely unemployed.)

title: Lions Gate Rejects Latest Icahn Offer
description: Lions Gate Entertainment said Tuesday that its board had voted unanimously to reject the tender offer made by Carl C. Icahn to buy the company for $6 a share. Lions Gate previously rejected Mr. Icahns bid to raise his stake to 30 percent, and it called the latest offer, for the entire company, financially inadequate and coercive.

title: Inside Out | New York in Bloom
description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

title: Why Virtual Nerd Declined a $70,000 Competition Prize
description: Its hard to imagine a scrappy start-up entering a prestigious business plan competition, working hard to advance, winning the competition  and then walking away from a $70,000 investment prize. But thats exactly what Virtual Nerd did after winning the 2008-9 Olin Cup competition at Washington University in St. Louis.

title: Ice Racing Fill-In
The Order That Changed Everything
description: If there was a single event that guaranteed Democrats the 216 votes they needed to adopt major health care legislation, it was the agreement that President Obama would issue an executive order clarifying federal policy banning the use of taxpayer money for abortions.

title: Christian Science Church Seeks Truce With Modern Medicine
description: Since the founding of their church 131 years ago, Christian Scientists have been taught to avoid doctors at all cost. It is a conviction rooted so deeply in church dogma that dozens of members have endured criminal prosecution rather than surrender an ailing person to what they see as the quackery of medical science.

title: Hill vs. Jennings, Redux
description: For a player with a brief rsum and no history of mischief-making, Jordan Hill generates an impressive amount of controversy and consternation.

title: Body Found After Brooklyn Fire
description: Firefighters at the scene of a three-alarm fire in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, early Tuesday found the body of a man behind a house, the Fire Department said. No cause of death was immediately available. Eight firefighters sustained minor injuries in the blaze, which began around 1:20 a.m. on 56th Street between Third and Fourth Avenues and engulfed three connected wood frame homes.

title: More Sellers Put Homes on Market, but There Are Fewer Buyers
description: The volume of home sales is slumping even as the number of properties on the market is rising, which is putting new pressure on prices, according to economic data released Tuesday.

title: Ex-Nazi Guilty in Wartime Murders
description: BERLIN  As German authorities pursue suspected Nazi war criminals to the last, a court in Aachen convicted an 88-year-old former SS soldier on Tuesday on charges of killing three Dutch civilians in reprisal for attacks by Dutch resistance fighters in 1944.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Calling It Armageddon
description: Monologue |  Monday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: President Obama won one of the great  theyre calling it  the great legislative victories of the last 50 years last night. He won health care reform approval to extend coverage to millions of uninsured Americans, or as the Republicans are calling it Armageddon. Personally, I think its great. Maybe now, I can finally get a gynecologist to see me.

title: Columbia, Michigan and Connecticut Among 25 Colleges to Add Common Application
description: Students applying to Columbia, the University of Michigan, the University of Connecticut and 22 other institutions in the next admissions season will, for the first time, be able to use the Common Application.

description: Rosie ODonnells forthcoming talk show will be squarely positioned as a suitable replacement for Oprah Winfrey, her producers said on Monday, adding a new twist in an effort by local stations to revamp their lineups in a post-Winfrey era.
