description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: A lot of upsets over the weekend. Kansas lost to Northern Iowa. Georgetown lost to Ohio. Republicans lost to the Democrats.

title: Move to Legalize Marijuana in California Sparks Fears About Drop in Prices
description: A proposal to put the legalization of marijuana in California to a vote this November is causing some growers of the plant in the state to worry about a sharp drop in the value of their crop if the measure succeeds.

description: How far back should a study go to show that food portions have increased over time? Ten years? Fifty years? What about all the way back to the Last Supper?

description: A network faces a challenge when it interrupts a TV shows weekly schedule. How can it remind fans what happened months earlier and at the same time invite new viewers to start watching?

description: Theres staying together because of the children, and now theres staying together because of the economy.

title: Smart Water Meters Take Hold in California
description: Smart water meters are taking off in California, according to a forthcoming report from the California Energy Commission. More than half of the states water utilities have some smart meters in their service areas, according to the report, Smart Meters and California Water Agencies: Overview and Status.

title: Davis Provides Mets a Glimpse of Their Future
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Ike Davis hit .480 this spring with 3 home runs and 24 total bases, but it wasnt good enough. The Mets sent him back to the minors on Tuesday after a most impressive spring in big-league camp.

title: Male Infertility Linked With Prostate Cancer
description: Infertility in men may signal a higher risk for aggressive prostate cancer, a new study suggests.

description: Most of the major provisions in the health care legislation do not take effect for months, if not years.

title: What Were Reading
What the Health Care Overhaul Means for Americans Abroad
description: On Monday, Times reporters answered reader questions about how the health care overhaul will affect consumers. But one reader question that remained unanswered was how the legislation will affect Americans abroad. Heres the answer.

title: Does the Ending Need Rewriting?
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  A team is ahead by 10 points with 1 minute 30 seconds remaining, and what follows can be a messy, disjointed, dragged-out display of basketball. The losing team starts to foul and there is a parade to the free-throw line, a stream of timeouts and a groan from the crowd.

title: Stefano Tonchi to Edit W Magazine
description: 12:15 P.M. Updated with comment from Stefano Tonchi.

description: Feel this grip, Zemo  its the grip of a man who loves liberty! cried Harvard Hottie from The Nanny Diaries.

description: These are radical times  and Americas publishers have discovered a vehicle to match the revolutionary tenor of the age, a battle-tested genre known to shake the foundations of tradition-bound institutions, serve notice to the powerful and set daring young imaginations on fire.

title: Britain Expels Israel Diplomat Over Fake Passports
description: LONDON  In a rare move by a friendly government, Britain expelled an Israeli diplomat on Tuesday to rebuke the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for what it says was the fraudulent use of a dozen fake British passports in the assassination of a Hamas official in a Dubai hotel earlier this year.

title: Blogging the Signing Ceremony
description: 12:01 p.m. |Final Handshakes

title: The Originals | Henry Conway
description: Henry Conway stepped into the British consciousness out of a white horse-drawn carriage, dressed like Beau Brummel, completely upstaging Paris Hilton (whose party it was supposed to be). The fact that he had been involved in a financial scandal that cost his Tory father his seat as a member of Parliament made the tabloids apt to pay attention: Londons Evening Standard gave the picture its front page. But as Conway, 27, himself observed in a different context in his fashion column for SuperSuper magazine, Where theres muck, theres brass. After dark, the event promoter socializes with the likes of Princes William and Harry at his Thursday-night wheeze at Mayfairs hip Mahiki Club. And he will soon debut a Friday party cheekily called Royal Jelly at Bungalow 8. He is also the co-author of a book on the history of knitwear and appears as a fashion expert on highbrow arts programs like the BBCs Newsnight Review. I am a slightly old-school cultural commentator, Conway says over the phone from London, not before mentioning hes just had an appointment with Victoria Beckhams facialist. But he doesnt see a conflict between his roles as budding public intellectual and private party host. I think you do have to experience life to be able to judge it and pass judgment on it.

title: Caesarean Births Are at a High in U.S.
description: The Caesarean section rate in the United States reached 32 percent in 2007, the countrys highest rate ever, health officials are reporting.

title: Questions Linger in Egypt as Leader Heals
description: CAIRO  President Hosni Mubaraks health continues to improve after surgery 17 days ago to remove his gallbladder, easing anxiety in this nation of 80 million people where uncertainty fueled rumors that the president was seriously ill, or even dead.

title: Unscheduled Detour at Atlantic Yards Site
description: Updated, 3:45 p.m. | Opponents of Atlantic Yards may have lost the battle to stop the bulldozers, but they have hardly given up the fight.

title: Obama Signs Health Care Overhaul Bill, With a Flourish
description: WASHINGTON  With the strokes of 22 pens, President Obama signed his landmark health care overhaul  the most expansive social legislation enacted in decades  into law on Tuesday, saying it enshrines the core principle that everybody should have some basic security when it comes to their health care.

title: Lexus CT 200h Compact Hybrid Gets U.S. Release Date
description: In his review for the Lexus HS 250h, the first dedicated Lexus hybrid, The Timess Jerry Garrett said, It is a hybrid that doesnt feel like one.

title: Alexie Wins PEN/Faulkner Fiction Prize
description: Sherman Alexie was named the winner of the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction on Tuesday for War Dances, a collection of stories and poems. Mr. Alexies book, along with books by the other finalists, Barbara Kingsolver, Lorraine M. Lpez, Lorrie Moore and Colson Whitehead, was selected from about 350 novels and short story collections published by American authors in 2009. Mr. Alexie, who also won the National Book Award for Young Peoples Literature in 2007 for The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian, will receive $15,000 from the PEN/Faulkner Foundation.

title: A Daughters Stress and a Mothers Worries
description: I wish my son were more stressed, said one mother in the circle, responding to the banter about the enormous pressure so many high school juniors experience.

title: With Jobs Open, Cornells Donahue Stays On Point
description: ITHACA  Cornell Coach Steve Donahue knows his name is out there.

title: In Newark, Arrests Are Made in 1978 Killings
description: They left behind the telltale trappings of teenage boys, circa 1978  a snazzy sweatsuit, a bass guitar, a half-eaten supper, basketballs, boxing gloves  and each stepped out into the warm Newark night. Their friend, a hulking, 25-year-old handyman named Lee Evans, had called asking for help with an odd job, and the boys all said yes.

title: Senator Isakson Is Hospitalized
description: Senator Johnny Isakson, Republican of Georgia, has been hospitalized since Monday with what his aides say may be a bacterial infection.

title: One for the Books
description: The N.C.A.A. mens tournaments Round of 16 doesnt start till Thursday, but one game has captured the countrys imagination. Kentucky vs. Cornell has taken on deep philosophical undertones, far beyond the usual Goliath vs. David clich. Yes, Kentucky has seven national championships and Cornell has a grand total of two N.C.A.A. tournament victories (both last weekend), and yes, Kentuckys famous sons include legends like Adolph Rupp, Dan Issel and Sam Bowie, while Cornell would rather point out that Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is an alumna, although we hear she does have a mean crossover move.

title: Britain Says Passports in Dubai Assassination Were Forged by Israel
description: Updated | Wednesday | 7:59 a.m. A British government investigation has concluded that Israel was involved in the forgery of 12 British passports used by suspects in the killing of a Hamas official in Dubai in January, Britains foreign secretary, David Miliband, said in a statement to the House of Commons on Tuesday.

title: Deal Provides Vaccines to Poor Nations at Lower Cost
description: Pfizer and GlaxoSmithKline will supply hundreds of millions of doses of their pneumonia vaccines to the worlds poorest countries at heavily discounted prices under a novel agreement announced Tuesday.

title: Do Paranoiacs Have Power?
description: Jack Shafer has a bone to pick with my review of David Aaronovitchs Voodoo Histories: The Role of the Conspiracy Theory in Shaping Modern History, which concluded by suggesting that the paranoid style seems to have much less influence over Western politics, birthers and truthers notwithstanding, than it did in the first half of the 20th century. description: On Monday, the Bucks team helped answer questions about the health care bill over on the Prescriptions blog. One reader asked whether the bill would extend Cobra eligibility through 2014, when many of the most crucial insurance affordability measures take effect.

title: Travel Auctions for the Whole Family
description: When it comes to vacations, what entices adults doesnt always appeal to those with toddlers and teenagers in tow. So Luxurylink.com, which offers discounts on high-end hotels,startedFamilyGetaway.com last month. Like its sister site, it offers deals and auctions, only theyre geared for families.

title: Critics Picks Video: Bringing Up Baby
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Howard Hawkss 1938 screwball comedy starring Cary Grant and Katharine Hepburn. While many contemporary romantic comedies try to mimic the frantic narrative of the film, Mr. Scott calls Bringing Up Baby the screwiest screwball of them all. Please share your thoughts on Bringing Up Baby.

description: Yearning for a Mickey Mouse ice cream pop? You may just be feeling left out, according to a new study forthcoming from the Journal of Consumer Research:

title: Norwegian Automaker Peddles Its Runabout
description: If you had been in downtown San Francisco on Monday, you might have caught a glimpse of a little red coupe zipping silently through the streets around City Hall.

title: Courted in California, but Dreaming of New York
description: Earlier this month, I picked up my phone and heard a voice I didnt recognize. Hello, my name is Elise and I am a B.S.U. student from U.C.S.D., she said, and I would like to congratulate you on your acceptance to U.C.S.D. (The B.S.U. is the Black Student Union at the University of California, San Diego.)

title: Dispatch | On the Slopes in Verbier
description: A soul-stirring weekend in Verbier, the resort town in the Swiss Alps, left me blown away. Its upscale but unflashy and sophisticated yet down to earth. With a W hotel landing there in a couple of seasons  the first of this Starwood brand in a ski resort  its sure to be the next mecca of the ski world. So go now, while its still all about renting a little chalet of your own. And yes, theres still tons of snow: ski season ends in late April.

title: Condoleezza Rice Endorses Fiorina
description: Condoleezza Rice, the former secretary of state, is backing Carly Fiorinas bid for Senate in California.

title: TimesCast | March 23, 2010
description: From the newsroom of The New York Times.

title: Boehner: A Somber Day for America
description: With giddy Democrats celebrating at the White House, the House Republican leader, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, said there was no reason for the good cheer.

title: Germany Seems to Signal a Compromise on Greece
description: BRUSSELS  Germany indicated on Tuesday that it might agree on an aid package for Greece financed in part by the countries of the euro zone  but only as a last resort and subject to tough conditions.

title: Yahoo Offers New iPhone Search Applications
description: On Tuesday Yahoo introduced two new search iPhone applications at the C.T.I.A. conference in Las Vegas.

title: Mets Expect Reyes to Return to Camp on Wednesday
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jose Reyess thyroid levels have returned to normal and he is expected to return to Mets training camp here on Wednesday, the Mets said.

title: Obamas Remarks at the Health Care Bill Signing
description: Following is a transcript of the remarks by President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday before Mr. Obama signed a landmark health care bill into law, as released by Federal News Service:

title: France Drops Carbon Tax After Defeat
description: After his governing conservative party took a pounding in regional polls on Sunday, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France has dropped a key environmental goal: setting up a carbon tax to limit the growth of emissions and spur the development of renewable fuels.

title: Robin Wright, Richard Shiff Set for Talleys Folly
description: Robin Wright,who has starred in the films The Princess Bride, Forrest Gump and The Private Lives of Pippa Lee, has agreed to make her Broadway debut in a revival of the Lanford Wilson comedy Talleys Folly planned for the 2010-11 season, its producers said on Tuesday. The play, about a wealthy, rebellious Missouri woman who is courted by an older tax accountant, will also star Richard Schiff (The West Wing), who will also make his Broadway debut.

title: Two Fewer Episodes Planned for Two and a Half Men
description: The CBS comedy Two and a Half Men will produce two fewer episodes because of Charlie Sheens stint at a rehabilitation center, the programs executive producer, Chuck Lorre, said.

title: Life Time: The Show Is a Hit for Discovery
description: When the Discovery chief operating officer Peter Liguori talked to colleagues about his plan tointroduce the sweeping new nature series Life on seven cable channels simultaneously, he said, Id love to be able to announce a big sloppy number for Life. The show deserves it.

title: Tips for Anderson Cooper: How to Fix Up Your Firehouse
description: Anderson Cooper has gotten heat for his plans to turn a former West Village firehouse into a private residence: Preservationists want to landmark the building; a man whose son worked at the firehouse and died in the Sept. 11 attacks wants Mr. Cooper to restore an honorary plaque; and an architect working on the renovation sued Mr. Cooper, saying she fell through the hole where the fire pole used to be.

title: At White House, Bidens Expletive Caught on Open Mike
description: Beyond the ebullient atmosphere, shout-outs and cheers at the White House signing ceremony of the health care bill, theres another moment that is being rewound and played again and again: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.s overheard, overly effusive aside to President Obama.

title: When Doctor Visits Lead to Legal Help
description: It was not the normal stuff of a pediatric exam. As a doctor checked the growth of Davon Cades 2-month-old son, he also probed about conditions at home, and what he heard raised red flags.

title: Appeals Court Looks Skeptically at Galleon Wiretaps
description: A federal appeals court expressed doubts on Tuesday over whether the Galleon Groups founder, Raj Rajaratnam, must turn over wiretap evidence to the Securities and Exchange Commission while the legality of the recordings remains an open issue, Reuters reports.

title: Deepening Deficits in the Developed World
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has put together a handy set of numbers showing deficits around the developed world. And according to the agency, every developed country except Norway ran a deficit last year:

title: In Health Vote Coverage, a Victory for Fox and a Rebound for CNN
description: Sundays dramatic vote on health care legislation kicked up viewing totals at all three all news networks, with the Fox News Channel scoring a significant victory, as it now almost always does in the cable news competition.

title: Madoff Makes List of N.Y.s Top Tax Delinquents
description: Bernard L. Madoff may be behind bars, but that doesnt mean that New York State isnt looking to recover some assets from the convicted Ponzi schemer.

title: A Remembrance: Three Who Helped to Shape the West
description: In recent weeks, the West lost three men who helped to shape it: Edgar Wayburn,a past president of the Sierra Club, Stewart L. Udall, who was the interior secretary in the 1960s, and Charles Muscatine, a Chaucer scholar who was among the University of California, Berkeley professors fired after they refused, in 1949, to sign an anti-Communist loyalty oath. Rehired after the State Supreme Court has ruled the oath requirement unconstitutional, Mr. Muscatine later helped mediate the warring forces in the days of the Free Speech Movement in the mid-1960s.

title: Sex Offender Leaves Piedmont and Bay Area
description: James Donnelly, the convicted sex offender who moved into his sisters home across the street from an elementary school in Piedmont last month after serving time in federal prison, has moved out, a police spokesman told Bay City News on Tuesday.

title: Police in Bangladesh Close Photo Exhibit

title: 6 Arrested in British Insider-Trading Inquiry

title: Eighth Graders May Just Have to Wait
description: Wednesday was supposed to be known as letter day. Thousands of eighth graders are eagerly waiting to find out where they will go attend high school in the fall. But they may have to wait some more.

title: W.T.O. Affirms Ruling of Improper Airbus Aid
description: The World Trade Organization ruled on Tuesday that the European plane maker Airbus received improper subsidies for its $13 billion A380 superjumbo jet and several other airplanes, hurting Boeing, its American rival, industry officials in the United States and Europe said.

title: Letter: Questionable Compliment
description: To the Editor: Regarding your column Student Rates for Young at Heart (March 14): As a 62-year-old proud of having an experienced and sophisticated old heart, I would like to know why young at heart is a more acceptable compliment than white at heart would be.

title: Letter: More Than Beaches
description: To the Editor: Regarding Sri Lanka: Checkpoints in Paradise (March 14): The Travel Section has extolled Sri Lankas beautiful beaches and fine accommodations. However, no mention is made of its outstanding archaeological sites like Sigiriya and Anuradhapura. Surely many readers would be interested in the rich heritage of the country.

title: Is Privacy Worth Sacrificing to Save on Insurance?
description: Would you let your insurance company electronically monitor your driving if you knew it might result in a discount?

title: More on Intergenerational Differences
description: I was pondering this month whether the next generation of old people will have values and attitudes different from the current one. Id intended the post as a way to mull over whether some characteristics that cause widespread complaints among families  intransigence about accepting help, for instance  were related to membership in a particular cohort as it aged or were products of aging itself.

title: Correction: Frugal San Francisco
description: The cover article on March 14 about the Frugal Travelers trip to San Francisco with his toddler misstated the fare for a BART train between the San Francisco airport and the 24th and Mission stop. It is $7.95 each way, not $5.10 each way.

title: Jamie Dimon Was Right
description: About the 19th century, that is.

title: Kentuckys New Tournament Threat: Its Womens Team
description: A lot is made of Kentuckys top-seeded mens basketball team being a team to watch.

title: Correction: Trekking With Wolves
description: Because of an editing error, the cover article on Feb. 21 about snowshoeing in northern Minnesota misidentified the location of the closest commercial airport to Ely, Minn., and the Boundary Waters. It is in Hibbing, Minn., not Duluth or Minneapolis-St. Paul.

title: Palermo Privata
description: It sits on the north shore of Sicily on a fan-shaped stretch of land between two towering stone promontories, and its been there, in one form or another, for almost 3,000 years. Empire after empire has trodden upon the place: Greeks, Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Romans; then Vandals, Normans, Moors, Spaniards; then Italians, the United States Army; and since the end of World War II, Cosa Nostra, whose influence over the place is only recently waning. For millennia its been built up and knocked down, robbed and bombed, patched up and left to fend for itself. So it is a spectral city, a city of ghosts and ruins, amid which the living citizens slip quietly and for the most part without expression; an inward city, not unkind but very private  Italia insulare, as they call it. Palermo can be very beautiful, in a decaying, Hubert Robert way; on sunny days the sky overhead is Mediterranean enamel blue; the food is wondrous. But above all, Palermo is full of secrets and very strange.

title: Palermo Privata
description: An insular city full of art and ruins reveals quiet wonders around every piazza.

title: Hating On Christiane Amanpour
description: Weird attack from Tom Shales, whos supposed to be a TV reviewer, on the choice of Christiane Amanpour as the new host of This Week. I have a stake in all this, since Im a regular on the show. But even if I werent, I think Id see this attack as distinctly off.

title: Health Reform Law Requires Calorie Labels at Restaurants
description: If you think the health care reform bill had nothing to do with your lunch, think again. A little noticed national calorie labeling rule tucked into the legislation assures that within a couple of years, everyone who walks into a chain restaurant will see calories counts displayed alongside the price of a meal.

title: A First Step on Fannie and Freddie
description: WASHINGTON  Despite growing pressure from Congress to act quickly, the Obama administration is moving tentatively to develop a plan to reshape Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage-finance companies taken over by the government 18 months ago.

title: Its Star Freshman Shaky, Baylor Draws on Experience
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Baylor Coach Kim Mulkey has a saying that she drills into her players: keep a cool head and a hot game.

title: In the Senate, a New Legislative Day
description: 3:48 p.m. | Updated  Debate on the reconciliation bill has begun in the Senate.

title: Data Show Decline in Mobility in U.S.
description: Americans stung by the recession and the burst housing bubble hunkered down as the decade ended. As a result, hot spots in the South and the West that had surged in population after 2000 grew more slowly or lost migrants to other places, according to census data released Tuesday.

title: Brill Building Is Named a Landmark
description: The Brill Building, the Art Deco sweatshop of smash hits on Broadway and 49th Street, is now a city landmark. The Landmarks Preservation Commission voted Tuesday to designate the building.

title: The Reality of Reform': Understanding the Health Care Law
description: Overview | How will health care reform change life and politics in the United States? What does the new law mean for individuals, families, businesses and insurers, as well as for politics and government leaders? In this lesson, students gauge their background knowledge of the health care reform act and take a close look at the legislation to clarify their understanding. They then execute a project on historical context, local reaction and/or the key players, and finish by creating collages of images and quotations that illuminate the issues.

title: Treasury Takes Steps to Reshape Fannie and Freddie
description: Under pressure from Congress, the Obama administration is taking a tentative first step in developing a plan to replace Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the huge mortgage-finance companies that the government took over in 2008, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: U.N. Group Rejects Shark Protections
description: PARIS  Delegates to a United Nations conference on endangered species voted down three of four proposals to protect sharks on Tuesday, handing another victory to Japan, China and countries opposed to the involvement of the international authorities in regulation of ocean fish.

title: Mix of Teams Adds New Intrigue
description: Which of the midmajors are for real and which top seeds are built to complete a run to the N.C.A.A. championship?

title: The Password Is Membership
description: AN ocean-view room at the Gansevoort Turks & Caicos, normally $460 a night, slashed to $285. A fireplace room at the $500-a-night Ventana Inn & Spa in Big Sur, Calif., for $315. A water villa at the Six Senses Soneva Gili resort in the Maldives, normally $1,040 a night, reduced to $840.

title: Two New Travel Apps for the iPhone: NileGuide and Gliider
description: Back in December, I wrote about Web tools that help travelers plan their trips. Now, two of those companies, NileGuide and Gliider, have just released iPhone apps - welcome aids to people who are not just dreaming about trips, but living them.

title: Pops Hair Apparent | Justin Bieber
description: Despite recent attempts to assume the vacant King of Pop throne (most notably by the members of the House of Jonas), its been a bleak interregnum. But a Justin Bieber-led restoration may soon be on the cards. As the impish prince of teen idolatry, Bieber  the 16-year-old YouTube breakout star turned bona fide pop royalty  has captured the popular imagination, sending teenage girls (real and honorary) into paroxysms of passion and mall-security guards into nervous fits every time he makes a public appearance. T paid court to Bieber, whose eagerly awaited new album, My World 2.0, is out today.

title: Q&A: Nicaragua With a Local Guide
description: Q.

title: Daimler Is Said to Settle Bribing Charges
description: WASHINGTON  The German carmaker Daimler has agreed to pay about $185 million in fines, and two of its subsidiaries will plead guilty to bribing foreign government officials, to settle a multiyear corruption investigation, according to a person familiar with the case.

title: Hotel Review: The Hotel Palomar in Philadelphia
description: THE BASICS

title: Off Sardinia, an Island With Wilder Shores
description: IT was half an hour after sunset in SantAntioco, one of the most undeveloped corners of Sardinia, and we were lost. I had driven out of the ancient Ligurian fishing port of Calasetta minutes earlier, following a strip of asphalt that dipped and rose through empty grassland and Mediterranean scrub. Quickly, the paved road leading south along the sea petered out, and my two sons and I found ourselves on a dirt path barely wide enough for our car.

title: With This View, Who Needs Legroom?
description: WINDOW seat or aisle? Ever since I was a small child, theres been only one answer. Sure, the aisle is a bit roomier, and its easier to get up to stretch your legs. But for me, its all about the views, especially those entrancing last few minutes before touchdown.

title: Book Review: The Lunatic Express
description: Anyone who has ever griped about freeway traffic or being elbowed on the subway should spend some time with the journalist Carl Hoffmans book. The majority of humankind, it is sobering to remember, has little choice in modes of transportation as they commute to work, and every day an alarming percentage dont make it home.

title: In Brazil: Unspoiled Beach Fit for the Chic
description: THE sun was blazing at the Tostex beach club in Bahia, Brazil, and the tanned and toned partygoers were lounging on rustic queen-size beds, fighting off the unrelenting mosquitoes on an otherwise lazy day. A scruffy D.J. from So Paulo who went by the name Julio swayed in his thatch-roofed booth and cranked up a funky remix of Laurent Garniers saxophone-infused song The Man With the Red Face.

title: Silent Days on the Sea in Venezuela
description: THE stereo died with a wheeze, the lights clicked out, and suddenly there was only darkness and the sound of the wind rustling through palm trees. The air was soft and warm, fluid against the skin. Stars began to rise against the inky blackness around them. The moon poured down.

title: Pasta With Broccoli and Chickpeas
description: Broccoli is an affordable vegetable, packed with nutrients and available in most supermarkets. To save on pasta, buy big bags of it at package stores. The Parmesan, the priciest part of the recipe, is optional.

title: U.S. and Mexico Revise Joint Antidrug Strategy
description: MEXICO CITY  Responding to a growing sense that Mexicos military-led fight against drug traffickers is not gaining ground, the United States and Mexico set their counternarcotics strategy on a new course on Tuesday by refocusing their efforts on strengthening civilian law enforcement institutions and rebuilding communities crippled by poverty and crime.

title: New G.O.P. Slogan: Repeal and Replace Health Care Law
description: Republicans are moving quickly from repeal the health care legislation to repeal and replace the measure President Obama signed into law Tuesday.

title: In Spring, the Vituperation Blooms
description: Since the early days of cycling, drivers of four-wheeled vehicles and others have complained about sharing the road with their two-wheeled brethren. Then as now, these complaints occasionally grew into demonization  literally, in the case of one 1893 depiction of a bike rider terrorizing traffic as a frog-faced demon of the wheel.

title: History, and Marcelas Owens, Look On
description: President Obama signed his health care overhaul  the most sweeping social legislation enacted in decades  into law on Tuesday during a festive, at times raucous, ceremony in the East Room of the White House. Among those who joined him around the desk were 11-year-old Marcelas Owens of Seattle, who became an advocate for health care reform after his mother died without health insurance.

description: KING-FM, a longtime classical music station in Seattle, announced on Tuesday that it would switch to a listener-supported public model in the summer of 2011. The board overseeing the station, which operates as part of a nonprofit organization, had been studying possible changes for a couple of years.

description: Tyler Cowen has a thoughtful post analyzing how the health care bill might evolve. The following part of his argument tracks, to some extent, with the more optimistic of the scenarios I sketched out yesterday:

description: The House majority leader, Steny Hoyer of Maryland, said Tuesday that he was disappointed by some lawmakers conduct during Sunday nights health care debate, and he urged House leaders to warn their members against inappropriate behavior.

title: Are Mothers Oppressed by Their Children?
description: A profile of a French writer in a British newspaper yesterday is worth the attention of American mothers.

title: Conrad Gessner's Animals
description: The finest example of the shift to carefully researched paintings of creatures was a 4,500-page tome called The Histories of Animals, published by the Swiss physician Conrad Gessner in the mid-1500s.

title: Report Questions S.E.C.s Handling of Inquiries
description: An internal review at the Securities and Exchange Commission raises concerns about the agencys oversight of the financial industry, The Washington Post reports. Among other things, the review found that in an 18-month investigation of Allied Capital, no one from the S.E.C. had ever visited the Washington-based private equity firm, even though it was only two miles away.

description: For BWP Bats, which makes 35,000 baseball bats a year at its factory in central Pennsylvania and has been around for only a decade, every customer counts.

title: Jury Shown Swastika Tattoo in Hate-Crime Trial
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Keith Brunjes and his best friend were hanging out watching the HBO prison series Oz one day in 2008 when they decided to get homemade tattoos, the kind depicted on the show. They bought ink at a Michaels arts and crafts store, and Mr. Brunjes studied up on the subject.

title: Plant Tour: Creekstone Farms
description: About 1,000 cattle are butchered each day at Creekstones state-of-the-art processing plant in Kansas.

title: Buying Time | Watches to Watch
Making Baseball Bats a Big Seller
description: In the bottom of the ninth inning in an otherwise meaningless spring training game last week, Angel Pagan of the Mets stepped to the plate with a man on and his team down a run. In his only at-bat of the game, Pagan hit the ball over the right-field fence for a game-winning two-run homer.

title: Super-Sizing the Last Supper
description: And in the most important behavioral economic news of the day: A new study finds that the portions depicted in paintings of the Last Supper have been getting bigger over the last 1,000 years.

title: Spending Time in New York Citys Wine Shops
description: You would probably not be surprised to learn that I love to spend time in wine shops, or as my sons might eloquently put it, waste time in wine shops.

title: In Baghdad, the Crime Scene Team
description: BAGHDAD  In the aftermath of a roadside bomb on Monday, the gray-uniformed members of the Iraqi police forensic unit known as the Crime Scene Team  a CSI Baghdad, of sorts  were on the job. The bomb, which went off during the morning rush in one of Baghdads busiest squares, was planted at the foot of a newly built blast wall outside of a bank. The wall directed the blast out into the highway just as a convoy was passing, shopkeepers said. Iraqi medical officials reported several people injured, but no one was killed.

title: Dancing to a Record
description: With a cast of competitors including Kate Gosselin, Buzz Aldrin and Pamela Anderson, the new season of ABCs Dancing With the Stars broke a series record and averaged 23.9 million viewers on Monday night, according to Nielsens estimates. That was up by more than a million compared with the season premiere a year ago. The ABC crime series Castle benefited from the strong showing, leading the 10 p.m. hour with 12.9 million viewers, also its largest audience ever. The two shows combined to give ABC the most Monday-night viewers it has had in more than nine years. CBS was second, drawing its best ratings for Two and a Half Men (14.4 million) and The Big Bang Theory (13.4 million). Fox finished in third, and NBC fourth.

title: Classical Music Station to Rely on Listeners
description: KING-FM, a longtime classical music station in Seattle, announced on Tuesday that it would switch to a listener-supported public model in the summer of 2011. The board that oversees the station, which operates as part of a nonprofit organization, had been studying possible changes for a couple of years. The move continues a decade-long trend among classical stations. Last year, WQXR in New York and WCRB in Boston were sold to public radio operators. (WQXR was sold by The New York Times Company.) Besides KING-FM, there are only 18 commercial classical radio stations in the United States. Marc Hand, an industry consultant at Public Radio Capital, said classical stations tended to have older listeners than other formats; those listeners, he said, were less appealing to advertisers but more apt to be the kind of dedicated, passionate supporters who give money to public radio. I think this move really makes for a station thats more economically viable, he said.

title: The Supersizing of the Last Supper
description: How far back should a study go to show that food portions have increased over time? Ten years? Fifty years? What about all the way back to the Last Supper? A new article in The International Journal of Obesity doesnt turn the clock back quite that far but looks at nearly a thousand years worth of paintings depicting the meal and concludes that the sizes of portions, plates and bread increased dramatically over those years. The study, conducted by two brothers  Brian Wansink, a professor of consumer behavior at Cornell and director of the schools Food and Brand Lab; and Craig Wansink, a professor of religious studies at Virginia Wesleyan College  looks at 52 Last Supper paintings made between about 1000 and 1800, including famous depictions by Leonardo (detail, above), Titian and El Greco. After the size of the food in the artworks was indexed against the average size of the disciples heads (which can vary from painting to painting), the study found that the main courses grew by 69 percent, the plates by 66 percent and the bread by 23 percent. The authors are careful to qualify what these findings mean. We can say that plates and the amounts grow in the paintings, Craig Wansink said on Tuesday in a telephone interview. Does that mean in terms of the actual culture and time that food itself increased? I dont think we have the social and historical data to back that up. But we do have the data to show that food took on increasing prominence.

title: Two Fewer Episodes of Two and a Half Men
description: The CBS comedy Two and a Half Men will produce two fewer episodes because of Charlie Sheens stint at a rehabilitation center, the programs executive producer, Chuck Lorre, said. Warner Brothers Television, which produces Two and a Half Men, said the series resumed production last week. In late February Mr. Sheen, one of the shows stars, entered rehab in what his spokesman called a preventative measure. In an interview on Monday, Mr. Lorre said: Instead of doing 24 shows this year, well be doing 22. But 22 is a full order. They had asked us to produce two additional episodes, which we normally do. But we wont do it this year. Mr. Sheen pleaded not guilty last week to charges of domestic violence stemming from a dispute with his wife and is scheduled to be tried in July.

title: Robin Wright Set for Broadway Debut
description: Robin Wright, below, a star of films including The Princess Bride, Forrest Gump and The Private Lives of Pippa Lee, will make her Broadway debut in a revival of the Lanford Wilson comedy Talleys Folly, planned for the 2010-11 season, its producers said on Tuesday. The play, about a wealthy, rebellious Missouri woman who is courted by a tax accountant, will also star Richard Schiff (The West Wing), who will also be making his Broadway debut. The revival is to be directed by Marshall W. Mason, a veteran interpreter of Mr. Wilsons work, who directed the original Broadway production starring Trish Hawkins and Judd Hirsch at the Brooks Atkinson Theater in 1980.

title: Sherman Alexie Wins Pen/Faulkner Prize
description: Sherman Alexie, below, was named the winner of the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction on Tuesday for War Dances, a collection of stories and poems. Mr. Alexies book, along with books by the other finalists, Barbara Kingsolver, Lorraine M. Lpez, Lorrie Moore and Colson Whitehead, was selected from about 350 novels and short story collections published by American authors in 2009. Mr. Alexie, who also won the National Book Award for Young Peoples Literature in 2007 for The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian, will receive $15,000 from the PEN/Faulkner Foundation.

title: Chris Evans Is Cast as Captain America
description: When casting mega-budget comic-book adaptations, Hollywood tends toward either established if offbeat stars (Michael Keaton in Batman, Robert Downey Jr. in Iron Man) or freshly scrubbed newcomers (Chris Hemsworth in the coming Thor). You can decide which category this falls into: Chris Evans, left, whose films include Cellular, London and The Nanny Diaries, has been cast as Captain America, the star-spangled Marvel Comics hero who wields a mighty shield, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Evans beat out a long list of prospective candidates that was said to include everyone from John Krasinski of The Office to Chace Crawford of Gossip Girl. Mr. Evans will play the role in a 2011 Captain America movie as well as a planned Avengers film that will also feature the heroes Iron Man, Nick Fury, Thor and the Hulk. And he has experience with superheroes, having played the Human Torch in two Fantastic Four movies.

title: House Hunting in ... Ecuador
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM VILLA IN THE TUMBACO VALLEY OUTSIDE QUITO

title: Art Clues to Trends in Diet, Ice, Quakes
description: Onechallengefor researchers who want to track shiftsin the environment over the centuries  or in humans responses to it is findingreliablemeasures of change over time.In some cases, artwork has provided scientists with useful clues.

title: Two Comedies by Female Playwrights on Roundabouts Fall Schedule
description: Two new comedies by female playwrights will be among the fall 2010 productions of the Roundabout Theater Company, the artistic director, Todd Haimes, said on Tuesday. One is by an established playwright working under a commission from Roundabout, and the other is by a graduate student at the Yale School of Drama.

title: Cabdrivers Demand an Apology
description: A small but vocal group of infuriated cabdrivers gathered Tuesday outside the offices of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission to demand an apology after the agency backtracked on accusations that tens of thousands of taxi drivers had overcharged passengers a total of $8.3 million.

description: Seantrel Henderson, an offensive lineman considered by most analysts to be the nations top high school football recruit, signed with Southern California on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Versace Mansion Reborn as Miami Hotel
description: The rococo Versace Mansion in the heart of South Beach remains an icon of fascination. Or thats the hope, anyway, of Barton G. Weiss, a Miami restaurateur who has turned the late Gianni Versaces beachfront villa into a 10-room hotel.

description: Among gay men, Fire Island Pines is a legendary place of romance, rowdiness and high real estate prices.

description: The renovation of Madison Square Garden is just getting going, but executives at MSG are not wasting time lining up marquee sponsors. A few months ago Delta became the first signature partner for the arena, whose overhaul will not be completed until late 2012.

title: As War Loomed, 3 Leaders Wandered Lost
description: The decades leading up to World War I were, across Europe, an era of dwindling dynasties and triumphal facial hair. King George V of Britain and Czar Nicholas II of Russia each possessed impeccable Vandyke beards; people had trouble telling the men apart. In Germany, Kaiser Wilhelm II had so elaborate a mustache, teased into an upward-slanting W, that it earned its own name: Er ist erreicht! or It is achieved!

title: Police Fire Killed Man in Bronx Shootout
description: The Bronx man who wounded a police officer in a shootout on Monday was killed by the police and not by a self-inflicted wound, the medical examiners office has determined.

title: At the New Directors/New Films Festival, Seriousness Often Means Sadness
description: This years New Directors/New Films, the annual roundup of recent moving pictures gathered by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art that starts on Wednesday and runs through April 4, pretty much looks like last years event  and those from years past. There are titles to treasure and those to avoid among the 27 features and 11 shorts, many of which have been cherry-picked and rather less discriminately culled from other festivals, including Cannes and Berlin. Among the bigger draws is the price of admission: if youre a member of either institution, you can nibble or binge at $10 a pop (but youll have to smuggle your popcorn past the guards at the Modern).

title: Rocking and Roughing It at a Festival in Mexico
description: MONTERREY, Mexico  Just before midnight on Sunday, in front of a stage in an abandoned drive-in movie theater in the southeast part of the city here, a few hundred fans huddled tight around the spasmodic Baltimore electronic musician Dan Deacon, looking for a little healing.

description: Properties in Portland, Ore., Boston, and Carefree, Ariz.

Its more than likely a Pokwalker, Nintendos new stopwatch-size motion detector, which comes as a surprise inside the box of two of the latest Pokmon games for the Nintendo DS: Pokmon HeartGold Version and Pokmon SoulSilver Version ($40 each, released last week at http://www.pokemon.com/us/).

description: During the 1950s, the teenagers of New York became a sensational new subject for art. The novel Catcher in the Rye and the musical West Side Story are among the most famous depictions of this citys adolescents in that decade.

title: A Military Musical With a Twist
description: Lust has been known to make many a hearty serviceman burst into song, or so the American musical tells us. But there are lots of ways for a soldier, sailor or Marine to express the sentiment that there is nothing like a dame  to borrow a lyric from Rodgers and Hammersteins South Pacific  and not all of them are pretty. Why, just listen to what the boys are singing in a little show 20-some blocks south of where South Pacific is enjoying a long-running revival at Lincoln Center.

Above all, they wanted to create space and comfort for the many guests and clients the family hosts.

title: U.S. Drug Move Said to Deprive Elderly

title: The Joads, the Highway, the Dust Bowl
description: The Grapes of Wrath, the American opera by the composer Ricky Ian Gordon and the librettist Michael Korie, based on the John Steinbeck novel, is long. At its premiere in 2007, presented by the Minnesota Opera, the work clocked in at just under four hours. And that was after an hour of the score had been cut during rehearsals.
