description: If any show in the 92nd Street Ys Lyrics and Lyricists series looked like a sure thing, it was Fred and Ginger in So Many Words: The Astaire-Rogers Songbook, which had five performances, Saturday through Monday at the Kaufmann Concert Hall. Written and hosted by the series' artistic director, Deborah Grace Winer, it offered filet mignon for an audience that becomes restive when the programming strays from the great American songbooks main composers, and chicken is the entree.

title: Toyota Recalled Floor Mats in Canada in 2003
description: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reported on Tuesday that Toyota recalled 408 cars in Canada in 2003 because of concerns that their floor mats would interfere with accelerator pedals.

title: Another Idea for Cutting State Aid to Schools
description: As state lawmakers struggle to close a projected $9 billion budget gap by the end of the month, school aid is emerging as the main battleground.

title: For Team Management, Nets Are Not Bag-Worthy
description: Brett Yormark, the Nets chief executive, knows his team is dreadful. At 7-63  with a chance to succeed the 9-73 Philadelphia 76ers of 1972-73 as the most futile team in N.B.A. history  that is a hard conclusion to avoid.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Long Island Beer Blast

title: For Easter, Almond Cookies From Lombardy
description: The assumption, when it comes to the almond cookies called amaretti, is that they are small, round and come from Saronno, Italy, in a tall red tin. But there are other kinds, notably these deeply flavored handmade ones from Gallarate, a city north of Milan in Lombardy. They are a classic Easter cookie from the region, rich with almond paste inside a delicate meringue-like confection, and are packed in a pretty, suitably pink gift box.

title: New Wine Shops in New York Put Patrons at Ease
description: ITS Friday night at Alphabet City Wine Company on Avenue C, and the juice is flowing. Two customers lounge on well-worn black vinyl chairs in what could pass for a graduate-school living room. Four more stand in front of a makeshift bar. Music streams from vintage KLH speakers, and Keith Beavers, one of the owners, is deep into his spiel.

title: Beef From Creekstone Farms Impresses New York Chefs
description: ARKANSAS CITY, Kan.

title: Making a Foreign Staple Work Back Home
description: YOU know its happened to you. Inspired by a trip abroad, a restaurant meal or even just a TV show, you decide to expand your culinary horizons. Youll learn to cook southern Indian food, you think. Or Cantonese. Or Catalan.

title: Brooklyn Flea Curates Central Park Food Vendors
description: CENTRAL PARK provides a haven for migratory warblers and American elms. It is a less congenial habitat for those humans who require a diet more varied and interesting than stiff pretzels and tepid hot dogs.

title: Egg Candles for the Holidays
description: Eggs figure importantly in Passover and Easter observances. These artful off-white porcelain candles, the size of goose eggs, would be suitable for either holiday table. The unscented candles glow delicately .

title: Farmed Halibut From Maine
description: Halibut, the largest of the flatfish, can weigh 300 pounds or more, and the wild catch is restricted to fairly large sizes. So serving a whole one on the bone has been out of the question.

title: Salt With Extra Seasonings
description: I have little use for flavored salts. But there are exceptions, like this fennel salt imported from Italy. It adds a hint of anise flavor and aroma when sprinkled on fish, omelets, deviled eggs or cheese.

title: Chin Chin
description: ITS getting intense, this business of walking into restaurants. The theater of the front door is in the midst of a busy third act. There are hosts and managers up there, and assistants to each, everyone peering into computers, stabbing at screens, juggling menus, telling you to wait.

title: Pilar Cuban Eatery
description: IN Cuba, a foreigner who has gone native is said to have become aplatanado, or like a plantain  presumably from having eaten too many.

title: A Rural Home in Ecuador
description: A four-bedroom villa in the Tumbaco Valley outside of Quito is on the market for $449,000.

title: Senate Republicans Offer More Amendments
description: The amendments are piling up.

title: Google or China: Who Has More to Lose?
description: Updated, 1:50 p.m. |  Ai Weiwei, a Chinese artist and political activist, joins our discussion.

title: In Health Bill, Obama Attacks Wealth Inequality
description: For all the political and economic uncertainties about health reform, at least one thing seems clear: The bill that President Obama signed on Tuesday is the federal governments biggest attack on economic inequality since inequality began rising more than three decades ago.

title: Chin Chin Music
description: This weeks restaurant review is of the restaurant Chin Chin, on East 49th Street, almost across the street from the Smith & Wollensky steakhouse. Its been there for 23 years, since Jimmy Chin took leave of his job at Auntie Yuan on the Upper East Side to go downtown with his brother, Wally, to open their dream business.

title: A Nobel Winner Is Reported to Be in Line for Cancer Post
description: Dr. Harold Varmus, a Nobel Prize winner and former director of the National Institutes of Health, is the White Houses leading contender to become the next director of the National Cancer Institute, according to cancer groups and scientists.

title: What Were Reading: Girl Gamers and Wireless Wars
description: LTE  AT&T and Verizons New Turf War  informationweek.comJenna Wortham says: Forget 3G coverage and download speeds. The next battleground for AT&T and Verizon: 4G networks.

title: Cansecos Lawyer Hears From Clemens Prosecutor
description: Roger Clemens and Jose Canseco have had a relationship that dates back over a decade. They played on three teams together, beginning in Boston in 1995, and have shared dozens of rounds of golf.

title: E.P.A. to Seek More Data on Emissions
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed adding the oil and gas sector and facilities that inject carbon dioxide into the ground to the greenhouse gas sources that are required to report their annual emissions to the government.

title: Madison Square Garden Shows an Interest in Mixed Martial Arts
description: Mixed martial arts is not legal in New York State, but that has not stopped Madison Square Garden from jumping into the cage.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,377 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: Sardinian Flatbread Meets the Seder Table
description: I never wanted to make matzo because I never thought it would be worth the trouble. Carta musica, however, a kind of Sardinian flatbread that is in the same family, is another story. Read about it here. And  when youre watching the video, above  note the hilarious new intro by NYT resident video genius Gabe Johnson.

title: A Thin Line Between Hate And Love
description: Compare and contrast:

title: Helping Cheap Earbuds Deliver Better Sound
description: The easiest way to improve the sound of your portable music player or phone is to improve your headphones. Sometimes its also the most economical way.

title: Clean-Water Cause Keeps Hope Afloat
description: JUST as water expands and contracts, so, too, does a water charity with roots in Madison Avenue.

title: Britain Raids a Leading Hedge Fund
description: LONDON  The London office of one of the worlds largest hedge funds, Moore Capital Management, was raided by British regulators and the police on Tuesday in the latest episode of a crackdown on insider trading.

title: Somali Backlash May Be Militants Worst Foe
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  For the past three years, the Shabab, one of Africas most fearsome militant Islamist groups, have been terrorizing the Somali public, chopping off hands, stoning people to death and banning TV, music and even bras in their quest to turn Somalia into a seventh-century-style Islamic state.

title: Prosecutors Expected to Seek Three-Month Sentence for Arenas
description: Gilbert Arenas of the Washington Wizards is scheduled to be sentenced Friday in District of Columbia District Court for a felony count of carrying a pistol outside his home without a license, and prosecutors recommended that he serve three months in jail, according to The Washington Post.

title: A Times Editor Is Named to Lead W for Cond Nast
description: Cond Nast Publications on Tuesday named Stefano Tonchi, the editor of T: The New York Times Style Magazine, to be the editor in chief of its fashion magazine W.

title: For Woods, a Familiar First Step at Augusta
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  When Tiger Woods showed up for a practice round at Augusta National Golf Club on Monday, his appearance might have been news. But as pre-Masters rituals go, it was close to ordinary.

title: Quarterly Profit Rose 4.5% at Walgreen
description: The Walgreen Company said Tuesday its quarterly profit rose 4.5 percent as it benefited from revamped product offerings and increased sales of 90-day prescriptions.

title: Corzine Returning to Wall St. as Chief Executive of MF Global
description: Jon S. Corzine, who spent more than three decades at Goldman Sachs and later used his vast fortune to start a career in politics as a New Jersey senator and governor, is returning to Wall Street.

title: Taking Baby Steps on 2nd Mortgages
description: JPMorgan Chase this week became the latest big bank to say it is willing to modify second mortgages for some struggling borrowers. While its a baby step in the right direction, it wont do much to fix Americas foreclosure woes.

title: Study Finds Racehorses Dying at Faster Rates
description: The first comprehensive analysis of thoroughbred injury data in the United States and Canada shows that racehorses die at the rate of 2.04 per 1,000 starts, a rate twice as deadly as in any other country.

title: N.F.L. Votes to Change Playoff Rules for Overtime
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The N.F.L. approved a new overtime rule for the playoffs Tuesday that will give each team at least one possession in the extra period unless the team that wins the overtime coin toss scores a touchdown on its first possession.

title: Calorie Data to Be Posted at Most Chains
description: Buried deep in the health care legislation that President Obama signed on Tuesday is a new requirement that will affect any American who walks into a McDonalds, Starbucks or Burger King. Every big restaurant chain in the nation will now be required to put calorie information on their menus and drive-through signs.

title: Indian Students Wield Tests for College Spots
description: NEW DELHI  Sadhvi Konchada took her fifth and final high school board exam this week. She was nervous, if not inexperienced, having already taken 11 board exams, pre-board exams or pre-pre-board exams since January, with more tests to come. By the time she enters college, Sadhvi will have taken 22 board or college entrance exams.

title: Police Killed Man Who Shot Officer in the Bronx
description: The Bronx man who wounded a police officer in a shootout this week was killed by the police and not by a self-inflicted wound, the city medical examiners office has determined.

title: Capitals Questioned About Their Ties to Chiropractor in Steroids Inquiry
description: Detectives questioned Washington Capitals players, coaches and officials on Tuesday about their ties to a chiropractor who has treated several of the teams players and was arrested earlier in the day on charges of distributing illegal performance-enhancing drugs.

title: India's College Exam Season
description: As the middle class has steadily grown, so has the pressure to compete for the limited slots in the countrys system of higher education.

title: Dozen Council Members Form a Bloc for Liberals
description: Frustrated by what they say are plutocratic policies that have squeezed the neediest New Yorkers, the City Councils most liberal members are establishing a new bloc to champion a progressive agenda on housing, economic development, labor and civil rights issues.

title: Legislator Accused of D.W.I. Goes on Trial
description: When Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV was taken to a police station house early one morning in March 2008, he seemed groggy, agitated and desperate to learn the results of an alcohol breath test that he had taken that morning, a video of him there shows.

title: In a Switch, Manhattan Lost People, Census Says
description: Manhattan reversed a decade-long streak of population gains and lost residents last year, even as New York City and its metropolitan area lost fewer people to other places than at any time since at least 1990, according to census estimates released on Tuesday.

title: Chinas Internet Giants May Be Stuck There
description: SHANGHAI  Even before Google began threatening to shut down its search service in China, it was not fitting in.

title: Nuggets Seek Championship While Karl Battles Cancer
description: There is no telling what the moment will be like, the day the Denver Nuggets gather for a playoff game in May and find out their coach will not be on the bench. They only know what the feeling was like that morning in February, when George Karl gathered the team and announced he had throat cancer.

title: Gridlock May Not Be Constant, but Slow Going Is Here to Stay
description: If you are thinking of driving in Manhattan on a Wednesday, perhaps to take in a Broadway matinee, think again: it is the most congested day of the week.

title: India: Pollution Fine Sought Against Coca-Cola
description: A state government panel recommended Tuesday that Coca-Colas Indian subsidiary be fined $47 million for damage to the water and soil in a southern Indian village that it said had been caused by one of the companys bottling plants. The plant, which opened in 2000 and closed five years later, polluted the groundwater and soil around the village of Plachimada, in the state of Kerala, the panel said. Coca-Cola said in a statement that it was unfortunate that the committee in Kerala was appointed on the unproven assumption that damage was caused, and that it was caused by Hindustan Coca-Cola Beverages. According to the panel, the bottling plant discharged a sludge that contained toxic chemicals like cadmium and lead. After villagers complained that the water table had dropped and farms were less productive, the village council decided not to renew the plants license.

title: Obama to Sign Executive Order in Private
description: There was plenty of hoopla in the East Room of the White House on Tuesday when President Obama signed the health care bill into law. But when Mr. Obama signs an executive order that secured the votes of some anti-abortion Democrats, he will do so in private.

title: China: 2 Protests by Students in Tibetan Areas
description: Groups of students in two Tibetan areas of Gansu Province, in western China, have held separate protests after Chinese security forces imposed lockdowns at boarding schools before the anniversaries of previous Tibetan uprisings, according to a report by the International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group. The report, based on information obtained by Tibetans in exile with ties to people in Gansu, was similar to an earlier report of the protests by Radio Free Asia.

title: Fancy Feet
description: Marilyn Monroe, Joan Crawford, Marlene Dietrich and Queen Elizabeth all wore them. We're talking about Delmans, the salon shoe line founded by Herman Delman in 1919. Today at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology shoe lovers can take a guided tour through "Scandal Sandals and Lady Slippers: A History of Delman Shoes," which explores the company's history and its greatest era of success in the 1930s through the 1950s. Around 50 shoes, dating from 1926, are presented along with period advertisements. A pair of "suede, instep strap sandals from circa 1939 performs a similar function. Boasting red, white, green, and blue color sections, four tiny bows are sequenced delicately down the vamp while a narrow ankle buckle strap, oval toe, and triangular heel maintain the shoe's elegant silhouette."

title: Taste of Cuba
description: Does just reading the word plantain make your mouth water? Than Pilar, the tiny Cuban restaurant that opened this fall in Brooklyn, is your spot. "Accompanying nearly every entree are sticky-sweet maduros, made with plantains so ripe, their peels are almost black. The spongy flesh is browned until lightly caramelized," writes Ligaya Mishan. There are also crisp tostones, "slices of green plantains that have been fried, flattened and fried again." Even the grilled cheese "gets a helping of the fruit, between gooey layers of Cheddar and Gruyre." If that sounds like too much, go for the subtle cream of plantain soup. "It proved an unexpected delight, the sweetness of the fruit sublimated into an earthy broth." The kitchen is headed by Ricardo Barreras, who runs Pilar with his wife, Lizbeth Moreno. Mr. Barreras grew up in Miami and his parents are from Camagey, Cuba. "In scale and in spirit, Pilar recalls Cuba's paladares, small family-run restaurants often operated out of private homes. The cooking takes time, so be prepared to linger."

title: Get Your Clogs On
description: "Clogs, which began as a collaboration between Bryce Dessner and Padma Newsome, both members of the indie-rock band the National, is something of a classical ensemble, although it borrows heavily from rock, avant-garde, folk and world traditions," writes Amanda Petrusich. The group released its fifth album, "The Creatures in the Garden of Lady Walton" earlier this month and will be performing songs at the Bell House tonight beginning at 8 p.m. Clogs will be joined by the vocalist Shara Worden of My Brightest Diamond.

title: Switzerland: Green Light for a Proton Collision Course
description: After spending $10 billion and making preparations for 16 years, scientists hope to start the worlds biggest physics experiment next Tuesday. Beginning that morning, engineers will try to collide protons in the Large Hadron Collider, a 17-mile underground racetrack, in the hopes of recreating primordial particles and forces beneath the French and Swiss countryside outside Geneva, CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, said Tuesday. The collider was designed to accelerate protons to energies of seven trillion electron volts and then smash them together, but design flaws will keep the collider running at only half power for the first two years of its operation. A long shutdown to bring the collider up to its full potential is planned for 2012.

title: At Some New York Schools, Wait Lists Grow Longer
description: It was once an unspoken social compact  move to the right school zone and your child was guaranteed a spot in the right school.

title: Turkey: Sharp Divisions Over Constitutional Changes
description: Turkeys Islamic-oriented governing party and the countrys staunchly secular judiciary traded barbs on Tuesday over whether to overhaul the countrys Constitution. Senior judicial bodies, responding to constitutional changes proposed Monday by the leadership of the governing Justice and Development Party, called the proposals unlawful and a direct challenge to the judiciarys independence. But Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, left, argued that the proposals derived from international practices and would promote a more democratic state.

title: Facebook and Twitter Keep Calipari Ahead of the Game
description: When Kentucky Coach John Calipari was talking to a group of 15 Chinese basketball coaches at his home last November, one pointed to Caliparis hulking German shepherd, Dash.

title: California, in Financial Crisis, Opens Prison Doors
description: LANCASTER, Calif.  The California budget crisis has forced the state to address a problem that expert panels and judges have wrangled over for decades: how to reduce prison overcrowding.

title: Stance by China to Limit Google Is Risk by Beijing
description: BEIJING  This is a nation that builds dams, high-speed rail lines and skyscrapers with abandon. In newly muscular China, sheer force is not just an art, but a bedrock principle of its seemingly unstoppable rise to global prominence.

title: Israel Absorbs Twin Rebukes From Top Allies
description: WASHINGTON  Israel found itself at odds with its two most stalwart allies on Tuesday as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu culminated a tense visit to Washington with a face-to-face session with President Obama that apparently failed to resolve the impasse between the two over a comprehensive Middle East peace plan.

title: Violence in the Land of Sleep
description: On the night, several years ago, that I tackled my nightstand, I should have known better. Jolted awake in the dark, my wife Alice peered over the covers to where I lay spread-eagled on the floor. I had lunged with open arms from our bed while still asleep, truly, I later mused, the consequence of an overactive imagination, all the more because my days playing football were long over. Alice joked that we should dust off the kids bed rails.

title: In Chicago, Obama Aide Had V.I.P. List for Schools
description: When Arne Duncan, the secretary of education, was chief executive of the Chicago Public Schools, his office kept a log of nearly 40 pages listing the local politicians and business people and others who sought help getting children into the citys most selective public schools.

title: Strip-Searches: The Truth Comes Out
description: In July 2002, the city ordered 20,900 disposable gowns for use in the city jails. This was supposed to be the start of a cheap solution to a big problem.

title: For Once, the Mets Get Good Health News: Reyes Is Returning Quickly
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The word started swirling around the Mets clubhouse about an hour before the first pitch Tuesday, and players were starting to get excited. Was it true? Jason Bay said to Jeff Francoeur. Was Jose Reyes on his way back already?

title: Obama Signs Health Bill
description: Before signing landmark legislation into law, President Obama gave a short address on the need for overhauling health care. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Binghamton Will Keep Mens Team in Limbo
description: The SUNY chancellor, Nancy Zimpher, recommended Tuesday that tighter controls be placed on the systems athletics, but the unsettled Binghamton mens basketball program will probably remain in flux into next year.

title: Prosecutors to Seek Three-Month Jail Term for Arenas
description: Gilbert Arenas of the Washington Wizards is scheduled to be sentenced on Friday for a felony count of carrying a pistol outside his home without a license. In preparation, both sides filed court memorandums on Tuesday.

title: In Germany, Xenophobia Diverted by Open Doors
description: VLKLINGEN, Germany  Everything seemed to be in place for a protracted xenophobic row and attendant media frenzy in this depressed industrial town near the French border.

title: U.S.C. Lands Henderson
description: Seantrel Henderson, a 6-foot-8, 340-pound left tackle widely considered to be the nations top high school recruit, signed with Southern California as expected. Henderson had delayed signing a letter of intent, saying he and his family wanted to wait until U.S.C. appeared last month before an N.C.A.A. infractions committee investigating the Trojans athletic department, football program and mens basketball program. It is not believed that penalties will be known until next month.

title: Moderate Inflation Versus Hyperinflation
description: Via Ryan Avent, I learn that Mike Kinsley isnt too happy with my critique of an earlier column in which he expressed anxiety about inflation.

title: Against Pro-Israel
description: Are you anti-Israel? If you fear that, deep down, you might be, I have important news. The recent tension between Israel and the United States led various commentators to identify hallmarks of anti-Israelism, and these may be of diagnostic value.

title: 57 Down: Like Russian Winters
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  In 1936, Executive Order 7523 designated a plot of land in Missouri as the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial. In 1948, the crossword superstar Eero Saarinen was selected to design a monument for the park. Ground was broken in 1963. In 2009, Peter A. Collins began construction of a tribute to the monument, and his effort reached completion  today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a growing demand by pet owners for food banks to provide food for animals as well as humans misstated the given name of the executive director of the Petco Foundation, the philanthropic arm of the pet store chain. He is Paul Jolly, not Peter Jolly.

title: Energized by Cornell, and Its Not Over Physics
description: On Sunday, as Cornells stunningly strong basketball team was trouncing the University of Wisconsin and edging closer to the third round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Todd L. Wolleman, class of 1980, was stuck in a vineyard in the Hudson Valley, surrounded by rows of vines and fellow Cornell graduates at an alumni event.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a request by defense lawyers to dismiss, under entrapment rules, a federal case against four men arrested in a plot to blow up two Bronx synagogues referred incorrectly to a request for a response from the United States attorneys office in Manhattan. A spokeswoman declined to comment; the office did not fail to respond.

title: Mets Get a New Sponsor for Spring Stadium
description: The Mets tradition at Tradition Field in Port St. Lucie stretches back to 1988. But traditions apparently are not what they used to be.

title: Former Chief Crane Inspector Admits Taking Bribes for Lies
description: A former chief crane inspector for New York Citys Department of Buildings pleaded guilty on Tuesday to taking bribes from a company in exchange for falsely certifying cranes that had not been inspected and issuing crane operators licenses to people who had not completed examinations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the impact of the health care legislation on various industries misstated the potential effect on the generics drug industry of a proposal that was omitted from the legislation the House adopted. That proposal would have placed new restrictions on patent settlement agreements with makers of brand-name drugs; it would not have benefited the generics industry.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 23, 2010

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Cornells 78-65 victory over Temple on Friday in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament misstated the name of the Birmingham, Ala., school attended by Cornell guard Louis Dale. It is the Altamont School, not Altamont High School.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 16 about digital archives from Salman Rushdie on display at Emory University misstated part of the name of the Emory library that has the archives. It is the Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library  not the Manuscript, Archives and Rare Book Collection.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Friday about the PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature next month misidentified an author in one event. Richard Price will be among the authors talking about how their books were made into films, not Richard Ford. (As the report noted, Mr. Ford is one of the writers who will pair up to interview each other.)

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions on Sunday for a performance by the American Chamber Ensemble scheduled for this Saturday misstated the location, phone number and Web site of the venue. It will be held at the Steinway Piano Gallery in Melville, on Long Island, not at the Steinway Piano Gallery in Westport, Conn. The Melville gallery is at 505 Walt Whitman Road; the phone number is (631) 424-0525 and the Web site is steinwayshowrooms.com/spg-long-island.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday and in some editions Sunday about Stewart L. Udall, a former interior secretary, referred incorrectly to Mr. Udalls support for John F. Kennedys 1960 campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. He backed Mr. Kennedy in Arizonas county and state conventions, not in a presidential primary. (Arizona did not hold a Democratic primary for that election.) And the version of the obituary on Sunday omitted one of his four surviving sons. Besides Tom, Scott and Jay, he is survived by Denis.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about the actor Fess Parker included several errors. Mr. Parkers daughter is Ashley Parker Snider, not Parker-Snyder. Eddy Arnold  not Eddie  was the singer who recorded one of many versions of The Ballad of Davy Crockett, the theme from a series of episodes of the television show Disneyland in which Mr. Parker starred in the 1950s. And a line from that song should have read: Raised in the woods sos he knew evry tree  not Raised in the woods so he knew every tree.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed essay on Sunday, about Google Translate, misidentified the mathematician who is considered the father of machine translation. He was Warren Weaver, not William Weaver.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Want to Use My Suit? Then Throw Me Something
description: NEW ORLEANS  Just after dusk on Friday night, Tyrone Yancy was strutting through one of the more uncertain parts of town in a $6,000 custom-made suit.

title: Pakistans War of Choice
description: Peshawar, Pakistan

title: Kitchen Confidential No More
description: THE New York City Board of Health has voted to require the citys 24,000-plus restaurants to post at their front doors letter grades reflecting the results of their sanitary inspections. The grades range from A (for the highest level of cleanliness) to B (passing) to C (failing).

title: Hail the Conquering Professor
description: WASHINGTON

title: Virginia: New Trial Sought in Fatal Vision Case
description: The 1970 murders of an Army doctors pregnant wife and two daughters were the basis for Fatal Vision, the best-selling book and mini-series. Now, the former doctor, Jeffrey MacDonald, who is serving three life terms, is requesting a new trial based on new DNA evidence and affidavits from witnesses who say they heard others confess to the crimes. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, will hear arguments on March 30. Mr. MacDonald, 66, has maintained that hippies who were high on drugs killed his family. His lawyers, who have been receiving legal assistance from the Innocence Project, said Tuesday that DNA showed that he was not the source of hairs found at the scene. Prosecutors argue that the DNA should not be admitted.

title: Ill Take a Manhattan (or Any Other Drink, if Its Free)
description: It sounds almost like an urban legend, a hazy rumor passed down through the ages, from Manhattan tippler to Brooklyn stoop-sitter to thirsty arriviste: you can, they whisper in a voice that sounds of whiskey and Pabst, drink free in New York City.

title: Catholic Abuse Accusations Declined in 2009
description: Roman Catholic bishops in the United States received fewer accusations of sexual abuse by the clergy in 2009 than in any other year since 2004, according to an annual audit based on self-reporting from Catholic dioceses. The audit documented 398 accusations, most decades old, about 286 offenders. The church says it spent about $104 million in connection with the abuse scandal in 2009. As the Catholic Church in Europe copes with an outbreak of abuse cases, the American bishops say reforms they made at the height of their scandal in 2002 are working.

title: A Proper Count of Inmates
description: The Census Bureau took an important first step toward electoral fairness when it announced that it would publish data on prison populations earlier than in the past, in time for the next round of legislative redistricting. This data, which will become available in the spring of 2011, will make it easy for state lawmakers to draw honest legislative districts made up of real residents instead of falsely inflated districts made up partly of prison inmates whose homes are often far away.

title: The Day After
description: It is worth pausing to dwell on what happened in the White House on Tuesday: President Obama, just over a year into a tumultuous presidency in which he was sometimes wrong-footed and often adrift, signed the most momentous social legislation in many years.

title: A Tea Party Without Nuts
description: President Obamas winning passage of national health care is both exhilarating and sobering. Covering so many uninsured Americans is a historic achievement. But the president had to postpone trips, buy off companies and cut every conceivable side deal to just barely make it happen, without a single Republican vote. If the Democrats now lose seats in the midterm elections, were headed for even worse gridlock, even though we still have so much more nation-building for America to do  from education to energy to environment to innovation to tax policy. That is why I want my own Tea Party. I want a Tea Party of the radical center.

title: An Openly Gay Bishop, and a Churchs Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Schools Run for Profit Come Under Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Fixing Missile Defense
description: It is always encouraging to see a commitment to the Sisyphean task of getting the most out of Americas gargantuan defense budget and reining in costs on expensive, badly managed or poorly performing programs.

title: The Politics of the Health Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: Cornells President, on Suicide Among the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: Google and China
description: Googles decision to stop censoring its search service in China on Monday was a principled and brave move, a belated acknowledgment that Internet companies cannot enable a governments censorship without becoming a de facto accomplice to repression.

title: More Universities Accept Common Application
description: Columbia University, the University of Michigan and the University of Connecticut are among 25 colleges and universities that will, for the first time, permit applicants to use the Common Application, beginning Aug. 1, the nonprofit organization that produces the form said Tuesday. A total of 414 colleges and universities will accept the application, which saves students time by allowing them to submit the same essays to any institution that accepts it. Because of its ease of use, the central form has also been blamed as contributing to the sharp increases in applications to selective colleges in recent years. Columbia is the last of the eight Ivy League schools to adopt it.

title: Tough Bill Advances in Arizona on Illegal Immigrants
description: LOS ANGELES  The Arizona Legislature gave preliminary approval Tuesday to a proposal that would allow the police to arrest illegal immigrants on trespassing charges simply for being in the state.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Big Wins for Hawks and Bruins
description: Ten games on Tuesday, but two of them stand out, big time. First, the clash in Atlanta between the ninth-place Thrashers, winners of four straight, and eighth-place Bruins, whose last game was a big victory over the pursuing Rangers. Second, the apocalyptic clash for leadership of the West between the astonishing Coyotes, winners of nine straight, and hiccupping Blackhawks, who have managed just 10 points from 10 games since the end of the Olympics.

title: 3 Senators Are Subpoenaed on Aqueduct Casino Deal

title: Bankruptcy Ruling in Student Loan Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday made it easier for people who say they cannot repay their student loans to receive bankruptcy protection. But the case arose in an unusual way, and the ruling is unlikely to have a broad impact.

title: Ex-Times Lawyer, an Army Nominee, Is Queried on Leaks
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Tuesday grilled President Obamas nominee to be the Armys general counsel, Solomon B. Watson IV, over the publication of two articles in The New York Times disclosing classified information when Mr. Watson was the newspapers chief legal officer.

title: Easy Victory After Intense City Council Race

Greenfield, the executive director of the Sephardic Community Federation, was elected Tuesday to succeed City Councilman Simcha Felder of Brooklyn in a seat that represents the Orthodox Jewish strongholds of Borough Park and Midwood and the ethnically mixed neighborhood of Bensonhurst.

title: Hard Stone, Soft Hearts
description: There are many ways to declare love on the streets of New York. A small concrete patch on the Upper East Side may be all you need. Or perhaps Central Park better frames your expansive affection, whether you express it formally or casually. (Note the left side of the park picture. There are two couples shown at Bethesda Terrace.)

description: Three people were discovered unconscious on a houseboat docked in a Long Island harbor on Tuesday evening and later pronounced dead, the authorities said.

title: News Quiz | March 24, 2010

title: A First Step on Fannie and Freddie
description: Despite growing pressure from Congress to act quickly, the Obama administration is moving tentatively to develop a plan to reshape Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage-finance companies taken over by the government 18 months ago, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Stuff column last Wednesday about Bomboloni, an Upper West Side pastry shop, misstated the price of its namesake sweet. Bomboloni are $1 each, or six for $5  not five for $6.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about efforts to overturn a restriction on the sale of homemade food at bake sales in New York City schools referred incorrectly to an action planned by the City Council. Gale A. Brewer, a Democratic council member from Manhattan, said she will introduce a resolution asking the Department of Education to overturn the regulation; the council has not scheduled a hearing about the regulation.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about salsa misstated Felipe Mendezs role in the restaurant La Superior in Brooklyn. He is an owner  not the chef, a job held by Nacxitl Gaxiola.

title: Britain Raids a Leading Hedge Fund

title: O.E.C.D. Mulls Guidelines for Banks on Client Taxes

title: Why Are Women Underrepresented in Science and Math Fields?
description: A recent report by the American Association of University Women found that although women have made gains, stereotypes and cultural biases still impede their success in science, technology, engineering and math (the so-called STEM fields). Does your own experience bear out these findings? Why do you think fewer women go into these fields?

title: Moores Founder: Stalks Prey and Likes Polo

description: Standard Life is entering the hedge fund arena.

title: Daimler to Pay $185 Million to Settle Corruption Charges
description: The German carmaker Daimler has agreed to pay about $185 million in fines, and two of its subsidiaries will plead guilty to bribing foreign government officials, to settle a multiyear corruption investigation, The New York Timess Charlie Savage reported, citing a person familiar with the case.

title: Profile in Style | David de Rothschild
description: By the time you read this, David de Rothschild will be floating somewhere in the middle of the Pacific Ocean on the Plastiki, a 60-foot catamaran made primarily from used plastic bottles. Assuming, that is, all goes as planned. The boat only averages five knots, he says with a laugh about the ambitious 11,000-mile itinerary. Thats about six miles an hour. But the 31-year-old heir to the Rothschild banking fortune is no stranger to adventure. Having visited some of the most beautiful places on the planet  in 2005 he trekked across Antarctica via the South Pole  he now travels to some of the most blighted, sharing his stories and spreading awareness through his Web site, adventureecology.com. In 2007 he took a team to Ecuador to explore the effects of oil drilling. The Plastiki expedition will take him and his crew to the Eastern Garbage Patch, an island of trash in the Pacific Ocean twice the size of Texas. The list of problems is big, he says optimistically, but the list of solutions is even longer. More

title: For One Biotech, an Expiration Date With a Twist
description: Capstone Therapeutics, a small biotechnology firm, has developed a radical new therapy for investors, Breakingviews says.

title: Plea Anticipated by Former I.B.M. Executive

title: Kurdish Spring Festival Is Political, Too
description: Tens of thousands of Kurds gathered in the southeastern Turkish city of Diyarbakir on Sunday to celebrate Nowruz. This festival, on the first day of spring, is known as the Kurdish new year (and is transliterated many more ways than that). It offers the Kurdish community a chance to demand broader rights and to express support of the outlawed Kurdistan Workers Party, or PKK.

The killing was thought to have been the first involving private contractors, the naval force said.

title: BG Group and Cnooc Sign $70 Billion Gas Deal

title: Sampler: California Begins Its Prison Inmate Reduction Plan, and Walnut Creek Pot Club Closes
description: State Begins Releasing Inmates | In recent weeks, California has started an effort to reduce its inmate population of 167,000 by 6,500 this year. Some prisoners may be released early for completing drug or education programs. Part of the plan includes changing how the state handles parolees, many of whom, at the moment, return to prison on technical violations, according to criminal system experts. California is the only state that places all prisoners on parole at release, but now hundreds of low-level offenders will be released without close supervision from their parole officers. The effort represents a seismic shift, said Joan Petersilia, a criminologist at Stanford Law School and a longtime scholar of the states prisons. The prison system costs the state $8 billion annually, about 11 percent of the state budget. [The New York Times]

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, March 24

title: Lets Make a Deal, Travelocity Says, on Hotel Rooms
description: The economy may have stopped getting worse, as some data indicate, but certainly consumers are still being frugal when it comes to spending.

title: How the Overhaul Will Affect You

The House also adopted a package of changes  agreed to in negotiations among House and Senate Democrats and the White House  which is being considered by the Senate.

title: A Physics Mavens Take on Skeptical Science
description: Ive been meaning to highlight a particularly interesting blog on climate, Skeptical Science, and finally have the chance. Whats appealing about it is the simple way its Australian creator, John Cook, has cast his journey. Its basically a list of reference-laden responses to the many assertions made by one or another of the variegated camps rejecting the need for action to curb greenhouse gases. There is a conventional blog stream covering developments as they occur. But most useful, perhaps, in a world of information overload, is the basic litany of 101 (and counting) skeptics arguments and responses. (Users of iPhones might say the most useful element is the popular new Skeptical Science application for the phone.) Heres one example from the online list:

Wednesday Reading

title: German Engineering
description: Hamburg is getting a lot of eco-buzz: its a darling of the Web site treehugger.com and will be Europes Green Capital in 2011. Surrounded by rivers and nature preserves, its navigable by bike, canoe, fuel-cell hybrid bus and solar-powered ferry. But whats really driving the city forward are its enviro-minded chefs, designers and shop owners.

title: The Tiger Bubble
description: Not too long ago, 2010 was shaping up as a good year for Tiger Woods. After knee surgery in 2008, Woods returned to competitive golf in 2009 and logged six victories. He led the PGA Tour in prize winnings for the ninth time and was voted player of the year by his peers for the 10th time in his 14 years as a pro. Because of the fortuitous location of this years marquee tournaments, Woods seemed primed to approach and maybe even equal Jack Nicklauss record of 18 major championships. In addition to the Masters at Augusta, Ga., where Woods has won four times, the 2010 United States Open will be played in June at Pebble Beach, in California; in 2000, the last time it was played there, Woods won by 15 strokes. The British Open will be held in July at the Old Course at St. Andrews, Scotland, which has hosted the tournament twice in the last decade; Woods won both times, by a combined total of 13 strokes.

title: BofA: Our Accounting Followed the Rules

title: He May Be the Antichrist
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: This morning, President Obama signed into law the health care bill that was passed by the House of Representatives on Sunday. The Republican Party is not happy about the bill. Senator John McCain told a radio show yesterday that the bill was done in quote, the most unsavory Chicago sausage-making that hes seen in all his years. First of all, I can say from experience that there is nothing unsavory about Chicago sausage. It couldnt be more savory, in fact. And thats not a liberal or conservative point of view. Thats an American statement right there, a fat American statement.

description: The nations schoolchildren have made little or no progress in reading proficiency in recent years, according to results released Wednesday from the largest nationwide reading test. The scores continue a 17-year trend of sluggish achievement in reading that contrasts with substantial gains in mathematics during roughly the same period.

title: Winfrey Settles Lawsuit Brought by Former Headmistress
description: You may see Oprah Winfrey next week on her syndicated talk show, but you wont be seeing the broadcasting queen in a Philadelphia courtroom. On Tuesday Ms. Winfrey settled a defamation lawsuit filed by the former headmistress of a school she set up in South Africa, who had said that the talk show host had defamed her after a sex-abuse scandal there, Reuters reported. Nomvuho Mzamane ran the Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy for Girls in South Africa at its founding in 2007 but left after students there said they were being abused by another staff member. After Ms. Winfrey held a news conference and said that Ms. Mzamane had ignored the students complaints, Ms. Mzamane said Ms. Winfrey had defamed her and made it difficult for her to find another job. A statement from lawyers representing both women said thedispute had been settled peacefully to their mutual satisfaction and both women had withdrawn their complaints, according to Reuters. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. A trial was scheduled to begin on Monday in federal court in Philadelphia, where Ms. Mzamane was living when she filed the suit.

title: An Initial Change to The Economists Anonymous Voice
description: The Economist has a long tradition of speaking with one voice, or at least making sure you dont know where the voice is coming from by not stamping most stories with bylines. As former editor Bill Emmott once explained to David Shaw of the the Los Angeles Times back in 2003, its a matter of motivating writers to take ownership over the whole enterprise, not just their own bylined corner of it:

title: Sympathy For Bart Stupak
description: Yes, the executive order that Stupak accepted as cover for his pivotal health care vote is probably meaningless. And yes, the health care bill, as passed, effectively tilts public policy in a more pro-choice direction: The fact that women are required to write a separate check for abortion coverage means that public money isnt literally paying for abortion, but it doesnt change the fact that federal dollars are being spent in ways that make it much easier to obtain abortion-covering insurance. (And thats without getting into the tangled issue of community health centers.) But what struck me most, at the end, wasnt the folly of Stupaks decision to compromise his pro-life principles by voting yes, but the extraordinary loneliness of his position before he folded.

title: Thinning Out
description: Ive been looking at the April issues, the month for taxes and shaping up and being sexy (in 60 seconds!), and Im feeling strangely energized, if not entirely hopeful about the future of magazines. I enjoyed Alexandra Jacobss piece about Polyvore in the style issue of The New Yorker. (I also was excited to see the piece on Brunello Cucinelli; interesting business, with annual sales of more than $200 million, reports RebeccaMead, and I know a lot of women who like the clothes, expensive though they are. But I was bored reading about him.) One thing in the Polyvore piece that amused me was the description of the companys office, the atmosphere of tact and friendliness  unlike magazine offices which, as Ms. Jacobs noted, are widely perceived to be snake pits. But looking at clothes and brands and trends on a computer screen is a different experience, isnt it? Magazines are diva pits, flesh-and-blood places, and they are probably less so today than 10 or 20 years ago, and of course that outsized feeling and passion for clothes is what helps stir the imagination of designers and editors alike. I guess things are thinning out now, and not just magazine pages. Polyvore is a useful site for people, but it does, as Ms. Jacobss reporting suggested, reflect a remote, blunt, user-friendly time.

title: Can Cornell Fans Turn an Orange Arena Red?
description: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team, which is seeded 12th in the East Region and beat Wisconsin Sunday to reach the N.C.A.A. tournament round of 16. Jon has been blogging for The Quad throughout this season. You can also follow him on Twitter.

description: Are you one of the (many) people who can never get Apples stock earphones to stay in your ear? No matter how much I twist and turn them, after a few minutes they slowly loosen and move out of my ear canal, the sound and bass response diminishing in direct proportion.

title: Social Networks a Lifeline for the Chronically Ill
description: A former model who is now chronically ill and struggles just to shower says the people she has met online have become her family. A quadriplegic man uses the Web to share tips on which places have the best wheelchair access, and a woman with multiple sclerosis says her regular Friday night online chats are her lifeline.

description: Deutsche Telekom said Wednesday that it had appointed Citigroup as its corporate broker in Britain to assist it in investor relations.

title: Manager of Justin Bieber Is Arrested
description: Let it be known that if you are the manager of a teenage pop-music sensation and cant tweet fast enough, you may face criminal penalties. That is what Scott Braun, the manager of the 16-year-old singer Justin Bieber, discovered on Wednesday when he was arrested on charges stemming from a November event at which Mr. Biebers fans caused a stampede during his appearance at a mall in Garden City, N.Y., The Associated Press reported.

title: Legislation to Uncover Hidden Airline Fees
description: Hate those hidden airline fees? A provision was added to the Federal Aviation Administration reauthorization bill, passed by the Senate earlier this week, that would require airlines and online travel agencies to clearly disclose all fees associated with the cost of a ticket, including holiday surcharges, baggage fees and seat assignments.

title: Its About Overtime
description: Depending on your point of view, the N.F.L.s new overtime rule is either a) great, because the current format favors the coin-toss winner too much; b) unnecessary tinkering with something that isnt broken; or c) great fun because it will make already overwrought coaches even more miserable (how many new shades of crimson can Tom Coughlins face turn?) handling the grenade of the decision whether to kick a field goal in overtime.

title: World Cup Memories: Bafana Bafana First
description: The South African national team will stride out to play Mexico in Johannesburg on June 11 in the opening game of the 2010 World Cup, a mere 12 years after the teams first appearance in the World Cup finals in 1998 against the host team, France.

title: Anne on the Move | AG, Stockholm
description: T Magazines womens fashion director keeps one step ahead of the trends.

title: Weird Al, the Movie Trailer
description: Video | Biopic parody about the song parodist:

title: Gospel Album Makes Debut at No. 2 on Charts
description: This week an unusual arrival is on the upper reaches of the Billboard album chart: gospel music. Here I Am (Verity) by Marvin Sapp, a veteran singer and preacher from Grand Rapids, Mich., reached No. 2 in its first week, with 76,000 sales, Nielsen SoundScan reported. It is the first time that a gospel album has been in the Top 10 since November 2008, when The Sound from Mary Mary reached No. 7, according to Billboard. It credits the sleeper radio success of Mr. Sapps 2007 song Never Would Have Made It with the new albums sales. (Thirsty, the album that contained Never Would Have Made It, peaked at No. 28.)Also on this weeks chart, Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) returns to No. 1 for a fourth time with sales of 93,000, bringing its eight-week total to just under 1.5 million. Ludacriss Battle of the Sexes (Def Jam), last weeks top seller, dropped two spots to No. 3 with 61,000. The Edge (Razor & Tie), a compilation of 32 songs by hard rock bands like Jet, Korn and Godsmack, opened at No. 4 with 53,000, and The Fame (Interscope) from Lady Gaga is No. 5 with 48,000 sales in its 73rd week of release.

title: A Photo Collage of New Wireless Gadgets
description: The C.T.I.A. wireless conference is currently under way in Las Vegas. Chief executives from most of the worlds wireless phone carriers and device makers, including AT&T, HTC and Sprint, present their latest wares at the conference, showing off their latest gadgets and applications. The images below make up a selection of some of the new mobile offerings being showcased at this years show.

title: The Alternative Medicine Cabinet: Cetaphil for Lice
description: Anahad OConnor, who writes the Really? column for The New York Times, explores the claims and the science behind various alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

title: Wrapping Your Head Around the Health Bill
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Bankers Meet to Sort Out Dubai Worlds Debt
description: Bankers were meeting in Dubai on Wednesday to work out a $26 billion debt plan with the state-owned Dubai World as a repayment deadline loomed, adding to the pressure on the emirate to settle the conglomerates debt, Reuters reports.

title: The Public Option Resurfaces
description: It has not been easy lately for Republicans and Democrats to find common ground. But Senate leaders in both parties are cringing at the possibility of a last-minute wrinkle in the health care debate: an amendment that would add a public option, or government-run insurance plan, to the budget reconciliation bill now being considered on the Senate floor.

title: As Expected, M.T.A. Trims Service
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted 11 to 2 on Wednesday afternoon to implement a package of severe cuts to transit service, including the elimination of two subway lines and dozens of bus routes.

title: Cheney Steps to the Line in Kentucky
description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney has injected himself into Kentuckys Senate contest, endorsing Republican hopeful Trey Grayson as the real conservative in this race.

title: Grant Ensures Anglo-Saxon Treasure Will Go to Museums
description: Not long after Terry Herbert found the Staffordshire Hoard, a collection of more than 1,500 pieces of gold and silver Anglo-Saxon treasure, in a farmers field in Britain, Mr. Herbert, an out-of-work metal detectorist, said, Ive had people go past and go, Beep, beep, hes after pennies. Now we know that Mr. Herberts discovery is worth just a bit more than that. On Tuesday Britains National Heritage Memorial Fund gave a grant of 1.285 million (about $1.9 million) to two museums that will keep the treasure, having raised a total of 3.3 million(about $4.9 million) to keep the collection intact, The Guardian reported. The Birmingham and Stoke-on-Trent museums will pay that money to Mr. Herbert and Fred Johnson, the farmer in whose field the hoard was found, having raised donations from around the world in a campaign that began in January. David Starkey, the historian who started the fund-raising campaign, told The Guardian, This is by far the most important archaeological discovery in Britain since the Second World War. He added, Frankly theyd have been demented not to give the money.

title: TimesCast | March 24, 2010
description: From the newsroom of The New York Times.

title: Going Against the Grain in Louisiana
description: Kurt Unkel is growing his brown rice without pesticides or chemicals.

title: The $1.3 Million Sticker Price for 6 Siblings to Attend College
description: Money, money, money, moneyMONEY! Some people say the most important thing in life is happiness; its a hug from a loved one, hope in the eyes of the unfortunate, the comfort and security of a loving family that makes life worth living.

title: Appeals Court Stays Order to Turn Over Galleon Wiretaps
description: 3:46 p.m. | Updated A federal appeals court on Wednesday granted a motion by hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam to stay the turnover of wiretap recordings to the Securities and Exchange Commission, pending an appeal.

title: Hofstra Coach Lands Job at Fordham
description: Fordham took a step on Wednesday that it hopes will make it more competitive in the Atlantic 10 Conference, naming Tom Pecora as its coach. Pecora, the Hofstra coach for nine seasons, will be introduced at a news conference Thursday.

title: Crop Mobs, Landless Farmers & the Agricurious
description: Flash mobs of volunteer agricultural laborers.

title: Russia and U.S. Report Breakthrough on Arms
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and Russia have broken a logjam in arms control negotiations and expect to sign a treaty next month to slash their nuclear arsenals to the lowest levels in half a century, officials in both nations said Wednesday.

title: China and Russia Pressed Iran to Accept U.N. Deal
description: MOSCOW  Russia disclosed on Wednesday that Russian and Chinese envoys had pressed Irans government to accept a United Nations plan on uranium enrichment during meetings in Tehran early this month but that Iran had refused, leaving less and less room for diplomatic maneuvering.

title: Google Alerts Gmail Users to Suspicious Logins
description: Google has introduced a new security feature that alerts Gmail users whose e-mail accounts may have been broken into by a malicious intruder and helps them regain full control.

title: Oakland to Be Overrun With Runners
description: A a tractor-trailer from Baltimore loaded with tables, mileage signs, water tanks and other race paraphernalia will pull into Oakland on Wednesday. Mile markers will sprout, and streets will be painted with turn-here arrows. The inaugural Oakland Running Festival opens this weekend, and more than 6,000 runners have registered for a variety of races: a marathon, a half-marathon, a relay, a 5K and a childrens race. The marathon, the first in Oakland in 25 years, has caught on as a way to support the city, the East Bay Express reports.

title: Financial Overhaul Is Next Priority of Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  Buoyed by passage of landmark health care legislation, the Obama administration and Democrats in Congress said Wednesday that an overhaul of financial regulations was the next legislative priority.

title: Republican Opts Not to Join Senate Race
description: Dan Senor, a private equity executive and former military adviser to President George W. Bush, has decided not to challenge Democratic Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the election this fall, he said in an interview on Wednesday.

title: Jets to Be Featured on HBO Show
description: The Jets will be featured on the HBO series Hard Knocks next season, according to three people with direct knowledge of the negotiations. The team will announce its selection Thursday with what it billed as a major news announcement.

title: How Not to Run an S.E.C. Investigation
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime and securities law for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: New Bow on a Minimal Box
description: FROM the late 1970s through the early 90s, despite some wide financial mood swings, Calvin Klein occupied an infinity of clean white space in the design world. Everything the brand touched was reflective of the spare architectural minimalism (that had yet to be mass produced by places like West Elm). The sumptuously erotic black-and-white Herb Ritts ads created a nostalgia for an easy Utopian future, full of startlingly intimate moments  snapshots of seaside romps with surreally beautiful lovers in various stages of undress. The designers wife at the time, invariably described as the leonine Kelly Klein, was admired for looking casually ravishing with loose hair, natural makeup and little or no jewelry. The Calvin Klein brand was a heady mix of white sand, cloudless skies, stress-less luxury and urgent passion.

title: Eco-Tripping | Brazil Three Ways
description: When it comes to sustainability, Brazil walks the walk: Eighty-five percent of its electricity comes from renewable sources, and its a top producer of environmentally sensitive products like vegetable-dyed leather and Amazonian cocoa butter. Now tourism is also going green, with a wide array of new conservation initiatives and eco-lodges proliferating across the country. Here, a regional sampler.

title: Reid Admits He Is Listening to Trade Offers for His Quarterbacks
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  One of the intriguing puzzles of this off-season surrounds what the Philadelphia Eagles will do with their three quarterbacks. Coach Andy Reid reiterated Wednesday that Donovan McNabb is the starting quarterback and Reid said he can still envision McNabb, backup Kevin Kolb and third quarterback Michael Vick all returning for the 2010 season. That, Reid said, is a pretty good situation for a coach.

title: Assemblymans Drunken-Driving Trial Begins
description: Arguments and testimony in the drunken-driving trial of Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV started on Wednesday morning with a prosecutor telling jurors that although Mr. Powell was not a fall-down drunk on the night he was arrested two years ago, he still was in no condition to get behind the wheel of a car.

title: Travel Deals: Save on a Spring Vacation
description: Airlines and hotels are offering spring vacation deals.

title: Wadsworth Atheneum Announces $16 Million Renovation Project
description: The Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, Conn., which has emerged from several years of financial struggle and staff upheaval, has announced plans for a $16 million renovation project that will result in the addition of 8,000 square feet more gallery space, a 14 percent increase, and the complete reinstallation of the museums permanent collection, said Susan L. Talbott, the museums director.

title: Senate Republicans Block Hearings
description: For the second consecutive day, Senate Republicans angry over the health care legislation blocked Senate committees from meeting on Wednesday, including an Armed Services Committee session that top officers stationed in Hawaii and Korea had traveled to Washington to attend.

title: A Good Excuse to Stay Home From the Gym
description: WHEN Laurie Davis wakes up in the morning, she sometimes feels like skipping her workout. But two days a week, hitting the snooze button is not an option: she knows that at 7 a.m., Yvette Rose will ring the buzzer at her Manhattan apartment with hand weights and resistance bands in tow.

title: Lineup Announced for Newport Jazz and Folk Festivals
description: Right on schedule, George Weins jazz and folk festivals are returning to Newport, R.I.

title: Bone May Reveal a New Human Group
description: A previously unknown kind of human group vanished from the world so completely that it has left behind the merest wisp of evidence that it ever existed  a single bone from the little finger of a child, buried in a cave in the Altai mountains of southern Siberia.

title: At Penn in 1979, a Freshman Mistake
description: Barron H. Lerner, a professor at Columbia University and the author of When Illness Goes Public, contributes to the health pages of Science Times.

title: Gooden Arrested After Traffic Accident
description: Dwight Gooden, the former pitching star who has battled drug and alcohol problems, was arrested Tuesday and faces several charges, including driving while under the influence of drugs, after an accident in Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: When the Middle of the Street Is the Perfect Meeting Place
description: There are two veteran doormen who work directly across the street from each other at the western end of 86th Street near Riverside Drive. The doormen, Michael Korson and Felix Torres, work similar schedules.

title: Financial Overhaul Is Next Priority of Democrats
description: Buoyed by passage of landmark health care legislation, the Obama administration and Democrats in Congress said Wednesday that an overhaul of financial regulations was the next legislative priority, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: League Moves to Add Relevance to Week 17 Games
description: The N.F.L. is so intent on preventing teams from resting theirstarters in late-season games that it plans to schedule only divi-sion games in Week 17, Commissioner Roger Goodell said Wednesday.

title: Reyes Gets Back to Work at Mets Camp
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jose Reyes returned to the Mets on Wednesday after a two-week absence while he recovered from thyroiditis, and immediately went back to work getting ready for the coming season.

title: Saudis Arrest 113 Militants
description: CAIRO  Saudi Arabia said Wednesday that its security forces had arrested 113 militants with ties to Al Qaeda who had been planning attacks against oil operations and security facilities in the eastern part of the kingdom.

title: Baseball Changes Schedule for League Championship Series
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The postseason schedule change announced by Major League Baseball on Wednesday is specific to one day. The off day that had been scheduled between Games 4 and 5 of the League Championship Series has been eliminated.

title: Pondexter Makes the Most of His Time at Washington
description: For a big man on campus  one of the biggest men, really  to sit in a makeup chair for nearly an hour, then put on a pair of ballet tights and take the stage for the Pacific Northwest Ballets Nutcracker shows that Quincy Pondexter has a certain level of comfort in his own skin.

title: African Teams Certain on World Cup, but Not on Coaches
description: A World Cup campaign is usually a four-year process that starts when a national team engages in torturous self-examination immediately after its ouster from the last championship. Coaches are fired (or their contracts are not renewed) and aging players retire from the international scene. Even the winner is often in need of a new manager to enliven the roster and refresh tactics for the interspersed continental championship and next phase of World Cup qualifying.

title: HBO Film Documents Immigration Battle
description: Updated The opening minutes of The Senators Bargain, a documentary film appearing tonight on HBO2, show Senator John McCain at a Congressional hearing in 2006, reading out loud from a newspaper article describing the death from broiling in the desert that befalls many immigrants trying to cross the border illegally.

title: The Morning Skate: N.H.L.s Fast-Tracked Rule Change Skips a Stop
description: Nothing comes easy in the National Hockey League and the proposed rule on blindside hits to the head is the latest example.

title: Dress to Regress | A Photographers Fashion Flashbacks
description: It doesnt take a mountain of fashion magazines or even a slim volume of Roland Barthes to understand that a mere outfit can be profound. Just look back at your wardrobe over time. (Thanks, Facebook, for making this painfully easier.) The prom dress in which you lost your virginity, the hideous interview suit for the job you never got  clothes become shorthand for experiences, and powerful triggers of memories. The universality of I dress, therefore I am is what propelled Ilene Beckmans 1995 memoir, Love, Loss and What I Wore, to the best-seller list, and then to a Broadway play by Nora and Delia Ephron. Now comes the photographer Jeannette Montgomery Barrons series of photographs and written recollections, My Mothers Clothes. A group of still lifes depicting the wardrobe of her late mother, the prominent Atlanta socialite Eleanor Morgan Montgomery Atuk, My Mothers Clothes will be on display in July at Jackson Fine Art in Atlanta and published as a book in March 2010.

title: College Rejections of the Rich and Famous
description: The Wall Street Journal has published an amusing (and, at times, even comforting) article today under the headline, Before They Were Titans, Moguls and Newsmakers, These People Were  Rejected. For those readers of The Choice whove gotten rejection letters themselves in recent weeks, the article may be something of a salve for raw wounds.

title: Gunmen Kill Iraqi Soldiers on Guard in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Gunmen shot and killed five Iraqi Army soldiers at a military checkpoint in south Baghdad on Wednesday as the country prepared for election results scheduled to be released Friday.

title: Hacking a GTO With an iPod Touch
description: Combine electronics aficianado with muscle-car enthusiast and youve got Dave Phipps.

title: Xavier Women Add Midmajor Magic
description: Add another college to the double Round of 16 club: Xavier.

title: Harold W. McGraw Jr., Publisher, Dies at 92
description: Harold W. McGraw Jr., who as leader of McGraw-Hill, his familys publishing business, helped build it into a billion-dollar enterprise in the 1970s and 80s, died on Wednesday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 92 .

title: Dear New Yorkers, Census Is Looking for You
description: City officials say New York is on track to grow to a record 8.4 million people when the 2010 census is tallied, but you wouldnt know it from the early returns. In parts of Soundview in the Bronx, Manhattans Lower East Side and Ocean Hill, Brooklyn, not a single census questionnaire has been returned with the deadline for mailing in the forms just a week away.

title: City Council to Lose Its Home (Temporarily)
description: At City Hall, democracy is about to leave the building.

title: Behind Consumer Agency Idea, a Tireless Advocate
description: WASHINGTON  Ask Elizabeth Warren, scourge of Wall Street bankers, how they treat consumers, and she will shake her head with indignation. She will talk about morality, about fairness, about what she calls their let them eat cake attitude toward taxpayers. If she is riled enough, she might even spit out the Warren version of an expletive.

title: The Sweet Smell of Success
description: David Brooks: Gail, I usually dont describe what I look like as I converse with you (believe me, these are mental images you do not want lodged in your brain) but at the moment I am sitting at my desk, at home, dressed in a suit, with cookie crumbs falling all over my keyboard.

title: The Battle Over Bottled Water
description: Published in recognition of World Water Day, a video called The Story of Bottled Water (at right, on top), made its debut on YouTube this week, using animation and snappy narration to convey what its makers consider to be the evils of bottled water. (It comes from the same folks who produced The Story of Stuff  an eco-themed viral video sensation from last year.)

title: Terra Firma Lawsuit Against Citi to Remain in N.Y.
description: 3:10 p.m. | Updated with statements A federal judge on Wednesday dismissed a motion by Citigroup to dismiss a lawsuit by the private equity firm Terra Firma over the takeover of British music label EMI. The bank had argued that the legal battle belonged in England, not the United States.

title: IPhone App to Sidestep AT&T
description: For a little $1 iPhone app, Line2 sure has the potential to shake up an entire industry.

title: Recipe: Louisiana Brown Jasmine Rice and Shrimp Risotto
description: 6 tablespoons butter

title: Ithaca Celebrates Cornell Run With Nerd Discounts
description: So, Cornell does not have Kentuckys basketball tradition, multiple national championships or players primping for the N.B.A. scouts. But the city of Ithaca, N.Y., is celebrating what Cornell does have (smart people) and offering a handful of discounts for the nerd crowd.

title: New Kits for Container Gardens
description: As more people have started growing their own vegetables, more kits for indoor/outdoor gardening have hit the market.

title: On Dance: In New Stars Season, a Different Moon Walk
description: Theres only been one episode of performances so far this season, but Dancing With the Stars has already broken a series record, averaging 23.9 million viewers on Monday night. As in years past, the show, now in its 10th edition, pairs 11 quasi-celebrities with 11 professional dancers, and promises to deliver a hard-to-resist mix of spray tans, awkward moves, cheesy comments and sequins.

title: Connecticut Continues Demolishing Opponents
description: Maybe No. 1 Connecticut should do something nice, show a benevolent side in the N.C.A.A. womens tournament.

title: Its Official: 2009 Was Worst Year for the Newspaper Business in Decades
description: Its no surprise that 2009 was the worst year the newspaper business has had in decades, but the scale of the damage, shown in figures released Wednesday by the Newspaper Association of America, is stunning.

title: States Differ on Marijuana for PTSD
description: DENVER  A decade ago, Colorado became one of the earliest states to legalize medical marijuana. Its neighbor New Mexico did so more recently. But that does not mean the two states agree on all the medicinal merits of cannabis.

title: A Collector of Scoops Steps Down
description: THERE were times when I got bad reviews in Womens Wear Daily, Calvin Klein recalled in an interview this week, but at least I always felt their criticism was written fairly, because thats what Patrick McCarthy did.

title: Google Calls for Action on Web Limits
description: A top Google executive on Wednesday called for rules to put pressure on governments that filter the Internet, saying the practice was hindering international trade.

title: Answers About Changing Careers in New York
description: Following is the first set of responses from Michele LoBianco, who teaches Recession Proofing Your Career at the School of Continuing and Professional Studies at New York University.

title: Samurai Shopper | London Trawling
description: It was Napoleon who dismissed England as a nation of shopkeepers. Wait, you tiny, arrogant Corsican, a nation of shopkeepers is catnip to Samurai Shoppers. Forget a nation: one slab of Oxford Street offers opportunity galore to divide and conquer. No icy, pricey, star-studded Dover Street Market wares here; Oxford Street features fashion in heavy rotation: affordably trendy, cheerfully commercial.

title: Steve McQueen: 30 Years Gone, Not Close to Forgotten
description: Steve McQueen, the hard-driving, hard-living existentialist hero of a generation of action movies, would have been 80 years old today. McQueen, an avid and accomplished motor racer, died in 1980 of a heart attack after surgery to treat mesothelioma, a form of cancer associated with inhaling asbestos fibers. Early racing suits, his motorsports contemporaries have noted, were dipped in a chemical solution that contained asbestos to make them fire-retardant.

title: Worlds Best Airports in Asia, Says Survey
description: Asia dominated the Skytrax World Airport Awards, which are based on more than nine million customer surveys.

title: Israeli Military Tries Two Soldiers for Conduct During Gaza War
description: Updated | Thursday | 7:53 a.m. As the Israeli newspaper Yediot Ahronoths Web site Ynet News reports, Israels military put two of its own soldiers on trial on Wednesday for allegedly forcing a 9-year-old Palestinian boy to open bags they suspected might contain explosives during a raid in Gaza last year.

title: Exhibit A: Exploring and Learning at Science Museums
description: Overview | What do science museums have to offer? How can visiting a science museum complement classroom curriculum and reinforce science standards? What can students get out of a trip to a science museum? In this lesson, students reflect on the exhibits, learning experiences and purposes of science museums, then prepare for and visit a local science museum where they engage in an open-ended scavenger hunt. Afterward, they develop scripts for a museum guide to use with visitors or generate ideas for their own science museum.

title: Talking to the Chief of Yelp, the Site That Businesses Love to Hate
description: Yelp! What happens when an online review site itself becomes the subject of harsh public scrutiny? Such is the case of Yelp, the review site that carries the motto, Real People. Real reviews. In recent weeks, Yelp has been hit with three class-action lawsuits from businesses claiming that Yelp sales representatives tried to press the businesses into advertising by offering  or threatening  to manipulate reviews. Jeremy Stoppelman, a Yelp co-founder and its chief executive, has seen the tables of Web 2.0 turned against his company as angry business owners have taken to Internet boards to pan Yelp. A condensed version of a conversation with Mr. Stoppelman follows.

title: China and Google
description: Americans tend to think of China as this vast, unstoppable, titanic force. Some would add menacing. But the confrontation unfolding today between China and Google is a reminder that the Politburo sees the situation very differently. They see a fragile China besieged on all sides, challenged at home, desperately needing to churn out economic growth to sustain its political model. In short, they see vulnerability where we tend to see invincibility  and thats one reason they took so tough a line on Google.

title: The Bumpy Blending of a Family
description: This morning, Pamela Kripke explored how parenting changes after a divorce, particularly when there are no male role models in the house.
