In a guest post this afternoon, Jennifer Cullen writes about parenting changes after a new marriage, specifically when a new dad moves in. A mother of two and a stepmother of one, Cullen thought she knew what she was getting into when she remarried three years ago. Shes learned a lot since then.

title: Heres Your Chance to Review Yelp
description: In an interview published on Wednesday, Jeremy Stoppelman, co-founder and chief executive of Yelp, encourages business owners not to fear the online review site but to embrace it: Focusing on that one review you feel is unfair, Mr. Stoppelman told Kermit Pattison, misses the value, which is the whole symphony of opinions you get on your page.

title: Pizza Fit for a First Family
description: posted by brossramirez on TwitVid

title: Take a Play, Then Adorn It With Opera
description: The English were wary of the Continental taste for opera in the 17th century, but they liked the idea of adorning plays with music. What composers and theater producers came up with is a curious compromise that Roger North, a writer at the time, called semi-opera. In this hybrid form, a play is presented straightforwardly, as spoken text, with masques  parades of songs, choruses and dance  interspersed within each act. The masques are an alternative universe: often, the play unfolds in the real world and the masques in the realm of the supernatural. And though the plays actors might remain as observers, they cede the stage to the singers and dancers and rarely interact with them.

title: An Afghan Voice for American Troops
description: Marja may have receded in the public consciousness, but it is no less critical in the battle for Afghanistan. Mauricio Lima, shooting for Agence France-PresseGetty Images, filed this photograph of Nekqadama, a contract interpreter for the Marines in Marja. He is also responsible for Slide 8. (Lens has covered the recent offensive in Helmand Province in Into the Maw at Marja and A Perilous Route to Marja.) The many layers and planes in Mr. Limas first photo give it a dreamlike quality. His previous appearance in Pictures of the Day, last November, also showed how capable he is of transforming an unpromising setting  in this case the streets of So Paulo, Brazil, during a blackout  into something evocatively moody.

title: Fuld Was Reportedly Nervous During Lehman Inquiry
description: Richard S. Fuld Jr., Lehman Brotherss longtime chief executive, may have felt vindicated by the court-appointed examiners inquest into his firms demise. But according to Fox Business Network, getting to that point was a bit of a struggle.

title: No Envelope, at Least Not Today
description: Eighth-grade students will indeed have to wait at least one more day before they can find out just where they will attend high school next fall.

title: Playing Games With an Afro-Brazilian Leap Into the Capoeira Circle
description: Jelon Vieira, the artistic director of DanceBrazil, has described capoeira as a fight that is like a dance and a dance that is like a fight. The form, which combines elements of dance and martial arts, is also something of a game, in which the movement is instantly identifiable: low shifts from side to side, whipping cartwheels into back flips, handstands, sweeping legs and sideway kicks. When the right sort of suppleness meets speed, a dancer appears to float in the air.

title: Orchard Beach in the Bronx, 1 P.M.
68 and Still Twisting, With a Bit Less Gusto
description: I havent been in a situation like this since March 1962 at the Copacabana, announced the eternally cheerful Chubby Checker shortly after taking the stage of Feinsteins at Loews Regency on Tuesday evening. Mr. Checker (real name Ernest Evans), who was dressed head to toe in blue denim, is now 68 and has the mixed blessing of his name being synonymous with a flurry of early-60s dance novelties, beginning with the epochal Twist.

title: Gritty Polish for a Tennessee Williams Jewel
description: The gauzy draping that usually trims productions of The Glass Menagerie has been packed up and put away. Do not come to the Laura Pels Theater, where the Roundabout Theater Companys terrific new revival of Tennessee Williamss career-igniting play opened on Wednesday night, looking for a standard dose of weepy Southern lyricism.

title: Eco-Tripping | The Dream Team
description: A few years ago, it was enough not to wash the towels every day. But it takes much more for hotels to earn their green stripes these days: those towels are now organic cotton, for starters, and the water to wash them is filtered and reused. Toilets are low flow, cleaning products are sulfate-free, hybrid cars meet guests at the airport, gardens are organic, and everything is recycled. Of course, its the rare hotel that actually does it all. But what if one did? Herewith, the hypothetically perfect eco-hotel.

title: A Danish Popsicle, Served Quickly Before It Melts
description: The members of Alphabeat took a bow and left the stage on Tuesday night at Santos Party House, and no one in the crowd moved an inch.

title: Finding Her Groove in Africa and a Violin
description: Regina Carter bookended her first set at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night with duologue, plucking or bowing her violin alongside the Malian kora player Yacouba Sissoko. The graceful symmetry of their exchanges came with a transparent subtext. Ms. Carter had landed at the club with a new agenda: to put a personal spin on African folk music, as she does throughout her forthcoming album, Reverse Thread (E1), due on May 18. Presenting Mr. Sissoko as a partner was a way to signal her intentions.

title: Shopping With Stephanie Moffitt
description: On a trip to New York, the design director of Mokum, an Australian textiles company, looked for interesting work by designers from her part of the world.

title: Arts Oasis in a Sporty Town
description: THE landscape of the uptown district of Charlotte, N.C., is dominated by mega-sports domes like the Bank of America Stadium, home to the Carolina Panthers, and the much-ballyhooed Nascar Hall of Fame, a 150,000-square-foot entertainment complex set to open May 11.

title: Design From Down Under in New York
description: AT least once a year, Stephanie Moffitt, the design director of Mokum, an Australian textiles company, travels to the United States from her home in Sydney to present her firms latest collection to showrooms across the country.

title: National Parks Get Quarters
description: The 50 State Quarters Program has a sequel.

title: Musicians as Movers, Navigating the Clutter
description: Success breeds imitation, the adage goes. In music that concept has produced a variant: any sufficiently distinguished piece, no matter how unorthodox its instrumental requirements, will spawn ensembles to play it, creating a demand for further similarly constituted pieces.

title: Suit Accuses Goldman of Having Mommy Track
description: Goldman Sachs was accused of sex discrimination in a lawsuit filed on Wednesday by a former vice president, who contended that the firm had consigned her to a mommy track that led to her firing while she was on maternity leave, Reuters reports.

title: Rice Dreams in Louisiana
description: When you own a 150-acre farm, having a change of heart about how you do things is a slow, costly process. When youre a third-generation rice farmer in rural Louisiana  a state with just 23 organic farms  deciding to try to grow brown rice without pesticides or chemical fertilizers is enough to get you certified not organic, but insane.

title: Spaghetti With Edamame, Parsley, Garlic and Olive Oil
description: This is a quick pasta to throw together if you have frozen shelled edamame or peas in your freezer, and its a dish that I find irresistible. You can find frozen edamame at most supermarkets; the green soybeans are a terrific source of protein and isoflavones. Seek out organic edamame.

title: What's New
description: A look at some of the films featured in the first week of the New Directors/New Films festival.

title: 36 Hours in Naples, Fla.
description: IF you filtered all the glitz out of Miami, youd get Naples, Fla. This small Gulf-side city has a pleasingly anodyne quality thats worlds away from the cosmopolitan bustle found only a two-hour drive due east, on the opposite coast. Affluent Midwesterners, who have adopted Naples as a getaway from nasty Northern weather, bring a certain oh-gosh air to town. Dont be surprised if you keep seeing the same faces over and over  these snowbirds might move at a slower pace than the Miami set, but they get around.

title: Lawyer Convicted of Visa Fraud
description: For the illegal immigrants who came to the lawyer, the benefits were immediately apparent. The immigrants, many of whom were from Pakistan and India, were able to live out in the open, work, pay taxes and travel abroad. And of course there was the glimmering prospect of a shortcut to citizenship.

title: A Solemn Mass, From Rossini, With Bounce
description: Rossinis Petite Messe Solennelle is a peculiar score, both as a 19th-century Mass and as a work of Rossinis. One of Rossinis few large works that was not written for the opera house, it has sections that sound as if they should have been: at times, the soloists and chorus seem on the verge of throwing on some costumes and hopping onto a scenery-filled stage. But elsewhere, the piece offers the solemnity promised in its title, conveyed in beautifully shaped solo writing and robust choral settings.

title: Britains Widening Insider Trading Inquiry
description: Britains investigation into a purported insider trading ring, an inquiry that has sent tremors throughout London, got a little bigger on Wednesday.

title: Interest in Toyotas Starts to Revive
description: Toyotas effort to regain the car buying publics trust with incentives appears to be working.

title: English-Style Club Hits Miami
description: The Ivy at the Grove, 3159 Commodore Plaza, Coconut Grove, Fla; (786) 552-9993.

title: Blockbuster Dips a Toe in the Mobile Stream
description: Blockbuster, the video-rental chain plagued by debt and unprofitable stores, is placing a bet on a mobile future.

title: Democrats Promote Overhauls Benefits to Older Americans
description: As Senate Republicans attack Democrats over proposed cuts in Medicare spending in the big health care legislation, Democrats on Wednesday sought to highlight some immediate benefits for Medicare beneficiaries. At a news conference at the Capitol, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said seniors were some of the biggest winners in the health care overhaul.

title: White Beans With Swiss Chard and Rice
description: This brothy dish isnt quite brothy enough to qualify as a soup  its more of a filling stew. I like to combine beans and greens, but this time I threw in some rice, which makes the dish all the more comforting and filling.

title: Black Bean Soup With Cumin and Tomatoes
description: Black beans are a great low-budget staple; ask anyone from southern Mexico or Brazil. They are loaded with anthocyanins, the phytonutrients found in blue and dark red foods (such as blueberries, red grapes, and red cabbage) that are being studied for their antioxidant properties. This is a simplified version of a black bean soup from the Veracruz region of Mexico. If you want spice, use the chipotle or serrano chile, but the dish is tasty with or without the extra heat.

title: Jim Marshall, 74, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies
description: Jim Marshall, a photographer who took some of the most famous images of rock and pop musicians, including Jimi Hendrix setting his guitar aflame at the Monterey International Pop Festival and Johnny Cash at San Quentin State Prison, died on Tuesday night in a hotel in New York. He was 74.

title: Medea Story Sways to a 19th-Century Island Rhythm
description: The lilting calypso playing before the show starts clues you in: Full of music and wordplay, Steve Carters 1990 Pecong, a retelling of the Medea story set in the Caribbean at the end of the 19th century, is too cheerful to work as high Greek drama.

title: On the Job With Patrick McMullan
description: How does one become the pre-eminent society photographer in New York City? Times video followed Patrick McMullan on a recent work night to find out.

title: Patrick McMullan Snaps but Never Bites
description: THERE are a few fundamental tenets to being a successful New York party photographer. First, dont take a picture of a married mogul wearing leather chaps. And never photograph an heiress if her nipple is showing or if she has passed out after drinking four double vodkas.

title: Bank of America to Reduce Mortgage Balances
description: Bank of America said on Wednesday that it would begin forgiving some mortgage debt in an effort to keep distressed borrowers from losing their homes.

title: Film Industry Group Asks Feds to Prevent Futures Trading on Box Office Results
description: The Motion Picture Association of America, the film industry group, has asked the federal commission that oversees futures exchanges to prevent the trading of futures contracts based on movie box-office receipts, calling such trading unbridled gambling.

title: Hunting Down an Elusive iPhone Signal
description: Bar-Hopping

title: Q&A:  Bolstering Coverage for the iPhone
description: Q.

title: A Cheesy Horror Turkey Becomes a High-Flying Cult Hit
description: If the title of Birdemic: Shock and Terror does not immediately tell you what kind of movie it is, its teaser trailer should do the trick.

title: Without Stupak, Anti-Abortion Groups Dinner Goes On
description: When an anti-abortion group hosts its annual Campaign for Life gala at the Willard Hotel tonight, Representative Bart Stupak, Democrat of Michigan, wont be getting his previously announced award. And no one will receive it in his place.

title: Wells Fargo to Buy GMACs Factoring Business
description: Wells Fargo said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy GMACs North American factoring business. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Unleashing the Camcorder Within Your Phone, via Apps
description: I once pitied owners of early iPhones and other older smartphones because their devices lacked at least one incredibly useful feature  a video camera.

title: Vain Glorious | Body Wash for the Boys
description: Who: Pattern

title: Mash-Ups, Dirty Couches and Rotten Lungs
description: If there are perhaps a great many negative things to say about the mash-up culture on the Internet, there are also several Bidenesque big-ahem-deal arguments for why its great.

title: T Exclusive | Ryan McGinley
description: An exclusive video of the opening for the new Ryan McGinley show at Team Gallery in SoHo.

title: Catholic Charity and Sprint Tangle Over Texting
description: When the earthquake devastated Haiti, Catholic Relief Services tried to gather contributions for its efforts using the hottest trend in giving: donations via cellphone.

title: Pelosi Names 3 to Obamas Deficit Panel
description: All 18 members of President Obamas bipartisan commission on reducing the national debt have been named now that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday announced three Democratic lawmakers as her choices.

title: Video: Elizabeth Warrens Mission
description: The Timess Jodi Kantor profiles consumer advocate Elizabeth Warren whom, she calls the chief conceiver of and booster for a new consumer financial protection agency. In addition to the article, we produced a video about Ms. Warrens crusade.

title: Take Five: A Walking Tour of Street Art, and Bulgarian Folk Singing
description: Wondering what to do this weekend? We have you covered:

title: At Home With Wendy Burden
description: A look inside the authors turn-of-the-century home in Portland, Ore.

title: Policy Change to Benefit Playwrights
description: With American playwrights and theaters perennially pinched for income, the Public Theater and Roundabout Theater Company in New York are changing policies to help writers earn a better living while allowing theaters to retain a financial stake in new plays when they go on to future theatrical, film or television productions.

title: Justin Biebers Manager Is Arrested in Tweeting Case
description: Let it be known that if you are the manager of a teenage pop star and cant tweet fast enough, you may face criminal penalties. That is what Scott Braun, the manager of the 16-year-old singer Justin Bieber, below, discovered on Wednesday when he was arrested on charges stemming from a November event at which Mr. Biebers fans stampeded during his appearance at a mall in Garden City, N.Y., The Associated Press reported. At that time the police told Mr. Braun to send out a message on Twitter saying the event was canceled. A lawyer for Mr. Braun said he sent two tweets in seven minutes, but prosecutors say it took him nearly two hours to post the messages. Mr. Braun surrendered to the Nassau County police on Wednesday and is awaiting arraignment on charges of reckless endangerment and criminal nuisance. He could be sentenced to up to a year in jail if found guilty.

title: Winfrey Settles Lawsuit With Ex-Headmistress
description: You may see Oprah Winfrey next week on her syndicated talk show, but you wont be seeing her in a Philadelphia courtroom. On Tuesday Ms. Winfrey settled a defamation lawsuit filed by the former headmistress of a school she set up in South Africa, who had said that Ms. Winfrey had defamed her after a sex-abuse scandal there, Reuters reported. Nomvuho Mzamane ran the Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy for Girls in South Africa at its founding in 2007 but left after students said they were being abused by another staff member. After Ms. Winfrey said at a news conference that Ms. Mzamane had ignored the students complaints, Ms. Mzamane said Ms. Winfrey had defamed her and made it difficult for her to find another job. A statement from lawyers representing both women said that the dispute had been settled peacefully to their mutual satisfaction, according to Reuters. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. A trial was to begin Monday in federal court in Philadelphia, where Ms. Mzamane was living when she filed the suit.

title: A Jail for Children Stirs a Ruckus in Brooklyn
description: Playground controversies usually involve bickering parents, unruly dogs or bullies.

title: Idol Wins the Night
description: Fox dominated the ratings on Tuesday night as American Idol faced light competition. The two-hour episode of Idol, with the Top 11 performers, delivered an average of 23.8 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. CBS had second place with reruns of NCIS (12.8 million) and NCIS: Los Angeles (11.2 million) while NBC ranked third with The Biggest Loser (8 million) and Parenthood (7.1 million). ABC placed fourth with a lineup that included Lost (9 million).

title: Wadsworth Atheneum Plans Renovation
description: The Wadsworth Atheneum, below, in Hartford, which has emerged from several years of financial struggle and staff upheaval, has announced plans for a $16 million renovation project that will result in the addition of 8,000 square feet more gallery space, a 14 percent increase, and the complete reinstallation of the museums permanent collection, Susan L. Talbott, the museums director, said. In 2003 the Wadsworth had planned an expansion that would have cost $120 million and required the museum to close for two years, but that plan was abandoned, along with a later plan that would have spread the museum into the former Hartford Times building. The museum  Americans oldest public art institution, opened in 1842  operated with budget deficits for several years and went through five directors and three acting directors in a decade as it tried to find its footing in a city with a high poverty rate. Composed of five separate but contiguous buildings built over more than a century, the museum will remain open during the renovation, which is expected to be completed by the end of next year.

title: Grant Ensures Treasure Will Go to Museums
description: Not long after Terry Herbert found the Staffordshire Hoard, a collection of more than 1,500 pieces of gold and silver Anglo-Saxon treasure, in a farmers field in Britain, Mr. Herbert, an out-of-work metal detectorist, said, Ive had people go past and go, Beep, beep, hes after pennies. Now we know that Mr. Herberts discovery, part of which is at left, is worth just a bit more than that. On Tuesday, Britains National Heritage Memorial Fund gave a grant of 1.29 million (about $1.9 million) to two museums that will keep the treasure, having raised 3.3 million (about $4.9 million) to keep the collection intact, The Guardian reported. The Birmingham and Stoke-on-Trent museums will pay that money to Mr. Herbert and Fred Johnson, the farmer in whose field the hoard was found, having raised donations from around the world in a campaign that began in January. David Starkey, the historian who started the fund-raising campaign, told The Guardian, Frankly theyd have been demented not to give the money.

title: Chart Gets Religion
description: This week an unusual arrival is on the upper reaches of the Billboard album chart: gospel music. Here I Am (Verity) by Marvin Sapp, below, a veteran singer and preacher from Grand Rapids, Mich., reached No. 2 in its first week with 76,000 sales, Nielsen SoundScan reported. It is the first gospel album to be in the Top 10 since November 2008, when The Sound from Mary Mary reached No. 7, according to Billboard. It credits the sleeper radio success of Mr. Sapps 2007 song Never Would Have Made It for the new albums sales. Also on this weeks chart, Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) returns to No. 1 for a fourth time with sales of 93,000, bringing its eight-week total to just under 1.5 million. Ludacriss Battle of the Sexes (Def Jam), last weeks top seller, dropped two spots to No. 3 with 61,000. The Edge (Razor & Tie), a compilation of 32 songs by hard-rock bands like Jet, Korn and Godsmack, opened at No. 4 with 53,000, and The Fame (Interscope) from Lady Gaga is No. 5 with 48,000 sales in its 73rd week of release.

title: Lineups Announced for Jazz, Folk Festivals
description: George Weins jazz and folk festivals in Newport, R.I., have set their lineups for the summer. The folk festival will return to Fort Adams State Park on July 31 and Aug. 1, with Richie Havens, top left; Sharon Jones, top right; and Levon Helm, John Prine, the Swell Season, the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, Yim Yames (otherwise known as Jim James of the band My Morning Jacket), Doc Watson and Calexico, among others. Steve Martin, who won a Grammy Award this year for his bluegrass album, will play the opening concert on July 30 at the International Tennis Hall of Fame. The CareFusion Newport Jazz Festival will run the next weekend (Aug. 6-8) with Wynton Marsalis, above left; Herbie Hancock, above right; and Chris Botti, Jamie Cullum, Ahmad Jamal, Mark OConnor, Jason Moran and Ben Allison. Mr. Wein, 84, who helped found the jazz festival in 1954 and the folk festival five years later, is once again the impresario for both, and at the jazz festival he will perform with Howard Alden, Randy Brecker, Randy Sandke and Bob Brookmeyer. CareFusion, a medical technology company, is also sponsoring Mr. Weins jazz festival in New York from June 17 to 26. Tickets for the Newport festivals go on sale Friday. More information: newportfolkfest.net or newportjazzfest.net.

title: Interest in Toyotas Starts to Revive
description: From our colleagues at the Bucks blog:

title: Wall Street Journals Local News Section for New York to Arrive on April 26
description: The Wall Street Journal will begin printing a local news section for the New York market on April 26, not April 12, as previously reported, according to two people briefed on the matter.

title: Robert Culp, I Spy Star, Is Dead at 79
description: Robert Culp, who, as the debonair secret agent Kelly Robinson on I Spy, was half of one of the first racially integrated casts on television to feature an African-American in a lead role, died, The Associated Press reported. He was 79.

title: A 1770s House on Drakes Island
description: The antiques dealer turned curator Corey Daniels lives in a house defined by Early American charm.

title: Posadas Move Down the Salary Chain
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Joe Mauers eight-year, $184 million contract extension with the Minnesota Twins means Jorge Posada will not be the highest-paid catcher in baseball next year. It is believed Mauer will make $23 million in each year of the deal, dwarfing Posadas $13.1 million annual salary. And it ends the rumors that Mauer would end up with the Yankees as a free agent after the 2010 season.

title: From the Vanderbilt in Reno, a European Success Story
description: Last Sunday, the final day of the Spring North American Championships in Reno, Nev., the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams was captured by Pierre Zimmerman from Switzerland, Michel and Thomas Bessis (father and son) and Franck Multon from France, and Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness from Norway. They won by 104 international match points to 94 over Martin Fleisher of New York; Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.; Bobby Levin of Lake Ariel, Pa.; Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y.; Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.; and Lew Stansby of Dublin, Calif.

title: What Black Writers Should Be Taught in Schools?
description: The 10th National Black Writers Conference begins this week at Medgar Evers College in New York, and among the topics the group will discuss is how to expand the list of black writers taught in schools. What works by black writers are taught in your school now? Do you think more should be added? What works and authors would you suggest? Why?

title: No Method to Her Method
description: NOAH BAUMBACHS new movie is called Greenberg, but it is equally  maybe even more so  the story of Florence Marr. Roger Greenberg, the title character, has the more familiar face by far; hes played by Ben Stiller, a big movie star sliding comfortably into a small, sharp movie. But Florences face is the first one we see. She wanders into the frame pulling a large, slow-moving dog and is then captured in close-up as she negotiates Los Angeles traffic on the way to her job as the household assistant of a well-to-do family with a house in the hills.

title: A Strange Brew May Be a Good Thing
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: The Diffa Dining by Design Benefit
description: Fantastical table settings and accessories were on display at Pier 94.

title: Cornell and Kentucky Have Something in Common
description: SYRACUSE  From budgets to tradition to fan base, it has been made very clear this week that Kentucky and Cornell do not have a whole lot in common.

title: Shades of Wall Street in Insider Trading Arrests
description: 6:32 p.m. | Updated While the sequel to Wall Street will finally hit theaters in a few months, it appears other elements of the movie  like the catchy Blue Horseshoe Loves Anacott Steel phrase used to abet insider trading  havent gone away.

title: The 1% More Savings Calculator
description: What would happen to your savings balances if you saved just one percent more a year?

title: Sweet Dreams App Puts Alerts to Sleep
description: Anyone who has had to dig through their phones system folder at bedtime to turn off alerts for IMs and e-mails, but still wants to let the phone ring through, will understand the value of an Android smartphone app called Sweet Dreams.

title: A Magazines Marriage Column Takes a Dramatic Turn; Will These Videos Be Viewed?
description: If theres one thing that has lasted as long as marriage, its marital discord.

title: Bank of America to Reduce Mortgage Balances
description: Bank of America, under pressure to keep distressed borrowers from losing their homes, said on Wednesday that it would begin forgiving some mortgage debt, The New York Timess David Streitfeld and Louise Story report.

title: Going Beyond Google to Find a Lost Friend
description: When I was 6 years old, I lost one of my best friends.

title: Direct Route to Lisbon Bypasses the Art House
description: IT says something (not good) about the state of foreign film distribution in the United States that the Portuguese director Pedro Costa has become one of the most exalted figures in world cinema without having a single one of his creations open in a commercial theater here. Instead his work has been disseminated through not-for-profit institutions like Anthology Film Archives (which presented a Costa retrospective in 2007) and the New York Film Festival (which showed his newest film, Ne Change Rien, a documentary about the French actress and singer Jeanne Balibar, in the fall).

title: Fairy-Tale Endings: Death by Husband
description: Paris

title: Use It, Plant It
description: MORE personal-care product companies are trying to make their goods earth-friendly inside and out. Consumer demand for such products is up, and new materials are becoming more widely available.

title: Starbucks Still Sees Growth, as Well as Dividends
description: From Claire Cain Miller, a DealBook Colleague:

title: Now, the Cosmetics Jar Matters, Too
description: LETS face it, Im a green drag queen who uses a lot of beauty products and loves them," said Chlo Jo Davis, who blogs about environmental and vegan issues. No offense, but we dont want to look like stinky hippies. In my bathroom, I want products that are good for me, good for the earth, that will make me look glam. And, the product, too, has to look good."

title: A Vanderbilt Descendant Laughs Off Dysfunction
description: PORTLAND, Ore.

title: Creepy-Crawly, Letter by Letter
description: Hugh Raffles was taking a shower in his Manhattan apartment when a three-inch-long water bug dropped from the ceiling and landed at his feet. His first reaction was one that might be expected. I admit it: I screamed, he writes in Insectopedia, his new compendium of thoughts about the creepy-crawly. Wouldnt you?

title: They Cant Wait to Tell You
description: WHEN he copped to yelling baby killer at Representative Bart Stupak during debate over the health-care bill on Sunday, Representative Randy Neugebauer became the latest member of a fast-growing club, the Interrupters.

title: Container Gardens Get Spring Started Indoors
description: ON a recent Saturday, over a cup of tea, I redefined the farm-to-table food movement. It didnt take much. All I did was move my herb garden  that is, the farm  to my dining room table. Potting mix, dirt, seedlings, water. Everything. Without boasting, I think I can say that food does not get more local than this.

title: Cherie DeCastro, Singer With DeCastro Sisters, Is Dead at 87
description: Cherie DeCastro, the last surviving member of the DeCastro Sisters, whose sultry ballad Teach Me Tonight sold millions of copies in 1954, died on March 14 in Las Vegas. She was 87.

title: Niese Impresses in Bid to Start
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jon Niese had a crisp two-inning stint in relief Wednesday during the Mets 5-2 victory over the Astros, and afterward Manager Jerry Manuel made it clear that Nieses hold on the fifth starters spot was becoming more secure.

title: Insectopedia
description: Air

title: With a Shrug, Beck Responds to Camerons Criticism
description: On his Fox News show on Wednesday, Glenn Beck donned a pair of 3-D glasses and shrugged off a series of criticisms leveled at him by the Avatar director James Cameron.

title: When Smart Homes Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: A Maine Antiques Dealer Rethinks His Aesthetic
description: Wells, Me.

title: The Intimacy of a Name
description: To the Editor:

title: A Showroom for Linens With a Global Pedigree
description: Ironically, a lot of beauty has come out of Bernie de Le Cuonas divorce in 1992. After briefly working as an interior designer and furniture importer, Ms. de Le Cuona decided to strike out on her own as a textile designer. I had to support myself, she said. A year spent in India served as a crash course in fabrics and dyeing techniques. Now, in addition to overseas showrooms in London, Milan, Moscow and St. Petersburg, Ms. de Le Cuona, a native South African, has opened one in Manhattan  her first in the United States.

title: Factory Blueprints Become Art Prints
description: Kevin Busta, a Cleveland boilermaker turned furniture maker, has released a limited-edition series of photos printed on old industrial blueprints. Birds on A Wire, above, is a 30-by-84-inch photograph printed on an original blueprint for a locomotive engine; it sells for $5,200 and is part of an edition of five.

title: Chilewich Creates Mats for Dogs
description: Sandy Chilewich didnt create her new pet mats so that Scooter, her black-and-white Havanese, could be chic. Ms. Chilewich, a Manhattan designer who makes place mats, floor mats and bags from woven vinyl, had a more practical motivation. When we make custom floor mats, we have scrap left over, she said. The Pet Mat ($35) was the answer, since it is relatively small, at 24 by 14 1/2 inches.

title: The Diffa Dining by Design Show and Dinner
description: THERE were many fantastical table settings at the Diffa Dining by Design benefit exhibition and dinner in Manhattan Monday night, but the most inventive accessory was a bare-chested young man who sat, eyes closed and legs crossed, in a yoga pose at the Poggenpohl for MMPI Morocco in New York display. There were tables and potted trees on either side, and tent-like drapes behind him.

title: Inside Designers Homes
description: Michele Keith, a writer who has been covering home furnishings and design for more than a decade, often found herself examining an interior design project and wondering whether the designers own home was as beautiful as the one he or she had created for the client. I didnt know, Ms. Keith said earlier this week. Do they try something new? Or are designers like the cobblers children and have no shoes?

title: Furniture, Fabrics and Beds on Sale
description: Flair, a store that carries new and vintage furnishings, is having its first warehouse sale, through March 28, with about 250 items on sale (a midcentury button-back chair, originally $3,600, is $2,150; a 1940s mirrored screen that was $5,800 is $3,400); 78 Grand Street (Wooster Street), (212) 274-1750 or flairhomecollection.com.

title: Nets Official Confronts Fan Over a Display
description: Brett Yormark, the Nets chief executive, knows his team is dreadful. At 7-63  with a chance to succeed the 9-73 Philadelphia 76ers of 1972-73 as the most futile N.B.A. team ever  that is a hard conclusion to avoid.

title: A Small Screen Empire
description: The film producer Jerry Bruckheimer has become equally prolific in television thanks to procedural dramas.

title: What Were Reading: Facebook Promotes Happiness  and Syphilis?
description: Facebook Data Team: Continuing our Study of Happiness  Facebook DataClaire Cain Miller says: Canadians are happiest the day before Thanksgiving, plus other happiness nuggets from Facebook.

title: 2 JWT Executives to Open Their Own Agency
description: Two longtime senior executives at JWT in New York, part of the WPP Group, are leaving to start their own agency in a departure that comes as a huge surprise.

title: Megan Mullally Departs Lips Together, Teeth Apart
description: The actress Megan Mullally, who won two Emmy Awards playing Karen on the NBC television show Will & Grace, has quit the forthcoming Broadway revival of the play Lips Together, Teeth Apart, its producer, Roundabout Theater Company, announced on Wednesday evening.

title: Simple Steps to Fix Social Security
description: With millions of jobs disappearing in this recession and more people taking early retirement, Social Security is expected to pay out more in benefits in 2010 than it takes in in payroll taxes, an event that wasnt expected until 2016. This effect may be reversed as the recession eases, but this tipping point reminds us of where things are headed. With more baby boomers retiring, by the end of this decade outlays will exceed revenues every year regardless of the condition of the economy. By 2037, Social Securitys surplus, currently at $2.5 trillion, will be exhausted.

title: Sid Fleischman, Childrens Author, Dies at 90
description: Sid Fleischman, a Newbery Award-winning author who never set out to write for children but flung himself into the field on a dare, died at his home in Santa Monica, Calif., on March 17, the day after his 90th birthday.

title: Japan Leader Aims to Root Out Bureaucrats
description: TOKYO  Six months after his partys historic election victory, tumbling approval ratings and mounting troubles threaten to make Yukio Hatoyama end up as just another unpopular Japanese prime minister. But in at least one crucial area, political experts say his new government has surpassed its predecessors: challenging the nations powerful and entrenched bureaucracy.

title: Advertisers Show Interest in iPad
description: Advertisers initially approached new media as if they were going duck hunting, tiptoeing cautiously into the waters of mobile phones and the Internet.

title: College Breaks a Tradition of Silence Before Games
description: GOSHEN, Ind.  At the small liberal arts college here known for its pacifist Mennonite traditions, sporting events have never begun with the same pregame routine as almost everywhere else  cheering hoopla for the home team, complete with a ritual salute to the flag and the playing of the national anthem. Usually, the Goshen College Maple Leafs just huddle and head out to play.

title: Seeking Lower Fuel Costs, Ukraine May Sell Pipelines
description: MOSCOW  In recent years, state-owned natural gas pipelines in Ukraine have been the source of such tension that a midwinter fight between Russia and Ukraine over pricing  often leading to Russias shutting the valves and leaving people in Europe freezing  has become an annual ritual.

title: Washingtons Pondexter Makes 4 Years Pay Off
description: When Quincy Pondexter walked into Washington Coach Lorenzo Romars office last spring for his after-the-season meeting, he saw documents Romar had prepared for him to sign and send into the N.B.A., requesting an evaluation of his prospects for the draft.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: iPad Apps, Computer Genius and Robots
description: In this weeks New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Jenna Wortham, who covers digital culture for The Times, tells Bettina Edelstein about the rush to build apps for Apples iPad. It poses a special challenge to developers, most of whom have been unable to get their hands on the device.

title: El Salvador Leader Apologizes for Archbishops Assassination
description: MEXICO CITY  Thirty years after a sharpshooter fired a single shot at scar Romero, the archbishop of San Salvador, killing him as he celebrated Mass, El Salvadors president apologized Wednesday for the assassination that helped push the country toward civil war.

title: Military to Revise Dont Ask, Dont Tell Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates will announce measures on Thursday to make it more difficult for the military to expel openly gay service members, an interim plan while the Pentagon examines repeal of the dont ask, dont tell policy, officials said.

title: Switch Banks? You Might Find Theres a Perk in It for You
description: THIS should be a golden age for banks that want to persuade people to ditch their checking accounts and start fresh elsewhere.

title: MGM Asks Lenders for More Time as It Weighs Bids
description: As expected, Metro Goldwyn Mayer on Wednesday asked its lenders for more time to reorganize its debts, as it considered three takeover bids, none of which was likely to satisfy creditor demands, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

title: After Health Vote, Threats on Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic lawmakers have received death threats and been the victims of vandalism because of their votes in favor of the health care bill, lawmakers and law enforcement officials said Wednesday, as the Congressional debate over the issue headed toward a bitter and divisive conclusion.

title: Ding! Mail. OMG! Its Steve Jobs.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Jezper Sderlund, a music producer in Gothenburg, Sweden, was thrilled to receive a one-word e-mail message earlier this month.

title: With the Death of a Physician, an Era Fades
description: DANBURY, Conn.

title: Possible G.O.P. Candidate for Senate Will Skip Race
description: Dan Senor, a private equity executive and former military adviser to President George W. Bush, has decided not to challenge Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the election this fall, he said in an interview on Wednesday.

title: Time for an Insurance Checkup, as Needs and Options Change
description: FEW things in our financial lives could be as tedious yet as important as reviewing the policies that insure what we own. Hours spent poring over pages written in arcane language can seem totally wasted. So we dont do it.

title: Attorney General Moves to Forefront of Virginia Conservative Resurgence
description: RICHMOND, Va.  In campaigning to become Virginias attorney general, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II made no secret of his conservative views, winning enthusiastic endorsements from the National Rifle Association and the National Coalition for Life.

title: Vatican Declined to Defrock U.S. Priest Who Abused Boys
description: Top Vatican officials  including the future Pope Benedict XVI  did not defrock a priest who molested as many as 200 deaf boys, even though several American bishops repeatedly warned them that failure to act on the matter could embarrass the church, according to church files newly unearthed as part of a lawsuit.

title: Free Speech Debated After Ann Coulter Cancels Appearance
description: OTTAWA  A decision by Ann Coulter, the conservative American political commentator and writer, to cancel an appearance at the University of Ottawa set off a debate over freedom of speech in Canada on Wednesday.

title: A Financial Report Card, Right in Your Tax Return
description: MOST of us would like an answer to this question: Am I on the royal highway toward realizing my long-term financial goals  building up savings for the childrens education and for retirement, for example  or am I bumping along a back road that ends far short of my goals?

title: Court Weighs Timing of Death Row Appeal
description: WASHINGTON  As is his custom, Justice John Paul Stevens did not ask a question on Wednesday until the lawyer before him had almost finished his argument. When Justice Stevens did speak up, it was in a seeming effort to guide his colleagues on the Supreme Court toward what he considered to be the central argument advanced by the death row inmate in the case.

title: Bloggingheads: G.O.P.s Misplayed Hand
description: Joshua Cohen, left, of Stanford University and Brink Lindsey of the Cato Institute discuss why the G.O.P. lost the fight over health care reform.

title: Times Co. Settles Claim in Singapore
description: The New York Times Company has settled a claim by leaders of Singapores government that they were smeared by an Op-Ed piece in The International Herald Tribune, publishing an apology in The Herald Tribune on Wednesday and paying about $114,000 to the leaders.

title: Ad Duel for Florida G.O.P. Senate Candidates
description: With Floridas primary now five months  to the day  away, the two leading Republican Senate candidates in the Sunshine State spent Wednesday firing political punches at each other.

title: Research Offers Clue Into How Hearts Can Regenerate in Some Species
description: Doctors who have treated heart attack patients with injections of stem cells have had little success so far in making the heart regenerate its stricken tissues. Researchers have now discovered that in nature, hearts are regenerated in a quite different way, one that does not depend on stem cells.

title: West Virginia Star Finds Theres More to Life Than Pizza
description: NEWARK, N.J.  When DaSean Butler was a freshman at West Virginia, his father, Ira Puryear, gave him a credit card to use in case of emergency.

title: Researchers Puzzled by Role of Osteoporosis Drug in Rare Thighbone Fractures
description: The case reports first surfaced about two years ago and they were frightening. A few orthopedists reported that women taking osteoporosis drugs to prevent broken bones were showing up with rare and serious fractures of their thighbones. The bone was snapping like a twig, sometimes splintering. Often there was no trauma, like a serious fall, to bring it on.

title: Britons Cling to Services, Despite Debt
description: LONDON  Britain operates one of the largest welfare states in Europe. And that, it seems, is just fine with many of the British.

title: Europe Looks at the I.M.F. With Unease as Greece Struggles
description: PARIS  With Greece facing a looming deadline to roll over $27 billion in debt, the countries of the euro zone are arguing nastily among themselves about whether and how to toss Greece to the tender mercies of the International Monetary Fund.

title: Assemble a Paper Trail, and Make Sure Your Heirs Can Follow It
description: NO one wants to think about dying. But refusing to look at the documents that will determine where your money goes when you pass away will not make you live longer. It will just make sorting through everything more difficult for your heirs.

title: New Overtime Rule Encounters Opposition
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Coaches grumbled that a new rule had been forced on them, and even a few owners seemed a little stunned at how rapidly things had moved. But the N.F.L.s new overtime rules for the postseason  and the momentum to change overtime in the regular season  were the result of Commissioner Roger Goodells legislative skills.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,013 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Reyess Arrival Boosts Morale
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  A flash of energy and good cheer brightened the Mets clubhouse Wednesday morning. After a two-week absence, Jose Reyes was back, bouncing along as he greeted teammates with his infectious smile and earnest hugs.

title: Albanys Pork Handouts
description: It pays to live in the home district of the New York Legislatures big shots. According to a new analysis by several citizens groups, Senate and Assembly leaders grabbed much bigger chunks of political pork than lesser members did. This is yet another in a long list of reasons to oppose member items, as pork is known in Albany.

title: Gone in a New York Nanosecond
description: When online registration for the 2010 New York City Triathlon opened at 12:01 a.m. last Nov. 1, Annabelle Fry manned two computers in hopes of doubling her chances at getting in. Fry successfully logged in, but as she filled out the application, all 5,600 slots were taken.

title: Tracking Cash Purchases Without the Receipts
description: CALL it the last frontier in budgeting.

title: Behind Consumer Agency Idea, a Scourge of Wall St.
description: Ask Elizabeth Warren, scourge of Wall Street bankers, how they treat consumers, and her no-nonsense bob will shake with indignation. She will talk about morality, about fairness, about what she calls their let them eat cake attitude towards taxpayers. If she is riled enough, she might even spit out the Warren version of an expletive.

title: Woods Is Getting Ready; So Are the Hecklers
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  When Tiger Woods returns to the golf course, someone  an aggrieved fan, an ambitious bettor, an exhibitionist looking for a SportsCenter moment  will want to be the first to do the inevitable.

title: Pelosi Chooses Three for Debt Panel
description: All 18 members of President Obamas bipartisan commission on reducing the national debt have been named now that the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, has announced three Democrats as her choices. They are Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, a moderate who is chairman of the House Budget Committee; Representative Xavier Becerra of California, a liberal lieutenant of Ms. Pelosi who is vice chairman of the House Democratic Caucus and a member of the Budget and Ways and Means Committees; and Representative Jan Schakowsky of Illinois, a liberal who is on the Energy and Commerce Committee.

title: F.B.I.s Crime-Fighting Web Site Focuses on Bank Robbers
description: Bank robberies may be down from a recent peak, but the Federal Bureau of Investigation is nevertheless making a push to track down suspects, enlisting the publics help through a new Web site.

title: Kentucky: Cheney Backs a Candidate
description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney endorsed Trey Grayson in the Republican primary for the Senate on Wednesday, calling him the real conservative in this race. In a statement, Mr. Cheney indicated that Mr. Grayson, Kentuckys secretary of state, would be stronger on national security and fiscal issues than his opponent, Rand Paul.

title: Texas: Condemned Man Gets a Stay
description: Less than an hour before Hank Skinner was to be put to death for the murder of his girlfriend and her two sons, the United States Supreme Court blocked his execution on Wednesday, giving him another chance to gain access to DNA evidence. Prosecutors and the state courts have repeatedly refused to let him test blood, fingernail scrapings and hair found at the scene of the killings against his genetic markers. The justices ordered the execution postponed until they decide whether to review the case. Mr. Skinner maintains he was sleeping on a sofa in a vodka-and-codeine haze when the killings took place on New Years Eve in 1993.

title: Texas: Housing Ban Is Struck Down
description: A federal judge in Dallas struck down an ordinance on Wednesday in the suburb of Farmers Branch that would have barred illegal immigrants from renting housing there. The judge, Jane J. Boyle of Federal District Court, issued a permanent injunction, finding that the ordinance violated the Constitution by regulating immigration, which she found to be an exclusively federal power.

title: How to Self-Diagnose Your Financial Health
description: YOU probably get an annual physical. Your doctor will ask about your concerns, take your blood pressure and 30 minutes later youre out of the paper gown and off to work  maybe with a new prescription for Lipitor.

title: Quarters Will Feature Parks
description: The United States Mint will start circulating quarters honoring national parks and other national sites in April. In all, the America the Beautiful Quarters Program plans to release 56 quarters through 2021, eventually highlighting sites in all 50 states, the District of Columbia and five United States territories. The first quarter will recognize Hot Springs National Park in Arkansas.

title: Japan, Struggling With Debt, Approves a $1 Trillion Budget
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government on Wednesday pushed a record 92.3 trillion yen ($1 trillion) budget through Parliament aimed at stimulating growth in the long-stagnant economy. It means another round of spending and adding to Tokyos already substantial public debt.

title: Skepticism and Optimism Meet With Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

title: House of Anger
description: Unfairly or not, the defining images of opposition to health care reform may end up being those rage-filled partisans with spittle on their lips. Whether the outbursts came from inside Congress  the baby killer shout of Rep. Randy Neugebauer, and his colleagues who cheered on hecklers  or outside, where protesters hurled vile names against elected representatives, they are powerful and lasting scenes of a democracy gasping for dignity.

title: Transit Agency Approves Cuts, and More Bad News Looms
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority formally approved on Wednesday a slate of severe service cuts that will eliminate two subway lines and dozens of bus routes in the city and create longer, more-crowded trips for the regions transit riders.

title: Fly Moves
description: "If I could see only one show this spring, I'd be hard pressed to talk myself out of 'No Time to Fly,' a new solo choreographed and performed by the singular Deborah Hay, who has been creating ensemble work for the past few years,"  Claudia La Rocco writes. "Hats off to Danspace Project and the guest curator Juliette Mapp for inviting this native New Yorker and ceaseless experimenter to be a part of the Back to New York City series." Ms. Hay, a former dancer with Merce Cunningham, and one of the most influential artists to come out of the Judson Dance Theater, will perform on Thursday at 8 p.m.

title: The Old Days
description: Hip-hop fans nostalgic for the glory days should head uptown to Maysles Cinema for the final night of the "Under the Influence of Ego Trip" film series. On Thursday night the series will screen "Public Enemy and LL Cool J Live in Europe," a 1987 film never before screened in the United States. Also on the bill is 1986's "Big Fun in the Big Town," directed by Bram van Splunteren. The film features rare footage of Grandmaster Flash, Run-DMC, Doug E. Fresh and the Get Fresh Crew, Biz Markie, Russell Simmons, Schoolly D and others. The screening will be followed by a discussion with Doug E. Fresh, Mr. van Splunteren and Schoolly D, as well as Bill Adler, a former executive at Def Jam Records, and then a reception sponsored by Sugar Hill Ale.

title: Part Play, Part Opera
description: "The English were wary of the Continental taste for opera in the 17th century," writes Allan Kozinn, "but they liked the idea of adorning plays with music. What composers and theater producers came up with is a curious compromise that Roger North, a writer at the time, called 'semi-opera.'" He goes on to say that "the staging of Purcell's 'Fairy Queen' that opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday evening makes a powerful argument for the hybrid form." Jonathan Kent directs this production of the 1692 adaptation of Shakespeare's "Midsummer Night's Dream," which features William Christie conducting his ensemble, Les Arts Florissants, and is the centerpiece of the new BAM Opera Festival. Go to listen to the music and look out for the masques, or mini-dramatic interludes. They "are freewheeling and almost vaudevillian in spirit," Mr. Kozinn writes, especially the "Masque of Seduction"  "presented at one point by an army of choristers in bunny costumes, offering what appeared to be a quick tour of the Kama Sutra."

title: Mobs Are Born as Word Grows by Text Message
description: PHILADELPHIA  It started innocently enough seven years ago as an act of performance art where people linked through social-networking Web sites and text messaging suddenly gathered on the streets for impromptu pillow fights in New York, group disco routines in London, and even a huge snowball fight in Washington.

title: U.S. Presses Israel on Housing as Dispute Widens
description: WASHINGTON  With Israeli officials saying that construction on a contentious Jewish housing project in East Jerusalem could begin at any time, President Obama pressed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday to give a written commitment to rein in any further building and to move ahead on peace talks with the Palestinians.

title: Start Saving Early, and Keep an Eye on Shifting Needs
description: EVEN economic oracles would have trouble predicting their retirement needs with a high degree of precision.

title: Coburns Erectile Dysfunction Amendment Is Killed
description: It was, by all accounts, the most politically volatile amendment proposed to the health care legislation so far: a proposal by Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, to bar federal health programs and the future federally regulated insurance exchanges from covering the cost of erectile dysfunction medication for convicted sex offenders.

title: Social Security to See Payout Exceed Pay-In This Year
description: The bursting of the real estate bubble and the ensuing recession have hurt jobs, home prices and now Social Security.

title: Retain Your Records No Longer Than You Must
description: IVE long been a pack rat when it comes to saving financial documents. I have a file cabinet full of old cellphone and credit card bills, brokerage firm and bank account statements and health insurance benefit forms.

title: The Importance of Being Counted (Pop. 842)
description: SAN ANTONIO, Fla.

title: Gallinari and Douglas Give Knicks Hope
description: If this is a renaissance, the Knicks picked a peculiar time for it. Their losing record is assured, the playoffs are a near impossibility, and the season is down to 11 seemingly meaningless games. There is little to gain now.

title: Cornell Counts on Closeness Against Kentucky
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  There are some days at the old, ramshackle house here on Dryden Road when things get so dirty that even 15 college guys cannot cope. In their rickety three-story dwelling, where 14 members of the Cornell basketball team and a team manager live near campus, teamwork involves cleaning with a shovel, scooping up the empty Mountain Dew cans and Subway wrappers as if they were another snowdrift.

title: After Arrests, Taliban Promote a Fighter
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Talibans supreme leader has replaced his top deputy with a relatively young but hardened fighter, an indication of the Talibans determination to push ahead with its insurgency despite the recent arrests of a handful of high-level commanders in Pakistan, according to Afghans and Pakistanis close to the Taliban.

title: The Predator Priest Who Got Away
description: An interactive timeline tracing the case of the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy, who admitted he sexually abused deaf boys at his boarding school for 22 years.

title: At the Movies Is Canceled
description: The balcony is closed, this time for good. After nearly three decades, At the Movies, the syndicated television program that introduced many viewers to the film critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert, as well as to film criticism in all its thorny and contentious glory, will cease production this summer, the studio that produces the show said.

title: Californias Overcrowded Prisons
description: Though prison overcrowding has long plagued California, a budget crisis is forcing the state to take unprecedented steps to shrink the prison population.

title: Robert Culp, Star in I Spy, Dies at 79
description: Robert Culp, who teamed with Bill Cosby as a secret agent in the hit 1960s television series I Spy and starred as one of the sexually adventurous title characters in the 1969 film Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: A Grand Achievement, or a Lost Opportunity?
description: WASHINGTON  When the last swords in the great health care clash finally clatter to the ground, and Congressional Democrats head home to savor their victory, a question that may still nag at them  and the partys liberal base  is whether they missed a last, best chance to create the government-run insurance plan known as the public option.

title: General Works to Salvage Iraq Legacy
description: JOINT SECURITY STATION LOYALTY, IRAQ  In the muddled aftermath of Iraqs election, the American commander here, Gen. Ray Odierno, landed at this base on the edge of Baghdad and reviewed the plan to close it.

title: Unions Make Strides as They Attack Banks
description: When the city of Los Angeles started looking into its complex financial contracts with banks earlier this year, some council members turned to an unusual corner for financial advice: labor unions.

title: China Says It Will Not Adjust Exchange Rate
description: WASHINGTON  Despite mounting pressure in Congress for the Obama administration to declare China a currency manipulator, the Chinese government is giving no indication that it will change its exchange rate policy.

title: British Regulator Makes 7th Arrest in Trading Inquiry
description: The Financial Services Authority, Britains top markets regulator, arrested a seventh person in an insider trading inquiry that has already ensnared workers at Deutsche Bank, Exane and the hedge fund Moore Capital Management.

title: Remembering Dan Naddor
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Dan Naddor, the author of todays puzzle, is no longer with us. He died of cancer complications on Dec. 29. But that doesnt mean hes done making us laugh.

title: Former Chairman, Once Convicted, Returns to Samsung
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Lee Kun-hee, the former chairman of Samsung who was convicted of corruption last August but pardoned by President Lee Myung-bak four months later to help a campaign for the 2018 Winter Olympics, returned to the helm of Samsung Electronics on Wednesday.

title: Two New Towers May End the Impasse at Ground Zero
description: Port Authority and other government officials and the developer Larry A. Silverstein have reached a tentative agreement that could resolve a 16-month impasse at ground zero and allow two new skyscrapers to be built on the site.

title: With a Little Star Power, Top Brass Ask for Ideas
description: EXECUTIVES at Allstate, known, after their famous slogan, as the good hands people, are looking for a few good advertising ideas  and are making that clear in attention-getting fashion.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Saturday about Lt. Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III as the leading candidate to succeed Gen. Ray Odierno as the top American commander in Iraq misspelled the surname of the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He is Adm. Mike Mullen  not Mullin.

title: Rodriguez Limits Discussion to Baseball
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Alex Rodriguez knew questions were coming about his coming interview with federal investigators regarding the Canadian-based doctor Anthony Galea. So Rodriguez stopped in front of his locker in the Yankees clubhouse early Wednesday afternoon to get them over with.

title: A Census Question
description: To the Editor:

title: How Immigration Is Changing the Face of America
description: To the Editor:

title: Too-Busy Bees
description: IN the past five years, as the phenomenon known as colony-collapse disorder has spread across the United States and Europe, causing the disappearance of whole colonies of domesticated honeybees, many people have come to fear that our food supply is in peril. The news on Wednesday that a Department of Agriculture survey found that American honeybees had died in great numbers this winter can only add to such fears.

title: School Standards: National or Local?
description: To the Editor:

title: Brave New Health Care World
description: Change is so traumatic.

title: Suicide Among the Young: How to Try to Prevent It
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fight Is Over, the Myths Remain
description: Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: The Pope and the Pedophilia Scandal
description: Pope Benedict XVIs latest apology for the emerging global scandal of child abuse by predatory priests  an issue that the Roman Catholic Church should have engaged years ago  is strong on forgiveness but far short of the full accountability that Catholics need for repairing their damaged church.

title: From Mrs. Obamas Garden
description: A year ago, Michelle Obama and pupils from a Washington elementary school dug up a patch of the South Lawn to plant a White House vegetable garden. Mrs. Obamas stated goal  apart from providing food for her familys meals and for formal dinners  was to promote healthful, locally grown fruit and vegetables and healthier eating by kids at a time of rising rates of childhood obesity and diabetes.

title: Escaping From Poverty
description: Before I ask for a drumroll and reveal the secrets of fighting poverty, a bit of background:

title: Prosecutors Gone Wild
description: Schools across the country are understandably concerned about students sexting  sending sexually suggestive photos and text messages by cellphone. But a Pennsylvania school district went too far when it referred several female students for criminal prosecution after their images showed up on other students phones and they refused to participate in an antisexting education program. A federal appeals court was right to rule last week that parents had the right to block the district attorney from prosecuting the girls.

title: Coyote Takes TriBeCa
description: WABC-TV

title: Cornell Adds Fences to Bridges to Deter Suicides by Students
description: Cornell University this week erected temporary fencing along three university-owned bridges that cross the deep gorges on its campus, where three students have jumped to their deaths in recent weeks.

title: Racial Slurs Preceded L.I. Attack, Victims Friend Testifies
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Walking in Patchogue with a friend shortly before midnight on a Saturday in November 2008, Angel Loja saw some young people approaching them.

title: Players on Committee Favor Fast Approval on Head Checks
description: N.H.L. punishment for blind-side checks to the head is becoming increasingly likely. Key members of the union on Wednesday endorsed the leagues move to speed approval for suspensions for such head checks starting immediately, rather than wait for the beginning of next season.

title: Mets Increase the Food Offerings, if Not the Homers
description: It should come as no surprise that sports teams are in the business of getting fans to part with as much of their money as possible when they visit the stadium: tickets, parking, scorecards, T-shirts and, of course, food and drinks.

title: Corrections
description: A headline and an article on Wednesday about President Obamas signing the health care overhaul into law misstated the number of pens he used. It was 22, not 20. (The president handed out 19 as mementoes, kept one for himself and set two aside to be archived.) The error was repeated in a caption on the front page.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 3 about a survey by Public Agenda, a nonprofit research group, of the opinions of high school graduates in the last dozen years toward their guidance counselors referred incorrectly to two ratios cited in the survey. The ratio of students to counselors that is considered optimal by the American School Counselor Association is 250 to 1, not 100 to 1. The average student to counselor ratio nationally is nearly 470 to 1, not 265 to 1.

title: Albany Senate to Release Some Files on Aqueduct
description: ALBANY  Senate Democrats said on Wednesday that they would make public some documents related to the controversial awarding of a casino gambling contract at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, even as they waged a legal battle to quash subpoenas from the state inspector generals office, which is investigating the Aqueduct deal.

title: Midge Costanza, a Top Assistant to Carter, Dies at 77
description: Midge Costanza, a top assistant to President Jimmy Carter whose habit of criticizing her boss and whose fractious relations with his inner circle of advisers led her to resign after less than two years on the job, died Tuesday in San Diego. She was 77.

title: Ex-Bouncer With a Death Stare Has Led Kansas States Resurgence
description: As the first American-born member of his Cuban family, Kansas State Coach Frank Martin worked nearly every job imaginable while growing up in Miami.

title: Inquiry Could Lead to Court-Martial for Ex-Army Surgeon
description: The former military surgeon and Medtronic consultant accused of falsifying research about the benefits of a bone-growth product used on soldiers injured in Iraq is now under investigation for a possible court-martial, officials at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center said Wednesday.

title: Paterson and Legislature at Odds as Budget Deadline Nears
description: ALBANY  The prospects of approving a state budget on time faded rapidly on Wednesday, as Gov. David A. Paterson said that his differences with the Legislature over spending were too great to bridge by the March 31 deadline. State officials, meanwhile, began preparing an emergency measure to keep the government functioning after the deadline.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 24, 2010

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a Toyota policy on replacing accelerator pedals in models recalled for pedal repairs referred incorrectly to the beginning of the policy. It was put into place in February, when the company announced its repair program, not earlier this month.

title: 3-D vs. High-Definition at the Garden
description: There were two versions of 3-D hockey at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night when the Rangers played the Islanders. One was in the Theater, where 2,600 fans, advertisers, members of the news media and others watched on a giant screen that was not ideal for 3-D.

title: Citibank Branch Property Is in Tunnel Planners Sights
description: New Yorkers who would like to see the number of bank branches in the city reduced at any cost may have a new reason to support efforts to build an $8.7 billion train tunnel between Manhattan and New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: The Your Money column on Saturday, about whether to pay off mortgage debt early, included an incorrect calculation in an example of tax treatment of mortgage interest. A household in the 35 percent tax bracket paying $20,000 a year in mortgage interest would reap tax savings of $7,000, not $7,500, making the net cost $13,000, not $12,500.

title: Delay for Notices About High School
description: Eighth-grade students will indeed have to wait at least one more day before they can find out where they will attend high school next fall.

title: Point Guards Injury Leaves West Virginia Thin in Backcourt
description: SYRACUSE  Darryl Bryant, West Virginias starting point guard, was on crutches Wednesday watching his teammates practice at the Carrier Dome. The loss of Bryant, known as Truck, to a broken right foot in practice on Tuesday could not have come at a worse time for the Mountaineers  two days before a Round of 16 matchup in the N.C.A.A. tournament against Washington  or to a more crucial position.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Tuesday about a fund-raising concert for Haiti at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night by the pianist Lang Lang and the Schleswig-Holstein Festival Orchestra referred incorrectly to the orchestras performance. Its American debut was on Friday night at the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville, N.Y. The Carnegie Hall concert was not its American debut.

title: Audit Faults Bookkeeping by Office Under Morgenthau
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office exhibited a lack of transparency in dividing $448 million in settlement accounts between New York City and New York State between January 2007 and December 2009, according to an audit released on Wednesday by City Comptroller John C. Liu.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Wednesday with a television review of the documentary The Senators Bargain, using information provided by HBO2, included three misspelled surnames. The film is part of the series How Democracy Works Now and the series coordinating producer is Rachel Salmon, not Solomon. One of the sound editors is Michael Feuser, not Fevser. And the colorist/online editor is Savvas Paritsis, not Paritis.

title: Is the Stagnation in Poverty Real?
description: The premise of my Thursday column  that the proportion of people living in poverty has stagnated since the 1970s  is sometimes contested by conservatives. They note that since the poverty threshold was devised in the 1960s, a range of programs have been introduced to alleviate poverty: free school lunches, food stamps, earned income tax credits, and so on. None of those safety net programs are counted in determining whether someone lives below the poverty line, and so  the argument goes  the proportion of people living in poverty is hugely overcounted.

title: Healthy Banks Gear Up to Buy Weaker Rivals
description: As the list of Americas problem banks balloons, healthy institutions are gearing up to capitalize on the misfortune of others. Just look at First Interstate BancSystem, the first bank to begin an initial public offering since before the financial crisis. It may use the proceeds to pick off failed rivals.

title: Corrections
description: A picture from The Associated Press on March 2 with an article about new research on selfishness and altruism, based on the behavior of men aboard the sinking ocean liners Titanic and Lusitania, was published in error. It showed the Mauretania  not its sister ship, the Lusitania.

title: Mount Sinai Shows Interest in St. Vincents Hospital
description: Representatives of Mount Sinai Medical Center have taken an interest in St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan, the struggling Greenwich Village institution that has been looking for a partner so it can stay afloat, officials said Wednesday.

title: Jim Marshall, Rock Photographer, Dies
description: Jim Marshall, whose images of musicians in the 1960s and 1970s helped define rock n roll photography, died at 74.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about new research that suggests early intervention is crucial to preventing obesity referred incorrectly to a plan by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation to spend $500 million to fight childhood obesity. It plans to spend that amount by 2015  not over 14 years.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about the pharmacologist James W. Black misstated the year he was born. It was 1924, not 1934. (The headline and the obituary correctly noted that Dr. Black, who was born on June 14, was 85.)

title: DNA Testing Leads to Arrest in 1981 Killing
description: A 56-year-old man already serving time for two murders was charged on Wednesday in a third killing, the strangulation of a Bronx woman nearly three decades ago.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Thursday about Wayne Collett, an American runner who was barred from competing again in Olympic competition after he was judged to have acted disrespectfully during a medal ceremony in Munich in 1972, misspelled the given name and the surname of the sports information director at the University of California, Los Angeles, where Collett had been a track and field star. He is Marc Dellins, not Mark Dellims.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Canada: Bill in Quebec Would Ban Veils in Dealings With Officials
description: In the latest of a series of measures related to religious displays, the province of Quebec introduced legislation on Wednesday requiring people to show their faces to receive government services. The bill does not make specific reference to Muslim women, but Premier Jean Charest told reporters that the law respects the principle of equality between men and women. Although Muslim women who cover their faces are not prominent in Quebec, there has been considerable controversy in the province about the practice.

title: Correction
description: An article last Thursday about home automation overstated Dan Levines role in the founding of CytexOne, a company that installs such systems. He was one of the companys founders, not its sole founder. An accompanying list of do-it-yourself home automation devices referred incorrectly to Indigo Touch, an app for the iPhone and iPod Touch. It is made by Perceptive Automation, not by Insteon, which is a home-automation technology.

title: Corrections
description: The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about women and aging, misspelled the surname of the feminist author who said of a womans later years, If you are going to pretend its youth, you are going to miss it. She was Betty Friedan, not Freidan.

title: Looking Ahead: Round of 16
description: EAST

title: Take a Few Hours and Unlock Some Cash
description: To be a modern American consumer is to be plagued by a never-ending, guilt-inducing stream of undone tasks.

title: In New Orleans, Getting Serious Over Suits
description: Many Mardi Gras Indians have become fed up with seeing their elaborate costumes on calendars and expensive prints without getting anything in return.

title: Consultations on Myanmar Produce Opposing Views
description: China and Britain emerged from closed Security Council consultations on Myanmar with opposite views on that countrys expected elections in the fall. Li Baogong, the new Chinese envoy to the United Nations, described the vote as a domestic matter and an important step toward national reconciliation and democracy. The British ambassador, Mark Lyall Grant, told reporters that the new electoral laws in Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, fall well short of what the international community expected in a free and fair process. Britain, which called the session, accused the military junta running the country of writing the laws specifically to make it difficult for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader and a Nobel laureate, to participate. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, above, said this week that she opposed registering her party for the elections. Her comments came hours after Myanmars highest court refused to accept a lawsuit filed by the party that sought to revoke five new election laws.

title: France: Man Accused of Hacking Twitter Accounts
description: After an investigation of months conducted jointly with the F.B.I., French authorities on Tuesday detained a 25-year-old Frenchman accused of hacking the Twitter accounts of several high-profile people, including the official account of President Obama and an account for Britney Spears, French media reported Wednesday. The man, known by the alias Hacker Croll, is accused of infiltrating the accounts on Twitter, a social networking Web site, in April 2009. French authorities have not revealed his real name. The man was released Wednesday but is set to face charges in court in June. He could be sentenced to up to two years in prison if convicted.

title: Jim Marshall, Rock n Roll Photographer, Dies at 74
description: Jim Marshall, a photographer whose images of Jimi Hendrix, the Rolling Stones, Johnny Cash and others in the 1960s and 70s helped define their subjects as well as rock n roll photography itself, was found dead on Wednesday morning in a Manhattan hotel. He was 74.

title: Word of the Day | consistent
description: consistent \kn-sis-tnt\ adjective

title: Richard Engquist, Kuni-Leml Lyricist, Is Dead at 76
description: Richard Engquist, whose witty way with a lyric sparked the Off Broadway musicals Kuni-Leml and Little Ham, died on March 18 in Brooklyn. He was 76.
