title: Shares Fall on Worries About Sales and Europe Debt
description: Shares on Wall Street pulled back from their recent winning streak on Wednesday amid concerns about debt problems in Portugal and disappointing home sales in the United States, The New York Timess David Jolly and Javier C. Hernandez reported.

title: Bucks Show May Be Over
description: After three episodes, Joe Buck says he does not expect his HBO show Joe Buck Live to continue. Theres only another nine months on that contract anyway, so I dont think its that big of a deal either way, he told the St. Louis sports talk station 1380 AM on Wednesday. Asked if he would miss it, he said: No, not really. There was a lot more behind the scenes, a lot more effort and hassle than I ever expected.

title: Rio Tinto Trial Ends in China, but Verdict Awaits
description: The trial of four employees of the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto ended in Shanghai on Wednesday afternoon, but a verdict had not been reached on charges that the group accepted millions of dollars in bribes from Chinese steel companies and stole commercial secrets, The New York Timess David Barboza writes.

It may use the proceeds to pick off failed rivals, the publication suggests.

description: Todays idea: The United States owes a debt for its founding to what is now Haiti, a scholar writes. Far from being a basket case during the American Revolution, the prosperous French colony was a vital transit hub for munitions and an economic engine behind French loans to the American cause.

title: The Influential Books Game
description: More than a week ago, Tyler Cowen kicked off an irresistible blogospheric listing exercise: In this case, the theme is 10 books which have influenced your view of the world. You can find Matthew Yglesiass list here, Will Wilkinsons list here, Matt Continettis here, and many more at this link. My own follows below. Note that these are not my 10 favorite books, nor the 10 best books Ive ever read, but the books that quickly came to mind  I was following Cowens go with your gut admonition  as having shaped my writing or pushed me in one intellectual direction or another over the years. As an experiment, Ive also tried listing them in rough chronological order, starting with the books that influenced me as a child and working my way upward (or downward, perhaps) toward adulthood. And like many people, Ive cheated and gone over 10  in my case, by doubling up on a few that share an author or a theme.

title: Sampler: Voters to Decide on Legalizing Marijuana, and the Mud Claims a Ghost Town
description: Voters to Decide on Legalizing Marijuana | For the second time in 40 years, voters in California will decide whether to legalize marijuana, after a ballot initiative  which proposes to legalize pot and allow it to be sold and taxed  qualified to be on the November ballot, state officials announced Wednesday. Supporters turned in 694,248 signatures from every county except Alpine. Officials in Los Angeles County, where the signatures were submitted Wednesday night, estimated 523,531 signatures were valid. To qualify for the November election, the ballot needed 433,971 signatures. Richard Lee, an Oakland marijuana entrepreneur, has spent $1.3 million to put together the campaign. Were one step closer to ending cannabis prohibition and the unjust laws that lock people up for cannabis while alcohol is not only sold openly but advertised on television to kids every day, he said. [The Los Angeles Times, The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: Theater Talkback: Costume Drama
description: Even before he opens his mouth, you can tell that the central character in Martin McDonaghs Behanding in Spokane is bonkers. Of course, its kind of a giveaway that hes being played by Christopher Walken, that master interpreter of psychos. But look closely at what hes wearing, and how hes wearing it. Everything is at least secondhand, and nothing really fits, including that big black coat and those oversize, way-too-short pants. Yet his clothes seem as much a part of him as his skin, or a carapace for an armadillo. This guy lives in those duds and probably has for a long, long time.

title: Nearly 30 Years After a Grisly Murder, A Charge
description: In the autumn of 1981, the partly clothed body of a 36-year-old woman was found in a shack on an abandoned lot just down the road from Crotona Park in the Bronx. She had been strangled with a scarf that was wrapped around her neck and tightened with a chisel.

As the original hosts, he and his crosstown rival Gene Siskel of The Chicago Tribune made the program required viewing for legions of film fans and armchair critics.

description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, looking to counter what it sees as a decline in local journalism and original reporting nationwide, said it is making funding available to set up seven regional reporting projects that will be collaborative efforts between public radio and TV stations.

title: How They Got the Shot
description: Some photographs are so famous that theyve become part of our collective visual history. But the stories behind them  and the lengths photographers have gone to capture them  are often more of a mystery. A new exhibition at Hasted Hunt Kraeutler in New York, Great Photographs of the 20th Century: Staged and Startled, looks under the skirts of 22 such photos by the likes of Richard Avedon, Irving Penn, William Eggleston, Steven Klein and Tina Barney.

title: Maazel to Join Munich Philharmonic as Chief Conductor
description: Lorin Maazel, the venerated maestro who ended his term as the music director of the New York Philharmonic last year, will not be sitting on his laurels for very long. On Wednesday, the City Council of Munich voted unanimously to approve Mr. Maazels appointment as chief conductor of the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra, the orchestra said on its Web site. His appointment will be effective with the 2012-13 season. In a statement, Christian Ude, the mayor of Munich, said the orchestra had succeeded in signing up one of the worlds pre-eminent conductors who will motivate and inspire excellence. Mr. Maazel, who was a highly visible figure in Munich when he served as the chief conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony, added in his own statement that the quality of the orchestra is unsurpassed, and that following in the footsteps of previous conductors like Sergiu Celibidache, who conducted the Munich orchestra until his death in 1996, represents a challenge that he will take on with joy.

title: Andy Warhols Daimler Works Are Shown After 22 Years
description: In 1986, Daimler-Benz commissioned the pop artist Andy Warhol to make a series of paintings to celebrate the automakers centennial. The plan was for 80 works, and the subjects would be 20 of Daimlers most important cars, including the Benz Patent Motorwagen of 1886, the first car ever built. But Warhol died on Feb. 22, 1987, of a heart attack shortly after gall bladder surgery. At the time of his death, he had completed only 35 silkscreens and 12 large-scale drawings. They were his last works.

description: One of the frustrating things about sandwiches is that they can be hard to eat if one element is much harder to bite through than the others. The bacon on a club sandwich is particularly troublesome in our house because I dont like to cut it too thin or cook it to a crisp cinder: I like it to be recognizable as meat. And of course a multi-layer construction of this kind is dangerous to start with.

title: The Coach King Feels the Bruises and Thanks You
description: Its not that runway debuts are unusual, but when the debut is by Reed Krakoff, the executive creative director of Coach, more attention is paid than to a struggling small fry. Reviews in February for Mr. Krakoffs collection for his own label were noticeably ungloved. Heavy and clunky noted Womens Wear Daily, while a commenter on its blog spat out zzzzs. Style.com sensed a Phoebe Philo influence. Suzy Menkes called the collection a work in progress. Scott Schuman, on his Sartorialist blog, praised the designer for hitting that sweet spot of design that is just aspirational enough while still being something that you can imagine in everyday life.

description: Two executives at a unit of the Fortress Investment Groups liquid hedge fund business have left the firm, Bloomberg News reported Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

title: Eco-Tripping | The Little Green Book
description: For many travelers today, the question isnt just where to go next but also the size of the footprint theyll make when they get there. Which is why hotels, restaurants, cruise ships and even entire cities are jumping on the biofueled bandwagon  without giving up the glamour. More

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Critics Seek to Halt Ethiopian Hydro Project
description: Several environmental and human rights groups have joined forces in drafting a petition decrying Ethiopias Gibe III hydroelectric dam project, which they say has the potential to destroy the livelihoods of 500,000 people in Ethiopia and Kenya.

title: A Bigger Sensor for a Coat-Pocket Camera
description: As longtime readers are painfully aware, I'm obsessed with big-sensor cameras. Or, rather, with big-sensor cameras that are, themselves, small.

title: Russian Tycoon Acquires British Newspaper
description: Alexander Lebedev, a Russian billionaire who was once a K.G.B. agent stationed in London, struck a long-awaited deal to buy The Independent newspaper on Thursday, little more than a year after he acquired another of Britains respected major papers, The Evening Standard of London.

title: Kiner Recalls Spring Training in the 40s
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Spring training has changed a lot over the years: nicer facilities for the players and fantasy camps and package tours for the fans. Things were simpler in the old days, so simple that rookies had trouble getting into the batting cage.

title: Beyond the Cheese Steak Wars in Philadelphia
description: UNTIL a few years ago, East Passyunk Avenue, the heavily Italian-American commercial corridor that runs through South Philadelphia, was mainly known for its warring cheese steak emporiums, Genos and Pats. Most of the other shops on The Avenue, as its known, were of little interest to tourists, unless they were looking for a Communion dress or a racy undergarment.

title: Health Care Vote Costs S.I. Congressman Support
description: Just a few weeks ago, New York City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn agreed to host a fund-raiser for a fellow Democrat who faced the prospect of a tough challenge this fall, Representative Michael McMahon of Staten Island.

title: TimesCast | March 25, 2010
description: From the newsroom of The New York Times.

title: What Happens as Google Uncensors Search in China?
description: HONG KONG  As Google began offering uncensored search results in China early Tuesday morning, it was unclear how much impact the companys move would have toward the companysstated goal: to meaningfully increase access to information for people in China.

title: No Poll Will Decide This Tournament
description: As the N.C.A.A. tournaments Round of 16 gets ready to tip off, lets pause for a second to absorb the tournaments beauty. Sure, the selection process seems suspiciously rigged in favor of the big-conference teams. And yes, it is really a gigantic business venture wrapped in the warm and fuzzy story line of shining moments and it will most likely be obliterated when the N.C.A.A. scraps the 65-team format in favor of a horrific 96-team money grab. But  and this doesnt sound novel except when you compare it with Division I college football  teams actually play one another to win a national title and there is no poll involved.

title: Accusations Fly Between Parties Over Threats and Vandalism
description: IVY, Va.  The authorities here confirmed Thursday that a gas line had been deliberately cut at the home of a brother of a Democratic congressman who voted for the health care bill, making it potentially the most dangerous of many acts of violence and threats against supporters of the bill in the last week.

title: Yankees Name Hughes as Fifth Starter
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Phil Hughes will be the Yankees fifth starter. Manager Joe Girardi confirmed that Thursday morning after the Yankees arrived here to play the Baltimore Orioles. Girardi told Hughes and Joba Chamberlain, who are not on the trip, just before the team bus left.

title: Without Warning, Ambivalence Takes Hold
description: Im beginning to realize, painfully and with much confusion, that the end results of my college decisions wont be so crazily important in the overall trajectory of my life. Its so odd to actually commit this revelation into words, because Ive invested so much of my life and energy into this self-divesting process. I feel like Ive betrayed myself in some way by admitting that all those terrible months of preparation, stress and waiting dont really amount to that much.

title: Households Facing Foreclosure Rose in 4th Quarter
description: The ranks of those facing foreclosure swelled by a quarter-million households in the fourth quarter, new government data shows.

title: Radioactive Leak Is Fixed at Vermont Plant
description: Technicians have found and fixed two holes in an underground pipe that were allowing radioactive tritium to flow into the groundwater at the Vermont Yankee nuclear reactor, the plants owner, Entergy, said Thursday.

title: New Face for That Face
description: The actress Elizabeth Marvel has departed the coming Off Broadway play That Face because of television and film commitments, she said on Thursday. Laila Robins (Frozen, Heartbreak House) will replace her in the central role of a manipulative mother in the Manhattan Theater Club production.

title: Europeans Reach Deal on Rescue Plan for Greece
description: BRUSSELS  After months of fractious debate, the 16 countries that use the euro agreed on a financial safety net for Greece, combining bilateral loans from those European nations with cash from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Assemblyman Convicted on Impaired Driving Charge
description: Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV was found guilty on Thursday of driving while ability impaired but cleared of more serious drunken driving charges, ending a two-year legal odyssey that began with his arrest in 2008.

title: Shortlist Unveiled for Lost Man Booker Prize
description: These were the ones that almost got away. In an act of literary reparation, the Booker Prize Foundation, the organization that bestows Britains most prestigious book prize, has named a shortlist of books published in 1970 that were never eligible for the Man Booker Prize because of a change in the award calendar.

title: Polls Show Public Still Skeptical of Health Care Law
description: While President Obama promotes health care legislation in Iowa today, polls taken since the bill passed find somewhat more support for the measure, but also reveal a nation still skeptical of overhauling the health care system.

title: Bin Laden Derides Obama and Threatens Americans in New Tape
description: On Thursday, Al Jazeera broadcast what it said was a new audiotape released by Osama bin Laden.

title: Unemployment Rate Drops Again
description: New York Citys unemployment rate dipped in February, raising hopes that the effects of the long recession are waning and the pace of hiring may pick up soon.

title: Phish in 3-D That Everyone Can See
description: Hmm. Can you think of any reason why the fans of a popular jam band might enjoy the experience of seeing their favorite musicians in a movie presented in 3-D? Off the top of our heads, we couldnt, but were still reasonably certain that a new 3-D film featuring Phish in a coming-at-you concert will find its audience.

title: Curious George Saves the Day
description: Images from the exhibition at the Jewish Museum.

title: A Military Downgrading of Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: WASHINGTON  Two distinct messages could be heard after Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced new measures on Thursday to make it more difficult for the military to discharge openly gay men and lesbians.

title: Equestrian Vaulting Gains Fans in the Northeast
description: PEDRICKTOWN, N.J.

title: Germany and France Agree on Plan for Greece
description: 5:47 p.m. | Updated After months of fractious debate, a rescue package for Greece began to emerge on Thursday when France and Germany agreed to a plan combining cash from the International Monetary Fund with financing from the 16 countries that use the single currency, The New York Timess Stephen Castle and Matthew Saltmarsh report.

title: Photo of the Week
description: India girls ride on a float in a small parade during the Hindu festival of Ram Navami in New Delhi, India. Ram Navami celebrates the birthday of Hindu god Rama.

title: Senate Passes Reconciliation Bill
description: 2:31 p.m. |56 Ayes and 43 Nays

title: Democrats Praise Health Care Laws Benefits
description: With the finish line in sight, Senator John D. Rockefeller IV seems pretty happy about the status of the health care debate. And he wasnt afraid to talk about it this morning.

title: Canadian Bacon (Plus) | Smoked Meat in Toronto
description: In my first hour in Toronto, I ate these things: stewed rabbit, blueberry-buckwheat pancakes, crisp ribbons of translucent guanciale and billowy mounds of smoked ricotta. And this was all just the first dish. Brunch at Hoof Caf  the new offshoot of Grant van Gameren and Jen Aggs Black Hoof, across the street  is a decidedly meat-focused affair. Stranger than this strange assemblage, which also included more blueberries and some syrup and  why not?  candied celery and which seemed to suggest the chefs were smoking more than cheese, was the fact that it all sort of worked. Not brilliant, but sweet and smoky and meaty and an oddly comforting way to begin the first meal of the day. The lines out the door should have tipped me off: Toronto is in the throes of a serious love affair with all things meaty.

title: Obamas Remarks in Iowa City on Health Care
description: Following is a text of President Obama's remarks Thursday at a health care rally in Iowa City, Iowa, as released by the White House:

title: Cantor Accuses Democrats of Exploiting Threats
description: The Congressional clash over threats and vandalism against lawmakers in the aftermath of the health care vote took a new turn Thursday as the No. 2 House Republican accused Democrats of recklessly exploiting the incidents for political gain.

title: Whats Possible Is Not Always Whats Best
description: Just because a thing is possible, doesnt mean that we have the wherewithal to actually pull it off.

title: These Zags Are a Tournament Threat Too
description: Mention the words Gonzaga basketball and most will think of the recent sustained success of the mens team.

title: Skillsofts Primer on Irish Deal-Making
description: Skillsoft said on Thursday that the proxy advisory service RiskMetrics had blessed the companys sale to three private equity firms, Berkshire Partners, Advent International and Bain Capital.

title: Congress Wrestles Over Small-Business Jobs Bill
description: Small businesses got a bit of good news on Wednesday when the House of Representatives passed a short-term job-creation bill. While the thrust of the legislation, which would cost $19 billion over 10 years, is infrastructure programs like Build America Bonds, a financing program for local governments, small businesses won $3.6 billion in tax breaks.

title: Schools Chosen for PCB Study
description: City and federal officials have chosen five schools, one in each borough, for a pilot study to assess the environmental risks posed by PCBs in school buildings.

title: Strength in Structure
description: WHO Martin Canellakis, a writer, and Faith Cromas, a wardrobe stylist

title: Some Skaters Skip Worlds for Post-Olympic Whirl
description: Evan Lysacek, the mens figure skating gold medalist at the Vancouver Games, did not try to defend his title at the world championship this week in Turin, Italy. He had other plans.

title: Pushcart Prize
description: This is the story of competing notions of the Indian-American dream. Place the accent on American, and you imagine the seedbed of modest beginnings flowering into modest, even immodest, empires. Place the accent on Indian, and you imagine rigid confinement within what is considered, even today in India, a low-class occupation  a chaat walla, preparing snacks from a vendors cart, buzzed by flies. It all begins with that deceptively simple word: chaat.

title: Ambac May Seek Bankruptcy After Regulators Step In
description: The Ambac Financial Group warned again on Thursday that it might seek bankruptcy protection after state regulators took control of some of the bond insurers most troubled assets, The Associated Press reports. The news sent the companys already devalued stock into a tailspin.

title: Bada Bing
description: And the Senate passes reconciliation. Atrios explains what comes next:

title: Inflation and Inflation
description: So, while I still think you should read the better text on inflation, I took a look at Mankiw, 2nd edition, which is the version close to hand. He divides the discussion of inflation  monetary, Zimbabwe-type inflation is in Chapter 28, 70s-type stagflation in Chapter 31  but the analysis is essentially the same as in my book, and similarly makes it clear  though not quite as clear  that theyre very different phenomena.

title: The Wizarding World of Harry Potter Will Open to Muggles in June
description: Universal Studios Orlando in Florida said Thursday that its high-profile Harry Potter expansion would open on June 18 and feature a centerpiece ride sending guests soaring over Hogwarts Castle, albeit in a virtual experience. Read more

title: Remix, Reuse, Recombine: Holding a Seminar on Mash-Up Culture
description: Overview | How are the dynamics of the Web affecting how we read, think and create? What is a mash-up, and what does this trend mean for our culture? In this lesson, students reflect on the cultural changes being forged by digital media and prepare and participate in a Socratic seminar on the issues. They then create their own mash-ups and reflect upon what is lost and gained through recombinant or appropriation art.

title: Will Republicans Support Financial Reform?
description: Chris Dodd seems to think he can pull in some GOP senators, and some political commentators agree. But my bet is no. Republicans will still, I believe, be eager to deny Obama any further successes; and theyre eager to curry favor with bankers who dont want their actions monitored by little punk staffers. And I dont think financial reform can be done through reconciliation, so the GOP doesnt have to worry about a Democratic success despite unified opposition.

title: Toyota Creates Quality Task Force
description: Toyota, which has been making a variety of moves after its recalls associated with sudden unintended acceleration in its vehicles, has created a new North American task force charged with improving vehicle quality issues.

title: Gatz to Kick Off Public Theaters New Season
description: In addition to a previously announced new play by Tony Kushner, the Public Theater announced on Thursday five other productions for its 2010-11 season, including the critically acclaimed Gatz  a six-and-a-half-hour staging of The Great Gatsby  as well as new plays by Lisa Kron, Rinne Groff  and Stephen Adly Guirgis.

title: 3 Ex-Madoff Employees Plead Not Guilty in Fraud
description: A former executive with Bernard L. Madoffs investment firm and two other former employees pleaded not guilty on Thursday to charges that they were involved in his enormous Ponzi scheme, The Associated Press reports.

title: Brooklyn Woman Charged in Beating Death
description: Updated, 4:16 p.m. | A 35-year-old home health care worker in Brooklyn was arrested on Thursday on charges she fatally beat the 67-year-old woman she was supposed to be caring for, according to a law enforcement official. She tried to cover up the crime, the authorities said, by saying a man broke into the apartment.

title: Spain Allows Case Against Noted Judge
description: MADRID  Spains Supreme Court announced Thursday that an investigating magistrate could proceed with a case against a crusading judge known internationally for indicting Osama bin Laden and the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet, according to court papers.

title: Urban Cruise Along L.A.s Polluted Coast
description: Its not exactly the Love Boat. A new cruise off the coast of Southern California, near Long Beach and the mouth of the Los Angeles River, showcases how overfishing, offshore oil rigs and heavy industry are hurting marine life.

title: Pushcart Prize
description: In Berkeley, the lure of Indian street food has turned one shop into a culinary sensation.

title: Union Aims to Emulate Sounders and Fire in M.L.S. Debut
description: Friday, March 26 |Sounders Defeat Union

title: Elements of Style
description: With daytime temperatures steadily edging higher each week, its time to start thinking seriously about ones warm-weather wardrobe. Specifically, what hip, intelligent T-shirt do you want to throw on to bolster your SPF for a summer of outdoor reading?

title: New Ways to Gauge the Finite Atmosphere
description: I recently became aware of fascinating efforts by Adam Nieman to help society appreciate environmental challenges in fresh ways by visualizing volumes that are otherwise abstractions. In 2003 he created the image above, illustrating the volume of the worlds oceans and atmosphere (if the air were all at sea-level density) by rendering them as spheres sitting next to the Earth instead of spread out over its surface. To my eye, this helps powerfully convey the finite nature of these shared global assets. In general, I think theres great merit in conceiving and testing new ways to communicate visually on the keystone issues of this blog (energy and climate, population and consumption, the relationship between humans and other life). Click here for his globe showing all the worlds land types as islands (and note how tiny the urban islet is).

title: Student Loan Overhaul Approved by Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Ending one of the fiercest lobbying fights in Washington, Congress voted Thursday to force commercial banks out of the federal student loan market, cutting off billions of dollars in profits in a sweeping restructuring of financial-aid programs and redirecting most of the money to new education initiatives.

title: 24-Hour Bike Shop (Bring Plenty of Quarters)
description: The squat black vending machine sits on the sidewalk on South Sixth Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, outside Traif Bike Gesheft, eliciting curious glances from passers-by and occasionally a more thorough visual inspection.

title: Inside a Troubled Mind, and Mideast Musical Theories
description: Caetano Veloso

title: J. M. W. Turners Last Rome Painting to Be Sold
description: A TURNER ROME PAINTING

title: Kerosene Lamps With a Long Afterglow
description: KEROSENE LAMPS

title: Canadian Banking Is Not the Answer
description: From Peter Boone and Simon Johnson at Economix:

title: Willy Wonka and The Admissions Process
description: This past week, I thought about a scene from one of my favorite films, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. In the scene, a mysterious machine  covered in brightly colored fabric to hide its innermost workings  spins, squeals and squeaks, until: pop! Out comes the Everlasting Gobstopper, a condensed nugget of infinite flavor.

title: Cerberus to Buy Massachusetts Hospital Group
description: Caritas Christi Health Care, the second-largest hospital group in Massachusetts, said Thursday that it had agreed to be acquired by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management in an $830 million deal that hospital officials said would allow the chain to reduce its debt and make major improvements.

title: In Iowa, Obama Calls Health Bill Pro-Business
description: IOWA CITY  President Obama on Thursday began an aggressive White House public relations blitz to sell his newly signed health care overhaul to a skeptical and sometimes confused public, calling the measure pro-jobs and pro-business and taunting Republicans who are vowing to repeal it.

title: Colicchio & Sons Evolves Some More
description: Tom Colicchios reuse of the old Craftsteak space has been a work in progress. When it opened, the menu was a la carte. Then Mr. Colicchio made an attempt to go prix-fixe, charging $78 for three courses, only to return to the original a la carte format a couple of weeks ago, shortly before Sam Siftons three-star review in the Times.

title: Study Shows Building Boom Before Market Crashed
description: A new report shows just how striking the changes in the real estate market have been in New York in recent years. The report, by New York Universitys Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy, reveals that the city gained a remarkable number of new housing units, and then watched the market fall faster than at any time in recent history.In a 140-page report released on Thursday morning, Furman Center researchers found that the city gained 170,000 new housing units from 2000 to 2008. But by 2009, the building boom ground to a halt. Building permits being issued dropped by 90 percent from 2008 to 2009. The city issued fewer permits for new housing units than any time since 1992.

title: Frum Forced Out at Conservative Institute
description: Updated: Over the past week, David Frum, a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research organization, has emerged as one of the leading critics of the way Republicans dealt with President Obamas health care bill.

title: The Medicare Millionaires Tax
description: A reader points out that one statistic in my column on Wednesday about the health care bill may have misled some people. I wrote:

title: Trying to Put Nutrition on the Lunchroom Menu
description: Jamie Olivers Food Revolution on ABC is about the eminently serious topic of what we feed our children. That isnt the sexiest subject for a prime-time reality show  even one hosted by the Naked Chef  so the series has been shaped as a culture clash between an abrasive British interloper and a city of stolid, overweight Americans. Those expecting a substantive look at our school lunch programs wont find it on the menu, but Mr. Olivers travails in the Huntington, W.Va., system can be entertaining in their own right.

title: Design for Eisenhower Memorial Is Selected
description: One of four designs by Frank Gehry for the Eisenhower Memorial has been chosen by the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission for a four-acre site at the base of Capitol Hill in Washington, the commission announced Thursday. Mr. Gehry was selected in March 2009 after a competition through the General Services Administrations Design Excellence Program, which asked him to create several options. In making its selection, below, the commission said it considered aesthetic and thematic issues, environmental impact and estimated construction costs. Still subject to final approval, the memorial will be between Fourth and Sixth Streets SW, south of Independence Avenue. Groundbreaking is planned for August 2012, with an opening scheduled for Memorial Day 2015.

title: A Contemporary Composer, and a Visit From Ophelia
description: Carnegie Hall has been giving the brilliant English composer, conductor and pianist Thomas Ads an unusual showcase for his varied talents. In the second of three concerts, at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening, Mr. Ads led members of the excellent Ensemble ACJW and guest musicians in works of his own and of the contemporary Irish composer Gerald Barry as well as music by Purcell and Brahms.

title: App Study | Tipping Tips
description: For Americans accustomed to traveling in Europe, leaving a few extra coins on a dinner bill has finally developed into a reflex. But remove us from the Continent and all kinds of tipping head scratchers present themselves. Whats a customary gratuity for scuba guides in Costa Rica, cooks for an Andean trek or doctors and nurses in Romania (if you press their flesh with a few bills, theyll press yours)? Beyond the exotic, travelers remain flummoxed by such courtesies as tipping the chambermaid (do so during your stay, not just on departure) and how much to give the concierge ($5 to $10 per request, more if its challenging, and as much as $150 at a luxury hotel, if youve really put him to the test).

title: Beyond the Bunny: Bach and Organs and Sacred Songs
description: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York, from Friday through Easter Sunday. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.)

title: Reflection and Renewal: Choral Works
description: A sampling of choral works for the Easter season in New York. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: In the Air: Parades and Flowers
description: A sampling of seasonal celebrations in New York, including dance, readings and processions. Admission is free unless noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: British Newspaper Sold for 1 to Former K.G.B. Agent
description: The Independent, a British newspaper, was sold for 1 ($1.48) on Thursday to Alexander Lebedev, a Russian billionaire who purchased the London Evening Standard last year for the same price.

title: Afghan Elders Meet in Marja
description: Moises Saman has taken the noteworthy  but not pictorially promising  occasion of a meeting of district leaders in Marja and transformed it into a canvas. Among these leaders are Taliban supporters, so the sense of disorientation in Mr. Samans photograph is well beyond poetic. It might be said to reflect the realities on the ground more than a sharp-edged picture could.

title: Answers From a Career Counselor, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of responses from Michele LoBianco, who teaches Recession Proofing Your Career at the School of Continuing and Professional Studies at New York University.

title: Delays and Delays (Not Tom)
description: Theres a new meme running around which claims that the deficit-reduction estimates for health reform are bogus because Democrats gamed the CBO. What feeds into this perception is the delay in implementing reform, with most of the program not kicking in until 2014. How serious a concern is this?

title: Imagining a More Watery New York
description: Abandoned neighborhoods. Boarded-up harbor facilities. An oil refinery submerged under several feet of brackish water. The Statue of Liberty slowly sinking into the sea.

title: Find a Better Bank
description: Do you really need a branch nearby? Would stopping and restarting your automatic payments with a new bank be that inconvenient? Arent more interest and lower fees worth it over time? Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, explains.

title: Obama Stops to Browse at a Bookstore
description: IOWA CITY  President Obama spent plenty of time in Iowa as a candidate. On Thursday, he had a little homecoming of sorts, making a surprise visit to the Prairie Lights bookstore, a business he had referred to during a campaign-style rally just an hour earlier.

title: Flipping for an iPhone Camcorder
description: Some online commentators have suggested giving your children a Flip recorder as a gift and letting them unleash their inner videographer.

title: Review Your Rewards Card
description: Look up the rules for your rewards card up online. Is there a fee for redeeming them? Are you getting real frequent flier miles that you can combine with those you earn on the plane? Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, explains.

title: Make an Extra Mortgage Payment
description: If you can manage it, pay a bit extra toward your mortgage. You'll pay off your loan years sooner and save many thousands in interest costs. You might be able to make more money by investing the potential extra payment in stocks and bonds, though. Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, explains.

title: G.E.s Love Note to New Deutsche Executive
description: Investment banks love trumpeting big new hires, but Deutsche Bank took things a step further on Thursday when it announced that John Utendahl, a trader turned relationship banker, would be joining the German bank as vice chairman, TheStreet.com reports.

title: Capital of Comfort Food
description: When Eric Ziebold, the chef of CityZen, one of Washingtons most buzzed-about restaurants, opens up a Southern-accented restaurant, local foodies dont waste any time reaching for their forks.

title: Walk a Loved One Through Your Affairs
description: If you were to die, could your family members find all of your financial information and easily close down your accounts? If not, show them where the files are. Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, explains.

title: Home Inventory
description: Tour your home with a video camera and record everything youd want an insurance company to replace. Put a copy of the video someplace safe other than a computer, in case of fire or a hard drive cash. And add up the replacement costs for all of those items to make sure you have enough insurance. Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, explains.

title: A Bigger Sensor for a Coat-Pocket Camera
description: As longtime readers are painfully aware, Im obsessed with big-sensor cameras. Or, rather, with big-sensor cameras that are, themselves, small.

title: Up and Down, Over and Out, Thats Sinatra (and Tharp)
description: The dance floor never clears in the bustling nightclub of Come Fly Away, Twyla Tharps celebration of the music of Frank Sinatra and the heated urgings behind the love songs he performed with such supple sensitivity.

title: First the Tween Heart, Now the Soul
description: LOS ANGELES

title: A Post-and-Beam Home
description: Martin Canellakis, a writer, and his wife, Faith Cromas, a wardrobe stylist, spend time with their 7-year-old daughter, Eva, and their dog, Poppy, in Sheffield, Mass.

title: Amid the Hilly Landscape, Hidden Gems
description: Like its famous Little Red Lighthouse, which is tucked under the George Washington Bridge, Washington Heights conceals its treasures almost too well. But whatever the reason for the modesty, this neighborhood of overflowing plates and Latin rhythms opens up with a little bit of investigation, and some of its secrets are surprising: a jazz club in a living room, for example, and a debutantes vandalism.

title: InvisibleHand Extends Its Reach
description: Black Friday, the big shopping day after Thanksgiving, is still months away. But gift-giving is never really out of season, and gift-giving also never ceases to be a chore for those who are shopping-challenged.

title: The Vanishing Point
description: Australians call the northernmost chunk oftheir continent the Top End, a breezy moniker, as though Australia were a boiled egg sitting upright in an egg cup waiting to be cracked open with a silver spoon. Just how much Top End there is is open to debate, the kind that gets worried out with maps drawn in the dust. While I was there last September, I saw dust maps that gave the

title: David Frum, AEI, Heritage And Health Care
description: David Frum* has been fired by the American Enterprise Institute; one has to assume that this is a response to his outspokenness about the Republican failure on health reform.

title: A Fair Shrinks, but Still Wanders Far
description: It remains to be seen if were living in the twilight of the art fairs. But lately these bellwether organisms have been shifting shapes, changing locations, shrinking or even ceasing operations. In addition, organized clusters of gallery exhibitions, like that of the Asian Art Dealers concluding this weekend, are gaining ground.

title: Mom and Pop Thrillers in Topsy-Turvy World
description: Early in Caught, Harlan Cobens crazily hyperactive new thriller, a wholesome teenage girl named Haley McWaid disappears from her happy New Jersey home. Shes the kind of girl who has a lot of sports trophies in her bedroom and keeps them neatly arranged. Mr. Coben, who occupies the family-guy niche among thriller writers, often takes note of such workaday domestic details.

title: How to Succeed in Business Without Knowing Very Much
description: There are no wrong notes.  Miles Davis

title: 'Jamie Oliver's Food Revolution'
description: The British celebrity chef tries to overhaul a West Virginia town's diet in this ABC reality series.

title: In Galleries, More Treasures From the East
description: If Confucius: His Life and Legacy in Art at China Institute Gallery has a knockout visual attraction, it is the set of hefty enamel-on-copper altar vessels from the Qing dynasty (1644-1911). The set has five components: a round-bellied incense burner; two vases with slithery dragon handles; and a pair of candle holders with bell-shaped bases, capacious receptacle trays and spikes on top.

title: S.E.C. Plans to Review Derivatives Used in Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced Thursday that it was reviewing the use of swaps and other derivatives by mutual funds, exchange-traded funds and other investment products that are often marketed to individual investors.

title: Losing It
description: For 12 years, I had a job I loved as the editor of House & Garden, a magazine that celebrated the good life. It would be an understatement to describe this enterprise as part of a company not primarily in the business of philosophical, spiritual or moral soul-searching. Cond Nasts roots and branches are in the material world. The good life at House & Garden generally meant cultivating your own backyard rather than being involved in the body politic. I pushed against the limits of making a so-called shelter magazine by publishing articles about spiritual issues and the environment, but I always felt clear-eyed about how things stood. I spent more than a decade in the belly of the beast of muchness and more. That was a precarious place to be when the real estate bubble began to leak.

title: McNally Play Is Postponed After Mullally Quits
description: The Broadway revival of Terrence McNallys play Lips Together, Teeth Apart has been postponed for the spring season, the Roundabout Theater Company announced on Thursday. The decision was made after the actress Megan Mullally quit the show this week because of frustration with the inexperience of a co-star, the comedian Patton Oswalt, whom she tried to have replaced, according to four people familiar with her departure.

title: Just Looking | Eva Hesse
description: Last week, a group of art-world heavy hitters (editors, writers, curators, etc.), led by the peripatetic London-based Swiss art dealer Ivan Wirth, were gathered around a large table in the back room of his New York gallery, Hauser & Wirth on East 69th Street, gazing with rapt attention at fragmentary objects that were close to nothing. Hauser & Wirth represents the estate of the sculptor Eva Hesse (1936-70), and assembled on the table were essentially outtakes from her studio delicate, insistently handmade studies in papier-cach (a version of papier-mch), cheesecloth and bits of adhesive. Not quite works in their own right, they were still riveting in their suggestion of themes that had preoccupied Hesse throughout her decade-long career (cut short by her death from brain cancer at age 34): plasticity, an engagement with ephemeral materials, the elusive and incomplete nature of memory, and a redolent corporeality.

title: Playgrounds for Skiers and Snowboarders in New Hampshire
description: LINCOLN, N.H.

title: The Struggles of Stepmothers
description: After reading yesterdays discussion about blending families, a reader led me to an article in the British newspaper The Guardian this week that takes an academic look at stepparenting.

title: Palin Will Be Keynote Speaker at Anti-Abortion Groups Gathering
description: The Susan B. Anthony List, an anti-abortion organization that this week rescinded its support for Representative Bart Stupak, announced earlier today that Sarah Palin, former governor of Alaska, will be its keynote speaker at a May 14 breakfast here in Washington.

title: Georgia Tech Coach Turns Down St. Johns
description: St. Johns struck out on its first attempt in its search for a new mens basketball coach Thursday morning when Georgia Tech Coach Paul Hewitt turned down an offer.

title: Envisioning an Abstraction Who Was Also a Man
description: You be nice to me, and Ill be nice to you. Doesnt that sound like a smart way to run the world? The Chinese philosopher Confucius thought so some 2,500 years ago. He also believed that education, hard work and respect for the past were essential; that excessive anything  money, fun, religion  led to trouble; and that social harmony was best achieved when people interacted courteously, but basically minded their own business.

title: Carnegie Benefit for Haiti: Tracking the Numbers
description: On Sunday night, the Chinese pianist Lang Lang announced from the stage of Carnegie Hall, at a concert billed as a benefit for victims of the Haiti earthquake, that the generosity of the participating artists and some corporations had allowed us to raise $100,000 for Unicef so far.

title: McNally Play Is Postponed After Mullallys Departure
description: The Broadway revival of Terrence McNallys play Lips Together, Teeth Apart has been postponed for the spring season, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Thursday. The decision was made after the actress Megan Mullally quit the show this week because of frustration with the inexperience of one of her co-stars, the comedian Patton Oswalt, whom she tried to have replaced, according to four people familiar with her departure. Read more here.

title: Lorin Maazel to Lead Munich Philharmonic
description: Lorin Maazel, below, the venerated maestro who ended his term as the music director of the New York Philharmonic last year, has been appointed chief conductor of the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra, the orchestra said on its Web site. His appointment will be effective with the 2012-13 season. Mr. Maazel, a highly visible figure in Munich when he served as the chief conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony, said in a statement that the quality of the orchestra is unsurpassed, and that following in the footsteps of previous conductors like Sergiu Celibidache, who conducted the Munich orchestra until his death in 1996, represents a challenge that he will take on with joy.

title: Design for Eisenhower Memorial Is Selected
description: One of four designs by Frank Gehry for the Eisenhower Memorial has been chosen by the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission for a four-acre site at the base of Capitol Hill in Washington, the commission announced Thursday. Mr. Gehry was selected in March 2009 after a competition through the General Services Administrations Design Excellence Program, which asked him to create several options. In making its selection, below, the commission said it considered aesthetic and thematic issues, environmental impact and estimated construction costs. Still subject to final approval, the memorial will be between Fourth and Sixth Streets SW, south of Independence Avenue. Groundbreaking is planned for August 2012, with an opening scheduled for Memorial Day 2015.

title: Public TV to Finance Regional News Projects
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, looking to counter what it sees as a decline in local journalism and original reporting nationwide, says it will provide money to set up seven regional reporting projects teaming public radio and television stations. The Local Journalism Centers, as they are being called, will hire reporters and editors to report on issues of regional relevance, including the reinvention of the industrial upper Midwest economy, efforts in upstate New York to attract innovative businesses, and agribusiness in the Great Plains. The ideas for what to cover came from the stations themselves, said Patricia Harrison, the president and chief executive of the corporation. These stations are looking at issues they think need a much deeper dive than they are getting now, she said. The corporation, which administers federal funds for public broadcasting, will invest $7.5 million in the project over two years, with $3 million more coming from local stations.

title: Phish in 3-D That Everyone Can See
description: Hmm. Can you think of any reason why the fans of a popular jam band might enjoy the experience of seeing their favorite musicians in a movie presented in 3-D? Off the top of our heads, we couldnt, but were still reasonably certain that a new 3-D film featuring Phish will find its audience. Phish 3D, which will receive a theatrical release in April, offers footage from the bands Festival 8 concerts in Indio, Calif., in October and November  this time with effects that require only the wearing of special glasses to be seen. Compiled from more than 16 hours of performances, Phish 3D has a downright economical running time of just over two hours (though your overall experience may vary) and will include songs from the bands start-to-finish cover of the Rolling Stones album Exile on Main Street, as well as its acoustic set. Sneak preview screenings for Phish 3D, will take place on  when else?  4/20, followed by its official opening on April 30. More information can be found at phish3dmovie.com. Tickets do not include admission to post-screening drum circles.

title: Idol Finalist Eliminated
description: The American Idol finalist Paige Miles failed to make the cut on Wednesday as the shows results episode attracted the nights largest audience in prime time, 21 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. Fox finished No. 1 for the night over all, even as its action series Human Target (6.8 million) struggled opposite CBSs Survivor (10.9 million). CBS ranked second with a lineup that also included reruns of Criminal Minds (8.3 million) and CSI: NY (7.6 million). NBC placed third and ABC was fourth.

title: Shortlist Unveiled for Lost Booker Prize
description: In an act of literary reparation, the Booker Prize Foundation, which bestows Britains most prestigious book prize, has named a shortlist of books published in 1970 that were never eligible for the Man Booker Prize because of a change in the award calendar. A three-judge panel unveiled the shortlist for the so-called Lost Man Booker Prize on Thursday, featuring six authors whose works are still in print. They are: The Birds on the Trees by Nina Bawden, Troubles by J. G. Farrell, The Bay of Noon by Shirley Hazzard, Fire From Heaven by Mary Renault, The Drivers Seat by Muriel Spark and The Vivisector by Patrick White. The winner, to be announced May 19, will be chosen by voters who make a selection on the Man Booker Prize Web site (themanbookerprize.com).

title: Gatz to Kick Off Public Theaters 2010-11 Season
description: In addition to a previously announced new play by Tony Kushner, the Public Theater on Thursday named five other shows for its 2010-11 season, including the critically acclaimed Gatz  a six-and-a-half hour staging of The Great Gatsby  as well as new plays by Lisa Kron (the author of Well), Rinne Groff and Stephen Adly Guirgis. The season will begin with Gatz, a production by Elevator Repair Service. It will be presented with two intermissions and a dinner break four times a week from Sept. 26 to Oct. 31. Ms. Krons new play, In the Wake, described by the Public as a wry meditation on love and country, will be directed by Leigh Silverman and run Oct. 19 to Nov. 21. The Tricycle Theater Companys play The Great Game: Afghanistan, about the culture and history of that nation as portrayed by an amalgam of playwrights and people involved in the American-led war there, will run at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts from Nov. 30 to Dec. 19. Ms. Groffs play Compulsion, about the legacy of Anne Frank, will run from Feb. 1 to March 6, 2011, and will be directed by the Publics artistic director, Oskar Eustis. The Publics season will conclude with Mr. Guirgiss new play (the title includes an obscenity), a presentation by LAByrinth Theater Company and the Public, scheduled to run in the spring of 2011.

title: 4 Schools Eliminate Waiting Lists
description: The wait is over. At least for some.

title: Monkey Business in a World of Evil
description: You dont really think about Curious George saving the day, as the title of the new exhibition at the Jewish Museum puts it. A good little monkey, he is called in the classic series of picture books by Margret and H. A. Rey, but he was no savior. He was a mischief maker, an innocent, born in the jungle and lured into the strange world of humans.

title: How Cornell Got So Good
description: SYRACUSE  When Cornell takes the floor Thursday for the most important moment in the programs history against top-seeded Kentucky in the Round of 16, two of the people responsible for building the Big Reds storied senior class will be nearby.

title: No Slaying Required: A Viking Aids an Enemy and Wins a Friend
description: The story told by How to Train Your Dragon  the new 3-D feature from DreamWorks Animation  is a fairly standard one, exploring themes that are so familiar in the universe of all-ages cinema that they hardly need elaborating. The hero, a young Viking named Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel), is a misfit adolescent who proves his mettle, pleases his hard-to-please father (Gerard Butler) and saves the world while learning important lessons and rattling off some wisecracks. Supporting characters include a spitfire love interest (America Ferrera), a gaggle of goofy friends (including the inevitable Jonah Hill and Christopher Mintz-Plasse), a crusty old mentor (Craig Ferguson) and a cute nonhuman sidekick.

title: Live Updates From the N.C.A.A. Tournaments Round of 16
description: Live coverage and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Pete Thamel will provide updates from Syracuse, and Billy Witz from Salt Lake City. Two longtime Quad contributors who have played in the tournament, Stephen Danley (Penn) and Zach Hillesland (Notre Dame), will also weigh in.

title: Palin to Star in a Documentary Series About Alaska
description: Pretty soon Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor, will be Sarah Palin, the Alaska documentary host.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

title: A Life to Live, This Side of the Bars
description: AS we were about to leave the prison that day, one of the guys asked, somewhat apologetically, if any of us would mind stopping at Trader Joes before heading back to New York. I had been going to the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury, Conn., for six months and had no idea there was a Trader Joes nearby.

title: Pat the Enormous Bunny
description: You, too, can meet Herbie the ginormous Flemish rabbit at the Prospect Park Zoo this weekend. Herbie, 18 pounds and, according to a zoo spokeswoman, Fran Hackett, such a mush, is a regular in the lineup these days at the zoos Live Animal Encounters program, held four times an afternoon on Saturdays and Sundays.

title: Jazz Listings
description: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: Lions Gate Appears to End Bid for MGM
description: Lions Gate Entertainment appears to have dropped out of the bidding for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

title: Times May Change, but Regret Endures
description: Hot Tub Time Machine is the poignant story of three men, adrift in their 40s, who try to recapture the lost joys and squandered possibilities of their youth. Im not entirely joking, though the movie itself is a nonstop barrage  somewhere between a riot and an orgy  of crude, obnoxious gags and riffs. If you are a connoisseur of sexual, scatological or just plain stupid humor, you will find your appetite satisfied, even glutted. But viewers of a certain age and background  lets say those who know the lyrics to Jessies Girl by heart, even if they never really liked that song  are likely to endure the merry anarchy with a twinge of pained, slightly nauseated nostalgia.

title: Movie Listings
description: MOVIES

title: Gang Colors in the Set, Part of a Rappers Scheme
description: There arent many generators of good will in New York currently more effective than Beamer, Benz or Bentley, the creeping, slightly sinister collaboration between Lloyd Banks and Juelz Santana, a radio staple and the foundation for dozens of remixes.

title: A-Rods Landlord Swings for the Bleachers
description: WHAT do Alex Rodriguez, the highest-paid player in baseball, and Henry Silverman, the billionaire who founded the Cendant Corporation, have in common? Besides piles of money, they share a landlord  Leroy Schecter, the 82-year-old steel magnate who owns the apartments they rent at 15 Central Park West.

title: Schrager Checks In and Out
description: IAN SCHRAGER, the hotelier and long-ago co-founder of Studio 54, says on the Web site for his eponymous real estate company that he always made it a habit to live in his hotels for a while in order to shake them down and make sure they functioned correctly. So it should come as no surprise that he now lives in a building he developed, 40 Bond Street, a condo that he describes as a radical redesign of a traditional cast-iron building. His perch in the place, which has hotel services, is a triplex penthouse.

title: Heat-Toting Ocean Currents Chugging Along
description: Heres a brief update on the great heat-toting oceanic currents that at one time were thought to be at risk from human-driven warming of the climate. Theres been no slowdown at all through much of the past decade and probably none since the early 1990s, according to new work using methods developed by Joshua Willis at NASAs Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

title: A D.J.s Place, With Sound-Proofing
description: ADAM GOLDSTEIN, better known as DJ AM, was a disc jockey to the stars. He worked on albums for Madonna and Will Smith. He dated Nicole Richie and Mandy Moore. And as if that werent enough fodder for the tabloids, he appeared on a reality TV show as a recovering addict.

title: Final Season for At the Movies
description: THE balcony is closed, this time for good. After nearly three decades, At the Movies, the syndicated television program that introduced many viewers to the film critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert, as well as to film criticism in all its thorny and contentious glory, will cease production this summer.

title: Dance Listings
description: Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

title: Caught
description: Prologue

title: Despite Authoritarian Rule, Myanmar Art Grows
description: YANGON, Myanmar  The dance music thundered through a crowd of thousands of drunken fans, past the pavilions where skinny women in impossibly high heels gyrated around metal poles and into the streets filled with taxis that ferried partygoers to this free, whiskey-soaked concert in the park.

title: Erasmus Hall and Its Offspring
description: PASSERS-BY can glimpse it only through iron gates, but the 1786 Erasmus Hall Academy, on Flatbush Avenue off Church in Brooklyn, appears to be the oldest school structure in New York. Empty for years and now dilapidated, the academy building is a designated landmark, enclosed within the vast courtyard of the Gothic-style Erasmus Hall High School, another landmark. Together they anchor a pinwheel of scholastic architectural history spanning two centuries.

title: Never Look Away
description: Detective Duckworth and I headed north, but in under a mile he put on his blinker and turned down a narrow gravel road that went down, then up, winding all the time. The inside of Duckworth's car smelled of french fries. The smell made me feel sick to my stomach.

title: Whitney Biennial Events
description: In the video Detroit, the artist Ari Marcopoulos captures two adolescent boys crawling around in a smallish room, manipulating the pedals of an amplifier to create distorted tones that veer between simply noise and coherent song.

title: Where the Water Tanks Were
description: FOR co-ops desperate for new ways to increase income, consider what the St. George Tower in Brooklyn Heights has decided to do. The co-op board for the Tower, a 27-story building at 111 Hicks Street, looked up one day and decided to sell the enclosed former home of the buildings water tanks for reuse as a 30th-floor penthouse apartment with a roof terrace. The price tag is $2.495 million.

title: St. Marys Is Running With the Giants
description: MORAGA, Calif.  As a reggae band jammed and the tangy aroma from a barbecue grill wafted through the commons, students at St. Marys College seemed to be making good use of the three hours each Wednesday when no classes are scheduled. It is called community time, and as the students soaked up the sights, smells, sounds and sunshine of a beautiful spring day, it was hard to tell this was midterm week.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Just a Friendly Game of Paintball
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  While Alex Rodriguez is speaking with federal investigators in Buffalo on Friday morning, his manager and general manager, along with Yankee staffers and a few baseball writers, will be playing paintball at a suburban Tampa facility.

title: 46 Circus Acts in 45 Minutes
description: Wheres Jack Bauer?

title: More Doctors Giving Up Private Practices
description: WASHINGTON  A quiet revolution is transforming how medical care is delivered in this country, and it has very little to do with the sweeping health care legislation that President Obama just signed into law.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Reyes, Day 2: All Is Well
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jose Reyes went through his second day of working out Thursday and added a little zip to it. Reyes took ground balls at shortstop and hit with the other players for the first time. Afterward he ran harder than he did the day before, and reported no problems.

title: Conflicting Demands Test Netanyahu
description: JERUSALEM  After contentious meetings in the White House, Israels prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, returned home on Thursday with the politically explosive task of responding to an unyielding American demand that he limit Israeli building in East Jerusalem.

title: Bernanke Hints at Timing and Pace of Exit Strategy
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, hinted on Thursday that the central bank might be open to selling part of its huge portfolio of mortgage-backed securities when the time comes to start tightening credit, Sewell Chan of The New York Times reports from Washington.

title: Theater Listings: March 26  April 1
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1. A female breadwinner raises the likelihood of divorce, according to a study of German couples. Not such a great pattern considering the continuing international mancession.

title: Two Centuries of Schools
description: A block in the middle of Brooklyn has two centuries of civil architecture.

title: Reaching the End of the Trail
description: EVEN as I proposed the ski trip to my brother, I worried I was out of my mind. It had been eight years since Id skied, and Id never been very good. At my best, intermediate trails were a challenge. On top of this, my last ski trip with my three sons had been a disaster. My oldest, Ben, an eighth grader at the time, had gone barreling off the trail, hitting a tree. I spent one of the worst nights of my life as a father, in an emergency room in Albany, waiting to see if Bens back was broken.

title: Inside the List
description: ALPHA DOG: Duane Chapman, the star of the hit A&E reality show Dog the Bounty Hunter, scored a No. 1 best seller in 2007 with You Can Run but You Cant Hide. Now Dog is back with a new book, Where Mercy Is Shown, Mercy Is Given, which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 15.

title: Line2 for iPhone
description: David Pogue tests Line2, an iPhone application that allows users to set up a second phone line, which can make calls over the AT&T network or over the Internet.

title: Arundathi Jayatilleke and Michael Gelfand
description: IT was September 1998, and Michael Gelfand was racing up the steps of Harkness Tower at Yale. The steep climb led to a carillon lesson, which itself would lead to an audition for the Guild of Carillonneurs, who play the 54 bells in the tower. Suddenly he stopped and stared.

title: S.E.C. Reviews Derivative Use by Some Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced Thursday that it was reviewing the use of swaps and other derivatives by mutual funds, exchange-traded funds and other investment products that are often marketed to individual investors, Edward Wyatt of The New York Times reports.

title: Better Ways to Help the Public Lose Weight
description: It seems like everywhere we turn  whether its bans on school bake sales, required calorie counts in fast food chains, or First Lady Michelle Obama toiling in her White House garden  we are being told to watch our weight. Theres even the national Campaign to End Obesity, which is dedicated to reversing Americas costliest medical condition and advocates for federal policies that promote healthy weight.

title: False Security of Wealth: A Tale Turns Cautionary
description: In Bluebeard, a sly rethink of the freakily morbid fairy tale, the filmmaker Catherine Breillat makes the case that once-upon-a-time stories never end. Divided into two parallel narratives  one focuses on Bluebeard and his dangerously curious wife, while the other involves two little girls in the modern era revisiting the tale  the movie is at once direct, complex and peculiar. It isnt at all surprising that Ms. Breillat, a singular French filmmaker with strong, often unorthodox views on women and men and sex and power, would have been interested in a troubling tale about the perils of disobedient wives. Ms. Breillat never behaves.

title: Proposed Tax Breaks for Ponzi Victims
description: Tens of thousands of Ponzi scheme victims across the country would get special tax breaks under a bipartisan bill introduced in the Senate on Thursday by Senators Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona.

title: What Were Reading: Wii Movies, Spam and Dog Collars
description: This bunch of headlines sound as if they were written by the folks atThe Onion, but only one really was. Heres what caught the eyes of the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times on Thursday:

title: Chvez Critic Is Arrested, Then Freed, in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Agents from Venezuelas military intelligence agency on Thursday arrested Guillermo Zuloaga, the owner of the independent television network Globovisin and one of the countrys most influential critics of President Hugo Chvez, heightening concerns over an intensifying clampdown on news organizations and opposition political leaders.

title: Love Triangle Devised by a Wary Wife
description: There are grown-up moviegoers who will appreciate Chloe  a titillating piece of fromage directed by Atom Egoyan from a script by Erin Cressida Wilson  for its psychological insights and its ideas about identity and desire in modern life. There are also teenage boys who get a hold of Playboy for the articles.

title: Shelby Criticizes Reform Bill, Saying It Wont End Too Big to Fail Problem
description: WASHINGTON  The Democratic bill to overhaul the nations financial system would not end the too big to fail phenomenon or adequately protect taxpayers from having to bail out large companies, a leading Republican senator said on Thursday.

title: U.S. Plans Big Expansion in Effort to Aid Homeowners
description: The Obama administration on Friday will announce broad new initiatives to help troubled homeowners, potentially refinancing several million of them into fresh government-backed mortgages with lower payments.

title: Pay Surges for Credit Suisse Chief Executive
description: The Credit Suisse Groups chief executive, Brady Dougan, received 19.2 million Swiss francs ($18 million) in compensation last year, increasing his salary almost sevenfold.

title: Bin Laden Threatens Any Americans Held
description: WASHINGTON  In a 74-second audio message released on Thursday, Osama bin Laden threatened to kill any Americans held by Al Qaeda if Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the chief planner of the Sept. 11 attacks, is executed.

title: Restlessness in Russias Western Outpost
description: KALININGRAD, Russia  Amid the sagging Soviet-era apartment blocks and hulking government buildings here, it can be difficult to imagine that this was once a German city graced with gingerbread-style facades and Teutonic spires.

title: As Murkiness Descends, Ghosts Grow Restless
description: A moody little number, The Eclipse makes good on its name by sometimes obscuring its themes and even point, which can have its charms though also severe drawbacks. Ciaran Hinds, an actor with a thousand and one gloomy (glum, dour, sour, grim, deathly) faces, plays Michael Farr, a widower who lives quietly with his two children and photos of his dead wife hanging on the kitchen wall. A teacher and writer who does less scribbling than instruction, Michael (and his dog) has started to hear things go bump in the night, leading him into the shadows where a figure suggests he might be haunted in more ways than one.

title: U.S. and Pakistan Agree to Reinforce Strategic Ties
description: WASHINGTON  Pakistan and the United States wrapped up two days of high-level talks on Thursday, with a raft of economic development initiatives, an agreement to hasten deliveries of military hardware and a promise to put their often mistrustful relationship on a new footing.

title: 'Logarithms? You Understood Those?'
description: David, Bruce Willis's character from "Moonlighting," on logarithms.

title: Prejudices Poison
description: How do domestic abuse and chronic alcoholism drive entire neighborhoods to ruin? How can drug trafficking and ethnic violence transform a vast public housing complex into a war zone? These are the sorts of questions raised by the gutsy Scottish writer Denise Mina in two series of sociologically freighted novels set in Glasgow. Each comes with its own locally born and bred (and nearly broken) female protagonist, one a social worker and the other a reporter, who approach crime by going to the root of it and asking how a civilized society can allow such injustice to flourish.

title: Hughes Earns Decision: Hes Yanks Fifth Starter
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  If Phil Hughes was the front-runner for the Yankees fifth starter job all along, he never acted that way. He kept working and throwing his changeup, which improved as spring training went along.

title: Up Front: Linda Gordon
description: Earlier this month, Linda Gordon won the Bancroft Prize in American history for her book Dorothea Lange: A Life Beyond Limits.

title: A Studio, Animated
description: Don Hahn and Peter Schneider, the director and producer of "Waking Sleeping Beauty," discuss some of the illustrations featured in the film.

title: Tentative Deal Struck for 2 Ground Zero Towers
description: The Port Authority, government officials and the developer Larry A. Silverstein reached a tentative agreement Thursday that would allow for the construction of two new skyscrapers at ground zero with up to $1.6 billion in public financing and subsidies.

title: Choosing Not to Forget What Is Painful to Recall
description: On a street off Washington Square, a bell tolled 146 times on Thursday, once for each woman and man who died in the great fire there so very long ago. Dozens of schoolchildren read the names of the victims, one by one, then laid carnations upon a makeshift memorial. A fire truck raised its ladder in tribute but only so far  a reminder of a rescue effort that fell tragically short.

title: Playground Jail, Drawing Outrage, Gets a Face-Lift
description: Playground controversies usually involve bickering parents, unruly dogs or bullies.

title: A Look at Famous Fables That Sing on the Screen
description: Waking Sleeping Beauty is a moderately engaging documentary about the renaissance of Disney animation during the golden decade (1984-94) that yielded The Little Mermaid, Beauty and the Beast, Aladdin and The Lion King. Directed by Don Hahn, the producer of Beauty and the Beast and The Lion King, the movie is a sly retrospective exercise in corporate self-congratulation masquerading as an insiders tell-all.

title: The Widening Scandal in the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: SHADOW AND LIGHT,  by Jonathan Rabb (Picador, $15.) Its 1927, and Nikolai Hoffner, a detective inspector for Berlins criminal investigations unit (and the protagonist of Rabbs earlier novel Rosa) is asked to investigate the suspicious death of a producer at a film studio. The producer, it develops, has ties to a right-wing militia and a secret society that is trying to take over the studio so it can promote its ideological agenda, and even Hoffners own son has become a Nazi. Our reviewer, Joshua Hammer, found the plot overly complicated but praised Rabbs gift for capturing the intoxicating  and toxic  atmosphere of post-World War I Berlin.

title: Ryan Happy With HBOs Rex in City
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets Coach Rex Ryan stood behind the lectern in a packed auditorium, so the room was all his. Even though he is slimmer than he was three months ago, his sense of humor has not shriveled  and neither has his bravado.

title: Citys Unemployment Rate Fell Last Month to 10.2%
description: New York Citys unemployment rate dipped again in February, raising hopes that the effects of the long recession are waning and the pace of hiring may pick up soon.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: SAFE FROM THE NEIGHBORS  By Steve Yarbrough.  Knopf, $25.95.

title: Council Approves Legislation to Hold Process Servers Accountable
description: It is a fairly unglamorous and lightly regulated task: serving legal papers to people who have been sued. Debt collection agencies and lawyers often farm out the work to private companies, which deliver the papers in person or by mail. They are known, in legal parlance, as process servers.

title: Before McDonalds
description: How important was Fred Harvey? Stephen Frieds Appetite for America says that as the nations first popular champion of fine dining, he invented chain restaurants, chain hotels and chain bookstores; glamorized train travel; pioneered cultural tourism; and as the writer Frank Waters put it, introduced America to Americans. Harvey Girls, who staffed company restaurants at railroad depots throughout the West, were the first major female work force in America. Prior to Coca-Cola, Fred Harvey was our biggest brand name.

title: Between Ordinary and Ecstatic
description: Contemporary American poetry is sometimes panned for being mundane. With all the splendor and terror in the world, why should we care about some guys memories of high school, or the quality time he spends with his cat? Glancing over it, you might suspect that Edward Hirschs poetry would lend evidence to this view. Hirsch will begin a poem with a line like Today I am pulling on a green wool sweater or Traffic was heavy coming off the bridge. Neither opening seems to burn with that hard, gemlike flame.

title: City Council Is Losing Its Home, Temporarily
description: At City Hall, democracy is about to leave the building.

title: A Mind of His Own
description: Many scientists are cautious to a fault when it comes to telling us what theyre unsure of, playing down any novel finding that hasnt been verified by another scientist. Not so Louann Brizendine. She is a neuropsychiatrist (the prefix makes any title sound smarter) who has put her professional training behind a breezy, incautious account of how the brain, urged on by hormones, makes men and women act completely differently. Youd never know from reading Brizendine that beneath the sea she blithely sails are depths that researchers have only just begun to chart.

title: The Land of Lock and Key
description: Prisons are sacred places. There our society claims control over the lives of men and women; there we assume the roles of gods. And whether the prison sprawls over thousands of acres like the penitentiary farms of the Deep South, or compresses its convicts on tight tiers, the air within holds a particular density, a palpable weight created not only by the crimes the inmates have committed but also by the ownership we have taken of the convicts, whether we acknowledge it or not.

title: Traveling Woman
description: She was neither the first nor the last diplomatic wife to receive the directive, later reduced to six words: Pay, pack and follow, at convenience. The version that reached Louisa Catherine Adams in January 1815 was less succinct  her husband was John Adamss son after all  but she could hardly have complied more swiftly. In three weeks she had crated up the St. Petersburg household, settled the accounts and prepared to set off, across 2,000 miles, to join her husband in Paris. It was winter. Europe remained pockmarked by the Napoleonic Wars. With her Mrs. Adams would take knives and forks; hidden bags of gold and silver; a governess; two servants, one of them trustworthy; and 7-year-old Charles Francis Adams, whose third language was English. They set out late on the afternoon of Feb. 12. It was Mrs. Adamss 40th birthday.

title: Consumed
description: Gabrielle Zevins timely new novel is full of holes, beginning with its title, The Hole Were In. The holes start small  in stockings, a nightgown, the backyard  but as they keep appearing, they grow deeper and harder to ignore. So does the metaphor. During the bubble years, encouraged by cheap credit and instant gratification, we got used to living beyond our means, ignoring the consequences. The Hole Were In criticizes our rabid consumer culture, as well as the people whove bought into it without examining the actual or hidden costs.

title: Please Pass the Baby
description: Perhaps youve heard of a controversial animal study that took place half a century ago at the University of Wisconsin. Known as the wire mother experiment, it was overseen by a psychologist named Harry Harlow, who separated baby rhesus monkeys from their birth mothers and placed them with mother surrogates: one a cylinder of rolled chicken wire, the other a block of wood covered in terry cloth, both rigged, in alternating experiments, to provide or withhold milk.
