The scientists wanted to see how important contact comfort was to an infants attachment to its mother  whether, given the choice, a baby preferred a mother that fed it or one that cuddled it. The babies, they were surprised to discover, overwhelmingly chose softness over sustenance.

title: What Lies Beneath
description: Moby-Dick is often viewed as a singularly American creation. Part of the beguiling genius of The Whale, a rhapsodic meditation on all things cetacean, is that Philip Hoare so suggestively explores the English origins of Herman Melvilles masterpiece while providing his own quirky, often revelatory take on the more familiar aspects of the novel. But The Whale is about much more than the literary sources of Moby-Dick. Always in the foreground of Hoares narrative is the whale itself, a creature that haunts and fascinates him as he travels to old whaling ports in both Britain and America, where he speaks with cetologists, naturalists, museum curators and former whalers on a quest to understand the whale, the cosmos and himself.

title: With Justices for All
description: In 1937, a few months after his landslide re-election to a second term, Franklin Roosevelt set out on one of the boldest and most dangerous courses of his presidency. The conservative Supreme Court had already struck down a series of New Deal programs. Roosevelt feared that the mostly aged justices would go on to destroy the rest of his legislative achievements before he would have a chance to make any new appointments. As a result, he proposed a reform of the courts that would, among other things, have added an additional justice to the Supreme Court for every current justice over the age of 70. It became the most controversial proposal of his presidency  so much so that it nearly paralyzed his administration for over a year and destroyed much of the fragile unity of the Democratic coalition.

title: Toronto Plays Itself
description: Atom Egoyan, the director of "Chloe," discusses his use of Toronto locations in the film.

title: On the Seventh Day
description: It is the Fourth Commandment of the time-honored Ten. Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy.

title: Honor Among Base Stealers
description: Professional baseball is a society, of sorts, and The Baseball Codes is a book of casual sociology. The premise is that ballplayers, managers, coaches and various other participants in the culture of baseball are all clued in to a value system, a mode of behavior that defines a gauzy ideal: the right way to play the game.

title: Can We Work It Out?
description: A number of years ago on a camping trip with another couple, I had a dreadful fight with the man who was then my boyfriend while we were hiking up the mountain. Well ahead, we paused in a clearing to holler at each other, when the other couple poked their heads through the brush. Later, mortified, I apologized to my friend. Oh, please, she replied. I was grateful! Eavesdropping on our battle, she and her boyfriend had consoled themselves: At least we dont argue about that.

title: American Terror Suspect Traveled Unimpeded
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An American charged with helping plan the 2008 terrorist attacks in Mumbai, India, moved effortlessly between the United States, Pakistan and India for nearly seven years, training at a militant camp in Pakistan on five occasions, according to a plea agreement released by the Justice Department last week.

title: Whos White?
description: Nell Irvin Painters title, The History of White People, is a provocation in several ways: its monumental in sweep, and its absurd grandiosity should call to mind the fact that writing a History of Black People might seem perfectly reasonable to white people. But the title is literally accurate, because the book traces characterizations of the lighter-skinned people we call white today, starting with the ancient Scythians. For those who have not yet registered how much these characterizations have changed, let me assure you that sensory observation was not the basis of racial nomenclature.

title: Paterson Seen With Key Role in Abuse Case
description: This article is by Danny Hakim, William K. Rashbaum and David Kocieniewski.

title: Cap and Trade Loses Its Standing as Energy Policy of Choice
description: WASHINGTON  Less than a year ago, cap and trade was the policy of choice for tackling climate change.

title: Audit Faults Honor System for Aid to Citys Homeless
description: The Bloomberg administration has done a poor job of monitoring nonprofit agencies that provide services to the homeless, doling out more than $152 million in handshake deals in 2008 to providers that did not have contracts, according to an audit released on Thursday by John C. Liu, the city comptroller.

title: To Sweeten Its Proposal, N.Y.U. Offers School Space
description: In the first move of what will most likely be a major charm offensive, New York University, which is proposing to expand in size by 40 percent over the next 20 years, announced on Thursday that it would donate space in a future university building for a new Greenwich Village elementary school.

title: Treaty Advances Obamas Nuclear Vision
description: WASHINGTON  The arms control treaty being completed by the United States and Russia represents another step toward closing the books on the defining struggle of the final half of the 20th century. But it also marks the opening of a broader campaign to counter the emerging threats of the 21st century.

title: Mets Rodriguez Guides Juan Urbina and His Teammates
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  On March 2, Francisco Rodriguez received a call from a cellphone inside the Penitenciaria General de Venezuela, a maximum-security prison in San Juan de los Morros, Venezuela.

title: About Obesity
description: For a movie about a man who doesnt let any food go to waste, Lbs. has spent an awfully long time on the shelf. Cast in 2000, filmed beginning in 2001 and first shown at Sundance in 2004, it arrives in theaters six years later just in time to capitalize on Michelle Obamas anti-obesity campaign.

title: U.S. Official Defends Contractors Mission
description: SAN ANTONIO  A Defense Department official who is suspected of using private contractors in Afghanistan to help track and kill militants has denied that he did anything wrong, and he asserted that all his work had been approved by top American military commanders.

title: Its a Bird!
description: "Birdemic: Shock and Terror" is a would-be thriller about avian rampage. Directed and written by James Nguyen, the movie was made for just $10,000 as a tribute to Mr. Nguyen's favorite director, Alfred Hitchcock. "Since 'Birdemic' was discovered at the 2009 Sundance Film Festival  where Mr. Nguyen brought it anyway and showed it in bars after it was rejected by the festival's selection committee  it has become a cult hit on the midnight movie circuit," Dave Itzkoff writes. "Crowds in Austin, Tex., Phoenix and Los Angeles have thrilled to its stilted dialogue, substandard production values and young heroes who defend themselves with coat hangers." The movie has "spawned a discussion about why, of all the Z-grade movies that are made each year, this particular one should find favor with audiences. What has made Mr. Nguyen a latter-day anti-genius to rival Edward D. Wood Jr., whose 1959 horror dud "Plan 9 From Outer Space" became legendary for its countless defects?" Find out tonight and Saturday when IFC Center screens the movie at midnight.

title: Cultural Mashup
description: "Growing up in Benin, Anglique Kidjo didn't hear only African music," Jon Pareles writes. "From America there were soul and Santana; from India there were Bollywood musicals. Her father loved jazz. They all had an effect on the music she would make herself, with her strong, wide-open voice riding African-rooted but thoroughly international arrangements." She "now applies her grown-up style to songs she learned from Miriam Makeba, Aretha Franklin and Curtis Mayfield, among others; the guitars and drums often have an Afropop lilt." Tonight listen to these songs as well as others from her new album, "Oyo." She'll be at Town Hall.

title: Cyclone Hits
description: Come Sunday, it will officially be spring, at least in our humble opinion. That's when the Coney Island Cyclone, the beloved roller coaster, will open for the season. The festivities begin at 11:30 a.m., with the first roller-coaster ride kicking into gear at noon. Go early: The first 100 riders go free. The ride is generally open from noon to 8 p.m. daily, depending on the weather. Hours vary during the spring and summer.

title: Lawmaker Is Acquitted of Drunken Driving but Convicted of Lesser Charge
description: A Manhattan jury acquitted Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV on Thursday of drunken driving but found him guilty of a lesser charge, driving while ability impaired.

title: Pope May Be at Crossroads on Abuse, Forced to Reconcile Policy and Words
description: ROME  Even as Pope Benedict XVI, faced with a sexual abuse scandal spreading across Europe, has called on victims to come forward and urged clerics to cooperate with civil justice, those strong words are running up against the complexities of his past.

title: China Officials Wrestle Publicly Over Currency
description: BEIJING  Signs are emerging of conflicting views among Chinas leaders over whether to allow the countrys currency to rise against the dollar.

title: Duke Feeling Pressure to Advance
description: HOUSTON  Duke is well aware that its last national championship came nearly a decade ago.

title: Vivian Blake, 54, Founder of Jamaica Drug Gang, Dies
description: Vivian Blake, a former top leader of the Jamaican Shower Posse, which United States prosecutors say was responsible for more than 1,400 drug-related killings in this country in the 1980s, died Sunday night in Kingston, Jamaica. He was 54.

title: Emirate Offers to Help Restructure Dubai World
description: Dubai moved on Thursday to recapitalize two companies at the heart of a financial crisis that shook global markets last autumn, saying that it would inject up to $9.5 billion into Dubai World and its property subsidiary and would seek to repay all creditors within eight years.

title: Past Decade Was Warmest on Record, Meteorological Agency Reports
description: The last decade was the warmest on record, the World Meteorological Organization said in a report on Thursday. The finding by the association, a United Nations agency, corroborates research by NASAs Goddard Institute for Space Studies, which has already said that its measurements show that the period from 2000 to 2009 was the warmest since modern instrumental recording of temperatures began in the 1850s.

title: France: Sarkozy Rival Forms New Party
description: Former Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, left, announced a new center-right party on Thursday, confirming expectations he is likely to challenge Nicolas Sarkozy for the presidency in 2012. The two, both ministers under Jacques Chirac, are bitter rivals. Mr. Sarkozy was hurt by a bad showing in regional elections, and while Mr. de Villepin said he was uneasy with the politics practiced today by the majority, he is considered more of a spoiler for Mr. Sarkozy than a real challenger.

title: U.S. and E.U. Agree to Expand Open Skies Accord
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union and the United States agreed Thursday to expand a three-year-old accord that allows airlines to operate more freely across the Atlantic.

title: Mexico: Guards Suspected in Jailbreak
description: Guards may have helped about 41 prisoners escape from a state prison on Thursday in Matamoros, across the border from Brownsville, Tex., officials said. The break occurred before dawn, and there was no sign that prisoners had scaled the walls, said Jos Ives Sobern Tijerina, the Tamaulipas State secretary of public security.

title: Two Sides to One Performer
description: The Puerto Rican comedy Manuela and Manuel is Almodvar Extra Lite: a candy-colored ode to tolerance and self-affirmation that will vacate your brain faster than you can say, un Cosmo, por favor. Though its tone wavers, telenovela-style, between farcical and sentimental, and its at least 15 minutes too long, the film is easy enough to sit through. Thats partly because of the director Ral Marchands vibrant palette  predominantly red, orange and lime-green  and mostly because of the permanently arched eyebrow of the Mexican actor Humberto Busto, who plays the title character(s) and gives the film a point of view and a core of feeling.

title: Legal-Marijuana Advocates Focus on a New Green
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Perhaps only in California could a group of marijuana smokers call themselves fiscal realists.

title: Californias Dairy Industry Takes Old Question to New Extreme
description: FOR years, the question Got milk? was actually asking consumers Got enough milk?  reminding them to drink milk by comically exaggerating the perils of running out. Now the Got milk? campaign is taking the opposite tack, by comically exaggerating the perils of never running out.

title: Which Side of History?
description: Which of these assertions is the less plausible?

title: Memo to Pope Described Transfer of Pedophile Priest
description: MUNICH  The future Pope Benedict XVI was kept more closely apprised of a sexual abuse case in Germany than previous church statements have suggested, raising fresh questions about his handling of a scandal unfolding under his direct supervision before he rose to the top of the churchs hierarchy.

title: A Gay Love and Marriage Tale
description: For the first 10 minutes or so of Just Say Love, a film version of a stage play by David J. Mauriello, you might think youve found that rare gay film that has a sophisticated sense of humor and avoids the formulaic gunk that makes most of this genre unwatchable. There are a couple of witty lines as Doug (Robert Mammana), a rugged-looking married carpenter, sits down on a bench next to Guy (Matthew Jaeger), a gay man who reads Plato, and strikes up a conversation that eventually leads them into a sexual relationship.

title: Average Con Ed Bill to Rise by $10 Over 3 Years
description: The monthly power bill for a typical New York City household will rise by more than $10 over the next three years under a new rate plan approved by regulators on Thursday.

title: Bloggingheads: Real Cost Controls?
description: Matthew Yglesias of the Center for American Progress and Jonathan Chait of The New Republic debate health care reforms cost control mechanisms.

title: Three More Decide to Sue Bloomberg L.P.
description: Three more women have been permitted to join a class-action lawsuit that accuses Bloomberg L.P., the financial services and media company founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, of discriminating against pregnant employees, a federal judge said Thursday.

title: House Democrats Who Rejected Health Bill May Face Trouble From Their Friends
description: WASHINGTON  The New York City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, agreed a few weeks ago to host a fund-raiser for a fellow Democrat who faced the prospect of a tough challenge this fall, Representative Michael E. McMahon of Staten Island.

title: Officers on Border Team Up to Quell Violence
description: United States law enforcement authorities, seeking to avert a spillover of drug violence from Mexican border cities, are cautiously trying out new cross-border cooperation with the Mexican federal police, according to senior Homeland Security officials. The efforts will include coordinated operations and expanded intelligence sharing.

title: India Tunes in as Its Top Striker Is Welcomed by M.L.S.
description: In terms of international celebrity or soccer pedigree, Sunil Chhetri is no David Beckham. He is not even Landon Donovan. As imports go, he is a work in progress. But because Chhetri, a star of Indias national team, generates such feverish interest in his country, the Kansas City Wizards of Major League Soccer timed their announcement of his signing more for the Indian news cycle than the domestic one.

title: Playgrounds Jail Theme Is Gone, but Perplexity Lingers
description: Building a playground is not as simple as installing a set of vertigo-inspiring monkey bars: These days, the world of playground design is rife with debate over how high the slides should be, whether the equipment should be brightly colored (kids say yes) or blend in with the environment, and whether themes like castles and rocket ships stimulate or stifle the imagination.

title: Alaskan Thrills
description: A small picture vibrating with grand passions, Godspeed transforms the vast lawlessness of the Alaskan wilderness into a playground for damaged souls and Old Testament mischief.

title: Health Worker Accused in Killing
description: A home health care worker in Brooklyn was arrested on Thursday on charges that she beat the 67-year-old woman in her care to death, the authorities said.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 25, 2010

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about New York Universitys plans to expand referred incorrectly in some editions to the size of the expansion in Greenwich Village. The total square feet, about three million, is a little more than that in the Empire State Building, not more than two Empire State Buildings. The article also referred imprecisely to another N.Y.U. project, in which the building on Macdougal Street that housed the Provincetown Playhouse theater is being turned into a research center for the law school and will also have a theater. While the facade of the Provincetown Playhouse entrance was preserved, the rest of the buildings facade was destroyed, not preserved.

title: Green Has Setback in Comeback Attempt
description: The comeback effort of the professional golfer Ken Green was dealt another blow Tuesday when he learned that his request for a major medical exemption on the Champions Tour had been denied.

title: Young Love Flowers
description: Floating uneasily between ghost story and gay tragedy, Dream Boy marvels as young love flowers on a dunghill of homophobia, incest and religious repression. The material may be florid, but its execution is sensitive as Nathan (Stephan Bender), the new kid on the school bus, locks eyes with Roy (Max Roeg), the silky-haired driver and farm boy next door. Algebra homework leads to a snuggle in the cemetery, and its not long before the natives are compelled to intervene.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the difficulties and successes over the past year for Leo J. Wise, the chief counsel and staff director for the Office of Congressional Ethics, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of the lawyer who defended Representative Sam Graves, Republican of Missouri, against conflict-of-interest accusations. He is Elliot S. Berke, not Burke.

title: Corrections
description: The Goshen Journal article on Thursday, about a decision by Goshen College, a small Mennonite school in Indiana, to break with tradition and play an instrumental version of the national anthem before sporting events, misstated part of the name of a baseball team from Michigan that defeated the Goshen Maple Leafs on Tuesday. The team is the Siena Heights Saints, not the Sierra Heights Saints.

title: 1 Across: Nightclub in the Trump Taj
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Henry Hook is a puzzling force of nature. Ive never met him in person, but Ive met a number of his puzzles, and they always confirm my opinion that hes one of the most clever and witty constructors  ever.

title: In Possible Retirement, the Likelihood of an Election-Year Confrontation
description: WASHINGTON  No announcement has been made, but the widely anticipated retirement of Justice John Paul Stevens in coming weeks has the White House, Senate and lobbying groups bracing for an election-year confrontation over the future of the Supreme Court.

title: Fix Health Reform, Then Repeal It
description: Washington

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about TV Guide Networks purchase of the first syndication rights to the HBO comedy Curb Your Enthusiasm misstated the genesis of the series Politically Incorrect. It began on Comedy Central and ran on ABC before being canceled; it was not an HBO show.

title: Now Comes the Hard Part
description: Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: An A.I.G. Lesson From Wisconsin
description: An A.I.G. Lesson

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the possibility that Chinas Internet companies will have difficulty becoming global brands misidentified, in some editions, a Chinese social networking site with more than 70 million users. It is Kaixin001.com  not Kaixin.com, a competing company.

title: Pecora Faces Tough Task at Fordham
description: Tom Pecora struck a happy pose in a reception hall at Fordham with his wife, two of his children, the athletic director, the university president and nine players from a basketball program that usually ends its season with March sadness.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 18 about a dispute between Amazon.com and publishers over e-book pricing misspelled the name of the chief executive of Idea Logical, which advises publishers on e-book matters. It is Mike Shatzkin, not Shatkzin.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about Fred and Ginger in So Many Words: The Astaire-Rogers Songbook, part of the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92nd Street Y, misstated the title of Deborah Grace Winer, who wrote and hosted the show. She is the series artistic director, not the Ys artistic director. (The Y does not have a position with that title.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a coming film by the writer-director James L. Brooks misstated a word in what is said to be the title. As the article noted elsewhere, it is How Do You Know, not How Do We Know.

title: A New Life in Ballet
description: Even if you dont know your plis from your battements frapps, the dance sequences in Dancing Across Borders are a delight. More problematic perhaps is a true-life narrative about a wealthy white woman (Anne Bass, a prominent Manhattan patron of the arts) who plucks a happy teenager (Sokvannara Sar, known to everyone as Sy) from his home in Cambodia and installs him in the School of American Ballet in New York.

title: What the Boss Learned
description: To the Editor:

title: Going to Extreme
description: I admit it: I had fun watching right-wingers go wild as health reform finally became law. But a few days later, it doesnt seem quite as entertaining  and not just because of the wave of vandalism and threats aimed at Democratic lawmakers. For if you care about Americas future, you cant be happy as extremists take full control of one of our two great political parties.

title: Reimagining What Washes Up
description: The Hudson River was as mean as usual this winter, roughing up the Manhattan shore and playing into the hands of Tom Loback, a sculptor who works in flotsam and jetsam. Nothing pretentious. Just more of his fragile, gone-tomorrow driftwood works to puzzle and please along the river rocks down from the apartment towers north of West 100th Street.

title: The Return of History
description: Some brilliant scholar has to write a comprehensive history of modern economics because the evolution of this field is clearly one of the most consequential things happening in the world today.

title: Loosening the Dont Ask Shackles
description: The Pentagon is taking a major step to ease the discriminatory burdens on gay and lesbian service members by ending the pernicious use of anonymous tips and biased hearsay to drum them from the military.

title: Records in Real Time
description: The Freedom of Information Act has done a lot to make government more transparent. But in Washington  where need-to-know is the favorite status symbol  most agencies still ignore the legal deadlines and take months, even years, to respond to requests.

title: Haitis Misery
description: The emergency in Haiti isnt over. Its getting worse, as the outside worlds attention fades away.

title: Here Comes the Recess Coach
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Insurer on AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Fact of Life in Mootopia
description: The California Milk Processor Board moves past the "Got Milk?" campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary and a headline on Monday about the former Nepalese prime minister Girija Prasad Koirala misstated his age, and the obituary misidentified his place of birth. Mr. Koirala was 85, not 86, and he was born in the state of Bihar, India  not in Biratnagar, Nepal. (As the obituary noted, Mr. Koirala was born in 1925, but he was considered to be 86 in Nepal, where by custom people are regarded as 1 year old at birth.)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 10 about Willie Davis, who succeeded Duke Snider as the Los Angeles Dodgers center fielder, misstated, in some copies, the surname of a longtime sports columnist at The Los Angeles Times who wrote critically about Davis. He was Jim Murray, not Maury.

title: Correction
description: Thomas L. Friedmans column on Wednesday, about empowering centrists and independents, misstated the terms of a recent California ballot initiative. It rescinded the State Legislatures power to configure districts for the State Senate, State Assembly and Board of Equalization, not for Congress.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Audit Finds Vulnerability of EnergyStar Program
description: WASHINGTON  Does a gasoline-powered alarm clock qualify for the EnergyStar label, the government stamp of approval for an energy-saving product?

title: Fresh Air for Myanmar's Music
description: Young people in Myanmar dance to musician Thxa Soe's different beat.  His western-style electronica is tolerated, and even enjoyed, by the government of the authoritarian state formerly known as Burma.

title: Its Done: House Passes Reconciliation Bill
description: The House of Representatives on Thursday gave final approval to the budget reconciliation bill containing a package of changes to the Democrats sweeping health care overhaul. The bill, which Democratic leaders hailed as a landmark achievement, now goes to President Obama for his signature.

title: Ivanchuk and Carlsen Tie for First at Amber
Photo Replay: March 25
description: A look at the first day of play in the Round of 16, when the upsets kept coming.

title: Political Tide Could Wash Away Utah Senator
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Senator Robert F. Bennett parked his white Acura, walked through the doors of Bryant Middle School and stood alone as he began the obstacle course that will determine his political fate.

title: Using Balanced Effort to Slow Washington, West Virginia Cruises
description: SYRACUSE  The Washington Huskies were perhaps the least-heralded double-digit seed in the Round of 16. For a team that had won 14 of its last 16 games, it barely received recognition outside of the Pacific Northwest.

title: Interview With Senator Bennett of Utah, Facing Re-election
description: Senator Robert F. Bennett, Republican of Utah, faces a difficult re-election to a fourth term. He must persuade 3,500 party activists to support him before his name will be placed on the ballot. In an interview with Jeff Zeleny this week in Salt Lake City, he discussed the challenges and the state of politics today. These excerpts are condensed and edited.

title: Keeping the Upsets Coming, Butler Beats Syracuse
description: SALT LAKE CITY  When Syracuse took its place along the free-throw line for the national anthem, half the Orange players were facing toward the flag in a corner of the arena. The other half  along with Coach Jim Boeheim  were facing the opposite direction.

title: Achilles Heel for Duke?
description: HOUSTON  Its always worrisome when a player expresses concern about his shooting technique.

title: When Star Is Covered, Cue 3-Point Shooter
description: ST. LOUIS  When Northern Iowas senior guard Ali Farokhmanesh chose to pull up for a 3-pointer with 35 seconds left in the Panthers second-round game against top-ranked Kansas on Saturday, he had a fan in Ohio State guard Jon Diebler.

title: Correction
description: The Mortgages column last Sunday, about the decision by Freddie Mac  one of two government-sponsored companies that set lending standards for mortgages  to stop backing interest-only mortgages, misstated the percentage of the companys loans that were delinquent at the end of last year. It was 3.98 percent, not 7 percent.

title: Hospitals Chief Expects to Cut 3,900 Jobs
description: New York Citys public hospitals will be forced to cut 3,900 jobs over two years  a tenth of the work force  if state budget cuts go through, the systems president said Thursday.

title: Republicans Lobby Against Recess Appointment
description: All 41 Republican senators urged President Obama on Thursday not to name a lawyer for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Service Employees International Union to the National Labor Relations Board during the Easter recess. Last month, the Democrats fell eight votes short of the 60 needed to overcome a threatened filibuster of a vote for the lawyer, Craig Becker. Two Democrats, Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas and Ben Nelson of Nebraska, joined Republicans in the 52-to-33 vote. In a letter to Mr. Obama, Republican senators said that because of his union work, Mr. Becker could not be viewed as impartial, unbiased or objective in labor board cases. Seven of the 10 members named by President George W. Bush were recess appointees.

title: Murder Case May Proceed in Georgia
description: A divided Georgia Supreme Court will allow a capital murder case to go forward despite the defendants claims that a lack of state financing for death penalty lawyers deprived him of access to effective counsel and a speedy trial.

title: Valerie Hegarty: Cosmic Collisions
description: In shows at the now-defunct Guild & Greyshkul, Valerie Hegarty took over the architecture in kudzulike fashion. Sculptures of trees and plants emerged from fissures in the walls and floors; sublime seascape paintings were made to look shipwrecked in the gallery.

title: New Hampshire: Spring Breaks
description: The ice broke on Lake Winnipesaukee on Wednesday, the earliest date since residents started keeping tabs in 1888, and a tantalizing signal of warmer days ahead. Its a passage of spring coming, and everyones been locked up in cabin fever all winter long, said David Emerson, who owns Emerson Aviation in Gilford and is responsible for calling the date the ice is out. Mr. Emerson declares the ice out when it clears enough for a cruise ship to navigate among five docks. The previous record was March 28. The date not only promises better weather, but also a big payday for the winners of the many local betting pools. Mr. Emerson guessed that bettors didnt expect such an early date, saying, I dont think I made anyone happy this year.

title: Ed Paschke
description: There he goes again  Larry Gagosian, that is  putting on a show that a New York museum should have done. This time the subject is Ed Paschke (1939-2004), whose toxically glowing paintings of circus freaks, extreme dandies, tattooed ladies and hairy, wingtip shoes explored the dark side of Pop Art. Along with Jim Nutt and Roger Brown, Mr. Paschke was one of the strongest talents to emerge from the Chicago Imagist school of the 1960s.

title: California: Cable Cars to Be Idled
description: Passengers will be rerouted from San Franciscos cable cars onto less charming buses starting in January as the cable system is upgraded. The cars, a picture-postcard element of the citys tourism industry, carry riders to and from Fishermans Wharf, up and down steep hills, and to the pier where boats depart for Alcatraz Island. The San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency will spend $24 million on the cars underground infrastructure and electrical systems. The agency expects the upgrade to be completed by June.

title: Anya Kielar: Face
description: In her third galley solo, Anya Kielar builds on her past interests in theater, fashion, photography, strong color, early modernist styles and deceptively simple fabrication methods. Her new high-octane monochrome reliefs and an eye-strewn folding screen also present a lively combination of recklessness and rigor. It is hard to say who might emerge from behind the six-panel screen  which is mostly purple and leavens its popping eyes with stencil-like silhouettes of breasts, gloves, socks and the odd bit of texture or textile. The possibilities include Bette Davis, Florine Stettheimer and Lotte Lenya.

title: Marcia Hafif: From the Inventory: Black Paintings, 1979-1980
description: Marcia Hafifs Black Paintings from 1979-80 may have improved with age, but I cant say for sure. I dont actually remember having seen them, although they were shown at the Sonnabend Gallery, then in SoHo, in 1981. Ms. Hafif, who is 80, is much more associated in my mind with bright colors and often smaller canvases.

title: Season in Balance, Rangers Are Saved by Rally
description: NEWARK  Because of Erik Christensen, the Rangers still live.

title: Dancing Across Borders
description: Even if you dont know your plis from your battements frapps, the dance sequences in Dancing Across Borders are a delight. More problematic perhaps is a true-life narrative about a wealthy white woman (Anne Bass, a prominent Manhattan patron of the arts) who plucks a happy teenager (Sokvannara Sar, known to everyone as Sy) from his home in Cambodia and installs him in the School of American Ballet in New York.

title: The Glory Days of Football
description: MORAGA, Calif.  When Omar Samhan was asked where St. Marys upset of Villanova ranked in the colleges history, he did not take time to ruminate.

title: Lbs.
description: For a movie about a man who doesnt let any food go to waste, Lbs. has spent an awfully long time on the shelf. Cast in 2000, filmed beginning in 2001 and first shown at Sundance in 2004, it arrives in theaters six years later just in time to capitalize on Michelle Obamas anti-obesity campaign.

title: Will Police Pay Increase Raise Hackles? And Highlights From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: An Awkward Time For a Wish to Come True | Three years ago, Gary P. Delagnes made a prediction to the members of the police union he heads: That in July 2010 the San Francisco police would be members of the highest-paid major police department in the country. But the police are reaching their long-awaited economic summit when the city is in an economic abyss. Gerry Shih reports that with a record $522 million budget gap facing the city, some in city government are pushing for the police to give up the 4 percent raise scheduled to take effect July 1 or to face layoffs that could result in a $17 million savings. Despite recent sharp cuts in controversial overtime payments, total police compensation has been rising for the past five years, city data show. In 2009, 52 members officers and members of the command staff took home more than $200,000, with one retiring deputy chief taking home more than $500,000. When I sit down with my constituency, said Supervisor David Campos, who was on the police commission before running for district office, the feeling I get is they want the police, but they dont want the police being the best compensated in the country when were shutting down gyms and pools.

title: Manuela And Manuel
description: The Puerto Rican comedy Manuela and Manuel is Almodvar Extra Lite: a candy-colored ode to tolerance and self-affirmation that will vacate your brain faster than you can say, un Cosmo, por favor. Though its tone wavers, telenovela-style, between farcical and sentimental, and its at least 15 minutes too long, the film is easy enough to sit through. Thats partly because of the director Ral Marchands vibrant palette  predominantly red, orange and lime-green  and mostly because of the permanently arched eyebrow of the Mexican actor Humberto Busto, who plays the title character(s) and gives the film a point of view and a core of feeling.

title: Word of the Day | cadaverous
description: cadaverous \k-dav-rs, -da-vr-s\ adjective

title: At the University of California, Some Would Rather Pay Than Protest
description: Heres a story where doing a little math is bound to prompt discussion.

title: Just Say Love
description: For the first 10 minutes or so of Just Say Love, a film version of a stage play by David J. Mauriello, you might think youve found that rare gay film that has a sophisticated sense of humor and avoids the formulaic gunk that makes most of this genre unwatchable. There are a couple of witty lines as Doug (Robert Mammana), a rugged-looking married carpenter, sits down on a bench next to Guy (Matthew Jaeger), a gay man who reads Plato, and strikes up a conversation that eventually leads them into a sexual relationship.

title: Godspeed
description: A small picture vibrating with grand passions, Godspeed transforms the vast lawlessness of the Alaskan wilderness into a playground for damaged souls and Old Testament mischief.

title: Dream Boy
description: Floating uneasily between ghost story and gay tragedy, Dream Boy marvels as young love flowers on a dunghill of homophobia, incest and religious repression. The material may be florid, but its execution is sensitive as Nathan (Stephan Bender), the new kid on the school bus, locks eyes with Roy (Max Roeg), the silky-haired driver and farm boy next door. Algebra homework leads to a snuggle in the cemetery, and its not long before the natives are compelled to intervene.

title: Even as Costs Rise, University of California Remains a Bargain
description: Alexander Dobranic, an undergraduate politics major at the University of California, Santa Cruz, is not taking math this spring. But he knows when numbers  like the tuition and fee increases that have led to protests and vandalism on U.C. campuses this winter  dont add up.

title: As Budget Gaps Widen, San Francisco Police Salaries Grow
description: Three years ago, Gary P. Delagnes, the president of the San Francisco Police Officers Association, made a bullish prediction after successfully negotiating a lucrative four-year contract: After a scheduled 4 percent pay raise phased in on July 1, 2010, Mr. Delagnes wrote in a note to the officers, the force would most likely fulfill a 20-year mission to become the highest paid major police department in the country.

title: Looking Ahead: Round of 16
description: MIDWEST

title: That Buzzing Could Sweeten Tomorrows Tea
description: If you spy a dark-haired woman gliding down Mission Street, past the taquerias and bodegas, in a white, head-to-toe bee suit  picture a hazmat suit crossed with a fencing mask  chances are its Cameo Wood, en route to a beehive. Ms. Wood, the 32-year-old proprietor of the Mission District shop Her Majestys Secret Beekeeper, cares for 15 hives in borrowed spaces around San Francisco. These are hidden away in friends backyards, in a restaurant garden, and on the roofs of government buildings and apartment complexes.

title: Rematch With Different Look
description: The last time Tennessee faced Ohio State in the N.C.A.A. tournament, in 2007, the Buckeyes had Greg Oden dominating inside and Mike Conley Jr. making sure everything flowed smoothly.

title: Kentuckys Defense Stymies Cornell
description: SYRACUSE  Top-seeded Kentuckys road to a national championship took a favorable turn Thursday night.

title: Street Repair Falls Victim to Budgets
description: San Francisco motorists may have to be prepared for more potholes in their already bumpy streets unless the city comes up with more money.

title: South Koreas Formidable Double Dragon
description: Ki Sung-yueng and Lee Chung-yong are on parallel and still rising career arcs that may peak the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.

title: Johnny Maestro, Brooklyn Bridge Singer, Dies at 70
description: Johnny Maestro, the pure-toned tenor who as the lead singer for the Crests, the Del-Satins and the Brooklyn Bridge recorded rock n roll hits like Sixteen Candles and The Worst That Could Happen, died Wednesday at his home in Cape Coral, Fla. He was 70 and had lived in Islip, N.Y., until seven years ago.

title: After a Dispiriting Lull, the Blackhawks Surge
description: Maybe it was that John McDonough.

title: Mountaineers Advance By Slowing Things Down
description: SYRACUSE  Against Washingtons relentless pressing defense and quick transitioning offense, West Virginia knew it might struggle to maintain its style of basketball.

title: Downstate Republican Faces Rough Road in Race for Governor
description: As Bill Brady made his way through a crowded ballroom at the Hilton on Michigan Avenue the other evening, heads did not turn to glimpse a political big shot. The Republican nominee for governor of Illinois, at least for now, is an unfamiliar face in the city.

title: Taking Xaviers Best Shots, Kansas State Survives
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Kansas State defeated Xavier on Thursday night, but the Wildcats did not really win their way to the West Regional final. They survived.

title: With Insurance Comes a New Need: More Primary-Care Doctors
description: Hours before President Obama signed the health care bill Tuesday, George Butler, a retired steelworker, was the first patient to enter Evanston-Rogers Park Community Health Center. By 9 a.m., all of the 22 black and gray molded plastic seats were filled.

title: Reform Plan for Pensions Has Critics
description: The remarkably swift reform of the states pension plans, thrust through Wednesday by Mike Madigan, the Illinois house speaker, does virtually nothing to make up a shortfall in funds, some of the states leading pension-reform advocates said.

title: Come Fly Away
description: Photos from Twyla Tharps new Broadway musical, set to the music of Frank Sinatra.

title: News Quiz | March 26, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Big Banks Said to Be Named in Municipal Bond Case
description: Documents obtained by Bloomberg News in an antitrust case against a group of Wall Street firms named JPMorgan Chase, Lehman Brothers and UBS as conspiring to pay unfairly low rates on investments made by state and local governments.

title: Purdues Tall Task
description: HOUSTON  Purdue has a tall task on Friday against top-seeded Duke in the N.C.A.A. tournaments South Region semifinals.

title: Northern Iowa Takes Many Paths to Victory
description: With the news that Kalin Lucas, Michigan States leading scorer, is out with a ruptured Achilles tendon, I decided to go back to the tape and take a more in-depth look at Northern Iowa.

title: Energy Sector Said to Drive Asia Deals This Year
description: Mergers and acquisitions jumped to $520.4 billion in the first quarter, accompanied by a big shift in global deal-making as emerging market and energy-focused takeovers made up a growing slice of activity, Reuters reported.

title: Shelby Says Dodd Bill Wont Cure Too Big to Fail
description: The Democratic bill to overhaul the financial system would not end the too big to fail phenomenon or adequately protect taxpayers from having to bail out large companies, a leading Republican senator said on Thursday, Sewell Chan reported in The New York Times.

title: Taylor Swifts Unlikeliest Fan
description: HOUSTON  The colorful personality of the gregarious St. Marys center Omar Samhan has been on full display during his 10th-seeded teams improbable run to its appearance in the N.C.A.A. tournaments Round of 16.

title: What Are the Most Memorable Photographs Youve Ever Seen? Why?
description: We ask todays question because weve been thinking about this article from the Week in Review about the power of the still image, as well as the Sunday Magazine series of heartbreaking photographs of the bedrooms of young American soldiers who died in Iraq and Afghanistan. What photographs  whether serious or playful, and whether taken by a professional or an amateur  have made the biggest impression on you? Why?

title: UBS Cuts 200 Jobs in Its U.S. Brokerage Unit
description: UBS, the Swiss banking giant, has slashed about 200 jobs in its brokerage unit in the United States, a source told Reuters.

title: A.I.G.s Near Collapse Yields Gold for Wall Street
description: Auctions of American International Groups assets have generated more than half a billion dollars in fees since its near collapse in September 2008, with every major Wall Street bank getting a piece of the action, estimates from Freeman Consulting show.

title: Dubai May See Dawn
description: Dubai may be close to ending its nightmare, Breakingviews says. As part of the proposal to restructure debts of $23.5 billion at the emirates flagship company Dubai World and its subsidiary Nakheel, the government is offering to convert more than $10 billion of loans it has made to the group into equity and inject $9.5 billion of new money. Lenders could still face some losses, but it could have been much worse, the publication suggests.

title: Ontario Teachers Buys British National Lottery
description: The Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, Canadas largest pension plan, said Thursday it would buy Camelot, the British national lottery operator, for 389 million pounds ($576 million), Reuters reported.

title: The Vanishing Point
description: Australians call the northernmost chunk of their continent the Top End, a breezy moniker, as though Australia were a boiled egg sitting upright in an egg cup waiting tobe cracked open with a silver spoon. Just how much Top End there is is open to debate, the kind that gets worried out with maps drawn in the dust. While I was there last September, I saw dust maps that gave the Top End most of Australia north of the Tropic of Capricorn  about a third of the continent. Others included only Cape York and the rather wind-swept-looking peninsula that includes the roistering town of Darwin, the capital city of the Northern Territory.

title: Pope May Be at Crossroads on Abuse, Forced to Reconcile Policy and Words
description: ROME  Even as Pope Benedict XVI, faced with a sexual abuse scandal spreading across Europe, has called on victims to come forward and urged clerics to cooperate with civil justice, those strong words are running up against the complexities of his past.

title: D.O.J. Said to Examine Calpers Transactions
description: Justice Department investigators in Los Angeles are scrutinizing certain investment transactions of public pension funds, including the California Public Employees Retirement Fund, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Plainfield to Return Money to Investors, Report Says
description: Plainfield Asset Management, the hedge fund run by Max Holmes, is planning to wind down its current portfolio and start over with its remaining funds, The New York Post reported.

title: Wisconsin Quarantines $64 Billion in Ambac Assets
description: State regulators in Wisconsin said they are taking control of roughly $64 billion of the worst assets at the bond insurer Ambac Financial Group, Reuters reports.

title: London Suspects May Have Been Front-Running
description: The arrest of seven individuals and raids on 16 offices by British regulatory agencies this week could be tied to the front-running of block trades, Bloomberg News reported, without identifying its source.

title: Are Covenant-Lite Loans Back on the Menu?
description: Is investor appetite for covenant-lite loans, which impose fewer financial requirements on the borrower, returning?

title: Selling Saints: Yves Smith Debunks The Big Short
description: Michael Lewiss The Big Short: Inside the Doomsday Machine, the best-selling book that profiles investors who predicted the financial crisis and made billions from it, has come under heavy flak in a recent review by Yves Smith.

title: Higher One Plans $100 Million I.P.O.
description: Higher One Holdings is planning an initial public offering of up to $100 million, even as pending legislation could change its business, The Associated Press reported.

title: Strategic Defaults
description: Tactical mortgage defaults whereby borrowers walk away from home loans they can afford to repay.

title: Rhetoric, but Scant Funds, for Wind Power
description: The head of New Englands power grid said Thursday that alternative energy is popular, but is not being funded, leading to uncertainty in the market.

title: Tentative Deal Struck for 2 Towers at Ground Zero
description: The Port Authority, government officials and the developer Larry A. Silverstein reached a tentative agreement Thursday that would allow for the construction of two new skyscrapers at ground zero with up to $1.6 billion in public financing and subsidies, The New York Timess Charles V. Bagli reported.

title: Northern Iowa Is No Fluke
description: Stephen Danley played basketball at Penn from 2003 to 2007.

title: In Paris, Kitanos Crazy Universe
description: The first-ever museum show of the Japanese artist, comedian and filmmaker Takeshi Kitano, now running at the Fondation Cartier in Paris through Sept. 12, reveals a carnivalesque universe of painting, installations, interactive games  including a giant, interactive sewing machine  all from the artists famously outlandish imagination.

title: Broadcast Company Will Fund Local Reporting Projects
description: From Elizabeth Jensen at Media Decoder:

title: Man Group Said to Mull Deals With SAC and GLG
description: The Man Group has been in preliminary deals talks with Steven A. Cohens SAC Capital Advisors and GLG Partners, as the worlds biggest publicly listed hedge-fund manager seeks out possible acquisitions and other deals in the United States, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the discussions.

title: Gores Said to Seek New Deal Talks With Polycom
description: The Gores Group was hoping to reopen talks with Polycom about a merger between the largest independent video-conferencing equipment company and one of the private equity firms portfolio companies, Siemens Enterprise Communications, The Financial Times reported.

title: UBS Taps Credit Suisse Banker to Head Swiss Unit
description: UBS has poached a banker from rival Credit Suisse to lead its Swiss operations, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: I.C.B.C. Profit Jumps on Lending Boom
description: Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, the worlds biggest lender by market value, reported a surge in fourth-quarter profit, fueled by a lending boom and lower provisions against sour assets, Reuters reports.

title: Germanys Mitteleuropa Redux
description: Todays idea: Germany is achieving by stealth what it failed to achieve in the past thousand years of intra-European struggles, an analyst writes: enduring dominance in continental matters.

title: Stray Questions for: Lauren Groff
description: Lauren Groff is the author of a novel, The Monsters of Templeton, and a story collection, Delicate Edible Birds.

title: State of the Giants: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Tip of the Week: Rescheduling With Google Calendar
description: Google Calendar has helped people set up meetings and coordinate schedules online over the years, and now the company has a brand new way to reschedule those meetings.

title: Sampler: Pitching Marijuana for the Revenue, and the Last Day for Google Broadband Applications
description: Marijuana Proposal Appeals to Need for Green | Proponents of the ballot measure to legalize marijuana in California wont dwell on the drugs safety or social acceptance. Instead, they will focus on money: They say that taxing its sales could raise $1.4 billion and ease the $20 billion state deficit. The measure, which qualified for the November ballot on Wednesday, would allow licensed retailers to sell up to one ounce at a time, a transaction that would be subject to tax. We need the tax money, said Richard Lee, founder of Oaksterdam University, a trade school in Oakland for marijuana growers. Mr. Lee backed the ballot measures successful petition drive. Second, we need the tax savings on police and law enforcement, and have that law enforcement directed towards real crime. Some are not so sure. We just dont think any good is going to come from this, said John Standish, president of the California Peace Officers Association. [The New York Times]

title: Treasury Said to Have Plan for Sale of Citi Stake
description: The United States Treasury may unveil a preset trading plan next month for the sale of its 27 percent stake in Citigroup, Bloomberg reported, citing people with direct knowledge of the matter.

title: Flash Mobbed
description: WHAT are flash mobs?

title: Why Goldman Wants a Branch in Warsaw
description: Goldman Sachs is looking to open a branch office in Warsaw, in a move to take advantage the Polish governments plans to sell $10 billion worth of assets in share offerings this year, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Speed Read for Friday, March 26
description: Here are some highlights from Fridays editions of The New York Times:

title: Rio Tinto Executive Admits to Taking Two Bribes
description: SHANGHAI  Stern Hu, an executive at the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto, has said in court that he accepted two large bribes in late 2008 and early 2009 totaling about $1 million from Chinese steel mills in exchange for agreeing to sell them long-term supplies of iron ore, his lawyer said Friday.

title: Report Supports Overhauls Savings Estimate
description: The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal-leaning fiscal policy research group in Washington, put out a point-by-point refutation on Thursday of claims from opponents of the new health insurance law that its projected savings, especially from Medicare, are based on budgetary gimmicks and will never be realized.

title: Afghan Marksmen  Forget the Fables
description: The recent Marine operations in and nearMarja brought into sharp relief a fact that contradicts much of what people think they know about the Afghan war. It is this: Forget the fables. The current ranks of Afghan fighters are crowded with poor marksmen.

title: A Strange Thing About the Rain in F1
description: It is a little ironic that in the midst of a soul-searching moment in Formula One about whether or not the series is boring, many people have spoken about how artificial things like a reverse grid or rain can help spice up the spectacle.

title: Moores Rifat Denies Insider-Trading Accusations
description: Julian Rifat, the hedge fund trader arrested as part of a major investigation by British financial authorities, on Friday denied accusations that he took part in insider trading.

title: Q. and A.: Bill McKibben on CO2 and the Future
description: Bill McKibben, an environmentalist and long-time advocate for action on climate change, believes we can still reverse the growing concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration now estimates at 390 parts per million.

title: Allawi Victory in Iraq Sets Up Period of Uncertainty
description: BAGHDAD  The secular party of Ayad Allawi, a former interim prime minister once derided as an American puppet, won a wafer-thin victory in Iraqs election, setting the stage for a protracted period of political uncertainty and possible violence that could threaten plans to withdraw American troops.

title: Tata Nano Goes Up in Smoke
description: 11:23 a.m. | Updated

title: Open Note to Student Commenters and Your Teachers: Thank You!
description: When our blog first launched in October, we werent sure how the whole daily Student Opinion question thing would go. Would anyone write in? Would real kids actually come and post thoughtful and honest comments, or would we get dutiful, dull writing from students answering only because a teacher was checking it off in a grade book?

title: Building a Maxwell: Its a Team Sport
description: IT took a small army of restorers from across the country to bring the Andersons Maxwell project to fruition.

title: History Thats More Than the Sum of Its Parts
description: ON the surface, it sounds like a nearly impossible task: assembling a rare brass-era car from scratch, using century-old parts that were tracked down one by one from all the dusty, rust-ridden corners of the collecting world.

title: To Curb Grade Inflation, Safety Tests Get Tougher
description: WHEN a straight-A student starts bringing home report cards riddled with Cs, its cause for concern.

title: Gas-Pump Freedom (Restrictions Apply)
description: DRIVING the Mini E in and around New York City highlights both the promises and the pitfalls of electric cars.

title: Scoring the Electric Mini Acid Test
description: TURNS out theres a sure-fire way to get the public excited about electric cars: let people have them. After reviewing 1,800 applications on a company Web site, BMWs Mini division selected 450 people last year to lease its all-electric Mini E for a full year in New York, New Jersey and greater Los Angeles.

title: The Early Word: Reconciled
description: And its done.

title: Read This Post or Youll Get Syphilis
description: Its Friday, and as hard as youve worked all week, lets face it: you could have worked harder. Theres always something you could have done better  a pithier memo, a firmer handshake with that client, a smoother edge on all those collated documents.

title: Meatpacking District, 12:50 A.M.
Toyota Slows Production in Europe as Sales Lag
description: TOKYO  Toyota Motor said on Friday that it would idle three plants in France and Britain for a total of 14 days to reduce inventory amid recent recalls and a slump in European sales.

title: U.S. Growth in 4th Quarter Revised Slightly Lower
description: Economic growth in the last quarter of 2009 was slightly less robust than previously thought, the government said on Friday. But corporate profit in the quarter rose significantly, providing hope that businesses might begin hiring again.

title: OMG! 30 Rock Knows The New York Times Exists!
description: For a moment, everything about this 30 Rock clip was going just right: Cheyenne Jackson was in it, and he was joking about Canadians and singing about hockey. And then he mentioned The New York Times! And thenoh. Jokes on us. Well, like the man said, its just an honor to be mentioned in the same breath as Dave Coulier.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Rangers Stay Alive on Drurys Late Goal
description: The New York Rangers were just 17 seconds from virtual elimination, but somehow they saved their season. That was merely the the most dramatic among Thursdays 11 games. Home teams listed first:

title: The Strange Case of the Playground Jail
description: Building a playground is not as simple as installing a set of vertigo-inspiring monkey bars: These days, the world of playground design is rife with debate over how high the slides should be, whether the equipment should be brightly colored (kids say yes) or blend in with the environment, and whether themes like castles and rocket ships stimulate or stifle the imagination.

title: The Times of London to Charge Online
description: The Times of London will charge readers for Internet access starting in June, News Corporation announced on Friday, putting Rupert Murdoch at the forefront of a movement to erect toll gates on news sites.

title: Rwanda Lodge Opens Near Monkey Forest
description: While mountain gorillas draw tourists to the north of Rwanda, the newNyungwe Forest Lodge, bordering a lush rain forest preserve, seeks to bring well-heeled safari goers to the countrys south.

title: Ristretto | The Daily Grind
description: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why its never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

title: American Scout for Mumbai Attacks Was Jokingly Called Agent Headley by Friends
description: As my colleague Jane Perlez reports, an American man admitted last week that he had helped to plan the Mumbai attacks by making several surveillance trips to the city, shooting video of targets and taking coordinates with a GPS unit.

title: China Bars Noted Scholar From Planned Trip to U.S.
description: BEIJING  A prominent Chinese scholar and film critic who was scheduled to speak at an academic conference in the United States this week said Friday that she had been barred from leaving China as punishment for her commentary on human rights and free speech.

title: A Bold U.S. Plan to Help Struggling Homeowners
description: Will it work this time?

title: Energy Star Found Wanting?
description: In case you missed it, Matt Wald reported on Friday that auditors were able to easily earn the Energy Star label for a host of bogus products, including the air purifier pictured above  essentially a heater with a feather duster attached to the top.

title: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Twilight Gets Really Graphic
description: Twilight fans rejoice  you now have another arena in which to engage in the eternal Team Edward vs. Team Jacob debate. This week marked the release of Twilight: The Graphic Novel Vol. 1, which stakes its claim at No. 1 on the hardcover list. This adaptation of Stephenie Meyers vampire saga, adapted by the Korean artist Young Kim, sold 66,000 copies in its first week of release, according to its publisher, Yen Press. (It probably didnt hurt that the graphic novel went on sale just a few days after the DVD release for The Twilight Saga: New Moon.) An excerpt from the comic adaptation, in which Bella is introduced to her new high-school cafeteria (and the Cullen family) can be found here.

title: Transportation Department Embraces Bikes, and Business Groups Cry Foul
description: Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood has announced a major policy revision that aims to give bicycling and walking the same policy and economic consideration as driving.

title: Pelosi Signs Reconciliation Bill
description: 10:33 a.m. | Updated

title: Shell Be the Judge
description: If previous years at the Wharton Business Plan Competition are any indication, the feedback of Madi Ferencz  a competition judge, marketing veteran and a serial entrepreneur  will be highly coveted at this years event (semifinals in early April, finals April 28). One reason is that her consumer-goods expertise provides some contrast to the opinions offered by her fellow judges, most of whom are high-tech-focused venture investors and entrepreneurs.

title: Ice Racing in New Hampshire
Ultraslim Speakers for Your Ultraslim TV
description: So you just plunked down a bundle for that new superthin LED-backlit LCD or plasma TV, and you have even mounted it on the wall. What do you do to keep that slim look when it comes to audio equipment?

title: Through a Glass, Busily
description: YOU have to hit the ground running, the artist Kiki Smith said recently, referring to her process. You have to have multiple things happening, so youre not just standing around. Its hard to imagine this is much of a risk for Ms. Smith, 56. So far this year, at least, she has hardly stood still.

title: Doctors Offer Thoughts on Cutting Health Care Costs
description: IN persuading Congressional Democrats to pass the health care overhaul, President Obama addressed one of the most pressing issues facing the country: providing broader access to medical insurance for as many as 32 million Americans who do not now have it.

title: I Loathe the 80s With John Cusack
description: Everybody who lived through the 1980s is in some way nostalgic for that decade, right? Cabbage Patch Kids, hair metal, Miami Vice, the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact  good times.

title: Shelf Life | Rough Justice
description: The work of Alex Ross, a celebrated artist in the comic book industry, is a wonder to behold. His painted pages have graced the pages of Marvels, a limited series exploring the early days of Spider-Man, Captain America and their ilk from the perspective of a photojournalist; Kingdom Come, which looked at the future of Superman and Batman and found a world overrun by irresponsible super humans; and countless comic book covers. Each time, fans have been treated to lush paintings of favorite heroes that seem as realistic as photographs.

title: Complaint Box | Religion on the Field
description: Now that the Boys of Spring are prepped for the 2010 season, I am, too.

title: Earning Her Food
description: Im a city girl from New York. Im also 82 and half-blind, so what am I doing deer hunting with my son, Sam, at the end of October in Montana? Were in the foothills of the Swan Mountains near Kalispell, south of Glacier National Park. For the last four days, Sam and I have been tramping dawn to dusk over tree debris that loggers call clear-cut. We havent eaten since we left his cabin before dawn. Now its snowing, and Im wet, tired and bloody cold.

title: The Marrying Kind
description: My mother has a sly way of backing into major announcements. Im renovating my kitchen was her way of introducing the fact that she and her beau were moving in together several years after my father died. A year or so later she said, Im spending the morning finishing paperwork, so this afternoon we can go ring shopping, which was her way of warning that a sapphire solitaire would soon grace her ring finger.

title: Trust Busting
description: A company shows anxiety on its face  that is, on its Web site, which has become the face of the modern corporation. Visit sites for recently troubled or confused enterprises, including Maclaren, Toyota, Playtex, Tylenol and, yes, John Edwards, and youll find a range of digital ways of dealing with distress.

title: Out of Africa
description: Since its publication in 1958,  Things Fall Apart,  the story of a Nigerian yam farmer who is unable to accept the changes wrought by British colonialism, has become the best-selling novel ever written by an African.  Well, I hear such exaggerated comments. I just leave them alone.

title: Bedbug Disclosure
Crossfire
description: Starbucks has lately found itself in the middle of a debate between advocates of open carry gun rights and of gun control; the former have held armed meet-ups at several of its locations, and the latter have demanded that the coffee chain prevent this from happening. Seeking to duck these fresh salvos in the long debate over how firearms fit into American life, the company has issued a statement that such matters ought to be worked out in the legislatures and courts, not in our stores. Well, sure. But drawing a line between official institutions of lawmaking and the daily sphere where citizens move about is not so easy. And one thing the pistols-and-Frappuccino moment has demonstrated is that this is acutely true for a business with an image carefully devised to blur the line between public space and commercial space.

title: Letter: The Limits of Rahmism
description: When things go wrong, everyone looks for a scapegoat, and the consensus, as Peter Baker reports, seems to be that everything is somehow Rahm Emanuels fault. I think the administrations problems are overblown. Yes, there have been growing pains and some communication difficulties, but not all is lost by any means. Blaming any one person, even the chief of staff, is terribly unfair and typical of the Washington finger-pointing game. It doesnt do anything to contribute to the serious dialogue needed to address the significant problems that we face as a country.

title: Letter: Issues With a Fix for Kids With Issues
description: Expensive, unproven approaches like vision therapy need to be questioned in order to protect the welfare of children and families and to uphold evidence-based treatment as central to quality care. Judith Warners article on vision therapy referred to a convergence-insufficiency treatment trial as a gold standard, but this single study, which recommended in-office therapy for convergency insufficiency, should not be used to substantiate all uses of vision therapy. As Warner notes, valid research shows that the most common reading disorder, dyslexia, is caused by problems with language processing, memory and attention, not with the eyes or visual system.

title: Bottled vs. Tap
description: From our Green Inc. blog comes this summary of the debate between advocates of tap water and those of bottled water. The first group includes most people I know, an increasing number of restaurateurs, and the United Nations, and the second includes the bottled water industry.

title: Letter: How to Cook Up a Food Celebrity
description: I found myself returning repeatedly to the lead photograph in Frank Brunis wonderful article about the foodie Katie Lee. Gillian Laubs marvelous photograph of this young lady hell-bent on celebrity lets us know that Lee is one tough cookie.

title: Letter: The Femivores Dilemma
description: Who exactly are the femivores? Do they eat only female things? Eat women? They sound like self-cannibalizing stay-at-home moms, which is probably not what the new pioneers of the domestic frontier have in mind.

title: Dear Poppa. Sincerely, Jerry
description: Not every fan letter written to Ernest Hemingway merits its own display in a museum, but when its author is J. D. Salinger a little pomp and circumstance is understandable. On Sunday, the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum in Boston will put on display a note from Salinger to Hemingway, written in 1946, that recounts a meeting between the authors and possibly hints at the coming publication of The Catcher in the Rye, The Associated Press reported.

title: Letter: On Language
description: You have honored the memory of William Safire in a fashion worthy of his legacy. You did not with thoughtless urgency pass the On Language baton to a self-appointed heir apparent salivating in the wings. Nor did you suspend the column altogether as some sort of respectful gesture to the master.

title: Twists and Turns on Way to Arms Pact With Russia
description: President Obama was angry. He was on the phone with President Dmitri A. Medvedev last month to finalize a new arms control treaty with Russia, only to be confronted with new demands for concessions on missile defense. A deal that was supposed to be done was unraveling.

title: Second Round of British Airways Strikes to Begin
description: British Airways is bracing for a second round of strikes, to last four days starting at midnight, as its chief executive is accused of trying to break the union. Read more

title: Pakistani Forces and Militants Clash at Border
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Taliban militants battled Pakistani security forces for control of a security outpost in a tribal region near the Afghan border, leaving five Pakistani security officials and dozens of Taliban fighters dead, Pakistani authorities said Friday.

title: Weekend Competition Q&A: A Bissel Yiddish?
description: This weekend, in the run-up to Passover, co-vocabularists are invited to share their love of Yiddish and pose questions to an expert on the language.

title: Friday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Japan Clears Man Imprisoned for 17 Years
description: TOKYO  For more than 17 years, Toshikazu Sugaya, a soft-spoken former kindergarten bus driver, lived behind bars, serving a life sentence for the murder of a 4-year-old girl.

title: Answers to Questions About New Mortgage Modification Program
description: 6:30 p.m. | Updated to add new detail and questions and answers The federal government announced new initiatives on Friday to help people who are having trouble paying their mortgages. Here are some questions and answers about the efforts.

title: Palin and McCain Reunite for His Campaign
description: TUCSON  Senator John McCain stages a political reunion here today at a campaign rally with Sarah Palin, the first time the former Republican running mates have appeared on the same stage since their 2008 presidential race ended.

title: Lewis Hamilton, on the Track and the Street
description: Oh dear. Lewis Hamilton was apparently so happy about being the fastest driver in the practice session at Albert Park in Melbourne on Friday that he went out to celebrate, and to show off in his road car on the streets of Melbourne.

title: Video: Music in Myanmar
In Policy Shift, Transportation Department Embraces Bikes
description: From our colleagues at Green Inc:

title: Femininity and Nature
description: Images from Masterpieces of European Painting From Dulwich Picture Gallery, at the Frick Collection.

title: Wi-Fi Set-Up Made Easier
description: Ask a friend to help you to set up a home wireless network, and his eyes will likely glaze over, perhaps hell fidget a bit, and then offer to loan you some money to call the Geek Squad.

title: A Matter of Life and Death: Suicides in the Army
description: The Army faces a battle over the life and death of its soldiers. The battle is not being waged in Iraq and Afghanistan, but in the minds and tortured souls of soldiers contemplating suicide. Last year the Army again reported an increase in suicides, and in response the Army now requires every soldier to complete an online assessment of his or her physical, mental and spiritual well-being.

title: Administrations Remarks on the Arms Control Treaty
description: Following is a transcript of the remarks made on Friday by President Obama; Hillary Rodham Clinton, the secretary of state; Robert Gates, the defense secretary; and Admiral Michael Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; in which details of a new arms control treaty with Russia were announced, as released by the White House:

title: Pelosi Signs Reconciliation Bill
description: At our Prescriptions sib-blog, colleague David M. Herszenhorn reports on the signing by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of the final revisions to the health care bill in a ceremony earlier this morning.

title: Chart: Video Clips of Pavements Reunion
description: Last year the 1990s indie rock band Pavement announced it was reuniting, and earlier this month it played its first few shows in New Zealand and Australia. Naturally, audience-made videos were quickly posted on YouTube. Rather than wait for Pavements set at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival on April 18, the artist Andrew Kuo  a longtime fan  rates the clips:

title: Andy Warhols Ferragamos
description: You cant buy these shoes without knowing the story behind them. Sure, theyre elegant, in an Old World, spaghetti Bolognese, Wheres Michael? kind of way. But whats with those specks of paint? someone might ask you. What kind of an animal would paint while wearing full-grain Italian calfskin shoes? Although there are many expensive mens shoes that now bear his name, Salvatore Ferragamo (1898-1960) designed only one style for men in his lifetime, and youre looking at it. Andy Warhol owned a pair and, naturally, he painted in them. And then Warhol died. And then, in 2006, the Ferragamo family bought those paint-specked Warhol shoes at an auction. And now, authorized copies are available for $990 at the Ferragamo flagship store on Fifth Avenue in New York. Call (212) 754-5200.

title: Among Kentuckys Stars, Respect for Cornell
description: SYRACUSE  In the locker room following Kentuckys shaky 62-45 win over Cornell in the Round of 16 on Thursday, Wildcats center DeMarcus Cousins wanted to finally put to rest more talk about the Big Reds collective I.Q.

title: Mixed Messages on Drinking and Driving
description: Its a simple refrain that we hear throughout our lives: Dont drink and drive.

title: Protests and Defense of a Transgender Comedy at Tribeca Festival
description: A film selected for the 2010 Tribeca Film Festival called Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives hasnt been screened there yet, but its already had that very effect on members of the transgender community and their supporters, prompting an advocacy group to call for the films removal from the festival lineup as well as a rapid defense from its creators and festival organizers.

title: A Beginners Guide to Board Approval
description: Q.

title: Stung by Defeat, Cornell Savors Its Season
description: SYRACUSE  Cornells charmed N.C.A.A. tournament run ended here on Thursday night. What began with a vibrant roar of optimism after it leaped ahead by 10-2 ended with the sobering reality that it lost to a more physical and more talented team.

title: Gaining Access to Proxy Votes
description: Q.

title: Congress Shifts Student Loan Program to the Government
description: Ending one of the fiercest lobbying fights in Washington, my colleagues David M. Herszenhorn and Tamar Lewin write in todays Times, Congress voted Thursday to force commercial banks out of the federal student loan market, cutting off billions of dollars in profits in a sweeping restructuring of financial-aid programs and redirecting most of the money to new education initiatives.

title: A Modest Size by Any Measure
description: Q.

title: Happy Passport Day
description: Need a passport pronto? Tomorrow, March 27, is your day.

title: Pacific Street Station, Brooklyn, 9:03 A.M.
description: Just a drill, said the man with the M4 rifle.

title: The United States of Unemployment
description: Fifteen states and the District of Columbia had double-digit unemployment rates in February, according to a new government report. Once again, Michigan had the dubious honor of holding the highest unemployment rate in the country.

title: What Does It Mean to Be a Good Wife?
description: In this weeks New York Times Magazine I write about the changed meaning of the word wife.

title: South Korean Navy Ship Sinks in Disputed Waters
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A South Korean Navy patrol ship sank near the disputed western maritime border with North Korea early Saturday after suffering damage to its hull, South Koreas military said.

title: Chrysler Offers Reinstatement to 86 Dealerships It Told to Close
description: DETROIT  Chrysler, which eliminated a quarter of its United States dealerships in the companys bankruptcy last year, said on Friday it would let as many as 86 of those dealers reopen.

title: Pope Had No Knowledge of Transfer, Vatican Says
description: ROME  The Vatican on Friday reaffirmed its position that the future Pope Benedict XVI had no knowledge of a decision to allow a known pedophile priest to resume pastoral duties when the pope was archbishop in Munich in 1980.

title: Taxes and the Deficit Commission
description: House Democrats named their three members of the new White House deficit commission this week, which completes the commissions roster. The commission will have 18 members (10 Democrats and 8 Republicans) and is scheduled to issue its recommendations by the end of this year. Below, youll find a full list of members.

title: Theyre No Longer Upsets
