description: Here is the truest sign yet that mens college basketball may be completely turned on its head: Butler pulls off a Round of 16 upset in the N.C.A.A. tournament that should warm the hearts of underdog lovers everywhere, knocked off a No. 1 seed (even if it was a seriously flawed Syracuse), is coached by a guy who looks as if he got his drivers license three days ago, plays in a gym straight out of a Leave It to Beaver episode and yet the Bulldogs walked off the court in Salt Lake City with no more dragon-slaying hoopla than if they just had just defeated Youngstown State in December.

title: Doctors Remedies for Rising Costs
description: Todays Patient Money column considers the pressing problem of rising health care costs, an issue brought to the fore by the past years health care reform debate. How can the country reduce medical costs while not compromising quality?

title: In Racing Four Wide, N.H.R.A. Takes a Gamble
description: O. Bruton Smith, the audacious racing mogul, has built a dragstrip near Concord, N.C., that is a little different from most other drag strips, and its opulence is just one attribute. The zMax Dragway, already nicknamed The Bellagio of Drag Strips, has four lanes, not two, and all four will be used at the same time this weekend at the inaugural N.H.R.A. Four-Wide Nationals.

title: Its Not Dry Yet
description: FEW modern myths about art have been as persistent or as annoying as the so-called death of painting. Unless, of course, it is the belief that abstract and representational painting are oil and water, never to meet as one.

title: Oh, Grow Up
description: Im a junior in college far from home, but I try to stay close with my old friends. Some of them think Ive become pretentious, and that my politics and tastes in food, drink and clothing have become elitist. I admit that Ive changed since high school, but I think of it as growing up. I felt awkward and insecure then; now Im more comfortable with myself. Still, Im afraid of alienating my oldest friends. What should I do?

title: Naughty by Nature
description: I started out in the south, but the island kicked me up here a few years ago, says Cathy Bilsky, who runs Cathys Angelite Om, a shop in the old plantation town Honokaa, on the northeastern coast of the Big Island of Hawaii. Like many locals, Bilsky, who came here from Michigan (by way of California), tends to anthropomorphize the island. Her store is piled high with jagged rocks, posters of Ganesh and signed autographs from fans like Andy Dick, who scribbled, Cathy, I love you! on his photo. This just felt like home when I got up here, she says as she kneads my shoulders with one of her crystals.

title: Two Experimentalists Under One Roof
description: SINCE its opening in 2005 the Baryshnikov Arts Center has been resolutely multidisciplinary in its programming. Still, the building is named after a man who is synonymous with dance, and it was something of a surprise to learn three years ago that Mikhail Baryshnikov had asked the Wooster Group, the venerable experimental theater collective, to take up residence in a newly acquired and still-to-be-renovated theater in the building in Midtown Manhattan.

title: A Head Full of Pictures, an Eye for the Stage
description: The singular downtown artist David Greenspan has made a name for himself as an actor for hire in productions like the off-kilter musical Coraline last year and Target Margin Theaters 2006 extravaganza Faust. (The review in The New York Times called his Mephistopheles irresistible even though you know you shouldnt go near him.) But hes also known as the cerebral playwright (and star) of sparely staged works like The Myopia, which the Foundry Theater presented in a critically praised revival this winter. Changing modes so regularly (hes now performing in Michi Baralls Rescue Me at the Ohio Theater), does he also change his approach?

title: London Underground | The White Cubicle
description: A ladies restroom in an East End pub is not the most likely site for art, but then the White Cubicle Toilet Gallery does not follow many rules.

title: Soothing Sounds for the Pontiffs Ear
description: VATICAN CITY

title: Good Politicians, Bad Party
description: From Mitch Daniels contribution to the Wall Street Journals Obamacare symposium:

title: Rebound in World Trade Is Seen
description: Led by economic growth in China and India, world trade is projected to expand by 9.5 percent this year after shrinking by 12.2 percent last year in the sharpest contraction since World War II, the World Trade Organization said on Friday.

title: Woman Convicted of Killing Real Estate Agent Gets New Lawyer
description: The woman convicted of murdering Linda S. Stein, the former punk rock manager and celebrity real estate agent, finally got her wish to change her lawyers on Friday.

title: Editors Choice
description: BACKING INTO FORWARD: A Memoir,  by Jules Feiffer (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $30.) Along with a frequently hilarious self-portrait, the acclaimed cartoonist offers a vision of New York City during the cultural and political foment of the 1950s, 60s and 70s.

title: Boston College Coach Interviewing With St. Johns
description: The Boston College mens basketball coach, Al Skinner, has received permission to interview for the head coaching position at St. Johns and is interviewing with Red Storm officials Friday, according to a Boston College official.

title: Tighter Rules Fail to Stem Deaths of Innocent Afghans at Checkpoints
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American and NATO troops firing from passing convoys and military checkpoints have killed 30 Afghans and wounded 80 others since last summer, but in no instance did the victims prove to be a danger to troops, according to military officials in Kabul.

title: TimesCast | March 26, 2010
description: From the newsroom of The New York Times.

title: Census Chief Apologizes for Negro Category
description: When Robert Groves, the director of the Census Bureau, appeared on C-Spans Washington Journal program Friday morning, he found himself having to defend the racial designations on the census form.

title: As It Turns Out, Maybe You Can Judge a Book by Its Cover
description: Which of these facts is more surprising: that there is an annual contest held by The Bookseller magazine for the years most bizarrely titled book, or that a volume about Nazi eating utensils didnt win it? Sorry, Collectible Spoons of the Third Reich by James A. Yannes, but you received only enough votes to place third in the online competition for the Diagram Prize for Oddest Book Title of the Year, the magazine announced on Friday in a news release. A plurality of the votes  1,912 of the 4,553 ballots cast at TheBookSeller.com  went to Crocheting Adventures With Hyperbolic Planes by Dr. Daina Taimina.

title: Naughty by Nature
description: On the Big Island of Hawaii, Mother Earth gets hot and bothered.

title: In a 96-Team Field, Upsets Could Be a Thing of the Past
description: Joel Sokol is an associate professor of operations research at the Stewart School of Industrial and Systems Engineering at Georgia Tech.

title: The Return of China
description: In the coming decades China will likely surpass United States as the worlds biggest economy. That may seem strange and uncomfortable to many Americans, but it wouldnt be the first time China dominated the global economy.

title: The Rumors Say Ushers Making a Comeback
description: ATLANTA

title: Fighting Obesity
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Michelle Obama is going to be honored for her anti-obesity campaign at Nickelodeons Kids Choice Awards, hosted by Kevin James. I mean, seriously  fighting obesity at a show hosted by Kevin James. Thats like fighting adultery at a show hosted by Jesse James.

title: Restricted, but Not Deterred
description: Besides being a dictator, a political thorn for the West and a Dr. Evil-like figure of pop culture ridicule, the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il is also a film buff. Other dictators have taken an interest in cinema as a propaganda tool  Stalin exploited Sergei Eisenstein and Hitler hired Leni Riefenstahl  but Mr. Kim has gone further.

title: The Pentagon Will Ease Up
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton was down in Mexico earlier this week. Nothing important. She has to go down there every year at this time to drag Bill back from spring break.

title: Judge Voids City School Closings
description: Updated, 3:16 p.m. | A Manhattan judge on Friday reversed a city decision to close 19 schools for poor performance, ruling that education officials engaged in significant violations of state education law and failed to follow proper process in closing the schools.

title: Now Online | T Travel Spring 2010 Issue
description: Its all about . . . Back to the land, starting with our cover story on Hawaiis Big Island, an off-the-grid wonderland where Mother Nature went a little bit nuts. Then we head down under to Australia to commune with the cane toads in the awe-inspiring Top End, and to Lake Powell, a no less jaw-dropping corner of the American West. We check in with the urban refugees yearning to buy the farm (for a weekend), pay a visit to the schnapps makers of the Austrian Alps, and get to know the environmental adventurer David de Rothschild. Not that weve entirely forgotten the charms of city life: Theres a stop in newly energized Bordeaux, France; a wander through the half-closed doors and shadowy lanes of Palermo, Italy; and a rip-roaring meet-and-greet with the movers and shakers of Beirut. And because you cant go back to the land if you dont take care of it, theres Ts first-ever guide to eco-tripping.

title: Baylors Udoh Is No Samhan, On or Off Court
description: HOUSTON  While St. Marys center Omar Samhan is outgoing off the court and powerful on it, Baylors forward/center Ekpe Udoh may just be his foil.

title: Book Review Podcast: Nell Irvin Painter and Pamela Paul
description: This week: Nell Irvin Painter discusses her book The History of White People; Pamela Paul tells us about group marriage therapy; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Healthful Dining on a Dime
description: Healthful cooking doesnt have to be expensive cooking. In this weeks Recipes for Health series, Martha Rose Shulman provides five nutritious meals that wont break the bank.

title: Book Review Podcast: Nell Irvin Painter and Pamela Paul
description: This week: Nell Irvin Painter discusses her book The History of White People; Pamela Paul tells us about group marriage therapy; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: What Were Reading
Shepard Fairey Returns to New York (With Permission)
description: The artist Shepard Fairey has become a museum darling but is still close enough to his street-art roots to have been arrested, jailed overnight and sentenced to two years of probation last year in Boston for pasting his work on buildings before a retrospective at the citys Institute of Contemporary Art. Now  as he prepares for a May exhibition at Deitch Projects in New York, that gallerys final show as its owner, Jeffrey Deitch, closes the business to take over the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art  Mr. Fairey is planning to put up street art the polite way, by asking building owners.

title: If Its About the Journey, Cornell Didnt Lose
description: Syracuse

title: Lions Gate Takes Fight With Icahn to Shareholders
description: Shareholders are being invited to get involved in the battle between Lions Gate Entertainment and the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, who already controls nearly 19 percent of the companys stock, The Associated Press reports.

title: Ticked-Off Trannies Actor Responds to Controversy
description: Earlier, ArtsBeat reported on a dispute over the film Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives, which the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation and others have demanded be removed from the lineup of the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Cheering in Halls as Drug Cases Are Dismissed
description: Yelling and cheering erupted again on Friday in the hallways at San Franciscos Hall of Justice as a judge dismissed more than 50 drug cases set to go to trial.

title: March (Jobs) Madness
description: So far weve reported dutifully on March Madness brackets based on each schools alumni salaries and grade inflation. In that haphazard tradition, here are the picks from the Labor Department, ranked by the job growth in each universitys home city over the last year:

title: Lang Lang Offers Up a Polonaise for Haiti
description: The pianist Lang Lang was the headliner at a concert designated as a benefit for Unicef at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, and was joined onstage for one song by Wyclef Jean, one of the prime movers behind the Hope for Haiti Now concert and telethon and the resulting album. While expenses for the Carnegie concert exceeded proceeds from ticket sales, contributions from corporations including Sony, with whom Mr. Lang signed a recording deal this year, and Columbia Artists Management, which represents Mr. Lang, have meant that, under Mr. Langs auspices, Unicef has received around $100,000.

title: A Fight for a Church Is Evoking Introspection
description: When news spread the other day that work crews were draping black steel netting over the facade of Our Lady of Loreto Church, the people fighting to save the building from demolition found themselves stymied  and reflecting on a yearlong campaign at the brink.

title: Energy Star Rating Questioned
description: A Government Accountability Office investigation shows that many appliances backed by the Energy Star program are not tested for efficiency. (Video: NBC)

title: Bullet Fired at Cantors Window Was Random
description: When Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the second-ranking Republican leader in the House, held a news conference Thursday to accuse Democrats of exploiting the threats and vandalism they have faced since passing the health care bill, to reap publicity and partisan advantage, he got quite a bit of publicity himself by announcing that a bullet had been shot through the window of one of his Richmond campaign offices earlier in the week.

title: What Lang Lang Brings to Chopins Heroic Polonaise
description: Lang Langs approach to the grand opening bars of Chopins Heroic Polonaise, which he is offering as a single on iTunes with a portion of the proceeds going to Unicef, is worthy of the titular appellation. What comes afterward, though, has less to do with heroism than with Mr. Langs flamboyant dexterity and what it allows him to do. He tugs and teases at bars and phrases like an over-caffeinated stylist with a jittery hand and a reality show.

title: Of Water, Electricity and the Time of Day
description: Water accounts for an astonishing percentage of electricity use  19 percent in California, for example  partly because of all the energy needed to pump it.

title: Appetite for America
description: Chapter One: Pot Walloper

title: The Impact of Images: Considering the Place of Photojournalism Today
description: Overview | In a world where digital cameras and amateur photos are as ubiquitous as the cell phones that carry them, has photojournalism lost impact? Or has the proliferation of images only made us more receptive to, and appreciative of, professional work? In this lesson, to commemorate the seventh anniversary of the Iraq war, students look at and respond to photos of fallen soldiers bedrooms. They then create and present creative photo essays.

title: Blasts Kill Dozens at Cafe and Restaurant North of Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  A day of high drama here was marred by a pair of explosions that ripped through a cafe and a restaurant in a violent town north of Baghdad on Friday, killing 43 people and wounding at least 65 others, the authorities said.

title: Santa Clara County to Consider Restricting Toys With Fast Food
description: Ken Yeager, the president of the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors, has been on Fox, CNN and MSNBC in recent days because of a proposal he has floated that the county restrict fast-food restaurants tendency to use toys to reward children for making unhealthy food choices.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Greta Gerwig, New Paintings and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Netanyahu Remains Firm on Jerusalem Housing
description: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, stood firm Friday on his governments policy of continued building in East Jerusalem, a major point of contention with the Obama administration. His office said the policy remained unchanged.

title: Some Tax Considerations to Keep in Mind for 2010
description: The discussion this tax season has been dominated by some big changes in tax and other laws. One allows some taxpayers to convert their regular retirement account to a Roth I.R.A., which would incur a tax bill now but the gains would then accumulate tax-free. Another is the expiration of the estate tax for 2010. And with the passage of the health care overhaul this week, there is now the prospect of surcharges for higher earners (though not until 2013).

title: The Baseball Codes
description: Chapter 7: Don't Show Players Up

title: The Moviegoer | Limited Release
description: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

title: Bush Returns to the Viral Video Charts
description: Video of former Presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton visiting earthquake survivors in Haiti this week has returned Mr. Bush to the viral video charts for the first time since he left the White House.

title: In Germany, a Highway Threatens the Mosel Wine Region
description: Despite the chill pouring in through the open window next to my desk, spring is here. For me, that means thoughts turn to riesling, German riesling in particular.

title: The Morning Skate: Rivalries and Head Checks Refuse to Fade Away
description: Hockey news away from the N.H.L. has been somewhat more uplifting lately. Echoing the gold medal Olympic clash, rival teams of U.S. and Canadian servicemen in Afghanistan have squared off in a street hockey games, part of a morale-boosting tour for Canadian troops that runs through this weekend. The delegation includes includes 15 N.H.L. alumni, Maple Leafs executives and the Stanley Cup. National Public Radios Morning Edition ran a piece on the tour today (audio) and Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment executive Tom Anselmi has been blogging from Afghanistan and his posts include some video with Leafs General Manager Brian Burke and Hockey Hall of Famer Lanny McDonald.

title: Fitch Expects Financial Overhaul to Cut Bank Risks
description: The proposed overhaul of American financial regulations should reduce the extent of risk-taking by the biggest banks and may bolster their credit ratings, Fitch Ratings said Friday, Reuters reports.

title: Music Manager Sues Axl Rose
description: The company that managed Axl Roses career in Guns n Roses for much of the last two years has sued him to collect what it says is $1.9 million in unpaid fees. Front Line Management, whose founder and chief executive is Irving Azoff  who is also executive chairman of Live Nation Entertainment, which merged with Ticketmaster last month  filed suit in Los Angeles Superior Court on Thursday,saying that Mr. Rose is in breach of an oral contract that obliged him to pay Front Line 15 percent of his gross earnings as a performer. The suit says that Mr. Rose has not paid the management fees on recent concerts in Asia, South America and Canada, which grossed $12.5 million. A spokesman for Mr. Azoff declined to comment further on the suit, and representatives for Mr. Rose  including his new manager, Doc McGhee  did not respond to inquiries.

title: The Irresistible Henry House
description: Chapter 1: Welcome Home, Henry

title: The Sabbath World
description: Part 1: Time Sickness

title: RadioShack Jumps on Report of Possible Sale
description: Shares of RadioShack rose as much as 9.5 percent on Friday after The New York Post reported that the consumer electronics chain was considering strategic alternatives including a possible sale of the company for more than $3 billion.

title: Greeks, Romans, and Financial Reform
description: Im trying to wrap my mind around the details of financial reform, and in particular the difference between the Frank bill, already passed by the House, and the Dodd bill. And I keep coming back to an odd analogy, involving ancient history.

title: Travel Deals: Guided Tour of Dubai
description: Friendly Planet Travel, a tour operator based in Pennsylvania, is offering a six-day Dazzling Dubai sightseeing tour starting at $1,499, including round-trip airfare from New York on Emirates Airlines. The package also includes accommodations at the Fairmont Dubai, modeled after an Arabic wind tower, and tours with an English-speaking guide. For departures from Houston, add $130, for Los Angeles or San Francisco, add $200.

title: Taxing CO2 Emissions at Europes Borders
description: Is the time approaching when the European Union will impose greenhouse gas controls on products and services imported from parts of the world that lack such regulations?

title: We Made It Ourselves | Say Head Cheese!
description: In her column, We Made It Ourselves, Charlotte Druckman writes about restaurants and small businesses with interesting house-made treats.

title: In Long Island, Gatsby Would Feel Right at Home
description: KINGS POINT

title: Perspective On Interest Rates
description: Scary-sounding story in the WSJ about spiking interest rates. But, oddly, no perspective on how this looks in terms of the history of interest rates since the crisis  just charts of the last few days.

title: Financial Tuneup: Should I Take Less Risk?
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off of our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Protecting an Array of Gems in the Bronx
description: IN the 1970s, when the Hunts Point section of the Bronx became associated with drugs, crime and prostitution, a group of bow-front row houses in the 800 block of Manida Street remained an oasis of tranquillity.

title: Karen Elson Is Dressing the Part, and Singing It
description: LIFE is unfair and everybody knows it, but should you require a refresher, you need only to watch Karen Elson, the redheaded supermodel, design muse and wife of Jack White of the White Stripes, sing.

title: A Tense Baghdad Learns Election Results
description: Even before the results of the parliamentary elections were released in Iraq, supporters of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki were protesting in Baghdad (Slide 1). After it was announced that former Prime Minister Iyad Allawis coalition had won the most seats, Mr. Maliki denounced the results as fraudulent. Both the first and second photographs in this slide show were taken for The Times by Joo Silva.

title: Europeans Vow Effort to Bring Economies Closer
description: BRUSSELS  Jolted by the Greek debt crisis and alarmed at the prospect of bailing out a fellow member state, European Union leaders on Friday promised new efforts to coordinate policies to bring their divergent economies closer.

title: Living in NoLIta
description: NoLIta, framed by Houston, Lafayette and Kenmare Streets and the Bowery, is short on green space, but long on little spots that have kind of become New York landmarks, as one resident described  it.

title: Seller as Lender
description: FOR most home sellers, their ties to a property end at the closing. But for a few others the attachment can continue on for years, because they also assume the role of banker.

title: In Canada, TV Goes Deep on Climate
description: In a world of shrinking conventional coverage of (non-medical) science and the environment, it was refreshing recently to become aware of the The Agenda with Steve Paikin, a popular current-affairs program on public television in Ontario  particularly its five-hour string of shows devoted to some of the prime facets of the climate challenge.

title: Touring the Road to Freedom
description: Road to Freedom: Photographs of the Civil Rights Movement, 1956-1968, an exhibit of 150 images organized by the High Museum of Art in Atlanta that capture the struggle for equal rights, will be on display from March 28 through Aug. 11 at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.

title: Willpower, and Maybe a Camera, to Get Rid of Your Unused Junk
description: I HAVE a strange affinity for those reality shows where teams of people go into incredibly messy homes, see masses of clutter, get it all cleared out and then end up with beautifully redecorated homes that look like stage sets.

title: A Time Capsule Invaded
description: VISIT NoLIta early enough on a weekday, before all the boutiques stir to life at 11 or even noon, and you might feel as if you had traveled back in time 75 years. Weathered walk-up tenement buildings cast shadows over the side streets; homeless men trudge through on their way to the Bowery; pizza shop workers settle in for a day at the ovens.

title: Turning Up the Heat Over a No Vote
description: In the continuing fallout over the vote to overhaul health care, several influential Democratic groups are pressing a veteran Albany lawmaker to cancel a fund-raiser she was planning for a Democratic congressman who voted against the measure.

title: On the Street | Toe Dance
description: In New York, the comfort factor drives fashion. In the French capital it's all about status and taste, regardless of discomfort.

title: Fired From the Mommy Track
description: A friend called me last night to tell me she was denied a promotion because she was engaged. Planning her wedding, she was told, would mean she would be too distracted to do her new job properly and would probably end up having babies and leaving the company anyway.

title: All in the Family
description: IT was happenstance that brought Kevin Cheng to Astoria, Queens. A friend had an extra bedroom in his apartment, which was on the ground floor of an attached two-family row house.

title: Advantage for Taiwan Automaker Lies in the Countrys Tech Sector
description: Early this month, Luxgen, a Taiwanese automaker, issued a news release about its presence at the Dubai auto show, which took place last December.

title: In East Orange, Seeds for Redevelopment Are Planted
description: EAST ORANGE

title: One Composer, Served Two Ways
description: Lincoln Centers split-focus Beethoven symphony cycle, which began on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall, is a fantastic case study in how a slight tweak can make a commonplace programming idea seem compelling, and how marketing overdrive can then make the whole idea look silly.

title: Renovations Make a Comeback
description: THE Columbia is a tall yellow-brick condominium at the corner of Broadway and West 96th Street, populated by many families and professionals. On weekday mornings, the lobby bustles with kids scurrying to school and grown-ups hurrying to work. Lately, though, there has been an addition to the hubbub: Contractors, lines of them, waiting for authorization to ascend the elevator to the apartments they are in the process of renovating.

title: Everyday Rapture May Replace Lips Together, Teeth Apart
description: Everyday Rapture, a critically acclaimed musical built around the actress Sherie Rene Scotts experiences with religion, theater and fame, is a leading contender to replace the postponed Broadway revival of Lips Together, Teeth Apart in Roundabout Theater Companys spring season, according to two people with knowledge of Roundabouts planning.

title: Domesticated Kitsch
description: BACK in the 1970s, when Jeff Nesmith was growing up in Birmingham, Ala., a defining image of his childhood was the paint-by-numbers version of Leonardos Last Supper that hung above the sofa in his grandmothers living room. The artist was his mother, an ardent practitioner of the paint-by-numbers craze that swept the nation in the postwar years, and the small oil was heavy on the lurid greens and purples.

title: Crash Devastates a Kentucky Family
description: For years, John and Sadie Esh lifted up their Mennonite community in central Kentucky with mellifluous gospel singing. Their congregation of 20 families likewise embraced them when their son Johnny died and again when their house burned down.

title: Theodore S. Hammer
description: Mr. Hammer, 64, is a managing partner at HLW International, an architectural, interior design and engineering firm based in New York.

title: California Climate Law Would Add Jobs, Study Suggests
description: Californias climate change law wont decimate the states economy and will help increase job growth modestly over the next 10 years, according to a state air control group study released this week.

title: Theater Sale Draws Scrutiny
description: NORWALK

title: Cheyenne Jackson Gets His New York Times Profile. (Sort Of.)
description: On Thursdays 30 Rock, Danny Baker, the earnest sketch comedy performer played by Cheyenne Jackson, is told that hes going to be profiled in The New York Times. (As filler, Danny says, because of dwindling ad sales. Ha ha ha.) But due to the nefarious machinations of Dannys television colleagues, we never learn if he gets his profile article after all.

title: Aplomb in a Showcase for Technique
description: The guitarist Ralph Towner has always, it seems, made music of glowing introspection. Since at least the early 1970s, when he began recording for the German label ECM, he has practiced a pristine, self-sufficient style, endlessly awake to his instruments acoustical properties. This makes him an ideally transfixing solo performer, though he works no less as an ensemble player, notably in Oregon, his long-running band.

title: One Word: Eyjafjallajokull
description: These are particularly dark days in the land of fire and ice, as the people of Iceland, or at least the travel agents among them, like to refer to their country.

title: Sweat Equity, the Movie
description: THERE are low-budget films, there are micro-budget films, and then there is Breaking Upwards. It may be hard to imagine how someone could make a feature-length romantic comedy in New York City for just under $15,000, but Daryl Wein and Zoe Lister-Jones managed to do it.

title: Hefty Tax Break Spared in Health Care Bill
description: The health care bill that passed this week offers subsidies to people with low income so they can afford health insurance. To help pay for those subsidies, people with large incomes will have higher tax bills.

title: Pasta With Sardines
description: Mark Bittman makes a Southern Italian dish with ingredients you can find in your pantry.

title: Whats in Your Health Savings Account?
description: This weeks Your Money column is about how health savings accounts managed to survive the health care reform process and looks at who else may get access to the tax breaks they offer.

title: Alone, Exploring Fleeting Moments
description: A few years ago, Deborah Hay, one of the courageous choreographers responsible for Judson Dance Theater, the radical 1960s movement, pulled back from performing to apply her solo methodology to other dancers.

title: Courts Take On Campaign Finance Decision
description: WASHINGTON  Two federal courts here issued decisions on Friday addressing the impact of Citizens United, Januarys big Supreme Court campaign finance ruling, on a new issue  whether the government may constitutionally restrict the size of contributions to groups that spend money to support political candidates.

title: Palin and McCain, Together Again
description: TUCSON  Senator John McCain and Sarah Palin embraced on stage here on Friday as they made their first joint campaign appearance since their presidential race, with Ms. Palin assuring Republicans in Arizona that Mr. McCain should not be dispatched from office by a conservative challenger.

title: Bringing Back a Concerto From a Youngster, Mozart
description: There are many reasons repertory falls through the cracks. Mozarts charming Keyboard Concerto No. 6 in B flat has perhaps simply been overshadowed by his later masterpieces in the genre. The work received its New York Philharmonic premiere on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, with Jeffrey Kahane performing and conducting from the piano.

title: Credit Suisse Proves a Willing Lender to Directors
description: Directors at Credit Suisse borrowed a bit more money from the generous Swiss banking giant last year, the banks annual report shows. Nine directors accounted for about $23.7 million in loans (based on the current exchange rate of 93.4 cents to the Swiss franc), up from the seven directors who owed about $22.2 million at the end of 2008, according to the annual report, which was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday.

title: Our Lady of Loreto Church
description: Take a look at the frescoed ceilings and fine Italian statuary of the Brooklyn church.

title: Lindpere Is the Red Bulls Traveling Man
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J.  The whistle stops in Joel Lindperes soccer career are not on anyones top 10 list of interesting travel destinations.

title: A Pasta Dish Hiding in the Pantry
description: AT least once a week I scrounge for dinner without shopping, a cooking style that I suppose is counter to current trends but one that admirably displays the benefits of my dedication to pantry stocking.

title: Sunday Preview
description: The shallow waters of Los Roques national park, off the Venezuelan coast, is considered one of the worlds great saltwater fly-fishing spots in the world. Sam Sifton, the restaurant critic for The New York Times, wades into untouched shoreline, and reels them in.

title: Sinatra, Focused on Sex and Sizzle
description: The choreography for the new dance musical Come Fly Away is overwrought. Thats hardly surprising; its by Twyla Tharp, whose artistic temperament has always been marked by ambition and excess, often with exciting results. Its hard to imagine anyone in the audience falling asleep for a moment: the music, nearly all Sinatra songs, is loud, and the dancings energy is whiz-slam high.

title: Quote Unquote | A Follower of Fashion
description: The stylist Nicola Formichetti describes how, as a student, he would cut class to stalk Alexander McQueen. Thats one way to pursue a fashion education.

title: Oh Dad, Poor Dad: What Will CBS Name His Show?
description: CBS is testinga TV show inspired by a Twitter feed with a name that is normally unprintable on this Web site. Lets just call it Shocking, Obscene and Hilarious Statements My Dad Says.

title: Bill on School Lunch Is Scaled Back. Criticism of School Lunch Isnt.
description: Its been an unusually tough month for the people who make school lunches.

title: Send Us Your Videos: What Do You Want to Know?
description: The new health care legislation will significantly impact the delivery ofhealth care in America. But most people do not understand how the changes will affect them. The Times wants to hear your questions, via video submissions, and help answer them.

title: Cities Rush to Woo Google Broadband Before Friday Deadline
description: Update 10:45 p.m. Adding final count of communities expressing interest in the Google Fiber project.

title: Cooking Timers, Golf Tethers, Windup Toys: Its All Rhythm
description: Time and again during the concert that So Percussion presented at Zankel Hall on Thursday night, you found yourself smiling in a quiet amazement that could verge on disbelief. Sometimes this had to do with a sound whose origin you simply could not determine. In other instances the response had more to do with the extremes of imagination and resourcefulness demonstrated by Dan Trueman and Steven Mackey, the composers of two new pieces on the program.

title: High School Gardening  for Credit
description: Starting this week at Princeton Public High School, students can take gym class in the garden.

title: Going Underground in a Private Paris
description: PARIS

title: AT&T to Take $1 Billion Charge for Health Care
description: AT&T said Friday that it would take a $1 billion noncash accounting charge in the first quarter because of the health care overhaul and that it might cut benefits it offers to current and retired workers, The Associated Press reports.

title: Metropolitan Opera Receives $30 Million Gift
description: The philanthropist Ann Ziff has given $30 million to the Metropolitan Opera, the largest single gift from an individual in its history.

title: If Declarer Has a Secret, Keep It
description: The Machlin Womens Swiss Teams was won at the Spring Nationals in Reno, Nev., by Phyllis Fireman of Chestnut Hill, Mass.; Migry Zur Campanile of New York; Shannon Cappelletti of Dania Beach, Fla.; Shawn Quinn of Houston; and Martine Verbeek and Wietske Van Zwol from the Netherlands.

title: Marty Lederhandler Dies; At D-Day and 9/11
description: Marty Lederhandler of The Associated Press  I never want to stop saying that, he declared on his retirement  was there on June 6, 1944, and on Sept. 11, 2001, and on a remarkable number of occasions in between. (Including Gov. Nelson A. Rockefellers honeymoon flight to Venezuela.)

title: In NoMad, a Bar With a Pub Vibe
description: ITS really no wonder that rock stars from abroad, like Bono for one, might feel at home in the new Ace Hotel in the neighborhood labeled NoMad (for north of Madison Square Park). Not only are the hotel rooms outfitted with Gibson guitars, turntables and vinyl records, but the Lobby Bar also has a comfy pub feel throughout its vast space, and the adjoining Breslin Bar serves British-inspired cuisine.

title: Letter From Austin | SXSW Standouts
description: Coming to South by Southwest in search of a record deal seems so last-century. While the festival used to serve a key A&R purpose in showcasing bands for labels, it long ago evolved into more of a showcase for already-established acts to show off their wares. But further down the totem pole from Hole and Stone Temple Pilots, upstart acts still come. The Brooklyn singer-songwriter Alina Simone, who released an album of Russian punk songs in 2008, was back for her fourth South by Southwest because, she said, something weirdly good always seems to happen there. In years past, she picked up a nice write-up in Billboard magazine and found a manager.

title: Solar
description: The place was emptying, and he was not ready. Someone very old with snow in his beard and a damp, unlit cigarette on his lower lip came in muttering ill-temperedly, snatched Beard's bag, took it out to a sled hitched to a snowmobile, and drove off. Both the waitress and Jan had disappeared, and Beard was the only person in the lobby. This was a long-forgotten experience from his school days, not only being late but feeling ignorant and incompetent and wretched, with everyone else mysteriously in the know, as though in league against him. Fatso Beard, always last, useless at team games. With that memory came added clumsiness and indecision. Although he was dressed in ski clothes of many layers, he was expected to climb inside this extra skin, even to wear his own boots inside another pair. There were inner gloves and giant outer gloves, a heavy balaclava made of carpet underlay to wear over his own, and goggles, and a motorcycle helmet.

title: Answers From a Career Counselor, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of responses from Michele LoBianco, who teaches Recession Proofing Your Career at the School of Continuing and Professional Studies at New York University.

title: Greeks, Romans and Financial Reform
description: From Paul Krugman on The Conscience of a Liberal:

title: Survival Tales Told in Snapshots: Czech Jews Enduring the Holocaust
description: We have seen these images before, wizened men and women recalling unspeakable events that occurred when they were teenagers, sometimes tartly mocking their own cluelessness.

title: Manager Sues Axl Rose
description: The company that managed Axl Roses career for much of the last two years has sued him to collect what it says is $1.9 million in unpaid fees. Front Line Management, whose founder and chief executive is Irving Azoff  who is also executive chairman of Live Nation Entertainment, which merged with Ticketmaster last month  filed suit in Los Angeles County Superior Court on Thursday, saying that Mr. Rose, left, is in breach of an oral contract that obliged him to pay Front Line 15 percent of his gross earnings as a performer. The suit says that Mr. Rose has not paid the management fees on recent concerts in Asia, South America and Canada, which grossed $12.5 million. A spokesman for Mr. Azoff declined to comment further on the suit, and representatives for Mr. Rose  including his new manager, Doc McGhee  did not respond to inquiries.

title: Dear Poppa, Sincerely, Jerry
description: Not every fan letter written to Ernest Hemingway merits its own display in a museum, but when its author is J. D. Salinger a little pomp and circumstance is understandable. On Sunday, the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum in Boston will put on display a note from Salinger to Hemingway, written in 1946, that recounts a meeting between the authors and possibly hints at the coming publication of The Catcher in the Rye, The Associated Press reported. In the letter, a young Salinger writes to Dear Poppa that he is in a hospital in Nuremberg, Germany, and says the talks I had with you here were the only hopeful minutes of the whole business. There are flashes of Salingers wit throughout: he asks Hemingway how his latest novel is coming along and warns him not to option it to Hollywood. (Youre a rich guy, he writes. As Chairman of your many fan clubs, I know I speak for all the members when I say Down with Gary Cooper.) Salinger also writes that he has a very sensitive novel in mind, and I wont have the author called a jerk in 1950. (I am a jerk, he continues, but the wrong people musnt know it.) Thomas Putnam, the director of library, told The A.P. there was no indication whether Hemingway ever wrote back.

title: Artist Looks to Be Legal
description: Though the artist Shepard Fairey, right, has become a museum darling, hes still stayed close enough to his street-art roots to have been arrested, jailed overnight and sentenced to two years of probation last year in Boston for pasting his work on buildings before a retrospective at the citys Institute of Contemporary Art. Now, as he prepares for a May exhibition at Deitch Projects in New York, Mr. Fairey is planning to put up street art the polite way, by asking building owners. This is your chance to experience the art and be a part of the OBEY phenomenon, in addition to contributing to the enhancement of the urban landscape, said an announcement this week on Mr. Faireys Web site (obeygiant.com), referring to the name of his studio and his trademark posters. His crew is looking for sites in Manhattan and Brooklyn where owners would allow artwork to be pasted  work that, depending on the kind of material to which it is glued, could last for years. In the past, Mr. Fairey has received permission to paste in some locations in Boston, Cincinnati and Pittsburgh. He might be leaving behind his illicit means for good, or he might just be keeping a low profile until his other legal trouble blows over: a civil lawsuit and a criminal investigation stemming from his use of an Associated Press photograph without permission to make his well-known Barack Obama Hope poster.

title: Transgender Comedy Not Amusing to Some
description: A film selected for the 2010 Tribeca Film Festival, Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives, is having a similar angry effect on some transgender people and their supporters, prompting the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation to call for the films removal from the lineup. In a listing for Ticked-Off Trannies, a comedy by Israel Luna, the film is described as a campy homage to the exploitation films in which a group of transgender women are violently beaten and left for dead, but then the violated vixens turn deadly divas. That summary alone was enough to prompt many angry comments at the festivals Web site, tribecafilm.com. In a statement, GLAAD said, The film, its title and its marketing misrepresent the lives of transgender women and use grotesque, exploitative depictions of violence against transgender women. It urged its members to contact the festival and demand that the film be pulled. The festival responded in a statement: The filmmakers provided a copy of this film to GLAAD in February, and for weeks the organization had been supportive to the filmmakers. In fact, GLAAD representatives advised the films producer, director and cast on how to describe the film to its core constituency. The festival added that it looks forward to the films premiere next month.

title: CBS Wins Thursday
description: CBS led Thursday night in the ratings with its live coverage of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, while medical dramas helped lift ABC to second place. According to Nielsens estimates, an average of 11.1 million viewers tuned in to CBS over the course of prime time, fewer than ABCs Greys Anatomy (11.4 million) in the 9 p.m. hour but more than either Private Practice (8.8 million), on ABC at 10, or ABCs science fiction series FlashForward at 8 (6.2 million). NBC was third, and Fox was fourth.

title: Judging Books by Their Titles
description: Which of these facts is more surprising: that there is an annual contest held by The Bookseller magazine for the years most bizarrely titled book, or that a volume about Nazi eating utensils didnt win it? Sorry, Collectible Spoons of the Third Reich by James A. Yannes, but you received only enough votes to place third in the online competition for the Diagram Prize for Oddest Book Title of the Year, the magazine announced on Friday. A total of 1,912 of the 4,553 ballots cast at TheBookSeller.com went to Crocheting Adventures With Hyperbolic Planes by Dr. Daina Taimina. In a statement, Philip Stone, charts editor of The Bookseller, said that Dr. Taiminas book had won the prize, awarded to a work published in 2009, because, very simply, the title is completely bonkers. Second place went to What Kind of Bean Is This Chihuahua? by Tara Jansen-Meyer. Other top vote-getters included Afterthoughts of a Worm Hunter by David Crompton and The Changing World of Inflammatory Bowel Disease by Ellen Scherl and Marla Dubinsky.

title: Election Results in Iraq
description: Even with a declared winner, Iraqs parliamentary election left almost everything unresolved, and months of tense political maneuvering lie ahead.

title: For 3-D Travelers, a Cosmic Journey
description: In the standard histories of the universe there are so many impossible things to believe before breakfast, as the White Queen put it in Through the Looking Glass  black holes, antigravity, dark matter and all those sneaky subatomic particles zipping through us  that the strangest and most amazing part of the universe gets short shrift. That would be us, collections of space junk, somehow perceiving and pondering the grandiosity that gave us birth in a sort of intellectual and emotional equivalent of the snake eating its tail.

title: The Mystery Cabinet of the Gowanus Canal
description: The former headquarters of the National Packing Box Factory on the banks of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn have not pumped out a packing box in decades.

title: Now Accessorizing | Rabbit Is Rich
description: If the bunny in the book looked anything like this, its no wonder Alice went headlong down the rabbit hole. The jewelers Soraya Silchenstedt and Candice Pool (their line is called Finn) made this 18-karat-gold and diamond pendant for a friend who wanted them to replicate the stuffed animal belonging to her 5-year-old. She was a bit sad at the time, Silchenstedt says, so it had to be really beautiful. The resulting piece,inspired by the mask Candice Bergen wore to Truman Capotes Black and White Ball and photos of rabbits gamboling in the snow, contains 3.5 carats of sparklers of various sizes that are meant to represent snowflakes. Call it bling for the hippity-hop set. Its $9,875 at Barneys New York.

title: Iraqi Election Results: Reactions From Around Iraq
description: As Rod Nordland and Timothy Williams write in The New York Times, the secular coalition led by former Prime Minister Ayad Allawi won the most seats in Iraqs parliamentary elections, narrowly edging out the incumbent Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who angrily denounced the results as fraudulent.

title: The CSI Treatment for the E.R.
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Reyes Runs as Trainers Hold Their Breath
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jose Reyes continues to advance in his conditioning work, getting closer each day to playing in a game. On Friday Reyes ran almost full speed in a straight sprint in the outfield and looked fine doing it, even if the trainers might have been holding their breath.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 26
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Economic Desperation, Reshaping Morality
description: My colleague Jesse McKinley has a fascinating article today about how legal-marijuana advocates are promoting the fiscal virtues of their cause. Not coincidentally, another banned substance was legalized in the wake of major economic upheaval: alcohol, during the Great Depression. The Noble Experiment known as Prohibition ended in 1933, when a legalized alcohol market promised more job opportunities and additional sales tax revenues for governments under stress.

title: For 24, Terror Fight (and Series) Nears End
description: If any one show has represented the post-9/11 era on television, it is 24, the Fox drama that has offered counterterrorism as entertainment for nine years.

title: Moodys Cuts Ambac Debt to Its Lowest Rating
description: Moodys Investors Service on Friday cut the senior unsecured debt of the Ambac Financial Group to its lowest rating above default after the bond insurers major subsidiary was hit with a state regulatory action, The Associated Press reports.

title: Zimbabwe Shrugs Off Gay Rights
description: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwes president, Robert Mugabe, said Thursday that any thought of putting gay rights in the nations new constitution was madness, and Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai, who often disputes almost everything Mr. Mugabe says, this time seemed to agree.

title: As Obama Hails Arms Pact, Applause in Kremlin Is Faint
description: MOSCOW  On a Friday that began in Washington with a triumphant presidential news conference about the conclusion of arms talks with Russia, Moscow seemed to have its mind on other things.

title: Filipino Political Scion, Set to Assume the Mantle
description: QUEZON CITY, the Philippines

title: At End of the Day, a Show and a Superhero Had to Retire
description: It arrives near the end of every season of 24. Call it the moment: the unmarked but discernible instant at which you know you can relax.

title: Heather Rieman, Thaddeus Ferber
description: Heather Ann Rieman and Thaddeus Ethan Ferber are to be married Sunday at Reflections at the Buttes, an event space in Tucson. The Rev. Mark M. Canfield, a minister of the United Church of Christ and an uncle of the bride, is to officiate, with the participation of the Rev. Richard Van Horn, an Episcopal priest.

title: Hes Sensitive About the Pancakes
description: Richard Melville Hall, known to all as Moby, recorded his 2009 album,  Wait for Me,  in his studio in NoLIta, which now doubles as his crash pad while his apartment up the street is being refurbished. A self-professed dweeb, Moby, 44, broke onto the music scene by creating hypnotic dance music and popularizing electronica. His 1999 album,  Play,  went multi-platinum. A longtime vegan, he recently co-edited Gristle, a collection of essays about the hazards of eating meat. He also has a Web site, mobygratis.com, offering free music to independent filmmakers, and he is running a competition to select a new video for the title song on Wait for Me.

title: Kerry McNamara, Brian Gallagher
description: Kerry E. McNamara and Brian M. Gallagher were married Friday at St. Francis de Sales Parish in Far Rockaway, Queens. Msgr. John J. Brown, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Mastin, Brian Giglio
description: Jennifer Ellen Mastin and Brian Michael Giglio were married Saturday at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Washington. Msgr. Alan Placa performed the ceremony.

title: A Relationship as Serious as a Heart Attack
description: SYRACUSE  When Kentucky and West Virginia take the court in Saturdays East Region championship game, two of college basketballs winningest coaches will share a moment in the spotlight for only the ninth time in their careers.

title: Can No Revive the Republicans?
description: Well, Karl Rove isnt one to let a downpour dampen his parade. Democrats are celebrating victory, the Republican strategist wrote in The Wall Street Journal after President Obama signed the health care reform package. The public outcry against what theyve done doesnt seem to bother them. They take it as validation that they are succeeding at transforming America. But weve seen this movie before and it wont end happily for Democrats.

title: Live Updates From the N.C.A.A. Tournaments Round of 16
description: Live coverage and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Ray Glier and Kevin Armstrong will provide updates from St. Louis, and Thayer Evans from Houston. Two longtime Quad contributors who have played in the tournament, Stephen Danley (Penn) and Zach Hillesland (Notre Dame), will also weigh in.

title: Kristen Olson, Joseph Lyons
description: Kristen Elizabeth Olson, the daughter of Linwood L. Olson and John E. Olson of Houston, was married in Austin, Tex., Saturday to Joseph Hurley Lyons, the son of Elaine Hurley Lyons and Paul V. Lyons of Milton, Mass. The Rev. Mike Rinehart, a minister ordained by Riverbend Church, a nondenominational congregation in Austin, officiated at the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center at the University of Texas at Austin. William B. Koffel, a Roman Catholic deacon, took part in the ceremony.

title: Coyote Bound for Undisclosed Location
description: The female coyote who was captured Thursday after roaming the streets of Lower Manhattan is resting comfortably at a shelter uptown, but where she is headed next is a secret. Officials at the parks department refused to say Friday where in the city they intend to release her.

title: Alexandra Harris, Matthew Shear
description: Alexandra Lynn Harris, the daughter of Ruth J. Harris and Eric I. Harris of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to Dr. Matthew James Shear, a son of Beatrix W. Shear and Stephen B. Shear of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Dr. David M. Posner officiated at the Pierre in Manhattan.

title: Keeping a Closer Eye on Employees Social Networking
description: A service released earlier this week by Teneros, an online communication services company, makes it much easier for companies to keep tabs on their employees social networking activities.

title: A Library That Most Can Only Dream Of
description: You, over there, mouthing off about the death of print. Keep it down; this is a library. Not just any library: This is Battery Park Citys public library branch, the citys newest, greenest one yet, and its quite a sight to behold.

title: Liana Sheintal, John Bryant
description: Liana Sheintal, a daughter of Kimberly D. Sheintal and Jonathan Sheintal of Sarasota, Fla., was married there Saturday night to John Whigham Bryant, the son of Mary W. Bryant and Robert W. Bryant Jr. of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Brenner J. Glickman officiated at the C dZan Mansion at the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art.

title: Elizabeth Vicens, Jonathan Bashi
description: Elizabeth Vicens and Jonathan S. Bashi are to be married Sunday afternoon in Brooklyn. Rabbi Jeffrey F. Gale is to officiate at Stage Six at Steiner Studios, an event space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Brian Distelberg and Ryan McAuliffe
description: Brian Joseph Distelberg and Ryan Patrick McAuliffe were married Saturday at the Harvard Faculty Club in Cambridge, Mass. Phoebe Kosman, a friend of the couple who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to perform the ceremony, officiated.

title: Lauren Druyan, Scott Lustig
description: Lauren Ann Druyan, the daughter of Eileen Druyan of Old Westbury, N.Y., and the late Chaim Druyan, was married Saturday evening to Scott Brandon Lustig, the son of Marsha Lustig and Tom Lustig of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Dan Sklar officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in Manhattan.

title: Carolyne Beaty and Todrick Hilton
description: Carolyne Suzanne Beaty and Todrick Shawn Hilton were married Saturday evening at the Biltmore Ballrooms in Atlanta. The Rev. Darlene Henderson, a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Anne Marie Cablitas and Michael Simsuangco
description: Anne Marie Reyes Cablitas, a daughter of Carmen R. Cablitas and Zosimo A. Cablitas of Saddle Brook, N.J., was married Friday to Michael Roy Simsuangco, a son of Elsa N. Simsuangco and Roy L. Simsuangco of Carteret, N.J. The Rev. Colin Kay, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Annes Church in Fair Lawn, N.J., where he is parochial vicar.

title: Tammy Yahner, David Snyder
description: Tammy Lynn Yahner and David Lawrence Snyder were married Saturday morning. The Rev. Gerald Donnelly, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Carolina Inn in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Jennifer Flandro, Scott Sampson
description: Jennifer Lynn Flandro and Scott Paulik Sampson were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. The Rev. Joanna Fernandes, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Montauk Club.

title: Chic in Review | Steven Klein Goes Gaga
description: Babies R UsSelling a T-shirt that reads, Someday Ill Be Trashed at Prom. Look for product placement on 16 and Pregnant.

title: Risa Heller and Ryan Toohey
description: Risa Beth Heller and Ryan Frederick Toohey were married Saturday evening at Coach Insignia, a Detroit restaurant. Rabbi Joshua L. Bennett officiated, with Rabbi Paul Yedwab taking part.

title: Elizabeth Scarlett and Andrew Klingle
description: Elizabeth Scarlett and Andrew Thomas Klingle were married Saturday by Msgr. J. Patrick Keleher, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Newman Center at the State University of New York at Buffalo, where the bride is an associate professor of Spanish literature and culture in the department of Romance languages and literatures.

title: Excerpt: '24'
description: This is the final season for the counter-terrorism series, Fox announced.

title: Jaclyn Cohen, Nathan Nussbaum
description: Jaclyn Ida Cohen and Nathan Coleman Nussbaum are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Down Town Club in Philadelphia. Rabbi Seymour Rosenbloom is to lead the ceremony, with Rabbi Rachel Nussbaum, the bridegrooms sister, participating.

title: Becky Strauss, Max Lipkind
description: Becky Irene Strauss and Max Gregory Lipkind were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Mayer I. Perelmuter officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Alicia Lowery and Eric Rosenbaum
description: Alicia Trinette Lowery and Dr. Eric John Rosenbaum were married Saturday evening at the Yale Club in New York. Rabbi Jeffrey J. Sirkman officiated.

title: Juliette Levy, David Millman
description: Juliette Levy and David Martin Millman were married Monday at the Foundry, a restaurant in Los Angeles. Hannah Ceri Jones, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated.

title: Elizabeth McArdle, Richard Rainey
description: Elizabeth Ann McArdle, the daughter of Judy A. McArdle and Jack J. McArdle of Ardsley, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Richard T. Rainey, a son of Carol N. Rainey and Dr. Jon M. Rainey of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Stephen Sauer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in New Orleans.

title: Melissa Rosenstein, David Benin
description: Dr. Melissa Greer Rosenstein and David Joshua Benin were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Darby Jared Leigh officiated.

title: James Beller Jr., Christopher Wolf
description: James Lee Beller Jr. and Christopher Wolf were married Saturday evening at the Jefferson Hotel in Washington. Judge Paul L. Friedman of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia officiated.

title: Allison Bond, Scott Bischoff
description: Allison Martin Bond, a daughter of Gloria V. Bond of Darien, Conn., and Kenneth W. Bond of Bronxville, N.Y., was married on Saturday to Jonathan Scott Bischoff II, the son of Elizabeth K. Bischoff and J. Robert Bischoff of Wilson, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Terry L. Wilson, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at St. Lukes Chapel in Charleston, S.C.

title: Emilio Morenatti, Honored and Recovered
description: This has been the week for Emilio Morenatti.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 26
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include an unlikely friendship, a jail-themed playground, and a coyote in the city.

title: What Meeting? A-Rod Still in Tampa
description: TAMPA, Fla.  There was no Alex Rodriguez sighting in Buffalo on Friday because the Yankees third baseman did not meet with federal investigators as planned. About 3:30 p.m., Rodriguez jogged into the outfield at Steinbrenner Field for stretching with the rest of his teammates. And he was in the lineup, batting cleanup against the Phillies.

title: Civil Rights Battles, in Black and White
description: Some of the most gripping images in Road to Freedom went unseen for decades. Pictures showing a mob attacking and setting fire to a bus carrying Freedom Riders in Anniston, Ala., are chilling in their step-by-step precision. Yet they were locked away in the files of a law firm.

title: Nuclear Labs Raise Doubts Over Viability of Arsenals
description: In a challenge to the White House, the nations nuclear weapons laboratories have warned Congress that federal programs to extend the life of the nations aging nuclear arsenal are insufficient to guarantee the viability of the weapons for decades to come.

title: Palin Speaks in Favor of McCain
description: John McCain hopes Sarah Palin's credibility with the Right will help him win the nomination of his party for the Senate seat he currently holds. (Video: MSNBC)

title: McCain Recuits Palin for Tough Race
description: Senator John McCain taps former running mate, Sarah Palin, to help him win the nomination of his party for the Senate seat he currently holds. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Chet Simmons, a Founding Force of ESPN, Dies at 81
description: Chet Simmons, a television sports executive with ABC and NBC who became ESPNs first president and then the first commissioner of the upstart United States Football League, died Thursday in Atlanta. He was 81 and had homes in Atlanta and Savannah, Ga.

title: N.Y.P.D. Confidential
description: CASE file: His night began in the bars of Staten Island, and by 2 a.m., he was buying crack cocaine. Inside his car, he flicked a lighter and inhaled. He picked up a woman; they got high together. She left after he spotted the authorities.

title: 4 Charged in Incident at Office of Senator
description: NEW ORLEANS  The conservative activist who in January had been accused of tampering with the telephone system of Senator Mary L. Landrieu  a felony  will instead face only misdemeanor charges in the case, federal prosecutors said Friday.

title: Deciding Who Will Lead a Health Care Leader
description: BOSTON  Here in the cradle of health reform, where universal coverage was pioneered, this years tightening race for governor is focused on the question that now confronts the nation: how to keep spiraling costs from bankrupting the experiment.

title: Police Say Stray Bullet Hit Office of Lawmaker
description: On Thursday, Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the second-ranking Republican leader in the House, said that Democratic members of Congress were not the only ones who had been the targets of threats and vandalism in recent days. He said that he had been threatened, too, and that a bullet had been fired through the window of his campaign office in Richmond.

title: Kandahar, a Battlefield Even Before U.S. Offensive
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  American forces have begun operations to push back Taliban insurgents in this most important southern province, the birthplace and spiritual home of the Taliban, and a full-scale offensive is expected in coming weeks.

title: From Deep in the Closet to a Needy Girls Prom
description: Trapped in closets all over New York, and probably the world, are ghosts from thousands of prom nights, Sweet 16 parties, weddings.

title: Charting Dantes Descent Through 9 Circles of Hell
description: Last June, a small group gathered outside the E3 Expo, the electronic entertainment conference at the Los Angeles Convention Center, to protest Dantes Inferno, a video game based on the 14th-century poem about the underworld. They held signs like EA = Electronic Anti-Christ, referring to Electronic Arts, maker of the video game. Other signage included Play Dantes Inferno, Go to Hell and the assonant Trade in your PlayStation for a pray station.

title: After a Supreme Court Loss, Washingtons Gun Laws Pass Muster
description: Washington can restrict the right of its residents to own guns  again  a federal judge ruled Friday.

title: Harry Carpenter, the Voice of Boxing in Britain, Dies at 84
description: LONDON  Harry Carpenter, a popular sportscaster for the BBC who was hailed as the voice of boxing in Britain and who announced some of the sports biggest fights, died on March 20 in London. He was 84.

title: Biologist Wins Templeton Prize
description: Francisco J. Ayala, a biologist and former Roman Catholic priest whose books and speeches offer reassurance that there is no essential contradiction between religious faith and belief in science, particularly the theory of evolution, has won the 2010 Templeton Prize. The John Templeton Foundation awards the annual prize, worth about $1.5 million, to a living person who has made exceptional contributions to affirming lifes spiritual dimension. Dr. Ayala is an evolutionary biologist and a geneticist at the University of California, Irvine.

title: Maine: Interest in Phone Warning Cools
description: The Maine Senate on Friday joined the House and voted down the bill. With Gov. John Baldacci also opposed, the measure is dead. The Technology Association of America, representing nearly 1,500 technology companies, praised the decision, with Kim Allman, a lobbyist for the group, issuing a statement that said: "We are glad to see that the state legislature in Maine has taken a stand by recognizing that the body of scientific evidence as a whole does not indicate a public health risk caused by mobile phones. Requiring unnecessary labels on wireless devices sold there would have only misled consumers by implying that the federal safety standards are insufficient.

title: Seizures of Illicit Cash Rise
description: Customs authorities along the border with Mexico seized $85 million in illicit cash in the last year, the first year of the Obama administrations enforcement plan, Department of Homeland Security officials said Friday. It was a 22 percent increase over the previous year. More than $29 million of the money was seized leaving the United States, in the first year of expanded inspections of southbound traffic, including screening of all rail shipments to Mexico. Drug seizures in Pacific waters off San Diego increased sixfold, to 57,437 pounds, the officials said.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: IMoveGreen, a new E.P.A.-certified moving company in the Bronx, would like to add a fourth R word to the environmental mantra reduce, reuse and recycle: relocate. In addition to using biodegradable packing materials, reusable plastic boxes and hybrid vehicles, the business donates part of the proceeds from each move to pay for tree-planting in the Brazilian rainforest. As a result, clients need not worry as much about their carbon footprint  leaving them free to be stressed instead about, say, where to put all those books. Jeffrey E. Sitt (above), the owner, said that his rates were comparable to those of other movers and that he would happily move Manolos as well as Birkenstocks. I am not a tree hugger at all, he said. The goal of iMoveGreen is to encourage a simple premise: Be respectful of the environment when moving to a new home. And if, after unpacking, you do discover a scarcity of the citys least renewable resource  storage space  Mr. Sitts green self-storage company, iStoreGreen, which opened in Brooklyn in 2008, can help with that too.

title: In Subway Ads on Abortion, a Pretense of Neutrality
description: The woman in the ad is young and has a short, hip haircut, the kind you see all over the East Village. Her solemn face is half in shadow. I thought life would be the way it was before, the copy reads. And then: Abortion changes you.

title: Panel Suggests That U.S.O.C. Add Members to Its Board
description: A panel led by Paul Tagliabue, the former N.F.L. commissioner, has recommended expanding the United States Olympic Committees board to 15 members from 11, according to a report released Friday.

title: What Were Reading: Steve Jobs, Eric Schmidt and Barbed Wire
description: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times were obsessing about people on Friday:

title: West Virginia Rides a Guard in Full Revival
description: SYRACUSE  Joe Mazzulla introduced himself to the college basketball world in the N.C.A.A. tournament two years ago when he slapped his palms against the court to mock the Duke tradition after West Virginia upset the Blue Devils.

title: F.D.A. Says Millions Got Unapproved Heart Pills
description: Doctors in the United States wrote more than four million prescriptions last year for nitroglycerin tablets, heart drugs placed under the tongue to reduce the chest pain angina or to stop a heart attack.

title: Purging the Pharmacy of Unapproved Drugs
description: If consumers want to know for sure whether the drugs that pharmacists are using to fill their prescriptions have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration, they can check the F.D.A.s Web site.

title: Cigarettes and Hearts Ablaze
description: Smoking cigarettes, which the zeitgeist has determined is unsexy, can nonetheless be a good relationship starter. Theres the business of bumming, the shared sense of exile from polite (nonsmoking) society and, of course, the romantic opportunities of asking for a light. The following poems about cigarettes and romance were found last week in the Missed Connections section of craigslist.newyork.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

title: Toyota Cuts Production in Europe After Sales Slump
description: Toyota Motor said on Friday that it would idle three plants in France and Britain to reduce inventory amid recent recalls and a slump in European sales. The company will suspend output for four days in early April at its factory in Valenciennes, France, and for five days in May at its Burnaston and Deeside factories in Britain, according to a Toyota spokeswoman, Ririko Takeuchi. Toyota also plans to halt one of the two assembly lines at Burnaston for five days in early June, Ms. Takeuchi said.

title: After a Long Layoff, Woods Can Learn From Hogan
description: A frenzied celebrity media throng will await Tiger Woods next month at the gate to the Augusta National Golf Club. Golf history, embodied in the spirit of the resolute Ben Hogan, awaits him on the first tee.

title: Sales Fall at American Apparel
description: American Apparel said sales at its existing stores fell in the fourth quarter and will fall further this year. American Apparel, which operates 281 clothing stores, said that sales at stores open at least a year will probably drop 10 percent in the first quarter. Comparable-store sales, excluding the effects of currency fluctuation, fell 7 percent in the fourth quarter, the company said.

title: Differences Set Aside, Palin Lends McCain Aid
description: TUCSON  They have rarely spoken in 17 months. Their relationship, as America now knows, turned testy before they parted ways. But as at many family reunions, the old feelings were set aside as Sarah Palin embraced Senator John McCain here on Friday and argued that he should not be unseated by a conservative challenger.

title: A Hamlets Eyesores Prompt a Revolt
description: MASTIC BEACH, N.Y.

title: Its Underdog Days Over, Butler Is Thinking Big
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Butler Coach Brad Stevens has not yet thought about taking a tape measure to the rims at Lucas Oil Stadium, the site of next weeks Final Four, just to remind his team that they are indeed 10 feet above the floor.

title: On Sandlot Day, Children Call Their Own Shots
description: Every year, it seems, youth sports become more organized. Uniforms fit better. Seasons stretch another week or two. Even the quality of the snacks has improved at many recreation fields.

title: Why Is This Matzo Different?
description: EIGHTEEN minutes. The whole process must be completed in 18 minutes, to echo the Jews rushing out of Egypt, too quickly for the bread to rise. The flour and water  nothing else  are combined, the dough rolled, perforations made and, poof!, after a brief trip through a 1,000-degree oven: matzo.

title: Voices From the Citys Ethnic News Media
description: SINCE the beginning of time, political scandal has been an important source of nutrition for the press. And so it is for New Yorks ethnic newspapers. They often report such items, however, with a dual focus on the United States and their homelands. In the past month, a Caribbean paper analyzed the troubles of Representative Charles B. Rangel, an Indian newspaper pondered a New York politicians reaction to routine political misbehavior in India, and a Korean paper explored the struggles of Mr. Rangel and Gov. David A. Paterson through their impact on striving minorities  like its own readers. KIRK SEMPLE

title: Talent Agents a New Force in the Video Game Industry
description: LOS ANGELES  It happened to the motion picture industry in the 1930s and the music trade in the 1960s. Talent agents, initially brushed off as nothing more than opportunistic middle men, succeeded in making themselves vital parts of the machinery, helping the fast-growing but messy businesses mature.

title: Coach Says Race Was Factor in Ouster
description: The suspended coach Kevin Broadus has filed a racial discrimination complaint against Binghamton University with the New York State Division of Human Rights.

title: Saarinens Work, in 2 Parts, at Yale
description: Eero Saarinen was one of the most exciting and prolific architects of the 20th century, and the current show of his work at the Yale University Art Gallery and the Yale School of Architecture Gallery further cements his reputation.

title: Voters May Prefer a Crusader in the Governors Race. But Which One?
description: ALBANY  For months, Democratic strategists who support Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo have envisioned a governors race this fall defined by a candidate who was a crusader for political reform far removed from Albanys culture of scandal and dysfunction.

title: Honoring a Long Life? But Shes Just 30 Plus 71
description: Among the ceremonial duties of the consul general of Barbados in New York is a charming custom rooted in the colonial history of that island nation. When a Barbadian here turns 100, the consul attends the birthday party, and each subsequent one, bearing flowers and a proclamation celebrating the persons life and longevity.

title: At the Heart of the Home
description: Stony Brook

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the fallout from the Roman Catholic sexual abuse scandal in Europe misstated the estimated number of children in Ireland who were victims, according to two government reports last year. The report said the children numbered in the tens of thousands, not the hundreds of thousands.

title: Layers of Contradiction in L.I. Hate-Crime Trial
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  The crime seemed brutally simple: Seven high school students attacked two Hispanic immigrants in Patchogue in November 2008, prosecutors said, after a night of Mexican hopping, a sport made of assaulting Latino men in Suffolk County on eastern Long Island.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 26, 2010

title: For Years, Deaf Boys Tried to Tell of Priests Abuse
description: They were deaf, but they were not silent. For decades, a group of men who were sexually abused as children by the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy at a school for the deaf in Wisconsin reported to every type of official they could think of that he was a danger, according to the victims and church documents.

title: Where the Littlest Composers Learn Composure
description: LIKE many 8-year-olds, Chantal Loaiza is occasionally given to shyness. But as she moved about her classroom in a school behind St. Gabriels Roman Catholic Church in New Rochelle last month, dictating to the visiting musicians how she wanted her work-in-progress played, she sounded every bit the confident composer. And that was music to Jon Deaks ears.

title: Alberto Arroyo, Jogger Familiar in Central Park, Dies at 94
description: Alberto Arroyo claimed to be the first person to jog around the Central Park Reservoir, and by the time he died in a Manhattan nursing home at 94 on Thursday, who could dispute him? What is certain is that generations of runners came to treasure the leathery-skinned gentleman with flowing white hair and matching mustache as a peculiarly New York institution.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about Representative Gregory W. Meeks, a Queens Democrat whose spending habits have drawn the scrutiny of ethics watchdogs, misspelled, in some editions, the name of the model of leased car that he drives. It is a Lexus, not a Lexis.

title: Port Authority Official Criticizes Towers Deal
description: The news on Thursday that the Port Authority and the developer Larry A. Silverstein had ceased hostilities and come to a tentative agreement at ground zero was greeted with a great deal of fanfare. But judging from a blistering note the next morning from the Port Authoritys vice chairman, the next 120 days are going to be anything but peaceful.

title: The Storytelling Trance
description: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP

title: New Era Involves Fun and Games for Yanks
