description: TAMPA, Fla.  Before questions about Alex Rodriguez took the smile off his face, Brian Cashman, the Yankees general manager, circulated through the teams clubhouse Friday afternoon checking on those who participated in a nonbaseball, off-site activity that morning  a game of paintball.

title: Lawmakers Recess and Prepare to Defend Health Votes
description: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress headed home on Friday for a two-week recess during which they will try to shape public opinion and defend their votes for or against the new health insurance law.

title: Judge Blocks Closing of 19 New York City Schools
description: A judge on Friday blocked the closing of 19 schools for poor performance, finding the city engaged in significant violations of the new state law governing mayoral control of city schools.

title: An Ear for the Music of the Adirondacks
description: Mike Holober, artistic director of the Westchester Jazz Orchestra, has climbed 45 of the 46 so-called High Peaks in the Adirondacks. So it was only natural that when he wrote the orchestras first original work, he found inspiration in the northern high country, particularly Lake Tear of the Clouds, the Hudson Rivers source, and the nearby Opalescent River  two shimmering spots with which he is well acquainted.

title: Spring Came Too Soon for the Syrup
description: WEST BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  Its on the calendar. Its widely advertised. This year, everybody knows about it but the trees. And they are the central characters in Vermonts annual maple syrup open house this weekend, when tourists descend on the state to watch trees being tapped and sap being boiled.

title: Some States Find Burdens in Health Law
description: Because of the new health care law, Arizona lawmakers must now find a way to maintain insurance coverage for 350,000 children and adults that they slashed just last week to help close a $2.6 billion budget deficit.

title: Corrections
description: The Patient Money column last Saturday, about choosing a nursing home, referred incorrectly to an organization where Janet Wells, who commented on the issue, is director of public policy. The advocacy group is known as NCCNHR (formerly the National Citizens Coalition for Nursing Home Reform). It is not the National Consumer Voice for Quality Long-Term Care, which is a slogan used on the organizations Web site.

title: Catholic Order Admits Its Founder Abused Boys Over Decades
description: ROME  A powerful Roman Catholic religious order acknowledged in a statement on Friday that its founder, a close ally of the late Pope John Paul II, molested seminarians and fathered several children, and it expressed sorrow and grief to anyone damaged by our founders actions.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Friday about Butlers victory over Syracuse on Thursday in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament misspelled the surname of a Butler player in some copies. He is Willie Veasley, not Veazley.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the reaction on the campus of St. Marys College in Moraga, Calif., to its success in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament misstated the given name of the college president. He is Brother Ronald Gallagher, not Robert.

title: Mets Reliever Takahashi Has More Pitches Than He Knows What to Do With
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  During his 11-year career in the major leagues, Rod Barajas has caught future Hall of Famers, Cy Young Award winners, the gifted, the mediocre, the terrible, and everyone in between.

title: Looking for Rodriguez? Dont Head to Buffalo
description: For hours on Friday, reporters in Buffalo staked out the airport and the downtown offices of the United States attorney. They surveyed the building where one of Alex Rodriguezs lawyers works. They were hoping to catch a glimpse of Rodriguez as he slipped into a meeting with federal investigators but, in the end, never spotted him.

title: Corrections
description: A headline last Saturday with an Inside summary for an article about a University of Northern Iowa basketball player whose father played volleyball for Iran in the 1980 Summer Olympics misidentified the location of the university. It is in Cedar Falls, not Cedar Rapids.

title: Rebel Music
description: Music may be the universal language, but those of us who spend our lives with it are expected to know it in depth, from early on. Many composers, whether traditional or experimental, have been steeped in Western classical music from the cradle. That was not the case with me.

title: Arnold Forster, Who Fought Anti-Semitism With Bnai Brith, Is Dead at 97
description: Arnold Forster, an American Jewish leader, lawyer and writer who was a longtime executive of the Anti-Defamation League of Bnai Brith, died on March 7 in the Bronx. He was 97 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: 41 Across: Theyre Made by Origami Artists
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  A big part of any solve is the number of correct assumptions one makes along the way. If ones assumption quotient (A.Q.) is high, it might mean a good day. If its low, things could take a while. Lets take a look at how I fared today, as an example:

title: Corrections
description: An architecture review on Friday about Rising Currents: Projects for New Yorks Waterfront, at the Museum of Modern Art, misspelled the surname of an architect who took part in a research project on which the show is based. He is Adam Yarinsky, not Yarinksy. The review also omitted a firm that was a partner in the design shown in a series of images of Lower Manhattan in 2080. Besides Architecture Research Office, dlandstudio also developed the design.

title: In Hardscrabble Town, Refined Comfort Food
description: BACK in the 1940s, when mall was just a word for shady promenade and downtown Haverstraw was still a shopping hub for Rockland County, the sturdy old brick building that houses Union Restaurant and Bar Latino was a clothing store called Presslers. Its safe to say the Presslers would not recognize the place today.

title: Fresh and Bountiful
description: Anyone interested in cutting food costs will be happy with the prices and the variety offered at La Marqueta, a sparkling new market in Mount Kisco.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 36 this weekend about ways to prevent the next financial crisis misstates the amount of the TARP bailout fund established in 2008. It was $700 billion  not $787 billion, which was the size of the stimulus package approved in 2009.

title: Only Soy Died for These Dishes
description: When Nilsa Rodriguez was growing up in Jersey City, fast food was everywhere, she said. So when Ms. Rodriguez, 46, opened Subias Organic Market and Cafe there in 2003 with her twin sister, Yvonne, and their brother, Eddie, 50, We wanted to show people who eat meat they could have healthy options, she said. (Subia is their mothers original name; their parents ran a bodega on the premises for many years.)

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Carb-Counting Stops Here
description: It might not be possible to live on bread alone, but you may feel inclined to do so when you enter Collinsville Baking Company, where attractive loaves  of ciabatta, rye, six-grain, semolina, whole wheat, country French and more  are piled high on racks behind the counter.

title: From Wlffer, Four Stars
description: Mother Nature was benevolent to Wlffer Estate Vineyard in 2005 and 2007. Roman Roth, the winemaker, captured the grapes richness in two chardonnays and two merlots. These strikingly delicious wines, from Sagaponack, on the South Fork, almost certainly will display more nuance in coming years.

title: Nice and Spicy, but Short of Scorching
description: LEMON LEAF slipped into Mineola last June and took root on Mineola Boulevard, a Thai newcomer in a neighborhood that is a stronghold of Portuguese restaurants. It was not crowded on my visits, but it deserves more attention, for this is a very good place. (The Lemon Leaf Grill in Carle Place is under the same ownership.)

title: Tennessee Fells Another Favorite
description: ST. LOUIS  Tennessees Bobby Maze was stepping to the free-throw line with 13 seconds left in a 1-point game with Ohio State, but the Volunteers J. P. Prince was bent over, hands on his knees and out of gas at the other end of the floor. Wayne Chism, the senior forward, yelled, Come on J. P. for Prince to come up the floor.

title: British Airways Cabin Crews Are Set to Resume Walkout
description: PARIS  British Airways cabin crews will resume their walkout for an additional four days beginning Saturday, labor leaders said Friday, after talks with management failed to resolve a dispute over pay and working conditions.

title: Culinary Surprises and Peruvian Charm
description: WHILE Peruvian cuisine may not be one of the worlds most distinguished, the fare at Quechua (named for the old Inca language and culture) in Norwalk is worth exploring. From the bright abstract rugs on the walls to the warm welcome of our waitress, Quechua exudes good cheer. And its many personal touches, combined with pleasant culinary surprises, raise this sprightly little storefront restaurant a few notches above the usual.

title: Baylor Celebrates Win, Then Plays Another Half
description: HOUSTON  With Baylor already well on its way to the Round of 8, Bears Coach Scott Drew did a little early celebrating Friday night.

title: Donald P. Kelly, Master of Leveraged Buyouts, Dies at 88
description: Donald P. Kelly, a Chicago businessman who in the 1980s helped oversee the $6.2 billion leveraged buyout and breakup of the Beatrice Companies food conglomerate, died March 18 at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 88.

title: The Words of a Victim
description: Steven Geier, 59, is among the former students of St. Johns School for the Deaf who has accused the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy of sexual abuse. He spoke Thursday to David Callender, a reporter covering the story for The Times, in Madison, Wis. The following is a transcript of their conversation. It has been edited and condensed, and it contains mature language.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: In Seoul, Green Transit Is Mayors Pet Project
description: SEOUL  On a recent morning, the mayor of Seoul stopped by a local amusement park to inaugurate an electric tram system to ferry tourists around the grounds, replacing an old noisy one that belched exhaust. Music blared. A phalanx of TV crews trailed him.

title: Bloggingheads: Google vs. China
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Robert Kagan of the Carnegie Endowment debate information technology and freedom in China.

title: Derailing Help for Consumers
description: Washington

title: A Budget for New Yorks Future
description: Like New Jersey, California and almost every other state, New York faces a devastating budget deficit this year  a shortfall estimated at $9 billion and growing. Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch warns that if the budget isnt realigned soon, the state will be out of cash by June 1, maybe earlier.

title: State Budget Stalls on Finding $1 Billion More in Cuts
description: ALBANY  New York State lawmakers ended the week with little progress toward striking a budget deal on time, as the Paterson administration demanded that the Legislature find additional cuts of at least $1 billion, people involved in the negotiations said Friday.

description: Now that the health care bill is passed, what are we going to do with our time?

title: Lawmakers Head Warily for Home
description: Members of Congress are heading into recess with no guarantee that the hateful rancor and violent incidents that marred passage of health care reform will not haunt them anew in their home districts. Democrats subjected to death threats and vandalized offices will have discreet police protection.

description: Medford, Mass.

title: Mr. Obama and Israel
description: After taking office last year, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel privately told many Americans and Europeans that he was committed to and capable of peacemaking, despite the hard-line positions that he had used to get elected for a second time. Trust me, he told them. We were skeptical when we first heard that, and were even more skeptical now.

title: Whose Country Is It?
description: The far-right extremists have gone into conniptions.

title: Another Win Puts Nets Step Further From History
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  For a late-season matchup of teams whose combined winning percentages do not add up to .500, Friday nights Nets-Pistons game at the Izod Center had an unmistakable air of consequence, the scent of history in the unmaking.

title: Toast of a Wine-Making Tradition in Italy
description: VALPOLICELLA, ITALY  There cant be many places in the winemaking world where they start crushing red grapes early in February. The vines are dormant in the northern hemisphere. In Australia the grapes are ripening, but its a bit early for the vintage. In Chile, Argentina and South Africa, the harvesting of the reds is usually just getting underway in March and April.

title: St. Johns Pivots on Its Coaching Search
description: The search for a new St. Johns coach has switched from one locked in on a big-name hire to an exploratory phase.

title: Another  T.S.A. Nominee Withdraws
description: President Obamas choice to lead the agency that guards United States airports abruptly withdrew his nomination on Friday night amid questions about his work as a defense contractor, the second time the White House has lost a nominee for the critical security post.

title: Duke Grinds Its Way Back to Familiar Territory
description: HOUSTON  When Duke received the third No. 1 seed for the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament instead of its fellow top seed Syracuse, it caused a wave of discord.

title: Spartans Writing a New Ending Without a Key Player
description: ST. LOUIS  Michigan State had lost its starting point guard, Kalin Lucas, to a left Achilles heel injury last weekend, but there were still reminders of the Spartans explosiveness Friday night inside the Edward Jones Dome.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Wings One Win Closer to Safety
description: Three games on Friday night, and in one of them the Detroit Red Wings took another step toward assuring themselves of a 19th straight season in the playoffs. That would still leave them 10 seasons shy of the all-time record (Bostons 29, from 1968 through 96), but they can get to that later. Home teams listed first:

title: Driving an Electric Wave
description: They have identical cars but in two different settings. Tom Moloughney lives in the suburbs and Adam Moore in the city. They tell us all about driving the BMW Mini Electric Cooper.

title: Looking Ahead: Round of 8
description: EAST

title: A Second Strike at British Airways
description: British Airways cabin crews began their second walkout in a week on Saturday to protest cost-cutting plans that include a wage freeze and cuts to in-flight staffing.

title: Vettel Sets Stage for Australian Grand Prix
description: Sebastian Vettel sighed with relief and said, Well show them! as he set the pole position for the second time running this season. Two races, two poles  and the seventh pole of his career.

description: Video | Brothers of invention, jalopy edition:

title: Captured Near the Holland Tunnel
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: Classic Ad: Mini
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich writes about the new electric Mini, which BMW has leased to select customers in the United States.

title: Maliki Contests the Result of Iraq Vote
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis party lost the Iraqi election, but a day after the results were announced it became clear that he would fight to hold on to his post  and had taken steps to do so even before the outcome became public.

title: In N.F.L. Draft, Should Marijuana Be a Deal Breaker?
description: News item No. 1, from SI.com:

title: Red Bulls Sign Academy Player
description: One day before their first Major League Soccer game in their new stadium, the Red Bulls signed a second player, striker Juan Agudelo, from their youth development academy.

title: The Saturday Word: Recess
description: With two major victories under his belt this week, President Obama enjoys a getaway at Camp David while Congress is also on recess.

title: Red Hot Patriot
description: Last night I went to see Red Hot Patriot, a one-woman show with Kathleen Turner as the late Molly Ivins (I was there along with a big ACLU contingent). To be honest, I was worried  the play could easily have been either too preachy or too cute. But it got the tone just right. And Kathleen Turner was awesome.

title: FinReg Reading
description: On the whole, I dont like the term FinReg for financial reform  it sounds too DC-ish, not catching the huge importance of the issue. But it is what all the insiders are calling it.

title: Home Run Leaders by Team
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: Its a Little Expensive
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: President Obama was at a bookstore in Iowa yesterday, and he bought a $37 pop-up book for Press Secretary Robert Gibbs son. When he gave it to him  this is true  Gibbs said, Its a little expensive, sir. And Obama said, I can handle it. And then he called the president of China and said, Can I borrow $37? Yes, I am calling collect.

title: Standard Stump Speech
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Well, President Obamas out on the road selling his healthcare plan to the American people. One of the biggest criticisms of this almost 3,000 page bill is its so complicated, its so complex, nobody really understands it. To give you an idea of how confusing this healthcare bill is, more Americans now understand the plot of Lost.

title: More About Bond Vigilantes
description: Yesterday I criticized the WSJ for writing as if a fairly small rise in long-term interest rates spelled doom, doom I tell you, for deficit spending. Brad DeLong has a nice chart. But maybe I can make the case a bit clearer by comparing the current scary, scary rate rise with something that happened back in 2003. Then as now, the economy was growing, but without yet generating job market improvements.

title: A Health Legislation Fail-Safe Works, but Not as Expected
description: WASHINGTON  Just a few months into his first term in 1993, President Bill Clinton went to Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the protector of Senate rules, to ask permission to use a fast-track budget process known as reconciliation to enact a bold health care overhaul.

title: Next Year in the White House: A Seder Tradition
description: WASHINGTON  One evening in April 2008, three low-level staff members from the Obama presidential campaign  a baggage handler, a videographer and an advance man  gathered in the windowless basement of a Pennsylvania hotel for an improvised Passover Seder.

title: Brown and Party Show Signs of Life
description: LONDON  For all but the first few months of the three years he has been at 10 Downing Street, Prime Minister Gordon Brown has been cast by many of Britains leading political pundits as a man doomed to lead the Labour Party to a crashing general election defeat by the opposition Conservatives, ending 13 years of Labour rule.

title: Agencies Suspect Iran Is Planning Atomic Sites
description: WASHINGTON  Six months after the revelation of a secret nuclear enrichment site in Iran, international inspectors and Western intelligence agencies say they suspect that Tehran is preparing to build more sites in defiance of United Nations demands.

title: As Archbishop, Benedict Focused on Doctrine
description: MUNICH  When Pope Benedict XVI was archbishop of Munich and Freising, he was broadly described as a theologian more concerned with doctrinal debates than personnel matters. That, say his defenders, helps explain why he did not keep close tabs on a pedophile priest sent to his archdiocese in 1980 and allowed to work in a parish.

title: Wheel of Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  If youve solved the puzzle, you can go right to Emily Cox and Henry Rathvons notes at the bottom for a little background information and a question.

title: T.S.A. Could Be Leaderless for Months After the Withdrawal of a Second Nominee
description: WASHINGTON  The agency that guards airline security inside the United States is likely to remain without a Senate-confirmed leader for months to come after President Obamas nominee for the position abruptly withdrew late Friday night amid questions from Congress about his work as a defense contractor.

title: Obama Chooses Health Policy Scholar as the Director for Medicare and Medicaid
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will soon name Dr. Donald M. Berwick, an iconoclastic scholar of health policy, to run Medicare and Medicaid, the programs that serve nearly one-third of all Americans, administration officials said Saturday.

title: Why I Joined the Tea Party
description: Many of the Tea Party movement's leaders were jolted into action by economic dislocation, like a job loss or the housing downturn. Diana Reimer is one example.

title: With Scrutiny, Vatican Faces Test of Moral Credibility
description: ROME  As Pope Benedict XVI faces growing pressure to address his role in the handling of sexual abuse cases over the years, the Vatican acknowledged on Saturday that its ability to handle the crisis was a crucial test of its moral credibility.

title: With No Jobs, Plenty of Time for Tea Party
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  When Tom Grimes lost his job as a financial consultant 15 months ago, he called his congressman, a Democrat, for help getting government health care.

title: Jets Woody Johnson Leaps Into the Limelight
description: For years, Woody Johnson was known as the reclusive billionaire owner of the Jets. He ran one of the most secretive organizations in football, the headquarters lined with a barbed-wire fence. So this month, when Johnson verbally slapped the N.F.L. over a clandestine coin flip and invited HBOs cameras into training camp with full access, his behavior seemed so out of character.

title: Hey, PayPal, Why Verify?
description: HAVING recently spent a lot of time on the phone booking an assortment of reservations, the Haggler has been pondering some travel-related mysteries.

title: Death of a Loophole, and Swiss Banks Will Mourn
description: WITH all the hoopla over the health care bill, hardly anybody noticed that a job creation bill that President Obama signed on March 18 makes it much harder for United States citizens to avoid taxes by hiding money in overseas bank accounts.

title: Strickland Is Experiencing a Role Reversal
description: Syracuse

title: Day Traders 2.0: Wired, Angry and Loving It
description: Encinitas, Calif.

title: In Midwest, College Boards of a Different Sort
description: ST. LOUIS  Michigan State forward Delvon Roe has caught some glimpses of Tennessee this season and its handiwork on the backboards. He understands Tennessee makes itself at home on the glass in most games, but he did not necessarily want to hear about it. Roe smiled a wicked smile, and sat up a little straighter in his chair, almost insulted at the suggestion there is another formidable rebounding team out there besides the Spartans.

title: Sometimes, You Have to Say My, Not Our
description: This interview with Debra L. Lee, chairwoman and chief executive of BET Networks,, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Push to Eat Local Food Is Hampered by Shortage
description: EAST MONTPELIER, Vt.  Erica Zimmerman and her husband spent months pasture-raising pigs on their farm here, but when the time came to take them to slaughter, an overbooked facility canceled their appointment.

title: A Clash of Facial Hair in the West
description: SALT LAKE CITY  When Butler and Kansas State take the court for todays West Regional final, it will be an interesting clash of playing styles, coaching styles and hairstyles.

title: Does This Bank Watchdog Have a Bite?
description: Houston

title: Letters: Acorn Revisited, Political Labels and Plagiarism
description: Here are additional reader responses to the columns: Acorn Revisited, Lost in the Secondhand and Journalistic Shoplifting.

title: Seeking a Safe Masters for Woods
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The silver-haired man striding with purpose some 20 yards in front of Phil Mickelson on Friday, clad in khaki pants and a pastel golf shirt, could have easily passed for an honorary observer, a walking scorekeeper or even an unusually fit member of the news media covering the Arnold Palmer Invitational from inside the ropes.

title: Urban Forager | Seize the Day Lily
description: Update, 3:46 p.m., March 29| After publishing this post, City Room was informed that it is illegal to harvest plants in city parks. Details here.

title: Nations Pride in a Single Pitch
description: URASOE, Okinawa  A year later, the play lives on in Japan and South Korea, where the World Baseball Classic has taken on a megalife in its fledgling four-year existence that far surpasses the impact the tournament has had in the United States.

title: Imagining an Israeli Strike on Iran
description: In 1981, Israel destroyed Iraqs nuclear reactor at Osirak, declaring it could not live with the chance the country would get a nuclear weapons capability. In 2007, it wiped out a North Korean-built reactor in Syria. And the next year, the Israelis secretly asked the Bush administration for the equipment and overflight rights they might need some day to strike Irans much better-hidden, better-defended nuclear sites.

title: Patchwork Defense May Weave Playoff Tale
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Everything starts with Raymond Felton. He was the consolation prize in the 2005 draft, picked directly behind the All-Star point guards Chris Paul and Deron Williams.

title: Along Expected Lines, Celebrations and Protests
description: BAGHDAD  As it goes in Iraq, the celebrations and protests following Ayad Allawis election victory were expressions of sectarian identity, displays in which the rhetoric of politics, religion and violence were often indistinguishable. And each was a prelude to a what could be a tough fight over weeks or months to form the next government. Here are two perspectives on Iraqi reactions.

title: No Fun and Games for the Hitting Coach
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The morning after a night game is rough on most people. Saturday, Kevin Long, the Yankees hitting coach, had a worse time than anyone else. At 6:15 a.m., he was in the trainers room getting treatment for the pulled left hamstring he sustained playing paintball on Friday. Long was embarrassed enough about being hurt, and he wanted to be in and done before any players arrived.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 28
description: Its no surprise here that health care remains the dominant topic on Sundays talk shows as Democrats relish a hard-won victory and both parties vie for victory over the topic in Novembers elections.

title: Art That Needs No Hook or Pedestal
description: The Museum of Modern Arts architecture and design collection contains thousands of things that have shaped the way we think about form: a Wedgwood cup, a Tiffany lamp, the Band-Aid, the Q-tip, a Bell helicopter, a New York City manhole cover, the classic chromium public-toilet flush valve.

title: Carrots, Sticks and Lower Premiums
description: FOR all the debate lately, one basic fact about Americas health care crisis is rarely mentioned. Namely, the one thing that could really reform health care is you, collectively speaking: People living healthier lives.

title: Replacement Bones, Grown to Order in the Lab
description: IF a lover breaks your heart, tissue engineers cant fix it. But if sticks and stones break your bones, scientists may be able to grow custom-size replacements.

title: Cars Familiar Profile Returns to Nascar
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Nascars Sprint Cup series will sport a new look on Sunday at Martinsville Speedway. Make that a new, old look.

title: Trying to Tame the Unknowable
description: THE economy is recovering, in baby steps, from the financial crisis and deep recession of 2008 and 2009. A big question still looms on the horizon: What can policy makers do to prevent this kind of thing from happening again?

title: Leave the Budget to the Experts
description: The New York Legislature and Gov. David Paterson are deep into negotiations over the states finances, but one thing is already certain: there will be sharp cuts and palpable pain across the state. To move forward, we must change Albanys budget process.

title: The Wisdom of the Short-Sellers
description: SHORT sellers profit by finding stocks or other securities that will underperform the market. But how do the short-sellers accomplish this? A new study provides some answers.

title: Fleeing Rebels Kill Hundreds of Congolese
description: TAPILI, Congo  Depleted by an American-backed offensive and seemingly desperate for new conscripts, the Lords Resistance Army, one of the most infamous armed groups in Africa, has killed hundreds of villagers in this remote corner of Congo and kidnapped hundreds more, marching them off in a vast human chain, witnesses say.

title: Dont Let Lawmakers Draw Their Districts
description: In 2002, at the end of my fourth term as a New York state senator, I heard that the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, wanted to talk to me. It was the beginning of the decennial state redistricting, and Mr. Bruno showed me a map of his plan for Brooklyn  which had my district cut into pieces and allocated to other senators.

title: Lady Vols Bad Start Only Gets Worse
description: MEMPHIS  Since being suspended for two games after punching an opponent in the face earlier this month, Baylors 6-foot-8 center Brittney Griner had grown somewhat timid, reluctant to fully exert herself, knowing the referees would pay her increased scrutiny.

title: End the Unions Sweetheart Deals
description: New Yorks painful fiscal crisis should be an opportunity to restructure state finances for the benefit of future generations.

title: Mubarak Returns to Egypt; Succession Debate Persists
description: CAIRO  President Hosni Mubarak arrived back in Egypt on Saturday, three weeks after undergoing an operation in Germany, ending a period of intense speculation over the state of his health but maybe not about the future of his countrys leadership.

title: Seeing Red Over R-Rated Trailers
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Overspending Is a Bipartisan Affliction
description: New York has some of the highest state and local taxes in the country, as well as high (and rising) debt from years of borrowing. Why? Because both political parties have electoral bases that support spending.

title: When Does Political Anger Turn to Violence?
description: The mercury is running high, all right, and it has nothing to do with the weather.

title: From a Step Back, a Leap Forward
description: THE idea subverts the old notion of a steady climb up the corporate ladder: Sometimes you have to go backwards in order to get ahead. Its how many careers play out these days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: An Urge to Lead
description: PEOPLE often ask me, Are you Mexican or American? I say, Im Texan. Most of my family has been in south Texas since it was a territory of Mexico.

title: Struggling Towns Must Evolve or Die
description: When Buffalo hosted the 1901 Pan-American Exposition, it was the eighth-largest city in the United States and rightly called itself a city of the future. But for the past half-century, it and other upstate industrial cities have been losing jobs and people. Today, nearly two-thirds of the states population has concentrated in just 12 downstate counties.

title: Pro-Business Lobbying Blitz Takes on Obamas Plan for Wall Street Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  With the Obama administration looking to score another major legislative victory, an array of pro-business groups and fiscal conservatives are mounting a well-financed campaign to scale back or block altogether the Democrats plan to overhaul regulation of the financial industry.

title: File Under Vile
description: OK, I finally got around to reading Douglas Holtz-Eakins op-ed on health care reform. Its much worse than I thought; time to scratch Holtz-Eakin off my shrinking list of reasonable, reasonably honest conservatives.

title: At the Vatican, Up Against the World
description: Of the many heartbreaking details in the latest round of outrage over child sexual abuse in the Catholic Church, one stands out as particularly emblematic: a tidy window into Church leaders mindsets; a bracing glimpse of what went wrong.

title: No More Aid for the Affluent
description: Long after the recession and political crises are history, Albany will continue to be pressed fiscally, unless changes are made in three big areas of state spending: Medicaid, education and employee benefits, which together account for 70 percent of the budget.

title: Someone, Take Charge
description: In the words of Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch, who should know because he was there, Albanys current financial woes are much worse than those of New York City in the dark days of the 1970s. The scale of the budget shortfall is bigger, and there is no government that can help the state the way the state helped the city 35 years ago.

title: Dealing With The Debt: A Brief Note
description: I get a lot of worried mail along the lines of how on earth will we ever be able to pay off our debt? Look, there are real worries  but the math per se isnt very hard.

title: Can New York Be Saved?
description: Three out of four New York residents think their state is headed in the wrong direction, recent polls suggest. No wonder: Its economy, like the rest of the nations, is only now coming out of a severe recession, and unemployment still sits at nearly 9 percent. Lawmakers are struggling to narrow a $9 billion budget deficit. And the states leadership has been hamstrung by corruption, resignations and squabbling. The Op-Ed editors asked seven experts to describe what they would do to save the state.

title: A Master of the Slow Game Whos a Speed Demon, Too
description: The best players in the world are ranked on their ability to play slow, or classical, chess, in which each side has at least a few hours for a game. None of them are slouches at blitz chess, in which an entire game lasts five minutes or less, but it puts a premium on tactical skill and quick thinking  which is usually the forte of younger players.

title: Obama: A Giant-Killer, Feeling His Oats
description: WASHINGTON  Is this it, then? He hath slain the health-care Goliath. Does that mean, a year and a half into the job, that President Obama has acquired the political savvy and tactical confidence to take on other juggernauts?

title: A Papal Conversion
description: Denver

title: Shake, Rattle, Seattle
description: AS an engineer who advises companies on how to make their buildings survive earthquakes, I have visited the aftermath of nearly every key quake since 1970, observing how new and old buildings have performed when the ground shook beneath them. I try to learn from each new disaster how to change our design techniques, construction practices and building codes to reduce future losses of life and damage. From my perspective, the shock that hit Chile in February was the most important earthquake of the last 100 years.

title: Google Searches for a Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON  When Google announced last week that it would shut its censored online search service in China, it was doing more than standing up to a repressive government: it was showing that, with the United States still struggling to develop a foreign policy for the digital age, Internet companies need to articulate their own foreign policies.

title: Why the Line2 App is Up and Down
description: 6:08 p.m. | Updated Peter Sisson now reports: We found another solution to keep out the hackers without taking away the free trial.

title: The Rage Is Not About Health Care
description: THERE were times when last Sundays great G.O.P. health care implosion threatened to bring the thrill back to reality television. On ABCs This Week, a frothing and filibustering Karl Rove all but lost it in a debate with the Obama strategist David Plouffe. A few hours later, the perennially copper-faced Republican leader John Boehner revved up his Hell no, you cant! incantation in the House chamber  instant fodder for a new viral video remixing his rap with will.i.ams Yes, we can! classic from the campaign. Boehner, having previously likened the health care bill to Armageddon, was now so apoplectic you had to wonder if he had just discovered one of its more obscure revenue-generating provisions, a tax on indoor tanning salons.

title: Indonesias Islands Are Buried Treasure for Gravel Pirates
description: Islands in the Indonesian archipelagoare literally disappearing as thieves dig them up and sell the sand and gravel for construction projects in China, Thailand, Hong Kong and Singapore, The Times of London reports.

title: Prime Number
description: 69.2: The percentage increase in the sizeof the main course in 52 paintings of the Last Supper over the last millennium, a study in the International Journal of Obesity found. The study, by the brothers Brian Wansink of Cornell University and Craig Wansink of Virginia Wesleyan College, also found that plate size increased by 66 percent and bread size by 23 percent. Brian Wansink says the findings suggest that the phenomenon of serving bigger portions on bigger plates  which pushes people to overeat  has occurred gradually over the millennium as food has become more abundant and affordable.

title: A Nope for Pope
description: WASHINGTON

title: Hole in None
description: Horton Smith won the first MastersTournament at Augusta National Golf Club, on March 25, pocketing the $1,500 prize for a score of 284 over 72 holes. But for a little luck, the day could have belonged to Billy Burke, the 1931 Open champion. Heres how The Times reported it:

title: Quotations of the Week
description: If the anti-incumbent tide is as strong as some people think it is, I will be swept out, despite all my efforts. If the anti-incumbent tide is a lot of conversation, but has no center of gravity as a true political movement, then Ill be just fine. Theres no way to know.Senator Robert F. Bennett, Republican of Utah.

title: Hobby or Necessity?
description: If you think this latest Israeli-American flap was just the same-old-same-old tiff over settlements, then youre clearly not paying attention  which is how Id describe a lot of Israelis, Arabs and American Jews today.

title: A Fight to Save a Church in Brooklyn
description: Former parishioners try to save Our Lady of Loreto Church, built by Italian immigrants with their own hands in the early 1900s.

title: What Makes It Itch?
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Sometimes its worth taking an extra moment to fully consider what the Sunday puzzles title may mean. In the case of todays, deciphering that CH added to IT forms ITCH is a pretty good hint of whats to come.

title: Vols Looking for Hopson to Find His Rhythm
description: ST. LOUIS  Tennessee Coach Bruce Pearl has recruited one McDonalds all-American, Scotty Hopson, the 6-foot-7 sophomore guard.

title: Q&A With Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe
description: Hans Backe, the new coach of Major League Soccers Red Bulls, is an itinerant soccer lifer. He has zealously followed the game in a coaching career that has lasted nearly 30 years  taking him from his native Sweden to Norway, Denmark, Greece, England, Mexico and now the United States.

title: Williams Works Way Back Into Vols Rotation
description: ST. LOUIS  Brian Williams is the magic act of the Tennessee basketball program. Now you see him. Now you dont.

title: Live Updates From N.C.A.A. Tournaments Round of 8
description: Live coverage and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Pete Thamel will provide updates from Syracuse and Billy Witz will provide updates from Salt Lake. Two longtime Quad contributors who have played in the tournament, Stephen Danley (Penn) and Zach Hillesland (Notre Dame), will also weigh in. You can follow Pete Thamel on Twitter throughout the tournament.

title: Q. & A. With Woody Johnson
description: For the profile on the Jets owner Woody Johnson in The Times on Sunday, I interviewed him on three occasions over two months. I met Johnson once at the new stadium, where we conducted the first interview and took a tour, and twice at his office in New York, which has both a fish tank and a fantastic view of St. Patricks Cathedral. Over all, we spent about five hours talking about his family, his tenure as owner of the Jets, his hobbies, Johnson & Johnson, his charity work. No topics were off limits.

title: Butler Back in the Big Time
description: Butlers run to the Final Four may be unlikely, but basketball fans in Indianapolis with long enough memories recall the Bulldogs playing on the same stage as Big Ten and other major-conference teams in the 1950s and 60s. And in those days before ESPN  heck, in those days when no one on our block had a color TV  a Butler fan could watch the Bulldogs about as often as he could see Indiana and Purdue.

title: Palin Rallies Tea Party Crowd in Nevada
description: SEARCHLIGHT, Nev.  Several thousand people converged on this small town on Saturday for what was billed as a showdown with its most famous native, and one of the highest ranking Democrats in Congress, Senator Harry Reid.

title: States Seeking Cash Hope to Expand Taxes to Services
description: In the scramble to find something, anything, to generate more revenue, states are considering new taxes on virtually everything: garbage pickup, dating services, bowling night, haircuts, even clowns.

title: 4 People Arrested and 30 Guns Seized in Brooklyn Raid
description: Police officers searching a two-story house opposite an elementary school in Brooklyn on Friday night discovered scores of guns, bullet-making materials and an odd array of weapons more appropriate to a Western or a spy novel, including antique firearms and an umbrella with a dagger hidden in its handle, officials said on Saturday.

title: Palin Rallies Tea Party Activists in Reids Nevada Hometown
description: SEARCHLIGHT, Nev.  Several thousand people from as far away as Illinois converged on this small town on Saturday for what was billed as a showdown with its most famous native, and one of the highest-ranking Democrats in Congress, Senator Harry Reid.

title: Butler Goes Home to Indianapolis for Final Four
description: SALT LAKE CITY  As Butlers buses rolled to the Indianapolis airport earlier this week, they passed Lucas Oil Stadium, the site of the Final Four. Hanging from the side of the stadium is a sign that reads: The Road Ends Here.

title: Nominee to Disability Council Is Lightning Rod for Dispute on Views of Autism
description: When President Obama nominated Ari Neeman to the National Council on Disability, many families touched by autism took it as a positive sign. Mr. Neeman would be the first person with the disorder to serve on the council.

title: New Hampshire Budget Gap Fuels Fight Over Gambling
description: Like several other states, New Hampshire has been wrestling with ways to address its budget deficit and has been considering new forms of gambling to help fill its treasury and add jobs.

title: Elinor Smith, One of the Youngest Pioneers of Aviation, Is Dead at 98
description: In the days of rickety open-cockpit biplanes seemingly held together by baling wire, 8-year-old Elinor Patricia Ward got her first flying lesson  at her kitchen table in Freeport, N.Y., on Long Island.

title: In Partisan Battle, Clashes Over Health Lawsuits
description: ATLANTA  Reflecting the bitter partisan divide over health care, governors in at least six states are at war with attorneys general from the other political party about whether to join litigation challenging the new federal health insurance mandate.

title: Illinois Democratic Party Chooses a Familiar Name as Lieutenant Governor Nominee
description: CHICAGO  In the end, the winner of the Illinois Democratic Partys open audition to be the nominee for lieutenant governor was not one of the some 200 unknowns who had stepped forward, among them a brick salesman, a police officer and a violinist. Instead, party leaders on Saturday chose a name familiar across the state: Sheila Simon, the daughter of former Senator Paul Simon.

title: Quake Accentuated Chasm That Has Defined Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The lights of the casino above this wrecked city beckoned as gamblers in freshly pressed clothes streamed to the roulette table and slot machines. In a restaurant nearby, diners quaffed Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin Champagne and ate New Zealand lamb chops at prices rivaling those in Manhattan.

title: Obama Bypasses Senate Process, Filling 15 Posts
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, making a muscular show of his executive authority just one day after Congress left for spring recess, said Saturday that he would bypass the Senate and install 15 appointees, including a union lawyer whose nomination to the National Labor Relations Board was blocked last month with the help of two Democrats.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 36 this weekend about ways to prevent the next financial crisis misstates the amount of the TARP bailout fund established in 2008. It was $700 billion  not $787 billion, the size of the stimulus package approved in 2009.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transcription error, the Boss feature last Sunday about Eric Hippeau, chief executive of The Huffington Post, misstated his description of the companys growth rate. He said that its revenue and its traffic have roughly doubled each year in its four-and-a-half-year history  not that they have doubled over that entire period. The column also misidentified the magazine where Mr. Hippeau was once publisher. It was PC Magazine, not PC World.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Patti Smith misstated the title of one of her songs. It is Because the Night, not Because of the Night.

title: Defending Champions in Rally Disqualified
description: The 20th edition of the Rallye Acha des Gazelles in Morocco came to a close Thursday, with the official prizes awarded Saturday in Essaouira after the defending champions were disqualified for cheating. The winners of the nine-day, all-women road rally were Christine Laloue and Claudine Amat of France. The defending champions, Corentine Quiniou and Florence Migraine Bourgnon, were disqualified after the officials determined they had been manipulating their satellite tracking device and setting back their odometer.

title: Corrections
description: MAGAZINE

title: Unquestioned Recruiter, Oft-Questioned Coach
description: HOUSTON  After a 90-79 first-round loss to Purdue in the N.C.A.A. tournament two years ago in which his teams poor transition defense resembled that played in an Amateur Athletic Union game, Baylor Coach Scott Drew was frustrated.

title: Other Voices: Sorting the Victims and Villains
description: Re The Acorn Sting Revisited (March 21):

title: The Boys Have Fallen Behind
description: Around the globe, its mostly girls who lack educational opportunities. Even in the United States, many people still associate the educational gender gap with girls left behind in math.

title: Credit Ratings: The View From Standard & Poors
description: To the Editor:

title: Arms Controls New Era
description: The negotiations took a lot longer and were more grueling than anyone expected, but the United States and Russia have finally agreed on a nuclear weapons agreement to replace the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. Although the deal makes only modest cuts in both countries arsenals, President Obama deserves credit for reviving an arms control process that his predecessor disparaged as a cold-war relic. He is now leading the way on reducing the nuclear threat.

title: Making Haiti Whole
description: A donors conference at the United Nations this Wednesday is meant to be the beginning of the long, slow birth of a new Haiti. Representatives of the Haitian government, the United States and other nations and aid organizations will be discussing large, ambitious, farsighted plans. Participants will be asked for lots of money: $11.5 billion to start, $34.4 billion over 10 years.

title: An Exceptional Nominee
description: The first major appeals-court nomination fight of the Obama presidency may be shaping up over Goodwin Liu, a highly qualified teacher and legal scholar. Mr. Liu, nominated to the San Francisco-based United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, is raising hackles on the right because of some of his legal views, and because he is seen as a strong candidate for the Supreme Court in the near future. The White House and Senate Democrats should fight hard for the confirmation.

title: In Finance Reform, an Opportunity for Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Human Currency in Mexicos Drug Trade
description: Mexico City

title: Afghan Poppies, American Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: Centrist Voices, Drowned Out by Hyperpartisans
description: To the Editor:

title: Player Ratings: Red Bulls vs. Chicago
description: HARRISON, N.J.  A frosty night for the first M.L.S. game at the new $200 million, 25,000-seat Red Bull Arena. The temperature was 39. By the end of the game it was 38 degrees (but the WeatherBug said it felt like 28). Club missed an opportunity for the perfect opening promotion  Red Bull Long Underwear Night!

title: Correction
description: A short article in the In Transit column last Sunday about the Marina Bay Sands Resort in Singapore, using information from a publicist, misstated the number of rooms at the resort, which has scheduled a preview opening on April 27 and a grand opening on June 23. The Marina Bay Sands will have 2,560 rooms  not 963, which is the number of rooms expected to be open for the preview.

title: Vows: Brian & Ryan
description: Brian Distelberg and Ryan McAuliffe met at Harvard eight years ago. They agreed to a date at a coffee shop and realized sparks over mugs. Being each other's first love, they've been together ever since.

title: Solid Outing Hints at Chamberlains Relief Role
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  In his first relief appearance since losing the fifth starters job to Phil Hughes, Joba Chamberlain made two mistakes even before he reached the mound Saturday. He threw too many warmup pitches in the bullpen, and then he miscalculated the distance to jog in from the bullpen in right-center.

title: Reyes Feels Ready to Play, but Mets Are in No Rush
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Moments before Jose Reyes burned across the outfield of Field No. 2 at near top speed, he walked past General Manager Omar Minaya, who was driving a golf cart from one end of the Mets complex to another. The two spoke for a moment in Spanish as Reyes, backpedaling in the opposite direction, yelled to Minaya that he was ready to play.

title: A High Profile for Fehr in the Players Union
description: For Donald Fehr, it was a subtle shift but a potentially significant one.

title: For Nets, Lottery Is No Sure Thing
description: By recording their ninth victory Friday night, the Nets avoided becoming the worst team in N.B.A. history. But they entered Saturdays game against the Chicago Bulls with a chance to finish in a tie for that distinction with the 1972-73 Philadelphia 76ers if they did not record a victory in the last 10 games.

title: Technology Can Improve Health Care
description: In 1900, an American man could expect to live on average until he was 45 years old. By 1940, that life-expectancy number had jumped to 62 years, while for women the average number increased from 51 years to 66 years.

title: Crane Falls Against Financial District Building
description: A crane tipped and fell against a commercial building in Lower Manhattan on Saturday evening. There were no injuries, the police said, but four buildings and part of a fifth were evacuated and traffic was rerouted.

title: Ai, a Steadfast Poetic Channel of Hard Lives, Dies at 62
description: The prominent American poet Ai, whose work  known for its raw power, jagged edges and unflinching examination of violence and despair  stood as a damning indictment of American society, died on March 20 in Stillwater, Okla. She was 62 and lived in Stillwater.

title: A Race for Assembly, Strikingly Varied
description: Given the dysfunction in Sacramento, it is a little surprising that anyone with stature in a community would want to run for the Legislature these days. But in the Democratic Party primary to represent a Peninsula district in the Assembly, three such gluttons for punishment have stepped forward.

title: Blanche Thebom, Star at the Met and Beyond, Dies at 94
description: Blanche Thebom, a mezzo-soprano who was discovered singing in a shipboard lounge as a teenager and went on to sing more than 350 performances with the Metropolitan Opera, died on Tuesday at her home in San Francisco. She was 94.

title: Closing of Auto Plant Forces Suppliers to Scramble
description: For the last nine years Doc Skinner, a plant manager at the Vuteq California Corporation in Hayward, has supervised the 65 employees who build interior trim parts for the Toyota Tacoma truck. But that part of his rsum is no longer likely to secure his financial future.

title: After a Long Ride, the Fantasy of a Perfect Day
description: Markos Moulitsas is founder and publisher of Daily Kos, the largest liberal blog in the United States, with one million to three million unique visitors a month. Mr. Moulitsas, 38, started his blog in 2002 after a stint at law school persuaded him that it would be a cold day in hell before he ever worked as a lawyer. Born to a Salvadoran mother and a Greek father, he is the co-author of Crashing the Gate: Netroots, Grassroots and the Rise of People-Powered Politics. He lives in Berkeley with his wife and two children. (His words have been edited and condensed.)

title: The Male Half of the Sky
description: The idea for my Sunday column, about why boys fail, arose in part when Sheryl and I were on book tour peddling our book Half the Sky. We would talk about how women in poor countries were being left behind, and so often some member of the audience would say something like: But why are boys in this country lagging?

title: Audio Aesthetics a Bit Removed From the Standard Do-Re-Mi
description: On a craggy outcrop in the Marina, the sounds of the sea become art. The Wave Organ, a sprawling waterfront sound-art installation created with materials from a demolished cemetery, has been quietly performing an oceanic symphony since 1986. Pausing to cup an ear to one of many protruding pipes amid the installations sun-blanched granite and marble terraces, you hear a strange liquid music. It alternately whispers like wind passing through conch shells, gurgles like an old man laughing and assaults the senses with cataclysmic thunderclaps.

title: No Meltdown for You
description: HOUSTON  Although tradition-rich Duke has not been to a Final Four since 2004 or won a national championship since 2001, Coach Mike Krzyzewski insists that he does not feel any added pressure this N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: In Sundays Bay Area Report
description: Plant Closing Forces Suppliers to Scramble | New United Motor Manufacturing, which is jointly owned by Toyota and General Motors, will close on Thursday  throwing 4,700 people out of work. Some of its suppliers are rushing to create new markets and products. It is a race against time, but some may succeed if they are nimble enough to reinvent themselves.

title: Seeking Edge on School? Its Just a Fact of Life
description: As I took my kindergartner to Ravenswood Elementary School last week, most parents were ignorant of the latest Chicago Public Schools scandal. The few who knew werent aghast to learn that theres gambling in Casablanca.

title: A Promise of Jobs Remains Only Partly Fulfilled
description: When Ronald Bender and about 260 other workers were unexpectedly laid off from a North Side window factory 15 months ago, they staged a sit-in and gained national attention as symbols of a work force battered by hard times.

title: A Graffiti Artist Hides; Reporter Seeks
description: It came to me in one of those terrifying flashes of clarity that drive some people to drink and and others to gorge on pie: My life had become a cut-rate Samuel Beckett play.

title: West Virginia Ends Half-Century of Waiting
description: SYRACUSE  After West Virginias loss at Connecticut on Feb. 22, West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins sat his team in a circle in the locker room. Huggins has broken a few chairs and made some power forwards blush with his language over the years, but that day he calmly reminded the Mountaineers of their potential.

title: The Pulse: Scrutinizing the Numbers in Caterpillars Complaint
description: Caterpillar Inc. of Peoria has jumped to the forefront of manufacturing companies complaining about the cost of the federal health care overhaul. On March 18 the company sent a letter to Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Representative John A. Boehner, the Republican leader, saying mandated changes would cost it $100 million in the first year alone.

title: The Pulse: Massage Measure Advances, but Only Up to a Point
description: Despite the opposition of Mayor Richard M. Daley's top zoning official, the City Council's zoning committee last week endorsed a proposed ordinance meant to deter new massage parlors near residential neighborhoods.

title: South Korea Searches for Survivors of Sunken Navy Ship
description: The South Korean Navy continued its search for survivors of a sunken patrol ship in waters near the disputed western maritime border with North Korea on Sunday. Hopes were dimming for 46 missing sailors, and the mystery of what caused their ship to break in half in a blast and sink Friday evening remained unresolved.

title: Rare Lapse by Lundqvist Costs Rangers
description: TORONTO  Henrik Lundqvist has saved the Rangers countless times in his five years in the N.H.L., never more often than this season.

title: Nets Winning Streak, Their First of Season, Ends at 2
description: CHICAGO  Having secured their ninth victory of a desperately forgettable season Friday night against Detroit, the Nets will not go down as the most futile team in N.B.A. history.

title: A True Spartan, Playing Through Pain
description: ST. LOUIS  When Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo whistles the start of War, a five-minute practice drill in which five players in the paint block out five hard-charging perimeter players, he sends Delvon Roe, his 6-foot-8, 220-pound soldier, off the floor.

title: Does This Bank Watchdog Have a Bite?
description: For now at least, the nations front line for consumer financial protection resides on the 34th floor of a downtown office tower in Houston amid cubicles surrounded by posters that read, Improving the Customer Experience  Be a LEADER in every call.

title: No Closure for Wizards in Arenas Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Gilbert Arenas saga is over, at least as far as the judicial system is concerned, and that was enough for Ernie Grunfeld, the Washington Wizards president, to declare closure. The truth is more complicated.

title: Mountaineers Are Comfortable With Being Favorites
description: SYRACUSE  With half of the Final Four set, the early read here is that West Virginia will be considered the resounding favorite. Butler joined the fray earlier Saturday, but even with a home-court advantage in Indianapolis its hard to consider the Bulldogs favorites.

title: Day Traders 2.0: Wired, Angry and Loving It
description: Remember the day traders?

title: Baylors in the Zone, and Duke Is Ready
description: HOUSTON  With third-seeded Baylors 1-2-2 zone having stifled a strong shooting team in 10th-seeded St. Marys on Friday night, Duke got plenty of questions Saturday about facing it.

title: Vasily Smyslov, Former World Chess Champion, Dies at 89
description: Vasily Smyslov, the seventh world chess champion, who was known for both the artistry of his play and the solidity of his technique, died Saturday at a hospital in Moscow. He was 89.

title: Lobbying Blitz Takes On Obamas Wall St. Overhaul
description: With the Obama administration looking to score another major legislative victory, an array of pro-business groups and fiscal conservatives are mounting a well-financed campaign to scale back or block altogether the Democrats plan to overhaul regulation of the financial industry, The New York Timess Eric Lichtblau and Edward Wyatt report from Washington.

title: The Word on Obamas Recess Appointments
description: Sometimes, nominees get held up because they are controversial, like Craig Becker, a labor lawyer who Republicans thought might relate too well to one side in issues brought before the National Labor Relations Board. Sometimes, nominees for tax-related jobs get held up because a senator is angry about a ban on candy-flavored cigarettes in Canada. And sometimes, a presidents political base doesnt like who he has chosen. President Obamas 15 recess appointments, announced on Saturday, were held up for a variety of reasons. Heres a roundup of the new officials:

title: Kirkuk: Arabs, Baathists, Insurgents and Turkmens United Against the Kurds
description: KIRKUK, Iraq  Amazing and surprising were some of the words exchanged Saturday by many jubilant Arab and Turkmen residents of this hotly disputed northern Iraqi city.

title: Not Liking the Stool
description: HOUSTON  Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski hated the stool that he sat on during his top-seeded teams victory against fourth-seeded Purdue in the N.C.A.A. tournaments South Region semifinals on Friday night.

title: Keeping It Clean at Baylor
description: HOUSTON  As a small private Baptist university, Baylor is sometimes mocked by opposing fans for its religious affiliation.

title: Button Wins Wild Australian Grand Prix
description: MELBOURNE  After two weeks of criticism over a processional race at the season opener in Bahrain and accusations that the Formula Ones new rules had made the series a bore, the second race of the season proved to be one of the most exciting in the last decade.

title: Tulipmania at Amsterdam Museum
description: Tulips were as important a part of the Dutch Golden Age as canal houses. They were treasured as possessions, speculated upon as commodities and revered as subjects for artists. Though so-called tulipmania has died down, aspects of the obsession continue. Every spring, Dutch crowds and tourists flock to the Keukenhof gardens to take in endless fields of flowers, and the flowers are the subject of a small ongoing exhibition at the Rijksmuseum (Stadhouderskade 42; 31-20-674-7000; www.rijksmuseum.nl), simply titled Tulips in Amsterdam.

title: Rajon Rondos Sticky Fingers
description: Kentucky is one of the most storied programs in college basketball, and the Celtics are one of the most storied franchises in professional basketball. So the fact that Boston point guard Rajon Rondo owns the single-season record for steals for Kentucky and the Celtics is saying something.

title: Ask About Growing Indoor Plants
description: This week, Tibor Fuchs, president of the Metropolitan New York Chapter of the Indoor Gardening Society of America, responded to readers questions about growing plants and keeping them alive inside.

title: Thai Premier Faces Off With Leaders of Protests
description: BANGKOK  Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva of Thailand met Sunday with leaders of the antigovernment protest movement here, the first significant effort to defuse two weeks of street protests.

title: Former Giants Linebacker Cliff Livingston Dies at 79
description: From an obituary that will be appearing in The Times.

title: 2 Are Killed in Stabbings on Subway in Manhattan
description: Two men were fatally stabbed early Sunday morning in a brawl on a subway car in Lower Manhattan, and by the evening detectives were questioning two men in connection with the deaths, a law enforcement official said.

title: Video: Why I Joined the Tea Party
description: In an article published today, The Timess Kate Zernike examines  the influences of economic dislocation on people who have joined the Tea Party movement. Many were jolted into political action. We produced a video featuring one member, Diana Reimer, who has become a leader in the effort.

title: Looking Ahead: Round of 8
description: Midwest

title: Bucks Improvise, and Improve
description: After guard Michael Redd sustained a knee injury against the Lakers on Jan. 10, the Milwaukee Bucks were four games under .500 and preparing to play the rest of the season without one of their most talented and highest-paid players.

title: In Afghan Trip, Obama Presses Karzai on Graft
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Obama personally delivered pointed criticism to President Hamid Karzai in a face-to-face meeting on Sunday, flying here for an unannounced visit that reflected growing vexation with Mr. Karzai as Americas military commitment to defeat the Taliban insurgency has deepened.

title: Smear Today, Gone Tomorrow
description: That was fast. Via Jon Chait, I learn that a whole smear campaign against me was born and died before I even heard about it.

title: Crist, Rubio Spar Over Spending in Debate
description: MIAMI  Spending, spending, spending  Social Security spending, $787 billion in stimulus spending and a $134 hair cut.

title: Democrats Defend Appointments
description: A leading Republican predicted Sunday that President Obamas appointment of 15 officials while sidestepping Senate confirmation would make it more difficult to get bipartisan support for future legislation.

title: Poor 3-Point Shooting Is Kentuckys Downfall
description: SYRACUSE  In the teary locker room following a loss in the East Regional championship game Saturday night, Kentuckys players shrugged off a dismal shooting performance as just one of those nightmarish nights.

title: The Wisdom of the Short-Sellers
description: Short-sellers profit by finding stocks or other securities that will underperform the market. But how do the short-sellers accomplish this? A new study provides some answers, Mark Hulbert writes in his Strategies column in The New York Times.

title: North Korea Warns South Over Buffer Zone
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea accused the United States and South Korea on Monday of creating provocations by allowing tourists and journalists into the heavily armed buffer zone that has divided the Korean Peninsula since the armistice signed more than a half century ago.

title: Live Updates From N.C.A.A. Tournaments Round of 8
description: Live coverage and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Ray Glier and Kevin Armstrong will provide updates from St. Louis and Thayer Evans will provide updates from Houston. Two longtime Quad contributors who have played in the tournament, Stephen Danley (Penn) and Zach Hillesland (Notre Dame), will also weigh in. You can also follow Pete Thamel on Twitter throughout the tournament.

title: Iraqi Exiles Celebrate in New York
description: NEW YORK  It was 10:30 a.m. on Friday when our political cinema professor at the Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute at N.Y.U. gave us a five-minute break before watching the movie Battleship Potemkin.

title: Chinese Activist Surfaces After a Year in Custody
description: BEIJING  Gao Zhisheng, the Chinese rights activist who has been missing for more than a year, has resurfaced near his hometown in northern China.

title: Telecom Industry Seems Ripe for Consolidation
description: Naguib Sawiris, the chief executive of Orascom, the Egyptian group that runs wireless phone networks around the world, believes the global industry of mobile operators is about to enter a turbulent period of Darwinian struggle, The New York Timess Kevin J. OBrien reports from Berlin.

title: Freed American in Iraq Expected to Return to U.S.
description: BAGHDAD  An American civilian who had been kidnapped and held for more than two months by a Shiite militia group was released several days ago, and will return within a week to the United States, the American military said.

title: Geely of China Agrees to Buy Volvo From Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company reached an agreement on Sunday to sell its Volvo subsidiary to a Chinese conglomerate, in the clearest confirmation yet of Chinas global ambitions in the auto industry, The New York Timess Keith Bradsher reports from Hong Kong.

title: Washington Mutual Files Chapter 11 Plan
description: Washington Mutual filed a Chapter 11 reorganization plan, two weeks after resolving a $4 billion dispute with JPMorgan Chase and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, The Associated Press reports.

title: Opinions About Chamberlain Are Not a Secret Anymore
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Lesson No. 1 for Yankees pro personnel director Billy Eppler: In the land of pinstripes and Joba Chamberlain, leave yourself some wiggle room.

title: Search Continues for Head of Abu Dhabi Fund
description: Rescuers searched a Moroccan hillside lake on Sunday for the head of the worlds largest sovereign fund, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, two days after his plane crashed into it, Reuters reports.

title: Crist and Rubio Spar Over Spending in Debate
description: MIAMI  Gov. Charlie Crist and Marco Rubio faced off Sunday in the first debate of the race to become Floridas next senator, and each unleashed a line of attack based on dollars and cents.

title: Obama Speaks in Afghanistan
description: President Obama makes a surprise trip to Afghanistan and addresses U.S. troops at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan. (Video: MSNBC)

title: New CDs
description: ALAN JACKSON Freight Train (Arista Nashville)

title: Broadways Unlikely Hit Gives Hope to the Bold
description: Bipolar disorder, electroshock therapy, a yearning for peace of mind: these are not the usual elements of a successful Broadway musical. Yet Next to Normal, which passed its one-year mark on Broadway on Saturday and is preparing for a national tour in November, now qualifies as a hit: it has earned back its $4 million capitalization, the producers said last week.

title: Unearthing the Sex Secrets of the Prigord Black Truffle
description: The black truffle of Prigord, the cynosure of every foodies dreams, is about to yield its most intimate secrets to a team of French and Italian researchers who have decoded its genome. Surely a great day for gastronomy and yet  truffle-lovers be advised  some of the new discoveries may reveal more than you really wanted to know.

title: Power Tools
description: If you were an avid television watcher in the 1980s, you may remember a clever show called Moonlighting. Known for its snappy dialogue and the romantic chemistry between its co-stars, it featured Cybill Shepherd and Bruce Willis as a couple of wisecracking private detectives named Maddie Hayes and David Addison. While investigating one particularly tough case, David asks a coroners assistant for his best guess about possible suspects. Beats me, says the assistant. But you know what I dont understand? To which David replies, Logarithms? Then, reacting to Maddies look: What? You understood those?

title: A Composer Who Knows His Way Around a Piano
description: This season Carnegie Halls Keyboard Virtuosos I series has already presented recitals by Murray Perahia, Vladimir Feltsman and Emanuel Ax. Maurizio Pollini appears in April.

title: Funk, Jazz and Bollywood With Rhythms of Africa
description: It took about an hour before Anglique Kidjo had the crowd on its feet en masse at Town Hall on Friday night, but once she did there was no turning back. Dedicating her next song, Afirika, to the great South African singer Miriam Makeba, she slipped into the wings and reappeared on the floor, belting her way up and down the aisles. Then she summoned any and all comers onto the stage for Agolo, and kept them there for Tumba, which became an amateur dance-off, utopian in its welcoming exuberance.

title: Learning About War Through a Camera Lens
description: Tatjana Solis haunting debut novel begins where it ought to end. In this quietly mesmerizing book about journalists covering the war in Vietnam, the first glimpses of the place are the most familiar. The year is 1975. Americans are in a state of panic as North Vietnamese forces prepare to occupy Saigon. The looters, the desperate efforts to escape this war zone, the mobs surrounding the United States Embassy, the overcrowded helicopters struggling to rise above the chaos: these images seem to introduce Ms. Solis readers to a story they already know.

title: Michigan State Soothes Its Aches With a Little Perseverance
description: ST. LOUIS  In order to return to the national semifinals, Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo duct-taped his defense, rotated 11 players onto the court and overcame rocky relationships with point guard Korie Lucious and shooting guard Durrell Summers. Izzo called the loss of point guard Kalin Lucas to a ruptured Achilles tendon last weekend traumatizing, but he kept it all together to exceed expectations again.

title: A Discard Proves Crucial in the Swiss Teams
description: The Open Swiss Teams event at the end of the Spring Nationals in Reno, Nev., was won by John Diamond of Boca Raton, Fla.; Brian Platnick of Evanston, Ill.; Eric Greco of Philadelphia; Geoff Hampson and Fred Gitelman of Las Vegas; and Brad Moss of San Anselmo, Calif.

title: JPMorgan Says Dubai Plan May Be Negative for Banks
description: The debt-restructuring plan of Dubai World may prove to be negative for its bank creditors because loan repayments will be financed by asset sales and dividends, according to JPMorgan Chase, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Invigorated by Challenges, an Eager Symphony Steps Up
description: This season the big news in American classical music has been driven by Gustavo Dudamel at the Los Angeles Philharmonic and Alan Gilbert at the New York Philharmonic. Amid all the talk of innovations at these and other orchestras, the continued success of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra under Michael Tilson Thomas, in his 15th year as music director, has perhaps been taken for granted.

title: Obama's Visit to Afghanistan
description: President Obama made an unannounced visit to Afghanistan, his first as commander in chief.

title: Exuberant Alienation Wearing Sneakers and Jeans in the Big, Bad City
description: It takes a particular kind of work to let students youthful qualities shine through without obscuring their prodigious technical abilities. In the latest installment of Juilliard Dances Repertory, on Thursday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, that work was Jerome Robbinss N.Y. Export: Opus Jazz.

title: In Praise of a Virile Star of the Bolshoi
description: Ballet galas are not for the fainthearted. Full of Big International Stars and Big International Egos, high on technical tricks and low on artistic integrity, they are like a buffet of delicious dishes that makes you feel full in no time.

title: City Critic | Reading Green
description: A tour of the new, environmentally friendly public library in Battery Park City.

title: From a Cooing Voice, New Moods and Knots
description: Norah Jones had just finished oozing her way through Sunrise on Saturday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden when an audience member piped up with some surprising news.

title: Famous Features
description: [Pippi Longstocking] had no mother and no father, and that was of course very nice because there was no one to tell her to go bed just when she was having the most fun, and no one who could make her take cod liver oil when she much preferred caramel candy.

title: Going Clubbing by Staying at Home
description: The crowd was about 50 strong, dressed somewhere between postwork casual and preclub glam, when Nicole Atkins plugged in her guitar on Friday evening and began to play. She hawked her CDs between songs, and the sound system was run by a Knitting Factory employee  all pretty typical for Ms. Atkins, a New Jersey-bred songwriter who has reams of critical acclaim but is still struggling for her big break.

title: Closing Date for The Miracle Worker
description: After only 21 preview performances and 38 regular performances, the Broadway revival of William Gibsons play The Miracle Worker will close at Circle in the Square Theater next Sunday, the producers David Richenthal and Dini von Mueffling said on Sunday. The show cost $2.6 million to mount and will close at a total loss to its producers and investors, a spokesman for the show said.

title: Sound and Fury Signify Significance at Red Bull Arena
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The new Red Bull Arena can create a sensory overload for spectators.

title: Japanese Team Wins Pritzker Architecture Prize
description: Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa, partners in the Japanese architectural firm Sanaa, have won the 2010 Pritzker Architecture Prize, the professions highest honor.

title: Styles That Are Centuries, or Even Just a Day, Apart
description: Beethoven Then and Now: The Complete Symphonies, the weekend festival presented by Great Performers at Lincoln Center that offered concerts by two orchestras, first in period style, then in modern style, seemed intended to invite close comparisons. But with variables more often multiplied than curtailed, it allowed, in the end, for only the broadest judgments.

title: Robin Hood to Open Cannes Film Festival
description: The premiere of Robin Hood, from the director Ridley Scott, will be the opening film of the 2010 Cannes Film Festival, Reuters reported.
