And though Robins men look more menacing than merry in this script by the Green Zone screenwriter, Brian Helgeland, the film is not there to be judged, festival organizers said in a statement. The movie, starring Russell Crowe as the thief with a heart of gold and Cate Blanchett as the headstrong Maid Marian, will screen out of competition when it opens the festival on May 12, before a worldwide release on May 14.

title: Corpus Christi Canceled in Texas
description: A Texas university class production of Corpus Christi, by Terrence McNally, below, has been canceled by college officials citing safety and security concerns for the students as well as the need to maintain an orderly academic environment, The Austin Chronicle reported. Corpus Christi, Mr. McNallys 1998 play depicting a gay Jesus figure, was scheduled to be performed on Saturday as part of a directing class at Tarleton State University in Stephenville, Tex. But early on Friday, Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst condemned the performance, saying in a press release that no one should have the right to use government funds or institutions to portray acts that are morally reprehensible to the vast majority of Americans. Although Tarletons president, F. Dominic Dottavio, first defended the students right to perform a play he considered offensive, crude and irreverent, university officials changed course late Friday night, canceling the performance after receiving threatening calls and e-mail messages, according to The Star-Telegram. In 1998 the first New York production of Corpus Christi, at the Manhattan Theater Club, was canceled amid intense protests by religious groups. The show was reinstated after an outcry from artists and civil liberties organizations.

title: Dragon Rules the Box Office
description: How to Train Your Dragon (above) was No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend despite softer than expected ticket sales of about $43.3 million. Some Wall Street analysts expected opening-weekend sales of up to $60 million for this 3-D picture from DreamWorks Animation, on a par with the studios last release, Monsters vs. Aliens. A variety of factors may have dented How to Train Your Dragon, from a sudden glut of 3-D pictures to the decision last week by many theater chains to raise ticket prices. Animated titles also do better when they feature broad comedy, something this movie lacked. Still, positive reviews will likely help How to Train Your Dragon in the weeks ahead, when many children are out of school for spring break. Alice in Wonderland (Walt Disney Studios) was second with about $17.3 million for a new total of $293 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. The MGM comedy Hot Tub Time Machine was third with about $13.7 million, a so-so result considering the hefty promotional muscle the beleaguered studio put behind it. Sonys Bounty Hunter was fourth with about $12.4 million ($38.8 million total), and Diary of a Wimpy Kid (20th Century Fox) was fifth with about $10 million ($35.8 million total).

title: Lebanese Artist Wins Spalding Gray Award
description: The 2010 Spalding Gray Award has been given to Rabih Mrou, below, an actor, director, playwright and visual artist in Beirut known for controversial work that reflects his countrys political climate. The Lebanese Interior Ministry banned his 2007 performance piece about that countrys civil war, How Nancy Wished That Everything Was an April Fools Joke, written with Fadi Toufic. (The ban was later reversed.) The award, named after Gray, the monologist who died in 2004, is sponsored by a consortium that includes Kathleen Russo, Grays wife; Performance Space 122 in New York; the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis; the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh; and On the Boards in Seattle. It comes with a stipend to create a new work and provides for a full production of that work by each organization.

title: Judge Orders Prince to Pay Promoters
description: Prince must pay Irish concert promoters $2.95 million for canceling a 2008 show, according to a ruling by a judge in Dublin on Friday, The Associated Press reported. High Court Justice Peter Kelly decided to make public a confidential settlement between Prince and MCD Productions after the promoters complained that Prince had not paid them. The original settlement, signed on Feb. 26, stemmed from Princes cancellation just a few days before the concert, at Croke Park stadium in Dublin in June 2008, with no explanation. MCD said 55,000 tickets had been sold, it had paid $950,000 to book the stadium and it had already paid Prince $1.5 million. Justice Kelly also ruled on Friday that Marc Geiger, Princes agent at William Morris, was not liable. Testifying in February, Mr. Geiger said he had warned Prince of MCDs frustration, and Prince replied: Tell the cat to chill. We will work something out.

title: Closing Date for The Miracle Worker
description: After only 21 preview performances and 38 regular performances, the Broadway revival of William Gibsons play The Miracle Worker will close next Sunday at Circle in the Square Theater, the producers David Richenthal and Dini von Mueffling said on Sunday. The show cost $2.6 million to mount and will close at a total loss to its producers and investors, a spokesman for the show said. The story of a young Helen Keller (Abigail Breslin, above left) learning to communicate under the guidance of her teacher, Annie Sullivan (Alison Pill, right), The Miracle Worker opened on March 3 to mixed reviews and never managed to attract much of an audience. The shows grosses during full weeks of eight performances were uneven, ranging from $165,000 to $256,000. Mr. Richenthal had secured financing this month to keep the show running through mid-April in hopes of capturing a share of the school vacation market. He then left New York to tend to health issues, leaving his decision-making authority about the show to Ms. von Mueffling, his wife. In response to questions about why the show would not run until at least until mid-April, Ms. von Mueffling said in a statement: In spite of additional advertising, ticket sales did not pick up as much as we thought they would. Closing is the only fiscally prudent choice, as difficult and sad a decision as it is.

title: Is the Health Care Law Unconstitutional?
description: Just minutes after President Obama signed the health care legislation into law on Tuesday, 13 state attorneys general, led by Bill McCollum of Florida, filed a federal lawsuit challenging the laws constitutionality. Virginias attorney general, Kenneth Cuccinelli, filed a similar suit the same day. Both complaints charge that Congress has no power under the Constitutions Commerce Clause to require that all Americans buy health insurance or pay a penalty.

title: For a B&B That Doesnt Exist, the Online Reviews Keep Coming
description: One recent TripAdvisor review of the agrotourism destination Schrute Farms awarded four stars, lavishly praising the food, while another yielded just one star, casting aspersions on the owners sanity. This wild disparity is especially odd because Schrute Farms doesnt even exist.

title: In Britain, Family Buys 2nd Ailing Paper
description: When Alexander Lebedev and his son, Evgeny, took over The Evening Standard of London 14 months ago, the media coverage focused on the fathers status as a former K.G.B. agent and Russian oligarch, and on both mens taste in beautiful women. Many news reports asked whether they would be an unhealthy influence on one of Britains major newspapers.

title: Euro Trashed
description: Tbingen, Germany

title: Golf Course Designed by Tiger Woods Runs Into Problems of Its Own
description: Tiger Woods has long maintained a cloak of exclusivity, charging top dollar to top sponsors. The same is true for his golf course company, Tiger Woods Design, which since opening in 2006 has designed three courses, two outside the country: in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, and Ensenada, Mexico.

title: Cliff Livingston, Key Part of Giants in 1950s and 60s, Is Dead at 79
description: Cliff Livingston, who played in four National Football League championship games as a linebacker for the Giants in the 1950s and 1960s, died March 13 at his home in Las Vegas. He was 79.

title: Another Advantage for the Biggest Banks
Donald N. Frey, Designer of the Mustang, Dies at 86
description: Donald N. Frey, the engineer who spearheaded the design and development of the Mustang, the spunky, stylish, affordably priced pony car that the Ford Motor Company rolled out in the mid-1960s in one of the most successful car introductions in automotive history, died March 5 in Evanston, Ill., where he lived. He was 86.

title: Not Creating Content. Just Protecting It.
description: Should we be surprised that the biggest fight over freedom of expression in years involves Google, a company that produces algorithms rather than articles?

title: Scandal Tests Catholics Trust in Leadership
description: ARMAGH, Northern Ireland  As the sexual abuse scandal sweeps through the Roman Catholic Church in Europe and the United States, there are few places where dismay and confusion among worshipers strikes as deep a chord as here in Armagh, seat of the embattled cardinal whose fate has become closely entangled with the widening controversy facing Pope Benedict XVI.

title: Scientists Say F.D.A. Ignored Radiation Warnings
description: WASHINGTON  Urgent warnings by government experts about the risks of routinely using powerful CT scans to screen patients for colon cancer were brushed aside by the Food and Drug Administration, according to agency documents and interviews with agency scientists.

title: A Game That Has Been on Ice for 21 Years
description: When Delbartons Mike Pendy and St. Josephs Kenny Blum were supposed to take the opening face-off in the New Jersey high school hockey championship game, their hamstrings were 21 years younger and there was no need to reintroduce themselves or discuss children and careers.

title: Stocks Soar, but Many Analysts Ask Why
description: The unemployment rate remains locked in a range that recalls the economic doldrums of the early 1980s. Housing is stuck in a ditch, with foreclosures rising. And consumers are still reluctant to part with the little cash they do have.

title: UConn-Tennessee Is a Rivalry Worth Resuming
description: DAYTON, Ohio  They are immediately identifiable by one name, Pat and Geno, like Brazilian soccer players and legendary cheesesteak joints of the same appellation in south Philadelphia.

title: Accused in a Ponzi Scheme, Fugitive Extradited to Serbia
description: A notorious fugitive Serbian banker accused of stealing more than $130 million in a Ponzi scheme was extradited to Serbia from the Netherlands on Friday, the Dutch authorities confirmed Sunday.

title: A Time for Contrition
description: During a frustrating argument with a Roman Catholic cardinal, Napoleon Bonaparte supposedly burst out: Your eminence, are you not aware that I have the power to destroy the Catholic Church? The cardinal, the anecdote goes, responded ruefully: Your majesty, we, the Catholic clergy, have done our best to destroy the church for the last 1,800 years. We have not succeeded, and neither will you.

title: Rift Exposes Split in Views on Mideast
description: JERUSALEM  When Israel announced new housing units for Jews in East Jerusalem at the start of a visit this month by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized for the timing and expressed regret at the embarrassment. Mr. Biden accepted his explanation, and the two sides seemed prepared to move on.

title: Coverage Now for Sick Children? Check Fine Print
description: WASHINGTON  Just days after President Obama signed the new health care law, insurance companies are already arguing that, at least for now, they do not have to provide one of the benefits that the president calls a centerpiece of the law: coverage for certain children with pre-existing conditions.

title: Nets Likely Owner Faces a Nation
description: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, a basketball-loving Russian billionaire who is expected to be approved as the majority owner of the Nets next month, moved into the American spotlight Sunday with a profile on CBSs 60 Minutes.

title: Dreaming of Cuban Profits in Post-Embargo World
description: CANCN, Mexico  Would Americans playing bingo in a Havana retirement home violate the Cuban governments socialist ethos? How about avowed capitalists living on their 401(k) accounts in condominiums along the Cuban coastline? Or, horror of horrors, fast food outlets offering Big Macs, Whoppers and buckets of fried chicken along the seaside Malecn?

title: Butlers Coach: Competitiveness Wrapped in Calm
description: SALT LAKE CITY  It did not take Tracy Stevens long to discover how important basketball was to her husband, Brad. On their third date, as sophomores at DePauw University in Greencastle, Ind., he took her to a high school basketball game more than an hour and a half away.

title: Best Cookin Show Ever
description: Cookin Cheap was true to its name. It was a TV show about cookin, and it was cheap. It came from a public television station in Roanoke, Va., in 1981, and went national for a while on PBS. That was when I saw it, and was floored.

title: Wrapping Things Up From the Midwest
description: ST. LOUIS  A few odds and ends from the Midwest Regional championship game:

title: Overqualified? Yes, but Happy to Have a Job
description: GRANDVIEW, Mo.  Don Carroll, a former financial analyst with a masters degree in business administration from a top university, was clearly overqualified for the job running the claims department for Cartwright International, a small, family-owned moving company here south of Kansas City.

title: The Legal Assault on Health Reforms
description: No sooner had President Obama signed comprehensive health care reform than the attorneys general of 14 states scurried to the federal courts to challenge the law. Their claims range from far-fetched to arguable and look mostly like political posturing for the fall elections or a Hail Mary pass by disgruntled conservatives who cannot accept what Congress and the president have done.

title: The Talent to Contend, and the Experience to Win It All
description: SYRACUSE

title: North Koreans Use Cellphones to Bare Secrets
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea, one of the worlds most impenetrable nations, is facing a new threat: networks of its own citizens feeding information about life there to South Korea and its Western allies.

title: Obama Team Is Divided on Anti-Terror Tactics
description: WASHINGTON  Senior lawyers in the Obama administration are deeply divided over some of the counterterrorism powers they inherited from former President George W. Bush, according to interviews and a review of legal briefs.

title: After Gang Crackdown, Police Become Targets
description: HEMET, Calif.  By the time four city trucks were set ablaze next to Hemet City Hall last week, the police here had become familiar with their new life under siege.

title: Duke Prevails Against Baylor; Returns to Final Four
description: HOUSTON  When Dukes Mike Krzyzewski was asked Thursday where his top-seeded team ranked among the other Blue Devils squads that he had coached, he declined to speculate.

title: Europeans Woo U.S., Promising Relevance
description: BRUSSELS  Stung by a perception of Americas indifference to its historical alliance with Europe, senior European leaders are calling for a rebalancing of the relationship, promising the Obama administration that the Europeans can be partners for global challenges ranging from security to climate change.

title: Sony Pursues a Bold Success to Match Its Scale
description: NAGOYA, Japan  The airy new Sony store in this central Japanese city has floor-to-ceiling windows, sleek white counters and friendly employees, called stylists, who offer advice and tailored counseling on Sony gadgets.

title: Looking Ahead
description: A HOLIDAY  Markets will be closed in the United States in observance of Good Friday.

title: After Googles Move, a Shift in Search Terms
description: HONG KONG  Chinese searches for politically delicate terms peaked the day Google stopped filtering its search results, but the government pressed on with a campaign to remove online praise of the company.

title: In New York, Breaking a Law on Roommates
description: Doua Moua, 23, played a menacing gangster in a Clint Eastwood movie, but Mr. Moua swears he really is a nice, gentle and rules-abiding fellow. At least he was until he moved to New York City and unwittingly slipped into a world of lawlessness.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Monday, and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Why Senate Democrats Sound Like Republicans on the Budget
description: ALBANY  The districts represented by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and John L. Sampson, his fellow Democrat and the Senate leader, lie just a few miles apart in New York City. But when it comes to their priorities for the state budget, the two men inhabit different worlds.

title: For Federal Prosecutor, Low-Key Style in High-Profile Job
description: It should have been the culmination of a distinguished prosecutorial career.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 19 about the release of a naturalized American citizen, Nyi Nyi Aung, from prison in Myanmar referred incompletely to his sentence. While Mr. Nyi Nyi Aung, a pro-democracy advocate, was released a month after being sentenced to five years, he was to have served only three years. (A judge decided that several sentences would run concurrently.)

title: Conquering 46-Part Goal, Peak by Icy Peak
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  The ice on Mount Jo glittered in the bright sunlight. The woods echoed with the crunching sound of the crampons worn by the two hikers. It was an easy climb, despite the thick slabs of ice stretching across the trail.

title: Corrections
description: A headline with a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about legislation that would severely restrict the practice of full Muslim veiling in the Canadian province of Quebec misstated the status of that legislation. As the report noted, it has been introduced, not passed.

title: In a Test of Sales Savvy, Selling a Red Brick on YouTube
description: AN agency whose founder went door to door to sell stoves before he got into advertising  and was so good at it that the company asked him to write a manual for the other salesmen  is creating a contest that celebrates selling.

title: An Overhaul Passes, the Vitriol Lives On
description: WASHINGTON  Congress has voted, President Obama will hold a last signing ceremony on Tuesday, and still, Americans are struggling to make sense of the health care debate  what it means for them and their families, for businesses and the economy, for states, for lawmakers in the November elections, for Mr. Obama and his presidency, for the nations future, and in a most elemental way, for the future of civil democracy.

title: Accounts, People and Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Crane Operators License Is Suspended
description: City officials on Sunday suspended the license of a worker who had been operating a 250-foot-high crane before it crashed into a 25-story building in Lower Manhattan, saying he had failed to secure it properly before leaving the site for the day.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 28, 2010

title: New Tool Could Help in Testing for H.G.H.
description: A test similar to one used in cancer treatments has antidoping officials encouraged that they have found a new, and important, way to catch athletes using human growth hormone.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Free Advice on Money for Those With Little
description: For three years, Juan Maldonado worked in a sleek skyscraper in Midtown, reconciling stock trades at a Lehman Brothers subsidiary that managed $216 billion in assets. These days, he toils in a cramped, decidedly unglamorous office in southeastern Queens, helping the poor and the unemployed stretch budgets that often amount to a couple of hundred dollars a week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 17 about studies included in legislation moving through Congress that would impose tighter financial regulation overstated the effect of the studies that are included in the House bill. While the House legislation indeed calls for dozens of studies, some of which consumer advocates contend could delay implementation of laws and regulations to address the underlying causes of the financial crisis, the House bill does not include dozens of studies that will effectively delay for up to two years the possibility of addressing those problems.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Friday about the Rangers 4-3 shootout victory over the New Jersey Devils on Thursday in the National Hockey League described Rangers center Erik Christensens participation in shootouts incorrectly. His shootout attempt in the game was his third of the season, not of his career. (He is 18 for 34 in his career.)

title: Upper West Side Church Offers Homeless a Home, and More
description: Crystal Chatwood and Eugene Thomas had hitchhiked from Georgia to Florida in search of work, and finding none, had taken a ride north to New York with another couple. The couple dropped them off in Central Park, promising to return in a few hours.

title: Seton Hall Hires Iona Coach; McCaffery Leaves Siena
description: Of the three prominent New York metropolitan area college basketball jobs open, two have been filled with local coaches considered strong in the area.

title: In the Park, Honoring a Legend of Jogging
description: Relatively few runners ventured out in the cold, gray drizzle to circle the Central Park Reservoir on Sunday, but many of those who did stopped, some in tears, to pay tribute to one of the reservoirs most colorful and enduring figures.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about the actor Robert Culp referred incorrectly to the 1972 movie Hickey & Boggs, which Mr. Culp directed and in which he starred with Bill Cosby. It was a crime drama, not a comedy. The obituary, using information from Mr. Culps agent, also misidentified the city where Mr. Culps son Jason lives. It is New York City, not Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: A Start-Up Has Survived to Beam Up Your Gestures
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  Making computers see humans has not been easy for Canesta.

title: Pitching Issues Remain as Mets Prepare to Come North
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  With a week to go until opening day, the Mets are still facing the same questions about their starting rotation they did in the off-season. Twenty-five games into spring training, no one seems exactly certain what the staff will provide this year.

title: Democrats Cheer Now, but Grim November May Lie Ahead
description: In politics, as in sports, the thrill of victory sometimes pales alongside the agony of defeat. In 2010, Democrats remain on track to experience both.

title: What if No One Went to the Office? Inc. Magazine Finds Out
description: Max Chafkin, a senior writer for Inc. magazine, couched the idea as a sort of joke: for his article on virtual offices, perhaps the entire magazine staff should work remotely while making the issue?

title: For Yankees, Next Choice Settles Left and Center
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In the next few days, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi will decide the second-most interesting position battle in camp, one pushed into the background by the Phil Hughes-Joba Chamberlain drama for fifth starter.

title: Lawmakers Face Fallout at Home From Health Vote
description: Representative Alan Grayson, a Florida Democrat who supported President Obamas health care bill, drew shouts of amen as he returned home on Friday. But his supporters did not publicize a speech he delivered Saturday morning, out of fear it would be disrupted by protesters.

title: Women and Islam
description: As a follow up last year's Muslim Voices series, BAMcinmatek is presenting "The Female Perspective." The series features six films that look at the role of women in Islam. They include, Dave Kehr writes: Havana Marking's "Afghan Star," a documentary on an Afghan singing competition; "Persepolis," Vincent Paronnaud and Marjane Satrapi's animated adaptation of Ms. Satrapi's account of growing up during the Iranian Revolution; and tonight, Jafar Panahi's gracefully subversive "Offside," about a group of young women trying to penetrate the male-only confines of a Tehran soccer stadium.

title: Threepenny at 30
description: The life of a literary magazine is always precarious. But The Threepenny Review, which was started by Wendy Lesser in 1980, is celebrating 30 years of publishing fiction, poetry and criticism. Go to McNally Jackson Books tonight to enjoy an evening of readings by Ms. Lesser, Daisy Fried, Mary Gaitskill, Ethan Iverson, James Lasdun, Richard Locke and C. K. Williams. The event begins at 7 p.m.

title: Curious George Goes to the Museum
description: "You don't really think about Curious George saving the day, as the title of the new exhibition at the Jewish Museum puts it. A 'good little monkey,' he is called in the classic series of picture books by Margret and H. A. Rey, but he was no savior. He was a mischief-maker, an innocent, born in the jungle and lured into the strange world of humans," writes Edward Rothstein. "But as the exhibition points out, at least outside of the books' frames, Curious George really did save the day, and more than once. In early September 1939, just after World War II began, the Reys  a husband-and-wife team of German Jews living in Paris  sought refuge at Chteau Feuga, an old castle owned by some friends in southern France. At such a time, Hans A. Rey wrote in a letter, 'it feels ridiculous to be thinking about children's books.' But that is what they were doing, prolifically, including a book about a monkey named Fifi, who later became known as Curious George." Make an early trip to the museum to find out more about the history of the couple and their beloved creation and to get there before Passover begins. The museum closes at 2 p.m. on Monday and stays closed for the first, second, seventh and eighth days of the holiday.

title: Six Districts, Two Sides, One Weekend
description: A week after passing sweeping health care legislation, members of the House returned to their districts to find a bewildering cross-current of political forces awaiting them.

title: In Uncertain Times, Jazz Keeps Rolling
description: Carlos Boozer could have left the Utah Jazz last summer, could have been traded at midseason and could still walk away in July. He didnt, he wasnt and he hasnt yet, but his uncertain status provides a handy guide to Utahs championship aspirations.

title: Ford Agrees to Sell Volvo to a Fast-Rising Chinese Company
description: HONG KONG  Ford Motor reached an agreement on Sunday to sell its Volvo subsidiary to a Chinese conglomerate, in the clearest confirmation yet of Chinas global ambitions in the auto industry.

title: Finding Natural Gas, Safely
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will soon begin a much-needed study of the effects on water quality and public health of a method of extracting natural gas called hydraulic fracturing. An E.P.A. investigation in 2004 was rightly seen as superficial and skewed toward industry, which provided much of the underlying data. This one must be comprehensive and transparent.

title: Turning Women Into Scientists
description: To the Editor:

title: Punks and Plutocrats
description: Health reform is the law of the land. Next up: financial reform. But will it happen? The White House is optimistic, because it believes that Republicans wont want to be cast as allies of Wall Street. Im not so sure. The key question is how many senators believe that they can get away with claiming that war is peace, slavery is freedom, and regulating big banks is doing those big banks a favor.

title: Count Us in Favor
description: At least there is one area in Congress where bipartisanship is possible. The 2010 census started only two weeks ago, and a bipartisan group in Congress has already introduced a smart bill to improve the 2020 count.

title: Man or Machine: Who Is the Better Translator?
description: To the Editor:

title: Vasily Smyslov, 1921-2010, an Appreciation
Jenson Button Wins Wild Australian Grand Prix
description: From our colleagues at Formula One:

title: The Next Belichick Takes Up Coaching, Determined to Make Her Own Name
description: AMHERST, Mass.  The offensive drill was under way near a sideline, two against the goalie inside McGuirk Alumni Stadium. Amanda Belichick leaned on a lacrosse stick nearby, watching every nuance from behind her sunglasses.

title: Analysts Ask if the iPad Can Live Up to Its Hype
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When the Apple iPad goes on sale on Saturday, most of the major questions surrounding the device will have been answered, save for one: can it live up to the hype?

title: Mergers of Wireless Companies Are Expected to Rebound
description: With global markets on the upswing and governments around the world looking to blanket populations with mobile broadband service, industry experts say the wireless companies are poised for a wave of mergers and deals.

title: Q&A With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: More Clicks to Escape an E-Mail List
description: It takes more clicks to be removed from an e-mail list than it once did, the online marketing firm Responsys says. In a study of 100 large online retailers, the firm found that the proportion requiring three or more clicks to unsubscribe had grown more than fivefold since 2008. And the proportion letting users opt out with a single click shrank to 3 percent, from 9 percent, over that period.

title: Article on Footage of Shooting in Zambia Raises Questions for Media
description: Does a journalists confidentiality agreement with sources cover footage of an apparent killing?

title: The Force of Water, the Power of Words
description: If words were water, the drought problems so lengthily discussed in the new play by Kia Corthron, A Cool Dip in the Barren Saharan Crick, would evaporate pretty quickly. The title alone would suffice for a sponge bath. The subject of water actually consumes a large portion of the dialogue in this venturesome but disjointed drama about a young African man studying theology and ecology, and the American family that harbors him during his college years.

title: Ballet Stars Now Tweet as Well as Flutter
description: In the rarefied world of ballet, where dancers are expected to speak with their bodies, sometimes it seems that aloofness is something to aspire to. Lately, though, the ribbons are loosening. Courtesy of Twitter, dancers are starting to make themselves heard. It isnt always dainty.

title: Subway Blasts Kill Dozens in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Huge explosions during morning rush hour in two subway stations in central Moscow killed more than 33 people on Monday, officials said, raising fears of a renewal of terrorism here.

title: N.C.A.A. Replay: March 28
description: A view of the day in the mens and womens N.C.A.A. tournaments.

title: News Quiz | March 29, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Death of a Loophole, and Swiss Banks Will Mourn
description: With all the hoopla over the health care bill, hardly anybody noticed that a job creation bill that President Obama signed on March 18 makes it much harder for United States citizens to avoid taxes by hiding money in overseas bank accounts.

title: Accused in Ponzi Scheme, Fugitive Extradited to Serbia
description: A fugitive Serbian banker accused of stealing more than $130 million in a Ponzi scheme was extradited to Serbia from the Netherlands on Friday, the Dutch authorities confirmed Sunday.

title: WaMu-JPMorgan Tax Break Said to Trip on F.D.I.C.
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is not on board with Washington Mutuals bankruptcy reorganization plan, including a massive tax refund to JPMorgan Chase, according to the company and a Wall Street Journal report.

title: Scandal in the Catholic Church
description: Note: We realize that many teachers and parents want to help their students and children understand the current sexual abuse scandal in the Catholic Church. I chose the article below because it provides a good basic overview, without any graphic details. To find updated news and more background, visit the Times Topics pages on the Roman Catholic Church Sex Abuse Cases, Pope Benedict XVI and the Roman Catholic Church.

title: General Growth Said to Be Near Bankruptcy Exit Plan
description: General Growth Properties is getting closer to filing a bankruptcy exit plan, with its board planning to meet on Monday to give final approval to the proposal, sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.

title: Moscow Attack a Test for Putin and His Record Against Terror
description: MOSCOW  The brazen suicide bombings in the center of Moscow confronted Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin with a grave challenge to his record of curbing terrorism, and raised the possibility that he would respond as he had in the past, by significantly tightening control over the government.

title: Word of the Day | imbroglio
description: imbroglio \im-brol-()yo\ noun

title: Another Advantage for the Biggest Banks?
description: No wonder banks like being too big to fail, Reuters Breakingviews says. The certainty of a bailout, should their bets go wrong, isnt just reassuring to risk-taking employees. Customers also value infallibility, Breakingviews notes.

title: Swatch Chief Sees Potential for Bulgari
description: Nick Hayek, chief executive of Swatch, told the German magazine Focus that Bulgari was a large, interesting brand with the potential to develop.

title: Buttons Double Justification for  Joining McLaren
description: A lot of people wondered why Jenson Button last year chose to move to McLaren Mercedes from the Brawn team where he had just won the world drivers title. Part of the question had to do with Brawn being so strong last year, so why move? The other part had to do with Lewis Hamilton, Buttons future teammate. Why would Button risk ruining his own reputation by teaming up with such a good driver?

title: Rio Tinto Employees Sentenced in Bribery Case
description: Four employees of the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto, including an Australian citizen, were convicted by a Chinese court on Monday and sentenced to seven to 14 years in prison for accepting millions of dollars in bribes and stealing commercial secrets, David Barboza reports in The New York Times.

title: Chongqing Water Jumps 74% in Shanghai Debut
description: Chongqing Water, which has a monopoly in the west-central region of China, soared on its debut, as investors shrugged off recent sluggish first-day performances to pile into a water industry that stands to gain from big government infrastructure spending, Reuters reported.

title: Portraying Moscow With a Camera Phone
description: Correction appended | After photographing the aftermath of the earthquake in Haiti, Todd Heisler, a staff photographer at The New York Times, traveled to Moscow for an exhibition.

title: Nets Likely Owner Faces America
description: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, a basketball-loving Russian billionaire who is expected to be approved as the majority owner of the Nets next month, moved into the American spotlight Sunday with a profile on CBSs 60 Minutes, The New York Timess Richard Sandomir reported.

title: Why Do Boys Lag Behind Girls in Reading?
description: Last week, we asked why females tend to be underrepresented in science and math. This week, were looking at mounting evidence that boys lag behind girls in K-12, especially in reading. Why might that be?

title: Is Russian Tycoon Best Hope for British Papers?
description: When Alexander Lebedev and his son, Evgeny, took over The Evening Standard of London 14 months ago, the media coverage focused on the fathers status as a former K.G.B. agent and Russian oligarch, and on both mens taste in beautiful women. Many news reports asked whether they would be an unhealthy influence on one of Britains major newspapers.

description: Companies owned by private equity groups are suffering a credit  and possibly credibility  discount, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: Britain Is Said to Scrutinize S.&N. Trades in Insider Case
description: In the largest ever investigation of its type in Britain, an alleged insider-trading ring is said to be suspected by the governments Financial Services Authority of making up to 20 million ($30 million) by dealing in the shares of the drinks company Scottish & Newcastle and others, The Financial Times reports.

title: DFS Owner Takes British Sofa Retailer Off the Block
description: Graham Kirkham has pulled the plug on an 500 million ($748 million) auction of the British sofa chain DFS, The Times of London reported.

title: Me Ret Zikh Op Fun Hartsn
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared their love of and fascination with Yiddish.

title: Op-Ed: Euro Trashed
description: The European Monetary Union, the basis of the euro, began with a grand illusion. On one side were countries  Austria, Finland, Germany and the Netherlands  whose currencies had persistently appreciated, both within Europe and worldwide; the countries on the other side  Belgium, France, Greece, Italy, Portugal and Spain  had persistently depreciating currencies.

title: A Start-Up Has Survived to Beam Up Your Gestures
description: Making computers see humans has not been easy for Canesta, The New York Timess Ashlee Vance writes.

title: Munch Comes to Paris, No Scream in Sight
description: For the first time in 20 years, Paris is hosting an exhibition of the work of the Norwegian artist Edvard Munch. His most famous painting isnt included  and thats the whole point.

title: The Present Value of Producing Future Taxpayers
Vinocur: In Germany, a Very Risky Business
description: At the time, the remark was widely seen as a quixotic outburst, more a pol jousting at a windmill, perhaps after a bad nights sleep, than the statement of an uncomfortable truth, John Vinocur writes in his latest column in The International Herald Tribune.

title: The Heart of Allawis Win
description: BAGHDAD  The victory by the former Iraqi prime minister Ayad Allawi in the national parliamentary elections was received everywhere as a surprise, which in a way, of course, it was. But when you look closer at his campaign in comparison with that of the man he defeated, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, it doesnt look like a surprise at all.

title: Krugman: Punks and Plutocrats
description: Health reform is the law of the land. Next up: financial reform. But will it happen? The White House is optimistic, because it believes that Republicans wont want to be cast as allies of Wall Street. Im not so sure, Paul Krugman writes in an Op-Ed in The New York Times.

title: Stocks Soar, but Many Analysts Ask Why
description: The unemployment rate remains locked in a range that recalls the economic doldrums of the early 1980s. Housing is stuck in a ditch, with foreclosures rising. And consumers are still reluctant to part with the little cash they do have.

title: Sinopec Stakes $2.5 Billion Upstream Foothold
description: China Petroleum and Chemical, or Sinopec, Asias top oil refiner, will acquire a stake in deepwater oil assets in Angola for $2.46 billion and said it wanted more such deals, which could shield it from high oil prices that hit margins in the fourth quarter, Reuters reported.

title: Sinking of Ship Feeds South Koreans Fears of the North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The mystery of what caused a South Korean warship to sink in disputed waters may not be solved for days, with rescuers still hunting for 46 missing sailors, and a recovery crane slowly being moved to the site.

title: Shell Sells Units in New Zealand for $490 Million

description: The Royal Bank of Scotland said Monday it had agreed to sell R.B.S. Factoring, a unit that provides loans secured against company invoices, to GE Capital, The Associated Press reported.

title: With Euro Zone Pledge, Greece to Issue 7-Year Bonds
description: Greece is testing the waters again. The countrys debt agency said Monday that it had signed on five banks to underwrite a seven-year bond issue, just days after the major members of the euro zone and the International Monetary Fund agreed on a plan to support its debt.

description: 12:29 p.m. | Updated The New York Timess Eric Dash provides more details about the Treasurys plan to sell its stake in Citigroup.

description: 10:33 a.m. | Updated Citigroup said Monday that it was continuing to build its hedge fund servicing unit, and had made 13 new appointments in the last few weeks.

title: Sampler: Confusion Over Medical Marijuana Rules, and Mall Parking Erased for Green Cars
description: How Much Medical Marijuana Is Too Much? | Police, prosecutors and defense lawyers have struggled with the question of how much pot a medical marijuana patient may possess since the California Supreme Court threw out a conviction and struck down a state law that imposed an eight-ounce limit. Instead, patients are entitled to a reasonable amount of the drug for their ailments, the court said in its January ruling. The ruling has resulted in a number of marijuana cases being dismissed; other trials ended in acquittals. Law enforcement agencies around the state are struggling with the aftermath of the ruling. Gray is not a good color for the law, said Gerald Benito, the Shasta County district attorney, who dismissed a case this month. It makes it very difficult for us to enforce the law  I think everyone is crying out for a clear line. [The Associated Press]

title: Politicians Ask, and the M.T.A. Jots It Down
description: New Yorks politicians have plenty of questions for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. For example: how do I get to the United States Open tennis tournament? And can you keep the noise down so HBO can film a movie?

title: Headphones New Zealand Sheep Died For
description: Because I apparently had missed the Gadgetwise memo that this was headphone week  see the posts from my colleagues Roy Furchgott on inexpensive earbud adapters and Eric Taub  Im getting in on the trend a little late.

title: Cadillac Reveals 550-Horsepower CTS-V Sport Wagon
description: Cadillac revealed its mega-horsepower CTS-V Sport Wagon two days ahead of the New York auto shows media days, which begin unofficially with a series of parties on Tuesday night and officially on Wednesday morning.

title: Is Your Small Business More Than Just a Job?
description: Im often surprised at how hard it can be to get business owners to think of their companies as assets, with value that can be built and extracted at the right time. I recently had the opportunity to speak with Chia-Li Chien (shell tell you its pronounced Jolly Jan), a certified financial planner and owner of Chien Associates, a North Carolina firm that specializes in offering exit-planning strategies to women business owners.

title: Macau Buget Airline is Grounded
description: According to Bloomberg News, Viva Macau, the citys first budget airline, had its license revoked by the aviation authorities after failing to offer assistance to passengers stranded by flight cancellations.

title: Q.& A.: Mets Bloggers Assess the Coming Season, Part 1
description: As opening day draws near, The Times will be previewing the Yankees and Mets seasons from all angles, with analysis from Tyler Kepner, Ben Shpigel, David Waldstein and others. But with so much happening this off-season there are a lot of opinions to go around. As we did last season, we have reached out to some Yankees and Mets bloggers for their thoughts on the 2010 season.

title: Threes Company, Fours Against the Law
description: Doua Moua, 23, played a menacing gangster in a Clint Eastwood movie, but Mr. Moua swears he really is a nice, gentle and rules-abiding fellow. At least he was until he moved to New York City and unwittingly slipped into a world of lawlessness.

title: China Leads in Clean Energy Investments
description: Chinas investments in renewable energy in 2009 exceeded those made by the United States for the first time, according to a report by the Pew Charitable Trusts.

title: Reaction to the Bombing
description: MOSCOW  Russians reacted with alarm, anger and resignation to the terrorist attacks on the Moscow subway system on Monday. Here is a sampling of opinion from the Russian-language blog of The New York Times, as well as other Russian-language media and blogs on livejournal.com, as translated by the Moscow bureau of The Times.

title: U.S. Consumer Spending Up Modestly
description: Household incomes remained flat in February as a weak jobs market crimped paychecks, the Commerce Department indicated on Monday.

title: Optimism About Recovery Lifts Shares
description: A brighter outlook for the American consumer and signs that foreign debt troubles were easing helped propel Wall Street higher on Monday.

title: The Robots Among Us
description: Ive always wanted a robot. I often fantasized as a child about my own personal robot that could carry my backpack to school for me or stay up late and help me with my homework.

title: Rescuers in China Struggle to Free 153 Trapped Miners
description: BEIJING  Rescue workers in northern China struggled Monday to reach 153 miners trapped a day earlier when water gushed into a warren of tunnels dug for a new underground coal field.

title: A Site That Pays You to Recycle
description: A couple of weeks ago I hauled a carload of old tech products to an electronics recycling event. I paid $10 to get rid of two old desktop computers, a non-working Apple TV, a couple of cellphones, a network-attached storage (NAS) drive, two ancient iPods, and a photo printer. At the time, I considered the money well-spent, since I created fresh space in closets and muted my partners complaints about the mountain of gadgets I have amassed.

title: Ministers Reaffirm Jerusalem Stance
description: JERUSALEM  Senior Israeli ministers have publicly rejected American demands for curbs on building in Jewish areas of East Jerusalem and other concessions to the Palestinians, indicating no imminent end to the rift between Israel and the United States.

title: U.S. to Sell 27% Stake in Citigroup This Year
description: Nearly 18 months after the federal government stepped in to bail out Citigroup, Washington announced plans on Monday to sell off its ownership stake.

title: Community Creator Writes to Child, Disses Spielberg and Wins Our Hearts
description: This blog has previously expressed its affection for the NBC comedy Community and its creator, Dan Harmon, the only man who seems to watch more television than we do. And now, if its possible, we like him even more.

title: Joe Drapes New Top Ten Derby Hopefuls
description: In Tuesdays Times, Joe Drape will examine the Derby contenders after last weekends prep races and, in the chart below, ranks his early Derby favorites. The odds are drawn from the Kentucky Derby Future Wager. Then watch the newly important Sunland Derby. Last years Kentucky Derby winner Mine That Bird finished fourth in New Mexicos biggest race. Did another potential Derby winner run here?

description: American International Group said Monday that it had finalized the sale of Pinebridge Investments, the asset manager, to Pacific Century Group for $277 million in cash.

description: Professors Jonathan Zinman and Victor Stango argue that the debate over the proposed Consumer Financial Protection Agency should be over what the agency does, not where it is located in the governments bureaucracy.

title: Moscow Commuters Post Grim Video and Photos Online After Bombings
description: Updated | 6:08 p.m. In the immediate aftermath of bombings at two Moscow subway stations on Monday morning, video and photographs were posted online by commuters in the Russian capital showing some of the damage and the evacuations that followed.

title: June Havoc, Vaudeville Star and Actor, Dies
description: June Havoc, who first appeared on vaudeville stages when she was 2 as Baby June and went on to a successful stage and film acting career  but saw her real-life accomplishments overshadowed by the fictionalized portrayal of her in the 1959 musical Gypsy  died on Sunday. She was believed to be 97 and lived in Stamford, Conn.

description: With Congress on recess, many lawmakers spent their first weekend back in their home districts, and some faced the music and the taunts over the recent passage of the health legislation.

description: MOSCOW  Investigators were still marching in and out of the Lubyanka subway station on Monday morning, but Nina Ivanovna, a 57-year-old retiree, was not waiting around to hear their conclusions.

title: Monday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Speed Read for Monday, March 29
description: Highlights from media coverage in todays New York Times:

title: Off the Menu: The Empire Room
description: Its hard to believe the cocktail lounge thats opening in the Empire State Building today is brand new because it looks so right. At 3,500 square feet of brushed stainless steel, a generous curved marble bar, tufted banquettes, glass-topped tables and Art Deco chandeliers, it accommodates up to 150 people in sophisticated style in a former postal substation. I feel like Im giving the Empire State Building the cocktail lounge it deserves, said the owner, Mark Grossich, who also owns the Campbell Apartments in Grand Central Terminal, and the World Bar in Trump World Tower, among others.

title: The Staten Island Ferry, 6:05 A.M.
Addressing the Attacks in Russia With Students and Children
description: Tuesday, March 30, 8:55 p.m. | Updated  How are you talking about the subway bombings in Moscow in class or at home? We hope these resources help you address it with your students or children. And as this story is evolving, please check back for updates.

description: Four players to watch when the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament resumes on Saturday with Michigan State playing Butler and West Virginia playing Duke at Lucas Oil Stadium in Indianapolis:

title: Texas Weighs Efficiency, Solar Mandates
description: Texas regulators may soon ramp up mandates requiring tougher energy-efficiency standards and development of renewable energy sources other than wind power.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Boyer Coffee Company, Denver, chose TDA Advertising and Design, Boulder, Colo., as its first advertising agency of record. Advertising had previously been handled internally. Spending was estimated at less than $1 million.

title: Tribeca Festival Adds Freakonomics Film to Lineup
description: Does a documentary film adapted from a best-selling nonfiction work about the application of economic theories and models to unusual real-life situations stand any chance at the box office? Attendees of the Tribeca Film Festival will get an early chance to answer that nonacademic puzzler. On Monday, festival organizers said the film version of Freakonomics, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner (both are contributors to The New York Times), will be shown as its closing night gala on April 30. The film, making its world premiere at the Tribeca festival, includes segments directed by Alex Gibney (Taxi to the Dark Side), Morgan Spurlock (Super Size Me), Rachel Grady and Heidi Ewing (Jesus Camp), Eugene Jarecki (Why We Fight) and Seth Gordon (The King of Kong).

title: Out-of-Pocket Health Care Spending
description: Americans spent $138.5 billion in out-of-pocket health care expenses in 2008, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And that number excludes health insurance premiums, nursing home care, nonprescription drugs, nonprescription vitamins, and topical remedies and dressings.

title: U.S. Names Education Grant Winners
description: Delaware and Tennessee beat out 38 other states and the District of Columbia to win a share of $4 billion in federal education grants, convincing the Obama administration that they have bold plans for overhauling their public school systems.

title: Oakland Rallies for Runners and Itself
description: At some point during the half-marathon on Sunday in Oakland, part of the Oakland Running Festival, I realized that people were yelling Go Oakland at me and other runners as well as the usual Good Job and Way to Go.

title: HSBC Ejects Carbon Traders From Index
description: The banking giant HSBC removed two companies involved in carbon trading from its Climate Change Index on Monday because they had lost too much value.

title: When Taking Care Taps the Soul, and the Wallet
description: Who among us has ever read Uncle Toms Cabin? Not me, and not you either, I suspect. Why should we? We know all about that book: it is dated, stilted and full of distasteful stereotypes. We have all outgrown it.

title: An iPhone Remote Control: Simple but Not Useful
description: One of the big problems with turning the iPhone into a universal remote is figuring out how to get the device to send IR signals to your home theater components.

title: What Were Reading
June Havoc, Actress Who Outgrew Tyranny of Her Momma Rose, Dies
description: June Havoc, who appeared on vaudeville stages when she was 2 as Baby June and went on to a successful acting career  but saw her accomplishments overshadowed by the fictionalized portrayal of her in the 1959 musical Gypsy  died on Sunday at her home in Stamford, Conn. She was believed to be 97. The death was confirmed by her caregiver, Tana Sibilio.

title: Go, Metz!
description: Depending on how you look at it, the venerable Centre Georges Pompidou, designed by Richard Rogers and Renzo Piano, will get either a new sibling or a new rival next month, when a branch opens to the public in Metz, France. The Centre Pompidou-Metzs inaugural exhibition has blockbuster written all over it; the coyly titled Masterpieces? will feature some 800 of the worlds most prized modern works, from Alexander Calders Josephine Baker IV to Yves Kleins Grande anthropophagie bleue (ANT 76). A TGV rail link makes the museum an easy 80-minute trip from Paris. And then there is the building itself. Conceived by Shigeru Ban and Jean de Gastines as a series of modules around a central spire, it is flamboyantly capped by an undulating lattice roof structure (made from 11 miles of glue-laminated timber beams) and sheathed in a fiberglass and Teflon membrane that gives the place an otherworldly glow when lit up at night. All the better for stealing the spotlight.

title: Church Hires Hundreds, but Doubts Surround Project
description: In December, the pastor of a fledgling storefront church in Red Hook, Brooklyn, began spreading word among several dozen evangelical Christian congregations that he was hiring employees for a huge new social service program. Hundreds of applicants packed meetings where, many people say, the pastor declared that he had a grant from World Vision, the international relief agency, to help the poor and spread the Gospel.

title: Rent Controversy Inspires Musical
description: The nonprofit New York Theater Barn will hold a benefit concert on April 5 of a new musical that the troupe is developing. The show is based on a 2008 controversy in Rowlett, Tex., over a local high schools plans to produce a version of Rent, the Tony Award-winning musical.

title: Commercial-Free Channel Runs a Commercial    and Apologizes
description: Since its founding almost 16 years ago, the Turner Classic Movies cable channel has promoted itself as running films uncut and commercial-free. But on Sunday night, the commercial-free part ended  temporarily and inadvertently, the channel said on Monday.

title: While Our Lessons Are On Spring Break, Try These April Ideas
description: Our lesson plans are taking a spring break this week, from Monday, March 29 to Friday, April 2. (Thats right: just imagine them stretched out on a beach, frosty drinks nearby.)

title: Tale of Two Tournaments: Exciting Side of Womens Draw Looms
description: There seems to be two womens N.C.A.A. Tournaments going on: one that has No. 1 Connecticut utterly destroying all opponents, and a second filled with exciting, tense games.

title: Debate Between Media and Apple Over iPad Hardly a Flash in the Pan
description: As our colleague Brad Stone points out, no one knows what kind of sales the iPad will gin up out of the gate on Saturday, and its just as tough to guess what forms of media will be on this newest form factor in computing.

title: G.M. Previews the 40 M.P.G. 2011 Chevrolet Cruze Eco
description: Its not exactly the Son of Volt, but the 2011 Chevy Cruze Eco will continue General Motors theme of green when it is formally introduced Wednesday at the New York auto show.

title: Militia Charged With Plotting to Murder Officers
description: CLAYTON, Mich.  David B. Stone Sr. and his wife, Tina, made no secret about the fact that they were part of a militia, neighbors say. The couple frequently let visitors in military fatigues erect tents in front of their trailer home at the intersection of rural dirt roads, and the sound of gunfire was routine.

title: Robert Plant to Bring Joy to the World
description: Robert Plant still isnt reuniting Led Zeppelin, but he is digging deep into his past for the name of his next project. Coming off a highly successful collaboration with the bluegrass singer and fiddler Alison Krauss, Mr. Plant will next hit the road with a group called the Band of Joy, a name cribbed from the 1960s band from Birmingham, England, in which he performed with the future Led Zeppelin drummer John Bonham. In a news release Mr. Plant said the lineup for the new Band of Joy would include the singer Patty Griffin, the instrumentalist and vocalist Darrell Scott, the bassist Byron House, the drummer Marco Giovino and the guitarist Buddy Miller. The band will begin a 12-city tour on July 13 in Memphis and conclude on July 31 in Miami; it is also preparing a new album on which Mr. Miller will serve as co-producer and that will be released by Rounder Records in the late summer or early fall.

title: Ex-I.B.M. Executive Pleads Guilty in Galleon Case
description: 2:12 p.m. | Updated with Mr. Moffats court statement A former I.B.M. senior executive pleaded guilty on Monday to providing confidential information about Advanced Micro Devices and Lenovo to a hedge fund consultant accused of participating in a wide-ranging insider trading scheme.

title: Times Squares Homeless Holdout, Not Budging

description: Updated, 2:21 p.m. | Southbound service on the No. 1 train was back to normal by 1:43 p.m., the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said.

title: TripAdvisor Reviews Pour in for Schrute Farms
description: The agrotourism destination Schrute Farms, which belongs to Dwight Schrute of the NBC series The Office, is doing big business  for TripAdvisor. In 2007, TripAdvisor set up a review page, thinking it would be good for a quick laugh or two. Reruns and DVDs keep inspiring new visits to the site and there are now over 600 reviews. Read more

title: Four Who Endured
description: While you consider the wreckage that is probably your N.C.A.A. tournament bracket -- in our Times staff picks, it is possible to have one Final Four team correct and be in the top five. Seriously  take a bit of comfort in the complete zaniness that is the Final Four. The truly big-time, blueblood team that made it, Duke, was being written off a year ago as a has-been basketball power. Injury-riddled Michigan State might be considered a powerhouse, except its team is being held together with chewing gum and baling wire. West Virginia won the Big East tournament, which in retrospect looks like Albert Pujolss winning a tee ball game. And then you have Butler, whose coach looks barely older than his players, who all look 12, and can be found charmingly chest-bumping them after victories.

title: Drone Strikes Are Legal, U.S. Official Says
description: A map showing U.S. drone strikes in Pakistan from a study by The New America Foundation. Enlarge.

title: Teaching Boys Where They Learn
description: Any parent of a son was probably not surprised to read Nick Kristofs column this weekend, about how boys have slipped well behind girls by many academic measures in the U.S. and Western Europe.

title: The False Safety of Bonds
description: One of the things that Im most worried about right now is people taking money that they want to keep safe and trying to find investments that earn a yield thats a little higher. This is called stretching for yield, and it can be be a dangerous game, especially if you dont understand the rules.

title: Interview: Mia Hansen-Love
description: Mia Hansen-Love, the director of "The Father of My Children," discusses the dual meaning of the film's title.

title: The Originals | Diablo Cody
description: Diablo Cody is in on the joke. And this stripper-turned-writer is as agile on the page as she was on the stage: among her current projects are developing the sudsy Sweet Valley High books into a film, while simultaneously writing an original screenplay called Young Adult, about a divorced author of teen fiction who returns to her hometown to chase her now-married high school boyfriend. This is the kind of career-as-meta-gag that smart young writers dream of, but almost nobody can pull off. Cody, a Los Angeles resident (who in an earlier life was Brook Busey from Chicago), made her name with the Oscar-winning screenplay for Juno. She followed up with the Showtime series United States of Tara, a writerly tour de force about a suburban mom (played by Toni Collette) with multiple personalities, now in its second season. Its safe to say that I need everything to be embellished, creatively or otherwise, says Cody, 31. Just like Im inclined to put on too much jewelry or get too many tattoos, I need my writing to be a little over-the-top.

title: Using Hands and Heads to Help Hearts
description: A campaign intended to better acquaint the public with the technique of hands-only cardiopulmonary resuscitation is getting some, well, helping hands.

title: Emergency Bill Passed to Keep Government Running
description: ALBANY  The State Senate approved emergency legislation on Monday to keep essential government services functioning after the March 31 budget deadline, an indication that lawmakers do not expect to quickly reach a budget deal with Gov. David A. Paterson.

title: Mental Health Experts Applaud Focus on Parity
description: Even without the new health care law, mental health advocates were getting ready to celebrate parity  a law requiring benefits for substance abuse and mental illnesses to be on par with benefits for medical illnesses.

title: TimesCast | March 29, 2010
description: From the newsroom of The New York Times.

title: Come Fly Away': One Show, Two Opinions
description: Twyla Tharp has been choreographing to the music of Frank Sinatra since the 1970s, but Come Fly Away brings her Sinatra dances to Broadway for the first time. Charles Isherwood, a New York Times theater critic, hailed it as a major new work of pop dance theater, while the Timess chief dance critic Alastair Macaulay called the choreography  less sensational than sensationalistic  this is intimacy perverted into exhibitionism.

title: Amazing Race for the Rest of Us
description: Ever watch CBSs reality show The Amazing Race, and say to yourself ,I could do that? Heres a chance to prove it.

title: Bolshoi Theater Plans Reopening in Fall of 2011
description: Closed since 2005 for a renovation project that has run years behind schedule, the Bolshoi Theater, the Moscow home of both the Bolshoi Ballet and Bolshoi Opera, is now aiming to reopen in October 2011, Agence France-Presse reported. We are assuming that the Bolshoi Theaters historic building will be opened on Oct. 2, 2011, the theaters deputy general director, Anton Getman, said, according to Agence France-Presse. I will not risk naming an earlier date, he said, but we must do all that is in our power to let the public in on Oct. 2, and we will, adding that performers and staff members might be allowed access to the building as soon as June or July. Before you get your hopes up, keep in mind the star-crossed history of the theaters $700 million restoration, which has taken nearly 5 years of its 185-year existence: originally planned to be finished in 2008, the repair work was delayed, and last year prosecutors opened an investigation into the possible embezzlement of funds intended for the project.

title: Main Opposition to Boycott Myanmar Election
description: BANGKOK  After months of internal debate, members of the party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the long-detained pro-democracy leader, defied Myanmars junta by announcing Monday that they would boycott the countrys first elections in two decades.

description: In todays Media Equation column, David Carr writes:

title: Mootopia
description: This milk commercial takes place in a make-believe land of plenty called Mootopia in a new campaign for the California Milk Processor Board.

title: Idiot-Proofing Financial Regulation
description: Ezra Klein expresses some skepticism about my skepticism. I worried that no financial reform will work if the government is dominated by people who dont believe in regulation; Ezra counters that the FDIC has been pretty robust to idiots in power.

title: Now Booking | The Exedra Milan
description: Were Lady Gaga on the prowl for a sense-dislocating set for a new video, she couldnt find one more suitably psychedelic than the Exedra Milano, the newest member of the Boscolo hotel group. In transforming what was an 11-story bank into a canny hybrid of Alice in Wonderland fantasy and space-age chic, the architect Italo Rota tickles the modernist tradition of Gio Ponti, who designed Milans landmark Pirelli Tower (which, in turn, inspired New Yorks Pan Am building). The hotel made its debut in October.

title: Greece Raises $6.7 Billion in Bond Sale
description: Just days after European Union leaders agreed to stand behind Greece as it struggled to restore its public finances, the authorities in Athens put their new guarantee to the test Monday, selling 5 billion euros of seven-year bonds to refinance debt.

title: Ethics Report Faults Ex-Congressman
description: WASHINGTON  Nathan Deal, a former Republican congressman who is running for Georgia governor, resigned from the House last week in a move that seemed certain to end an ethics investigation that could have proved politically embarrassing.

title: Good News On Mandates
description: One big concern about health reform has been the argument that the individual mandate  which is essential to keeping the risk pool broad enough  wont work, because the penalties for noncompliance are too weak. But Austin Frakt does some calculations which seem to suggest that the penalties for noncompliance under Obamacare are, if anything, slightly stronger than under Romneycare  and that since gaming of the system doesnt seem to be a large problem in Massachusetts, it probably wont be a big problem nationally.

title: CKX Confirms Sales Talks
description: CKX, the owner of the American Idol and So You Think You Can Dance franchises, confirmed on Monday that it is holding talks to sell itself, after media reports said that the entertainment company was negotiating with its chief executive and One Equity Partners, a private equity firm owned by JPMorgan Chase.

title: Man Accused of Threatening Cantor
description: Federal authorities in Philadelphia announced that a local resident has been charged with threatening to kill Representative Eric Cantor, the No. 2 Republican in the House, according to wire service and news reports.

title: Chinese Court Hands Down Stiff Sentences to Four Mining Company Employees
description: SHANGHAI  Four employees of the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto, including an Australian citizen, were found guilty by a Chinese court on Monday of accepting millions of dollars in bribes and stealing commercial secrets.

title: Application for the Forgetful Driver
description: Plenty of portable navigation devices and iPhone apps can help you with those senior moments when you forget exactly where you parked the car. The trouble with those apps is that you still have to remember to mark your parking spot in the navigation system or smartphone before you walk away. But soon you wont even have to remember to do that.

title: Getting More Fish in Your Diet
description: Nutritionists are increasingly enthusiastic about the benefits of omega-3 fatty acids, present in fatty, cold water fish such as tuna, mackerel and salmon, as well as in some nuts and vegetable oils. The benefits of regularly eating these foods include lower triglyceride levels and a reduced risk of coronary artery disease, studies have found. Experts are also researching a possible role for omega-3s in boosting the immune system and protecting against hypertension, depression and other ailments.

title: The Morning Skate: Honors for Ex-Devils Coach Pat Burns
description: If you have a half-hour or so, spend it with this segment from Ottawa radio Team 1200s Three Guys in the Morning earlier today (audio). Youll hear a terrific conversation in which the hosts, John J.R. Rodenburg, Steve Warne and Jim Jerome, talk with Pierre McGuire and Hall of Famer Larry Robinson. Robinson and McGuire discusses a couple of coaching greats, Pat Burns and Scotty Bowman, some coaching philosophy and a host of other hockey topics.

title: Ethics Report Faults Ex-Congressman
description: Remember the Georgia Congressman who announced his resignation from Congress, but then postponed it until he could vote against the health care bill in the House last week? Well, the Republican Congressman, Nathan Deal, did in fact call it quits in the hours after the final vote last weekend. But that move, done so that he could run for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in Georgia, didnt silence an ethics inquiry that had been swirling around him.

title: Confronted by Team, a Spartan Responds
description: ST. LOUIS  They do not always do things delicately at Michigan State, whether rebounding in bruising fashion or calling out a teammate for playing without enough passion.

title: Index-Finger Cooks, Pizza Bumps, Speed-Scratch Products, & Lazy Food
description: Novel terms associated with convenience cooking.

title: New Directors/New Films Video: Mia Hansen-Love
description: The French director Mia Hansen-Love brought her latest film to the New Directors/New Films festival this year, The Father of My Children. The film explores the business and home life of a film producer and how the pressures of his job, including mounting debts and increasing demands, lead to a tragic end. Father is inspired by the life and death of the French film producer Humbert Balsam. Ms. Hansen-Love discussed her film  which will be released in theaters May 28  and the dual meaning of its title:

title: Should You Hire Someone Whos Overqualified?
description: Is it actually a good idea to hire someone who is technically overqualified for a position?

title: Democrats Try to Split Bankers on Financial Bill
description: Even with Congress in recess for two weeks, the battle over financial regulatory overhaul continues to heat up. Democrats are going on the offensive, accusing industry lobbyists of improperly portraying community banks as victims of the financial regulatory legislation, when Wall Street is writing the checks to halt the bill.

title: Financial Tuneup: The Gym Cancellation Follies
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Florida State Gets Next Crack at Undefeated Connecticut
description: Hey Florida State, congratulations on reaching the final eight in the N.C.A.A. womens tournament for the first time. Your reward, however, is facing the steamroller also known as No. 1 Connecticut (36-0) on Tuesday.

title: Fatty Foods May Be Addictive
description: More evidence that junk food may be addictive, as reported by CNN and others, here.

title: Where Everyone Majors in Murder
description: This is the week when millions of college applicants will find out whether they got into their first-choice schools, were put on the waiting list or were rejected. Anyone whose heart is set on Hudson University will be disappointed.

title: Panel in Iraq Moves to Disqualify 52 Candidates
description: BAGHDAD  A government commission sought Monday to disqualify six people who had won seats in Iraqs parliamentary election and 46 other candidates because of what it called their ties to the banned Baath Party.

title: Two Colts Remain Atop Derby Contenders
description: On this years Kentucky Derby trail, two colts have towered over the current crop of 3-year-olds. Eskendereya was a crushing eight-and-a-half-length winner in the Fountain of Youth in Florida; Lookin at Lucky easily came from behind to win the Rebel Stakes by a head.

title: Overhaul Will Lower the Costs of Being a Woman
description: Being a woman is no longer a pre-existing condition. Thats the new mantra, repeated triumphantly by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Senator Barbara A. Mikulski and other advocates for womens health. But what does it mean?

title: Artifacts | Antony Gormleys Human Pop-Ups
description: All too often, public art means some clueless civic agency has plunked an annoying bronze obstruction in the path of New Yorkers already pressed for space. Well, surprise! The 31 life-size nude figures that popped up this week in the Flatiron district are not just giving public art a good name. They are giving pedestrians reason to scream with delight.

title: Subway Blasts Kill Dozens in Moscow
description: Female suicide bombers set off explosions at two Moscow subway stations during the morning rush hour, killing more than three dozen people.

title: An Accelerated Transition at Seattles Intiman Theater
description: Whatever Bartlett Sher had to teach Kate Whoriskey, she evidently learned it faster than anticipated: on Monday, the Intiman Theater in Seattle announced that its interim arrangement under which Mr. Sher (the director of Broadways South Pacific and Light in the Piazza, and the Metropolitan Operas Tales of Hoffman) and Ms. Whoriskey (who directed the Off-Broadway production of Ruined for Manhattan Theater Club) would share the title of artistic director, and Ms. Whoriskey would take over from Mr. Sher next year, was being accelerated. The theater has made Ms. Whoriskey its artistic director, effective immediately, and she will select its remaining plays for the season; Mr. Sher was named the theaters artistic director emeritus. Working with Kate over the past months has affirmed for us that that we are ready now to move forward with her vision for the theater as the sole artistic director, the theaters board president, Kim A. Anderson, said in a statement. On Sunday, the producers of the Broadway revival of The Miracle Worker that Ms. Whoriskey directed at Circle in the Square theater said it would close April 4.

title: Ilgauskas Trade Highlights Salary Cap Quirks
description: Cleveland traded Zydrunas Ilgauskas to Washington on February 17, as part of a three-team deal that also brought Antawn Jamison to the Cavs. Ilgauskas was included in the trade for financial reasons only, with his salary providing the ballast needed to make the trade legal. Sure enough, Ilgauskas was waived on February 25, without playing a single game for the Wizards.

title: In All Those Pages, a Surprise or Two
description: Tucked inside the huge health reform bill signed into law last week were many surprising and little-noticed provisions that will affect consumers in ways large and small. It emerged that chain restaurants, for example, would have to disclose the calorie counts of items on their menus. Who knew? Here are some other examples:

title: A Cycling Snob Unmasked
description: One of New Yorks best known yet most elusive cyclists is about to emerge from the shadows.

title: Rothschilds Bring in Outsider to Run the Show
description: More than 200 years ago, a German banker, Mayer Amschel Rothschild, sent his five sons to different European cities to guarantee the survival of what became one of the most prominent banking dynasties, The New York Timess Julia Werdigier reports from London.

title: Bradford Awes Observers in Pro Day Workout
description: Ah, the internet. It brings all the mundane activity of a college pro day to your living room and office. On Monday, the world got a look at Sam Bradford, the Oklahoma quarterback who is coming off major shoulder surgery to reconstruct the AC joint. His workout was the most eagerly anticipated this side of Tim Tebows because Bradford, unlike Tebow, could be the first overall pick by the St. Louis Rams.

title: What Can Benedict Do?
description: Thats Rod Drehers question, prompted by my column today:

title: Travel Deals: Kids and Art Lovers Package in Boston
description: The Renaissance Boston Waterfront Hotel, a 492-room hotel along the citys recently renovated harbor, is offering two packages starting at $189 a night: one for couples who love art and another for parents and pint-sized travelers.

title: Playwrights Horizons Announces More of 2010-11 Lineup
description: In addition to mounting the previously reported New York premiere of Edward Albees play Me, Myself & I, Playwrights Horizons on Monday announced four additional productions for its 2010-11 season, including new plays by Adam Bock (The Drunken City) and the actor David Greenspan (Coraline).

title: Interview: Laura Poitras
description: Laura Poitras, the director of "The Oath," discusses her documentary which profiles Abu Jandal, the former bodyguard of Osama bin Laden.

title: On Second Thought, Dont Eat the Plants in the Park
description: On Saturday, we published a post informing people that the shoots of the day lily flower now pushing out of the ground in parks around the city were delicious to eat. Several commenters asked why we were promoting an illegal and destructive activity.

title: A Piece of Mets History, Rewritten in Stone
description: Last season, fans hammered the Mets for not incorporating enough of the teams history into Citi Field. Now that the team has been working to fix the problem, some fans wonder if they should try a little harder when it comes to accuracy.

title: No Matter What, We Pay for Others Bad Habits
description: Im tired of paying for everyone elses stupidity, is a comment I read on the Internet last week after the health care bill was passed. It summed up the views of many Americans worried about shelling out higher premiums and taxes to cover the uninsured.
