Why should we pick up the tab when so much disease in our country stems from unhealthy behavior like smoking and overeating?

title: Dozens Killed in Moscow Subway Attacks
description: If a single face can stand in for Muscovites whose city was upended by terrorist attacks, this scarred commuter may be the one. Female suicide bombers set off huge explosions in two subway stations in central Moscow during the Monday morning rush, Russian officials said, killing more than three dozen people and raising fears that the Muslim insurgency in southern Russia was once again being brought to the countrys heart. There is a slide show devoted to the bombings.

title: R.N.C. Spends Thousands on Private Jets, Limos and Clubs, Report Shows
description: The Republican National Committee opened an investigation on Monday into why money from donors was paid to reimburse a $2,000 tab at a risqu California nightclub earlier this year, party officials said.

title: Law May Do Little to Help Curb Unnecessary Care
description: Dr. Robert Colton, an internist in Boca Raton, Fla., has a problem, and he knows it. His patients come in wanting, sometimes demanding, tests and treatments that are unnecessary, just adding to the nations huge health care bill. He even has patients, he says, who come in and report that their chief complaint is, I need an M.R.I.

title: Come Fly Away': Quantity Is Not Quality
description: The Timess Charles Isherwood and Alastair Macaulay are discussing Come Fly Away, which opened last week at the Marquis Theater. Previous posts are here.

title: Salmon Fillets With Tomatillo Salsa
description: Tomatillos have an acidic flavor that goes beautifully with salmon. The colors are great together too. Be sure to seek out wild salmon, which is in season now.

title: Potato and Tuna Pure
description: This is comfort food at its finest, similar to a tuna noodle casserole but dressed up and simpler at the same time. Its inspired by the rich Provenal salt cod pure called brandade, which often includes potatoes. But salt cod is hard to come by here, and its expensive and salty.

title: Brooklyn Building Collapse Injures Four
description: A three-story building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that was being renovated collapsed Monday afternoon, critically injuring a worker who was trapped in the rubble and leaving three other people with minor injuries, according to the Fire Department and witnesses.

title: A Tale of Two Democrats
description: Across the country, politicians returned home to face the aftermath of their health care reform votes.

title: Baked Trout With Tomatoes and Olives
description: Although this Provenal staple is traditionally a summer dish made with fresh tomatoes, you can make it successfully with canned tomatoes. The dish is a nice way to warm up your winter table and a great way to serve farmed trout, an easy fish to find.

title: G.O.P. Opens Inquiry on Club Expenditure
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican National Committee on Monday opened an investigation into why party money, which donors contributed to help win seats in the midterm elections, was used to pay a $2,000 tab at a risqu Hollywood club in late January.

title: The Planet Be Damned. Its All About Me.
description: Ian McEwan has long had a penchant for creating unsavory, disreputable characters: children who bury their mother in the basement (The Cement Garden), a Machiavellian sadist who preys on a pair of middle-class tourists (The Comfort of Strangers), a dead womans conniving former lovers (Amsterdam), an adolescent girl who makes false accusations against a man that will alter his life and the life of her entire family (Atonement).

title: Tuna and Pepper Stew
description: This recipe is loosely based on a Basque tuna soup called marmitako, a fishermans dish with simple origins. It was originally made with bread and tuna, but in later years was greatly enhanced with the arrival of peppers, tomatoes and potatoes from the New World. Every cook has a version of this dish, and I am no exception. Fresh albacore tuna from North America are often lower in environmental contaminants than other types of tuna and the most eco-friendly choice.

title: From Rage to Relief: View From a Nurses Station
description: Several weeks ago on the hospital floor where Im a nurse, we had a V.I.P. patient whose spouse expected, and got, the red-carpet treatment. The patients spouse made many demands, but what struck most of us as particularly galling was the meal service both received. Day after day, meal after meal, a hospital employee wheeled a china-laden cart into that patients room. It looked like room service at a fancy hotel.

title: At Columbia, Sarkozy Calls for Change at U.N.
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy of France presented ideas on a new world governance structure on Monday to students at Columbia University. Mr. Sarkozys address was part of the universitys World Leaders Forum, which since 2003 has attracted several heads of state, among them Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. The visit from Paris was far less controversial, but the message nonetheless relatively radical.

title: Scoop du Jour | Thierry Marx Leaves Bordeaux for Paris
description: Thierry Marx is finally moving to Paris. The French chef and Bruce Willis lookalike, who has impressed diners who have made the trek to Cordeillan-Bages in Bordeaux with his inventive molecular fare since 1996 (read about it here), has always seemed too big of a talent even for the grand 18th-century chateau owned by the Lynch-Bages wine-making family. (Imagine if Thomas Keller were stuck in Yountville.) A year from now, he will be installed at the Mandarin Oriental in Paris, which is scheduled to open in 2011 on the rue Saint-Honor. Whether he brings his two Michelin stars  or his signature dish of Aquitaine beef wrapped in plastic with burning cabernet vines  with him remains to be seen.

title: Oakland to Discuss Plan to Reach Aggressive Greenhouse-Gas Reduction Goal
description: As of November 2009, at least 139 cities in the United States had climate action plans, including Portland and Chicago. Oakland doesnt have one yet, but it does have a goal: by 2020, the city seeks to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 36 percent of what they were in 2005. That goal is more aggressive than those of either San Francisco or Berkeley, which both have climate action plans.

title: Consumers Big Question: Whats in It for Me?
description: More than a week after President Obama signed the sweeping new health care law, which will eventually provide insurance coverage for 32 million uninsured Americans, many of us are still scratching our heads. What just happened? And how and when will we start feeling its effect?

title: Come Fly Away': The Nature of the Event
description: The Timess Charles Isherwood and Alastair Macaulay are discussing Come Fly Away, which opened last week at the Marquis Theater. Previous posts are here.

title: The Professors Appeal Saves Him With One Arsenal Fan
description: The harmony of 60,000 voices that drifts out of the Emirates Stadium in London every other week is evidence that sport can bring people together.

title: Playing Musical Chairs to Capture Beethovens Spirit
description: The ostensible lure of the four-concert series the conductor Ivan Fischer presented with the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment and the Budapest Festival Orchestra at Lincoln Center was the chance to hear all nine Beethoven symphonies performed in close proximity by two exemplary ensembles representing different traditions: the period-instrument band and the modern orchestra.

title: Disabled Immigration Detainees Face Deportation
description: For lawyers offering free legal information at large immigration detention centers in remote parts of Texas, the task is difficult enough: coaching hundreds of detainees on how to represent themselves at assembly-line deportation hearings. But the lawyers soon discover a more daunting problem: many detainees are too mentally ill or mentally disabled to understand anything.

title: Readers Separate Church From Home Plate
description: Are you saying Jesus Christ cant hit a curveball? asked Eddie Harris in the baseball movie classic Major League. Mr. Harris was in the locker room with his teammate Pedro, who was trying to explain how Jobu, his god, would help him hit the ball straight. Like Pedro and Mr. Harris, many players today appeal to a higher power when on the field. But what is Gods role inside the diamond?

title: Nets Executive Has New Take on Brown Bagger
description: In the long, strange trip known as the Nets 2009-2010 season, Tuesday may turn out to be a red-letter day on the weirdness calendar.

title: Russias Fear of Female Bombers Is Revived
description: MOSCOW  The two powerful explosions that tore through Moscows subway on Monday revived a peculiar fear in the Russian capital, one that goes beyond the usual terrorism worries of a metropolis: the female bomber.

title: 2-Man Cast Shares Stage With a Vivid Character
description: I wonder, Mark Rothko muses, staring at one of his canvases. Do you think theyll ever forgive me?

title: Jos Saramago, Litblogger
description: Can a blog rise to the level of literature?

title: Finger Family Takes Aim Again at Bank of America
description: 5:44 p.m. | Updated The Finger family of Houston, a relatively large and very dissatisfied shareholder in Bank of America, sent a scathing letter to shareholders in advance of the banks annual meeting in late April, urging them to vote against the re-election of one board member and to vote for a provision to make it easier to claw back executive compensation.

title: Rubber Soles | 50 Years of Dr. Martens (The Musical)
description: By the time Britains skinheads completed their devolution from hard-edged dandies to racist hooligans, their cherished Dr. Martens boots had gone viral. Before long, the list of D.M. devotees would span the length of the screw-up spectrum: Mods, glams, punks, ska, psycho-hillbillies, grebos, Goths, industrialists, nu-metal, hardcore, straight-edge, grunge, Britpop and on and on, says Martin Roach, D.M.s de facto historian. Now, Dr. Martens is marking its 50th anniversary. To celebrate, the company has commissioned covers of 10 cult songs from acts like the Human League, Buzzcocks, the Pogues and even the Cold War Kids. (Full details here.) The songs and music videos drop on Thursday at drmartens.com. For an exclusive-to-T taste, watch profiles of three of the cutting-edge acts involved in the project.

title: 10 Mexican Students Killed in Another Violent Weekend
description: MONTERREY, Mexico  Mexico reeled Monday from another bloody weekend of drug-related killings that was made even more horrible by the baffling massacre of 10 young people and children traveling in a pickup truck in Durango State.

title: Making Sense of the Health Care Law
description: Confused by the new health care law? Todays special section on health reform in Science Times helps you figure out what it might mean for you.

title: Making a Spiritual Connection With Matzo
description: There was the flour, the water, and the intention of turning them into unleavened bread to be consumed during Passover. But what made this matzo-making operation different from all others?

title: Ads for Community Papers, but Are They Local?
description: The story of newspapers woes is well known, and the news is almost continually dire. As major media organizations erect digital fortifications  across the pond and right in our back yard  community newspapers, those bastions of local event photos and pothole exposs, find themselves no less threatened by changing reading habits and the negative prognoses they engender.

title: Baird Lures 2 Executives From Morgan Stanley
description: Baird Private Wealth Management has lured two executives from Morgan Stanley Smith Barney to join its office in Scottsdale, Ariz., Reuters reports.

title: For Photographers, the Image of a Shrinking Path
description: By the time Matt Eich entered photojournalism school in 2004, the magazine and newspaper business was already declining.

title: Robert Plants New Band Has an Old Name
description: Robert Plant still isnt reuniting Led Zeppelin, but he is digging deep into his past for the name of his next project. Coming off a successful collaboration with the bluegrass singer and fiddler Alison Krauss, Mr. Plant, left, will next hit the road with a group called the Band of Joy, a name cribbed from the 1960s group from Birmingham, England, in which he performed with the future Led Zeppelin drummer John Bonham. In a news release Mr. Plant said the lineup for the new Band of Joy would include the singer Patty Griffin, the instrumentalist and vocalist Darrell Scott, the bassist Byron House, the drummer Marco Giovino and the guitarist Buddy Miller. The band will begin a 12-city tour on July 13 in Memphis and conclude on July 31 in Miami; it is also preparing an album.

title: Rent Controversy Inspires a Musical
description: The nonprofit New York Theater Barn will hold a benefit performance on April 5, offering a full reading and songs from a new musical that the troupe is developing. The show takes its inspiration from a 2008 controversy in Rowlett, Tex., over a local high schools plans to produce a version of Rent, the Tony Award-winning musical. High school drama clubs across the country have run into opposition trying to mount productions of Rent: School Edition, a slightly toned-down adaptation of the Broadway show, which featured straight and gay characters who cope with drug addiction, infidelity, homelessness and AIDS. New York Theater Barns project, Speargrove Presents, is described by the company as a humorous, heartfelt account of a debate over Rent in a small Texas town. The benefit will be at the Julia Miles Theater on West 55th Street.

title: The Walking Dead Rises on AMC
description: With a schedule that includes Mad Men and Breaking Bad, the AMC channel has often been credited for its brains, which should make the newest additions to its original programming lineup very happy.

title: New Booking Site for Down Under
description: Need to get from Alyangula to Wagga Wagga? A new online travel site, Wotflight.com makes it easier to search for flights within Australia.

title: Playwrights Horizons Adds Four Shows
description: In addition to mounting the New York premiere of Edward Albees play Me, Myself & I, as previously reported, Playwrights Horizons on Monday announced four productions for its 2010-11 season, including new plays by Adam Bock (The Drunken City) and the actor and writer David Greenspan (Coraline). After opening the season with the Albee in August, Playwrights Horizons will produce After the Revolution by Amy Herzog, about a family confronting its history with Marxism. Mr. Bocks Small Fire, about a woman losing her senses, will follow. Next up will be Kin, about the relationship between a Texas poetry scholar and an Irish personal trainer, by Bathsheba Doran (Living Room in Africa). Mr. Greenspans new play, Go Back to Where You Are, is described by the company as a melancholy comic romance about a chorus boy (played by Mr. Greenspan) from ancient Greece in purgatory who is dispatched after 2,000 years to mix with a vacationing family in the Hamptons. A sixth production is to be announced later.

title: TriBeCa Festival Adds Freakonomics
description: Does a documentary film adapted from a best-selling nonfiction work about the application of economic theories and models to unusual real-life situations stand any chance at the box office? Attendees of the Tribeca Film Festival will get an early chance to answer that puzzler. On Monday, festival organizers said the film version of Freakonomics, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner (both are contributors to The New York Times), is to be shown at its closing-night gala on April 30. The film, making its world premiere at the festival, includes segments directed by Alex Gibney, Morgan Spurlock, Rachel Grady and Heidi Ewing, Eugene Jarecki and Seth Gordon.

title: A One-Woman Job at Intiman Theater
description: Whatever Bartlett Sher had to teach Kate Whoriskey, she evidently learned faster than anticipated. On Monday, the Intiman Theater in Seattle announced that the interim arrangement under which Mr. Sher would share the title of artistic director with Ms. Whoriskey, who was to take over next year, was being accelerated. The theater has made Ms. Whoriskey its artistic director, effective immediately, and she will select its remaining plays for the season; Mr. Sher was named the theaters artistic director emeritus. Working with Kate over the past months has affirmed for us that we are ready now to move forward with her vision for the theater as the sole artistic director, the theaters board president, Kim A. Anderson, said in a statement. On Sunday, the producers of the Broadway revival of The Miracle Worker, directed by Ms. Whoriskey at Circle in the Square theater, announced it would close on April 4.

title: Basketball and Boss Help CBS Win
description: N.C.A.A. mens basketball, 60 Minutes and Undercover Boss lifted CBS far ahead of its competitors in the ratings on Sunday. CBS began the night in the lead thanks to a half-hour overrun of its basketball coverage from the afternoon, earning an average of 18 million viewers from 7 to 7:30 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Coming next, CBSs 60 Minutes remained on top with 14.5 million, while The Amazing Race garnered 13 million viewers in the next hour. At approximately 9:30, CBSs Undercover Boss delivered the nights largest nonsports audience with 16.1 million viewers. NBC lagged behind but finished in second place over all, attracting 7.3 million viewers for Celebrity Apprentice, after episodes of Dateline (4.5 million) and Minute to Win It (5.8 million). ABC was third with mostly repeats, and Fox ranked fourth.

title: Bolshoi Theater Planning Fall 2011 Reopening
description: Closed since 2005 for a renovation project that is running years behind schedule, the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, home of both the Bolshoi Ballet (backstage in 2001, above) and Bolshoi Opera, is now aiming at October 2011 for its reopening, Agence France-Presse reported. We are assuming that the Bolshoi Theaters historic building will be opened on Oct. 2, 2011, the theaters deputy general director, Anton Getman, said, according to Agence France-Presse. I will not risk naming an earlier date, but we must do all that is in our power to let the public in on Oct. 2, and we will. Before you mark your calendar, though, keep in mind the star-crossed history of the theaters $700 million restoration, which has taken nearly 5 years of its 185-year existence: originally planned to be finished in 2008, work was delayed and last year prosecutors opened an investigation into the possible embezzlement of funds intended for the project.

title: Performers in Two Distinct Worlds, Real and Projected
description: Choreographers have long been fascinated by the illusions that can be spun from the intersections of light and the moving body. That fascination goes back at least to Loie Fuller at the end of the 19th century, but lives on in the work of Alwin Nikolais, Mummenschanz, Pilobolus and Momix.

title: F.D.A. to Examine Menthol Cigarettes
description: For the cigarette industry, the menthol debate is about to flare up again.

title: Downsizing Sacred Works for Intimacy of a Chapel
description: The Chopin and Schumann bicentenaries and the Barber centenary have received ample attention this year, but let us not overlook Giovanni Battista Pergolesi, who was born in 1710 and lived only 26 years. He is best known for music he did not actually compose: the suite movements that Stravinsky thought were Pergolesis when he reconfigured them in Pulcinella turn out to have been by Domenico Gallo, and the popular Concerti Armonici were discovered to have been by Unico Wilhelm van Wassenaer.

title: Among Weathercasters, Doubt on Warming
description: The debate over global warming has created predictable adversaries, pitting environmentalists against industry and coal-state Democrats against coastal liberals.

title: New Directors/New Films Video: Laura Poitras
description: The Oath, directed by Laura Poitras, looks inside the life of Abu Jandal, a Yemeni taxi driver who was once the bodyguard for Osama bin Laden. The film also peers deeper into United States government interrogation methods at Guantanamo and poses further questions about how America is handling terrorism in after 9/11. Ms. Poitras spoke about how she came to make a documentary involving Abu Jandal and Al Qaeda, when it wasnt her original intention:

title: Daring Acts and Hard Sells
description: Its brash. Its bold. Its untamed. Its the chaos of merchandising that swallows visitors entering Madison Square Garden to see FUNundrum!, the new offering from Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus. While the show turns out to be the best the troupe has presented in years, to get to it youll have to fight through hawkers in the lobby, along the hallways and up and down the aisles, each insistent on selling you (or rather, your children) a reminder of an experience you havent yet had, with all the subtlety of an air horn blown into a megaphone.

title: Weather Forecasters on Global Warming
description: April 7, 9:59 a.m. | Updated  The Colbert Report has weighed in on meteorology and climatology:

title: Road Warriors Recruit for Military
description: The words military business travel may conjure up images of soldiers strapped in airplane cargo holds. But when recruiters for the four branches of the United States military go on business trips, its often hard to tell them apart from civilian travelers.

title: The New Landscape of Health Care
description: Tuesdays special section in Science Times helps you make sense of the health care overhaul.

title: Making Some Hits From 1500 Sound Fresh Again
description: The Tallis Scholars have long been stars in the world of early music. The groups performance on Friday evening at St. Bartholomews Church on Park Avenue, conducted by Peter Phillips, showcased this choir at its luminous best.

title: Will the Moscow Attacks Help Putin?
description: The terrorists will be destroyed, Prime Minister Vladimir Putin of Russia vowed on Monday, after two female suicide bombers set off blasts that killed dozens in two Moscow subway stations at rush hour.

title: When Styles Converge and Diverge
description: Watching pieces by choreographers who have all worked with an influential mentor is a little like seeing a family. In a certain light, or at a certain angle, in the way a head tilts or someone stands, you spot the resemblances clearly. At other moments independence prevails.

title: At Hyundai, New Models  and a New Marketing Boss
description: The coming New York auto show  officially, the New York International Auto Show, April 2 to 11 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center  is bringing automotive executives from around the world to peddle their wares in New York City. Among them is the newest marketing executive at a major marque, Christopher J. Perry of Hyundai Motor America.

title: E.P.A. Delays Plants Pollution Permits
description: WASHINGTON - The Environmental Protection Agency said Monday that it would not require power plants or other industrial sites to obtain federal pollution permits for emitting greenhouse gases before next January.

title: Learning More About the New Law
description: Now that Congress has adopted the big health care legislation, a lot of people are looking for more information about the bill in hopes of figuring out what it means for them, or how their members of Congress voted.

title: Addams Family Has Another $1 Million Week
description: The new Broadway musical The Addams Family grossed more than $1 million last week for the third week in a row, a strong showing for a production that is still in preview performances  spurring stage whispers along the Rialto that the Nathan Lane-Bebe Neuwirth musical might be critic-proof (at least as long as the two stars are in it).

title: Critics' Picks: 'Singin' in the Rain'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at the 1952 musical.

title: Park Place
description: Inserting a new house into a once-industrial neighborhood isn't always an easy task. Designing something exponentially fancier than its surroundings makes no sense, but going the faux-former-factory route is just as bad. Luke Ogrydziak and Zoe Prillinger of Ogrydziak/Prillinger Architects, a 10-year-old San Francisco firm, navigated a graceful middle ground in their design for this 6,000 square-foot, three-story house and private art gallery in the city's South of Market district. Its plain, rugged materials, elegant proportions and openness to its surroundings make it an asset to its setting -but a suitably unobtrusive one.

title: Musicians Without Borders
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  Combining the essences of different kinds of music used to be a stroke of creativity. Now its almost a rule of commerce. The word eclecticism has been used so much for the last 30 years that it has become meaningless  a sad, grasping pile of obstruents and sibilants, like a dying fires last pops and hisses.

title: All About Me to Close Sunday
description: The new Broadway musical All About Me, in which pianist Michael Feinstein and entertainer Dame Edna Everage have dueling acts on stage, will close this Sunday after 27 preview performances and 20 regular performances.

title: 6 Teenagers Are Charged After Classmates Suicide
description: It is not clear what some students at South Hadley High School expected to achieve by subjecting a freshman to the relentless taunting described by a prosecutor and classmates.

title: Local Agglomeration
description: Aha. I have to give a talk in a couple of weeks at the American Association of Geographers, and found myself thinking of a sign one sees while driving into New York. I was researching the history of the North New Jersey embroidery industry, and discovered that someone has a Flickr picture.

title: Alstom at Center of Web of Bribery Inquiries
description: The detention last week of three executives at the British unit of the French industrial giant Alstom was the latest in a tangle of investigations regarding possible bribes paid by the conglomerate to secure contracts around the world, according to investigators in several countries.

title: Critics Picks Video: Singin in the Rain
description: A. O. Scott gets a glorious feeling when he looks back on Singin in the Rain in Critics Picks this week. The film, which takes place during Hollywoods transition out of the silent era, is best known for its musical numbers. Its made up of one showstopper after another, Mr. Scott says. The lyrics are witty, the music is beautiful, the choreography is spectacular, he continues. Please share your thoughts about Singin in the Rain. Do you consider it one of the best musicals ever made?

title: Oak Hill Investment Names Managing Partner
description: Oak Hill Investment Management said Monday that it had hired Mark J.P. Anson as a managing partner and chairman of its investment committee.

title: Space Invaders
description: We are aboard the spaceship Kaleidoscope, leaving the earths orbit at warp speed as intergalactic flight attendants comfort the giddy and slightly disoriented passengers. The rockets engines rumble, the earth simulation rooms are readied for the homesick, and bubbles pour forth from the ceiling. Welcome to Flight 18,  a free-spirited experimental theater piece and joyride.

title: For Filmmaker, Ethiopias Struggle Is His Own
description: WASHINGTON  Among the courses Haile Gerima teaches at Howard University is one called Film and Social Change. But for Mr. Gerima, an Ethiopian director and screenwriter who has lived here since the 1970s in what he calls self-exile, that subject is not just an academic concern: it is also what motivates him to make films with African and African-American themes.

title: Dont Be Narrow-Minded
description: Via Brad DeLong, I see that Greg Mankiw seems to favor narrow banking: require banks to hold all their deposits in liquid, short-term assets, thus obviating the risk of financial crises.

title: Ears Looking at You
description: There is a cacaphony of headphones on the market, with choices that range from sleek in-ear to old-school on-ear, in materials from blingy crystal to crafty wood.

title: Limits Eased on Pakistani Scientist
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani court on Monday eased some travel restrictions on Abdul Qadeer Khan, the scientist and pioneer of Pakistans nuclear arsenal who admitted six years ago that he had been running an illicit proliferation network. But the court maintained a prohibition on news interviews with him about his past nuclear activities, according to lawyers involved in the case.

title: Mad as Hell and Ready to Fight the Gods
description: There are few good guys in Greek mythology. Or good gods, for that matter. One of the great motifs of the ancients was that the gods were just as, uh, human, as the rest of us. In fact they are generally less moral than humans because they have been corrupted by their power.

title: Greece Raises $6.7 Billion in Bond Sale
description: Just days after European Union leaders agreed to stand behind Greece as it struggled to restore its public finances, the authorities in Athens put their new guarantee to the test Monday, selling 5 billion euros of seven-year bonds to refinance debt, The New York Timess David Jolly reports.

title: Has Viral Gone Viral?
description: Over the last year, weve seen the rapid development of the real-time Web, incorporating the spread of news, status updates and the entertainment we share and consume. Its as if the idea of going viral has, well, gone viral itself.

title: S.E.C. Questions Wall St. Firms About Accounting
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is questioning Wall Street firms about whether they employed accounting strategies like those that Lehman Brothers was accused of using to hide leverage, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Report Conveys Despairs Reign in a Torn Haiti
description: The Quake makes its debut on PBSs Frontline on Tuesday night, only two and a half months after the earthquake that pulverized parts of Haiti. Reported by Martin Smith, its an intelligent, conscientious, elegantly produced throwing up of the hands.

title: Common Sense and Insider Trading
description: Two years ago, I wrote about Oleksandr Dorozhko and an opinion by a federal judge who thought he should be allowed to keep his ill-gotten gains:

title: Repo Men, Exposed?
description: The S.E.C.s division of corporate finance appears to have read that huge report on Lehman Brothers. And now it wants to know if Lehmans repo game was common.

title: A New Chance to Strengthen an Eroding Bond
description: At a wedding recently, I met a woman, a freelance photographer in her early 40s. She was intrigued by my work as a doctor and began asking me questions related to her own health. When she showed me a picture of herself with her four children, I realized why. This gaunt woman had lost almost 20 pounds in the month since the photo had been taken and, despite efforts to stop the weight loss, was still losing more.

title: What Were Reading: iPad Fanboys and Facebook Likeboys
description: The clickstream of the Times technology journalists is overflowing like a New York storm sewer:

title: Televised Debates Come to British Politics
description: A half century after John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon squared off on the small screen, this year British politicians are going head to head in live televised debates for the first time ever ahead of an election.

title: Icahn Defends His Lions Gate Bid as Fair
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn shot back again at Lions Gate Entertainment on Monday for rejecting his $6-a-share takeover offer, telling Reuters that the bid was a fair price and that the only reason that the movie studios stock has been trading above $6 was because of him.

title: Judge Invalidates Human Gene Patent
description: A federal judge on Monday struck down patents on two genes linked to breast and ovarian cancer. The decision, if upheld, could throw into doubt the patents covering thousands of human genes and reshape the law of intellectual property

title: Somalis Protest Against Shabab in Mogadishu
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia - Hundreds of enraged protesters marched through the streets of Mogadishu on Monday to protest against the Shabab, a militant Islamist insurgent group, in one of the largest demonstrations in recent years.

title: Mets Considering Feliciano for Setup Role
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Manager Jerry Manuel dropped a big hint Monday that Pedro Feliciano could become the Mets eighth-inning setup man. He said Feliciano, who has been almost unhittable this spring, was among the candidates, which was not exactly a declaration. But then Manuel made sure reporters knew that he told them something fairly important.

title: Twin Bombings in Moscow
description: Suicide bombers at two subway stations killed dozens in central Moscow during rush hour Monday.

title: British Candidates Debate Hard Choices on Finances
description: LONDON  All three agreed, at least, that things were going to be tough and that hard choices and painful cuts would have to be made. But none of them  not Alistair Darling, the chancellor of the Exchequer, nor the two men who hope to succeed him, George Osborne of the Conservative Party and Vince Cable of the Liberal Democrats  ventured to say exactly where and when the cuts would come.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,016 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: CNN Fails to Stop Fall in Ratings
description: CNN continued what has become a precipitous decline in ratings for its prime-time programs in the first quarter of 2010, with its main hosts losing almost half their viewers in a year.

title: Early Diagnoses of the New Law
description: Love it or hate it, the health care overhaul is the most significant piece of domestic legislation to emerge from Washington in decades. The new law is also ferociously complex: the original Senate bill, which served as the blueprint for most of the changes, ran well over 2,000 pages.

title: Lack of Video Slows Hunt for a Killer in the Subway
description: While there were some conflicting witness accounts, the police believe the man who fatally stabbed two others with a knife during a subway brawl early Sunday morning fled the train at the Christopher Street station.

title: In New York, Salvation Is Not Nigh. Our Messiahs Just Arent Up for It.
description: A custom observed at Passover Seders on Monday night involved filling a cup of wine for the prophet Elijah and opening the front door to usher him in. Tradition holds that Elijah is a harbinger of the Messiah. As such, his arrival is fervently awaited. Among Jews, it has been awaited for a good many centuries. If waiting were an occupation, believing Jews could enjoy enviable job security.

title: A Standout Player Who Is Happy Blending In
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  For the first time in Jason Bays recollection, perhaps in his entire career, he was roundly booed. It happened here March 11, when the Mets played the Red Sox and many of the Boston fans in attendance chose to express their displeasure with Bays decision to leave the Red Sox with a sustained, grumbling boo when he came to the plate.

title: A Lawyer Rejoins a Cause That First Gripped Her 70 Years Ago
description: Ileta Green woke up Monday morning feeling anxious and dizzy, but when she arrived at the Supreme Court building in Brooklyn, she felt the pressure dissipate. There, waiting for her by the foreclosure settlement room on the third floor, was Shirley Adelson Siegel, a small 91-year-old woman in a silk scarf and a brown leather cap. Hello, dear, Ms. Siegel said, smiling at Ms. Green. Youre looking well.

title: Companies Push to Repeal Provision of Health Law
description: An association representing 300 large corporations urged President Obama and Congress on Monday to repeal a provision of the health care overhaul that prompted AT&T, Caterpillar and other companies to announce substantial charges for the current quarter.

title: A Back Hall Where Rules Are Ignored
description: ALBANY  The sign just outside the door to the State Assembly chambers back hallway could not be clearer. All lobbyists must use east entrance to chamber, it reads, adding, This is west side.

title: Teenager Testifies About Attacking Latinos for Sport
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  It was a Friday night in November 2008, and three Long Island teenagers looking for something to do ended up talking about going beaner hopping.

title: He Opened a Door and Found a Long Career
description: In the nearly 50 years since 460 East 79th Street was built, the doors have been replaced. The doorman has not. Steve Keschl first opened the doors there in a professional capacity in June 1960, when he was 33 and the building was newly completed. Today, Mr. Keschl is 83, and he is still a doorman at the 20-story tower, now a condominium building. The lobby has two chairs, but Mr. Keschl does not sit in them, neither during his five-day-a-week shift nor during two interviews. He said it wouldnt look right.

title: S.E.C. Looks at Wall St. Accounting
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Monday it had started an inquiry into about two dozen financial companies to determine whether they followed accounting practices similar to those recently disclosed in an investigation of Lehman Brothers.

title: Former Cabdriver Pleads Guilty in Crash That Killed Rider
description: A former New York taxi driver admitted on Monday that he had stopped taking his medication and had a seizure just before the cab he was driving crashed nearly four years ago, killing a 20-year-old Pace University student who was a passenger.

title: Ex-I.B.M Executive Pleads Guilty to Fraud in Galleon Trading Case
description: A former I.B.M. senior executive pleaded guilty on Monday to providing confidential information about Advanced Micro Devices and Lenovo to a hedge fund consultant accused of participating in a wide-ranging insider trading scheme.

title: Bloggingheads: Neurowar
description: John Horgan, left, of the Stevens Center for Science Writings and George Johnson, author of The Ten Most Beautiful Experiments, debate applying neuroscience to warfare.

title: New York Is Denied Grant of $700 Million for Schools
description: Among the 16 finalists for the competitive federal education grant known as Race to the Top, New York came in second to last on Monday, leaving the state out of the money but with plenty of blame to spread around.

title: Williamsburg Building Collapse Injures 4
description: A three-story brick building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that was being renovated collapsed on Monday afternoon, critically injuring a worker who was trapped in the rubble and leaving three other people with minor injuries, the Fire Department and witnesses said.

title: Woods Fuels Minor Surge in Masters Ticket Prices
description: When Tiger Woods declared on March 16 that he would emerge from golf hibernation at the Masters, Dalton Daves of Little Rock, Ark., was offering four tickets to next Wednesdays final practice round on eBay for $1,400.

title: New E.P.A. Scrutiny Is Set for a Chemical in Plastics
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency plans to add bisphenol-A, or BPA, a plastic widely used in food packaging and plastic bottles, to its list of chemicals of concern because of potential adverse impacts on the environment and human and animal health.

title: Iraqi Ex-Premier Looks to Past in Fighting Critics
description: BAGHDAD  Ayad Allawi has seldom spoken publicly about the night more than 30 years ago when a pair of ax-wielding assassins turned his London bedroom into an abattoir.

title: Spurt of Home Buying as End of Tax Credit Looms
description: DES MOINES  Nine hundred days after putting their house on the market, Andrew and Jane Palestini were beginning to think they might be stuck in Iowa forever.

title: Counting the Blessings of Insomnia
description: Drip, drip, drip  thats what insomniac thoughts feel like, a leaky faucet behind the eyes. Last night the ideas were plinking; forehead-pounding regrets over past deeds, horrid fantasies, car crashes of expectations, unrealizable longings. Its sheer torture. I dont deserve it! Drip: Or maybe I do.

title: A Club With a Hollywood Tint
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  It is, admittedly, a rare occasion when the phrase understated elegance shares space in the same review as half-naked girl hanging from a net across the ceiling. But these sorts of descriptions appear in tandem in a number of reviews of Voyeur, the high-priced, bondage-themed club where the Republican National Committee spent nearly $2,000 in February, according to Federal Election Commission filings.

title: A Guiding Voice Amid the Ruins of a Capital City
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  A veiled female journalist (who also happens to be wearing a snug denim skirt) sits in a soundproof studio with a fuzzy microphone in front of her face.

title: The Time to Let Moore Be Moore
description: DAYTON, Ohio  When Connecticuts Maya Moore committed early defensive lapses against Iowa State, Coach Geno Auriemma said nothing. When she committed a clumsy offensive foul, he stood with his arms folded, mute.

title: For Star Power, Look to Bench, Not the Court
description: INDIANAPOLIS  When savvy coaches break down an N.C.A.A. tournament they always recommend picking the team with the most sure-fire N.B.A. draft picks. Recently, North Carolina won national titles in 2005 and 2009 with future N.B.A. stars.

title: Get on Your Dancing Shoes
description: We're usually quick to delete the e-mail promotions we get from the many different tourism boards  that's true even for you, Alaska House  but we couldn't resist this one from the Singaporeans. From noon to 5 p.m. today, Matt Harding, the viral video celebrity known for dancing in front of major landmarks around the world, will be in Times Square for a flash dance in support of Singapore's travel board. Join him in an impromptu groove-fest. Participants can also record their own dance moves on video and enter them into a contest with the chance to win an all-expenses-paid trip to the country.

title: Remembering McQueen
description: Armadillo heels made famous by Lady Gaga, plumed dresses covered in gold leaf, and a final collection that was a "vision of Gothic glory." The death of Alexander McQueen was a major loss for the fashion world. Pay tribute to the designer by visiting Housing Works Thrift Shop in Hell's Kitchen today. The store's window displays will feature a selection of over 30 gowns and accessories by Mr. McQueen in a silent auction. Bidding for the clothes began on March 29 and runs through April 11.

title: Keep It Rockin
description: "Anyone who didn't make it to the musical smorgasbord of South by Southwest this month can still benefit from one of its byproducts: post-festival tour routing," writes Ben Sisario. "Many of the 2,000 or so bands that passed through Austin, Tex., for SXSW stay on the road, playing shows for gas money home or as part of a continuing tour. Tonight check out Micachu and the Shapes, featuring Mica Levi, "a British music-school survivor who makes fascinating, fractured post-post-punk out of little chunks of noise pollution. The band was one of the breakout acts at South by Southwest in 2009; it's a sign of how fast things move that there was no need to return." He'll be at Le Poisson Rouge at 6:30 p.m.

title: Berlusconis Coalition Makes Gains in Italy Regional Vote
description: MILAN  Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconis center-right coalition made significant and unexpected gains Monday in regional elections that called some 40 million Italians to the polls, wresting four regions from the opposition.

title: State Debt Woes Grow Too Big to Camouflage
description: California, New York and other states are showing many of the same signs of debt overload that recently took Greece to the brink  budgets that will not balance, accounting that masks debt, the use of derivatives to plug holes, and armies of retired public workers who are counting on benefits that are proving harder and harder to pay.

title: A Quiet and Steady Hand at the Controls for Duke
description: HOUSTON  Jon Scheyer has an undisputed reputation among his Duke teammates for being a clutch performer in football and in soccer.

title: R.N.C. Dismisses Aide Over Outing to Club
description: A Republican Party spokesman said Monday evening that a staff member has been dismissed following a February outing to a risqu Hollywood nightclub, where a party donor submitted a $2,000 tab and asked for reimbursement from the Republican National Committee

title: Afghan Leader Is Seen to Flout Influence of U.S.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  This month, with President Hamid Karzai looking ahead to a visit to the White House, he received a terse note from aides to President Obama: Your invitation has been revoked.

title: The Issue of Liquidity Bubbles Up
description: WASHINGTON

title: Sabathia Opts for Afternoon Game and the Chance to Hit
description: TAMPA, Fla.  On a typical split-squad day, a veteran starting pitcher gets to choose where he would prefer to pitch. If the games fall as they will on Tuesday, when the Yankees play Atlanta in Lake Buena Vista in the afternoon and face Toronto at Steinbrenner Field at night, most pitchers will probably take the home game over the 90-minute bus ride up Interstate 4.

title: Teixeira Leaves Game After Taking Pitch on the Elbow
description: Baltimore Orioles starter Jeremy Guthrie hit Mark Teixeira on the right elbow with a pitch in the second inning of the Yankees 11-7 victory on Monday.

title: How TV Makers Are Selling the Idea of 3-D at Home
description: THE consumer electronics world thrives on the latest new thing. And this year that would be 3-D. It was once considered a quirky technology gone nowhere, but, because of the popularity of Avatar, television makers now are racing to bring multidimensional viewing to the living room.

title: President Obama in Kabul
description: President Obamas visit to Afghanistan on Sunday was a long overdue, and desperately needed, attempt to persuade President Hamid Karzai to clean up his act.

title: An Education Basic
description: Nearly 600,000 students in the New York City area take the bus or subway to school. For years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has given most of them three free rides per school day. With the transit agency facing severe budget deficits and paring staff and services, it has threatened to eliminate all student passes. Officials say it would save $214 million a year.

title: Lehman Says Debtor Claims May Decline
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings, which has been reviewing demands from creditors for payment, said in a regulatory filing on Monday that unsecured claims might fall to $260 billion as it rejects inappropriate claims.

title: Physical Reactions
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  I mentioned Elizabeth Gorskis name yesterday. Here she is with todays puzzle, with what I like to think of as an Olympics theme. You know, the Cops, in slang thing. I cant tell if thats funny or not. For heavens sake, do not click here to listen to that theme song. It will take days to get the tune out of your head.

title: Godfather of iPod Severs Final Ties With Apple
description: An era is formally ending at Apple. Tony Fadell, one of the creators of the iPod and iPhone, is breaking off his nine-year affiliation with Steve Jobs & Co.

title: Regulators Reject a Drug Makers Plan to Use Its Alertness Pill to Overcome Jet Lag
description: Air travelers for now may have to rely on coffee instead of a wonder drug to help them function in new time zones.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about a Tea Party Express rally in Nevada at which several speakers denounced Democrats for portraying Tea Party members as angry and violent paraphrased incorrectly from comments by one speaker who said that he doubted an account of how Representative John Lewis was treated during a Tea Party rally outside the Capitol recently. The speaker said he did not believe that protesters had shouted racial epithets at Mr. Lewis; he did not say the account was about protesters spitting at the congressman. (A spokesman for Representative Emanuel Cleaver II of Missouri said Mr. Cleaver had been spat on by a protester outside the Capitol. )

title: Corrections
description: A Congressional Memo article on Thursday about the decision by Democrats to pass a health care bill that did not include the government-run insurance plan known as the public option misstated the number of new customers that private health insurance companies are expected to gain under the new law. It is 16 million, not 30 million. (The Congressional Budget Office estimates that about 30 million to 32 million uninsured people will be covered by the new law.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a new study on traffic patterns in Manhattan based on data gathered by GPS devices on cabs referred imprecisely to the holidays that were excluded from calculations to determine the weekday with the fastest traffic during the period studied. While federal holidays were excluded, not all holidays were. (Yom Kippur, which was on Monday, Sept. 28, 2009, was included in the study. The report ranked that date as the weekday with the fastest traffic.)

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 29, 2010

title: In Mexico, Security Is in the Planning
description: NOGALES, Mexico

title: Animal Abusers
description: To the Editor:

title: Google and Censorship
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sandra Bullock Trade
description: Two things happened to Sandra Bullock this month. First, she won an Academy Award for best actress. Then came the news reports claiming that her husband is an adulterous jerk. So the philosophic question of the day is: Would you take that as a deal? Would you exchange a tremendous professional triumph for a severe personal blow?

title: Moscow Under Attack
description: Moscow

title: Alive, Alive
description: Moscow

title: Right of Passage
description: A Mississippi school board was grossly discriminatory and mean-spirited when it told Constance McMillen that she could not attend her high school prom with her girlfriend. A ruling by a federal judge that Ms. McMillens constitutional rights had been violated is a welcome sign that gay people are continuing to make progress toward equality. It should also be a warning to school districts nationwide about the cost of discrimination.

title: Laws for the History Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Makers and Obesity
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Officers Seek to Add Defendant in Abuse Lawsuit
description: Lawyers for three police officers named in a civil rights lawsuit by a man alleging sexual abuse filed a motion on Monday in federal court in Brooklyn that seeks to make an officer likely to testify against them a defendant in the case as well.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the sale of commercial properties on Fire Island misstated the role that John Whyte, a previous owner of the properties, played in the Pavilion, a discotheque that was included in the recent sale. Mr. Whyte bought the Pavilion in the late 1980s; he did not build it in 1981.

title: Two Springs
description: Lately, Ive been studying celestial navigation, the seafaring kind that requires a sextant, a chronometer, and a nautical almanac. Its a way of adding a little trigonometry to a life thats mostly addition and subtraction.

title: Is Social Security Ripe for Reform, Too?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Magic Potion
description: With the marathon effort to overhaul the health care system behind us, it is time for the Obama administration to move quickly and powerfully to the monumental task of putting Americans back to work.

title: Parking Rules for Passover
description: Because of the first and second days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Tuesday and Wednesday in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Originally a Yankee, Thames Eagerly Pursues a Return
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Every winter, Marcus Thames begins his off-season training by watching the same videotape for inspiration.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions on Monday with an article about Dukes victory over Baylor on Sunday in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament gave an incorrect identification from The Associated Press in some copies for the Duke player shown celebrating with a raised fist. He is Andre Dawkins  not Nolan Smith, a teammate. (A photograph of Smith appeared in other editions.)

title: Even in Distant Lands, the Welcomes Are Warm
description: UNTIL the age of 18, I never traveled outside of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. But in the last four decades, Ive clocked more than two million miles and have been in more than 120 countries. Last year, I was in South Africa, Zambia, Cambodia, Vietnam, India, Sri Lanka, Nepal and Bangladesh, all countries in which Room to Read has programs.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Monday about the cancellation of a production of Terrence McNallys play Corpus Christi, which features a gay, Jesus-like figure, at Tarleton State University in Texas, misstated the name of a newspaper that reported on the cancellation along with The Austin Chronicle. It is The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, not The Austin Star-Ledger. (There is no Austin newspaper with that name.) The report also referred incorrectly to the distance between Stephenville, Tex., where Tarleton State is located, and Austin. They are about 140 miles apart; Stephenville is not near Austin.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Easter concerts in some copies on Friday misstated the given name of the music director of a choral concert at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York on Good Friday. He is Mitchell Crawford, not Michael.

title: Company That Owns American Idol Is Planning a Sale to a Private Equity Group
description: The American Idol television brand may soon be in the hands of private equity.

title: Corrections
description: Two pictures in the Living Here listings in the Escapes pages on Friday were reversed. The yellow house pictured at the bottom is the five-bedroom house in Woodstock, Vt., listed for $2,395,000. The brown house shown above it is the four-bedroom house in Floyd, Va., listed at $995,000.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Tenth Victory Means Nets Are Bad, Not Historic
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  History will reflect that the Nets of 2009-10 are bad. It will also now reflect that they are not the worst team in N.B.A. history.

title: Jazz Gains From Every Knicks Loss
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Six years ago, the Utah Jazz made a fairly inconsequential trade with the Phoenix Suns that will, at long last, produce a consequential result and another cringe-worthy moment for Knicks fans.Call it the final stanza of the Stephon Marbury curse.

title: Citigroup Exit May Be Profitable
description: Uncle Sam is ready to get out of Citi. The Treasury is set to sell its 27 percent stake in Citigroup about two years after rescuing it.

title: To Afghanistan, in Darkness and Secrecy
description: Something had come up, I told my visiting guests on Friday. Id unexpectedly been detailed to cover a political story and would not be able to join them for the rest of the weekend.

title: Lehman Brothers Objects to Billions in Claims
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings said Monday it believes that claims from creditors against its bankruptcy estate should be cut to $605 billion, according to a document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: News Quiz | March 30, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: St. Johns Set to Hire Lavin as Its Coach
description: The seemingly endless St. Johns mens basketball coaching search appears close to completion. The university is poised to hire the former U.C.L.A. coach Steve Lavin. The two sides met Monday for several hours in Manhattan and were optimistic about completing a deal.

title: Rare Struggles for Argentine Powers
description: Two of the most popular teams in Argentina  River Plate and Boca Juniors  and their legions of frenzied fans are not a happy bunch these days.

title: MaxLinear Closes Initial Public Offering
description: MaxLinear said Monday that it closed its initial public offering of more than 6.4 million shares at a price of $14 per share, The Associated Press reported.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Bruins and Thrashers Miss Big Chances
description: Five games on Monday, including a perfect pair of results for the 10th-place Rangers as No. 9 Atlanta and No. 8 Boston both lose. Home teams listed first:

title: Corrections
description: A theater entry in the Listings pages on Friday about Love Is My Sin, which is in previews at the Duke on 42nd Street and opens on Thursday, misstated the number of Shakespeares sonnets adapted for the work by the director Peter Brook. It is 31, not 29.

title: The Issue of Liquidity Bubbles Up
description: Conspicuously absent from any regulatory legislation floating around Capitol Hill is the precise level of capital that banks should hold for every dollar they lend, called a capital ratio, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes from Washington in his latest DealBook column.

title: UBS Said to Generate $2.3 Billion on Fixed-Income Unit
description: UBS generated about $2.3 billion of revenue at its fixed-income division in the first quarter as Switzerlands biggest bank rebuilt the unit following record losses, people with knowledge of the situation told Bloomberg News.

title: Blasts Could Derail Medvedevs Softer Tack in the Caucasus
description: MOSCOW  When two bombs ripped through Moscow subway stations at rush hour on Monday morning, Russias leaders reached for the kind of hunt-them-down-and-kill-them statements that propelled the country through two brutal wars in the Caucasus.

title: Word of the Day | sententious
description: sententious \sen-ten(t)-shs\ adjective

title: WaMu II: Resurrected on a Tax Break
description: Washington Mutual, the biggest bank failure in history, may have a second life after bankruptcy.

title: Bharti Deal Approaches, but Trips on Gabon
description: Bharti Airtels $9 billion expansion into Africa faced a potential new hurdle on Monday as the government of Gabon raised a regulatory objection to the deal, Reuters reported.

title: The Neue Look
description: Rene Price, the director of the Neue Galerie, devotes almost as much time to the museums shop as she does to the museums exhibition program. Shes drawn to things I would like in my own home, and gets ideas everywhere: in the shower, at meals (a recent breakfast hatched a Bauhaus-style egg cup) and at cocktail parties. Im always looking for ways to reinterpret the amazing things in our collection. More

title: Lloyds Chief Could Stay for Another Year
description: The Lloyds Banking Group will keep Eric Daniels as its chief executive for at least another 12 months, The Financial Times reported. This statement comes despite the recent commencement by Sir Win Bischoff, the banks chairman, of an emergency succession plan for the C.E.O.s role.

title: BlogTalkRadio Pockets $1.9 Million
description: BlogTalkRadio, a site that allows users to create free talk radio podcasts and listen to talk radio shows, has landed $1.9 million in a second round of funding, TechCrunch reported.

title: V.C.s Answer Yes to Quora
description: Quora, a start-up that offers a collection of Q&As that can be edited by users, has nabbed $11 million in a first round of funding, PaidContent reported.

title: Why Is This Seder Different From All Other Seders?
description: WHO has attended the Passover seders in the Obama White House?

title: Warren Says to Expect Commercial Real Estate Trouble
description: Elizabeth Warren, head of Congressional oversight for TARP and a major backer of the idea of a consumer protection agency, told CNBC on Monday that the U.S. economy still had a hard road ahead.

title: Glamazon Grandmothers & the Twiggy Effect
description: Glamorous, fashion-following grannies.

title: Idol Owner Confirms Buyout Talks
description: The American Idol television brand may soon be in the hands of private equity.

title: Primerica 1 of 4 I.P.O.s Set for This Week
description: Citigroups spinoff of its Primerica unit, a commission-based network of independent sales representatives selling life insurance and investment products, is one of four companies expected to go public this week, as the market for initial public offerings appears positioned for a comeback, The Associated Press reported.

title: Do You Socialize More Virtually Than in Reality?
description: Some experts in child development and others have observed that spontaneous play and childhood culture, including games that have been passed down from generation to generation, are disappearing. What do you think about this?

title: Jupiter Star Puts Half His Fund In Cash
description: Philip Gibbs, Jupiter Financials high-profile investor in financial stocks, has put more than half his fund into cash as uncertainty around the U.K. election and western governments debt hamper visibility, Reuters reported.

title: Investec Seeks to Buy Rest of Rensburg
description: Investec, the South African specialist banking group, has agreed to pay around 218 million ($328 million) to buy the 53 percent stake in Rensburg Sheppards that it doesnt already own, The Financial Times reported.

title: D.S.M. Sells Fertilizer Arm for $418 Million
description: Royal D.S.M., the Dutch chemicals company, says it will sell its fertilizer and melamine businesses to Egypts Orascom Construction Industries for 310 million euros ($418 million), The Associated Press reported.

title: Iranian Diplomat in Pakistan Is Freed
description: LONDON  An Iranian diplomat seized by gunmen in a little-known 2008 case in northwest Pakistan has been freed by Iranian agents after complex intelligence operations, state-run Iranian television reported on Tuesday without describing in detail how the envoy was released.

title: RDG Capital Said to Sweeten Offer for Benihana
description: RDG Capital, a New York Investment firm led by Russell Glass, has sweetened its offer for Benihana, the Japanese steak house chain founded by Rocky Aoki, The New York Post reported.

title: Citi Exit Will Profit U.S., but Bank Still Needs Work
description: Uncle Sam is ready to get out of Citi. The Treasury is set to sell its 27 percent stake in Citigroup about two years after rescuing it.

title: Optimism About Recovery Lifts Shares
description: A brighter outlook for the American consumer and signs that foreign debt troubles were easing helped propel Wall Street higher on Monday, The New York Timess Javier C. Hernandez reported.

title: China Said to Execute Thousands in 09
description: HONG KONG  China executed more people last year than the rest of the world combined, according to a report published Tuesday by Amnesty International.

title: State of the Eagles: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Grand Prix Circuit Returns to Istanbul
description: A rolling, moving, flowing, twisting, cool track. Thats how the racing writer Brad Spurgeon, who writes for The Timess Formula One blog, describes the Istanbul leg of the Grand Prix season.

title: AXA and NAB Advance on $12 Billion Australia Deal
description: One of the biggest acquisitions in Asia this year cleared a crucial hurdle on Tuesday, as National Australia Bank secured the agreement of AXA for a deal that would effectively carve up the Asia-Pacific operations of the French insurance giant, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: British Banks Face Refinancing Challenge, Fitch Says
description: Major British banks face a challenge to refinance more than 300 billion ($448.4 billion) of government-backed financing over the next two to three years, Fitch Ratings said in a report published on Monday.

title: Fed Official Prescribes Global Approach on Banks
description: Not only does the financial reform bill fail to specify or raise capital requirements for large banks, it also does not address the systemic risk presented by their size, said Richard W. Fisher, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.

title: Ungaro Owner Said to Hold Talks With Italian Financier
description: The owner of Emanuel Ungaro, the French fashion label suffering under a load of debt, recently held deal talks with Matteo Marzotto, an Italian financier, The New York Post reported.

title: Teach Your Neighbors Well
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: Good Marks for Moyhihan at Bank of America
description: When Brian T. Moynihan agreed in December to step into the top spot at Bank of America, he had a challenge ahead of him: rebuilding Bank of Americas image after a year marred by a taxpayer bailout and lawsuits by shareholders unhappy with its acquisition of Merrill Lynch, not to mention the task of regaining the trust of clients and raising morale among its beleaguered bankers.

title: R.B.S. Fined for Sharing Price Data
description: Royal Bank of Scotland has been fined 28.6 million ($43 million) for violating competition laws by sharing price data with Barclays, Britains Office of Fair Trading said on Tuesday.

title: Ireland Set to Announce Bad Bank Plans
description: Finance Minister Brian Lenihan of Ireland will set out his plans on Tuesday to free the countrys banks of troubled real estate loans and revive the financial system, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Private Equity Firms to Sit Down With Investors, Report Says
description: Executives of the Carlyle Group, TPG, Avenue Capital Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts are planning a meeting on Tuesday with investors who are seeking lower fees and more control over their investments, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people briefed on the gathering.

title: In Dubai, Troubled Nakheel Names a New Board
description: A council overseeing the restructuring of Dubais chief conglomerate said on Tuesday that a new board had been named to lead the deeply indebted Dubai World property development unit Nakheel through its restructuring, The Associated Press reports.

title: Q&A: Recharging the Zune on the Road
description: Q.

title: Can Using the Wrong Octane Fuel Lead to Disaster?
description: Last week, Gunnar Heinrich, who runs the site Automobiles De Luxe, wrote that a 2010 Cadillac SRX Turbo he had borrowed from General Motors for a review sustained serious internal damage during a test drive and that he had to be plucked from the side of a mountain road.

title: Sampler: The Man Behind Software Evading Government Censors, and Tony the Tiger Is Pulled From a Moat
description: Debt Threatens the Future of States | California is among a handful of states showing signs of debt overload similar to the debt that took Greece to the brink. In California, the debt looks manageable on the surface  just 8 percent of the total economy  but that does not take into account the big unstated debts, like the shortfall in its biggest pension fund. If that is counted, the states debt burden quadruples to 37 percent of the economic output, according to estimates. [The New York Times]

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, March 30
description: Here are some highlights from Tuesdays edition of The New York Times:

title: S. Korean President Visits Waters Where Ship Sank
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Lee Myung-bak became the first South Korean head of state to visit the disputed western waters off the Korean Peninsula as he visited to urge rescuers on Tuesday to continue searching for 46 sailors believed to be trapped in a naval vessel that sank after a mysterious explosion four days earlier.

title: The Hunger of Dustin Keller
description: Jets tight end Dustin Keller, who is a budding restaurateur, will write a food column once a month for the Fifth Down. Hell also answer football questions from readers. Post your question in the comments section, and hell answer a sampling within a week. Dustin starts off with a look at one of his favorite restaurants in New York: Peter Luger Steakhouse in Brooklyn.

title: The Chatty Effect
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: The Chatty Effect
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Bloggers Assess the 2010 Mets, Part 2
description: As opening day draws near, The Times will be previewing the Yankees and Mets coming seasons from all angles, with analysis from Tyler Kepner, Ben Shpigel, David Waldstein and others. But with so much happening this off-season, there are a lot of opinions to go around. As we did last season, we have reached out to Yankees and Mets bloggers for their thoughts on the 2010 season.

title: How I Found My New Office Space With Twitter
description: I started Backup My Info! from my small apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. After signing up a few clients, I hired my first engineer who worked with me in my apartment. I worked from my bedroom desk, and he worked from my kitchen table. I removed all of the pictures from my walls and replaced them with white boards that we used for strategy sessions. My floors were lined with duct tape that I used to hide and secure the network cords that ran between the bedroom and the kitchen. That year, my revenue reached $20,000, which was less than half my engineers salary. Looking back, Im not sure how we did it. But necessity is necessity, right?

title: 2 Emirates Exchanges Are Discussing a Merger
description: Owners of the Abu Dhabi Securities Exchange and Dubai Financial Market are discussing a possible consolidation, Dubai Financials executive chairman, Essa Kazim, said on Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Carbon Trading and the Great Recession
description: The recession brought with it a slowdown in industrial production, and that has translated into far fewer greenhouse gas emissions in 2009 than in previous years.

title: European Collider Begins Its Subatomic Exploration
description: PASADENA, Calif.  After 16 years and $10 billion  and a long morning of electrical groaning and sweating  there was joy in the meadows and tunnels of the Swiss-French countryside Tuesday: the worlds biggest physics machine, the Large Hadron Collider, finally began to make subatomic particles collide.

title: Greenpeace Takes Aim at Koch Industries
description: Youll likely hear a lot about this today and in coming weeks. Greenpeace has unveiled a new report highlighting Koch Industries, one of the biggest industrial conglomerates youve probably never heard of.

title: Napoleon Star Departs Comedy Central Series
description: 9:32 a.m. | Updated Was it the 100-episode commitment? Representatives for Jon Heder, the Napoleon Dynamite star, said he had left a new Comedy Central series that was about to go into production, one that sported a pedigree of prominent comic talents and for which the cable channel had the option to order as many as 100 episodes.

title: New York Falls Short in Race to the Top
description: New York came in second to last among the 16 finalists for the competitive federal education grant known as Race to the Top on Monday, leaving the state out of the money but with plenty of blame to spread around.

title: The Early Word: Break Out the Pens
description: Another Tuesday, another bill signing.

title: EBay Introduces a New Classifieds Site and More Mobile Apps
description: On Tuesday, eBay plans to unveil a new classifieds site, called eBayClassifieds, to replace its old site, Kijiji, in the United States. It will also introduce two new mobile apps, one for listing and selling items for sale and another for posting or searching classifieds. A third app, for the iPad, is to be released April 3.

title: Bo Bo Bey Bo! Jeff Goldblum Scats!
description: You can keep your kiddie productions of Scarface, your anonymous ChatRoulette balladeers and your button-down network anchors slow-jamming the news. If there were any justice on the Internet, this clip of Jeff Goldblum, the Law & Order: Criminal Intent star and jazz pianist, leading the studio audience of Late Night With Jimmy Fallon in an impromptu scat session would be the viral video of the morning.

title: Domesticities | Park Place
description: Inserting a new house into a once-industrial neighborhood isnt always an easy task. Designing something exponentially fancier than its surroundings makes no sense, but going the faux-former-factory route is just as bad. Luke Ogrydziak and Zoe Prillinger of Ogrydziak/Prillinger Architects, a 10-year-old San Francisco firm, navigated a graceful middle ground in their design for this 6,000 square-foot, three-story house and private art gallery in the citys South of Market district. Its plain, rugged materials, elegant proportions and openness to its surroundings make it an asset to its setting -but a suitably unobtrusive one.

title: Wall Street Manages to Stay on Positive Side
description: Wall Street ended slightly higher on Tuesday as an energized technology sector helped offset worries about foreign debt.

title: More New York Chefs Open in Las Vegas
description: Some chefs are still willing to bet on Las Vegas.

title: Strauss-Kahn Says I.M.F. Would Dictate Greek Terms
description: The International Monetary Fund would lay down the terms of assistance it provides Greece, the managing director, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, told Bloomberg News, reflecting tensions with European leaders over a possible rescue.

title: Mixed Report on January Home Prices
description: Housing prices are still inching up, but few analysts are presuming the trend will last.

title: The Heresies of John Cassidy
description: Last week, Reihan Salam predicted the appearance, among left-of-center writers, of thoughtful, honest assessments of flaws in theAffordable Health Care for America Act that were largely overlooked during the beat-the-Republicans phase of the debate. Now John Cassidy, The New Yorkers financial writer, has delivered an impressive two-part contribution to the genre. Cassidy supports the health care bill on moral grounds, but he has deep doubts about its fiscal sustainability. On this front, he makes two points that many right-of-center wonks have been hammering on for a while now. First, the individual mandate is a bit of a sham, and lots and lots of people will probably just pay the modest fine (or dodge it) until they get sick, at which point theyll show up demanding their guaranteed insurance policy, sending costs skyrocketing. Second, the subsidies for the individual market are so much more generous than the existing tax deduction for employer-provided health care that employers will have an enormous incentive to offload their employees onto the new exchanges:

title: Obama Defends Health Care Law
description: President Obama defended his health care program in an interview broadcast on Tuesday morning, portraying it as a centrist approach that Republicans are opposing mainly because they want political benefit in November.

title: A Financial Crunch for Photojournalists Is Transforming the Profession
description: In an era of shrinking magazine and newspaper circulation and dwindling advertising revenues, among the hard hit professions is photojournalism. Long romanticized as a creative, exhilarating and peripatetic way of making a living, the life of todays photojournalists is one of financial struggle and social deprivation. There are just not enough lucrative assignments out there.

title: Key Bloomberg Aide to Leave City Hall
description: Updated, 12:01 p.m. | Edward Skyler, who managed much of New York Citys government over the last four years as Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs most powerful aide, plans to leave City Hall by the end of April, said a person told of his plans Tuesday morning.

title: Director of Transgender Film Will Change Its Trailer
description: The director of Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives, a movie planned for the Tribeca Film Festival that has set off a war of words before being screened there, said he would amend its trailer so that it would not refer to real-life victims of violence.

title: Bermuda Tourism Still Sluggish
description: The global recession is continuing to take a bite out of Bermuda tourism. The British territorys government said that air arrivals in 2009 decreased almost 11 percent compared with the previous year.

title: Ryanair Ends Cellphone Usage
description: Ryanair has suspended its on-board cellphone service after the Swiss company that provided the technology elected to terminate the contract, the airline said Monday. The service, which went live in February 2009, had enabled Ryanair passengers to make and receive voice calls and text messages on 50 of the airlines fleet of 230 Boeing 737 planes.

title: Campaigning for Select Republicans
description: Monologue |  Monday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Former Gov. Sarah Palin has been very busy. Shes been campaigning for select Republicans, including John McCain, whos in the middle of a tough Senate race in Arizona. How does he introduce her? And now, the young woman who cost me the presidency, Sarah Palin!

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Transportation Trouble
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Did you hear about this? President Obama, big surprise visit to see the folks in Afghanistan. Did you read all about that? Thats kind of exciting. It turns out he was shooting an episode of Undercover Boss.

title: Pretty Quick Trip
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: President Obama made a surprise visit to Afghanistan this past weekend. I guess after the last 14 months in Washington, he wanted to go someplace where there was less fighting.

title: London Dance Journal: Hurtling Monks and Other Unhappy Tricks
description: LONDON  Surely not since Bndictine liqueur was invented at a medieval French monastery have monks produced anything so commercial as Sutra. Its an hour of physical-theater silliness that could be exciting fun if it werent doused in solemnity and mystique. At the end the audience went wild while I rushed for fresh air.

title: Tougher Emissions Rules for Ships Operating in North American Waters
