description: The International Maritime Organization gave the final go ahead on Friday to a plan for creating a North American emissions control area extending 200 nautical miles from the coasts of the United States and Canada.

title: Product Red Gives Marketing Students a Chance to Practice What They Study
description: A publisher is sponsoring a contest that will enable marketing students to put some of their studies to good use by suggesting a product that could be sold to help raise money to fight AIDS.

title: Charlie Vergos, Memphis Barbecue King, Dies
description: Charlie Vergos, founder of the Rendezvous barbecue restaurant in Memphis, died on Saturday. He was 84.

title: Financial Tuneup: What You Need to Shred
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: The Financial Times: A Newspaper With Good Business News  About Itself
description: On Monday, Decoder came across a rare sight in the wilds of Manhattan: a happy publishing executive.

title: Economists Who Say Ni!
description: OK, its actually the economists who say Inflation! But isnt it all too predictable that with almost 10 percent unemployment and ongoing disinflation  at this rate we could be looking at deflation in the core rate by next year  what the shadow open market committee is warning about is  inflation.

title: Live From Tribeca, Its Saturday Night
description: 3:40 p.m. | Updated The May 1 broadcast of Saturday Night Live may be a repeat, but it doesnt mean that its cast will get the weekend off. On May 2, some SNL performers will be at the Tribeca Film Festival for the premiere of Saturday Night, a documentary directed by James Franco that goes behind the scenes at that sketch show. Mr. Franco and the SNL stars will also be on hand for a question-and-answer session following the screening, the festival organizers said on Tuesday.

title: Confidential Aqueduct Ranking Released
description: ALBANY  The Paterson administration has released a confidential document that assessed the various bidders vying for the rights to operate a casino at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens.

title: Health Reform Revelations
description: One of the side benefits of health reform is that it has acted as a character test. If, for example, you thought of Mitt Romney as a person of character, his desperate attempts to disavow what is essentially his own policy proposal have cured you of that affliction. And as Menzie Chinn points out, Robert Samuelsons hysterical reaction to what is, when all is said and done, a fairly modest  and paid for!  expansion of social insurance tells what what really lies behind his constant harping on the long-run fiscal issue.

title: Samurai Shopper | Ears Looking at You
description: There is a cacaphony of headphones on the market, with choices that range from sleek in-ear to old-school on-ear, in materials from blingy crystal to crafty wood.

title: Particle Physics Fill-In
Disappointing Roach
description: I really dont know what to say about Steve Roachs column on China today. It doesnt sound as if hes read anything those of us calling for a tough stand on the renminbi have written. The whole thing is laid out as if China critics were focused on the US-China bilateral imbalance, when Ive made it very clear that this is not at all the right thing to focus on:

title: Roundabout Extends Run for The Glass Menagerie
description: The Roundabout Theater Companys revival of Tennessee Williamss The Glass Menagerie, starring Judith Ivey as Amanda Wingfield, will extend its run by two weeks through June 13, the theater has announced. Directed by Gordon Edelstein, the production had its start at the Long Wharf Theater and received rave reviews there and at Roundabout for Ms. Iveys performance. The show is running Off Broadway at Roundabouts Laura Pels Theater.

title: At Key West Beach, Wondering Whos a Vagrant
description: KEY WEST, Fla.  Quality of life for Steve Sanderson means securing a good sleeping spot that a new arrival will never find. For Denise Skinner, it means l-i-v-i-n with a view of the ocean from the mattress in her cherry red Jeep. Its heaven out there, she said last week, squinting out her back window. Its heaven.

title: Paying for the Bad Habits of Others
description: Its easy to blame the nations health care woes on people who dont take care of themselves. But personal responsibility for ones health is a surprisingly complex notion, writes Dr. Sandeep Jauhar.

title: Eagles in Our Midst
description: In a recent City Critic column, I went in search of some unlikely new visitors to Manhattan: bald eagles.

title: A Second Life For Twilight Fans
description: You can burn it, bludgeon it or behead it, but a lucrative literary franchise just doesnt stay down. (Same goes for vampires apparently.) If youve admired the way the four volumes of Stephenie Meyers Twilight Saga fit neatly on your bookshelf, youd better make room for a fifth. On her Web site Ms. Meyer writes that she will be publishing a new work set in the Twilight universe, to be released by Little Brown & Company on June 5. The novella, called The Short Second Life of Bree Tanner, is told from the perspective of the title character, a newborn vampire who turns up briefly in the third Twilight novel, Eclipse. Ms. Meyer said the story was originally written for The Twilight Saga: The Official Guide but was ultimately too long to include in that book. If the unsettling notion of newborn vampires keeps you from ever cracking open this book, know that one dollar from each copy sold will go to  where else?  the American Red Cross.

title: London Dance Journal: A Ballet Company to Watch
description: LONDON  The British company Ballet Black was founded in 2001 to provide role models to young, aspiring black and Asian dancers. The companys profile has risen markedly in the last two years, and in January it won the Critics Circle National Dance Award for outstanding company.

title: False Charges of Racism, Tanning Edition
description: So a guest on Glenn Beck claimed that health reform is racist because it imposes a special tax on indoor tanning salons.

title: King and Court Lose Subjects at CNN
description: As Bill Carter reported this morning, CNNs prime-time ratings have gone off a cliff. Is it about Larrys ties, Andersons hair, or something more far reaching? Lets discuss in comments.

title: The Choice and Colleges That Change Lives on Minnesota Public Radio
description: Jacques Steinberg, New York Times education writer and moderator of The Choice, and Marty OConnell, executive director of Colleges That Change Lives, discussed this years admissions and financial aid process in a one-hour interview broadcast live today on Minnesota Public Radio.

title: Why Being Female Is a Pre-existing Condition
description: Being female is essentially a pre-existing condition that inflates a womans health care costs, explains Denise Grady in todays Science Times. She writes:

title: Charles Ryskamp, Director of Morgan and Frick, Dies at 81
description: Charles Ryskamp, a literary scholar and art collector who was the director of two of New Yorks most prestigious small museums, the Pierpont Morgan Library and the Frick Collection, for nearly 30 years, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan and Princeton, N.J.

title: Head of Abu Dhabi Fund Found Dead
description: The Moroccan authorities recovered the body of the director of the worlds largest sovereign wealth fund on Tuesday, five days after a glider he was riding in plunged into a lake south of the Moroccan capital, Rabat, The Associated Press reports.

title: Justices Set Aside Ruling on Mutual Fund Fees
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that courts have a role, though a limited one, in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers.

title: Nissan Leaf Electric Car Priced at $32,780
description: The 2011 Nissan Leaf battery electric car, which will go on sale in the United States in December, will have a suggested retail price of $32,780, a Nissan spokesman, Mark Perry, said Tuesday morning. Nissan prefers to describe the price as $25,280 inclusive of a $7,500 federal income tax credit.

title: Stewart Returning to Broadway in Mamet Play
description: Patrick Stewart will return to Broadway next season for the first time since his Tony Award-nominated turn as Macbeth in 2008, starring in the David Mamet play A Life in the Theater, according to a statement on the Broadways Best Shows Web site.

title: A Winning Streak Ends
description: A couple of months ago, during the mayhem of college applications, Samantha, one of my best friends, said: Brian, dont worry. You are going to get into every college you apply to. And no, that did not make me arrogant or anything like that, but that statement did boost my confidence a little bit.

title: Interview: Eric Mendelsohn
description: Eric Mendelsohn, the writer and director of "3 Backyards," discusses his film that tells a trio of stories in suburbia.

title: How One Marijuana Cigarette May Lead to Deportation
description: ELMONT, N.Y.  When a police officer in this Long Island suburb found a marijuana cigarette in Jerry Lemaines pocket one night in January 2007, a Legal Aid lawyer counseled him to plead guilty. Under state statutes, the penalty was only a $100 fine, and though Mr. Lemaine had been caught with a small amount of marijuana years earlier as a teenager, that case had been dismissed.

title: When a Friend Feels Too Ugly to Socialize
description: Dr. Katharine A. Phillips, professor of psychiatry at Brown Medical School, recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D., a psychological condition in which perceived body flaws may make it impossible for people to work, go to school, socialize or have relationships. Here, she responds to one reader concerned about a friend who is obsessed with perceived flaws in his face.

title: Obama Signs Bill on Student Loans and Health Care
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  President Obama signed legislation Tuesday to expand college access for millions of young Americans by revamping the federal student loan program in what he called one of the most significant investments in higher education since the G.I. Bill.

title: Lowering the Health Costs of Womanhood (and Then Manhood)
description: My colleague Denise Grady has an article today about provisions in the new health law prohibiting health insurance discrimination by sex, meaning that women will no longer be charged a higher premium simply because as a group they often consume more medical services than men.

title: What a Zoo
description: Between the bike-path-taking coyotes and midnight opossums, it seems the wilds are increasingly invading the city. As Melissa Cooper on Out Walking the Dog writes, even the trees have spikes!

title: Access to Google Is Interrupted in China
description: SHANGHAI  Googles search engine was inaccessible in much of China late Tuesday. The exact cause of the disruption was not fully clear, but it led to speculation that the site was being blocked by the countrys Internet censors.

title: Dispatch | Israel by Design
description: Israel offers many good reasons to visit: breathtakingly diverse landscapes, endless historical and religious sights, and plenty of incredibly friendly and beautiful people. Recently the country added another feather to its cap of landmarks: its first museum devoted entirely to design. The project, in the Tel Aviv suburb Holon, is part of an ambitious plan to put the wealthy but otherwise bland municipality on the global culture map; in fact, an interesting group of international architects has already been invited to submit proposals for a new town hall on an adjacent lot.

title: TimesCast | March 30, 2010
description: From the newsroom of The New York Times.

title: Justices Set Aside Ruling on Mutual Fund Fees
description: 5:45 p.m. | Updated The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that courts have a role, though a limited one, in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers, The New York Timess Adam Liptak reports from Washington.

title: Q&A: Swapping an Apartment for One in Rome
description: Q.

title: Supreme Court Punts
description: Mutual fund managers tend to get paid multiples of what the same managers charge for managing similar pension funds. That is true even though a 1970 law imposes a fiduciary duty on fund directors to negotiate fair fees.

title: Manhattan Cocktail Classic  The Main Event
description: Need to brush up on your ice-carving skills? Your cocktail photography not what you want it to be? Not sure what sort of martini goes well with that filet mignon? Take heart.

title: Inside the Backyard Farms Greenhouse
description: Even as snow falls outside, workers harvest tomatoes year-round at Backyard Farms in Madison, Me.

title: Teixeira to Have Treatment on Sore Elbow
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  Mark Teixeiras right elbow remained sore Tuesday morning from the Jeremy Guthrie pitch that plunked him Monday night in Sarasota, Fla. Manager Joe Girardi texted Teixeira to check on him; Teixeira will report to Steinbrenner Field on Tuesday afternoon for treatment.

title: Javits Expansion Will Allow Auto Show to Grow for 2011
description: Ferrari was turned away from the New York auto show this year, said Chris Sams, a spokesman for the event, because the Italian supercar maker applied late for a stand and there was no room remaining.

title: The Last Piece in Place
description: President Obama signed the budget reconciliation bill containing a package of revisions to the big health care legislation after giving a speech at Northern Virginia Community College, a setting aimed at drawing attention to the education component of the bill.

title: Hello, 311, I Want to Complain About Being No. 2
description: Who says you cant fight City Hall? Win or lose, New Yorkers never stop trying. The city ranked second, behind San Francisco, in the number of calls per capita to 311 complaint centers, according to a recent survey.

title: Kaiser Permanente Invests in Solar Power
description: Kaiser Permanente, the biggest nonprofit health maintenance organization in the country, is going solar.

title: Agency Gets Outpost Outside New York, Again
description: MDC Partners is tinkering with its lineup of agencies again, combining two of its shops in Atlanta to give one of its largest agencies, Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal & Partners, its first office outside New York in four years.

title: Properties for $675,000
description: Houses in Chicago, Coupeville, Wash., and Titusville, N.J.

title: An Easy Pantry Dinner
description: Its not a problem being lazy if you have a well-stocked pantry. Some appealing traditional dishes, like the pasta with cannedsardines featured in this weeks Minimalist column, dont require a shopping trip.

title: The Dark Man Behind the Sunny Ballet
description: LONDON  To what extent should we dwell on the psyche of the artist who makes the art?

title: The Ten Missing Player Questions
description: ESPN The Magazines annual N.H.L. player survey has become a must-read, and this years edition is no exception. The 20-question survey gives players an opportunity to weigh in anonymously on a wide variety of topics. Readers will be treated to several shocking revelations, not the least of which is that ESPN apparently remembers that the N.H.L. exists.

title: Skinner and Boston College Part Ways
description: Gene DeFilippo, the Boston College athletics director, sat with Al Skinner last Wednesday and came to a mutual agreement that Skinner would no longer be the mens basketball coach. They agreed to keep the news quiet as Skinner interviewed for the position at St. Johns on Friday, but as Skinner fell behind Steve Lavin as the leading candidate there, DeFilippo said he could wait no longer to reveal Skinners fate.

title: What You Get for ... $675,000
description: CHICAGO

title: Build Your Own NYT Linked Data Application
description: Now that weve published nearly 10,000 of our tags as Linked Open Data, youre probably wondering what kind of cool applications you can build with this data.To help you get started (and since linked data applications are a little different from your average Web application), we thought wed provide a sample application and detailed information about how we built it.

title: Watchdog Group Seeks Justice Dept. Scrutiny of Ex-Georgia Congressman
description: Legal troubles for Nathan Deal, the former congressman running as a Republican for governor in Georgia, may not be over yet.

title: Pros and Amateurs Debate: Is Photography in Trouble?
description: 2:40 P.M. Updated with additional reader responses and blog responses.

title: Battle Continues Between Cohen and Ex-Wife
description: It may be hard to feel sorry for the billionaire hedge fund manager Steven A. Cohen, but his personal life is complicated. A nasty divorce from 20 years ago continues to haunt him, threatening his $13 billion financial empire, SAC Capital Advisors, which he rules with his current wife from his 32,000-square-foot mansion in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Bomb Pulse
description: A spike in carbon-14 levels, caused by atmospheric atomic bomb tests, which can be used to calculate the age of an organism.

title: Toyota Sees Sales Rebounding
description: Toyota, which introduced generous incentives in a bid to attract customers after a string of recalls, said on Tuesday that its sales in the United States probably rose by a third in March.

title: Second Acts | Veronique Branquinho for Camper
description: Veronique Branquinhos announcement that she was closing up shop because of the recession was one of the ones that had fashion insiders bemoaning the most. But the queen of Antwerp cool seems to be enjoying a new chapter of her career.

title: More Health Care Pens for Lawmakers
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  For those keeping count, thats yet another pen for Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Harry Reid. Only this time Mr. Reid was not on hand to collect it.

title: CNN: Look Out Below
description: Have people lost their taste for news? Half of CNN's audience has gone missing.

title: 96th St. Station on the 2 and 3, 11:40 A.M.
Northeast Storm Sets Records, Stops Traffic and Makes Life Miserable
description: A wind-driven deluge broke rainfall records across the Northeast on Tuesday, flooding roads and basements almost as quickly as it snapped umbrellas inside out, and compounding the lingering damage from a storm two weeks ago.

title: Come Fly Away': Whats Entertainment?
description: The Timess Charles Isherwood and Alastair Macaulay are discussing Come Fly Away, which opened last week at the Marquis Theater. Previous posts are here.

title: This Year in Kigali:  A Rwandan Seder
description: Josh Ruxin is the director of Rwanda Works and a Columbia University expert on public health who has spent the last few years living in Rwanda. The following is an account of a Seder he recently celebrated in Kigali.

title: Chrysler Says It Expects to Break Even This Year
description: Chrysler, which began its path into bankruptcy a year ago, expects to break even this year, its chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, said on Tuesday.

title: Back in Iraq, With Fresh Eyes
description: Yasmine Mousa is an Iraqi-Canadian journalist who left Iraq in 2003. On March 22 she wrote about her arrival back in Baghdad. Here she records impressions of her first week back home.

title: Publisher of Departures Magazine Is Retiring
description: Ed Ventimiglia, the publisher of the luxury magazine Departures, is taking a departure of his own. He will retire from American Express Publishing in June.

title: Ireland Lays Out a Plan to Help Banks
description: Ireland announced sweeping measures on Tuesday to tighten control over the financial sector, which has been hurt by the global economic crisis and the collapse of the Irish real estate market.

title: Abandoned Animals in Colombia
description: The New York Times's Simon Romero visits Villa Lorena, an animal refuge in Cali, Colombia, that often takes in the castoff pets of the country's drug lords.

title: As Schools Stay Open, Space May Become Scarce
description: New York City public schools are on spring recess until April 7, but that doesnt meana clean break from anxiety for either the citys Department of Education officials or many public school parents.

title: Hotel Review: Capella Telluride, in Colorado
description: THE BASICS

title: Mauritius Dreaming
description: SOMEWHERE near the Tropic of Capricorn, a gust of warm wind blew down on the old French colonial town of Mahbourg, rushing across strange, jagged brown hills and lightly rustling green fields of sugar cane. It carried the smell of damp vegetation  a result of a typical morning sun shower  as it rippled offshore and gently undulated the translucent curaao waters of the Indian Ocean around our slow-chugging motorboat.

title: With the Surfers on Costa Ricas Untamed Coast
description: SOME vacation destinations attract tourists. Others attract disciples. The surfer town of Puerto Viejo de Talamanca and the tiny beach communities southeast of it, on the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica, are of the latter variety.

title: A Czech City Reclaims Its Past
description: HUGE hunks of rusting iron and coal dust might not seem like ideal catalysts for a cultural revival. But a former mining town in the Czech Republic that once epitomized Communist-era bleakness is embracing its industrial heritage, with a little help from punk rock, an all-night party street and a castle made of steel.

title: Motels Boost the Thread Count
description: PLATFORM beds with crisp white sheets and taupe coverlets; 32-inch flat-screen TVs; bright colors on the walls and mod furnishings that maximize space. No, its not the latest boutique hotel. Its the new look of Motel 6.

title: Developer Defends Ethiopian Hydro Project
description: Responding to complaints about the Gibe III hydroelectric dam project in Ethiopia, Salini Costruttori, the Italian hydropower developer behind the project, issued a statement late last week arguing that the projects critics are opposed to Africas development.

title: Roots of an Iraqis Reputation as Saddam Lite
description: In an interview with my colleagues Rod Nordland and Tim Arango in Baghdad on Monday, Ayad Allawi, the former Iraqi exile who may become Iraqs next prime minister, described an incident from his past that has burnished his reputation for toughness. In 1978, he managed to fight off two ax-wielding assassins sent to kill him after he broke with Saddam Husseins Baath Party.

title: Restaurant Review: Sea Change in Minneapolis
description: Its not every gastronome who wants to savor a bowl of grilled swordfish cassoulet while staring at a 25-foot-tall photo of Arthur Miller. Yet there he is, either grinning or wincing (its tough to tell with Mr. Miller), outside the windows of this restaurant, which opened last July on the ground floor of the Guthrie Theater.

title: 36 Hours in San Antonio
description: SAN ANTONIO, the countrys seventh-largest city, features a trio of popular attractions: the River Walk (a meandering canal lined with restaurants and bars), Market Square (said to be the largest Mexican-style market outside of Mexico) and the Alamo (no explanation necessary). But get beyond the obvious tourist stops, and this old city offers excellent Chicano art, 19th-century-style shopping, church music that goes way beyond hymns, and plenty of that famous Texas hospitality.

title: Technology Coalition Seeks Stronger Privacy Laws
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A broad coalition of technology companies, including AT&T, Google and Microsoft, and advocacy groups from across the political spectrum said Tuesday that it would push Congress to strengthen online privacy laws to protect private digital information from government access.

title: Chinas Ancient Jewish Enclave
description: THROUGH a locked door in the coal-darkened boiler room of No. 1 Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine in Kaifeng, theres a well lined with Ming Dynasty bricks. Its just a few yards deep and still holds water. Guo Yan, 29, an eager, bespectacled native of this Chinese city on the flood plains of the Yellow River about 600 miles south of Beijing, led me to it one recent Friday afternoon, past the doormen accustomed to her visits.

title: Several Wounded in Gaza by Israeli Gunfire
description: GAZA  Several Palestinians were wounded by Israeli army fire in Gaza on Tuesday as they demonstrated close to the border with Israel, according to Palestinian medical officials and the Israeli military. But it was unclear who was responsible for the death of a Palestinian youth, 14, who was apparently shot in another part of the border area.

title: McNabb, and the Eagles Indigestion at Quarterback
description: The quarterback situation in Philadelphia is like a Chinese buffet. At first glance, theres a bounty of delectable options:

title: The Secret Rock and Roll Life of Creed Bratton
description: It takes a special sort of person to even be in the running for the weirdest person on The Office, but Creed Bratton has arguably claimed that mantle: the character (who shares his name with the actor who portrays him) turns up only once or twice an episode, usually to say something totally outrageous to the camera, make a leering remark about a female co-worker or just to impersonate the Joker from The Dark Knight. But he always makes an impression.

title: Insurers to Comply With Rules on Children
description: WASHINGTON  Under pressure from the White House, health insurance companies said Tuesday that they would comply with rules to be issued soon by the Obama administration requiring them to cover children with pre-existing medical problems.

title: What Were Reading
State of Play in the Galleon Insider Trading Case
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime and securities law for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Grass Fed | Who Eats Princess Cake?
description: Parenthood has brought with it a whole new vocabulary: technical terms for types of discharge, baby-related brand names that double as class signifiers, all kinds of goofy parent-speak that one can elect to adopt (neck cheese, say, for the stink between a newborns folds) or discard (see neck cheese). So when my friend Julie told me she was getting a princess cake for her daughters first birthday, I shunted the term in and out of the revolving door of my mind, figuring she meant something pink and frilly and possibly topped with Barbie wearing a crown.

title: Come Fly Away': Subtlety Isnt Everything
description: The Timess Charles Isherwood and Alastair Macaulay are discussing Come Fly Away, which opened last week at the Marquis Theater. Previous posts are here.

title: Koch Industries Responds to Greenpeace
description: Earlier today, we wrote about a new Greenpeace report that takes aim at Koch Industries, an industrial conglomerate based in Wichita, Kan.

title: Creed Bratton's 'Bounce Back'
description: Creed Bratton, the musician and actor best known for his work on "The Office," discusses his new album in a mockumentary style video.

title: Answers About New Consumer Laws: Part 5
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained people about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: A Fjord View in Oslo
description: A  3,000-square-foot five-bedroom house overlooking Oslo Fjord is on the market for 10 million kroner (around $1.67 million).

title: House Hunting in ... Norway
description: A 3,057-SQUARE-FOOT FIVE-BEDROOM HOUSE OVERLOOKING OSLO FJORD

title: A Big Empty Warehouse in Brooklyn Holds Dreams of Industrial Jobs
description: New York is trying to entice developers to buy the former Federal Building No. 2 in Brooklyn, a massive structure that is zoned for light industrial busnesses.

title: Once Again, Mr. Stanford Wants New Lawyers
description: R. Allen Stanford, the Texas financier accused of running a huge Ponzi scheme, is changing lawyers again and he wants to be tried someplace other than Houston, The Houston Chronicle reports.

title: Sports Injuries: When to Tough It Out
description: YOU have been playing a lot of tennis recently, and now you think you have tennis elbow. Or youre a swimmer with an aching shoulder. A cyclist with sore knees. A runner with pain in your heel.

title: What Is Bike Culture?
description: With an increasingly permanent network of lanes and legal access to office buildings around the city, the bicycle is becoming more entrenched as a mode of transportation. An entity no less mainstream than the United States Department of Transportation is on board, recently describing bicycles and pedestrians as equals to trains, planes and automobiles and encouraging further development of cycling infrastructure at the state and federal level.

title: Ford Shifts and Gains Ground in Asia
description: CHONGQING, China  The sprawling Ford assembly plant here runs two shifts a day every day except Sunday, with workers putting in as many as 10 hours a day. Employees take turns having lunch so production almost never stops at potential bottlenecks, like the building where cars are painted.

title: Charleston Symphony Orchestra Suspends Operations
description: The Charleston Symphony Orchestra in South Carolina has canceled the rest of its season and suspended operations, saying it has run out of cash to pay its expenses, The Post and Courier of Charleston reported. The board president, Ted Legasey, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday that the critical issue was a decline in fund-raising. He said that major gifts were down 60 percent from last season, creating a shortfall of about $400,000. People who had purchased tickets for the final concert of the CSOs season, on April 17, are being offered refunds.

title: Branford Marsalis to Compose Music for Fences Revival
description: The Grammy Award-winning saxophonist Branford Marsalis announced on Tuesday that he will make his Broadway debut this spring as the composer of original music for the forthcoming revival of August Wilsons Fences.

title: F.B.I. Investigates Militia Groups
description: Members of a Christian militia were indicted on sedition and weapons charges on Monday in connection with an alleged plot to murder law enforcement officers.

title: Sarkozys Eat Half-Smokes at Bens Chili Bowl
description: Someone really needs to tell world leaders that people mostly go to Bens Chili Bowl at 4 in the morning when they need sustenance to cushion the impact of a night of bad behavior.

title: Izzo Refutes Rumors of Oregon Offer
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  Michigan State coach Tom Izzo refuted rumors Tuesday of any impending deal for Oregon to hire him as coach.

title: Through Cage Bars, an Exotic Peek Into Drug Wars
description: CALI, Colombia  Of all the animals that come to die under Ana Julia Torress samn trees, the ocelots are among the most numerous. There are eight of them here, seized from the estate of a murdered cocaine trafficker, who apparently collected them in the belief that any self-respecting drug lord should always have eight ocelots in his dominion.

title: Now Screening | The Man Next Door
description: Space and light and order. Those are the things that men need just as much as they need bread or a place to sleep, the architect Le Corbusier once said. But what happens when one mans search for light disturbs the sense of space and order of another?

title: Under a Shadow in the Moscow Subway
description: James Hill, a photographer with a deep knowledge of Russia, has brought an intimately impressionist eye to the day-after scene in the Moscow subway. (Slides 1 and 2.) These photographs, taken for The Times, are imbued with a sense both of sorrow and fear. An underground realm known for its sparkling tiles and chandeliers is rendered strangely dark and foreboding. The mood of the city is evident on peoples faces, said Maria Anzhaurova, 21, a student, at the Lubyanka station, the site of the first attack on Monday. People are watching each other closely. It is clear that people are afraid, very afraid.

title: Ireland Lays Out a Plan to Help Rescue Its Banks
description: Ireland announced sweeping measures on Tuesday to tighten control over the financial sector, which has been brought to its knees by the global crisis and the collapse of the Irish real estate market, The New York Timess Matthew Saltmarsh reports.

title: In Revival of Verdi, a New Note of Drama
description: Who would have guessed that a routine revival of La Traviata at the Metropolitan Opera could cause such a ruckus? The problem was that the conductor Leonard Slatkin, appearing at the Met for the first time in 12 years, showed up for rehearsals not fully knowing the score. You did not have to believe the reports that spread on opera chat lines to know this. Mr. Slatkin conceded as much on his personal Web site, leonardslatkin.com.

title: Would You Like Fries With That Diploma?
description: New York University and Michigan State are not the only organizations christening new campuses in China. McDonalds is now trying to get a foothold on Chinas wealth of human capital, too. From The Associated Press:

title: Insurers to Comply With New Rules on Children
description: Under pressure from the White House, health insurance companies said on Tuesday they would comply with rules to be issued soon by the Obama administration requiring them to cover children with pre-existing medical problems.

title: Russian TV on Sidelines After Attacks in Subway
description: MOSCOW  As frantic Muscovites turned to Russias main television channels for information in the first hours after suicide bombers struck here on Monday morning, they were astonished to find only the usual lineup of cooking shows and police dramas, along with a Soviet-era spy film called The Road.

title: An Empty Warehouse Holds Dreams of Industrial Jobs
description: To hear it described by one broker, the football-field-long former Navy warehouse off the Brooklyn waterfront inspired awe from all but a few of the prospective buyers invited on a tour of the long-vacant site last month.

title: California Queries Banks About Swaps on State Debt
description: Californias state treasurer, Bill Lockyer, has sent a letter to six big banks that underwrite the states municipal bond sales, asking about the banks involvement in selling credit-default swaps on California debt, Reuters reports.

title: South African Runner Plans Return
description: Caster Semenya, a teenage South African runner, announced Tuesday that she planned to resume her career on the international circuit, attempting to force track and fields world governing body to make a decision about gender verification in her case.

title: Crist Backer Uses Ethnic Terms About Rubio
description: MIAMI  Gov. Charlie Crist proudly announced the endorsement of Col. Bud Day, the Vietnam veteran beloved by conservatives for his membership in the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth. Then Colonel Day complicated matters.

title: A Wine Panel Tastes Rioja Crianzas
description: Over the years Ive made it clear how I feel about Rioja: I love it. I feel most strongly about old-fashioned, well-aged gran reserva Riojas, a style of wine that these days seems somewhat marginalized but is still available to those who seek it out. But what of younger, less-expensive Riojas, intended for early drinking rather than long-term aging?

title: Vote for the Worst Company in America
description: If you have strong feelings about who the worst company in America is, heres one way to express them.

title: A Pea in the Prada
description: When I was pregnant, I made a vow that no matter how much poundage I piled on I would not devolve into one of those slovenly sweat-pants-wearing preggos that you see waddling down the street leaving a trail of Saltine crumbs. Making an effort, after all, is what separates us from the animals, and nowhere is this truer than during that distinctly mammalian experience of childbirth. Even when I could no longer see my toes, I could rest assured that they were freshly pedicured.

title: InterContinental Plans Hotels Across China
description: InterContinental, the largest foreign hotel operator in China, said in a statement that it would open a 320-room property near Sanlitun, an entertainment area in the Chaoyang district of Beijing.

title: That Synthy, Dancey European Club Sound
description: Delorean, from Barcelona, had just finished its sold-out show at the Mercury Lounge on Monday night, and Ekhi Lopetegi, the bands bassist and singer, was trying to say something. The sound system had been cut off, so his words werent easy to make out. But they seemed to involve the location of an after-party, which would only make sense. A four-piece synth-pop outfit originally formed in the Basque region of Spain, Delorean traffics in airy atmospherics and enveloping rhythm: ideally, music for a dance floor in the hours preceding dawn.

title: Six Senses Offers Voluntourism in the Maldives
description: Two Six Senses resorts in the Maldives, the Soneva Gili and Soneva Fushi, will encourage travelers to engage in what is being called voluntourism, the company said Tuesday in an e-mailed statement.

title: All About Me to Close on Sunday
description: The new Broadway musical All About Me, in which Michael Feinstein and Dame Edna Everage, above, have dueling acts on stage, will close on Sunday after 27 preview performances and 20 regular performances. Directed by Casey Nicholaw, the production opened at Henry Millers Theater on March 18 to mixed and negative reviews and never built much of an audience. The show grossed $216,425 last week, only 23 percent of the maximum possible, with more than half of the seats empty at some performances. Asked for the cost of the musical and whether it would close at a loss to investors, a spokesman for Jeffrey Richards, one of the lead producers, did not immediately reply.

title: Stewart Back on Broadway in a Mamet Play
description: Patrick Stewart, right, will return to Broadway next season for the first time since his Tony Award-nominated turn as Macbeth in 2008, starring in the David Mamet play A Life in the Theater, according to a statement on BroadwaysBestShows.com. The lead producers of the project  Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel and Steve Traxler  have mounted two recent productions of Mamet plays on Broadway: Race, which is still running, and Speed-the-Plow, from last season. Mr. Stewart will star as a veteran actor, Robert, whose complicated mentoring relationship with a younger actor forms the central narrative of the play. Mr. Stewart played Robert in a London production of the play in 2005, opposite Joshua Jackson (Pacey on televisions Dawsons Creek, among other roles). Neil Pepe, who directed the Speed-the-Plow revival on Broadway last season, will direct.

title: A Second Life for Twilight Fans
description: You can burn it, bludgeon it or behead it, but a lucrative literary franchise just doesnt stay down. (Same goes for vampires, apparently.) If youve admired the way the four volumes of Stephenie Meyers Twilight Saga fit neatly on your bookshelf, youd better make room for a fifth. On her Web site (stepheniemeyer.com), Ms. Meyer, above, writes that she will be publishing a new work set in the Twilight universe, to be released by Little, Brown & Company on June 5. The novella, The Short Second Life of Bree Tanner, is told from the perspective of the title character, a newborn vampire who turns up briefly in the third Twilight novel, Eclipse. Ms. Meyer said the story was originally written for The Twilight Saga: The Official Guide, but was ultimately too long to include in that book. If the unsettling notion of newborn vampires keeps you from cracking open The Short Second Life, know that one dollar from each copy sold will go to  where else?  the American Red Cross.

title: Charleston Orchestra Runs Out of Money
description: The Charleston Symphony Orchestra in South Carolina has canceled the rest of its season and suspended operations, saying it has run out of cash to pay its expenses, The Post and Courier of Charleston reported. The board president, Ted Legasey, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday that the critical issue was a decline in fund-raising. He said that major gifts were down 60 percent from last season, creating a shortfall of about $400,000. The orchestra describes itself as the largest professional arts organization in South Carolina, but it is small by national standards, with a budget for this season of $2.3 million. (The budget of the New York Philharmonic is $68.9 million.) The orchestra depends on fund-raising for over half of its budget. Mr. Legasey said the board would work with musicians and the community to try to develop a restructuring plan and would notify ticketholders by May 1 of their options for next season. There is not much room to cut expenses, so weve got to really broaden the base of revenue sources, Mr. Legasey said.

title: Trailer to Change for Transgender Film
description: The director of Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives, a movie planned for the Tribeca Film Festival that has set off a war of words before being screened there, said he would amend its trailer so it would not refer to real-life victims of violence. In an e-mail message, Israel Luna, who wrote and directed the film, said he was inspired to create the movie in part by the hate crimes against the trans community. He said he included references in his trailer to Angie Zapata, a transgender woman who was beaten to death in Colorado in 2008, and to Jorge Mercado, a gay teenager who was murdered in Puerto Rico in 2009, to give a disturbing reality to my film about transgender violence. After listening to some of the voices in the trans community, Mr. Luna said, Ive decided to remove those references from the trailer. A listing for the movie at tribecafilm.com had drawn angry comments, and the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation had sought the movies removal from the festival, saying, The film, its title and its marketing misrepresent the lives of transgender women and use grotesque, exploitative depictions of violence against transgender women.

title: Napoleon Star Departs Comedy Central Series
description: Was it the 100-episode commitment? Representatives for Jon Heder, below, the Napoleon Dynamite star, said he had left a new Comedy Central series that was about to go into production, one that sported a pedigree of prominent comic talents and for which the cable channel had the option to order as many as 100 episodes. Comedy Central announced last summer that it would make a comedy series that would star Mr. Heder and be produced by Gary Sanchez Productions, the company run by Will Ferrell and Adam McKay. At that time the concept for the series was undecided; more recently, its co-stars Chris Parnell and Horatio Sanz said the show would feature Mr. Heder as a fallen financial whiz who returns to his hometown. On Monday night a publicist for Mr. Heder said in a statement: Comedy Central, Gary Sanchez Productions and Jon Heder have mutually decided to part ways over creative differences with the character. It is not known who is being considered to replace Mr. Heder if the channel proceeds with the show. Comedy Central did not immediately comment.

title: Dancing to the Top
description: Dancing With the Stars waltzed past the competition on Monday as 22.6 million viewers tuned in to the ABC reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. ABC dominated the nights ratings over all, as its crime show Castle (14.5 million) easily outperformed a rerun of CBSs CSI: Miami (8.1 million). CBS finished runner-up on the night with a lineup of mostly repeats, including Two and a Half Men (10.8 million) and The Big Bang Theory (9.8 million). Fox ranked third with 24 (8.3 million) following a rerun of House (5.5 million), while NBC placed fourth.

title: Dalai Lama Juggles Dilemmas
description: The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibets Struggle for Freedom, a documentary by Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, is so awkwardly executed that at first it may come across as just another chorus of a familiar song: that Tibetans think they have been done terrible injustices by China. But pay close enough attention, and eventually another, entirely different theme emerges: the Dalai Lama may be losing his ability to keep the more radical elements of the free-Tibet movement in check.

title: Summer Love, a Sea of Trouble
description: The Last Song: if only it were. But it is likely that we can look forward to more movies starring Miley Cyrus, the teenage chanteuse attempting some serious acting in this beachy melodrama. And we will also have many more films based on the work of Nicholas Sparks. We have already had two this year  Dear John and this one  and a comparison is instructive, if also exhausting.

title: A Bullock Double Take: Us and Peoples Copycat Covers
description: Its not just the subject of Us Weeklys and Peoples covers this week that is the same  Sandra Bullocks marriage. The photo of Ms. Bullock they ran is near-identical:she islooking mournful but glamorous, dressed in a knotted pink sheath.

title: Whirlwind Off-Season for Yankees Trophy
description: It was a relatively quiet off-season for the New York Yankees, but an extremely active one for the teams 2009 World Series championship trophy. While Derek Jeter presumably spent a relaxing winter at his residence in Florida, the trophy was on a whirlwind global tour, with stops at an international fashion mall in Beijing, a baseball-themed cafe in Tokyo and the national palace of the Dominican Republic.

title: Plastiki Reports From the Middle of the Ocean
description: It has been 11 days since Plastiki, the 60-foot sea voyager made of recycled plastic bottles, sailed through the Golden Gate Bridge on its way to Australia. Before the crew left, it was visited on deck by Robin Williams, who performed a queen of England riff that was captured on video.

title: Retro Handsets for a Cellphone
description: Native Union has created a line of handset adapters for mobile phones that cant quite decide whether they are retro or futuristic. Either way, many people are likely to find its Moshi Moshi02 line an improvement over shouting into a tiny mobile phone.

title: Amid Desolate Lives and Pitched Battles, One Delicious Anomaly
description: With its close-ups of beautiful people, exquisite cuisine and delirious lovemaking in the hills outside Milan, I Am Love, a voluptuous Italian melodrama directed by Luca Guadagnino, is the guilty pleasure of this years New Directors/New Films series. The movie, which wallows in luxury, has an elegant lead performance by Tilda Swinton and a throbbing musical score by John Adams.

title: Verizon Untethers Skype Users From PCs
description: Heres a head-scratcher partnership: Verizon Wireless and Skype have teamed up to offer free Skype-to-Skype phone calls over the Verizon voice network. Thats potentially a lot of free chatter, considering that 91 million people use Verizon Wireless and Skype counts 600 million users worldwide.

title: Pennsylvania A.F.L.-C.I.O. Backs Specter
description: Senator Arlen Specter  the Pennsylvania Democrat currently facing a primary challenge  has won the backing of his states A.F.L.-C.I.O., the latest in a string of endorsements he has received from organized labor.

title: A Service Economy in Haitis Tent Cities
description: Updated | Wednesday | 12:10 p.m. As my colleagues Deborah Sontag and Simon Romero have reported recently, many Haitians are still living in vast tent cities that sprang up after the earthquake destroyed so many homes in January.

title: Ruby, Its You
description: Ruby Ross who? I forgive you for asking. Ruby Ross Wood, the woman Billy Baldwin called quite simply the finest decorator who ever lived (take that, Sister Parish!), earned exactly 166 words in The New York Times when she died in 1950. You could argue that the cult of the society decorator had yet to take hold, but then Elsie de Wolfe, whose own light went out just five months later, was buried with many column inches and a picture. It all begins to seem just a little unfair when you consider that Wood is responsible for the way most people today know de Wolfe, as the author of The House in Good Taste: Wood ghosted it in 1913. De Wolfe was also an actress and an international hostess, and had hard-working friendships with luminaries like the Duchess of Windsor who were out of Woods reach. But still.

title: International Exchange Is Eyed by Theaters
description: Fresh off its acquisition of 16 additional theaters in the West End of London and across Britain, the Ambassador Theater Group is seeking business deals with theater owners and producers in the United States to create a cross-Atlantic distribution network for shows, one of the companys co-founders said Monday.

title: The Pattern of Priestly Sex Abuse
description: Reproduced below is a chart from the John Jay Report on sexual abuse in the Catholic priesthood, commissioned by the U.S. Council of Catholic Bishops, showing the number of credible accusations of abuse across the last half-century. Its part of the basis for my columns claim that something in the moral/cultural/theological climate of the 1960s and 1970s encouraged a spike in sexual abuse, and also for my assertion that weve since seen the church come to grips with the problem, at least in the United States.

title: Oil Prices Find a Sweet Spot for World Economy
description: HOUSTON  Oil prices have done something remarkable over the last half-year or so: they have barely budged.

title: New Directors/New Films Video: Eric Mendelsohn
description: At a screening of his latest film at New Directors/New Films on Sunday, Eric Mendelsohn called himself a newish director. The filmmaker brought his first feature, Judy Berlin, to the festival in 1999 and is back with 3 Backyards, a collection of three stories about life in suburbia. After the screening, Mr. Mendelsohn spoke about his film and his desire to avoid clich in its structure:

title: A Plan to Spur Growth Away From Haitis Capital
description: Even as outsiders feel sympathy for Haitis suffering, they tend to look upon it as a country beyond saving.

title: BlogTalk: All (Health Care) Politics Is Local
description: After voting on the landmark and contentious health care legislation, members of Congress are back in their home districts facing, as my colleague Adam Nagourney put it, a bewildering crosscurrent of political forces. In fact, the health care vote is dominating political campaigns across the country, and not just for those running for Congress. Heres a sampling:

title:
Risks Seen in Cholesterol Drug Use
 in Healthy People
description: With the governments blessing, a drug giant is about to expand the market for its blockbuster cholesterol medication Crestor to a new category of customers: as a preventive measure for millions of people who do not have cholesterol problems.

title: Art + Rock | The Whitney Brings the Noise
description: Its not often that a prestigious art institution hosts an evening of face-melting noise music. Yet that is exactly what happened on Friday at the Whitney Museum when Ari Marcopoulos, an artist in this years Biennial, was invited to curate the museums My Turn program. The series uses artists recent work as the jumping-off point  which in this case just happened to be ear-splitting cacophony.

title: Jerusalem, Two Visions for One City
description: Last week, we looked at how plans for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict seem hamstrung by the fact that both groups want to make Jerusalem their capital. If sharing one country is out of the question, how will two nations find a way to share one city?

title: Recette
description: A GRAND parade streams along the West Village sidewalks, corner of 12th and Greenwich Streets, crossroads of a particular world. There are dog-walking flneurs; Westbeth pensioners; the young and desperate en route to the meat markets of the meatpacking district a few blocks north. Here are cabs stopping to let out real housewives. There are young professionals walking home to small apartments filled with books.

title: Evolving Sexual Tensions
description: Males and females are different.

title: A SoHo Visionary Makes an Artsy Bet in Miami
description: MIAMI  The developer Tony Goldman is known for envisioning thriving and architecturally appealing neighborhoods where others see only desolation or neglect. He was a major force in the revival of SoHo and South Beach, and has invested his time and money transforming small stretches of Center City Philadelphia and the financial district in New York.

title: A Touch for Funny Bones and Earlobes
description: MONTECITO, Calif.  Ill buzz you in, Dear, a bright, familiar voice said through an intercom outside a Spanish-style ranch home here. A gate opened, and at the end of a circular drive, crowded inside a doorway to avoid an unusual steady California rain, stood the oblivious Starlett OHara, the vainglorious Nora Desmond, the tempestuous Eunice Higgins and the one woman who embodied them all, Carol Burnett.

title: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit on A.I.G. Red Flags
description: A federal judge in Manhattan dismissed a shareholder lawsuit on Tuesday that accused current and former executives and directors of the American International Group of ignoring red flags, leading to the giant insurers near collapse and about $180 billion in federal bailouts, Reuters reports.

title: Reclaiming Irelands Culinary Heritage, One Roast Lamb or Sponge Cake at a Time
description: IN 1968  when Alice Waters had just graduated from Berkeley, when Paula Wolfert was studying couscous in Tangier, when Diana Kennedy was writing recipes after years of research in Mexico  another young woman, this one from the Irish Midlands, went to work at a peculiar new restaurant on the southern coast of County Cork.

title: Recette, Please
description: This weeks review is of Recette, on Greenwich Street at West 12th in the West Village. Its an ambitious restaurant in the space of a deeply casual one, with a menu that appears to embrace the small-plates trend. Really its more complicated than that: The best way to experience Recette is to order a lot of snacks, and then a couple of other dishes per person, which creates a kind of modified three-course tasting menu for everyone and leads to some serious delights. And the pastry chef, Christina Lee, has much to commend her as well. Save room for smores, course number four.

title: In M.L.S., First Kicks and Last Teams Standing
description: Among the tidbits, factoids and other news in a communique from M.L.S. on Tuesday was a section titled First Kick Wins vs. Postseason Berths.

title: The Rush of Gaming the Casino
description: Josh Axelrads Repeat Until Rich, his new memoir about winning some $700,000 playing professional blackjack, emits a lively hum from the second you crack it open. Like Dave Eggers in A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, Mr. Axelrad tattoos every available surface of his books front matter.

title: Empty Nesters Still Need a Place to Sit
description: IM not entirely sure how I got into this mess. I know it started with my husbands saying we were moving back to New York for his job and with our putting our house up for sale and buying a second smaller one in California to return to some day.

title: Repeat Until Rich
description: Chapter 1

title: Marketers in Warm-Up for World Cup
description: ALTHOUGH March Madness still has a weekend to go, advertisers are already gearing up for June and July Jubilation.

title: A TV Show and Congress Tackle School Lunches
description: ITS been an unusually tough month for the people who make school lunches.

title: Giant Greenhouses Mean Flavorful Tomatoes All Year
description: Madison, Me.

title: Project Sandwich Offers International Lunch
description: Call it the international house of sandwiches, each filling assembled from combinations of ingredients that are tied to a particular country or region and piled on a length of French bread. Want a taste of Mexico? There is smoked trout seasoned ceviche style with cilantro, lime and cumin. Grilled bulgogi meat and pickled daikon slaw represent Korea. For the Middle East there are grilled vegetables with hummus, and for France, a delicious mustardy egg salad with smoked duck on frise. The first-rate Brazilian nudged Argentina with steak, chimichurri and mozzarella. Alongside, the organic falafel chips are not to be missed.

title: Robert, the Wright and Sandwiched
description: Visitors to Manhattan museums have three new places to eat. None threaten the position of The Modern, Danny Meyers elegant dining room at the Museum of Modern Art, at the pinnacle of culture-dining in New York; they sit atop metaphorical foothills or, in one case, well below grade.

title: A Deco Lounge for the Empire State Building
description: Its hard to believe the cocktail lounge that opened in the Empire State Building on March 29 is brand new because it looks so right. At 3,500 square feet of brushed stainless steel, a generous curved marble bar, tufted banquettes, glass-topped tables and Art Deco chandeliers, it accommodates up to 150 people in sophisticated style in a former postal substation at street level.

title: Mexican Favorites at El Parador
description: KEEPING up with the sheer volume of new restaurants in New York can be daunting, not to mention disappointing. Being first through the door is never all its cracked up to be. Why be a guinea pig?

title: At a Bespoke Bagel Shop, Cream Cheese Is Customized
description: The angle at Vics Bagel Bar is that the cream cheese to be slathered on any of 17 varieties of bagels, hand rolled on the premises, can be custom dressed, like ice cream, with an array of mix-ins. Blueberries, edamame, zaatar (a Middle Eastern spice blend), scallions, almonds, sun-dried tomatoes and, of course, smoked salmon are among the dozens of options. In addition to cream cheese, the spreads include hummus, Nutella and tuna, whitefish and egg salads. Given all these options, you could eat a different bagel sandwich every day for years.

title: Riojas That Satisfy in Taste and Value
description: WE on the wine panel are subject to the same economic pressures that buffet the rest of the country, so we, too, want to spend less on wine. Of course, we were always concerned with value. Now we are extra concerned with finding not just good, inexpensive wines but also the best values in every category.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: Breaded Jalapeos
description: Adapted from El Parador, Manhattan

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Nissan Juke
description: Shown on Tuesday, March 30: 2011 Nissan Juke

title: On Chinas Hainan Island, the Boom Is Deafening
description: SANYA, China  One developer is building what he calls Asias largest hotel, with space for a casino and a greyhound racetrack.

title: New York Auto Show: Test Driving the Chevy Volt
description: By December, two compact cars  the Chevrolet Volt and the Nissan Leaf  will vie for mass-market buyers, and perhaps the green-car mantle thats been held by Toyota and its hybrids. That battle should also provide early clues as to whether consumers will prefer an all-electric car, the Leaf, or one that is a plug-in hybrid, the Volt.

title: Maryland: Impeachment Threat Over Gay Marriage
description: Don H. Dwyer Jr., a Republican member of the House of Delegates, plans to bring impeachment charges on the House floor on Wednesday against the states attorney general, Douglas F. Gansler. Mr. Dwyer said that Mr. Gansler overstepped his authority in issuing a legal opinion last month saying the state would recognize same-sex marriages from other places and ordering state agencies to give gay married couples the same rights as heterosexual couples. Mr. Ganslers opinion does not change the law, but it was meant to guide state officials. The impeachment matter is most likely to be dismissed by the House speaker, Michael E. Busch, a Democrat. If so, Mr. Dwyer has said he will probably call for a ruling from the full House, which is controlled by Democrats.

title: Start-Up Aims to Be a Hub for Location Data
description: Location may be the next mobile frontier for app developers. But for many, the biggest barrier to entry is a lack of access to geographic data, like the locations of businesses near a user.

title: French Court Upholds Verdict in Oil Spill
description: PARIS  A French appeals court on Tuesday confirmed a ruling that the oil giant Total and related parties were responsible for environmental damage caused by a disastrous oil spill from the tanker Erika off Brittany in 1999.

title: Volcker Optimistic for Financial Revamping This Year
description: WASHINGTON  The White House and one of its top outside economic advisers, Paul A. Volcker, expressed confidence on Tuesday that legislation to overhaul the nations financial system would be completed this year, possibly before the Congressional summer recess.

title: Pakistan Arrests a Top Crime Official
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Supreme Court ordered the arrest of a senior white-collar crime official on Tuesday, and threatened to send the nations top anticorruption official to jail if he did not swiftly seek the reopening of corruption cases in Switzerland against President Asif Ali Zardari.

title: Uproar Over School Cafeteria That Doubled as a Nightclub
description: Books by day, beers by night  at least that is what school district officials in Philadelphia say was offered at a charter school there, where they say the schools cafeteria was used weekends as a nightclub.

title: What Were Reading: Twitter Predictions, Glee, Tumblr and the iPad
description: We tried, really, we tried to get through a day without an iPad citation. We failed. But we somehow found a connection to Glee.

title: Suicides, Some for Separatist Cause, Jolt India
description: HYDERABAD, India  Sai Kumar Meegada, a 20-year-old straight-A chemical engineering student at a prestigious university here, came home from breakfast one morning early this month, slipped a length of clothesline around his neck, tied it to the ceiling fan in his dorm room and hanged himself.

title: Obama Signs Overhaul of Student Loan Program
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  President Obama signed legislation on Tuesday to expand college access for millions of young Americans by revamping the federal student loan program in what he called one of the most significant investments in higher education since the G.I. Bill.

title: A Haitian Familys Hope Grows at a Boston Hospital
description: Jean Paul Coffy, who lives in Chicago, somehow found his parents alive amid the rubble six days after the devastating earthquake that hit Haiti in January, a reunion that attracted international attention as a glimmer of hope amid the destruction.

title: City Pays $98,000 to Critical Mass Cyclists
description: New York City agreed Tuesday to pay tens of thousands of dollars to five cyclists who filed a lawsuit saying they were harassed during the monthly cycling group-ride Critical Mass  including one man seen on videotape being shoved off his bicycle by an officer. As part of the settlement, the city will pay the cyclists a total of $97,751, with each plaintiff receiving $500 to $30,000 apiece and their lawyers receiving a total of $35,000.

title: Only a Few Can Multitask
description: Scientists have known for decades that the human brainhas trouble simultaneouslyprocessing more than one stream of information. A growing body of more recent research has reinforced the notion there are seriouscognitive challenges posed by various kinds of multitasking.

title: With Hirings, Yahoo Steps Up Its News Coverage
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo has recruited nearly a dozen journalists from traditional and online media outlets and opened a bureau in Washington to push into original content and increase the popularity of its online news site.

title: In Michelle Wies Gallery, Artistry Off the Course
description: PALM DESERT, Calif.  Bloody skulls, a robot mauling a teddy bear, a schoolgirl wearing a plaid skirt and a gas mask. The golfer Michelle Wie looked up from her artwork and said with a laugh, Its like drawings you do in fifth grade and someone says, You need help.

title: The Government and the Militia Movement
description: The F.B.I.s raids against members of a Michigan-based Christian militia over the weekend added to concerns about rising far-right activity across the country. Nine members of the group, called the Hutaree, face sedition and weapons charges in a scheme to kill law enforcement officers to incite an antigovernment revolt.

title: Despite Doubt, Karzai Brother Retains Power
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Ahmed Wali Karzai, the most powerful man in southern Afghanistan, may maintain links with drug dealers and insurgents, as some American officials and Afghans believe. And he might have played a central role in last summers fraudulent presidential election, as Western diplomats charged.

title: Live at the Masters, Woodss First Shot, but Not the Second
description: The Augusta National Golf Club, which has the fewest broadcast hours and the highest television ratings of any major golf tournament, has not given ESPN a free hand to show all of Tiger Woodss shots live in his postscandal return at the Masters.

title: City Will Stop Paying the Poor for Good Behavior
description: An unusual and much-heralded program that gave poor families cash to encourage good behavior and self-sufficiency has so far had only modest effects on their lives and economic situation, according to an analysis the Bloomberg administration released on Tuesday.

title: A Bridge to Fame in Boise, Honest
description: BOISE, Idaho  For 14 years Doug Stirling has worked the register at the Airport Chevron and watched as this city and its ambitions grew around him.

title: In E-Book Era, You Cant Even Judge a Cover
description: Bindu Wiles was on a Q train in Brooklyn this month when she spotted a woman reading a book whose cover had an arresting black silhouette of a girls head set against a bright orange background.

title: 9th Member of Militia Arrested
description: DETROIT  A ninth member of a Michigan-based militia accused of plotting to kill law enforcement officials was arraigned Tuesday. The accused, Joshua M. Stone, who was arrested Monday evening after the other members appeared in the Federal District Court here, was ordered held without bond until a hearing Wednesday.

title: On Coaching Go-Round, Its Hop On, and Hold On
description: St. Johns wants to be a player. Boston College wants to be a player. Everybody wants to be a player.

title: In Florida, the Seafood Becomes Less Local
description: ISLAMORADA, Fla.  The postcard Florida experience: sun, fun and plenty of local seafood. It was the latter that brought Gary and Vicki Haller from Kansas to Wahoos here last week, with its waterfront views, toucan colors and promise of fresh food from our docks.

title: Journalists E-Mails Hacked in China
description: BEIJING  In what appears to be a coordinated assault, the e-mail accounts of more than a dozen rights activists, academics and journalists who cover China have been compromised by unknown intruders. A Chinese human rights organization also said that hackers disabled its Web site for a fifth straight day.

title: Senator Isakson Returns to Hospital
description: Senator Johnny Isakson, a Republican from Georgia who was ill last week and missed the reconciliation vote on health care, has returned to the hospital after doctors found he had an irregular heartbeat.

title: Gallinari Takes Blame for Loss to Jazz
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Sometimes the best measures of a young players growth come without the basketball in his hands, or the game clock running. Some steps are taken in near solitude, in a quiet corner of the locker room.

title: Haiti Frets Over Aid and Control of Rebuilding
description: UNITED NATIONS  More than $1.35 billion has been committed to Haiti in humanitarian assistance since the devastating earthquake on Jan. 12, but less than $23 million in cash has been given to the Haitian government so far, leaving President Ren Prval beleaguered and wary about the reconstruction.

title: Georgia Attorney General Spurns Suit on Health Care
description: ATLANTA  In 14 states across the country, attorneys general have filed lawsuits challenging the constitutionality of the recent federal health care overhaul. But here in Georgia, the Democratic attorney general has rejected such lawsuits as frivolous and a waste of taxpayer money. Now that position has led to calls from Republican lawmakers for his impeachment.

title: Census Day Is Near, Carrying a Weight Far Beyond the Raw Numbers
description: Thursday is Census Day  the date when Americans are urged to fill out their census forms if they want to avoid a visit from a federal worker  and the deadline will put to test a months-long campaign by antigovernment activists who are encouraging people not to complete the questionnaires.

title: Tigers Moral Hazard
description: When Tiger Woods tees up his Nike golf ball at the first hole of the Masters next week, will you be wishing him well? Or will you hope he yanks his drive into the pines and spends four days trudging toward the searing defeat that, in your view, he richly deserves?

title: In and Out of Love
description: "Ernestine Anderson, a soulful and experienced singer, is at her best weighing the ups and downs of love," writes Nate Chinen. "She should have no problem covering that terrain with help from a frequent foil, the tenor saxophonist Houston Person, and a rhythm section consisting of the pianist Lafayette Harris Jr., the bassist Lonnie Plaxico and the drummer Willie Jones III." She'll be performing through April 4 at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m. at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola.

title: Small Plates, High Concept
description: The new West Village eatery Recette, "is small and crowded behind its windows, loud in the way that little Village restaurants can become loud, the sort of place men go wearing blazers, then pull them off halfway through the meal, where women flush and everyone leans into the table to talk," Sam Sifton writes. The restaurant, run by Jesse Schenker, features "American food with Spanish flavors, cooked with French technique; small plates and high concept." Start with snacks, like codfish fritters or the charcuterie plate or, say, the tte de cochon. Then move on to pork belly cooked with a sherry-laced caramel or ocean trout with a dressing of smoked bacon. "The cooking at Recette is smart and imaginative, the food that results from it elegant and full of flavor. The wine list is deep and the service friendly and able, if sometimes overwhelmed. You may have to ask for water a couple of times. There will be the occasional crash of a dropped wineglass. It is casual, almost to a fault. But Recette is a very good restaurant."

title: The Glass Menagerie
description: "The Glass Menagerie" might bring to mind memories of overwrought high school productions. So too might "The Miracle Worker," about the life of Helen Keller, which did not fare well in its recent Broadway revival. A new production of "Menagerie" looks like it might have more luck. "Do not come to the Laura Pels Theater, where the Roundabout Theater Company's terrific new revival of Tennessee Williams's career-igniting play opened last week, looking for a standard dose of weepy Southern lyricism," writes Charles Isherwood. "Instead you'll find something unexpected, namely the fiercely moving and seriously funny play Williams actually wrote, in a production directed by Gordon Edelstein that's lightning-lit from within by the tough, compelling and first-rate Amanda Wingfield of Judith Ivey, giving what is surely the performance of her career."

title: Arms Control May Be Different on Paper and on the Ground
description: WASHINGTON  An official photograph of a B-52 bomber at Barksdale Air Base in Louisiana shows it with a formidable arsenal of nuclear weapons it can carry all at once  14 air-launched cruise missiles, four B61-7 gravity bombs and two B83 gravity bombs.

title: Vatican and Pope Stumble in Response to Abuse Crisis
description: VATICAN CITY  The Vatican has been ramping up its defense of how Pope Benedict XVI and the church have handled a growing sexual abuse scandal. But deflecting criticism has proved challenging for this papacy.

title: Obama Expects U.N. Sanctions on Iran to Be Approved Soon
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama predicted on Tuesday that he would be able to persuade the United Nations to move forcefully against Iran with new sanctions within weeks, not months, as he turned up the pressure on Tehran to back off its nuclear program.

title: Is Polanski Case Nearing Its End?
description: LOS ANGELES  Is the 33-year-old sex-crime prosecution of Roman Polanski finally creeping toward its end-game?

title: A Drug Maker Targets a New Audience
description: Editors discuss a drug giant's plans to expand the market for its blockbuster cholesterol medication and medical experts' concerns.

title: Weak Rules on Toxins and Safety
description: For 14 years until just last month, GlaxoSmithKline sold a denture cream called Super Poligrip that contained high levels of zinc.

title: Moscow After the Attacks
description: Commuters held impromptu memorials while Russian leaders faced pressure to prevent further attacks.

title: China: Bodies of 21 Babies Are Found
description: The bodies of 21 babies were found in plastic bags in a river in northeast China, state media reported Tuesday. The bodies, some in bags marked medical waste, others with hospital identification tags on their toes, were recovered Sunday and Monday from a river in Jining, a city in Shandong Province. The authorities said at least 15 bodies appeared to be of aborted fetuses or infants who had died at Jining Medical College Hospital, state media said. Hospital officials could not be reached for comment.

title: France: Warning Over Veil Ban
description: Frances top legal advisory body, the Council of State, warned Tuesday that a ban on the full facial veil would most likely be unconstitutional and contravene the European Convention on Human Rights. There appears to the Council of State to be no legally unchallengeable justification, the report said in addressing a request by Prime Minister Franois Fillon, above, about how best to carry out a ban. President Nicolas Sarkozy has said the full facial veil has no place in French society.

title: The Details on Zinc and Denture Cream
description: My column this week mentions a fair amount of scientific information about zinc in denture cream. If youre interested in reading more, the following should help:

title: Tales of Indiana Hoops, as Told by the Hoosier
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Since leading tiny Milan High School to the Indiana state basketball championship in 1954, storytelling has become a big part of Bobby Plumps life.

title: After Patent on Genes Is Invalidated, Taking Stock
description: Many biotechnology stocks fell on Tuesday as investors struggled to understand the impact of a ruling that threw out parts of two gene patents and called into question thousands more.

title: Amassing a Shrine to His Old School
description: Not many former wards of New York Citys public schools would cherish a splinter that pierced the rear of their public school principal in 1942, but Martin Raskin, it is safe to say, is in a class by himself.

title: Welcome to Lavins World. Enjoy the Ride.
description: A little more than a month before Steve Lavin, with John Wooden as his best man, was to marry the actress Mary Jarou at an exclusive cliffside resort in Laguna Beach in 2007, several hundred wedding guests received an e-mail message from the couple.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Jail Officers Protest Cuts as Assaults Show a Rise
description: New York City correction officials are closely monitoring violence in the municipal jails following a recent increase in serious assaults and a confrontation Saturday night in which four jail officers were injured.

title: Another Exit From Bloombergs Inner Circle
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg so prizes stability and loyalty that he discouraged goodbye parties for employees of his media company, writing in his memoir that he could barely bring himself to wish departing workers good luck. Why should I? he asked.

title: Paterson Delays School Aid, Citing States Lack of Money
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson ordered the delay of $2.1 billion in aid payments to local school districts on Tuesday, saying the state did not have enough cash to pay bills and still end the fiscal year with its budget balanced.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 30, 2010

title: For Mack, Life Has Imitated Art Imitating Life
description: INDIANAPOLIS  There will be plenty of comparisons to the film Hoosiers now that the Butler Bulldogs have made an improbable trip to the Final Four, and the one plot line that may imitate life the most is the Butler guard Shelvin Mack.

title: Real Estates Crash Recasts a Scorned Landlord as a Potential Savior
description: Tenant advocates and many of his own renters regard Laurence Gluck as the scourge of subsidized middle-class housing.

title: In Patent Fight, Nature, 1; Company, 0
description: For years, women have gone to a genetics clinic at Columbia University, stuck out their arms and watched their blood fill glass tubes.

title: Upscale Shoe Brand
description: I float like a butterfly and sting like a bee,Your hands cant hit what your eyes cant see.

title: Yankees Venditte Remains More a Curiosity Than a Prospect
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  His afternoon of pitching finished, C. C. Sabathia took a seat in the Yankees dugout at Champion Stadium, grabbed a towel, rubbed the sweat off his face and watched the skinny minor league left-hander who replaced him warm up.

title: Two More Ugly Outings for the Mets Rotation
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The St. Louis Cardinals major league hitters were crushing balls in one direction. On an adjacent field, the Cardinals minor league batters were smacking them in another. It was a simultaneous assault Tuesday, and two members of the Mets starting rotation were the ones absorbing the damage.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about the Moscow subway station bombings misidentified two subway lines. The line that crosses the Moscow River and passes the Lenin Library is Serpukhovsko-Timiryazevskaya, not Zamoskvoretskaya. The line that crosses the Moscow River and passes Red Square is Zamoskvoretskaya, not Lyublinskaya.

title: Corrections
