description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a missing Chinese rights activist, Gao Zhisheng, who has resurfaced a year after being taken into custody by public security personnel, omitted the date of the photograph of Mr. Gao. It was taken in December 2005.

title: Past Failure a Lesson in Success
description: DAYTON, Ohio  Three years later, the newspaper photograph remains in Tina Charless locker at Connecticut. The picture reminds her of being torched as a freshman by Louisiana States Sylvia Fowles in the 2007 N.C.A.A. tournament. More broadly, it is a daily admonition against complacency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a memorial near the Central Park Reservoir to Alberto Arroyo, who died last week at 94 and was known to joggers as the mayor of Central Park, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of one of the volunteers who pushed Mr. Arroyo around the reservoir in his wheelchair. He is Marty Barolsky, not Barlowsky.

title: Wishing Doesnt Make It Law
description: When noncitizens are convicted of aggravated felonies, federal law makes it relatively easy to remove them from the country  and it should. But the law is not a weapon for overzealous immigration officials who want to deny immigrants fair deportation hearings.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the federal governments plans to sell its ownership stake in Citigroup misidentified the entity that will hold hearings next week on the roles of several federal financial regulators. It is the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, or F.C.I.C.  not the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, or F.D.I.C.

title: Playing With Passion, Rangers Stay in Playoff Hunt
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Rangers are not a team associated with displays of joy, but there were two rare and significant ones from Rangers players in their 4-3 victory over the Islanders on Tuesday night at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Corrections
N.Y.U. Plan for Expansion
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics and Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Lo-Sweet, Lo-Fat, Lo-Salt
description: PepsiCo has an intriguing new approach to salt. It has reportedly designed a powdery salt crystal that dissolves more efficiently on the tongue, releasing more of its saltiness before its swallowed. The company hopes that that will allow it to reduce by a quarter the amount of salt it puts on its Lays potato chips.

title: A Project for Haiti: The Eradication of Two Diseases
description: To the Editor:

title: Should There Be an Inquisition for the Pope?
description: WASHINGTON

title: What Makes Chechen Women So Dangerous?
description: Chicago

title: The Bill Is Passed, but Debate Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: The Moscow Bombings
description: Russians, and all of the world, were reminded again of the cruelty and senselessness of terrorism on Monday morning after two rush-hour bombings on the Moscow subway killed 39 people and injured more than 70 others. We share the horror and remember our own anguish. Nearly 10 years after the 9/11 attacks, the memory of innocent lives taken in the midst of a mornings routine moments has not faded.

title: Enforcing School Standards, at Last
description: Washington has historically talked tough about requiring the states to reform their school systems in exchange for federal aid, and then caved in to the status quo when it came time to enforce the deal. The Obama administration broke with that tradition this week.

title: This Time We Really Mean It
description: This newspaper carried a very troubling article on the front page on Monday. It detailed how President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan had invited Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, to Kabul  in order to stick a thumb in the eye of the Obama administration  after the White House had rescinded an invitation to Mr. Karzai to come to Washington because the Afghan president had gutted an independent panel that had discovered widespread fraud in his re-election last year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about comparable precedents to Tiger Woodss expected return to golf in April after a lengthy layoff misstated the time between Ben Hogans nearly fatal automobile accident, in February 1949, and his victory in the 1950 United States Open. It was 16 months, not 11 months.

title: North Carolina to Face Dayton in Title Game
description: Whether it was inexperience, injuries or simply an inability to understand Coach Roy Williams, North Carolina, the reigning N.C.A.A. champion, faltered much of this season, frustrating Williams to no end.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Wednesday with a television review of N.Y. Export: Opus Jazz, a film of a Jerome Robbins ballet on PBS, reversed the identities of two dancers. Robert Fairchild was at the left, and Andrew Veyette was in the center. (As the caption correctly noted, Adam Hendrickson was at the right.)

title: Corrections
Corrections
description: A review in the Art in Review column on March 19 about #class at the Winkleman Gallery in Chelsea, using information from the gallery, omitted a moderator of a panel about racial integration in the art world. Besides Joanne McNeil, a writer, the panel was also moderated by An Xiao, an artist. (A correction in this space on March 23 also omitted the artist.)

title: Colombia: Guerrillas Free Soldier
description: Guerrillas on Tuesday released Sgt. Pablo Emilio Moncayo, a soldier taken captive as a teenager in 1997 by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC. His release came almost three years after his father, Gustavo Moncayo, a schoolteacher, walked for 46 days across Colombia to lend attention to the plight of his son and other hostages held by FARC. The group hopes to negotiate an exchange of captives in its control for guerrillas held by the government.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 22 and in some copies on March 21 about the disc jockey and music historian Charlie Gillett referred incorrectly to his birthplace, Morecambe, England. At the time he was born, in 1942, Morecambe was a separate town, not a town within the city of Lancaster. (Lancasters boundaries were expanded in 1974 to include Morecambe, although both still tend to be thought of as separate urban centers.) The obituary also misstated the year that Another Saturday Night, a compilation of songs by Louisiana performers on Mr. Gilletts Oval Music label, was released. It was 1973  not 1990, which was the year it was reissued on CD.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Man Dies in Leap Off Empire State Building
description: A 21-year-old man leapt to his death from an observation deck of the Empire State Building on Tuesday, the police said.

title: Q&A With Johnnie Mac, Street Performer
description: When you travel, you see them everywhere: a guitarist strumming and crooning in the Paris Mtro, a juggler in an Italian piazza, a human statue on a New York City corner. They are buskers, and these street performers are not necessarily locals; many are travelers looking to make a bit of extra money and prolong their journeys around the globe.

title: Left Out Because Hes Not a Righty
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As a left-handed batter on a team that needed a righty off the bench, Jon Weber faced the near-impossible task of making the Yankees this spring no matter how well he hit. But that didnt make the inevitable any easier for him to take.

title: France: Burglars Hit Parisian Bank
description: Burglars tunneled their way into a Parisian bank vault late Saturday night and raided about 125 safe deposit boxes, the police said Tuesday. The bank, a branch of Crdit Lyonnais on Avenue de lOpra on the Right Bank, was closed for renovations, but a security guard investigating noises was overpowered and tied to a chair. As the robbers left, they set the bank on fire, and the sprinkler system flooded the vault.

title: Herb Ellis, Jazz Guitarist, Is Dead at 88
description: Herb Ellis, a jazz guitarist whose polished, blues-inflected playing earned him critical acclaim as an outstanding soloist and worldwide recognition as a member of the pianist Oscar Petersons trio, died Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.

title: Bloggers Assess the 2010 Yankees, Part 1
description: As opening day draws near, The Times will be previewing the Yankees and Mets seasons from all angles, with analysis from Tyler Kepner, Ben Shpigel, David Waldstein and others. But with so much happening this off-season, there are a lot of opinions to go around. As we did last season, we have reached out to some Yankees and Mets bloggers for their thoughts on the 2010 season.

title: Cisco Wi-Fi Router Delivers Simple Set-Up
description: Cisco has begun selling a new line of wireless routers that promises to bring simple set-up to those who have never heard of an IP address. The company says its new Valet Wi-Fi routers have taken advice from the team that created the intuitively easy-to-use Flip pocket video camera, which made video a breeze to shoot and share. Cisco bought Flip a year ago.

title: Dan L. Duncan, Oil Billionaire, Dies at 77
description: HOUSTON  Dan L. Duncan, a billionaire oilman known for his philanthropy and global hunting of exotic animals, died Sunday at his home here. He was 77.

title: A Rescued Menagerie
description: In Colombia, the Villa Lorena sanctuary offers a strange window into the excesses and brutalities carried out in Colombias endless drug wars.

title: Footprints, Invisible and Not
description: The terrain of city streets does not impress easily. Hundreds, thousands, millions of people may pass along a stretch of pavement without leaving a trace. Even boot after boot in a Veterans Day parade on Fifth Avenue fail to make a permanent mark. But a puddle of wet paint can change the asphalt canvas dramatically, with a single footfall.

title: Lexus Invites the Green-Oriented to Take a Dark Ride
description: To help a new model stand out in an increasingly crowded category of hybrid automobiles, Lexus is turning to a new agency that specializes in strategic ideas  in this instance, to portray a green car as one honkin fast, hot ride.

title: Obama to Open Offshore Areas to Oil Drilling for First Time
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is proposing to open vast expanses of water along the Atlantic coastline, the eastern Gulf of Mexico and the north coast of Alaska to oil and natural gas drilling, much of it for the first time, officials said Tuesday.

title: I.B.Ms Bid to Woo Software Start-Ups
description: I.B.M. wants to enlist fledgling software companies in its Smarter Planet strategy, which seeks to apply technology to big challenges like improving the efficiency of energy use, water management, transportation and health care.

title: Interview: Tanya Hamilton
description: Tanya Hamilton, the writer and director of "Night Catches Us," compares the themes of her drama about the final days of the black power movement to coming home from a war.

title: Edmund P. Pillsbury, Director at Kimbell, Dies at 66
description: Edmund P. Pillsbury, a distinguished American museum director known for adding a string of European masterworks to the permanent collection of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, died March 25 near Dallas. He was 66 and lived in Dallas.

title: Mortgage Bonds Present New Risks
Interview: Ben Wheatley
description: Ben Wheatley, the director of "Down Terrace," discusses how he mixed improvisation into his screenplay to give the film's performances a sense of realism.

title: Man, 29, Found Stabbed to Death at Home in Queens
description: A 29-year-old man was found stabbed to death in his Queens apartment on Tuesday afternoon, the police said. The man, identified as Edelbuerto Gonzalez-Andujar, was found in his home at 69-30 62nd Street in Ridgewood, near Glen Ridge Park, the police said. His body was discovered about 4 p.m. by relatives who were worried because they had not heard from him.

title: Correction
description: An article last Wednesday about food vendors being brought to Summerstage events in Central Park by organizers of the Brooklyn Flea market reversed the locations for the market on weekends. Starting in April, the market will be in the former Williamsburgh Savings Bank Tower on Sundays, and in its Fort Greene location on Saturdays.

title: Notable Deaths of 2010
description: Remembering George Steinbrenner, J.D. Salinger, Teddy Pendergrass, Howard Zinn and others who died this year.

title: News Quiz | March 31, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Aid Promises Dont Stop Rise in Greek Borrowing Costs
description: Markets drove up Greeces borrowing costs again on Tuesday, despite last weeks promise of a financial backstop from other European countries, indicating the countrys debt crisis was far from over, The Associated Press reports.

title: Dayton in N.I.T. Final
description: Daytons Chris Johnson, a 6-foot-6 swingman, had 22 points and 9 rebounds to lead the Flyers to a 68-63 victory against Mississippi in a National Invitation Tournament semifinal Tuesday at Madison Square Garden. The Flyers (24-12), who will be playing for their third N.I.T. title and first since 1968 on Thursday, will face the winner of Tuesdays second semifinal between North Carolina and Rhode Island.

title: Samsung Life Said to Aim for $4.5 Billion in I.P.O.
description: Samsung Life Insurance, South Koreas top life insurer, wants to raise up to around 5.1 trillion won ($4.5 billion) in the countrys biggest initial public offering and second largest offering in Asia so far this year, sources told Reuters.

title: UBS Confirms Fixed-Income Earns Nearly $2.3 Billion
description: UBS expects first-quarter revenue in its rebuilt fixed income business to be slightly below $2.3 billion, the Swiss bank confirmed on Tuesday.

title: Word of the Day | quell
description: quell \kwel\ verb

title: Lars Nilsson: A Look at His Designs
description: Heres a look at pieces from the designers new line, and his work throughout his career, including designs for Gianfranco Ferr, Nina Ricci and Bill Blass.

title: Redwood Said to Eye Sale of $200 Million in C.D.O.s
description: Redwood Trust is looking to float at least $200 million worth of securities backed by home mortgage loans, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the situation.

title: Sex.com: Between Bankruptcy and Foreclosure
description: A lender claiming it is owed millions by the operator of the domain name Sex.com is asking a federal bankruptcy court to dismiss an involuntary bankruptcy case against the company, so it can resume a foreclosure auction, according to new court documents.

title: Ruby, Its You
description: Christopher Petkanas on the best decorator youve never heard of.

title: How Will Russia Respond?
description: WHO is suspected to have perpetrated the attack on the Moscow subway?

title: Schottenfeld Reaches Galleon Settlement With S.E.C.
description: Schottenfeld Group, the company where three people charged in the Galleon Group insider trading case worked, agreed to pay $1.2 million to settle a lawsuit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Wall Street Manages to Stay on Positive Side
description: Wall Street ended slightly higher on Tuesday as an energized technology sector helped offset worries about foreign debt.

title: Mortgage Bonds Present New Risks
description: Investors seem remarkably relaxed about the end on Wednesday of the Federal Reserves $1.25 trillion program to buy mortgage-backed bonds guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, Breakingviews remarks.

title: Should a Gay Teenager Be Allowed to Take a Date to the Prom?
description: Constance McMillen, a high school senior in Mississippi, was told that she could not take her girlfriend to the prom  and that she had to wear a dress, not a suit, if she did attend. (Later, the school cancelled the event.) Now a federal judge has ruled that the school violated Ms. McMillens rights. What do you think?

title: Mulcahy to Retire From Board of Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation said Tuesday that its chairwoman, Anne M. Mulcahy, planned to retire in May, The Associated Press reported.

title: Gainers & Feederism
description: People who deliberately gain weight.

title: Ambassador Theater Sews Up U.K. Deals
description: Fresh off its acquisition of 16 additional theaters in the West End of London and across Britain, the Ambassador Theater Group is seeking business deals with theater owners and producers in the United States to create a cross-Atlantic distribution network for shows, one of the companys co-founders said Monday.

title: Lawmakers Resist Karzais Move on Election Panel
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan lawmakers dealt President Hamid Karzai a rare and potentially significant rebuke on Wednesday when the lower house of Parliament voted overwhelmingly to reverse his decision to take control of what had been the countrys only independent election-fraud monitor.

title: American Idol: The Top 10 and the Lightness of Being Usher
description: Lee DeWyze > Crystal Bowersox > Michael Lynche > Andrew Garcia > Siobhan Magnus > Aaron Kelly > Katie Stevens > Casey James > Tim Urban > Didi Benami

title: Gartmore Suspends Rambourg Amid Trading Inquiry
description: Gartmore Group, the British fund manager, said Tuesday that talks with the Financial Services Authority had led it to suspend Guillaume Rambourg until it resolves an internal inquiry over directing trades.

title: In Insider Trading Case, a Debate About Swaps?
description: A landmark case of insider trading heading to court next week will be a litmus test of the limits of regulators authority to pursue such charges in regards to credit-default swaps, The Wall Street Journal writes.

title: Macarthur Coal Rejects $3 Billion Peabody Bid
description: Macarthur Coal of Australia said Wednesday that it rejected a $3 billion bid by Peabody Energy, citing rising demand for coal as it tried to stave off the latest attempt by a foreign firm to invest in Australian energy reserves.

title: 3 Women Sue BofA and Merrill Lynch Over Bias
description: Bank of America and Merrill Lynch were accused of discriminating against women in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday by three female financial advisers at the companies, The Associated Press reported.

title: Consensus on Finance Rules Fading, I.M.F. Says
description: An international drive to impose new regulations in the wake of the financial crisis is fading and global cooperation is diminishing, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund said Tuesday.

title: Can Leinart Handle a Heavy Load in Arizona?
description: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating, among other statistical pursuits, at NFLStatAnalysis.net.  He also contributes at classactsports.com.

title: Bharti and Zain Seal the Deal
description: Bharti Airtel said Tuesday that it had sealed the deal to buy most of Zains African assets for $9 billion, making it one of the largest carriers in the world.

title: Facebook Veterans in Venture Capital Spotlight
description: As Wall Street eagerly awaits signs that  Facebook will offer shares to the public, the venture capitalists that prowl Silicon Valley are keeping close tabs on another hot commodity: the employees leaving Facebook, Reuters writes.

title: Chechen Rebel Says He Planned Attacks
description: MOSCOW  A former Chechen separatist who reinvented himself as a proponent of global jihad stepped out of the shadows on Wednesday to take responsibility for two suicide bombings on Moscows subway, and to offer himself as the face of an increasingly lethal pan-Caucasus insurgency.

title: Daimler Denies Talk of Maybach Sale
description: Daimler, the German carmaker, dismissed market talk on Tuesday that it could divest its Maybach super luxury brand, after Chinese media reported that a Chinese company was considering buying it.

title: Philadelphia News Lenders Appeal Bid Ruling
description: Lenders to the bankrupt Philadelphia Newspapers have appealed a court decision preventing them from bidding what they are owed in an auction of the publishers business, Reuters reported.

title: Strategic Defaults: Lessons From the Great Depression
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Europe Approves Irish Bank Aid, But Opens Inquiry
description: The European Commission said Wednesday that, while it was approving the latest aid package for Anglo Irish Bank and Irish Nationwide Building Society, it would open an investigation into the total aid the lenders had received as well as the restructuring measures taken to address their weaknesses.

title: Crisco Inferno
description: Video Classic | Take the doughnuts off the Lazy Susan and a few notches off your wide white belt with the Disco Body Shaper:

title: Economist Urges Breakup of Big U.S. Banks
description: Americas big banks must be broken up and their risk-taking curtailed or the worlds richest economy will face another massive financial crisis, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, Simon Johnson, says in a new book.

title: Australia Approves, in Principle, 2nd Stock Exchange
description: Australia is ending its stock exchanges monopoly and has given approval in principle to a unit of Nomura, the Japanese brokerage, to open a second exchange in a move to spur development of the industry, the financial services minister said Wednesday.

title: Google Links Web Attacks to Vietnam Mine Dispute
description: HONG KONG  Google, fresh off a dispute with China over censorship and intrusion from hackers, says it has identified cyber-attacks aimed at silencing critics of a controversial, Chinese-backed bauxite mining project in Vietnam.

title: Can Humans Manage the Atmosphere?
description: As recently as 2006, geoengineering  using countermeasures to blunt the heat-trapping impact of accumulating greenhouse gases or sop them up directly  had a someday feel to it. The following video clip is a fun introduction to some of the basic ideas:

title: Close Bloomberg Aide Takes Citi Job
description: 9:25 a.m. | Updated One of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs closest advisers is bidding farewell to City Hall to take a job on Wall Street.

title: Sampler: San Jose Considers Medical Marijuana, and San Francisco Crime Lab Was Overworked
description: San Jose to Consider Medical Marijuana Collectives | On Tuesday, the San Jose City Council voted to draft an ordinance that would permit medical marijuana collectives and impose additional taxes on them. The proposal will be considered again in June. Mayor Chuck Reed said the ordinance doesnt mean anybody can do anything they want to do anywhere they want to do it. He added, Were trying to implement state law in a way that allows us to control what we do in our city. [The San Jose Mercury News]

title: Bombing Caught on Camera in Dagestan
description: At least 12 people were killed on Wednesday by two bombs in Dagestan, a region of southern Russia that borders Chechnya, as my colleague Michael Schwirtz reports. The second of the two explosions in the town of Kizlyar in Russias volatile North Caucasus can be seen in the mobile phone footage embedded below, which was obtained by Russia Today, a government-run satellite news channel.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, March 31
description: Here are some highlights from Wednesdays edition of The New York Times:

title: Madison Dearborn Signs Deal for BWAY
description: Madison Dearborn Partners is paying almost $485 million in cash to buy out Bway Holding, a maker of plastic and steel containers, The Associated Press reported.

title: Six Shocks of Entrepreneurship
description: Theres nothing like a tough economy  and unemployment  to encourage people to take the plunge and open their own businesses. Some have more business experience than others. Some have more education than others. When I started my company, I went through a series of surprises and shocks and the occasional nightmare. With all of the recent interest in entrepreneurship, I thought I would highlight six warning signs that you are about to be broadsided by one of the classic and inevitable struggles of business ownership. If you hear yourself saying these words, take a step back and think about what youre doing. My hope is that by being more aware you will be better prepared.

title: Adult Day Programs: A Reprieve for Families and the Elderly
description: The other morning, I stopped by Senior Care, an adult day program near my home in Montclair, N.J. Things were hopping, as usual.

title: The Knife With Self-Destructing Memory
description: Imagine how delighted the Swiss Army must be today: theyve just been told that the makers of the venerable Swiss Army knife have released a new version, which contains a U.S.B. flash drive that will self-destruct if it falls into the wrong hands.

title: Why Palm Is Headed for a Buyout, by RIM
description: From Saad Fazil of VentureBeat:

title: The Early Word: Drill, Obama, Drill
description: President Obama is expected to announced an expansive new offshore drilling policy Wednesday in a speech at the Andrews Naval Air Facility.

title: Ferris Buellers Choice Ferrari for Sale
description: Fans of Ferris Buellers Day Off who couldnt talk themselves into spending $2.3 million for Cameron Fryes house (in a down market, no less) now have a second chance to blow excessive amounts of cash on film memorabilia.

description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Lincoln MKZ Hybrid

title: Hopes Fade for Chinese Miners Trapped in Flooded Shaft
description: BEIJING  Despite the efforts of 1,000 rescuers, hope appeared to be fading Wednesday for 153 miners trapped in a coal shaft in northern China that was flooded on Sunday.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Tatjana Soli
description: Tatjana Soli is the author of a new novel, The Lotus Eaters.

title: New York Auto Show: Driving the Ford Transit Connect Electric
description: 11:29 a.m. | Updated

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Mercedes-Benz R-Class
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Mercedes-Benz R-Class Wagon

title: An Up Quarter Ends With a Down Day
description: Wall Street ended its first quarter on a disappointing note on Wednesday as worries about the job market overshadowed enthusiasm for the energy sector.

title: Two Apologies, No Trial Over Srebrenica
description: Updated | 11:26 a.m. On Tuesday night, after a 13-hour debate, Serbias Parliament narrowly passed a resolution apologizing for the states failure to prevent the massacre of more than 7,000 Bosnian Muslims by the Bosnian Serb army at Srebrenica in 1995.

title: Dire Legal Effects of a Marijuana Cigarette
description: When Jerry Lemaine was arrested in Elmont, N.Y., for a single marijuana cigarette in his pocket, a Legal Aid lawyer counseled him to plead guilty because state statutes called for a $100 fine and nothing more. Even though Mr. Lemaine had been caught with a small amount of marijuana years earlier as a teenager, that case had been dismissed.

title: New Directors/New Films Video: Ben Wheatley
description: Ben Wheatley, the director of Down Terrace, has made a crime drama that seems to have more in common with the realism of Mike Leigh than the romanticism of Martin Scorsese. His intimate, low-budget family portrait was shot in eight days and moves with ease from humorous moments to violent ones, all grounded by a sense of reality. Mr. Wheatley spoke about his method of merging improvisational lines with the words in his screenplay to get fresh performances out of his actors:

title: Tis the Season for Catching Tax Scofflaws
description: If your fear of getting caught for tax fraud starts to spike in the next few weeks, its probably by design. The Internal Revenue Service appears to deliberately ramp up publicity of its tax fraud cases just before Tax Day, a new study finds.

title: Dollar Movies, Ordered From a Phone
description: With all of the Blockbuster stores closing in my neighborhood, Im becoming a devotee of Redbox, the DVD vending machines that charge about a dollar a day for movie rentals.

title: Now Tying | Pierrepont Hicks
description: Technically speaking, men have been wearing ties less and less for decades now. Yet anyone whos moved even slightly in the hipster-trad circles of Brooklyn and Portland, Ore., and Madison, Wisc., knows that a certain kind of man now regularly pairs a tie with his jeans and rumpled button-down and work boots in a way that is perfectly cool. Which goes a long way toward explaining the quiet buzz that has been building around a new necktie label called Pierrepont Hicks, which opened last fall and just recently released its second (spring/summer) collection.

title: LL Cool J Challenges Fox News on Promotion of Palin Show
description: Update: Fox News said it would cut an interview with LL Cool J from the debut episode of Real American Stories.

title: Can Animals Be Gay?
description: The Laysan albatross is a downy seabird with a seven-foot wingspan and a notched, pale yellow beak. Every November, a small colony of albatrosses assembles at a place called Kaena Point, overlooking the Pacific at the foot of a volcanic range, on the northwestern tip of Oahu, Hawaii. Each bird has spent the past six months in solitude, ranging over open water as far north as Alaska, and has come back to the breeding ground to reunite with its mate. Albatrosses can live to be 60 or 70 years old and typically mate with the same bird every year, for life. Their divorce rate, as biologists term it, is among the lowest of any bird.

title: Thai Protesters Shed Culture of Restraint
description: BANGKOK  Thailand is a country of 145,000 Mercedes Benz sedans and about 75,000 villages, many of them hamlets afflicted by poverty.

title: Come Fly Away': Drinks All Around
description: The Timess Charles Isherwood and Alastair Macaulay are discussing Come Fly Away, which opened last week at the Marquis Theater. Previous posts are here.

title: White House Forum on Workplace Flexibility
description: Starting at 1:15 p.m. today you can watch what has the potential to be a deeply informed discussion at the White House on the subject of flexibility in the workplace.

title: New York Auto Show: Da-Da-Daaah  The A-Team Van
description: One of the beloved vehicles of 1980s television was the black hot-rod van from the A-Team, the show about four ex-Special Forces soldiers wanted for a crime they did not commit. After disappearing into the Los Angeles underground, the team becomes mercenaries, helping the helpless, while running away from the military officer charged with hunting them down. The group also manages to maintain a sense of humor.

title: Please Put Me on Hold
description: This is the time each decade when America takes stock of itself and counts heads. Residents are asked to complete their census forms as of April 1 if they want to be counted.

title: EMI Licensing Talks With Rivals Collapse
description: EMI abandoned talks with Sony Music and Universal over licensing rights in North America as the music firm is faced with a looming debt default, a person familiar with the matter told DealBook.

title: Eyes Have It
description: According to Ver Bien Para Aprender Mejor (See Well to Learn Better), a program sponsored by the Mexican government, about one-tenth of the countrys children do poorly in school simply because they cant see well. Thats not just because glasses are expensive, but also because in Mexico theyre often perceived as evidence of a handicap. In an attempt to address both problems, Ver Bien turned to the industrial designer Yves Bhar, who, as the creator of the One Laptop Per Child XO (the original $100 computer), has earned a reputation as a maker of inexpensive, attractive products for kids in the developing world. Bhar designed a set of split frames, which makes the glasses less costly to assemble in the field and lets kids customize them using a smorgasbord of color options. Theyre at the intersection of practicality and personal expression, Bhar says. With the help of Augen, the manufacturer, Ver Bien can keep the total cost  including an eye exam and shipping  at just $10. This year alone, it will give away 400,000 pairs. This is about using the very best not to make the most expensive product, Bhar says, but to make the most valuable product  and to make it efficiently.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Debut Set for Tales of the City Musical
description: The world premiere of the musical Tales of the City, adapted from two books by Armistead Maupin, will take place next spring at American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, the theater has announced.

title: And an iPad in Every Backpack
description: Everyone is looking for an angle on much-hyped entrance of the iPad to the marketplace and Seton Hill University in Pennsylvania has grabbed a piece by announcing that every incoming freshman will be handed a tablet when they walk in the door for the 2011-2012 academic year. The campus is wired end-to-end and students also get a new Macbook, which sounds like a bonanza, except the part about a $500 fee per semester for all the digital convenience. Nobody ever said the future would be cheap.

title: Obamas Remarks on Offshore Drilling
description: Following is the text of President Obama's speech on Wednesday announcing his proposal to open vast expanses of water along the Atlantic coastline, the eastern Gulf of Mexico and the north coast of Alaska to oil and natural gas drilling, as released by the White House:

title: David Mills, Television Writer and Producer, Dies
description: 12:24 p.m. | Updated David Mills, an Emmy Award-winning writer and producer for crime dramas like The Wire on HBO and Homicide: Life on the Streets on NBC died on Tuesday in New Orleans, a press representative for HBO said. The New Orleans Times-Picayune reported that Mr. Mills died from a brain aneurysm. HBO is about to broadcast the debut of a new series, Treme, on which Mr. Mills worked as a writer and producer.

title: Court Upholds Provocative Bangladesh Show
description: Word comes from Dhaka, Bangladesh, that Crossfire, an exhibit of photographs by Shahidul Alam exploring extrajudicial killings in that country, has reopened. The police shut down Mr. Alams Drik Gallery on March 22, just before the show was to open, on the grounds that it was likely to incite anarchy.

title: Suspect Says Jurez Killers Had Pursued Jail Guard
description: MONTERREY, Mexico  A gang member arrested in connection with the killings of three people linked to the United States Consulate in Ciudad Jurez has told investigators that the killers were pursuing a guard at the El Paso County Jail, and not workers at the consulate, the authorities said in a statement released late Tuesday.

title: Fox News Will Cut LL Cool J Interview From Palin Show
description: Fox News said on Wednesday that it would drop an interview with LL Cool J, the rapper and NCIS: Los Angeles star, from the debut episode of Real American Stories, a new series hosted by Sarah Palin. LL Cool J, whose real name is James Todd Smith, wrote Tuesday on his Twitter account that Fox News was misrepresenting him in promotions for the show by using a 2008 interview with him in its advertisements.

title: Museum of Model Art | Hannelore Knuts Hangs a Show
description: To non-Belgians, the small Flemish town of Hasselt might be best known for hosting the Junior Eurovision song contest in 2005. Clearly, a mecca of taste this isnt. But that is about to change as the Hasselt Fashion Museum unveils UltraMegaLore, a show devoted to ber-mannequin Hannelore Knuts. The gambit? Knuts isnt just the exhibits main subject but also its chief curator.

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Infiniti QX56
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Infiniti QX56

title: A Girl Scout Cookie Cookoff
description: I went head to head with my colleague Melissa Clark on Wednesday morning and lost.

title: Answers About Growing Indoor Plants
description: Following is the first set of responses from Tibor Fuchs, the president of the Metropolitan New York Chapter of the Indoor Gardening Society of America who responded to readers questions about growing plants and keeping them alive inside.

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Volkswagen Touareg Hybrid
description: 8:04 a.m. | Updated

title: One Saving Strategy: Bank One Salary
description: Now that our financial lives are a bit more stable than they have been in recent years, my husband and I need to create a new budget and figure out what our saving and spending strategy should be.

title: Mashing His Way Through History
description: IF Theater were to meet you downtown at the intersection of Politics and Pop Culture, waiting to greet you would be Alex Timbers.

title: London Dance Journal: A Ballet Thats Home Sweet Home
description: LONDON  Frederick Ashtons version of La Fille Mal Garde (The Wayward Daughter) is 50 years old. It was the greatest hit of his career. And though he was skeptical about the afterlife of his works, Ashton himself admitted that he expected Fille would stay around for quite a while. In the last 10 years alone, it has been danced by the Bolshoi Ballet, American Ballet Theater and the Paris Opera Ballet.

title: Elizabeth and Bayard Streets, 9:55 A.M.
On the Coaching Carousel, All Is Forgiven
description: While the college basketball coaching roulette wheel spins into a bizarre parallel universe  an actual university hired Steve Lavin? Tim Floyd? Did someone fall asleep and miss everything since 1998?  the most ludicrously successful one of all has coached his way into a different bizarre parallel universe. Geno Auriemmas Connecticut team is so good that unless you really like watching teams win by 40 points, he has squelched almost any reason to watch the N.C.A.A. womens tournament. The last time the Huskies lost a game, people still thought those interest-only subprime mortgages were a fabulous idea.

title: Obama Oil Drilling Plan Draws Critics
description: WASHINGTON President Obamas proposal to open vast expanses of American coastlines to oil and natural gas drilling drew criticism from both sides in the drilling debate.

title: Art Institute of Chicago Cuts Some Gallery Hours
description: The Art Institute of Chicago has begun closing some galleries for one to two hours a day in an effort to close a budget gap, Carrie Heinonen, the museums vice president for public affairs, said. The rotating closures are an experiment so far, but the museum projects being able to save $150,000 annually if they are continued, Ms. Heinonen said. She added that none of the most-visited galleries  like those displaying Impressionist paintings or famous works like Edward Hoppers Nighthawks or Grant Woods American Gothic  had been closed and that the museum had received very few complaints. The closures were reported by Time Out Chicago.

title: Now in the Movie Marketing Mix: Six Flags
description: Hollywood studios are always looking for ways to promote new releases. The Six Flags amusement parks are now offering themselves as places to introduce coming films.

title: Recycled Cooking Oil Found to Be Latest Hazard in China
description: SHANGHAI  Regulators are investigating whether restaurants throughout China are creating food hazards by cooking with recycled oil, some tainted with food waste, and prominence given to the issue in the state-controlled media suggests that the problem could be widespread.

title: The Other Pat Venditte, Sort Of
description: TAMPA  Maybe some of you know this. Maybe you dont. But Pat Venditte isnt the only ambidextrous pitcher in the Yankees organization.

title: Journalists E-Mails Hacked in China
description: BEIJING  In what appeared to be a coordinated assault, the e-mail accounts of more than a dozen rights advocates, academics and journalists who cover China have been compromised by unknown intruders. A Chinese human rights organization also said that hackers had disabled its Web site for five days in a row.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Rangers, Thrashers and Bruins All Win
description: Three Eastern teams on the playoff bubble in action among the nine games on Tuesday night, and all were winners. Home teams listed first:

title: Turkoglu Becomes Torontos Expensive Distraction
description: Sitting in the stands during summer league games in Las Vegas last year, Orlando General Manager Otis Smith made a simple statement, both boastful and honest.

title: Blogs With Bite
description: Heres the latest Blogs With Bite, from Mike Licht, on bacon, buffalo meat and Lebanese nachos.

title: Justin Bieber Tops the Chart
description: Justin Bieber, the shaggy-haired, baby-faced Usher protg, is barely 16, but he now has a No. 1 album on the Billboard chart. My World 2.0 (Island), his first full-length LP, sold 283,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Billboard reported that Mr. Bieber is the youngest solo male artist to top its album chart since a 13-year-old Stevie Wonder reached No. 1 in 1963 with Little Stevie Wonder/The 12 Year Old Genius. (Upon receiving the chart news on Wednesday, Mr. Bieber tweeted about how he was celebrating: SCHOOL  buzzkill). Mr. Biebers minialbum, My World, released in November, rose five spots to No. 5 this week with 50,000 sales; together the two records have sold just under 1.4 million copies.

title: Rhode Island Swamped by Record Rain
description: WEST WARWICK, R.I.  Bill and Stacy Prisco considered themselves lucky  only their house was under water.

title: World Bank Mulls $3.75 Billion for South African Coal Power Expansion
description: The World Bank is calling on its members to back a contentious $3.75 billion loan request from Eskom, South Africas state run electricity supplier, to finance initiatives that would shore-up the countrys struggling power sector.

title: American Teams Up with JetBlue
description: American Airlines announced today that it is forming a partnership with JetBlue Airways to allow JetBlue customers to connect to Americans international flights.

title: TimesCast | March 31, 2010
description: A look inside the newsroom at the stories The Times is following. Today's edition covers movement of military equipment and personnel from Iraq to Afghanistan and the challenge the U.S. Census faces in immigrant neighborhoods.

title: Icahn Trims His Stake in Troubled Blockbuster
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has reduced his stake in Blockbuster, selling more than 13 million shares of the troubled video rental chain, which possibly faces bankruptcy, Reuters reports.

title: For Butlers President, Excellence Is Expected
description: As the first American-born child of Chinese immigrants, Bobby Fong, the Butler University president, learned math by computing baseball statistics. He learned about the United States by studying the game of baseball.

title: The Morning Skate: Captains Under Fire for Flames, Flyers Flaws
description: Its finger-pointing time in the N.H.L.

title: New York Auto Show: A Sporty Suzuki, Engine to Follow
description: The Suzuki Kizashi Sport is the automotive Tin Man of the New York auto show. It needs a heart, or more to the point, a suitable engine.

title: At Club Monaco, How Basic Can It Get?
description: OF all the clubs Ive been turned away from in this city, Club Monaco was the most vexing. My first attempt at visiting the store on Fifth Avenue at 21st Street was foiled by preparations for a party celebrating the photographer Bert Stern, who shot this seasons advertising campaign. Fair enough: it gave me time to ponder his photos, blown up huge and hung in the stores windows, radiating respectable fashion out onto the street.

title: Glee, Modern Family and Craig Ferguson Win Peabody Awards
description: What could be more exciting for those singing, dancing, impregnating glee-club kids at William McKinley High School than a victory at sectionals? How about a Peabody Award? On Wednesday Glee, the hit Fox series, was named one of the recipients of a George Foster Peabody Award, given annually by the University of Georgias Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication for excellence in electronic media, the college said in a news release. The ABC comedy Modern Family was also recognized by the Peabody board, as were The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS, the HBO series In Treatment and The No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency and the PBS movie Endgame, about the end of the apartheid era in South Africa.

title: Taxes and Salaries, County by County
description: Syracuse Universitys Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse published its annual Internal Revenue Service report on Wednesday. It includes some intriguing statistics on income and tax data for each of the countrys 3,000 counties.

title: Reader Rejoinders
description: An occasional assemblage of overheard or underappreciated words  generously emailed by co-vocabularists.

title: TV Cameras Focus on School Lunch
description: If you are appalled at what is served in your childs lunchroom, you are not alone. My colleague Kim Severson takes a look at the latest in the battle to improve school lunch in the dining section of The Times today.

title: Feeling For | Rolex Redux
description: Were all familiar with the fashion crowds fixation with black, but if youre also obsessed with watches, check out Black Limited Edition, a series of vintage stainless steel Rolexes turned into Tron-like collectors items. Alejandro Alcocer, a watch fanatic and design entrepreneur who has previously delved into skateboarding, catering and handbag design, followed the legend of a black watch supposedly released by Rolex in the late 1960s for the Royal British Army soldiers stationed in South Africa. It was thought that only 500 were made, but Rolex never confirmed their distribution and they became the holy grail of watch collecting. So Alcocer decided to make his own, with the help of a Pennsylvania-based company that had previously done contract work for the U.S. Army but had fallen on tough times. Aside from the dial and crystal, which remain in vintage original condition, the watches were transformed into matte black beauties using highly specialized chemical applications. Black is the new black, and Im feeling for the Rolex redux.

title: MGM Wins More Time to Pay Back Debt
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer said on Wednesday that it had secured another extension of a debt forbearance agreement with its lenders, as it considered ways to pay off its hefty financial burden.

title: A Lot of Slime
description: Monologue | Tuesday night on NBC: Happy Passover, everybody. Speaking of that, as you may have heard, Vice President Joe Biden did it again. He showed up at the White House Seder last night with a bunch of ham sandwiches.

title: Text Alerts for Baby Care
description: Tuesday at 2:04 p.m., I received the following text message:

title: What Tiger Woods Could Do for Women
description: Gail Collins: David, in honor of Passover, Ive been trying to think of a subject that will not depress you. Although youve never admitted this, I have a strong sense that your funk was mainly due to the dreadful behavior of so many, many Republicans over the last few months. So lets change the topic. You will not catch me bringing up the Republican National Committees expense account issues with the bondage-themed nightclub in West Hollywood. Really, my lips are sealed.

title: Whoa, Here We Go
description: Monologue | Tuesday night on CBS: Now heres a fascinating story. And this kind of thing happens all the time. But every time it happens, we always say, Whoa, here we go. The Republican National Committee had a big party at some kind of a sex club in Los Angeles. They spent $2,000 of campaign donation money on the bill at the sex club in Los Angeles. But the guy who organized the big Republican sex party apologized on the Golf Channel, so thats good.

title: The Future of a Club and a Commission Are at Issue
description: View Suede, a nightclub, and neighbors in a larger map

title: Tricks of Math and Physics
description: The Census Bureau counted about 2,500,000 people in Kings County, N.Y., also known as Brooklyn, in 2000, spread over 70 square miles. This is roughly 35,000 people per square mile, a fact that the following graphic, circulating online, uses to present an interesting question: If every American  all 300 million of us  lived in one state, how big would that state have to be for everyone to fit as comfortably as Brooklynites?

title: The New Health Care Law
description: Monologue | Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: On the Today show this morning, President Obama said that adjustments will need to be made to the new health care law. In fact, its getting so many adjustments, Obamas now calling it the Heidi Montag of Congressional bills.

title: Floral Accessories Are Big for Spring
description: IF the sudden onset of 60-degree weather hasnt fully spurred your spring fever, try slipping on a pair of Valentinos Fairy Tale booties. The blush-colored flower-festooned shoes are some of the sweetest, frilliest (some might say silliest) accessories of the season. And, in contrast to all those strictly tailored on-trend pieces that are presumably hanging in your closet, such blooming femininity has a saucy appeal.

title: A Critics Place, Thumb and All
description: TWO weeks ago I went to Atlanta to give a talk at a conference devoted, in part, to The Future of Criticism. The gist of my remarks was that there is one. This was a contrarian, and perhaps also somewhat self-serving, position to take. After all, the countervailing evidence is hard to avoid.

title: Census Deadline
description: Monologue | Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Thursday is census deadline day. The census would like every resident of the United States to fill out their form and mail it in. If you dont know how many people live in your house, just count the number of iPods.

title: After Fight, a Brooklyn Brownstones Costly Rescue
description: When he worked at one of New Yorks most respected preservation firms, Timothy Lynch would have spared no effort to save brownstones like the two that stood before him on a January morning.

title: Snowbirds Cast Off Their Inner Fashionistas
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: New York Auto Show: Rodents Rule as Kia Spot Is Named Top Car Ad
description: Unleashing some hipster hamsters paid off for Kia Motors: a commercial for its trend-surfing Soul box car was named Automotive Ad of the Year on Wednesday at the New York auto show.

title: New York Auto Show: Ford, Microsoft and E.V.s
description: The electric version of the Ford Focus, to be released next year, will be the first car to benefit from a collaboration between Ford and Microsoft that uses wireless connectivity to make it easier (and presumably less costly) to charge electric vehicles.

title: Leave New York? Maybe Not
description: If youd asked me a year ago whether I would be considering going to college in New York City, I would have laughed. Loudly. For some time now Ive felt that I need a change of scenery  a break away from my comfort zone, including my supportive, big family and the New York City transit system. I need to know that I can survive in an entirely new environment without having the option of a 30-minute train ride home.

title: Opening Day Questionable for Mets Murphy
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets first baseman Daniel Murphy walked through the clubhouse with a noticeable limp Wednesday, casting doubt on his ability to be ready for opening day.

title: New York Auto Show: Ford Chief Stresses Growth as Crucial to Success
description: 5:30 p.m. | Updated

title: What Were Reading
Forgotten Florida, Through a Writers Eyes
description: THINK of Florida and some well-worn images are likely to spring to mind: gaudy seaside hotels, palm-studded avenues, beaches dotted with towels and umbrellas.

title: Behind-the-Screens Help
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  Jordan Otts role in Michigan States Final Four preparations involves staring at a computer screen nearly nonstop for three days in a windowless room, his sleeping bag stashed nearby. His goal of logging every screen, jump shot, inbounds play and trap-laden defense of the Final Four teams Butler, Duke and West Virginia has not yet been reached.

title: Hutchison Reverses Course, Will Stay in Senate
description: And shes staying.

title: Banning Texting in Trucks Raises Other Questions
description: The Department of Transportation on Wednesdayproposed to makepermanent a rule prohibiting cross-country truckers from sending text messages while driving.

description: What: Cynthia Rowley for Roxy ballet flatsHow much: $79 at cynthiarowley.comWho: Bifen Xu, Ts associate fashion editor

description: The game of musical chairs at the powerful Rent Guidelines Board is now over.
