description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Chevrolet Cruze Eco and RS

title: Vatican Official Defends Popes Handling of Case
description: VATICAN CITY  A top Vatican official issued a detailed defense of Pope Benedict XVIs handling of sexual abuse cases and extensively criticized The New York Timess coverage, both in its news and editorial pages, as unfair to the pope and the church.

title: Ellen, Idol and the Power of Niceness
description: ELLEN DEGENERES leaves no opportunity untapped, not even a few seconds of chat on American Idol.

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Volvo S60
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Volvo S60

title: Mixed Bracket Results for Prognosticator in Chief
description: Its good that President Barack Obama has a steady day job, because he clearly wouldnt make it as a successful N.C.A.A. tournament pool prognosticator this year.

title: Senator Seeks to Limit Banks Role in Derivatives
description: Senator Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio, is seeking to restrict the Wall Street banks ownership of clearinghouses for over-the-counter derivatives. Under his proposed amendment to the financial overhaul bill, the large broker-dealers could be mostly shut out of this potentially lucrative business, raising concerns as to where liquidity would come from to clear the huge inflow of O.T.C. trades expected to hit the open market in the near future.

title: Hairstylists Who Make House Calls
description: ITS been two years since Janna Levine has stepped into a salon. Her blowouts, cuts, highlights and even her Brazilian keratin frizz-reducing treatments are all done in the privacy of her Manhattan apartment.

title: Credit Suisse Chief to Get $67.6 Million in Stock
description: Brady W. Dougan, the chief executive of Credit Suisse, will receive company shares valued at 71 million Swiss francs, or about $67.6 million, under an incentive program at the Zurich-based bank, Bloomberg News reports.

title: The Sartorialist Blog Is a Victim of Knockoffs
description: THE success of Scott Schuman, the photographer of street style and creator of The Sartorialist blog, has spawned countless copycat sites over the last five years, not to mention a swarm of fashionista-paparazzi stationed outside the runway shows. But only one seems to have gotten under his skin.

title: Empowered Sadrists Organize New Ballot in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Followers of Moktada al-Sadr, the militant cleric whose militia was a major force in the Shiite insurgency against American forces, announced Wednesday that they were arranging a special vote to pick Iraqs next prime minister.

title: Pfizer Gives Details on Payments to Doctors
description: Pfizer, the worlds largest drug maker, said Wednesday that it paid about $20 million to 4,500 doctors and other medical professionals for consulting and speaking on its behalf in the last six months of 2009, its first public accounting of payments to the people who decide which drugs to recommend.

title: Uncertainty Remains on Pakistan Corruption Case
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani government officials told the Supreme Court on Wednesday that the countrys top anticorruption agency had asked the Swiss authorities to reopen corruption charges against President Asif Ali Zardari.

title: New York Auto Show: Lexuss Green Scene
description: On Tuesday night Lexus hosted an odd event it called The Darker Side of Green, a sort of environmental forum-meets-dance-party held at Skylight West, a large loft space in the club precincts of Manhattans far West Side.

title: Update: That V Made Lost Hard to See
description: Does ABC really understand how rabidly fans of Lost watch their favorite show, parsing out every bit of information on the screen?

title: Yank! to Move to Broadway Next Season
description: Citing the national debate over the dont ask, dont tell military policy as an inspiration, the producers of the Off Broadway musical Yank!  a love story about two American servicemen during World War II  said on Wednesday that they planned to bring the show to Broadway during the 2010-11 season.

title: E.C.B. Chief Sees Greece Gaining Market Confidence
description: The European Central Bank on Wednesday joined Greece in putting a brave face on the countrys financial prospects, even as Moodys downgraded its ratings on five Greek banks and analysts expressed skepticism that the European Union would be able to avoid a test of the guarantee it extended last week, The New York Timess David Jolly reports.

title: Release of Client Names Is a Step Closer for UBS
description: The Swiss cabinet said on Wednesday that it no longer supported rulings by two Swiss courts that have prevented a planned handover of more than 4,000 names of UBS clients suspected of tax evasion.

title: Financial Tuneup: The Case for Saving a Little Bit More
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 BMW Alpina B7 xDrive
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Alpina B7 xDrive

title: New York Auto Show: BMW 335is
description: 10:22 a.m. | Updated  with new photo from BMW.

title: Kleiner Perkins Pledges Money for iPad Developers
description: Some people are wondering whether consumers will need an iPad if they already have iPods, iPhones and iMacs. John Doerr is not one of those people.

title: Case Study | Fifteen Large and Counting
description: I try to ignore the swirl of P.R. events by companies seeking ink for whatever new offering theyre thrusting upon the world, but recently I got an invitation I felt compelled to accept. Next month, Rmy Martin is releasing a very limited bottling (30 in the U.S.) of a single cask of Louis XIII, its top offering. The Cognac comes in a specially designed black crystal decanter made by an ensemble of 20 craftsmen at Baccarat working together, the design taken from a 16th-century flask found on an ancient battlefield in Cognac in the 19th century. All of this is quite impressive, certainly, but none of it more so than the price: $15,000 per bottle.

title: Homeless in Paradise
description: An effort by the police in Key West, Fla., to enforce "quality-of-life" regulations is raising concern among homeless people, who see themselves as down and out, but not vagrants.

title: New York Auto Show: Bobsled Team Shows Off the Gold
description: Team Night Train added Olympic gold medal gloss to the unveiling of the 2011 Mercedes-Benz R Class. The winning bobsled driver, Steve Holcomb, along with his three teammates and their bobsled shared the stage with Mercedes-Benz executives at the New York auto show.

title: How to Register a Start-Up
description: Think registering your business sounds like a perfunctory and insignificant task? Think again.

title: Hartford Repays $3.4 Billion in Bailout Money
description: The Hartford Financial Services Group said Wednesday that it had paid back the $3.4 billion that the insurance company received in the governments banking bailout.

title: Travel Deals: Three-Day Cruise Sale
description: Holland America is having a three-day sale on cruises worldwide. Fares start at $499, and the third and fourth guests on some cruises sail for free. Sale ends midnight Friday.

title: Drumroll: N.F.L. Announces Preseason Schedule
description: The N.F.L. is taking its sweet time announcing its regular-season schedule - officials say its not done yet, so the announcement of the kickoff and Thanksgiving weekend games that usually takes place during the annual meetings was postponed - but to keep us entertained in the meantime, they sent the preseason schedule Wednesday.

title: The Pattern of Priestly Sex Abuse, Cont.
description: A few follow-ups on the previous post. First, I would invite readers who are skeptical of the data pattern shown in the chart I reproduced to read the entire John Jay Report, as well as the National Review Board report that accompanied it, and (especially) the statistical addendum that John Jay put out in 2006. These are impressively thorough documents, and you may find that many of your objections are addressed in their pages. Where a subject like this is concerned, no statistical assessment is going to be completely dispositive, but I am persuaded that the John Jay/N.R.B. portrait of the pattern of abuse  the rise from the late 50s till 1980, and the drop-off since  is as rigorous as one can hope for at the moment. (In addition, the National Review Board report does an impressive job of addressing many of the cultural issues related to the crisis in an evenhanded and non-hysterical way.)

title: Top Bloomberg Aide to Lead Charity Board
description: In a move without precedent in New York City government, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has appointed a sitting deputy mayor in his administration to simultaneously run his charitable foundation.

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Acura TSX Sport Wagon
description: 8:23 a.m. | Updated

title: 401(k) Matches Are Coming Back
description: Many employers are reinstating  or planning to reinstate  their 401(k) match to employee contributions, according to a new survey from Fidelity Investments.

title: Germany Readies Bank Tax for Future Bailouts
description: The German cabinet agreed in principle on Wednesday to impose a tax on banks to help finance any future bailouts, but it left details of the plan to be worked out in legislation that would be forthcoming in a few months, The New York Timess Matthew Saltmarsh reports. The German plan won cautious backing from the French economy minister, Christine Lagarde, who attended the cabinet meeting in Berlin, where she called for international coordination on the matter.

title: Shopping With Clarissa Richardson
description: A designer of award-winning spas looked for luxurious bath fixtures with a modern, pared-down feel.

title: Lost Watch: Sun Without Jin
description: This post contains spoilers.

title: Dot Earth 2.0
description: After 940 posts as a news blog, Dot Earth is moving to the Opinion side of The New York Times, where it will re-emerge in about a week. Dont expect momentous changes. Im not going to suddenly be revealed as an ardent liberal or conservative.

title: A New Use for Medical Marijuana?
description: Theres one thing that helps my Tourettes more than anything, and its marijuana, says Louis Centanni, the 24-year-old actor and comedian featured in Patient Voices: Tourettes Syndrome. Dr. Robert A. King and Dr. James F. Leckman of the Yale School of Medicine, who recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about Tourettes, here respond to readers asking about the use of marijuana for easing the tics, vocalizations and jerking movements of the syndrome.

title: In 3-D, Masters Does Have Extra Dimension
description: If the test footage shot recently at the Augusta National Golf Club is an authentic gauge, the Masters in 3-D will look terrific. Only a few thousand early adopters with 3-D television sets will be able to see the tournament in this manner, but they will be fortunate: one look at Augusta in 3-D will make high-definition seem obsolete.

title: Swiss Closer to Releasing Names in UBS Tax Case
description: The Swiss cabinet said Wednesday that it no longer supported rulings by two Swiss courts that a planned handover of more than 4,000 names of UBS clients suspected of tax evasion was illegal and could not take place, The New York Timess Lynnley Browning reports.

title: Last-Minute Change at Outreach Program Stokes Doubts
description: Lo sentimos, pero no podemos publicar comentarios sin traduccin. Favor de comentar en ingls.

title: Steeling Beauty | Karl Plays It Safe
description: You think Karl Lagerfeld makes a trip to his safety deposit box every time he wants to change up his precious knuckle hardware? Of course not. Karl has his own walk-in safe. But not just any old walk-in safe. The worlds most expensive walk-in safe, and he designed it himself. And you can have one just like it. The Narcissus, as the Dottling Safes model is called, is 1,600 pounds of steel-bodied, gleaming chrome-plated aluminum home security. It can be fully customized with watch winders, jewelry drawers or special compartments for whatever you value most. Glorious peace of mind? $340,000. Having the same safe as Karl Lagerfeld? Priceless.

title: In Iraqi Politics, Considering the Commute
description: BAGHDAD  Ayad Allawis opponents pulled few punches in the close-run election campaign that he won, calling him a new Saddam, a Baathist, a friend of terrorists, even questioning his parentage  claiming he could not become prime minister because his mother was not born an Iraqi. Interestingly, one thing they did not often accuse him of was living abroad and only visiting Iraq when it was convenient  like when he ran for prime minister.

title: Obama Proposes New Offshore Drilling
description: Reporter John M. Broder discusses the president's announcement.

title: Russian Rights Advocate, 82, Attacked in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Lyudmila M. Alexeyeva, a prominent Russian human-rights activist who is 82 years old, was punched in the head on Wednesday night while she was visiting a memorial in a subway station that was bombed by terrorists on Monday.

title: One Loves It. One Loathes It. Thats Life.
description: Twyla Tharp has been choreographing to the music of Frank Sinatra since the 1970s, but Come Fly Away brings her Sinatra dances to Broadway for the first time. Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The New York Times, hailed it as a major new work of pop dance theater, while The Timess chief dance critic Alastair Macaulay called the choreography less sensational than sensationalistic and intimacy perverted into exhibitionism.

title: New York Auto Show: Scion iQ
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Scion iQ

title: How the Health Care Law Affects Your Business
description: You have questions; we have answers. Mostly.

title: Sinead OConnor Calls for Catholic Boycott
description: Nearly two decades after the Irish singer Sinead OConnor tore up a photograph of Pope John Paul II on Saturday Night Live, to protest what she said was the Vaticans responsibility for child abuse, she has called on fellow Irish Catholics to boycott the church until Pope Benedict XVI makes a full confession and agrees to a full criminal investigation of the churchs role in concealing the sexual abuse of children by members of the clergy.

title: The Familiar Comforts of Conspiracies
description: Conspiratorial thinking has been a staple of American political discourse since the founding of the Republic. But lately the rhetoric of sinister plots and endangered liberty has reached new heights, or depths, whether it is Glenn Beck using a whiteboard to explain how the Progressive Era reforms of Theodore Roosevelt put the nation on to the path of totalitarianism, or Tea Party activists deploring the impending loss of constitutional liberty.

title: BlogTalk: Whose Issue Is It, Anyway?
description: When President Obama announced this morning that he would open vast expanses of American coastlines to oil and natural gas drilling, much of it for the first time, he said he hoped the reaction would move beyond the tired debates between right and left, between business leaders and environmentalists.

title: A Shaper of American Music, and Musicians
description: Early in Joseph W. Polisis book American Muse: The Life and Times of William Schuman (2008) he cites a sweeping critical claim about his subject, the American composer and educator whose centennial is being celebrated this year. Writing in The Washington Post in 1992, the critic Joseph D. McLellan asserted that although Schuman never achieved the name recognition of his colleagues Aaron Copland and Leonard Bernstein, he probably had a stronger and more durable effect on American musical life.

title: Researchers Report Progress on E. Coli Test
description: Its not the pathogenic E. coli microbe itself that harms people who eat ground beef or other foods that contain it. Rather, its the toxins that E. coli produces that do the actual damage. Proper testing of food should look for both, though, since it is possible for one to be present without the other.

title: Little House in the Hood
description: Its remarkable how often you can, in fact, judge a book by its cover. Whats more dangerous is judging a writer by her reputation. I mowed down several thousand pages of In Search of Lost Time before figuring out that Proust, touchstone of novice food writers everywhere, had about as much to say about food as he did about lasers.

title: Crackling Corn Bread
description: 6 tablespoons butter or bacon grease

title: Lard and Cracklings
description: 1 pound pork fat, chilled (leaf lard or fat back, preferably from humanely raised pork)

title: Mattila Withdraws From Mets Tosca
description: The soprano Karita Mattila has withdrawn from the Metropolitan Operas spring performances of Puccinis Tosca, the Met said Wednesday. Patricia Racette will perform the title role instead on April 14, 17, 20 and 24, the dates Ms. Mattila had been scheduled to sing. Ms. Mattila is suffering from problems with a disc in her back, said Peter Clark, the Mets press director, adding that she would not be performing until well into May.

title: Beach Volleyball to Float in Oceans of Lotion
description: The A.V.P.  Association of Volleyball Professionals  is getting a new title sponsor for its tour that makes a lot more sense than previous sponsors like shoes and sport utility vehicles.

title: Bicycling With Parkinson's
description: Video 1 shows a 58-year-old man with a 10-year history of idiopathic Parkinson's disease and an incapacitating freezing of gait. Video 2 shows his continued ability to ride a bicycle.  (Credit: The New England Journal of Medicine)

title: Reviewing the Site That Reviews Everyone
description: Over the last decade, the Internet industry has nudged regular people to review restaurants, products, vacation destinations, even plastic surgeons.

title: Understanding Post-Adoption Depression
description: Its not uncommon for new mothers to experience depression, which is usually attributed to hormonal fluctuations and lack of sleep after childbirth. But new research shows that depression after the arrival of a child isnt limited to birth parents: adoptive parents are also at risk for depression after bringing a child home.

title: How Much Exercise Prevents Weight Gain?
description: Losing weight is difficult, and keeping it off may be even harder. So Harvard researchers set out to determine exactly how much physical activity women need in midlife to avoid gaining weight as they age.

title: Indonesia Airline Expands Routes
description: Garuda, Indonesias national carrier, said in a statement on Wednesday that it was increasing flights to Hong Kong, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore as part of an attempt to triple its number of international departures by 2014.

title: A Record Drop in Tuberculosis Rates
description: Tuberculosis rates in the United States dropped more than 10 percent last year compared with 2008, the sharpest decrease ever recorded in a single year, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are reporting.

title: Swiss Await Decision on Polanski Appeal
description: Swiss officials will decide whether to extradite the film director Roman Polanski to the United States only after an appeals court in California rules on Mr. Polanskis latest petition for review of his case, a spokesman for Justice Ministry in Switzerland told The Associated Press on Wednesday. This action allows the extradition process to adapt to the U.S. proceedings, Folco Galli, the ministry spokesman, said. The 33-year-old sex-crime case against Mr. Polanski was jolted two weeks ago by new claims of improper conduct by Judge Laurence J. Rittenband, who originally handled the case and is now dead. On Tuesday the Los Angeles County district attorney, Stephen L. Cooley, joined deputies in opposing the latest appeal, which seeks among other things to have Mr. Polanski sentenced while he remains abroad. Mr. Polanski was charged with rape and other crimes after having sex with a 13-year-old girl in 1977. He pleaded guilty to a charge of having sex with a minor but fled the United States in 1978 before sentencing.

title: Tea Time
description: Kentuckys Republican Senate primary, to be held May 18, is one of those elections that is being treated as some sort of defining event, a measure of general antipathy toward Washington and the federal government, mainly because youre ahead in the polls. Do you credit Tea Party activists for your success?  Absolutely. I think theres a Tea Party tidal wave coming. I think its going to sweep a lot of incumbents from office.

title: Fox News Drops Old Interview With LL Cool J From Palin Show
description: Fox News said on Wednesday that it was dropping an interview with LL Cool J, right, the rapper and NCIS: Los Angeles star, from Thursdays debut episode of Real American Stories, a program hosted by Sarah Palin. LL Cool J, whose real name is James Todd Smith, wrote Tuesday on his Twitter account that Fox News had lifted an old interview I gave in 2008 to someone else and was misrepresenting to the public in its promotion of the show. Press representatives for LL Cool J said Fox News was repurposing an old interview without his permission. Fox News said that it conducted an interview with LL Cool J about 18 months ago for a program called Real American Stories, and that it did not need his permission to use the interview on the new program. In a statement Fox News said, As it appears that Mr. Smith does not want to be associated with a program that could serve as an inspiration to others, we are cutting his interview from the special and wish him the best with his fledgling acting career. In addition to his NCIS role, LL Cool J has starred in the films Any Given Sunday and Deep Blue Sea and on the television series In the House.

title: Branford Marsalis Composing for Fences
description: The Grammy Award-winning saxophonist Branford Marsalis, below, announced that he would compose original music for the coming revival of August Wilsons Fences this spring. The leader of a jazz quartet bearing his name, Mr. Marsalis said in a statement that working on the Broadway production, which will star Denzel Washington and Viola Davis, was a dream come true. Fences, which won the Tony Award for best play in 1987 as well as the Pulitzer Prize for drama, has not been produced on Broadway since the original production starring James Earl Jones and Mary Alice, which ran for 15 months. The revival is scheduled for a 13-week engagement at the Cort Theater, with preview performances to begin on April 14 and an opening night of April 26.

title: An Uptick for Broadway
description: Compared to the dark days of the economy during the first three months of 2009, Broadway enjoyed modest improvements in ticket sales and attendance during the first quarter of 2010, according to a data analysis by the Broadway League released on Wednesday. Blockbuster musicals and star-studded productions were especially helpful in boosting the numbers.

title: Justin Bieber Is No. 1
description: Justin Bieber, below, the shaggy-haired, baby-faced Usher protg, is barely 16, but he now has a No. 1 album on the Billboard chart. My World 2.0 (Island), his first full-length LP, sold 283,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Billboard reported that Mr. Bieber is the youngest solo male artist to top its album chart since a 13-year-old Stevie Wonder reached No. 1 in 1963 with Little Stevie Wonder: The 12 Year Old Genius. Mr. Biebers mini-album, My World, released in November, rose five spots to No. 5 this week with 50,000 sales; together the two records have sold just under 1.4 million copies. Also on the chart this week, Monicas album Still Standing (J), whose creation was documented in a BET reality series, opened at No. 2 with 184,000 sales, and Now Thats What I Call Music! Volume 33, with songs by Kesha, Lady Gaga, Owl City and 18 others, opened at No. 3 with 135,000. Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville), last weeks top seller, dropped three spots to No. 4 with 78,000. Volume 2 (Merge), the second album by She & Him  featuring the actress Zooey Deschanel and the jack-of-all-indie-trades M. Ward  opened at No. 6 with 47,000.

title: Yank Is on the March
description: Citing the national debate over the dont ask, dont tell military policy as an inspiration, the producers of the Off Broadway musical Yank! (with, from left above, Zak Edwards, Jeffry Denman and Joseph Medeiros)  a love story about two American servicemen during World War II  said on Wednesday that they planned to take the show to Broadway during the 2010-11 season. A spokesman for Yank! said that the Broadway production would cost about $5 million, and that the producers were encouraged by interest from investors. No details about the cast, director, performance dates or theater for the Broadway run were ready for announcement on Wednesday.

title: Glee and Craig Ferguson Win Peabody Awards
description: What could be more exciting for those singing, dancing, impregnating glee-club kids at William McKinley High School than a victory at sectionals? How about a Peabody Award? On Wednesday Glee, the hit Fox series, was named one of the recipients of a George Foster Peabody Award, given annually by the Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication at the University of Georgia for excellence in electronic media, the college said in a news release. The ABC comedy Modern Family was also recognized, as were The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS, the HBO series In Treatment and The No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency and the PBS movie Endgame, about the end of the apartheid era in South Africa. Awards also went to the HBO documentary Thrilla in Manila, about the Joe Frazier-Muhammad Ali boxing matches of the 1970s; two episodes of CBSs 60 Minutes; an episode of the WNET series American Masters; and an episode of the WGBH series Frontline.

title: Cycling Provides a Break for Some With Parkinsons
description: Dr. Bastiaan R. Bloem of the Radboud University Nijmegen Medical Center in the Netherlands thought he had seen it all in his years of caring for patients with Parkinsons disease. But the 58-year-old man who came to see him recently was a total surprise.

title: Mattila Leaves Tosca
description: The soprano Karita Mattila has withdrawn from the Metropolitan Operas spring performances of Puccinis Tosca, the Met said Wednesday. Patricia Racette will perform the title role on April 14, 17, 20 and 24, the dates Ms. Mattila had been scheduled to sing. Ms. Mattila is suffering from problems with a disc in her back, said Peter Clark, the Mets press director, adding that she would not be performing until well into May. Ms. Mattila sang the role in the fall in the controversial production of the opera, staged by Luc Bondy.

title: Applications to Selective Colleges Rise as Admission Rates Fall
description: April 2, 3:25 p.m. | Updated Please use the scroll bar on the chart below to view the latest admissions data on colleges, including the University of Chicago, Princeton, Yale, Pomona, Wesleyan, the University of Wisconsin-Madison and the University of Iowa.

title: A Troupers Journey From the Apollo to Broadway
description: Leslie Uggams was born in a trunk in the Apollo Theater on 125th Street. That is how she metaphorically remembers her origins in her smartly revised version of Born in a Trunk, the sprawling Judy Garland number from A Star Is Born. The song is the thematic grounding wire of Leslie Uggams: Uptown Downtown, at the Cafe Carlyle, her first New York cabaret show in 18 years.

title: Zombies, Lucifer, a Little Bonnie Tyler
description: If the creepy girl from The Ring fought the masked killer from a slasher film, who would win? Why do people on the run from demons and zombies always seem to find a random pile of guns? Is it possible to get Total Eclipse of the Heart out of your head?

title: BlackBerrys Maker Misses Estimates
description: Research In Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, reported fourth-quarter sales and shipments on Wednesday that missed analysts estimates and said that its profit margin would shrink this period.

title: Must Haves | Design
description: Interior design gets all flowery and bright for spring, glass tables in happy hues and a light and lively chair for fun in the sun. More

title: Londoners Find a Home in Uruguay
description: After visiting, Martin and Annie Summers were inspired by the Pueblo Garzon area of Uruguay and built a home there.

title: Loving a Writer and His Women
description: Vera should be happy. Her former love Floyd (Michael Jones), who had gone away with another woman, has come back. Now he wants her to join him in Chicago. But Vera (Thursday Farrar) is having none of it. She once lay in bed and searched my body for your fingerprints, she tells him. But now its too late.

title: In Uruguay, a House That Disappears Into the Landscape
description: PUEBLO GARZN, Uruguay

title: Q&A: Easing Laptop Typing Pain
description: Q.

title: Me and My Hormones, Raging in the 1970s
description: The Diary of a Teenage Girl, the compelling 2002 novel in words and comics by Phoebe Gloeckner, stings with truth, though its author calls it fiction. But Minnie Goetze, its 15-year-old narrator, looks a lot like a young Ms. Gloeckner, and like her was raised in Philadelphia and San Francisco.

title: Senate Loses First Round in Subpoena Fight
description: ALBANY  Inspector General Joseph Fischs office prevailed in the first round of a court fight with the Senate, which has sought to quash subpoenas issued in an ongoing investigation of the awarding of a casino gaming contract at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens.

title: The Nine Lives of Designer Lars Nilsson
description: YOU might be surprised by the number of globetrotting fashion-industry professionals who, almost paradoxically, suffer from profound phobias of airplanes  among them Hedi Slimane, the former mens-wear designer for Dior, and Alexandra Shulman, who once said she had not flown for a decade before she was the editor of British Vogue. Another one, the designer Lars Nilsson, has a theory about a fear of flying, which is true in his case.

title: Assimilated Americans, Defying Asian Stereotypes
description: Except for the title, you probably wont remember a single line from Ching Chong Chinaman. Yet you may recall having a pretty good time. While this scattershot satire, which follows a Chinese-American family and the indentured servant they obtain from China, loses focus as it hurries from one wacky setup to the next, that same vigor also makes for a lively, likable show.

title: City Settles With Two Arrested After Police Confrontation
description: To settle a lawsuit, the city has paid $20,001 apiece to two people who were arrested in the East Village in 2007 after objecting to police officers sawing through the locks of bicycles that had been locked to parking meters.

title: Furor Grows Over Celebrity Appearances on Palin Show
description: 7:49 p.m. | Updated Hours after LL Cool J complained that Fox News was recycling an old interview with him for a new program hosted by Sarah Palin, representatives for the country musician Toby Keith, who was also listed as a guest for the show, made a similar charge against the cable channel.

title: Imaginary Chats and Texts When a Quick Getaway Is in Order
description: I was really hoping to get an invitation to President Obamas Seder this year. Or at least a fake one.

title: After 17 Years, a Glimpse of a Lunar Purchase
description: Richard A. Garriott has finally seen the item he bought 17 years ago for $68,500.

title: Dr. Scholls Widens Its Insole Campaign
description: SUBSCRIBERS to the May issues of In Style and All You, and to the June issue of Shape will find an unusual ad for Dr. Scholls for Her Open Shoe insoles: affixed to the heavy-stock paper will be an actual right insole.

title: Obama Urges Workplace Flexibility
description: He probably has the most flexible and least flexible job in the world.

title: Collector in Chief Hoards Nations Irreplaceable Stuff
description: WASHINGTON  In 1961 David S. Ferriero, a grandson of Italian immigrants and great-grandson of Irish ones, was a high school sophomore in Beverly, Mass. He wrote a brief letter to President John F. Kennedy inquiring about the proposed Peace Corps. He also requested a photograph of the president.

title: A Pop Presidency
description: The director Alex Timbers narrates a look at the show "Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson."

title: What Were Reading: Wii, Women and Yahoo
description: The tech reporters and editors of the New York Times paused for a moment today on these Web articles. They thought you should too.

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Scion tC
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Scion tC

title: Letter: Who Needs Wall Street?
description: I was struck by Roger Lowensteins essay in The Way We Live Now. It is the most measured and keenly perceptive analysis of how Wall Street careered off the tracks from its basic role in our society. Instead of being a vital engine for economic progress, Wall Street has spent the past two decades feathering its own nest at the expense of the entire country and beyond. A mighty pushback is necessary before our economy can right itself, but the concept of a transfer tax on frenetic trading-for-the-sake-of-trading is a weak solution. Such activities, which benefit only a few but have the potential for severe repercussions, must be isolated so only the players themselves take the risks, reap the rewards or take the hits directly. Otherwise they should be tightly regulated or abolished.MICHAEL A. NAYORWestport, Conn.

title: Detectives Investigate Killing of Woman in Queens
description: Detectives are investigating the killing of a 29-year-old woman whose body was discovered on Tuesday afternoon inside an apartment in Glendale, Queens.

title: Letter: The Medium
description: While the real roadrunner doesnt beep like its cartoon counterpart, contrary to Virginia Heffernans column (Beep!), there is an animal that beeps: the human. Since the inception of the Warner Brothers Road Runner more than 60 years ago, its beep beep (some think its meep meep) has been supplied by human voices, the Looney Tunes artist Paul Julians being the first.Pleasantville, N.Y.BILL STOLLERPleasantville, N.Y.

title: YouTube Aims for Stickiness With Redesign
description: In December, I wrote about YouTubes  multifaceted effort to keep users on its site longer as it sought to compete more effectively with television. Much of the work to make YouTube more sticky focused on helping users discover videos they might want to watch based on what they had watched or liked before.

title: Letter: The Shrine Down the Hall
description: I am still in tears over the photographs of those sad, empty rooms, which were once filled with youthful hope for the future  futures interrupted forever, lives lost forever.

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Mazda 2
description: What is it? The Mazda 2 was introduced at the Los Angeles Auto Show in December, minus many specifics, including drivetrain. At the New York auto show on Wednesday, Mazda finally provided some technical details.

title: Albany, 11:49 A.M.
description: David W. Johnson, the suspended aide to Gov. David A. Paterson, with his lawyer Oscar Michelen, right, arrived at the Public Integrity Commission to testify in the investigation of the Paterson administrations solicitation of Yankees World Series tickets. Mr. Johnson would not comment before or after his visit to the commissions offices.

title: Interview: Yorgos Lanthimos
description: Yorgos Lanthimos, the director of "Dogtooth," discusses his ideas behind the isolated family at the heart of his film.

title: An Insomniacs Best Friend
description: Chief was my insomnia buddy. As far as late-night companions go, you could do worse than a dog. We humans fill the sleepless void with mental anguish, constructing indexes of recriminations and future-forward panic. Dogs, anchored in the present, know no such travail. The sum total of their fixations are food, belly rubs and alerting to possible intruders. Chief and I, the worrier and the worry-free, formed a yin and yang of preoccupation. We were perfect partners.

title: The Rising Stars of Gossip Blogs
description: IT had all the elements for the perfect tabloid gossip item  a clash between star financial journalists, big egos and a surprise ouster that had Wall Street buzzing: Henry Blodget, the well-known disgraced-analyst-turned-financial-pundit and co-founder of the much-read blog, The Business Insider, stunned the financial community last week by firing John Carney, the star managing editor of the sites Clusterstock blog, reportedly because of philosophical differences over the sites coverage.

title: Arab Press Reaction to Ayad Allawis Election Success
description: The outcome of the recent parliamentary elections in Iraq has been followed by a collective sense of relief in the larger Arab world. The surprise winner, former Prime Minister Ayad Allawi, is widely seen as a less divisive figure than Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

title: Stepping From Jay-Zs Shadow Into Spotlight
description: A few years ago, when Jermaine Cole was a freshman at St. Johns University, he came to the downtown nightclub S.O.B.s to check out a performance by a young rapper just beginning to make a name for himself. The show was packed tight, and Mr. Cole, an aspiring rapper himself, and new to New York, stood in the audience and tried to imagine the night as a glimpse into his own future.

title: A Note On The Term Spread
description: Brad DeLong reads Megan McArdle getting confused about interest rates; hes a better man than I am. But I think theres a bit more to say about the subject.

title: Federal Judge Finds N.S.A. Wiretaps Were Illegal
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge ruled Wednesday that the National Security Agencys program of surveillance without warrants was illegal, rejecting the Obama administrations effort to keep shrouded in secrecy one of the most disputed counterterrorism policies of former President George W. Bush.

title: Separating April Fools From Fraud on the Web
description: On the Internet, every day is April Fools Day.

title: Washingtons Scrap Dealers
description: WASHINGTON

title: Chinas Affluence Island
description: Even in a country where new wealth spawns new tales of luxury living every day, Hainan island is viewed with a mix of awe, envy and disgust.

title: Crisis Panel Hot Seat Awaits Rubin and Prince
description: Get ready for Round Two in the search for answers about why the financial system nearly collapsed in 2008.

title: For Toyota, Its Business as Usual at Auto Show
description: Toyotas display at the New York International Auto Show was a vision of normalcy on Wednesday.

title: Next Big Thing in English: Knowing They Know That You Know
description: To illustrate what a growing number of literary scholars consider the most exciting area of new research, Lisa Zunshine, a professor of English at the University of Kentucky, refers to an episode from the TV series Friends.

title: Whats Behind Obamas Drilling Plan?
description: President Obama today proposed opening vast areas of the United States coastline to oil and natural gas drilling.

title: Panoramic Hindsight on Wall St. Disaster
description: Roger Lowensteins account of endemic financial collapse is bookended by anecdotes about Robert L. Rodriguez, an unusually cautious fund manager. The prologue of The End of Wall Street describes a dream Mr. Rodriguez had in February 2006. He saw himself in a courtroom, being grilled about why his mutual fund had invested in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two government-sponsored enterprises that, he dreamed, were already bankrupt.

title: The End of Wall Street
description: Introduction

title: Roy McMakin: When Is a Chair Not a Chair
description: Roy McMakin: When Is a Chair Not a Chair (Skira/Rizzoli, in association with Matthew Marks Gallery, $65) asks the right question about the work of the 53-year-old artist, furniture designer and architect. The answer: sometimes.

title: A Precarious, Sometimes Slow Road to a Title
description: The Flight B (0 to 1,500 master points) and Flight C (non-Life Master) North American Open Pairs Championships were decided on the final day of the recent Spring Nationals in Reno, Nev.

title: The East Side Siren Conquers the West End
description: LONDON

title: The Lost Gardens of the Brandywine at Winterthur Museum
description: The Lost Gardens of the Brandywine, an exhibition at Winterthur Museum and Country Estate, near Wilmington, Del., offers a history of the gravy days that followed World War I through the lavish gardens created by the du Pont family, whose gunpowder fueled the war. Curated by the historian Maggie Lidz, the display includes hundreds of period photographs as well as wry touches, like 53 pairs of worn garden gloves to represent the 53 gardeners who worked for Henry F. du Pont at Winterthur.

title: Shredders: What to Buy
description: You can buy a shredder for less than $30. You can also take your top-secret documents and drop them in a basket full of kittens.

title: Modern Fixtures for the Home Shower
description: AT the 40,000-square-foot Lapis spa at the renovated Fontainebleau hotel in Miami Beach, visitors are welcomed by a minimalist expanse of creamy white marble and frosted glass, and what Clarissa Richardson, one of the designers, calls rain tunnels  rooms that take the notion of showers to an extreme, with ceilings covered in 6-foot-by-18-foot showerheads.

title: New Patterns Inspired by Disneys Fantasia
description: The Walt Disney Signature brand now includes upscale wallpapers inspired by paintings used to create the 1940 film  Fantasia.

title: Growing Your Own Horseradish
description: OUR horseradish roots looked so innocent when they arrived in the mail last spring. Just little brown sticks, about eight inches long and as narrow as pencils.

title: Using Industrial-Strength Shredders at Home
description: BY now, one might assume that the mania for bringing industrial-size appliances into the home  from restaurant-caliber stoves, refrigerators and espresso makers to theater-style entertainment systems  has run its course. What else is there to super-size, the alarm clock?

title: Questions to Ask Before Buying a Shredder
description: ONE of the easiest ways to steal someones identity has nothing to do with computers and passwords and everything to do with Dumpster diving.

title: Discounts on Furniture and More
description: Dcor Insider, a new members-only Web site, is offering home furnishings and accessories at discounts of up to 80 percent off retail (the Desert Sky 100 percent hand-spun wool rug from Odegard, originally $12,319, is $4,035; the Alvar Aalto Beehive pendant lamp, originally $2,800, is $585); decorinsider.com.

title: On Designing a Dining Chair That Reclines
description: Carol Poet, a West Hollywood-based interior and furniture designer whose two decades-old firm serves many in the movie business, was at a dinner last year when a familiar accident occurred. It was after the meal, the moment when people push away from the table and maybe even tip back a bit in their chairs. We were all sitting in these French antique chairs, Ms. Poet said, and one guy leaned way back and snapped the back off. It was terrifying. Ms. Poet drove home that night and sketched a solution: an office chair that looks like a 30s-style upholstered Parsons dining chair. In the spirit of Passover (Why on this night do we recline?), she shared her thoughts on it.

title: A Parsons Symposium on Scent as Design
description: WE arrived late for Headspace: On Scent as Design, a symposium held March 26 in the auditorium at Parsons the New School for Design, and so missed the smell of birth being spritzed into the room.

title: Your Stove Just Needs to Vent
description: THE stovetop range hood may be the most underused and undervalued thing in the kitchen. It is designed to whisk away odors and health contaminants released by cooking, but most of us switch it on only when we burn something  and some of us dont even have one.

title: New Directors/New Films Video: Tanya Hamilton
description: Night Catches Us, the debut feature from the director Tanya Hamilton, takes place in Philadelphia in 1976 and focuses on the aftermath of the black power movement. The film, starring Anthony Mackie and Kerry Washington, first appeared at this years Sundance Film Festival, where Manohla Dargis wrote that it wonderfully weds the political to the personal. Ms. Hamilton spoke about her film influences and compared this period in the black power movement to coming home from a war:

title: General Growth Plan Allows Time to Seek Other Bids
description: 7:14 p.m. | Updated A reorganization plan that General Growth Properties intends to file as soon as Wednesday will give the bankrupt mall operator until Dec. 31 to solicit other offers, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

title: One Books Take on Life, Death and Devotion
description: THE medieval book of hours was a novel, chapel and art gallery rolled into one. In the most luxurious examples, painstakingly illustrated folios transformed reading and prayer into intensely visual and sensual experiences.

title: China Agrees to Consider Steps on Iran
description: UNITED NATIONS  After months of resisting the idea of new Security Council sanctions against Iran over its nuclear program, the Chinese government appears to have taken a step closer to supporting them, agreeing to enter negotiations over the language of a new resolution to intensify international pressure on Iran.

title: Secretary of the Army Says He Will Not Pursue Dont Ask, Dont Tell Discharges
description: WASHINGTON  The secretary of the Army, John M. McHugh, said Wednesday that he was effectively ignoring the dont ask, dont tell law because he had no intention of pursuing discharges of active-duty service members who have recently told him that they are gay.

title: Dick Giordano, Comic Book Artist, Dies at 77
description: Dick Giordano, a comic book artist and former executive editor at DC Comics who helped revive longstanding comic book characters and reimagine them for new audiences, died on Saturday at the Memorial Medical Center in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 77 and lived in Palm Coast, Fla.

title: Extreme Makeover Wall Street Edition
description: A few months ago, Public Strategies, a Washington-based consulting firm, quietly polled the American public about its highest-profile client, Goldman Sachs.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Hacking iPhones and Watching Mobile Movies
description: In this weeks Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein examines the iPhone hack that was a winner at the 2010 Pwn2Own contest, held last week at the CanSecWest conference in Vancouver. She speaks with Ralf-Philipp Weinmann, a researcher at the University of Luxembourgs Faculty of Science, Technology and Communication, who explains the basic strategy of the exploit. It took about 20 seconds, using the Safari browser, to seize control of the phones text message database, though as Mr. Weinmann explains, other personal information, like contacts, photos and e-mail and even iTunes files, could also be vulnerable. And only a firmware update can patch the vulnerability, he says.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,018 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: The Curious Case of a Housing Complexs Puzzling Name
description: There was a time when public-housing buildings were named after the greats. Jacob Riis. Walt Whitman. Eleanor Roosevelt.

title: Parents at Work
description: The Presidents Council of Economic Advisers on Wednesday released its report on Work-Life Balance and the Economics of Workplace Flexibility. What inspired it? Well, in short, this:

title: Backing Up a Sick iPod Classic
description: Backing Up

title: Flush and Looking to Spend
description: AS the economy continues to recover, many companies are flush with cash. Now they just need a way to spend it  and that may include some deal-making.

title: Business Jets, an Economic Indicator?
description: THE image of the Big Three auto executives flying in their corporate jets to Washington in November 2008 to ask for billions in federal bailout money may still be fresh in most peoples minds, but the fact is that business jet use has been falling sharply  by double digits  for the last two years.
